column2: The murals presented to the Naval Receiving Barracks in Brooklyn by the Citizens Committee for the Army and Navy, Inc., were unveiled at a tea yesterday afternoon. Among those who attended were several naval officers, Mrs. Junius S. Morgan, vice chairman of the Citizens Committee, and artists who have been engaged on the murals.

LONDON, March 13 -- The Japanese conquest of Malaya has forced Britain to depend on her own soil for tin. The mines of Cornwall, abandoned as uneconomical, are now being scraped for metal to keep the war machine going.

KEARNY, N.J., March 13 (AP) -- The Western Electric Employes Association, an independent union representing 18,000 workers at the company's Kearny plant, said today efforts to conciliate a wage dispute had failed and "the employes have no alternative but to use their economic power."
BERNE, Switzerland, March 13 -- British prisoners of war in Germany are treated on the whole according to the stipulations of international conventions, it was stated here today.
The Home Owners Loan Corporation sold the dwelling at 260 Van Nostrand Avenue, Jersey City, N.J., to Henry Wolf through the George J. Wolf Realty Company and Charles L. Munch, brokers.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- A bi-partisan congressional group is strongly advocating curbs on overtime pay in war industry.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The House of Representatives passed the Agriculture Appropriation Bill today after approving cuts totaling nearly $57,000,000 over the protests of farm group members, and imposing other restrictions which may make the savings far more.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today granted the Pullman Company's application for a 10 per cent increase in its rates for parlor and sleeping-car accommodation. In view of wage increases and the monopolization of some 20 per cent of the company's rolling stock by the Army and Navy for troop movements, the company's revenues were declared to be inadequate.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 13 -- Warner Brothers today closed a deal to borrow Paul Henreid from RKO for the lead opposite Bette Davis in "Now Voyager," which will go before the cameras early in April with Irving Rapper directing.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 13 -- The Japanese have sent new naval forces eastward into the Solomon Islands on the curve sheltering Australia and New Zealand from the east and north, it was announced tonight in an Australian communique.

Two hundred and nine additional delegates to the eighteenth annual Columbia Scholastic Press Association convention arrived on the Morningside Heights campus yesterday, the second of the three-day convention, swelling the total number of attending student journalists to 2,785 and the number of States represented to twenty-five.

Hearings on higher commissions on the New York Curb Exchange, which will start on Monday, promise to reopen the entire question of a minimum clearing fee on Exchange transactions, it was learned yesterday. Members of the Curb Exchange want higher commissions but are objecting strenuously to the insistence of the Securities and Exchange Commission that they impose a minimum clearing fee as a condition of getting them.

CASTRIES, St. Lucia Island, March 13 (AP) -- An enemy submarine damaged two ships here Monday night in an attack upon this Windward Island, on which outposts of United States Caribbean defenses are located.

BALTIMORE, March 13 (AP) -- Chester F. Hockley, chairman of the Maryland Racing Commission, proposed today that Maryland tracks contribute 95 per cent of their net profits to the nation's war effort for the duration.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- George Sylvester Viereck, Nazi propagandist, was sentenced today to serve two to six years in jail, the heaviest penalty provided for his crime of withholding material facts from the State Department when registering as a foreign agent.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 13 -- On the recommendation of District Attorney Edward J. Neary, County Judge Cortland A. Johnson dismissed today charges of second-degree assault that had been lodged against Ewing R. Philbin Jr., 21 years old, of Hewlett, L.I., and Newell Phipps Weed Jr., 23, of Hartford, Conn., after they allegedly struck Patrolman Edward Lynch of the Nassau County police force while he was questioning them in Woodmere on Nov. 22.

The government's new power to requisition tools and materials needed for war production, without regard to the wishes of owners, was mentioned in Federal court yesterday, and had the effect of obtaining the release of 15,000 tons of scrap metal.

MIAMI, Fla., March 13 -- A four-horse spill, the worst of the Winter season in Florida, occurred at Tropical Park today. Three jockeys were injured and it was necessary to destroy the racer Royal Man.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 13 -- In the Swedish Senate an interpellation was deposited today on the seizures of yesterday's issues of a number of Swedish newspapers and periodicals for having printed atrocity stories judged harmful to one of the belligerents. No date has been set for the hearing of the interpellation.

Several underwriting firms here have anticipated the sale on next Tuesday of $3,850,000 of the Louisville Transmission Corporation's bonds and studied the bond indenture and specifications with a view to preparing bids. Blyth Co., Inc.; the First Boston Corporation and Lehman Brothers have investigated the situation but whether they will compete for the bonds has not been disclosed.

With a display of tremendous hitting power, F. Barry Ryan Jr. of the Yale Club defeated G.A. Froelich of the New York A.C. last night in the first round of the national amateur squash tennis championship on the Yale Club courts. The score was 15 -- 3, 15 -- 12.

The story of the three United States Navy airmen who with almost unbelievable fortitude survived for thirty-four days on a rubber life raft in the Pacific after their bomber was forced down will be made into a full-length book. Robert Trumbull, who talked to the men at Pearl Harbor and whose account of the ordeal appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Wednesday, has agreed to expand the story for Henry Holt, publishers.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- President Roosevelt confirmed today that he was studying proposals to put ceilings on wages, profits and prices to prevent inflation but said that no final decision had been reached.

Thomas C. Britton of Sarasota, Fla., a member of Yale University's crack swimming squad for three years, received the John D. Plant Cup last night at the thirty-eighth annual dinner of the New York Alumni Association of the Peddie School, Hightstown, N.J., at the Phi Gamma Delta Club, 106 West Fifty-sixth Street.

MIAMI, Fla., March 13 -- The famous screwball delivery, he admits, isn't quite what it used to be. Neither is his fast ball. But the curve is still standing up well enough, and so is that lean, sinewy left arm, which, for all its approaching thirty-nine years and deformed twist at the elbow, seems to be feeling better than in several years.
BOSTON, March 13 (AP) -- The commercial bulletin will say tomorrow:

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- The Office for Emergency Management is still trying to find out what happened to all the pots and pans donated by housewives in the aluminum salvage drive nearly seven months ago.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce protested to Congress today that "trade associations are too busily engaged in helping with war problems to be harassed with new legislative problems that have no significance to the war effort."

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Temporary, barrack-like wooden dormitories should be constructed on Washington's Mall between the Lincoln Memorial and the Capitol to provide rooms for single government workers at a charge of only 50 cents a day, President Roosevelt said today.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 13 (AP) -- Lloyd Mangrum, youthful Chicago professional, swept the boards in the $4,350 Victory golf tournament today by taking first prize in the thirty-six-hole medal competition and teaming with poloist Michael G. Phipps to win the pro-amateur honors.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 13 -- The Dodgers today acquired another catcher, one who undoubtedly will replace the promising rookie, Cliff Dapper, as second-string backstop of the National League champions.

Caroline Gilbert of 600 Riverside Drive, 20-year-old Hunter College honor student, has been missing since 2:30 P.M. Thursday, the police reported last night. She disappeared immediately after a meeting of the Hunter College Classical Club at which she was elected president of the club.

"The Archbishop Spellman Roll-call of Catholic Men" will be started tomorrow in every parish of the Archdiocese of New York. This will culminate on April 12, the annual Holy Name Sunday, when not only Holy Name men themselves but members of their families will be asked to receive holy communion and to pray for the men now serving in our armed forces.
Businesses of a wide variety figured in the commercial rentals yesterday, when a number of contracts for full floors as well as stores were reported by brokers and agents.

The Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference came into being yesterday when representatives of eight local colleges met at the New York A.C. and agreed to set up a league that would be on an informal basis, yet give more solidarity to the diamond front.

Paul J. Kern continued his attacks on the La Guardia Administration yesterday by giving William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, information on two additional cases of alleged fraud against the city, making a total of thirteen cases he has laid before the Department of Investigation this week.

Sermons will be preached tomorrow pointing out the duty of the church in the defense program, with special reference to Australia and India as they figure in the new war picture. Clergymen will urge civilians not to complain at the greatly increased Federal income tax, arguing that the young men of the country are giving their lives.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 13 -- Mayor La Guardia of New York withdrew today his objections to the construction of a Westchester County airport adjacent to Rye Lake in Purchase. The Mayor had contended that the airport, authorized by Westchester and the Federal Government, would constitute a hazard to the purity of Rye Lake, part of New York's watershed system.
Sober visages melt into smiles tomorrow, and fasting becomes feasting. Lent is half accomplished, Easter is the assurance ahead. And a convivial celebration is the antique custom of the day.

Consolidation of the mild gains made on Thursday occupied the greater part of yesterday's session of the stock market, with addi]tions generally held to fractions. -The list suffered somewhat in its rallying effort by the drag of the railroad issues.

The cotton market experienced yesterday another quiet and featureless session. Prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved within an 8-point range and finished at levels 1 point higher to 2 points lower than the previous close.

DETROIT, March 13 -- G. Allan Dash Jr., labor umpire for the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers (C.I.O.), ruled today that auto holidays and swing shifts in the corporation's plants should be paid double time.

The opening of "Fun to Be Free," the topical revue employing the talents of the theatre's outstanding artists, has been postponed from April 14 until a later date, according to a spokesman of Fight for Freedom, sponsor of the production.

LONDON, March 13 (U.P.) -- Japanese troops have driven 100 miles up the 360-mile road from Rangoon to Mandalay in an attempt to throw a wedge between British troops on the right and Chinese armies on the left wing of the Burma defense arc, Far Eastern dispatches said today.

NOW there is something really stirring afoot. The indoor track season is expected to come to a smashing climax in the Columbian Mile that will be run off in the K. of C. Games at Madison Square Garden tonight. There will be many other events, to be sure, but circumstances have brought about a brilliant build-up for the Columbian Mile.

Persecution, deportation and murder of thousands of Jews in Southeastern Europe at the hands of the Nazis or through their influence is going on with undiminished fury, S.B. Jacobson, chief representative of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee in the Balkan area for the last two years, reported yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 13 -- The willingness of the American people to accept basic changes in employment, work habits and routine of daily life for the sake of the war effort is evidenced in a survey just completed by the American Institute of Public Opinion, which reveals these three facts:

COLOMBO, Ceylon, March 13 (U.P.) -- Governor Sir Andrew Caldecott suppressed two Ceylonese political parties today as this British island off Southeast India threw up defenses to withstand expected Japanese attacks.

This reviewer had an advantage last night which he rarely shares with an audience, of hearing the last instead of the first "Rosenkavalier" performance of the current Metropolitan season. As a result, he regrets that he cannot more often listen to performances in that state of maturity, and wait till they have reached that stage to write about them.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 13 (AP) -- Qualifying seven of its eight entries for tomorrow's semifinals, Penn State took an unexpected lead in the quarter-finals of the Eastern intercollegiate wrestling championships tonight.

In what was said to be the first conviction in this county in an abortion ring, Dr. Nathanial Collins, 44 years old, a physician, of 2 West Tenth Street, and his sister-in-law, Mrs. Ella Frankel, 38, a lawyer, with offices at 2 Lafayette Street, were found guilty in General Sessions yesterday on two of six counts of a conspiracy abortion indictment.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- A recommendation that plants engaged in war production set up canteens, under the direction of expert dietitians, to provide nourishing and energy-building foods for their employes was made today by Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator.

MANDALAY, Burma, March 10 (Delayed) -- At 2 P.M. Monday, with the Japanese closing in rapidly, a score of demolition experts in Rangoon pressed buttons and blew oil refineries, port installations, munitions dumps, the power station and other essential plants sky high with a roar that shook Burma's empty capital and sent flocks of mournful crows swirling away in startled flight from the deserted streets.

LONDON, March 13 (AP) -- British and Chinese troops stood in a common line tonight about eighty miles above Rangoon for the defense of Central Burma and for flank protection of the approaches to India.

Sales of the J.C. Penney Company for 1941 rose 23.9 per cent to $377,571,711 from $304,539,326 the year before, according to the annual report, to be made available today. The expansion represented by this new peak in volume occurred largely in the second half of the year and "coincided in great measure with the rapid expansion in industrial production incident to defense efforts of the country," E.C. Sams, president, said.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., March 13 -- Absolute priority for defense works and the appointment of a defense construction council to see that plans are pushed at the maximum pace was revealed by the government today. Announcing this decision Prime Minister Peter Fraser said the country was now on a war footing and facing the supreme test.

PHILADELPHIA, March 13 (AP) -- The Third Circuit Court today adjudged S.I. Newhouse, publisher of the Newark Star-Ledger, and the Newark Morning Ledger Company in contempt of court for "failure to reinstate" Miss Agnes Fahy, suspended American Newspaper Guild member, in compliance with a court order issued May 2, 1941.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- In a novel procedure Senator Thomas of Oklahoma, chairman of an appropriations subcommittee which has in charge the War Department Civil Functions Appropriation Bill, asked six government officials and four labor leaders today to appear at closed hearings beginning Monday to comment on complaints about the war-production program.

The victory of Penn State over Fordham in the team race at the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. track and field championships a week ago today was upheld by the executive committee of the I.C. 4-A, which refused to disqualify Norman Gordon of Penn State, whose entry violated an obscure rule of the association.

A plan of reorganization of the Warren Brothers Company, of Cambridge, Mass., approved by the Federal Court in Massachusetts on Feb. 13, was mailed yesterday to nearly 10,000 holders of the company's convertible 6 per cent debentures, 5 1/2 per cent notes, other allowed claims, first and second preferred stocks, convertible preferred stock and common stock.

New life insurance written in February showed an increase of 10.6 per cent over February of last year, while the total for the first: two months of this year was 38.4 per cent above the corresponding period in 1941, according to a report of the Association of Life Insurance Presidents to the United i States Department of Commerce.
Ohio has evolved a means of putting some of its big game hunters to good defense use, according to a report received from the Conservation Commissioner of that State.

Loquacious Miss Alice Jones, who said her father thirty-five years ago had told her she was 35 at the time, appeared in the Felony Court yesterday as complainant against Stephen J. Hassett, 60, an ex-convict and confidence man of 569 West 125th Street, and Miss Frieda Poliener, 56, bookkeeper in his auctioneer's establishment at that address.

The year's outstanding photographs taken by the city's press photographers were marked with awards last night at the opening of the seventh annual exhibition of the Press Photographers Association of New York at the New York Museum of Science and Industry in Rockefeller Center.

Substitutes for sperm oil and coconut oil, two of the many vital defense materials placed under full priority by WPB, have been developed by leather chemists at the National Oil Products Company plant in Harrison, N.J., it was announced yesterday by B.A. Schiller, manager of the tanning oil division.

Argentinita opened her final series of performances this season at the Shubert Theatre last night, and the size and enthusiasm of the audience gave evidence that she has by no means worn out her welcome in spite of the number of appearances she has made.

HYDE PARK, March 13 -- The Republican club of President Roosevelt's home town has unanimously voted to discontinue meetings for the duration of the war as a patriotic and practical measure. The action was taken at its regular March meeting Monday evening with Wilfred Borner, club president and Republican town councilman, presiding.

Isn't it about time for the farm bloc leaders in Congress to embark on a series of fervent speeches passionately denouncing the complacency of the American people? The farm members in the House of Representatives have just put over another piece of profitable business in the matter of keeping the government's huge accumulated farm surpluses off the market.

On the ground that New York's central business districts, including the Times Square and Grand Central zones, have too small a number of parking garages, the Regional Plan Association made public yesterday a five-point program designed to clear away legal and zoning obstacles to traffic and parking efficiency in these districts.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 13 -- In a renewal of raids aimed at "dangerous enemy aliens" throughout California, Federal agents and police moved today against suspected Nazi propagandists in the Bay area and seized nearly 200 Japanese, including six Buddhist priests, in the southern part of the State.

Argentinita opened her final series of performances this season at the Shubert Theatre last night, and the size and enthusiasm of the audience gave evidence that she has by no means worn out her welcome in spite of the number of appearances she has made.

The Common Council of Detroit, Mich., yesterday authorized Charles Oakman, City Controller, to advertise for bids on an issue of $16,758,000 of general obligation refunding bonds. The sale will take place at 10 A.M., March 31.

PITTSBURGH, March 17 -- Reversing the usual procedure, the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company has made its own contract proposals to the C.I.O. United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, demanding, among other things, the abolition of overtime pay.

On the ground that New York's central business districts, including the Times Square and Grand Central zones, have too small a number of parking garages, the Regional Plan Association made public yesterday a five-point program designed to clear away legal and zoning obstacles to traffic and parking efficiency in these districts.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 13 -- In a renewal of raids aimed at "dangerous enemy aliens" throughout California, Federal agents and police moved today against suspected Nazi propagandists in the Bay area and seized nearly 200 Japanese, including six Buddhist priests, in the southern part of the State.

What The New Republic regards as "apparently well authenticated reports" would have us believe that last November the Japanese dropped on Changteh mixed cotton rags and rice contaminated with the bacilli of bubonic Plague. Soon after Dr. R. Pollitser, former epidemiologist of the League of Nations, found that five rats caught in Changteh were infected.

As rationing administrators representing every State were planning for a Chicago meeting next Friday to make final preparations for setting up elaborate machinery for sugar rationing, it was learned yesterday that rationing may become unnecessary.

LONDON, March 13 (AP) -- Squadron after squadron of the Royal Air Force swarmed over Northern France from the Belgian border to Paris today in the biggest daylight raids yet of the new Spring offensive and at least eight German fighters were knocked down in one clash alone.

DETROIT, March 13 (AP) -- The Chrysler Corporation is expending upward of $66,000,000 in expanding its war implement production facilities, K.T. Keller, president, told stockholders today in a formal message.

CANBERRA, Australia, March 13 (Netherlands Indies News Agency) -- An incomplete list of the Netherlands Indies officials who have come to Australia with Lieutenant Governor General Hubertus J. van Mook to organize a new center of anti-Japanese resistance was obtained today from authorized quarters.

BERLIN, March 13 (From German broadcast recorded by The United Press in New York) -- A Japanese Government spokesman asserted today that the Brazilian Government had acted contrary to international law in restraining the freedom of Japanese Ambassador Itaro Ishii in Rio de Janeiro in retaliation for the purported treatment of Brazilian Ambassador Frederico de Castello-Branco Clark in Tokyo.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The National Association of Manufacturers was accused before the Ways and Means Committee today of putting forward corporate tax proposals designed to shift the tax load from the large to the small corporations.

New York City was under brief bombardment at 3:40 P.M. yesterday, but not from the enemy. Eight 37-millimeter shells from an American anti-aircraft gun stationed on East River Drive whistled over the financial district. Seven vanished. One hit masonry between the thirty-seventh and thirty-eighth floors of the Nassau Street wall of the Equitable Building.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 13 -- President Edward Grant Barrow saw his Yankees in battle today for the first time this year and left Waterfront Park highly satisfied. The world champions snared their third straight victory, shutting out the Reds, 2 to 0.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The food bill of the average family rose 0.5 per cent between mid-January and mid-February, according to Acting Commissioner Hinrichs of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, who said that this meant a total increase of 25 per cent over prewar levels.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The Office of Price Administration stated today that typewriter dealers were free to rent used machines, but ordered that the rate must not exceed that which the dealer charged for a similar machine on March 5.

The return meeting at a mile between Leslie MacMitchell and Gilbert Dodds, a crowd-catcher beyond compare, will jam Madison Square Garden to the rafters tonight for the Knights of Columbus track meet.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- National Coordinators for practically every type of sport or exercise have been named by the Office of Civilian Defense, Senator Byrd said today.

NEWARK, N J., March 13 (AP) -- Vice Chancellor Charles M. Egan declined today to reopen a decree issued in 1933 discontinuing stockholders' suits against the American Tobacco Company. He advised the petitioners that he saw "no evidence of fraud having been imposed on any one in the settlement of the suits," and added, "I am convinced the suits and settlements were a benefit to the corporation and its stockholders."
Members of Brooklyn society attended the fourth New York concert by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Dr. Serge Koussevitzky conducting, in the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night.

MELBOURNE, March 13 -- Though the battle of New Guinea appears to be developing rapidly, with continuing air raids by United Nations fliers, it is considered possible that the Japanese operations may prove to be a feint covering a powerful blow elsewhere.

LONDON, March 13 (AP) -- Germany offered a reward of 100,000 marks today for help in arresting the writer of an allegedly forged letter signed by the late Colonel Werner Moelders, saying the Nazi ace pilot became a Catholic before he died.
The text of the speech broadcast last night by Prime Minister John Curtin of Australia, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES, follows:

A series of six concerts featuring vocal and instrumental soloists and chamber music groups will be presented under the joint sponsorship of the Second Region Council Citizens Committee for the Army and Navy and the National Music League, on Tuesdays at 5:30 P.M., starting March 23, in THE NEW YORK TIMES Hall, formerly the Little Theatre, in Forty-fourth Street.

Attempted fraud in a civil service examination, although the candidate passes on his merits without the aid of the fraud, justifies his dismissal from the position to which he is appointed, even if the incident is not discovered until years after the appointment, the Appellate Division ruled yesterday in a three-to-two decision reversing rulings of Supreme Court Justices Denis O'Leary Cohalan and Morris Eder.

BOSTON, March 13 -- Attorney General Francis Biddle declared at Boston University's Founders' Day dinner tonight that the government would soon utilize the services of every one in its effort to win the war.

CANBERRA, Australia, March 13 -- Prime Minister John Curtin announced tonight that the 6,980-ton Australian cruiser Perth and the 1,060-ton sloop Yarra were overdue on their return to Australia from waters around Java and must be presumed lost.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Special provisions for assuring ample stocks of canned fruits and vegetables for the armed services, lease-lend and other governmental requirements were contained in orders issued today by the War Production Board. In two new orders,

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- An executive order was issued today formalizing the recent naval changes by which Admiral Ernest J. King, Commander in Chief of the United States Fleet, took over the duties of Chief of Naval Operations.

L. Lewis Luckenbach, president of the American Bureau of Shipping, announced yesterday that "censorship requirements" had caused the indefinite suspension of the bureau's regular bulletin, which had been issued monthly for the benefit of subscribers in shipping and allied fields.

BERLIN, March 14 -- (From German broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -Z The German High Command I claimed tonight that the toll ofI shipping sunk by U-boats in Amner- I ican waters now has passed theI 1,000,000-ton mark with the sink-! ing of twelve additional vessels m l the Caribbean.

THE water-color medium has not been exactly neglected in the year's exhibition schedule as carried through to this point. In February the Whitney Museum presented its admirable American survey, which traced developments over a period about a century and a half in extent.

CALIFORNIA, as many non-Californians have said, smiling slyly, is not a place but a state of mind. That might have been only measurably true on this long, heterogeneous, cold-to-blazing stretch of coast line before Pearl Harbor, for we had our various interests and our family rivalries. This State, with the possible exception of Florida, is composed of more diversely rooted groups than any other State in the Union.

PHILADELPHIA, March 14 -- John B. Kelly, Director of Civilian Fitness in the office of Civilian Defense, expressed today his willingness to debate the worthiness of his "Hale America" program with Senator Byrd on the floor of the Senate.

A series of six afternoon concerts beginning March 24 will be sponsored by the Citizens Committee for the Army and Navy, Inc., and the National Music League, Inc., which bridges the gap for young musicians between music school and commercial management.
Thank you very much for reproducing my two ski water-colors, "On the Glacier" and "Powder Snow," on Page 10 of your issue of Feb. 22.

KEUKA PARK, N.Y., March 14 -- Former Girl Scouts now students at Keuka College have organized a college defense service to coordinate wartime activities among undergraduates. The constitution of the group has been approved by the National Girl Scout Organization.

FARM SCHOOL, Pa., March 14 -- Immediate employment, with jobs ranging from turkey breeding on Cape Cod to an orchardist on the farm of Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr., awaits each of the fifty-three young men who will be graduated from the National Farm School, Bucks County, on March 22.
The Riverdale Country School will celebrate its thirty-fifth anniversary on Friday with a dinner at the Biltmore Hotel. Tribute will be paid at that time to Frank S. Hackett, founder and headmaster.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- President Roosevelt urged today, in identical letters to State Governors, that speed limits of forty miles an hour be established for the country's highways and roads to conserve tires. The President also suggested that regulations be established for regular inspection of tires in order to make sure of their repair or possible retreading at proper times.

Ethelbert Smith said that everybody knows how the war in Europe found the democracies unprepared, and especially this country. But he thought that people were thinking perhaps too much about our lack of planes and tanks and heavy guns, and not enough about our most serious omission.

The official Italian news agency Stefani broadcast yesterday a wholly unconfirmed report that the 81,235-ton British liner Queen Mary has been torpedoed and "heavily damaged" in the South Atlantic while carrying 10,000 "North American" troops.

IF a soothsayer had told a poor widow in the tiny village of Fenghwa that one day her son would walk on terms of full equality with Kings and Emperors and the President of one of the greatest countries in the world she might not have shaken her head in doubt and bewilderment.

Department store sales, as reported by the Federal Reserve Board, are listed in the following table of percentage comparisons with a year ago for the Reserve districts, for the last two weeks and the latest four-week period:

A former chief flag officer of the Englewood Basin Y.C., Charles H. Leach of Roselle, N.J., whose flagship is the snappy cruiser Catherine F. II, was returned to the post of commodore at last week's annual election. The retiring three-star man, William H. Wunner, received as a compliment a set of silver stars and a silver plaque.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., March 14 -- Establishment next September of a new School of Humanities in Stanford University, designed to assist the student in acquiring a grasp of the past development of Western civilization and its relation to the social, cultural and philosophic forces shaping life in the modern world, has been announced by Chancellor Ray Lyman Wilbur.

ALTHOUGH we have been asked to give up some things that we thought were necessary in our daily lives, flowers are not among the deprivations. Beauty contributes to morale, and morale contributes to victory. Even though we are working on a restricted wartime budget, we can have the beauty of blossoms in the garden and bouquets and floral arrangements in the house.

HAVING written some excellent books on Latin America and on our own Southwest where her home is, Erna Fergusson has turned to a new field in Hawaii. Here she goes frankly as a tourist, and she has written what was undoubtedly intended to be a tourist book.

Continued increase in the allotment of automobile tires and tubes for the second quarter of March was reported yesterday by Lee S. Buckingham, acting Federal rationing administrator, 530 West Forty-second Street.

Food manufacturers, seeking to maintain production of branded lines affected by tin-container restrictions, are anxiously turning for assistance to the already overburdened dehydrated foods industry, where, it was learned yesterday, the government is sanctioning a large-scale expansion program despite wartime shortages of machinery and equipment.

RECENT investigations in plant nutrition have revealed the fact that commercial plant foods applied in liquid form are more effective than when applied dry in the usual manner. The "weak-tea" liquid manure that grandmother applied to her geraniums and to garden flowers that seemed to need a pick-me-up had a scientific basis, even if she did not recognize the fact.

THIS deeply moving story about two small children and the war in Spain recalls a picture booklet published some years ago by the Spanish Child Welfare Association. It was a collection of sixty drawings, showing scenes of bombings, tanks, burning houses and dead soldiers, drawn in naive lines by Spanish children during the war.

Aviation courses will be introduced in elementary and secondary schools throughout the country next September, it was announced yesterday by Robert H. Hinckley, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Air. Mr. Hinckley spoke yesterday morning at a general session of the Columbia Scholastic Press Association's eighteenth annual convention in the McMillin Academic Theatre, Broadway and 116th Street.
LONDON, March 14 (Reuter) -- Results of British football games today follow:
THE three garden club organizations which participate in the International Flower Show are interpreting this year's theme, "These United States," in a varied, helpful and lively series of exhibits.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- James M. Landis, director of the Office of Civilian Defense, announced tonight that President Roosevelt had approved an agreement for transfer of the physical fitness division of the OCD to the Office of Defense Health and Welfare Services under Paul V. McNutt.

TO the owner of a small garden plot no phase of horticulture is more interesting than the desire to produce some home-grown fruit. The bush and berry fruits do not usually present any great difficulty as their limited space requirements make them eminently adaptable to the small garden.

IN this war the civilian -- every American civilian -- is subject to three methods of attack: military attack or invasion from the air or from the sea; psychological attack by propaganda; sabotage, "which may precede or accompany each of the other methods."

A MAN named Smith parked his small car in the paved courtyard of the deserted-appearing stone mansion and climbed stiffly from behind the wheel, awkward in an extra overcoat and clumsy ski boots. There was nothing extraordinary in this, except that it was a little before 6 o'clock on a Winter morning and, in the ordinary course of his life, Smith would never have been there at any hour.

KNOWLEDGE, understanding and affection combine to make this one of the best books on China that have yet appeared. Moreover, it stands up as a novel. It is quite obvious from information furnished on the jacket of the book that not a little of the narrative is autobiographical.

WAR or no war, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has decided to give Mickey Rooney an old school tie. "A Yank at Eton," first announced three years ago as a transatlantic project, has been revived by the studio and Lionel Houser is preparing the scenario for filming next month in Hollywood with Norman Taurog, Rooney's mentor in the "Boys Town" pictures, as director.

BELLPORT, L.I., March 14 -- Winslow Guertin Turtle, New York City stockbroker, was found dead, a suicide, this afternoon in a garage at the Summer home on Brown's Lane here of his mother, Mrs. Frank Day Turtle of New York City.

CHUNGKING, China, March 14 -- Fiction writers for years have thrilled us with stories of exciting exploits of the war birds of the first World War. A composite picture of these heroes was a hard living, hard fighting, hard drinking, individualistic sentimentalist.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, March 14 -- New Zealand's total mobilization for defense against the Japanese threat was announced by Prime Minister Peter Fraser today. He revealed that the War Cabinet had decided to extend the use of the country's man power into the ranks of older men and also to enlist women for war work.

LONDON, March 14 (AP) -- Adolf Hitler is insistently pressing upon his Japanese allies a grandiose scheme of world conquest and promising, as reward for their collaboration, that their empire may be so far extended as to include part of Africa, a foreign diplomatic source said today.

The placing last week by the United States Steel Corporation of one billion dollars of insurance against the risks of fire, wind storm, civil commotion and malicious mischief, aroused widespread interest in all spheres of private enterprise and government.

It will have its initial trial starting tomorrow in Pontiac, Mich., site of numerous armament projects thirty miles from Detroit.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- On a table in the drawing room of the Polish Embassy here is a colored engraving of Thomas Jefferson. The inscription, in French, is addressed to "my illustrious friend." The artist and inscriber was the Polish patriot and American Revolutionary General, Thaddeus Kosciusko.

Since the outbreak of war in 1939 the Norwegian merchant marine has lost about 200 ships of 1,300,000 deadweight tons, representing approximately 18 per cent of its pre-war tonnage, according to Arne Sunde, Minister of Shipping and Supply of the Royal Norwegian Government in London.

CHUNGKING, China, March 14 (U.P.) -- Japan will not need the "breathing spell" that normally follows a major campaign because she used fewer supplies, equipment and men than she had anticipated in Malaya and the Netherlands Indies, military experts said today.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 14 -- The favored Wise Bob, a $3,000 claim midway through the Hialeah meeting and a victor in the Dinner Party Stakes there, was a decisive winner of the $3,130 Orange Blossom Stakes at Tropical Park today.

The regular National Hockey League campaign will come to a close tonight, so far as competition in New York is concerned, when the Brooklyn Americans tangle with the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden. With practically nothing to lose, the Americans are intent on carrying a blistering fight to their Northern rivals, and the battle promises to be an entertaining one.
CANBERRA, Australia, March 14 -- Port Moresby, Papua, had its thirteenth air raid today and islands near Thursday Island also were attacked.
OMAHA, Neb., March 14 -- Are high school seniors in the Middle West thinking of next September in terms of college, the production line, the armed forces or the farm?

PHILADELPHIA -- Philadelphia's nineteenth annual flower show is being held March 16-21 at the Commercial Museum. Again this year the huge floor space is being used for one unbroken stretch of landscaping, approached as through the entrance of a large estate.

CURRENT agitation by film exhibitors to nullify the consent decree, which they sponsored, and return to a modified form of block-booking and blind-selling of motion pictures has aroused apprehension among the majority of Hollywood producers, who, reversing their own original stand, have embraced the decree which they at first feared.

In these days of increased cooperation between the American and British people it is of interest to note that these two great nations are sharing not only in the vital war effort for the preservation of democracy but in the effort to maintain the tradition of free scientific inquiry.
Joseph Lordi, the defending titleholder from the New York A.C., made his first appearance in the national amateur squash tennis championship yesterday at the Yale Club.

As significant as the success of the recent British parachute raid on Bruneval was the nature of its objective. The purpose of the coordinated air and sea action was to destroy a German radio location post on the coast of France -- a post which could give advance warning of the approach of British planes from across the Channel.
LONDON, March 14 (U.P.) -- A Free French column raiding inside Libya has destroyed another Italian outpost, Free French headquarters reported tonight.

CURRANT COMEBACK -- The red currant, banned because it endangered the $400,000,000 United States white pine tree crop by aiding the spread of blister rust disease, may be restored to the nation's housewives as the result of researches made by Glenn G. Hahn, a government scientist at Yale University.

Net sales of $27,707,675 in 1941 were reported yesterday by the Peoples Drug Stores and subsidiaries. These, it was stated, were the largest in the company's history, and compared with $23,979,909 in 1940.

PAPA MONETA has retired. His anything but shabby restaurant on shabby Mulberry Street -- for more than a quarter of a century a starred entry in gourmets' address books -- has closed its doors. MEXICO CITY, March 14 -- Most qualified observers here are waiting for confirmation of the assurance given this correspondent last night by high official sources that the Mexican Government intended soon to round up thirty or more Nazi leaders and hand them over to the United States.

MADRID, March 14 (AP) -- Foreign Minister Ramon Serrano Suner and the Argentine Ambassador, Dr. Adrian Escobar, today signed a barter trade agreement amounting roughly to 500,000,000 pesetas -- or approximately $40,000,000 at the official rate of exchange.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today assigned for hearing on April 1 at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, before Examiner Schutrumpf, the application of the trustees of the Erie Railroad Company to abandon its ferry service between Jersey City and West Twenty-third Street, New York City.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J -- While this resort city preens itself for what it expects will be its largest crowd of Palm Sunday and Easter holiday visitors, a wide variety of sports and social functions mark the pre-season programs.

RICHMOND, Va., March 14 -- Ordinary table salt improves the anti-skid properties of auto tires, according to claims in a patent (No. 2,274,855) granted to Edward H. Wallace of Detroit. The "salted tires," the patentee asserts, have less tendency to skid on wet roadways.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -Aides of Secretary Wickard said today that the Agricultural Department would appeal from the decision at Dayton, Ohio, declaring illegal the 49-cent penalty on 1941 over-quota wheat.

SANTA FE, N.M. -- Jokes about mothers-in-law are often the route to merriment among average Americans, but mothers-in-law are not idly dealt with by the Navajo Indians, inhabitants of the nation's largest reservation in Northwestern New Mexico.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 14 -- Employing workaday sleuthing methods after an elaborate literary trap had failed, detectives arrested today Bruno Wesolowski, 19-year-old senior at the Thomas Jefferson High School here, as the person who tried unsuccessfully to burn down the school last Wednesday.

The first in a series of five programs covering the varied work of the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York was broadcast yesterday afternoon over WMCA in connection with the 1942 Appeal of the Charities. Archbishop Francis J. Spellman was the principal speaker.

CHICAGO, March 14 -- Eastern and professional speculators who have been on the buying side of rye for some time started to liquidate their holdings on the Board of Trade and found support lacking. Prices broke sharply and ended the day at their lowest points, with losses of 1 3/4 to 1 7/8 cents a bushel, the lowest quotations in more than two months.

A task which Brigham Young first assigned to the National Women's Relief Society -- to store up wheat and supplies against a day of need -- is being resumed today as the group, 113,000 strong, is preparing to commemorate quietly on Tuesday its one hundredth anniversary.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 14 -- Dr. Harry P. Hammond, dean of the School of Engineering at the Pennsylvania State College, cited figures today which indicated that the total output of all engineering schools in the United States would not begin to meet the demands of government, industry and the armed forces during the next seventeen months.

Private Joe Kelly of Company K is an amateur detective who has just been caught in the draft. Consequently, when another member of the company is murdered, Joe wants to take a hand in the investigation. He knows that it would be useless to try to get official backing for his sleuthing activities, so he goes ahead on his own and promptly lands in the guardhouse.

LONDON, March 14 -- Details of the destruction of three Nazi submarines, identified as the U-131, U-434 and U-574, that took part in a five-day attack on a British convoy in December, were made public by the Admiralty yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (U.P.) -- President Roosevelt, at White House conferences today discussed such various topics as unemployment, shipping and this nation's relations with Soviet Russia.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 14 (AP) -- Roaring to victory in the University Mile Relay, last event on the program, Notre Dame tonight won the team championship at the tenth annual Butler University indoor relays, breaking Michigan's eight-year-domination of the meet.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The largest untapped scientific resource in the country lies with the professionally trained women not now using their scientific knowledge, officials of the Civil Service Commission said today.

THERE have been no new plays since your correspondent last corresponded, but one revival of more than ordinary interest has come in. It was "The Doctor's Dilemma," in which Vivien Leigh returns to the West End stage after an interval largely devoted to "Gone With the Wind."

BERNE, Switzerland, Sunday, March 15 -- Eighteen days after the start of their offensive against the encircled Sixteenth German Army, Russian troops smashed their way through two important German lines of defense yesterday afternoon to enter the northern suburbs of Staraya Russa, according to reports received here this morning from Moscow.

LONDON, March 14 -- Wholesale German looting of Netherland art treasures has not taken place, much to the surprise of observers in this country, who have been watching for evidence of something of that kind since May, 1940.

A FOUR to six week start in the garden may be won by buying seeds early and starting them indoors in flats. It's a simple job and one that pays big dividends in husky seedlings, ready to be set out in the garden at a time when ordinarily seeds would just be going into the ground.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., March 14 -- Indiana University beginning in May will introduce for all entering freshman students a system of "personalized education" operating through its newly created junior or lower division.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 14 -- Joe Gordon made his first miscue of the year at Waterfront Park today as the Yankees resumed hostilities with the Cardinals and the consequences were many.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 14 -- Establishment of the Fairleigh Dickinson Junior College as a coeducational institution, with Dr. Peter Sammartino as its president, has been announced by a committee of high school principals representing fifteen towns in this area. The school will be housed in the Ivison Castle here.

STEWARDS of tax-exempt funds dedicated to the general welfare are expected periodically to inform the public of their activities. While many of them are derelict in this duty, the Rockefeller and Carnegie philanthropies have through the years set a commendable example of reporting to the public.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that cotton consumed during February totaled 893,745 bales of lint and 107,539 bales of linters, compared with 945,909 and 116,247 during January this year, and 793,428 and 106,838 during February last year.

Robert Conway, president of the New York Newspaper Guild, C.I. O., said yesterday that John F. Ryan, a paid organizer of the union, had not been authorized to sign a petition demanding the liberation of Earl Browder, Communist leader, who is serving a penitentiary sentence for passport fraud.

The fourteenth annual Spring sale in aid of the Children's Village in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., will be held on March 25 and 26 at the New York store of Arnold Constable Co. under the auspices of the Village Cottage Committees of Westchester.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The War Production Board today extended the prohibition on the use of "bright work" on automobiles to cover all type of motor vehicles and trailers, prohibited its use in replacement parts and accessories and placed rigid restrictions on disposal of remaining inventories of such materials.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- A majority of the Senate Finance Committee expressed qualified approval today of a sales tax as a means of raising part of the $7,000,000,000 additional revenue being sought to aid in financing the war.

THE seventh annual Three Choir Festival of New York, to be held March 27 and 28, at Temple Emanu-El, under the sponsorship of Congregation Emanu-El and its choir committee, will be devoted to "Songs of War and Peace."

Main floor departments were active throughout the week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, with expanding volume also noted in Spring coats, suits and blouses, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Sports wear sold steadily.
ALBANY, March 14 -- More than 460 war plants in the State have been helped to speed up production since Dec. 7, by permission to work longer hours or in multiple shifts, Governor Lehman said today.

LONDON, March 14 -- With typical speed and efficiency, the American Red Cross has tackled the problem of preventing boredom from settling down among the United States troops that have recently arrived in Northern Ireland.

The public response to the Ecole Libre des Hautes Etudes, newest unit of the New School for Social Research, is exceeding all expectations, Dr. Alvin Johnson, director of the New School for Social Research, declared yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, March 14 -- Ed Hueber starred as Pennsylvania beat Columbia today by 41 -- 34 in its first Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League victory in two years. It was the sixth straight setback of the season for the Lions.

The College of St. Elizabeth Glee Club of the College of St. Elizabeth, Convent, N.J., presented a program at Town Hall last night before a responsive audience of good size. Frederic Joslyn conducted and Shirley Prothers, soprano, and Anita Falla, piano, were the soloists.

SPECIALISTS' trials of new annuals are all very well for specialists, but they do not replace for the amateur the pleasure and interest of conducting his own try-outs in his own garden. The results of personal experiment are after all the best, since they acquaint each gardener with the possibilities of plants under the conditions which he alone offers, and among these conditions may be the hazard of imperfect care and even mild neglect.

MONTREAL, March 14 (AP) -- In one of the wildest hockey games seen here in over a decade, the Canadiens turned back the Red Wings, 4 -- 3, tonight to strengthen their hold on sixth place in the National League and virtually assure themselves of a play-off berth.

Capturing five first places and getting no worse than second place in any of the other events, Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School's squad won the senior team championship for the ninth year in a row at the fifteenth annual Catholic High School A.A. indoor track and field championships conducted at Madison Square Garden yesterday.
LONDON, March 14 (Canadian Press) -- Everton and Blackpool, which have clinched final-round berths in the Football League War Cup competition, played a 2-2 tie today. A crowd of 12,000 saw the game.

MAKING armaments that fly in the air and rumble on the ground, Fisher Body division of General Motors Corporation announces transformation of its automobile body and fittings works into six war production sections at scattered plants.

NOWADAYS few meals seem complete without what has become almost an American tradition -- the mixed green salad. Since most green vegetables lose their freshness soon after picking, the home garden offers an opportunity to achieve the ultimate in mixed green salads.
