PRINCETON, N.J., March 14 -- Completion of the conversion of Princeton University to operation on a wartime footing was in sight today with the announcement by Wilbur F. Kerr, registrar of the university, of detailed plans for the college's first full-fledged Summer term of study in nearly a century.

In the Magazine recently the author of "Elephants in Warfare" overlooked the description of the war elephant's equipment and supporters as set forth in Maccabees, Chapter XI. The elephants were in the army of Antiochus:

TEN per cent is a fair estimate of the amount of convoy material this book contains. The rest of it comprises Mr. Reynolds's thoughts and reminiscences about a variety of subjects; the title merely serves as a binder.

Wheat supplies for the United Nations in the war are ample, provided adequate transportation facilities are available. With a prospective carryover of 625,000,000 bushels on July 1 next, and a new crop expected to be at least 125,000,000 bushels in excess of home requirements for the following twelve months, the United States alone is in a position to supply most of the deficiency of the other United Nations.

IT may sometimes be difficult for the experienced gardener to realize that to the beginner "borders" containing numerous perennials with special requirements are seemingly collectors' corners, awesome in aspect. On top of this the catalogues with their lists of glowingly described perennials present a confusing array of material, making choice difficult.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 14 (AP) -- Despite recent official declarations that various parts of Axis-occupied Yugoslavia have been cleared of irregulars, Belgrade and Zagreb newspapers indicate increasing guerrilla activity.

AT a time when so many gardeners are thinking in terms of planting vegetables with an eye on the war emergency, which is to say for basic food value, it is curious that so little is said in behalf of the edible soy bean.

THE "Captain Horatio Horn-blower" trilogy, by C.S. Forester, is full of salt spray and breath-taking adventure. "Beat to Quarters" is the first volume of the series, and in it the intrepid sea-dog sails in a thirty-six-gun frigate to find later that his tribulations were many and his goal nothing less than to destroy Spain's power in the New World.

IT is a little difficult to see exactly what Samuel Rogers, author of the Atlantic Prize Novel "Dusk at the Grove," has tried to accomplish in his new book, "Flora Shawn." Obviously, it is a careful and workmanlike study of a selfish and enormously self-centered woman from the time she was a small girl, around 1900, until she reached her late thirties.

LONDON, March 14 -- Although the newly defined functions of Captain Oliver Lyttelton, Minister of Production, exceed the powers held previously by Lord Beaver-brook, the major changes in Britain's organization to control raw materials were not expected.

A resolution, calling on President Roosevelt and Congress to protect the armed forces from liquor and commercialized vice and thus safeguard the physical and moral welfare of American soldiers, was adopted yesterday by the executive committee of the Federal Council of Churches, 297 Fourth Avenue.

LONG before snowdrifts vanish from protected corners, plans for the gardening season may be taking shape, but it will be some time before the weather permits actual work in the flower garden. No such delay, however, is necessary in the case of the lawn.

IN these times, the person who has successfully grown flowers, shrubs and trees and continues to do so is just as important, in a sense, as the amateur gardener who grows plants for their food value. While it is true that one must eat to live, there are other things that make life worth living.

IN every Victory Garden a few herbs may well be included to bring variety and interest to the table. Planting food is only half the battle -- the preparation of produce raised and victuals bought is the other half. Monotony will be inevitable in the rationed days ahead unless the hand that stirs the pot has genius behind it or a herb patch near.

INSTEAD of the slowing down that was expected to arrive on the eve of income tax payments, there has been an upturn. Whether this will persist after the money has been passed along to the government remains to be seen, but there is a theory now among retailers that the great over-all lift in purchasing power may mean continued trade increases until actual merchandise shortages check them.

BECAUSE so much publicity has been given gardens that will produce food this Summer, the notion has spread abroad that ornamental gardening -- flowers, trees and shrubs -- is not among the first necessities; that it were better classed with boondoggling and eurythmic dancers.

THE most dramatic episode in this country's relations with Japan has been given scant treatment in the history books. Perhaps Commodore Perry's exploit has been overshadowed by that of his illustrious elder brother at Lake Erie.

LONDON, March 14 -- Enemy patrols are reported to be moving north from the region of Taikkyi in Burma, where the main Japanese forces are concentrated, according to a communique issued in New Delhi. It adds that operations around Nyaunglebin and Shwegyin are proceeding satisfactorily.

SEPTEMBER, 1940. A mid-Victorian London terrace of six-storied basemented houses. All left standing, by Blitzkrieg freak, except one, of which nothing remains but debris. A middle-aged naval captain, service-ribboned, walks briskly to where, facing the shambles, a little old lady "in summery grey with a touch of white about it" is standing lost in a past of which "Number Twenty" had been the nucleus.

ON the whole this is a realistic story of people in Clay County, Mo., in the two decades just before the Civil War. It never loses its healthy feeling of being about real people, yet part of the time it has a touch of magic about it, especially when Timothy stops for a few days with those other Larkins in the lazy country bordering the Mississippi away south of home.
MELBOURNE, Australia, March 14 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

MIAMI, Fla., March 14 -- The Giants might well have won a fine ball game in the first inning today, but midway in the effort their offensive bogged down, and in the end this oversight cost them the battle.

Another tribute to the memory of Herman E. Mellenthin of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., America's greatest breeder and exhibitor of cocker spaniels, will be paid by the Wildwood Kennel Club of Saratoga Springs. This organization's fifth annual exhibition win be held Sunday, Aug. 16, at the up-State resort and will be named in honor of Mellenthin.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Another question about the Office of Civilian Defense came up today in discussion as to whether air raid wardens, fire watchers, rescue squad members and other volunteers in the country should receive Federal compensation in the event of injury in line of duty.

At the very beginning of this book there is a cast of characters, or rather of the principal characters, with the exception of the detective. The list includes ten persons, and we are told that among these there are two victims and a murderer.

The author of "A Taste for Honey" brings us another adventure of Sidney Silchester and Mr. Mycroft. In the opening chapter we find Silchester established in Los Angeles as a professional decoder and doing fairly well at it. Mycroft comes into the picture later on, after Silchester has almost forgotten the curious incident of Mr. Intil -- the incident with which the first chapter deals.

Since there is a growing scarcity of sugar, the gardener may well turn his attention to other sweets as substitutes. Honey is the logical one and since our experimental stations have long stressed the value of trees and shrubs as bee pasturage, the time has arrived when the general public should take recognition of this, also.

Now that Japan has gained control of the Netherlands East Indies after the capture of Malaya and Singapore, the Allied Nations are in the position of having to wait to see where Tokyo will turn next. They do not know, and that they do not quite evidently constitutes a great disadvantage.

Despite the imminence of the income tax payment period, retail trade here continued active last week. Department store sales were estimated as showing a gain of around 25 per cent over a year ago. Spring apparel met a stronger call and soft goods generally continued to come to the fore.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 14 -- Western Reserve University offers, beginning this week, a series of short, non-credit courses intended to help build civilian morale and serve community needs through low cost popular education, Winfred Leutner, president, announced today.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., March 14 -- Imperatives for winning both the war and the peace will hold the attention of Williams College undergraduates, visting student delegates and a score of speakers next week-end in a conference on "A Grand Strategy for America."

For almost one out of five Americans last week the words "surtax net income" and "balance subject to normal tax" symbolized the impact of war more forcefully than Rangoon, Port Moresby, Staraya Russa, no tires, no radios, less sugar. In homes, offices, banks, at internal revenue headquarters, men and women were preparing their Federal income tax blanks, seeking out legal counsel, obtaining the notary's stamp, for the deadline marked by the Ides of March.

THE Brooklyn Botanic Garden is represented at the International Flower Show in its usual location on the third floor with a fascinating and explanatory exhibit of graftage, one of the oldest arts of the gardener. Innumerable examples of graftage, and its related form, budding, round out a vivid demonstration.

Greatly expanded memberships likely to triple present enrollment is facing British leaders of boys' and girls' clubs as a wartime necessity. How they will provide additional facilities in view of reduced personnel available is one of the problems with which club leaders are wrestling, according to Miss Charlotte Niven, who returned to this country last week after eighteen months as head of personnel for the British Y.W.C.A.

Diversion of rapidly rising consumer purchasing power into soft goods has now become the major prospect in distribution, reversing almost entirely the trend which featured most of last year, merchandising authorities here said last week.

LONDON, March 14 -- Parading publicly for the first time since their recent arrival in London, a small detachment of United States troops now here underwent an inspection in Green Park this forenoon while a crowd of Londoners who outnumbered the doughboys looked on.

FINLAND is continuing the custom of most European countries in according postal honor to their rulers, whether of royalty or chosen from civilian ranks, while they are still living. From Finland's Director General of Posts and Telegraphs in Helsinki comes official word that Finland issued on Feb. 20 two series of portrait stamps each in values and colors of 50-pennia green, 1.75-markka light gray, 2m orange, 3 1/2m pale blue, 5m red-violet.

Every soldier, every prospective soldier, every veteran of the First World War and a goodly number of mothers, wives and sweethearts must have been interested in the War Department's announcement that a standard necktie for officers and enlisted men has been adopted.

PHILADELPHIA, March 14 -- Conserving its strength until the final eight minutes, Princeton came through with a sensational 46-32 victory over Pennsylvania before 3,500 at the Palestra tonight to finish in a first-place tie with Dartmouth in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League.

School buildings after the war will be built to meet community needs as well as academic demands and will be adaptable to a variety of public functions, Dr. N.L. Engelhardt, Professor of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University, declared yesterday. Dr. Engelhardt is a specialist in the planning of school buildings and has acted as educational consultant for many communities throughout the country.

LONDON, March 14 -- There is something disquieting in the mood and temper of the people of Britain today that was not noticeable last year. It is not that they have grown complacent or lost heart because of recent months of quiet at home and disasters abroad, although both factors enter.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The most serious naval defeat the United Nations have suffered since Pearl Harbor was inflicted on their forces by the Japanese Navy in the Battle of Java Sea between Feb. 27 and March 1, a joint United States-British announcement revealed today.

United States defense savings bonds, Series E, are redeemable at a stipulated price at the option of the holder after sixty days from the date of issue. The Series F and G bonds are redeemable, also "at a price," after six months from the date of issue.

BOUILLABAISSE -- that superlatively good stew -- is said to have originated in Marseille when two sailors in a moment of inspiration combined a variety of fish in a wonderful potage. New Orleans chefs are now sending up tins of the savory stuff, containing oysters, shrimp, crabs and clams -- all blended with wine and seasonings.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 14 -- Breaches in Westchester's first county-wide test blackout, to be staged at an unspecified time tomorrow night, will be reported to the Westchester District Warning Center here by radio from an airplane, Colonel Frederick L. Devereux, chairman of the Westchester County Defense Council, revealed today.
Stephenson not only as a genius of steam and bolts and screws, but also as a likable person who had the simplicity and the modesty of the truly great.

DETROIT, March 14 -- During the past week a Federal Grand Jury, acting on instructions from Washington, began an investigation of the controversy surrounding this city's defense housing project, known officially as Sojourner Truth Homes.

The 20 per cent reduction in gasoline will be accepted by the Eastern States Gasoline Dealers Conference as "something that has got to be done," Sol A. Herzog, general counsel for the group, said yesterday. The conference comprises some 90,000 dealers of the Eastern seaboard.

The fiftieth anniversary of the School of Engineering at Manhattan College will be marked today by an anniversary mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral at 10 o'clock, which is to be followed by a communion breakfast at the Hotel Commodore. Celebrant of the mass, at which more than 1,000 alumni and friends are expected, will be the Rev. William R. Denue, who was graduated from the School of Engineering in 1928.
Boston -- Onions and orchids will parade together under a crimson "V" made with 20,000 roses at the seventy-first annual New England Spring Flower Show here in Mechanics Building from March 16 to 21.

AIKEN, S.C., March 14 -- Springtime in Aiken is evoking a predominant interest in equestrian events among the colonists and their guests now in residence here. Of signal interest in the season's riding programs is the increasingly important part being played by the children, who don their riding clothes to participate with their elders in the daily events on the race tracks, bridle paths and through Hitchcock Woods.

THE new book by the author of "The Yearling" is not a novel. But it could have been written only from a born novelist's sensitiveness and skill. "Cross Creek" is one of those unclassifiable books which weave the threads of personal experience and observation and acquaintance into a far-spun texture beyond the writer's individual existence or surface contact.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 14 -- In response to the demand for more workers to replace able-bodied men called to the colors, a rehabilitation clinic for a picked group of physically handicapped individuals -- first of its kind in the United States -- will be held tomorrow in the New Haven Hospital and the Yale Department of Psychology.

Another long and tragic toll of men and ships was added to the list of losses that the war has cost when the Navy Department announced yesterday details of the naval defeat in the Java Sea suffered by a United Nations fleet in the last days of February.

Forty-five centuries ago there were cities gray with age in the Indus Valley in Northwest India. Women with bracelets of silver, clad in garments of cotton or wool, bearing on their heads pottery jars to fill at tinkling fountains, walked past buildings fantastically sculptured.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- President Roosevelt was reported tonight to have decided to commandeer the strike-bound 239-mile Toleda, Peoria Western Railroad early next week unless George P. McNear Jr., railroad president, heeds the President's personal appeal to comply with a National War Labor Board order requiring arbitration of the wage dispute between the carrier and two railroad labor unions.

TORONTO, March 14 (AP) -- Toronto clinched at least second place and advanced within one point of the leading Rangers in the National Hockey League race by downing the world champion Bruins, 6 to 4, at Maple Leaf Gardens tonight.

Despite tire rationing and wartime restrictions on food supplies, supermarket operators are optimistic about future prospects and 205 new supermarkets have been opened since Dec. 7, according to a nation-wide survey of the industry just completed by the trade publication, Supermarket Merchandising.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 14 -- Local oddsmakers put a 10-to-1 tag today against Alsab, 1941 juvenile champion, as nominations for the 1942 Kentucky Derby were released.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 14 (U.P.) -- Germany was reported tonight to be dispatching strong reinforcements to Norway, massing quantities of war materials and troops in Denmark, and intensifying her military preparations at key points along the Baltic coast.

PITTSBURGH, March 14 -- The Weirton Steel Company was accused today by the C.I.O. Steel Workers Organizing Committee of unfair labor practices in the dropping of thirty key union men. Complaints were sent to Donald M. Nelson, chief of the War Production Board, and the chairmen of the National Labor Relations Board and the War Labor Board. Government intervention was asked.

Women weather observers have become a wartime necessity, Dr. Gordon C. Darkenwald, Professor of Meteorology at Hunter College, announced yesterday. The college has one of the best meteorological stations in the country.

DIET is now in the movies. The Federal Security Agency is presenting a two-reel picture, "Hidden Hunger," starring Walter Brennan and dramatizing the need for adequate diet. The film was produced by the American Film Center and privately financed.

A VISITOR recently returned from Nassau reports that travel to the Bahaman resort is steadily climbing and that Pan American Clipper ships between Miami and Nassau are operating to capacity each day. Plans are under way for special Easter parties for college girls and boys who have come to include the island in their Spring vacation tours.

Wars are not won by a superiority of resources, but by the determination of a people who are willing, if necessary, to die for their cause, declared Dr. Tsune-chi Yu, Chinese Consul General, yesterday at the annual luncheon of the New York University School of Education alumni at the Fifth Avenue Hotel.
LONDON, March 14 (AP) -- British Headquarters in Burma issued this communique today:

Trading was virtually at a standstill yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, but values were firm slightly above the low marks reached in the precipitous drop in the early days of last week. The volume of trading was 174,640 shares, almost 100,000 less than the preceding Saturday's turnover of 271,980 shares and the second dullest two-hour session of the year.

The curriculum of Spring courses about to open at branches of the New York Y.W.C.A. reflects radical changes in response to requests of women eager to be trained for wartime duties and wartime economies. For many of the older women's clubs formed within the branches the emphasis is given to problems of consumers in view of the food rationing expected and reduction of household equipment.

NO lesson of this war has been more clearly taught than the permanent importance of production -- no lesson has been more widely or more tardily learned. For two years now, and for another year to come, the democracies must suffer frustration and the bitterness of retreating and defending while they wait for their factories to catch up with their enemies.

Maximum open-road speed limits in five States and the District of Columbia are forty miles an hour or less, while fifteen States have no fixed overall limits, the National Highway Users Conference indicated yesterday.
SIXTEEN FAMOUS BRITISH PLAYS. Compiled by Bennett A. Cerf and Van H. Cartmell. With an introduction by John Mason Brown. 1,000 pages. New York: Garden City Publishing Company.

THE American Library Association's Committee on Aid to Libraries in War Areas, headed by John R. Russell, librarian of the University of Rochester, is faced with a number of serious problems and hopes that American scholars and scientists will be able to help in the solution of one of these problems.

Those who long to see a vastly different world order emerge from this bitter war and who are convinced that the time to be planning this is now must have been heartened by several proposals made at Town Hall on March 10 by Professor Archibald Henderson of the University of North Carolina.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Organization of an "inventory-control branch" within the War Production Board's Division of Priorities is now under way here and is expected to be announced formally in the near future. Although a plan of operations under which the new branch will become one of the most important parts of the WPB organization has been drawn up, authorities have not settled upon a candidate to fill the post of branch director.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Twenty-seven volumes from the personal library of the President's mother, Sara Delano Roosevelt, were presented to the Library of Congress today by Mr. Roosevelt.

CHICAGO, March 14 -- The Great Lakes' largest passenger ship, the Seeandbee, soon will be an aircraft carrier, and it will be used on the Lakes to train Navy fliers, according to an announcement last night by the Ninth Naval District headquarters.

THERE are usually two main reasons for growing small fruits in the garden -- for pleasure and to provide fruit with that garden freshness that can be secured in no other way. This year there is a possible third reason, the patriotic duty to produce food in the Victory Garden program.

The city lost ground to the rest of the nation in manufacturing and retail sales during the period from 1929 to 1939, but held its own in industrial employment, according to a survey made public yesterday by the Regional Plan Association.

May the author of "This Age of Fable" be permitted to write a sort of postscript about the American tax policy. It centers around three extremely dangerous fallacies. The first is the belief that nothing but the absolute amount of taxation matters in the fight against the specter of inflation.

New evidence of hostility between John L. Lewis and the rest of the Congress of Industrial Organizations was apparent yesterday when it became known that nine locals of the United Construction Workers, a Lewis-controlled union, had been expelled from the Greater New York Industrial Union Council for non-payment of dues.

Any one who has as a child lived through even a minor cataclysm and its aftermath will recognize his own curiously mingled emotions in those of Rose Ann as wind and rain beat down upon the little house, as the water and the family waited through the long night wondering if the roof could withstand the hurricane which roared over the South Carolina island.

ONE of the topics most discussed among gardeners is that of just what the term "hardy" means as it applies to chrysanthemums. Misunderstanding on this point is common even among growers who have had a good deal of experience with this, the most appreciated of all Autumn flowers.

An average of 2,000 persons applying daily at the New York City offices of the United States Employment Service for training and jobs in war time industry that are not available presents a local picture contrary to the national situation cited in behalf of the Baldwin bill, soon to be presented in Congress, which would provide for compulsory registration of women.

Four or five times during the past few weeks THE TIMES has voiced the bitter complaint which appears in an editorial of March 11: "To this day the Army and Navy have no joint staff to direct their combined operations."
ADOLF BUSCH will lead his Chamber Music Players in the first of a series of three concerts in Town Hall tomorrow night The first program will consist of three of the Brandenburg concerti by Bach.

In a series of questions directed to Edward J. Flynn regarding charges that courtyard of the Flynn estate at Lake Mahopac was paved by city workmen using city materials, Paul J. Kern, who first revealed the charges, demanded of Mr. Flynn whether he should not resign as Democratic National Chairman "in view of the national emergency and the imperative need for confidence in our public leaders."

The instrument of murder in this story appears to be a Hollerith machine, and that, it seems, is one of those complicated mechanisms into which one feeds perforated cards until the needed information pops out. This machine is part of the equipment of the Anglo-British Engineering Company, which is manufacturing munitions for the British Government.
HONOLULU, March 14 -- An air raid alarm was sounded throughout the Hawaiian Islands this morning at 9:40 o'clock, but no activity was observed. The all-clear came at 10:33 o'clock.

Members of the Eastern College Basketball Coaches Association voted unanimously in favor of making the rectangular backboard standard equipment in preference to the fan-shaped board at their Spring meeting yesterday at Toots Shor's.

AT one time or another every gardener finds places in his border or garden which are bare and entirely uninteresting. For such a situation a flowering plant of quick growth and stimulating color value is needed. Summer-flowering bulbs perfectly meet both requirements.

THE second treasury of the world's great letters may stand on the shelf beside the first. It will stand, indeed, in a place that has been waiting for it. This new volume which follows Mr. Schuster's first collection by almost exactly a year is no mere addition but a complement.

AN incidental remark in the course of a conversation has started Ivor Brown on a train of thought which has led him to make a vigorous protest in The Manchester Guardian against a certain tendency in contemporary literature. Hugh Walpole was contempuously dismissed by the speaker as knowing nothing of life because he "lived in a library."

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., March 14 (AP) -- The Mercersburg (Pa.) Academy team successfully defended its national preparatory school swimming championship today, beating tankmen from sixteen other Eastern schools in the Lawrenceville School pool.

College basketball's two post-season classics, the national invitation tournament here and the N.C.A.A. championship, semi-finals of which will be staged in New Orleans and Kansas City, will get under way this week.

Regarding the clever "Japanese" poem, appearing in THE TIMES Magazine several Sundays ago, here is an imaginary letter, from a NON-existent Japanese, which I did NOT receive, but which may add to the gayety inspired by that verse:

This is a story of the pulp magazine and of Johnny Saxon, once a private detective, then a successful writer for the pulps until his inspiration ran dry, and now attempting to make a comeback as a private detective. No sooner has he put the "I Never Sleep" sign on his office door than a publisher of pulp magazines is murdered and a promising young girl writer of love stories disappears.

BROOKINGS, S.D., March 14 -- A plan for the reorganization of South Dakota State College instruction along junior-senior college lines, with an intensive student personnel and guidance program, and the addition of two-year terminal courses, was announced this week by Dr. Lyman E. Jackson, State College president.

IT is possible that the Axis powers will try to use Cyprus as a stepping-stone to the Middle East and Suez. This age-old island was first colonized by the Phoenicians about 1100 B.C., then became dependent in succession on the Greeks, Assyria, Persia, Egypt, Rome, and Byzantium.

Meeting with little opposition from Textile, the Stuyvesant H.S. fencing team recorded an 8-to-4 triumph on the strips of the Washington Irving gymnasium yesterday. The victory was the fifth straight for the defending city titleholder in the Public Schools Athletic League tournament.

This deft mystery story aims at nothing more than diverting light reading for young people and succeeds admirably. Much of the puzzle which baffled Cap when she and her brother Tod went out to Arizona for a visit lay in a strange clash of personalities.

LEWIS N. COTLOW is a New York insurance man whose lifelong hobby has been adventure. And when he says adventure he means it. There was that time when the gorilla turned on him in the Tshibinda forest of the Belgian Congo, for example; and although the lions that stopped his car were apparently merely perplexed and quite peaceable, adventure was pretty sure to keep company with a traveler who insisted on wandering across Africa unarmed.

One hundred years ago New York City began building its brownstone houses in solid rows and played lavish host to Charles Dickens. The first horse-drawn street railway was opened; Horace Greeley completed his initial year as editor of The Tribune.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, March 14 -- Arming of Brazilian ships or a declaration of war against the Axis is not contemplated by President Getulio Vargas at the present time, it was learned today in high official circles. The informant, however, would not say if such steps would be considered in the near future.

NEARLY 1,000 news photographs in all classifications went on view yesterday at the New York Museum of Science and Industry, in the Seventh Annual Exhibit of the Press Photographers' Association of New York.

In complete command of the hostilities from start to finish, Cornell topped off its Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League campaign last night by trouncing Columbia's cellar-dwelling quintet, 52 to 27, in the Morningside Heights gymnasium.

SELDOM does the beginner at gardening realize fully the part which the soil itself must play in his effort to grow plants of any sort -- vegetables, flowers, even shrubs and trees. One of the greatest mistakes the gardener can make is to think that by merely adding fertilizers he can solve his soil problems.

YOU will try in vain to define the type of memoirs to which Mme. Tabouis's new book belongs. Forty years ago Georg Brandes endeavored to make a rough classification of personal reminiscences and autobiographies.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., March 14 -- Two forty-room mansions and 200 acres of land in this town have been bought by the Society of Jesus of New England to be used for a Jesuit high school and college. Title to the Oliver Gould Jennings estate has already passed to the Jesuit Society, while title to the Walter B. Lashar estate will pass before April 1.

The Metropolitan Opera Association closed yesterday its fifty-eighth season with "Faust" in the afternoon and "Lohengrin" in the evening. Whether there will be a season next Winter has not been decided, but the members of the company played their parts and the capacity audiences chatted in the intermissions with calm expectancy that opera would continue.

SPRING is fiesta time in Mexico, and now, too, the days are sunny and little rain, if any, falls on the plateau around the capital. The average temperature in Mexico City is 60 degrees F., which rises to 65 degrees in May. Mornings and evenings are cool.

THOSE who are planning Victory Gardens this Spring may well include some gladiolus corms in their seed order. A few rows of "glads" planted right in the vegetable garden will lend color and good cheer and at the same time provide a supply of gorgeous blooms for cutting in mid-Summer, when good flowers for home bouquets are apt to be scarce.

A new $375,000 wing of the Frances Schervier Home and Hospital for the chronic sick, 227th Street and Independence Avenue, the Bronx, will be dedicated and formally opened at 3:30 P.M. today. Archbishop Francis J. Spellman will officiate and the Very Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham University, will be the principal speaker.

ONE evening several months ago, a telephone rang in the offices of the American Flying Services Foundation, Inc., at 60 East Forty-second Street. The United States Navy was calling from Floyd Bennett Field.

WASHINGTON, March 14, -- Letters from women from forty-six States, the District of Columbia and Hawaii, stating their desire to join the proposed Women's Army Auxiliary Corps have been read into the Congressional Record by Representative Edith Nourse Rogers, sponsor of the bill creating such a corps, which is scheduled to reach the floor of the House Monday.

CIVILIAN pilots between the ages of 21 and 41 who have commercial licenses are wanted by the air Corps for pilot instructor jobs, it was announced last week. Such men will not be used for combat duty.

Spring fashion shows, which for several years have been among the principal fund-raising activities of various groups working for philanthropic causes in the post-Winter weeks, will be as numerous this season as in the past. In most cases the shows are arranged for presentation during the luncheon period.

CONVENT STATION, N.J., March 14 -- The war has finished the task of leveling the impenetrable wall which once separated the women's seminary of learning from the community, according to a survey of the emergency programs of New Jersey women's colleges made by Miss Marion G. Hennion, director of public information of the College of St. Elizabeth here.

The State executive committee of the American Labor party in a statement issued by Lester Rosner, State executive director, announced yesterday its support of the war revenue program for 1942 proposed by Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr., pronouncing it sound and equitable, and opposed the proposal for the imposition of Federal sales taxes.

THE blackbirds come back, the snowdrops come out and Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Novice debate whether or not to make a garden. There is much talk around them of war gardens and victory gardens this year. Some of their neighbors have banded together and leased a vacant half-block for the purpose of increasing the country's food supply.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 14 -- Land owners of Brigantine, semi-exclusive seashore resort to the immediate north of Atlantic City, sought today to negotiate the repurchase of its once - proud Brigantine Hotel, Casino and Recreation Pier, which were sold this week to followers of Father Divine, Negro cult leader.

THE detective whose exploits are dealt with in this story is Chief Fire Marshal Ben Pedley of New York. It is his duty to investigate all fires of incendiary origin and to apprehend the persons responsible for them.

SIMILAR to the reduced air-mail rates granted the United States armed forces, there are air-mail concessions for the British Expeditionary Forces, in addition to free franking on ordinary mail addressed to Britain.

BOSTON, March 14 -- Asserting that the fuel situation in New England was extremely grave, the Governors of the six States called upon the Federal Government today to take prompt action "to prevent disastrous interruption of war production" in the area.
Articles ranging from antique furniture to jewelry will be offered at auction here this week.

THIS little collection of short sketches concerns a little girl at the engaging age of 4. As the title suggests, the man ner is of the doting-parent style, yearning, adoring and sentimental. (It is to be hoped that Miss Boo didn't acquire her name as an abbreviation of "booful.")

The toll of American and Allied ships and seamen continued to mount yesterday as the Navy disclosed the sinking off the Atlantic coast of another United States freighter, with apparent loss of twenty lives, and official sources in Cuba, Nassau and Mexico revealed losses of four other ships, two American.

THERE are many places on the average home grounds that do not readily lend themselves to the usual planting of full borders or lawns -- steep banks, rocky slopes, or areas partially shaded by trees, or even bare-looking stretches of ground under shrub plantings.
ASHEVILLE, N.C. -- Some resort cities are by the sea, some are by the mountains and a few are definitely in the mountains. That's Asheville. And for that reason it is a hiker's paradise.

With German and Italian troops increasing their pressure in an attempt to shatter the resistance of Yugoslavia to their occupation, detachments of women guerrilla fighters are taking up the fight under General Draja Mikhailovitch, leader of the revolt, according to word received here yesterday from a secret Yugoslav radio station.

Alto Saxology (Decca A-246, five ten-inch records) assembles examples of the work of some of the outstanding alto saxophone players. The intention was to provide boys and girls studying the instrument with a living textbook, but the average collector who is fond of hot jazz will find much to entertain him.

Simplicity imposed by war conditions will mark the observance of the fortieth anniversary of the Catholic Young Women's Club of New York, at a corporate communion mass this morning at St. Patrick's Cathedral. Yet the presence as celebrant of the Most Rev. Francis J. Spellman, Archbishop of New York, lends significance to the event and symbolizes the place this group has earned in the community.

SAMUEL ELIOT MORISON, the biographer of Columbus and author of the classic "Maritime History of Massachusetts," is a very hale looking scholar with an authoritative manner. The story is told in Boston that one day when Mr. Morison was much younger an old lady looked at him and said in a cool, clear voice:

Winston Churchill, in the language of which he is master, has described certain crucial points of the war as "climacterics." In this category belong the fall of France, the Luftwaffe's setback in the Battle of Britain, the enactment of the American Lease-Lend Law, the Wehrmacht's invasion of Russia, the Red Army's counter-offensive, the attack on the United States, and the swift Japanese conquest of the Malay Barrier.

The recent decision of the majority of the Supreme Court in the case of the teamsters union in this city is a remarkable document. No attention seems to have been paid so far to one of the most remarkable aspects of it, its conception of what it calls "traditional labor union activities."

CAIRO, Egypt, March 14 -- With the positions of the two armies virtually unchanged since the Germans halted their counter-attack more than a month ago, warfare in Libya remains a matter of patrol fighting.

Blair McClosky, baritone, was heard in a recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The program contained three excerpts from Handel's "Almira," an aria from the same composer's "Acis, Galatea e Polifemo," and Mozart's short Masonic contata, "Die ihr des unmesslichen Weltalls Schoepfer ehrt," as its initial offerings.

FORT WORTH, Texas, March 14 -- Numerous courses dealing directly with the Southwest have been introduced on the Texas Christian University campus to give the students something of the heritage and culture of this important section of the United States.

ALTHOUGH the spraying and dusting necessary for particular crops may be warily approached by the novice gardener, there are a few simple rules of cleanliness in gardening that should be a part of every gardener's practice.

The Blue Hill Troupe, a widely known company of amateur singers who for many years have given performances of Gilbert and Sullivan operettas, are now in rehearsal for their eighteenth annual production. They will present "The Pirates of Penzance" on April 15, 16 and 14 at the Heckscher Theatre.

" OBSTINACY": A year and a half ago the Netherlands Government appointed a Minister Extraordinary to negotiate with a Japanese mission seeking a new trade treaty with the Netherlands East Indies. The Dutch representative was blond, burly Dr. Hubertus Johannes van Mook, Java-born colonial trade authority.

PHOENIX, Ariz. -- A gold mine is actively operating in the largest city park in the world. South Mountain Park, lying at the southern terminus of one of the main thoroughfares of this city, has an area of 14,675 acres -- more space than is occupied by any other city park in existence.

NEWARK, N.J., March 14 -- Eight unopposed candidates for office in the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs were presented to the executive board yesterday by Mrs. Jacob Hodel, chairman of the nominating committee. Election will take place at the annual convention in May.

BUTLER, Pa., March 14 (AP) -- Lieutenant Andrew J. Hudock of the State Motor Police reported today the arrest at near-by Mars of two heavily armed soldiers riding in an Army reconnaissance car and said to be absent without leave from Tyndall Field, Fla., since Thursday.

The training of skilled engineers for war industries will be expedited at Cooper Union by a special session during the Summer, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Edwin S. Burdell, director. Although there will be no incoming class in September, men and women may enter the free Day School of Engineering in July or February and, if the emergency continues, be graduated with a bachelor's degree in two and two-thirds years.

A billion dollar expenditure for public housing for workers in war industry, on a permanent basis wherever possible and with a correlated program of community facilities, the setting up of rent controls on private housing and the removal from the National Housing Agency of "real estate appeasers" were urged yesterday at a luncheon of the National Public Housing Conference at the Town Hall Club, 123 West Forty-third Street.

" FRANKLIN STREET" is a collection of jovial reminiscenses a good deal in the vein of the Clarence Day, Thurber and Mencken tales of their early days. There is much fun and a happy zest for living in it, though it strikes the reader rather as a warmly good-humored book than a primarily humorous one.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 14 -- Next to Donald Nelson's job of organizing America's wartime industry, the most challenging problem before the country today is how to organize the entire civilian population for war -- how to mobilize our human resources so that every person can find a way to put his shoulder to the wheel.

The symbol of the ending of the first phase of the Far Eastern conflict was the silence that hung last week over conquered Java. A bit more than three months from the raid on Hawaii and the beginning of Nippon's vast southward drive, hardly more than a week after the invasion of its soil, the "citadel" island of the Indies had fallen.

MOSCOW, March 14 -- The troops opposing the Germans on their Eastern Front are men in white driving white trucks and white tanks and handling white guns in illimitable white spaces. Thus in war do the Russians wipe out what in peacetime is the most striking feature of the Winter scene -- the precise outline of detail against the snow.

The Forest Service and the Bureau of Plant Industry under an act recently passed are proceeding with a program for government production of guayule rubber in the Western Hemisphere and for investigating the possibilities of other rubber-bearing plants.
HOUSTON, Texas -- The color of khaki will form the background this Spring for the white and orange and lilac of the land beyond the Shining Mountains.

SAN FRANCISCO -- War has seemingly exerted no braking force on the wheels carrying the vanguard of this year's travelers to the West Coast. Nor have events on the far side of the Pacific dampened in any way the plans of those looking forward to a Summer vacation at the end of the sunset trail.

Winning six of her seven bouts in the final round-robin, Miss Helena Mroczkowska of the Fencers Club annexed the tenth annual women's metropolitan open foils championship at the Salle Santelli yesterday. Runner-up in this event last year, the former Hofstra star succeeded Mrs. Marion Lloyd Vince, who did not defend her title.
BERLIN, March 14 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., March 14 -- A joint concert by the Harvard Glee Club and the Sarah Lawrence College Chorus, sponsored by a committee of graduates of the colleges headed by Harrison Tweed, Mrs. Chauncey Fox Howe and Mrs. Robert Armand Schmid, will be held for the benefit of the colleges' scholarship funds in Town Hall on April 4.

Retail trade continues to show gains, although the pace of previous weeks is not being maintained in all sections of the country, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., March 14 -- Adelphi College is preparing to put into effect an accelerated and intensified program for training young women for essential war services, Dr. Paul Dawson Eddy, president, announced today.

PITTSBURGH, March 14 (AP) -- Declaring that modern, high-speed basketball is not injurious to the players, Dr. H.C. Carlson, veteran coach at Pitt, said today he would oppose a suggestion that the national rules be amended to slow down the game.

Each year around this time, with the regularity of the seasons, three major events take place in my life -- my income tax returns, "Parsifal" at the Met and the subsequent observations of the music critics concerning my departure from the stage during the first temple scene of the opera.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 14 -- Japanese bombers raided islands only thirty miles off the northeastern tip of Australia today in what may have been a softening-up prelude to an invasion attempt against the mainland from newly won bases in New Guinea. The attack, on a small scale, was directed at islands in the vicinity of Thursday Island. These islands lie like steppingstones across the 100-mile-wide Torres Strait, between Australia and New Guinea.
LONDON, March 14 -- Dining out in London these days, or lunching either, is always an adventure, while breakfasting is usually a disappointment, especially to Americans.
While gladiolus grown in mixtures are pleasing, separate colors in named varieties are more effective and interesting. Among the readily obtainable varieties are:

THE son and grandson of a British admiral, Commander King-Hall, after seeing service in the last war, is now ashore and his feelings as an ancient mariner are understandable. Everything he sees around him, all that he reads and hears, is novel and interesting.

BRISTOL, Va., March 14 (AP) -- Two Army deserters, Charles J. Lovett, 21 years old, of Philadelphia, and James E. Testerman, 22, of Clinchburg, Va., pleaded guilty today to a charge of murder of an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

PROBABLY Clements Ripley -- who has written "Gold Is Where You Find It" and "Clear for Action" and any number of motion picture scripts -- has devised one of the least solemn and, from the reader's standpoint, least laborious of all known methods of writing historical fiction.

ENGLAND needs India, and needs her badly. Will England get India's help in this supreme hour of trial? This question is asked by the peoples of the United Nations. But most of us have been looking in the wrong direction for the answer. The key to the riddle still lies in London, where Churchill resides, and not in Wardha, where Gandhi goes on with his spinning wheel.

DO the shows of any other painter in America leave the visitor with such a sense of discovery and excitement as those of Marsden Hartley? To me this perennially young and vital septuagenarian artist is indeed unique.

THE perennial argument over subject-matter against technique has no meaning for Clarence John Laughlin, painter-turned-photographer, who has reduced technique to a routine, thereby permitting concentration almost entirely on the potentialities of the subject-matter.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 14 -- Italians suffered a shock today, reports from Rome said, when they learned their bread ration had been reduced, beginning tomorrow, from 200 grams to 150 grams, or about 5 1/2 ounces, a day. Those hardest hit will be the poorest families.

A campaign to enact a bill in Albany to provide State aid for kindergarten has been started by the United Kindergarten Mothers of New York City, Mrs. Ruth M. Baylor, president, disclosed yesterday. A delegation of mothers went to Albany last week to present their views to the legislative leaders.

Shippers and foreign traders who have been making a vigorous effort to save the moribund foreign trade zone on Staten Island have succeeded, it was disclosed yesterday, in obtaining the offer of other piers in the port district as a stop-gap measure for the duration of the war.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- The Navy, in an order today, laid restrictions on communication by commercial coastal radio stations with vessels and aircraft at sea unless such interchanges have Navy approval.

FIRST: The first American casualty of World War II, according to a report issued last week, was Private Archie R. Gurkin of Pinetown, N.C. Private Gurkin was admitted to a Honolulu hospital with a chest wound twenty minutes after the opening of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor.

Now that it has become patriotic to be economical, decorating on a budget is practically a fashionable indoor sport. It may even turn out to be amusing to go back to the good old gas-light era, those halcyon days when mother made most of the dresses for the girls, and sofa cushions were always covered with material left over from the new living-room curtains.

THERE has been a multiplication of books about democracy in recent months, and it is well that this should be so. There is room for every fresh and intelligent discussion of the democratic way of life, for every book that makes us more keenly aware of values that stand imperiled. It is good to have the anthologies which have been assembled, each so far with a character of its oxvn.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Moving to conserve fuel oil in East and West Coast areas remote from the sources of supply, the War Production Board today issued an order, effective at once, in effect forbidding future installations of new fuel-oil heating equipment in seventeen Eastern States, the District of Columbia and Oregon and Washington State.
The nation moved another step toward the organization necessary for total war last week when the Navy Department, following the War Department's example, streamlined its high command.

The Second Evacuation Hospital, a unit sponsored by St. Luke's Hospital and now in service with the armed forces, will benefit from a gala concert to be held on March 24 at the Pierre. Artists who have offered their services are Richard Bonelli, baritone, and Kathryn Meisle, contralto, both of the Metropolitan Opera Company; Marcel Hubert, French 'cellist, and the guitarist Jose Renato.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 14 (AP) -- Sweden stepped up her defense preparations to the highest degree tonight as signs of invasion by the still powerful German Army increased the tension in the war-encircled Scandinavian kingdom.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- A 20 per cent reduction in gasoline deliveries to filling stations in Eastern seaboard and Pacific Northwest States was ordered by the War Production Board today in a step which informed quarters said was preliminary to rationing.

STAMPS believed to be the last ones which left Netherlands Indies prior to the Japanese invasion reached New York last week. Macy's Philatelic Center was informed from Batavia that "in accordance with the scorched earth policy it is almost certain that all the stamp-making equipment as well as the plates and the remaining stamps were destroyed."

LONDON, March 14 -- British, New Zealand, Australian and Netherland fliers under the Royal Air Force command continued widespread and highly successful night and day operations over Germany and German-occupied France in the twenty-four hours through this evening, letting the enemy know once again that British spokesmen meant business when they said with the return of good flying weather the Nazis would be raided right around the clock.

Although virtually no business in New York is immune from the increasingly stringent effects of priority regulations, hardly more than a handful of companies have established any effective system for meeting priority problems, according to Stanley G. Oppenheim, consulting analyst for the Priorities Field Service's regional office here.

THE Metropolitan Opera Association's subscription season of 1941-42, which came to an end last night, has withstood on the whole very successfully the impact of war. When that war reached the United States last December it already had reached our lyric theatre.

School administrators all over the country face the most serious shortage of teachers in American history. Responsible authorities estimate a shortage of 100,000 teachers by the end of the current year and the consequent closing of thousands of rural and even urban schools. Many States have lowered their requirements so as to qualify less desirable teaching material.

Holding up under the most withering pace-setting ever fashioned in a mile race, Leslie MacMitchell reached deeply into the remnants of his dwindling reserve power to find a sprint that beat Gilbert Dodds in a 4:08 Columbian Mile last night.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- The Everglades Club will bring to a close its schedule of major golf events for the season with the annual six-club team tournament on Tuesday over its lake-facing course. More than eighteen teams of men and women, three each, will participate, those holding low scores in all units to receive silver trophies.

Establishing a new team record for the meet, New York University won the thirteenth annual St. John's University invitation intercollegiate rifle tournament at the Metropolitan Rod and Gun Club in Brooklyn yesterday. It was the third victory in four years for the Violets, who gained permanent possession of the team trophy as a result.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- This city, the ever-growing "Boom Town on the Potomac," will experience major transportation difficulties within the next few months, and at a time when the demands of war will make speed of movement even more important.

THE varieties of sweet corn now usually grown are different from those grown as recently as ten years ago. This rapid change is due to the hybrid method of breeding, which has produced disease-resistant varieties with better quality.

Dr. Hu Shih, Chinese Ambassador to the United States, appealed to the people of India to fight side by side with the Chinese for the sake of civilization, in an address before the East and West Association last night in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The national struggle against inflation, which may, in fact, be as serious in its consequences as an Axis victory, had reached such proportions this week that President Roosevelt was considering proposals to "freeze" wages, profits and prices at fixed levels.

With the armies of Chiang Kai-shek are fighting 30,000 Koreans, exiles from their Japanese-ruled country. Other Korean exiles, in the United States particularly, stand ready to aid in the war against Japan and her Axis partners. These exiles know Japanese psychology, often speak Japanese.

FIXED used tire prices announced last week by the Office Of Price Administration settled a motorists' market which has been disrupted since tires were frozen at the start of this year. For more than two months prices of tires available to the average motorist have gyrated.

JUDGED by any critical standards, "Larrish Hundred" is a notable first novel. It has an unusual plot, rich characterization, excellent background and polished writing. What gives it added stature as a fine creative piece of work is the fact that its author, A.R. Beverley-Giddings is an Englishman.

The college girls who changed their sweaters and skirts for overalls this year to learn first hand what makes an automobile go have proved that they can fix flat tires, drain radiators and adjust fan belts as well as boys "who think they know it all."

An increased interchange of professors, as distinct from student exchange, is advocated by Dr. Francisco Walker Linares, Professor of Sociology at the University of Chile, as a greatly needed measure of inter-American intellectual cooperation. Dr. Linares is here at the invitation of our State Department to establish cultural contacts with Eastern colleges and universities.
LONDON, March 14 -- At no time in the course of World War II has success or failure of Allied sea strategy been so momentously important as it is at the present minute.

WEST POINT, N.Y., March 14 -- On Dave Wilhelm's "sudden death" goal, Yale's polo team won the intercollegiate indoor title in Army's big riding hall today. That tally, coming after one minute of overtime, gave the Elis a 4-3 triumph over Princeton's defending champions, to culminate one of the tightest fights this tourney has seen in its twenty-two years of existence.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 14 -- Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, assisted by local policemen, made seventeen raids tonight on the homes of Japanese, German and Italian citizens in Atlantic and Cape May Counties. An undisclosed number of aliens were arrested and a considerable quantity of contraband seized.

IN the "good cheer" annual borders which most gardeners are planning for next Summer, American-bred novelties will have an honored place. This year for the first time all the new annuals awarded honors by the All America Flower Selections Committee (and most of the non-prize winners as well) are from American breeders.

THE twenty-ninth International Flower Show, casting its annual spell of pre-Spring magic over Grand Central Palace from tomorrow afternoon to next Saturday night, carries on this year the grand tradition of the gardener's art.

After a State-wide contest among high school senior girls, the choice of New York's and New Jersey's "good citizens" is announced by the Daughters of the American Revolution in these two areas. They are Miss Janet Sutherland of Middletown, N.Y., and Miss Elizabeth Green of Morristown, N.J. Both were selected by the organization for their academic standing and their essays on "How the Youth of Today Should Prepare for the Future."

An all-day meeting on the problems of social disease in wartime has been arranged for members of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs and will be held tomorrow at the Hotel Astor by its division of penology and delinquency. A number of speakers will be heard on two panels, for which the chairman will be Miss Helen Kisby, educational director of the Social Service Bureau of the city magistrates' courts.
WITH a few dollars in your pocket, a glint of adventure in your eye, a love of romance in your heart and a hint of cast iron in your stomach, you have what you need to enjoy a time in Mexico.

With contract negotiations still deadlocked, employer spokesmen warned yesterday that between 20,000 and 30,000 workers in New York dress, coat and suit factories would be forced into idleness tomorrow unless a settlement was reached in the strike of 1,500 truck drivers and helpers that had tied up all deliveries of materials since last Thursday.

LAUGHTER (as one used to write at school) distinguishes man from the animals, and possibly the distinction becomes even more necessary when millions of men are fighting like jaguars. They indeed -- the fighting men -- may have little leisure for amusement, but the civilian, the recruit, the static defense services all live in a queer if quieter Wonderland.

WITH the new gardening-for-victory program well under way, the 1942 Spring crop of new gardeners promises to be a bumper one. That their literary requirements will be well taken care of is indicated by the appearance of ten new books dealing with vegetable cultivation and this figure does not include the new titles devoted to herbs.
The Children's Aid Society's Homeless Children's Fund will benefit from an exhibition of Renoir's paintings, in the Durand-Ruel Galleries, 12 East Fifty-seventh Street, during April.

CHICAGO, March 14 -- The furniture industry is going "all out" for defense housing lines at the three Spring trade shows at Chicago, Grand Rapids and Jamestown, but mixed with the specially designed items will be an increased emphasis on lines already in production which are suitable for this type of consumer demand.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- As March 16 draws near, the day Uncle Sam takes money out of some of his pockets and puts it into others, the United States Bureau of Internal Revenue reaches the peak of its labors on the biggest job it has ever done, the filing of 28,000,000 income tax returns and the collection of the largest tax bill in the history of the nation.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., March 14 -- The Lexbrook Stable's 5-year-old gelding Potranco clipped four-fifths of a second from the 2-day-old six-furlong track record at Oaklawn Park today to win the Eastman Hotel Handicap by four lengths in 1:10 1-5.

Trade buying and hedge selling continued yesterday to feature moderately active trading in the cotton market. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange moved, however, within a 7-point range and finished at levels 3 points higher to 2 points lower than on Friday.

WELLESLEY, Mass., March 14 -- Students of art at Wellesley College are enabled to better understand the limitations imposed on the artist by the materials with which he works because the Art Department combines practical work with theory.

ONE of the real pleasures of gardening comes in watching the sprouting seeds as they make their way through the soil and spread their leaves in the sunshine. And dark is the disappointment when seedlings fail to appear. But seldom does the good gardener suffer defeat in this earliest skirmish.

FIXED used tire prices announced last week by the Office Of Price Administration settled a motorists' market which has been disrupted since tires were frozen at the start of this year. For more than two months prices of tires available to the average motorist have gyrated.

JUDGED by any critical standards, "Larrish Hundred" is a notable first novel. It has an unusual plot, rich characterization, excellent background and polished writing. What gives it added stature as a fine creative piece of work is the fact that its author, A.R. Beverley-Giddings is an Englishman.

The college girls who changed their sweaters and skirts for overalls this year to learn first hand what makes an automobile go have proved that they can fix flat tires, drain radiators and adjust fan belts as well as boys "who think they know it all."

ALBANY, March 14 -- Additional housing facilities must be provided to keep up with expanding production and payrolls in urban centers throughout the State unless the war effort is to be handicapped, Edward Weinfeld, State Housing Commissioner, declared today in his annual report to the Governor and Legislature.

An appeal for active participation in civilian defense was directed to members of the Fathers Club of St. Joseph's College for Women, Brooklyn, at its annual corporate communion breakfast yesterday at the college.

Led by a color guard in Continental uniforms into the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street, members of the New York Chapter, Sons of the American Revolution, held their annual church service yesterday for twenty-one chapter members who died since last year's service.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 15 -- All of Westchester County went black tonight in a major demonstration of what an area of 448 square miles with nearly 574,000 inhabitants will do in case of an air raid.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., March 15 -Long-range, hard-hitting bombers of the type necessary to carry offensive war to the enemy are now rolling off mechanized assembly lines only a little more than three months after Japan plunged the United States into the world-wide war.

MOSCOW, March 15 -- German counter-attacks of increasing intensity were reported today from many sectors of the front. As Spring thaws approach, softening the snow and causing mud, the necessity for regaining control of communications that the Russian penetrations have cut becomes urgent and the Reich is not sparing men or equipment in its efforts.

BERNE, Switzerland, Monday, March 16 -- Having successfully crushed the defenses of the 294th and 218th Divisions, the Northern wing of Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's Central Armies on the Donets front was reported this morning to be poised for a blow at Dniepropetrovsk itself, according to information received here.

VICHY, March 15 -- The National Agricultural Credit Fund has just been authorized to issue five-year bonds bearing interest of 3.25 per cent, with the special feature that the interest for the first two years will be paid in advance by a deduction made in the purchase price, while the interest for the last three years will be paid only upon redemption.

JUST recently somebody said that there were more young fellows playing basketball than any other sport in this country. It wasn't Ned Irish who said it, but he would be the last to deny it. Basketball is his pet game. Mr. Irish is the enterprising gent who puts on those college double-headers that attract enough spectators to make the sides of Madison Square Garden bulge outward in the indoor season.

PERTH, Australia, March 15 -- Commander W. Smirnoff, oldest pilot of the Royal Dutch Air Lines and a fighter pilot in the last war, recounted today in his hospital bed here how his Douglas DC3, with twelve persons aboard, was shot down by three Japanese fighters sixty miles north of Broome on March 3, the day Broome itself was attacked.
Two schools conducting courses in aircraft training as part of the war effort have acquired quarters in Newark, N.J., for expansion.

The fact that Jesus has authority over all realms except the human spirit is both "the crown and the tragedy" of mankind, the Rev. Dr. Horace F. Martin, president of the Biblical Seminary in New York, declared yesterday in a sermon at the Lutheran Church of the Advent, Broadway and Ninety-third Street.

The New York City Symphony Orchestra completed its third season yesterday with its twentieth concert at Carnegie Hall in the popular-priced series sponsored by Mayor La Guardia and the City WPA Music Project. Sir Thomas Beecham was the conductor and, despite the 5:30 starting hour, there was a large audience.

Extreme measures being taken by Nazi Germany at home and in the occupied countries of Europe in an effort to mitigate the shortage of food, fuel and clothing are disclosed in an economic report for the week of March 9-15 broadcast officially from Berlin last night and recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Diplomatic representatives of sixteen nations will attend the "Musical Festival of Allied Nations" to be held Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. David Dubinsky, chairman of the concert committee.

The new $375,000, seven-story wing of the Frances Schervier Home and Hospital for the aged and chronic sick, at 227th Street and Independence Avenue, in the Spuyten Duyvil section of the Bronx, was dedicated and formally opened yesterday by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The goldfish bowl, used in the First World War draft lottery and in the first and second selective Service lotteries in 1940 and 1941, will be brought to Washington tomorrow from Independence Hall in Philadelphia for the ceremony on Tuesday in which 7,000 capsules will be drawn.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 15 -- The Swedish Minister of Justice has decided to prosecute the Goeteborgs Stifts-Tidning, a clerical newspaper published by Vicar Ivar Rhedin, for an article entitled "Odd Times," in which Stalin is called "a mass murderer."
Mrs. Charles O. Bruce, daughter of Brig. Gen. Clifford Lee Corbin, U.S.A., and Mrs. Corbin, has come from Washington, D.C., to the Ambassador.

LONDON, March 15 -- Dominated almost entirely by the war developments in the Far-East, the stock markets had last week their quietest period in several months. The only activity was in the gilt-edge issues, although even there it became evident that the reinvestment demand springing from funds released by the call-up of India sterling stocks was beginning to lose its influence.

LONDON, March 15 -- The aerial offensive against Germany that Britain undertook more intensively last week with the return of favorable flying weather was in a slight lull this March Sunday, but Royal Air Force planes went out and shot up five German E-boat fast motor torpedo craft off the Netherland coast during the day.

Aubrey Pankey, Negro baritone, who made his local debut two years ago in Town Hall, gave his second recital in the same surroundings last night. In the interim Mr. Pankey has made marked strides forward as vocalist and interpreter.

NEW ORLEANS, March 15 -- Despite the approval by the House of Representatives of the amendment to the Farm Fund Bill prohibiting sale of Federal stocks of cotton at prices below parity and indications of a record-breaking consumption in February, cotton futures on the Exchange here were narrowly uneven last week.

Ten thousand New York University students are enrolled in courses directly related to the nation's war program, Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase announced yesterday in his statement to the faculty on "New York University and the War."

A tendency "to make religion a national whoopee in wartime" was scored by Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen yesterday in his fourth lenten sermon at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Archbishop Francis J. Spellman presided in the sanctuary.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Here are the answers, prepared by the Petroleum Coordinator's office, to some questions about the gasoline curtailment program, which becomes effective on Thursday in seventeen East Coast States, the District of Columbia and Washington and Oregon:

A delightful performance of Bach's "Musical Offering," under the direction of Fritz Stiedry, was the principal feature of the concert given by the New Friends of Music late yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. The "Musical Offering" was preceded by the Motet, "Jesu Freude," for two sopranos, alto, tenor and bass, sung by a small chorus from the Schola Cantorum.
" I can't tell you where I am, where I am going or where I have been, but you can believe me when I say we are getting around."

LONDON, March 15 -- The government is taking steps to force those who toil not yet prefer a gay life in wartime London to go back whence they came, it was learned today. These are the British variety of what President Roosevelt described as Washington's "parasites," who take up valuable space and contribute nothing to the nation's war effort.

AN EAST COAST CANADIAN PORT, March 15 (Canadian Press) -- After more than three days afloat in frail lifeboats on the chill North Atlantic, twenty-nine survivors from a torpedoed Allied merchantman have been landed here by a Canadian naval craft.

I am wondering whether the gentlemen in Congress who lay the tax burdens upon the American people are aware that if Mr. Morgenthau's program is adopted it will reduce a considerable group of citizens to practical destitution.

" Designed for a duchess" is literally true of a group of gold-and- turquoise jars and bottles with their elegant, delicately scented contents. The whole thing started in Paris with an amber-colored fluid of fifteen ingredients, prescribed by the great lady's doctor for cleansing her sensitive skin.

All members of the Police Department were instructed yesterday in a general order by Commissioner Valentine to enforce compliance of the request made on Saturday by President Roosevelt that automobile speed rates be reduced to conserve tires.

During the first half of last week, decline in stocks continued. Wednesday's market averages were not only lowest of the war, but actually lowest since May, 1933. Unfavorable war news, and the previous week's proposal for new taxes, were the obvious cause.
LONDON, March 15 -- A translation of Adolf Hitler's address at Berlin today, as heard here from a German broadcast, follows:

LONDON, March 15 -- There are 25,000 persons in London who are taking shelter each night in subways, trenches, arches, tunnels and cellars, although it is nearly eight months since the last bomb fell on the British capital.

What General Douglas MacArthur has been doing in his famous "fox-holes of Bataan" has been told and retold with such vividness that every American knows the story. But sportsmen like to recall another side of this many-faceted man. They like to think back to 1928, when he served as the President of the American Olympic Committee.

CANBERRA, Australia, March 15 -- Planes of the Royal Australian Air Force again bombed Gasmata, Japanese-occupied town on the southern coast of the island of New Britain, from a low level today. There was heavy anti-aircraft fire but no fighter opposition. Sticks of heavy bombs were dropped on the airdrome.

William Fellowes Morgan Jr., who resigned as Commissioner of Markets in December because of alleged interference by Mayor La Guardia in the affairs of his department, including the appointments of subordinates, was recently questioned by William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, it was disclosed yesterday.

One thousand acres of land in Palestine will be bought by the Jewish National Fund with the proceeds of a testimonial dinner for the Rev. Dr. Stephen S. Wise in the Hotel Astor last night, the Rev. Dr. Israel Goldstein, president of the fund, announced.

CHICAGO, March 15 -- Corn has been showing independent strength recently on the Board of Trade, due in large part to continued limited country offerings, high prices for hogs, which is regarded as guaranteeing heavy farm consumption, and a belief that if the pending legislation in Congress should become a law this grain is in line for a substantial advance in prices.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, March 15 (AP) -- Epithets against the Germans rose from thousands today at a Porto A legre demonstration Over the sinking of Brazilian ships as a drive against fifth columnists in Brazil resulted in the seizure of a high Japanese Army officer posing as an ice cream dealer.

DELAND, Fla., March 15 -- Timely triples by Harlond Clift and Chet Laabs, a double by the former Cardinal, Don Gutteridge, and a couple of solid singles by George McQuinn more than balanced the one big blow made by the second-string Dodgers today.

Spring officially comes to the north temperate zone next Saturday; and in Russia its dread harbingers -- the rolling troop trains and the rumbling tanks -- were already heralding last week another phase of the greatest campaign in military history.

It has been many years since there was a shortage of books in this country, although the distribution of them still leaves something to be desired. But now a prospective dearth of paper, other materials and manpower that goes with war is already making itself felt.
Names prominent on and radio stage programs were in the lists of new apartment rentals reported over the week-end.

Problems and anxieties involved in the care, protection and training of younger children under the dislocations of war, will be the theme of four sessions planned for succeeding Wednesdays at The New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, beginning March 25.
BERNE, Switzerland, March 15 -- In Europe today the battle for food is becoming more intense than the battle for hegemony. It may well decide the issue of the war rather than the force of arms.

Donald M. Nelson's drive for speedier manufacture of guns, tanks, planes, ships and machine tools will move into high gear tomorrow morning, when 600 representatives of management and labor gather at the call of the War Production Board chief in the auditorium of the Engineering Societies Building at 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 15--Is France on the verge of monetary inflation? The question is being asked here following reports that the Vichy Cabinet at its meeting yesterday decided upon increases in salaries, especially school teachers.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices advanced from 103.4 to 103.6. A 0.2 per cent decline occurred in the raw materials group as price decreases in live poultry, potatoes and grains exceeded price rises in livestock and eggs.

Shortening of the academic schedule in the schools of the nation to allow students to earn college degrees in twelve years of schooling was urged yesterday by the Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham University, in his annual report to the trustees.

The City Fusion party announced yesterday that it would demand a full and impartial inquiry "from other sources," if the agencies now investigating charges that city labor and materials were used wrongfully in paving a courtyard on the Lake Mahopac estate of Edward J. Flynn, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, failed to "make known to the public every detail of their findings, no matter where they may hit."

Completion of plans for a national competition on the basis of which a design for a heroic-sized bronze statue of Christ will be selected was announced yesterday by the Liturgical Arts Society, 300 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Simplicity, functionalism, small size and sound economy are the keynotes of the furniture recommendations being made by the Consumer Division of the Office of Price Administration to all manufacturers interested in providing furniture for war workers living in housing projects.

LONDON, March 15 -- Estimates of the world's surplus of wheat for the season ending with July have been compiled by The Corn Trade News. They give a total of 1,449,600,000 bushels, which will constitute a record. This amount compares with last season's record of 1,204,000,000 bushels, with 1,048,000,000 bushels two years ago and 996,000,000 bushels in 1939.

Once again today the Horticultural Society of New York brings to the city an oasis of fragrance and beauty in the annual flower show. Never was the exhibition at the Palace more welcome. Concentration on the grim business of winning the war will not suffer if we remind ourselves for a moment of the eternal truths of life, and welcome a vernal awakening that knows no edict of dictatorship.

LONDON, March 15 -- Britons were asked by F.P. Bishop, assistant manager of The Times of London, in a broadcast tonight, to reconsider the true value of their newspapers in view of the cut in the paper supply, which goes into effect tomorrow.
