MARJORIE KINNAN RAWLINGS bad bean a sob-sister on newspapers in a number of cities, and her sentiments were rather thoroughly battered by the time she escaped to a kind of Walden in the Florida back-country, Cross Creek.* She always had wanted to write short stories and novels, but had tried to make her stories salable -- and such stories are very hard to sell.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The Club Razor and Blade Manufacturing Corporation, Newark, N.J., wholesaler of Fan brand razor blades, has promised the Federal Trade Commission to discontinue using any price marking or purported retail selling price which is fictitious, exaggerated or more than the price for which its products customarily are sold in the usual course of retail trade.

PINKHAM NOTCH, N.H., March 15 -- Finn Ferner, Harvard's talented captain, and Bob Meservey, Dartmouth's intercollegiate champion, finished in a tie for individual honors as the Big Green ski forces from Hanover successfully defended their laurels in the eighth annual invitation Appalachian Mountain Club downhill race today.

ALBANY, March 15 -- The Legislature will start its adjournment drive this week, but with the leaders doubtful that the slate can be cleared before the recess which will come the first few days in April because of the Jewish holy days and Easter week.
BERNE, Switzerland, March 15 -- Adolf Hitler predicted today that Russia would be defeated with "complete destruction of the Bolshevist hordes" next Summer.

A heavy influx of buyers to attend openings of new lines and trade exhibits, with many others coming to check up on deliveries and to complete their purchasing for the balance of the year, was reported in a summary of last week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading local resident buyers.

After a preview that will open tomorrow at the Pan American Union in Washington, a comprehensive book exhibition exemplifying the best in United States, book design, illustration and manufacture in the last ten years will be sent on a two-year tour of Latin-American republics.

Herr Hitler appeared in Berlin yesterday. He turned up unexpectedly in the glass-roofed courtyard of the Arsenal Museum on Unter den Linden to deliver his annual address on the German memorial day. Perhaps he flew to the capital from the windswept heights of Kiev, the advertised headquarters of the Spring campaign.

A taciturn six-footer whose long black cape and black hat were a familiar sight on the East Side was found dead yesterday in a metal chamber that served as his bed in the two squalid rooms he had occupied for thirty-five years at 79 Allen Street:

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The trucking industry has developed an efficient system for the settlement of industrial disputes without government intervention, according to a report on a study of "teamsters and transportation" published today by the American Council on Public Affairs.
LONDON, March 15 -- A two-day offensive by United Nations air forces against Japanese troops in lower Burma was reported today in dispatches from New Delhi, India.
ROME, March 15 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

CHICAGO, March 15 -- The 1942-43 edition of Who's Who in America, now being distributed, contains 3,560 new biographies, many of high-ranking Army and Navy men and many of refugees from Europe. The new edition contains 2,580 pages with 31,692 sketches of noteworthy persons.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Young men from nations opposed to the Axis are training at a recently constructed airfield in the Salt River Valley of Southern Arizona to fight the enemy with American airplanes, the War Department revealed today.

LONDON, March 15 -- Queen Wilhelmina, broadcasting today to her loyal subjects in the Netherlands, as well as to Netherlanders all over the world, pledged the reconstruction of the Netherland Navy "by the purchase of new vessels" and adding that "we are fully convinced of the powerful assistance yet to be given us by our allies."

ALBANY, March 15 (AP) -- New York's Department of Law recovered $317,957 last year for persons swindled in fake stock transactions and other illicit sales of securities. Of the amount recovered, $170,777 was obtained by the New York City bureau.

An encouraging subscription has been reported for the luncheon and fashion show, entitled "Boutonniere of Spring Fashions," to be held tomorrow in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis for the benefit of the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery. Mrs. Harold H. Hackett is chairman of the executive committee for the event.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 15 -- For a while today it seemed as if the Yankees would snap that winning streak of the Cardinals.

With automotive copy dropping 70.3 per cent and all but one classification showing decreases, advertising linage in newspapers of fifty-two cities measured by Media Records, Inc., registered a decline of 6.4 per cent for February from the like month last year.

There is still time for the citizens of Westchester to realize what is being put on them in regard to a site for an airport in the county. The War Department has never asked for an airport in the county, but the civil branch of the service does want a flying field in Westchester, largely for keeping pilots in practice, but also for possible military purposes.
CALCUTTA, India, March 15 (U.P.) -- More thousands of crack, American-armed Chinese troops are pouring into Northern and Central Burma, it was announced today.

Now that the country is straining every sinew to increase production the question of food is all important. Not that we lack food, but that something is wrong with the American diet. The right food means energy, and we need all the energy we can muster. Are vitamins the answer?

The Mutual Life Insurance Company sold the two-family house on a plot 35 by 100 feet at 405 Avenue F. adjoining the corner of East Fourth Street, Brooklyn, to an investor for cash. The property is assessed at $12,500 and was sold through the Bulkley Horton Company.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Working in smooth-functioning unison, all arms of the United States Coastal Patrol combined to blast from the seas "certainly one" and "very possibly three" members of the Axis submarine pack that had sunk two vessels off our coast within the preceding forty-eight hours.
LONDON, March 15 (AP) -- The Ministries of Air and Home Security issued this communique today:

The report of the Kennecott Copper Corporation for 1941, released for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $49,251,857 after taxes, depreciation, retirements and a reserve of $4,000,000 for contingencies, but before mine depletion.

MIAMI, Fla., March 15 -- The Giants' heavy guns finally boomed with force and effectiveness today. Paced by Manager Melvin Ott's first home run of the exhibition campaign plus four ringing hits by Johnny Mize, the Polo Grounders managed to sink the Dodgers, 7 to 4.

Only two films are scheduled to open on Broadway this week. These are "Valley of the Sun," an RKO picturization of the Clarence Budington Kelland story and featuring Lucille Ball, James Craig, Sir Cedric Hardwicke and Dean Jagger, due Wednesday at the Rialto, and "Bedtime Story," a comedy from the Columbia studios, which is due on Thursday at the Radio City Music Hall.

LONDON, March 15 (AP)--Alarm was expressed in some British quarters tonight over the possibility that efforts to bestow self-government upon India might bring dangerous repercussions throughout the strategically vital Moslem world, which the Axis is striving to incite to revolt.

The New York City Nutrition Program Committee, headed by Mayor La Guardia and including educational and nutrition experts, announced yesterday that information and literature covering every phase of nutrition now was available at its headquarters, 125 Worth Street.

CHICAGO, March 15 -- Operations in oats last week on the Board of Trade were on a reduced scale, prices holding within a range of around 1 1/2 cents a bushel, with the action of other grains the dominating influence. Final sales yesterday showed gains of 1/4 to 1/2 cent for the week, with May at 56 1/8 cents, July 55 5/8 cents and September 56 1/8 cents.

ALBANY, March 15 -- The Ives committee presented today to the Legislature, to the Governor and to business and labor in the State another comprehensive blueprint for present and future action in the field of industrial and labor conditions, in making public its fourth annual report.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- British trade union leaders have been sounding out officials of the American Federation of Labor about dropping their long-standing opposition to cooperation with trade unionists in Soviet Russia so that the labor movements of Great Britain, the United States and Russia may join in an international federation to help the war effort of the United Nations, it was learned today.

LONDON, March 15 (AP) -- Sacrifice of the United Nations naval forces in the Java Sea battle in vain effort to block the Japanese invasion will bring repercussions in Parliament, political quarters forecast today.

The Police Department will soon begin a series of practice blackouts in various local areas throughout the city, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday in his regular weekly "Talk to the People," broadcast from his desk in City Hall via WNYC, the municipal radio station.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The National Aeronautic Association will hold a meeting tomorrow to plan for the immediate installation of junior aviation courses in public schools throughout the country.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 15 -- Casey Stengel, hard-bitten commanding officer of the Boston Braves, took the salute from the infantry of Philadelphia Phils before their exhibition game today, and it was no gag.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 15 (AP) -- The British Middle East communique today said:

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 15 (U.P.) -- The escape of 420 R.A. A.F. fliers and ground workers from three isolated island air bases just before a big Japanese invasion fleet arrived, was reported officially today.

Today is the seventy-fifth anniversary of the death of Benjamin Russell Hanby of Ohio, once famous as a composer of songs. He was a sophomore at Otterbein College in 1856 when he wrote "Darling Nelly Gray," his most popular composition. In the late Fifties and Sixties -- and we don't know for how much longer -- it was sung all over the North.

Anticipating industry's post-war shift of emphasis from production to distribution, a survey of college and university courses in marketing and selling, aimed at closer future understanding between educators and business executives, was announced here yesterday by the National Federation of Sales Executives.

CLEVELAND, March 15 (AP) -- Backlogs on plate mill books are at the highest level ever attained and sheet shipments show a stronger trend toward higher priorities than in February, the magazine Steel reported today.

WASHINGTON, March 15 Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, has ordered an immediate inquiry into the sudden resignation yesterday of Robert W. Guthrie, head of the WPB textile, clothing and leather goods division, and two of his aides, it was understood here tonight.

PEORIA, Ill., March 15 -- Four blasts of shotgun fire were fired today into the home of Harold E. Kipling, chief special agent of the Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad, against which a strike has been in progress for seventy-seven days.

Successful record assaults by two stars of the Women's Swimming Association of New York, Miss Gloria Callen and Miss Helene Rains, were the high spots of an A.A.U. aquatic meet yesterday at the Madison Square Boys Club.

Detective John Jacoby of the Queens Village Squad shot and killed an armed hold-up man last night and wounded an accomplice who fled from the Village Pharmacy, 216-19 Ninetieth Avenue Queens Village, after the pair had tried to rob the place. Because of recent robberies in the neighborhood, Detective Jacoby was stationed in the shop for just such an emergency.

NEW DELHI, India, March 15 -- Air Marshal Sir Richard E.C. Peirse, new Air Chief of India, predicted today that Burma would prove to be different from the areas in which the United Nations had fought and lost, because "from the start we were able to gain air superiority."

VICHY, France, March 15 -- A series of financial measures adopted by the Cabinet at its last meeting were published today. The government has increased wages in the lower brackets, increased various pensions, increased family allotments and relief for soldiers families and increased the price of tobacco, cigars and cigarettes.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 15 (U.P.) -- Former Postmaster General James A. Farley today urged the American public to fall in line whole-heartedly with the war and peace aims set forth by President Roosevelt.

The New Jersey State Fish and Game Commission has just issued a report of the income and expenditures of the fund obtained through the sale of hunting and fishing licenses, and it makes very interesting reading for the man interested in comparisons.

Discouragement about human nature today is one of the shortest routes to disbelief, and we have all felt the lure of it, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick said in his sermon yesterday in the Riverside Church.
LONDON, March 15 -- Lord Croft, Under-Secretary of State for War, today called on the British people to stamp out "fretful and querulous criticism."

LARCHMONT, N.Y., March 15 -- As what appeared to be the break of Spring spread over Long Island Sound, two of Yale's crack skippers engaged in a sailing duel today in the dinghy racing at the Larchmont Yacht Club. It was real competition and Jack Ware, former vice commodore of the Yale Corinthian Yacht Club and now taking a post-graduate course at Columbia, won by a single point.

A special service commemorating the thirty-fifth anniversary of the installation of the Rev. Dr. Matthew Foster Johnston as pastor of the Morrisania Presbyterian Church, Washington Avenue and 168th Street, the Bronx, was held yesterday. More than 500 members of the congregation were in attendance.

If you haven't heard of Master Francis Kennedy, you probably will pretty soon. For he's the author of as choice a cable as was ever filed from this country for delivery (but never sent) to "Adolf" and "Musoline" and the "Yellow Japs."

In the hope of averting a last-minute rush, offices of the Bureau of Internal Revenue here were open yesterday for the first time on a Sunday to receive income tax returns. The deadline for filing is midnight tonight.

The New York Rovers displayed their keenest form yesterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden. Led by Art Kendall and Bob Kirkpatrick, each of whom performed the "hat trick," the Red Shirts broke a first-place tie with the Johnstown Blue Birds and captured the Eastern Hockey League championship.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 15 (AP) -- American correspondents and photographers have arrived after an eighteen-day non-stop voyage that included a near collision with an enemy submarine and a violent storm at sea.

TOKYO, March 15 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in San Francisco) -- Press dispatches from the Netherlands Indies asserted today that American, British and Australian forces were among more than 50,000 war prisoners taken in the Bandung area of Java alone and that Netherland resistance in Sumatra had collapsed.

As the Navy acknowledged last night that another big American tanker had fallen victim to the Axis U-boat invasion of United States Atlantic waters, twenty-six survivors, blackened and burned by oil and flames, told of their desperate fight for life after their armed ship had been torpedoed and set afire by an enemy submarine.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 15 -- Charles Chaplin will begin filming "Shadow and Substance," Paul Vincent Carroll's Broadway play of the 1937-38 season, in three months, the Chaplin studio has announced. Chaplin is adapting the drama to the screen, and he will produce and direct it, but will not appear in it.

Except for three items of unfinished business, the decks have been cleared for college, basketball's two big post-season classics, the fifth annual national invitation tournament opening at Madison Square Garden tomorrow and the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship, which will start simultaneously at New Orleans and Kansas City on Friday.

The cheerful young man with the silver spatula clasped in his capable hand lifted the small square cake out of the shining showcase and placed it on the counter before our entranced eyes. He did so with a casual air of unconcern that hardly befitted the occasion.
BERLIN, March 15 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German communique said:

CHUNGKING, China, March 15 -- Major Gen. Lancelot Dennys, chief of the British Military Mission to China, two members of the United States Military Mission to China and three other Americans were among thirteen persons who were killed last night in the crash and fire of a Douglas transport plane en route to Chungking from Kunming.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The American Button Mould Manufacturers Association, Inc., New York, four of its officers and six member firms, making approximately 80 per cent of the button and buckle parts made in the United States, are charged in a complaint issued by the Federal Trade Commission with combining and conspiring to fix prices and restrain trade.
MELBOURNE, Australia, March 15 (AP) -- This south-coast metropolis experienced an air-raid scare today.

There's life in the Brooklyn Americans yet. The lightly regarded sextet from across the East River, skating on the thin ice of elimination from the National Hockey League play-offs, retained a mathematical chance of qualifying for the post-season battles for the Stanley Cup by handing the Toronto Maple Leafs a 6-to-3 setback at Madison Square Garden last night.

CHICAGO, March 15 -- The Rangers tonight clinched the National Hockey League championship as they defeated the Black Hawks, 5 to 1, before 16,381 persons at the Chicago Stadium. It was the New Yorkers' final game of the regular campaign and the victory gave them 60 points to 57 for second-place Toronto, which still has one game to play.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 15 -- Eighty-two years after it had been suspended following the "unfavorable" plebiscite that gave Nice to France, the Nizzardo re-appeared on newsstands in Rome today, dedicated to the annexation of Nice to Italy.

Nothing would be gained by trying to disguise the fact that in the Battle of the Java Sea the United Nations suffered a great naval defeat. All five of the United Nations' cruisers engaged in the battle, together with at least six destroyers and one sloop, were lost. Perhaps other vessels were damaged.

Germany has virtually abandoned her air attack on England except for token raids. Only twenty-two persons were killed by sky bombs in all England during February, less than one a day. Such casualties are wholly without military significance. The British, on the other hand, have resumed mass raids both over France and Germany in what appears an attempt to outdo the tremendous assault of last year.

Nothing would be gained by trying to disguise the fact that in the Battle of the Java Sea the United Nations suffered a great naval defeat. All five of the United Nations' cruisers engaged in the battle, together with at least six destroyers and one sloop, were lost. Perhaps other vessels were damaged.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The War Department announced today the appointment of six educators, recreational and entertainment experts to the faculty of the new training school for Army recreational officers at Fort Meade, Md.

Complete paralysis of manufacturing in the women's coat, suit and dress industry and enforced idleness for the industry's 115,000 workers appeared as a possibility last night after negotiations for settlement of a strike of 1,500 garment truck drivers broke down at the Hotel New Yorker.

ALBANY, March 15 (AP) -- Accused of plugging fire extinguishers in the important Bayer Company plant in Rensselaer, William Henry Tobin, 41, a World War veteran, was arrested today and charged with violating the Federal sabotage law.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 15 -- The annual dinner of the Committee of One Hundred will be held at the Surf Club on Tuesday. Dr. William Mather Lewis, president of Lafayette College, will be one of the speakers.

Increases in contributions to churches may be expected another year because of the broadening of the Federal income tax base, the Rev. Rowland Hill Kimberlin said in a sermon yesterday morning in the Fort Hamilton Presbyterian Church, Fourth Avenue and Ninety-fourth Street, Brooklyn.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 15 -- Mr. and Mrs. Frank C. Henderson gave a luncheon today at the Bath and Tennis Club. Among the guests were Mr. and Mrs. Robert McCoskry Butt, Mr. and Mrs. William Q. Cain, Mr. and Mrs. H. Winfield Chapin, Mrs. Theodore W. Stemmler, Mrs. Charles Easton, Mrs. Frederick Herreshoff, John J.A. Murphy and Privates Michael Cirila and Nick Resonavich of Morrison Field.

The regiment of Negro soldiers guarding strategic points within the city has been "adopted" by the City College School of Business and Civic Administration, 17 Lexington Avenue, which will provide athletic, educational and social facilities for the diversion of the troops.

Yale University sold for cash the three-story brick store and loft building on a lot 16.8 by 120 feet, at 40 Bowery, 125 feet north of Bayard Street and facing the Manhattan Bridge Plaza. The buyer, a client of Walter M. Wechsler, attorney, intends to modernize the property, which is assessed at $21,000, of which $18,000 is land value.

Our deepest danger today is ignorance of the eternal war that underlies the outward war, the Rev. Samuel M. Shoemaker, rector, asserted yesterday in a sermon in Calvary Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- The first official Japanese list of interned American civilians, received from Tokyo through the International Red Cross and containing 219 names, was published today by the War Department.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that Dr. Willard C. Rappleye, Commissioner of Hospitals since Oct. 1, 1940, had given up his city post to return to his duties as dean of the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University.

Mario Castelnuovo-Tedesco's "King John," his seventh overture for a Shakespearean play, received its first performance before an audience of 2,100 yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony under John Barbirolli, to whom the work is dedicated.

Mrs. Charles Dana Gibson heads a group of prominent men and women in charge of the arrangements for an unusual exhibition of paintings and drawings from the William H. Coverdale collection of historical Canadiana which will be opened formally with a preview and tea dance on April 6 at the Grand Central Galleries and will continue there for two weeks.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 28 -If any place can be said to benefit from the war it is South America, the only continent not directly embroiled in it, although the process of being benefited is distasteful to the Latin peoples.

Prices of cotton continued last week to move within a narrow range, as they have done since early in February. At the close of business on Saturday, net changes in active futures contracts on the New Cotton Exchange ranged from nothing to an advance of 11 points.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Mrs. Julia O. Flikke, superintendent of the Army Nurse Corps, has been promoted to the grade of colonel, and Florence A. Blanchfield, assistant superintendent, to lieutenant colonel, each for the duration of the war.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- An account by Ensign William J. Maddocks, the only surviving officer, of the destruction of the United States destroyer Truxtun on Feb. 18 in a Winter gale off St. Lawrence Harbor, Newfoundland, disclosed tonight that many of those lost had been swept to sea by high waves as the ship lay on a reef within sixty yards of the shore.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 15 -- Japanese propagandists in Chile engineered their most ambitious coup of the war today when two leading Chilean newspapers published a story saying a certain belligerent, whose trade with Chile was now cut off, had announced it was ready to resume sending ships here soon under convoy.

Addressing 3,000 representatives of Jewish fraternal and benevolent organizations of Greater New York, Jan Masaryk, Minister of Foreign Affairs of the Czechoslovak Government-in-exile, declared yesterday afternoon that he considered the Czechoslovakian question inseparable from the question of all minorities and that he would never consent to a settlement that would not provide for equal rights of all minorities, including the Jews.

The Jesuit Philippine Bureau, with offices at 51 East Eighty-third Street, made public yesterday a cable received from the Right Rev. James T.G. Hayes, American Bishop of Cagayan, Mindanao, disclosing that he and thirty-four Jesuit priests, four scholastics and four brothers immediately under him were "safe and well."

BEDFORD CENTER, N.Y., March 15 -- Three more members of the family of Robert Hoffner died today in the Northern Westchester Hospital at Mount Kisco of burns suffered in a fire that destroyed the family's two-story frame dwelling on Harris Street here late yesterday afternoon, bringing the death list to four.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- The first official Japanese list of interned American civilians, received from Tokyo through the International Red Cross and containing 219 names, was published today by the War Department.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that Dr. Willard C. Rappleye, Commissioner of Hospitals since Oct. 1, 1940, had given up his city post to return to his duties as dean of the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University.

Mario Castelnuovo-Tedesco's "King John," his seventh overture for a Shakespearean play, received its first performance before an audience of 2,100 yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony under John Barbirolli, to whom the work is dedicated.
One of Westchester largest groups of modern garden apartment buildings has just been returned to private ownership.

ALBANY, March 16 -- The $100,000,000 of short-term notes sold today by allotment by State Controller O'Leary will be delivered tomorrow to the Bank of the Manhattan Company in New York City for conveyance to the buyers. Proceeds of the sale will be used for general governmental purposes.

John Barbirolli, the British conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, will fly to England next month for a ten-week visit, during which he will conduct the London Philharmonic, the London Symphony and the British Broadcasting Corporation Orchestra in London and on tour.
An inspection of 250 old Third Avenue Railway Company street cars with wooden bodies was started yesterday by the Transit Commission at the request of the company.

Charles Braveman, head of the Empire Trucking Company of Utica, N.Y., appeared as the prosecution's first witness yesterday in the General Sessions trial of twelve men on the forty-five-count conspiracy-extortion indictment in the so-called $157,800 shakedown of independent milk dealers and truckers in this State from 1937 to last July.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Mainly because of the difficulty of converting to war production existing facilities for the supply of non-durable consumers' goods civilian consumption during 1942 probably will be only a tenth less than its record volume in 1941, according to the March Survey of Current Business published by the department.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- With the Army quartermaster about to receive bids for 1,500,000 mattresses, Acting Price Administrator John E. Hamm today announced that OPA is issuing for signature by individual manufacturers and distributors of bed ticking voluntary agreements stabilizing the price of bed tickings somewhat below current quotations.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- President Roosevelt signed the Bland bill giving the Maritime Commission authority to deal with the problems of freight forwarding for export, talked to Democratic leaders from Congress, met with members of the Senate Naval Affairs subcommittee, and with Representative Mary T. Norton.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- A tremendous new contract calling for the construction of 200 Liberty cargo ships by means of a secret adapation of the automobile industry's assembly line technique was announced tonight by the Maritime Commission.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, March 16 -- The Ministry of the Interior, in a decree believed to point to further steps by the government to prevent Axis agents from using Argentina as headquarters for their activities throughout the continent, ordered all amateur radio stations off the air today to aid the police in the detecting and eliminating of secret sending stations.

LONDON, March 16 -- The United States forces in Britain and Northern Ireland will be reinforced by many trained Americans who are serving with the Canadians and British here as soon as the authorizations for their transfer are settled by Washington, London and Ottawa, it was stated today.

The five-story apartment house at the northeast corner of Morris Avenue and East 172d Street, in the Bronx, has been sold by the Re-Mo Holding Corporation, J. Yasgur, president to an investing client of Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc., brokers.

Mrs. Edwin Philips Kohl and Miss Barbara Sincerbeaux, as co-chairman, have organized a floor committee of fifty members for the Furlough Frolic, a Spring dancing party to be given by the Young Women's Organization of the Women's National Republican Club on the night of March 27 at the clubhouse, 3 West Fifty-first Street.

Long Island University wild meet West Virginia, and West Texas State will face Creighton at Madison Square Garden tonight in the opening games of the fifth annual national invitation basketball tournament, a four-night carnival that is expected to unfold before full houses from start to finish.

Lambert R. Walker, formerly assistant secretary of the Commercial Credit Corporation, is with the Bankers Commercial Corporation as new business consultant on the financing of accounts receivable and war contracts.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 16 -- Foreign Minister Juan Bautista Rossetti of Chile "summoned" the German and Italian Ambassadors and the Japanese Minister to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs "in connection with the sinking" of the Chilean freighter Tolten, which was torpedoed off the United States East Coast with a loss of twenty-seven members of the crew, according to a statement published tonight by the Chilean Government.

Exercising their option on the choice of the site for the opening conflicts in the National Hockey League's Stanley Cup play-offs, the New York Rangers yesterday announced that Series A, involving the Rangers and second-place Toronto Maple Leafs, would get under way on Sunday night at Madison Square Garden.

The National Orchestral Association was scheduled to present a "music play" at Carnegie Hall last night. War forced abandonment of the project, but Leon Barzin, the director, saw to it that the subscribers did not suffer, for he devised a program that was both a good concert and a good show.

LONDON March 16 (AP) -- In the heaviest fighting of the year on the Russian front, the Red Army was delivering mighty blows out of the swirl of blizzards today against three of Reichsfuehrer Hitler's encircled "Spring offensive" bases and striving hard to draw the strings on two others caught in deep pockets.

For three and a half hours at the Bronx Coliseum last night amateur boxers from various sections of the East tossed leather in the first round of the Tournament of Champions. Golden Gloves winners, seeking berths on the Eastern team that will oppose the West at Madison Square Garden on March 30 provided a crowd of 5,000 with enough excitement and laughs to last a long time.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Legislation which, for the duration of the war, would suspend all laws and contracts calling for the forty-hour work week, would outlaw the closed union shop and at the same time limit industrial profits on larger defense orders to 6 per cent, was presented today to a Congress seething with demands for "action now" against factors deemed to be withholding production from the absolute maximum required for the war effort.

Spring is the time for sentiment. It is the time for daffodils and fleecy clouds, for holding hands in the park, for soft rain and waltzes. It is the time of year to wear a sweet, Victorian scent -- a demure medley of the flowery fragrances our grandmothers loved.

In an effort to enlist "every bit of help possible in speeding production of vital war materials" in the plants of the General Electric Company, joint committees of management and labor will be set up immediately for the specific purpose of accelerating output, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended March 11 aggregated $10, 277,000,009.

The "casting office" plan for distributing war production work in much the same way that Hollywood producers select actors and actresses will be the subject of an experiment by the War Production Board and the National Association of Manufacturers, it was learned here yesterday.

Police Inspector Camille C. Pierne, attached to the Tenth Division in Brooklyn, became yesterday the second high-ranking departmental officer to apply for retirement within the past five days at a time when their official conduct was being studied by Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen's grand jury investigating alleged police protection of organized gambling rings in Brooklyn.

ALBANY, March 16 -- The prospects of making the State income tax payable in four equal installments dropped sharply tonight, as Chairman Moffat of the Ways and Means Committee reported to the Legislature that so many shifts in other tax payment dates would be necessary in order to facilitate the income tax reform, that the problem should be weighed carefully before coming to a final decision.

LONDON, March 16 -- The Times will publish tomorrow on its respected and authoritative leader page an article by Sir William Beveridge that, before its reverberations die, may echo from Whitehall to the humblest crofter's home in Scotland.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores had an increase of 19 per cent in sales last week, as compared with the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The following accounts of exploits of Russian automatic-rifle men written by M. Bulkin, a Russian writer, was cabled from Moscow to the Soviet Embassy, which made it available to THE NEW YORK TIMES today:

ALBANY, March 16 -- Due primarily to seasonal activity in the apparel industries, coupled with further expansion of war production, factory employment in the State rose 2 per cent and payrolls 3 per cent in February, Industrial Commissioner Miller announced today.

CHICAGO, March 16 -- Weakness in rye, which declined around 2 cents a bushel in the early trading on the Board of Trade today, was largely responsible for the heavy undertone in the grains markets. Liquidation and stop-loss selling, combined with the closing of spreads with corn, accounted for the sharp break in rye which carried prices to the lowest levels since early in January.

Trading in cotton futures continued quiet and featureless yesterday as outside news offered traders no basis for important commitments on either side of the market. Active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange moved within a 9-point range and closed with net losses of 2 to 6 points.

ALBANY, March 16 -- In its proposed reallocation of State Senate seats, the legislative Reapportionment Commission has drafted new district boundaries for Manhattan that place three present Senators in the same district and constitute the Harlem area as a separate district, it was learned here tonight as a map of the suggested New York County districts became available.

Mayor La Guardia opened the new Employment Agency Center Building at 80 Warren Street yesterday with the announcement that henceforth the city would no longer tolerate the "curb market" practices of employment agencies that have been operating for years on sidewalks along Sixth Avenue from Twenty-third Street to Forty-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (U.P.) -- "Things are not too bad" in the besieged fortress of Corregidor in Manila Bay, but the women in the garrison have had to cut their hair because there are no hairpins left, a letter from an Army nurse revealed today.

LONDON, March 16 -- Fifty-seven hours after he had bailed out of his damaged Spitfire seven miles from the Channel Islands, Squadron Leader J.C. Carver was picked up by a destroyer after he had paddled a distance of nearly forty miles in his rubber dinghy, it was revealed today.

St. Patrick celebrations are not confined to the Murphys, the Donovans and the O'Tooles. All New York is Irish today. Old-line Yankees, ladies with the soft lisp of Spain, the gentlemen whose first steps were taken on the Russian steppes are proudly wearing the green, while almond-eyed laundrymen are likely to greet their customers with "The top of the morning to you."

A bill pending in both houses of the Legislature gives the Board of Estimate, with the Mayor's approval, power "to assign for any public purposes any city property, including property the alienation of which is prohibited by law, for whatsoever purpose originally acquired, which it may find to be no longer required for such purpose."

South Carolina will enter the market on March 31 with $3,000,000 of State highway certificates of indebtedness, for which bidders are to name the interest rate. The certificates, dated April 1, are to mature on April 1, 1949 to 1958.
Eddie Cantor attended his first graduation exercises yesterday, as a proud father and principal speaker at the fifty-eighth annual commencement exercises of the American Academy of Dramatic Arts.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today denied Friday's petition by the Office of Price Administration to have the effective date of the recent 6 per cent freight rate increase on a number of basic commodities postponed until April 15. Accordingly, the increased rates will go into effect tomorrow at midnight.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 16 -- On his way from Oslo to Helsinki General Field Marshal Siegmund Wilhelm List spent the weekend in Stockholm. He left yesterday for Helsinki with his staff. The journey is generally taken in military circles here to mean the imminence of an offensive against Leningrad to form part of the general German drive.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 16 (AP) -- Mrs. Estelle Lawson Page of Chapel Hill won the medal again today in the annual North and South women's golf tournament with a round of 40, 34 -- 74 on the No. 1 course.

Peeking back to the sinful days of 1926, Rowland Brown has discovered a Greenwich Village speakeasy. In "Johnny 2x4," which was staged at the Longacre, he has made a densely populated play out of it, and fitted it out with some good vintage songs and one brilliant trumpet solo.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Ways and Means Committee heard further pleas today for a Federal sales tax, and received from the Treasury and from the Congressional Joint Committee on Internal Revenue Taxation studies indicating that a 10 per cent sales tax on all commodities except those now taxed, or on sales to government or to defense contractors, might yield from $3,296,000,000 to $3,680,000,000.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Rogers bill to create a Women's Army Auxiliary Corps reached the floor of the House late this afternoon after a long discussion about rules, during which Representative Nichols of Oklahoma said he would introduce an amendment to give women members of the corps equal protection and pension status with the regular soldiers.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 16 -- Count and Countess Giovanni di Castagnola entertained today with a cocktail party for which The Patio was the setting.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Reichsfuehrer Hitler's speech yesterday promising victory for the Axis, defeat of the United States, and denouncing the democracies was rejected by Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, today with the statement that "throughout the world Hitler's declarations and promises are recognized everywhere as being but a tissue of lies offered solely for purposes of deceit.''

Aldo Spoldi, 138 1/4, West Side, gained an eight-round decision over Ernest Robinson, 145s 3/4, Jamaica, in the feature bout before 3,500 persons at the St. Nicholas Palace last night. The contest was hard fought.

Enemy submarines have struck again in home waters, this time sinking the 1,858-ton freighter Tol-ten, operated by Chile, one of the two Latin-American countries that have not severed diplomatic relations with the Axis, the Navy Department revealed last night.
Spruille Braden, newly appointed United States Ambassador to Cuba, and Mrs. Braden are at the Plaza.

Miroslaw Arciszewski, recently appointed Minister to Argentina by the Polish Government in Exile in London, arrived at La Guardia Field early yesterday morning aboard a Pan American Airways Clipper. He said that, in the opinion of his government, Josef Beck, former Polish Foreign Minister, is a "dupe of Hitler."

The President is on firm ground in insisting that the labor dispute which has been in progress on the 239-mile Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad since Dec. 28 must be submitted to arbitration. The strike involves 104 members of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Engineers and the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, who contend that a proposed new contract ignores seniority rights and would have the effect of reducing wages.

CONCORD, N.H., March 16 -- New Hampshire, leading ski State in the Northeast, has mapped a survey of safety precautions for skiers. A report will be made on the advisability of creating a State Ski Commission.

The annual report of Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., announced yesterday by C. Donald Dallas, president, shows a net income for 1941 of $4,066,616 after providing for all charges, including depreciation, Federal income and excess-profits taxes.

The war effort has emphasized the importance of safeguarding the health of our young people. One step in this direction is the Crews bill, introductory 469, in the New York State Assembly, which provides for the physical examination and chest X-ray of students in vocational high schools.
The income taxes on corporations proposed by the Treasury are, I believe, so full of dangers to the economic system that this whole subject should be restudied and the system revised.

MANDALAY, Burma, March 16 -- In commenting today on the successful diversion that had permitted the Rangoon garrison to escape a Japanese trap, Lieut. Gen. Harold R.L.G. Alexander, the commander in Burma, said that "if our troops had been bottled up in Rangoon there would have been nothing between the Japanese and the Irrawaddy oil fields."

The report for 1941 of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., released for publication today, showed in terms of United States currency a consolidated net income of $34,356,401 after all charges, taxes and reserves, and equal, after preferred dividend payments, to $2.22 each on the 14,584,025 common shares.
CHICAGO, March 16 (AP) -- A new high at $15.50 was made for choice to prime steers on the livestock market today as salable receipts continued small.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Navy tonight reported the recent sinking of an enemy freighter "in Japanese waters" and of a 3,000-ton gasoline tanker "in the Philippine area."

"Gone With the Wind" will return to Broadway for a third time on March 31, when the David O. Selznick production will open a continuous-run popular-price engagement at the Astor Theatre. The film, which already has grossed $30,000,000, the biggest business ever to be recorded by any picture, has played to more than 52,000,000 paid admissions in more than 12,500 engagements, according to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, the distributors.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Ensign Thomas H. Taylor today received from Secretary Knox the decoration of the Navy Cross for extreme heroism in the action at Pearl Harbor.

Partial Settlement of the strike of 1,500 truck drivers in the garment industry, members of Local 102 of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, was achieved yesterday by Mayor La Guardia after all-day conferences with representatives of all parties at City Hall.

LONDON, March 16 -- Civil defense workers throughout Britain, several hundred thousand of them in all branches of the service who are growing restive as a result of enforced idleness, will have productive, spare-time jobs found for them, it was learned today.

Although trading slumped again yesterday on the Stock Exchange to the lightest since last Summer, the stock market managed a moderate recovery, particularly among some of the high-priced issues which had suffered wide losses in recent weeks.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review a decision by a three-judge Federal court at New York which dismissed suits brought by the National Broadcasting Company, Inc., and the Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., to enjoin the Communications Commission from enforcing restrictions on chain broadcasting.

The New York City banks felt yesterday the first effects of income tax day, although today, when the Treasury deposits the checks, will be the big day. Yesterday the Treasury disbursed far more in this district than it actually collected.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 16 -- Increasing Axis air activity, which had been reported several times lately by the British, was noted again today in official reports on the operations in Libya.

Cancellation of freight advertising by American steamship operators in foreign trade and shipping publications is causing serious concern to publishers of these papers, it was reported here yesterday. Some five of the leading lines canceled all copy last week on the ground that such copy was unnecessary because there were no available bottoms.

A total of 327 commercial banks and trust companies in this State have now established payroll deduction plans for employes for the purchase of defense savings bonds, it was announced yesterday by the New York State Bankers Association. Of these banks, more than 44 per cent report that all officers and employes are participating in the plan.

Recommending that the United Nations virtually abandon for the time being their attempts to check the spread of Japan in the Pacific area, Lieut. Col. W.F. Kernan, author of the widely discussed book, "Defense Will Not Win the War," declared yesterday in an interview that if the Allies were to concentrate their sea and air power in support of a European invasion the Japanese problem eventually would become "a simple matter."

The Citizens Union asked Governor Lehman and Attorney General John J. Bennett yesterday to supersede District Attorney Samuel J. Foley of the Bronx in his investigation of the charges involving Edward J. Flynn, chairman of the Democratic National Committee and leader of the Democratic organization in the Bronx.

A succession of broken windows, apparently smashed by missiles fired or thrown from an automobile that moved downtown on Fifth Avenue and later crossed to the West Side, engaged the police of mid-Manhattan precincts last night but led to no official explanation.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Operation of tomorrow's draft lottery will be similar to that previously followed. Each registrant will receive a number from his local draft board, and those holding the first numbers drawn from the goldfish bowl will be the first called for service.

With a national gross of $5,000,000 to its credit to date, the Warner Brothers are expecting "Sergeant York" to attain a final gross of "at least $10,000,000." The gross so far represents only the returns from pre-release engagements of the film, which went out last July.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Required expansions of health and social services for children and maintenance of safeguards against their exploitation in industry and in agricultural employment on other than home farms were discussed at all-day sessions today of a conference called by the Children's Bureau to consider the special needs of children during the period of emergency created by the war.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 16 (AP) -- The British Middle East General Headquarters communiqu said today:

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- President Roosevelt requested George P. McNear Jr. of Peoria, Ill., president of the Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad Company, in a letter made public by the White House today to comply immediately with the order of the National War Labor Board for arbitration of the labor dispute which has the 239-mile road strike-bound.
BERLIN, March 16 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communiqu said today:
ST. PETERSEURG, Fla., March 16 -- Charley Ruffing finally checked in at the Yankee training base today, and Manager Joe McCarthy immediately ordered the big redhead into uniform.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 16 -- Master Key, a New England campaigner flying the silks of B.A. Dario, scored his initial success of the Winter in the Miami Springs purse at Tropical Park today. Under an energetic ride by Billy Thompson, one of the boys in the four-horse spill last Friday, Master Key easily defeated nine rivals over the mile and a sixteenth distance and paid $24.$0 for $2.

LONDON, March 16 -- The stock markets opened quietly today but the undertone was firm. Prices of gilt-edge issues were maintained and the home rails were unchanged. In the industrial section the breweries were good with Guiness at 86s.

Donald Nelson is quite right in warning labor and management that the American people will rise up in their wrath if every available factory, machine, man and hour of time, is not used to the limit in our effort to beat the Axis. While our freedom hangs in the balance is no time to haggle over hours and wages, profit and loss.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Office of Civilian Defense found itself enmeshed in new Congressional controversy today, with both House and Senate deadlocked over the question of whether air raid wardens, fire watchers, members of rescue squads and other volunteers should receive Federal compensation in the event of injury in line of duty.
The Maine veterans still insist that the fishing season there will open, at least in the southern part of the State, on the first day of legal fishing, April 1.

Music-making for the sheer joy of it was the order of the evening at the Town Hall last night. Adolf Busch, violinist and excellent musician, gathered with friends and members of his family to play through some Bach. Though the ensemble was billed formally as Adolf Busch and Chamber Music Players and though the men and women of the group wore formal clothes, the spirit of the performances was genial and informal.

Immediate construction of enough aid raid shelters to protect the city's population was proposed yesterday in the City Council, whose members also considered a request that Mayor La Guardia cancel his six-day-week order for city employes and that he make public the text of the Sarnoff report on the effectiveness of air raid sirens.

Two companies announced yesterday that they had undertaken definite programs which aimed at enlisting both management and labor in the forthcoming war production drive sought by Donald M. Nelson, Director of the War Production Board.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 16 -- While the French Supreme Court at Riom was preparing to begin a new phase of testimony tomorrow, signs were not wanting today that the German Government was about to seize upon the procedure of the court to date as a pretext for revision of Franco-German relations.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The care and repair of everything from nylon stockings to automobiles are being urged constantly by the consumer division of the Office of Price Administration. To induce civilians to take the proper precautions, this office from time to time issues specific instructions to housewives telling them the approved methods of conserving irreplaceable consumer goods.

The Indianapolis Gas Company announced yesterday a plan to terminate nearly six years of litigation with the city it serves. A group of fiduciary institutions, which included the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company, New England Mutual Life Insurance Company, the University of Rochester, N.Y., and the Savings Bank of Baltimore, endorsed the plan.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 16 -- Resolutions urging the State Legislature to amend the Westchester County charter so that the annual county budget hearings would deal with fiscal recommendations of the supervisors as well as of the county executive were adopted today by the board of supervisors.

The supreme strategy of victory must be for the United Nations to remain united, President Roosevelt warned last night in a letter read at the 140th dinner of the Economic Club of New York, held at the Hotel Astor. Two thousand members of the club and their guests, including diplomatic representatives of many of the United Nations and leaders in business, finance and the professions, were present.

Official carelessness was criticized by foreign traders yesterday as being responsible for much unnecessary worry and inconvenience in settling the matter of the foreign trade zone's continuance when it was learned that approximately three weeks were permitted to elapse between the official order to continue partial zone operations and its publication.

BERLIN, March 16 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The High Command acknowledged today that the Red Army, pressing the offensive from the Leningrad area to the Crimea, had breached the Nazi defenses at one point on the central front during a blinding snowstorm, but said a German counter-attack closed the gap.

DANVILLE, Ill., March 16 -- At least twenty persons were killed and about 170 others were injured in a series of tornadoes which roared across Champaign, Marshall and Vermillion Counties beginning at noon today.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- An annual saving of 550,000 tons of sugar, now diverted to the production of industrial alcohol for smokeless powder, will be possible once the War Production Board's plan for substituting grain for molasses in the production of 190-proof alcohol is adopted, William L. Batt, Director of the Materials Division of WPB, said today.

The shortage of several million tons of scrap iron, a hindrance to the production of steel for the war, may be eased as the result of a national "Gates to Freedom" campaign started in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn yesterday whereby iron gates throughout the country will be salvaged for scrap.

SO the K. of C. Games at Madison Square Garden, featured by a breath-taking, soul-stirring struggle between Leslie MacMitchell and Gil Dodds at the mile, didn't wind up the major indoor track season after all. There's a big meet up ahead. One week from tomorrow night. At the Coliseum in the Bronx. Come one; come all! It's to be a benefit for the Navy Relief Society and it should be a hummer.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- In an unanimous opinion the Supreme Court today sustained the constitutionality of the Natural Gas Act of 1938 and approved wide authority for the Federal Power Commission to regulate natural gas rates.

CHICAGO, March 16 -- Small business by an overwhelming vote wants a forty-eight-hour week without overtime pay and a national sales tax, and is opposed to the closed shop and union dues checkoff system, an opinion poll taken by the National Small Business Men's Association revealed today.

ALBANY, March 16 -- The Assembly tonight passed and sent to the Governor the Muzzicato "save the five-cent fare" bill. The vote was 147 to 2, after several members had protested against the bill's being called up out of its regular order.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 16 -- Charles Chaplin will prepare a musical score and a commentary for his 1927 silent film "The Circus" and will reissue it next Summer through United Artists if the returns on his current similar venture with his 1925 picture, "The Gold Rush," are sufficient to justify the new expenditure, the Chaplin studio announced today.

Under an order of the Navy Department, distribution of the 1942 Record published by the American Bureau of Shipping will be restricted to persons "of known reliability," as defined by the Navy, because the volume contains vital war information, J. Lewis Luckenbach, president of the bureau, announced yesterday.

Today is the day. St. Patrick's Day, to be sure. In honor of the kindly saint of Eire the Irish and their admirers will wear the green, big to the lilt of the ould sod's cunes, let loose golden floods of Celtic oratory and, above all, march up Fifth Avenue in all the pomp and panoply of their traditional parade.

Consumers of electricity and gas throughout Greater New York will be faced with the prospect of higher rates if new tax proposals on corporations recently proposed by Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau are enacted in law, Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the board of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, declared yesterday.
MOSCOW, March 16 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau broadcast this communiqu today:
PENDLETON, Ore., March 16 (AP) -- Two Army bombers crashed today in Pacific Northwest mountains, killing fourteen men.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, March 16 -- The collective mind of the inhabitants of this island and of the British Imperial forces committed to their protection is concentrated on the assumption that, during the weeks immediately ahead, Reichsfuehrer Hitler will make a new and perhaps final effort to overcome the handicap imposed by a dwindling oil reserve and send his forces crashing through to the Middle East.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's letter to George P. McNear Jr., president of the Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad Company:

George Herrick, 46 years old, of 230 Central Park West, who has been linked to fashionable and expensive gambling for years, pleaded not guilty yesterday to a new charge -- evasion of income tax. He was arraigned by J. Gerard Cregan, assistant United States attorney, and released in bail of $1,000 by Judge Grover M. Moscowitz for trial March 30.
ROME, March 16 (From Italian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command issued this communiqu today:

MANDALAY, March 16 (AP) -- Fliers of the American Volunteer Group, whose air defense of Rangoon was one of the few bright spots for the United Nations in the Southwest Pacific, are on hand for the defense of Central and Upper Burma and are being outfitted with new pursuit planes.

The planned allocation of pulp by the War Production Board may end for the duration the oft-repeated stories of a shortage in pulp, informed trade executives said here yesterday. While unforseen developments may eventually create such a scarcity, it was conceded, at the present time there is no immediate likelihood of such a shortage.

The 1942 International Beauty Show opened yesterday at the Pennsylvania Hotel with interest centered on a "Bombshell" hair-do in which all metal clips, curlers and bobby pins have been eliminated with the idea that they will find better use in a bomber.

BERNE, Switzerland, Tuesday, March 17 -- After a three-day feint in the direction of Dniepropetrovsk, during which his forces smashed the defenses of the German 218th and 294th Infantry Divisions, Marshal Semyon Timoshenko at dawn yesterday launched what appeared to be his main drive a considerable distance north of the central Donets front along a line running from Orel in the north to Kursk and Kharkov in the south.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- America's third draft lottery, in seventeen months -- and the first in the present war -- will take place tomorrow night as Uncle Sam starts classifying an estimated 9,000,000 men for possible military service.

Tokyo dispatches relayed through Berlin admit stronger Allied resistance over New Guinea than anywhere else in the Pacific. It is convenient for the moment for the Japanese to forget the Philippines where MacArthur's army still stands undaunted. But Allied air pressure on enemy bases in New Guinea and New Britain has increased noticeably in the past fortnight.
BROWDER, Ky., March 16 -- Fourteen persons were reported killed and at least eleven injured when a tornado struck this Western Kentucky coal mining community at 5:30 P.M. today.

CANBERRA, Australia, March 16 -- Darwin, the United Nations' base in Northern Australia, had its third raid this afternoon. Fourteen Japanese heavy bombers operated over the town in two formations and the bombs that they dropped included fragmentation bombs intended to inflict casualties on personnel.
The first war class of new policemen was warned at City Hall yesterday by Mayor La Guardia to be vigilant against enemies from within as well as those who might attack the city from outside.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The War Department announced tonight that American troops were in Australia. This was the first official confirmation of a fact that had been widely published in newspaper dispatches from the Far East.

LONDON, March 16 -- A lone German reconnaissance plane today caused the first daylight sounding of sirens in the London area since last June 6. The last time the warning sounded in the capital was the night of Nov. 1. Today's warning was the 573d in the London area.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 16 -- The National League champions tangled with an American League team today for the second time in the citrus circuit campaign and for the second time couldn't get themselves untangled.
Residential properties figured in most of the realty transactions reported in Manhattan yesterday. In several cases the buyers were operators.
It seems that the demand for women to enroll for the training as nurse's aide has not abated. A great many more are needed than have registered for training.

MIAMI, Fla., March 16 (AP) -- Directors of the Miami Jockey Club were told today that profits from the forty-six-day race meeting at Hialeah Park were approximately half those of the 1941 season. Complete figures have not been compiled.

MONTREAL, March 16 (Canadian Press) -- Increase in net income to $34,361,432 for 1941 operations was reported today by Canadian Pacific Railway as compared with $20,145,056 in 1940. Earnings were equivalent to $2.18 in 1941 and $1.13 in 1940 on the ordinary capital stock. Net income in 1941 was the highest since 1930.

A plot fronting 150 feet on Queen Anne Road, at the northeast corner of DeGraw Avenue, Teaneck, Bergen County, N.J., has been sold by William P. DeGraw to Teaneck Markets, Inc., for improvement with a business structure, which has been leased on a long term to the A. concern for a supermarket.

The Navy gambled another $2,610,000 yesterday on the proposition that it could raise the capsized 83,000-ton hulk that used to be the superliner Normandie. The money was deposited to pay the City of New York for Pier 88, which is needed for the "maintenance, repair, renewal and alteration" of the former French Line flagship, now the U.S.S. Lafayette.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., March 16 -- Plans for providing a sharply increased supply of war materials to New Zealand and the making over of New Zealand as a United Nations war base were revealed by Supply Minister D.G. Sullivan, member of New Zealand's recent war mission to Australia, in a nationwide broadcast last night.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 16 -- Ten men were accused in City Court here today of disorderly conduct because of their alleged refusal to comply last night with civilian defense rules during Westchester County's practice blackout.

Radio broadcasters in general are not "sufficiently realistic" about the effect of war on broadcasting, and "vastly more" will be expected of them as the war continues, Frank E. Mullen, vice president and general manager of the National Broadcasting Company, told a meeting of NBC officials and regional executives yesterday at a meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
VICHY, France, March 16 -- Adolf Hitler's strictures on the Riom trial were received in authorized circles here today as indicating a misunderstanding as to the nature of the trial.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 16 -- The Giant and Red Sox pitchers, seven all told, were far ahead of the hitters today. So much so, that the vaunted clouters of the two clubs had to battle twelve inning before Joe Cronin's clan, which tied the score in the ninth, could sink the Polo Grounders, 2 to l.

NEW DELHI, India, March 16 -- The princes of India were asked today by the Marquess of Linlithgow, Viceroy, to sacrifice their privileges "should they in any way impede the war effort." His address was made at the annual session of the Chambers of the Rulers of Native States and it paved the way for arrival in India of Sir Stafford Cripps, British Lord Privy Seal.

Spring splashed its vivid colors and the soft fragrance of 2,000,000 blooms over four floors of Grand Central Palace yesterday for the benefit of 25,000 beauty-hungry New Yorkers as the twenty-ninth annual Flower Show got under way for a six-day run.

PEORIA, Ill., March 16 -- George P. McNear Jr., president of the Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad Company, said today upon receipt of President Roosevelt's letter ordering arbitration of the dispute that he "respectfully questioned" the right of the government to order arbitration.
Plans were filed yesterday for a six-story apartment house estimated to cost about $400,000 on the vacant plot at 404-20 East Fifty-third Street, once occupied by the American Ice Company plant.

GREAT LAKES, Ill., March 16 (U.P.) -- The story of how the gun crew of a United States freighter fought back at a submarine that torpedoed their ship in the Caribbean three weeks ago was revealed tonight by Lieut. Comdr. R.A. Brown, U.S.N.R., public relations officer of the Ninth Naval District.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., March 16 -- The city of Niagara Falls will be fifty years old tomorrow, as it was on March 17, 1892, Governor Flower signed the act of Legislature that merged the former villages of Niagara Falls and Suspension Bridge.

Yesterday afternoon, New York's fashion world got something new to think about. It was Adrian's first collection made for Mrs. General Public and was presented at Bonwit Teller's. This is the first collection by the designer since he left Hollywood.

Leslie MacMitchell, Gil Dodds, Greg Rice, John Borican and Al Diebolt head the list of entries announced yesterday for the Navy Relief Society track meet at the Bronx Coliseum on Wednesday, March 25, under the sponsorship of the Track Writers Association.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The minority of the Senate Privileges and Elections Committee today began presentation of its opposition to the majority proposal to expel Senator Langer on grounds of moral turpitude. Senator Murdock, one of the three minority members, held the floor throughout the day.

In this country's history there is at least one flagrant case in which valuable information must have been conveyed to the enemy by the disclosure of bad news. The guilty man was an American in high official position who wrote a letter.

A division in the ranks of the butlers employed by leading New York families was disclosed yesterday by the announcement that a second butlers' ball would be held March 25 at the Hotel Commodore for the benefit of the British- American Ambulance Corps, Inc.

TRENTON, N.J., March 16 -- Hudson County's record-breaking 1942 budget of $18,486,046 was approved today when two of the five members of the State's Local Government Board voted not to overrule certification of the budget by Walter R. Darby, local government commissioner and board chairman.

PORT MORESBY, New Guinea, March 16 -- Australians in the Huon Gulf country in the unexplored regions of Northeastern New Guinea are waging guerrilla warfare against the Japanese along the Markaham River, it was revealed today.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 16 -- Extending the enemy alien control program 1,000 miles inland from the Pacific Coast, Lieut. Gen. John L. De Witt, Western defense commander, tonight designated as military areas four more States, Idaho, Montana, Nevada and Utah, and set apart 934 more "prohibited zones."

The largest collection of income tax payments in the history of the United States was recorded yesterday. All records were broken here and in other sections of the country, not only in the amount the government received but in the number of returns made in person and by mail.

W.S.S. Rodgers, president of the Texas Corporation, will report today to stockholders for 1941 a consolidated net profit of $51,874,681 after all charges, including provision for Federal income and excess profits taxes. In the year income was charged $7,000,000 for reserves for possible losses on foreign investments.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended March 11: Increases of $57,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans, $61,000,000 in United States Government obligations, $68,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and $314,000, 000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and a decrease of $82,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- A Navy Department communiqu, based upon reports received up to 3 P.M. today, follows:

Funds for the initial principal and the second interest payment due on $22,000,000 of Consumers Public Power District, Eastern Nebraska Division, although not due until April 1, were deposited yesterday with the paying agents here, Chicago and Lincoln, Charles B. Fricke, president, announced.

Preparations for Passover were begun yesterday when fifty rabbis donned white coats and supervised the baking of their own "matzoh shmoorah" in the bakery of the Horowitz-Margareten Matzoh Company, 369 East Fourth Street, in keeping with the 2,000-year-old custom.

The charges made by Robert R. Guthrie, that there exists within the War Production Board "strong opposition to a really all-out effort to speed conversion to maximum war production," call for a thorough investigation, although some of the force has been taken out of these charges by Donald M. Nelson's statement of the circumstances surrounding the resignation of Mr. Guthrie and two of his aides from the textile, clothing and leather goods division of WPB.

"Let women keep all thought of war out of their clothes. Let them make themselves beautiful for their men returning from war or training to make war. Let them be high-spirited too, to lift the spirits of their men. That's one of the jobs women must do today.

The Board of Higher Education voted last night to abolish Townsend Harris High School, which has been operated since 1907 as a three-year preparatory school for exceptional students planning to attend City College.

Literary communiques on General Douglas MacArthur: As of this date three books concerned with General MacArthur, his life, writings and the Philippine campaign are in sight. The first to come out will be a biography that will carry the subtitle "Fighter for Freedom." Winston, Philadelphia publishing firm, announces this title for March 25.

PONTIAC, Mich., March 16 -- This "guinea pig" city, which volunteered itself for an experiment in transportation conservation, tonight completed its first day of rescheduled living and directors of the experiment said the patient had done nicely.

ALBANY, March 16 -- Revision of the State's Unemployment Insurance Law to extend the duration of benefits from thirteen to twenty weeks, to include coverage of the partly employed who now do not receive benefits, to reduce the present waiting period from three to two weeks and to increase the maximum benefit rate by 20 per cent, or from $15 to $18, was recommended tonight by Governor Lehman in a special message to the Legislature.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, March 15 (Delayed) (AP) -- British light naval forces sailed up to the Italian Island of Rhodes early today and poured shells into dock and manufacturing facilities. The rain of shells struck just as the Royal Air Force closed in with a coordinated bombing of airdromes of the island, which is in the Dodecanese group off the Turkish coast.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 16 (AP) -- Joe Kaminski of Youngstown took first place in the singles of the American Bowling Congress tournament today with 692 and moved into a tie for first in the all-events with 1,889. Russell Shuster, a fellow townsman, hit 673 for fifth in the singles.

MEXICO CITY, March 16 -- It was said today in official circles here that the aim of the government is to remove all Japanese from coastal and frontier regions by the end of March. This refers to the barred zone, sixty-two miles from the coasts and borders.

Dr. Gilbert H. Fletcher, who was born in Paris thirty-one years ago and was graduated from the University of Brussels last November, said yesterday when he arrived on a Portuguese ship, that the Germans in Belgium and occupied France are counterfeiting United States dollar bills and circulating them among the populace.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Senate Finance Committee unanimously reported today a bill to raise the Federal debt limit from $65,000,000,000 to $130,000,000,000, but with an amendment that all obligations of Federal corporations be included in this figure.

In response to President Roosevelt's appeal for a forty-mile speed limit to conserve tires, the police of New York City yesterday began keeping a close watch on traffic on the city's parkways and express highways.

The exhibition called "Children of France," organized to aid the American Friends Service Commitee (Quaker) in its distribution of milk to French children in this time of tragic suffering abroad, is invitingly installed in second floor galleries at Wildenstein's, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The changing administration position with respect to stabilizing wages together with other costs has been accompanied by -- as if it were a new proposal -- the statement that war profits must be restricted in the same process. It is argued -- as if any of the advocates of overall price-controls had disputed it -- that the former would be unjust and ineffectual without the latter.

Two men, one of them a private in the Army, were held in $25,000 bail when arraigned in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday charged with wartime espionage, an offense for which conviction could result in their execution.

PHILADELPHIA, March 16 -- Simulated leather made from synthetic resin and "tougher than the genuine product" is an ingenious substitute material which may be proffered by shoe manufacturers in response to the recent order restricting top-grade leathers to military use, according to Charles L. Simon of the Industrial By-Products and Research Corporation of Philadelphia.

Having completed her stint in the film "Three's a Crowd," Glenda Farrell is remaining in Hollywood for a day or so in case retakes are necessary before returning to New York to act in "The Life of Reilly." Miss Farrell has informed her husband, Dr. Henry Ross, that she will be here late this week or early next.

HAVANA, March 16 -- Although official figures in yesterday's partial Congressional election will not be announced for several days, tabulations up until tonight indicated the government parties had obtained an overwhelming majority.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Three investigations, all based on charges that there was still "strong opposition" within the War Production Board to total coversion of American industry to war production, were started today as a result of the resignation of Robert R. Guthrie, head of the WPB Textile Clothing and Leather Division, and two of his assistants.
CANBERRA, Australia, March 16 (AP) -- A Royal Australian Air Force communiqu said today:

PHILADELPHIA, March 16 -- Caroline Lee Gilbert of 600 Riverside Drive, New York City, 20-year-old Hunter College student, disappeared today from a Philadelphia hotel where she had registered last Thursday night, a few hours after leaving her home city.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 17 -- From Berlin comes news today that Germany wishes to develop cultural relations with France, in token of which much is being made of the first issue of a new periodical entitled France-Germany, in which Otto Abetz, representative of the Reich in occupied France, blossoms forth as an author, and which pictures France and Germany as daughters of the same spiritual mother, Greece, which influenced Latin culture.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 17 -- An increasing concern over the effect on vegetable production as a result of the evacuation of thousands of Japanese farmers from Pacific coastal areas was translated into preventive action today by Lieut. Gen. John L. DeWitt, Western defense commander.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Plane production has been stepped up 50 per cent since Pearl Harbor, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, said tonight in a radio address. He warned, however, that there was no reason for complacency, because the country was nowhere near its goals.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 17 (AP) -- After dodging two submarine attacks, Captain Henry Steel, British Army public relations officer, has arrived in Australia from Java on a boat on which he and the British consul served as stokers because the ship was short of crew.

Ten men and a corporation pleaded guilty in Federal Court yesterday to charges of mail fraud in a case involving the alleged sale of $300,000 in stock to the investing public. Seven other persons and three corporation are to go on trial before Judge Simon H. Rifkind on the same charges today.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- In an effort to expedite conversion of the typewriter manufacturing industry to war work, the War Production Board today ordered a heavy cut in production and simultaneously assumed control of the distribution of all new machines.

John J. Bennett Jr., State Attorney General, advised the Citizens Union yesterday that he had no power under the law to grant its request that he supersede District Attorney Samuel J. Foley of the Bronx in the investigation of charges involving Edward J. Flynn, chairman of the Democratic National Committee.

L.A. Chambliss, president of the New Jersey Bankers Association, announced yesterday that forty-nine New Jersey banks had established payroll deduction plans to enable employes to purchase defense savings bonds. He said the association was campaigning to have every bank in the State adopt the plan.

LONDON, March 17 -- The life of Great Britain's children next Winter will depend largely on the efforts of dairy farmers in the coming months, the Duke of Norfolk, Joint Parliamentary Secretary in the Ministry of Agriculture, told a Yorkshire audience yesterday.
