Each of the four principal operating departments of the General Electric Company had a record amount of new business in 1941 and substantially increased volume of output over that for the preceding year, according to the annual pamphlet report to be mailed today to stockholders.

Representatives of the leaf tobacco industries of the dark fired tobacco regions of Kentucky, Tennessee and North Carolina pleaded yesterday against the introduction of a proposed minimum wage of 40 cents an hour on the ground that it would compel dismissal of many employes because of the slump in business due to the cessation of exports because of the war.

The announcement that General Douglas MacArthur is to take command of all the United Nations' forces in the Western Pacific will be applauded by an overwhelming majority of Americans, and will certainly bring enormous heart to the endangered people of Australia.

Yara Bernette, 22-year-old pianist from Sao Paulo, Brazil, gave her first New York recital last night at Town Hall. She proved to be a fiery and persuasive interpreter of music by her fellow-countrymen, as well as an able player of European classics.

A conspiracy to sell higher ratings in the Merchant Marine to ships' officers taking examinations before the Marine Inspection Service was charged yesterday to two examiners for the service and a salesman for a marine engineering school.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 17 -- German attempts to "make something" out of the British bombing of the Paris area on March 3 have led to the arrest and imprisonment of at least twenty-five persons in the Boulogne-Billancourt region, according to a Frenchman just arrived from Paris.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- President Roosevelt told his press conference that he favors continuing the requirement that time and a half be paid for work over forty hours a week; he conferred with Sumner Welles, with Donald Nelson, with the American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations Labor War Board; lunched with Robert McLean, president of The Associated Press.
Several store and office leases along Broadway were included in the list of commercial rentals reported by Manhattan brokers yesterday.

Four major functions which American advertising must perform to help the country's war effort were listed yesterday by the Advertising Federation of America in announcing a thirty-nine-point code drawn up for the guidance of all advertising interests.

RIOM, France, March 17 -- France's unpreparedness trial, criticized by Reichsfuehrer Hitler and the subject of warnings from the Paris press suggesting suspension, proceeded imperturbably today with the first witnesses while Fernand de Brinon, Government Delegate General in Paris, was conferring with authorities in Vichy.

Power sales by the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation system set a new high record of 9,600,000,000 kilowatt-hours in 1941, A.H. Schoellkopf, president, announced yesterday in his annual report to stockholders. Industrial customers throughout the system's territory used 6,500,000,000 kilowatt-hours, an increase of 30 per cent over 1940.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (U.P.) -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, issued a series of administrative orders today delegating many of his sweeping powers to the directors and heads of subdivisions.
LONDON, March 17 -- Lord James Stewart-Murray, a 62-year-old bachelor, is a duke in succession to his late brother, the eighth Duke of Atholl, whether he likes it or not -- and he doesn't.

Whether or not St. Patrick ever drove the snakes out of Ireland, challenged High-King Loigaire by lighting the Paschal fire on the Hill of Slane on the night of Easter Eve, or was carried off at the age of 16 by a band of marauders (and Irish marauders at that) -- one thing is certain.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 17 -- Deanna Durbin's next picture will be "Three Smart Girls Join Up," a photoplay about women in war industry, which will go before the cameras next month, Universal announced today. The studio has engaged Paul Jerrico and Richard Collins to write the scenario from a story of Derek Bolton, R.A.F. pilot.

The packaged dog food field will provide a testing ground for both dehydration and new containers, as it is among the first to bring out new products and containers as a result of the tin shortage, it was pointed out yesterday. Red Heart dog food in dehydrated form will be out shortly in a cardboard carton sealed at both ends with bonderized plate while Ken-L-Ration will appear in glass.

TAMPA, Fla., March 17 -- The Giants, it is now feared, are leaving their fight on the road. Certain it is they had little fight left late today after the Reds had battered them with about everything that came ready to hand in winning an exhibition joust, 16 to 2.
NEWARK, N.J., March 17 (AP) -- The Public Service Corporation lost before the Essex County Tax Board yesterday a move for dismissal of $98,835,242 in omitted tax assessments for 1940 and 1941.
WASHINGTON: March 17 -- Here is the text of the statement issued today by the Office of Facts and Figures:

It shows how big a country we are when it is disclosed that more than 80,000,000 Americans have not seen the film version of "Gone With the Wind." As a result the picture up to date has had to be content with a mere 52,000,000 paid admissions.

LONDON, March 17--Chinese troops fighting in Burma appear to have established closer contact with the Japanese than have the British Imperials serving under Lieut. Gen. Harold R. L. G. Alexander, who are bracing themselves against an expected attack, according to reports today from Burma, China and India.
The Commonwealth and Southern Corporation system will spend $37,800,000 for new construction and expansion during the current year, Justin R. Whiting, president, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- President Roosevelt went back today to a speech made in 168 B.C. by Lucius Aemilius, Roman Consul charged with conducting the war with the Macedonians, to find an answer to what the President called the dear happy-thought people (commentators and editors) and other amateur strategists who tell him who should lead our armies and when and where offensives should be undertaken.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Wednesday, March 18 -- General Douglas MacArthur's arrival to assume the United Nations command in the Southwestern Pacific was hailed jubilantly by the Australian press today as the most important and most welcome move thus far in the defense of this Commonwealth.
Colonel Walter W. Metcalf, acting regional director of the Office of Civilian Defense, Second Corps Area, had a cold yesterday and found that vitamins would cure it.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- Harold F. Dixon, 41, an aviation chief machinist's mate, received the Navy cross today for "extraordinary heroism" in saving the crew of a Navy torpedo bomber forced down Jan. 16 in South Pacific during operations against the enemy.

ALBANY, March 17 -- Spokesmen of local city governments in the State clashed today with representatives of real estate boards at a joint hearing of the Legislative Taxation Committees over the establishment of a State-wide and local system of assessment and review.

LONDON, March 17 -- All Norway's ports from North Cape to Aalesund had been closed by the Germans today, presumably to screen stealthy marshaling of German military and naval forces that indicated that those far-northern waters were about to become a newly active major war theatre.

The Swedish Government has neither placated Germany nor smothered the conscience of the Swedish people by suppressing eleven newspapers which dared to print accounts of Nazi atrocities committed on their helpless kinsfolk in Norway. Indeed, the very attempt has defeated frantic German efforts to hide the truth.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The war may aid in the development of Latin-American resources, but it will be a one-sided sort of aid which may retard economic diversification and delay industrialization, the Foreign Policy Association declared today in a survey written by John C. de Wilde.

TORONTO, March 17 (Canadian Press) -- Frank Selke, acting general manager of the Toronto Maple Leafs, announced tonight that the Leafs would meet the New York Rangers here Saturday night in the first game of their four-out-of-seven Stanley Cup semi-final series as the result of a change in plans.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- A total of 3,747,000,000 pounds of agricultural commodities which cost the Agriculture Department $417,000,000 to buy and deliver at shipping points was turned over to representatives of the United Nations for lease-lend shipment prior to Feb. 1.

Over the objections of Monroe Goldwater of Goldwater Flynn, the hearing before Supreme Court Referee Richard P. Lydon into the affairs of Serge Rubinstein and the Chosen Corporation turned yesterday to an examination of the formation and subsequent history of a Delaware corporation called Chosen (1934), Inc.

A mine sweeper and a submarine chaser were launched by the Navy here yesterday, and keels for two more ships of similar type were laid down on the same ways a few minutes later as the Navy accelerated the tempo in its "production belt" of small vessels for anti-submarine and mine work.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- General Douglas MacArthur today became Supreme Commander of the United Nations forces in the Southwestern Pacific.

Miss Mary Beecher Budd gave a luncheon yesterday in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre for members of the junior committee serving with her in the interests of the fashion show and luncheon to be given May 7 in the main ballroom of the hotel for the benefit of the Nearly New Shop.

The Bank of France was accused before the Appellate Division yesterday of attempting to delay until after the war any decision in the suit brought on behalf of the National Bank of Belgium for recovery of $228,000,000 of the gold of the Bank of France held here, in order to prevent the Free Belgian Government in London from using this fund to prosecute the war against Germany.

Income tax collections in the Second District credited to Monday at midnight, the final day, totaled approximately $129,000,000 and brought the amount received to date to $233,000,000, indicating a record-breaking total of $250,000,000 for the first quarter by the time all returns are in, Collector William J. Pedrick announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 17 -- Strength in the flaxseed market in Minneapolis, where prices were up the permissible limit of 6 cents a bushel and at a new seasonal high price, tended to impart a firm undertone to grains and soy beans on the Board of Trade here today. While outside interest was relatively light and prices held within narrow limits, professional operators were not inclined to press the selling side to any extent.

The sinking of at least three, and possibly four, ships by Axis submarines operating off our Atlantic coast was disclosed yesterday. The victims were a medium-sized merchant ship of United States registry, a 5,785-ton Uruguayan vessel, an unidentified vessel from which fifty-seven survivors were landed in Nassau, and possibly a large United States tanker reported sunk in the Bahamas.

With a go-ahead spirit predominating the members of the Handicap Class of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound gathered last night in the New York Yacht Club, 37 West Forty-fourth Street, for their annual dinner-meeting, and made plans for the Summer's racing.

MOSCOW, March 17 -- The Ger mans are throwing in many more planes in their attempt to stem the Russian advances, the Army newspaper, Red Star, reported today. Stiff counter-attacks also were described by Pravda, which told of fighting between opposing tank forces around villages in a river valley that forms the defenses of an unnamed town in the Donets Basin.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- "The best news of the war!" That was the jubilant American reaction today to the announcement that General Douglas MacArthur, the Philippines commander, had arrived in Australia to take over the supreme United Nations command in that area.

The general death rate in New York City last week rose to 11.5 per 1,000 population, the highest for this year so far, it was reported yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner. Increased mortality was due to cancer, diabetes, heart ailments and accidents.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 17 -- Crowds of young Chileans, resentful at the refusal of the government to permit them to hold a meeting to protest last Friday's sinking of the freighter Tolten off New Jersey, tonight smashed windows of the pro-Axis newspaper Chileno, a German bar, the Casa Hombo, a Japanese novelty shop, and the Casa Oberpaur, a German clothing store.

LONDON, March 17 (AP) -- The joint United States-British communique, which acknowledged the loss of thirteen Allied warships in the losing sea battle of Java, was criticized in Parliament today on two opposite counts -- for not giving adequate emphasis to the odds against which the United Nations warships fought, and for listing their losses so fully as to give "valuable and reliable information to the enemy."
SYDNEY, Australia, March 17 (AP) -- The mystery of the missing sloop Yarra was dispelled today.

ALBANY, March 17 -- A new plan for pay increases for the lesser paid State employes was worked out today by the State Association of Civil Service Employes and was immediately incorporated in the Republican fiscal program. The Assembly Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee reported out the measures, amended to meet the wishes of the civil service groups.

Several dinner parties were given before the preview of the Henri Rousseau exhibition of paintings last night at the Museum of Modern Art. Mr. and Mrs. Samuel A. Lewisohn gave a dinner at their home, 115 East Seventy-third Street, for Daniel Catton Rich, Director of Fine Arts at the Art Exhibition of Chicago, who directed the Rousseau exhibition.

In what is believed the first voluntary action of its kind in the women's apparel trades, a leading manufacturing furrier announced here yesterday that he has put into effect a limitation on profits on the basis of a "maximum of 6 per cent on working capital for the duration of the war."

LONDON, March 17 -- Strongly advocating the creation of an Empire War Cabinet, Viscount Bennett, former Conservative Prime Minister of Canada, in a speech at Sheffield yesterday said the participation of the dominions was needed in the shaping of imperial policy.

JACKSON, Miss., March 17 (U.P.) -- Over debris-choked roads and wrecked communication lines reports trickled in tonight of one of Mississippi's most destructive storms, in which the death toll was reaching toward the 100 mark and damage into the millions.

A group headed by the Equitable Securities Corporation received yesterday the award of a new issue of $635,000 of sewer and water bonds of the city of Wilmington, N.C., on an interest cost basis to the city of 2.67 per cent. The successful bid was 100,024 for $166,000 as 3s, $311,000 as 2 3/4s and $158,000 as 2 1/2s.

There were faint tears in the eyes of Mrs. Glenn Dickinson as she peeled her second onion. Mrs. Louis R. Breslin Jr. was in desperate struggle with a recalcitrant can opener. Mrs. Ernest B. Burton and Mrs. William L. Burton II were doing the best they knew how with raw turnips.

Twenty chess experts from the metropolitan area, divided into three sections, are ready to start in the preliminaries of the biennial tournament for the national championship Friday night and Saturday afternoon. The entry list will be left open until tomorrow afternoon.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 17 -- Supreme Court Justice Mortimer B. Patterson dismissed today a suit brought by Truman S. Mersereau, Purchase estate owner and president of the Westchester Citizens Committee, for an injunction restraining Westchester County from developing an airport on a 503-acre tract adjacent to Rye Lake in Purchase.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- General Douglas MacArthur, who recently became 62 years old, but who looks and acts much younger, has been twice a full general in the American Army, holds the title of Field Marshal of the Filipino forces and has won probably more decorations than any other living American soldier.

Italian-held Rhodes is the most advanced Axis spearhead for penetration of the Near East. If Hitler plans to overrun Cyprus and invade Syria in a dash for the oil fields of Iraq and Iran, this island stronghold would be the logical jumping-off place for such a campaign. The British attack on Rhodes was to forestall and disrupt the attempt.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Charges that industrial production in New Jersey is only 49 per cent of its potential maximum, as recently asserted by the head of the C.I.O.'s New Jersey State Industrial Council, are essentially correct and typical of the situation in the whole country, Donald M. Nelson, head of the War Production Board, said in a letter made public today by Senator Barbour, who asked for information.
Joseph, J. Lordi, New York Athletic Club squash tennis ace, stands within one match of continuing his reign as overlord in the national field.

The stock market staged yesterday its best recovery since late in January, with prices up 1 to 4 points on the Stock Exchange. Labeled for weeks as an oversold market and thus ripe to respond to news of a favorable character, traders seized upon the appointment of General MacArthur to command the United Nations forces in the Western Pacific and his arrival in Australia as a prelude to the long-demanded offensive action by the Allies.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- Rear Admiral Adolphus Andrews had been assigned to "exclusive duty" as commander of the Eastern Sea Frontier. He will be replaced as commandant of the Third Naval District at New York by Rear Admiral Edward J. Marquart.

LONDON, March 17 (AP) -- The loss of the 1,090-ton British Destroyer Vortigern and the destruction of at least five German motor torpedo boats in a week-end series of battles in the North Sea was announced tonight by tile Admiralty.

Fifteen hundred Friendly Sons of St. Patrick drank a toast in the Hotel Astor last night to President Roosevelt as Commander in Chief, and pledged their full aid in the emergency. They were led in the pledge and tribute by Joseph F. Higgins, their president, who presided at the organization's 158th anniversary dinner.

To win the war the United Nations must cooperate to the fullest extent, Mrs. R.G. Casey, wife of the Australian Minister to Washington, said yesterday afternoon at the opening of an exhibition of paintings and sculpture at the American British Art Center, 44 West Fifty-sixth Street.

JUST as this observer was digesting a file of papers concerning athletes, armies and Greek roots, the whole submitted by the eminent John T. (Terry) McGovern, barrister, scholar and athletic official, there arrived a chap who handles foreign news. He handed over a clipping, the contents of which are herewith exposed to view:

Out on the Harlem River since Monday, Columbia's heavyweight eight-oared flotilla has exactly a month's work ahead before its first race of the year, with Rutgers in New York. Four sprint regattas are carded for the Lions, according to the schedule released yesterday.

New York City will make its first substantial contribution to war production in the form of a huge aluminum plant, employing 10,000 to 20,000 persons, to be built soon within the city limits, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday.

Investment bankers ran into direct competition yesterday with a life insurance company for an issue of $3,850,000 of Louisville Transmission Corporation twenty-five-year first mortgage bonds and were outbid by 8 1/4 points. This spread reflects an unusually wide divergence of opinion in the appraisal of the value of a new issue of securities, although the disparity was not among investment bankers but between underwriters and an institutional investor.

Radio's contribution to national morale and suggestions for improved broadcasting in wartime were emphasized yesterday at the final session of a two-day meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel of National Broadcasting Company officials and regional executives.

The lag between retail and wholesale price advances is greater today than it was prior to Pearl Harbor, Fred Lazarus Jr., chairman of the Retailers Advisory Committee, representing all branches of retailing, said in an interview yesterday. Mr. Lazarus, who was in the market here conferring with retail executives, cited the latest Bureau of Labor statistics in support of his statement.

History has recorded the drive of the Paris taxicabs when the German advance threatened that city during the first World War, and now a New Jersey conservation official has suggested a somewhat similar drive on German submarines off our coast, with fishing boats substituted for taxicabs.
Walter Nash, the Minister from New Zealand, and Mrs. Nash have arrived from Washington, and are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

UNITED STATES ARMY HEADQUARTERS, in Australia, Wednesday, March 18--General Douglas MacArthur flew over some of the hottest fighting areas in the Southwestern Pacific on his journey of more than 2,000 miles from the Philippines to as-...

Of the estimated $2,700,000,000 of quarterly income-tax collections for the nation, the Second Federal Reserve District may account for about $750,000,000, when all of the checks are put through by the Treasury. It was estimated yesterday that the collections here thus far had reached $450,000,000.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- A plea for night broadcasting time was filed with the Federal Communications Commission today by WNYC, the New York municipal radio station.

DURHAM, N.C., March 17 (U.P.) -- Wallace Wade, athletic director and head football coach at Duke University since 1931, today was notified of his appointment as a major in the field artillery of the United States Army.

The Golden Gloves Tournament of Champions went into its second round at the Bronx Coliseum last night. Amateur boxers from this city, together with the survivors of competition sponsored by various newspapers throughout the East from Buffalo to Miami, vied with each other in a lengthy program that was witnessed by a crowd of 5,613.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 17 -- A statement that "the aircraft industry is going great guns, running well ahead of so-called impossible schedules," was made by Eugene B. Wilson, president of the United Aircraft Corporation, in a radio address tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The inquiries into the resignation of Robert R. Guthrie as chief of the Textiles, Clothing and Leather Division of the War Production Board should lead Congress easily into a study of differences of opinion over priority and personnel policies in WPB itself.

A double bombshell exploded at the start of the fifth annual national invitation basketball tournament before 16,585 unbelieving fans in Madison Square Garden last night when the two top-seeded teams, Long Island University and West Texas State, were rocked right out of the party.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 17--The Office of Civilian Defense in Washington notified county executive Herbert C. Gerlach of Westchester today that Cortlandt, Hastings, Irvington, Larchmont, Mount Vernon, Ossining, Port Chester, Tarrytown and Yonkers were receiving priority ratings as communities scheduled to get shares of the $100,000,000 civilian defense equipment ordered by the government.

Samuel Greenberg, the operator, has purchased from the Queensboro Corporation through Max Dattner three of the fourteen apartment buildings comprising the Cambridge Court group in Jackson Heights, Queens, which was constructed in 1924 by Stone Webster, Inc., and sold on the tenant- ownership plan.
In the residential leasing reported yesterday, many suites on the East Side were taken. The list follows:

The cream of the 1942 film productions will be made available in 16mm prints by the motion-picture industry without cost for the entertainment of United States Army personnel on duty abroad and for those assigned to base commands not equipped with the regulation 35mm projectors, it was announced yesterday by the War Department.

CANBERRA, Australia, Wednesday, March 18 (AP) -- Prime Minister John Curtin told his people today that "it is most gratifying that I am able to announce that there are most substantial American forces in Australia."

Surrogate James A. Foley yesterday approved an application of the executors of the estate of Samuel Untermyer to form a charitable corporation to receive and hold for a year his Greystone estate at Yonkers, N.Y., which he bequeathed to the State of New York as a public park and which was declined.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The War Department said tonight that William Clark of 117 Library Place, Princeton, N.J., had been named for a temporary commission as lieutenant colonel in the Army.

TRENTON, March 17 -- A peaceful picket, bearing placards in the best union labor manner but more interested in something to eat than in words intended to provide only food for thought, held forth in front of the State House here today while in the Assembly Chamber a legislative committee held a public hearing on a bill to repeal the Milk Control Act.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- A series of orders clarifying the authorities, functions and responsibilities of directors or heads of twelve divisions or offices of the War Production Board were issued today by Donald M. Nelson. The general administrative orders are numbered 11 to 22.

DETROIT, March 17 -- Conversion of the automobile industry to war work has cut down business activity in this area from the previous month, according to the monthly business survey of the Purchasing Agents Association of Detroit, released today.
MacArthur of the Philippines yesterday became MacArthur of Australia.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 17 -- "We want bigger and better bombers and bigger and better bombs -- the bigger the better," a Royal Air Force tactical expert said yesterday. He added, referring to America:

" I know a bank whereon the wild thyme blows," sang Shakespeare many years ago. And some three centuries later current cook-writers still sing the praises of bay and basil, mint and marjoram, thyme and tarragon.

A conspiracy to restrict and monopolize the business of installing the hydraulic gasoline storage and fueling equipment used by the Army and the Navy was charged in a Federal indictment yesterday to two corporations and seven of their officials.

An odd and significant thing about Australia is that the instant the fighting ground shifts to that island continent from Malaya and the Netherlands Indies the battle of the Far East turns into the battle of the Far West.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 17 -- The most audacious patrol exploit tried by the Germans in recent weeks on the Libyan front failed yesterday when British mobile forces approached a strong enemy column that had moved forward around Cherima, which is about twenty-two miles southwest of El Gazala.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The House passed today a bill creating a volunteer Women's Army Auxiliary Corps, whose members, by taking over duties now performed behind the lines by enlisted men, would release many men for combat duty.

Walter Nash, New Zealand's first Minister to the United States, yesterday praised the placing of General Douglas MacArthur in command of United Nations forces in the Western Pacific as one that demonstrated unity among the nations opposing the Japanese.

In the year ending September, 1941, three new high school buildings were opened in New York, each costing nearly three million dollars, not including the expense for staffing. On the other hand, it costs New York the comparatively small sum of $300,000 a year to operate Townsend Harris High School on the upper four stories in the School of Commerce Building of the City College.

" Valley of the Sun," which will be shown at the Rialto, is this morning's only film arrival. The cast of the RKO screen version of the Clarence Budington Kelland story is headed by Lucille Ball and James Craig. Dean Jagger, Sir Cedric Hardwicke, Billy Gilbert, Peter Whitney, Tom Tyler and Antonio Moreno are featured in the Western drama.

With three scientific expeditions preparing to invade South America in search of new sources of quinine and other medicinal plants to replace those lost because of the war, the New York Botanical Garden won two prizes at the Flower Show yesterday with an exhibit that its officers believe will help to revive the art of "make-him-feel-good as practiced by the Indian medicine man.

LONDON, March 17 (AP) -- British tanks and infantry, with the aid of "sufficient" air support, were reported today to be crashing through the Burmese jungles to guard the battered but unbeaten main Imperial army from Japanese columns feeling their way north along the roads from Rangoon to Toungoo and Prome.

LONDON, March 17 -- The stock markets were quiet today pending developments in the war situation. Gilt-edged issues were brighter with the 3 1/2 per cent war loan at 105 13-16. The home rails hardened.

Having developed into a potent 4:10 miler this season, Jim Rafferty of the New York A.C. yesterday decided to go back to his old love, the two miles, for the Navy Relief Society benefit track meet at the Bronx Coliseum on Wednesday, March 25. Iron Mike is confident that he will break nine minutes and will be able to push Greg Rice to a new record.

WELLESLEY, Mass., March 17 -- Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, wife of the head of the Chinese Government, was elected today an honorary member of the Phi Beta Kappa chapter at Wellesley College, from which she was graduated in 1917.

Waste material dealers were urged yesterday to keep scrap metal flowing into defense plants by Dr. Donald H. Wallace, assistant administrator, Office of Price Administration, who compared any one hindering this flow to a saboteur.
BERLIN, March 17 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communiqu said:

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 17 -- Mr. and Mrs. Albert Sidney gave a luncheon at the Bath and Tennis Club today for the Archduke and Archduchess Franz Josef of Austria, Countess Helene Chlapowski, Mrs. Irving Hall Chase, Countess de Narkiewicz-Jodko, Mrs. George Luke Mesker, Arthur Bradley Campbell, Harvey S. Ladew and Channing W. Hare.
LONDON, March 17 (AP) -- An Admiralty communiqu said today:

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- President Roosevelt, at the moment when Congressional sentiment for anti-strike legislation became accentuated, stated today that there was no strike problem at the present moment and cautioned against rushing labor legislation to enactment when things were going along pretty well.

American food manufacturers throughout the country feel that greater sacrifices are necessary to make the war effort effective and have lost patience with the farm and labor lobbyists in Washington, Paul S. Willis, president of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, declared yesterday.

The International Business Machines Corporation reported yesterday for 1941 a net income of $9,844,633 after deducting $9,200,000 estimated United States Federal and Canadian income and excess profits taxes, of which $4,070,000 was United States excess profits tax, and a special reserve of $500,000 for post-war adjustments.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Chinese diplomats are still negotiating with the Treasury on the terms of a $500,000,000 loan to China voted by Congress and approved by Pres ident Roosevelt more than a month ago, it was learned authoritatively today.

John Aldrich, 20 years old, was described yesterday by Assistant District Attorney Harold X. McGowan in Felony Court as "one of the most unusual hold-up suspects I've ever come across." John Jefferson, 47, owner of a tailor shop at 450 Tenth Avenue, had just told Magistrate Glebocki that, pretending he had a pistol, Aldrich ordered him on Monday to hand over all his money, $18, but a moment later returned the money to his victim.

The pledge not to resort to strikes during the war made on behalf of organized labor by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, and Philip Murray, chairman of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, following their conference with the President yesterday, will meet with approval throughout the nation.

Shall the schools of the City of New York continue to be under the control of the Board of Superintendents and their associates and the Board of Education, or shall the door be open for control by the politicians? Nothing less than this is the issue raised by the so-called Supply Bill, Senate Int. 1351, Pr. 1638.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Dr. F.D. Patterson, president of Tuskegee Institute, and Claude A. Barnett, director of the Associated Negro Press, have been named special assistants to the Secretary of Agriculture.

Many American readers may have been puzzled by recent references, such as that contained in a dispatch to this paper yesterday, to the "Princes of India." The phrase opens up a wide and confusing field. About two-fifths of the soil of India and about one-fourth of the population are still under native rulers.

LONDON, Wednesday, March 18 (U.P.) -- British newspapers today hailed the transfer of General Douglas MacArthur to Australia as marking the end of the United Nations defensive policy in the Far East and the substitution of the offensive tactics for which he is famous.
CHUNGKING, China, March 17 -- "We are now going through the darkest period of the war," said the Chinese Government spokesman, T.F. Tsiang, former Ambassador to Russia.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Steps designed to force an early decision in Congress on bills which for the duration of war would suspend the forty-hour work week, freeze open and closed shop conditions and put ceilings on defense contract profits were taken by House leaders today as demands for such legislation on the Senate side precipitated more than four hours of heated debate in that body.

Libby Holman, who has acted on Broadway chiefly in musical shows, will have her first dramatic role on a New York stage when she appears under the sponsorship and direction of Robert Lewis at the Barbizon-Plaza Theatre on April 18. That night will see "Mexican Mural," by Ramon Naya, open there for a run.

BUFFALO, March 17 (AP) -- New York State streams spilled over their banks today, flooding dwellings and business establishments, damaging bridges and blocking highways as the aftermath of torrential rains and thawing of the Winter's snow.
MEXICO CITY, March 17 (AP) -- The first large investment of United States capital in Mexico since the oil expropriation was announced today, on the eve of the fourth anniversary of the expropriation.

Former Senator Daniel O. Hastings, now a practising attorney in Wilmington, Del., and counsel for the plaintiffs who obtained a $3,852,000 decision for the Pennroad Corporation in a suit against the Pennsylvania Railroad, has been nominated for election as a director of the Pennroad Corporation at the annual meeting to be held in Wilmington on March 26.

A Chinese waiter, only three years in the United States, still a trifle shaky in his English, and a former seaman, of Greek extraction, a veteran of eighteen months' active service in the Spanish civil war, were the only two New Yorkers yesterday who held the first number drawn in the Selective Service lottery in Washington -- 3485.

Four young men returning to their homes in Brooklyn from a St. Patrick's Day party at Moran's Cross Bay Hotel, Broad Channel, Queens, were killed early today when the automobile in which they were riding collided with the concrete and steel structure dividing two roadways at the approach to Cross Bay Boulevard Bridge.

DUBLIN, March 17 -- Playgoers who packed the Olympia Theatre here last night for the European premiere of Paul Vincent Carroll's war play, "The Strings, My Lord, Are False," gave it a stirring reception, which it well deserved. Not since he wrote "Shadow and Substance" has Carroll done such good work.

The strange case of Henri Rousseau, the little French customs officer and "primitive" extraordinary, is unfurled on the walls of the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, where an invitation preview took place last evening.
MOSCOW, March 17 (AP) -- The Soviet Bureau of Information is sued the following communiqu today:

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- Although the Interstate Commerce Commission speedily rejected a request from the Office of Price Administration for suspension of railroad freight rate increases in ten commodities yesterday, the Office of Defense Transportation today put its weight behind the OPA proposal.

Soft dressy materials went into the silk suits that took the spotlight yesterday at the fashion show presented at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel by Stein Blaine, Inc. The woman of the Easter parade will wear a suit but it will be a feminine one, according to the styles shown.

Visiting buyers registered in the market last week totaled 1,228, as against 1,152 in the preceding week and 990 in the like period of last year, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's registrations numbered 497, which compared with 602 for last Tuesday.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 17 -- Thirty-three thousand tons of wheat was the figure estimated by the International Red Cross Committee today to cover the needs of starving Greeks for the next three months.

Brown University at Providence, R.I., has received as a gift from Leon Wallerstein, New York business executive, a collection of eighty-five original etchings and aquatints by the Spanish artist Francisco Jose Goya, the university announced yesterday.

Voters went to the polls yesterday to elect Mayors and other local officials in most of the incorporated villages of Westchester, Nassau, Suffolk, Rockland, Orange and Putnam Counties. Because of the war voting was lighter than in previous years and contests were few. Details of the elections follow:

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- With a voice vote and virtually no discussion the Senate passed and returned to the House today a bill raising the national debt limit from $65,000,000,000 to $130,000,000,000.

LAKELAND, Fla., March 17 -- Neat, but not gaudy. That is an accurate appraisal of the 1942 debut of the amazing Lefty Vernon Gomez, who pitched four innings as the Yankees were adding to the woes of the Tigers by romping off with a 2-to-1 triumph in full view of 1,526 onlookers today.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 17 -- Best Seller, a colt that beat all the name horses in the Widener Handicap at Hialeah but lost to The Rhymer in a photo finish, today carried the green and white silks of Colonel Edward R. Bradley to victory in the St. Patrick's Day Purse before a cheering crowd of 7,311.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- In a statement which emphasized that "the people of a democracy are entitled to know the facts, whether they are good or bad, cheerful or depressing," the Office of Facts and Figures announced today a policy of releasing all war information which will not give aid and comfort to the enemy.

ALBANY, March 17 -- The Assembly today passed and sent to the Governor the Young-Milmoe Bill, which has its aim to facilitating of the use of school children over 14 years old to harvest crops in the State during school hours, due to the shortage of farm labor.

PHILADELPHIA, March 17 -- Caroline Lee Gilbert of 600 Riverside Drive, New York City, Hunter College student who had been missing since last Thursday night, was discovered at 1 A.M. today in a diner in South Langhorne eating doughnuts and drinking coffee and insisting she was "Mary Hedges."

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The Treasury reported today that from March 1 through yesterday $1,753,000,000 of individual and corporate income taxes for 1941 had been paid to internal revenue collectors and turned over by them to Federal Reserve Banks or other approved government depositaries.

ALBANY, March 17 -- The Assembly today passed and sent to the Governor the Young-Milmoe Bill, which has its aim to facilitating of the use of school children over 14 years old to harvest crops in the State during school hours, due to the shortage of farm labor.
Wartime conservation of automobile tires and gasoline through lower speeds, rationing and other means gained momentum here yesterday.

Army patrol bombers operating off the Eastern seaboard are "bending every effort to give the fullest protection" to United States and Allied shipping, Major Gen. Follett Bradley, commanding officer of the First Air Force, Mitchel Field, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The sinking by Axis submarines of the Chilean freighter Tolten and of other Latin-American merchant vessels was said today by Sumner Welles, acting Secretary of State, to be a clear indication of the intention of the Axis powers to undertake a completely indiscriminate policy of sinking all ships of the American Republics without distinction.

LONDON, March 17 (AP) -- The Vichy government's order to British coastal residents of French Morocco to move inland is believed to be a German-dictated action, apparently designed as a reprisal for the R.A.F. raids on Paris factories. A well informed diplomatic source predicted the Nazis would insist also upon restrictions on Americans.

The action of the War Production Board in shutting off shipments of steel plates to railroads found to have inventories in excess of normal working stocks may be taken as a warning that increasingly effective measures to prevent piling up of materials will be taken, according to Sydney Hogerton, regional director of the Priorities Field Service of the WPB.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 17 -- A suit brought on behalf of creditors of the defunct Westchester Title and Trust Company of this city to collect $2,000,000 from 500 stockholders came to trial here today before Charles B. Sears of Buffalo, Supreme Court referee and former judge of the Court of Appeals.

LONDON, March 17 -- A warning that Britain is more and more entering the phase of "fortress economics," in which every one must get along with diminishing quantities of all kinds of articles, Hugh Dalton, President of the Board of Trade, announced in the House of Commons today that the government would make a severe reduction in the civilian clothing ration beginning June 1.

Stimulated by active price-fixing operations by mills, the cotton market advanced in the late trading yesterday, and on the New York Cotton Exchange active futures closed at the best levels of the day, showing net gains of 8 to 11 points.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- A statement that a sales tax was not necessary to raise the revenue needed for the war effort was made today in testimony before the Ways and Means Committee. The Representatives were told that the needed funds could be produced by raising tax rates for corporations and individuals.

The list that follows contains the numbers drawn up to the press time of this edition from the goldfish bowl in Washington in the third selective service lottery. The numbers are arranged in the numerical sequence of serial numbers.
ORLANDO, Fla., March 17 -- Hitting more like the champions they're supposed to be, the itinerant Dodgers today struck back hard at the Senators, flattening the Washington boys under a 13-4 score.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The prepared text of Donald M. Nelson's radio address tonight was as follows:

Borough President John Cashmore, speaking last night at the annual dinner of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in Brooklyn's Columbus Club, urged that the fifteen New York City school teachers suspended because of charges of communism of perjury be tried immediately so that they could be dismissed or cleared.

The United States Government is boasting of a best seller, pointing to a first edition of 27,000 copies of one of its books selling out in two weeks. The book is the "United States Government Manual," Spring edition, a 698-page directory of the ins and outs of official Washington.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- The Navy Department announced today the names of 185 retired officers who are to receive promotions.

WASHINGTON, March 17- The Defense Plant Corporation and the Metals Reserve Company have made agreements with the Freeport Sulphur Company whereby $20,000,000 will be made available for the production of nickel in Cuba.

CHICAGO, March 17 (AP) -- Transportation Director Joseph B. Eastman looked ahead today to the time when all domestic freight traffic will be devoted to the movement of war materials and essential civilian supplies and said the railroads must then plan on expanded sharing of equipment and facilities.

DANVILLE, Ill., March 17 -- Three tornadoes in Middle Illinois late yesterday killed 18 and injured 170. Hardest hit were Lacon, in Marshall County, where 6 were dead, 13 seriously injured and 50 more with Minor hurts, and Alvin, in Vermilion County, where 5 were dead and 55 injured. State health authorities in the two communities administered anti-typhoid shots and took other precautions against possible epidemics.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Organization of "pressure groups" to insist upon legislative relationship of public welfare activities to the nation's war work was urged today by Mrs. Roosevelt upon the Children's Bureau Commission which opened a three-day conference on the needs of children in wartime.

Barnet Metzger, owner of the Freeman Dairy Corporation at 56-24 Fifty-eighth Street, Maspeth, Queens, testifying yesterday at the trial of twelve men in the alleged extortion of $158,000 from independent milk dealers and truckers, swore he paid $16,000 to two of the twelve to avoid labor difficulties.

LONDON, March 17 -- Alfred Duff Cooper, who recently returned from the Far East, where, as representative of the British Cabinet, he established a war council at ill-fated Singapore, warned the public against complacency tonight.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, March 18 -- Fighting fierce rearguard actions, German forces defending Kharkov were reported this morning to be rapidly ceding ground northwest and west of the Ukraine city as Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's forces ended the second day of their main offensive on the southern front.

The three-story private dwelling at 601 Second Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Bank for Savings to Lucille B. Teitelbaum through the Harry M. Lewis Company, Brooklyn brokers. The sale was closed for cash above a $7,000 purchase money mortgage.

HAVANA, March 17--A story of fighting off sharks while floating on pieces of wreckage after the torpedoing of a freighter off Puerto Padre, in Oriente Province on the north coast of Cuba, was told today by Viat Alfreds of New York, a cook, one of thirty-six rescued crew members who have reached Havana.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The War Department issued the following special communiqu:
The Insurance Company of North America reported yesterday that admitted assets on Dee. 31 amounted to $117,816,917, an increase of $4,051,425 over the total at the end of 1940.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The text of Brig. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey's talk opening the third draft lottery tonight follows:

Secretary of War Stimson drew the first number -- 3,485 -- from the famous goldfish bowl in Washington at 6:05 o'clock last night to begin America's third draft lottery in seventeen months, although its first in wartime since 1918.

An all-out fight against censorship, possibly affecting the New York stage, was promised last night by representatives of organized groups in the legitimate theatre, who pledged their opposition to the recent closing by Paul Moss, license commissioner, of burlesque houses.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- A supplemental appropriation of $17,579,311,253 for War Department planes will be asked of Congress tomorrow, President Roosevelt announced at his press conference today. This will increase the budgeted cost of the war program to more than $164,000,000,000.

BOSTON, March 17 -- The Brooklyn Americans' last feeble hope of qualifying for one of the six National Hockey League play-off berths was crushed tonight when the Boston Bruins gave them an 8-3 trouncing in their regular season's finale before 9,000 at the Boston Garden.
PHILADELPHIA, March 17 (AP) -- Dartmouth and Princeton will clash at the University of Pennsylvania's Palestra tomorrow night to decide the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League championship.
Small residential properties were involved in most of the Manhattan transactions reported by brokers yesterday.

Three hundred representatives of management and labor in plants manufacturing guns, ships, planes and machine tools met yesterday with officials of the War Production Board and discussed plans for speeding the production drive announced by President Roosevelt on Feb. 27 and later elaborated upon by Donald M. Nelson, production chief, in two speeches.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Demands that Congress enact some type of wartime labor legislation met further Administration opposition today when Army, Navy and Maritime authorities told a special Senate inquiry that there was no need for such action.

The WPB has finally cracked down on pinball. No more of those machines to be manufactured after May 1. The reasons given are the usual ones: the saving of copper wire, etc.; shifting of the industry's production facilities -- and they are considerable -- to the manufacture of Signal Corps radios and other military materials.

The Baltimore Ohio Railroad's management eliminated all arrears of interest on its bonds yesterday by appropriating $22,000,000 out of 1941 income for this purpose. This will leave all bonds in precisely the position in which they were in 1938 before the management requested their holders to accept a temporary reduction in interest in order to avert a financial stringency.

The arrangements to be made by the police and other city departments in cooperation with the city's public utility companies for caring for large concentrations of persons -- such as the crowds normally visiting ball parks and beaches during the Summer -- in the event of an air raid were discussed yesterday at a meeting of the city's defense officials at the line-up room at Manhattan Police Headquarters.

The New York Stock Exchange authorized yesterday the listing of 2,015,565 common shares of $1 par value of the Sperry Corporation, which will not be admitted to dealings until further notice. At present voting trust certificates for a like number of common shares are listed on the Exchange.

ALBANY, March 18 -- While legislative committees cleaned up their calendars, and the 1942 session settled down to dispose of many important matters, Governor Lehman signed today the law reducing the State income tax by 25 per cent, effective on the tax payable this year and next year.

John Charles Thomas, baritone, gave his only New York recital of the season last night in Town Hall as the final event in this Winter's Town Hall Endowment Series. Replacing Lawrence Tibbett, who was unable to appear because of illness, Mr. Thomas provided an evening of distinguished vocalism.

France is necessary to the world and her civilization cannot go on if her present generation is lost, but America will not abandon her, Professor Pierre Brodin, author, lecturer and educator, said yesterday at the eighth "Pot au Feu" luncheon of the Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies, Inc., at the Hotel Plaza.

An up-to-the-minute fashion show, emphasizing the happy combination of chic and durability, was staged by Abraham Straus yesterday in the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn. Sixty-eight costumes covering every phase of a busy woman's life were shown in a two-and-a-half-hour revue, applauded by an audience of 2,000 women.

RIOM, France, March 18 -- General Maurice Gustave Gamelin, once the supreme commander of France's armies, today broke silence before the Supreme Court, where he is on trial with four other former French leaders on a charge of responsibility for France's defeat.

A smouldering fire sent heavy smoke curling from the second-floor windows of the Tango Palace, a dance hall on the southwest corner of Broadway and Forty-eighth Street, shortly after 7 P.M., last night, before the dance hall had opened for the evening.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The White House rejected today the request of George P. McNear Jr., president of the Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad, for a personal conference on Friday with President Roosevelt to present his reply to the Chief Executive's request that he comply immediately with a National War Labor Board order requiring arbitration of the wage dispute of 104 employes who have been on strike since Dec. 28.

Both principals in tomorrow night's twelve-round feature bout at Madison Square Garden, Ray Robinson and Norman Rubio, appeared before the New York State Athletic Commission yesterday and underwent physical examinations by Dr. William H. Walker.

" Bedtime Story," a Columbia comedy-romance starring Fredric March and Loretta Young, will be the new attraction today at the Radio City Music Hall. The film, which was directed by Alexander Hall, features Robert Benchley, Allyn Joslyn, Eve Arden, Helen Westley, Clarence Kolb and Joyce Compton.

Two coiffures showing the new functional emphasis in hair-styling received joint first-prize rating at the fifteenth annual International Hairstyling Competition, held last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania. The competition, in which thirty-six American hairdressers took part, was staged in connection with the International Beauty Show.

PHILADELPHIA, March 18 -- With 5,000 sitting in Pennsylvania's Palestra, Dartmouth came through to undisputed ownership of the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League championship tonight by defeating Princeton in the seventh play-off in the circuit's history, 46 to 38. For nearly all of the game the Indians were in the lead, but there was no time until the closing minutes when they were safe.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- President Roosevelt asked Congress today for a supplemental War Department appropriation of $17,579,311,253, of which $8,515,861,251 would go to the Air Corps.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 18 -- Competent foreign circles here have been speculating about whether there will actually be a German Spring offensive in Russia. Since commanders are not in the habit of telling the enemy beforehand of their intentions, there has been a feeling here that the Spring offensive has been too much advertised.

The influence of taxes on the net incomes of railroads was shown in the report of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway for February and the first two months of 1942. Gross revenues in both periods were ahead of the tital for the same periods last year, but net income, particularly for the two-month interval, was down substantially.

CHICAGO, March 18 -- Liquidation developed today in the rye market after a steady opening and with stop-loss orders uncovered in profusion prices dropped 3 5/8 cents a bushel from yesterday's close before covering by shorts and commission-house buying could stem the downturn.

Richard S. Childs, chairman of the Citizens Union, renewed his request to Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. yesterday that District Attorney Samuel J. Foley of the Bronx be superseded in his investigation of the charges against Edward J. Flynn, chairman of the Democratic National Committee.

LONDON, March 18 -- British propaganda methods -- and lack of them -- aroused the House of Lords today to stormy debate in which Sir Robert Vansittart, former Permanent Under-Secretary of the Foreign Office, delivered his maiden speech tinged throughout with anger.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Retail selling prices of gasoline were ordered frozen at Friday's levels in seventeen Eastern and two Pa cific States and the District of Columbia in an order issued tonight by John E. Hamm, Acting Federal Price Administrator.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Representative Sauthoff of Wisconsin proposed today that a $75,000 top be placed on all salaries and that the government tax newspaper and radio advertising.

A city mail clerk, alleged by police to have stolen small amounts of money from letters sent to patients in Bellevue Hospital, pleaded guilty yesterday to the charge of petit larceny at a hearing before Magistrate William Klapp in Yorkville Court and was held in $500 bail for trial in General Sessions.

There are in the United States today many thousands of men of sufficient ability and character to have earned in the past annual incomes ranging from $5,000 to $15,000, or more, who want to work, because they must, and who would like to serve their counting in its hour of need because they are decent, patriotic citizens.

Along with the simple life that lies ahead of us will come back the simple names for things. We shall not only see a good deal more of made-over dresses and patched shoes, but we shall hear and read more about seamstresses and cobblers.

BERLIN, March 18 (From German broadcasts recorded in New York by The United Press) -- The German High Command claimed today that its troops in Russia had hurled back all attempts to break through their lines.

LONDON, March 18 -- Surprised and concerned, the British Foreign Office today took up a report that telephone connections between Afghanistan and Tokyo would be established tomorrow under special arrangements whereby conversations would be restricted to the Japanese language.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 18 (AP) -- Francis B. Sayre, United States High Commissioner to the Philippines, returned to the United States today insisting that the United Nations can win the war only "by aggressive and furious attack."

Nothing said here should be construed as meaning that "Johnny Doodle" is a well-written play or that it is well performed. As put on last evening at the Popular Theatre, 320 West Fifty-seventh Street, it is very much on the amateur side, both in craftsmanship and acting.

It can never be forgotten of Great Britain that for a full year, from the fall of France in June, 1940, until the assault on Russia in June, 1941, there was but one front in this war and the British held it alone. When German military power was at its peak, the English Channel was the one trench in Europe it could not storm.

The immediate post-war era will present a potential market in this country for at least 10,000,000 to 15,000,000 new or pre-constructed family housing units with a value of more than $20,000,000,000 for the building industry, Bror Dahlberg, president of the Celotex Corporation, said at a luncheon meeting of the New York Society of Security Analysts yesterday at 54 Broad Street.

Fifteen hundred alumni and parents of students of Townsend Harris High School attended last night a protest meeting in the City College auditorium at Lexington Avenue and Twenty-third Street to voice disapproval of discontinuance of the school voted by the Board of Higher Education on Monday night.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., March 18 -- Evacuation of all Japanese, citizens as well as aliens, from the Far West's Military Area No. 1 will get under way early next week, when 1,000 volunteers from Los Angeles will travel by automobile, bus or train to a reception center now under construction at Owens Valley, it was announced here tonight by Lieut. Gen. Dewitt, Western defense commander.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- In a unanimous decision, four employers joining, the National War Labor Board asserted today its authority to grant or deny a union security clause covering the 175,000 employes of "Little Steel."

Good things come in small packages, so it is said. And good things also come in Winter, we say. During the three months that have just passed, an exciting variety of unusual, satisfying food has appeared for the first time in city stores.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The Army has begun organization of a corps of troops to specialize in operations and experiments with equipment in desert warfare. This training will soon be in full swing somewhere "west of the Colorado River," it was stated.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The United States will build and maintain during the war and for six months thereafter, if desired, the military highway through Canada to Alaska, according to detailed arrangements set forth in an exchange of notes made public by the State Department today.

Because of Washington's child labor laws the Spring tour of "Lady in the Dark," the Gertrude Lawrence show at the Alvin, has been canceled and the New York run has been indefinitely extended, it was said last night by Miss Lawrence's representative.

LONDON, March 18 -- The news of General MacArthur's new appointment was responsible for a more cheerful sentiment in the stock markets today. Gilt-edge issues were steady, but the home rails showed small losses.

Visitors to the new Criminal Courts Building, facing Center Street, witnessed yesterday the first attempt at escape since it was opened last September. The break was made by 17-year-old Betty Stover, a pretty brunette, who slipped out of the grasp of her custodian, Miss Romaine Harburg, in front of the White Street entrance to the adjoining new Tombs.
MELBOURNS, Australia, March 13 -- Following is the text of Australian Prime Minister John Curtin's statement today:

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Combined Australian and United States "island-based air forces" wiped out a sizable part of a Japanese invasion fleet in raids on New Guinea bases, with the loss of only one airplane, the Navy announced today.

Presentation of an affidavit by Mayor La Guardia denouncing burlesque shows and their producers marked a heated two-hour legal battle before Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy yesterday when burlesque operators sought to compel reopening of their theatres.

Encouraged by the market's show of strength in late trading on Tuesday, active mill buying carried over into yesterday's session to sustain the firm undertone. Hedging operations continued active also, however, and these were enough to offset the mill demand.

The directors of Julius Kayser Co. created yesterday the post of chairman and elected Henry L. Van Pragg to fill it. Mr. Van Pragg resigned as president because of ill health, after forty-six years of service with the company. Theophil H. Mueller was elected president and chief executive officer and Ralph H. Baruth was elected first vice president.

The order of the War Production Board for a 20 per cent cut in sales by retail gasoline distributors, except on "preferential" demands, will go into effect this morning. Approximately 125,000 filling stations will be affected. The order applies to the entire Eastern area as well as the States of Oregon and Washington.

Mrs. Alma Clayburgh gave a dinner last night at Sherry's for Bruno Walter, noted conductor. Among the other guests were Mr. and Mrs. John Barbirolli, Lord Marley, Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Mitchell, Baron and Baroness Georg Daubek (Jarmilla Novotna), Mrs. Walter Hoving, Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Lyons, Mr. and Mrs. James Hooper Grew, Mme. Olga Samaroff Stokowski, Mrs. Edward Savage Crocker, Alfred de Liagre, William B. Ziff and Savely Sorine.

PHILADELPHIA, March 18 -- Teachers and principals attending Schoolmen's Week at the University of Pennsylvania were advised today by Captain Donald S. Leonard of the Office of Civilian Defense to reverse a customary procedure by having sons and daughters counsel their parents as to the danger that the United States might lose the war.

Charges against Harry Kazen, 30 years old, of 284 East 172d Street, who was alleged to have falsified his motor car registration under the name of his half-sister, Dorothy Miller, 16-year-old high school girl, were dropped yesterday in Downtown Traffic Court when the girl testified that she really owned the car that he drove.

Among the Dan Toppings and the Pat di Ciccos and the Ben Finneys, they didn't have a suitable pot in which to cook a chicken on St. Patrick's Day. The result is that Mr. di Cicco, husband of the former Gloria Vanderbilt, will appear in Yorkville Court today to answer a summons charging simple assault.

Two more United States merchant ships have been torpedoed off the Atlantic Coast, it was announced yesterday by the Navy Department. Eleven lives were lost in the two sinkings, both of which occurred early last Sunday morning, and five additional members of the crew of one ship are missing and presumed lost.

With a pair of stunning upsets marking the start of the national invitation tournament on Tuesday, the City College and Toledo basketball teams will have their fingers crossed firmly tonight when they move out on the Madison Square Garden court for the second half of the first round of play.

LONDON, March 18 (AP) -- The Admiralty issued today a warning that all the Bay of Biscay, except for a twenty-mile strip along the Spanish coast, and thousands of square miles of the Atlantic Ocean southwest of England "are dangerous to shipping."

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 18 -- While little is known of the extent of Japanese activity in Madagascar, French island off Eastern Africa, it is gathered from information that may be considered reliable that within recent months many German self-styled "experts" arrived on the island and that others who had been there had taken up dubious duties as "technicians'' with the expressed intention of cooperating with the government.

UNITED STATES ARMY HEADQUARTERS, in Australia, March 18 -- Judging from the reaction today nothing could have given a bigger upswing to Australia's spirit than the news that General Douglas MacArthur had been named Supreme United Nations Commander in the Southwestern Pacific and had already arrived in this country to take over the command.

TORONTO, March 18 (Canadian Press) -- A net profit of $4,439,732 was realized in 1941 by the Steel Company of Canada, Ltd., and subsidiaries, equal after preferred dividends to $7.96 on each common share outstanding. This compared with $4,264,384, or $8.28 a common share, after dividends on the preferred stock in 1940.

For the better protection of coastwise shipping against enemy raiders, particularly submarines, Secretary Knox announced here yesterday that ships will be required hereafter to proceed only in a specified northbound lane or in a southbound lane, which may be cleared for them by surface and airplane patrols.
Renting of apartments over a wide area from Greenwich Village to Washington Heights was reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, and Robert P. Patterson, Under Secretary of War, moved jointly today to eliminate bureaucratic "red tape" in the civilian and military war agencies they represent.

NEWARK, N.J., March 18 -- Marked by bitter clashes between rival groups, a stockholders' meeting was held here today in the office of the Breeze Corporation to decide whether interests headed by Joseph J. Mascuch, former president, would continue to control the company or whether they would be supplanted by representatives of a faction styling itself the stockholders protective committee.
HAVANA, March 18 -- With the enemy submarine campaign against American shipping in the Caribbean bringing the war closer to Cuba, war plans were being rushed today by the government.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Acting Secretary of State Sumner Welles says everything possible will be done here to facilitate and expedite the sending of needed military material to Turkey which now wants the benefit of American lease-lend aid in building up her defenses.

Water-colors and drawings by eight artists, appointed by the Office for Emergency Management to record activities in specific defense areas, are being shown at the National Gallery of Art in Washington. The artists were given permission by the United States Army and the United States Navy to paint and draw in restricted areas.

Mgr. Robert F. Keegan, secretary of Catholic Charities, told Mayor La Guardia at City Hall yesterday that the equipment and personnel of his agency was at the city's disposal in major emergencies and would work with other civilian defense agencies.

Advertising is undergoing a fundamental change, which has been intensified by the war economy, Dr. Kenneth Dameron, director of the committee on consumer relations in advertising, said yesterday before the class in trends in retail distribution of the Massachusetts Department of Education University Extension Course at Boston.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The President's annoyance with back-seat drivers is more than understandable. Every Chief Executive throughout history has complained of it, especially in time of war. But if, in his quotation from Livy at his press conference yesteday, the President meant that only back-seat drivers (persons ignorant of military matters) support the call for a unified military command under his authority as Commander in Chief, he is mistaken.
Earnings of the Electrolux Corporation for 1941 increased to $2,716,538 before taxes from $2,074,528 in 1940, according to official figures released yesterday.

The War Labor Board, while recently denying the outright closed shop to the union in the Bower Roller Bearing Company of Detroit, none the less granted the union the "voluntary check-off." Apparently in this case the board applied the so-called "Marshall Field formula." In the Marshall Field case, decided on Jan. 29, it was provided that:

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- A War Relocation Authority under which enemy aliens who have been forced to move from military areas, especially on the Pacific Coast, may voluntarily enlist in a War Relocation Work Corps was created by President Roosevelt today.

Our smashing victory over the Japanese invasion fleet off the north coast of New Guinea will help to soften the sting of defeat suffered by Allied naval forces in the Java Sea. It was equally decisive. In some respects it was the most spectacular victory of the Pacific war and one of the most encouraging.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- Future automobile license plates will be "small date tabs" not more than four square inches attached to present license plates to bring them up to date, under a War Production Board order issued today.

There is every expectation that the Reconstruction Finance Corporoation will settle all claims for damages to civilian property in Hawaii resulting from the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7, according to a preliminary report of the Board of Underwriters of Hawaii received yesterday by the National Association of Insurance Agents, at 80 Maiden Lane, New York.

BUFFALO, March 18 (AP) -- A temperature drop in New York State tonight further checked the rampaging creeks and rivers which, in two days caused highway, bridge and property damage running into millions of dollars.

An official blueprint of the Nazi method of subjugating a conquered country is contained in a Polish White Book made public yesterday by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Polish Government in Exile.

The list that follows contains the numbers drawn from the goldfish bowl in Washington in the third selective service lottery, as revised after correction of errors in the draw. The numbers are arranged in the numerical sequence of serial numbers.
LIMA, Ohio, March 18 (AP) -- Pilots of four Army planes perished today as their ships crashed and burned in a blinding snowstorm on farms east of Lima.

LONDON, March 18--Minister of Agriculture Robert S. Hudson declared in the House of Commons today that the future history of Britain and perhaps of the world might depend on this year's harvest in the United Kingdom.
Washington, March 18 -- The Navy Department issued the following communique today:

GENERAL M'ARTHUR'S HEADQUARTERS, in Australia, March 18 (U.P.) -- The Americans have taken Australia by storm. To the Australians, the Americans are "fair dinkum." To the Americans, the Australians are "right guys." Both phrases mean the same.

Possible limitation of retail charge accounts as one means of closing an "inflationary gap" of about $11,000,000,000 between purchasing power and the available supply of consumer goods is being considered by the Federal Reserve Board, it was learned here yesterday.

The Music Education League, which conducts annual auditions for music students, announced yesterday that almost 100 soloists, most of whom are pianists, have registered for its first series of auditions, which will be held at Steinway Hall from this Saturday until April 2.

Goldman, Sachs Co. and H.B. Boland Co. received yesterday the award of an issue of $357,000 of general improvement bonds of Monmouth County, N.J., on their bid of 100.07 for 2.40s. The bonds, dated March 15, 1942, will mature on March 15, 1943 to 1956.

A further drop last week of 1,090,000 barrels in stocks of gasoline and light and heavy fuel oil along the Atlantic Coast was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. Gasoline stocks deelined 365,000 barrels to 18,043,000, light fuel oil supplies decreased 41,000 to 7,700,000 and heavy fuel oil stocks lost 684,000 to 6,292,000.

MOSCOW, March 18 (AP) -- Tonight's Russian communique said merely that nothing of importance had taken place at the front today. It claimed the destruction of forty-four German planes yesterday, compared with sixteen Russian planes lost.

Women entered the USO ranks in their own right yesterday when Mrs. Maurice T. Moore was appointed chairman of the newly formed National Women's Committee. At the same time she assumed duties as vice chairman for USO's second country-wide campaign.

ALBANY, March 18 -- Control of rents in areas where housing shortages have been caused by a concentration of war industries is proposed in a measure submitted to the Legislature tonight by Assemblyman Moffat and Senator Page for the Republican majorities.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Amendment of the Social Security Act to provide for "substantial increases" in Federal aid grants to meet the needs of children in war production areas was approved today by the Children's Bureau Commission on Children in War Time.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 18 (AP) -"The significance and importance of the appointments of General Douglas MacArthur and General George H. Brett in the crucial Pacific area cannot be overstated," Dr. Herbert Vere Evatt, Australian Minister for External Affairs, said on his arrival today en route to Washington with a special mission.

An investor bought from the Home Life Insurance Company the six-story apartment house for sixty families at 1866 Ocean Avenue, corner of Avenue N, Brooklyn. The property is assessed at $195,000 and was sold through Byrne, Bowman Forshay, brokers.

RAHWAY, N.J., March 18--A fire that is believed to have been smoldering for some time before being discovered, caused damage estimated at $15,000 to Grover Cleveland School here today. The school, which accommodates 400 pupils from Kindergarten to the eighth grade, was ordered closed until Monday pending an investigation of what Fire Chief Walter H. Ritzman termed "certain suspicious circumstances."
Hope that China, "a leader through the years," will continue to lead in constructing a better world at the war's end was expressed yesterday by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.

The conservation of the nation's greatest asset, its soil, yesterday occupied the attention of many of the 30,000 visitors to the Flower Show and of 500 officials and exhibitors gathered at their largest formal meeting of the week. Officials flatly rejected the possibility that the show would be dropped next year because of the war and exhorted all Americans to renew their soil contacts as one of the most effective means of preserving their country.

CHUNGKING, China, March 18 (U.P.) -- The newspaper Yi-Shih-Pao said today that Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, United States Army, new chief of staff to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek as Allied Commander in Chief of Southeast Asia, was organizing joint Allied opera-

CHICAGO, March 18 (AP) -- A top of $15.50 a hundredweight was paid today for strictly choice steers on the livestock market, equaling the highest point reached in more than a year, as the salable run of better grade offerings continued small. Prices on choice steers and yearlings were steady to slightly higher than yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- A request to management and labor representatives in the retail milk distribution field to work out plans for readjusting local milk delivery services as a means of conserving tires and motor vehicle equipment, was sent out today by Joseph B. Eastman, Director of Defense Transportation.

LAKELAND, Fla., March 18 -The Dodgers proved good medicine today for the losing streak sickness of the Tigers, who were cured abruptly. Previously the Bengals had played and lost five contests without scoring more than two runs per game and only a total of seven.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 18 -- RKO today signed Frank Ross to produce two pictures for the company's 1942-43 program, the first of which will be "Another Dawn," a love story written by Ross. It is expected that Jean Arthur, Ross's wife, will be starred in his second film, although the commitment is not yet definite, and no title has been announced for the possible Arthur vehicle.

Many underwear mills were said yesterday to be taking advantage of the present lull to check their delivery positions, following the recent Fall buying spurt, in order to make certain that they have not booked too much merchandise for shipment during any specific month to limited-credit accounts.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 18 -- The Federal Government agreed today to modify its contract for the airport on land adjacent to Rye Lake in Purchase so that Westchester County, which has accepted a $634,000 Federal grant for runway construction, could abandon the airport after twenty years and sell the property.

Representatives of all the bar associations in the city met last night at the building of the Association of the Bar, 42 West Forty-fourth Street, and formed a war committee through which attorneys and judges will make their contribution toward solving problems created by the war.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Regulations adapting the 1917 Trading With the Enemy Act to the needs of the present war and removing for this purpose many of the restrictions on trading or communication with the other American republics and with certain other areas which were specified under the old law, were issued today by Secretary Morgenthau, in conjunction with Byron Price, Censorship Director.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 18 -- A capacity audience filled the Everglades Club's music room tonight for the program of monodramas by Soo Yong, celebrated Chinese actress, sponsored by the Four Arts Society. Proceeds will aid China's homeless, wounded and needy and further its fight against the common enemy of the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -President Roosevelt asked Congress for an an appropriation of $17,500,000,000 for materials for the Army, presented to Rear Admiral William H. Standley, new Ambassador to Russia, the Navy's Distinguished Service Medal.

I have read with interest Topics of The Times concerning Justice Steinbrink's decision declaring the new street peddling law unconstitutional. In upholding Judge Steinbrink's decision, you evidently overlooked a number of reasons which are potent and factual.

The Dutch Treat Club, which usually celebrates the arrival of Spring with an entertainment severely satirizing current follies, announced yesterday the cancellation of this year's annual dinner and show, scheduled for April 10 at the Waldorf-Astoria.
