Sales of a town residence, a loft building and rooming houses marked realty activity in Manhattan yesterday.

Plans for a mass of requiem for Ensign John S. Connery, reported missing and presumed dead by the Navy Department in the sinking of the cruiser Houston during the Battle of Java, were changed with joy on the part of his Staten Island family yesterday to the celebration of a mass of thanksgiving for unofficial reports of his safety.

SUVA, Fiji Islands, March 18 (AP) -- Another heroic wartime saga of the seas, of dangerous days and nights in storm-tossed lifeboats, was related today by survivors of two vessels torpedoed by Japanese submarines last December.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 18 -- The unveiling of Lefty Vernon Gomez having been encompassed with satisfactory results, the Yankees today were looking forward to the debut of two more stars tomorrow when they journey to Lake Wales for an exhibition game against the Kansas City Farmhands.

Instructions on how to make out the State income tax return to take advantage of the 25 per cent reduction authorized by the Legislature after the forms were mailed were issued yesterday by the State Department of Taxation and Finance.
ALBANY, March 18 -- Two bills designed to eliminate possibilities of alien fifth column activities or dissemination of Axis propaganda in the State were introduced in the Legislature today.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- With three mistakes out of more than 7,000 possibilities of error, the first draft lottery of the war ended today, establishing the order in which 9,000,000 men will be called for possible service in the Army.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Bills proposing that all women between the ages of 18 and 65 register for service to release men for active duty and to create a women's auxiliary in the Navy were introduced in the House today.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., March 18 -- The finance officials of four Hudson County municipalities, including Raymond M. Greer, Controller of this city, as principal witness, testified today as hearings began before Supreme Court Commissioner Philip M. Grece in the suit of the four municipalities and ten individual taxpayers against the constitutionality of a law setting a flat assessment rate of $3 a $100 on second-class railroad property in the State.

In announcing Arnold Constable's Spring fashion presentation, which took place yesterday in the Sert Room of the Waldorf Astoria at the luncheon hour, Mrs. Anne Albee, fashion director for the store, said that owing to war conditions women unquestionably would spend more time in the city during the late Spring and Summer than in previous years. With this in mind the collection was centered on town clothes.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, March 18 -Sao Paulo police investigating Axis fifth column activities have rounded up several Japanese, including Misutaka Taoki, alias Misutaka Aoko, who calls himself "Count."

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Twenty-two officers and men of the cruiser Omaha today won special commendation by the Navy for their shares in capturing a German ship one month before the Japanese attacks in the Pacific Ocean embroiled this country in the world-wide war.

Nathan Gottlieb, 47 years old, a former laundry owner of 95-15 123d Street, Ozone Park, Queens, who pleaded guilty last week to withholding from the government money paid by employes as Social Security taxes, was sentenced yesterday by Judge Marcus B. Campbell in United States District Court, Brooklyn, to fifteen months in a Federal penitentiary.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 18 (AP) -- General Douglas MacArthur and his party arrived at a Central Australian town last night aboard two United States Army planes. [The British Exchange Telegraph agency said the town was Alice Springs.]

Three local boys gained berths on the East team that will face the West in the annual intersectional amateur boxing battles between Golden Gloves winners at Madison Square Garden on March 30. This was determined at the Garden last night as the Tournament of Champions came to a close before a crowd of 15,119 persons.

The retail price index for use with the "last-in, first out" or "lifo" method of inventory valuation, compiled for the National Retail Dry Goods Association by the National Industrial Conference Board, made its appearance yesterday.

MOSCOW, March 18 -- The emergence of Leningrad's three million population from tests severer than any imposed on a besieged city in modern warfare is becoming known as the stirring tale of the city's endurance and steadfastness is pieced together from available accounts.

A basketball show for the benefit of various war charities has been arranged by the Metropolitan Intercollegiate Basketball Committee, Chairman Jack Coffey of Fordham announced yesterday during a luncheon at Toots Shot's restaurant.

UNITED STATES ARMY HEADQUARTERS, in Australia, March 18 -- Lieut. Gen. George H. Brett, who is deputy commander of all Allied forces in the Southwest Pacific and is directly in charge of all air operations, said today that the United States airmen could take on Japanese at a ratio of one to two and beat them every time. General Brett made his statement at a press conference, basing it on his experience in Java.

The New York money market is now over the "hump" caused by heavy income tax payments and Treasury disbursements in this district. It was estimated in banking circles yesterday that the Treasury put through yesterday about $50,000,000 in income tax checks for collection, after about $150,000,000 the day before.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 18 -- The Watch, bred by Thomas Piatt, the breeder of Alsab, surprised most of the 6,660 fans at Tropical Park today when she easily defeated eight other juveniles in the Homestead Purse.

The longstanding campaign of United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa against racketeering in the movie industry took a sudden step forward yesterday when Nick Dean, alias Circella, walked into Federal court and pleaded guilty to a charge of extorting "upward of $1,000,000" from four big film companies.

OTTAWA, March 18 -- One hundred and seventeen sailors and six girls are on their way from the islands of St. Pierre and Miquelon to join the Free French forces in England or wherever they may be sent. They have arrived in Halifax and it is the first time that some of them have left their native islands and seen trees, tall buildings and street cars.

Basil Harris, executive vice president of the United States Lines, was named president of the concern at a special meeting of the board of directors yesterday at 1 Broadway. He succeeds John M. Franklin, who has been commissioned a colonel for duty with the Army Transport Service.
CHICAGO, March 18 -- Two anti-trust law indictments charging conspiracy to fix prices on American and brick cheese as returned today by a Federal grand jury included the following names:

A vigorous campaign to increase sharply collections of all types of scrap rubber was inaugurated yesterday at the concluding session of the twenty-ninth annual convention of the National Association of Waste Material Dealers at the Hotel Astor.

CHICAGO, March 18 -- A special Federal grand jury returned two indictments today accusing 105 defendants of having conspired to fix prices of American and brick cheese in violation of the anti-trust laws. Among the defendants are forty-six corporations and fifty-six individuals engaged in buying, selling, processing and distributing cheese.

GENERAL M'ARTHUR'S HEADQUARTERS, in Australia, March 17 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The safe passage of the United States convoy to Australia can be ascribed to anti-submarine precautions that left not even an empty can or pop bottle to mark the crossing of the Pacific by thousands of troops.

A comprehensive program calling for direct subsidies amounting to $50,000,000 to colleges and students who may be in financial stress as a result of the accelerated three-year war courses has been proposed by the United States Office of Education, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- If tomorrow enemy bombers should suddenly attack cities and towns within the boundaries of the continental United States there are some communities in which the civilian defense organization would undoubtedly function smoothly and efficiently, James H. Landis, director of the Office of Civilian Defense, said today, but he added:

English children's fear of the "bogeyman" has been replaced by dread of the collapse of an air raid shelter, according to a report on children of Great Britain received here yesterday by Mrs. Edna Blue, executive chairman of the Foster Parents Plan for War Children, 55 West Forty-second Street.

Acting on President Roosevelt's suggestion that parades and flag-waving were better calculated to stimulate labor enthusiasm for the war program than repressive legislation, local labor leaders recommended yesterday that Mayor La Guardia sponsor a parade of A.F. of L. and C.I.O. unionists in this city.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 18 -- Flying through sandstorms that almost obscured their targets, American built Boston bombers have for three successive days struck telling blows at enemy airdromes in Cyrenaica. Defying weather that would have kept many planes grounded, these superfast light bombers struck quickly and got away before Nazi planes or anti-aircraft guns could harm them.

HONOLULU, March 18 -- Dean Grant Darrow, 25-year-old fire-controlman, third class, from Milwaukee, is walking around the Pearl Harbor Naval Hospital with a machine-gun bullet in his heart. He has not undergone medical treatment for his wound but is recuperating from an operation for appendicitis.

ALBANY, March 18 -- A strenuous protest by Mayor La Guardia against the Young bill, creating an adolescents' court in New York City, resulted today in a call by Chairman Reoux of the Assembly Judiciary Committee for a hearing on the measure Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, March, 18 -- Following is the prepared text of the broadcast made tonight by Lord Halifax, British Ambassador:

A large subscription has been reported for the performance of Barrie's "A Kiss for Cinderella" on Monday night at the Music Box Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the Child Education Foundation.

Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday that the city is far from being unprepared for an air raid and he expressed the hope that New Yorkers will show themselves able to "take it, instead of whining and crying."
BERLIN, March 18 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique today said:

LONDON, March 18 -- Professor Julian Huxley, who is lecturing in the United States, is no longer secretary of the Zoological Society. The council took action today to abolish the post because of "financial stringency owing to the war." Professor J.B.S. Haldane and H.G. Wells, among others at the council meeting, expressed astonished dismay at this action.

LONDON, March 18 -- Deputy Prime Minister Clement R. Attlee told the House of Commons today that Lord Beaverbrook was returning to the United States "in order to carry on work he has already begun regarding the pooling of resources between the United Nations, together with such other duties as may be entrusted to him from time to time by the War Cabinet."

YESTERDAY I planned to read Nicholas John Spykman's massively documented "America's Strately in World Politics,"* a book which I had inspected in galley proofs and knew to be a sound pioneer effort to create a native school of geopolitical thought of a caliber sufficient to counter the school founded by the German General Haushofer.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, March 18 -- Japan has rejected a request made by the British Government through the good offices of the Argentine Foreign Ministry for permission to send a Red Cross ship to the Far East with food, clothing and medicines for the English, Canadian and Australian soldiers and civilians taken prisoner in Hong Kong.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 18 -- Aided by a spanking breeze and a conveniently close right-field fence, the Giants and Indians opened their 1942 exhibition series today by peppering each other with homers in most lively fashion.

The United States Steel Corporation broke all production, sales and payroll records in 1941, with steel production for military, naval and other national emergency needs accelerated in every practical way, according to the annual report signed by Irving S. Olds chairman of the board of directors, and issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Plans for new taxation to meet war demands and at the same time prepare the way for later readjustment to peacetime conditions were submitted to the Ways and Means Committee today by two witnesses.

LONDON, March 18 -- A strong force of Japanese has clashed with British forward units south of Kanyutkwin, where the invaders appear to be trying to advance up the main road toward Toungoo, forty miles further north. A communique issued in New Delhi, India, reporting this action, said the Japanese main strength was still south of Taik-kyi.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 18 -Violent public demonstrations to protest the sinking of the Uruguayan ship Montevideo by an Axis submarine continued today both in this capital and throughout the country.

The steel industry appears to be close to the point at which the War Production Board will have to consider allocation of all available ingots to finishing facilities so that Army, Navy, Maritime Commission and lease-lend needs may be met on schedule, according to Iron Age.

Russian troops are now reported fighting in the suburbs of Kharkov. There is an air of expectation in the Russian press, and Moscow hints that the city's "hour of liberation is near." Yet in the last three weeks of heavy fighting there has been no great change in the Russian war map. The Russian and German lines remain approximately where they were. Why, then, would the recovery of a single city be so important?

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Great Britain is sending 80 per cent of its rising war production overseas to guard against expected Axis moves in Russia, the Middle East and elsewhere, Viscount Halifax, the British Ambassador, said tonight.

The boom In stocks inspired on Thursday by the appointment of General Douglas iV[ac_rthur to supreme command in the Southwestern Pacific faded quickly and the markets returned yesterday to their downward course. Prices dropped fractions in the general list, while several issues had large losses.

FLINT, Mich., March 18 -- Buick-built bomber engines for the country's armed forces are being produced this month at the rate originally planned for next December, with production nine months ahead of schedule. Trainload shipments are being made to plane manufacturers.

MEXICO CITY, March 18 -- Today was a national holiday in Mexico in commemoration of the nationalization of the oil industry formerly owned mainly by Americans and Britons. The official Government party, which took the lead in celebrating the day, issued a manifesto calling the expropriation "a historic event for joyous memory" because it involved the nationalization of the subsoil wealth -- which the Supreme Court recently held was unconstitutional.

The International Harvester Company is preparing a registration statement covering not to exceed 250,000 shares of its common stock. Filing of the statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission probably will not take place for several weeks, but it is expected that the registration requirements will be fulfilled in time to permit public distribution of the stock next month.

GENERAL M'ARTHUR'S HEADQUARTERS, in Australia, March 18 -- American front-line troops and air forces have been pouring into Australia for two months, beating back the Japanese invasion vanguard by air and streaming by trainloads to prospective battle stations, it is possible to reveal tonight.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 18 (AP) -- When the history of this war is written, one of the brightest chapters will deal with the transport of men, planes and arms across the dangerous waters of the Pacific -- a remarkable naval achievement.

CANBERRA, Australia, March 18 -- There was little air activity in the North Australian zone yesterday. United Nations aircraft raided Kupang, Netherland Timor. Despite poor visibility hits were scored on an airdrome from 5,000 feet.

WHAT with the national invitation basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden and the Dartmouth-Princeton play-off at the Palestra hard by Franklin Field, basketball, the sport that has been fifty years a-growing, is certainly up there in the headlines.
The more contact you have with the out-of-doors, at least so far as hunting and fishing are concerned the more you realize that hard and fast rules pertaining to these sports are made to be broken.
CAIRO, Egypt, Mach 18 (AP) -British Army headquarters issued this communique today:

LOS ANGELES, March 18 (AP) -- Jeff Cravath, former coaching aide and football star at the University of Southern California and head mentor at San Francisco University last year, was signed today as head football coach at U.S.C.
A continuance of the demand for business quarters in this city was indicated by the latest list of new rentals yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- A complete reversal of the trend of United States trade with Latin America from a net United States export balance during the previous three years to a net import balance in the calendar year 1941 was reported today by the Bureau of the Census.

MOSCOW, March 18 -- News from the central front today suggests that important German forces comprising the Gzhatsk garrison are in a plight similar to that of Nazi units cut off farther north around Staraya Russa.

An audience of 2,100 attended the "Music Festival of Allied Nations,'' which was presented last night at Carnegie Hall for the benefit of the trade-school and workshops of ORT in Leeds, England. The three-hour program was presented by the American ORT Federation and the Labor and Peoples ORT with the assistance of the Inter-Allied Information Committee.

Samuel (Red) Levine, 39 years old, of 30 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn, who, according to Assistant District Attorney Sol Gelb, was the "strong-arm chief" for Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania, the vice-ring leader now serving a long State prison term, was convicted yesterday in General Sessions of perjury before the grand jury in denying he witnessed a hold-up.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The House begins work tomorrow on restrictive labor legislation in disregard of President Roosevelt's opposition and in the face of a warning today by Speaker Rayburn that the war effort is harmed by criticism of labor, management and government.

Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday, in a letter sent by messenger to William Fellowes Morgan Jr., his former Commissioner of Markets, who resigned last December, that he did not intend to cast reflections on Mr. Morgan's integrity in a radio broadcast from City Hall on Jan. 25.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Declining for the first time to pay in cash its $30,000 monthly per capita tax to the Congress of Industrial Organizations, the United Mine Workers of America, headed by John L. Lewis, has reminded the C.I.O. that it owes the miners' union $1,665,000 and has asked that the per capita taxes due in February and March be deducted from this indebtedness.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 18 -- The Title Guarantee and Trust Company of New York and affiliated companies were accused here today before Charles B. Sears, Supreme Court referee, of having formed a dummy corporation in 1933 as a repository for their stock holdings in the Westchester Title and Trust Company of this city, with intent to avoid statutory liability to creditors of the latter concern.

Recent establishment of new industries in the Little Neck-Great Neck area, with the consequent influx of workers and their families, is creating a demand for residential properties, according to Bryce Rea, broker.

Last year the Rockefeller Foundation distributed free of charge 4,260,680 doses of yellow fever vaccine of which 1,938,300 were given to the Army, Navy and public health agencies. This was announced in the annual report of the foundation, made public yesterday by Raymond B. Fosdick, its president.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Committees representing the Army, Navy and the Office of Civilian Defense will soon be established in each of the nine districts into which the country is subdivided by the Army and OCD, James M. Landis, director of the OCD, said today.

Yugoslav Day was observed yesterday afternoon with a reception at "The Street of United Nations," 6 East Fifty-seventh Street, where goods of peoples under Axis domination are being exhibited and sold for the benefit of war victims in prison camps.

The American Cyanamid Company had in 1941 a net income of $6,766,292, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $2.42 a share on the common stock, according to the annual statement of W.B. Bell, president, announced yesterday.

A policy of limiting purchases of fabrics by the ready-to-wear industry to quantities which can be readily merchandised within the current season was urged upon the textile industry yesterday by the Uptown Credit Group of the National Federation of Textiles.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 18 -- Herbert Vere Evatt is on many counts one of the most remarkable figures this dominion has produced. The burly 47-year-old politician is not only in the forefront as Minister for External Affairs, Attorney General and member of the War Cabinet and the War Council, but in his own profession of law he is considered one of Australia's ablest judges.

Marked changes in the physical appearance of books are inevitable, Will Ransom writes in the current issue of Bookbinding and Book Production. Mr. Ransom is cheerful about the prospect, however, although admitting that publishers, designers and readers may be caused some "esthetic heartaches" as they adapt themselves to the changes.

George S. Kaufman, playwright and director, yesterday confirmed an announcement by Warner Brothers that he would go to Hollywood for the studio under a three-way contract as producer, director and writer. Mr. Kaufman will have complete authority over the pictures he makes.

Haydn's oratorio "The Seasons" was performed by the Brooklyn Symphony Orchestra last night at the fifth and final concert of its first season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The work was conducted by Carl Bamberger before a capacity house.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Card rationing of gasoline within a month or six weeks for all consumers in the East Coast area and in Oregon and Washington States was forecast today by Secretary Ickes.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 19 (AP) -- Stockholders of the Standard Oil Company of Kentucky were told today at the annual meeting that the company was "in a sound position to carry on."

The Philharmonic-Symphony concert directed by John Barbirolli last night in Carnegie Hall began with a new arrangement of the Vitali "Chaconne" for organ and strings by Alfonso Gibilaro, who is Mr. Barbirolli's brother-in-law. Robert Bagar, in his program annotation, tells us of the origin of this arrangement:
A special one-day exhibition entitled "Conversation Piece" at the International Flower Show yesterday was a center of attraction for the 30,000 visitors that thronged Grand Central Palace.

LONDON, March 19 (AP) -- The Bank of England's statement, issued today, reported an increase of more than 16,000,000 in private deposits for the week ended on Wednesday and government securities improved almost 9,000,000.

Arguments in the long public utility battle between government and management were brought to the fore again yesterday by Ganson Purcell, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission. Utility holding companies, Mr. Purcell argued in an address in Philadelphia, should proceed promptly with meeting the standards of Section 11 of the Public Utility Holding Company Act; otherwise many of them would face bankruptcy proceedings.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 19 -- Joseph A. Bower, treasurer of the Republican State committee, announced here today he would run in the September primary for the Republican nomination for United States Senator. If nominated he would oppose Senator William H. Smathers, Atlantic County Democrat, who has announced he will run for re-election.
ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 19 (AP) -- Four favored teams were eliminated in the national amateur-professional golf event today when first-round results were in.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- President Roosevelt gave orders today for the registration on April 27 of all males between the ages of 45 and 64, inclusive, in the United States and its territories in another move to mobilize the country's man power "to insure victory, final and complete, over the enemies of the United States."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 19 -- News of the recent visit of Field Marshal Erwin Rommel to Reichsfuehrer Hitler's headquarters on the Eastern Front, as revealed by the latest German newsreel released this week in Berlin, gave rise to speculation there tonight that the much-heralded German Spring offensive may have the Suez as one of its principal aims so that Germany and Japan may join hands across India.

The three-story apartment house containing twenty-four suites at 361 Madison Street, Passaic, N.J., has been sold by the Investors Mortgage and Realty Company to the Able Management Corporation, subject to a new first mortgage arranged by the New Jersey Realty Company.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 19 (U.P.) -- Intricate details of an Irish Republican Army plot -- possibly Nazi-inspired -- to determine the strength and disposition of British and American forces in Northern Ireland and other military secrets were revealed in Special Court today.

"Woman of the Year," Metro's Katharine Hepburn-Spencer Tracy vehicle, which completed a record six-week run at the Radio City Music Hall on Wednesday night, recorded a total of 754,799 paid admissions over that period, it was learned yesterday.

A plan for emergency allocation of coal supplies for use "if and when it is needed," is being formulated by government and industry experts, Howard Gray, acting director of Solid Fuels Coordination, said here last night. Addressing the "United for Victory" convention of the solid fuel industry at the Hotel Astor, Mr. Gray said:

PHILADELPHIA, March 19 -- Public utility holding companies were urged today by Ganson Purcell, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, to take advantage of statutory provisions for recapitalizing in order to gird for the stresses and strains which will be placed upon them as the war effort continues.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 19 -- Smoky Joe Wood, one-time big league pitching ace who tutored Eli baseball teams for two decades, received his dismissal notice from Yale today. This wartime economy move at the same time eliminated two other coaching positions.

Sam Brier, 37 years old, of 1023 Avenue St. John, the Bronx, a race horse tipster according to the police, who has customers all over the country to whom he gives sure winners, at 2 P.M. yesterday looked over the index cards of his clients. He selected one and then walked into a stationery store at 149tJ Street and Prospect Avenue, the Bronx.

A loan exhibition of paintings and sculpture to aid the United China Relief and the British and Russian War Relief Societies will open at the Demotte Gallery next Thursday. The works have been lent by stage, screen and radio personalities.

LONDON, March 19 -- The second phase of the Burma campaign, following the fall of Rangoon, appeared to be developing rapidly today with the Japanese making a fierce attempt to drive northward by two routes. The first of these follows the Sittang River toward Toungoo, 190 miles below Mandalay.

PALM BEACH, March 19 -- Colonel and Mrs. William Hayward had as their dinner guests tonight at the Everglades Club Mr. and Mrs. Aksel Wichfeld, Mr. and Mrs. Claude K. Boettcher, Mr. and Mrs. Harold W. Brooks and Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Holmesen.

Yesterday's weekly statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total bills discounted for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date. Holdings of United States Government securities decreased $4,250,000.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- More government executives including Donald M. Nelson, War Production Board chairman, and Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, appeared on capitol hill today to oppose enactment of legislation to suspend premium overtime payments for labor beyond the forty-hour week and outlaw the closed shop for the duration of the war.

Among the steps taken to increase the production of Thunderbolt pursuit planes, as the P-47 model of the Republic Aviation Corporation is called, the company has made the design available to other aircraft producers at the request of the government and has expanded both its plant facilities and its subcontracting arrangements, according to the annual report signed by W. Wallace Kellett, chairman of the board.

Bank clearings for twenty-three leading cities of the country for the week ended on Wednesday established a new peak for this year at $7,929,673,000, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. This represents an increase of 24.5 per cent over the $6,369,250,000 reported in the preceding week and 10.3 per cent more than the $7,187,506,000 for the corresponding week last year.

The problems of Summer theatre operators and the prospects for the season will be discussed by operators from all over the country who will meet here Wednesday and Thursday, April 15 and 16, under the auspices of the Summer Stock Managers Association.

John P. Kennedy, held as a material witness by the District Attorney's office since last Summer, testified yesterday before General Sessions Judge Wallace and a jury that a group of defendants charged with conspiracy and extortion had smashed trucks and soured the milk of independent milk dealers after they had decided to "move in" and take charge of the Council of Independent Milk Dealers.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Secretary Stimson told reporters this morning, that his recent tour of the Canal Zone had demonstrated that there was an alien problem connected with defense there. The problem, he said, is not so great as that posed in the defense of Hawaii, and it has, he continued, "been very well handled by the Panamaian Government already."
HERE, in a book called "The Itching Parrot,"* is another treasure found, so to speak, in a trunk. Or at least it must seem so to an Anglo-Saxon reader.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 19 -- Berlin dispatches received here today confirmed earlier reports that Reichsfuehrer Hitler has recalled virtually all the field marshals and other army commanders ousted "for reasons of health" during the "generals' crisis" last December.

Inasmuch as Catholic Charities constitutes "an intrinsic part of our country's war effort," Bishop J. Francis A. McIntyre, Chancellor of the New York Archdiocese, intimated yesterday to campaign workers that they need not apologize when asking for contributions to their 1942 fund appeal.

Investments in mortgages on Manhattan real estate declined last month in number and dollar volume from the previous month and for the year to date are far below the totals for comparable periods of the five preceding years, except that of 1938.

Torpedoing and sinking of the 5,042-ton Yugoslav freighter Trepca in the United States Atlantic waters, with four of her crew killed and thirty-three rescued after drifting three days in open liftboats, was announced yesterday by the Navy Department.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 19 -- Augie Galan, handyman of the Dodgers, played first base today, because Dolph Camilli has a sore left arm, and contributed largely to the 4-2 victory over the Cardinals.

LAKE WALES, Fla., March 19 -- Joe DiMaggio played his first game of the year against the Kansas City Blues, Charley Keller romped around left field, Tiny Bonham did his first five-inning chore, his longest pitching stint since he turned back the Dodgers in the fifth and last game of the world series last year, and still the Yanks could not win today.

All aliens, including enemy aliens, are to be reclassified by their draft boards forthwith, Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, New York City Director of Selective Service, announced yesterday. Colonel McDermott said that he had received instructions from Brig. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, National Director of Selective Service, for this action.

For the first time in local labor history rival A.F. of L. and C.I.O. unions have agreed to negotiate jointly with employers for a uniform collective bargaining contract covering 5,000 workers employed in the manufacture of electrical wiring devices, it became known yesterday when Mayor La Guardia invited all the parties to meet with him at City Hall April 4 to begin the negotiations.
NEW DELHI, India, March 19 (AP) -- British headquarters in Burma issued the following communique today:

MONTREAL, March 19 (AP) -- Montreal's Canadiens, who barely squeezed into the six-team Stanley Cup play-offs of the National Hockey League, closed the regular season tonight by turning back the second-place Toronto Maple Leafs, 7 to 3.

DETROIT, March 19 -- The U.A.W. is seeking a flat $1 a day wage increase and further increases every ninety days based on a cost of living index, in negotiations which open tomorrow with General Motors.

The Architectural League of New York awarded prizes for small sculpture and for architectural rendering last night at the private opening of an exhibition at its clubhouse at 115 East Fortieth Street. Ninety-three examples were entered in the competition.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 19 -Chile is drafting a note to the United States in connection with the sinking of the Chilean ship Tolten by an Axis submarine off the United States coast, it was learned tonight. There were reports the note would serve formal notice that Chilean ships hereafter would sail with lights on regardless of orders by any foreign power.

The Man Who Would Be King was no small potatoes. The Man Who Wouldn't Be a Duke looks greater, rarer, choicer. Major Lord James Stewart-Murray, brother of and heir to the late Duke of Atholl, objects to being a Duke. He looks modest in the British Who's Who.

Irving T. Bush, president of the Bush Terminal Company, informed stockholders in the annual report that he will recommend to directors at the March meeting that four quarterly dividends on the preferred stock, now in arrears, be declared, to be paid in April, and that the balance of the accumulated dividends be liquidated as promptly as the finances of the company permit.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- Secretary Stimson gave War Department approval today to "pre-induction" training of men in colleges and local communities, but stressed that additional military equipment and instructors could not be spared from the armed forces for that purpose.

LONDON, March 19 (AP) -- Radio stations in unoccupied France continued today to report huge Japanese invasion forces moving toward Western and Eastern Australia in a gigantic naval and aerial pincers, but the reports lacked confirmation from any other sources.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Clear sailing was indicated in the Senate today for House-approved legislation authorizing the creation of a women's army auxiliary corps of 150,000 volunteer members.

A system of compulsory rationing of gasoline by means of ration cards is to be instituted in the East and Pacific Northwest, according to Petroleum Coordinator Ickes. Since it has apparently become necessary to limit gasoline consumption in these areas, this is a wise move.

If this war is lost, it will be lost by the bureaucrats and politicians in Washington who spend their time and energy fighting each other instead of the common foe, Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase of New York University declared last night at the seventy-fifth anniversary dinner of the New York University College of Dentistry, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Leo Durocher, manager of the Brooklyn Dodgers baseball team, has leased residential quarters in the building at 46 E. 61st St., according to Duff Conger, Inc., agents.

A major cast replacement will be made in Irving Caesar's conception of "My Dear Public" before the musical arrives at the Broadhurst on Thursday night, April 2. Mitzi Green is relinquishing the leading feminine role because she feels she is unsuited for the part, it was said.

A new 1942 high is marked by the current week's engineering construction awards, which also are the second highest on record, according to The Engineering News-Record. The volume of $273,702,000 is more than double that of last week and 206 per cent above the figure for the corresponding week of last year.

CHICAGO, March 19 -- Formation of a national association of race track operators, which had failed to materialize after all previous attempts, came today as the first apparent result of the three-day meeting of the American Racing Congress.

The general executive board of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, whose three former leaders, George E. Browne, William Bioff and Nick Dean, are now in jail for racketeering, has adopted a constitutional provision prohibiting former convicts from holding office, it was disclosed yesterday.

WITH THE UNITED STATES FORCES, in Australia, March 19 -- With the lifting of the censorship ban on the mention of the United States forces in Australia, one Melbourne newspaper has printed an open letter to hostesses to give advice on how to entertain the "Yanks."

A referendum in which 8,000 members of Phi Delta Kappa, American educators' national honor fraternity, cast ballots, disclosed that 60 per cent of the membership favors admitting men of any race, it was revealed yesterday in letters sent by the national executive council's offices in Chicago to the heads of the ninety-one chapters.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The surplus fats and greases from American kitchens are to be gathered and sent to rendering plants for processing into glycerine and the fatty acids which make soap. The collection drive, which will be a nation-wide campaign, will be a commercial venture under government sponsorship, it is understood.

CHUNGKING, China, March 19 (U.P.) -- Japanese troops have seized Siangshan, Chekiang Province coastal port about 120 miles southeast of Shanghai, a Chinese military spokesman acknowledged today, but, he said, they face an impossible task if they hope to seize all the innumerable other coastal bases for United Nations air and sea raids on their homeland and Formosa.

Declaring that the principal battlefield of this war is that for American opinion, Archibald MacLeish, director of the Office of Facts and Figures, made a slashing attack last night on American "divisionists" and "defeatists," who, he charged, care more for their private hatreds than for their country.

In one of the most thrilling city P.S.A.L. senior high finals ever staged, Andrew Jackson High turned back a scrappy Erasmus Hall five, 27 -- 25, at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon. The Hickories accomplished their task the hard way and it was a lad who answers to the name of Ken Haggerty who brought to the Queens school its first city basketball championship.

A Federal court jury, after deliberating for six hours last night, convicted ten members of the "Manfredonia-Lapadura bootleg syndicate" and acquitted two other defendants of conspiracy to defraud the government out of $1,600,000 in alcohol taxes.

In the course of a recording session with the NBC Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon, Arturo Toscanini took time out to make a recording of "The Star-Spangled Banner." Mr. Toscanini asked that his royalties be turned over to the Red Cross.

Careful preparation on the part of the Treasury and the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, in setting the financial stage so that the money market would not be disrupted by the record-making quarterly tax collections, were reflected in the banking figures released yesterday for the week ended on Wednesday.
BERLIN, March 19 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:
MOSCOW, March 19 (AP) -- The !kIazis are counter-attacking on virtually every front in desperately futile efforts to rescue trapped troops and stem theRussian advance, the Red Army reported tonight.

The fight between John L. Lewis and left wing union leaders in the Congress for Industrial Organization for control of local unions resulted last night in a switch of a building service local from the United Construction Workers, headed by A.W. Lewis, brother of the mine union chief, to the National Maritime Union, headed by Joseph Curran.

After two days of relatively active trading, the cotton market turned quiet again yesterday with important commitments checked by the lack of conclusive outside developments. On the New York Cotton Exchange, prices of active futures moved within a 6-point range and finished at levels unchanged to 3 points lower than the previous close.

The effort to liberalize military specifications in the production of war goods is the outstanding step in the joint program announced yesterday by the War Production Board and the War Department to slash red tape, business men declared.

M.J. Carlson is absolutely right; it is time the facts about those Amritsar riots were better known in this country. Since we are in agreement on this, I know that Mr. Carlson will find the following lines very interesting:

Stocks idled yesterday in a session lacking any exciting elements and with the smallest volume since last June. Except for a few isolated large losses, fractional changes ruled throughout the list. Selling was not pressing, neither was there any spirit to the demand, and the market acted more like a Saturday performance than a five-hour day.

As authors have a way of doing, Gladys Schmitt started young -- when she was all of 7. Her first novel was being poured out at 15, but after 300 pages the young author noticed that her "style" had undergone a change midway in the manuscript.
In an editorial of March 11 this newspaper declared:

LONDON, March 19 -- Prime Minister Churchill announced today the appointment of Richard G. Casey, Australian Minister to the United States, as a Minister of State to represent the War Cabinet in the Middle East, with headquarters in Cairo.

The upset epidemic in the national invitation basketball tournament felled City College, startling 17,860 spectators in Madison Square Garden last night. The Beavers, third seeded team, followed L.I.U. and West Texas State, the two top-ranking ones, to the exits in an unceremonious departure.
THERE is to be a fight tonight at Madison Square Garden between Ray Robinson and Norman Rubio and this observer just happened to mention it when John Golden, the theatrical producer, cut in sharply:

The transfer of General Douglas MacArthur to Australia and the reiterated suggestion of Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Ambassador, for the establishment of a second front in Europe heightened the anticipation yesterday of many who have been urging that the United Nations mount an immediate offensive.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 19 -- Priscilla Lane and George Brent will be starred by Paramount in "Silver Queen," the story of a woman gambler, by Forrest Halsey and William Allen Johnston, which the studio first announced two years ago.

Homer Lea's prophesying wasn't confined to the Japanese nor to his book "the Valor of Ignorance," which was reviewed on this page yesterday. After he wrote that book of warning and gloom in 1909 he was invited to England by Field Marshal Lord Roberts and to Germany by Kaiser Wilhelm.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The State Department was requested today by a Jewish delegation calling upon Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary, to use its good offices with the British Government to bring about a modification of the policies of the Palestine administration with regard to admitting Jewish refugees to Palestine.
DETROIT, March 19 (AP) -- The Red Wings continued their mastery on home ice tonight by defeating the fourth-place Black Hawks, 6 to 4, in their final game of the National Hockey League season.

Spring arrives this week-end. It will find the feminine population buying new bonnets, the young fry purchasing myriads of marbles and the butchers of the city transacting business much as they did a week ago. The change of season has had but an imperceptible effect on retail meat prices, according to the latest report from the Consumers Service Bureau of the Department of Markets.

The appointment of ten leading industrialists and two labor leaders as national group chairmen in the campaign to obtain funds for the Navy Relief Society was announced yesterday by Clarence Dillon, chairman of the National Citizens Committee.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- A declaration that the government should use "$1-a-year-men" as consultants on industrial conversion problems but not permit them to give orders or determine policies, particularly on subjects affecting their own industries, was made today by Robert R. Guthrie before a House Military Affairs subcommittee.

The flared skirt, flattering to both the slim and the plump of womankind, appeared in volume yesterday in the Spring collection of day and evening clothes produced by Anna Nelson, head of Nelson-Hickson, Inc., 9 West Fifty-seventh Street.

The impact of the Public Utility Holding Company Act on the North American Company, the nation's second largest holding company, has been such as to necessitate an accelerated debt reduction program and has "imposed" a disadvantage on the company's common stockholders, Edward L. Shea, president, asserted yesterday in his 1941 annual report to stockholders.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- The Navy reported today that James Irving Thompson, chief boatswain's mate, and Carmin Debello, fireman second class, had been commended for "coolness and bravery of the highest degree" in attempting to rescue a shipmate from drowning at the Naval Mine Warfare School, Yorktown, Va., on the night of July 31, 1941.

How an Axis submarine lighted its own way to destruction was told here yesterday by members of the crew of a venerable American freighter that may claim the distinction of being the first United States merchantman to sink an enemy undersea boat in this war.

Occasionally, and as it were by the laws of chance, even Hitler speaks the truth, or something that comes near to being true. He has said that the Winter in Russia was the worst in 140 years. As an excuse for his failure in Russia, this does not go too far.

RIOM, France, March 19 -- In contending before the Supreme Court today that high officers of the French Army had not appreciated the value of aviation in warfare, Edouard Daladier, a former Premier, cited a preface written by Marshal Henri Philippe Petain to a book by Colonel Narcisse Chauvineau entitled "Is an Invasion Still Possible?" and published in 1939.

CHICAGO, March 19 -- Scattered liquidation developed today in the wheat market, due mainly to sympathy with rye and corn and reports indicating that about $3,000,000 acres of volunteer wheat might be left for harvest as a result of a recent change in a Department of Agriculture program.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Germany is expected in both Washington and London to start a drive within the next five weeks to make a junction with the forces of Japan. The Japanese now possess the rubber, tin and oil resources that the Nazi war machine lacks to a critical extent.

For many weeks I have read the newspapers carefully and ruefully to see if I could discover any trend toward simplification in the OCD-Congress disputes. Also I have had occasion to see behind the scenes in certain New York City welfare organizations. May I suggest a possible method of simplification.

ALBANY, March 19 -- Governor Lehman vetoed today, as unsound and political, two bills which would have permitted the payment of the State income tax in four equal installments this year and next year. Instead, he proposed a four installment plan of his own, effective next year, which he challenged the Republican-controlled Legislature to accept.

UNITED STATES ARMY HEADQUARTERS, in Australia, March 19 -- General Douglas MacArthur announced today that his plans for conduct of the war in the Southwest Pacific were already being put into operation. The announcement was made through Brig. Gen. Patrick J. Hurley, United States Minister to New Zealand and former Secretary of War, under whom General MacArthur served as Chief of Staff.
CANBERRA, Australia, March 19 (U.P.) -- Prime Minister John Curtin, aroused from his bed to hear of Richard G. Casey's London appointment, said the matter was "purely a personal one to Casey."

M.M. Freeman Co., Inc., of Philadelphia received the award yesterday of an issue of $211,000 of sewer and library bonds of the city of Paterson, N.J., on a bid of 100.173 for 1.90s. The bonds, dated March 1, 1942, will mature serially from March 1, 1943, to 1960.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Coordination of the programs of all existing agencies concerned with the well-being of children and young persons, in harmony with the principles approved in conference by the Commission on Children in War Time, will be the continuing obligation of the commissioners, under a plan of operations made public today.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Jonathan M. Wainwright, new commander in chief of American and Filipino forces in the Philippine Islands, today became a Lieutenant General, when the Senate confirmed immediately action by President Roosevelt in promoting him from his former rank of Major General.

ALBANY, March 19 -- A bill designed to eliminate present practices of some retail merchants in which they seek to sell their goods to the public by giving the impression that they are allowing consumers "wholesale" prices was introduced in the Legislature by Senator Feinberg, Plattsburg Republican, and Assemblyman Delany, Manhattan Democrat.

PITTSBURGH, March 19 -- The Weirton Steel Company established plant committees today to work with representatives of the Weirton Independent Union to speed production of vital war materials. The action is believed to be the first taken by a major unit of the country's steel industry in response to the appeal of Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 19 -- While Nicholas von Kallay, the new Hungarian Premier, was outlining his government's program to the lower house in Budapest today, Michael Antonescu, the Rumanian marshal's brother and acting Foreign Minister, brought up the question of Transylvania in the crowded assembly hall of the Bucharest Law Faculty.

GUATEMALA, March 19 -- United States bombing planes, ready for any eventuality, now are carrying out important patrols in defense of Central America and the Panama Canal from an air base "somewhere in Guatemala."

Ray Robinson, the Harlem welterweight who possesses the most imposing record in the boxing realm, will seek to extend his string of successes tonight when he boxes Norman Rubio, sturdy Schenectady battler, at Madison Square Garden. The fight is listed for twelve rounds, and Promoter Mike Jacobs is confident that it will attract a crowd of more than 10,000 fans.

Warning that "unemployment of enormous proportions" faces the women's garment industry in this city as a result of the war, the International Ladies Garment Workers Union urged yesterday that Federal procurement policies be revised to guarantee "a fair and adequate share of defense production" for New York garment factories.

The last of the seventy-seven loft and store units in the twelve-story Fur Center Building at 104 West Twenty-ninth Street has been leased by Chanin Management, Inc., to Lemkin Furs, Inc., and soon will be occupied by that concern.

The Pullman Company, subsidiary of Pullman, Inc., has sold to the railroads for rebuilding into vehicles for soldiers and munitions workers almost all the parlor cars no longer required for Pullman travel, David A. Crawford, president of Pullman, Inc., said in his report for 1941, issued yesterday.

The position which the Roman Catholic Church of St. Andrew, Cardinal Hayes Place and Duane Street, holds as a site of international fame and as a memorial to Patrick Cardinal Hayes, whose birthplace occupied a part of the site, was stressed yesterday on the one hundredth anniversary of its dedication.

LONDON, March 19 -- In an out-of-the-way corner in the Information Ministry is Sir John Russell, one of Britain's foremost authorities on agriculture, preparing a schedule of what Russia and Middle Europe will need when the war is over.

PORTLAND, Ore., March 19 -- There is no prospect of an agricultural labor shortage this year in the war-zone area State of Oregon, according to the women; if the men are not available to pick the beans and berries and hops and dig the potatoes, the women say they will.

Retail credit collections showed an increase of 0.48 per cent in February, compared with the same month last year, according to the twenty local store index issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York. Ten of the reporting stores had increased collections for the month.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 19 -- The military reverses of the United Nations during the past six weeks have brought about a decline of public confidence in Winston Churchill throughout England, and in President Roosevelt throughout the United States.

Transfers of New York Stock Exchange seats from the late Claude C. Pinney to Carl M. Loeb and from Oliver D. Filley to L. Raymond Billett have been approved. On April 2 the board will consider transfers from Rawson G. Lizars to A.A. Mol for $21,000 and from the late Howard Crosby Foster to William B. Anderson for $20,000.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The Uruguayan Government informed the United States in a note from its Foreign Minister, Dr. Alberto Guani, dated yesterday and made public today by the State Department, that as soon as all the facts were assembled it would present the case of the sinking of the Uruguyan merchant ship Montevideo by an Axis submarine to the Pan American Union for "appropriate action."

Charles Brinton of Princeton University won the unofficial squash racquets championship of the United States yesterday, when he turned back Lester Cummings, national professional champion, in a benefit match for the Red Cross at the University Club.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Establishment of a more direct connection between war industry on this continent and front-line needs everywhere was urged on President Roosevelt, Donald M. Nelson and Army and Navy leaders here last week by Lieut. Gen. Andrew McNaughton, commander of the Canadian forces in Great Britain, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- Archibald MacLeish, director of the Office of Facts and Figures, announced today that Malcolm Cowley had resigned from its writers' staff because of "a desire that the wartime work of OFF should not be impeded as the result of charges of radicalism" made against Mr. Cowley.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The American Federation of Labor sent to the Ways and Means Committee today its tax program, which included the recommendation that "surplus income of individuals and corporations should be taxed heaviest."

FULTON, N.Y., March 19 -Between 500 and 600 members of the Fulton Local 54, International Brotherhood of Pulp, Sulphite and Papermill Workers, (A.F.L.) voted at a meeting tonight to continue a strike against the Oswego Falls plant of the Sealright Corporation, maker of paper containers.
Mayor La Guardia distributed the $86,750 proceeds of the annual Police-Fire baseball game yesterday to the relief funds of the two departments and a list of special charities.
Plans have been completed for a luncheon bridge to be held April 7 at Sherry's in aid of the McMahon Memorial Temporary Shelter. Mrs. Ashley T. Cole heads the arrangements committee.

Governor Lehman informed the Citizens Union last night that he had rejected its request that he supersede District Attorney Samuel J. Foley of the Bronx in the investigation of the use of 8,000 city-owned paving blocks, laid by city employes to improve the country home of Edward J. Flynn at Mahopac, N.Y.

Declaring that maintenance of production was the "over-all concern" in the event of enemy bombings, James M. Landis, director of the Office of Civilian Defense, said yesterday his office would insist that no air raid alarms be given until bombers actually are overhead.

Warren Schlickenrieder, 20 years old, a junior at Manhattan College, of 2042 Blackrock Avenue, the Bronx, takes problems in his civil engineering course seriously. Yesterday he went down to the East River at the foot of Castle Hill Avenue, the Bronx, to get specimens of mud for a classroom problem involving the weight-bearing qualities of certain types of mud.

On the silver screen -- in dramas of intrigue and espionage -- it is possible for long-nailed, languorous ladies to play a dramatic and significant part in the war. In the actual, practical pursuit of freedom and the "American way of life" this unfortunately is not the case.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Friday, March 20 -- Messages from Port Moresby, New Guinea, said yesterday that the Japanese had found a fifth column in New Guinea among German Lutheran missionaries from Finschhafen, near Lae, recently established capital 65 miles north of Salamaua, whence the enemy is advancing along the Markham River valley, led by missionaries.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Largely as a result of higher prices for live stock and for clothing, the general level of wholesale prices continued to advance during the week ended on March 14, reaching the highest level since September, 1928, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

William M. Holmes, president of Bonwit Teller, Inc., announced in the annual report mailed to stockholders yesterday that sales for the year ended on Jan. 31, 1942, increased to the record volume of $10,547,363 from $9,887,824 reported for the preceding fiscal year.

Representatives of the county committees of the Republican, Democratic and American Labor parties placed fifty-seven of their Assembly District headquarters at the disposal yesterday of civilian defense, the Red Cross and other agencies.

Gasoline dealer organizations in the metropolitan area and other districts along the Eastern seaboard expressed themselves yesterday as opposing the card rationing system for gasoline deliveries, as announced by Secretary Ickes in Washington.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 19 -- The Giants, who have been conducting a sort of good-will tour among the rival camps along Florida's west coast the last few days, brought their expedition to a close today by gayly tossing off a game to the Senators, 4 to 3.

The definite trend to large-size packages which started two years ago has received greater impetus as a result of war developments, such as tire and gasoline rationing and shortage of tin and other packaging materials, it was pointed out yesterday in merchandising circles.

LONDON, March 19 -- Symbolizing the esteem in which the United States Navy is held by the British people and their thankfulness that the powerful United States Fleet is ranged alongside the Royal Navy in the war, British naval officials joined with a large gathering of civilians in paying final tribute to the first United States Navy enlisted man to be killed in London in this war.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that the cotton-spinning industry operated during February at 135.9 per cent of capacity on a two-shift, eighty-hour week basis, compared with 136.9 per cent during January, this year, and 115.4 per cent during February, last year.

Having thoroughly surveyed all cost factors in the manufacture of newsprint, officials of the Office of Price Administration will meet today with members of the Canadian Wartime Controls and Price Board in Ottawa to establish a joint ceiling price for newsprint for the second quarter of the year, it was learned here yesterday.

Seeking to minimize traffic hazards at the northerly end of Union Square, Borough President Edgar J. Nathan Jr. of Manhattan submitted a plan to the Board of Estimate yesterday featuring a parking area in Seventeenth Street between Union Square West and Union Square East.

This is the time of the season when skiers doff windbreakers and shirts for sun-tan sport at the higher elevations of the Catskills, Adirondacks, Green and White Mountains and the Laurentians. Although skiing is associated with the cold weather, some of the finest running is available in the Spring, when brilliant sunshine during the day and freezes at night give a "sugar" or "corn" surface to the snow.
DETROIT, March 19 -- The General Motors Corporation suggested today to the United Automobile Workers (C.I.O.) that the negotiations for a new contract which begin tomorrow be open to the press.
CANBERRA, Australia, March 19 (AP) -- An Australian communique said today:

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- A bill to establish a Women's Auxiliary Reserve in the Navy, identical with the Maas bill presented to the House yesterday, was introduced in the Senate today by Senator Willis of Indiana.

Governor Lehman and Mayor La Guardia have written to John W. Hanes, chairman of the 1942 campaign of the Greater New York Fund, endorsing the campaign to raise $5,000,000 to support 400 voluntary welfare and health agencies in the city.

By midnight tonight all members of Actors Equity who take seriously the so-called "isms," or anti-Red amendment, which would bar Communists, Nazis and Fascists from membership, will have cast their votes. The polls close at that time and at 10 A.M. tomorrow tellers will start counting the ballots.

The adjectives "pro-labor" and "anti-labor," as recently used by some professional labor leaders, and thoughtlessly parroted in other quarters, have acquired some queer connotations. By some strange twist of logic, people will now even be found denouncing as "anti-labor" legislative proposals whose principal object is to protect the laborer from exploitation by unscrupulous union officials.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 19 -- Mrs. Dorothy Black Milligan of Harrison, who was convicted March 10 by a jury here of having killed a child through negligent driving of an automobile, was sentenced today by County Judge Frank H. Coyne to serve two to four years in State Prison, but the sentence was suspended and she was placed on probation.
The annual report of the Brunswick-Balke-Collender Company and its subsidiaries, announced yesterday, shows net sales last year at $20,796,823 against $16,901,234 in 1940.

BERLIN, March 19 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press in New York) -- The German Government cut the normal civilian rations of bread, fats and meat today and pinned its promise of return to fatted days on retention of "food space" in the East (Russia) and increased production elsewhere in Europe.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- In the proper and necessary pursuit of its functions as a coordinate branch of the government, Congress is constantly calling the heads of the executive branch to appear before its committees and subcommittees. During wartime, when policy and procedural disputes increase in proportion to the size and immediacy of the war problems, these required appearances become much more frequent.

The official arrival of Spring tomorrow is accented by large shipments of seasonal flowers being received in the New York flower markets. Nearly 20,000 bunches of daffodils are arriving daily, while a great increase in iris shipments from North Carolina also is noted.
Harry D. Gideonse, president of Brooklyn College, has been reappointed for the year ending June 30, 1943, by the Board of Higher Education, it was made public yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 19 -- Charles B. Sears, Supreme Court referee presiding at the trial of a $2,000,000 suit here against 500 stockholders of the defunct Westchester Title and Trust Company, said today he would approve offers by two defendants to make eighty-five per cent settlements of the claims against them.
Investments in loft buildings in Manhattan continued yesterday to feature realty trading.

Owners of all dwelling places and business establishments in the city will be required to install equipment to protect their premises against incendiary damage resulting from air raids under the terms of a local law to be introduced in the City Council on Tuesday, it was learned yesterday.

LONDON, Friday, March 20 (AP) -- General Douglas MacArthur's escape by speedboat and plane from the Philippines to take supreme command in Australia "will make any story of the war hitherto written look pale by comparison," The News Chronicle's correspondent with the United States troops reported today.

The first of a series of large-scale blackouts to prepare New York City against the possibilities of an enemy air raid was held at 9 P.M. last night along the twelve-mile city coastline bordering on the Atlantic Ocean from Sea Gate at the western end of Coney Island to the Nassau County border at Far Rockaway.

NEW DELHI, India, March 19 -- A general outline of Sir Stafford Cripps's mission, as reflected in the growing list of those who invited to meet him, began taking shape today as one organization after another announced its intention of holding sessions during the period immediately following most of his appointments.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- A War Department communique, based on reports received up to 10 A.M. Eastern wartime today, said:

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Adoption of some variation of the Canadian system for establishing price differentials to cover cost differences in the manufacture of uniforms in different localities, has been recommended to the War Production Board's division of purchases, it was learned here today.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. announced today that he would wait until July 1 to determine whether the voluntary sale of defense savings bonds had been a failure and whether some compulsory scheme should be substituted.

Continued Japanese military successes in the Far East have made further increases necessary in war-risk cargo rates, and following on last week-end's upward revision of rates for Western Hemisphere ports, marine underwriters yesterday announced new schedules with the Australasia and India areas principally affected.

Dr. Gustav Stolper emphasized a point that is all too often forgotten in his letter to THE TIMES of March 15 -- the function of war taxation is not only to raise revenue but to effect such a redistribution of the resources of the country as to effect a balance between civilian supply and civilian purchasing power.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- On recommendation of General Douglas MacArthur, Secretary Stimson suggested to Congress today that legislation be enacted raising the pay of officers and enlisted men in the Philippine Scouts and the Philippine Commonwealth Army to the level for the United States Army.

CHICAGO, March 19 -- Montgomery Ward Co., mail-order and retail merchandisers, reported today a net profit of $22,351,716 for the year ended on Jan. 31 after provision of a $5,000,000 reserve for possible future inventory price decline.

For some time the organized sportsmen of this area have been puzzled as to the reason and purpose of an organization known as the Emergency Conservation Committee of New York, but those who will take the trouble to read the annual report of this group will no longer find the purpose hidden.
MANDALAY, Burma, March 19 -- Forty-three American former taxi and truck drivers are patrolling thousands of miles of road in Upper Burma, salvaging hundreds of lease-lend vehicles.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- President Roosevelt proclaimed April 27 as Registration Day under the Selective Service Act for all men between the ages of 45 and 64, inclusive. He sent to the Senate the nomination of Major Gen. Jonathan M. Wainright to be a lieutenant general.

Six men, five of them officers and members of the crew of the Greek steamship Stavros, were arraigned as smugglers yesterday in the Federal Building, in Brooklyn, before United States Commissioner Martin C. Epstein. The defendants were charged with violation of a Presidential proclamation barring the export of platinum.
Let your fur coat be in keeping with your suit and your uniform -- this is Jaeckel's message for Spring. In its first war collection, this house stresses simple furs.

Consolidated gross operating income for 1941 reached a new high level at $46,194,088, compared with $34,570,748 in 1940, William G. Skelly, president of the Skelly Oil Company reported to stockholders in the twenty-second annual statement issued for publication today.

TRENTON, N.J., March 19 (AP) -- Charles Quinn, president of the State Board of Tax Appeals, said today in an opinion that "while States may not levy a tax in any form upon United States securities, they may tax the shares of stock of banks and of other corporations whose assets consist, in whole or in part, of such securities."
MOSCOW, March 19 -- Information from the fronts available here today remains in the brighter vein that has characterized the news for the last few days.

LONDON, March 19 -- Home Secretary Herbert Morrison announced in the House of Commons today that the government had warned the often ill-mannered and generally raucus London Daily Mirror it must mend its ways or it would be suppressed under the defense regulations.

A fine of $5,700 -- believed to be the largest ever imposed for violation of the Multiple Dwelling Law -- was levied yesterday by Magistrate Raphael R. Murphy against the Stone State Realty Corporation of 1320 Madison Avenue, owner of the old five-story, twelve-family tenement house at 354 West 119th Street.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Establishment of an agency to resettle aliens moved from military zones on the West Coast and a plan to Americanize loyal Japanese, Germans and Italians in this group were urged upon Congress today in a report by the Tolan committee which investigated the evacuations and migrant problems.

LONDON, March 19 -- The stock markets today saw prices remain firm but the approach of warships week and an announcement on the budget kept business quiet. Gilt-edge issues were steady and home rail prior charges were better.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 19 -- A walkout today of about 1,000 "graveyard shift" workers was adjusted this evening at the Todd California Shipyard in near-by Richmond and the men waited to return to their jobs of building cargo ships for Great Britain.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- The Senate completed Congressional action on the second war powers bill today by agreeing to elimination of compensation benefits for civilian defense workers, such as air raid wardens, who are injured while on duty.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Continuing to show large increases over a year ago, department store sales during the week ended March 14 were 24 per cent above the corresponding week of 1941, following an increase in the previous week of 28 per cent, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

No estimate of the military situation can be accurate which fails to take into account the full effects of the British blockade of the European Continent. Until June of last year the British blockade (the application of which did so much to win the First World War for the Allies) was reduced in effectiveness by Russia's economic cooperation with Hitler.

The annual reviews of the Rockefeller Foundation, prepared by its president, Mr. Raymond Fosdick, have always been more than records of work accomplished. They are documents of the highest social importance. Though they have expressed their loathing of totalitarianism and its blighting effect on original thinking, they breathe no hate.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 19 -- America's $60,000,000 annual brush business is threatened with virtual extinction by war priorities and frozen shipping, more than 200 delegates to the twenty-fifth annual convention of the American Brush Manufacturers Association were told today at sessions at the Hotel Traymore.

A grand jury handed up a first-degree murder indictment yesterday against an obscure actress college graduate and three men in the strangling of Mrs. Susan Flora Reich, 52-year-old Polish refugee, in a suite in the Hotel Sutton during a robbery on March 5.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- During the week ended March 18 member bank reserve balances decreased $29,000,000. Reductions in member bank reserves arose from an increase of $67,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts and a decrease of $23,000,000 in gold stock, offset in part by decreases of $46,000,000 in money in circulation and $8,000,000 in Treasury cash and increases of $4,000,000 in Reserve Bank credit and $2,000,000 in Treasury currency.

ALBANY, March 19 -- The Court of Appeals, by a 5-to-2 vote, ruled today against Mayor La Guardia in the long court battle that grew out of the attempt of the City Council committee investigating the Municipal Civil Service Commission to subpoena papers held by Mayor La Guardia.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, outstanding military authority on China, today assumed command of the Fifth and Sixth Chinese armies fighting the Japanese in Burma.
West Side buildings drew a large share of the new apartment tenancies reported yesterday, with many of the lessees going into the Washington Heights area.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Despite objections by the anti-trust division of the Department of Justice and the Secretary of Agriculture, the Interstate Commerce Commission granted today the application of Associated Transport, Inc., of New York to merge eight Atlantic seaboard trucking companies into what will be the largest single motor carrier in the United States.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Elimination from the $300,000,000 War Public Works construction program of all building materials not absolutely necessary was ordered today by Philip B. Fleming, Federal Works Administrator.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Ralph A. Bard, assistant secretary of the Navy, told the House Naval Affairs Committee today that his "own personal viewpoint," was that the standard war production work-week before overtime premium payments began could well be changed from forty to forty-eight hours.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 20 -- When the Yankees go, they go all out, regardless of the direction. The world champions met the Dodgers before 3,784 fans at Waterfront Park today for the first time since that October occasion that was so distressing to Flatbush, and forthwith they went into a violent nose dive.

Five thousand members of the Holy Name Society of the Police Department will attend the twenty-fourth annual communion tomorrow at the 8 A.M. mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral and a breakfast to follow at the Hotel Astor.

Time out for a note or two about the fabulous Saroyan. A one-act play out of his word foundry, "Across the Board on Tomorrow Morning," was acted last evening at the Theatre Showcase, 341 West Forty-seventh Street. The same group of actors is giving an intelligible performance of Nicolas Evreinov's "Theatre of the Soul," which is the most intangible sort of script.

CHUNGKING, China, March 20 -- "America means business in this war and the happiest day of our lives will be when Chinese and American troops together enter Tokyo," declared Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell today in his first conference with the press since coming to China and since his appointment as Chief of Staff to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek as well as commander of the Fifth and Sixth Chinese Armies in Burma.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- College courses to prepare women for the war jobs they must undertake were suggested today by Secretary Perkins to representatives of 104 institutions of higher learning, along with the recommendation that Latin, Greek and mathematics were probably the best subjects for teaching a student the self-discipline she would need for war work.

MELBOURNE, March 20 (U.P.) -- Prime Minister John Curtin, in a statement today expanding earlier accounts of successful attacks, on Japanese shipping at Lae and Salamaua, New Guinea, and at Rabaul, New Britain, said that United States and Royal Australian Air Force planes had disabled or sunk twenty-four ships -- twenty-three in Huon Bay and one, a 10,000-ton cruiser, at Rabaul, where two other near misses were scored.
