A soldier who had removed all his insignia and his identification tag stabbed himself at 10:05 o'clock last night in a confessional box in back of the main altar of St. Patrick's Cathedral, on the Madison Avenue side near Fifty-first Street, and then wandered out to the Fifth Avenue portal near Fiftieth Street, leaving a trail of blood.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 20 -- Boston bombers of the South African Air Force destroyed a number of German aircraft on the ground and hit several tents and trucks yesterday during their fourth daylight raid on Martuba, in Northern Libya.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- The Associated Transport, Inc., also received authority to issue 54,049 shares of preferred Stock, having par value of $100 per share, and 931,891 shares of common stock, without par value, in connection with the merger.

Passion Sunday will be observed tomorrow in the churches. A week from tomorrow is Palm Sunday, ushering in Holy Week, and two weeks from tomorrow is Easter. In synagogues this morning programs will be announced for the observance of Passover, which begins Wednesday, April. 1, at sundown.

The dark-domed planetarium of the American Museum of Natural History has constituted in recent years one of New York's outstanding outlets of escape. When the light-circles that simulated the stars went on with dramatic suddenness to make a country night sky, an explosion of "ahs" from the audience indicated release from the humdrum of everyday things.

Young women of prominence in New York and Westchester have organized to serve as manikins modeling Spring fashions at the Children's Village Shopping Benefit to be sponsored by the Village's Cottage Committees of Westchester next Wednesday and Thursday at Arnold Constable, Fifth Avenue.

That commercial dressmakers are using wool "while the sun shines" was emphasized yesterday at a woolknit fashion show held during luncheon at the Hotel Pierre. Hand-knits and deceiving simulated products from eight New York stores were presented as a benefit for the American Hospital in Britain.
CANBERRA, Australia, March 20 (AP) -- An Australian communique said today:

MIAMI, Fla., March 20 -- Irked but otherwise far from discouraged, Manager Melvin Ott took stock of his battered Giants today and promptly decided there was nothing so wrong with his club that plenty of hard work could not iron out.

RIOM, March 20 (AP) -- The worst blow to the French Army's morale was the order to fall back on the Maginot Line after penetrating into the Waarndt Forest the first month of the war, General Fernand Lenclud testified today.

There's one thing about the March winds in the country: they are good for both the woodpile and the waistline. The one grows, the other diminishes, in almost direct proportion. And all because the winds of a changing season have sorted out the trees and laid low those no longer fit to stand of their own strength.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 20 -- The success of the farm bloc in pushing through the House of Representatives a provision forbidding the government to sell government-held farm surpluses under parity prices and thus depriving the Administration of an important inflation-control lever is another indication of a gap between public opinion and Congressional action.

CANBERRA, Australia, March 20 (U.P.) -- Prime Minister John Curtin today acclaimed General MacArthur's disclosure of plans for an eventual offensive to free the Philippines as also an expression of the Australian spirit and intentions.

The fact that "affirmations of compliance" are no longer required by the Office of Price Administration in the cases of a wide range of price schedules in which they were originally ordered does not mean that there has been any relaxation of the requirements for record-keeping and monthly sales reports, according to Walter Gellhorn, regional attorney for the OPA.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, Australian Minister for External Affairs, arrived in Washington today to demand that Australia and New Zealand be seated as full partners in the war councils of the United Nations and to warn the United States that "next month may be a month too late" to provide the airplanes and other armaments needed to stop Japanese aggression in the Southwestern Pacific.

Compulsory registration of women for war service was approved yesterday by the board of directors of the National Consumers League, meeting in the Allerton House for Women, 132 East Fifty-seventh Street, preliminary to the annual meeting of the league today in the Hotel Commodore.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Pilots on commercial air lines must henceforth broadcast all weather information in a special code in order to shield this valuable information from the enemy. Regulations ordering the code into use became effective early this morning.

Closely patterned after Thursday's market, stocks continued yesterday to fall back under the weight of mild selling and lack of support. Softness in several pivotal issues American Telephone at with a new low price of 117 3/4 appeared to have a dampening affect on the rest of the list, and although prices were steadier toward the close, the demand was insufficient to offset the losses.
NORFOLK, Va., March 20 (U.P.) -- Secretary Knox urged better protection today for the Norfolk-Portsmouth harbor, adding:

Ordinary Seaman William R. Lowans, U.S.N., got into port yesterday from his first sea voyage. With him came an almost incredible story of how he sighted six survivors on a bobbing raft through three miles of gale-driven rain and mist in the North Atlantic at dusk last Wednesday.

We read a letter in THE TIMES of March 14 from a misguided Fordham rooter, Sydney H. Lane, to the effect that Bob Williams of Dartmouth willfully allowed Norman Gordon of Penn State to beat him on the last leg of the two-mile relay in the I.C.A.A.A.A. meet.

The "Street of the United Nations" at 6 East Fifty-seventh Street, organized by the British War Relief Society in cooperation with the relief organizations of other countries opposed to the Axis powers as a demonstration of their solidarity, will close this afternoon with a ceremony that will be heard in countries all over the world now in the grip of invading armies.

The association of Vincent Bendix as chairman and a director with the Bendix Aviation Corporation has been terminated, it was learned yesterday. Action on his resignation was taken on Wednesday at a meeting of the board of directors in Detroit, and no successor was chosen.

PATERSON, N.J., March 20 -- City records which would have played an important part in next week's trial of six members of the Board of Aldermen on charges of conspiracy have disappeared from City Hall, it was announced this afternoon by Prosecutor Arthur C. Dunn, a short time after the death of City Clerk Edward DuPree, who as City Clerk and Clerk of the Board of Aldermen had charge of the records.

Spring is all things to all men. To the Mayor it was something he would not discuss even with his secretary -- at least not for publication. But every one else was willing to talk about it. And to most New Yorkers, Spring was something like Santa Claus, stealing into town while they slept -- at 2:11 A.M., to be exact.

"PAST IMPERFECT,"* by Ilka Chase, is largely made up of reminiscence of that plushy but nervous environment that is peopled by the best dressed, the best partied and the most frequently newly in love. Because it has a happy ending it is cheerful recital, but it is in its quality as a true history of a romantic in a coolly careerist world that the book makes its surest appeal.

PHILADELPHIA, March 20 (AP) -- John C. Martin, former publisher of The Evening Ledger and son-in-law of Cyrus H.K. Curtis, filed a voluntary petition in bankruptcy today, listing liabilities of $3,502,920.05 and assets of $14,858.77.

Facing an April 1 deadline for submission of his 1942-43 executive budget to the Board of Estimate, Mayor La Guardia will go into his annua budget retreat this morning in the office of Budget Director Kenneth Dayton in the Manhattan Municipal Building, where he expects to spend most of his time for the next ten days.

Organized labor continued its protest yesterday against the Smith bill which would suspend the forty-hour week, overtime pay and closed shop restrictions, and which would limit profits on munitions contracts to 6 per cent for the duration.
BOSTON, March 20 (AP) -- The commercial bulletin will say tomorrow:

Gil Dodds deserves the highest recommendation for his forthright acceptance of an invitation to compete in the Navy Relief Society track meet at the Bronx Coliseum next Wednesday night in "any race the writers think my presence will do the most good."

The A.S. Beck Shoe Company, manufacturers of shoes and operators of a chain of retail shoe stores throughout the United States, have leased two floors with a total of about 20,000 square feet of space in 25 West Forty-third Street, where they plan shortly to install their executive offices.

LOS ANGELES, March 20 -- The Navy will acquire all of the great Rancho Santa Margarita y Las Flores in San Diego County for expansion of Marine Corps training facilities, according to Rear Admiral R.S. Holmes, commandant of the Eleventh Naval District.

An appeal for lifting the ban on sales of used typewriters, on the grounds that far more are now available for rental purposes than are needed or expected to be needed, has been forwarded to the War Production Board by the Office Machine Dealers of New York, John A. LaHiff, chairman of the board, announced yesterday.

Although their inventories of housewares are already well above normal, a number of department stores were reported yesterday to be still actively seeking merchandise. Unable to get further shipments from manufacturers with whom they have dealt directly in the past, many stores are now combing the market in an attempt to place orders with jobbers.

Lucy Boehmler, 18 years old, must spend five years in prison for the diligent work she did in spying out defense secrets and reporting them to Germany, Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard decided yesterday. The girl, a demure blonde who was born in Stuttgart but has lived in Queens since early childhood, received comparatively light treatment in consideration for the help she gave the government in convicting six other members of her group.
In line with the trend throughout the country, sales of new small residences being made in Nassau County show that war-plant executives and workers are involved in most of the deals.
Wilhelm Munthe de Morgenstierne, the Norwegian Minister, and Mrs. Munthe de Morgenstierne have arrived from Washington and are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

NEW DELHI, India, March 20 (AP) -- The report in today's Burma communique of Chinese in action south of Pyu showed not only the offensive determination of Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, the American commander of the Chinese forces, but also the Chinese liaison with their British allies.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The United States and Canadian Governments completed arrangements today by which about 15,000 citizens of this country who are serving in the Canadian Army may transfer to the Army of the United States.

For the second consecutive week new bonds offered to the public were restricted this week to the tax-exempt field. Flotations amounted to $9,827,000, compared with $2,827,000 in the preceding period. New bond financing a year ago amounted to $61,595,000.

New York State, not Connecticut, is entitled to collect the estate tax on the $16,000,000 left by William Evarts Benjamin, retired financier and collector of historical documents, under a unanimous ruling yesterday of the Appellate Division holding that Mr. Benjamin was a resident of New York City and not of Greenwich, Conn., at his death on Feb. 24, 1940.

LONDON, March 20 -- Kitchen garbage, meat bones, scrap iron and waste paper, all of which are used for making tanks, shells, bombs, guns, chemicals and other war materials, have added 5,409,912 to this country's war effort during the twenty-seven months between Nov. 1, 1939, and Jan. 31, 1942, it was announced today.

Ray Robinson had a little trouble last night with Norman Rubio, rugged campaigner from Albany, but the undefeated Harlem welter-weight caught up with his rival in the seventh round of their scheduled twelve-round battle at Madison Square Garden and pummeled him so steadily and devastatingly with both hands as to render Rubio practically helpless.

CHICAGO, March 20 -- Liquidation continued in the grain and soy bean markets on the Board of Trade here today. Wheat and rye were off 1 1/2 cents a bsuhel or more while soy beans declined the permissible limit of 6 cents at one time.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 20 (AP) -- The defending champions, Sammy Snead of Hot Springs, Va., and Wilford Wehrle of Racine, Wis., paced a select quartet of teams into the semi-finals of the $3,000 national professional-amateur best-ball golf tournament today in two rounds of match play.

Axis U-boats that have hunted unceasingly in United States Atlantic waters since mid-January have sent another Allied ship -- a Greek freighter -- to the bottom, the Navy revealed last night, but the entire crew of thirty-five was rescued and landed safely in Norfolk, Va.

CANBERRA, Australia, March 20 -- The clash between British Prime Minister Winston Churchill and Australian Prime Minister John Curtin over the former's appointment of Richard G. Casey to a British Imperial post continued today and Mr. Curtin let it be known that a white paper on the issue would be published next week.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- President Roosevelt expressed belief today that labor shortages will develop in the Fall when production of armaments attains greater speed.

The American Red Cross is appealing for $65,000,000 to provide relief for American war victims and to carry on rapidly expanding Red Cross services for the armed forces. The Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York is seeking $7,330,000 of the national goal in a united local chapter appeal in the five boroughs, as follows: Manhattan and the Bronx, $6,250,000; Brooklyn, $700,000; Queens, North Shore, $50,000; Central Queens, $250,000; Staten Island, $80,000.

Placing the support of its large national mailing list behind the Victory Book Campaign, the drive in which 10,000,000 books of all types are sought for the use of the Army, Navy and merchant marine, the Book-of-the-Month Club, it was learned yesterday, will enclose in its next mailing of circulars to members a separate appeal for contributions.
The Volunteers of America have opened a salvage collection depot and warehouse at 246-48 Cherry Street.

CHICAGO, March 20 (AP) -- Little Greg Rice, who has been taking the measure of all foot-racing competitors at the two-mile distance for more than two years, tonight defeated Gil Dodds by more than half a lap as he won the event in the Chicago Relays with a time of 8 minutes 53 seconds.

Decisions were reached in five of last night's six matches in the biennial championship series of the United States Chess Federation. The Section B competition was held at the Manhattan Chess Club and that in Section C at the Marshall Chess Club.

Stuart W. Jackson and Louis Matthes Jr., president and vice president, respectively, of Stuart W. Jackson, Inc., together with members of their staff, will join Johnson Higgins, insurance brokers, at 63 Wall Street, effective on April 1.

LONDON, March 20 -- The Yugoslav Government in exile released today details of what it said was the massacre of 4,000 Yugoslavs, including 100 schoolboys with books under their arms, by German machine-gunners near the town of Kragujevac last Oct. 21.

As recently as Dec. 6, 1941, almost any American's eyes would have popped at news that an American general "had been placed in command of all United States forces in China, India and Burma," and that the general in question had declared that "we won't be satisfied until we see American and Chinese troops in Tokyo together.

KEARNY, N.J., March 20 -- The 1,630-ton destroyers Lardner and McCalla, the latter sponsored by Mrs. Arthur MacArthur, sister-in-law of General Douglas MacArthur, were launched at a double ceremony soon after noon today at the shipyard of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 20 -- Aerial fighting of increasing vigor was reported today over the islands north of Australia, with the greatest activity about Port Moresby, potential enemy invasion base near the southern tip of New Guinea.

The wartime odyssey of a real-life American character known as Little Drop is published today in a brightly illustrated edition that contains both French and English texts. It is the story of a mission on two continents. Literary critics might pronounce the writing somewhat naive; the illustrations conceivably could be called amateurish.

NEW DELHI, India, March 20 (U.P.) -- The United States air force in India, commanded by Maj. Gen. Lewis H. Brereton and built around other veterans of the Philippine and Netherlands Indies campaigns, has settled down and is ready for action.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 20 -- Robert Young will play the lead opposite Jeanette MacDonald in Metro Goldywn-Mayer's "Shadow of a Lady," which will go before the cameras next week, the studio announced today. W.S. Van Dyke will direct the picture, which is based on the story by Ladislaus Fodor about a film star and a newspaper man in Egypt.

The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has sold the four five-story flats at 50-56 Eleventh Street, Hoboken, N.J. The parcel is valued for taxation at $96,200 and was sold for $65,000, according to the stamps on the deed. The purchaser, the Fifty-Eleventh Corporation, Robert Musyl, president, gave back in part payment a purchase money mortgage for $51,500.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 20 (AP) -- For the eighth straight day, leaders were toppled in the American Bowling Congress tourney today.

PEORIA, Ill., March 20 (AP) -- George P. McNear Jr., president of the strike-harassed Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad, said that Chairman William H. Davis of the War Labor Board telephoned him tonight that President Roosevelt wanted a "yes" or "no" answer "within an hour" on the Chief Executive's earlier request for arbitration.
CHUNGKING, China, March 20 -- The government is instituting remedial steps to check the serious and continuous rise of commodity prices, which is mainly due to too much money and too few commodities.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 20 -- A concerted effort and experiments are now being made to revive the American hog bristle industry and thus save from virtual extinction the nation's brush business, totaling some $60,000,000 annually.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., March 20 -- The listing of defense works as essential and serious measures to carry them out at high speed were announced by the administration today in a final effort to prepare the country for all possible developments.

WEEHAWKEN, N.J., March 20 -- A work stoppage that had halted loading operations on three large freighters of the Alcoa Steamship Lines at Pier K here for twenty-two hours ended at 1 P.M. today when an unidentified stevedore led a "back to work" movement by shouting: "Hell, this ain't no tea party.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- A German submarine entered Fort-de-France, Martinique, Feb. 21 to discharge an injured officer and, as a result, the United States Government formally demanded assurances from Vichy that French Western Hemisphere possessions would not be used as bases by Axis warships or airplanes and obtained what are regarded as satisfactory pledges.

LONDON, March 20 (AP) -- The Thyssen steel works, between Hamborn and the Rhine, were bombed by a small number of planes during the Royal Air Force raid on the Ruhr Valley's industrial centers on March 9, the Air Ministry news service disclosed today.

BERLIN, March 20 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Heavy Russian attacks in the last few days northeast of Orel have carried through the German lines, the Russians capturing one village, it was admitted here today.

The confusion among hockey officials, writers and fans, manifested in the woefully apparent lack of certitude as to just who is or will be regarded as the 1942 National League champion, brings to light a situation that certainly is in need of straightening out.

LONDON, March 20 -- Captain Sir Seymour Fortescue, 86 years of age, former Sergeant-at-Arms in the House of Lords and equerry to three kings, was found dead early this morning on the railway tracks one hundred yards beyond the platform of Victoria Station.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 20 -- The American tank, long an important part of British equipment in Libya, got an indirect stamp of approval yesterday with the departure of Colonels E.W. Piburn and Joseph M. Colby for Washington. The officers have been in the Middle East introducing the United States-built machine to the British Army and their return to Washington means that the tank has now proved itself satisfactory for operation in British hands.

Advocates of the forty-hour week originally defended it frankly as a forty-hour week. Recognizing that such a defense has become untenable in wartime, many of them now defend the forty-hour week by the curious contention that it doesn't exist. An employer can work his men as long as he wants, they now argue -- provided only, of course, that he pays them a penalty rate of 50 per cent extra for overtime.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 20 -- The Floral Park Bank and Trust Company announced today that it will be absorbed by the First National Bank of Floral Park at the close of business on Saturday, March 28. It was organized in 1908. It will transfer about 1,300 regular and 6,000 special accounts to the First National, bringing the latter's deposits to about $5,000,000.
DETROIT, March 20 -- A fleet of the largest Great Lake ore carriers moved from Lake Erie through the Detroit River today to open the 1942 lakes' navigation season almost a month early.

Davis Catterall, leading cotton goods, converters, announced yesterday that they were offering all of their customers finished goods for delivery during May and June at prices they have quoted for the last sixty days.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Manufacturers of beds, bed springs and mattresses were instructed to effect sharp curtailment in their use of iron and steel in an order issued by the War Production Board's Division of Industry Operations, effective April 1.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Today's War Department communique indicated that nothing had happened in the Philippine Islands, but it listed officers who accompanied General Douglas MacArthur on his journey and now form his operations staff in Australia, where the former commander of Philippine forces has the new responsibility of Supreme Commander of Allied Forces in the Southwestern Pacific.

LONDON, March 20 -- A feature on the Stock Exchange today was a sharp rally in the tobacco shares, after a further decline in the early dealings, when the market learned that the Tobacco Control had no knowledge of an impending cut in the supply.

State and municipal financing scheduled for next week by thirty-three municipalities aggregates $7,836,100, compared with $13,054,322 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $23,891,063.

NOW it really counts on ice. The Big league hockey clubs were just skirmishing through what is fancifully known as "the championship season." All they did in all that time was to whip six teams into shape for the real slashing struggles in the Stanley Cup series and eject one team, the doddering Americans, from further consideration.

The Research Division of the Office of Price Administration has furnished the Joint Committee on Internal Revenue Taxation with some estimates on the distribution of consumer income. These estimates, intended to aid the committee in its study of sales tax proposals, contain some surprising figures.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 20 (AP) -- Britisk headquarters issued tlis communiqu today:

PHILADELPHIA, March 20 -- Aubrey Williams, administrator of the National Youth Administration, in calling today for a continuation of that agency, described it as "the only one in existence" which could recruit and train the bulk of 2,000,000 new workers to be needed by war plants before the end of the year.

Seventy-five per cent of the company's production at the close of last year was for war, William C. Dickerman, chairman of the American Locomotive Company, declared in the fortieth annual report to stockholders, issued yesterday. Today the company is a major producer not only of tanks but of gun carriages, shells, Diesel engines for ships and other items.
LONDON, March 20 (Reuter) -- The Moscow radio broadcast toContinued on Page Two night an announcement of the terms of the renewed Soviet-Japanese fisheries agreement, as follows:
BERLIN, March 20 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The present capital gains tax has defeated its own purpose as a revenue producer, Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, told the Ways and Means Committee today.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Amendments proposed today by Secretary Jones to the Smaller War Plants Corporation bill sponsored by Senator Murray of Montana brought from the Senator tonight a statement that the proposals "would be fatal to the purposes for which the bill was devised."

TOKYO, March 20 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- The Japanese Navy intends to salvage fifty-three Allied ships sunk or damaged at Surabaya, former Netherland naval base on the northeast coast of Java, the Domei news agency asserted today.

TORONTO, March 20 (AP) -- All the cripples of both the New York Ranger and Toronto Maple Leaf National Hockey League teams except Reggie Hamilton, Leaf defenseman, will be in shape for tomorrow night's opening game of the Stanley Cup play-offs -- the world series of the ice.

In a talk delivered in this city on Thursday, Director James M. Landis of the OCD was realistic in declaring that if "the enemy choose to attack, some of his bombers will get through, and as they get through, men and women will be killed and property destroyed." Director Landis thought it particularly important not to stop work until the bombers were overhead.

BERLIN, March 20 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Domei (official Japanese news agency) dispatches from the Philippines said today that a 1,160-ton United States steamer was captured and that a 3,000-ton transport ship and four other "enemy vessels" ranging from 500 to 1,000 tons were sunk from March 4 to 6 by Japanese naval forces in Central and Southern Philippine waters.

Combining a bit of educational propaganda with scenic beauty, the Garden Club of New Jersey became a double prize winner of yesterday at the Flower Show with its display of a miniature forest that reproduces a section of the million-acre wilderness in South Jersey known as the Jersey Pine Barrens.

Benjamin Rockower, 230-pound burglar who escaped from the police March 8, after he had volunteered to assist them in solving a Brooklyn shooting, was captured early yesterday morning as he lay in bed in the servants' quarters of the West Shore Country Club at White Lake, N.Y.

LONDON, March 20 -- The question of increasing the hours of work permitted for juvenile workers between the ages of 14 and 18 was raised in the House of Commons today. Kenneth Lindsay, National Laborite, asked for a special government inquiry into the conditions of employment for juveniles and cited cases of youths working in factories and elsewhere more than sixty hours a week.

Dueling addicts from thirteen Eastern universities jammed the Salle Santelli strips for approximately fourteen hours yesterday as the forty-ninth annual Intercollegiate Fencing Association championships opened. Representatives of N.Y.U. and Army supplied most of the high spots.

The growing use being made of arbitration, instead of strikes, as a means of settling disputes between labor and management is shown in the February report of the State Board of Mediation, made public yesterday by Arthur S. Meyer, chairman of the board.
MOSCOW, March 20 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau broadcast this communique today:

NEW ORLEANS, March 20 (AP) -- Jim Olsen, who could hardly miss the hoop, led Dartmouth to a 44 -- 39 victory over Penn State tonight in the semi-finals of the National Collegiate A.A. basketball championship play-offs.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 20 -- Picture approximately 574,000 persons sitting in the dark for thirty-two minutes and you have the "inside" story of Westchester County's blackout demonstration last Sunday night.

PHILADELPHIA, March 20 -- The United Corporation received permission today from the Securities and Exchange Commission to reduce the stated value of its preference stock from $50 to $5 a share, an act it had declared was necessary before $7,466,136 in accrued dividends could be paid.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, operating simultaneously in thirty-six cities, have seized sixty members of the largest lottery ring in the United States, it was announced tonight by the Department of Justice.

SANTA PAULA, Calif., March 20 (U.P.) -- Clark Shaughnessy, head football coach at Stanford University, will resign tomorrow to accept a similar post at the University of Maryland, his son, Clark Shaughnessy Jr., confirmed tonight.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 20 -- The Balkan storm signals, raised yesterday by Michael Antonescu, brother of the Rumanian Premier and Acting Foreign Minister, in his speech before the Bucharest Law Faculty, flew straight out today in a growing gale of vituperation between Bucharest and Budapest as both sides took editorial positions on the rights and wrongs of their cases.

The nation-wide nutrition campaign sponsored jointly by the government and the food industry will get under way on April 1, when the government printing office releases the first of two posters, Paul S. Willis, president of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, announced yesterday.

ALBANY, March 20 -- The State Banking Department announced today that Bedding Local, 140, Credit Union, with headquarters at 80 East Eleventh Street, New York, has filed an organization certificate with the department. The incorporators listed are Aaron Mandel, Frank Sergi, Joseph Solonche, Morris Schiller, Jane B. Burke, Morris Yankowitz, Hyman Sack and Robert Laupheimer.
MOSCOW, March 20 -- The Russian Government announced tonight a one-year extension of the Soviet-Japanese fisheries agreement that expired last December.

BERNE, Switzerland, Saturday, March 21 -- Russian forces in the Staraya Russa sector raided the eastern defenses of that key town yesterday and captured a railroad station after a brief but fierce encounter, according to a semi-official report from Moscow this morning. Reports current last evening that the Russians had entered the town, however, appeared to be premature, though the fighting continued.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today in its final ginning report of the 1941-42 season that cotton of the growth of 1941 totaled 10,728,751 equivalent 500-pound bales, compared with 12,564,988 in the 1940 crop and 11,815,759 in the 1939 crop.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Evidence of high labor turnover in war industry areas where housing facilities are lacking has led government officials in interested agencies to back a plea for civilians to provide apartment space in their homes as a vital defense move.

Average annual earnings of regular hourly rate employes of the General Motors Corporation in the United States, including those whose employment was intermittent, rose to $2,141 in 1941 from $1,894 in 1940 and $1,503 in 1939, it was announced yesterday by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman, whose annual report will be sent to stockholders on Monday.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey indicated today that it would not be the dependents that a man has but the importance of his job in war production that would be the determining factor in his deferment from military service.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on March 14 totaled 262,063,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines. This represented an increase of 1,999,000 barrels in the week, comprising increases of 1,628,000 and 371,000 barrels in domestic and foreign stocks, respectively.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, March 18 (Delayed) (AP) -- An American-built "ugly duckling" freighter flying the Stars and Stripes has braved the challenge of Nazi bombers and submarines by sailing through the Eastern Mediterranean into Alexandria, bringing war materials to reinforce Britain's North African armies.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 20 -- Santa Anita Park, noted centre of wintertime horse racing, will be the site of an induction centre for Japanese nationals and American-born Japanese about to be moved out of the West Coast's military area No. 1.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 20 -- John Whitlow Wyatt, who pitched the Dodgers to a pennant last year and then scored Brooklyn's only triumph over the world champion Yankees in the world series, will help pitch the Brooks to another possible pennant this year unless either he or President Larry MacPhail is too stubborn to reach a compromise.

A new nightly radio program from the United States to Brazil, to be prepared and spoken by a staff of Brazilian journalists and radio men, is scheduled to begin March 30, it was disclosed here yesterday by Dr. Assis de Figueiredo, assistant director of Brazil's Department of Press and Propaganda.
With regard to the bickering of Sydney H. Lane (who labels himself as a Fordhamite) over an I.C.A.A.A.A. injustice, I would like to bring out a few points.

Retail trade here continued active this week, with department store sales estimated as running about 22 per cent ahead of last year. Purchases of Spring apparel are now increasing steadily and are moving toward the period of heavy pre-Easter buying.

TOKYO, March 20 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Japanese Navy charged today that the United States and Britain, since the start of the war in the Pacific, had waged "extreme warfare based on retaliation and hatred."
Here is an answer from Dartmouth to Sydney H. Lane. Bob Williams did run wide and did slow down on the anchor leg of the I.C.A.A.A.A. two-mile relay and he can be justly criticized for this action.

LONDON, March 20 -- The Japanese invaders in Burma were reported today to be in the vicinity of Toungoo, where heavy fighting is still in progress. In a clash near Toungoo, 150 miles north of Rangoon, the enemy was said to have suffered 700 casualties, but it was indicated that the British withdrawal continued.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Robert R. Guthrie, former $1-a-year executive with the War Production Board, told a House Military Affairs subcommittee today that war materials needed by the Army and Navy had been delayed by insubordination in the board and government red tape.

BERLIN, March 20 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- A dispatch from Tokyo tonight said that "details" of changes in Article VIII of the Japanese Naval War Law of 1914 were as follows:

A delay in Congressional procedure is all that is preventing institution of a system which WPB estimates would reduce the sugar shortage by some 550,000 tons annually, according to reports here yesterday. Whisky distillers are prepared to ship raw whisky to industrial alcohol plants for redistillation into industrial alcohol, used in smokeless powder, thus releasing high-test molasses made from cane from which raw sugar had not been extracted.

Imposition of a minimum clearing fee on New York Stock Exchange transactions has revived discussion of the possibility that Stock Exchange firms might be able to save money if the banks were to take over the clearing job. In the words of Stock Exchange officials, the matter is arguable, but nobody has given a simple Yes or No.

I have been an interested spectator at every basketball game in Madison Square Garden this season. Along with many other New York fans, I was disappointed that Long Island University and City College were eliminated in the first round of the national tournament.

An exhibition of art by children of the Western Hemisphere opens today at the Brooklyn Museum, to remain through April 19. It is being presented by the museum in cooperation with the Progressive Education Association and was assembled with the assistance of the State Department for the eighth international conference of the New Education Fellowship, sponsored by the Office of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs.
RIOM, France, March 20 -- Evidence of the default of French aviation in the war continued to accumulate with the testimony of four more military witnesses before the Supreme Court here today.

CHICAGO, March 20 -- All elements of the racing industry were banded together today in an organization called the Turf Committee of America and plans were started immediately to translate into action many of the suggestions made here during a two-day meeting of racing interests.

PHILADELPHIA, March 20 -The Illinois Commercial Telephone company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment to its registration statemefit: disclosing a reduction in the amount of new securities t9. be issued' to the public.

A training program for workers in the shipbuilding industry, for those skilled in other fields and for unemployed apprentices was announced yesterday by Gavin MacPherson, national representative of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C.I.O., as a means of speeding up the construction of ships for war needs.

ALBANY, March 20 -- A bill creating a ten-man temporary State Commission to draft and correlate State-wide plans for post-war public-works projects was introduced in the Legislature today after a series of conferences between Governor Lehman and legislative leaders.
LOS ANGELES, March 20 (AP) -- Courtney Fred Rogers, 24-year-old church organist, told officers today that he killed his aged grandmother, Mrs. Sophie Spiegelmann, as well as his parents.
LONDON, March 20 -- The threat yesterday by Home Secretary Herbert Morrison to suppress The London Daily Mirror for its sniping at officialdom's conduct of the war aroused outburst of protests today.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- President Roosevelt told his press conference today a fantastic story of General Douglas MacArthur's escape from Bataan in a rowboat disguised as a Filipino fisherman, and got one of his own criticisms thrown in his face by a secretary.
RIOM, France, March 20 -- Evidence of the default of French aviation in the war continued to accumulate with the testimony of four more military witnesses before the Supreme Court here today.

CHICAGO, March 20 -- All elements of the racing industry were banded together today in an organization called the Turf Committee of America and plans were started immediately to translate into action many of the suggestions made here during a two-day meeting of racing interests.

PHILADELPHIA, March 20 -The Illinois Commercial Telephone company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment to its registration statemefit: disclosing a reduction in the amount of new securities t9. be issued' to the public.

ALBANY, March 20 -- A bill creating a ten-man temporary State Commission to draft and correlate State-wide plans for post-war public-works projects was introduced in the Legislature today after a series of conferences between Governor Lehman and legislative leaders.
LOS ANGELES, March 20 (AP) -- Courtney Fred Rogers, 24-year-old church organist, told officers today that he killed his aged grandmother, Mrs. Sophie Spiegelmann, as well as his parents.

In the move toward war control of New York's hundreds of thousands of electric signs and exterior lighting devices, the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity has obtained "very gratifying" compliance with its new wartime regulations, Commissioner Patrick Quilty reported yesterday.

American soldiers in Australia are having trouble with the native slang. As between male and male this leads only to temporary misunderstanding. In mixed company there is occasional embarrassment, but likewise temporary, let us hope.

The Downing Holding Corporation sold to a client of Bernard Trencher, attorney, the six-story apartment building at 10 Downing Street for cash over mortgages aggregating $536,300. The house was erected about a year ago by Milton Kleban and has been sold through Ackman Bros., brokers.

DETROIT, March 20 -- The program put forward by the General Motors Corporation in today's contract negotiations, in a letter signed by H.W. Anderson, vice president in charge of personnel, and the point-by-point analysis by Walter P. Reuther, director of the General Motors Division of the United Automobile Workers (C.I.O.), are as follows:

MELBOURNE, Australia, Saturday, March 21 -- Melbourne organized a tumultuous welcome today for General Douglas MacArthur, Supreme Commander of the United Nations forces in the Southwest Pacific, who said yesterday in his first public statement since his arrival in Australia that he planned to organize an offensive that would drive the Japanese out of the Philippines.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 20 -- Mr. and Mrs. Theodore W. Stemmler entertained with cocktails today at their residence in honor of their guest, Mrs. Leroy Stoddard of New York.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- President Roosevelt today proclaimed April 6 as Army Day, but said that all of the armed services would participate in the observance as was done on Navy Day last Fall.

Cruising taxicabs will be barred from the midtown area of Manhattan in an effort to conserve gasoline, Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday. A formal order to this effect is being prepared and will be promulgated next week, he said.

Twenty-nine pilots of the R.A.F. paid their first visit to New York yesterday, and the customary whirl of dinner dances, cocktail parties and theatre events that sweeps up visiting military men played second place as the blue-uniformed pilots showed principal interest in the regular sights of New York City.

The cotton market lost ground moderately again yesterday as business continued limited. On the New York Cotton Exchange prices of active futures moved within a 5-point range and finished 1 to 4 points lower than the previous close.

Statistics of particular interest both to masculine and feminine householders are contained in a recent release from the United States Department of Labor. This report, based on a survey made in the nation's grocery stores, reveals that the average cost of food rose .5 per cent from the middle of January to the middle of February.

LONDON, March 20 -- Major Gen. R.M. Weeks, director general of equipment for the British Army, said today that all ordnance supplies, including tanks, tank and anti-tank guns and wireless equipment, that Britain promised Russia had so far been sent right on schedule.

Twentieth Century-Fox's "Secret Agent of Japan," which opens at the Globe, is today's lone film newcomer. Preston Foster, Lynn Bari, Noel Madison, Janis Carter and Addison Richards are featured in the adventure. . . . "Bara En Trumpetare," a Swedish importation, will have its local premiere today at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre.

Large shipments of brown and rainbow trout have been received from the Conservation Department by the Westchester Sportsmen's Legislative Council, it is reported, and these fish have been planted in the open fishing waters of the county.

The effects of tax day are still not yet complete. Of about $700,000,000 of first-quarter taxes for the Second Federal Reserve District an estimated $600,000,000 is in hand and of the expected $2,700,000,000 for the entire country close to $2,000,000,000 is in hand.

DETROIT, March 20 -- Countering union demands for a blanket wage increase of $1 a day, the General Motors Corporation proposed today the establishment of a system of "incentive payments" to speed up arms production along the lines suggested by Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board.

While no attractions are scheduled to close on Broadway this evening, the road will have two casualties in Boston tonight. Specifically, they are "Tobacco Road" and "Louisiana Purchase." The Jack Kirkland play, headed by John Barton, terminates a thirty-two-week coast-to-coast tour after grossing in excess of $300,000, notwithstanding the competition offered by the motion-picture version.

LONDON, March 20 -- Major Gen. R.M. Weeks, director general of equipment for the British Army, said today that all ordnance supplies, including tanks, tank and anti-tank guns and wireless equipment, that Britain promised Russia had so far been sent right on schedule.

Preston Foster, Lynn Bari, Noel Madison, Janis Carter and Addison Richards are featured in the adventure. . . . Large shipments of brown and rainbow trout have been received from the Conservation Department by the Westchester Sportsmen's Legislative Council, it is reported, and these fish have been planted in the open fishing waters of the county.

Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board.

TRENTON, March 20 -- All municipalities along the New Jersey coastline and for ten miles inland were ordered today to reduce all lighting to protect off-shore shipping or face the prospect of complete blackouts if the area is made a war zone by the United States Army.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- President Roosevelt designated April 6 as Army Day, held his press conference, met with the Cabinet and received the following visitors: Secretary Wickard and Murray Lincoln, Representative Marcantonio, Louis Johnson, Representative Crosser and Layne Coy and Australian Minister Casey, with Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, Australian Minister of External Affairs.

HILAIRE BELLOC'S charming gifts as an essayist are brought to bear, under this volume's alluring title, on a subject which has always been part of his life and vital to his work and -- need we add? -- dear to his heart.
TITLE-MAKING is an interesting part of movie-making. And it can afford as much pleasure, if not more, perhaps, than the actual shooting of the movie scenes themselves.

Orchids are glamorous flowers, their odd and fragile-appearing petals hinting of legend and mystery, but they are no longer unattainable blooms, even in a house. This is not to imply that they are as easy to grow as philodendron, but any one who can cope successfully with a miscellaneous collection of house plants can bring his garden intelligence to fruition with orchid blooms.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., March 21 -- Franks Boy, Mrs. J.L. Chesney's stretch-running 6-year-old chestnut horse, took the Majestic Hotel Handicap today at Oaklawn Park in a photo finish with Coward and Dupuy's Marriage.

The battle line in Russia, as Spring came to 1942, showed clearly the fundamental strategy of the two fighting armies. There were deep Russian indentations, the flood tides of the Soviet advance around the German strongholds. There were the key points still held tenaciously by the Wehrmacht, islands of dogged resistance in the Soviet sea.

A week ago it was pointed out that three possible drives were in the intentions of the Japanese -- against Australia, against India and against Russia. It was also pointed out that it was doubtful that Japan could try all three at once and that, in the meanwhile, she enjoyed the advantage of keeping her enemies guessing as to which way she would move.
The voice of General Douglas MacArthur was broadcast throughout the United States yesterday for the first time, it was said, since he left this country.

From a Warwick (N.Y.) garden come notes of an unusual hobby that should be of interest to gardeners. Here flower borders have been planted with a twofold purpose: to present a well planned, continuously blooming effect, and also to provide a source of nectar for several beehives.

LONDON, March 21 (Canadian Press) -- Bradford City, whose season record gives little indication of power, today downed the Blackburn Rovers by 5 -- 0 in the Football League's War Cup qualifying competition.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 21 -- The defending champion team of Sam Snead, Hot Springs, Va., and Wilford Wehrle, Racine, Wis., advanced to the final round of the national professional-amateur golf championship today when they defeated Chandler Harper, Portsmouth, Va., and Sam Bates, Virginia Beach, Va., 1 up.

A streamlined six-event track meet, each test featuring headline runners in special record attempts, will be staged at the Bronx Coliseum Wednesday night, with all of the proceeds going to the Navy Relief Society. Sponsored by the Track Writers Association and conducted by the directors of New York's major meets, the show will provide a grand finale to the campaign.

A REAPPRAISAL of Japan is clearly in order in the light of her victories of the last three months. But is it Japan's strength that should be re-examined or the soundness of our own judgment? For five years American opinion has reflected the American state of mind rather than the physical properties of Japan.

THE sidewalk prognosticators in the Sardi-Shubert Alley sector are pretty firmly of the opinion that legitimate theatre business on Broadway this coming Summer will be comparatively terrific, because fewer people, they say, will be going to the country, the mountains and the seashore.

Methods of factory management that will achieve ceaseless production in war industries while not generally working any employee more than a five-day, forty-hour week were endorsed yesterday by State Industrial Commissioner Frieda S. Miller.

Without a greenhouse or even frames one may start early plants under cover. The back of a house or a mere shed, may serve the purpose. For instance W. D. Switzer of Bellows Falls, Vt., has a part-time plant house where many seedlings get an early Spring start.

MOSCOW, March 21 (AP) -- "Tens of well-trained divisions," drilled and equipped on the plains of Siberia, awaited tonight the command that would send them into the front lines to give added power to the Russian offensive driving forward relentlessly in the north, the center and the south.

Your editorial "Physically Unfit," in THE TIMES of March 9, poses a problem which has been lost, apparently, in the maze of more obvious difficulties -- the problem of what becomes of those men rejected for physical defects.

The Federal Reserve Board has asked retailer recommendations regarding possible limitation of retail charge accounts to be submitted by April 1, it was learned here last week. Decision to name a special committee to study the numerous phases of the proposed credit control was reached at a meeting held on Friday at the offices of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., March 21 -- One hundred and seventy-five delegates, representing twenty-four New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania colleges, will meet at Bryn Mawr College, March 29-31, for the annual session of the Model Assembly of the League of Nations.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- A House committee heard testimony today that a War Production Board consultant long resisted proposed adulteration of wool for civilian uses as a conservation measure, but had now recommended that it be adulterated in military supplies.

LONDON, March 21 -- Urging immediate opposition to any "unjustified suppressive government action under defense regulations," the so-called 1941 Committee, of which J.B. Priestley is chairman, issued a statement today in connection with Home Secretary Herbert Morrison's warning to The Daily Mirror because of its publication of a cartoon dealing with increased price of gasoline.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 21 -- Deputy Prime Minister Francis M. Forde spent yesterday afternoon inspecting a United States Army camp. It was his first view of the American encampment and he said the experience was thrilling because American soldiers were so much like Australians.
The pitiless spotlight of total war focused on the "land down under" last week as Australia, rallying behind the leadership of General Douglas MacArthur, prepared to repel the enemy at her gates.

CLINTON, N.Y., March 21 -- Approximately one out of every three Hamilton students is taking special college work intended to better prepare him for military service, President W.H. Cowley said today. Registration in eight special courses inspired by the defense effort has passed the 150 mark, although two of the courses are without college credits.

Joe Louis will make his second grand gesture to the charity offices of his country's armed forces when he defends his heavyweight championship of the world against Abe Simon, huge Richmond Hill challenger, at Madison Square Garden on Friday night.

MAY I trespass upon your space to follow up Ben Hecht's recent lament about the critic situation? I have no desire to repeat what Mr. Hecht said, but to suggest specific remedies. I am well qualified to make suggestions because "Under This Roof" [of which Mr. Ehrmann was author] played to twelve responsive audiences until after the critics reviewed the opening in New York.

Angered by the refusal of a hospital interne to climb a twenty-five-foot ladder to a roof where a steeple-jack lay injured, a throng of workers of the Baker Castor Oil Company plant at 35 Avenue A, Bayonne, N.J., threatened yesterday to hurl the doctor into the near-by bay.

CALL it air express, call it air freight, or lump it all into the general term "air cargo," but whichever you choose for a designating term, it's going to succeed the transportation of passengers as the biggest source of revenue for the commercial air lines of the United States.

The study of the war should be made an important part of the school curriculum, officials of the Board of Education declared yesterday at the fortieth annual conference and luncheon of the New York City Association of Teachers of English in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

STOCKHOLM, March 21 -- Conditions have made Sweden a bashful country. Nothing displeases her people and leaders so much as to be suddenly projected into the limelight. Shadow is a more natural element for a country that desires nothing more than to be forgotten -- for the time being, at least.

AFTER all we have heard of the difficulties of our publishers the unexpectedly large number of their Spring announcements brings a shock of pleased surprise. A scrutiny of the individual items, however, modifies one's natural impulse to offer congratulations, for many of them were included in the Fall lists, so that their appearance now really indicates postponements and disappointments.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., March 21 -- Recent drafts have increased the militia force by at least a third. Drafting of men to serve in the Home Guard and air raid precautions services will put younger men in the Home Guard.

PAUL ENGLE is a thin, wiry poet from-Iowa. "I'm the first member of my family to finish high school, so far as any of us know. Both my grandfathers fought in the Civil War -- they joined up when they were young.

The United States Maritime Service has issued an appeal for young Americans who want to make a career of going to sea. The service's training stations along the nation's coasts are being enlarged, and the government is anxious to keep the schools filled to meet the demand for seamen for the rapidly growing merchant marine.

INTO her tale of Chiquitico, "The Least One," and of Paco, the little boy who loved the tiny burro dearly and was positive that he was the most beautiful, the most to be desired of all burros in Mexico, Ruth Sawyer has put a bit of genuine, endearing childhood, a kindly humor and authentic Mexican atmosphere.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 21 -- The Eastern intercollegiate swimming championships developed into a Yale interclass meet as the Elis swept all six titles contested tonight, set records in five events and concluded the two-day show with ten of the eleven crowns.

Two middle-aged business men died in hospitals yesterday of injuries received several hours earlier in a Greenwich Village street fight with a group of neighborhood hoodlums who, detectives said, "just didn't like their looks."

Dr. Stephen S. Wise, chairman of the American Emergency Committee for Zionist Affairs, announced yesterday that he has received word from more than 350 rabbis, of Orthodox, Conservative and Reform denominations, approving the proposal to establish a Palestine Jewish army to fight as an independently organized unit under British command.

AUSTRALIANS -- the "hard men from Down Under" -- have a way of speech, especially in their slang, that has often been compared to American talk. Some say that theirs has even more bite and color than ours.

With the announcement yesterday by the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound that the delegates of the member clubs would gather in the New York Yacht Club at 5 P.M. on March 31 to adopt the championship racing program for the coming Summer, was a proposed schedule of tentative dates predicated upon the usual fixed dates. In it were a number of changes.

As several campaigns to rush all kinds of scrap materials back into industry gained momentum, the importance of the salvage program was stressed here yesterday by Sydney Hogerton. District Manager, Priorities, Bureau of Field Operations, War Production Board.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 21 -- Yale University has adopted a new curriculum for its Department of Architecture which, Dean Everett V. Meeks of the Yale Art School said today, is planned to both adapt itself to the needs of the war and to break off the shackles of European tradition.

A popular prelude to the musical advancement of this city's younger generation is the series of Young People's Concerts of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society Next Saturday morning Carnegie Hall will present an appealing spectacle already familiar to many parents who deem the musical education of their children a very important asset of cultural back ground.

Additional affidavits denouncing the type of burlesque at the Gaiety Theatre, were submitted yesterday by Assistant Corporation Counsel Charles C. Weinstein to Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy in the proceeding to compel Paul Moss, License Commissioner, to renew the license of the theatre.

DEPICTING the beauty of "This England" before the coming of war, a collection of forty-eight prints by Val Doone, noted English photographer, are on exhibition at the Newark Museum, Washington Park West, Newark, through April 15.
WITH the expected passage of the War Powers Bill, now undergoing certain revisions, soldiers, sailors and marines will be allowed free franking on all ordinary mail.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 21 -- In the last war America entrusted some of her men to an Australian general in their first offensive action. On Independence Day, 1918, 1,000 Americans, who until then had been holding the line, fought beside the Anzacs in the Battle of Hamel under the late General John Monash, Australian Commander in Chief, who led them to a great victory.

AIR correspondents of London newspapers recently carried stories to the effect that German engineers have developed the "rocket principle" to assist Luftwaffe bombers in getting off with unusually heavy bomb loads.

PHOTOGRAPHING and examining 350,000 copies of the United States 1861-67 2-cent black stamp, familiarly known as the "Black Jack" because of the combination of its color and its portrait of Andrew Jackson, have brought to light three which were printed on double paper.

The War Shipping Administration has approved the application of a surcharge of 35 per cent of all ocean freight rates between Atlantic and Gulf ports of the United States and eastern ports of South America, it was announced yesterday by the River Plate-Brazil Conferences in New York.

Four men play parcheesi, apparently for high stakes, and Charles Cathcart is the heaviest loser and a bad loser at that, for he hurls three of his parcheesi pieces out of the window. The others have already left and before morning one of them is shot to death in his own home.
CHICAGO, March 21 (AP) -- Livestock prices were unchanged today at the close of a week of moderate gains.

PORTLAND, Ore., March 21 -- Growing apprehension that the United Nations may be overwhelmed in the western Pacific before this country has really started to fight is freely expressed among virtually all elements of Oregon's population.

IN "I Knock at the Door" Sean O'Casey wrote of his childhood. "Pictures in the Hallway," the second chapter of his unusual autobiography, covers the years between the death of Parnell and the Boer War, the years of his youth.

A police chauffeur gazing at the circulars of wanted men in the offices of the first detective district yesterday recognized among them a photograph of a bartender of his acquaintance, and brought about the arrest of Charles Richardson, indicted last Spring on charges of receiving jewelry stolen in the $100,000 hold-up of Mrs. Henry W. Breyer and her daughter-in-law, Mrs. Margaret McK. Breyer, at Berwyn, Pa., Feb. 28, 1939.

TEA was served on Royal Worcester china in the graciously furnished parlor of the charitable institution, and the newest inmate was glad she was wearing a Schiaparelli frock and a moleskin coat with white gloves.

A resolution urging the War Department to form a mixed combat division of men of all creeds, faiths and colors was adopted unanimously yesterday at the Victory through Unity conference held by the Council Against Intolerance in America at the Hotel Edison.

LOS ANGELES, March 21 -- Praise for aircraft manufacturers and criticism of the War Department and the Office of Production Management, as causing "a 'slowdown'," were highlights of a report released today by a special aviation subcommittee of the Senate committee investigating war production.

Taking a leaf from the Postoffice Department's book, the Bishop Loughlin Memorial High boys delivered the mail though the weather was awful in the second annual Brooklyn Prep relay carnival on the Crown Heights school's outdoor track yesterday.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 21 (U.P.) -- An American woman who braved the siege of Corregidor and a daring sea and air flight from beleaguered Bataan Peninsula appealed directly today to the women of Australia to "help our men in every way."

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 21 -- Making racegoers wonder how he could have run so dismally in the recent Widener Challenge Cup Handicap at Hialeah Park, Charles S. Howard's Mioland today came through with a record-breaking triumph in the $7,500 added Coral Gables Handicap before a crowd of 9,319 at Tropical Park.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- Easter and Palm Sunday visitors to this resort are going to find the Atlantic City beach front a somewhat dimmer place than in the past.

NAZI propaganda authorities in France are sponsoring a stamp sale which they apparently hope will extract money from collectors in the United States, Great Britain, France and wherever else philately thrives. They have issued a so-called soldier stamp for use on letters mailed by members of the "Legion of French Volunteers Against Bolshevism," the French military units fighting on the side of the Germans against the Russians.

An American general -- he was 55, looked younger -- stepped ashore at Manila one day in the Fall of 1935 after a long voyage from the United States. He was Douglas MacArthur. He had just finished five years' service as Chief of Staff, the highest Army post his country could offer.
SPRING, in its capricious way, has made several false starts in recent weeks, and then faithlessly yielded to a wintry blast. Now, however, it's official. The calendar says that Spring is here.

THAT long silence from the workshop of S.N. Behrman means nor peace nor rest -- simply that Mr. B. is working on two plays. One, and it is almost finished, is called "The Pirate." It is based on -- though remotely -- an old play by Fulda, its locale is Santo Domingo, its time is the early nineteenth century.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 21 -- Many of the nation's outstanding athletic coaches will be in the group of more than 200 who will report to the Naval Academy Monday to begin a month's indoctrination course in preparation for service as Naval Reserve officers.

RICHMOND, Va., March 21 -- Micro-television facsimile in which the images received are too small to be viewed by the human eye but may be enlarged by projecting them on a screen is the invention (Patent No. 2,275,898) of Dr. Alfred N. Goldsmith, radio and television researcher of New York City.
DALLAS, March 21 -- A demand for action, centered on speeding up war production by every possible means, characterizes the attitude of the Southwest toward the conduct of the war.

WITH automobiles being removed from service at the rate of about 17,000 a day, the bicycle is coming into its own. And all indications are that the government intends to keep the bicycle industry working hard in an effort to keep the nation on wheels.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- An agreement between the United States and China, giving effect to the $500,000,000 loan voted by Congress more than a month ago, was signed at the Treasury today by Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. and T.V. Soong, Chinese Foreign Mister.

THOSE rare glimpses of life in the Soviet Union which the world at large used to get in the news reels were generally in the processions of buxom, straight-haired girls whose very bouncing health was somewhat forbidding. You see them marching, with heads held high and arms swinging, across Red Square on May 1 or romping over crowded Black Sea beaches.

PORT MORESBY, New Guinea, March 21 (U.P.) -- Small native uprisings in the Sepik River area of Northeast New Guinea were reported today. Some of the natives were said to have reverted to head-hunting and cannibalism.

OTTAWA, March 21 -- Comment in the Droit, Ottawa French-language newspaper, on the bombing by the Royal Air Force of the Renault works at Billancourt, suburb of Paris, has resulted in that newspaper's being charged with breaking defense regulations.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- A fundamental change in the priorities system, under which a specific requirements approach to the control and distribution of scarce materials will replace the use of general or blanket priority rating orders, will be made over the coming three months, J.S. Knowlson, director of industry operations for the War Production Board, announced today.

There is no prohibition against use of benzol in industry in New York State, either in laws or regulations, Frieda S. Miller, State Industrial Commissioner, said yesterday. Her comment was occasioned by reports in THE NEW YORK TIMES of efforts of potential users of benzol to obtain relaxation of State regulations.
The article "As India Sees It," by Krishnalal Shridharani in the Magazine deserves comment.

Stuyvesant, defending city titleholder, swept through its sixth straight opponent, Forest Hills, to continue the undefeated leader of Division I in the Public Schools Athletic League fencing tournament at the Washington Irving High School gymnasium yesterday.

THE Flower Show in any year is more than a display of man's ingenuity with growing things; it is a tribute to those growing things themselves. And this year it is a fitting celebration of the earth's enduring strength and unfailing bounty. It is a reminder of fundamentals in a world of violent change.

FOR admirers of Debussy's music there is good news this month. Two of his works appear in new recordings of much better than average quality. Fritz Reiner and the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra have done Iberia (Columbia M-491, three twelve-inch records), and a trio consisting of Marcel Moyse, flute; Lily Laskine, harp, and Alice Merckel, viola, has made the Sonata No. 2 (Victor M-873, two twelve-ich records).

Broad discretionary power in public-utility rate-making was granted last week to regulatory, agencies under the United States Supreme Court's ruling sustaining the constitutionality of the Natural Gas Act of 1938. The act and a rate reduction ordered by the Federal Power Commission had been challenged by the Natural Gas Pipe Line Company and the Texoma Natural Gas Company, which, under joint operation, transport gas from the Panhandle field to utilities in Illinois.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., March 21 -- With undergraduate interest in child development study paralleling a present need for trained workers with young children, the Mount Holyoke College Summer session in 1942 will offer a special unit of work in child study, including courses in the field of education and psychology, physiology and sociology.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The Navy announced tonight the probable loss of the United States gunboat Asheville after she had been attacked by the Japanese south of Java early this month.

College students throughout the country have adopted a hopeful, realistic outlook toward the war, and have subordinated all normal activities that might interfere with the war program, a survey of undergraduate editors reveals. All traces of the ivory tower life disappeared when the Pearl Harbor raid began.

Automobile dealers and other persons in businesses whose products have been frozen by order of the Office of Production Management or other government agencies cannot be held to the terms of any leases for space that they might have after the date when their businesses were stopped by government order, according to a decision yesterday by Justice Harold J. Crawford in Municipal Court in Elmhurst, Queens.

NEW ORLEANS, March 21 -- Dartmouth's Indians trailed for seven minutes and then completely dominated the Kentucky Wildcats tonight to win the Eastern Division National Collegiate A.A. basketball championship by the lop-sided score of 47 to 28.

Five-hundred new courses, created to meet wartime education needs, have been added to Columbia University's 1942 Summer Session curriculum, making a total of more than 1,500 courses, the most extensive summer program ever offered by any university, Professor Harry Morgan Ayres, director, announced yesterday.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: "Frost is out -- and peas go in." This applies to both sweet and garden peas. If soil is heavy, two or three inches of sand drilled along the bottom of the trench before planting will assure better germination. If only an inch or so of soil is placed over the seed, the trench can be filled in gradually as the plants grow.

Because his doctor has ordered him to take a rest from the strain of tracking down criminals, Desmond Shannon goes to a tiny island in the West Indies to visit an old friend, Nikolai Andrenov. Does he get his much needed rest?

TAX CUT: There was good news last week for one group of taxpayersgthose of New York State. Governor Lehman signed a bill reducing the State income tax by 25 per cent. The cut, which will be effective this year, will mean a total saving of $87,000,000 to 1Wew York's citizens.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 20 (Delayed) (AP) -- The fall of the Kallay government in Hungary, to be followed by a regime more subservient to Germany, was predicted today by an informed Axis source.

Operations in the oil industry have slumped below those of a year ago. With the exception of a brief period in the depression of the early Nineteen Thirties this is possibly the first time in the history of the industry that operations have failed to hold above those of the previous year.

Enforcement of more than 100 price ceilings and something over twenty-five voluntary price agreements, together with the few rationing systems already under way, has required the expansion of the local inspection staff of the Office of Price Administration and further expansion is contemplated, according to Sylvan L. Joseph, regional director of the OPA office here.

Regardless of the driving rain, J.J. VanGonsic broke 100 straight targets in the scratch event at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. It was the second time this Winter that a perfect score had been made by a Winged Foot gunner.

Here is a story of a family of young people that in their zest for living, their pleasure in simple everyday things, their pluck and perseverance, their sense of humor and their fine personal integrity remind us of the characters created by Louisa Alcott.

ALBANY, March 21 -- A single-sentence bill amending the general municipal law to provide specifically that municipal governments shall be divided into three distinct branches of government, legislative, executive and judicial, will be introduced in the legislature on Monday by Senator Desmond, Republican chairman of the Cities Committee.

OBVIOUSLY too little time has passed since Busoni's death for one to be free to discuss his works objectively and dispassionately; there are still living memories of him and it is almost inevitable that a living dedicatee should spring to his defense with the unfortunate and dubious weapon of personal abuse.

A number of clear-headed Americans merit praise for timely response to a vital social question. I am one of the number that have watched in horror the increasing feminine wear, as described recently in the Magazine, of the masculine leg-covering device, long pants.

IT is not often that musicians consider it necessary or important to explain, by written statements, why they unite in any artistic project. But these are unusual times, and musicians are wise not to take things for granted.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Following a prolonged lull in hostilities in the Battle of Bataan, the War Department reported today "sharp skirmishes" that suggested the long-anticipated Japanese offensive there would soon be launched.

PEORIA, Ill., March 21 -- George P. McNear Jr., president of the Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad, who resisted efforts of President Roosevelt to bring about arbitration of the road's wage and working-conditions dispute, made public today with the consent of Mr. Roosevelt's secretary, Ross T. McIntyre, the text of his seventeen-page refusal to arbitrate the dispute.

Opposition to the proposal for a joint income tax for husbands and wives is uniting national women's organizations as few other current Federal issues have done. Their views on any suggestion for making such a tax mandatory will be given directly to the Ways and Means Committee of the House, when their representatives appear at public hearings to be held in Washington Wednesday and Thursday.

MIAMI, Fla. -- Conforming to a schedule designed to save time and money for competitors in Florida's two big annual pistol matches, the Miami International Open Tournament will start tomorrow on the range of the Palmetto Pistol Club here, continuing through Friday.

The Samaritan Home for the Aged and the Sunnyside Day Nursery will be joint beneficiaries of a benefit performance of "The Moon Is Down," by John Steinbeck, to be presented April 9 at the Martin Beck Theatre. Committees of women prominent in society are now completing arrangements for the event.

CHARLESTON, S.C. -- A late frost retarded the blossoms in gardens hereabouts so that the camellias, usually at their best early in March, are just now in their prime. The shadowy cypress lagoon (part of the Cypress Gardens) is starred with these waxy blooms, looking like spirit flowers against the dim, mysterious background of hanging moss.

TWO years and a half ago a German youth this writer knew in Berlin went into the German Army. He was mobilized in July, 1939, two months before the war began in Poland. His job was driving a gasoline truck, one of a fleet of such tankers which followed the Panzer divisions into the battle lines.

Retail trade continued active last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Consumer demand for Spring coats and suits continued brisk; dresses were fairly good.

"One-two-three-four" chorused from the ballroom or auditorium of a woman's clubhouse these days no longer means a dancing class in progress. It heralds another of the exercise sessions through which members are getting in trim for war duties and "toughening up" for possible emergency tasks.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 21 (U.P.) -- Randall Hughes, who has an artificial leg but desires to join the Air Corps, believes he would be of more value than "some of the fellows with two legs who do not have their hearts in fighting." He is 24 and lost his right leg seventeen years ago in a sandlot football accident.

Under date of March 9, President Roosevelt transmitted to the Senate for its ratification a convention between the United States and Canada "providing for avoidance of double income taxation, modification of certain conflicting principles of taxation, reduction of certain rates of taxation, and establishment of exchange of information between United States and Canada" in income tax matters.

Members of the nursing profession and government representatives interested in the growing need for nursing care for the armed forces will join in a conference tomorrow and Tuesday at the Hotel Stevens, Chicago. The meeting has been called by the Nursing Council on National Defense, headed by Miss Julia Stimson. State nursing organizations will send representatives.

WITH nearly everything in this modern warlike world now more or less "ersatz," even music and radio, it is interesting to discover a movement in the opposite direction. Music on the air -- at least part of it -- is going back to original themes and ideas.

LONDON, Sunday, March 22 (AP) -- The Empire family row over the shift of Richard G. Casey from the post of Australian Minister at Washington to Britain's inner War Cabinet began with Winston Churchill's insistence on the move against the wishes of Prime Minister John Curtin of Australia and finally exploded in a communications mix-up, it was disclosed officially today.

THAT the accomplished M.L. Parrish was not always a flawless technician in the art of book collecting is recorded at the outset of a pleasant little essay by him in the latest number of The Princeton University Library Chronicle.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- Government recapture of all war profits above 6 per cent was proposed today by Senator Walsh, chairman of the Naval Affairs Committee, who said that he would try to write this into a bill approved by the House which would extend the Navy's authority to negotiate contracts without competitive bidding.

Millions of club women throughout the country are being enlisted this week in an anti-hoarding drive. In their day-to-day marketing and home management, leaders contend, women comprise the most important voluntary force for anchoring soaring prices and implementing that essential service to national morale, the equal distribution of goods, as production for the consumer market is curtailed.

The acceptance by the Vatican of a Japanese mission to the Holy See would be entirely justified, Archbishop Francis J. Spellman intimated in an address yesterday morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral, in which he pointed out that the Pope must be impartial and neutral in the world conflict.
