THE all-out war has some striking repercussions in the field of sports. A heavyweight boxing champion of the world came out of the ranks of the last war. A heavyweight boxing champion of the world went into the ranks in this war. Gene Tunney and Joe Louis, in that order.

With lovers of horticultural beauty hailing it as one of the best shows "artistically" ever held here and with commercial exhibitors gleeful about record-breaking sales, the twenty-ninth annual International Flower Show bowed out of the metropolitan scene last night as Spring herself beckoned for the spotlight with a dictatorial gesture.
This attractive and informative book is made up of articles selected from among those which have appeared recently in the garden section of The Home Magazine of the Oregon Sunday Journal.

FAR more novels have been written about National Socialism in Germany than about Italy's dictatorship, perhaps because the undisguised brutality of the Teutonic version of fascism lends itself conveniently to melodramatic fiction.
LINCOLN, Neb., March 21 -- Courses designed especially for the student who can spend only two years on the campus will be offered in ten fields of study by the University of Nebraska next Fall.

NOW on the shelf, whither it moved to make room for "Duffy's Tavern" on Tuesday nights at 9, "We the People" is slated to return (again over WABC) on Sunday, April 26. It will not be quite the same sort of show, though -- more of a "We the People at War," or the average citizen in time of crisis.
MacARTHUR'S HEADQUARTERS, Australia, March 21 (U.P.) -- General Douglas MacArthur escaped capture by a Japanese destroyer in the Philippines only by quick thinking, courage and good luck.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 21 (AP) -- Cornell defeated Syracuse and Colgate, 45 to 27 1/2 and 14 1/2, for the tenth straight year in the annual triangular track meet tonight -- but it was Lynn Radcliffe's show.

KATE AUSTEN, in the years following the first World War, was an attractive Australian girl with wanderlust, a level head and an honest zeal for usefulness. It was natural that she should become a trained nurse and work wherever work was needed in her own country: in the congested areas of cities, the mines and ranches, the pioneer hinterland.
AUGUSTA, Ga. -- The annual seniors' championship golf tournament at the Forest Hills Club will be played over the course tomorrow and Tuesday.

THE third issue of "Dance Index," the new magazine edited by Baird Hastings, Lincoln Kirstein and Paul Magriel, is just out, and it is a pleasure to report how faithfully the publication is living up to its initial promise to constitute itself "a serious attempt to provide a historical and critical basis for judging the present and future of dancing."

Plans are going forward rapidly for the Musicians Emergency Fund dinner to be held on April 7 in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria as a tribute to Dr. Walter Damrosch, dean of American musicians, now in his eightieth year. Mrs. Lytle Hull heads the women's committee for the event; Thomas W. Lamont, the dinner committee, and Albert Spalding, the artists' committee.

While the metropolitan district devotees of badminton have suffered from the lack of courts large enough for their tournaments, the game is still being pursued with enthusiasm in the hinterlands. Now that the New York City armories are closed to badminton due to the war, the only important tournament held here this season was the metropolitan championship which Miss Mary Hagen defended successfully for the third time in a row.

Many of the men in our armed forces are fighting and dying and the rest of us are devoting long hours day and night training for similar roles -- nor do we demand overtime rates beyond forty hours. Yet we read constantly of the dinners, cocktail parties and whatnot in which various -- well, let's be polite and call them citizens -- are indulging at various popular resorts.

THIS is the story of Jonathan Slocum, a high-minded medical quack of the deep Mississippi South -- river boat "doctor," druggist putting out his own elixirs and nostrums, peripatetic peddler and side-show hawker of Dr. Slocum's Golden Discovery Vermifuge and Dr. Slocum's Medical Miracle Chill Tonic, medicaments consisting of alcohol and mildly unpleasant taste which win high favor, especially after prohibition comes along, among others than those suffering from worms or malaria.

MEXICO CITY, March 21 -- The fact that Mexican Foreign Minister Ezequiel Padilla's visit to Washington will approximately coincide with the report of the oil experts evaluating the expropriated United States petroleum holdings in Mexico has given rise to speculation here about a possible early settlement of the question, which in the words of one official, "hangs like a pall over Mexican-American relations."

WASHINGTON, March 21 - Major William P. Fisher, American airman who commanded a heavy bombardment squadron at Clark Field in the Philippines and an interceptor group in East Java, called on President Roosevelt today, and told reporters later that Japanese airmen had shot at American pilots parachuting to earth after bailing out.

THE appointment of Sir Arnold Bax, who succeeds the late Sir Walford Davies as Master of the King's Musick, has been received with satisfaction by the profession, but it has also caused a little surprise. It is not that doubts were ever entertained about the propriety of the choice.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 21 -- Minnesota and its surrounding States seem to be at a stage somewhere between the lethargy and complacence of a few months ago and the complete absorption in the war that is on its way.

In the Spring number of The Yale Review Dr. Cross traces its ancestry down to 1911, when he became its editor. First in the line of unofficial Yale quarterlies conducted by members of the faculty and graduates was The Christian Spectator, sponsored at its birth in 1819 by President Jeremiah Day.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 21 -- K.N. Woodward of Queens received the Atex Grand Award Gold Cup tonight for the outstanding stamp array of the Atex national stamp exhibition at Colton Manor Hotel.

Latin-American university students should come to the United States to learn better methods of study and research, asserts Dr. Estuardo Nunes, a member of the faculty of letters of San Marcos University, oldest university of the New World, at Lima, Peru.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Representative Elliot of Massachusetts wrote today to the House Committee on Accounts, requesting it to take "into account the Dies Committee on un-American Activities and the Ku Kiux Klan.

"A CRITIC," writes Sean O'Faolain in his preface to this first novel by Maura Laverty, "must always be cautious when he falls in love as much as I with 'Never No More.'" The first pages had come to him as editor of a monthly magazine.

TWO American archaeologists, Tim Mulligan and Elsie May Hunt, visit the hacienda of Simon Fonte in a remote section of Colombia. Upon their arrival they find that their host's wife is in a state of terror, the reason for which is not immediately explained.

MR. DAVIS'S first novel makes its mark as a strong characterization of an unusual man against an unusual background. The place is in and around Baudette in Northern Minnesota, a "wild, desolate, blizzardy land."

ABOUT once a year, usually in the Spring, stripes break out as a fashion idea in either clothes or interior decoration. And each time they have a sparkling freshness that stimulates the eye and the disposition. Striped hats, collars, cuffs or gilet with a dark dress are a fine tonic and cheap and easy to make from a yard of cotton or several lengths of wide taffeta ribbon.

The 1942 silhouette is emerging. It's as streamlined as the wings of a bomber. It belongs especially to this age of action. Bouffant skirts are as out of place as idle hands and dull minds. The present demands efficiency in every line.

THE third award of $2,500 in Houghton Mifflin Company's "Life in America" series has been given to Sam Byrd for his book, "Small Town South," which will be published in midsummer. This series and the awards that go with it were inaugurated in 1941, and the previous recipients were Agnes Morley Cleveland for "No Life for a Lady," and Donald Culross Peattie for "The Road of a Naturalist."

FROM his refuge in Switzerland Felix Salten, author of "Bambi" and "Renni, the Rescuer," sends this new group of animal sketches which speak with their old magic, with that sense of the oneness of nature and the unity of all living creatures which is his especial gift.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- No word has been received of the crew of the Asheville, it was indicated here today, and all must be presumed lost.

ON a certain happy day early in 1941 every child in the public schools of New South Wales was given a holiday, and more than a quarter of a million people packed the streets of Sydney to set the heavens resounding with a constant roar of joyous welcome; from seven months of victorious war service, the Australian cruiser Sydney had come home.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The war may have adjourned politics, theoretically, if not actually, but not the Congressional lobby. Pressure groups, as is the war effort, are "all-out."

Acting upon a recommendation made by the Rapp-Coudert Legislative Committee in its interim report on subversive activities in the city's schools, the Board of Higher Education has taken steps to insure a greater control over the extra-curricular activities of the 50,000 students in the four municipal colleges, it was learned yesterday.

THIS Spring marks the fifty-second anniversary of the arrival of the European starling in New York City. And of all birds ever brought here and turned out to shift for themselves none has ever done better, or acted worse.

If the Germans succeed in reaching Iraq in their generally expected drive through the Middle East this Spring, time will still stand across their quest for oil, for all that country's oil wells will be sealed against them despite a still strong pro-Nazi sentiment among the Iraqi, according to Dr. Calvin K. Staudt, founder and for seventeen years director of the American School for Boys in Baghdad.

ASHEVILLE, N.C. -- Famed for many years for its scenery, Roan Mountain on the North Carolina-Tennessee line has been acquired by the United States Forest Service and will be developed and operated by the government as a recreational area.

BERLIN, March 21 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- German troops repulsed six violent Russian attacks yesterday southeast of Lake Ilmen [the Staraya Russa area] and inflicted heavy losses, it was reported today by the German radio.

THE Philharmonic-Symphony had to return $15,000 in checks to those who wrote too late for tickets for the Beethoven cycle that Arturo Toscanini will conduct next month. The box-office never even opened. The subscribers to the society's eight regular series snapped up every ticket, and even they had difficulty.

DETROIT, March 21 -- Negotiations for a new contract between the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers of the C.I.O. continued today to set new patterns in labor relations when C.E. Wilson, president of the company, and Walter P. Reuther, director of the union's General Motors division, agreed to take part in a joint press conference to discuss methods of attaining the maximum war production in the company's ninety plants.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- Immediate establishment of a price "ceiling" for bituminous coal, which commodity, he said, ranked second only to food in importance to the war effort, was recommended today by Luther Harr, counsel for the Bituminous Coal Consumers, an independent Federal agency to protect soft coal users.

Strange Court Procedure Since the beginning of the Riom trial there has been a sense of something odd and novel about the proceedings. You feel that things are not moving the way they should. And then it comes to you with a rush.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C. -- With the hotels filled and reporting large bookings for the Easter holidays, the remainder of March and early April will be marked by several outstanding horse events and golf tournaments.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- A War Department communique based on reports received up to 9:30 A.M. today aid:

LONDON, March 21 (AP)-ztkVictorious Free French forces have returned to their Chad territory bases from a 2,000-mile raiding ex-' pedition that took them into the south of Libya and devastated enemy outposts.

Will Japan fight Russia in the near future? Such a war would complete the circle and mean that every great power was fully lined up on one side or the other in what is far more truly a World War than was the conflict of 1914-18.

An audience of 1,000 attended the jazz concert which was presented late yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. Like the two similar ones that have been given there in the last four weeks, it was presented by Ernest Anderson and directed by Eddie Condon, guitarist.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, March 21 -- Plans for a military attack against the State of Sao Paulo and thereafter on other places in Brazil, by Japanese military forces already here were reported by all afternoon newspapers today.

This is all about patrician young Southern womanhood, personified in Joan of the Bainbridge estate in Virginia. She had been married for two years when what she imagined was the one love of her life died. So she left her career and dragged back to the two aunts and the estate and languished for another two years.

THE fate of some 6,700 feet of Technicolor film shot in the Hawaiian Islands or their vicinity on Dec. 6, 7 and 8 by Twentieth Century-Fox camera crews has been shrouded in mystery for the last three months.

PARTICULARLY noteworthy advances are evident in the work of two of the current exhibitors since their last shows. One of the painters is Douglas Gorsline, whose recent canvases at the Babcock Gallery indicate that the artist is escaping from certain rather overpowering influences in earlier work.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 21 (AP) -- Troops may get "a usuable introduction" to the language and character of the country where they are to be stationed, under a new War Department program. Dean Francis T. Spaulding of the Harvard Graduate School of Education, who is now civilian consultant in the special services branch of the War Department, outlined today a program of study available for soldiers during off-time duty.

THE history of this outstanding journal of the Western Reserve joins the ranks of other newspaper chronicles and well deserves a place on the shelf. The Plain Dealer had its beginnings in the earliest days of that community which was to grow great as the city of Cleveland.

CHICAGO, March 21 (AP) -- Major meat packing concerns have completed arrangements to begin on Monday wholesale selling of pork under the temporary ceiling order invoked by the Office of Price Administration earlier in the month.

The familiar cry "Hi-Ho Silver" has more meaning for boys and girls than you'd think, according to Frederick Wyatt in his psychological study of "The Lone Ranger" (Evaluation of School Broadcasts, Ohio State University). "Everybody will remember occasions, most probably during his adolescence," he says, "when a Certain word or words had a strange emotional effect upon him far beyond their real meaning."

PRINCETON, N.J., March 21 -- Peak efficiency of the individual employe engaged in prolonged war production can be best maintained by a forty-eight-hour work week, according to a study conducted by the industrial relations section of the Department of Economics and Social Institutions of Princeton University, the findings of which were made public today.

MIAMI, Fla., March 21 -- Lightning, they say, does not strike twice in the same place but something of the sort smashed the Giants today when Eddie Lyons, a 19-year-old high school boy from North Carolina, who wrecked Mel Ott's Polo Grounders in Orlando with a pinch single last Thursday, laid the New Yorkers by the heels again today.

A HUNDRED years ago, vacations were frowned upon. The pioneer father who paused not in the course of his labors was held up as the universal example. Every one was expected to hold to the simpler virtues, including the sanctity of work, and leisure was justified only by illness.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- President Roosevelt today commandeered the 239-mile Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad after the company president, George P. McNear Jr., rejected for the sixth time urgent Federal appeals that he arbitrate a wage dispute which resulted in a strike of 104 engineers and trainmen on Dec. 28.

TORONTO, March 21 -- Toronto took a one-game lead in the Stanley Cup semi-finals by downing the Rangers, 3 to 1, before 13,313 spectators at Maple Leaf Gardens tomight. The second contest of the four-out-of-seven series will be played in Madison Square Garden, New York, tomorrow night.

Treated like recruits although they could not enlist, eight youngsters previously found the most fit among 50,000 members of boys' clubs in the city passed standard Army examinations with flying colors yesterday before a board of four doctors at Governors Island.

More than fifty Barnard College students are giving three hours of volunteer service a week to settlements, hospitals, refugee bureaus and other social service agencies throughout New York City, it was disclosed yesterday by Miss Jane Devonshire, chairman of the Community Service Bureau at Barnard.

LONDON, March 21 -- An advanced force of 600 Japanese troops who had occupied Letpadan, key junction about seventy-five miles north of Rangoon on the railroad running to Prome, has been driven out of the town by a detachment of a Gloucester regiment, according to a Burma communique issued in New Delhi today.
America today is producing weapons of war in large volume.

It's up to everybody to make their houses and apartments the pleasantest possible places these days -- with so much talk about how we shall all be doing more of our living at home in the future. One place to start is with background colors.

The American Youth Commission composed of leading educators and laymen has been studying for six years every phase of the "youth problem" in the United States and has now issued its final report. That report, "Youth and the Future," definitely orients the commission's findings toward answering two questions: What are the most urgent things which must be done for and by youth now in the light of the national emergency?

In the March issue of American Forests the leading article points out the immense destruction that could so easily be caused by the dropping of incendiary bombs from enemy planes over the vast forest lands of the Pacific Coast.

ON Dec. 30, 1941, Manuel Quezon was inaugurated for the second time as President of the 6-year-old Philippine Commonwealth, with Sergio Osmena as Vice President. The inauguration might normally have earned a few lines of type in American newspapers.
BERLIN, March 21 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- Today's German High Command communique follows:

NEXT Thursday Arturo Toscanini has his seventy-fifth birthday. There will be no fuss about it, and few, if any, outside his household circle will be with him. For if ever there was a man with a detestation of ceremony, it is this one. Toscanini wil be as happy as he can be in the present state of the world, which gives him agony, with his family.

WHEN, several years ago, Glenn Ford took his first screen test, the talent prospectors at Paramount subjected him to "corrective make-up" and dressed him in tails. The result was a painfully juvenile replica of Noel Coward.

CANBERRA, Australia, March 21 -- Messages received today from Papua reported that the withdrawal of the Australian civil administration from Japanese-invaded Northeast New Guinea had resulted in an outbreak of tribal warfare among the natives in the wild Sepik River area. This outbreak threatens not only the whites remaining in the area but also any Japanese troops who may filter through from the Huon Gulf, where the Japanese have made several landings.

CHICAGO, March 21 -- Hart Schaffner Marx, Chicago manufacturers of men's clothing, sent its retail store customers this week a special letter outlining the changes entailed by the recent wool conservation order and pointing out that it "is evident that many people have the wrong idea about what the changes involve."

OMAHA, Neb., March 21 -- The accusation of complacency has been having considerable play here in the geographical heart of the country, and that heart is inclined to beat somewhat resentfully over it. Whatever the truth may be of Middle Westerners in the mass, individually they do not think they are at all complacent.
NEW DELHI, India, March 21 (AP) -- British Headquarters issued this communique today:

SAN FRANCISCO, March 21 -- Every Japanese gain in the southwest Pacific brings to this coast a greater awareness of the war. Outward calm can no longer be interpreted as indifference. Contrary to what appears to be the conception in some other parts of the country, California residents are not huddled fearfully in their blackout rooms or in bomb shelters waiting for the incendiaries to all.

Activity at wholesale was well maintained last week, with most of the ready-to-wear markets showing the customary pre-Easter action, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.

DURING the past few weeks Howard Lindsay, irate parent of "Life With Father," has been asking why the drama critics have not risen in protest against the city's despotic closing down of the burlesque shows.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 21 (U.P.) -- Japanese propagandists, less adept than their Nazi teachers, got their wires crossed yesterday in reporting the "death" of Manuel Quezon, President of the Philippines Commonwealth.

BOSTON, March 21 -- The emotional outburst which followed Pearl Harbor has passed away. Instead, there exists now throughout New England a spirit of grim determination, and the sober and deliberate attitude of this people toward their responsibilities in this war is more significant than was the paroxysm of anger which the attack on Hawaii produced.

Declaring that the National War Labor Board's most important job is to settle labor disputes so as to guarantee a maximum production of war materials, Wayne L. Morse, public member of the board, said last night he is opposed to any restrictive legislation fixing a wage ceiling or which otherwise would limit the board in deciding each dispute on the facts.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- This week Americans started to get official reports on bad news as well as good, and the government, through the Office of Facts and Figures, reported that "the people of a democracy are entitled to know the facts, whether they are good or bad, cheerful or depressing."

Miss Howard has divided the setting of her two or three other novels published here between England and Egypt. This one is almost entirely in Egypt, and is correspondingly sultrier. About half way through, when the Egyptian prince hints to the two English girls of certain societies of assassins, one feels murder coming on.
CHUNGKING, China, March 21 (AP) -- It may be the task of Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, commander of United States forces in China, India and Burma, to clear the bases from which to bomb Japan.

FOR SALE -- a limited number of unrationed 1942 cars. Warning -- save your permanent antifreeze mixture drained from the radiator. These are two items of interest to motorists announced recently in Washington by the Office of Price Administration.

THE girl of the title is Margaret Weldon, a devout young person picking wild flowers in memory of her mother, who had wandered under those trees. The boy was sobbing on the ground when she first saw him.
Definite dates for the Spring regattas of the Intercollegiate Yacht Racing Association were announced yesterday, including those for the national championships and the Coast Guard Bowl.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., March 21 -- Clark D. Shaughnessy, who went from a school that gave up football to one that reached the Rose Bowl in his first year, will report as head coach at the University of Maryland in about a week to take on a new job and security.

Trade buying and hedge sales featured trading in cotton futures again yesterday in a moderately active session on the New York Cotton Exchange. Prices of active contracts moved within a 6-point range, and finished with net gains of 1 to 4 points.

LONDON, March 21 -- The reverses of the United Nations in the Pacific are forcing drastic reductions in the consumption of commodities here. Although further cuts in rations may be expected, the week produced a reduction in household fuel to save coal stocks, and one in the clothing ration to save shipping and the labor of bringing wool from Australia.

A DASH of wine gives the same luxurious lift to a simple dish as a spray of orchids does to last year's dress. Both the wine and the orchids induce that delightful, best-is-none-too-good feeling. Cooking with wine, however, unlike bedecking one's self with orchids, is happily not an expensive procedure.
PANAMA, March 21 -- Latin America like Gaul is divided into three parts so far as contribution to the effort needed to win the war against the Axis powers is concerned.

While many individual filling stations are expected to close today, no general shut-down of gasoline dealers because of rationing was anticipated yesterday by spokesmen for dealer groups throughout the city. In Long Island areas, however, the beginning of "gasless Sundays" was expected.

In years of peace the Travelers Aid Society did a remarkable job of directing bewildered visitors to their proper destinations, rounding up stray children from other cities and quietly straightening out the inevitable tangles that travel entails. Now that we are at war, the task of the society has more than doubled.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Housewives and older students must prepare themselves to fill 5,300,000 war jobs in the next two years, A. Ford Hinrichs, Acting Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, warned today.

COIIANDER: From headquarters [ at 2Vfandalay, in the country of pagodaI crowned hills, the commander of British forces in Burma, Lieut. Gen. Harold Rupert Leorio George Alexander, spoke last Week of tactics.

With the three top-seeded teams out of the picture as the result of last week's stirring first-round competition, the fifth annual national invitation basketball tournament will be completed this week. The semi-finals will be played at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night and the final and third-place game on Wednesday.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 21 (AP) -- The West New York Memorial High School romped off with the Group IV title tonight by downing Asbury Park High School's defending champions, 51 to 37, to end the twenty-fourth annual New Jersey interscholastic athletic association basketball tournament.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 21 -- Joe DiMaggio exploded his first home run of the year today against the Cardinals at Waterfront Park. Joe Gordon, the Old Rock, stroked his second and these two clouts for the circuit, coupled with a bit of perfect pitching by Atley Donald, brought the Yankees a victory that pulled them out of a couple of losing streaks.

INDIANA, Pa., March 21 -- Student response to a constructive emergency program at the Pennsylvania State Teachers College has been gratifying to the administration and faculty, according to an announcement made today by President Leroy A. King.

The people of Luxembourg, continuing to resist attempts to Germanize them, ruined a recent census plan of the Nazi invaders, according to information smuggled out of the Grand Duchy and just arrived here.

For a twinkle in the eye of a traffic officer or the open-mouthed admiration of the elevator boy a woman is willing to suffer much discomfort and squander a fortune. In a relentless search for that ineffable "feeling of beauty" the American woman spends half a billion dollars a year on lotions and lipsticks and enlists for stiff fees in institutions of the before-and- after variety -- the Cinderella schools.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 21 -- The only consistent characteristic of the Dodgers is their inconsistency. Yesterday they massaged Yankee pitchers for nineteen hits. Today they were limited to three puny singles by a couple of rookies as Joe Cronin's Red Sox turned them back by 8 -- 1.

Whatever the truth may be about Hollywood, in fiction it is firmly established as a completely wacky community whose only god is the motion picture industry and whose only priests and lawgivers are the motion-picture moguls.

AGE gives way to youth in the High Commands. "Men shut their doors against the setting sun," says Shakespeare. "Superfluous lags the veteran on the stage," says Dr. Johnson. "We must be young to do great things," says Goethe.

With proper enforcement and, better still, widespread observance of a voluntary character, the forty-mile-an-hour speed limit on the highways, urged upon the Governors of all States by President Roosevelt, should serve several highly useful purposes in the emergency.

EXPERIENCE in England has shown that children in a family stand up to wartime experiences pretty much as their parents do. There were further sidelights on the effect of war upon children abroad -- and at home since Pearl Harbor -- at the recent conference of the American Orthopsychiatric Association in Detroit.

A patriotic contribution to the Nation's war production program is needed from college trained women today. While the country's industrial pace is constantly steppe up, trained workers essential to these industries are at the same time taken from their positions to join the armed forces.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- Contracts for fifty-eight additional mechant ships, twenty-six tankers and thirty-two emergency cargo vessels were awarded today by the Maritime Commission.

American education today is confused, lacks perspective and makes a fetish of change, Dr. Edgar W. Knight, Kenan Professor of Education at the University of North Carolina, asserts in the current issue of the Kappa Delta Pi lecture series.

The scene of this thriller is the national capital, and the story's most entertaining feature is its Washington chatter. When Lila Donnelly is acquitted after a sensational trial for murder her dear friends lose no opportunity for catty gossip as they gather at the big party given in celebration by her lawyer's young wife.

A plan for pooling office machines, under which companies would meet the growing shortage of typewriters and other equipment by shifting them from one department to another to handle fluctuations in activity, was suggested last week by a number of companies that have installed the system in recent years strictly as an advance in office management.

The full impact of war conditions on the nation's commercial banking system will be reflected importantly for the first time in the quarterly statements of condition soon to be issued. Loans to war industries have increased sharply in the three-month period now drawing to a close, and holdings of United States Government securities have increased.
MOSCOW, March 21 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

Retail trade here continued active last week, with estimates putting department store sales ahead of the corresponding week last year by 22 per cent or more. Expanding demand for Spring apparel was reported, with home furnishings volume well maintained.

The annual sale of the New York Division of the Women's National Farm and Garden Association will be held on Wednesday at the home of Mrs. Stephen C. Clark, 46 East Seventieth Street. The event will open at 10 o'clock in the morning and will continue throughout the afternoon when tea will be served.

Bills which have been introduced in both legislative houses at Albany to terminate the active service of teachers at the age of 65 are being strongly supported by the Public Education Association, one of the oldest lay organizations in New York City, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Samuel A. Lewisohn, director.

CHICAGO, March 21 -- Week-end evening-up by shorts was largely responsible today for a firmer undertone in the stain and soy bean markets on the Board of Trade here. There was a lack of the scattered liquidation and stop-loss selling that was evident yesterday, and in some quarters the belief prevailed that the markets had passed into an oversold condition.

I DO not suppose the author of "Lean Men," "The Olive Field," the fantastic "Rainbow Fish" and the collection of short stories and sketches called "Sirocco" needs an introduction here. But a reminder might be in order.

THIS department welcomes rebuttal. We have regard for the fellow who replies -- provided, of course, his rejoinder makes sense and doesn't make us look too bad. That is why we were excited by the suggestion of Ernst Lubitsch some days ago that he write a dissenting opinion to our daily review of his new film, "To Be or Not To Be."

WHILE they have their fingers crossed for the important two weeks before Easter, retailers were amazed last week at consumer ability to double up on income tax payments and still keep on buying at a rate that maintained substantial gains over a year ago.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Attacking organized labor in terms seldom used by an official, Thurman Arnold, assistant attorney general, accused the unions today of a long list of misdeeds which he asserted were preventing the efficient use of men and machines and hampering the distribution of civilian necessities.

As a result of government controls over inventories of most important raw materials and the abandonment of forward buying by industry, purchasing agents expect a lifting of pressure on many commodities and the consequent development of weak spots in prices, they reported here last week.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 21 -- Key members of a Japanese secret society, closely allied with the notorious Black Dragon, were seized here today by Federal agents. Several of those taken were described as gamblers and gunmen, at least one of whom had served a penitentiary term for a slaying.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- War Production Board officials said today that an order was being prepared to forbid priority aid to all nonessential construction, including private dwellings outside defense housing areas, and probably would be issued soon.

TO the French people it is in the nature of things that childhood should be a happy age. Writers and artists through the changing eras of France's history have found inspiration in the family life which, among peasants and city dwellers alike, exemplified the Frenchman's love and concern for children. Today, when the concentration camp has replaced family life for thousands of French children, the past illumi nates the present with a bitter irony.

The dogs of America may bark their way down the corridors of history with the geese whose cackling saved Rome as a result of the approval, announced yesterday by the Army Quartermaster Corps, of a plan to train dogs for sentry duty.

Dr. Harry Kline, erstwhile University of Pennsylvania star, and Harry Baker of the Steinitz Chess Club were first-round victors in Section A of the United States Chess Federation championship preliminaries yesterday at the Marshall Club.

Miss Gloria Callen of the Women's Swimming Association of New York shattered another of the former Miss Eleanor Holm's back-stroke marks by covering 100 meters in 1:14.8 in a special exhibition that featured an aquatic carnival in the pool of the New York Athletic Club last night.
"MacArthur has gone to Australia." That word flashed swiftly over the world last Tuesday and stirred the hearts of all Americans.

It is fortunate for the American war effort and for our after-war economy that, within and outside the military services, there are men who have a real understanding of the almost limitless highway in a new dimension which aviation has thrown open. In foreign affairs one of these men, Grover Loening, presents a stimulating argument for the immediate production and use of large cargo planes as an urgent war measure.

In one respect Inspector Luke Bradley is old-fashioned. In situations where most modern detectives would explode into language that used to be represented by dashes (that was before our literati lost their inhibitions), Luke merely exclaims "Mercy!"

FOR the people of the Confederate States of America the Fourth of July, 1863, produced news almost as discouraging as that we are getting today as the Japanese accumulate victories. On that day Lee was stopped at Gettysburg, and Vicksburg, last stronghold of the South on the Mississippi, was surrendered to General Grant, with 30,000-odd men and large stores of arms and ammunition.

A flood of anonymous letters accusing the recipients of various crimes or indiscretions disrupts the social life of a peaceful English village. So many persons are suspected of having written the letters that scarcely any one feels safe in associating with any one else.

BETHEL, Me., March 21 -- With the dedication recently of a new home economics cottage by Mrs. Sumner Sewall, wife of Maine's Governor, the Gould Academy has begun a program of teaching girls the science of "right home living."
MELBOURNE, Australia, March 21 (U.P.) -- Shore batteries at Christmas Island, in the Indian Ocean, have sunk a Japanese submarine, it was revealed today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 21 -- Berlin hinted today that the next few weeks would bring developments of "utmost importance" regarding Turkey. Spokesmen for the Reich's Foreign Office did not commit themselves on details, but pointed to Ambassador Franz von Papen's trip from Ankara to Berlin and to the journey of Turkish Minister R. Husrev Gerede in the opposite direction.

CHICAGO, Ill., March 21 -- As a result of the accelerated three-year program, causing the colleges and universities to operate on a twelve-month basis, college libraries will have a greater strain placed on them than ever before, Charles H. Brown, president of the American Library Association, declared today.

As part of its morale-building program, Hunter College defense headquarters announced yesterday the formation of a correspondence bureau which will take over the task of providing girls to write "intelligent and entertaining" letters to men in the armed forces.

IN the Summer of 1882 the 4-year-old son of a tailor in San Antonio looked on, fascinated, at the desperado killing which began one of the most lurid of Southwestern serials. Over a span of years, writes M. Koenigsberg in his autobiography, "I sold the yarn, revamped on each occasion, to thirty different newspapers."

IN an age when film beauty concerns itself with a froth of tortured curls, eyelids weighted with a preposterous fringe of false lashes and a lower lip like an amplified frankfurter, there is something strangely refreshing in the untampered with and faintly acerb appearance of an Aline MacMahon.

CHICAGO, March 21 -- There is no complacency in Illinois and neighboring States, once known as isolationism's stronghold, concerning the war. The martial spirit is evident. Everywhere may be found a grim determination to fight the war to victory, with full realization of the price which the fight will exact.
INDIANTOWN GAP, Pa., March 21 (AP) -- Three Sergeant Osmans are serving in the Army here, a father and two sons.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 21 -- Officers who arrived here with General Douglas MacArthur said today that en route from the Philippines their party was forced to lie low to escape a Japanese destroyer sighted in the distance.

Amid the picturesque setting of the "street of the United Nations," 6 East Fifty-seventh Street, yesterday afternoon, messages of hope, cheer and ultimate victory were projected over the powerful short-wave radio of WRUL to the peoples of those countries who have felt the heel of Axis aggression.

THE fact that 52,000,000 persons already have paid more than $30,000,000 for the privilege of viewing "Gone With the Wind" in its first two rounds of the nation's theatres is no deterrent to either David O. Selznick, its producer, or Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, the contented distributors.

The airing of the Guthrie case and its charges that the war effort is suffering from too many "practical" men, brought forth the assertion by foreign traders last week that their contribution to defense is being hampered by the very lack of such experts.

A.J. McCarthy, vice president of the United States Lines and a veteran shipping operator in the North Atlantic trades, was elected a director of the line last week at a special meeting of the board. He was also elected a director of the International Mercantile Marine Company, the parent organization within which the United States Lines and other shipping lines have been members for many years.

FASCINATING the Henri Rousseau restrospective exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art undeniably is. But I think this fascination resides to a very large extent in the incongruous melange of elements that, taken together, create problems not solved, it seems to me, either on the walls or in Daniel Carton Rich's exhibition book.

HAMILTON, N.Y., March 21 -- Colleges which are accelerating their programs in order to cover in three years' work formerly covered in four might do well to have their men and women students study in unmixed groups to avoid time wasting, Dr. F. Kenneth Berrien of Colgate University said today in a psychology department report on "How Quickly Do Students Start Studying?"

Adapting its special abilities to wartime needs, the Garden Club of America has accepted the task of creating gardens for sixty-eight Red Cross recreational buildings in Army camps throughout the country. Member clubs have already completed thirty-four in the Western and Southern States where climatic conditions have permitted hem to carry on during the Winter.
Antique as well as contemporary furniture and furnishings are included in auction sales here this week.

The Navy announced yesterday the sinking of two more American ships, described merely as "large merchant vessels," and of a smaller Honduran ship. Only six lives were lost in the attacks on the American merchantmen, but forty-four persons, including three women, two girls and a small boy, are missing in the sinking of the Central American craft.

The best aid to memory is a picture. We plan to have our family camera fan photograph the garden every two weeks during the coming season. Next Winter this exciting and instructive record will recall our garden so vividly and in such detail that our enjoyment will be doubled and trebled.

PHILADELPHIA, March 21 -- Temple University's undefeated girls swimming team established two intercollegiate records today in overcoming the previously unbeaten New York University mermaids, 32 to 25, in Conwell Hall pool.

The Actors Equity Association, plagued for several years by charges of "Red control" of its governing board, settled the question it was disclosed yesterday by approving in a referendum of its membership the adoption of the proposed constitutional amendment barring Communists, Nazis and Fascists from holding office or being employed by the union.

SHORT stories are a strange inconsistency of the American public. It will absorb and like them, by the hundreds of thousands, when they are published in pulps and elevated periodicals, but when collected between covers they are not generally so popular.

JERUSALEM, March 21 -- Roman ruins. Phoenician glass and some marble coffins dating back more than 1,000 years before Christianity have been found by workers constructing the rail line between Haifa, Palestine, and Tripoli, Lebanon, which will close the gap in rail communications from Egypt to Turkey.

ANTHONY EDEN, reporting on atrocities he said were committed by the Japanese on prisoners at Hong Kong, termed "nauseating hypocrisy" the long-standing Japanese claim that their armed forces are all governed by "bushido," the ancient knightly code of the samurai.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals in a unanimous decision here yesterday upheld the conviction of Joseph M. Schenck, former chairman of the board of directors of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, and Joseph H. Moskowitz, his confidential associate, for income tax evasion.

On Jan. 20 the House Naval Affairs Committee published a very formidable report on profits made on Government contracts and on other matters. It contained nearly 300 pages of complex tables and charts alone and ran to the equivalent of some 230,000 words. Nowhere in the report was there any compact and readable summary of its full contents.

While some of the towns in the area along the New Jersey coast and for ten miles inland, which were ordered to dim all lights for the duration of the war by the New Jersey State Defense Council on Friday, had dim-outs last night, as they did on Friday night, others had complete blackouts because of their inability to get dim-out equipment in time.

LONDON, March 21 -- Great Britain's far-flung Empire has been rocked to its foundations by the impact of the war. Economic stress and the dynamics of revolution, as well as the armed might of the enemy, have placed a heavy strain on the tenuous links that bind the dominions and colonies to the crown.

CHICAGO, March 21 -- All sugar sales in the United States will be halted at midnight April 27 for about one week, government officials announced here today after they had set six days in April and May for the nation-wide sugar rationing registration.

THE diamond, says the author of this book, is an explosive subject. Certainly it is also, as he goes on to say, a subject which has "many facets of human, historical, technical and popular interest." James Remington McCarthy has brought out that interest with a good deal of freshness, as well as necessary technical detail, in the picturesquely named "Fire in the Earth."

Robert H. Patchin, vice president of W.R. Grace Co., told 500 members of the Foreign Policy Association at a luncheon meeting yesterday at the Hotel Astor that "the arsenal of democracy is effective only as its production can be delivered to the fighting fronts overseas."

Prices of shares moved little yesterday on tile New York Stock Exchange. They closed steady and mixed in the dullest and narrowest Saturday session since last August. Volume was only 160,690 shares, against 174,640 on the previous Saturday.
May I attempt briefly to answer the letter of Dr. Gustav Stolper which appeared in the March 15 edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES. I take issue with Dr. Stolper on the following points:

FROM Leopoldville comes word that Belgian Congo has issued a large-sized bicolored 50-francs plus 50c semi-postal for the benefit of the Belgian Spitfire Fund, the design being a native scene with Spitfire planes superimposed.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 21 -- President Walter C. Coffey is conducting a survey of the University of Minnesota to determine where economies can best be effected if loss of student enrollment, accompanied by loss of fees, makes necessary any sharp contraction.

In an address entitled "Women Wanted" Miss Naomi Ranson, chairman of the West Side Federal Savings and Loan Association, told the second annual regional conference of the American Savings and Loan Institute, District 2, at the Hotel McAlpin yesterday that the magnitude of the war effort made it clear "that only through a large scale employment of women can the necessary production be accomplished to win this war."

Bob White is whistling in the meadows. Across the stubble, through the upland fields and along the hedgerows the bird dogs are ranging wide. Sportsmen, whistles dangling from neckcords, trudge behind them watching every move of their charges, stopping now and again to draw in deep drafts of early Spring air.

Only a sparkling performance by an outstanding Columbia foils trio prevented New York University from achieving a clean sweep of the team crowns in the forty-ninth annual Intercollegiate Fencing Association championships, concluded last night at the Salle Santelli.

Valuable furniture, tapestries and furnishings, including a palace carpet used at a court held by Queen Victoria, were sold at auction yesterday in the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Councilman Stanley M. Isaacs of Manhattan announced yesterday his intention to submit to the City Council on Tuesday a resolution to protect the pension rights of city employes now serving in the nation's armed forces who are not receiving from the city the differential between their military pay and the pay formerly received on their city jobs.

MEXICO CITY -- Mariano Gallego, the guide, has an idea that not all Americans want to see the pyramids, the cathedrals, and the night clubs in Mexico. He thinks the visitor may want to see Mexico City's real estate developments.

COLUMBUS, down in Mississippi, the "Sleeping Beauty of the Deep South," Will be very much awake on April 10, 11 and 12 as she dons her hoopskirt and puts her best foot forward through the ruffles of her pantalets to welcome the guests of her third annual Pilgrimage.

DESPITE the war, Town Hall bookings indicate an unusually busy year ahead in the musical field. Not only do the bookings of Town Hall's concert department for next season outnumber those made last year at this time, but several new concert series will be given.

SO great a success was "This Above All," his novel of England after Dunkerque, that I am afraid it may have obscured the memory of Mr. Knight's earlier triumphs. Specifically -- though it seems incredible -- I fear that some people have now labeled him as a wholly serious writer and have forgotten that he is also the creator of the immortal Sam Small.

"THE British are a queer bunch. They pan themselves so much that you never know really how good they are." This comment, made by an American military observer as we were following a battalion of Warwickshire Yeomanry into battle, implies a state of good-natured bewilderment shared by many in the Middle East reporting on the habits of a host that consists mainly of amateurs -- the British Expeditionary Force.

It is arresting to find on the title page of a book for children the name of a writer who through his three books for adults, "Ancient Civilizations of the Andes," "The Fall of the Inca Empire" and "The Spanish Main," has won recognition as the leading authority on Peruvian history and archaeology.

An American bomber of the Eastern Air Forces, surprising an enemy submarine on the surface in an undisclosed area off the Eastern United States coast, destroyed the U-boat with depth charges, Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commanding the Eastern Army Forces, announced last night.

AUSTRALIA, once the most isolated of continents, has become a war zone. Japanese bombs have fallen on mainland airdromes and on strategic ports like that of Darwin. For the military and industrial effort that support modern warfare the 7,000,000 people of Australia have been totally mobilized, mobilized to defend the homeland that is now menaced by the Japanese cruisers, aircraft carriers and transports that slash across northern shipping and air routes.

FORREST DAVIS has written a vigorous tract for the time which might well have been called "The Genesis of the Atlantic Charter." He sees in that declaration the clearest verbal expression thus far of a trend in Anglo-American relations which originated about 1890 and which may culminate in a post-war collaboration to achieve an American-British peace not dissimilar in character to the Pax Britannica of the nineteenth century.

THE name of Juan Beautista Plaza of Venezuela should be added to the list of Latin-American composers who have visited this country, for he is here for a three-month stay at the invitation of the Pan American Union. He will study our methods of teaching music and lecture on the colonial music of his country in New York and other cities.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Merits of the "dollar-a-year" executive drafted from business to give government the benefit of his special knowledge and experience, are again challenged through the resignation of Robert R. Guthrie, chief of the textile, clothing and leather goods branch of the War Production Board.
The Social Security Board is considering a payroll tax of 1 per cent to defray the cost of hospital care of sick and disabled workers. Half the tax would come from the worker, half from his employer.

The charge that Nazi propaganda was "behind this whole movement to do away with wage and hour standards" was made yesterday by L. Metcalfe Walling, recently appointed administrator of the wage and hour division of the United States Department of Labor.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce, defended himself in a report of Reconstruction Finance Corporation operations, published today, against allegations that he had delayed the program for making synthetic rubber.

A musical score of twelve numbers, including a song, "I'm in Love With the Flower of Flatbush," dedicated to Brooklyn, has been selected for "Saints Alive," the forty-ninth annual varsity show of Columbia University. The production, written by university students, will be given in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Astor Thursday and Friday evenings and in the Scarsdale (N.Y.) High School auditorium next Saturday.

Last year, before its defeat in the House, I endeavored to expose the evil consequences of "Mandatory Joint Tax Return of Husband and Wife Living Together." Now, before its resurrection is attempted, I shall try to expose the errors of certain statements which then helped to win the surprising vote of one-third of the House.

The primary purpose of my letter dealing with the Indian and Irish questions, upon which several of your correspondents have commented, was to suggest that it would be disastrous if a dispute between Indian or Irish parties, or between those parties and the British Government, should somehow become a dispute between the American and British peoples or governments.

It is pleasant to have available in convenient and attractive form a collection of verse written by Negro poets, but aside from its racial interest "Golden Slippers" is a fresh and appealing anthology that schools and libraries will welcome and all young poetry lovers will enjoy.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 21 (AP) -- A woman set foot for the first time today on glistening American Bowling Congress alleys that had been so carefully feminine-proofed throughout the forty-two-year history of the classic.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- A new interpretation of the conditions under which men engaged in civilian activities necessary to war production or essential to the support of the war effort may be deferred from service in the armed forces was issued today by the Selective Service system.

The Australian radio, in a broadcast recorded by the Columbia Broadcasting System yesterday, reported an exchange of messages between William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, and the Australian Council of Trade Unions, in which Mr. Green pledged American labor to do its part in building war materials for Australia.
ATLANTA, March 21 -- The Southeast is in a fighting mood about the American war effort, a feeling intensified by various casualty reports.

HAVANA -- The Ministry of Communications has made available an advance photograph of a half-cent postal tax stamp which will be for obligatory use, in addition to normal postage, on all classes of mail, the income to benefit the National Red Cross.

MADISON, Wis., March 21 -- An Army institute of correspondence to help soldiers continue their educational training at the same time that they serve in the nation's armed forces will be established by the Federal Government at the University of Wisconsin this Spring, President C.A. Dykstra has announced.
MELBOURNE, Australia, March 21 -- Lieutenant T.H. Moorer, United States Naval aviator, was credited today with the rescue of two crews, that of his own seaplane and another from a ship.

Increased efforts to broaden the personnel guidance services in the evening division of Brooklyn College, bringing it closer to standards set for the day session, are being made this semester, Dr. James W. Park, director of the night session, announced yesterday.

A FIRST-RATE story, with no apparent marks of collaboration upon it, is this novel by Houston Branch and Frank Waters. It might be called a historical novel, and show better claim to the title than many works more pretentiously burdened with scholarship.

A demand for the establishment of a "very definite" wartime labor policy to insure the maximum production of essential materiel for the forces was voiced last night by Representative John W. Boehne Jr., Democrat of Indiana, at the eighteenth annual banquet of the Real Estate Board of the Bronx in the Hotel Commodore.

TO drive or not to drive? The once carefree owners of private automobiles are in a quandary. They can't decide whether to store their cars or maintain them ready for use. On the one hand the life span of their tires is wheeling out and gas ration cards are but a few weeks away.

The 1,630-ton United States destroyer Buchanan, named for the first American naval officer to set foot on Japanese soil, was commissioned yesterday morning at a ceremony in the New York Naval Yard, Brooklyn, in the presence of 400 naval personnel, yard workers and invited guests.

Under arrangements with the belligerent powers, Swedish shipping has continued through the first weeks of 1942 at approximately the rate maintained through 1941, it was announced here last week by the American-Swedish News Exchange.

In about two weeks a telegram, addressed to us, will arrive from an old friend who lives on the shore of a lake up in Maine, but some one else will open that wire this Spring and read the few but exciting words: "The ice is out."

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 21 -- Although Chile is awaiting a definite report on the sinking of the Tolten before deciding whether to file a protest, the government meanwhile has been maintaining contacts with representatives of the Axis in hope of obtaining their guarantee that Chilean ships will be permitted to continue transporting copper nitrates and other materials to the United States, informed sources said today.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 21 -- With the United States building up the largest fighting force in her history, many observers believe the time will soon come when -- as in the case of the last war -- young men with dependents will have to be drafted into the armed forces in large numbers.

Miss Thayer Gibbons heads the junior committee, and Miss Joan Russell the debutante committee, aiding in the sale of tickets for the special performance of "Village Green," a comedy by Carl Allensworth, to be presented by the Amateur Comedy Club on the night of April 7 at the Heckscher Theatre for the benefit of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, March 21 -- Courses allied with national defense and the current war situation have been under way at the University of Iowa for the past year. In recent months the tempo of these courses has been stepped up, enrollments have increased and new studies have been added to the curriculum.

WASHINGTON'S famous cherry blossoms will soon put on their big Spring show and visitors as in other years will follow the paths leading to one of the city's most popular beauty spots. Though this year there will be no Cherry Blossom Festival, the orchard's site is an important unit in the stretch of shade trees, flowers and promenades, so inviting on a sunny day.

ILKA CHASE has been an actress since her boarding-school days; and as these began when she was 5, her histrionic skills may reasonably be said to be lifelong. But when you read the first chapter of her autobiography you know that her grandmother could well have supplied not only an inheritance but an example of talent, resolution and temperament.

DODGE CITY, Kan., March 21 -- Farmers in the Wheat Belt, where the labor shortage may be acute at harvest time because of the drain of war and war industries on the young men, will depend on women and girls rather than on enemy aliens.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- The long smoldering Philippine fighting front burst into flame today, and the American-Filipino defenders braced for a new full-scale Japanese offensive.

CHICAGO, March 21 -- Plans for a united Protestant assembly in 1944 that would bring 50,000 to 100,000 churchmen in conference here were revealed yesterday at a conference of interdenominational leaders. The object would be the promotion of brotherhood and Christian unity.

DETROIT -- An exponent of the lightweight, economy car for civilian war driving is William B. Stout, automotive and aircraft designer, who several years ago introduced, without much success, his rear-engined tear-drop Scarab car.

It has been widely noted that Hitler's speech of a week ago lacked the note of confidence which was present in Nazi utterances as recently as last October. He spoke of the "economic misery" which, he said, had been inflicted upon the German people by the Treaty of Versailles.

Among the first signs of Spring in the furniture shops is the advent of picturesque chests, cupboards and coffee tables with painted designs. Those who have looked in vain throughout Pennsylvania for an old-time dower chest or a kitchen dresser decked out with painted tulips, romantic hearts and Old-World legends can now find freshly painted examples which may reflect an even greater charm.

WATERVILLE VALLEY, N.H., March 21 -- Feature competition of the 1941-42 ski season for women in this part of the country is slated tomorrow when the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association holds its annual downhill, slalom and combined fixtures under the auspices of the Black and Blue Trail Smashers of Lowell, Mass.

IT is not often that a commemorative concert can be arranged of so fitting a character as the one that will be given by the Schola Cantorum next Wednesday night in honor of the career and achievements of the late Kurt Schindler, founder of the Schola Cantorum, which he established as a choral body in 1909.

DONALD FRANCIS TOVEY, who died in Edinburgh on July 10, 1940, at the age of 65, was one of Britain's most active and influential musicians. He wrote music, played it, wrote about it, lectured about it and worked for it.

The General Motors Corporation will launch today a threefold program to help to train the great number of mechanics needed to maintain modern armies and fleets, to place its own engineers in the field to observe operating experience, and to assist the Army and Navy in having replacement parts on the spot when needed.

The New York premiere of the Twentieth Century-Fox technicolor production, "To the Shores of Tripoli," which will take place on Wednesday evening at the Roxy Theatre, is under the sponsorship of the Greater New York Detachment of the Marine Corps League, assisted by a committee of women prominent in society.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 21 -- Within a few hours after his arrival in wildly cheering Melbourne today General Douglas MacArthur, Supreme Commander of the United Nations in the Southwest Pacific, plunged into discussions with Australian and American staff officers on military problems connected with the projected offensive against Japan.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 21 -- Governor Hurley sent a letter today to President Roosevelt protesting against what he says is an unpublicized and "utterly undemocratic" method of making available Army Air Corps commissions to young men who thus might "possibly avoid the rigors of selective training and combat service."

Property of the late Daniel Carter Beard, one of the founders of the Boy Scouts of America and National Scout Commissioner and honorary vice president of the organization, will be sold at auction at the Kende Galleries at Gimbel Brothers next Friday morning and afternoon and Saturday afternoon.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., March 21 -- Military victory depends on new methods of economic and psychological warfare conducted on a world-wide scale, it was asserted here today by speakers addressing a Williams College Conference on " A Grand Strategy for America."

The war has created a need for separate colleges to train women for the dominant role they are destined to play in public affairs, not only for the duration of the war but even after the peace, according to Dr. George N. Shuster, president of Hunter College.

Twenty-nine-persons were injured and eight of them were taken to Kings County Hospital last night when a surface car and a bus collided at Rogers and Foster Avenues, Brooklyn. The car was derailed and the bus badly battered.

Hockey warfare will be conducted on three fronts tonight as the survivors of the regular National Hockey League campaign endeavor to further their causes in the quest for the Stanley Cup and the championship of the world. At Madison Square Garden the Rangers, who won the league crown by finishing in first place, will continue their series with the Maple Leafs.

AMONG the radio's sundry curious phenomena is the ironic fact that, by sheer persistence and incalculable range, it can create an impression more enduring than the truth that should be remembered. This is, of course, the starting point for the less admirable forms of propaganda, but now and then you run across it in other kinds of programs and it is always disturbing and frequently sad to behold.

REHABILITATION -- More workers are needed to take the places of able-bodied men called to the colors. So a rehabilitation clinic for a picked group of physically handicapped individuals -- the first of its kind in the United States -- has been organized by the New Haven Hospital and the Yale Department of Psychology.

As soon as microbes invade the body and we fall sick antibodies are formed. It is the function of the antibodies to fight the microbes. Now comes the remarkable news from the California Institute of Technology that Drs. Linus Pauling, Dan Campbell and David Pressman have for the first time in history succeeded in producing antibodies in a glass flask.

NONE of the direful things that are shaking the earth can hold back the Spring. We may as well accept it as it comes. Out of the sky, out of the soil, out of the warm, bright South it takes possession of the land, dissolving the icy crust of Winter and draining the chill out of the noontime air.

"ISLAND NOON" is a fine story of courage and strength, with a setting on the New England Coast. It focuses on the stormy problems of an American girl who by force of character and physical labor works out her destiny on a rocky New England island.
An unimaginative policeman nearly prevented the unofficial official arrival of Spring in the Palisades Interstate Park in New Jersey yesterday.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 21 -- In increasing number Vassar College students are adding a fourth R, radio, to their education by taking part in semi-weekly broadcasts presented by the college in cooperation with the local broadcasting station, WKIP.

BOMBAY, India, March 21 (AP) -- Four main political factions of controversy-ridden India sharpened their differences today in tense expectation of the arrival of Sir Stafford Cripps, Great Britain's special envoy, and his plan for the country's future.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C., March 21 -- A crowd of about 6,000 watched jumpers from the stables of Paul K. Mellon of Upperville, Va., and F. Ambrose Clark of Westbury, L.I., win the two feature races of the eighth annual meet of the Sandhills Steeplechase and Racing Association today.

READERS who can still glean light-hearted enjoyment from Pacific travel adventure will find much to entertain them in this book from Borneo. It is completely light-hearted, and it serves up its gayety and excitement with all the exotic flavor that the popular recipes demand.
THIS biography of an early baron of the wilderness adds another welcome chapter to the history of the development and settlement of Western New York.

It has been said, and with justification, that printed discussions of garden club affairs and flower arrangements have all too often seemed directed to women exclusively. To a great degree this would appear to result from the fact that women seem to be in the majority in most garden clubs.

Two years of college have made the average Queens College junior more familiar with contemporary events than the average college student in the United States, but Queens women are lagging behind their male classmates in this respect, Professor Harry N. Rivlin, chairman of the Education Department, declared yesterday in a report to Paul Klapper, president.

LIKE those medieval magicians who sought the "philosopher's stone," a host of latter-day wizards have been whipping their wits for years to find an infallible formula for making successful films. Script writers, directors and producers in Hollywood have blended the smoke of endless cigars and conned a myriad of carbonated brews in their endeavors to discover the invariable elements of a "hit."

THE publication of a second volume of reminiscences by the Irish playwright, Sean O'Casey, is another reminder of the changes that have been taking place in the practice of autobiography. Only last Autumn, Mr. Mencken put forth a second chapter in the story of his life.

An impressive schedule of offerings of securities for these uncertain times has been mapped out by investment bankers for the next month or six weeks. In the corporate field, preparations are well under way for the flotation of securities aggregating more than $134,000,000.

Some gardeners may have been reluctant to grow herbs in their gardens because of the frequent references to ways and means of curing them, while the fact that herbs can readily be used green, directly from the garden, often is not mentioned.

Details of blackout drills to be held in Richmond tomorrow night and in lower Manhattan forty-eight hours later were made public yesterday by Police Commissioner Valentine. The drills will halt all but emergency traffic.

Arrangements for registration in April and May of trade and household users under the sugar rationing program, announced yesterday in Chicago, contemplate the use of 90,000 persons in this city who are being trained by the Board of Education to act as registrars.

MEXICO CITY, March 21 -- The former methods of independent and individual military zone commands will probably be replaced with a tie-up of all the country's army through the establishment of military centers in all sections of Mexico to be directly supervised by inspectors of the Department of National Defense, according to an official statement issued by Presidential chief of staff tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Donald M. Nelson, Chairman of the War Production Board, said today that "we will take whatever steps are proper and necessary to see to it that machine tools are distributed in the interests of the war program."

PALM SPRINGS, Calif. -- Reaching its climax, but not its end, with the gay annual Desert Circus at Palm Springs from Wednesday to Saturday and the subsequent impressive Easter dawn observance here and in Arizona, the present desert season is proving one of the most enjoyable and popular ever known.

Saying that nothing must be permitted to check vigorous prosecution of the war, Representative James W. Wadsworth declared yesterday that all special groups, particularly labor and farm blocs, must surrender special advantages as millions of other Americans will have to do.

As the strain of rising costs plus the wartime obligations they have assumed makes itself felt on club treasuries, women's organization leaders are turning to practical economies keyed to the needs of the time.

AFTER long months of Winter driving most cars need special springtime attention extending to all parts. Motorists now confronted with the absolute necessity for keeping their present cars in operation should look carefully to this essential seasonal servicing.

RANDALL STEWART, who edited "The American Notebooks by Nathaniel Hawthorne" in 1932, now carries his task forward with an equally exhaustive and scholarly edition of "The English Notebooks by Nathaniel Hawthorne."

LONDON, March 21 -- London today opened its Warships Week -the name given to intensified locality campaigns for war savings -- with the announcement that during the first twenty-two hours 27,310,160 had been subscribed. With the week's goal as 125,000,000 the figure subscribed meant that in less than one-seventh of the time allotted more than one-fifth of the total sought had been obtained.

VALLETTA, Malta, March 21 -- British fighter planes, ranging out to meet persistent Axis air attacks, and a murderous screen of anti-aircraft fire brought down twelve German bombers and two fighters in the twenty-four-hour period ended at 7 o'clock tonight -- one of the best records made in the recent days of Malta's defense.

A VOLUME entitled "The Language of Poetry" should provide a proper introduction to books of poetry, because in poetry the language is the thing, the infallible outward sign of the inner equipment. In reviewing books of verse this reviewer has often the conviction that if only the writers had a clue as to how to struggle toward their own special language, some of them might make themselves real poets.
Some events of interest to gardeners scheduled for the coming week are:

THE accelerated pace of the war in the Pacific has given this book a plausibility that not even its author could have dreamed of at the time of writing it only a few months ago. In a normal world these hastily concocted pages would "sound like a cheap spy story," in the very words used by the author.
The Australians have done a great thing. They deserve well of mankind; not only of us Americans. Certainly, they have paid us a high compliment in paying a rare one to General MacArthur.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Reports from American officials in the Far East confirming British charges regarding Japanese atrocities in Hong Kong have been received by the State Department, it was announced today.

"IT is not written down in the book that we shall win this war," says Marquis W. Childs in merciless challenge. We may win it if we can work hard enough and fight hard enough. Otherwise we may lose it "For too long we have been told that we could lick the world with one hand tied behind us.* * *

MANDALAY, March 21 (AP) -- Strong Japanese forces were reported massed tonight for a crosswise drive through the Sittang River defenses near Toungoo toward the Irrawaddy, eighty miles to the west, on the Burma flank where Chinese troops under an American commander, Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, already have gone into action.

America's largest body of yachtsmen, the United States Power Squadrons, which is gathering thousands of new members particularly among pleasure boatmen who are studying navigation for possible wartime service in the Navy or Coast Guard, has admitted its eighty-seventh branch unit.

A specially rewarding feature of last night's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under John Barbirolli, in Carnegie Hall, was the polished performance accorded the Saint-Saens violin concerto in B minor by John Corigliano, the organization's second concertmaster.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The War Production Board issued an order today forbidding the production after May 31 of a wide variety of metal household furniture, ranging from tables and chairs to mirror frames and shoe racks, and made effective drastic limitations on the production of such products in the interim period.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, March 21 -- Rubber has been hoarded by Brazilians and foreigners who refuse to sell, awaiting higher prices.

LONDON, March 22 -- A somewhat abbreviated survey of United States troops in Northern Ireland shows that they appear to be settling down to work and training all over the six counties and working with British troops in a manner satisfactory to both sides.
At least seven new films will have local premieres this week. The schedule follows:

Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation has issued for publication today a report for 1941 which shows a consolidated net income of $42,041,625 after all taxes, charges and reserves. This sum is equal to $4.53 each on 9,277,788 capital shares.

Facing an April 1 deadline for submission of his 1942-43 executive budget to the Board of Estimate, Mayor La Guardia expects to spend most of this week in his annual retreat in the office of the Budget Director.

In its final year as a producer of automobiles for civilian use until the war is won, General Motors Corporation broke all performance records save one, according to the annual report for 1941 forwarded to stockholders today by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman, and Charles Erwin Wilson, president of the company.

There was a pre-Spring lull on many fronts last week as the Japanese mopped up scattered resistance in the Netherlands Indies and the armies of the Axis and the United Nations marked time in the North African desert.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 22 (AP) -- Sammy Snead and Wilford Wehrle today defeated Bill Nary and Freddie Haas, 6 and 5, to win the $3,000 national amateur-professional best-ball golf tournament for the second year in a row. The Hot Springs, Va., pro and the Racine, Wis., amateur clipped twelve strokes from par for the thirty-one holes required.
ALBANY, March 22 -- Governor Lehman issued today a proclamation designating the month of April as Cancer Educational Month in the State.

The locality, of an aluminum reduction plant is not determined by the nearness of the mines nor by the distance of factories for converting the refined metal into airplanes. It is determined by one factor only--the availability of electric power; and this because it takes ten kilowatt-hours to free one pound of aluminum from its, chemical bhnds.

CENTREVILLE, Md., March 22 (AP) -- John Palmer Smith, State's Attorney of Queen Anne's County, said today that more than 100 men had been placed in farm jobs in the last ten days as a result of a "work-or-fight-or-go-to-jail" campaign.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The State Department declined to comment tonight on the report that Admiral Darlan had announced "full agreement" between Vichy and the United States.

OTTAWA, March 22 (U.P.) -- M.J. Coldwell, leader of the Cooperative Commonwealth Federation, placed his party today behind the government's plebiscite policy, urging the country to approve the government's request that it be released from its promise not to conscript Canadians for military service outside the Dominion.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., March 22 -- Grand strategy for winning the war and the peace involves our taking the initiative away from the Axis on the military, economic and psychological fronts, it was asserted today by a score of speakers addressing a Williams College conference attended by delegates from many Eastern colleges.
