CHICAGO, March 22 -- Trading in soy beans on the Board of Trade has fallen off sharply recently, and operators see little prospect of a revival until after April 10, when the government is scheduled to pay $2 a bushel for beans of high oil content and good germination to be used for seed.

I am sorry to see the statement of Dr. James G. Heller, president of the Central Conference of American Rabbis, in the paid quarter-page advertisement of American Emergency Committee for Zionist Affairs, favoring a Jewish army for Palestine.

In a report made public yesterday as president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, Dr. Nicholas Murrray Butler expressed the belief that "the war may last for an indefinite period" or it may, through economic exhaustion, "come to an end earlier than many anticipate."

The 350th anniversary of the birth of Jan Amos Comenius, prominent Czech theologian and educator of the seventeenth century and the last Bishop of the Czech Brethren Church, was celebrated yesterday morning by a special service in the Jan Hus Church, 351 East Seventy-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The capital is in a short-tempered mood. The shortage of shipping and the growing realization that we are still far from any major offensive action have served to increase the tension over the Administration's labor and social policies, and much more of this tension is expected to be displayed in Congress this week.

Americans are fighting for their God-given rights and every real American knows that he must fight, and, if necessary, die, for the principles that have had "their noblest exemplification in history in the government of the United States," Archbishop Francis J. Spellman declared last night in a radio address over a national hook-up on a program under the auspices of the Fourth Degree, Knights of Columbus.

Three more United States merchant ships, all officially described as "medium-sized," have been sunk by enemy submarines in waters off our Atlantic Coast with the loss of eighteen lives, the Navy disclosed yesterday. Two of the ships were torpedoed Wednesday and the third, which was attacked in broad daylight while two other vessels were within sight, was sunk Thursday.

Centralized detention of 16, 17 and 18 year-old boy offenders would be a necessary auxiliary of a centralized youth court, the Society for the Prevention of Crime declares in a report to be published today. The society, which favors a centralized youth court, proposes that two floors of the Manhattan City Prison in the new Criminal Courts Building that are now used for adolescent boys would be entirely suitable for centralized detention purposes.

Newspaper linage in this State may be bolstered somewhat if the Legislature passes the New York State Trade Practice Act introduced this week by State Senator Benjamin F. Feinberg and Assemblyman Edmund J. Delaney, according to Alfred J. Worsdell Jr., executive manager of the New York State Council of Retail Merchants, which is sponsoring the legislation.

VICHY, March 22 -- Important increases in taxes have been adopted by the Council of Ministers, but they are not designed to reduce the deficit between expenses and receipts in this year's budget. The new resources have been presented as devoted exclusively to covering new expenditures which it was decided at the same time to authorize, including measures in favor of soldier and civilian victims of the war and their families.
WITH THE CHINESE ARMY in Burma, March 19 (Delayed) -The Chinese today fought their first major battle in Burma and inflicted heavy casualties on the Japanese.

Mayor La Guardia interrupted his budget retreat for forty minutes yesterday to broadcast from a studio of WNYC, the municipal radio station, his weekly "Talk to the People" on miscellaneous matters connected with civilian defense and municipal administrative affairs.

WICHITA, Kan., March 22 (AP) -Brig. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, national Selective Service director, advised employers today to take stock of the men on their payrolls and decide "what you can spare and what you need."

The memoirs of the late Sherwood Anderson will be published on April 9. "My life has been so rich and crowded that I want to tell something about it before the bell rings," he writes in the opening pages. "It began just at the right hour and I hope it may not carry on too far."

ARMONK VILLAGE, N.Y., March 22 -- Two youths, one a sailor in uniform, were drowned early today when the sedan in which they were riding crashed through a guard rail, plunged end-over-end down a ten-foot embankment and landed on its side in Kensico Reservoir.

PITTSBURGH, March 22 -- Production of steel ingots rose last week half a point to 97.5 per cent of rated capacity, but the shortage of scrap materials throughout the country continued and was a major factor in preventing an operating rate of 100 per cent of rated capacity.

Prices of cotton futures fluctuated narrowly again last week, holding within about the same range as has prevailed since the beginning of February. At the close of trading on Saturday, active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains of 3 to 9 points for the period.

An example of the kind of statement that no responsible public official should make today is that of L. Metcalfe Walling, recently appointed administrator of the wage and hour division of the United States Department of Labor. Mr. Walling declared that "The Nazi propaganda machine is behind this whole movement to do away with wage and hour standards, although I cannot cite chapter and verse, and the newspapers have been taken in."
MOSCOW, March 22 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau communique today follows:

Protestant, Catholic and Jewish World War veterans gathered yesterday afternoon in the chancel of St. Andrew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and 127th Street, and lighted memorial candles for men of the armed forces who have died in the present war.
CHICAGO, March 22 -- Rain and snow blanketed the greater part of the Grain Belt last week, and from a moisture standpoint the situation is regarded as the best in a long time.
MOSCOW, March 22 (AP) -- American-built Airacobra fighter planes were rushed to the front today by the Red Army for a Spring air offensive.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 22 -- Enticed by the prospect of another "Spring gift" for little or no real military participation, Bulgaria is believed to be on the point of falling in with Adolf Hitler's plans. The Germans have finally swayed King Boris to proceed to Berlin.

In a world of increasing emotional tension caused by a general gloom over the futilities of war, personal and social conflicts grow in people and nations, and in such times there is greater need to hold to the truth with ever more precise understanding, the Rev. Dr. Allan Knight Chalmers, pastor of the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, at Fifty-sixth Street, said yesterday in his sermon at the morning service.

LONDON, Monday, March 23 (AP) -- The Daily Mail said in a Madrid dispatch today that French Vice Premier Admiral Darlan had announced a "full agreement" between the Vichy Government and the United States was near, pledging among other things the neutrality of the French Fleet.
An art gallery on Park Avenue is about the last place in the world one would expect to find soldiers and sailors drinking beer and dancing on Saturday evenings.

It is not a major problem that is raised by The Sun's department, Manners of the Moment, but it may be more susceptible of solution right now than most of our other problems. Should a housewife greet her husband at the front door every evening as he reaches home from the office or the shop ?

LONDON, March 22 (AP) -- Sir Stafford Cripps arrived in India today on his ticklish assignment to win India's full cooperation in the war against the Axis by offering some sort of formula for Indian freedom.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Industrial activity throughout the United States increased further in February and the first half of March, a summary of general business and financial conditions in the nation prepared by the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System disclosed today.

The New Friends of Music presented its fourth concert in its orchestral series late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Like the first two, it was devoted to Mozart. The orchestra, under Fritz Stiedry, played the Symphony No. 25 in G minor and the G major piano concerto with Artur Schnabel as the soloist.

GENERAL WAINWRIGHT'S HEADQUARTERS, Fort Mills, Corregidor, March 22 -- A Japanese ultimatum demanding that American forces defending this fortress and the Bataan Peninsula surrender or suffer the consequences expired at noon today, and two hours later there still was no sign of any all-out Japanese offensive.

The Equitable Life Assurance Society, which recently assembled a large tract near the Brooklyn Navy Yard and filed plans for a housing project, has added to the site by purchasing two dwellings on Clinton Avenue. From the estate of A.B.

VICHY, France, March 22 -- Propaganda for more babies will form a part of the curriculum in the elementary and secondary schools and detailed instructions to teachers to counteract France's falling birthrate are published in the Official Journal here today.

Eight points in support of the recent order of the Board of Higher Education for discontinuance of Townsend Harris High School were cited yesterday by Ordway Tead, chairman of the board, in a letter to the Senate and Assembly Committees on Public Education and the Assembly Rules Committee, which are considering the Young-Davidson bill for the mandatory upkeep of the school by the board.

The warehouse at 26 to 32 Mitchell Street, Newark, N.J., has been leased by the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company from John H. Carlo Sons, who have moved to new quarters at New Jersey Railroad Avenue and Wright Street. It contains 30,000 square feet and will be used to store tires repurchased from dealers as a result of the recent restriction on sales.

A plan of reorganization of the Associated Gas and Electric Company and the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation, prepared by Henry A. Stix, former vice president and controller of the two companies, has been submitted to the trustees of the companies and to the Securities and Exchange Commission in Philadelphia.

FORT DIX, N.J., March 22 -- More than 2,200 soldiers and their visitors watched Champion Joe Louis box six hard rounds with his four sparring partners today in preparation for his bout with Abe Simon in Madison Square Garden on Friday night.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 22 (AP) -- British General Headquarters issued this communique today:

Three novelties figured on the program presented by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under John Barbirolli, yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, with Rudolf Serkin as the assisting artist. The overture, "Sir Andrew and Sir Toby," by Anthony Collins, received its initial hearing at this concert, while Delius's "A Song of Summer" and Arcady Dubensky's "Variations and Finale on Stephen Foster Themes" had their first New York hearings.

Miss Marilyn Sahner, the 17-year-old Great Neck High School junior, who has just about spread-eagled the local free style swimmers, yesterday added the metropolitan senior 220-yard championship to her collection in a meet conducted by the Women's Swimming Association in the 75-foot London Terrace pool.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- Army engineers reported today that $17,260,100 could be profitably expended for new work on twenty-five navigation and flood-control projects in New York State in the next fiscal year -- twice as much as provided in the House-approved 1943 War Department Civil Functions Supply Bill.

ALBANY, March 22 -- Progress made this week in solving the principal problems before the Legislature will go a long way toward determining whether there is to be an adjournment by April 17 or a prolonged session.

West Virginia will face Toledo and Creighton will oppose Western Kentucky State at Madison Square Garden tonight in the semi-finals of the national invitation basketball tournament. The winners will meet in the final, with the losers playing off for third place, on Wednesday night.

A plan for the reconstruction of Battery Park calling for the elimination of the old Aquarium building and incorporating its site in a stately avenue through the park that would give a vista of the Statue of Liberty from lower Broadway will be sent to the Board of Estimate today by Park Commissioner Robert Moses.

DOYLESTOWN, Pa., March 22 -Inefficient distribution is the only thing that agriculture has to worry about today, fifty-five graduates of the National Farm School were told today by Dr. Ernest L. Nixon of Philadelphia, agricultural counselor of the Pennsylvania Chain Store Council, who delivered the address at the forty-second annual commencement exercises in Louchheim Auditorium.
BERLIN, March 22 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, March 22 -- The United States sold to Nicaragua in 1941 merchandise valued at more than $9,000,000, or 88 per cent of this country's total imports amounting to $10,500,000, the largest volume since 1929. Colonel Irving A. Lindberg, Collector General of Customs and High Commissioner, announced today.

The suggestion that corporation profits on war contracts should be limited to a flat 6 per cent after costs of production has a plausible appeal to the well-nigh universal sentiment that there should be no excessive profits made out of war. Unfortunately, there are serious dangers in such a plan, as Under-Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson has pointed out in testimony before the House Naval Affairs Committee.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 22 -- Myrna Loy will play the leading role in "O Bury Me Not," an unproduced stage comedy by Patricia Coleman which Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has purchased for a reported $40,000. Miss Coleman's play, written in three acts, deals with a Broadway actress who deserts New York for a Western ranch.

PROFESSIONAL baseball, football, racing and boxing are going to contribute important sums to various war relief funds. So are many other games, amateur and professional. But it's useless to look for intercollegiate competition to swell the relief funds to any great extent. The truth of the matter is that, under war conditions, the schools, colleges and universities are going to have a tough time paying the bills to keep any athletic program going.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 22 (U.P.) --General Douglas MacArthur, swinging into action at once in his post as Supreme Allied Commander in the Southwest Pacific, will confer on Monday with War Minister Francis M. Forde and high Australian Army officers, and soon will attend an emergency meeting of the war Cabinet, it was announced today.

Two thousand volunteer workers will assemble this morning in the Hotel Astor for a breakfast at which the Greater New York Fund will open its 1942 campaign in behalf of 400 voluntary welfare and health agencies in the city.

CHICAGO, March 22 -- A goal by Des Smith after 6 minutes 51 seconds of sudden-death overtime tonight brought the Boston Bruins a 2-to-1 decision over the Chicago Black Hawks in the first game of their two-out-of-three Stanley Cup quarter-final play-off series.

DETROIT, March 22 -- The Detroit Red Wings, on two goals by Center Don Grosso, defeated the Montreal Canadiens, 2 to 1, at the Olympia tonight before 12,371 spectators in the opening game of their two-out-of-three quarterfinal Stanley Cup hockey play-off series.

Although suffering from a severe attack of bronchitis, Josef Hofmann bravely ventured to give his recital last night in Carnegie Hall. Under the circumstances it would have been nothing short of a miracle had the performances he put forth averaged up to his usual superlative standard in a program containing compositions making heavy demands on an artist's physical strength and control of nerves.

MONTREAL, March 22 (U.P.) -The opening of a second front in Europe and all possible aid for Russia were cited here today by Premier General Wladislaw Sikorski of Poland as essential moves to hasten the defeat of the Axis powers.

TAMPA, Fla., March 22 -- With the resiliency of the well-known priority product, the Dodgers bounced back today for an easy 7-1 triumph over the Reds and tonight moved on to Lakeland for another go at the Tigers tomorrow.

LONDON, March 22 -- One of the financial paradoxes of this war has been the substantial rise in prices of bonds at a time when the cost of living, as measured by prices of commodities, also has mounted steadily. At the present time commodity prices are at the highest level since the outbreak of the war, while bond prices are not much below their peak.

Their defense holding strong against their foes' heaviest charges, the Toronto Maple Leafs gained an easy triumph over the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night. The visitors did less rushing than the home sextet, but their advances were certainly more productive as they skated their way to a 4-to-2 success before 14,696.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose another 0.2 per cent to 103.8. In general, the effect of price changes was a moderate gain in each of the major commodity indexes. Among the subgroups, however, there were divergent trends.

BERLIN, March 22 (From German Broadcasts, Recorded by The Associated Press in New York) -The German High Command claimed today that Axis "offensive operations" were successful on a number of sectors of the Russian front and claimed for the air force heavy bombings in the Crimea and Donets Basin.

Faced with curtailments this Spring, the fresh and salt water anglers alike have at times discussed the abandonment, if temporary, of a good part of their customary sports program. There has been some doubt in their minds as to the advisability of getting away from the city for a day, or a few hours, even though such trips would be in abbreviated form as compared with those of bygone years.

LOS ANGELES, March 22 -- Answering those who have asserted that the Administration was "letting the people down because it did not lead," Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt declared tonight in another of her sponsored broadcasts over the Blue Network that "the President and the Administration should not be held solely responsible for policies such as freezing prices, profits and wages."
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- A War Department communique, based on reports received up to 1 P.M. Eastern war time today, said:

Laymen eventually will provide the leadership that will guide Protestants under a federation of denominations into "a more active part in the affairs of the State," declared the Rev. Ralph Conover Lankler in a sermon yesterday commemorating the seventy-fifth anniversary of the Memorial Presbyterian Church, Seventh Avenue and St. John's Place, Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, March 22 -- Spreaders on the Board of Trade who bought rye and sold corn some time ago when the May delivery of the former grain was about 10 cents a bushel less than corn, went out of their holdings last week, and there was also fairly general liquidation by smaller holders, resulting in prices dropping rapidly to the lowest levels since last December.

A syndicate of investors bought from the Bank for Savings the twelve-story store and loft building at 242-50 West Fifty-fifth Street for cash over a ten-year first mortgage of $239,000. Assessed at $535,000, the property is 92 by 114 feet and was sold through the George Comfort Company, broker.

BOSTON, March 22 -- Rolling gently at her berth on an ebbing tide, "Old Ironsides" -- the United States frigate Constitution -- the most famous warship in American history, today was the scene of memorial services for the heroic dead of the destroyers Jacob Jones and Truxtun, which were lost last month while on fighting duty.

LONDON, March 22 -- The British Board of Trade's index of wholesale prices for commodities in February, based on 1930 as 100, was 158.5, compared with 156.4 for January, 150.0 for February, 1941, and 98.1 for August, 1939. The rise of 1.3 per cent in February, compared with January, was the largest increase in a month since November, 1940.

LOS ANGELES, March 22 -- In an effort to attain the production goal set by President Roosevelt, the Douglas Aircraft Company today announced the organization of a new joint employment-management committee to help speed the production of war planes.

Registering sixty points, Johnny Simmons of the Aberdeen Skating Club of Stamford, Conn., carried off the senior men's crown at the New York State indoor skating championships held in the New York City Building at Flushing Meadow Park yesterday, under auspices of the Department of Parks in cooperation with the Middle Atlantic Association.
The greatest parade under arms since Pearl Harbor will be held on Army Day, Saturday, April 4.

May I echo the plea made recently by James G. Blaine and James J. Farley for a community chest for New York? The Greater New York Fund, which now provides supplementary funds for nearly four hundred agencies through a once-a-year campaign, has made an auspicious start in that direction.

CHICAGO, March 22 -- Corn showed independent strength last week on the Board of Trade here, losing only 5/8 to 1 cent a bushel, with more or less buying of that grain against sales of wheat and rye by spreaders. In addition prospects of near-record feeding operations and limited movement of free grain from the country tended to strengthen the market.

WAR is Beauty because it realizes the mechanical man Perfect with the gas mask the terrifying megaphone the flame thrower or enclosed in the armored car which establishes the domination of man over the machine. War is Beauty because it commences the metallization of man of which we used to dream. . . .

A report reviewing the accomplishments of the National Youth Administration, with recommendations for using its facilities for the war as well as in the post-war period, presented to President Roosevelt last week by Charles W. Taussig, chairman of the National Advisory Committee of the NYA, was made public yesterday.

Mrs. Edith C. Ringling, the "First Lady of the Circus," is about to become a producer of Broadway plays, the first member of the famous Ringling family to acknowledge such an interest. She will not abandon the circus, with which she has been associated for more than fifty years, but will leave her theatrical venture in the hands of Stuart Lancaster, her 21-year-old grandson.

The Motor Transport Service of the American Women's Voluntary Services has fulfilled 1,582 assignments in Manhattan in the last month, requiring 7,682 hours of service, according to a report released yesterday by Mrs. Margaret Furst, commander of the service for Greater New York.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday the appointment of Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, who has been in the city's service for twenty-seven years, as Commissioner of Hospitals, to succeed Dr. Willard C. Rappleye, who resigned last week to resume his duties as dean of the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University.
CANBERRA, Australia, March 22 (AP) -- A communique issued by Prime Minister John Curtin said today:

With the bulk of Easter apparel purchasing completed, there were fewer buyers in the markets, according to a summary of last week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buyers. Wherever buying opportunities occurred, stores continued to place advance orders for staple goods.

CHICAGO, March 22 -- Failure of the Senate to take prompt action on the House bill which would prevent sales of government-owned wheat at less than parity prices, combined with pronounced weakness in rye, started last week a liquidating movement on the Board of Trade which carried prices of wheat off around 8 1/2 cents a bushel from the recent high and into the lowest ground since late in December.

Four gifted young American singers, whose average age is 25, reached the apex of their youthful vocal careers yesterday when they received contracts with the Metropolitan Opera Company. The four, the largest number of winners in one season, were proclaimed the winners of the Metropolitan Opera Auditions of the Air at the closing session over the National Broadcasting System red network.

The State organization of the Labor party, through Lester Rosner, executive director, sent yesterday a letter to the Naval Affairs Committee of the House of Representatives, urging the committee to kill Representative Harold W. Smith's bill to end the forty-hour week in war industries.

I am a senior at a large Eastern college. I was married last August and I plan to graduate this June. My husband has a 3-A classification; however, it is our mutual wish that he enter the armed forces soon. It will therefore be necessary for me to support myself after graduation.

A post-war America with a slowed-up birth rate and a stepped-up production of goods and the possibility of increased prosperity for all if technological unemployment can be overcome is foreseen by Stuart Chase, economist, in a forthcoming report to the Twentieth Century Fund, advance sections of which were made public yesterday by Evans Clark, the fund's executive director.

MIAMI, Fla., March 22 -- Affairs with the Giants hit a new low today, but otherwise Mel Ott's mournful men hit practically nothing else as Bucky Harris's surprising Senators polished them off for the second successive afternoon, 6 to 1.

A four-goal drive in the second period by the invaders proved too much for the New York Rovers to overcome yesterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden. As a result, the Eastern Hockey League champions suffered their first defeat in three starts in the Amateur Hockey Association of the United States championship play-off series, bowing to the Washington (D.C.) Eagles, 5 to 2.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The War Department revealed today that an enemy ultimatum to Lieut. Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright, the American commander in the Philippines, to surrender had been ignored.
In the Deep South of long ago, where little happened to break the still and sleepy pattern in which one sultry day followed another, cane-crushing time was a gala event, eagerly anticipated.
This war may be the knife in the hands of "the Great Surgeon who wounds to heal," Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen declared yesterday in his Lenten sermon at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Wartime menus will never be spiceless, according to spokesmen for three local spice concerns. Baked hams will continue to sport cloves, puddings and bakery goods will flaunt cinnamon and nutmeg, and a favorite bread and popular beverage will still derive their names and existences from ginger, they predicted.

The necessity for last week's order rationing gasoline deliveries to filling stations and for the prospective coupon rationing of motorists themselves was made clear yesterday in a report by the American Petroleum Institute. The report estimated that for every tanker sunk at least 100,000 motor cars had to obtain gasoline from some other source.
Louis Levy, former N.Y.U. player, led the field last night in the United States chess championship preliminaries at the Marshall and Manhattan clubs.

The Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, reporting on its educational activities for 1941, has had to face some disconcerting facts. Its thirty-one years of work for a better world have been contemporaneous with two world wars, one of which now threatens the future of all civilization.

NEW DELHI, India, March 22 -- Sir Stafford Cripps arrived at Karachi this afternoon looking fit and cheerful. He is expected to fly on to New Delhi tomorrow on his special mission to bring India solidly into the war against the Axis.

As a means of releasing ground crew members of the Royal Canadian Air Force for other duties or for remuster to the flying force, enlistments of women are being accepted in an auxiliary organization known as the R.C.A.F. (Women's Division), it was disclosed yesterday.

A sharp decline in the Canadian dollar featured business in the foreign exchange market last week. Weakness was particularly acute on Tuesday and Wednesday, when remittance on the Dominion sagged to 86.56 cents, a loss of 1 7/16 cents from Monday's top, and lowest since last January.

LONDON, March 22 -- Japanese mass aerial attack, with sixty bombers escorted by twenty fighters, was made yesterday on a British airfield "somewhere in Central Burma," it was revealed today in reports received here.
The week after this holds three Broadway openings, the latest entry being "Nathan the Wise," arriving at the Belasco on Saturday night, April 4.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- A committee of fifteen to study economic conditions in the button and buckle manufacturing industry and to recommend a minimum wage above the statutory 30 cents an hour level but not higher than 40 cents an hour was appointed today by the Wage and Hour Division of the Labor Department.

Throughout unoccupied France the Axis partners have established control commissions whose activities supersede in many instances the authority of the Vichy government, according to an account of a traveler who, after a sojourn in France, has arrived here from Europe.
NEW DELHI, India, March 22
WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -Industries with peacetime sales aggregating more than $5,000,000,000 and employing nearly 750,000 workers are on the road to conversion to war production.

Last week was a period of more or less confusion, which in the end resulted in little except bewilderment. It was the week of income-tax payments, when the first cash installment served as reminder of the great increase in rates, this year and a year from now.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 22 -- British, South African and Free French troops raided German positions around Tmimi and the airdrome at Martuba yesterday, captured at least 150 Axis troops, killed others, and damaged Martuba facilities with artillery fire.

Commissioner Valentine cautioned the police yesterday against divulging any information of a military nature that might come into their possession or discussing any topics that might give aid to the enemy or "tend to lower the public morale."

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 22 -- Whether Terry Moore caught Mike Chartak's line smash on the fly or on the bounce to end today's game between the Yankees and Cardinals will always be a moot question. Umpire Ed Rommel said Terry made a diving catch and his word carried more authority than the noisy protests of Coaches Art Fletcher, Earle Combs and Johnny Schulte and Manager Joe McCarthy of the world champions.

LONDON, March 22 -- Clement R. Attlee, Dominions Secretary, in a speech at Liverpool today, gave a thumbnail sketch of the war production coupled with a reference to The Daily Mirror case. On the latter he observed:
Women -- from Mary quite contrary of nursery-rhyme fame on up -- are perverse creatures who stubbornly refuse to realize that there is a Right Way and a Wrong Way to do everything.
WEST NEW YORK, N.J., March 22 -- The "practical demonstration" of civilian defense planned by West New York authorities did not come off according to schedule today.

False leaders of labor or capital should be ousted, the Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray declared yesterday in his sermon at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration, the "Little Church Around the Corner," Twenty-ninth Street, east of Fifth Avenue.

The submarine menace on our Atlantic seaboard has not yet been successfully met. The U-boat toll of nearly half a hundred vessels in less than three months cannot be offset by any complacent estimate that this represents only a small part of our coastal shipping.

Twenty men whose ship was torn apart and sunk by a Japanese bomber two and a half days after they had "sneaked out" of war-battered Manila Harbor and who owe their lives to the skill and daring of a Dutch rescue flier arrived here yesterday after a voyage of fifty days.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The first public hearing by the War Labor Board on a case involving the question of extra wages for Saturday and Sunday work will be held Wednesday, the board announced today. The case is one in which the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations acted jointly for the first time in an appeal to the board.

UNITED STATES ARMY HEADQUARTERS, in Australia, March 22 -- Negotiations are going on between General Douglas MacArthur and Washington and London that will determine whether or not this crucial Southwestern Pacific war area will have a really unified command, it was learned tonight from an authoritative source.

MANDALAY, Burma, March 22 (U.P.) -- American missionary physicians and nurses have undertaken to administer medical service to the entire Chinese army in Burma along the 500-mile front from the mountains of the Shan States down to the tropical plains in the southwest, it was revealed today.

Dr. William Withers, president of the New York Federation of College Teachers, an affiliate of the A.F. of L., wrote yesterday to Assemblymen Moffat, Ives and Steingut and State Senator Coudert objecting to a bill that he said would empower the New York Board of Higher Education to alter salary schedules in the public colleges "at a moment's notice."

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 22 -- Whether Terry Moore caught Mike Chartak's line smash on the fly or on the bounce to end today's game between the Yankees and Cardinals will always be a moot question. Umpire Ed Rommel said Terry made a diving catch and his word carried more authority than the noisy protests of Coaches Art Fletcher, Earle Combs and Johnny Schulte and Manager Joe McCarthy of the world champions.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- A plan to start production drives in 2,000 major airplane, tank, gun, ship and machine-tool plants by April 1 is being organized by the War Production Board.

CHICAGO, March 22 -- With speculative interest in the lard futures market at a virtual standstill as the market is at ceiling levels, more attention is being paid by operators to the situation existing in the cash article. The latter is also priced at ceiling levels, and the relatively high price of hogs is regarded as resulting in the current make of lard being produced at a loss.

CLERMONT-FERRAND, France, March 22 -- On the occasion of Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's official visit today the markets of Clermont-Ferrand, for the first time in many months, were flooded with food produce of all sorts.

The double-decked bus, which for years has careened through heavy Fifth Avenue traffic like a howdah-mounted elephant and become one of the traditional sights of the thoroughfare, is on its way out, the annual report of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company disclosed yesterday.

State Senator Allan A. Ryan of Dutchess County has been suggested by influential party, members for the Republican nomination for Representative in the Twenty-sixth Congressional District to replace Representative Hamilton Fish, it was learned yesterday.

LONDON, March 22 -- A great four-motored Sunderland flying boat of the Royal Air Force has rescued fifty-six British seamen who had been adrift sixteen hours off the African coast after their ship had been torpedoed, the Air Ministry disclosed today.

An audience of 1,200 attended the "Inter-American Entertainment," which was presented last night at Town Hall for the benefit of the Little Red School House. Dr. Robert Speer of New York University, who acted as master of ceremonies, introduced the acts like a commentator for a travelogue.

AMITYVILLE, L.I., March 22 -- Fifty persons, mostly patients, were led or carried to safety this afternoon in a fire that wrecked two-thirds of the Long Island Home, a private hospital for neurological and convalescent cases on Louden Avenue near Broadway here.

CHUNGKING, China, Monday, March 23 -- Dr. Sun Fo, president of the legislative department of the Chinese Government, today urged President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill to announce a "Pacific Charter" that would pledge the United Nations to recognize the independence of India, French Indo-China, Korea and the Philippines.

PEORIA, Ill., March 22 -- The Government took possession of the Toledo, Peoria and Western Railroad today upon the arrival of John W. Barriger 3d, who was appointed Federal manager of the strike-bound 239-mile freight line yesterday by Joseph B. Eastman, Director of the Office of Defense Transportation.

The American Smelting and Refining Company and its subsidiaries had in 1941 a net income of $30,532,011 after all charges except income and corporate taxes, compared with $18,948,979 the year before, according to the forty-third annual statement issued for publication today.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 22 -- In their first attack on inland Australia, the Japanese today bombed Katherine, on the railway 180 miles south of Darwin, while United Nations fliers struck again at Lae, Japanese-held base in New Guinea, and destroyed or damaged seventeen grounded enemy planes.

DETROIT, March 22 -- Automobile factories converted to the manufacture of guns, tanks, planes and other instruments of war are re-employing jobless workers more rapidly than had been forecast when the government ordered passenger-car production shut down seven weeks ago.

LONDON, March 22 -- A fall last week in the industrial share index from 76.0 to 74.9 and a slight decline in the bond index from 134.4 to 134.3 were the small net results of a very quiet week in the stock markets.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 22 -- Repeating her victory of last year here, the English-bred whippet, Champion Flornell Glamorous, owned by the Mardormere Kennels of Mrs. George A. Anderson of Glen Head, L.I., and handled by Percy Roberts, captured the best-in-show award at the third annual fixture of the Saw Mill River Kennel Club tonight.

Statistics showing the wide variety of commodities that Germany requisitioned from occupied and unoccupied France in November, 1941, are given in the current issue of France Speaks, published here under the editorship of Jean Rollin and Albert Grand at 7 East Fifteenth Street.

In its fight against the proposed mandatory joint income tax return for husbands and wives the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs yesterday announced the enlistment of Wendell L. Willkie in its cause.

Dr. Paul Grindlinger bought from George A. and Margot K. Williamson of Fair Haven, N.J., as executors of the estate of Elsie K. Fair, the three-story residence at 123 Quentin Street, corner of Austin Street, Kew Gardens, L.I., for a home and dental office.

A "Spring offensive" to raise funds for medical and humanitarian relief work in Russia will be launched at a city-wide conference on April 11 in the Hotel Commodore, it was announced yesterday by Russian War Relief, Inc., of 535 Fifth Avenue.

BERNE, Switzerland, Monday, March 23 -- A special supplement to the Russian midnight communique referring to activity on the Kalinin front said today that the Germans during the ten days that ended Saturday midnight had lost at least 12,000 killed and much materiel.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Organized labor is expected to demand that the Roosevelt Administration disavow the bitterly worded attack on unions by Assistant Attorney General Arnold.

The Association of Customers Brokers has addressed to Representative Clarence F. Lea, chairman of the House Interstate Commerce Commission, its views regarding amendments to the Securities and Exchange Acts now being considered by the committee.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 22 -- Forcible evacuation of all Japanese from Bainbridge Island in Puget Sound, opposite the Bremerton Navy Yard, was ordered today by the Army, effective on March 30.

The American Red Cross is appealing for $65,000,000 to provide relief for American war victims and to carry on rapidly expanding Red Cross services for the armed forces. The Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York is seeking $7,330,000 of the national goal in a united local chapter appeal in the five boroughs, as follows: Manhattan and the Bronx, $6,250,000; Brooklyn, $700,000; Queens, North Shore, $59,900; Central Queens, $250,000; Staten Island, $80,000.

The war reports of the last few months have repeatedly dealt with the German cruiser Prinz Eugen. Readers probably never bother to find out who this Prince Eugen is or was, in whose honor the Nazis named one of their biggest ships.

The Smith-Herring bill now before Congress implies that we can produce more goods if we suspend all laws limiting hours of work, eliminate overtime pay, invalidate existing contracts mutually agreed upon between employes and employers, prohibit the closed union shop and place a 6 per cent limit on profits in defense contracts.

WATERVILLE VALLEY, N.H., March 22 -- Miss Rebecca Fraser, 17-year-old Woodstock (Vt.) High School senior, dominated the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association's women's championships today on Tecumseh Trail of the White Mountain National Forest.

While the sins of mankind create schisms and build fences of enmity, religion reconciles and destroys barriers of hatred, the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo said yesterday in his sermon in the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

CHICAGO, March 22 -- Many of the questions that have perplexed housewives since sugar rationing was first announced were being carefully studied today following a two-day discussion of plans for the registration for ration books that will be held throughout the country May 4, 5, 6 and 7 for individuals and on April 28 and 29 for industrial concerns, wholesalers, retailers, grocers, restaurants and hotels.

The Capitol yesterday changed its schedule so that "The Invaders" will continue for a fourth week, beginning Thursday. "The Lady Is Willing," co-starring Marlene Dietrich and Fred MacMurray, which was to have opened this Thursday, has been set back several weeks on the Capitol's program.

NEWARK, N.J., March 23 -- Coincidental with the signing this afternoon by Governor Charles Edison of the Student Labor Commission Bill, leaders of three New Jersey organizations, composed mainly of women, issued a joint statement supporting the measure but, at the same time, warning against pending legislation to legalize "harmful types of child labor in this State under the threadbare disguise of a war necessity."

"Hoarders create scarcities which otherwise could have been avoided and may force the government to institute rationing of goods of which there is no real shortage," the National Consumer-Retailer Council declared yesterday in announcing a nation-wide campaign to combat hoarding. The project as outlined by Roger Wolcott, executive secretary of the council, includes programs for retailers and for consumers.

Under a low-hanging cloud ceiling, of the sort favored by enemy bombers, Staten Island moved through its first practice blackout last night with an effectiveness that won praise from Mayor La Guardia and other officials.

The Pacific Lighting Corporation reported yesterday for 1941 a net income of $7,727,859, an increase of $347,800 over 1940. Last year's net was equal to $3.35 a common share, compared with $3.13 a share the year before. Gross revenues amounted to $48,681,962, a gain of $3,452,206 over the previous year.
NEW DELHI, India, March 23 (AP) -- The British issued this communique today:

Two down in the series, the Rangers will skate out on the Madison Square Garden ice tonight against the Toronto Maple Leafs determined to get into the running for the Stanley Cup. Although they were outplayed in the first two games of their semi-final series, the New Yorkers are far from discouraged and are hopeful of turning the tables.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The Federal Reserve Board today designated the used-car guides to be used by automobile dealers in calculating the maximum credit value of second-hand automobiles to comply with the board's installment credit regulations. The credit value must be based on the purchase price or the average retail value of the car as stated in one of the designated used-car guides, whichever is lower.

The increased freight rates and accessorial charges awarded the railroads by the Interstate Commerce Commission recently will add $4,600,000 to the revenues of the Erie Railroad, based on results for 1941, Robert E. Woodruff, president, said in his annual report issued yesterday.

The fifth annual drive of the Greater New York Fund was opened yesterday with a breakfast in the Hotel Astor attended by 2,000 volunteers who came at their own expense to launch the campaign for $5,000,000 in behalf of 400 participating health and welfare agencies.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- United States submarines "operating in Japanese waters" have sunk three merchant ships, damaged and probably sunk a destroyer or similar type of anti-submarine vessel, and damaged two other cargo vessels, Navy Department reported tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended March 18 aggregated $12,363,000,000.

CHICAGO, March 23 (AP) -- Sears Roebuck Co., mail order and retail merchandise concern, reported today net income of $36,711,504, equal to $6.35 a share, in the twelve months ended on Jan. 31. This compared with $36,086,668, equal to $6.32 a share, in the preceding fiscal year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 23 -- Walter Wanger's next production for Universal will be "The Arabian Nights," a photoplay which Michael Hogan is writing as a vehicle for Jon Hall, Maria Montez and Sabu, the studio announced today.

The Carter Hotels chain added a new link to its organization yesterday when a subsidiary, King Hotels, Inc., purchased from the Bowery Savings Bank the twenty-four-story Hotel Dixie and bus terminal at 250-62 West Forty-third Street, just off Times Square.

ROME, March 23 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press in New York) -- A heavy naval engagement was reported raging today off the North African coast, with Italian warships hammering at a big British convoy, which, the Italian High Command said, has been crippled by Axis torpedo-carrying planes in a running fight.

In part as a repercussion to the action of President Roosevelt in seizing control of the Toledo, Peoria Western Railway, the railway managements are considering a petition to Joseph B. Eastman, head of the Office of Defense Transport, to ease a potential labor shortage by eliminating "extra crew" and "featherbed" rules.

THIS baffled bystander doesn't know whether the MacLeish Manifesto runs over into the sports field or not. If it does, there is going to be some fun. And no more criticism of any kind. In these times it's better not to take a chance. A fellow who even hints that the Giants are weak at second base might be blasted as a Nazi propagandist or a Japanese agent.

NEW DELHI, India, March 23 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, arriving here today, said in a statement to the press that he would seek within two weeks decisions for India, on the basis of the British War Cabinet plan, that would enable the Indian people "to associate themselves fully and freely" with the United Nations in the war.

Threats by Joseph V. Moreschi, president of the International Hod Carriers, Building and Common Laborers Union, A.F. of L., to "break" the Sandhogs Union, Local 147, unless its officers would "turn the local over to us" and "play ball" were charged yesterday by Brian Feeney, business agent of the local, before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook.

JERUSALEM, March 23 -- With Palestinian industry, both Jewish and Arab, reaching the peak of employment figures throughout many branches, the question of pre-war unemployment has almost completely disappeared in the Holy Land today. But, on the other hand, abrupt increases in prices and a scarcity of goods for public consumption otherwise cloud a bright outlook for Palestine's economy.
Paper box manufacturers, contractors and dress firms figured in some of the largest business leases reported by brokers in Manhattan yesterday.

Traffic congestion and the parking problem in New York have been much reduced by two direct outgrowths of the war. The first is the marked reduction in driving which has resulted from tire shortages and rationing and from the realization that the family car must serve for the duration.

CHUNGKING, China, March 23 (AP) -- Large-scale Japanese preparations for an attack on Soviet Siberia "as soon as conditions are favorable," were reported today by the Northwest China Daily News, organ of the Chinese Communists.

NEWPORT, Vt., March 23 -- Held for investigation to determine whether, as an enemy alien, he was "dangerous to the peace and security of the United States," the Rev. Yutaka Minakuchi, 63-year-old Congregational minister and former Chautauqua lecturer, was accused today of being in the pay of the Japanese Consulate.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 23 -- Mrs. Van Wie Willys and Mr. and Mrs. Jose de Landa entertained with a dinner tonight at Casa Virginia for Countess Helene Chlapowska. Their other guests included Mr. and Mrs. Albert Sidney, Colonel and Mrs. William Hayward, Mr. and Mrs. Murray Hoffman, Archduke and Archduchess Franz Josef of Austria, Countess de Narkiewicz-Jodko, Mrs. Marjorie Oelrichs, John P.S. Harrison, Dr. Edmund LeRoy Dow, Werner Said-Reute and Channing Hare.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 23 -- The Wilhelmstrasse today continued to attempt to minimize the importance of the Hungaro-Rumanian disagreement, maintaining in general a middle-of-the-road comment when such could not be avoided.

Steel production this week will excell all past records of accomplishment by 1.1 per cent, according to an American Iron and Steel Institute announcement that output is scheduled at 1,681,600 net tons of ingots, comparing with 1,663,000 tons last week, the previous high, and 1,610,700 tons a year ago.

A questionnaire will be sent to every physician, dentist and veterinarian in the United States the first week in April by the Procurement and Assignment Service, Washington, "designed to give an opportunity to the 270,000 persons in these professions to state their preference, should they be called, whether in military, governmental, industrial or civil activity."

Lewis Spencer Morris has sold to a well-known New Yorker, a client of Pease Elliman, Inc., his English basement residence at 116 East Eightieth Street which he built in 1922 from plans by Cross Cross, architects.

The Public Education Association has written to Senator Fred Young and Assemblyman Irwin D. Davidson asking them to withdraw their bill which would amend the education law so as to require the New York City Board of Higher Education to continue any school under its control in January, 1942.

The Missouri Pacific Railroad disclosed yesterday that it would be in the market on April 7 with four new issues of equipment trust certificates aggregating $4,550,000. Officials of the road and its subsidiaries have obtained the necessary authorization by Federal Judge George H. Moore for Guy A. Thompson, trustee for the road, to proceed with the financing.

Park Commissioner Moses offers two alternatives in his proposed reconstruction of Battery Park, or one more than usual. We can have the Park with or without the structure known at various times as Fort Clinton, the Aquarium and Castle Garden. Mr. Moses prefers it without.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 23 -- The struggle of the Norwegian Church against Premier Vidkun Quisling's "new order" entered yesterday a new and perhaps decisive phase when most Norwegian ministers announced their decision to resign unless the Nazi-Quisling regime desist from trying to control the youth of the country and separate young people from their families and church.

Abandoning dealer cooperative advertising and consumer magazines, the Goodall Company will concentrate its entire 1942 advertising campaign for Palm Beach suits in factory-placed newspaper copy, it was announced yesterday. Newspapers were selected by Ruthrauff Ryan, Inc., who were appointed to handle the account last year, because they can be keyed to weather in the markets being covered.

The Class I railroads moved an average of 904,000 tons of revenue-paying freight a mile every minute in 1941, according to the Association of American Railroads. In October, the month of maximum traffic, they moved 1,069,000 tons a mile every minute.

LONDON, March 23 (AP) -- A Daily Telegraph dispatch from Perth, Australia, said today that a United Nations submarine now in friendly waters had hit a Japanese aircraft carrier with torpedoes on the night of March 3. off Bali in the Netherlands Indies and that "if the carrier was not sunk it will be out of action a long time."

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 23 (AP) -- Sixty-seven bombs were dropped today by nineteen Japanese bombers raiding Port Moresby, New Guinea. The airdrome there apparently was the chief target. Damage was believed to be slight.

A contest between City College and Long Island University, a "natural" to metropolitan fans, will be included on the Army Emergency Fund basketball program at Madison Square Garden next Saturday night.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended March 18: Increases of $76,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans, and $138,000,000 in "other securities" and decreases of $171,000,000 in holdings of Treasury bills and $119,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 23 -- The Westchester County Board of Supervisors approved today and sent to the Legislature a proposed bill to curtail powers of the County Planning Commission. The 4-year-old county charter prohibits the county board from making capital appropriations during a fiscal year unless the Planning Commission approves. The new bill would permit the Supervisors, by a two-thirds vote, to override the Planning Commission.

IN his "Enjoyment of Science,"* Jonathan Norton Leonard, a first-rate popularizer who has yet to achieve popularity, has an intelligent little essay on ecology, "the science which studies the interrelation of living things and their environments." I was struck by the resemblance between the ecologist and the student of geopolitics that is Nicholas John Spykman, author of "America's Strategy in World Politics,"* to which this column gave a wholly inadequate paragraph last week.

Awards of $37,285 to 124 property owners for damages to eighty-five homes in Forest Hills, Queens, during a cloudburst on Aug. 23, 1938, were announced yesterday by Official Referee James C. Van Siclen in Queens.
ALBANY, March 23 -- The most comprehensive revision of New York City's finances agreed to in many years was disclosed here tonight as bills carrying out the major part of the program were introduced.

On March 19 you published a letter from Walter LaM. Sparry, referring to Judge Steinbrink's decision on the peddler law. Mr. Sparry's views are respected and his statements are substantially correct, but I feel that he has omitted several important points.

DETROIT, March 23 -- Sixteen hundred machines that had been standing idle in automobile factories in Michigan have been put to work producing instruments of war in the last month, officials of the automotive branch of the War Production Board reported today.

C.C. Collings Co. of Philadelphia received yesterday the award of an issue of $120,000 of voting machine bonds of Berks County, Pa., on a bid of 100.31 for 1s. The bonds, dated April 1, 1942, will mature serially from April 1, 1943 to 1946.

PHILADELPHIA, March 23 (AP) -- Proposals for a big open tennis tournament, pitting outstanding professionals against top-ranking amateurs for a war charity gate, were frowned on today by a spokesman for the United States Lawn Tennis Association.

Replying to assertions by Mayor La Guardia and Ordway Tead, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, that there is no longer any educational need for Townsend Harris High School, Manfred Nathan, president of the school's Parent-Teacher Association, declared yesterday that the recent action of the board in ordering dissolution of the institution was based wholly upon "political grounds."

JERUSALEM, March 23 -- Carved ornamentation found on ossuaries, or stone coffins, in cave tombs outside Jerusalem, dating back to the period commencing with the Hasmoneans and continuing through the Herodian reigns until just before the destruction of the second temple, is believed likely here to prove of great help in determining the contemporary styles of architecture in the Holy City in those times.

A longshoreman was being questioned last night as a suspect in the fatal stabbing and beating of two business men in a street fight early Saturday at Eighth Avenue and Jane Street in Greenwich Village. Meanwhile, the police opened a wide search for a second man who fled after the fight.

LONDON, March 23 -- The arrival of United State troops in Northern Ireland inevitably brought home to Eire, as it had never been brought home before, the possibility that Eire might become involved in the war.

LONDON, March 23 -- With Warships Week in its stride the stock markets opened quietly today. Giltedge issues were in demand reflecting the hope of a reinvestment business after today's 65,000,000 payment for requisitioned Canadian securities. The home rails were steady.

UNITED STATES ARMY HEADQUARTERS, in Australia, March 23 (U.P.) -- After conferring with General MacArthur today, Army Minister Francis M. Forde left for Canberra to submit a preliminary report to Prime Minister John Curtin.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 23 -- Disturbed by the recurrent automobile crashes in Westchester County that have cost the lives of junior drivers and youthful passengers, Supervisor Harvey Miller of New Rochelle proposed to the county Board of Supervisors this afternoon a State bill that would require parental supervision of drivers under 21 years old.
PITTSBURGH, March 23 -- The State Supreme Court ruled today that the Pennsylvania Labor Relations Board may not appeal court decisions revoking its order or espouse any party's cause in litigations.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Completing an investigation initiated last December into the earnings of eight major cigarette companies, the Office of Price Administration today concluded that the wholesale price ceilings it set up on cigarette prices last year "are fair and equitable" and will be continued in effect.

The technical situation was credited yesterday with being responsible for a moderate rise in prices of stocks on the Stock Exchange. The volume, however, was still too restricted to lend a conclusive tone to the movement. As was the case most of last week, while price swings in isolated cases were of major proportions, most alterations held within a fractional range.
ATLANTA, March 23 -- A move to suspend intercollegiate football at the University of Georgia and Georgia Tech brought fresh controversy tonight to the State's university system.

BERNE, Switzerland, Tuesday, March 24 -- Despite a disclaimer in the Soviet midnight communique of any important change in the Eastern Front, reports from Moscow this morning indicated that three important developments had occurred in yesterday's fighting.

Burglars painstakingly worked their way down the nine-story building at 550 Fifth Avenue early yesterday and tried to punch, chisel or rip open six safes. Four of the attempts succeeded and they made off with $3,300 in cash, some defense bonds and stamps, and $3,000 worth of the stock from the Weber Heilbroner store on the street level, including choice outfits for themselves.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 23 (AP) -- British headquarters issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Francis B. Sayre, High Commissioner to the Philippines, arrived here today after escaping from Corregidor and a flight across the Pacific. He expressed doubt that the Japanese would make an all-out attempt at this time to capture the fortress because of the price they would have to pay.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 23 -- Mrs. H. Goldwasser, who lives in suburban Kirkwood, on Sappington Road, dislikes getting postcards addressed to her husband and signed "Helen."
MOSCOW, March 23 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

BERLIN, March 23 (From broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- The German High Command said today that a 6,000-ton merchant vessel was sunk and that two others were damaged seriously during an attack yesterday by German fighter and bomber planes on a strongly guarded British convoy in the Eastern Mediterranean.

MANZANAR, Calif., March 23 -- The vanguard of 112,000 Japanese, aliens and American-born, who must evacuate the West Coast combat zone rolled up the Owens Valley by motor convoy this evening to temporary new homes.

The Treasury's announcement yesterday that it will offer next month two new issues of certificates of indebtedness caused no undue excitement in government bond market circles here. It was generally interpreted as an effort by the Treasury officials to meet a growing demand on the part of certain institutional buyers of governments for a short-term coupon obligation.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 23 -- A message from Prime Minister Winston Churchill to the American Field Service, which serves under British command, was made public at a gathering of correspondents here today to meet Colonel Ralph Richmond, head of the Field Service units in the Middle East. The message said:

Walter P. Paepcke, president of the Container Corporation of America, said at the annual meeting at Chicago yesterday that first quarter earnings will be "significantly" higher than a year ago, when net profit was $497,042, or 64 cents a share on 781,253 shares.

NEWARK, N.J., March 23 -- Quo warranto proceedings were instituted in Supreme Court here today in an effort to oust former State Senator Arthur F. Foran from his post as State Milk Control Director. Separate but similar actions filed simultaneously seek to oust from the Legislature Senators George H. Spanger of Cumberland, Mr. Foran's counsel, and Howard Eastwood of Burlington Milk Board counsel.

General Draja Mikhailovitch is 49 years old, six feet tall, spare, blond and blue-eyed. He is fond of a joke. But he fights like a scalded cat. This man, almost single-handed, has brought Yugoslavia back into the war and thereby re-established the only battle front in conquered Europe.

Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, announced yesterday during a celebration that marked the anniversary of his first job as a dock worker thirty years ago, that a new contract had been made providing a $15-a-month pay Increase for 2,500 towboat workers.

BROOKLINE, Mass., March 23 (A) -- Miss Hope Knowles of Avon, Conn., seeded first, had little trouble defeating Miss Gilda Ciccone of Newton today 6 -- 2, 6 -- 2, in the first round of the women's national indoor tennis championships at the Longwood Cricket Club's covered courts.

The old adage that woman's place is in the home is steadily losing force because of the war. Among the women now doing what was once regarded as men's work are Mrs. Pauline Arnold White, vice president of a market research organization here, and Miss Margarget Ingels of Syracuse, N.Y., an authority on air-conditioning.
President Roosevelt has deeded to the Warm Springs Foundation for Infantile Paralysis all his Georgia farm properties, except the "Little White House" on Pine Mountain.
Buying by the trade near the close of trading yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange lifted cotton futures to their best levels of the day and the close was at net gains of 4 to 7 points.

H.L. Mencken's "New Dictionary of Quotations on Historical Principles," to be published by Knopf on April 20, represents the editor's "intermittent labor of twenty-five years," but embraces far more than a personal gathering.

The time lost by strikes is much less than the loss from another cause of which too little has been said -- sickness. For every day's time lost because of strikes last year fifteen times as much was lost because of sickness among workers -- at least 350,000,000 man-days in 1941.

UNITED STATES ARMY HEADQUARTERS, in Australia, March 23 -- At a remarkably frank press conference today, General Douglas MacArthur discussed with forty American, British and Australian newspaper writers the war and how he believes it will be won.

NEW ORLEANS, March 23 (AP) -- J.W. St. Clair of Southern Methodist University today was elected chairman of the National Basketball Rules Committee, which concluded its annual session with fewer changes made in the game than at any recent meeting.

Net sales of Franklin Simon Co., Inc., for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31 increased to $10,055,586 from $8,578,848 in the previous year, J. Howard Denny, president, said yesterday in his annual report to stockholders.

The proposal that the double-deck bus of the town shall cease and desist will sadden many a pious heart. It is for the expert to justify or refute the financial reasons given for razing these two-storied coaches. Long custom and wont, sound esthetic, physical and moral considerations, all plead for these old friends; and obviously only a person of the firmest character would take the trouble to go upstairs.

LONDON, March 23 -- With heavy fighting reported south of Toungoo in Burma, increasingly severe Japanese air attacks in Central Burma were seen here today as a sign that an enemy offensive could be expected soon. It was officially acknowledged that Japanese bombers had carried out "serious" attacks on a Royal Air Force base yesterday.
A shortage of sugar and the imminence of rationing already are influencing the type of desserts Mr. and Mrs. New Yorker will be able to order when dining out, a survey showed yesterday.

Daniel P. Woolley, Commissioner of Markets, yesterday explained the full details of a plan for guaranteeing the flow of 55,000,000 pounds of foodstuffs daily into the city under emergency conditions. Mayor La Guardia had outlined the plan on Sunday.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- President Roosevelt sent a message to the C.I.O. emergency conference; met with legislative leaders from Capitol Hill; talked with Francis B. Sayre, with Secretary Wickard and Senator Russell, with Charles F. Palmer, and with Admirals King and Andrews, and received representatives of the Supreme Lodge of the Order of Ahepa.

Vito Gurino, ace trigger man for the Brooklyn murder ring, who ran screaming into a Catholic church in Manhattan one Summer night and begged to be taken into custody by District Attorney William O'Dwyer of Brooklyn, pleaded guilty yesterday to three charges of second-degree murder based on underworld killings.

The first comprehensive control of railroad freight traffic for shipments to Latin America to be instituted since the war's outbreak was announced yesterday by the Association of American Railroads. Intended to prevent congestion at shipping points resulting from shortage of bottoms, the control affects North Atlantic ports from Portland, Me., to Hampton Roads, Va., and restricts the movement of all but government materials unless cargo space has already been booked.

LONDON, March 23 (U.P.) -- General Draja Mikhailovitch's army of thousands of Yugoslavs is ready to swoop down again from the mountains on the Axis forces occupying Yugoslavia in a "Spring offensive" to coincide with a "general Balkan revolt," it was reported today.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., March 23 (AP) -- Masculine, the Lemar Stock Farm's 3-year-old speedster, came through in the stretch today to beat Mrs. C.C. Winter's fast-finishing Plucky Muffin by a head and win the fourth race at Oaklawn Park.

Louis Nessel, 45 years old, a stock salesman, of 1521 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, pleaded not guilty before Judge Goldstein in General Sessions yesterday to a bucketing and grand larceny indictment, the first of its kind handed up by the New York County grand jury in recent years.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- President Roosevelt told an emergency conference of 500 Congress of Industrial Organizations representatives today that "American workers dare do no less than meet the challenge of old slavery with courage, with energy and with a determination that nothing shall interrupt our country's march to victory over the Nazis and the Japs."

CHICAGO, March 23 -- Out of a series of group meetings of the Edison Electric Institute that preceded tomorrow's general sessions came suggestions today that utilities and other appliance dealers support a campaign not only to keep present appliances in good repair but to bring back into service idle household apparatus that can be restored through the replacement of broken parts.

Moving toward the traditional pre-Easter peak due in the next ten days, sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week showed an increase of 20 per cent over the corresponding week last year, according to figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

PHILADELPHIA, March 23 -- The National Oil Products Company, Harrison, N.J., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement proposing the sale of $1,000,000 of sinking fund 3 1/4 per cent debentures, due on April 1, 1957.

Being a violinist of extensive experience and sound background, Arved Kurtz tried to avoid the worn-out warhorses at his Town Hall debut last night. He played one frequently performed work, the Vitali Chaconne, but gave that a different twist by using organ accompaniment.

To me, an ordinary citizen of a small town, the most absurd charge yet is the one that those wishing anti-strike legislation and changes in the 40-hour week law are doing so to obstruct the war effort.

If Sir Stafford Cripps, Britain's special envoy to India, lacks any quality it is not courage. Arriving in New Delhi yesterday, he announced: first, that he intended to stay two weeks; second, that he hoped to talk with representatives of every important group in the country; third, that his mind was "equally open on all points of view."

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Whatever the union labor leaders may say of the rush of protests to Congress against the forty-hour base work-week, many members feel an uneasy certainty that the protests are sincere. They know the torrent of correspondence has in some degree been stimulated and in places organized.

ALBANY, March 23 -- The 1942 State campaign had a two-hour preview on the floor of the Assembly tonight as the Republican majority moved to enact, over Governor Lehman's veto, the Whitney bills to permit payment of the State income tax in quarterly installments, effective this year and next.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 23 (AP) -- It was back to school again for 200 college coaches and sports personalities who came to the United States Naval Academy from every corner of the nation today.

Alice had been reading out loud to them the headlines from the war front and the production front, now and then adding a word of explanation or an example from history. When she had finished the little company was silent for a little while.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Attorney General Biddle has ordered a nation-wide round-up of about 8,000 alien seamen who have deserted their ships and are thus hampering the shipment of war supplies to the Allies.

By action of the War Production Board it is now illegal for any one to destroy any article containing reclaimable rubber, Clarence H. Low, chairman of the New York City Salvage Committee, said yesterday. He announced also that junk dealers who may refuse to accept scrap rubber have been made subject to disciplinary action by License Commissioner Paul Moss.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Lavish distributions of bonuses and pay increases by an Ohio company capitalized at $100,000 and holding $58,191,893 of Army and Navy contracts at profits described as around 100 per cent, a House investigating committee was told today, has caused the government to lose an estimated $734,480 in corporate taxes on last year's earnings.

The Cinderella team of the national invitation basketball tournament staged another stunning upset before 17,935 incredulous fans in Madison Square Garden last night as hustling West Virginia, seeded last among the eight entrants, and accorded a bid to the show almost as an afterthought, overturned Toledo, 51 to 39.
FORT DIX, N.J., March 23 -- Trainer Mannie Seamon was convinced today that Champion Joe Louis had mastered Abe Simon's left-handed technique.

A Navy transport ship arrived here yesterday with 505 refugees from the Far East. Although the group was outwardly jubilant, there was a depressing undertone as some related tales of hardship, suffering and bombings and told of abandoned homes they had left behind.

VICHY, France, March 23 (AP) -- Two French sailors who wounded the captain of the freighter Gabriel Guisthau recently in an unsuccessful plot to deliver the ship to the anti-Axis nations were executed today by a firing squad at Oran, Algeria, after Marshal Henri Philippe Petain rejected their clemency plea.

LONDON, March 23 -- The people of this bomb-scarred capital are digging deep into their pockets today to build a fleet to carry the war to the enemy. Their goal is 125,000,000 -- enough to provide four battleships, three aircraft carriers, five cruisers, five submarines and forty destroyers.

The Standard Oil Company of Indiana and its subsidiaries had a net profit in 1941 of $48,385,967 after all charges including Federal income and excess profits taxes, according to the preliminary report announced yesterday.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 23 -- General Douglas MacArthur bosses the United Nations armies in this part of the world, but in his own household the supreme command rests with his dark-eyed little wife. This was demonstrated today when Mrs. MacArthur took their small son, Arthur, on a shopping tour.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 23 (AP) -- The arrest of an elderly watchman was announced tonight following a Federal Bureau of Investigation inquiry into a fire that caused $50,000 damage at a small arms plant of the High Standard Manufacturing Corporation earlier in the day.

New York's historic 130-year-old City Hall, already stripped of many of its colonial museum pieces by the requirements of Mayor La Guardia's civilian defense program, began to lose its collection of historical paintings yesterday as workmen started to remove them to a secret hiding place for the duration of the war.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 23 -- R. Kenneth Fairman, Princeton's director of athletics, has received a leave of absence in order to serve in the United States Army, it was announced tonight by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university.
The order of events was set yesterday for the Navy Relief Society track meet at the Bronx Coliseum tomorrow night. The meet is to start at 8:45 P.M. and will be over by 10:30

CHICAGO, March 23 -- Liquidation was on again today in the grain and soy bean markets. Wheat prices dropped to new low levels since last December and soy beans since mid-January, with numerous stop-loss orders uncovered on the way down.

Thomas J. Ahearn Jr., manager of the New York loan agency office of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, announced yesterday on his return from a two-day conference in Washington that the RFC's thirty-one loan agencies throughout the country had been empowered to make loans of as much as $100,000 to accelerate the lending program.

Members of the Advertising Men's Post of the American Legion, in an informal vote to test sentiment, approved yesterday a proposal that veterans of this war be invited to join the Legion when the war ends.

The New York regional office of the Securities and Exchange Commission began an action in the Federal court at Newark, N.J., yesterday to obtain an injunction against the George Washington Memorial Park Cemetery Association of Bergen County and its officers and promoters on the charge that investment contracts have been sold without a registration statement with the SEC being in effect.

Arranged as a benefit for British, Chinese and Russian war relief, the large loan exhibition called "Art and the Stars" (its slogan: "Art to smash the Axis") opens at the Demotte Galleries, 39 East Fifty-first Street, with previews this afternoon and tomorrow afternoon, from 3 to 6 P.M., and to the public Thursday morning.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The announcement yesterday by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation that 500,000 ounces of 2,000,000 ounces of quinine that it purchased on the recommendation of the War Production Board had been lost at sea today drew attention to America's situation with regard to this highly essential drug.

ALBANY, March 23 -- The Senate by unanimous vote tonight completed legislative action for this session on the Mitchell concurrent resolution eliminating the provision which holds that eligible voters within New York City must have lived in a county at least four months.
The New York Stock Exchange today will admit $1 par common shares of the Sperry Corporation to the list and to dealings and will suspend from dealings voting trust certificates for these shares.

American merchant seamen, despite their heavy losses, are still ready to laugh heartily at the salty tales of their comrades, a group of 400 seamen from torpedoed ships showed yesterday. They attended a meeting at the National Maritime Union office at 346 West Seventeenth Street.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Distribution of an occupational questionnaire aimed at ascertaining the background of men who registered for the Selective Service Feb. 16 was announced today.

Walter Sandt of 100-08 157th Street, Howard Beach, Queens, the air raid zone warden who was suspended Feb. 18 for his part in circulating a petition urging the removal of Mayor La guardia as head of the city's civilian defense organization, called upon the Mayor and Police.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Sales tax advocates on the House Ways and Means Committee indicated today that they were being driven into a political corner as the result of continued demands from large segments of business to be "left alone" in the new tax bill, or to be "let off" comparatively lightly.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (U.P.) -- Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the Maritime Commission, declared today that grave difficulties must be surmounted if President Roosevelt's 1942 merchant ship construction program is to be fulfilled.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The movement to alter the Wage-Hour Law received powerful support tonight when Speaker Rayburn expressed the opinion that time-and-a-half pay should begin after forty-eight hours, instead of forty, as at present.

Earl Walsh, one-time running mate of the immortal George Gipp at Notre Dame, who has been Sleepy Jim Crowley's first assistant ever since Jimmy took over Fordham's football reins in 1933, yesterday put in his first day as the Rams' new football custodian for the duration of the war.

Substitution of single-deck for double-deck buses by the Fifth Avenue Coach Company probably will be made first on the Convent Avenue line between 114th and 152d Streets, John E. McCarthy, president of the company, said yesterday.
