BERLIN, March 23 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Soviet forces, still attacking in the Kerch Peninsula of the Crimea and in the Donets Basin, have been repulsed, the High Command said today. Particularly bitter fighting was reported in the Donets Basin.

For the second time in its 150-year history, the New York Stock Exchange breaks a tradition today by recommending the purchase of a particular security. Emil Schram, president of the Exchange, urges investors to buy Defense Savings Bonds in an advertisement appearing this morning, sponsored by the Association of Stock Exchange Firms.

In your issue of March 20 that able military commentator, Hanson W. Baldwin, correctly states the interdependence of offense and defense in war and rightly condemns one-sided military thinking. One might almost say that offensive and defensive were Siamese twins -- with the offensive indeed the positive one of the pair, but with each indispensable to the well-being of the other.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The $100,000,000 Corn Products Refining Company and its sales subsidiary, Corn Products Sales Company, Inc., of New York, have been ordered by the Federal Trade Commission to cease discriminating in the prices charged and the services and facilities afforded their customers and from exclusive dealing arrangements in violation of the Robinson-Patman and Clayton act.

Thirty-five persons, passengers and crew members, were lost and 135 saved when an American passenger and cargo vessel, carrying women defense workers and government aides, and a Panamanian tanker were torpedoed by enemy submarines, the Navy disclosed last night in Miami, Fla.

A funeral service for Sidney R. Kent, president of Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and a pioneer in the development of the motion picture industry, who died last Thursday morning, was held yesterday morning at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

UNITED STATES ARMY HEADQUARTERS, in Australia, March 23 (AP) -- A conference at which General Douglas MacArthur gave news correspondents a complete account of the Pacific war situation today was "off the record," but the correspondents agreed that the Supreme Commander left nothing to the imagination as he dealt out the facts.

Marine underwriters announced an innovation in war-risk rates, yesterday when Western Hemisphere cargo shipments to and from United States Atlantic ports north of Cape Hatteras were quoted on a higher basis than shipments to and from the ports south of that point.

News of the death of Professor Hermann Strauss, head of the Jewish Hospital in Berlin, who committed suicide recently on the eve of his deportation to a ghetto in Poland, was received here by The Jewish Day yesterday shortly after it had been received by Aufbau, German emigre publication.

The Japanese ultimatum to General Wainwright claims that Japan now has overwhelming superiority in the Philippines and is therefore "entirely free either to attack and put to rout the American forces or await their inevitable starvation within the narrow confines of the Bataan Peninsula."

Carl Pilnick, City College champion, and Louis Levy, former N.Y.U. star, met last night in the third round of the United States Chess Federation championship preliminaries at the Marshall Club. The result was a draw in thirty moves, Levy playing the black side of a King's Indian defense.

LONDON, March 23 (Reuter) -- Unimpeachable trade circles report that the Ministry of Supply has appointed Sir Cecil Rodwell as controller of industrial diamonds. Sir Cecil has important gold and copper interests. The Diamond Syndicate, wholly owned subsidiary of De Beers, will thus from now on be subject to government control.

News of the death of Professor Hermann Strauss, head of the Jewish Hospital in Berlin, who committed suicide recently on the eve of his deportation to a ghetto in Poland, was received here by The Jewish Day yesterday shortly after it had been received by Aufbau, German emigre publication.

The Department of Welfare is well enough organized to meet any air raid emergency that may arise in this city even to the extent of providing a new plan of central registration in each community, so that families who have become separated may be easily traced, William Hodson, Welfare Commissioner, told 2,300 members of his emergency staff yesterday at Hunter College.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, March 23 (AP) -- A high government source said tonight that the chiefs of the Argentine Military Purchasing Commission in Washington were returning home "because the necessities of war prevent the United States from delivering at this time arms required by the belligerents."
LONDON, March 23 (AP) -- The Admiralty issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Using powers acquired under the Emergency Price Control Act, the Office of Price Administration tonight set maximum retail prices for seven major household appliances and for new typewriters. It was the first time that the OPA had taken action on such a broad scale in fixing prices that retailers can charge, and was intended to stop price increases in the items covered.

MIAMI, Fla., March 23 -- Convinced the situation was one calling for summary action but still unable to put his finger on any one point as the seat of all his troubles, Manager Melvin Ott today announced a shake-up in the Giant ranks of revolutionary proportions.
BERLIN, March 23 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Today's German High Command communique:

The Department of Welfare is well enough organized to meet any air raid emergency that may arise in this city even to the extent of providing a new plan of central registration in each community, so that families who have become separated may be easily traced, William Hodson, Welfare Commissioner, told 2,300 members of his emergency staff yesterday at Hunter College.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, March 23 (AP) -- A high government source said tonight that the chiefs of the Argentine Military Purchasing Commission in Washington were returning home "because the necessities of war prevent the United States from delivering at this time arms required by the belligerents."
LONDON, March 23 (AP) -- The Admiralty issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Using powers acquired under the Emergency Price Control Act, the Office of Price Administration tonight set maximum retail prices for seven major household appliances and for new typewriters. It was the first time that the OPA had taken action on such a broad scale in fixing prices that retailers can charge, and was intended to stop price increases in the items covered.

SEBRING, Fla., March 23 -- A severe case of stage fright overtook the Newark Bears today in the presence of the Yankee varsity squad. Taking full advantage of the awe-stricken farmhands, the world champions rushed over six runs in the first inning for a 9-to-5 triumph that was far from impressive.

CANBERRA, Australia, March 23 -- The Japanese Air Force, severely hammered in week-end United Nations operations against enemy bases in Northeast New Guinea and New Britain, struck back today by raiding Wyndham, in Northern Australia, and Port Moresby, in New Guinea. The raid on Port Moresby, carried out by nineteen bombers and some fighters, was the heaviest there thus far.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 23 -- Neil S. McCarthy's Augury, a California refugee who had equaled the 1:10 six-furlong track record in her only previous Florida race, today ran last at Tropical Park as a 3-to-4 favorite in the Biscayne Purse, a six-furlong dash which drew only four starters because of the muddy strip.

TRENTON, N.J., March 23 -- Over the objection of Assemblyman Roscoe P. McClave, Bergen County Republican, sponsor of bills to create a State water authority, the House joined with the Senate this afternoon in passing three bills to carry out recommendations of a special study commission for interconnection of existing water systems to provide an adequate supply instead of establishing new sources.

LAKELAND, Fla., March 23 -- Behind six innings of shut-out pitching by the veteran southpaw Larry French, the Dodgers today evened matters with the Tigers by beating them, 7 -- 2, in the final game of Brooklyn's tour of Florida's west coast.

Gracefully styled culottes and slack suits for bicycling and gardening, and high fleece-lined lounging slippers, long-sleeved nightgowns, and warm jackets for dinner dresses, for houses with oilless furnaces, are fashion guideposts urged by consumers who are being invited to share with retailers their problems in planning a war-time wardrobe.

The Greater New York Fund, which opened its fifth annual campaign yesterday, has two aspects, the businesslike and the humanitarian. It is businesslike to enable 11,638 corporations and firms, and their employes, to make a single gift once a year to an agency representing 400 voluntary private charities.
CANBERRA, Australia, March 23 (AP) -- Prime Minister John Curtin issued this communique today:
ROME, March 23 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Today's Italian High Command communique:

The ordinarily humdrum virtue of thrift becomes enormously important in war times. As the savings banks of New York State have pointed out, savings of every kind, whether put into defense bonds or deposited in the savings bank will help to buy equipment for the fighting men.

Mellow orange marmalade, delightfully permeated with the fragrance of the fresh fruit, may be seen in the round, clear, glass jars that sedately sit on the shelves of city stores. This marmalade, with its amber translucence and satisfying savor, suggests pleasant scenes of bygone tranquillity -- a crackling wood fire, a wicker basket of hot buttery toast, a squat pot of tea and the friendly notes of a grandfather's clock striking five.

Increased military needs for leather this year will cut the quantity available for civilian consumption about 20 per cent, Merrill A. Watson, executive vice president of the Tanners Council of America, declared yesterday at the opening session of the Shoe Style Conference and Leather Opening sponsored jointly by the council and the National Shoe Retailers Association at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Hearings on a bill to abolish the Civilian Conservation Corps and the National Youth Administration on the ground that the war labor demand had made relief agencies needless, began today as members of the Senate voiced amazement over newspaper reports that the NYA had been "hoarding" millions of dollars' worth of vitally needed machine tools.

PEORIA, Ill., March 23 -- The strike which had slowed down the wartime shipments of the Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad for eighty-four days and brought about seizure of the 239-mile freight line yesterday by the government, was ended by an agreement reached at noon today by the railroad brotherhoods and John W. Barriger 3d, Federal manager of the road.

Railroad men who commented on the government's seizure of the Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad, because its president declined to accept arbitration of a labor dispute, recalled that the heads of the unions concerned in this dispute had gone on record in the past against any arbitration of controversies over wages or working conditions.

Mrs. John Sloane gave a luncheon yesterday at her home, 48 East Ninety-second Street, for Mrs. Hugh A. Drum and Mrs. Adolphus Andrews in advance of the recital by Rudolf Firkusny, pianist, held later in the afternoon at Mrs. Sloane's home under the auspices of the English-Speaking Union's common interests committee.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The War Department issued this communique today, based on reports received before 9 A.M.:

While buying of Spring coats and suits is receding from its peak levels, the filling of orders already booked keeps production at peak levels, according to the report issued yesterday by the National Coat and Suit Recovery Board. Distribution of coat and suit labels last week reached a new high for the period, totaling 529,750.

Just twenty-five years ago tonight Eddie Cantor of the banjo eyes went to work for the late Florenz Ziegfeld in "The Midnight Frolic" on the roof of the New Amsterdam Theatre. And so tonight he will celebrate. Of course, he was no novice in 1917, having started in vaudeville ten years earlier, but that show led him, the following June, into the "Ziegfeld Follies" and thence on to fame and fortune.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Lack of news concerning action involving other American Army forces indicated that there was nothing to report from the Philippines, where Lieut. Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright, successor to General Douglas MacArthur, is preparing his forces for an expected all-out effort by the Japanese to destroy the resistance of United States and Filipino forces.

Buyers arriving in the New York market last week numbered 953, which compared with 1,228 in the preceding week and 1,089 in the similar period of 1941, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals totaled 362 as against 497 for last Tuesday.

BETHPAGE, L.I., March 24 -- Right now Lieutenant Edward H. O'Hare may be "grubbing" a cigarette from some of his fellow air fighters somewhere out in the Pacific Ocean area, but if a certain shipment reaches him he will have 230,000 cigarettes all for himself.

The United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, C.I.O., announced yesterday that it was willing to waive time and one-half pay for Saturdays and double time for Sundays and holidays, provided the money thus saved is turned over to the Treasury to be used by the government specifically for paying for manufacture of war materials.

The costume jewelry industry was told bluntly yesterday that it must stop manufacturing goods using a long list of critical metals by May 31. The advice was given by Sydney Hogerton, district manager of priorities of the War Production Board, at a priorities round table on metals and metal products held at the office of the Commerce and Industry Association in the Woolworth Building.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 24 -- Nassau County's 300 square miles, including virtually certain targets in case of a real air raid, held its first blackout from 9:05 to 9:26 o'clock tonight. Despite flaws here and there, the test was described by Colonel Edward C.O. Thomas, county director of civil defense, as "entirely satisfactory."

LONDON, March 24 -- Sir Stafford Cripps again attended a meeting of the Viceroy's Executive Coucil in New Delhi, India, today, after a conference with Sir Maurice Gwyer, Chief Justice of the Federal Court of India, and the Governors of the Northwest Frontier Province, the United Provinces, the Province of Madras, the Province of Bombay and the Province of Bengal.

The nation's war program is impaired when freight is damaged in shipment, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, said in a statement issued yesterday endorsing the "perfect shipping campaign" conducted by the National Association of Shippers Advisory Boards.

DETROIT, March 24 (AP) -- Miss Genevieve Samp, whose suspension from work in a war plant here has been brought to the attention of Congress, has been out of her job for the last two weeks in accord with procedure under the union shop contract of the National Stamping Company with the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O.

The manufacture of 14,000 separate articles of clothing each day for men of the Navy by the United States Naval Clothing Depot at Third Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, Brooklyn, was described yesterday by Lieut. Comdr. John T. Tuthill Jr., Naval public relations officer for the Third Naval District.

RIOM, France, March 24 -- Four more generals before the Supreme Court here today added their testimony on the state of morale and defects in the army organization, training and materiel that led to the French defeat.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Air-raid sirens wailed in Washington today and the test was symbolic of what the coming of Spring may mean.

Expected to be the largest wooden aircraft in the world, a revolutionary plane for long-range military transport will be built by Curtiss-Wright Corporation almost entirely out of non-strategic materials, the company announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, March 24 -- Reorganization proceedings under Chapter X of the Bankruptcy Act were undertaken by 108 companies with assets aggregating $80,000,000 and indebtedness totaling $39,500,000 in the second half of 1941, it was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 24 -- The Giants exploded out of their losing streak today with a terrific detonation, but Manager Melvin Ott remained a somewhat puzzled young skipper.

BALTIMORE, March 24 (AP) -- Army morale chiefs in Baltimore and at the Aberdeen (Md.) proving ground joined today in sharp criticism of the Amateur Athletic Union's suspension of a soldier athlete after he competed, under orders, with his service buddies against a professional basketball team.

The first of the Department of Welfare emergency centers for victims of possible air raids was officially dedicated yesterday at 157 Henry Street by Welfare Commissioner William Hodson, who was appointed last months by Mayor La Guardia as Emergency Welfare Administrator.

Arthur MacArthur's father thought the boy should wait some time in Melbourne before getting his hair cut, as a precaution against catching cold. The boy's mother decided a haircut would do no harm, but fitted out the 4-year-old with woolen underwear, a warm cap and heavy clothes.

MONTREAL, March 24 -- The Canadiens moved back into contention for Stanley Cup honors tonight when they defeated Detroit, 5 -- 0, to even their two-out-of-three play-off series at one victory apiece. The teams clash in the deciding game at Detroit Thursday night, with the winner advancing to the semi-finals.

Employers in New York State, who are required by law to have withheld from wages of their employes who live outside the State the full State income tax due for 1941, were ordered yesterday by the State Tax Department to return 25 per cent to those employes at once.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, urged Congress today to let wage and hours statutes alone, to permit the continuance of payment of time-and-one-half for work beyond forty hours a week, and not outlaw, even for the duration of war, the closed union shop.

Speaker Rayburn has expressed the opinion that legally obligatory time-and-a-half pay should begin after forty-eight hours instead of forty, as at present. This is clearly the most sensible solution of the forty-hour week controversy.

HONOLULU, March 24 -- How thirty-two sailors trapped in the hull of the capsized battleship Oklahoma at Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7 were saved by navy yard workmen who cut through the steel sides of the ship while under fire was revealed today in official reports to the navy yard commandant.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The departure for Buenos Aires of the chiefs of the Argentine military and naval missions who have been discussing arrangements here for obtaining defense materiel was said today by Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, to be with a view to submitting their opinions and recommendations to their government for its consideration.

CLEVELAND, March 24 (AP) -- Declaring that "the time has long passed when this nation should be 'playing at war,'" the advisory committee of the National Federation of Republican Women's Clubs said today that "boondoggling, departmental duplications, defiant administrative doctrines must go."

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., March 24 -- Dr. Paul Dwight Moody, president of Middlebury College since 1921, made public today his intention of retiring and in announcing his decision to the faculty this afternoon said:

The Sayville Playhouse, Inc., of which Edith Gordon of Manhattan is president, has purchased the playhouse property on Candee Avenue, in Sayville, L. I., from Lila Robinson and Caroline Greene at a reported price of about $50,000. The buyers operated the playhouse successfully there for its first season last Summer.

The Board of Higher Education announced yesterday that during March it had received the resignations of three City College faculty members and one Brooklyn College professor who had been scheduled to appear before trial committees on charges of Communist activities.

CHUNGKING, China, March 24 -- "One consensus here is that Japan has reached the peak of her military glory and that the fortunes of war will gradually run in favor of the Allies," declared Vice Foreign Minister P.S. Foo, acting as government spokesman today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, March 24 -- Otto Waebel, former German consul at Santos, and Reinhold Pohl, employe of a German coffee exporting firm, today were accused of aiding the flight of eleven officers and crewmen from the German freighter Windhoek.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- Representative Rich suggested today that a need for new labor legislation was emphasized by the case of a young woman who reported that she had lost her job because she worked harder than other employes in a Detroit plant.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- President Roosevelt nominated Earl G. Harrison as Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, held his press conference and received Judge William Clark, Senator Clark of Missouri, the Polish Ambassador and Polish Premier General Sikorski and the Minister of New Zealand.
LONDON, March 24 -- Chinese soldiers, without benefit of air support, today bore the brunt of the heaviest fighting in Burma in some days, according to reports from New Delhi, India.

The American Red Cross is appealing for $65,000,000 to provide relief for American war victims and to carry on rapidly expanding Red Cross services for the armed forces. The Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York is seeking $7,330,000 of the national goal in a united local chapter appeal in the five boroughs, as follows: Manhattan and the Bronx, $6,250,000; Brooklyn, $700,000; Queens, North Shore, $50,000; Central Queens, $250,000; Staten Island, $80,000.

UNITED STATES ARMY HEADQUARTERS, in Australia, March 24 -- A promise by General Douglas MacArthur not to suppress news of the progress of the war but to make the truth public was issued today by Army headquarters.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 24 -- Addressing a meeting of party functionaries and Nazi leaders Dr. Joseph Goebbels, German Minister of Propaganda, declared the hopes "the plutocratic-Bolshevistic coalition" had pinned on the abnormal Winter of 1941-42 had been "smashed and put to shame" through "the fortitude and admirable bearing of the German people, which faced Winter's difficulties and privations with unprecedented courage."

MOSCOW, March 24 -- Information in the Red Army's possession indicates that the German High Command, trying to stabilize its Eastern Front, has transferred thirty-eight divisions [possibly 500,000 men] to its various sectors from all parts of Europe since Jan. 1. Large air reinforcements also have arrived recently.

LONDON, March 24 -- The issue of freedom to criticize, with emphasis laid on the press will be debated in Parliament before the Easter recess. The discussion arising from the warning to The Daily Mirror by Herbert Morrison, Home Secretary, is expected to lead to a suggestion that the offending regulation be annuled.

LONDON, March 24 -- With the approach of Spring, this country's thoughts turn inevitably again to the dangers of invasion. A few bombs dropped last night on south coast towns served as a pointed reminder that Great Britain is still very close to the war zone.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The farmers of America will turn away in this year of war from such classic crops as wheat to the soy bean and the peanut, according to an estimate of 1942 plantings issued today by the Crop Reporting Board. There is a trend to plant crops that can be crushed for urgently needed vegetable oils.

WHY the Mayors of other cities do not rise in revolt this baffled bystander doesn't know. Perhaps some national priorities board should step in and take command. Let's face it! The final of the national invitation basketball tournament is coming up tonight. Where? In New York City. There is to be a rubber race at a mile tonight between Leslie MacMitchell and Gil Dodds. Where? In New York City!

CAIRO, Egypt, March 24 -- According to a German special order captured by the British in Libya, Reichsfuehrer Hitler is seasoning his armies with Storm Troop divisions to form the basis of a huge State police force that will help him to rule the Reich and its "subject peoples" after the war.

The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it would install new electrolytic tinplating facilities at a cost of $10,000,000 at plants of its subsidiaries in the Chicago, Pittsburgh and Birmingham districts. The move will aid in saving 6,750,000 pounds of pig tin a year.

Yesterday the Germans pounded the battered town of Dover and the Japanese loosed a fleet of their new bombers on the defiant fortress of Corregidor. On the same day Britain suffered the worst raid of the year and the American stronghold in Manila Bay its heaviest air attack.

General Ben Lear's troops know him for a hard commander, a strict disciplinarian and a good realist. To all the current talk of what will win the war -- planes, money, tanks, machines, ships, food, or what not -- he returns a simple answer. He says "fighters will win the war."

Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra gave a neatly balanced program of music by three Russians at Carnegie Hall last night, with a brilliant assist from Nathan Milstein, who was also born in Russia, as violin soloist.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The text of the formal statement by Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, before the House Naval Affairs Committee today was as follows:

" To the Shores of Tripoli," a Twentieth Century-Fox drama dealing with the Marine Corps, will have its local premiere this morning at the Roxy. John Payne, Maureen O'Hara and Randolph Scott head the cast of the Technicolor production, and Nancy Kelly, William Tracy, Maxie Rosenbloom and Henry Morgan are featured in supporting roles.

A motor boat of the Columbia University crew yesterday rescued two 16-year-old boys and a patrolman clinging to an overturned canoe in the Harlem River Ship Canal near 225th Street. The boys, Jay Constantine, 568 West 192d Street, and Marius Charlet, 540 West 186th Street, were taken to Jewish Memorial Hospital, suffering from exposure and submersion.

The local premiere of John Steinbeck's dramatization of his own novel, "The Moon Is Down," scheduled for next Tuesday night at the Martin Beck, has been delayed for a while. The production, which opened its pre-Broadway engagement on Monday night in Baltimore, most likely will remain there through the first half of next week or all of that week in order to allow the cast additional practice.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- President Roosevelt deplored today the existence of a "sixth column," which, he said, was made up of Americans who wittingly or unwittingly spread the rumors and doubts devised by fifth columnists.

To emphasize the importance of the relationship between hats and hair styling, a joint showing of Spring millinery and individually styled coiffures was presented yesterday in the Charleston Garden at B. Altman Co. Three basic coiffures by Charles of the Ritz were shown in twelve adaptations for women of different types.

Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor and president of the Union Labor Life Insurance Company, owned by national and international unions comprising the A.F. of L., made public yesterday the company's statement of financial condition as of Dec. 31, 1941.

CLEVELAND, March 24 (AP) -- Jack Heintz, Inc., under fire for alleged excessive profits on war contracts, announced tonight the voluntary limitation of profits to 6 per cent in the future and drastic salary reductions for the company's three top executives.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Vallejo and Napa, Calif., with a rise of 65 per cent in department store sales during February, still led all other cities in percentage increases as compared with February, 1941, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Seattle was next with an increase of 49 per cent.

Predictions that the war would be won more quickly than most expect, that the capital market might be all but wiped out in the next year or so, but would revive to do a tremendous job when the fighting ended, and that Washington would become the "hub of the world" after the victory, were made yesterday afternoon by Dr. Marcus Nadler, Professor of Banking and Finance at New York University.

The two teams that were ignored most by the fans and experts in the pre-tournament ratings, Western Kentucky State and West Virginia, will clash tonight in the final of the fifth annual national invitation basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden.
MOSCOW, March 24 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:...

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 24 -- Those "heavenly twins," Peewee Reese and Pete Reiser, collaborated nicely with Johnny Rizzo at City Island Park in a ninth-inning rally by the Dodgers that beat the Red Sox, 4 to 3, today.

Joseph Hidalgo Jr., chess champion at the High School of Commerce, shared first place with Matthew Green yesterday in the United States Chess Federation championship preliminaries when he defeated John W. Barnhart at the Marshall Chess Club in 31 moves in Section A.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Representative Frank Keefe, Republican, of Wisconsin, speaking in the House today, accused Sears, Roebuck Co. of circumventing "the plain mandate" of he law governing priorities of rubber by selling farm wagons equipped with standard automobile tires, without requiring the purchaser to make affidavit that the tires were not to be removed from the farm vehicle.

Talking to the newsmen at his headquarters in Australia, General MacArthur had a number of useful things to say about the always difficult question of censorship in wartime. He began with the assumption, which is certainly correct, that the American public neither expects nor desires the publication of news which will really play into the hands of the enemy.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Robert R. Guthrie, resigned chief of the War production Board's Textile, Clothing and Leather Branch, was described today as an incompetent and arrogant executive whose overbearing manner antagonized his subordinates.

The National Music League presented the first of a series of six chamber music concerts late yesterday afternoon at THE NEW YORK TIMES Hall. The artists were Ruth Freeman, flutist, and William Gephart, baritone, who are soloist members of the league, and the four auxiliary members who make up the New Manhattan Quartet.

BOSTON, March 24 -- Chicago's determined Black Hawks bounced out of a sudden death setback and deadlocked their best-of-three National Hockey League quarter-final play-off series by overwhelming the Boston Bruins, 4 -- 0, tonight before 14,200 fans at the Boston Garden.

LONDON, March 24 -- Sentiment on the stock markets was helped today by the progress of Warship Week subscriptions and with Canadian call-up money coming in the markets had a cheerful and active day. Rises covered most sections.

NEWARK, N.J., March 24 -- A suitable epitaph for the grave of each United Nations' soldier killed in Malaya, Luzon or Java would be: "He fought valiantly, without air support," Robert H. Hinckley, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Air, told some 400 educators here today.

ALBANY, March 24 -- Full State aid for education became the law today for the first time since 1938, when Governor Lehman signed, without comment, the State budget as amended by the Republican controlled Legislature. In 1939 the Republicans took the initiative in cutting educational appropriations, but they restored them to their full statutory proportion this year, after the Governor, in accordance with the Republican policy, had listed only 98 per cent in his budget.
Election of Frederick P. Clark as planning director of the Regional Plan Association was announced yesterday by C. McKim Norton, executive vice president of the association.

Since the city government has to take many a rough lick from many a tongue, it is all the more just to thank it for its foresight in removing to safe places the colonial and other objects of art in the City Hall. There on two floors was and will be again a museum worth visiting.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 24 -- Charley Ruffing, a recent Yankee holdout, made his 1942 debut against the Tigers at Waterfront Park today under distressing circumstances.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Fifty more persons accused as members of the $10,000,000 Cohen lottery ring were arrested over the week-end and yesterday, bringing to 110 the total thus far, J. Edgar Hoover, head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today.
CANBERRA, Australia, March 24 (AP) -- Prime Minister John Curtin issued this communique today:
With the renting of eight more apartments since Jan. 1 in Rockefeller apartment building at 17 West Fifty-fourth Street, that structure now is fully occupied, according to Dougas Gibbons Co., agents.

LONDON, March 24 -- Establishment of a joint war-production staff, to clamp together -- the phrase is Prime Minister Winston Churchill's -- needs of the three fighting services and to allocate between them, was announced today by Captain Oliver Lyttelton, Minister of Production, in opening House of Commons debate on production.

After members of the Police and Fire Departments had failed to obtain the support of the Democratic majority in the City Council for their Albany bill providing a 15 per cent pay increase for both departments, Councilman Meyer Goldberg, Manhattan Republican, introduced a resolution in the Council yesterday requesting adoption of the bill.

Citing Secretary Wickard's reminder that "food is a munition of warfare, just as surely as shells and anti-aircraft guns," the annual report of the Jewish Agricultural Society, made public yesterday, pledges unstinted efforts to step up production.

The following table shows how the reapportionment bill introduced at Albany yesterday would lay out the State Senate districts anew as a result of the Federal census of 1940. The citizen population is shown by counties and proposed districts.

KUNMING, China, March 24 -- Pilots of the American Volunteer Group smashed forty planes at the Thai airport of Chiengmai today in a dawn attack that caught the Japanese by surprise, it was announced here. Lampun, ten miles to the south, also was raided, but results were not revealed.

Ecuador has the agricultural resources to supply half of the United State needs of Manila hemps and an important portion of its requirements of quinine, tapioca, rubber and sugar, provided sufficient economic inducement is given, Dr. Roberto Levi, now here on a special economic mission for that country, declared yesterday.

BIRMINGHAM, England, March 24 -- Councilor Norman Tiptaft, Lord Mayor of Birmingham, has declared war on Whitehall over the regional system for civil defense and plans to invade London next week, taking with him the municipal leaders of Manchester and Sheffield.

One rainy day, not so long ago, a pale-faced young woman strolled along the quiet aisles of a Manhattan art museum, eyeing with envy the faint, shell-rose flush of Botticelli's Venus, the pink-and-white perfection of Gainsborough's court ladies, the bright, luminous bloom of a complexion by Renoir.

Physicians who are practicing in the neighborhood of plants that are on war production work are conscious of the increasing number of patients who come to them as a result of physical fatigue. The establishment of a seven-day work week, even as a war emergency measure, is a questionable procedure.

YONKERS, N. Y., March 24 -- The Yonkers Common Council voted, 3 to 2, tonight against a motion to receive a bill of particulars prepared by the City Manager League of Yonkers amplifying charges previously made against City Manager Raymond J. Whitney in an effort to remove him from office.

PHILADELPHIA, March 24 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission granted permission today to the Union Electric Company of Missouri to issue and sell $10,000,000 additional of its first mortgage and collateral trust bonds, 3 3/8 per cent series due 1971, and to use the proceeds for new construction and for the purchase of up to $10,000,000 additional par value of the capital stock of its subsidiary Union Electric Company of Illinois.

ALBANY, March 24 -- The Senate completed by unanimous vote legislative action for this session on the Ives constitutional amendment seeking to establish a Department of Commerce in the State Government.

Mayor La Guardia expressed his approval yesterday of a local law introduced in the City Council by Councilman Stanley M. Isaacs that provides wartime fire protection for every building in the city and specifies the type and amount of equipment that must be provided.

The general death rate in New York City fell last week to 10.2 per 1,000 population, the lowest mark of the year so far, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, reported yesterday. In the previous week the death rate was 11.5, the year's peak.

FALL RIVER, Mass., March 24 -- William H. Davis, chairman of the War Labor Board, tonight took action in an effort to end a labor controversy which earlier in the day had closed five cotton cloth mills here, resulting in more than 8,000 workers being idle and threatening to assume larger proportions.

The leather and shoe industry agreed yesterday to go on a war basis, in which manufacturers would confine the number of Fall colors produced to five basic shades and black, and produce efficient, economical and durable footwear which will not require the use of new equipment and will not interfere with the war effort.
CHUNGKING, China, March 24 (AP) -- A communique from Chinese Army Headquarters in Burma said today:

PHILADELPHIA, March 24 (AP) -- A Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company stockholder, represented by Thomas E. Dewey, former Republican Presidential aspirant, made an unsuccessful attempt at the annual meeting today to oust Robert V. White as president of the company.

CHICAGO, March 24 -- High intelligence is no bar to early and successful marriage among business women, according to Ann Brewington, assistant professor of business education, and Evely Berg, research assistant at the University of Chicago.

Mrs. Ellen Proctor, 31-year-old wife of a Minneapolis shoe store manager, had never been to New York before. Her address, since Monday, has been the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Mrs. Proctor was summoned here. She suspected the reason, but it was not revealed until she arrived.

COCO SOLO, C.Z., March 24 (U.P.) -- Robert Emmet Kelley, 17 years old, sole survivor of the thirty-three-man crew of a torpedoed American tanker, said today he watched ten of his shipmates die, one by one, during twenty-one days adrift in an oil-soaked open boat in the Caribbean.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- William L. Batt, War Production Board official, testified today before the Senate Defense Investigating Committee that Jesse H. Jones, Federal Loan Administrator, overruled recommendations in 1940 for building up the country's synthetic rubber production to 100,000 tons annually because, he said, he did not believe it was necessary.

Several young matrons and debutantes of this season and recent years will act as manikins in the fashion show and luncheon in behalf of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children to be held on Saturday at the Pierre. They will display a collection of original models made of British tweeds.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The War Department communique, based on reports received up to 10:30 A.M., follows:

The reclassification before long of 30,000 men in the city whose local draft boards had granted them occupational deferments may cause a labor shortage in the next three months and Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, Selective Service Director here, last night urged employers to begin training women and older men immediately as replacements -- if they have not already done so.

The report of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Feb. 28, issued yesterday, showed a consolidated net income of $11,968,039, after expenses and charges. After preferred dividend charges, on which unpaid accumulations amounted to $21 a preferred share on Jan. 1, the net was equal to 8.8 cents a share on the corporation's outstanding common stock.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., March 24 (AP) -- The Double H Ranch's Stalking nosed out T.H. Heard Jr.'s Be Blue and came within a fifth of a second of the track record for six furlongs to win the Blytheville Purse at Oaklawn Park today. Stalking, with Johnny Longden up, was timed in 1:10 2-5 and paid $4.10 for $2.

Three hundred representatives of management and organized labor from 110 war plants conferred yesterday in the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street, in another effort to promote establishment of management-labor committees to improve efficiency and obtain maximum output.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The C.I.O. and the A.F. of L. agreed separately today to give up premium pay for Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, but to insist upon time and a half for the sixth consecutive day of work and for over eight hours' work in any given day.

Moderate priced dwellings in Brooklyn are steadily rising in demand, according to brokers in many residential areas. The three-story house containing eleven rooms and two baths at 166 Prospect Place was sold by the estate of Bridget Meehan to a client of the Ralph Beattie Real Estate Corporation, brokers in the deal, for occupancy.

Flat rejection of union demands for wage increases and improved working conditions for 70,000 workers in 3,000 buildings throughout the city was announced yesterday in a communication to the union by the Realty Advisory Board of Labor Relations, speaking for the owners.
Lady Sinclair, wife of Sir Walrond Sinclair of London, and their daughter, Miss Yvonne Sinclair, who spent the Winter at Fort George, Fla., have returned to Essex House.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 23 -- Kitty- hawk escort fighters shot down two and probably three German Messerschmitt 109's yesterday while protecting Boston bombers in another telling daylight raid on Martuba airport, it was announced here today.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Operations that very possibly forecast the reopening of an expected heavy Japanese offensive took place today in the Philippine Islands, but two reported engagements ended with successes for the United States and Filipino defenders.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Dr. Henry F. Grady, a former Assistant Secretary of State and a member of the advisory mission to India, was designated today active chairman of the mission.

The Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank has sold the eleven-story loft building at 81 to 95 University Place, northeast corner of East Eleventh Street, to University Lofts, Inc., represented by George M. Jaffin. The property, also known as 41 to 45 East Eleventh Street, fronts 157 feet on University Place and 141 feet on East Eleventh Street, one block from Broadway.

ALBANY, March 24 -- The long-awaited legislative reapportionment plan, prepared by the Republican-controlled special legislative committee headed by Harry A. Reoux, was introduced today in the Legislature. The measure greatly increases the legislative representation of New York City and the counties of Westchester, Nassau and Suffolk, but, framed as it is within the constitutional limitations set forth in 1894, it preserves for the up-State rural areas representation beyond their actual population.

ALBANY, March 24 -- Industrial Commissioner Frieda S. Miller reported today that retail stores in the State lost 1.8 per cent in forces and payrolls from January to February, while wholesale dealers reduced forces 0.8 per cent, with practically no net change in payrolls.

ALBANY, March 24 -- Governor Lehman and Mayor La Guardia held today their first formal conference since last Fall, when bitter words were exchanged during the Mayoralty campaign. They got along very well.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 24 -- Les Kennedy, 24-year-old rookie from Lynn, Mass., who had never finished higher than a tie for fifth place in the Winter meets, led a field of golfing greats today in the first round of the 72-hole North and South open championship.

Nine college students have been selected to take part in the final competition for cash prizes in architecture offered by the American Academy in Rome. These have been selected as a result of a twenty-four-hour competition. Forty-six students entered the competition originally.
CHICAGO, March 24 -- T.V. Houser, vice president in charge of merchandising for Sears, Roebuck Co., issued this statement tonight:

John Van Kuren Newkirk, known in Burma as "Scarsdale Jack," whose death was reported yesterday, was the leader of the Second Pursuit Squadron of the American Volunteer Group. Flying over the Burma Road, he recently brought down his twenty-fifth Japanese plane. The British this month awarded him the Distinguished Service Order.

KATE AUSTEN, the miracle woman of Elliot Merrick's "Northern Nurse,"* is an Australian. If all the Australians are like her, the Japanese will die by the hundreds of thousands and even the millions before they even make a dent on the land Down Under.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, March 25 -- German forces on the Leningrad front were reported from Moscow this morning to be staggering back to new positions at many points on the Northern Front as a result of a heavy offensive launched by an estimated twenty-five divisions of Soviet troops shortly after dawn yesterday.

PEORIA, Ill., March 24 -- The Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad was accused of entrapment today by attorneys defending three men accused of contempt of court in an alleged conspiracy to dynamite one of the road's bridges during the recent strike, which resulted in appointment of a Federal manager to operate the line

DETROIT, March 24 -- Addressing a conference called by the War Production Board to promote the establishment of management-labor committees in plants charged with responsibility for one-fifth of the national arms program, C.E. Wilson, president of the General Motor Corporation, said today that it was "too bad that we can't win this war with committees and talk."

UNITED STATES ARMY HEADQUARTERS, in Australia, March 24 -- A detailed story of General Douglas MacArthur's five-day journey by torpedo boat and plane from the Philippines to Australia was made public today by United States Army authori ties. It was revealed that the daring trip through the Japanese blockade, in which the party was soaked repeatedly by high seas and many suffered from seasickness, was made possible by the general's own foresight.

Connecticut trout streams that are close to towns and centers of populations will be stocked heavily this season. This general policy, adopted by the State Board of Fisheries and Game, was made known yesterday by Russell P. Hunter, State Superintendent of Fish and Game, who stated that this plan had been adopted in line with the anticipated limitation of travel during the coming months.

All is set for the "dream" track meet that is to be held tonight at the Bronx Coliseum for the benefit of the Navy Relief Society. The games, sponsored by the Track Writers Association and conducted by directors of local major meets, are expected to attract a capacity crowd to the uptown arena.
Four panel discussions on "The Child in Wartime" will be held in the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, today and April 1, 15 and 22.

THE TIMES'S editorial of March 25 "Distribution of Incomes," discussing certain OPA estimates for 1942 as compared to 1941, features the fact that in these estimates the entire estimated increase in national income going to individuals would go to the incomes above $2,500.

CHICAGO, March 24 -- Although there was little increase in the outside interest in the grain markets today, the strength in cotton brought in sufficient buying to lift prices rather sharply. Closing trades on wheat on the Board of Trade here showed gains of 1 to 1 1/4 cents a bushel, with the finish about the top.

The Bureau of Internal Revenue has by no means finished the task of putting through the mountain of checks for income and excess profits taxes it received on March 16. Current guesses are that the task will require at least another week, due to the vast amount of work involved in checking the returns against the attached drafts.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 24 -- Sir William and Lady Garthwaite gave a luncheon at the Chambord for Mrs. Frank Vance Storrs. Also in their party were Mr. and Mrs. Balthasar Odescalchi, Mrs. Daniel E. Sickles, Mrs. Louis Mendelssohn and Channing Hare.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 24 -- Reports in foreign military intelligence sources in Ankara tonight said fresh strong concentrations of parachutist-carrying bombers and more than 100 troop-carrying Junkers planes were on Crete and that 10,000 parachutists and assault troops were massed in Sicily, Southern Italy and Rhodes, indicating the long-awaited German Spring offensive was nearing the jump-off phase.

Charged with forgery in an attempt to impersonate Bing Crosby's brother, a man who gave the name of Robert E. Ray, 51 years old, of the Claridge Hotel, Broadway and Forty-fourth Street, was arrested yesterday at the office of Shapiro, Bernstein Co., music publishers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 24 -- Dorothy Comingore, who has been inactive since she appeared last year in "Citizen Kane," was named today by RKO to co-star with Richard Carlson in "The Silver Spoon," which will go before the cameras April 1.
Store leases figured largely in the reports of commercial rentals reported by brokers in Manhattan yesterday. Clothing manufacturers also were involved in a number of the contracts.

One of the great battles of the war enters its decisive phase today as Sir Stafford Cripps, special envoy from the British War Cabinet, begins his series of conferences with the partisan leaders who hold the fate of India in their hands. It is none the less a battle because it is being fought with words instead of explosives.

Developments yesterday in the investment market tended to balance in respect to influencing activity in the new-issue market in the near future. It was learned hat the Louisville Nashville Railroad will invite bids soon on an issue of $10,000,000 of equipment trust certificates.

ROME, March 24 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press in New York). -- The Italian High Command claimed today that a total of nineteen British warships and merchant vessels were sunk, damaged or at least hit in an air and naval engagement that ranged from the Gulf of Sidra off the Libyan coast into the Eastern Mediterranean.

The styles offered by the Tailored Woman at a luncheon showing in the Oval Room of the Ritz Carlton yesterday were directed toward the woman who wants to buy sensible clothes for "the duration." There was a notable lack of chi-chi.
ROME, March 24 (From Italian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command communique said today:

ALBANY, March 24 -- Strong opposition to adoption of the Young bill, establishing a Youth Court division in the Domestic Relations Court in New York City, for offenders between 16 and 19 years old, was expressed here today at a public hearing on the measure by Mayor La Guardia, by judges of criminal courts in the city, and by the district attorneys of Brooklyn, the Bronx, Richmond and Queens.

First licensing of publications will go into effect on April 1, when scientific, technical or professional publications which may contain information, the transmission of which to foreign countries may be inimical to the military interests of the United States, will be licensed prior to export.

A trap that began to take shape three weeks ago, when an official of Local 350 of the Allied Bedding and Curtain Workers Union, A.F. of L., complained to District Attorney Frank S. Hogan that two officials of "paper" locals were trying to "shake him down" for $5,000 of his local's funds under threats of jurisdictional strikes was sprung yesterday with the arrest of the pair.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Once more supplies will be sent from the United States to French Morocco. The supply agreement, arrived at some twelve months ago, has been twice suspended.
LONDON, March 24 (AP) -- A joint communique of the Air and Home Security Ministries said today:

Magistrate Alex Pisciotta, appointed to the bench on Jan. 1 and now a captain in the Army, has waived his right to the difference between his $10,000 pay as a magistrate and his Army salary, it was disclosed yesterday by William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The House began consideration today of the 1943 fiscal year supply bill for the Interior Department, carrying $162,634,845, a reduction of $75,466,435 under this year, and $17,682,421 below Bureau of the Budget estimates.
BERLIN, March 24 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The regular German High Command communique said:

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- Registration of women for war work, a measure proposed recently by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, was advocated today by members of Congress who have become apprehensive lest a shortage of skilled labor develop in munitions plants.

OTTAWA, March 24 -- Gasoline rationing goes into effect in Canada on April 7, but tourists from the United States who happen to be there then will not be stranded without gasoline, the Department of Munitions and Supply stated today.

All phases of the Inland Steel Company's operations except net profit set new records in 1941, according to the annual report issued by Edward L. Ryerson, chairman of the board, who noted substantially higher marks for production, sales, payrolls and taxes, while net profit was virtually stationary.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- A letter from President Roosevelt urging retention of the Civilian Conservation Corps and the National Youth Administration as essential to the prosecution of the war effort was put in the record of a hearing by the Senate Education and Labor Committee today by Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 24 (AP) -- County Judge Forrest Chapman signed a Probate Court order today approving a proposed compromise of more than thirteen million dollars in Federal income and estate tax claims against the John Ringling estate, for $850,000 cash.

OTTAWA, March 24 -- Extension of the age limit for compulsory military service in Canada from 24 to 30 was one of a series of regulations announced in the House of Commons by Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King today.

BERLIN (from German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press), March 24 -- A German High Command communique declared today that U-boats off the coast of North America had sunk thirteen more merchant ships, totaling 80,300 tons.

Debutantes of this season, headed by Miss Cornelia Wilmont Allen and Miss Grace Colgate Rumbough, are aiding in the plans for the Spring dance known as "Furlough Frolic" to be given Friday night at the clubhouse of the Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, under the auspices of the Young Women's Organization of the club.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Loss of the United States destroyers Pillsbury and Edsall in the vicinity of Java was announced tonight by the Navy Department.

Facilities for production of atabrine, said to be the only substitute for quinine in the treatment of malaria, are being increased 8,000 per cent above the pre-war capacity in this country, James Hill Jr., president of Sterling Products, Inc., disclosed yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders in Wilmington, Del.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 24 -- King George and Prime Minister Emmanuel Tsouderos of Greece expect to pay an official visit to the United States soon to discuss American plans regarding post-war Europe and reconstruction of ravaged Greece, Mr. Tsoudreros said Wednesday in an interview here.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The Ways and Means Committee completed hearings today on the Treasury's proposal to eliminate or reduce the depletion allowance for oil and minerals in the new tax bill.

CANBERRA, Australia, March 24 -- During the last few weeks pilots of the Australian civil airlines have repeatedly flown unarmed and relatively slow machines with evacues from and essential materials to the military areas of New Guinea, Java, Timor Island and other places, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- When the War Production Board staff executives assemble next Monday the decentralization committee, headed by Sidney J. Weinberg and J.S. Knowlson, is expected to submit the details of a plan to conduct WPB operations on a regional and industrial basis hereafter, in so far as it is possible to do so.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 24 -- "Get out of business before you lose your money" was the advice given to the small business man who is finding it increasingly difficult to operate because of priorities, by Arthur C. Weick, Division of Industry Operations, War Production Board.

Spurred by the strongest and most persistent buying movement in more than a month, the cotton market rose sharply yesterday. On the New York Cotton Exchang prices of active contracts closed at the best levels of the session, showing final net gains of 33 to 38 points, or $1.65 to $1.90 a bale.

BERLIN, March 24 (From German broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- Captain Hideo Hiraide, official spokesman of the Japanese Navy, said today that Japan seemed to be "on the defensive while the Anglo-American camp is on the offensive.

The Union Securities Corporation and Goldman, Sachs Co. received yesterday the award of $400,000 of paving and sewer bonds of Lynn, Mass., at an interest cost basis of 1.4362 per cent. The bid was 100.06 for $200,000 as 1 1/4s and $200,000 as 1 1/2%s.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- House members demanded today that "the profit be taken out of war" as new testimony was presented to the Naval Affairs Committee that increases in the incomes of some corporation executives had amounted to as much as 700 per cent last year.

Twenty patrolmen and detectives surrounded Hearns Department Store, Westchester and Third Avenues, the Bronx, for twenty-five minutes yesterday and refused to let any one in or out of the five-story building while they searched in vain for an armed thug who had held up a shoe store two blocks away and then ran into Hearns to escape his pursuers.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Curtailment in the manufacture of floor and table lamps, and other portable lamps, excepting flashlights and battery-operated lighting devices, were ordered into effect today by the War Production Board.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- President Roosevelt said today that pretty good team-work had been established between the United States, Australia and New Zealand in dealing with Southwestern Pacific war problems.

LONDON, March 24 -- The British Admiralty announced tonight that recent naval action in the Mediterranean resulted from efforts to get a convoy through with reinforcements and supplies for beleaguered Malta and that the outcome had been quite different from the version of the fighting given out yesterday in Rome, where it was said a British cruiser and a 10,000-ton merchantman had been sunk and other warships and supply ships damaged.

MANZANAR, Calif., March 24 -- A self-government set-up with block representatives and "ward leaders" to help Federal officials develop the Owens Valley reception center into a model Japanese community was worked out in blueprints displayed today as the first 1,000 evacuees from the proscribed West Coast military areas swung willingly into camp routine.

Dr. Everett R. Clinchy, president of The National Conference of Christians and Jews, last night received the annual award of Pi Lambda Phi as a "true exponent of humanitarianism and brotherhood" at the forty-seventh annual Founders Day celebration of the national collegiate fraternity at the Advertising Club, 23 Park Avenue.
The pair have at last been reconciled. Good economy and sound nutrition, which had been at odds for many months, are now working together, hand in glove in happy harmony.

In the flood of conflicting recommendations for changes in the Unemployment Insurance Law of this State which appeared last week, the tremendously significant and constructive proposals made by a majority of the State Advisory Council on Unemployment Insurance were, unfortunately, completely deluged.

Sales of defense savings bonds throughout the nation are expected to exceed $500,000,000 this month, despite diminished purchases by persons of small means because of income tax payments. This figure is based on Treasury reports and estimates of some of the leading sellers here of defense bonds.

ALBANY, March 24 -- The Senate passed today by a vote of 38 to 8 the Hammond bill amending the conservation law to permit youths of 14 years or over to take out hunting licenses and use firearms, other than pistols and revolvers, for hunting in the field. At present the age limit is 16 or over.

Survival of the free enterprise system in this country depends very largely upon the steps which private industry takes now in preparing to make jobs during the post-war period, Bert H. White, vice president of the Liberty Bank of Buffalo, asserted yesterday at the opening of the financial conference of the American Management Association at the Hotel New Yorker.
CANBERRA, Australia, March 24 -- Port Moresby, New Guinea, was raided again this morning by two waves of Japanese bombers accompanied by fighter planes. No damage has been reported.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 24 (UP) -- Prime Minister John Curtin said today that the Japanese already had seen the "handwriting on the wall." The future, he said, "holds increasing disappointment and retreat" for the enemy.

The annual report of Safeway Stores, Inc., issued by L.A. Warren, president, for publication today, reveals a consolidated net income of $5,036,060 after income and excess profits taxes, interest charges and adequate depreciation, but before preferred dividends.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 24 -- Lord Beaverbrook will remain in the United States "a very short time, not more than a few days," he told newspaper men at a press conference in Trinidad last night. He said he would return home "as soon as my duties will permit," but he did not say what his duties are.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 24 -- Two patrolmen of the New York City Police Department were indicted today on extortion charges by a Westchester County Grand Jury after a Mamaroneck resident had accused them of "framing" him on a liquor charge to get $400 hush money.

Carle C. Conway, chairman of the board of directors of Continental Can Company, said yesterday at the annual meeting at Millbrook, N.Y., that while sales to March 10 of this year were ahead of the 1941 period, this cannot be taken as a criterion of volume in the coming months, considering the limitations placed on the use of tin and tin plate by can manufacturers beginning Feb. 11, 1942.

Trading in bonds again yesterday played the dominant role in the securities markets, as the switch from equities to low-priced railroad liens assumed major proportions. Yet the stock list was not neglected, for further recovery tendencies were registered and several issues recently under severe pressure managed to recover sizeable amounts.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- Nearly 500,000 recapped tires will be made available next month for limited numbers of taxi drivers, defense workers, traveling salesmen and certain other civilians, the Office of Price Administration said today.

The Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, that hive of exhibition industry, presents another show to the public today. Last week's offering, the Henri Rousseau retrospective, seems to be doing nicely. The new attraction, scheduled to continue for an indefinite period, is installed in adjacent galleries on the second floor.

In a changing world March brings each year some things that do not change -- the first robin, the Flower Show, the Federal income tax and New York City's annual budget crisis. It is here again, and once more the city's budgetary problems are to be dealt with on an eleventh-hour, emergency, stop-gap basis.

The Rangers fought their way back into the running in the postseason play-offs for the Stanley Cup last night by blanking the Maple Leafs, 3 to 0, at Madison Square Garden. Losers in the first two games of the four-out-of-seven semi-final series, Frank Boucher's athletes flashed the hockey that had earned them the National League title in the regular campaign and registered a decisive triumph.

In twenty separate panels that bring between the covers of one book President Roosevelt, Prime Minister Winston Churchill, Secretary of Agriculture Claude Wickard, prominent historians, scientists, authors, educators and labor specialists, a forthcoming "handbook of the American war effort" will run through a full range of opinions on America's war and peace aims and how she intends to carry them out.

On Feb. 28 the Japanese radio announced that on the previous Tuesday (which would be Feb. 24) a squadron of ships of the United Nations had attacked Wake Island. The Japanese admitted the loss of one patrol boat and acknowledged that some damage had been done to land installations on the island.
NEW DELHI, India, March 25 -- Sir Stafford Cripps talked today with Maulana Abul Kalam Azad, president of the All-India Congress party, and Mohammed Ali Jinnah, leader of the Moslem League.

NEWARK, N.J., March 25 -A treasure chest of patents, including those for the manufacture of synthetic rubber and gasoline and other important chemicals, became available, royalty free, to American industry at large today through government action against the Standard Oil Company, six of its subsidiaries and the I.G. Farbenindustrie, huge German chemical trust, in Federal court here.

Ten thousand Girl Scouts will be available for "victory service" at 100 bureaus now being established at strategic points throughout the city, it was announced yesterday at headquarters of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York, 670 Lexington Avenue.

George A. Sloan, Commissioner of the City Department of Commerce, appealed yesterday to business concerns to stagger the time of arrival and departure of their employes to relieve the peak loads on transit lines during the morning and evening rush hours.

BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, March 26 -- Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's forces on the Donets front early yesterday morning began closing their lines in the middle of the semi-circular battle sector as Soviet troops slashed their way through German defenses east of Stalino and started a fierce house-to-house battle with machine guns and bayonets to take the important Ukraine steel center.

The Hon. David Bowes-Lyon, 39-year-old brother of Queen Elizabeth of Great Britain, and Henry R. Luce, publisher, were among the forty-eight passengers who arrived yesterday aboard a Pan American Airways transatlantic clipper at La Guardia Field.

ALBANY, March 25 -- The Assembly passed today the Moffat bill which changes the end of the fiscal year of the State from July 1 to April 1 in 1944 and sets the basis for permanent quarterly payment of State income taxes over which the Republicans and Governor Lehman are involved in controversy.

Fred A. Miller, 42 years old, former superintendent of claims of the Eagle-Star Insurance Company, Ltd., at 90 John Street, pleaded guilty yesterday in General Sessions to one count of a six-count indictment charging the theft of $770 from the concern, but last night, when three other former employes were arrested, the total of the thefts during the last five years was reported to be more than $183,000.

PHILADELPHIA, March 25 -- The Public Service Company of Indiana, Inc., filed today with the Securities and Exchange commission an amendment under the Holding Company Act seeking permission to sell $4,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, Series D, 3 3/8 per cent, due in 1971, to four insurance companies.

CANBERRA, Australia, March 25 -- General Douglas MacArthur will meet Prime Minister John Curtin and other political leaders of Australia tomorrow in circumstances indicating that he can have anything he asks for.

A drive to enroll 10,000 young women as volunteer nurses' aides for the duration of the war will be staged during the week of April 6-12, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Winthrop W. Aldrich, vice chairman of the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office.

LONDON, March 25 -- Burma's Chinese defenders face "a serious situation" in heavy fighting around Toungoo, according to reports received here both from the scene of the operations and from Chungking, China.

Trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, which received the home of the late George Blumenthal, financier and president of the museum, petitioned Surrogate James A. Foley yesterday for permission to retain the property for five years or until two years after a treaty of peace has been ratified by Congress or whichever period is longer.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 25 -- Considerable lowering of morale among the soldiers of the four picked German divisions in Northern Norway and an increased wave of sabotage by Norwegian patriots are reported tonight.

Robert Gaffney, 47 years old, the pseudo-detective who aided a gang of blackmailers alleged to have extorted $1,000,000 from men who were placed in compromising situations, was sentenced by Judge Jacob G. Schurman Jr. in General Sessions yesterday to two and one-half to six years in Sing Sing.

The mortgage business of banks under war conditions will be analyzed at the two-day real estate mortgage clinic of the American Bankers Association, which will open today in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. Several hundred bankers from New York State, New Jersey and Connecticut are expected to attend.

ALBANY, March 25 -- The Senate passed by unanimous vote today the Graves bill establishing a fifteen-man temporary commission to make a thorough study of the fiscal affairs of the State government with a view to the effecting of economies and the maintenance of a sound fiscal policy throughout the war.

In renewing its proposal for mandatory joint income-tax returns of married couples this year the Treasury has endeavored to meet some of the objections raised to the proposal last year. It would permit an adjustment for earned income.
BERLIN, March 25 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique said today:

Louis Kaufman devoted the larger part of his fourth local violin recital, last night in Town Hall, to four contemporary works, all of which received their first New York presentation. These novelties comprised Ernest Toch's sonata, Op. 44; Robert Russell Bennett's concerto in A major; Darius Milhaud's "Concertino de Printemps," and William Grant Still's "Studies in the Vernacular."

VICHY, France, March 25 -Measures to reduce the consumption of bread in France are announced in the rationing restricttions for April. There will be fewer numbered bread tickets and more lettered tickets, whose value is set each month by a special order.

The cargo and crew of the Swedish motorship Sicilia were blessed yesterday afternoon by the Most Rev. Athenagoras, Archbishop of the Greek Orthodox Church of North and South America, in a ceremony aboard the ship at Pier 33, East River.

CHICAGO, March 25 -- Reconciliation of business differences between the wo sons of the founder of Fairbanks, Morse Co. was revealed today when Charles H. Morse, one of the sons and former president and chairman of the board, returned to the board of directors after a two-year absence.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -Drastic steps to cancel the United States citizenship of foreign-born persons disloyal to this government, especially members of the German-American Bund, will be taken immediately, Attorney General Biddle said today.

PITTSBURGH, March 25 -- The Buhl Planetarium warned today that a large group of spots with high magnetic activity is moving over the face of the sun and that the earth may be bombarded in a few days with the heaviest electron discharge in many decades.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Attorney General Biddle was asked at his press conference today whether the recent denunciation of certain union practices by Assistant Attorney General Arnold represented the official views of the Department of Justice. He said they did not, and he added that he thought the "timing was rather unfortunate."

LONDON, March 25 -- Lord Addison read in the House of Lords today sections of a letter he had received from the colonel in command of a Scottish regiment at Singapore, on which he based a demand for a Royal Commission to inquire into Singapore's fall.

PHILADELPHIA, March 25 -Hundreds of men and women, attending a consumer-retailer victory forum today, saw many examples of how research will lessen the impact of the war upon civilian life by providing substitutes for materials needed in the military effort.

Among the new apartment rentals reported yesterday by brokers and agents was one with William S. Scott, member of the security brokerage concern of Shepard, Scott Co., who took a suite in East Village, 220 East Seventythird Street, from Bing Bing, Inc., agents, through Gilliam McVay, Inc., brokers.

The cotton market continued its upturn yesterday, gaining as much as 17 to 21 points in early trading. as mill interests sustained the steady buying pace which had lifted futures prices on Tuesday to the highest levels since the end of January.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Lord Beaverbrook, former British Minister of War Production, arrived in Washington today and went at once to the White House, where he had dinner this evening and held the first of a series of consultations with President Roosevelt on the completion of Anglo-American war machinery.

New money financing for the Republic Drill and Tool Company will be undertaken today with an offering to the public of 125,000 shares of convertible preferred stock of $1 par value. The stock will be priced at $5 a share. Craigmyle, Rogers Co. is the underwriter.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP)--The Maritime Commission awarded contracts today for the construction of fifty-six large tankers, sixty emergency cargo vessels of the Liberty ship design and a new six-way shipyard at Brunswick, Ga.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -Price increases of one-half a cent a gallon for gasoline and of fourtenths of a cent a gallon for fuel oils used in home oil burners were authorized for New York and other Eastern seaboard States today by the Office of Price Administration.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -The Navy Department communique based on reports received up to 9:30 A.M. follows:

CLEVELAND, March 25 (AP)--Kenneth R. Proctor, vice president in charge of sales, was elected tonight president of the National Refining Company, ending a proxy battle with Louis S. Peirce, vice president, secretary and general counsel, who has been serving as chief executive officer.

Paul J. Kern, former president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, declared last night that a year and a half ago Mayor La Guardia would have acted instantly on information that city employes and city material were being used to pave a courtyard on the Lake Mahopac estate of Edward J. Flynn.

If Congress accepts one of the "economies" which have been written into the legislative appropriations bill, the Library of Congress will be unable to buy a single new book during the next fiscal year. It will have just enough money to continue its existing subscriptions to periodicals.

Adding an air raid warden's armband to his familiar dark blue suit and broad-brimmed black hat, Mayor La Guardia stood at Broadway and Murray Street for twenty minutes yesterday handing out circulars that advised the public of the proper steps to take in an air raid.

The schools motion-Picture comi mittee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary an high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, l unless otherwise specified.

PATERSON, N.J., March 25 -- The Wright Aeronautical Employes Association, an independent union of workers in the five Paterson area plants of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation, made known today that it will not go along with the government's request to give up premium pay for Sundays and holidays, which are part of the regular work week.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 25 -- The German Government has promised to pay indemnity to Chile for the sinking of the Chilean merchantman Tolten if Chilean board of inquiry decides that the Reich was responsible, reliable sources reported tonight.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 25 (AP) -- Ben Hogan, who engineered a sweep of the Carolina golf tournaments two years ago, was back in the driver's seat again tonight with a 135, nine strokes under par, at the halfway mark in the fortieth North and South open.
Five residential properties in various sections of Brooklyn were reported yesterday to have been purchased by as many clients of one brokerage firm.

A seven-point program designed to protect working capital during the war and to finance vitally needed industrial initiative in the post-war period was outlined yesterday by Clarence B. Nickerson, assistant professor of accounting at Harvard School of Business Administration and former controller of the Greenfield Tap and Die Corporation, at the concluding session of the financial conference of the American Management Association at the Hotel New Yorker.

It should not be forgotten that the double-decker Fifth Avenue bus, whose approaching liquidation has just been proclaimed, is also a double-fare bus, if we take the five-cent fare as normal. Since nothing was said about fares in the Fifth Avenue Coach Company's announcement, the present ten-cent charge will presumably remain and with it the present guarantee of a seat for every passenger.

Joe Louis and Abe Simon yesterday ended their boxing workouts for their heavyweight championship bout at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night, from which the Army Emergency Relief is to benefit. Out at Fort Dix Louis went four rounds and impressed observers.

Sales and earnings of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31, 1942, were the largest on record, according to the annual report of Samuel W. Reyburn, chairman, released last night.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 25 (AP) -- The New York Barge Canal system will be opened to traffic April 6, the earliest date in nine years, in an effort to relieve heavily burdened railroads and to alleviate petroleum shortages along the Eastern seaboard.

LONDON, March 25 -- A quiet little ceremony held this afternoon in the imposing Soviet Embassy in Kensington Palace Gardens provided Russian Ambassador Ivan Maisky with an audience and an occasion for the delivery of a speech remarkable in more ways than one.
