BERNE, Switzerland, March 25 -- Having avoided to date any open military participation in Axis conflicts, but having at the same time received three important "gifts" for his "loyal" attitude, King Boris of Bulgaria is reliably reported tonight to have acceded to new German demands for action, under threat of losing the fruits of his "bloodless" conquests, and to have agreed to sever diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union.

The sale by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank of the six-story apartment house at 355 East Fiftythird Street, northwest corner of First Avenue, was announced yesterday. The property, which was reconstructed recently, is assessed at $230,000 and contains forty apartments of two, three and four rooms.

Five new buildings of cottage type to provide "country living" for the inmates of the Brooklyn Home for Children were dedicated yesterday at exercises in the unit's administration building, 67-12 112th Street, Forest Hills, Queens.
One paragraph stands out before all the others in the excellent and heartening statement made by General Douglas MacArthur at his recent newspaper conference in Australia. The general said:
The palatial town residence at 934 Fifth Avenue, formerly owned by Charles E. Mitchell, banker, has been purchased by the Vichy French Government for occupancy by the consulate general of France.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 25 -- Kirby Higbe today had the distinction of being the first Dodger pitcher to work seven innings in an exhibition game, but he didn't enjoy it much.

Declining volume of business on the New York Stock Exchange has revived discussion of the possibility that Wall Street banks might be able to do a more economical job of clearing securities than the clearing members of the Stock Exchange.

A long-standing "disagreement" between Roger William Riis, author and son of the late Jacob Riis, and John Murtagh, an assistant Federal attorney, over the theories and practices of Thurman Arnold's anti-trust division of the Department of Justice burst into the open yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 25 -- The grain markets showed a fair degree of strength in the early trading today on the Board of Trade, but the outside interest remained relatively light and, when soy beans started to decline, grains followed, with selling orders disclosing a lack of support.

NEW DELHI, India, March 25 (AP) -- The Andaman group consists of 204 jungle-covered islands, which from 1858 to 1921 were used as an Indian convict settlement and where since 1868 the British have operated a large meteorological station for shipping.

L.D.H. Weld, director of research, McCann-Erickson, Inc., states in an article in Printers' Ink, out tomorrow, that his estimate of $1,920,000,000 paid out for advertising in its various forms in 1941 is closer to the actual expenditure than any issued by him in the past because of data made available by the Harvard Study on "The Economic Effects of Advertising."
In a recent letter in your column Lyman Beecher Stowe commented on current newsreels of the war which he considered "misleading at this time" in their treatment of our war production program.

In his first report to civilians of the Northeastern States since he took command on March 7 of the First Air Force, Major Gen. Follett Bradley warned that enemy planes could slip through protective air defenses to bomb New York and other East Coast cities.
DETROIT, March 25 -- The big Chrysler tank arsenal, already seven months ahead of schedule in its output of medium tanks for the United Nations, is now tripling its productive capacity.

OTTAWA, March 25 -- Owing to the "deterioration" of the war situation, especially in the Far East, Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King today announced that his government had authorized the mobilization of two additional divisions, the Seventh and Eighth, but he said it had been decided by the military authorities of the United Nations that Canadian troops would not be sent to Australia.

The Mutual Life Insurance Company filed yesterday plans for alterations in the building containing its main offices at 28-40 Nassau Street, 18-32 Liberty Street and 45-65 Cedar Street. The plans were submitted by McKim, Mead White, architects, who estimated the cost at $150,000.

A syndicate headed by John Nuveen Co. submitted yesterday the high bids for an issue of $1,861,000 of Seattle, Wash., light and power revenue bonds, according to advices received here. No official award of the bonds was announced. The Nuveen group made two bids, offering 94.42 for the bonds as 2 1/2s, or 97.28 for 2 3/4s.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Under the Soldiers and Sailors Civil Relief Act of 1940 persons in the military service of the United States and American citizens servicing with allied military forces have legal protection against financial loss which they might incur as the result of commitments entered into prior to their induction.

MANZANAR, Calif., March 25 -- California's Owens Valley, "guinea pig" in the greatest forced migration in American history, showed evidence today of a determination to make an asset of an influx of Japanese evacuees while other communities all over the Far West were opposing such a wartime step if it involved them, military necessity or no military necessity.

Roger Hicks, a slim little youngster with tousled blond hair, stepped to the foul line with the score tied and twenty seconds left in the national invitation basketball final at Madison Square Garden last night and, as the tumultuous cheers of the season's record crowd of 18,251 rang in his ears, sank the shot that won the tournament for West Virginia.

LONDON, March 25 -- The strain on Germany's economy, now being watched so closely by the British, it was said today, must not be mistaken for a sign of weakness. Shortages and hardships, multiplying in German civilian life, were attributed to diversion of effort to the war machine.

Cotton mills would require another major expansion in machine hours worked throughout the year to meet the present "apparently limitless demand," W. Ray Bell, president of the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants, asserted in his annual survey of textile data, issued yesterday.

CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., March 25 (U.P.) -- The unranked team of Mrs. Philip Theopold and Miss Virginia Ellis, both of Brookline, scored a major upset today by defeating top-seeded Mrs. Patricia Canning Todd of Jackson Heights, N.Y., and Miss Hope Knowles of Avon, Conn., 7 -- 9, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 3, in a semi-finals doubles match of the women's national indoor tennis championships.

PHILADELPHIA, March 25 (AP) -- Counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission asked today for an immediate vote of holders of securities on an amended plan of reorganization of the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, March 25 (U.P.) -- Brazilian authorities claimed today to have smashed the center of an Axis spy ring with headquarters in Sao Paulo.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -Twenty-five of America's leading women pilots are now "on their way" from this country to England under contracts to fly for the British Air Transport Auxiliary, it was confirmed here today in official sources, although the number actually in service in England or in training in Canada was not made known.

A new department-store service providing for the reconditioning or mending of customers' wardrobe or household effects will be established today by B. Altman Co., Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street. The plan--to be known as the "save-it service"--is expected to help housewives and professional and business women reclaim possessions which might otherwise be discarded.
MOSCOW, March 25 (AP) -- The Soviet Bureau of Information-issued the following communique today:

The known underground reserves of crude oil in the United States at the beginning of this year were estimated yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute at a new record of 19,589,296,000 barrels. Based on the production of 1,404,182,000 barrels in 1941, these reserves are sufficient to last fourteen years.

The Sperry Corporation, maker of marine and aeronautical precision instruments, showed a net income for 1941 of $8,281,511 after all charges, including taxes and provision for post-war adjustments, according to the annual report of Thomas A. Morgan, president, issued yesterday.

Police Lieutenant Terence J. Harvey, attached to the Borough Headquarters Squad, West, in Brooklyn, filed an application for retirement yesterday. Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen said that he was investigating the source of $42,000 spent by Lieutenant Harvey during a seven-year period in which his salary never exceeded $4,000 a year.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The War Production Board intruded into the personal matter of whiskers today with an order sharply curtailing the manufacture or razors and razor blades.

By discontinuing production of studio couches and other types of beds requiring large amounts of steel, manufacturers hope to prevent too great a reduction in total output of sleeping units under the order just issued by the War Production Board, which limits them, starting April 1, to a percentage of the metal used in the year ended June 30, they said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -New testimony of mounting compensation paid to executives of corporations with defense contracts was given to the House Naval Committee today by Edmund Toland, its counsel. He reported that a sample survey of fifteen companies handling naval contracts had shown that the salaries and bonuses of their officials in 1941 ranged 22 to 1,331 per cent above the 1934 total.

Although five of the seven member colleges in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League will hold their commencements this year earlier than in the past, a full forty-two game schedule will be played by the circuit, according to an announcement made yesterday by Asa S. Bushnell, secretary-treasurer.

With manufacturing operations of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation system outside of the Western Hemisphere either under war restrictions or enemy control, the management of the corporation is said to be considering the construction in South America of an equipment plant to supply the growing demands of its Latin-American communications subsidiaries.
The child living under wartime tensions must not be denied recreation, Mark E. McCloskey, director of recreation of the Federal Security Agency, declared yesterday.

LONDON, March 25 -- In the interest of science, fourteen men and women, selected from 500 volunteers, appeared at a homeopathic hospital today and had mustard gas dropped upon their arms so that doctors could test the efficacy of an antidote to be taken internally.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The Treasury's proposal for mandatory joint income tax returns for husbands and wife was attacked today before the House Ways and Means Committee by witnesses for several women's organizations, principally on allegations that it was unconstitutional, that it would be a step toward returning women to the "status of chattels," and would be "an abandonment" of the American principle of equal rights.

Net sales of the Glenn L. Martin Company in 1941 were $67,237,689, more than double the $30,663,337 reported for 1940, the previous best year for the company, according to the annual report mailed yesterday to stockholders by Glenn L. Martin, president.

In a decision interpreting the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938, Supreme Court Justice Francis G. Hooley in Queens yesterday ruled that the provisions of the law included minor employes of concerns engaged in interstate commerce, although such employes might not be directly engaged in production of goods.

If private enterprise were still pursuing its unhampered way, the manufacturers of stirrup pumps, water pails, hose, shovels and flashlights would feel happy over the civilian defense bill which has been introduced by Stanley Isaacs, with Mayor La Guardia's blessing, in the City Council.

LONDON, March 25--Japan occupied the Andaman Islands in the Bay of Bengal last Monday, it was acknowledged in New Delhi today. Apparently the enemy moved in without having to fire a shot, as British troops evacuated together with a "considerable portion" of the population "some days previously."
FREEPORT, L.I., March 25 -- Sport fishing is one of the principal industries of Freeport and anything pertaining to it is certain to strike a responsive note among its citizens.

The Schola Cantorum, Hugh Ross conductor, gave a concert in memory of Kurt Schindler, founder and first conductor of the organization, last night in Carnegie Hall. The most important part of this observation lay in new compositions which American, Spanish and South American composers had based upon Spanish folk-songs contained in Schindler's posthumous collection of the "Folk Music and Poetry of Spain and Portugal," published last year by the Hispanic Society in the United States.
One of the effects of the war on professional football was revealed yesterday when the coaches' rules committee of the National Football League held its annual meeting at the Hotel Commodore.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -State and local health departments were called on today by Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator, to assume without delay their rightful "dynamic roles" in the organization and operation of the national defense health and welfare program.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The Office of Defense Transportation issued today a general order prohibiting city transit systems from substituting bus service for existing street railway lines, except upon authorization by the ODT.

KEARNY, N.J., March 25 -- The Employes Association of the Western Electric Company's huge plant here, engaged extensively in the manufacture of communications equipment for the government, was preparing today for a strike at midnight Friday unless the government intervened.

In a recorded message broadcast to New York last night as part of the celebration of Greek Independence Day, King George II of the Greek Government-in-Exile promised a free constitution and democracy, instead of the pre-war Greek dictatorship, to Greece after the Axis is defeated.

A public appeal for $32,000,000 to finance the second year of USO's campaign -- its wartime job of service to American men in uniform -- will be made from May 11 to July 4, it was announced yesterday by Prescott S. Bush, national campaign chairman of the United Service Organizations.

ALBANY, March 25 -- The Republican leadership in the Legislature presented its version of a State defense bill to Governor Lehman today on a "take it or leave it basis." They left their ideas on how State defense should be handled with the Governor and made an appointment to come back tomorrow to find out how far the Governor would go along with them.
In an editorial of March 21 on the forty-hour week you state that the costs of overtime premium rates are prohibitive because the payment for overtime "jumps unit labor costs by 50 per cent."

Boys Town, a home for underprivileged boys conducted by Mgr. Edward J. Flanagan at Boys Town, Neb., receives $50,000 in trust under the will of Miss Mary A. Dowd, filed in Surrogates' Court yesterday. Miss Dowd, who had been active in Catholic charities for years, died at Palm Beach, Fla., on Feb. 5.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, March 25 -- We feinted and bluffed, dodged in and out of smoke screens, fired our guns -- although it was sometimes like shooting peas at a barn -- took time out for tea in the midst of battle, and got our convoy safely to Malta after a naval engagement in which valor triumphed over might as it seldom does even in the most romantic of fiction.

PEORIA, Ill., March 25 -- The story of an alleged dynamite plot was presented today in Federal District Court, the chief witness being William J. Wheeler, 42 years old, an ex-convict and Army deserter, on whose testimony the Toledo, Peoria and Western Railroad hopes to win a contempt of court finding against two former strikers and a press agent for the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen.

Clarence H. Low, chairman of the New York City Salvage Committee, asked the members of the retail division of the Waste Materials Conservation Council of Greater New York at a meeting yesterday in Bloomingdale's Department Store to use their "strategically situated facilities" to aid the campaign against waste.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- General Douglas MacArthur has received the Congressional Medal of Honor, the highest award for gallantry by an American soldier. He is the first full general to win this medal.

The confiscation of a compact short-wave radio transmitting and receiving set marked a series of spot checks on the homes of enemy aliens in the vicinities of Fort Tilden and Floyd Bennett Field on Tuesday night, it was revealed yesterday.

The obituary of Victor Margueritte in THE TIMES of March 24 deals with his career as the writer of novels that became storm centers of controversy. It omits, however, reference to another field of activity in which M. Margueritte was very much interested but which unfortunately attracted less public attention.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 25 -All reports reaching here from France agree that the food problem is increasing rapidly. Moreover, the people generally now know the reason. In fact, the Franciste, a weekly that appears in both the occupied and unoccupied zones and advocates reconciliation with the victor, says bluntly:

LONDON, March 25 -- Optimism on the war outlook coupled with the response to Warships Week kept the stock markets firm today. Gilt-edge issues were steady, with old consols at 83 1/8 and others steady. Home rails continued to improve.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- "It hardly seems possible, but the United States, to reach its goal of increased food production, is running out of both farm land and farm labor," said Secretary of Agriculture Claude R. Wickard today, expressing his pleasure with yesterday's report of the Crop Reporting Board on what farmers intend to plant this year.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -President Roosevelt established by executive order seven maritime control areas on the West Coast, conferred with Lord Beaverbrook, discussed problems of military strategy with the joint Mexican-United States Defense Commission and later with his military and naval advisers.
Without benefit of sirens, nearly one-quarter of Manhattan Island was blacked out last night in a demonstration that cloaked some of the world's most famous buildings in darkness.

Household staffs of prominent New York families attended the butlers' charity ball in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Commodore last night for the benefit of the British-American Ambulance Corps, Inc.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- One of the panels of the National War Labor Board has rejected by a 3-to-2 vote the demand of affiliates of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations for a union security clause covering 25,000 employes in eight plants of the International Harvester Company.

The loss of two medium-sized merchant ships, one of United States registry and the other British, was announced by the Navy yesterday. Both vessels were torpedoed by Axis submarines in waters off our Atlantic Coast. The British ship was sent to the bottom on March 18, while the American vessel was sunk early Saturday morning.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Despite an expected record production of steel plate next month, the War Production Board stated today that demands for available plate are so heavy that next month's output will fall at least 50 per cent behind demand.

Those reported short stories of the mysterious and embattled author, Jan Valtin, become a published fact on April 13, when Alliance issues a collection of twenty-three of them as "Bend in the River." The stories included are said to have been written as long as twelve years before the publication of "Out of the Night."

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Under the slogan, "Victory Begins at Home," the Consumer Division of the Office of Price Administration has just issued a pamphlet of recipes demonstrating how sugar can be conserved through wise cooking methods.
LONDON, March 25 -- An excess of about 210,000,000 is indicated by last week's Exchequer returns. Ordinary revenue was given as 1,996,485,228.

The Jewish Telegraphic Agency made public yesterday messages it had received from President Roosevelt and other noted persons in connection with its twenty-fifth anniversary as a press agency covering news of Jewish interest in all parts of the world.

Another casualty of a bleak season is "Fun to Be Free," which is definitely not going to be produced. "Internal friction" among those who were to have whipped this topical revue into shape for the benefit of Fight for Freedom, Inc. and allied groups is blamed for the decision.

Down a winding street in an out-of-the-way corner of Los Angeles is a diminutive store that is scarcely larger than a jewel case. A white, square sign hanging over the narrow entrance invites investigation, and within there is a wonderful fragrance that permeates every nook and niche.

As the Citizens Budget Commission and the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce joined yesterday in condemning Mayor La Guardia's proposal to divert relief tax money to general city purposes, Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, disclosed that he had refused to comply with the Mayor's request that all department heads submit two budget schedules showing cuts of 10 and 12 per cent respectively.

One hundred Bronx business men serving on the fund-raising committee yesterday attended a luncheon in the Concourse Plaza Hotel, the Bronx, which started the 1942 Bronx campaign of the Greater New York Fund. The Bronx quota is $150,000.

DETROIT, March 25 -- Charles A. Lindbergh, who was one of the country's leading isolationists before the Japanese attacked Pearl Harbor, will accept a position in the new $60,000,000 Willow Run bomber plant of the Ford Motor Company if no objection is raised by the War Department, Harry H. Bennett, Ford personnel director, said tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- A reorganization plan for the Minneapolis, St. Paul Sault Ste. Marie Railway Company under which capitalization would be reduced to about $95,000,000 from $169,202,628, plus $28,459,266 of accrued and unpaid interest on fixed-interest-bearing debt, a total of $197,661,894, was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 25 -- Under one of Don Meade's typical front-running rides, Mrs. H. Teller Archibald's Twotimer today won the Viscaya Stakes, only fixture of the Tropical Park meeting for 2-year-old fillies. Paying $12.80 for $2 and stepping the half mile in 0:46 3-5, the bay daughter of Double Scotch and Candy May earned $2,145 first money by two lengths before 6,073 fans.

The purchase of nearly $90,000 worth of new machine tools, equipment classified as vital to war industries, was authorized yesterday by the Board of Education for the Machine and Metal Trades High School.

Milder weather throughout the country in the last two weeks has improved scrap-iron collections and its flow to mills, with the result that threatened shortages have been averted, according to local scrap dealers yesterday. Spring normally brings a pick-up in collections, according to dealers, and, with nation-wide attention being focussed on scrap iron, the seasonal improvement will be accentuated now.

After three sessions of advancing prices, although with only faint buying demand, the stock market slipped yesterday to a colorless performance with prices in a moderate retreat. Cheering news from the Pacific sector of the war failed to stir the market and the halt to the upturn in the second grade railway bond section, induced mainly by profit-taking, tended to chill speculative enthusiasm.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 25 -- Purchase of screen rights to the music of John Philip Sousa for $128,000, plus royalty, was announced today by Albert DeCourville, European film producer, who disclosed that he would use the works in a "cavalcade of the United States Marines" to be called "The Stars and Stripes Forever" after one of Sousa's marches.

Frederick F. Bulkeley, 74 years old, father of Lieutenant John D. Bulkeley, who commanded the tiny motor torpedo boat that stole into Binanga Bay in the Philippines in January and torpedoed a Japanese ship and who later was in command of the "mosquito boat" flotilla that took General Douglas MacArthur from Bataan, walked into Third Naval District headquarters at 90 Church Street recently and declared that he was "ready for action," it was disclosed yesterday.

In case the soldiers have nothing to do in the evening, some young actors on Broadway have assembled a remarkably pleasant bill of stage entertainment, "It's All Yours," which was acted in the Y.M.C.A auditorium on Governors Island after supper yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The House moved slowly today in considering the $162,000,000 Interior Department supply bill, but a coalition of Democrats and Republicans effected tentative small savings in some of the items.

Reporting a net profit of $343,572 for the quarter ended Jan. 28, 1942, comparing with $262,833 earned in the first calendar quarter of 1941, Gar Wood Industries, Inc., has notified stockholders that at the annual meeting on April 16 they would be asked to increase the number of directors from five to seven.

The seventh annual "Young America Paints" exhibition will open next Thursday at the American Museum of Natural History and will continue through April 19. The show will feature the work of school children from kindergarten through high school age, including those in public, private and parochial schools in the United States.

If one is inclined to snicker at a 4:07.8 mile and regard with disdain an 8:52.9 two-mile effort, then Leslie MacMitchell and Greg Rice were the only two athletes who failed in last night's super-thriller streamlined track meet at the Bronx Coliseum, where the Track Writers Association sponsored a six-event classic for the benefit of the Navy Relief Society.

A reference to the unsolved 1937 murder of Norman Redwood, leader of an earlier local of the Sandhogs Union, started a verbal battle yesterday at the trial before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook of an injunction suit brought by the Sandhogs Union, Local 147, against Joseph V. Moreschi and other officials of the parent International Hod Carriers, Building and Common Laborers Union, A.F. of L.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 24 (Delayed) -- Anti-Russian demonstrations were staged in Sofia today, according to radio reports picked up here. Usually well-informed foreign diplomatic observers opined tonight, on the basis of those reports and information filtering in from the Balkans, that King Boris of Bulgaria probably was surrendering to German pressure for Bulgaria's immediate participation in the war.

NEW ORLEANS, March 25 -- President Lawrence di Benedetto of the Amateur Athletic Union was fighting mad today when he challenged the Baltimore Army major who bracketed the A.A.U. with "Axis efforts by fifth columnists" in a dispute over the status of amateur athletes competing with or against Professionals while in military service.

HONOLULU, March 25 -- United States naval forces in the Pacific, continuing the harassing tactics begun in the Marshall and Gilbert Islands at the end of January, struck two more blows in February and March at outlying Japanese-held island bases.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -Suggestions by which Americans may take part in a "victory garden" program designed to increase the production and consumption of fresh vegetables and fruit to the end that the United States will become a stronger and healthier nation were put forward today in a joint pamphlet by the Office of Civilian Defense and the Department of Agriculture.

CANBERRA, Australia, March 25 -- Prime Minister John Curtin, in an address to the House of Representatives today, said that the United Nations' recognition of the importance of Australia in the war may be the turning point in the conflict.

CANBERRA, Australia, March 25 -- Three Japanese bombers raided Port Moresby, New Guinea, today. It was one of the smallest forces yet used in a raid, contrasting sharply with the previous two attacks. It is believed that fighters not seen high in the clouds accompanied the bombers. No damage or casualties were reported.

Despite the fact that operations of the Electric Bond and Share Company system set new high records last year, stockholders of the company were warned yesterday that preferred dividends may not be maintained at their regular rate.

A short time ago I received from one of the Community Service Society's regular contributors a letter in which he wrote that in these changed times "one naturally puts contributions to direct war relief agencies ahead of any others." He added that the agencies he wanted to support were those which adjusted their programs to new conditions.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman announced yesterday the names of twenty-two women prominent in charitable work in the Catholic Archdiocese of New York who are to receive the Pro Pontifice et Ecclesia Cross from Pope Pius XII.

LONDON, March 25 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill today announced the text of a message he had sent congratulating Rear Admiral Philip L. Vian of British destroyer Cossack fame and his officers and men for the notable naval victory achieved when they passed a convoy safely to Malta under the guns of a superior Italian force and the bombs of Italian and German planes.
LONDON, March 25 (British official wireless) -- The British Admiralty issued the following:

ALBANY, March 25 -- The Republican legislative plan for reapportionment, which was-made public yesterday, has not sufficient support for passage at the present time, according to a survey today. The party leaders will have to crack the whip to have the measure adopted, and there is no indication yet that they plan to do so.

A massing of the colors by local units of the Marine Corps League and the uniforms of marine detachments from the Brooklyn and Philadelphia Navy Yards last night lent a lively note to the opening ceremonies of "To the Shores of Tripoli" at the Roxy, a premiere otherwise somewhat subdued by wartime police regulations which allowed only two arc lamps to illuminate the facade of the theatre.

From the Joint Legislative Committee comes, perhaps without too rosy expectation, a plan for reapportionment of legislative districts. There has been no such redistribution since 1917, no reallotment of Congress districts since 1911. The committee's report on that subject is still to come.

MIAMI, Fla., March 25 -- Having had it properly demonstrated by the jayvees that the thing could be done, the Giant regulars, back in action once more, took their turn at giving the hapless Phils a bit of a belting today.

MEXICO CITY, March 25 -Mexican Foreign Minister Ezequiel Padilla is on his way to Washington, to which all roads lead nowadays, and soon the reports of the special appraisers on the oil properties expropriated from United States companies will follow.

RIOM, France, March 25 -- Before the Supreme Court here today former Premier Edouard Daladier told how he had ordered the punishment of a French general who had circulated what M. Daladier held to be a political document.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Japanese bombers today hammered simultaneously the front and rear positions of the United States and Filipino forces on Bataan Peninsula, the War Department announced here. A brief communique indicated between its few lines of meagre description that the invaders were going through the operations preliminary to a long-expected attack.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 25--The somnolent Yankees were balked at every turn today at Waterfront Park in their struggle against their American Association farm link from Kansas City until, in the eleventh inning, they were balked right into a 4-to-3 victory.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 26 -- As the United States Senate prepares to pass a bill setting up the first volunteer women's Army Auxiliary Corps in the nation's history, a survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion finds that public opinion once again is ahead of its leaders in favoring conscription of all single women between the ages of 21 and 35 for wartime jobs.

The old Rausch farm, with the original old farmhouse building, long a landmark in the Dix Hills section of Huntington, Suffolk County, has been sold after an ownership of nearly a half century to Herman Rammelt of Roosevelt, L.I.

PHILADELPHIA, March 26 -- The Public Service Electric and Gas Company of New Jersey applied today to the Securities and Exchange Commission for the right to issue and sell $15,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage bonds, 3 per cent series, due in 1972, to seven life insurance companies.
Lester Arons, executive of a textile concern, has leased an apartment of seven rooms and three baths in the building at 30 West Seventieth Street through the Apartment Renting Company, Inc., broker.

Dr. Walter Damrosch, the ninth conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra's Centennial Season, who recently celebrated his eightieth birthday, conducted last night's concert in Carnegie Hall. It was evident that the audience had singled him out for special honor.

Senator McKellar proposes to legislate out of existence both the Civilian Conservation Corps and the National Youth Administration, and the President and Federal Security Administrator McNutt oppose him. The Senator argues that the war has made these much discussed youth agencies unnecessary, and the Administration retorts that on the contrary they are contributing to the war effort to the exclusion of all other activities.

All is quiet along the food front this week-end, according to the latest bulletin received from the Consumers Service Bureau of the New York Department of Markets. Meat prices have changed little since last Friday, and for the second week in succession remain reassuringly steady.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 26 -- Malta's defending fighters accounted for nine of a formation of thirty Stukas that yesterday attempted to attack a British ship near the island base. All these machines were so badly damaged it was considered unlikely they got home.

Mrs. Jennie Schweiger, 84 years old, an inmate of the Menorah Home for the Aged and Infirm at 871 Bushwick Avenue, Brooklyn, who charged in Brooklyn Felony Court last Nov. 23 that she had given her son, Samuel, $20,276 on his representation that "Hitler was coming to Brooklyn and the United States Government would confiscate all money in the banks," testified yesterday at her son's grand larceny trial in Kings County Court.

Breaking today in Utah daily newspapers, and in weeklies today and tomorrow, is the campaign of the Utah Chain Stores Association seeking postponement for the duration of the referendum scheduled to be placed on the ballot of the general election on Nov. 3 which, it is claimed, "sentences chain stores to slow death by special taxes."

WASHINGTON, March 26--The State Department has asked the Russian Government to supply as speedily as possible a quantity of seeds of a "cousin" of the American dandelion, the roots of which yield rubber, it was disclosed today.

Mayor La Guardia's action in sending a report on former City Magistrate Alex Pisciotta to the Bar Association was criticized yesterday by Presiding Justice Francis Martin of the Appellate Division, who said his court had sole jurisdiction over any charges involving city magistrates.

A "black market" in chemical materials, in which OPA price ceilings are violated without passage of money but which involves increasingly large values, was reported flourishing yesterday. Holders of various materials achieve the evasion of price ceilings by the simple expedient of exchanging materials they have for materials they need, and the quantities involved in the barter frequently bear no relation to the ceiling prices on either material.

WHAT luck! The C.O. at Fort Dix is letting rate J.L. Barrow out to attend another public function. It's almost in line of duty, too. It's a public function from which the Army Emergency Relief treasury will derive no little influx of current coin of the realm.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 26--While 400 Japanese evacuees began clearing sagebrush today at the 5,000-acre Owens Valley reception center, preparatory to getting the once highly productive land into shape for vegetable growing, nearly 250,000 other Japanese-Americans and Japanese, German and Italian aliens awaited the effective hour, 6 A.M. tomorrow, of a curfew order.

Patrolman Michael Curry was on duty yesterday at 144th Street and the Grand Concourse, the Bronx, when he stopped Robert A. Hart, 44 years old, of 480 Concord Avenue, the Bronx, for making a turn in his automobile without giving the proper signal.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings to be at the lowest of the year to date. Holdings of United States Government securities decreased $4,750,000 during the week.

Declaring that practice blackouts of ten or twenty minutes' duration are "almost a waste of time," Colonel Walter W. Metcalf, acting regional director of the Second Civilian Defense Area, warned New Yorkers yesterday against feeling complacent about the success of the blackout of lower Manhattan Wednesday night.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 26 -- A plan for compulsory savings to check inflation, involving withdrawal of $30,000,000,000 of present national income which could not be spent until the war is over, was advocated here today by Julian Goldman of New York, chairman of the National Committee to Keep Prices Down, in an address before the Advertising Club of Indianapolis.

CANBERRA, Australia, March 26 -- Following is the text of the speech made tonight by General Douglas MacArthur, Supreme Commander of the United Nations Forces in the Southwestern Pacific, at a dinner given in his honor at the Australian Parliament House:

The American people should be told that every dollar spent today for life insurance helps to protect the country against inflation, according to Nelson A. White, advertising manager of the Provident Mutual Life Insurance Company, Philadelphia, in a paper prepared for the Eastern round table of the Life Insurance Advertisers Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 26--Organized labor's pledge that no strike, for any cause, will be called or tolerated for the duration of the war was given direct to Congress today by Philip Murray, president of the C.I.O., and by William Green, president of the A.F. of L.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 26 -- Expressing his congratulations to the Knights of Columbus on their sixtieth anniversary, which occurs March 29, President Roosevelt, in a letter to Francis P. Matthews, Supreme Knight of Omaha, said:

I am a member of a union with an honorable history of over a century. I work in a small plant completely unionized with a closed shop contract. It is not a war industry, but that is not material, since the attitude I am attacking is opposed to all trade unions.

War housing, the post-war housing problem and the need for stimulation of savings to make mortgage loans possible were the principal topics discussed yesterday at the real estate mortgage clinic of the American Bankers Association in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Play in the National Squash J Tennis Association's veterans' sinI gles championship started at the Columbia University Club yesterday, with four competitors advancing to the quarter-finals after drawing first-round byes. They were Milton Baron, City A. C.; L. 1'. Sonneborn, Yale Club; W. P. Hoffman, ]ayside, and R. B. Haines of the home club.

Prominent members of the social and musical worlds and leaders in naval affairs are among the sponsors of the concert to be given tomorrow night at the Town Hall by the duo-piano team of Jacques Fray and Mario Braggiotti for the benefit of the Navy Relief Society.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The National War Labor Board announced today that four union leaders at the Cleveland plant of the Aluminum Company of America were being discharged for "instigating a slowdown" in operations at the plant which is vital to war production.

A call for volunteers to man switchboards for the Fire Department was issued yesterday by James G. Blaine, chairman of the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office. Declaring that New York is a greater fire hazard than London from the point of view of an incendiary bomb raid, Mr. Blaine said that it is planned to have a staff of 2,300 volunteers on duty within the next month.

KEARNY, N.J., March 26 -- The Western Electric Employes Association announced this afternoon that it had called off an order to its members to strike at midnight tomorrow at the huge Western Electric plant here and five branch plants after receiving word from Washington that Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins had certified the wage dispute between the independent union and the management to the War Labor Board.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) --Representatives of companies operating transportation services on the New York Barge Canal were appointed today as members of an advisory committee on wartime transport problems.

The Third Battalion of the Seventeenth Regiment, New York Guard, took over Gramercy Park at dusk last night in a practice manoeuvre to demonstrate the alertness of the guard in defending strategic points in the city.

Many business men want to end tax-exempt securities. In war time we must all bear the tax burden according to our abilities. The great estates and institutions can no longer escape their share of the burden. It is suggested:

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Admiral Ernest J. King, Commander in Chief of the United States Fleet, today took the oath of additional office as Chief of Naval Operations and gave the pledge, "Our days of victories are in the making -- we will win this war."

NEWARK, N.J., March 26 (AP) -- Fifteen railroads filed today in Federal Court here a suit to test the legality of the Interstate Commerce Commission's orders requiring them to permit freight cars to be transported in vessels in coastwise service. Application was made for a three-judge court.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Speed in formulating the $7,610,000,000 war revenue bill was demanded today by Representative Doughton, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, as he sent the committee into a night session to keep abreast of its calendar of witnesses.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- President Roosevelt has sent a sharp letter to several high officials of the government, including the Secretaries of War and Navy, directing them to remove all barriers to the shipment of supplies to Russia.

TOKYO, Friday, March 27 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Ken Harada, former counselor in the Japanese Embassy in Paris, has been appointed special Minister to the Vatican, it was announced today by Tomokazu Hori, Information Board spokesman.

Many dinners were given last night at the special entertainment in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre sponsored by the American Field Service. A percentage of the proceeds will be donated to the American Field Service to augment its funds for supplying complete ambulance service for the British Armies in the Middle East.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The assurances to the United States by Vichy during recent negotiations are considered as complete as assurances can be, and therefore, are believed to have removed any threat of an immediate break in relations between the two governments.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 26 -- A dinner was given this evening at Villa Today by Colonel and Mrs. LeRay Berdeau. Their guests were Mr. and Mrs. Jeremiah D. Maguire, Mr. and Mrs. John Charles Thomas, Mr. and Mrs. Clarence R. Bitting, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Strout Davis, Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Davis Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Rufus W. Scott, Mrs. John Drum of Monteagle, Tenn., and George Angus Bobyne.

The City Information Center under the Park Avenue ramp in Pershing Square, which heretofore has served uninformed New Yorkers as well as out-of-town visitors seeking directions and other facts about the city, is being converted into a civilian defense information center, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- If Washington is not now the Geneva of World War No. 2, it can simply be because the espionage agents of the Axis powers are napping, according to the opinion of many persons in Washington.

The War and Navy Departments and the Postoffice are making special efforts to see that mail to and from men in the services overseas is delivered promptly. This is one of the most important factors in maintaining the morale of our forces abroad. During the First World War it was too often one of the most neglected.

CANBERRA, Australia, March 26 -- General Douglas MacArthur, Supreme Commander of the United Nations forces in the Southwestern Pacific, said to members of the Australian Parliament tonight: "We shall win or we shall die, and to this end I pledge you the full resources of all the mighty power of my country and all the blood of my coutrymen."
LONDON, March 26 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

SAN FRANCISCO, March 25 (U.P.) -- The Shell Chemical Company will start construction immediately of a large plant to manufacture butadiene, principal ingredient of synthetic rubber, J. Oostermeyer, president, said today.

While the exigencies of war make it compulsory to withdraw products from their normal markets, there is no requirement to diminish consumer familiarity with goods nor the institutions which sponsor them, Howard P. Hildreth, promotion and advertising manager of the Mohawk Carpet Mills, told the luncheon meeting yesterday of the American Marketing Association at the Hotel Commodore.

Today's events: Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P.M.; Three Choir Festival, Temple Emanu-El, 2:30 and 5:15 P.M.; Adolf Busch and his Chamber Music Players, Town Hall, 8:45; Chamber Music Guild Quartet, Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, 8:45.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- New York's first major blackout last night focused timely attention upon the country's defenses against air attack.

Taylor Holmes yesterday was announced for the lead in "What Big Ears!" taking the part first intended for Lee Tracy. At the same time a new opening date was made known -- April 20 rather than April 13. The house mentioned is the Windsor.

WESTBURY, L.I., March 26 -- George W. Burrell, chief test pilot for the Republic Aviation Corporation of Farmingdale, was killed this afternoon in a leap from an Army-type pursuit plane after parts of the tail assembly broke away during a test flight.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The War Labor Board decided unanimously today to "make a final determination" of the controverted union security issue between the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company of Kearny, N.J., and the Congress of Industrial Organizations' Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilders, which once led to Federal seizure of the yard.

LONDON, March 26 -- Two enemy columns are converging on Prome, near the western end of Burma's defense line guarding the Yenangyaung oil fields, according to today's communique from British headquarters at New Delhi, India.

As the climax of a series of testimonial events that began in Hollywood two weeks ago in celebration of his thirtieth anniversary in motion pictures, Cecil B. DeMille was honored yesterday at a luncheon attended by 500 persons, including executives of film companies and broadcasting chains.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 26 -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, French Chief of State, today met Pierre Lavai, whom he deposed as "heir apparent" some fifteen months ago. The interview occurred at Randan, twelve miles out of Vichy.
Prices on the Stock Exchanges were easier yesterday in slow trading. The volume was the fourth smallest since last June and sales of 301,360 shares compared with 316,345 on Wednesday.

Recent snowstorms which left new covers ranging from six to fifteen inches in depth in the mountains of upper New York State, Northern New England and the Laurentians of Canada have brought untold delight to Eastern skiers.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 26 -- Maxwell Howard's roguish 7-year-old The Chief today snapped out of an extended slump and jumped right back into prominence with a driving half-length triumph in the six-furlong Coral Reef Purse at Tropical Park.

They will be battle scars and wound stripes -- those extra slashes and abrasions induced by making a razor blade do 20 per cent more work. WPB has set a quota which is supposed to make a blade last a week. To the possessors of fresh young faces between the ages of 15 and 30 this may seem a generous allowance.

Councilman Walter R. Hart, chairman of the Council Defense Committee, said last night that the Isaacs bill stipulating the kind and amount of air raid equipment for every building in the city probably would be revised as a result of discussion at a public hearing on the measure in City Hall at 2 o'clock this afternoon.

Nettie Rosenstein, outstanding dress style creator, has abandoned plans to retire and will re-enter the dress business in a Seventh Avenue plant operated under union conditions, it was announced here yesterday. A new concern has been organized in which Mrs. Rosenstein will be joined by her former partners, Mrs. Eva Rosencrans and Charles Gumprecht.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP)--Wholesale commodity prices continued their upward trend during the week ended on March 21, but rose only fractionally. The Bureau of Labor Statistics' index of nearly 900 price series rose 0.1 per cent to 97.2 per cent of the 1926 level.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 26 -- Leo McCarey and RKO will pay Howard Hughes a reported $250,000 in settlement of McCarey's contract with Hughes, it was learned today. The deal will leave McCarey free to join RKO as a producer-director, and he and the studio will acquire "Hollywood Legend," a photoplay which McCarey had prepared as a Hughes production.

BOSTON, March 26 -- A sensational exhibition of goal-tending by Frank (Zero) Brimsek enabled the Boston Bruins to gain the semifinal round of the National Hockey League's play-offs with a 3-2 decision over the smoother-playing Chicago Black Hawks tonight before 12,000 at the Boston Garden.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 26 -- An announcement today by the Nassau County Defense Council that Governor Lehman had ordered an immediate and permanent dim-out of three communities along the county's south shore carried the implication that the order might be extended to include all communities from Montauk Point to Coney Island.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- During the week ended March 25 member bank reserve balances decreased $412,000,000. Reductions in member bank reserves arose from increases of $413,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks and $7,000,000 in Treasury cash, and decreases of $25,000,000 in Reserve Bank credit and $2,000,000 in gold stock, offset in part by decreases of $12,000,000 in money in circulation and $22,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith, warning that war may well bring the "need of protection on the home front," yesterday praised the work of the Salvation Army in both peacetime and war. He addressed the final report luncheon of the Civilian Mobilization for the organization, held at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway.
WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -- The Treasury revealed today, that the United Kingdom sold $542,832,000 of its American securities in the last three years to pay for war materials.

The valuable collection of art and furnishings formed by the late Mrs. Christian R. Holmes and housed in her Fifth Avenue apartment and in her country home at Sands Point, L.I., will be sold at auction, it was learned yesterday.

The Western Electric Company made plans for expanding its war production in New Jersey by leasing the Big Bear property on the Hudson Boulevard in Jersey City from the Hudson County National Bank and the Gates Realty Company.

John D. Rockefeller Jr., honorary chairman of the United Service Organizations war fund campaign for $32,000,000, in an address yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the national women's committee, called the USO, in effect, "a civilian arm of the American Government" and a representative body through which the American people can support our fighting forces.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- With 785 jobs to fill and no applicants in sight, the Civil Service Commission sent out a nation-wide call today for 1,000 stenographers to fill present and prospective vacancies in government offices in Washington.

Arthur J. Taylor, a newspaper reporter better known as Major Taylor or simply "The Major," was guest of honor last night at a testimonial dinner in the Hotel New Yorker. Judges, lawyers, reporters and court clerks who had earned his friendship in the thirty-five years he "covered" the Federal courts here attended.

DETROIT, March 26 -- Officers of the Army Air Corps who have the greatest direct stake in stepping up the production of war planes think the rate at which automobile factories are swinging over to aircraft manufacture is "very, very encouraging."

Insurance underwriters and buyers are still completely in the dark as to how the government's new War Damage Corporation will function, it was indicated at a luncheon meeting yesterday of the Risk Research Institute at the Hotel Astor.

CHICAGO, March 26 -- The boxboard industry was warned today by William W. Fitzhugh of the War Production Board that a steadily increasing volume of war demands must inevitably curtail the supplies available for civilian users.

Public utility holding companies have been under considerable criticism in recent years for their practices in the late Twenties, particularly in situations where parent concerns paid excessive prices for stocks of operating companies that they were seeking to control.

Net sales of the National Steel Corporation and subsidiaries last year amounted to $200,575,863, the highest in company annals, comparing with a previous high mark of $157,900,000 in 1940, it was announced yesterday. The company's war production is stressed in the pamphlet report, signed by Ernest T. Weir, chairman.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 26 -- Today's preview of the National League opening at the Polo Grounds wouldn't have made any Flatbush fan happy. On the contrary, he probably would have been calling the players "dem bums" -- and really meaning it.

LONDON, March 26 -- How much freedom of the press is to be retained is becoming an important issue in this country, which until now has striven so valiantly to maintain it in fact as well as in theory, despite the stress of total war.

In this newspaper yesterday was the story written by a TIMES reporter of the American attack on Wake and Marcus Islands. Impressions seized on the wing and set down before memory could blur them make a continuous vivid picture, stroke added to stroke as the ship goes on.

A chief effect upon the American apparel industry of the Canadian restriction of manufacturers' styles by one-third will be a reduction in the number of samples and patterns purchased here, it was indicated yesterday. Many Canadian retailers and garment manufacturers in past years have purchased American sample garments for production in the Dominion.
A.V.G. HEADQUARTERS, in Central Burma, March 24 (Delayed) (AP) -- To the amazing record of the American Volunteer Group in Burma add these exploits:

The punch that Pat di Cicco, husband of the former Gloria Vanderbilt, threw at Peter Joyce, hotel room clerk, on St. Patrick's Day turned out yesterday to be only a push, so Magistrate Samuel Orr in Yorkville Court dismissed a summons charging Mr. di Cicco with simple assault.

Early April is lilac time along the avenues of Manhattan, with the muted purple bloom splashing softly over silken gowns in shop windows and lending its faint fragrance to sparkling new perfumes. Spring is in the air and everybody is buying lilacs for Easter.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Newsprint prices, which have remained unaltered since April 1, 1938, will continue at $50 a ton for the next sixty days at least, under a temporary price regulation issued today by Acting Federal Price Administrator John E. Hamm.

New York's first all-woman jury yesterday in General Sessions heard the prosecution's case against two Negroes accused of holding up two soldiers early Feb. 2 at Seventh Avenue and 127th Street. Judge John A. Mullen then adjourned the trial until today, when defense lawyers are to submit evidence.

DETROIT, Mich., March 26 -- Unless shippers and carriers cooperate voluntarily to increase the use of freight cars, the Federal Transportation Commission and the Interstate Commerce Commission may take arbitrary action to force them to do so, W.H. Day of Boston said here today at a meeting of the Great Lakes Advisory Boards.
RIOM, France, March 26 -- The Paris press continued to suggest today that the Riom unpreparedness trial will either be abandoned after Easter or that the public sittings will be discontinued.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Anti-aircraft gunners among the Philippine defenders today knocked down four heavy Japanese bombers while the Japanese pursued with growing vigor their new offensive action against the United States and Filipino forces on Bataan Peninsula and in the forts that still hold the entrance to Manila Harbor.

Frederick Loewe, pianist-composer, gave his first New York recital last night in Carnegie Chamber Music Hall. Mr. Loewe, who came to this country fifteen years ago from Vienna and is now an American citizen, wrote the music for "Great Lady," which was staged on Broadway in 1938.

Despite price rises in wholesale household furniture, averaging from 20 to 30 per cent for the last twelve months, the industry's sales at present are running well below those of a year ago, with dollar volume of new orders during the first two months of 1942 exceeding last year's comparable period by only 3 per cent, Seidman Seidman, certified public accountants, announced yesterday.

Just back from Burma, where she drove an ambulance on the curving Burma Road and for seven nights was under Japanese fire in Rangoon, Mrs. Gordon Seagrave, a Baptist missionary, spent most of yesterday here shopping for Easter finery.

Under the conditions of large and urgent government spending the opportunity for excessive corporation profits always exists. Sometimes temporary excessive profits cannot be avoided because of the difficulties of estimating costs in an untried field. Taxation can always recover such excessive profits.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Charged with conspiracy to violate the Sherman Anti-Trust Act, the National Association of Retail Druggists, the New Jersey Pharmaceutical Association, thirteen local and county pharmaceutical associations in New Jersey and fifteen of their officers and agents were indicted by a Federal grand jury in Newark today.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- In 1941, for the first time since the Treasury started publishing the figures in 1936, there was a net outflow of capital from the United States to foreign countries. It amounted, according to a Treasury bulletin today, to $496,923,000.

Delay in providing suitable free port zone facilities as a substitute for those in the original Staten Island area which have now been taken over by the Army amounts to "virtual suspension" of the Free Trade Zones Act, and is causing considerable economic hardship and inconvenience, importers asserted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended March 21 were 26 per cent above the corresponding week a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. Sales for the four weeks ended March 21 were up 24 per cent and for the year thus far 27 per cent above the corresponding period of last year.
CHICAGO, March 26 -- The pattern of radio appeals to the people for war effort is to be altered under arrangements worked out by the radio industry and the Office of Facts and Figures in Washington.

Two new film attractions will be presented in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Strand, Warner's screen version of the Elliott Nugent-James Thurber stage comedy, "The Male Animal," will be the new offering. Henry Fonda, Olivia de Havilland, Joan Leslie and Jack Carson play the leading roles in the picture, which was directed by Mr. Nugent.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 26 (U.P.) -- "We were directly abreast of two Japanese cruisers, steaming in the same direction," the commander of a rusty American destroyer said today, talking of the battle of the Java Sea.
BERLIN, March 26 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique today said:
DETROIT, March 26 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings moved into the Stanley Cup semi-finals tonight by routing the Montreal Canadiens, 6 to 2, in the third and deciding game of their series before 10,005.

Even the blind are anxious to give every aid in the war and are now participating as far as their limited capacities permit, Judge Henry W. Goddard, chairman of the board of directors of the New York Association for the Blind, told the organization's annual meeting yesterday at the Lighthouse, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street.

Captain William J. Pedrick, Collector of Internal Revenue, Second District, paid a surprise visit to Ellis Island yesterday afternoon accompanied by four members of his staff, Joseph Pirozzi, chief of the alien division; Raymond F. Ryan, assistant collector; Joseph V. Burns, chief field deputy, and Edward F. Dingivan, chief of the income tax.

Richard C. Patterson Jr., State chairman of the Defense Savings Staff and chairman of the board of the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation, will be entertained at a testimonial dinner May 18 in the Hotel Astor by the New York Young Democratic Club in recognition of his work in the defense bond campaign, it was announced yesterday by Robert Daru, chairman of the club's dinner committee.

Six students in the second-year class of the Columbia University Law School have been elected to the editorial staff of The Columbia Law Review, Dean Young B. Smith announced yesterday. The award of ten James Kent Scholarships, highest honors given to Law School students, also was announced.

With an eye on the metropolite's Spring yearning for a week-end in the country, Franklin Simon included a large collection of rural costumes in its Easter fashion show held yesterday during luncheon at the Hotel Plaza.

William Holzman, City College basketball star, has been named winner of the Walter Williamson Trophy of the Class of 1916 as the "athlete who has reflected the most glory on the City College during the past year by virtue of his athletic achievements," Tony Orlando, acting athletic director, announced yesterday.

Financing in the amount of $18,401,000 was announced yesterday by Cleveland, Ohio, of which part was effected by the award of an issue of $901,000 of sewage-disposal bonds to a banking group headed by the Northern Trust Company of Chicago on a bid of 101.919 for 2 1/4s.

Bank clearings at twenty-three leading cities of the country for the week ended on Wednesday were $6,952,637,000, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. This represents a decline of 12.3 per cent from the $7,929,733,000 for the previous week, but a gain of 8.8 per cent over the $6,392,781,000 a year ago.
The twenty-sixth annual exhibition of the Brooklyn Society of Artists opened with a private view yesterday at the Brooklyn Museum. It opens to the public today and will continue through April 19.

LONDON, March 26 -- The stock markets were quieter today; most sections held the gains made earlier this week. Gilt-edge issues were firmer but home rails eased fractionally. Chinese bonds in the foreign market improved.

Stockholders of the Wickwire Spencer Steel Company at the annual meeting here yesterday accused the management of seeking to perpetuate its control of the company through its voting trusteeship for the common stock. They attacked particularly the company's rejection of an offer of the Republic Steel Corporation to purchase certain assets of Wickwire without permitting the stockholders to express their views.

The city hopes to provide 1,000 always available hospital beds in the center of the city for possible air raid victims "before many weeks," Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday just before he administered the oath of office to Dr. Edward M. Bernecker as Commissioner of Hospitals.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- In view of the anti-trust division of the Department of Justice, the German-American industrial cartels are not only responsible for shortages in essential war materials because of their stipulated sales territory and patent restrictions; they are part of a deliberate German economic war plan.

UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, in Australia, March 26 -- More than fifty United States correspondents and photographers have converged at this headquarters. Some have come direct from the United States, others from Hawaii, the Philippines, Java and Africa.

Support should be given to the bill pending before Congress which will permit those native-born American citizens who lack birth certificates to prove their nationality. There must be hundreds of thousands of such unfortunates.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 26 -- The Japanese have limited their advance up the Markham Valley in Northeast New Guinea -- which had been regarded here as a possible attempt to strike overland at Port Moresby, Papua -- to the flat country as far as Mabzab, twenty-seven miles from Lae, according to reports reaching here today.

Attorney General Biddle describes the "timing" of Assistant Attorney General Arnold's recent statement on trade union practices as "rather unfortunate." But what of the "timing" of these practices themselves? Testifying before a House committee, Mr. Arnold said:

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey refused to reveal to the United States Navy and the British Government its processes for making synthetic rubber but turned over the process to Germany and Italy through the I.G. Farbenindustrie of Germany, before the United States' entry in the war. Thurman Arnold, assistant attorney general, told the Truman committee today.

LONDON, Friday, March 27 -- A heavy attack by hundreds of British bombers on Germany's industrial Ruhr area over Wednesday night and a strong offensive by Royal Air Force bomber and fighter planes over the coast of France throughout yesterday were reported by the Air Ministry.
NEW DELHI, India March 26 (AP) -- The British General Headquarters Burma communique said today:

What appeared as a final showdown between Mayor La Guardia and the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association on the rising number of retirement applications by policemen developed yesterday when it was revealed that the Association had submitted a questionnaire to 17,500 members asking them whether they favored the Mayor's recent request for a stagger system of retirement.

Trading in cotton futures was more two-sided yesterday as mill orders appeared in smaller blocks than in preceding sessions and offerings came into the ring more freely. Prices of active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced as much as 20 to 27 points in early trading, but by the close these had been pared to final net gains of 8 to 12 points.

Ganson Purcell, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and Clarence J. Reese, president of the Continental Motors Corporation, were the principal speakers last night at the sixteenth anniversary dinner of the New York Security Dealers Association in the Waldorf-Astoria.

There has been considerable demand for wool yarns with cotton cores, indicating that manufacturers plan men's clothing fabrics of this type in substantial volume for later in the year, according to the weekly report issued yesterday by the Wool Associates of the New York Cotton Exchange.

CHICAGO, March 26 -- Corn led other grains to higher prices on the Board of Trade today. Professional traders were active in buying corn, both outright and in the way of spreading with wheat, and while there was considerable profit taking on the upturn, the close showed gains of 5/8 to 3/4 cent.
The decision by New Jersey to widen its Governor's Fishing Tournament this season to include fresh water angling is another indication of how the Eastern States are appraising their outdoor programs.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 26 -- Mayor Stanley W. Church of this city, chairman of a Westchester County committee seeking to lift Federal restrictions on home construction, returned from Washington today and said he had scant hope of getting priorities on building materials for Westchester construction and for the $1,400,000 New Rochelle slum-clearance project.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -- Clarence B. Kelland, new executive assistant of the Republican National Committee, said today that the American people were "resentful and humiliated at being kicked around in this war" and felt that "some one is to blame."

The United Nations have to win this war if the world is not "to come to an end," Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, said yesterday in an interview at his home, 116th Street and Morningside Drive. The war may last several years or, in the event of economic collapse, only a little while, he declared.
NEW DELHI, India, March 26 -- Sir Stafford Cripps announced today that he expected to see Mohandas K. Gandhi tomorrow, as well as a number of other Indian leaders.

The Acme Air Appliance Company, Inc., which is forced to vacate its present quarters on Park Avenue, Brooklyn, because that thoroughfare is being widened, has leased the entire one-story structure on the northwest corner of Glenmore Avenue and Hinsdale Street, in the same borough, through the Harry M. Lewis Company, Inc., broker, and the Chauncey Real Estate Company, Ltd., agent for the Belday Corporation, the landlord.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, March 26 -- The smashing of a huge spy ring with the arrest of more than 100 Axis subjects, including a colonel in the German Army and a Japanese admiral disguised as a farmer, was announced tonight by Police Chief Filinto Mueller.

After less than a week in Washington discussing the Australian position in the war, Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, Australian Minister for External Affairs, told the press here yesterday that "we have advanced toward unity and control of command more rapidly than in the last war."
Mr. and Mrs. Louis Jacques Balsan, who were at the Waldorf-Astoria after their return from Casa Alva, their villa in Lantana, Fla., have gone to their country home in East Norwich, L.I.

Net sales of $80,549,180 reported by the American Viscose Corporation in its 1941 annual statement, to be made public today, were the largest in the corporation's history and exceeded those of the previous year 28 per cent.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 26 -- In his second game of the year Bill Dickey started hitting today and forthwith swung right into his old custom of winning ball games for the Yankees.

EASTON, Pa., March 26 -- Thirty-one men were killed outright at 9:18 A.M. today by the premature explosion of twenty-one tons of gelatinite at the Sandt's Eddy plant of the Lehigh Portland Cement Company quarry just west of the Delaware River about seven miles north of Easton.

The first performance of "Saints Alive," the forty-ninth annual Columbia Varsity Show, was given last night by the Columbia University Players before a capacity audience in the Grand Ball Room of the Hotel Astor. The performance will be repeated tonight at the Astor, tomorrow night at Scarsdale High School for Westchester patrons, and on April 10 in Cranford, N.J.

PEORIA, Ill., March 26 -- Three men, accused of conspiracy to dynamite a bridge of the Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad during its recent strike, in defiance of a Federal court order against violence, were found guilty of contempt today.

In the first two weeks of soliciting, contributions amounting to $45,160 were obtained by the special gifts committee of the 1942 Catholic Charities Appeal, it was announced yesterday by Chairman John A. Coleman at a report meeting of team captains in the Empire State Club.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Leo Crowley, Alien Property Custodian, said today that he would investigate, in conjunction with the Justice Department and the Public Health Service, the Winthrop Chemical Company's monopoly of German patents for the production of the only synthetic substitute for quinine -- atabrine.

Due almost entirely to a sharp increase in Treasury deposits with the Federal Reserve Banks, excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System fell $310,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $2,850,000,000, lowest level since Sept. 21, 1938.

Writing in the tenth issue of "New Writing," the paper-covered Penquin book that is issued periodically in England to set forth the work of young and unknown writers, John Lehmann, editor, remarks on a "deepening confusion about the proper spheres of prose and poetry."

Training courses set up on the advice of the New York State Committee on Child Care, Development and Protection have produced 1,000 volunteer trainees, Dr. Ruth Andrus, committee chairman, revealed yesterday.

MOSCOW, March 26 (U.P.) -- Russian planes, swarming up to defend Murmansk against an attack by sixty-eight German planes, were reported tonight to have destroyed or damaged thirteen raiders in a great battle over the Arctic port of entry for supplies from the United States and Great Britain.

Despite war conditions, New York hotel guests have indicated they will continue to travel this year, especially on business, members of the Hotel Association of New York City, Inc., were told last night at a meeting held in the Hotel Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- President Roosevelt issued an Executive Order authorizing the War and Navy Departments and the Maritime Commission to guarantee loans to government contractors and subcontractors to provide capital for arms production.

Andrew H. G. Evans, acting chief clerk of the Police Department, familiarly known to his colleagues as Andy, yesterday filed his application for retirement with the Board of Estimate. Mr. Evans leaves on his vacation on April 1 and his request is scheduled for consideration on the board's April calendar.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- A plan to decentralize War Production Board operations by establishing thirteen regional offices through the country has been approved by WPB and was reported tonight by J.S. Knowlson, industry operations director of the agency.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- President Roosevelt issued an executive order today under which the Army, Navy and United States Maritime Commission may make or guarantee loans to provide working capital for armament contractors or subcontractors.
Full-floor rentals featured the business leasing reports yesterday, with the midtown area drawing a good share of the activity.

Administering the first defeat suffered by Dr. Harry Kline, erstwhile University of Pennsylvania star, Matthew Green yesterday strengthened his hold on first place in Section A of the United States Chess Federation's preliminaries at the Marshall Chess Club.

LONDON, March 26 (AP) -- The Bank of England's statement, issued today, showed an increase in note circulation of 844,000, the fourth consecutive rise. Private deposits increased more than 22,000,000 and government securities rose more than 19,000,000.

Daffodils, iris and tulips continue to arrive in abundant shipments in metropolitan flower markets this week-end. Thirty thousand dozen daffodils are arriving daily from Southern areas. The bulk of the North Carolina crop already has come in, and shipments from the Gloucester County area in Virginia are beginning to arrive in quantity.

LONDON, March 26 -- The Battle of the Atlantic, on which Great Britain's life depends, has turned again in favor of the Axis, Prime Minister Winston Churchill confessed today in a speech delivered at the annual meeting of the Central Council of the National Union of Conservative and Unionist Associations in Caxton Hall.

An estate estimated at $1,250,000 will go to the Ohio County birthplace of a former Brooklyn banker and Park Commissioner instead of to the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences and the Orphan Asylum Society of Brooklyn, under a ruling made yesterday by Kings County Surrogate Francis D. McGarey.

National Football League teams will play their regular eleven-game schedules next Fall, it was decided yesterday as the annual meeting of the circuit opened at the Hotel Commodore. The club-owners toyed momentarily with the proposal to have a nine-game round robin list but speedily vetoed it.

The fundamental question in the controversy over the forty-hour week in war industries is simply whether plants can afford to pay time and one-half for overtime, Miss Louise McGuire, chief investigator in the wages and hours division of the Department of Labor, declared yesterday.
The measure to compel husbands and wives to file joint income tax returns is again being urged upon Congress by the Treasury Department.

The Fordham Athletic Association announced yesterday that the Rams would play a war relief charity football game against an eleven from the Naval Air Corps Training Station at the University of North Carolina. Fordham is the first university in the East to book such a contest.
Joe Louis will face huge Abe Simon in a fifteen-round bout at Madison Square Garden tonight, risking his heavyweight championship of the world for the benefit of the Army Emergency Relief.

Moses Dyckman, the jeweler, has purchased from the Bank for Savings for cash above a ten-year purchase money mortgage of $33,000 the five-story building at 28 West Forty-seventh Street, in a deal arranged by Nathan Miller, broker.

Gerald Shattuck, president of the Frank G. Shattuck Company, operator of the Schrafft's stores and restaurants, said at the annual meeting of stockholders here yesterday that sales thus far in 1942 were running 12 per cent ahead of last year, while net profits for the first quarter would be about the same as a year ago if taxes were not raised too sharply by Congress this year.

A sentence of sixty years' to life imprisonment was imposed in General Sessions yesterday on Stanley Schleifer, 24 years old, an ex-convict, on his guilty plea to second-degree murder in the hammer slaying of Frank Clayton Cole, 62, a patent attorney, in a robbery in a washroom in the Chrysler Building on Jan. 2.

When we black out Coney Island, Staten Island, part of Manhattan Island, Westchester County, the State of Connecticut, or, as may ultimately be the case, the entire Atlantic Coast, we have to reverse our values. We have to make a kind of photographic negative in which black areas are a good thing and white areas a bad thing.

A fist fight that started over a slight argument, according to the police, caused the death yesterday of one participant, who fell from the crowded Pacific Street station platform in front of an incoming subway train, and the arrest of the other on a charge of homicide.
