PINEHURST, N.C., March 26 (AP)--Playing the course where he won his first tournament two years ago, Belting Ben Hogan today took the North and South open golf championship with a record score of 271, 17 strokes better than par.

"NAPOLEON'S INVASION OF RUSSIA -- 1812,"* by a Bolshevik professor of history named Eugene Tarle, was quite obviously written in expectation of the Nazi attack of June 22, 1941. The hero of the story is the Russian common man, who, despite the shackles of Czardom and the land-owning classes, harried Napoleon's mixed-bag army of French, Germans, Austrians, Illyrians and Italians out of the wintry country between Moscow and the river Niemen.

BEGENFIELD, N.J., March 26 -- Ten soldiers were hurt tonight, one fatally and another critically, when an automobile ploughed into the rear of their column as they were marching eight abreast in little-used Liberty Road, apparently in a drill in preparation for a review tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Czechoslovakia and Mexico resumed diplomatic relations today. The move was a direct consequence of the adoption, at the suggestion of Ezequiel Padilla, the Mexican Foreign Minister, of a resolution of sympathy for conquered nations at the conference of American Foreign Ministers in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, last January.

How a small, unarmed American freighter rammed and presumably sank a German submarine in the Caribbean last month was belatedly revealed yesterday as the Navy announced the loss of two more American ships -- a small Coast Guard cutter sent to the bottom by shellfire from a submarine and a medium-sized United States merchant ship torpedoed off the Atlantic Coast with the loss of twenty lives.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 26 -- While King Boris of Bulgaria was returning by train to his capital this evening, Bulgarian Deputies, who have clamorously opposed any participation by Bulgaria in the war, were being informed by their Speaker that, on orders of the King, Parliament would be adjourned from Saturday to Oct. 28 for ordinary sessions.

The battle for India is so far a political battle, but it proceeds in the atmosphere and tempo of the lightning war. The Japanese are at the gates, apparently pushing doggedly up the rivers and roads of Burma to the mountainous country ruled by the princes of the Shan States.

Officials of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey would not comment yesterday on the testimony of Thurman Arnold before the Senate Committee investigating the rubber shortage because they are expecting to be called to testify before the committee.
During the past few weeks have been reading articles about a runner, named Gilbert Dodds.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Dismissal by the American Bosch Corporation of twenty-three employes who are American citizens with German names was announced today by the corporation at Springfield, Mass., and the Treasury, which assumed supervision of the concern under its foreign fund control powers.

Mayor La Guardia was urged yesterday to retain sufficient funds in the Park Department budget for next year to provide adequate maintenance staffs in the parks and to guarantee the safety of all persons using the parks.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- The promotion of Brig. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, of Abilene, Kansas, to major general was sent to the Senate today by President Roosevelt. He is chief of operations, United States Army. An infantryman, General Eisenhower won a distinguished service medal for his training and organization of tank troops in the first World War.

Bankers were warned at the concluding session of the mortgage clinic of the American Bankers Association in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday that war and the heavy burden of taxation are bringing about a redistribution of wealth.

The charge made by Thurman Arnold, Assistant Attorney General, before a Senate Committee to the effect that Standard Oil Company of New Jersey had hindered and delayed the production of synthetic rubber in this country was declared yesterday by W.S. Farish, president of the company, to be "wholly without foundation."

MEXICO CITY, March 27 -- It is learned from official sources that the United States has agreed to send to Germany in the ship exchanging diplomats such Germans as Mexico may find personal non grata and may turn over to the United States -- in addition to the German diplomatic staff, which has already been sent to the United States from Mexico.

Charges of "unfair labor practices" against the New Republic, filed with the National Labor Relations Board by the Book and Magazine Union, Local 18, were amplified by the local in a release received yesterday by newspapers.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Sales from tea stocks of the country, enough in all to last for six months, were placed under restrictions today by the Division of Industry Operations of the War Production Board.

FORT MILLS, Corregidor Island, March 26 (Delayed) (UP) -- The Japanese will be driven from the Philippines by the forces of the United Nations and the freedom of the Philippine people will be restored, Commonwealth President Manuel Quezon promised in a message to the Philippine people read today over the Philippine-American radio station, "The Voice of Freedom."

DETROIT, March 27 -- The efficiency which enabled the automobile industry to make millions of passenger cars at prices that millions could afford to pay will save American tax payers huge sums in the manufacture of arms to defeat the Axis, Ernest C. Kanzler, chief of the automotive branch of the War Production Board, stated today.

LONDON, March 27 -- Developments in the Far East had a restraining influence on the stock markets today, but they closed steady with the announcement that London's 125,000,000 quota for Warships Week had been reached.

Year after year, when February comes to an end we tell ourselves hopefully, "Another month and Spring will really be here. Flowers and birds and bees and everything." And year after year ]oarch comes to an end and Spring is here, by the calendar, and only the first few of the birds and almost none of the flowers we were dreaming of are' on hand.

The Pacific Gas and Electric Company is planning further substantial additions to its facilities for power production to meet growing demands of war industries and military establishments throughout its territory, James B. Black, president, announced yesterday in his 1941 annual report to stockholders.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on March 21 were 261,724,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines, Department of the Interior. This represented decrease of 339,000 barrels in the week, comprising decreases of 17,000 and 322,000 barrels in domestic and foreign stocks, respectively.

FALL RIVER, Mass., March 27 (AP) -- Despite a plea of the War Labor Board that they go back to their jobs and not "dishonor their clear duty to their own agreement" not to strike, members of the American Federation of Textile Operatives voted today not to return to work.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 27 -- Chile deferred the imposition of gasoline rationing today upon receipt of assurances from the United States that this country would continue receiving enough for its needs.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 27 -- The Japanese can easily mobilize an army of 30,000 Japanese in Sao Paulo, it was asserted today, by Division General Manoel Rabello, former commander of the Fifth Military region in the State of Parana.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 27 (AP) -- The German Army has been ordered to hold six main points on the Russian front at all costs while Nazi transportation experts effect the difficult movement of new supplies for a Spring offensive now reported timed for the third week in April, advices from both German and neutral areas indicated tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, March 27 -- The Vinco Corporation of Detroit, manufacturer of hardened and ground tools and gauges, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering a proposed offering of 104,000 shares of $1 par common stock.

The cotton market extended yesterday its gains for the fourth consecutive session and reached levels $3.40 to $3.80 above the final quotations on Monday. Active profit-taking and realizing offered resistance on the bulges, however, and closing prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net increases of 9 to 13 points.

Mayor La Guardia issued a prepared statement yesterday in which he said he took full responsibility for sending a report on the activities of Captain Alex Pisciotta, former head of the Bureau of Weights and Measures in the Markets Department, to the Bar Association.

The Federal and State calls for banks' quarterly statements of condition are expected to be made next week. Call dates for the first quarter of the year, however, cannot be predicted accurately, as there has been considerable variation in recent years.

Aided by favorable weather conditions and the rising tide of pre-Easter apparel purchases, retail trade continued very active here this week. Department store executives estimated yesterday that volume was running at better than 25 per cent ahead of a year ago, and indicated the final figure for the week would be greatly affected by heavy volume, today.

Social agencies depending upon discarded materials for their existence are among the casualties of the world conflict, a survey of representative city groups has revealed. Along Second and Third Avenues, where thrift shops abound; in the offices of the Salvation Army, Catholic, Protestant and Jewish institutions, the same story is unfolded every day.
ST. PAUL, March 27 (AP) -- Governor Harold E. Stassen has joined the Naval Reserve and plans to resign as Governor to enter active service at the end of the next legislative session, in April, 1943.

PHILADELPHIA, March 27 (AP) Walter D. Fuller, president, reported today to stockholders of the Curtis Publishing Company that circulation of its four magazines in 1941 reached a new high average net paid total of 9,777,714 copies.

Leasing of the warehouse property of the American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation at 536 Ferry Street, Newark, N.J., to the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company for storage purposes in connection with the production of war materials was reported yesterday by David T. Houston Company, Inc., broker.

RIOM, France, March 27 -- The ill-fated Nivelle offensive of 1917, interrupted on Ministerial orders, was invoked before the Supreme Court here today when ex-Premier Edouard Daladier was explaining why he had no authority to intervene in the conduct of military operations.

WASHINGTON, March 27 Specific maximum price levels for wool products from the "pulled" stage through to worsted yarns, were set today in one of the most comprehensive price orders yet issued by the Office of Price Administration.

Governor Lehman announced last night at a review of the Twelfth Regiment, New York Guard, that plans were being developed for "intensive camp and field training" for the 17,000 officers and men of the Guard this Summer.

The seventh annual Three Choir Festival, under the auspices of Congregation Emanu-El and the musical direction of Lazare Saminsky, opened yesterday afternoon at Temple Emanu-El with two successive sessions, both of which attracted large and appreciative gatherings.

The last vestiges of what was to have been a new Eastern railroad system were liquidated at a loss of $40,953,995 by the Chesapeake Ohio Railway in 1941, the company disclosed in its annual report issued yesterday.

Adolph Busch seems to have been one of the few musicians to have realized that the sure way to fill a modern concert hall is to play the six Brandenburg Concertos of J.S. Bach, see that the music is worthily presented and leave the rest to the public. It is only curious that this did not become a seasonal practice years ago.

A physician and a woman lawyer, both previously convicted of abortion, each were sentenced yesterday in General Sessions to serve two terms of one to four years in State prison, the sentences to run concurrently. District Attorney Frank S. Hogan had described their business as "an assembly-line abortion mill."

MINEOLA, L.I., March 27 -- The Nassau County Defense Council today added Island Park, near Long Beach, to the list of three communities specifically mentioned yesterday as those which would have to dim-out immediately for the duration of the war.

Net sales and net earnings of the Yellow Truck and Coach Manufacturing Company set new records in 1941, according to the annual report of Irving B. Babcock, president, mailed last night to stockholders.

NYACK, N.Y., March 27 -- Rockland County was blacked out for thirty minutes tonight in the first county test of the regulations of the air raid precaution forces. It, was a successful blackout, civilian defense and State police observers said, as far as artificial illumination was concerned, but an enemy bomber crew would not have been bothered much by the blanket of darkness spread over buildings and highways.
CAIRO, March 27 (AP) -- A British Headquarters communique said today:

JERSEY CITY, N.J., March 27 -- Eight per cent of the sixty employes in the office of the Hudson County Register's office have been drawing salaries without working for periods ranging from one to seven years, James F. Murray, newly appointed anti-Hague Register, charging today in a letter to County Supervisor John F. O'Neill.

LONDON, March 27 -- The story of an escape from Norway -- incomplete because it is necessary to protect some of those who took part -- was told here today by Carl Wright, a business maw and a member of the Norwegian Parliament, who felt free to tell his experience under the auspices of the exiled Norwegian Government because he has no family for which to be fearful.

The War Production Board yesterday permitted the unrestricted sales of all electrical refrigerators in the hands of dealers, a step that brought joy to some retailers but did not help distributors, whose stocks remain frozen.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- An emergency program for the relief of the industrial fuel oil situation in the Eastern States, which have suffered most from the shortages created by the sinking of tankers carrying oil from the South, was made public today by Secretary Ickes.

The crowned and the uncrowned kings of the metropolitan basketball domain, City College and Long Island University, will clash at Madison Square Garden tonight in the interests of charity. The Army Emergency Relief will benefit from this feature of a post-season double-header.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Organization of a corps of Army ground force troops which will specialize in desert warfare and a new command to expand the training of paratroops and begin the training of glider-borne ground forces were reported today by the War Department.

A longshoreman, crying in anguish as he tried to reach his 18month-old daughter, was balked by a wall of flame on the second floor rear of a five-story brick tenement at 787 Washington Street yesterday morning and the baby burned to death in her crib.

The General Sessions trial of twelve men charged with extorting $157,000 from independent retail milk dealers in this and other States since 1935 was featured yesterday by a heated exchange between one of the defense lawyers and Judge James G. Wallace.

New bond financing this week was restricted for the third consecutive period to the tax-exempt field, where three loans were offered to the public in the aggregate amount of only $2,472,000. This compares with $9,827,000 in new issues marketed last week, and with a total of $55,908,000 offered in this week last year.

Opposition in its present form to the Johnson-Mitchell bill proposing the regulation of electric submetering under the supervision of the Public Service Commission was expressed yesterday in a statement by Arthur C. Bang, chairman of the public utilities committee of the Real Estate Board of New York.
Robert R. Diefendorf, a limited partner, and Beverley M. Eyre are to be admitted to Delafield Delafield on April 1.

NEW DELHI, India, March 27 -- Sir Stafford Cripps spent two hours and ten minutes today talking with Mohandas K. Gandhi, who emerged from the interview with the announcement that he was taking one of his periodical vows of contemplative silence.

LONDON, March 27 -- Russian troops, striking out by sea and air, have dealt a smashing blow at the rear of the German lines in the Murmansk sector, thwarting a German drive on that port of entry for United States and British war supplies, Stockholm dispatches reported tonight.

WOODBRIDGE, N.J., March 27 -- A nurse, trying to save from death a man who apparently was bent on taking his life, wrestled on a railroad trestle with him today as a train bore down on them. He resisted her efforts to drag him from the track and was killed. She got off the tracks just in time.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The Ways and Means Committee heard Treasury proposals to tax the income of existing and future State and local securities described today as "a subtle attempt" to extend the boundaries of Federal power under the pretext of obtaining war revenues.

GREENSBORO, N.C., March 27 (AP) -- Rod Munday, tall, quiet pro from Toledo, Ohio, who believes seriously that putting should not count in golf, turned around and putted left-handed today, and rapped out a record-tying 66 to lead the first round of the $5,500 Greensboro open.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 27 -- The Budapest correspondent of the Stockholm Aftonbladet asserts that the Hungarian Minister at Bucharest has been instructed to obtain further explanations from Premier Ion Antonescu.

A loft building in the textile area of downtown Manhattan, the eleven-story structure at 377-79 Broadway, on the southwest corner of White Street, has been sold by the Westchester County Savings Bank to an investing client of Richard S. Horowitz, attorney.

LONDON, March 27 -- Coincident with an Admiralty announcement that three motor gunboats had engaged and left sinking a German-armed trawler in the North Sea today, an outline was given of how the Battle of the Atlantic had worsened from Britain's viewpoint.

CHICAGO, March 27 -- The grain markets were strong in the early trading today, but as soon as the buying let up they turned reactionary under the weight of professional selling, and the finish on the Board of Trade was near the bottom.

After a long delay, Joe Louis held "open house" in his dressing room after he had stopped Abe Simon in the sixth round of their return meeting at Madison Square Garden last night. When reporters finally were admitted, they witnessed a familiar sight: the champion seated comfortably on a table, nonchalantly eating a red apple.
CANBERRA, Australia, March 27 (AP) -- Prime Minister John Curtin issued this communique today:

BERNE, Switzerland March 27 -- In view of comment aroused in Allied circles by the appointment of a Japanese Minister to the Holy See, it was remarked at the Vatican, according to information received here today, that there were 18,000,000 Catholics in the territories of the Orient at present within Japan's political sphere, including 11,000,000 in he Philippines.

The third upward revision of ceiling prices on wool came as no surprise to the trade yesterday. Wool circles had been expecting it for some time and the board of managers of the New York Wool Exchange, anticipating an announcement of the adjustment, voted at a meeting before the opening of trading yesterday to prohibit transactions at the new ceiling limit of $1.40 a pound for wool top futures until today.

TO glance into history after reading Constance Robertson's "Salute to the Hero"* is a little like opening Who's Who and finding the name of Uriah Heep, complete with business address, clubs and hobbies. A question that this novel poses might get the experts on Information, Please! It is: What politician became nationally known by killing his wife's paramour, and later succeeded in winning some renown as the "brains" on the field of Gettysburg?

TEANECK, N.J., March 27 -- Charles Mordaunt, 35-year-old automobile sales executive of Englewood, who is being held without bail in the Bergan County jail on charges of automobile manslaughter and driving while intoxicated in connection with the death of one soldier and the injury of fifteen others last night, was fined $50 for speeding two weeks ago, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The Japanese will certainly "get hurt" if they attempt a repetition of their disastrous raid of Dec. 7 on Hawaii by carrier-based planes, John J. McCloy, Assistant Secretary of War, told reporters today.

CANBERRA, Australia, March 27 (U.P.) -- General Blamey said today that he was looking forward to fighting alongside United States forces, as he had in World War 1, and he added: "We are going to give the Japs a bloody stiff run."

Denouncing provisions of the Isaacs bill, which requires air raid protection in every building in the city, as fantastic and far beyond the actual needs of public safety, members of the Democratic majority in the City Council said yesterday that the bill would be trimmed down to the minimum requirements for safety.

Life insurance advertisers were urged yesterday by H.W. Roden, president of Harold H. Clapp, Inc., Jersey City, to put their huge resources behind the work of the Advertising Council, which is the advertising field's liaison body with the government, and behind the various war programs of the Federal Government.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The first sedition prosecutions of the war period were ordered by Attorney General Biddle today against George W. Christians of Chattanooga, leader of the "Crusader White Shirts," and Rudolph Fahl, former physical instructor in a Denver high school.

The Army cast a virtual challenge to the National Football League at the second session of the circuit's annual convention at the Hotel Commodore yesterday when Army Emergency Relief representatives informed the magnates that the Army would have an All-America team of its own, willing to play any or all the professional elevens.

"It's About Time," a satirical revue, will begin a tryout run this evening at the Barbizon-Plaza Theatre. In the cast are Helen Tamiris, Dorothy Bird, Laura Duncan, Jane Hoffman, Linda Lee, Melissa Mason and many others. The sketches, lyrics and music are by Peter Barry, Sam D. Locke, Arnold Horwitt, Reuben Ship, David Greggory, Will Lorin and Al Moss.

Twenty-five of ninety-five applicants were elected to membership at the annual Spring meeting of the National Association of Women Artists. These include, from New York, Winifred Boegehold, Rosetta Bohnert, Nancy Ranson, Dorothy Mason, Dorothy Deyrup, Lisbeth Lofgren, Mildred Shire Mermin, Gertrude Mills, Edwina Lonstorf Phelps, Anne Cole Phillips, Joyce Rosenberg and Kate Sanford, painters, and Sylvia Wald and Helena Simkhovitch, sculptors.

MIAMI, Fla., March 27 -- As the Giants trooped wearily back to their training base this evening, they had only one game to show for their efforts in making a two-day trip up Florida's east coast. But that one game sufficed to put the entire cast, from Manager Melvin Ott down the line, in excellent spirits.

The abandonment by leading colleges of minor and even major sports because of the war does not make sense to me. It certainly does not jibe with the announced intention of the various service branches to encourage athletics in every way to promote physical fitness.

Gene McCann, who once answered to the title of "boy wonder of Wall Street," and who has been fighting his own court battles for years, won a strange victory yesterday, and it seems to mean that he will not have to spend the next six years in prison.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 27 -- Some of the white operators taking over Japanese leases on California farm land are plowing up the crops, according to reports to the Farm Security Administration.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The White House revealed today that President Roosevelt had invoked his constitutional authority as Commander in Chief in an effort to get the War and Navy Departments to carry out previous instructions issued by the President to bring shipments of military materiel to Soviet Russia up to the schedule promised in the Moscow Protocol.

CANBERRA, Australia, March 27 -- A Japanese bomber was brought down in flames by defending fighters over Port Moresby during the twentieth raid on that town in New Guinea today, it was officially announced here. Neither damage nor casualties were reported as a result of the raid.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The War Department communique, based on reports received up to 10 A.M. follows:

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The Navy today assumed sole command of anti-submarine activities off the East and West Coasts of the United States under an agreement with the Army giving "commanders of the sea frontiers" authority over Army air-patrol units.

UNITED STATES ARMY HEADQUARTERS, in Australia, March 27 -- The United Nations armies in Australia have been reinforced powerfully by the return of Australian expeditionary forces, it was announced today.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 27 -- There is anxiety in Italy concerning the currency and the constantly rising cost of living. It was reflected in a speech by Premier Mussolini yesterday afternoon in Rome to managers of popular banks throughout the country.

TRENTON, March 27 -- The scarcity of beauty operators in New Jersey has caused the State Board of Beauty Culture Control to relax rules and regulations to permit qualified women to enter the beauty industry.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- An appropriation bill carrying $18,302,021,148 in cash and contractual authority to house, pay, transport and feed an army of 3,600,000 men, and procure 31, more airplanes, was reported to the House today by the Appropriations Committee.
WELLESLEY, Mass., March 27 (AP) -- Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt told a Wellesley College forum tonight that propaganda along racial lines "must not be tolerated."

Freight moved on the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad in March was up 25 to 30 per cent from March, 1941, George B. Elliott, president, said in Washington yesterday. Military needs caused some of the increase. Mr. Elliott expressed the hope that locomotives ordered by the company would be delivered on time.

One of the peculiar ironies of the forty-hour week is that it did not begin until our so-called all-out production program got under way. The Wage Hour Act became law on June 25, 1938. Its hour provisions did not go into effect until 120 days after its passage. For the first year of their effectiveness they set up a basic working week of forty-four hours.

Attorney General John J. Bennett petitioned Supreme Court Justice Benedict Dineen yesterday to strike out substantial parts of an answer to his injunctive proceedings against the News Dealers Federal Labor Union, A.F. of L., because the statements were "sham, scandalous, irrelevant, impertinent and frivolous."
Former Governor Alfred E. Smith used Tammany Hall's decline in power yesterday to illustrate what he felt to be an important point in civilian defense.

NEW DELHI, India, March 27 -- The Chinese holding the eastern sector of the Allied lines in Burma have disposed of the Japanese force that captured the Toungoo airdrome. With the heartening help of newly arrived reinforcements they are now battling the invaders on three sides of the city, a Chinese communique announced tonight.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 27 -- Attorneys for Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, announced today that thirty-three of the defendants in a $2,000,000 suit involving the collapse of the Westchester Title and Trust Company of this city have agreed to settle for $170,000 the $200,000 claims against them.

Mothers of small boys are digging through closets, searching for the baseball mitts that were regretfully discarded after the first frost. Intent groups of little girls cluster on park sidewalks, absorbed in the intricacies of putting jacks "into the basket" and sending them "around the world."

NEWARK, N.J., March 27 -Double time for Sunday and holiday work was voluntarily surrendered here today for the duration of the war in favor of timeand-a-half by the 700 members of two locals of the Iron Moulders, Core Makers and Foundry Workers Union, -. F. of L. Leaders of the union said that the rest of its 110,-{ 000 members in this country and Canada would be asked to do likewise.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department issued today an amendment to a Federal order regulating the marketing of milk in the metropolitan New York marketing area which will have the effect of reducing the producer prices of Class One fluid milk about 26 cents a hundred pounds, effective April 1, for April, May and June.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- To prevent unnecessary hardship on dependents of men classed as 3-A by Selective Service Boards who desire to become officers in the Army under the new six-month training plan, a method has been devised to eliminate those who do not possess the required qualifications, the War Department said today.

Final negotiations are in progress for leasing two Columbia University buildings to the Navy for housing students in training for commissions under the V-7 plan, it became known yesterday. It is expected that the contract, to extend for the duration of the war, will be signed next week, Thomas A. McGoey, director of residence halls at Columbia, said.

Colonel Dragutin Savich, chief of a Yugoslav military mission that has just arrived in this country to seek lease-lend aid, announced yesterday that General Draja Mikhailovitch, the Yugoslav guerrilla leader, is getting ready to start his own Spring offensive against the with 100,000 patriots ready to die for freedom.

CHICAGO, March 27 - Indictments voted by a Federal grand jury in Newark, N.J., charging the National Association of Retail Druggists and other retail pharmaceutical groups with violation of the Anti-Trust Laws will be fought in the Supreme Court if necessary, John W. Dargavel, executive secretary and general manager of the National Association, said here today.
LONG BEACH, Calif., March 27 (AP) -- The Pirates today beat the White Sox, 4 to 1, for their fourth straight victory and eleven out of their last twelve games.

The New York Unemployment Insurance State Advisory Council is an official body containing representatives of workers, employers and the public, whose special function is to study the operation of the State Unemployment Insurance Act and make recommendations for its improvement.
I am glad to see that the metropolitan college athletic officials have approved the plan submitted by their baseball coaches to have a formal Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference.

LONDON, March 27 -- Royal Air Force bombers, numbering hundreds on the offensive, pounded industrial objectives in the Ruhr area of Germany last night for the second night in succession and also struck at the Nazis in the Netherlands, Belgium and France.

This is the 350th anniversary of the birth of Jan Amos Komensky. It is in its Latinized form, Comenius, that his name is best known to us. Comenius was the most renowned and distinguished Czech of his century and a lifelong fighter against intolerance, oppression and injustice.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The National Association of Manufacturers urged Congress today to "freeze" open and closed union shop conditions for the duration of the war, and to recapture excessive profits from industry by high taxation rather than by attempting to block them by setting a rigid and all-inclusive statutory limitation on earnings.
NEW DELHI, India, March 27 (AP) -- Reliable sources disclosed today that the British plan for Indian self-government might result in two Indian dominions.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Consumers are losing "the battle against inflation" in spite of "the good fight" to keep prices down being made by retailers, said Dexter Keezer, Assistant Administrator of the Office of Price Administration in charge of the Consumer Division, at a luncheon meeting today of the National Conference of Business Paper Editors.

The last issue of The Florida Catholic, a religious weekly published in St. Augustine, oldest Episcopal See in the United States, contains a blistering denunciation of the "disloyal activities" of "that un-American paper misnamed Social Justice." The Florida Catholic does not mince words in expressing its opinion of this widely circulated sheet.

The four-story residence at 33 Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by the City Bank Farmers Trust Company to Dr. Charles McQuade Bastable, who will use it for his offices and home. The house is on a plot 20 by 100 feet and is assessed for $18,000. The Charles Partridge Real Estate Company, Inc., arranged the sale. Thomas P. Mackey represented the purchaser.

LONDON, March 27 (AP) -- A ragged army of "Free Burmese" drawn from the teeming slums of Rangoon and the hill jungles of the north has joined the Japanese Army in its fight northward against British and Chinese forces in Burma.

Young women accountants who possess ability and "a sense of responsibility" are finding increasingly greater employment opportunities in their chosen field as a result of the progressive shortage of men accountants caused by the draft, according to Dr. Herman Feldman, dean of the City College School of Business and Civic Administration.
LONDON, March 27 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

Political and financial representatives of Vichy France suffered two legal setbacks yesterday in decisions of the Appellate Division overruling pleas by the French Government itself and by the Bank of France. Both decisions were unanimous.

Palm Sunday will be observed tomorrow. Many churches here will commemorate the day, as will be done at the request of King George in the British Commonwealth. The King has asked his people "wherever possible to unite in giving thanks to Almighty God for past blessings and in humble prayer for strength and guidance in facing the tasks that lie ahead."
The United States appears to have begun the application of economic pressure on Argentina by refusing to permit shipment of supplies to her from this country, exporters asserted yesterday.

The candidacy of Representative Michael J. Kennedy for the leadership of Tammany Hall to succeed Christopher D. Sullivan received considerable impetus last night at a dinner given by Generoso Pope, newspaper publisher, at the Hotel Biltmore.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 27 -- Heralded as the greatest array of swimmers in Yale's glamorous tank history, the Eli aquatic squad launched its anticipated march to the National Collegiate Athletic Association team crown in fine style today in the Harvard pool by bagging places in the fixture's first six finals for 38 points.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- President Roosevelt had no appointments.

GEN. MacARTHUR'S HEADQUARTERS, Australia, March 27 (UP) -- President Manuel Quezon of the Philippines has reached Australia with his War Cabinet to conduct his government again at the side of General Douglas MacArthur, the general's headquarters announced today.

Concerned over the plight of undernourished school children in unoccupied France, the children's committee of the Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies, 451 Madison Avenue, opened yesterday a widespread appeal for gifts of $3, sufficient to feed one child for one month.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 27 -- The all-out battle for control of the skies over Malta continued yesterday with British fighters and antiaircraft defense shooting down thirteen Nazi planes to none for the defenders.

VICHY, France, March 27 (AP) -- Pierre Laval discussed his proposed return to power in a collaborationist government with the Vice Premier, Admiral Francois Darlan, today. M. Laval was reported to have talked for two hours with Admiral Darlan at Chateldon, M. Laval's estate near here.
Msilaerrus is nothing alarmingly or taxingly new. It is just Surrealism spelled backward. One can try anything once in an effort to squeeze yet a drop of novelty from a desiccated sponge.

LONDON, March 27 -- With one day to go, London has passed its target figure of 125,000,000 in the Warship Week savings campaign. With 18,216,850 coming in today, the grand total now is 130,079,485, and Sir Robert Kindersley, president of the National Savings Committee, urged Londoners in a broadcast to try to reach 150,000,000.

"Canal Zone," which opens at the Globe Theatre this morning, completes the week's roster of new film arrivals. The Columbia action drama features Chester Morris, Harriet Hilliard and John Hubbard. Among the supporting players are Larry Parks, Forrest Tucker, Eddie Laughton and Lloyd Bridges.

Three main arguments have been advanced against the Treasury's proposal for taxing the income from outstanding and future issues of State and municipal securities: That the plan is impractical; that it is unconstitutional, and that, so far as outstanding issues are concerned, it is a flagrant breach of faith.

Reporting yesterday to stockholders on operations in the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31, Philip Le Boutillier, president, of Best Co., Inc., stated that the year's net sales of $17,787,990 were the largest in the history of the company and represented an increase of $1,403,870 or 8.57 per cent over the transactions of the previous year.

The recent edict of Mayor La Guardia substituting attendants for internes on city ambulances produced a minor complication yesterday, when an attendant left the scene of a gas suicide, convinced the man was beyond aid but legally without authority to pronounce him dead.

A seven-room suite high up in the sixteen-story apartment house at 29 Washington Square West, overlooking Washington Square Park and the quiet old residential section around it, has been taken by President and Mrs. Roosevelt for their New York City residence.

The fifty-fourth annual report of the Ohio Oil Company and subsidiaries, announced yesterday to stockholders by O. D. Donnell, president, disclosed for 1941 a consolidated net income of $10,799,736, after all deductions, representing an increase of $2,066,572 over the previous year.
The quarterly list Of 100 books recommended for members of the Roman Catholic Church by the Cardinal Hayes Literature Committee was released yesterday.

The status of the teaching profession should be strengthened and the future of candidates in this field protected under war conditions, educational leaders declared yesterday at the seventeenth annual Spring conference in the Hotel Commodore of the Eastern States Association of Professional Schools for Teachers.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 27 -- Manager Lippy Leo Durocher of the Dodgers had planned to unveil his recent hold-out hurler, John Whitlow Wyatt, against the Cards today, but the game was postponed.
You speak of the Russian Spring mud that immobilizes armies. If you knew this mud as I know it, you would not have to speculate on what the Hitler strategy will be.

VICHY, France March 27 -- Paris had another air raid alarm late last night, for the second night in succession, and according to reports here, bombs were dropped in some suburbs. No casualties were reported.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 27 -- Mickey Rooney and Hedy Lamarr will be co-starred by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in "Her Highness and the Bellboy," a photoplay which Gladys Lehman and Richard Connell are writing for production by Joseph Pasternack, the studio announced today.
MINEOLA, L.I., March 27 -- The Nassau County Home Bureau Center held a preview tonight of a model blackout shelter, the first of at least six to be opened soon in private homes throughout the county.

ALBANY, March 27 -- Governor Lehman signed today the Wright bill permitting insurance companies writing personal liability insurance to include in their policies an obligation to pay medical, hospital, surgical and funeral benefits to persons injured or killed "irrespective of legal liability of the insured."

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The Senate, by a vote of 52 to 30, upheld today the right of Senator William Langer, Republican, of North Dakota, to retain the seat he has held since his election in 1940. It rejected a finding of the Privileges and Elections Committee, voting 13 to 3, that Senator Langer had been guilty of moral turpitude as a State official and as a lawyer and was not entitled to a seat.

Directors of Bloomingdale Brothers, Inc., authorized yesterday a dividend of 20 cents a share, payable on April 25 to holders of the common stock. In April, last year, a similar amount was distributed.

Tonight in Lost Battalion Hall, Elmburst, will be commemorated the three hundredth anniversary of the birth of Newtown, venerable mother of an ungrateful child that has swallowed her. On march 28, 1642, Governor Keift of New Netherlands made a grant of land near Newtown Creek to an English clergyman, the Rev. Francis Doughty, and his associates.

The World Fellowship of Faiths will hold "a prayer service" throughout tomorrow at the Church of the Truth, 11 West Forty-second Street, in line with the program designated by King George VI for the British Commonwealth of Nations. Leaders of several religions will participate.

LONDON, Saturday, March 28 -- The Daily Herald reported today that the government was considering a plan to abolish the hereditary House of Lords and replace it with a "brain trust" chamber chosen on a representative basis.

Prices on the Stock Exchange continued to decline yesterday. Led by the high-priced issues, the list sank to the lowest level of the week. Almost general selling developed in the preferred stocks. Volume remained small with sales 313,440 shares against 301,360 on Thursday.

In his recent letter to THE TIMES Abraham Epstein called attention to the program recommended by the majority of the New York State Unemployment Insurance Advisory Council. Among other changes in the Unemployment Insurance Law the report recommends the introduction of dependents' allowances and of employes' contributions.

WITH GENERAL WAINWRIGHT'S ARMY IN THE PHILIPPINES, March 26 (Delayed) (UP) -- Two days and one night of intensive Japanese bombing raids on Corregidor left the venerable fortress virtually unscathed today and enabled its crack-shot gunners to shoot down at least ten enemy planes in sixty hours.
Although new restrictions will apply, fishing will be permitted in the lakes and reservoirs of the New York City watershed this season, according to an announcement made yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 27 -- A substantial public sentiment exists throughout the country for a large increase in the basic wage paid to men in the fighting forces. Instead of the present starting pay of $21 a month for Army privates, the public would set the figure closer to $40 a month.

I read your editorial "Stirrup Pumps, Etc." with interest. The conditions to which you call attention that would result from the passage of the bill to force owners to make provision of equipment against the air raid hazard, just introduced by me in the City Council, of course are quite likely to follow.
Joe Louis improved his time against Abe Simon last night exactly as he improved his time against every opponent he has been called on to face a second time.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Butcher shops and retail meat markets were urged today not to raise prices of ham, bacon, pork chops and other pork cuts above mid-March prices, and at the same time consumers were asked to report to the Office of Price Administration any marked increases for these products in their local stores.

Detroit, Mich., with an offering of $16,758,000 of noncallable refunding bonds, heads a list of thirty-nine municipalities which will seek to market next week $26,577,675 of new securities. The total compares with $12,736,100 this week and with a weekly average of $23,032,989 in new offerings for the year to date.

CHICAGO, March 27 -- Automobile finance companies are watching closely the actual working out of this week's Presidential Executive order permitting the guarantee of loans needed by small firms for participation in war production. The order permits the Army, Navy or Maritime Commission to enter into contracts with the RFC, any Federal Reserve Bank, "or any other financing institution" protecting them against loss of principal or interest on commitments for financing war output.

They sparred for several seconds before Simon pawed a left to the face. Louis missed a left for the head and was short with a right for the chin. Simon retreated as Joe stalked him. They traded light lefts to head. Simon was short with a left and Louis drove a left and a right to the jaw.

The Chamber Music Guild Quartet, composed of Elly Bontempo, piano; Bernard Ocko, violin; Ely Lifschey, viola, and Lucien L. Kirsch, 'cello, gave a concert last night at Carnegie Chamber Music Hall. The program consisted of the Beethoven string trio in C minor, Op. 9, No. 3; the Duo for violin and 'cello, and the Second sonata for 'cello and piano by Bohuslav Martinu, and Joseph Jongen's quartet, Op. 23.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 27 -- While Marcel Deat, a leading collaborationist was speaking in the Municipal Theatre at Tours last night a man in the gallery threw what is described by Germans as a bomb, by the French as a "lighted petard," or firecracker.

CLEVELAND, March 27 (AP) -- The Chesapeake Ohio Railway today formally disclosed a slate of directors whose election would return Robert R. Young, chairman of the Alleghany Corporation, to control of the road. The disclosure was made in a proxy statement sent to stockholders for the railway's annual meeting on April 21.
