A New York firm which in the past has concentrated on the erection of large apartment houses and hotels in various parts of the country has turned from this field of activity to the construction of housing for defense workers and government employes.

AFELLOW has to look fast now to keep up with what's going on in all directions. Indoor track just went out. Big league baseball is coming along. The Stanley Cup survivors still have some heavy checks to hand out in hockey. Spring football practice is afoot on many college fields. The professional football gents are still talking over their little problems.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 27 (AP) -- Our Boots, winner of $115,182 in two years of racing, came to life at Tropical Park today to score a three-length victory -- his first in nine months -- in the $1,200 Semi-hole.

On one page is the man who refused an offer of $80,000,000 for Coral Gables, of which he was the founder, and subsequently lost his whole fortune. On the next page a public utility estate once estimated at $54,000,000 shrinks to one-tenth before Federal inheritance taxes and to less than 1 per cent of the original amount in the final accounting.

In answering the demands of the War Production Board that retailers reduce prices on officers' and cadets' uniforms, New York store executives denied yesterday that their prices were unfair. Most of them insisted that their margin on officers' uniforms was smaller than on their men's regular clothing and that departments handling the uniforms were not being operated at unreasonable profits.

Greater protection is urgently needed for tankers and their crews, the Rev. P.B. Clayton, chaplain of the British tanker fleet, said yesterday at a luncheon given in his honor at the Chase National Bank by Winthrop W. Aldrich, president of the British War Relief Society of America.
BERLIN, March 27 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique said today:

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- The House Appropriations Committee approved today War Department plans for the expansion of air training facilities at West Point, descirbed by the academy commandant as "one of the most forward-looking things that has been done at West Point for a hundred years."

LONDON, March 27 -- Reports from Burma indicated tonight that the main Japanese pressure was still being exerted up the Toungoo road. The situation there was described as serious, with some Chinese forces still trapped.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 27 -- The clinical report on Hank Borowy, Yankee rookie right-hander, was highly satisfactory today. The ailing yearling was under observation for seven innings in the laboratory at Waterfront Park, where his old team-mates, the Newark Bears, were in attendance at the experiment, and the youth came through the ordeal with flying colors.

NEWARK, N.J., March 27 -- A serum, designed to provide simultaneous immunization against diphtheria and whooping cough, will be given to pre-school children in this city starting Monday, it was announced today by Public Affaris Director John A. Brady.

Determination of what should be a store's inventory under present conditions, and whether it is necessary and profitable to carry and finance larger inventories will be among the eight major problems to receive attention at a one-day regional conference, scheduled to be held by the bureau of smaller stores of the National Retail Dry Goods Association on April 9 at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

When a publisher is also an author (and one with a new book coming) he is apparently able to think in terms of both pursuits. Barry Benefield, for instance, author of "Valiant Is the Word for Carrie," is also an editor on leave from Reynal Hitchcock.

Harry Baker in Section A, Irving Chernev in Section B and Louis Levy in Section C, were the leaders in the United States Chess Federation championship preliminaries as a result of play at the Marshall and Manhattan Chess Clubs last night.

LONDON, March 27 (UP) -- Flying Officer Arthur Gerald Donahue of the Royal Air Force, a native of Minnesota, will receive the Distinguished Flying Cross for action against the Japanese in the Singapore area, where he was credited with bringing down several enemy planes, the Air Ministry announced tonight.

CHUNGKING, China, March 27 -- For many years Japanese military agents, mostly members of the "young officers' clique," disguised as mendicant Moslems, have traveled all over China, Mongolia, Malaya, the Philippines, the Netherlands Indies and India gathering surprisingly accurate information of military value, as evidenced in subsequent reports.

MEXICO CITY, March 27 -- Military circles said tonight that the lease-lend agreement signed in Washington today concerned supplying Mexico with 200 military airplanes, "many" anti-aircraft guns, motor trucks for use in the newly organized mobile defense system on the Pacific Coast and thirty locomotives.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The War Department announced today that Japanese bombers made seven attacks on Corregidor in the past twenty-four hours, following up aerial attacks on that Philippine island fortress on Thursday "almost continuously from early morning until midnight."

Some time today the ore carrier J.H. Sheadle, under Captain R.H. Hayward, is scheduled to tie up at her pier in Cleveland with the earliest cargo of iron ore moved down the Great Lakes in more than half a century. Yesterday she was on Lake Huron, freed at last of ice which had held her at midweek in the Straits of Mackinac.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 28 -- Mrs. Sherman R. Hoyt of Stamford, Conn., tonight made the award of best in show at the twenty-third annual exhibition of the Kennel Club of Atlantic City, naming the famous whippet, Champion Flornell Glamorous, owned by the Mardormere Kennels of Mrs. George A. Anderson of Glen Head, L.I., and handled by Percy Roberts.

Learning ought to be fun; parents should prepare a child to enjoy school, to which he should go "as to a festival," according to the great educator, Jan Comenius. Celebration of the 350th anniversary of Comenius's birth last week at Teachers College, Columbia University, reminds us that acceptance of new ideas takes a long time.

The democratic countries have found that army recruits drawn from civil life are not only untrained, but without long and hard preparation they are physically unable to withstand the strain of continuous combat.

"EVEN after this war is over, will the world ever be the same?" This is a question we often hear nowadays, and it is asked with legitimate anxiety. Many of us, in the Age of Happiness, used bitterly to criticize our civilization. Now that this civilization is in danger we are beginning to realize how excellent it was, with all its faults and shortcomings.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 28 -- Dartmouth, Williams, Amherst and Bowdoin will share the large Peterson collection of Chinese paintings from the Ch'ing period, recently given to Princeton University by William Bingham 2d of New York City, according to a plan announced today by Professor Frank J. Mather Jr., director of the Princeton Museum of Historic Art.
MACON, Ga., March 28 -- Mercer University began an educational experiment unique in its 109 years of history with the opening last Tuesday of its Spring quarter.

LONDON, March 28 -- Great Britain waits spellbound to see what fortune Sir Stafford Cripps will have in India trying to solve with a single daring stroke a problem that has baffled men for years. It is a remarkable tribute to him that a majority of the Britons believes he will turn the trick with a flourish.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Organization of a bureau of finance in the War Production Board's division of industry operations to assist contractors and subcontractors in solving financial problems which may arise in connection with the handling of war orders was announced today by J.S. Knowlson, director of industry operations.

RICHMOND, Va., March 28 -- Herbert Hoover Jr., son of the former President, is the inventor of a new way to "map" the subterranean structure of the earth's crust covered in a patent (No. 2,276,306) granted jointly to Herbert Hoover Jr. of Sierra Madre, Calif., and Hugh C. Schaeffer of Tulare, Calif.

LONDON, March 28 -- London's Warships Week had reached 140,141,768 at the end of banking hours today, but a spokesman for the National Savings Committee explained that that was "far from the final figure" and that there was no question that the capital would surpass its quota of 150,000,000.

TUCSON, Ariz. -- A recent discovery of ancient remains -- some dating back 7,000 years -- in a rock shelter called Ventana Cave, on the eastern slope of Castle Mountain, 110 miles west of Tucson, on the Papago Indian Reservation, has bridged several gaps -- so it is claimed -- in the reconstruction of ancient civilizations.

CHICAGO, March 28 -- A combination of bullish influences coming at a time when the market was oversold rushed prices of grains up rapidly today on the Board of Trade here. Business was unusually brisk for a week-end.

EVERY two and one-half seconds of the day and night somewhere in the United States a train starts on its journey and another reaches its terminal. Over these lines last year more tons of freight were moved more miles them were ever moved before in any one year by any one anywhere.

A SPECIAL benefit performance for the American Red Cross will be given tomorrow at Carnegie Hall by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra. Yehudi Menuhin, the violin soloist, has volunteered his services for this event, as have John Barbirolli, the conductor, and the entire orchestra.

Evaluations of women scholars as typical "Vera Vagues" explode into thin air before the hard realities involved in some of the studies that will be financed this year through twelve fellowships awarded by the American Association of University Women.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 28 -- A.B. Christopher's Daily Delivery, regaining the form that had seen him win three straight purses at Hialeah Park, today ran one of the gamest races of his career to eke out a head triumph in the De Soto Handicap at Tropical Park.

Noise is a menace to health, a safety hazard and a deterrent to industrial productiveness, according to medical research and field tests said William Reynolds, president of the National Noise Abatement Council. The council is carrying on a wartime campaign to arouse the public to the necessity for noise control.

LOS ANGELES, March 28 -- After the Ninety-fourth Squadron passed in review for Eddie Rickenbacker at the Long Beach Municipal Airport this week the man credited with twenty-six of the sixty-nine enemy planes which the Ninety-fourth Squadron destroyed during six months in the last World War declared:

More than 200,000,000 board feet of insulating materials will be needed in 1942 for the cold-storage plants of military cantonments, packing plants, creameries, dairies, bakeries, ice-cream plants and commercial refrigerators. Half the manufactured food products of the nation must be refrigerated at some stage of their preparation.

IT is heartening to read that the Berkshire Symphonic Festival given by Serge Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony Orchestra annually at Stockbridge, Mass., will be held this season as usual; and that whatever practical problems may be imposed upon the festival management by the exigencies of wartime will be met with characteristic American resourcefulness by the management of the festival and by the citizens of the community.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 28 -- The report that Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, Franch Chief of State, had a conversation Thursday at Randan near Vichy, with Pierre Laval, whom he deposed as "heir apparent" on Dec. 13, 1940, has still not been permitted publication in France.

The National Orchestra Association, under Leon Barzin, gave the fifth and last program of its Winners' Series, constituting this year's Gabrilowitsch Memorial concerts, yesterday afternon in Carnegie Hall. Again the program featured works by winners in national composition contests, and the soloist had received an award in an important vocal competition.

It is disturbing to note the trend of taxation toward a general sales tax under the guise of controlling inflation. The problem of keeping body and soul together is sufficient of a problem to our lower-income group without adding a general sales tax to the things which they must buy.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 28 -- Marquette University, heeding the urgency of the government's plea for a speed-up in graduates to free them for their niches in the war effort, has streamlined most of its courses and is making more intensive plans.

Industry has generally adopted a policy of keeping production lines running at capacity but at the same time of holding down inventories, according to the monthly report of the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, released yesterday.

ISSUING its general report in wartime, the American Youth Commission brings the work of several years to an effective summation in a "philosophy applicable both in war and in peace." Its examination thus goes back through the past decade and on through the present war period to the inevitable readjustments of the return to peacetime conditions.

MILLWOOD, N.Y., March 28 -- William Willis Reese, 73-year-old real estate broker of New York City, was killed and his wife, Mrs. Augusta Bliss Reese, 68, was injured critically this afternoon in an automobile collision on Taconic State Parkway here.

HOLLYWOOD. YOUTH is the predominant note of "Rally 'Round the Girls," the latest musical addition to this theatre of the Western Defense Area. And it presents itself as a comely youth with plenty of good-will, a pleasing amount of eagerness, but not much originality and only a fair sprinkling of talent.

The creator of John Thorndyke, M.D., says the detective story's historian, Howard Haycraft, in that standard work "Murder for Pleasure," was "modern before the moderns. He was the true and undoubted 'parent' of the scientific detective story in the highest meaning of that phrase, and remains today the living dean of that form."

WRITTEN with a directness and simplicity of style unusual in a first book, Angus McDonald's narrative of his father's struggles as a farmer and preacher in Eastern Oklahoma is an honest and graphic piece of work.

Those American friends who wonder how we ordinary Englishmen are getting on in these soul-trying times would understand our spirit the better if they had experience of the Western Front in the First World War. Our rough and often humiliating experience has made us a tougher people than we were in September, 1939.

The third and final day of the annual convention of the National Football League at the Commodore yesterday was devoted entirely to the schedule. Enough conversational material was furnished to keep the owners and officials behind closed doors until well into the evening.

THE Edgar M. Leventritt Foundation, Inc., established in memory of the late Edgar M. Leventritt, New York lawyer and music lover, will hold its third annual competition for young musicians early in October in this city.

The most significant contribution American colleges can make to the present emergency is to teach thoroughly and well the courses which have long been basic in the curriculum of liberal arts. For practical military service, courses in mathematics, physics, chemistry, and their applications in engineering are fundamental.

THE Living Thoughts Library, edited by Alfred O. Mandel, is sufficiently established to obviate the need of any general comment on the excellent series of these useful and often inspiring volumes. The two new additions justify their places beside the eighteen volumes which have gone before.

TORNADOES drove men to earth long before there were bombers in the skies. The Midwest, which last week was still counting its latest "twister" victims, has been pockmarked by "cyclone cellars" for half a century.

IN honor of the seventy-fifth birthday of Arturo Toscanini, which took place last week, Victor releases the conductor's version of Brahms's Symphony No. 1, in C minor, with the NBC Symphony Orchestra (M-875, five 12-inch records).

CHICAGO, March 28 -- Delegates representing the nation's 28,000 parent-teacher associations will meet in San Antonio, Texas, from May 3 to 7, at the convention of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers, to discuss a wide range of wartime activities for America's 2,500,000 P.T.A. members, it was announced today by Mrs. William Kletzer of Portland, Ore., president.

TO BE OR NOT TO BE is still a question -- at least as far as the critics are concerned in reviewing my latest picture. Some approve of it wholeheartedly; some condemn it with all the derogatory adjectives at their command; and there is a third group who apparently like the picture but don't seem to be quite sure if they did the right thing in enjoying it.

LONDON, March 28 -- Declaring that there could not be peace until "the wicked forces that have wrecked the world are cast down and utterly destroyed," King George VI called on his people tonight to observe tomorrow as a day of prayer in which they would give thanks for their survival and dedicate themselves anew to "the service of the just and good cause for which we fight."
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 28 -- After knocking at the door for years, Yale tonight captured the National Collegiate Athletic Association swimming team championship.

WHETHER the rolypoly koala bear with its tiny feet and big ears comes along as supercargo when our boys return from Australia, it's a safe bet that its amusing antics will delight (in off moments) the hard-working soldiers of Uncle Sam.

FRANCONIA NOTCH, N.H. -- With the higher elevations of the North Country covered by a heavy accumulation of snow, indications are that the best Spring skiing in several years is in store for the enthusiasts who thrill to trail and slope running in the scantiest of clothes under the brilliant sunshine of warmer days.

When New York's noted company of amateur Savoyards -- the Blue Hill Troupe -- presents "The Pirates of Penzance" as its eighteenth annual production on April 15, 16 and 17 at the Heckscher Theatre, the three performances will be noteworthy not only in the annals of the troupe but also for the widespread philanthropic endeavor represented by The Bargain Box, beneficiary of this year's presentation.

Immediately after the man is found dead. in the green sedan on a road in the suburbs of Los Angeles, persons who appear to be more or less involved in the affair begin to drop out of sight. First there is the girl who dropped a pistol and ran away shortly before the body was found.
BUENOS AIRES, March 28 -- In spite of the war Argentina's Olympic committee is going ahead with plans to stage the first Pan-American Games here this year "as a lesson to the dictators."

LONDON, March 28 -- The first group of volunteers, numbering 187 persons, who left St. Pierre and Miquelon after the Free French Christmas Eve raid, arrived in London today to join General Charles de Gaulle's forces.

CHUNGKING, China, March 28 -- With the lifting of Winter's protective shroud of almost daily mist or rain, and the return of bright sunshine, the local press is beginning to warn Chungking's residents that the "bombing season" is almost at hand.

ALBANY, March 28 -- The bitterest legislative debate in several years centered this week on the issue of quarterly installment income tax payments, with both Democrats and Republicans seeking to impress on the State's voters, in a Gubernatorial year, the benefits given to them by each party.

AT a time when the world needs joy and brightness more than ever before, the roses of California are doing their bit in a big way. No one who has ever seen the brilliant beauties forgets them. They are as constant as the sun and as welcome.

Modern designers consider color in the private area or outdoor living room a definite essential for present-day enjoyment. In the past, little thought has been given to color combinations. With the promise of more intense gardening, due both to the government's urgent request and to lack of facilities for other pleasures, here is an interesting opportunity for the gardener to experiment with color effects, both in carefully blended masses and in quick sharp accents.

Members of the Common Interests Committee and the Namesake Towns Destroyer Committee of the English-Speaking Union will give a tea on April 8 at the headquarters of the organization, 30 Rockefeller Plaza, for all Allied officers on leave and on duty in New York. Mrs.

When you first hear the name of Dr. Anton Adovich, that San Francisco psychiatrist is already dead. And at least one of the people in the Coronado Hotel knows it. But the only thing young Dr. Jim Chandler wants is to get back his tank of nitrous oxide from the young girl who -- inexplicably -- has stolen it.

IN a recent license agreement concluded with Canada, the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation gave permission to Fleet Aircraft, Ltd., to manufacture large quantities of Fairchild trainers now being used by our Army.

LOS ANGELES, March 28 (AP) -- The Pirates and the Cubs held an old home week celebration of their own at Wrigley Field today, the Bucs winning, 10 -- 9, in a free slugging ten-inning game featured by five homers. It was the Pirates' twelfth victory in thirteen starts.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, March 28 -- The young American fliers who are shortly to take on the Japanese have the proper fighting spirit. This becomes apparent in the course of a visit to one of the air fields tucked away in this vast country in which the Americans are getting final training before going to the front, and this last training is the most serious.

AMHERST, March 28 -- White rats, guinea pigs, rabbits, and chickens are doing their part for defense in an intensified research program at Massachusetts State College, as six departments unite in using the facilities of the small animals laboratory in projects ranging from determination of the effect of manganese on human growth to the vitamin K content of milk.

LATE in April, Duell, Sloan Pearce will publish "MacArthur on War," edited by Frank C. Waldrop, Washington correspondent. The book is a compilation of General MacArthur's reports, treatises and communiques covering the period from approximately 1920 until the present time.

CHUNGKING, China, March 28 (U.P.) -- Outnumbered, attacked from three sides and without air support against relentless enemy bombardment, the Fifth and Sixth Chinese Armies under United States Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell were taking a tremendous toll of Japanese troops at Toungoo, it was officially reported here.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- President Roosevelt has accepted the decision of his official aides that pending anti-trust suits deemed capable of interfering with war production be dropped and that such suits be avoided as far as possible during the conflict, it was revealed at the White House today.

During this coming week Macy's is sponsoring a "Vegetables for Victory and Flowers for Morale" exhibit. This display, which, in gardeners' language, covers about one-quarter of an acre of space, will show an assortment of garden supplies, from seed to trellises, for planting and decorating.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- A 15 per cent increase in productivity by the economic system of the United States as well as the diversion, in 1943, to armaments output of almost one-fourth of facilities devoted to the production of civilian goods in 1941 will be required to meet the war program demanded by President Roosevelt, according to a survey made by the Department of Commerce.

"THE present work," says the anthropologist Earnest A. Hooton in his foreword to Mrs. Crockett's record of residence in the wilds of New Guinea, "is a casual by-product of her contributions to science." And for so charming a book nothing could be sounder praise.
Wicky Harkins, 150, Philadelphia, outpointed Tony Ferrara, 150 1/2, Mount Vernon, N.Y., in the star attraction of eight rounds at the Ridgewood Grove in Brooklyn last night before a crowd of 3,000.

GLASSBORO, N.J., March 28 -- President Edgar F. Bunce of the Glassboro Teachers College has established a program for Victory Gardens on the College campus where vegetables will vie with flowers as points of attraction.

A performance by the Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House April 7 will benefit the Tolstoy Foundation, which gives aid to Russian refugees and is raising funds through its Relief for Russia Committee for the aid of Russian prisoners of war.

Some of the old rules governing the interpretation of taxing statutes have lost much of their force in the evolution of income tax law. For example, in case of doubt, "taxing statutes shall be construed most strongly against the government and in favor of the citizen"; their meaning "shall not be extended by implication," etc.

Miss Harper, who has already given us several excellent anthologies of seasonal stories and poems. "Ghosts and Goblins." "The Harvest Feast" and "Merry Christmas to You," has now filled in a gap where there has been a notable dearth with this volume of Easter tales and verse culled largely from contemporary writers.

Due to the rapid expansion of industrial activity throughout the territory served by the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation, total gas and electric sales of the system reached record levels in 1941, Edward Reynolds, president, declared yesterday in his 1941 annual report to stockholders.

EASTER business seemed headed for a record last week in a last flourish of public buying before war restrictions and controls clamp down on some of the traditional finery. When the holiday is over retailers will be in a better position to judge the trade outlook, but they have grown more optimistic about possibilities for the second quarter.

There is much talk about our apathy toward the present war effort. Although I believe this feeling is exaggerated, I look back to 1917, when I was serving in the Army, and it seems to me that the public showed more enthusiasm then.

Spurred by pre-Easter buying, the quickened pace of retail trade last week again emphasized the acute delivery situation prevailing in wholesale markets as manufacturers have been unable to accumulate merchandise, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 28 -- Imbued with the spirit of adventure and all but oblivious to the dust that swirled down the unpaved streets of California's newest "boom town," over in the desert country a thousand Japanese were digging up sagebrush and performing odd jobs this week in the Owens Valley reception center, a symbol of the West Coast's fear of espionage and sabotage following Pearl Harbor.

The "three blind mice" of this story's title may or may not be the three husbands of the beautiful and unscrupulous Linda Douglass, all of whom are involved in the mystery over the death of the latest one's former wife. The lovely Linda's ruling passion is acquisitiveness: what any one else has is what she wants; and she gets it.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Fierce fighting flared again in Burma and Bataan in the past week as the Japanese attempted to conclude these campaigns before the start of the Orient's torrential rains in mid-May.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under John Barbirolli, gave the first of a series of Tchaikovsky programs at its concert last night in Carnegie Hall. Michel Piastro, the organization's concert master, was the soloist in the violin concerto, and the purely orchestral offerings consisted of the "Nutcracker Suite" and the Sixth symphony.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 28 (AP) -- A pair of Philadelphia keglers gambled and lost by one pin a chance at the doubles leadership in the American Bowling Congress today.

ANY one interested in medicine or surgery will find Dr. Frank G. Slaughter's new novel, "Spencer Brade, M.D." an absorbing book. For besides telling a romantic tale, he opens the door to chambers of a professional world closed as a rule to the layman.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- As the implications of this global war are driven home by constant increases in its geographical range and ever-fresh evidence of the extent of our enemies' preparations for it, responsible quarters in Washington appear to tend ever more to the belief that if the United Nations are to be victorious the complete mobilization of men and women in the United States is imperative.

CAKE for birthdays, plum pudding for Christmas, turkey for Thanksgiving -- special foods are an integral part of all our great moments. Every Christian land has food customs with which it marks Holy Week and Easter.

A recent series of articles on American Jews in a national magazine was criticized by rabbis in sermons here yesterday. Other sermon topics included tributes to Rabbi Isaac Mayer Wise, "father of Reform Judaism in America," and Rabbi Saadiah, and the Great Sabbath before Passover, observed yesterday.

The St. Francis Prep swimming team of Brooklyn easily won the city Catholic High Schools Athletic Association championship in the Columbia University pool yesterday. Scoring heavily throughout the eight-event program, St. Francis totaled 73 1/2 points, with Bishop Loughlin, the runner-up, having 41.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce, has indicated that the minimum war damage insurance rate will be $1 for each $1,000 of insurance.

The cotton market yesterday registered gain for the fifth consecutive session as trade and mill buying continued to lend steady support. Prices of active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange closed at their best marks for the day with net gains of 7 to 15 points, reaching levels as much as $4 a bale above the final quotations on Monday.

A COMPETITION for an opera by an American-born composer is announced by Mrs. Lytle Hull, president of the New Opera Company. The winner will receive a sash award of $1,000, coupled with a guarantee that the prize work will be performed by the New Opera Company during the Fall season of 1943, if the judges deem it suitable.

WILL ROGERS once said, "There is more quaintness and different things to see here in Mexico than I saw in the whole of Europe." One aspect of Mexico's quaintness is the names. A study of nomenclature often tells you more about a people than their history does, and in Mexico nomenclature shows humor, irony, artistic leanings and grandiloquence.

OLIVER GOLDSMITH, when he wrote the lines "Ill fares the land, to hastening ills a prey," was writing about the dispossessed. Carey McWilliams was writing about the dispossessed when he chose the title for his book.

FROM its sensational title and colorful jacket depicting a slant-eyed Cambodian dancing girl in a ritualistic dance pose one might infer this to be one of those incandescent novels of European importation which a few years since roused the righteous indignation of Boston censors and in New York brought booksellers to General Sessions charged with vending obscene literature.

Yesterday saw the dullest Saturday session since last August on the New York Stock Exchange, with volume of only 131,350 shares. Of the 444 issues traded 164 fell, 128 rose and 152 were unchanged. THE NEW YORK TIMES rail, industrial and combined averages dropped 0.07 point apiece, to 18.04, 118.84 and 68.44, respectively.

THE thirty-six-player entry list in the annual masters' individual championship, which will be played April 10, 11 and 12 at the Park Central Hotel, has been made complete by the entries of Myron Fuchs and Robert Appleyard, both of New York.

SHORTLY before Adolf Hitler launched his surprise assault on Soviet Russia the German consul at Moscow told a close friend: "It would be a tremendous error if we ever found ourselves at war with the Russians. Although Moscow can be occupied within six weeks, it is a country which can never be conquered."

IT begins to look as if this Summer might see a revival of the horse and buggy, at least for people in the country, which is a charming nostalgic picture. But, unfortunately, this phase of the return to the simple life is not so simple. A whole generation has grown up not knowing anything about horses, and this group is in for some nasty shocks.

A large subscription has already been reported for the lecture to be given by Carveth Wells, explorer, engineer and author, on the night of April 14 in the clubhouse of the New York Junior League for the benefit of the New York Child's Foster Home Service.
TWO general conclusions seem to be warranted on the basis of six years of continuous surveys of American public opinion.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (U.P.) -- The 167,000 inmates of State prisons throughout the country will join the war effort under plans being perfected tonight by officials of the War Production Board.

Congressmen have been swamped with mail recently on the subject of the forty-hour week in wartime. The great bulk of it, most of them have declared, has been in opposition to the forty-hour week. Defenders of the forty-hour week have made two answers to this avalanche of letters.

An acute shortage of teachers, expected to become critical in some fields by next Fall, will probably be met largely through retraining teachers qualified in fields where no shortages exist and by calling back these who have left the profession, according to Dr. E. George Payne, dean of the New York University School of Education.

Spring fashion displays of the latest costumes for all occasions given in conjunction with luncheon parties at leading hotels in the city are continuing as a popular means of augmenting the maintenance funds of various philanthropies. Several unusual style revues, with younger members of society acting as manikins, have been planned for the near future.

WAR is a great scatterer. It sends fighting men to the ends of earth and ocean and, even inside a country, it sends all sorts of workers with hand and brain to new assignments in new and strange places.

Wall Street is beginning to mix a measure of confidence with its hope that Congress will modify the capital-gains tax. Leaders who have been attending hearings in Washington have returned with optimistic stories regarding the attitude of the Congressional committee and the stand taken by the Treasury.

IDEAS have a strange way of shuttling around the world, for, born in one man's mind, they fly an ocean or a continent and lie dormant in books, sometimes for centuries, ready to take new life and vigor when they fall, like a seed, into an intellect ripe to rephrase and adapt them to the circumstances of his own day.

ALBANY, March 28 -- Governor Lehman signed without comment today the Muzzicato bill designed to prevent an increase in the 5-cent subway fare in New York City. At the same time he vetoed, as unnecessary in view of this action, the Crews bill covering the same territory.

GENERAL M'ARTHUR'S HEADQUARTERS, in Australia, March 28 (U.P.) -- Seven Japanese bombers raided Darwin today, but they were intercepted by United Nations fighting planes and no important damage was reported. It was the seventh raid on the Darwin area.

CHUNGKING, China, March 28 -- Japanese military operations the length and breadth of China, particularly the battles now developing in Shansi and Suiyuan Provinces, are being watched with keen interest by military observers here. While the scattered engagements, separately considered, are relatively little importance, they are regarded as a part of Japanese preparations for an overland invasion of Siberia from Manchukuo and Inner Mongolia in collaboration with an aerial and naval attack on Vladivostok.

An all-out effort to contribute to the comfort and welfare of the young men in the armed forces is manifest currently in the many springtime dances, cocktail parties, luncheon-fashion shows and theatre parties arranged for the near future by women prominent in society, civic and artistic circles.

AID: In peacetime the gondoliers who plied the picturesque canals of Venice were an attraction for tourists, an inspiration for poets and song writers. War and the lack of foreign visitors have brought economic hardship for the romantic boatmen. Last week, according to a rport from Berlin, they received relief.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 28 -- A manifold educational program embracing the specialized facilities of each institution in an effort to cope with the needs of a nation at war is the role of New Jersey's universities and colleges today.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., March 28 -- Miss Mary Reinach's steady-going Vassal Star won the jumper championship at the fifth annual Boulder Brook Club junior horse show today by taking blues in two events.

IT is not really strange that, as John Cournos points out in introducing his very interesting anthology of forecast, "prophets have gained a popularity in our day rarely accorded them before." When the present is in upheaval the attempt to foretell the future is widely alluring.

"Divide and Conquer," a government pamphlet disclosing Nazi methods of undermining and destroying enemy resistance through propaganda and so-called psychological warfare, is soon to be released for public distribution, the Office of Facts and Figures disclosed yesterday.

AUSTIN, Texas, March 28 (AP) -- Harold Hunt of Nebraska soared over the 14-foot mark in the pole vault today in one of two record-bettering performances at the fifteenth annual Texas relays. The University of Texas dominated the meet.

The Navy Department revealed last night that enemy submarines have torpedoed at least two and possibly three more medium-size United States merchant vessels off the Eastern seaboard. Twenty-four seamen are missing and feared dead in the two disasters, but forty-five were saved.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: Many perennials are starting growth now, and the sooner borders can be worked over and all Winter-hardy weeds removed the better. Care must be taken, however, not to disturb the late starting species of perennials which are not yet pushing through the surface. . . . If the lawn has not already been fertilized, the sooner a complete plant food is applied the better.

FACING the snow-white marble quarries of Mount Pentelikon and overlooking the entire plain of Attica, a massive, square, two-story house stand on top of a pine-clad hillock at the westernmost end of Maroussi, one of the suburbs of Athens least contaminated by the divers manifestations of our "civilization."

Astonishing changes can be brought about in old and too familiar quarters with mirrors. There are plenty of them around in the stores, in many shapes and sizes, and you can have them cut to measure at the various glass and mirror works along Third Avenue in the Forties and Fifties and in the cross-streets in that part of town.

Typewriter factories are capable of almost 100 per cent conversion to war ordnance production with later release of scarce and critical war materials, skilled labor and well-equipped plants to help win the war, Harvey C. Mansfield, chief of the office equipment and machinery unit of the OPA, told members of the National Typewriter and Office Machine Dealers Association here yesterday afternoon.

I HAVE been concerned for some time with that old custom, in programming concerts for children, of including a majority of musical works which attempt the imitation of all manner of sounds in nature and everyday life, and the further literal interpretation placed by commentating conductors on the more abstract works.

WHILE most concertgoers may be unaware of it, the familiar Hollywood practice of sneak previewing is also in use among some concert artists. The unheralded preview concert is a method by which the artist makes certain that his programs are foolproof for performance before a paying audience.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 28 -- Addressing Parliament before its adjournment today, Premier Bogdan Philoff said that the prime requisite for the establishment of the new order in Europe was the destruction of bolshevism, "which has always constituted one of the greatest menaces for Europe and its civilization."
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- A War Department communique based on reports received up to 10 A.M. said:

NEXT Sunday the Christian world celebrates Easter, and this year more Americans than ever before will join in the celebration. To some the celebration may mean that new Easter hat, those Easter eggs, chicks and bunnies, those Spring flowers on the corsage, a shine on the shoes and a smile on the face.

Creation of a "department of student life," with a permanent staff of personnel and guidance counselors to administer the expanding program of extracurricular activities for the 7,000 students attending the evening session of the City College School of Business and Civic Administration, was recommended yesterday by Dr. Robert A. Love, director of the session, in his annual report to President Harry N. Wright.

LONDON, March 28 -- The campaign for defense of Burma, and perhaps in the long run for India as well, still seems going against the British and Chinese armies, reports received here indicated, although an early communique from New Delhi said the situation on the Toungoo front appeared to have improved.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 28 -- Promotion, recommendation for the Navy Cross or both for nineteen Marines, forming a new list of Pearl Harbor heroes, together with stories of the heroism which earned recognition for them was announced today by Maj. Gen. William P. Upshur, commanding the Marine Corps Department of the Pacific in this district.

TWO out-of-town organizations figured among the group shows recently opened. Five members of the Dutchess County Art Association are showing paintings at the Argent Gallery while nearly a score of members of the New Hope (Pa.) Art Associates are represented in the fourth floor picture gallery at Bloomingdale's.

YOUR attention is called this morning to a parcel of time changes coming up a week from tomorrow night (April 6) on the NBC-Red Network, to wit: "Cavalcade of America," now heard at 7:30 P.M., adjourns to 8; the concert hour currently scheduled at 8 P.M. moves to 9 and "Dr. I.Q." (rescued from limbo by the arrival of a new sponsor) will take to the air at 9:30 P.M. instead of 9.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 28 -- In urging that methods of swimming instruction be changed to meet the needs of war, Henry Ortland, Navy mentor, reminded the gathering of coaches that the breast-stroke was of great value
A NEW YORK radio station's phone jingled the other evening; the caller asked to speak to the broadcaster's "transmitter engineer in charge." "Yes, this is sire ---," a pleasant voice answered.

"SALUTE TO THE HERO" has been presented, in its advance publicity and on the jacket blurb, as a historical novel -- possibly because it is a great deal easier to call it that than to say in full and precise detail how much else it is in addition.

ABSTRACTION has been sneaking up on us of late; coming to represent a more and more major phase of our exhibition schedule. Those especially interested in this type of expression (a general type that in itself compasses a very considerable gamut) can put in a lot of time to advantage visiting various abstract shows about town.

From January to March is the period of heaviest snowfall on the Russian front. In those three months the movement of mechanized armies is brought virtually to a standstill. Blinding blizbards and bitter cold sweep the region from Murmansk to the Crimea -- a straight-line distance of some 1,700 miles.

CHICAGO, March 28 -- The Pilgrim from the center of the war program at Washington has hardly begun to talk to his first smoking-room acquaintance before a subject which seems uppermost in the American mind comes to the surface. As soon as the war enters the discussion, which is soon, this question is almost invariably posed:

ONCE in a blue moon a book like the present one is published, a book which affords the reviewer both a fresh intellectual experience and an esthetic pleasure. Given the nature of the book, this is a large statement to make of a little volume no longer than sixty-odd pages -- hardly twenty thousand words in all.

The clothes moth has an axis partner. It is a slim, swift-footed insect technically known as Lepisma saccharina, but popularly called "silverfish" and sometimes "fish moth." The two pests have formed an alliance rather like that of the Germans and Japanese.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 28 -- The Nazis' Middle Eastern war of nerves -- Adolf Hitler's usual preliminary to more concrete action -- can now fairly be considered to have begun. Turkey is being subjected to a barrage of Axis diplomatic visits, with a background of hints, rumors and more or less spectacular threats.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., March 28 -- Representative Hamilton Fish has informed Orange County Republican leaders that he will take up residence in Orange and seek reelection in a district consisting of this county and Ulster and Sullivan Counties if his home county, Putnam, is severed from the present Twenty-sixth Congressional District under a reapportionment plan now under consideration.

Aristide Briand, Premier of France during the first World War, was eulogized by friends and former associates at ceremonies honoring the eightieth anniversary of his birth yesterday afternoon in the Gould Memorial Library at the University Heights campus of New York University.

DETROIT -- America's boast that it operates one automobile for about every four persons, against one car for every 150 persons in the rest of the world, is going into the discard. By the end of 1942, experts believe, at least 5,000,000 of America's 28,000,000 cars will be laid up because of tire shortage.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Sounds from the "battle of the forty-hour week" reverberated this week on Capitol Hill and in the downtown offices of the Executive department and defense agencies, but as the smoke lifted at the week's end it seemed clear that the issue had more psychological and political implications than effect on war production.

IT is amazing how very vexatious have become the obtrusions of standardized plots in our so-called "service pictures" ever since the war became real. Prior to the air raids on London -- indeed, prior to the Pearl Harbor attack -- it was not beyond the realm of possibility to take, with a soupcon of salt, the silly, implausible stories around which these films were always made.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 28 (AP) -- Limited to only one first place, Illinois, defending champion, grabbed enough also-ran points to top seven other rivals in the 1942 National Collegiate Athletic Association gymnastic meet at the United States Naval Academy today.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 28 (AP) -- Lehigh University's small-bore rifle team scored 1,393 points in the prone, kneeling and standing fire today to take top honors in the Eastern sectional rifle tournament at the United States Naval Academy.

Ways and means of helping the average American housewife meet the restrictions upon food habits and diets without injuring the nation's war production schedule are being explored in a series of courses conducted by the Queens College department of home economics.

CLEVELAND, March 28 -- Refusing to take on its own shoulders responsibility for a decision on the question of renouncing double time for Sunday and holiday work, the international executive board of the United Automobile Workers (C.I.O.) voted today to call a special convention of representatives of its 534,000 members to pass on Donald M. Nelson's demand for abandonment of premium pay within the limits of the forty-hour week.

JUST around the time that the Spanish Civil War broke forth in all its fury Garcia Lorca's interest in the theatre became the most intense. In fact, the young poet from Granada had almost decided to completely devote himself to the drama.

BALTIMORE, March 28 (AP) -- The destroyer Campbeltown, which the British announced tonight was used in ramming the main dock gate at St. Nazaire, was formerly the U.S.S. Buchanan, named in honor of Captain Franklin Buchanan, the first American to set foot in Japan on Commodore Perry's expedition.

ABOUT all that an average well-educated person knows of the scientific work of Benjamin Franklin is that he invented the lightning rod and that he once went out into a thunderstorm and drew electricity from the clouds by means of a key that hung from the string of a kite.

Even in normal times the average amateur gardener has some difficulty in keeping his borders colorful throughout the season. This year, with help difficult to obtain, and extra demands from many directions on each gardener's own time, careful planning to avoid "skips" in the flower beds is more important than ever.

Uninterrupted public support of private charities in wartime as an aid to victory was urged yesterday by prominent speakers on radio programs in behalf of the 1942 appeal of New York Catholic Charities.

The detective hero of this story is Doc Miller, physician and coroner. Although his official function ceases when the cause of death has been determined, he takes complete charge of the case by sheer force of personality, overriding the District Attorney and the police.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Increased Federal expenditures for housing projects and for industrial facilities were largely responsible for a rise of 36.4 per cent in the value of building permits in February, as compared with February, 1941, and of 51.6 per cent over January of this year, the Labor Department said today.

The railroads' managements, which believe that they have not been exactly gainers by recent policies of the Washington Administration, are hopeful that they will receive favorable treatment of a proposal by which they may take advantage of present conditions to carry out what may prove to be a unique undertaking in respect to reducing their burden of funded debt.

THE thesis of this new volume by Mr. Ewen, who turns out books on musical themes with the frequency and regularity of some mystery writers, is to show that this country is coming of age musically. He does not believe that we have achieved full maturity in every respect, but he holds -- and proves -- that we have come a long way from our position less than a century ago.

THIS admirable work should be read by every one who wishes to know the story of the trans-Mississippi Indians in their relations with the agents of the Federal Government. No one is more competent to tell the story than Mrs. Seymour.

AN AMERICAN ARMY CAMP IN AUSTRALIA, March 28 (U.P.) -- Colonel Lewis S. Webster, commander of this brand-new camp that has risen quickly on a dusty plain, has been shouting so many orders recently that he has laryngitis. But he is happy about the set-up.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sunday, March 29 -- More than 2,000 Germans had been killed, much materiel seized and twenty-eight strong points captured by the Russians on the Leningrad sector at the conclusion last night of a two-day battle in the neighborhood of Volosovo, according to reports from Moscow this morning.

The eighth annual Tip Top Ball for the benefit of Stony Wold Sanatorium, given by Auxiliary No. 5 of that institution, will take place April 11 at the clubhouse of the New York Junior League, 221 East Seventy-first Street.

The Graduate School of Fordham University has completed plans for the broadening of political and social science courses to include the study of defense and post-war problems, according to the Rev. Dr. Moorehouse I.X. Millar, S.J., head of the Political Philosophy Department.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., March 28 -- Basing their work on the theory that the best test of the reliability of knowledge in any field is usefulness in making sound predictions, seventy Union College sophomores are analyzing prophecies made before the attack on Pearl Harbor regarding the possibility of war in the Pacific in the light of what has since happened.

A SOUTH PACIFIC PORT, March 28 (AP) -- A Netherland Navy spokesman said today that the unified command of the United Nations naval forces under Vice Admiral C.E.L. Helfrich of the Netherlands had to be dissolved after the first big engagement in the Java Sea Feb. 27, when United Nations ships withdrew to different refueling ports.

On Army Day New York will see a war parade. The President has said that the time has come for more parades. Others have said so too, but for some the flag-waving still comes hard. WASHINGTON, March 28 -- "The typewriter brigades, the shorthand battalions and the girls on the 'filing line,'" are becoming increasingly necessary in the war program, according to a statement issued today by Mary Anderson, director of the Women's Bureau in the Department of Labor.

SOMEWHERE IN ENGLAND, March 28 -- Britain has built up a vast stock of food reserves, mostly canned edibles, and has placed them in a large number of storehouses at points throughout the country, where they are being held for distribution among the population in time of national urgency such as an enemy invasion.

CZECHSLOVAK diplomacy, in which Mr. Josef Hanc has played a part since 1921, had a special and rather unusual trait. This was due to the fact that it was based, thanks to two great leaders, T.G. Masaryk and Edouard Benes, on scientific methods.

Eight Metropolitan Opera singers have been engaged to appear in the forthcoming opera season at the Teatro Colon in Buenos Aires, it was announced jointly yesterday by Ferrucio Calusio, who was sent here by the theatre to engage talent, and Andre Mertens, head of the South American division of Columbia Concerts, through whom the contracts were negotiated.

Fordham sent Jack Coffey's twenty-first season as the Rams' baseball coach off to a flying start by routing St. Peter's College of Jersey City, 8 to 1, at Fordham Field yesterday. On the basis of what the Rams showed in their opener there will be another strong nine on Rose Hill this year.

BATON ROUGE, La., March 28 (AP) -- A quartet of well-drilled University of Wisconsin Badgers carried off the team honors in the National Collegiate A.A. boxing tournament tonight with victories in the final round.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, March 28 (AP) -- Secret instructions from Berlin attaching "the greatest importance to all movements of shipping toward the Red Sea" were reported uncovered today as authorities announced additional arrests in their clean-up of a vast Nazi espionage ring.

The Homeless Children's Fund of the Children's Aid Society will benefit from an exhibition of paintings by Renoir, which will open Wednesday at the Durand-Ruel Galleries, 12 East Fifty-seventh Street. The exhibition, which will continue throughout the month, is part of the society's campaign to collect funds for the emergency care for homeless and dependent children.

A milestone in the history of American social legislation was reached on June 25, 1938, when President Roosevelt signed the Fair Labor Standards Act, or Wage and Hour Law, as it has been popularly known. The basic provisions of this New Deal measure were: (1) A minimum wage of 40 cents an hour for workers in interstate industry; (2) a maximum forty-hour week, with payment of time and a half for overtime.

Everybody will have a vegetable garden this season, which means that many gardens will be very small indeed. For such, seedsmen offer pocket-size varieties, so that the gardener on the tiniest area can have something rather like a doll's garden but none the less highly productive, growing much in little.

DOUBTLESS it is a little early to be talking about what constitutes the ideal war program on the radio -- i.e., the program best designed to stir its hearers to an acute awareness that they are participants, each and every one of them, in a conflict that marks a turning point in history.
The Boland bill, H.R. 6358, is an important step forward toward the enactment of a sound capital gains tax law.

Without the actual building of a single new car, the equivalent of almost 120,000 freight cars can be added to the overtaxed railroad facilities of the United States by obviating charges for demurrage, the time during which cars stand idle, waiting to be unloaded.

KANSAS CITY, March 28 -- Hitting their stride in the last ten minutes, the Stanford Indians slipped into a three-point-a-minute pace against Dartmouth tonight to transform a tight game into a 53-38 rout and win the N.C.A.A. basketball championship before 6,000 spectators.

Spring coats, suits and blouses severe active in the brisk retail trade experienced last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Main floor trade was strong, dresses were fairly good, homefurnishings fair, and china and glassware active.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 28 (AP) -- Bulgaria was pledged in principle to war against Russia today by her premier, Bogdan Philoff, but he avoided an outright promise of the troops Adolf Hitler has demanded of King Boris.

The State Department has for over a year devoted a great deal of time and attention to relations with Vichy. There have been rough spots. Many critics have thought more than once that Washington should have severed relations with the government of Marshal Petain. But, as matters stand now, the State Department could make out a very good case for the wisdom of its policy.

CHICAGO, March 28 -- The fifth annual all-breed dog show of the International Kennel Club of Chicago opened this morning in the International Ampitheatre with 1,440 dogs benched, a slight increase over last year.

The month of April begins with a full moon, which occurs at 8:32 A.M. (E.W.T.) on Wednesday and will rise at about sunset. And since there are about twenty-nine and one half days from one full moon to the next we shall have full moon again at 5:59 P.M. on Thursday, the thirtieth.

SINCE the NYA has been prohibited from spending money except for work that is directly related to defense, the NYA Symphony Orchestra of New York will give its last concert under government auspices at 5:30 P.M. next Sunday at the Benjamin Franklin High School.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Regulations, under which 1 per cent of the new passenger cars now held in a government pool as the result of Rationing Order No. 2-A may be released for general sale under restrictions, were issued today by the Office of Price Administration.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Defending its figures on strikes in war and non-war industries, which were questioned when submitted to the House Naval Affairs Committee yesterday, the National Association of Manufacturers issued a statement today declaring that they were essentially accurate and far better than those issued by the Department of Labor.

LONDON, March 28 -- The explanation made this week by Captain Oliver Lyttelton, Minister of Production, to the House of Commons that, administration of Britain's raw materials would remain with the Ministry of Supply was applauded generally because it leaves efficient control of that organization intact and relieves the Ministry of Production for the more important work of production of weapons.

Yachtsmen who have pampered their sailing charts over the years, buying new editions and entering meticulously those changes itemized by the Coast Guard's "Notice to Mariners," will have to do some plain and fancy guessing this season.

REMOVING the liquid content is the oldest method of preserving food, and one which is as up-to-date as a paratrooper. Primitive man learned, at the dawn of history, to spread his meat and fish in the sun, where it dried.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 28 -- Hurrying to meet tomorrow night's "deadline" in Lieut. Gen. John L. Dewitt's order "freezing" present Japanese residents in Military Area No. 1 until further notice, many hundreds of Japanese-Americans and Japanese nationals moved today to inland regions.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, March 28 -- Dynamite was found in the possession of a native Brazilian and in sufficient quantity to blow up two city blocks, according to a police statement today, which charged that he was a Nazi agent bent on destruction of railways and bridges, apparently in an attempt to block shipments of material to the United States.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The Marine Corps has enlisted the cooperation of the National Youth Administration in its program to train enlisted men for mechanical Jobs, Aubrey Williams, NYA administrator, reported today to Paul V. McNutt, Administrator of the Federal Security Agency.

"Scoreboard" or "beat the quota" campaigns, which are being adopted in war industries as an incentive for greater production, have previously proved successful in private industry, management engineers pointed out yesterday. While they have been used for many years, only in the last two or three, when demand for products began to outstrip the available supply, have they been adopted on a wide scale, it was pointed out.

AS many amateur photographers have learned to their dismay, theatre managements generally frown upon the use of cameras during performances. In the beginnings of miniature photography some years ago the small size of the camera as well as the speed of the lens and the introduction of more sensitive emulsions suggested the camera's use by amateurs attending the theatre.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., March 28 -- The University of North Carolina, which has made its service available to the nation on an emergency basis since the Summer of 1940, has stepped up its war-job program in recent months to the point where it has become a sort of State center for civilian defense as well as military training.

Several young women who will make their debuts in forthcoming seasons, including the Misses Cynthia McAdoo, Virginia McCulloch, Nadine Nunes and Mimi McAdoo, are aiding in the plans for the bomb shelter cocktail party to be held on the afternoon of April 6 in the Fable Grill and Vanity Fair Room of the Sherry-Netherland for the benefit of the New York Institute for the Education of the Blind.

G. Hilmer Lundbeck, general manager of the Swedish American Line in the United States, said yesterday that the steamship Drottningholm, now berthed at Gothenburg, which has been chartered by the United States Government to repatriate American and Axis diplomats, will leave that port in ten days and come empty to New York.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, March 28 (AP) -- Clarence Budington Kelland, executive director of the Republican National Committee, asserted in an address to the Youngstown Young Republican League that if any man, Democrat or Republican, "shall raise his voice in appeasement or for negotiated peace the Republican party will denounce or repudiate him."

THE ninth annual National Folk Festival will be held at Constitution Hall in Washington from May 6 to May 9, its fifth successive year in the Capital under the sponsorship of the Washington Post Folk Festival Association.

AS is clear enough from Mr. Brown's title, this book is in general about his lectures, tours over the country, talks before clubs, school work during the Summers at various colleges, lantern slide talks, public dinner talks, all kinds.

To meet the needs of their expanding wartime program, the New York State and City Leagues of Women Voters have leased new and larger offices at 461 Fourth Avenue. Headquarters will be moved from the present address at 151 East Fiftieth Street about April 10.

THE grotesque figure of the shoemaker's son who charmed the whole world with his stories has the childlike appeal of a character of his own invention, as well it might, since so much of his own sufferings and joy went into the making of his tales.

The Embassy Suite of the Ambassador will be the setting for the forty-first annual meeting and luncheon of the Graham Alumnae Association, to be held April 15 for the benefit of the association's scholarship fund.

"SEVEN months after the first man flew, the first woman flew. Five months before the Wright brothers first flew, a woman soloed a powered aircraft." These sentences are from the first paragraph of a book which tells the story of women in aviation.

WHEN a literary magazine postpones reviewing a book to four months after issue, the public is wont to assume that the book has been read with care and pondered by the reviewer -- even if it is a book of 777 pages.

The Bergen Beach Gun Club, shooting over its own traps, won the second leg of an inter-club shoot against the Whitcomb Gun Club of the Bronx yesterday, 214 to 209. Since the visitors won the first leg earlier in the season, a deciding leg will be shot on April 26 over the Whitcomb traps.

FOR the first time since Switzerland began issuing official stamps, in 1938, sale of these in mint condition has been authorized by the postal authorities, according to word from Bern. Heretofore they have been obtainable by collectors in only canceled condition.

HEALTHY SEED -- If Dr. James G. Horsfall of the Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station is right, about 60 per cent of all vegetable diseases are seed-borne. It follows that the disease can be controlled largely by careful purchasing of seeds and treatment at the source.

A project aimed directly at Axis activities in this country is being sponsored by the National Committee on the Cause and Cure of War. In cooperation with the Council for Democracy, the committee is preparing a pamphlet briefly analyzing the numerous foreign propaganda devices being used to drive the poisonous wedges of disunity and dissatisfaction into the heart of the national war effort.
IF the razor blade shortage becomes acute and ball players blossom out with whiskers, it will be hard to tell the Phillies from a House of David team, especially when they are playing.

The old-fashioned jack-of-all-trades would be flabbergasted by the "list of selected occupations" which is to be sent out with the new selective service questionnaire. Some of the trades mentioned would be familiar to him, of course. He could qualify as blacksmith, boatbuilder, bricklayer, carpenter, cooper, stonemason, farmer, gunsmith, loom fixer, machinist, millwright, painter, plasterer, plumber, printer, seaman, ship fitter, upholsterer or weaver.

IN a letter to THE TIMES recently, Paul Henry Lang may have closed one "controversy," but he has definitely opened another. Referring to Reinhold Gliere, whose "Marche Heroique" was performed by the New York Philharmonic under Eugene Goossens, Mr. Lang stated that the work in question was "a salon piece by an amateur (Gliere)."

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Dr. H.V. Evatt, Australian Minister of External Affairs, here as a special envoy, renewed Australia's demand for the formation of a supreme war council for the United Nations, to sit in Washington and in which Australia would have a voice, in an address tonight at the dinner of the Overseas Writers Club at the Hotel Willard, here.

Fifty-four British children from the Silverlands School, Surrey, England, now living at the Edwin Gould Foundation, will give performances of "Gratefully Yours," a musical revue, on April 7 and April 12 at the Imperial Theatre for the joint benefit of the American Theatre Wing War Service and the British and American Ambulance Corps.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 28 -- United States uniforms are no longer a rarity in the relatively remote Middle East. In the busy thoroughfares of Cairo, in the Eritrean uplands, on the teeming waterfront at Basra or in the Teheran bazaars one is just as likely as not, nowadays, to see men in fawn-colored trousers walking behind men in British battle-dress or hear a more generous accenting of the English tongue.

Shudders run up and down the spine when we read of planned bacterial warfare. Yet bacteria have always played their part in war. They defeated Xerxes. They killed from one-third to two-thirds of the Athenian population during the Peloponnesian wars. They wrought more havoc among the Crusaders than the Saracens.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 28 -- Henry Ortland, United States Naval Academy swimming coach, told a meeting of the College Swimming Coaches Association of America today that the youths of this country must be taught to "swim like the Japs."

CHICAGO, March 28 -- The government through the federally financed Dairy Products Marketing Association lifted wholesale butter prices here today 2 cents to as high as 36 cents a pound. The increase came as a surprise to dealers, since butter production, although currently about 10 per cent smaller than a year ago, is with that exception about the largest in history.

Just as dawn was breaking over the waterfront yesterday, Federal Bureau of Investigation agents swooped down on the German Seamen's Home in Hoboken and took into custody seventy-one persons suspected of being members of a spy ring. Equipment confiscated could easily have been used to notify prowling submarines of impending ship movements, it was said.

EXPRESSING whole-hearted agreement with President Roosevelt's recent assertion of his belief that "the war effort will not be hampered but actually improved by sensible participation in healthful recreational pursuits," the city's Park Department officials are anticipating record use of park facilities this Spring and Summer.

Judged by past history, no nations in this war are stranger bedfellows than Germany and Japan. Allied now they have an almost unbroken tradition of unfriendliness and suspicion toward each other. Two generations ago the concept of the "Yellow Peril" -- the doctrine that the Oriental races were bent on engulfing the Occident -- was a pet theme in Germany.

Reorganizing on a war basis, Boys' Clubs of America has announced a new victory program which will train their entire membership of 350,000 boys for service to the nation in the armed forces and in defense industries. The new program lays special emphasis on physical fitness and vocational training.

Rudolph Ganz has an individual style of humor and his young people's concerts with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra have become successively livelier as he has given his humor freer rein. Since yesterday morning's concert at Carnegie Hall was dedicated to "Humor in Music," Mr. Ganz had a field day.

A mobile unit of the American Red Cross blood bank will be installed in the auditorium of the Ridgewood, N.J., Woman's Club on Saturday to be operated on that day for the convenience of donors in the community. The unit is one of two which is maintained by the New York headquarters for use in the metropolitan area.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- A long-neglected source of information which will be of great value to the government in pressing the economic phases of the war will be tapped shortly when government agents begin calling upon executives of companies engaged in international trade, it was learned here today.

The swordsmen of Stuyvesan High School experienced little dif ficulty in gaining +._heir seventh consecutive victory in the Publi Schools Athletic League yesterdayd disposing of Seward Park, 9 -- 3, inL a Division I encounter at Wash ington Irving High School.

A nation-wide aviation project, intended to reach the 30,000,000 elementary and high school students of this country, is now being formulated and will be introduced into the everyday school curriculum this Fall. Beginning in the first grade and touching the seniors in the secondary schools, the program will concentrate on the task of making America's youngsters air-minded.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The War Department in its communique today again suggested that the long-anticipated Japanese drive to crush American and Filipino resistance on Bataan Peninsula might be imminent. It reported "almost continuous" enemy bombing of Corregidor Island, an attempt at night raids on Corregidor by the Japanese -- frustrated by the effectiveness of the American searchlight batteries there -- and much enemy patrol activity on the Bataan front.

THE Savoy Opera Guild, the little band of Gilbert and Sullivan folk which has been doing right handsomely, will celebrate the first year of its career at the Cherry Lane Theatre on April 15. There'll be a dinner and dance on that date, and on evenings all around that date the group will be repeating "Trial By Jury" and "Pinafore," with which it began a year ago.

NEW DELHI, India, March 28 -- The second round of conversations between Sir Stafford Cripps and Indian leaders began today, while there was virtual confirmation, on the eve of publication of the War Cabinet's proposals for settlement of the Indian problem, that one of the main items was "Pakistan," or the Moslem League's program of partition.

ALBANY, March 28 -- State Senator Allan A. Ryan Jr., Poughkeepsie Republican, announced today that he would seek the Republican nomination in the Twenty-sixth Congressional District, the seat for which now is held by Hamilton Fish, whose isolationist views have caused protests in his district.

CAMDEN, S.C., March 28 -- Rustic Romance, sensational 8-year-old from Paul Mellon's Rokeby Stables at Upperville, Va., paced a field of seven horses today and won the thirteenth annual running of the Carolina Cup Steeplechase at this Winter resort. More than 10,000 persons lined the course.

Throughout much of the Northern Hemisphere the frost has left the ground. Even in the latitude of Moscow it will soon be gone. The green of new grass moves northward over all the fertile lands. The Spring plowing has begun.
LONDON, March 28 -- This third Spring of the war finds Great Britain not yet ready to undertake a large scale offensive anywhere except perhaps in Libya.

TROY, N.Y., March 28 -- The curriculum of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute's Department of Economics, Business Administration and History has been enlarged to meet newly indicated needs. The department will continue to train students in the major fields of business -- finance, production and distribution; but it will also make available to these students courses providing general familiarity with engineering methods and objectives.

J. Lewis Luckenbach, president of the American Bureau of Shipping, when questioned yesterday as to his observations on the Sea Otter, expressed the opinion that in its present design the ship fitted no definite purpose in the war program.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla. -- With public transportation services taxed to capacity for the Easter holidays, Florida is looking forward to a creditable wind-up of its Winter tourist season. Although travel to this State fell off after Pearl Harbor and continued dull through January, very near the usual volume of traffic arrived in February and held on through March.

A more ideal hunting ground for American submarines could not be imagined. To them the Navy Department credits a full third of Japan's present ship loss of 120 vessels, naval and commercial, aggregating 500,000 tons.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- Management-labor committees, keystones in the government's drive for an immediate speed-up in war production, have been organized in more than 100 plants, it was learned today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 28 -- In the face of statistics indicating that Harvard is entering a scientific decade, Dean A. Chester Hanford of Harvard College emphasizes in his annual report that the preservation of "the liberal and humane tradition" is of vital importance when college students are preoccupied with technical courses and accelerated programs.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 28 -- A store of rim-fire ammunition blew up in a small unit of the Remington Arms Company plant here this afternoon, and tonight three men and three women were missing and believed dead in the wreckage.

THE region spotlighted in this new addition to the American Folkways series is the richest repository of the American folk heritage. Bounded roughly by the Ohio River on the north, the great Kanawha on the east, and the Tennessee on the south and west, it contains part of some eight States whose center is the Cumberland Gap celebrated in song and story.

LONDON. FROM time to time in these chronicles, the name of the Westminster Theatre crops up. This modest building near Victoria Station originally was a picture house, but was put out of business partly by the advent of the talkies, with their elaborate equipment, and partly by the rise of half a dozen movie palaces in the neighborhood.

New York's twelve outstanding college basketball players will be honored tomorrow night at the sixth annual dinner of the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association at the Hotel Abbey, an occasion which will observe with all due ceremony the passing of the 1941-42 court campaign.

The proposal that "the industry of education convert itself into the production of citizens fit to face the present emergency" was made yesterday by Walter E. Myer, director of Civic Education, Washington, D.C., at the closing session of the annual conference of the Eastern States Association of Professional Schools for Teachers, held in the Hotel Commodore.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Limitations on profits were tied suddenly and unexpectedly to huge appropriations for war today as the House of Representatives approved and sent to the Senate a sixth supplemental money bill providing $18,301,961,345 for a 3,600,000-man Army and making large grants to the Navy and civilian agencies.

Every one knows what leadership is. It is getting out in front and doing what one knows is right, regardless of the doubts and indecisions of others. To take a vote and then do what the majority want may be politics or democracy, but it is not leadership.
An American steamship which had been reported by the Japanese as sunk in the Far East arrived yesterday with 175 passengers in Jersey City after an enforced trip round the world.
Because of the advantageous location and equipment of their council houses, the Girl Scouts of America are giving substantial assistance to the nation's war effort.

Throughout the past quarter-century more and more young people were going to college, for more and more reasons. Many wanted a degree only because the business world now prefers it; others because of social advantages; a few because they wanted to play football, and others just because they wanted to prolong boyhood.

Recipe for a Springlike room: flower colors, abundant use of white, and yards and yards of chintz adorned with bright blossoms. With these ingredients one does, of course, need to work out a harmony; the homemaker who is not naturally a wizard at interior decoration can, however, plan her room around one of those groups of harmonized curtains, upholstery fabrics and rugs.

Wind-up of Easter trade this week will climax new records in consumer purchasing of soft goods, particularly apparel and accessories, with the percentage of dollar volume increases comparing favorably with those noted for Christmas trade last year in many communities.
The growing demand for expanded day nursery care from women who are eager to accept jobs in war industries is reflected in a survey just made by the National Association of Day Nurseries.

CANBERRA, Australia, March 28 -- General Douglas MacArthur, Supreme Commander for the United Nations in the Southwest Pacific, has gotten away to a good start in his first week in this country. He was only a name, albeit a name of legendary dimensions, on his arrival here.
