BERNE, Switzerland, March 28 -- Last Sunday, day for day, the propagandistically annihilated Russian armies entered the tenth month of what was to have been a six-week Blitz with German forces on the defensive at four major points on the 2,000-mile Eastern front.

C.R. Beardsley, chairman of the Brooklyn chapter of the American Red Cross, has made public a radiogram sent from Melbourne, Australia, by General Douglas MacArthur, in reply to a pledge from the borough unit to supply blood plasma from 75,000 donations in the next eighteen months.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- Appointment of Colonel John M. Franklin, formerly president of the United States Lines, to head the Army Transport Service was announced today by the War Department.
A hint of the approaching golf season is seen in the announcement by the Metropolitan Golf Association of its honor roll for 1942.

Three employes of the Unexcelled Manufacturing Company, Inc., maker of explosives, were killed instantly and four others were burned badly yesterday morning in an explosion in a small mixing building at the company's plant at 1204 Richmond Avenue, Graniteville, on the north shore of Staten Island.
Elizabeth, Lady Cheylesmore, will return to the Savoy-Plaza next week from Pinehurst.

According to District Attorney Samuel J. Foley of the Bronx, members of the March grand jury will begin hearing evidence tomorrow into the charges that Edward J. Flynn, chairman of the Democratic National Committee and Democratic leader of the Bronx, used city materials and employed men working for the city in paving his courtyard on his Lake Mahopac estate.

WHEN in 1871 a group of Fisk University students started on a tour singing the songs their slave mothers had taught them the audiences were generally surprised and some were shocked. They had been used to the seriocomic interpretations of the Negro character given by white comedians with burnt-cork makeups.

A new committee to direct and stimulate participation in war relief activities among members of the Connecticut State Federation of Women's Clubs has been formed by executives of the organization. Mrs. Laura Hale Gorton of Glastonbury, former federation president, has been named to head the project, according to an announcement by Mrs. Eric V. Johnson of Danielson, the present executive.

GIFT: The Indians who roamed the Georgia countryside centuries ago knew' Warm Springs as place Where warriors came to immerse their wounded bodies in the warm waters and soft mud. In recent years the springs have drawn other sufferers -- victims of the disease poliomyelitis.
IN response to a question of whether he didn't feel hurt or perhaps doubtful when people discussing him as a writer more often mentioned his old books than his new ones, Louis Bromfield said:

EAST LANSING, Mich., March 28 -- Oklahoma A. M. amassed 31 points to beat Michigan State and win its sixth straight championship in the fifteenth annual National Collegiate Athletic Association wrestling tournament tonight.

Over the global battlefronts last week hung an air of expectancy. There was little doubt that the opposing forces were gathering their power for a fresh and, if possible, decisive trial. The diminished tempo or the comparative deadlock in the fighting, from the plains of Russia to the jungles of Burma and New Guinea, seemed to screen the aggressors' preparation for new hammer blows.

THE spectacle of a bookseller in the throes of hunting for the price of a book used to be something to excite the awe and admiration of the amateur. It was most impressive to watch him haul down one volume after another in that endless series of annual auction records, run through its pages with a practiced eye, and restore it to the shelf.

By defeating Dr. Harry Kline, former University of Pennsylvania player, Harry Baker maintained his lead in Section A of the United States Chess Federation championship preliminaries at the Marshall Chess Club with a score of 4 -- 1 yesterday.

AUNT CHARLOTTE is right. Henry Owens is not the right man for her niece, Clare Cabot. The engagement of Clare and Henry is the culmination of a shipboard romance, and as our story opens we find Clare and her aunt on their way to Stone House to meet Henry's family.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 28 -- In 1941 Pete Reiser won the National League batting championship with an average of .343 -- and did it swinging from the left side of the plate. This Spring the youngster has hit in twelve of fifteen major league exhibition games for a mark of .350 -- and again all from the port side.

POSTMASTER GENERAL WALKER announced last week that first-day cover service for philatelists will be provided with the opening, on April 15, of the Raleigh County (W.Va.) postoffice which has been named MacArthur in honor of General Douglas MacArthur.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (U.P.) -- A group of Senators prepared today to scrutinize patent rights in general. Senator Homer T. Bone of the Patents Committee said his group would open hearings April 13 on legislation to permit use of patents "needed to win the war."

ON Aug. 6, 1763, King George III, of his "special grace, certain knowledge, and meet motion for the due encouragement of settling a new plantation within our said Province," granted a charter for a town near what is now the southeastern corner of the State of New Hampshire.

IT was from poor imprisoned Queen Juana, whom men called mad, that the lad Pedro de Cordova heard the great admiral's own story -- as she and her sister Catharine had listened behind their parents' throne -- of the first landing in the "happy isles under the hot sun," the finding of that "wonderful new world across the western sea."

UNITED STATES ARMY HEADQUARTERS, in Australia, March 28 (U.P.) -- President Manuel Quezon of the Philippines and his War Cabinet are on the way to headquarters to set up their government in exile, it was announced today.

MOST favored, if most baggy-kneed, of all the devices employed by the press agent to butter the box office, inflate the flame of the play he serves, add to the ennui of the editors, is the stratagem of citing cycles in the endurance of his exhibit.

The report of the Borg-Warner Corporation, for last year, shows a net profit of $7,475,049, after Federal income and excess profits taxes of $15,463,552, and after deducting a reserve of $2,000,000 for contingencies. This is equivalent to $3.20 a share on the outstanding stock.

PARTICULARLY interesting to a certain group of cover collectors are those items which reflect the changes wrought by war. A set of covers can show a country dominated by another, then independent, then under domination once again.

ALLAN STEWART was, it appeared, just one of those likable, diffident young Englishmen who spoke German well enough to enjoy vacationing in the Black Forest at a time when Hitler, after absorbing Austria into the Reich, was soothing startled Europe with the assurance that Germany had no further territorial ambitions.

AFTER three years of costly inactivity Leo McCarey has finally settled with Howard Hughes the contractual tangle which forced him to sit on the sidelines. The cost was understood to be $250,000, paid by McCarey and RKO, which he now will join as a producer-director.

Officers of the Queen Wilhelmina Fund, 601 Fifth Avenue, announce that a drive to raise money during the next six weeks has been launched on behalf of an emergency appeal for assistance that is badly needed now by victims of the Japanese invasion in the Netherlands East Indies.

LONDON, March 28 -- Using the former American destroyer Buchanan, renamed H.M.S. Campbeltown, as an explosive ram, British Commandos with naval and air support staged a heavy raid at St. Nazaire, France, early today, carrying out demolition work that included destruction of the main dock gate.
LONDON, March 28 (AP) -- Combined operations headquarters issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- Congressional leaders conceded today that controversy over proposed new levies may so delay final enactment of the new tax bill that Federal revenues for the next fiscal year will fall far short of the $9,000,000,000 increase asked by President Roosevelt in January.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., March 28 (AP) -- Myrna Loy said today that she had separated from her husband, Arthur Hornblow Jr., movie producer, that she would start divorce proceedings soon. They separated last Fall for several months but effected a reconciliation.

STILL in the dark about details of individual gasoline rationing, American motorists may familiarize themselves with aspects of Canada's ration system printed elsewhere on this page. However, as the United States is the world's "drivingest" nation, fuel allotments probably will be between 400 and 500 gallons a year, compared with a 600-gallon average for passenger cars in the past.

ROME, March 28 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Strong German formations raiding Malta have scored direct hits on one cruiser and two destroyers and have sunk one of three merchant vessels struck by bombs, the Italian High Command reported today, adding that one 8,000-ton merchant ship had been set on fire and that anti-aircraft guns had been silenced and heavy damage caused on military buildings.

HOUSE CLEANING would probably be a lot easier if one had a little portable stand on which to carry around the soap, cleaning rags, bottles of fluid, and so on. Hearn's has just such a carrier -- a small metal box with shelves and a handle.
CHICAGO, March 28 (AP) -- Prices of livestock were steady today after having made moderate gains in all departments.

"After an absence of a year I come back to Laurel Hall, meet my worst enemy, and immediately she gets killed," Michele James sums up the situation after the first murder, and adds, "Nice going." The ironic comment is even more pertinent after the second murder, for Michele is suspected of that, too.

Reversing its field with such rapidity in the second half that the Long Island University quintet never had a chance to take a deep breath, City College gained undisputed possession of the metropolitan basketball championship before 16,251 spectators at Madison Square Garden last night.

FROM a lofty aerie in the tower of the Chrysler Building the Pan American Airways System links five continents together. There its executives and engineers watch over close to 100,000 miles of airways, stretching three-quarters of the way round the globe.

HARSANYI'S new novel about the Flemish painter, Pieter Paul Rubens, brings to life one of the most startling personalities of the Catholic Baroque. Rubens's story is not, like Michelangelo's or Rembrandt's, one of suffering, disappointments and inner loneliness.

More than 1,100 delegates from all sections of the country, representing trade unions, church organizations, the crews of American ships and other organizations, opened the two-day session of the National Free Browder Congress yesterday afternoon at the Manhattan Center by cheering demands for the release by President Roosevelt from the Federal Penitentiary in Atlanta, Ga., of Earl Browder, general secretary of the Communist party of the U.S.A.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., March 28 -- With Regards, Kentucky-bred "Cinderella horse" picked up for $800 by T.D. Grimes, won the $5,000 added Arkansas Derby today with a new track record of 1:50 for the mile and a furlong.

VICHY, France, March 28 (AP) -- The French Government announced today the establishment of the first civilian representation in Germany since diplomatic relations were broken at the outbreak of war in 1939.

TORONTO, March 28 -- Toronto beat the Rangers, 2 -- 1, tonight to take a 3-1 lead in games in their four-out-of-seven semi-final Stanley Cup hockey play-offs. A record crowd of 15,624 at Maple Leaf Gardens saw all the scoring concentrated in the last period.

With the announcement yesterday that the New York watershed lakes and reservoirs will be open to fishermen, another doubt was removed from the mind of the city angler awaiting the start of the trout season in this State on Saturday.

THE latest hall of animals shown strikingly in their natural haunts will open in the American Museum of Natural History a week from Thursday. It is the new Hall of North American Mammals, which had its origin eighteen years ago in the imagination of Dr. Harold E. Anthony, who saw the necessity of preserving a life-like record of the slowly disappearing species of American wild life.

BOSTON, March 28 -- A survey of industrial properties in the six New England States, completed two days ago, shows that since Dec. 1, 1941, when the last survey was made, there has been a substantial shrinkage in the amount of idle industrial space in the Northeast, according to Henry W. Merrill, vice president of the Society of Industrial Realtors, a division of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- President Roosevelt today signed the second War Powers Bill which establishes criminal penalties for violation of government priority orders and extends the Executive's property secure powers. It also provides free postal service for members of the armed services serving overseas.

HONOLULU, March 28 -- How an Army photographer, aboard one of the Army bombers in a group that arrived on Oahu Dec. 7, scared off three Japanese planes by pointing his movie camera at them, is revealed for the first time by Technical Sergeant Jesse Schneider, of San Diego, Calif, a crew chief in the flight.

IN the mighty effort of our nation necessary to win this war and so survive, a shortage is becoming apparent which is far more serious than the shortage of sugar, or even than the shortage of rubber: this is the shortage of trained brains.

MIAMI, Fla., March 28 -- A couple of slightly faded left-handed mound aces, Al Milnar and Al Smith, dealt the Giants a lot of misery from the bottom of the deck today, with the result that Lou Boudreau's Indians vanquished the Polo Grounders for the second time this Spring, 2 to 0.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 28 -- Yankee hopes of a triumph over the Cardinals in their annual Spring series crashed today on a collapse of the first line of defense as Billy Southworth's band romped off with its fifth triumph over the champions.
DENVER, March 28 (AP) -- Rear Admiral John R.Y. Blakely, 69, retired, was killed instantly today in what Army officers described as a leap from the fifth floor of Fitzsimons General Hospital.

BERLIN, March 28 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command, in a special statement tonight on the British raid at St. Nazaire, said it was modeled after the "Zeebrugge enterprise" of the World War, a British naval action which bottled up the Germans in the Belgian harbor.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 28 -- Premier Vidkun Quisling is Norway's "first Bishop," according to the report here today of a statement at Oslo yesterday by a Quisling spokesman. He added that the "first Bishop" was planning the creation of a "new Norwegian Christianity based on race and Lebensraum."

LONDON, March 28 (Reuter) -- Subhas Chandra Bose, former president of the All-India National Congress, who had gone over to the Axis forces, was killed in an airplane crash off the coast of Japan, according to the Lyon (France) radio, which quoted a Tokyo message.

Here is a book which puts the joys of puppeteering, right into unskilled and unwealthy hands. Its title indicates the economy of time and money with which the puppet play may be produced so long as there is some imagination and a good five-and-dime store handy.

PITTSBURGH, March 28 -- William Johann Adams, aged 40, a German alien of this city and New York, was held for court today in $20,000 bond on charges of swindling Pittsburghers in a German bond exchange racket. He was specifically charged with obtaining money by false pretense, violation of the Pennsylvania Securities Act, blackmail and fraudulent conversion.

HOW frequently, during these days of horror and hot steel, do we find ourselves pausing in the midst of American plenty to exclaim inwardly: "What right have I to this beautiful food while so much of England starves?"

Reflecting the increased industrial activity and the shortage of other metals because of their need for the war effort, the consumption of silver in industry and arts in the United States now is running at the record rate of 120,000,000 to 130,000,000 ounces yearly.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 28 -- Prime Minister John Curtin announced today that the Japanese had lost a bomber and a fighter in yesterday's raid on Port Moresby, New Guinea. One United Nations plane was downed by three enemy fighters.
DETROIT, March 28 -- In the time it used to take to change passenger car models, Michigan automobile factories have taken long strides toward transforming themselves into arsenals.

BATON ROUGE, La. -- The tourist visiting the bayou country in Louisiana this Spring and next Summer may be lucky enough to stumble upon an "assemblee Francaise," one of those spontaneous gatherings to which the French people of the State are turning as if in protest against the dying out of gayety in Old France.
CHILDREN need the ability to buckle down and stick to a task. So we're being told in a tone of voice implying that this is a brand-new idea.

KATHERINE MANSFIELD was made of tragic stuff. A sensitive, tortured soul seeking fulfillment in work and in love, she died with a sense of personal defeat. Her greatest enemy, she felt, was time, and yet it was her greatest friend.

Stimulated by good weather and active buying of Easter apparel and accessories, retail trade here was very active last week. Estimates put department store sales at better than 25 per cent ahead of the corresponding week last year, with larger increases estimated for apparel specialty stores.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., March 28 -- All work in fine arts for both Haverford and Bryn Mawr Colleges will now be done at Bryn Mawr, it was announced today by President Marion Edwards Park. At the same time Miss Park announced the first joint faculty appointment made by the two schools.

Tuesday marks the twenty-fifth anniversary of the transfer of the Virgin Islands from Denmark to the sovereignty of the United States. Governor Charles Harwood has issued a proclamation declaring a holiday and appropriate ceremonies will take place on this occasion.

CLINTON, N.Y., March 28 -- Establishment of a memorial scholarship in tribute to David Green Adams of Caldwell, N.J., the first Hamilton College graduate to die in the service of his country during the war, was announced today by President Cowley.

Governmental control of industry will become more important than ever before in our economic set-up after the war, according to Dr. Carroll R. Daugherty, chairman of the department of economics at Hunter College, who announced yesterday that Hunter's curriculum has been completely revised to prepare students for changing conditions.

BATTLING with Germany even in the radio sphere, the Russian wireless rides the new Reich transmitter on 11.885 megacycles, and at 9:15 in the evening Kuibyshev eclipses Berlin. Hearty Cossack tunes blot out astronomical figures of Hitler's submarine and air successes; then, at 9:30, the scene shifts and English news from Soviet fronts is backed by German ditties.

MUSHROOMS have gone alcoholic in a certain city store. There you may take your choice of mushrooms in port or in sherry. The tiny buttons should be tidily impaled on toothpicks to occupy the place of prominence on your canape tray. Five ounces of either sort may be had for 69 cents . . .

MOST people think of an air force solely in terms of combat planes. But the fact is 55 to 60 per cent of an air force's plane strength is in training craft of various sorts. The finest combat planes in the world are worth nothing if experienced airmen to fly and fight them are not available, and airmen are trained in small planes the average person never hears about.
Ethelbert Smith found himself strongly impelled to the view that we need a statute of limitations on columnists. There were already too many of them, and there was no telling where it would all end.

THE newly formed Concert Orchestra of New York, composed of some thirty musicians, will give a series of programs on Monday nights, starting April 13, at the intimate Concert Theatre. Dr. Otto Klemperer and Laszlo Halasz will be the conductors, appearing alternate weeks.

Stressing the grave responsibility that is felt today by merchant ship operators for their part in the war, Basil Harris, recently elected president of the United States Lines, pointed out yesterday that merchant ships now are the life line of the fighting forces.

Establishment of a Food Administration, a single independent agency to coordinate and direct the operations of the food industry in the war effort, is being seriously considered by top government authorities and is likely to be announced in the near future, it was learned last week.

Although increased buying of tea by some food concerns has been reported by wholesalers in recent weeks, chain store organizations declared yesterday that they had noted no rush in retail tea buying as a result of the War Production Board order reducing by 50 per cent the amount of deliveries from tea packers to retailers, and suggesting a quarter pound limit for customers.
JUST as the atmosphere of the White House has altered with the progress of the war so, too, has the list of advisers on whom President Roosevelt depends. It has been shuffled and shortened.

GREENSBORO, N.C., March 28 -- The lesser lights of golf gave the game's big names a thorough beating in the $5,500 Greensboro open today and held the four first places at the halfway point in the seventy-two-hole event.

IT is difficult to determine the extent and kind of Patchen's influence on contemporary readers of poetry. That he is an original and important poet I myself have no doubt whatever. But the modern anthologies barely tolerate him and the critical books on modern poetry scarcely mention him.

THE poetic world has been in quite a turmoil of late, what with Archibald MacLeish trumpeting a confession of triviality, from the steps of the Library of Congress, and Van Wyck Brooks responding with a blast against "coterie writers" and other despicable triflers who have been hogging the poetic limelight.

NIGHT breaks up like an ice jam. Shoals of morning cloud slowly separate and move across the river of blue sky. The sun blinks through scrub pine on the horizon. Barracks stand out of shadow. Ruby lights on the water tower wink and die.

OTTAWA -- Next Wednesday Canadians will begin their first experience of war rationing. From that day it will be impossible to buy gasoline in the Dominion without a purchaser's license, or ration coupon.

New Yorkers will have an opportunity to see a survey of the work of Canadian artists of the past and present when an exhibition of Canadiana opens at the Grand Central Art Galleries under the auspices of the Maple Leaf Fund, Inc., on April 6.

CHUNGKING, China, March 28 -- Bitter hand-to-hand fighting between Chinese defenders and Japanese troops infiltrating into the southwest corner of Toungoo was reported today by the Chinese High Command here.

FLORENCE LAKE STATION is the highest in the Southern California Edison Company's hydroelectric system, which supplies light and power to Los Angeles. Here for nine years Lila Lofberg lived with her husband, the construction engineer operating the station, and, snowbound for eight months of the year, they found in the wild life about them compensation for the lack of human society.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 28 -- Few controversies have stirred the nation so deeply in recent months as the current controversy over the forty-hour week. From all over the country letters are pouring in on Congress from the folks back home, expressing strong views on the issue.

A PHOTOGRAPHIC mural, one of the largest made, covers an entire wall of Willoughbys, said to be the largest photographic store in the world. The scene is a birdseye view of New York City taken from the world's tallest building, the Empire State.

CHUNGKING, China, March 29 (U.P.) -- Chou En-lai, Chinese Communist leader and liaison agent in Chungking, gave an analysis today of future military possibilities based on his years of study of the Japanese war effort.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- With the bitter controversy over labor legislation hanging over the capital, the Senate this week will attend to a variety of wartime tasks, while the House begins an unofficial two-week Easter vacation.
The first home-and-home game of the Lewis Cup soccer series between Brookhattan and the New York Americans ended in a 2-2 tie at Starlight Park, the Bronx, yesterday, before a crowd of 3,000.

For sheer daring the British commando descent on St. Nazaire surpasses any similar raid of the war. Irrespective of immediate success or failure, so bold an answer to home demand for offensive action must lift the fighting spirit of the whole British people.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., March 29 -- Renewing his attack on the movement for a longer working week, Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, told several thousand textile workers here today that the campaign was designed to lower wages of war workers and to destroy protective labor legislation.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- A heavy Japanese attack was launched some time yesterday evening on the right center of Lieut. Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright's Bataan line, the War Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- American eyes were fixed last week on Australia and on the exotic lands and seas immediately to the north of that continent where United States and Japanese air forces were trading bomb for bomb.
The divine origin of the Bible is indisputable, the Rev. Arthur Franklin Williams, pastor of the First Baptist Church, Broadway and Seventy-ninth Street, declared yesterday morning in a sermon.

A rough idea of what the United States Government may be required to borrow through open-market operations in the final quarter of its fiscal year starting this week is ascertainable with a somewhat greater degree of accuracy now that the total receipts from income taxes this month are fairly well known.
LONDON, March 29 (AP) -- The old American destroyer that joined the British Navy and found death and glory at St. Nazaire went to her self-appointed end defiantly, her guns blazing.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The Missouri Pacific Railway Company and a subsidiary, the St. Louis, Brownsville Mexico Railway, have asked the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to sell $3,530,000 of equipment trust certificates.

A committee of the League of New York Theatres, consisting of Gilbert Miller, Brock Pemberton and Herman Shumlin, has recommended the rejection of demands by the Scenic Artists Union, after a meeting with a union committee March 13.

LONDON, March 29 -- The Chinese defenders of Toungoo continued stubborn resistance today in the eastern part of the city against the mounting invasion of the Japanese, according to a communique received here.

The two-story colonial-type dwelling with nine rooms and three baths at 39-05 223d Street, Bayside, Queens, has been sold by the City Bank Farmers Trust Company. The house is on an irregular plot about 77.2 by 207 feet and is assessed for $13,000, of which $4,000 is on the land.

PITTSBURGH, March 29 -- By raising its output of steel ingots one point last week to 98 1/2 per cent of rated capacity, the steel industry made a new production record in its all-out drive for war production. It is expected that the same level of operations can be maintained this week, owing to the slightly better flow of scrap material throughout the country.
CHUNGKING, China, March 29 (AP) -- The Chinese communique for the Burma front follows:

The stock market's rise and fall of last week about duplicated the swings of the period ended on March 21, and except for marked weakness in some of the high-priced issues, the week on balance offered no variety. Even in terms of business there was no choice from the preceding week, for the daily volume on the New York Stock Exchange appears to have been fairly well stabilized just above the 300,000-share mark.

Apparently so enfeebled by age that they could not walk the few steps to their well-stocked kitchenette, two 90-year-old twin sisters were found semi-conscious of malnutrition yesterday afternoon in their fourth-floor suite in the fourteen-story apartment building at 10 Sheridan Square, at the corner of Grove Street.

CLEVELAND, March 29 (AP) -- Employes of Jack Heintz, Inc., which was under fire at a hearing of the House Naval Affairs Committee in Washington last week, will receive each month, beginning April 1, a general wage increase in defense bonds worth $150 at maturity, William S. Jack, president of the company, said today.
The toll of dead or missing in the munitions explosions Saturday on Staten Island and at Bridgeport, Conn., rose yesterday to twelve.

Fritz Stiedry's arrangement for chamber orchestra of Bach's "Art of Fugue" was the offering at the season's final concert of the New Friends of Music, late yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. As at its premiere performance here a year ago under the same auspices, the work was conducted by Mr. Stiedry, and again Ernest Victor Wolff and Ignace Strasfogel, pianists, were the assisting artists.
SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 29 (AP) -- Barney McLean of Denver won the sixth annual Harriman Cup races ski crown today and with it the official international downhill and slalom combined championship.

A device designed to produce a vaporous fog that would obscure large industrial areas in the daytime and hide rivers and lakes to complete a night blackout will be tested this morning near the Navy Yard in Brooklyn, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday in his weekly broadcast over WNYC.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 29 -- With the inauguration of President-elect Juan Antonio Rios only three days away, evidence is accumulating that his administration will mark a significant shift to the Right from the Popular Front government of the late President Pedro Aguirre Cerda.

An adjustment is to be proposed for $47,769,000 of first and refunding 4 per cent bonds of the Delaware Hudson Company due on May 1, 1943, it was announced by J.H. Nuelle, president, in his report for 1941. The company controls the Delaware Hudson Railroad Corporation and various other railway and coal properties.
"Friendliness is the only power in this world that can really conquer a man," the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick declared yesterday in his sermon at Riverside Church.

PITTSBURGH, March 29 -- Westinghouse Local 601, United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, C.I.O., voted today at a mass meeting to adopt a proposal of international officers to waive some overtime pay, provided that the savings in labor costs be turned over to the United States Treasury.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 29 (AP) -Army rules under which a limited number of German and Italian aliens, and a handful of Japanese, may be exempted from exclusion orders and military curfew regulations covering military areas in the West were listed tonight.

The Penhoet shipyards at St. Nazaire, France, which are to the east of the Penhoet Basin at the port, are the largest shipyards in Continental Europe. There the French liner Normandie was built and it was capable of building and repairing the largest liners of the world.

An audience of 2,100 attended "Hebraica," the festival of Jewish arts which was presented last night in Carnegie Hall by the Long Island Zionist Region. The feature of the program was "Shabbat Kodesh," a liturgic cantata by Max Helfman which was presented by the Temple Emanuel Choral Society of Paterson, N.J., with the composer conducting.

Great Britain and France began by relying too heavily on the economic blockade of Germany. They did not recognize until too late the terrific power of offensive weapons and the offensive spirit. But if the United Nations can turn out these weapons in overwhelming quantities and maintain this spirit, they may take confidence in the knowledge that the economic blockade is still an added weapon not to be underestimated.
Lieutenant Ronald T. Lyman, U.S.N., and Mrs. Lyman of Boston have come to the Ambassador from Vienna, Va.
LONDON, March 29 -- Part of the Battle of the Atlantic is being fought out on land.

MOSCOW, March 29 -- The price Yugoslavia's White Russian colony is being made to pay by partisans and patriots for its share in the attempted sell-out to Germany is told in Yugoslav diplomatic circles here.

The Affiliated Young Democrats have decided to maintain a "hands-off" policy in the election of a leader of Tammany and will not support any of the aspirants for the leadership. This was said to reflect the attitude of the national Administration and New Dealers in Washington and have the approval of President Roosevelt.
The month of April will be an important one for sportsmen and those directly concerned with the preservation of wild life.

Steamships of the last line to carry passengers and freight to New England have just passed into control of the Government. This Providence line was the final survivor of the boats that plied to New Haven, Norwich, Stonington, New Bedford, Boston, Providence. The Old Fall River boats, relics of the plush-romantic age, passed away, not unsung.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 29 (AP) -- The R.A.F. issued the following communique:

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- More than 2,500 merchants of fine and coarse paper have been asked to enter into voluntary arrangements with the Office of Price Administration to maintain maximum wholesale mark-ups for many fine and coarse paper items comparable to those now generally used in the trade.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 29 (AP) -- Spectators at the American Bowling Congress tournament got a thrill today when Edward Copenhagen of Rochester, N.Y., rolled ten straight strikes. As Copenhagen's string lengthened on the scoreboard, spectators flocked to seats behind his alley.

Announcement that the War Production Board was setting up regional offices operating under a single head in each region and aiming at decentralization was welcomed by business men here, but they were skeptical of beneficial results unless there is real decentralization.

The benefits of an occasional illness -- say once a year -- are so obvious that it is a reproach to the medical profession that more publicity hasn't been given to the matter. The ailment must not be too severe; but it must be grave enough, of course, to have caused some preliminary anxiety and to make necessary the luxury of having the doctor call at the house.

Strong public support of the New York Catholic Charities annual campaign for funds for its 200 health and welfare agencies was urged yesterday by Joseph T. Higgins, district Collector of Internal Revenue.

DETROIT, March 29 -- Oldsmobile and Packard have taken the lead among automobile manufacturers in developing war-time programs to stimulate the productivity of their workers by increasing their interest and pride in their jobs.
BERLIN, March 29 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, March 29 (U.P.) -- Diplomats and members of Congress tonight hailed Britain's offer of Dominion status to India as a vital contribution to the United Nations war effort and a concrete application of the principles of the Atlantic Charter.

CHICAGO, March 29 -- The wheat market continues under the domination of influences which, in normal conditions, might have little efect as price-making factors. However, the Senate is not expected to consider the House bill to limit sales by the Commodity Credit Corporation to parity prices until late in April or early in May, so that vague reports as to possible legislative action are likely to cause erratic price changes in the open market.
Savings banks and trust companies were principals in several of the city realty transactions reported over the week-end.

WHEN a poet comes to the defense of athletes, it should be inscribed so that he who runs may read. The following letter came from David Morton, the distinguished poet and Professor of Literature at Amherst College:

The report for 1941 of the Continental Oil Company, released for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $15,398,082 after all charges, taxes and reserves, equal to $3.29 each on the 4,682,565 capital shares outstanding. For 1940 the company had reported a net income of $4,317,657, or 92 cents a capital share.
Commander Gilbert P. Chase, U.S. Navy, retired; Haanel Cassidy, in Sutton Hall, 1075 1st Ave.

The old customer who paid his bills promptly is indicated as the favored outlet in the filling of orders by manufacturers, according to the preliminary findings of the recently completed manufacturers shortage survey conducted by the research and statistical division of Dun Bradstreet.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 29 -- Dispositions tantamount to general mobilization in Bulgaria during the last twenty-four hours have presented the German High Command a mixed blessing of some 200,000 Bulgarian troops -- the Balkans' finest -- for use under German "technical" advisers, ostensibly on the Eastern Front against the Russians.

Bill Tilson saved the day for the New York Rovers yesterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden. Not only did the speedy wingman account for the "hat-trick," but his third marker, coming at 6:05 of a ten-minute overtime period, broke a 4-all tie and enabled the Red Shirts to top the Boston Olympics, 5 -- 4, in an Amateur Hockey Association of the United States play-off.
Eight new films are scheduled to reach Broadway screens this week. The line-up follows:
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The heaviest snowfall in Washington's records for two decades crippled the capital's traffic today and felled thousands of trees lining its streets.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices remained constant at the previous week's level of 103.8. There were a few minor price changes among the sub-groups, but these were so small that they had no noticeable effect on the broader indexes.

The crowds of Broadway are no different from the multitudes of Jerusalem for which Jesus expressed compassion on the first Palm Sunday, the Rev. Dr. Allan Knight Chalmers, pastor of the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, at Fifty-sixth Street, suggested in his sermon yesterday morning.

The anti-trust policy announced by the President, as a result of a memorandum to him signed by the Attorney General, the Secretary of War, the Secretary of the Navy and Thurman Arnold, is so obviously in accordance with the dictates of common sense that it must meet with general acceptance.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., March 29 -- Word has been received here of the death in the Philippines of Major Joseph A. Cleary, whose mother, Mrs. John W. Cleary of 192 Fairview Avenue, became uneasy about him when he failed to respond to a message cabled to him on March 19, his thirtieth birthday.

Thomasina Talley, young Negro pianist from Nashville, Tenn., who, after studying three years at the Juilliard School of Music, is now working for a doctorate in music at Columbia University, yesterday afternoon gave her first New York recital at Town Hall.

Christ's triumphal entry into Jerusalem, His betrayal, passion and crucifixion were commemorated yesterday in a two and one-quarter hour traditional solemn ceremony witnessed by 3,800 persons at St. Patrick's Cathedral.
JAMES T. FARRELL, glumly as is his way, adds more panels to the Farrell record of the times in a book of short stories* published this morning.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Vice President Wallace declared tonight that charges, made public today by Representative Dies, chairman of the committee on un-American Activities, and accusing thirty-five officials of the Board of Economic Warfare as having records of affiliation with Communist-front organizations, attempted to raise "doubt and anger" in the public mind which "might as well come from statements of Goebbels himself."

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 29 (AP) -- When Japanese bombers attacked yesterday at Port Moresby, New Guinea, heavily outnumbered Australian fighters took to the air and downed five of the accompanying Japanese fighters, said reports from the town.

CHICAGO, March 29 -- The fifth annual all-breed fixture of the International Kennel Club closed tonight as Mrs. M. Hartley Dodge of Madison, N.J., awarded best-in-show to the Pekingese Ch. Che Le of Matson's Catawba, owned by Mrs. James M. Austin of Westbury, L.I., and handled by Ruth Burnette Sayres.

BOSTON, March 29 -- After being spotted three early goals which Jack McGill tried to erase by performing the difficult "hat trick," the Red Wings broke an ancient jinx by defeating the Bruins, 6 to 4, in the opener of their two-out-of-three National Hockey League semi-final play-off series for the Stanley Cup tonight before 13,100 spectators at the Garden.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 29 -- If it is true that coming events cast their shadow before, Charley Ruffing is in for a lot of first-inning trouble this year. In his second start in the citrus belt, the big redhead today faced the Cardinals and, as was the case against the Tigers last Tuesday, Ruffing took a pounding in the opening frame.

Your Washington dispatch of March 19, reporting the tax program just sent by the American Federation of Labor to the House Ways and Means Committee, does scant justice to an unusually well-reasoned document. The A.F. of L.'s comments upon the Treasury Department's proposals to tax all outstanding State and municipal tax-exempt securities and to forbid the future issuance of such bonds are of particular interest to every one who believes in preserving local self-government.

NEW ORLEANS, March 29 -- The return of mills to the spot market for considerable actual cotton, topped off by a statement attributed to high officials of the Commodity Credit Corporation that consumption of cotton in 1943 might reach 13,500,000 bales, gave impetus last week to an advancing cotton market after prices had turned up earlier on poor crop advance reports and widespread assertions that American war production was attaining a colossal scale.

In a notice of the reclassification of all aliens, including enemy aliens, by their draft boards, published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of March 20, no mention was made of the classification of Austrian nationals.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 29 -- Jed Harris, Broadway producer who joined RKO last September, will leave the studio without having made any pictures, it was learned today. No reason for his resignation could be obtained, but it is expected that he will return to stage production.

Under the title "Beware the Sixth Column," the American Federation of Labor placed an advertisement in this morning's newspapers charging that an unfair campaign was being waged against President Roosevelt and the organized labor movement in demands for abolition of the forty-hour week, accompanied by accusations that labor was not doing its part in the war.

Corporations, labor unions and all other groups must lay aside selfish interests and cooperate whole-heartedly in winning the war, Adolf A. Berle Jr., Assistant Secretary of State, declared last night. He spoke at the annual dinner of the New Leader at the Hotel Commodore before 1,000 persons active in the labor movement and the American Labor party.
ROME, March 29 (From Italian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command communique follows:

The Stuyvesant String Quartet, a group known for its recordings of important contemporary and ancient works, gave its debut recital last night in Town Hall. Its personnel consists of Sylvan Shulman, first violin; Maurice Wilk, second violin; Emanuel Vardi, viola, and Alan Shulman, 'cello, all of whom are members of the NBC Symphony Orchestra.
The following Helsinki communique was broadcast by Trans-ocean, German news agency:

CHUNGKING, China, March 29 (U.P.) -- Chinese troops have broken through a Japanese encirclement at Toungoo and now, from positions in the eastern suburbs, are warding off an increasing flow of Japanese reinforcements in a violent battle that has been raging unabated since Friday, dispatches from the front said tonight.

- gavotte composed by one of] the founders of the New York Phil- I harmonic-Symphony Orchestra recently has been discovered by one of his descendants and it will beI played for members of the Phil-t harmonic-Symphony League at aI special concert for them at theI Hotel Plaza on April 7.

CHICAGO, March 29 -- With trading in lard futures at a virtual standstill because of price ceilings, traders in provisions and packers of meats are paying more attention now to the distributing business.

ALBANY, March 29 -- The possibility that neither the legislative nor the Congressional reapportionment bills will even be put to a vote during the current session was admitted here today as legislators began to realize that only two days remain in which the measures may be introduced.

VICHY, France, March 29--France is threatened with a bread shortage and needs 3,000,000 quintals of wheat to meet the deficit, Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, Chief of State, said tonight in a broadcast to the peasants, asking their cooperation in the crisis. [A quintal is 220.46 pounds avoirdupois.]

I should like to comment on one aspect of the "Forty-Hour Week War" which I feel requires clarification. In many of your editorials, and in many statements by those who would suspend the Fair Labor Standards Act, the argument is presented that the purpose of this act was to spread employment.

The National Football League schedule of fifty-five games extending from Sept. 13 to Dec. 6, partly drawn up during the three-day convention at the Hotel Commodore that ended on Saturday, was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Representative Hamilton Fish said today that State Senator Allan A. Ryan Jr., who yesterday announced his candidacy for Mr. Fish's House seat, would be serving his country better if he enlisted in a combat outfit rather than running for a "safe job in Congress."
HACKENSACK, N.J., March 29 -- Early morning accidents in Bergen County today caused four deaths and injuries to three persons.

DETROIT, March 29 -- Leaders of the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., asailed today what they called a "vicious, studied campaign" on the part of Congressional and financial interests to strip labor of its gains.

PEARL HARBOR, Oahu, Hawaii, March 29 -- This is the story of Lieutenant Edward H. O'Hare, 28-year-old American naval flier who, flying in South Pacific skies as a guard over an aircraft carrier a few weeks ago, single-handedly tackled a squadron of attacking heavy planes, shot down five and damaged a sixth, and thus accounted for an estimated $500,000 worth of enemy aircraft and thirty airmen.
LONDON, March 29 (AP) -- A communique from Combined Operations Headquarters said:

The Philip Barry comedy, "Without Love," which has Katharine Hepburn and Elliott Nugent for its protagonists, is not yet ready for Broadway, according to an official source. That is the main reason why the Theatre Guild offering is being kept out of town and will not be brought here until all factors concerned agree.

Ackman Brothers, brokers, have obtained for the Walbern Realty Corporation a ten year $285,000 first mortage at 4 1/4 per cent on the recently completed six-story apartment house on the southwest corner of Valentine Avenue and East 192d Street, the Bronx.

Packaged goods continue to be the reliance of the advertising field for maintained expenditures this year, despite the obvious increase in service and institutional campaigns in industries hit by shortages. At the present time the food and drug industries are going through a packaging and product transition and it will probably be Fall before this changeover is completed.

Quite apart from questions of revenue, it is clear that corporation profits on war contracts ought to be limited. When ceilings are being put upon prices and ceilings are being contemplated for wages, it is natural that there should be a demand for a "ceiling" on profits. Yet the nature of such a ceiling is extremely important in its effect on our war effort.

AT GENERAL MacARTHUR'S HEADQUARTERS, in Australia, March 29 (U.P.) -- United Nations army officers revealed tonight that plans were being made for landings on Japanese-controlled islands in an offensive -- already under way but still in low gear -- to drive the enemy out of the Southwestern Pacific.

The taxpayer property at 16-20 South Lexington Avenue, between Main Street and Martine Avenue, White Plains, Westchester, has been sold by Alice M.L. Vier to the Charuth Realty Company in a deal negotiated by William J. Sherry, broker.

VICHY, March 29 -- The question of the method of settling the economic relations which will be established after the war continues as the chief topic of discussion here. It is an even more timely topic among the different Allied nations whose relations have been profoundly modified by the war, and thus has raised the question of an international money to be used in common by American States.

A whole city full of youngsters with bright and shining faces is the ambitious ideal of a young woman with a Fifth Avenue beauty clinic. Little people, she believes, are all too eager to brush their teeth and wash behind their ears, if approached in a diplomatic manner.

Reviewing the history of the Free Synagogue since its inception in 1907, Dr. Stephen S. Wise declared yesterday in his sermon in Carnegie Hall that it had remained faithful to its ideals of a free pulpit supported in democratic and voluntary fashion.

GREENSBORO, N.C., March 29 -- Samuel Dewey Byrd, a Georgia-born ball player turned professional golfer, won the $5,500 Greensboro open today with a seventy- two-hole score of 279, five shots under par.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The trend of average residential bills for electric current in cities of 50,000 inhabitants or more has been steadily downward since 1924, according to a report made public today by the Federal Power Commission, but the rate of decrease was less in 1941 than in preceding years.

NEWARK, N.J., March 29 -- Albert W. Hawkes of Montclair, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce and head of Congoleum Nairn, Inc., of Kearny, expects to announce his candidacy for the Republican nomination for United States Senator early this week, it was admitted today by friends of the industrialist.

LONDON, March 29 -- Thirty thousand persons massed in Trafalgar Square today and heard speakers declare Britain should launch a second front or otherwise embark on strong offensive action to ease the pressure on Russia.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The War Department communique based on reports received until 1 P.M. said:

The Long Island University rugby team defeated the Queens Rugby Club, 12 -- 3, at Park Field, Astoria, yesterday in the opening contest of the season for both teams. The score was tied, 3 -- all, at the intermission, Jim Conners tallying for Queens on a penalty kick, Thomas Cardacci carrying over for L.I.U.

VICHY, March 29 -- The statement of the Bank of France for the week ended on Feb. 26 shows an increase of 1,500,000,000 francs in ordinary advances to the State, but advances of only 97,000,000 for the costs of occupation by the German armies. There were only unimportant variations in credits accorded to the security markets with the exception of a decrease of 105,000,000 francs in advances on bonds.

If Mahatma Gandhi said it is "a postdated check," he gave the best definition of the British offer to India. It is not an undated promissory note, like previous vague pledges that India's demands for self-government will be satisfied after the war. The proposal announced yesterday by Sir Stafford Cripps differs from anything suggested heretofore, by specifying clearly the terms and time of settlement of the empire's No. 1 problem.

Winning their three matches in the four-team round-robin competition on their home strips, members of the Salle Santelli A squad yesterday captured the metropolitan open electric epee fencing championship.

NEW DELHI, India, March 29 (AP) -- Accepting at face value reports of the death in a Japanese airplane crash of their one-time Nationalist colleague, Subhas Chandra Bose, the venerable Mohandas K. Gandhi and the Congress party president, Maulana Abdul Kalam Azad today paid tribute to the man rated by the British as a potential fifth columnist.

LONDON, March 29 -- It was an offer of complete independence and equality in the British Commonwealth of Nations as soon as the war is won, with the right of ultimate secession, that Sir Stafford Cripps took to India, the government announced tonight in disclosing for the first time the carefully guarded details of the plan for protection of racial and religious minorities, as unanimously approved by the War Cabinet.

One thousand Yugoslav-Americans, representing fifty organizations in the United States, pledged themselves to work for the defense of America and for the liberation of their mother country at a rally yesterday in Arlington Hall, 23 St. Marks Place, under the auspices of the Union of Yugoslav Americans.

More than 5,000 persons attended special Palm Sunday services yesterday morning at the Episcopal Cathedral of St. John the Divine. It was the largest gathering of worshipers since the opening of the one-tenth-mile-long nave several months ago.

PITTSBURGH, March 29 -- The jurisdictional dispute within the American Federation of Labor at Acme Fast Freight, Inc., which has halted delivery of 100 tons of vital war materials for nearly a week, has been cited to Representative Howard W. Smith, co-psonsor of the Smith-Vinson bill as an example of a condition which William Green, president of the A.F. of L., testified on Thursday did not exist.

The National Free Browder Congress ended its two-day sessions yesterday by urging President Roosevelt, in a resolution approved by 12,000 persons at three meetings, to exercise Executive clemency and "immediately release" Earl Browder, general secretary of the Communist party, who has served one year of a four-year sentence in the Federal Penitentiary at Atlanta, Ga., for having used a passport containing a false statement.
MOSCOW, March 29 (AP) -- The Soviet Bureau of Information issued the following:

Lawrence P. Lindeloff, international president of the Brotherhood of Painters. Decorators and Paperhangers, A.F. of L., with headquarters in Lafayette, Ind., yesterday notified officials of District Council 9 of the union, covering Manhattan. Richmond and the Bronx, of revision of the union's rules, removing restrictions on the movement of union members to war jobs in various parts of the country.

Naval censorship wisely forbids the publication of news about the fighting ships in our harbor. But it is divulging nothing of value to the enemy to report that USO-Camp Show units are occasionally playing on salt water in the crew's mess-room of ships that happen to be in port.

Professor Henry P. Van Dusen of Union Theological Seminary, Broadway and 120th Street, outlined yesterday morning "three of the deepest secrets of human existence: the ways of men, the way of God and the way of victory," and interpreted them in the light of the current world crisis.

Founder's Day in honor of Isaac Mayer Wise, founder of Reform Judaism, was observed yesterday afternoon in the Central Synagogue. Fifty-fifth Street and Lexington Avenue, with a special service under the auspices of the Greater New York City Alumni of the Hebrew Union College.
MIAMI, Fla., March 29 -- Melvin Ott and his Giants concluded six weeks of training here on a high note today by wrenching a ten-inning struggle from Lou Boudreau's Indians, 3 to 2.

A story of American heroism and skill is being written in the skies above Burma by the Flying Tigers -- the American Volunteer Group of pilots, trained and led by Brig. Gen. Claire L. Chennault, U.S.A., retired, one of the greatest fliers our Air Corps ever had. Though his men have been limited by circumstance to ammunition for only a few bursts, they have employed it with deadly effect.

BERNE, Switzerland, Monday, March 30 -- Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's Red Army forces appeared this morning to have won the first round in a general drive along the entire southern front in Russia from Kharkov to the western end of the Kerch Peninsula of the Crimea.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 29 -- The Senators blew into City Island Park today boasting a four-game winning streak and a citrus circuit record of fourteen triumphs in seventeen starts. But the Dodgers, with Curt Davis and Whit Wyatt pitching, snapped the victory string, triumphing by 6 -- 1.

Down on South Street, two sprawling barnlike buildings form the nucleus of the Fulton Fish Market. There, almost beneath the shadow of Brooklyn Bridge, wholesale dealers, who may usually be recognized by their thick rubber boots, sell more than 150 kinds of fish each year, in amounts that total about 300,000,000 pounds.

MOSCOW, March 29 -- Red Army troops have won a five-day battle against a strong German force carrying out a counter-attack against the tip of a Russian wedge thrust deep into the German lines on the northern part of the central front -- the Kalinin Province sector.

LONDON, March 29 -- The stock markets here long abandoned looking to Prime Minister Winston Churchill for bull points and consequently they were not disturbed seriously last week by his fresh reminder that grim, testing times are not far ahead. There was, nevertheless, some downward drift of prices following his statement that the Battle of the Atlantic had become more serious again for the United Nations.

Last-minute calls for a variety of apparel needed by stores for pre-Easter selling, and increasing difficulty in filling orders for many items due to material scarcities, were reported in a summary of last week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buyers.

Defeating Matthew Green in a sensational upset after 24 moves of a Sicilian defense, Harry Baker maintained his lead in Section A of the United States Chess Federation championship preliminaries at the Marshall Chess Club yesterday. It was the first outright loss for Green since the beginning of the tournament.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- There need be no consumer shortage of tea this year "if housewives are not panicked into hoarding," according to Benjamin Wood, managing director of the Tea Bureau, central organization for the United States tea industry.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The War Department issued its first casualty list tonight under the new governmental war news policy, disclosing that Army casualties in the Pearl Harbor attack Dec. 7 numbered 226 killed and 396 wounded.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 29 -- While the railroads of New England will do "everything we can within the limitations of equipment to provide transportation for New England's recreational industry this Summer," there probably will not be enough rolling stock to meet the demands, Laurence F. Whittemore, assistant to the president of the Boston Maine Railroad and the Maine Central Railroad, said today.

AT GENERAL MacARTHUR'S HEADQUARTERS, In Australia, March 29 -- United States Negro troops, whose presence here could not be mentioned in dispatches until today have been well received. The ban was lifted with the announcement by Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson at Washington that Negroes made up part of the American Army in Australia.

LONDON, March 29--The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, was 110.3 on March 17, compared with 110.3 a fortnight before, 109.9 a month before, 104.3 a year before and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

CHICAGO, March 29 -- The market for corn has been showing a strong undertone for several weeks, with the result that the discount of that grain under wheat has narrowed. Many speculators are said to have bought corn and sold wheat on the belief that the domestic situation in corn was growing in strength, due to excellent demand for that grain for feeding and industrial purposes.

Maintenance and expansion of the work of the National Youth Administration was urged yesterday, in contradiction to recent criticism of the organization, in a report submitted by the New York City and Long Island Advisory Committee of the NYA to S. Burns Weston, director of the NYA National Advisory Committee in Washington.

Sharpshooting by Alex Shibicky and Lynn Patrick last night kept the New York Rangers in the running for the Stanley Cup and the hockey championship of the world. A pair of tallies in the first session by Shibicky and a brilliant scoring achievement by Patrick in the final chapter enabled the blue-jerseyed athletes to turn back the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3 to 1, at Madison Square Garden.

SILVER CREEK, N.Y., March 29 -- Jackie Swanson, 17, of Buffalo, who gained nation-wide publicity a little more than a year ago as "the apple boy," was arrested by State police today in connection with a lunch-car hold-up.

Pleading for national unity as a weapon essential to defeat of the nation's enemies, Father John P. Boland, chairman of the State Labor Relations Board, yesterday cited the "complete unity between the legislative and administrative branches" of the government in this State as an example of how to maintain industrial peace during the war.
THE TIMES states in its issue of March 24 that there is to be a hearing by a Senate committee on Thursday with regard to conditions on our merchant vessels.

LONDON, March 29--A British ship flying the Royal Navy ensign at half mast came into port today with a load of wounded commandos. From these and others the story of St. Nazaire began to be pieced together as a combined naval, commando and Royal Air Force raid in which the objectives were attained at a cost of many dead and wounded left behind.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 29 -- How much does France pay Germany each day for the upkeep of the Army of Occupation? A measure of mystery has surrounded the question for many months, but the veil now seems raised and the upshot is that the sum remains at 400,000,000 francs a day, of which 100,000,000 francs are paid in foreign currencies.

VICHY, March 29 -- Complete results of the conversions of the 4 per cent rentes of 1925 and the 4 1/2 per cent rentes of 1937 have been reported to the Treasury as the date for cash redemptions has passed. The operation was regarded as entirely successful for reimbursements reached 5,400,000,000 francs, or 20 per cent of the total, while new subscriptions for the 3 1/2 per cent rentes produced 5,625,000,000 francs.
NEW DELHI, India, March 29 -- The text of a statement issued today by Sir Stafford Cripps on British proposals to Indian leaders follows:

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- In its efforts to conserve rubber without in any way impairing the efficiency of the vehicles which it already has or will receive in the future the War Department has availed itself of the services of Sheldon P. Thacher to direct the rubber conservation program of the Army Quartermaster Corps Motor Transport Division.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- In its efforts to conserve rubber without in any way impairing the efficiency of the vehicles which it already has or will receive in the future the War Department has availed itself of the services of Sheldon P. Thacher to direct the rubber conservation program of the Army Quartermaster Corps Motor Transport Division.

ALBANY, March 29 -- In a report to Governor Lehman, made public today, Robert M. Benjamin makes recommendations for legislative reforms in the existing system of judicial review of quasi-judicial determinations of fact by State administrative agencies, and for legislative and voluntary changes for the improvement of administrative procedure in those agencies.

The Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York has been oversubscribed, Leon Fraser, general chairman of the appeal here, announced yesterday. As of Saturday night a total of $7,491,000 was in hand, Mr. Fraser said, or $191,000 more than the quota set for the metropolitan area in the national campaign to raise $65,000,000.

AN ENGLISH PORT, March 29 -- Lieut. Gen. A.G.L. McNaughton, commander of the Canadian forces in Britain, declared in an interview today that Germany should be attacked on the European Continent by Dominion and British forces at the first "proper opportunity."

SOMEWHERE IN NEW JERSEY, March 29 --In the streamlined, low-slung plant of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation Propeller Division several hundred women today are tussling with tools. Two months ago not a single nose was being powdered in the production room.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 29 -- Lord Beaverbrook, in the United States to speed lease-lend aid to the Allies, tonight singled out the Russian Front as the one on which "the hopes of humanity" were centered and urged that all possible supplies be sent to this "most critical battlefront in the history of civilization."

LONDON, March 29 (AP) -- R.A.F. planes swept across the hazy English Channel today in their mounting Spring offensive, following a night in which Luebeck, the most important German port in the Western Baltic Sea, was subjected to heavy attack.
THE TIMES states in its issue of March 24 that there is to be a hearing by a Senate committee on Thursday with regard to conditions on our merchant vessels.

With volume too small to be indicative of any trader or investor reaction, the stock market continued to drift narrowly yesterday, with final prices steady. Business on the Stock Exchange contracted to the lightest since May 19, 1941, and to the second tightest session since August, 1940, as sales aggregated 229,290 shares, against 313,440 on last Friday.

DETROIT, March 30 -- So critical is the housing shortage in this expanding arms center that the Federal Government will have to spend more money providing homes for workers at the Ford bomber plant than it did in building the plant itself.

At a time when money can be saved by the city administration -- and the Mayor says that ways must be found to economize -- something comes up that indicates that public money is to be wasted in the hundreds of thousands of dollars.

Announcing the winners of a short story contest in which 2,492 entries were submitted by writers under the age of 30, the editors of Mademoiselle Magazine declared yesterday that a survey of the entries revealed an encouraging change in the writing patterns of younger writers.

ALBANY, March 30 -- The proposed Congressional Reapportionment Bill, dividing the State into forty-five Congressional districts in place of the present forty-three districts and two Representatives-at-large, was made public here tonight.

The wage increases sanctioned by President Roosevelt's emergency board late in 1941 cost the Gulf, Mobile Ohio Railroad $452,000 in that year and will cost $1,700,000 annually, I.B. Tigrett, president, said in his report for 1941, issued yesterday.
ALBANY, March 30 -- An amendment to the rules affecting law students was announced today by the Court of Appeals.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Earnest hope was expressed today by Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, that a satisfactory solution would be found for the Indian question. Mr. Welles would make no other comment on the proposals of Sir Stafford Cripps, but moderate Indian opinion in Washington was inclined to approve them and to be optimistic about their acceptability.

AT GENERAL MacARTHUR'S HEADQUARTERS, in Australia, March 30 (U.P.) -- Port Moresby dispatches received today said that a forty-inch rainfall in the Markham Valley in Northeast New Guinea had driven the Japanese back twenty-seven miles to their beachhead at Lae, cutting short their drive through tropical jungles in the direction of Port Moresby, the Papuan town that could serve them as a springboard for attacking Australia.

Councilman Stanley M. Isaacs, who introduced the air raid protection bill that was disavowed by Mayor La Guardia last Sunday, said yesterday that he could not understand the Mayor's repudiation, "unless it is viewed as another of those mysterious mistakes for which he is fast becoming famous."

BERNE, Switzerland, Tuesday, March 31 -- Russian tanks, cavalry and infantry, supported by strong formations of parachute troops, were reported in Moscow broadcasts this morning to have crushed German positions atop important heights southwest of Vyazma on the central front and to have closed the entrance to the Vyazma pocket after forty-eight hours' intensive fighting.

A former president of Local 32E of the Building Service Employes International Union, who said he wanted to be an honest and conscientious labor official but who ended his labor career by mulcting the union and Bronx landlords of $100,000, will be sentenced today in Bronx County Court for attempted grand larceny.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The most recent Japanese assault on the defenders of Bataan Peninsula and the Manila Bay fortifications settled down today into persistent bombing, but lessened ground activity, the War Department reported in a single communique.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 30 -- Foreign Minister Enrique Ruiz Guinazu of Argentina, who arrived last midnight as the head of a special delegation for Thursday's inauguration of Juan Antonio Rios as President of Chile, called on Senor Rios this afternoon to the accompaniment of great pomp and ceremony.

A method of creating artificial fog to hide vital military and naval installations was tried out not far from the Navy Yard in Brooklyn yesterday. Army and Navy officers and representatives of the Police and Fire Departments who were present declined to comment on its effectiveness, but other observers said the fog was almost immediately dispelled by the wind.

The War Production Board yesterday halted the manufacture of a long list of table or plug-in electrical appliances effective on May 31, except on priority orders above A-2. This will actually be a boon for many manufacturers, who otherwise would have been compelled to stop manufacturing of numerous appliances today, it was pointed out yesterday by distributors.

In a letter printed on this page today Maurice P. Davidson, trustee of the State Power Authority, defends the construction of the Government's thirty-million-dollar power line from New York to Massena, though it will have little or no surplus power from these parts to transmit, and this on the one ground that we need all the aluminum that we can produce.

Prices of active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange approached yesterday the twelve-year high marks set in January as the cotton market extended its gains for the sixth consecutive session. Prices advanced 18 to 25 points in late trading, but profit-taking near the close pared these gains to 12 to 19 points.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The Inter-American Defense Board, composed of military, air and naval representatives of all the American republics, convened here today for the first time to undertake the task of complete unification of hemisphere defenses.

LIMA, Peru, March 30 (U.P.) -- The Spanish Embassy, representing Axis interests in Peru, announced today that two United States vessels sailing from Callao next month would carry Axis diplomats and citizens on the repatriation journey from four Latin-American countries.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 30 -- In preparing Westchester County for a surprise blackout of long duration the County Defense Council filed tonight a critique of the March 15 blackout, listing twenty-two defects that included unfriendly dogs chasing air raid wardens and inquisitive politicians overrunning alarm centers.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The Senate today, by a vote of 74 to 0, passed and sent to the House legislation granting substantial pay increases to enlisted men and the lowest grade officers in the Amy, Navy, Marine Corps and other uniformed services.

Up at Union College in Schenectady there is unpleasant medicine brewing for the journalists, economists and military experts of the nation. Seventy sophomores are devoting the second part of the college year to a study of the prophetic gift as exhibited by various publications and individual writers.

LONDON, March 30 (U.P.) -- British sources today accepted the creation of a Pacific War Council in Washington as a logical sequel to the appointment of General Douglas MacArthur as United Nations Commander in the Pacific theatre, which is now "primarily an American-Australian show."
BERLIN, March 30 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique said today.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Notable rulings defining the power of the States to control peaceful picketing by labor unions were handed down today by the Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The Treasury recommended today to the Ways and Means Committee, as provisions to achieve a more equitable distribution of the larger tax load the public will be called upon to bear, that a limited deduction be allowed for family medical expenses and that the credit for minor children be extended from 18 to 21 years where the dependent in college.

A large subscription already has been reported for the performance of John Steinbeck's new play, "The Moon Is Down," the night of April 8 at the Martin Beck Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the Kips Bay Boys Club. Mrs. Olmsted Houghton is chairman and Mrs. Richard C. Berresford, vice chairman, of the committee in charge of the sale of tickets for the benefit.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- Army has won the fifteenth annual national intercollegiate rifle team championship with the third highest total in the history of the matches, the National Rifle Association announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Secretary Morgenthau said today that the legal division of the Treasury Department was studying silver legislation to determine whether the department could "lend" silver for use in the war production program.

In two decisions on union picketing yesterday the Supreme Court upheld unanimously in a New York City case the right to picket against a system involving the peddling of bakery products and ruled 5 to 4 that Texas could bar picketing in areas not directly related to the labor dispute in question. [1:1.]

By winning in the two heavyweight contests that ended the program, New York defeated Chicago, 9 to 7, for the first time in eight years in last night's intercity Golden Gloves amateur boxing bouts. The event, held in Madison Square Garden under the sponsorship of The News Welfare Association, attracted 16,571 spectators.

GENEVA, Switzerland, March 30 -- The March issue of the League of Nations' monthly statistical bulletin, just issued, contains a special table giving some indications of the balance sheets of national banks throughout the world, with particular emphasis on their advances to their respective governments since the war began in September, 1939.

Our local chapters of the Red Cross have not only raised their quota of $7,300,000 but gone over the top to the tune of more than $200,000. That means a contribution of slightly more than a dollar from every man, woman and child in the city, a record to be proud of.

Buses were substituted for trolley cars on the Hamilton Avenue line in Brooklyn on Sunday by the Board of Transportation, it was learned yesterday. An order issued on March 25 by the Office of Defense Transportation in Washington forbidding the replacement of trolley cars by buses except with the specific approval of the ODT will go into effect tomorrow.
An otherwise uneventful inspection trip of some of the trout waters that are usually focal points on opening day in this State terminated in the midst of a snowstorm.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 30 -- James Cagney and his producer-brother, William Cagney, today signed a contract with United Artists for the production of five films for U.A. release in the next three years. They also announced the formation of Cagney Productions, of which they are the sole owners.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 30 -- Forty-two Japanese-owned high-powered launches, each fitted with radio, were tied up by the authorities at Sao Paulo today, pending a ruling by the Department of Justice and military officials on disposition of the boats.
TORONTO, March 30 -- It's do or die for the Rangers tomorrow night when they tangle with the Maple Leafs in the sixth game of the National Hockey League's Stanley Cup semi-final play-offs.

Morgan J. O'Brien, former Presiding Justice of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, who died in June, 1937, at the age of 85, left a gross estate of $958,566 and a net of $889,341. This was learned yesterday in a transfer tax proceeding in which Surrogate James A. Foley set the New York estate tax at $34,351.

KUNMING, China, March 30 (U.P.) -- Two Netherland submarine officers, among the few United Nations war prisoners to escape from Japanese prison camps, said on their arrival here today that their captors had tried liquor, an offer of "girls" and finally third-degree tactics in a futile attempt to learn military secrets.

One of the interesting financial aspects of the 1941 annual report of the Cities Service Company concerns itself with the source of income of the parent concern. Last year Cities Service received $9,1575,110 in the form of interest on bonds and indebtedness it which owns in subsidiary companies.

Citing the record already achieved in meeting both war and civilian needs by the textile industry, Sidney Scheuer of Scheuer Co. yesterday asserted that the industry can continue to do this if existing specifications for the armed forces are eased.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- Francis B. Sayre, High Commissioner to the Philippines, released today the names of more than 1,500 persons, mostly Americans, interned in Manila and said that the International Red Cross was attempting to obtain the appointment of a Swiss citizen to act as its representative there.

PITTSBURGH, March 30 -- Shipments of vital war materials consigned to local defense industries remained frozen today on the docks of Acme Fast Freight, Inc. Acme's North Side terminal has been shut down a week by a jurisdictional dispute between two American Federation of Labor unions.

A loft property in midtown and another in the Franklin Square area, the former shadowed by the Empire State Building and the latter by the Brooklyn Bridge, were among the Manhattan realty parcels changing hands in the deals reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Ezequiel Padilla, the Mexican Foreign Minister, who captured the imagination of and exeercised a deep influence on the Conference of American Foreign Ministers at Rio de Janeiro in January through his espousal of continental unity, arrived here today for an official visit, declaring that the solidarity of the Americas has a meaning for the future, especially if the war proves to be a long one.

LONDON, March 31 -- Pictures of St. Nazaire, French-occupied port, taken since Friday's British naval and Commando raid, show clearly that the outer gates of the big drydock were destroyed and that the explosive-laden destroyer Campbeltown had vanished, a naval officer who was on the raid said here today.
