General Wladyslaw Sikorski, Premier of the Polish Government-in-Exile, addressing a group of nearly 200 American writers and journalists at the Princeton Club last night, asserted that Hitler is "Enemy No. 1" in the present world conflict and called for the opening of a second Allied front and unstinted aid to Soviet Russia.

A speedy guilty verdict in General Sessions late yesterday afternoon against two Negro robbers by the first all-women jury in a criminal trial in this city, was accompanied a few minutes later by considerable verbal pyrotechnics set off by some of the fourteen women who had listened to the evidence.

ALBANY, March 30 -- The State Federation of Women's Republican Clubs went on record this afternoon as favoring the proposal for a Women's Army Corps as outlined in a House bill introduced by Representative Edith Nourse Rogers of Massachusetts.

Out of the jungles of Peru comes a new color for fingernails -- a warm, sunburned red with deep brown undertones. This glossy polish, inspired by the fluted, copper-toned orchids that blossom in the deep recesses of the tropical forest, is one of the most sophisticated shades we have seen in some time.
Stimulated by war business, two automobile manufacturers showed large earnings last year, according to their annual reports issued yesterday.
Faced with the loss of male employes to the armed services, several savings banks have started to employ women tellers, the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York reported yesterday.

Seasonal phenomena being close to the rim of censorable material these days, it may be best to give only the sparest details of an occurrence yesterday traditionally associated with the arrival of Spring.
LONDON, March 30 -- Sentiment in the stock markets was strengthened today by Britain's proposals to India, but the approach of the announcement on the budget kept business in check.

If only because of the deep satisfaction with which this news will be received in Australia, yesterday's announcement of the creation of a Pacific War Council in Washington would be good news. It is no secret that the Australians have been dissatisfied with an arrangement which, in effect, made them mendicants at the table of the two strongest Powers among the United Nations, Britain and the United States.

Clarifying the recent order of Federal Works Administrator Philip B. Fleming eliminating all "non essentials" in the planning and construction of public works under the current $300,000,000 program, John M. Gallagher, regional representative of the FWA for New York and New England, explained yesterday that no sacrifices would be made at the expense of safety and utility.

WITH THE UNITED STATES ARMY, in Northern Ireland, March 30 (AP) -- A message from President Roosevelt on White House stationery to every member of the United States forces here arrived at headquarters today for distribution to the soldiers.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- A head-on clash between the United States Steel Corporation and the Congress of Industrial Organizations on the union security issue brought a new crisis in Federal handling of labor relations today. The probability is that the National War Labor Board's decision in the case will determine the effectiveness in handling industrial disputes for the duration of the war in the absence of a definite policy enunciated by Congress.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities found itself under the floodlights of Congressional controversy again today after its chairman, Representative Dies, had made charges against employes and officers of the Board of Economic Warfare, headed by Vice President Wallace.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 30 -- Although no consequences are yet forthcoming from the meeting last Thursday at Randan, near Vichy, between Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, Chief of State, and Pierre Laval, the "heir apparent," whom he deposed in December, 1940, there is reason to believe that their conversation may soon be followed by a revelation of what is to replace the policy of "collaboration."

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- "Mere enactment" of the National Labor Relations Act could not prevent Wisconsin from dealing with an industrial dispute through her own much discussed Employment Peace Act, the Supreme Court ruled today.

BERLIN, March 30 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command announced today an attack by German destroyers against a Murmansk-bound. United Nations convoy protected by a "strong, superior" force of cruisers and destroyers.

Benefiting by the war's stimulation of all business, the Mead Corporation in 1941 had net sales of $32,452,148 and 440,602 tons of product, compared with $24,506,440 and 358,948 tons in 1940, the increase in dollar sales being 32.4 per cent, George H. Mead, president, reported yesterday in the annual statement to stockholders.

On the heels of the Guthrie incident, charges appeared yesterday that "business as usual" was still winning over efforts at all-out production when the largest bathrobe manufacturer in America asserted that his efforts to ban the use of wool in bathrobes as unnecessary resulted in a realignment of committees in which others interested in maintenance of wool use in that industry were permitted to prevail.

Under the terms of the armistice in June, 1940, France agreed to pay 400,000,000 francs a day as the costs of the German Army of Occupation. Germany was able to use these occupation costs in two ways. Since they amounted to far more than actual costs, a large part was used to buy up control of French industry.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 30 -- Dr. Frank F. Marino, 42 years old, member of the New Rochelle Zoning Board of Appeals and former member of the local Board of Education and the Westchester County Board of Supervisors, was accused here today of having performed a criminal abortion that caused the death Saturday of Miss Cleo F. Moore, 19, a juke box company employe.

A banking group headed by B.J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., received yesterday the award of $1,267,000 of city of Camden, N.J., refunding bonds on a bid of 100.65 for the obligations bearing interest at the rate of 3.40 per cent. The bonds, dated Jan. 1, 1942, and maturing from Dec. 1, 1967 to 1970, were reoffered at a price to yield 3.25 per cent.

Plans were filed yesterday for new residential buildings in the Bronx and Queens and for several alteration jobs in Manhattan and Brooklyn. A group of eleven one-family homes to cost a total of $41,800 is slated to be erected in the Flushing-Hillcrest area of Queens by the M. P. Homes Corporation, according to the specifications submitted by D.J. Levinson, the architect.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Creation of a Pacific War Council that will sit in Washington was announced today by President Roosevelt. The member nations are the United States, Australia, New Zealand, China, the Netherlands, Canada and Great Britain. Speaking through Stephen T. Early, his press secretary, the President said:

CHICAGO, March 30 -- The grain and soy bean markets turned up sharply today after a brief period of weakness at one time. Corn assumed market leadership on buying by houses with Eastern connections and professional traders induced by the continued strength in hogs and cotton, and prospects that there would be a material expansion in the use of this grain by distillers.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- By a majority of 8 to 1, the Supreme Court today interpreted the Wagner act to mean that a company and a labor union could not agree on a closed-shop contract if the company had aided the union with "unfair labor practices."

GENERAL WAINWRIGHT'S HEADQUARTERS, Bataan, March 30 (U.P.) -- American artillerymen again have bested the Japanese in a savage duel that resulted in the wounding of Lieut. Col. Lester J. Tacy of Virginia Beach, Va., after he had shown the greatest heroism in trying to save a brother officer.

NEW DELHI, India, March 30 -- Britain's eleventh-hour plan for India went through the political mill today and will again tomorrow as the leaders of the conflicting parties and sects try to digest it with the speed recommended by Sir Stafford Cripps.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Zippers lawn mowers and electrical appliances all fell under manufacturing restrictions of the War Production Board today as that war agency scanned civilian industries in which critical materials are being consumed.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 30 -- Reorganization of the Westchester County Board of Supervisors under the "weighted vote" plan, which would give voting strength to each Supervisor in proportion to the citizen population he represents, was approved this afternoon by the County Board by a vote of 33 to 4.
Several of the current exhibitions and others about to open in New York galleries have been organized as benefits. In most instances proceeds go to various war relief funds.

At ceremonies this afternoon at the War Defense Center of the American Jewish Congress, 50 West Sixty-eighth Street, Mrs. Stephen S. Wise, on behalf of the women's division of the organization, will present a check for $160,000 to Mrs. Lytle Hull, State vice chairman of the New York Defense Savings staff, for the purchase of defense savings bonds.

While Paul J. Kern, deposed president of the Civil Service Commission, was testifying yesterday before the Bronx Grand Jury about the paving of the Belgian courtyard on the Lake Mahopac estate of Edward J. Flynn, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, Borough President James J. Lyons and Robert L. Moran, his Commissioner of Public Works, were being questioned by city investigators on Mr. Kern's charges of "irregularities" in the Borough President's office.

In his annual report on the state of the cinema, Will H. Hays, president of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America, yesterday outlined the functions of the screen in wartime and reviewed the program of self-regulation begun by the industry in 1922 with the creation of his association.

In his preface to a forthcoming collection of short stories. "A Story to Tell" (Scribner, April 13), Peter Fleming, author of "Brazilian Adventure," beats reviewers to the draw by pointing out that if he were to sit in reviewing judgment on the thirteen stories he would accuse the author of pre-occupation with the coup de theatre and a pursuit of the dramatic twist.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 30 -- There was no note of apprehension in Joe McCarthy's 1942 farewell to St. Petersburg tonight.
Passover, the Jewish holiday commemorating the escape from the bondage of the Pharaohs, will begin at sundown tomorrow with the Seder service so rich with tradition.

The Alec Coppel murder-mystery, "I Killed the Count," should come to a local Shubert house sometime in late April, Agnes Morgan reported yesterday. She and her associate, Frank Carrington, will be coproducers and codirectors of the English-made melodrama which they presented at the Paper Mill Playhouse at Millburn, N.J., late in 1940.

With the opening of the New York racing season little more than a week away, the Board of Stewards of the Jockey Club announced yesterday the appointment of officials for the forthcoming campaign. The thoroughbred sport will get under way a week from Thursday at Jamaica.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Use of General Douglas MacArthur's picture in advertisements supporting alleged anti-labor legislation was protested today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, who asked Henry L. Stimson, Secretary of War, to take official action "to prevent further abuses of the same nature."

Artur Rodzinski, Fritz Reiner, Alexander Smallens, Howard Balow and Efrem Kurtz have been engaged as the conductors for the twenty-fifth season of concerts by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium this Summer, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer, chairman of Stadium Concerts, Inc.

ALBANY, March 30 -- Assemblyman Frank J. Caffery, Democrat, of Buffalo, has received letters from Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, and a representative of Prime Minister W. L. Mackenzie King of Canada urging the start of construction on the power part of the St. Lawrence Seaway project as an essential war need.

ALBANY, March 30 -- The Senate voted 44 to 4 tonight to continue for another year the Rapp-Coudert legislative committee investigating the education system of the State and the subcommittee investigating subversive activities in The York City schools.

Ralph Prisco, 27 years old, of 141 Mott Street, nephew of Raffaele Prisco, Chevalier of the Royal Crown of Italy and former East Side banker, was shot dead by a policeman yesterday in the doorway of a drug store at 307 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, after an attempted hold-up.

AT GENERAL MacARTHUR'S HEADQUARTERS, in Australia, Tuesday, March 31 -- The creation of a Pacific War Council at Washington, which was announced simultaneously here and in Washington, apparently has given the Australians just what they wanted.

Frederic Delzell, young director of music at Avon School in Avon, Conn., made his New York debut as a conductor last night at the Concert Theatre, leading the American Symphony Orchestra, an ensemble of thirty members of the Alumni Association of the National Orchestra Association.
CHICAGO, March 30 -- For the first time in nineteen months the highway death toll decreased in February, the National Safety Council reported today.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 30 -- Osservatore Romano, the Vatican City newspaper, published today the following statement regarding the establishment of diplomatic relations between the Holy See and Japan:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 30 -- A strong United Nations convoy on the way from New York to Murmansk, Russia, was attacked three times by German dive-bombers and warships -- twice on Saturday and once yesterday -- it was announced officially in Berlin tonight.

Sites on the New Jersey side of the harbor are being studied for a union grain terminal elevator with a storage capacity of 7,000,000, according to the annual report of the Port of New York Authority, which was made public yesterday.

DOVER, N.J., March 30 -- That the women of this country are eager to do their part in the war is clearly seen in the daily mail of Major L.C. Bessom of Picatinny Arsenal, who is swamped with offers by women who want to work in this defense industry.

Substantial decreases in accidents, deaths and injuries in traffic cases in the city were reported yesterday by the Safety Bureau at Police Headquarters for the last week, as compared to the corresponding week a year ago.

Carl Pilnick, City College champion, qualified last night in Section C of the United States Chess Federation championship preliminaries. He defeated Louis Persinger in an irregular queen's pawn defense in seventy-three moves at the Marshall Chess Club.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 30 -- All Japanese nationals and Japanese Americans living in two critical areas near Terminal Island at Los Angeles will be notified tomorrow that they are to be evacuated over the week-end to the new assembly center at Santa Anita race track.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 30 -- Jake Freedman's Homeward Bound, who had failed to make good in half a dozen previous starts in Florida this Winter, came through with a photo finish triumph in the Normandy Isle Purse at Tropical Park today.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 30 (AP) -- Ray Hultquist, 28-year-old Chicagoan, after getting only nine pins in the first frame of his last singles game, rolled eleven straight strikes to score 279 and boost his three-game total to 735 for the lead in that event today.

As the budget makers and purchasing agents of their community, American women must play a vital role in furthering the sale of Defense Savings Stamps and Bonds, Mrs. Lytle Hull, State vice chairman of the New York Defense Savings Staff, said last night.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 30 -- Six hundred and twenty Danes are in a concentration camp that, although nominally Danish, is under close control of the Germans, according to a reliable witness, who has just reached Stockholm from Denmark.

PITTSBURGH, March 30 (U.P.) -- Harry Bobo, Pittsburgh Negro with a dynamite right, short-circuited the comeback attempt of Lem Franklin, Cleveland Negro, tonight with a knockout in the first round of a heavyweight bout scheduled for ten rounds.

Plump Long Island ducklings that are superlatively tender and richly flavored will make their first appearance of the season today in butcher shops throughout the city. These birds are aristocrats in duckdom, belonging to a celebrated strain known among the experts as the White Pekin.

" ONLY ONE STORM"* is ex-Communist Granville Hicks's return to the bourgeois world. It is also an excellent novel of ideas, with good, vital, colloquial talk running down almost every page. The talk ranges from portentous theorizing about international politics to gossip about the fight that followed a game of Post Office at a village party.

Basketball coaches, officials and players parked their cares in their feet beneath the festive board at the sixth annual dinner of the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association at the Hotel Abbey last night. After being kind to the court fraternity for the entire season, the scribes let go with every barrel in an ungenerous production they called "Foul Shots of 1942."

Maurice E. Rogalin, principal of the William Howard Taft High School, who was suspended last Wednesday by the Board of Education, was charged yesterday with accepting money, an automobile and other articles from teachers who received special assignments and exemptions from the dual job law that gave them extra income.
Following is the text of the address to the people of India broadcast yesterday by Sir Stafford Cripps from New Delhi, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

PHILADELPHIA, March 30 -- Gloria Dei Church, one of the landmarks of Philadelphia, was first used for services July 2, 1700, but the chronology of the Congregation goes back to 1669, when the first services were conducted in an old log blockhouse on the site of the present edifice.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 30 -- An eleventh-inning single by Billy Herman, his first hit after drawing twenty-one blanks, ended an overtime session with the Browns and gave the Dodgers a 5-4 triumph today.
ALBANY, March 30 -- Agreement on the main State Defense Bill was reached here this afternoon by Governor Lehman and the Republican legislative leaders and it is to be speeded into law.
William Withers in your issue of March 22 says: "England relies much more heavily on the income tax than we do. We have many more hidden excise taxes which bear heavily upon the poor."
MOSCOW, March 30 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau broadcast this communique today:

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended March 25: Decreases of $144,000,000 in holdings of Treasury bills, $91,000,000 in "other securities," $330,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, $436,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and $220,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.
May I inject an academic note into the controversy relating to the effect of the forty-hour base for payment of standard-rate wages?

A national effort to conserve vital building materials need in connection with war work has been started by the American Institute of Architects and the Producers Council, national organization of manufacturers of building materials and equipment, in cooperation with the War Production Board, acocrding to Richard H. Shreve of New York, president of the institute.

TRENTON, N.J., March 30 -- Meeting today in joint session, the Legislature elected Senator Robert C. Hendrickson, Gloucester County Republican, State Treasurer for a term of three years at $6,000 annually.

WITH CHINESE ARMY on the Toungoo Front, March 28 (Delayed) (AP) -- Disregarding danger from Japanese bombers and wild Dacoit tribesmen, an American missionary still is marshaling food supplies for the Chinese armies in Burma at an often-bombed Baptist agricultural school behind the front.

A human chain of office workers was formed on the ninth floor of 1372 Broadway yesterday to rescue Joseph Pasker, 44 years old, a window cleaner who was left dangling below the window when one end of his safety belt slipped.

Producers of woven elastic webs declared here yesterday that sharply expanded output at an early date of gas mask straps and elastic surgical bindings is likely to result from the War Production Board's sudden freezing of all rubber yarn and elastic thread stocks, announced to take effect at midnight on March 29.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Beginning with May, only monthly bank debits figures will be collected by the Federal Reserve Board; weekly bank debits statements will be discontinued after issuance of the statement covering the week ended on May 6.

Two Italians who have worked for years on Italian-language newspapers in this city were arrested yesterday and taken to Ellis Island, apparently for violations of paroles they had given to refrain from activities inimical to the welfare of the United States.
AN artist and a dramatic critic were talking over the recent Louis-Simon session of fisticuffs. They were not satisfied with the action of the referee, who, they thought, stopped it prematurely.

The procedure to be followed by a registrant for Selective Service who needs extra time to settle his personal affairs, after he has passed the Army physical examination and been found acceptable for induction, was explained last night by Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, city draft director, in a radio broadcast from Station WNYC.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 30 -- The Giants had a chance to square their series with the Indians today, but faded before the southpaw slants of Chubby Dean and Harry Eisenstat and swallowed their second shut-out in three days. The count was 2 to 0. Incidentally, it was a pair of Cleveland left-handers, Al Milnar and Al Smith, that blanked the New Yorkers on Saturday.

The Timken-Detroit Axle Company and all United States subsidiaries made a net profit of $2,966,152 in the six months ended with December after all deductions, including income and excess profits taxes and $1,000,000 provision for possible future inventory losses.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- President Roosevelt signed the bill lifting the debt limit to $125,000,000,000 and the bill to limit the base pay of $21 a month in the Army and Marine Corps only to those of the seventh grade.
Furs that escaped looking bulky through the use of dressmaker touches were featured yesterday by Gunther's in the presentation of advance fashions for Spring, the Summer and early Fall.

HOLLYWOOD, March 30 -- Lew Ayres, the movie actor who made his greatest hit in "All Quiet on the Western Front," based on Erich Maria Remarque's anti-war novel, left Hollywood tonight in the upper berth of a tourist sleeping-car for a conscientious objectors' camp at Cascade Locks, Ore.

Underhill Center, Vt., which is under the western flank of Mount Mansfield and a good place to be right now, reports that this "looks like a grand good maple-sugar year." The sugar bush is being tapped for all it is worth, and it is worth, in terms of sugar, about 50 cents a pound.

Sixty-eight exhibition games sent teams from one major league against those from the other in the first month of grapefruit circuit Competition, and for this period they are neck and neck, with each league owning thirty-four decisions, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

The three insurance groups that have been writing war-damage insurance for several weeks are ready to align themselves behind the plan drafted by a committee of the National Association of Insurance Agents for practical ways and means of cooperating with the $1,000,000,000 Federal War Damage Corporation, it was learned yesterday.

While coat and suit label sales last week were 20 per cent under those of the previous week they were the largest for the period since compilation of the figures, began in 1936, the National Coat and Suit Recovery Board announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The war labor legislation issue, temporarily sidetracked in the House by the Easter vacation, flared up in the Senate today, when demands for action brought from Senator Barkley a strong plea that Senators, in the interests of national unity, forego seeking to raise such a controversial question now.

A German submarine commander knew the home port, destination and cargo of a small United States merchant ship torpedoed off the Atlantic coast, according to two survivors of the vessel who were taken aboard the U-boat for questioning and later placed on life rafts.

" Gone With the Wind" will return to Broadway for the third time today when it begins a popular-priced engagement at the Astor Theatre. . . . "Broadway Big Shot" and "West of Tombstone" compose the week's new double bill, beginning today, at the New York Theatre. . . .

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that it had bought more than $800,000,000 of food and farm products in the first year's operation of the lease-lend progam. Most of the products were bought for shipment to Great Britain, Russia and other United Nations.

Whether he bleat or roar, old man March has behaved remarkably well in the engagement which ends today. He has given us nearly twice as much rain as usual. Of snow he has been unusually frugal. He has saved the city a lot of money. Taking note of the scarcity of rubber, he has issued few requisitions for overshoes.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, March 30 (U.P.) -- The Brazilian Government today imprisoned 200 Axis spies and suspected espionage agents in South America's first concentration camp, situated on Ilha das Flores in Guanabara Bay, near here, while police carried out further round-ups.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 30 -- Fourteen thousand "victory gardens" are being planted in Westchester County to grow food for home use and permit the channeling of regular farm produce into the war machine, according to Michael E. Buckley, coordinator or the projects and head of the Westchester Farm Bureau.

LONDON, March 30 -- The bitter fight for Toungoo in Burma must now be considered a rear guard action and the main battle will take place farther north, in the direction of Mandalay, a Chinese war communique issued in Chungking said today.

LONDON, March 30 -- The government's recent decision to tighten censorship regulations has caused considerable alarm here among foreign correspondents and among those who foresee further encroachments on the freedom of the press.

LONDON, March 30 (U.P.) -- The growing battle for control of vital northern supply routes flared with new violence today. The British reported two more German supply ships sunk or damaged and Germany reported a clash in the Arctic.

Henry Lockhart Jr., chairman of the board of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation, was re-elected yesterday to that office and made chief executive officer of the company. J.F. Metten, formerly president and chief engineer, was elected vice chairman of the board, and R.S. Campbell, formerly vice president and general manager, was made president and general manager.

The Associated Mortgage Companies, Inc., of Baltimore, announced yesterday a plan of liquidation involving $17,299,170 of twenty-year debentures due 1953. The 7,000 holders are invited to submit tenders on May 1. Interest on the debentures, but not the principal, is guaranteed by the United States Fidelity and Guaranty Company of Baltimore.

British rule in India, if only India herself so wills it, has come to an end. No other meaning can be read into the text of the War Cabinet's proposals; much less into the candid words of Sir Stafford Cripps's radio address of yesterday. One of the great revolutions of all history has taken place, peaceably, in the midst of war.

W. Alton Jones, president of the Cities Service Company, reported yesterday that the company had a consolidated net income of $14,283,892 last year, an increase of $4,355,864 over 1940. Gross revenues of the system increased to $260,947,398 from $238,690,169.
LAKELAND, Fla., March 30 (AP) -- Buck Newsom, Detroit holdout pitcher, has been sold to the Senators, General Manager Jack Zeller of the Tigers announced tonight.

Throughout 1941 the American-Hawaiian Steamship Company continued to divert its ships into defense and war activities, Edward P. Farley, chairman of the executive committee, declared yesterday in the annual report to stockholders.

ALBANY, March 30 -- State Senator Allan A. Ryan Jr., who on Saturday announced an intention of seeking the nomination for the Republican Congressional seat in the Twenty-sixth District, now held by Hamilton Fish, declared hero today that he did not intend to engage in "personalities or political egg-throwing antics" with Mr. Fish.

Your March 23 editorial "Local Aluminum" reaches the strange and unjustified conclusion that because of a tentative decision to build a new aluminum plant in New York City, where a power surplus is available, it is now "clearly unnecessary" to complete the transmission line to provide power for operation of the new aluminum plant now nearing completion at Massena.

It was panda-monium time at the Bronx Zoo yesterday. The baby giant panda, sent from Tibet as Mme. Chiang Kai-shek's gift to the United China Relief last year, celebrated her first birthday with a party at the zoo, and it was party to end all parties.

CHICAGO, March 30 -- Maybe it is because the tangible aspects of war are so few here in these States whose tributaries flow into the Father of Waters; only a trace of uniforms in the street crowds; no sirens; no blackouts; and lodging and transportation not seriously affected, as in the East.

Tracing large shipments of sugar to a six-story building operated as a "warehouse" at 447 West Thirty-sixth Street led yesterday to a raid on one of the largest illegal stills discovered in this city since prohibition. Six men found at work in the building were held on Federal charges of violating the Internal Revenue Act.

LONDON, Tuesday, March 31 (U.P.) -- The Daily Mail said today in a Bombay dispatch that Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, leader of the All-India Congress party, had thrown his support to the British proposals.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under the direction of John Barbirolli joined with Yehudi Menuhin, the violinist, to act as hosts at a party for the benefit of the Red Cross at Carnegie Hall last night. The hosts made music, and the guests, who paid their way in, listened delightedly and then behaved as if they had bought a bargain.

A report published yesterday by the Welfare Council disclosed that 245,335 persons in this city received public or private assistance in February. There were 109,148 persons on home relief and 58,951 on WPA.

Members of the United States, Canadian and British armed forces, when in uniform and traveling on furlough or leave at their own expense, will receive a 10 per cent reduction on meals served in dining cars or other equipment of eighteen Eastern railroads, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Continuance of the Civilian Conservation Corps to release soldiers from non-combatant duty and permit their training in combat activities was urged before the Senate Education and Labor Committee today by Major Gen. James A. Ulio, judge advocate general of the Army and War Department representative on the CCC.

The imaginative art of table-setting the latest field to be affected by the war. Battleships were placed beside brides and napkins were stacked in the form of a red cross in the contest-exhibit of twelve tables set by women's clubs of this area that opened yesterday at R.H. Macy Co.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- The Nazis have taken a lesson from the secret radio broadcasters who heckle them and have set up an "American Freedom" station.

The ballet will have a Roosevelt exponent when Theodora Roosevelt, granddaughter of Theodore Roosevelt, goes to South America to make her professional debut there as a dancer with Alexander Iolas as partner. It was announced yesterday that the two would appear at the Copacabana in Rio De Janeiro on May 2 for a ten- week engagement.

The sale yesterday of $10,000,000 of first mortgage bonds by the Union Electric Company of Missouri was marked by the closest competition for a utility issue since the enactment of the competitive bidding rule by the Securities and Exchange Commission last May. Lehman Brothers headed the syndicate that won the issue and to the amazement of many in Wall Street paid more for the bonds than their existing market bid price.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 30 -- Air Minister Arthur S. Drakeford, reviewing United Nations air operations in recent weeks, said today that they had established local superiority over the Japanese in New Guinea and New Britain -- a superiority "as marked as any throughout the Pacific war, with the possible exception of air operations at the opening of the Burmese campaign."
RALEIGH, N.C., March 30 -- North Carolina State got ten hits off three Cornell pitchers today to spoil the season's opener of the Ithacans. The score was 8 -- 2. It was also State's first game.

William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, clashed yesterday with Henry Feinstein, president of the Federation of Municipal Employes of 261 Broadway, over the latter's demand for investigation of an alleged credential mill for prospective city employes.

The failure of the attempt to convict former Premiers Daladier and Blum and their three co-defendants at Riom of anything that would seem a crime in a civilized country is now partially confessed. The trial is to be suspended for two weeks, perhaps in its present form forever.

Norman Lessing, undefeated in seven rounds, and Harry Baker, with an equal score of 5 1/2 -- 1 1/2, earned places in the United States Chess Federation finals, to be contested at the Hotel Astor this month, when they drew their last game in Section A at the Marshall Chess Club yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., March 31 -- The signing of the Toolan bill today by Governor Charles Edison paved the way for the employment of thousands of women on night shifts in New Jersey defense plants, it was asserted here by Samuel Steinman, a mediator for the State Mediation Board, who helped to obtain passage of the measure.

The validity of 200,000 New York City traffic summonses was upheld yesterday afternoon by Magistrate Edmund L. Palmieri in an eight-page decision that said that the personal signature of Chief Magistrate Henry Curran did not have to appear on the tickets.

BOMBAY, March 31 (U.P.) -- Provincial dispatches said today that seven Indians were killed and fourteen injured in two Hindu-Moslem clashes and a riot precipitated by hostilities between Moslem factions.
KANSAS CITY, March 31 (AP) -- A reform administration buried under a heavy vote today remnants of the old T.J. Pendergast Democratic machine, which it swept from the City Hall two years ago.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- In the opinion of diplomatic observers in Vichy, former Vice Premier Pierre Laval may be called back to office in the near future. Such is the construction put by these observers on the meeting of Marshal Henri Philippe Petain with his former Vice President of the Council in Randan last Thursday.

CHUNGKING, China, March 31 -- In reply to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's telegram commending him and his men for their gallant stand, General Tai An-lan, division commander at Toungoo, reports that since the fighting began March 19 more than 5,000 Japanese have been killed up to last Sunday.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Senate brushed aside today an effort to attach wartime labor regulations to pending small business legislation, but leaders were reported reliably to be considering a program which would provide early debate on the subject.

Some costlier perfumes may disappear from the American market for years but there is little likelihood of an acute shortage in the total supply of oils available for making perfumes, soaps and creams, according to an article entitled "Oils of Araby," appearing in the April issue of "Agriculture in the Americas," monthly publication of the Office of Foreign Agricultural Relations.

Accounting and recovery of an amount which may run to $80,000 or $100,000 was ordered by Judge John Bright in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York in the action brought by Adele D. Trounstine, executor for Norman S. Goldberger, against Bauer, Pogue Co., Inc., and Frederic R. Bauer over a security deal in 1933.

When Albert Stoessel and the Oratorio Society first presented an unabridged B minor Mass of J. S. Bach in 1927 the audience was of modest proportions. When the same work was given last night in Carnegie Hall, for the sixteenth time by this organization without cuts, the auditorium was crowded to its uttermost capacity.

LONDON, March 31 -- Brendan Bracken, Information Minister, explained today the new censorship rules. The day after Mr. Bracken received a deputation representing the Association of American Correspondents in London, asking clarification of the new regulations, Mr. Bracken said:

BERNE, Switzerland, March 31 -- Why Pierre Laval saw Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, Chief of State, last Thursday near Vichy continues to interest foreign circles here and various rumors still circulate. They vary according to the source and throw little further light on the situation.

Declaring that the United States was in the "most dangerous period of its history," Lieut. Col. Paul T. Logan, assistant chief of the Subsistence Branch, Office of the Quartermaster General, United States Army, yesterday called on every business organization in the country to contribute in some form or other to the war effort.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Under an order issued today by the War Production Board, the person who needs tooth paste or shaving cream must proffer an empty tube which formerly contained these products to the storekeeper when he asks for a new supply.

TROY, N.Y., March 31 -- Miss Helen M. McKinstry, a former physical education administrator in New York City, became acting president of Russell Sage College today. She has been director of the College School of Physical Education for thirteen years.

The Boeing Airplane Company and its subsidiary, but excluding the Canadian subsidiary, had a net profit last year of $6,113,144 including $3,317,224 proceeds of sales of engineering and other information and manufacturing rights.

Sales of United States savings bonds by all agencies other than postoffices in the Second Federal Reserve District in March amounted to $98,000,000 as of March 30, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. As sales on the final day of each month nominally are heavy, the business done on March 31 may lift the total for this district close to $100,000,000.

Increased retirement of public utility bonds lifted the total of bonds called before maturity for payment in March to $131,349,000, the largest monthly figure since December. This compares with $81,920,000 in February, and $336,186,000 in March, 1941.

PHILADELPHIA, March 31 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation had applied for permission to merge the Northwestern Ohio Natural Gas Company into the Ohio Fuel Gas Company.

DETROIT, March 31 -- The Detroit Red Wings entered the final round of the Stanley Cup hockey play-offs tonight with a 3-to-1 victory over the defending champion Boston Bruins in the second game of the best-out-of-three semi-final series before 13,525 fans, largest crowd ever to see a game here.

The underwriting syndicate headed by Lehman Brothers that won on Monday the award of $10,000,000 of Union Electric Company of Missouri first mortgage and collateral trust 3 3/8 per cent bonds, due in 1971, in competition with seven other bidders, will offer these bonds to the public today at 109 7/8 and accrued interest, to yield 2.871 per cent. The group got the issue on a bid of 109.28011.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 31 -- Prime Minister John Curtin today cabled Richard J. Casey, who is relinquishing the Australian ministership to the United States at midnight, and expressed the government's great regret over his resignation as severing direct ass ociation with the Commonwealth, adding:

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Donald M. Nelson warned labor and management tonight that they were on trial before the American people, and "this is our last chance to show that a free economy can survive." His message to industry and the workers was contained in a foreword to a supplement to the War Production Board's master plan for its production drive.

RIOM, France, March 31 (AP) -- Former Premier Edouard Daladier, one of five leaders of the defeated French Republic on trial for responsibility for France's defeat, shouted an angry warning today that, although France had bowed to Germany in this war, "it will not always be the same ones who get licked."
BERLIN, March 31 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- A German High Command communique said today:

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Sales of wholesalers at $310,126,000 in February were 34 per cent above February of last year, the Department of Commerce reported today. This was slightly less than the gain of 37 per cent for January.

HAVANA, March 31 -The Iorro Castle lighthouge w in operation again tonight as the blackout was totally suspended in Havana. It is expected that the government will institute test total blackouts within the near future.

Fifty-six winners in twenty-four classifications in the annual All-America Package Competition were announced yesterday by Modern Packaging Magazine, sponsor of the contest. Some 20,000 packages, displays and shipping containers from all parts of the United States and Canada were entered.

As March slipped into history last night these facts became a part of the record: There were only four Broadway openings during the month, as against six during the same period last year, but there were only four casualties, as compared to ten in March, 1941.

City policemen, FBI officials admitted yesterday, are engaged in a check-up of 256,000 aliens of enemy nations in this city. This fresh move to choke off possible fifth-column activity in the city was started on Saturday, according to P.E. Foxworth, local head of the FBI.

Mr. Roosevelt has earned the thanks of all antiquarians by declaring Gloria Dei or Old Swedes Church in South Philadelphia a national historic possession. There are no Finnish, no Dutch, structures, it is said, in Pennsylvania. The Swedes have been more fortunate. There are log cabins of theirs near Philadelphia. They were the originators of this style of building.

So widespread is the suffering which marks the wake of this war that the relief made possible through the United Jewish Appeal must now be distributed on five continents. Fugitives from Hitler must be cared for not only in Europe, the Near East and North Africa but in great numbers both in the United States and South America.

William B. Stokely Jr., president of Stokely Brothers Co. of Indianapolis, yesterday announced consummation of the capital readjustment plan approved by stockholders in January and the inauguration of dividends on the new $20 preferred stock, which is being issued in exchange for the old 7 per cent convertible and non-convertible preferred shares.

On April 29, 1941, Senator Barbour introduced in the Senate a bill to reorganize the trustee board of Howard University. This bill, S. 1407, was introduced at the request of the Alumni Association of Howard University, who recognized that the trustees were operating under an archaic system and needed to be brought in line with modern trends in the field of education.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- Senator McKellar asked James J. McEntee, director of the Civilian Conservation Corps, today to check with his field offices and supply the Senate Education and Labor Committee with data on how many young men had applied for CCC enrollment since the Japanese attacked Pearl Harbor.

A dismaying flood of opposition to the Cripps offer reveals the outstanding political leaders of India juggling with catchwords while an evil destiny marches steadily nearer. Pandit Nehru, the Congress party spokesman, belittles his own wisdom and courage when he denounces the British proposal because it "involves no transfer of control and direction of Indian defense to Indian hands during the war, even though it demands full Indian cooperation in the war effort."

Patrick Candido, secretary of the Press Photographer's Association of New York, has purchased from the Crestwood Homes, Inc., the new colonial house at 217 North Clayton Road, Greenburgh, in the Scarsdale-Longview section of Westchester County.

STONY POINT, N.Y., March 31 -- The last bitter-end fighters of the original 300 residents of Sandyfields, pre-Revolutionary hamlet nestled in the hills just west of here, who battled the State in an effort to keep their village from becoming a lake in the Bear Mountain-Harriman State Park, gave up the struggle today and settled with the Palisades Interstate Park Commission for $42,713 for the only remaining property not previously condemned.

"Boobs," not sabotage, are responsible for many factory fires, Magistrate Frank Giorgio told six men who were before him yesterday charged with smoking cigarettes in war factories in Long Island City.

"Young America Paints" is with us again, the present edition, set up at the Museum of Natural History, being the seventh annual. This remarkably broad survey of children's art has been installed, as usual, in the large Hall of Education. It opens with a preview this afternoon between 5 and 7 o'clock and to the public tomorrow morning.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., March 31 -- "Our fliers in the Far East are knocking five Japanese airplanes out of the air for every one of their own planes lost," Robert A. Lovett, Assistant Secretary of War for Air, told workers at the Republic Aviation Corporation plant here today.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Willful violators of OPA rationing orders and regulations face direct prosecution and severe penalties under provisions of the Second War Powers Act, Acting Price Administrator John E. Hamm warned today.

Although the volume of trading on the New York Stock Exchange in March was slightly larger than that of the previous month, with its smaller number of business days, activity was at its slowest pace since the Summer of 1940, and also was the dullest for a corresponding month since 1918.
An exhibition and sale of anti-Axis cartoons for the benefit of Russian War Relief were opened yesterday evening to an invited audience at Saks-Thirty-fourth Street.

The Ski Union of the Americas, consisting of the national ski associations of Bolivia, Chile, Canada and the United States, will hold its first Congress on Saturday and Sunday at the home of Roland Palmedo, 1185 Park Avenue, New York City.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 30 (Delayed) -- It has been nearly a year since British and Imperial forces entered Irap to quell Rashid el Gailani's German-inspired uprising. During that time much satisfactory progress has been made toward full exploitation of the military position of the United Nations in the Middle East.

Miss Frances Le B. Stoddard gave a reception yesterday afternoon at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Francis R. Stoddard of 791 Park Avenue, for members of the debutante committee for the Red, White and Blue Ball to be given April 17 at the Ritz-Carlton in aid of the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York.

New securities offered to the public here in March aggregated $109,749,000, of which $99,394,000 represented twenty-six bond issues and $10,355,000 four stock emissions. These figures compare with new flotations of $93,410,000 in February, when $74,635,000 consisted of twenty-four bond issues and $18,675,000 in two stock offerings.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Bombs dropped by the Japanese on Bataan Peninsula yesterday struck a base hospital and caused "a number of casualties," the War Department announced today in a communique describing continued operations in that Philippine theatre.

The 500-pound bomb bought recently in England by King Peter of Yugoslavia will be dropped on Germany, and not on the occupied city of Belgrade, Constantin Fotitch, Yugoslav Minister in Washington wrote in a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES received yesterday.
LONDON, March 31 -- There was little activity in the stock markets again today. Gilt-edged issues remained firm, but the home rails were lower and the aircraft, motor shares and tobaccos were dull.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 31 (U.P.) -- The Kansas City Journal suspended publication today after 84 years of daily operation.

A check for $250,000 to buy Defense Savings Bonds was presented yesterday afternoon to Mrs. Lytle Hull, vice-chairman of the New York State Savings Defense Committee, by Mrs. Stephen S. Wise and Mrs. Ira Frank on behalf of the women's division of the American Jewish Congress.

Retailing now has a "different road" to travel, a road which cannot bear the traffic of high-pressure promotional selling aimed at increased volume, but one on which customer information and public service in keeping with the war effort will be dominant, Richard G. Meybohm, manager of the sales promotion division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, said in an address yesterday before a luncheon meeting of the Fashion Group at the Hotel Astor.

LONDON, March 31 (AP) -- Adolf Hitler is moving 100 fresh divisions into Russia for a big push to blast the Soviet forces out of the Crimea on his flank and acquire a springboard for a jump toward the oil of the Caucasus, qualified informants said tonight.

DETROIT, March 31 -- This is the forge of Vulcan, and it is roaring with his fires in which the tools of battle are being fashioned. The conversion of the automobile industry into factories of the weapons of total war has been rapid and efficient, the results already overwhelming.

Charles C. Limbocker, president of the Wolverine Tube Company, advises stockholders that at their annual meeting on April 28 they will be asked to vote on a plan to accept an offer of Calumet and Hecla Consolidated Copper Company to purchase the assets of the company, good until June 1, for $2,690,361 in cash.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- With a record United States wheat supply in prospect for 1942-43, world supplies of wheat very large and exports small as a result of shipping difficulties, the United States Government faces the prospect of having to take over most of the 210,000,000 bushels that it has under loan in warehouses, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

Sale of a New York Stock Exchange seat for $18,000 was reported yesterday. This was a recovery from the forty-five-year low of $17,000 set on March 24. The market after the new sale was $18,000 bid, $20,000 asked.

H.W. Alma, in 166 E 96th St; Lynn S. Van Natta, through N.A. Berwin Co, in 12 E 97th St; Mrs. Mabel Dohn, in 152 E 46th St; Mrs. Mary McCullough, in 18 E 65th St; Simon Barod, in 38 Central Park South; Culver, Hollyday Co, brokers.
MELBOURNE, Australia, March 31 (AP) -- An Australian communique said today:

The announcement of the Treasury Department's appointment of Joseph J. Flynn as Coordinator of Security for the Federal Agencies of the Port of New York was made yesterday morning at a meeting held in the offices of Harry M. Durning, Collector of the Port.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, March 31 -- Apparently it is a tossup whether the United States should be prouder of its Flying Fortresses or the American boys who man them. Both have written magnificent records in the Java Battle and in the Philippines.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- More than a hundred familiar household articles -- kitchen utensils, cleaning apparatus and children's toys -- fell under War Production Board restrictions today when the Division of Industry operations made further moves to divert all available iron, steel, zinc and plastics to war use.

The Museum of Modern Art and the Women's City Club are inviting all school children in greater New York to contribute to the war effort by submitting anti-hoarding pictures for an exhibition to be held at the museum from May 9 to 25.

BERLIN, March 31 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command, acknowledging continued heavy pressure from the Soviet Armies in the Donets Basin and on the Central Front, asserted today that in the latter sector Russian attacks "with strong forces" collapsed and resulted in heavy casualties and the destruction of twenty-four Red Army tanks.

Plenty of merchandise for civilian use, except silk and rubber goods, will be available at least until next Spring, Walter Hoving, president of Lord Taylor, told 2,000 store employes last night at the annual presentation of gold medals to non-executive employes, when sixteen men and women were honored for their services during the year.
April showers and the May flowers that inevitably follow in their wake were the inspiration for a collection of springtime finery and perfumes introduced yesterday afternoon by B. Altman Co.

A practical and realistic program to teach high school students the social amenities, tolerance, cooperation and confidence in human relations is recommended in a report made public yesterday by a committee appointed a year ago by the Board of Education to study high school organization and the time allowed teachers for extra-curricular, administrative and other services.

Department store trade in this city in the month ended yesterday set a new high record for March, outstripping the previous 1929 high for the month and ranging above March, 1941, by more than 20 per cent, according to analysis in retail quarters here yesterday.

LONDON, March 31 -- The British have suffered tactical reverses along the Irrawaddy Valley in Burma, the War Office disclosed today. Japanese forces inching their war north are reported to have detoured around Imperial troops to establish road blocks far behind the British front line in the Prome sector.

LONDON, March 31 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill's tribute to the Conservative party at its recent meeting was criticized today by the Labor party, which, through its press service, issued the following statement:
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 31 -- Rumors of a forthcoming Japanese attack on Russia persistently circulate in Berlin, the correspondent of the Social Demokraten reports tonight.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 31 -- With the Germans resisting desperately and all available reserves being thrown in, the Russians claimed tonight to have penetrated the German lines further at many points in the Leningrad and Moscow sectors.

Bringing with him the prediction that the war is going to last "a good many years," Cecil Brown, foreign correspondent for the Columbia Broadcasting System, returned yesterday from the Southwestern Pacific. He was at Singapore for much of the campaign in Malaya and was aboard the British battle cruiser Repulse when she was sunk by Japanese planes off the Malay Peninsula.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Sales of independent retailers increased 3 per cent in February over February of last year, the Department of Commerce reported today. For the first two months of 1942 the gain amounted to 10 per cent over the corresponding month of last year.

Small apartment houses were involved in most of the realty deals reported on Long Island yesterday. Among the sales was an investment purchase of the four three-story multi-family houses at 35-29 to 35-35 Crescent Street, in Astoria, each accommodating six families.

After the City Council had side-tracked the much-criticized Isaacs air raid protection bill yesterday, members of the Democratic majority ridiculed a new bill submitted by the Mayor to ban waterfront smoking, on the ground that its sweeping language made smoking on beaches and cooking in homes on the city's waterfront boulevards illegal.

A dozen new Spring costumes chosen for their suitability and adaptability to life under war conditions were presented last night at a fashion preview by Saks Thirty-fourth Street in the new fifth floor dress gallery of the store.

Shortly after one of the Pan American Airways Boeing-built Clippers "put down" on Flushing Bay at noon yesterday, following a trip from Europe, and made its way to the dock at the international marine terminal at La Guardia Field, its youngest passenger, 18-month-old Teddy Rothermund of the Bronx, cut a five-foot birthday cake in the customs room, marking the second anniversary of transatlantic Clipper flights from New York.

Warren L. Marks, chairman of the real estate committee of Bundles for America, Inc., has started a drive to organize units among tenants of apartment houses throughout Manhattan, with the assistance of owners and managing agents, to gather clothing, unused materials and funds to aid the organization in "furnishing comforts and necessities to the families of men in our armed forces and to others adversely affected by war conditions."
WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- The Supreme Court was told today that a man may oppose the appointment of a Jew to public office without being anti-Semitic.

Three hundred student officers of the Navy will move into Furnald Hall, Columbia University dormitory at Broadway and 115th Street, on April 17, Thomas A. McGoey, director of university residence halls announced yesterday.
ITHACA, N.Y., March 31 -- Cornell University has set more than a score of its botanists and horticulturists to work to ferret out new sources of natural rubber.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 31 (U.P.) -- Deputy Prime Minister Francis M. Forde, in the first official recognition of the problem of marriages between Australian girls and American soldiers, today issued a delicately worded legal analysis of the immigration and citizenship difficulties involved.

The first city-wide survey of apartment occupancy in New York, conducted under the Department of Housing and Buildings and the Mayor's Committee on Property Improvement, shows that there are 77,836 vacant suites in the 129,395 occupied multiple dwellings in the five boroughs, Joseph Platzker, secretary of the Mayor's committee, announced yesterday.

Registrations of out-of-town buyers in the market last week totaled 607, against 953 in the preceding week and 886 in the like period of last year, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals numbered 192, which compared with 362 for last Tuesday.

Joseph V. Moreschi, president of the International Hod Carriers, Building and Common Laborers Union, A.F. of L., took the stand yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook and denied categorically that he had threatened to "break" the Sandhogs Union, Local 147, unless the local's officers would "play ball" and "turn over the local" to him.

CHICAGO, March 31 -- Scattered liquidation developed today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade and while corn was able to resist the general trend wheat showed a heavy undertone almost from the start and with a lack of aggressive support the close was at the bottom, with losses of 1 1/8 to 1 1/4 cents a bushel.

PATERSON, N.J., March 31 -- An unauthorized walkout was started in Paterson silk and rayon dyeing plants today after a stalemate had been reached in negotiations on the demand of the workers for a ten-cent-an-hour wage increase to meet increased living costs.
The Office of Civilian Defense for this program made public yesterday a proposed code of uniform emergency regulations to control traffic during air raids and blackouts.

TORONTO, March 31 -- A sizzling shot by Nick Metz only six seconds before the end of the game enabled the Toronto Maple Leafs to eliminate the New York Rangers from the race for the Stanley Cup and the hockey championship of the world tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, March 31 (AP) -- Staging a last-round two-fisted attack, Heavyweight Melio Bettina won a ten-round decision over the veteran Gus Dorazio before a capacity crowd of 9,000 at the Arena tonight. Until the last stanza the fight was virtually even.

CHARLOTTE AMALIE, V.I., March 31 -- The twenty-fifth anniversary of the transfer of the Virgin Islands from Denmark to the United States was celebrated today in the ball field after a colorful parade.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (U.P.) -- The Postoffice Department said today that the recently approved free-mailing privileges for men in the armed services would become effective at many points in the country by the end of the week.
WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- . The heaviest tax collection month in the Treasury's history closed tonight with more than $3,000,000,000 of income and excess profits taxes in the till.

LONDON, March 31 -- The British tonight finally got around to telling their side of the story of what happened to the convoy bound for Russia that the Germans intercepted. It was a different tale from that told by the Germans before the British got around to it.

BERLIN, March 31 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command said today that U-boats had continued attacks against a convoy carrying supplies to Russia by the Far Northern route, sinking two "heavily laden transports totaling 11,000 tons at the entrance of Kola Bay."

After an ownership of about fifteen months the Equitable Life Assurance Society has sold the fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 215 West Seventy-fifth Street, at the northeast corner of Broadway, to an investing client of Douglas L. Elliman Co., brokers.

Although production of new aluminum increased 46 per cent and net shipments were 22.8 per cent higher than in 1940, the net income of the Aluminum Company of America for the year ended on Dec. 31, 1941, declined 12.1 per cent, according to the annual report to stockholders signed by Arthur V. Davis, chairman, and Roy A. Hunt, president.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Civil non-agricultural employment as of Feb. 15, totaled 39,842,000, a decrease of 29,000 since mid-January, but an increase of 2,394,000 over February of last year, Secretary of Labor Perkins announced today.
WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- A United States mission will leave for Havana on Sunday to pave the way for opening negotiations whereby the United States hopes to buy Cuba's entire 1943 sugar crop.

The appointment of Charles Francis Coe, lawyer, novelist and former radio announcer, as assistant to Will H. Hays, president of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America, was announced yesterday. Mr. Coe, whose previous association with motion pictures was as the author of several screen plays, will take up his new duties today.

Dates and places of all the regattas on the championship schedule of Long Island Sound were set yesterday afternoon by the Yacht Racing Association at the New York Yacht Club, 37 West Forty-fourth Street. The full program, starting in May and running through September, was adopted.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Map makers, editors and manufacturers were asked by the Office of Censorship today to make certain that new maps and charts omit reference to military depots and production plants.
NEW DELHI, India, March 31 (AP) -- A British communique on the Burma situation said:

LONDON, March 31 (AP) -- The British and Russian Navies, fighting together for the first time, have beaten off Germany's initial naval assault on the Allied Arctic supply line to Russia, the Admiralty announced tonight.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 31 -- Chile's outgoing Foreign Minister, Juan Bautista Rossetti, gave a banquet tonight in honor of Enrique Ruiz Guinazu, the Argentine Foreign Minister, as Chile continued to shower honors on the statesman who led the opposition at the Rio de Janeiro conference to the breaking off of relations with the Axis.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, March 31 -- A report that Japanese along the Sao Paulo coast have been supplying fuel to German submarines was the outstanding sensation of a day in which police rounded up Axis nationals in raids in towns throughout that State.

In one of the largest business property deals closed in Manhattan this year the Equitable Life Assurance Society has disposed of the large loft buildings at 121-131 West Nineteenth Street and 111-119 West Nineteenth Street, running through to 110-118 West Twentieth Street.

Citing Mayor La Guardia's recent request for "drastic" budget reduction in all city departments, the Board of Higher Education voted yesterday to discontinue Townsend Harris High School on Aug. 31 instead of in January, 1944, as stipulated in a resolution adopted by the body two weeks ago.

The Metropolitan Golf Association's "war budget" schedule for the coming season, as announced yesterday by P. James Crowhurst, chairman of the publicity committee, bears out the resolve made earlier to cut everything to the bone.

Vienna kipferln -- vanilla horns -- re-create the happy carefree mood of a Continental Easter. Sugarcoated, crescent-shaped cookies, they are fastidiously fashioned out of fresh butter and chopped almonds and the merest suspicion of very fine flour.

CHICAGO, March 31 -- Loss of Scotch whisky by sinkings of vessels carrying cargoes to the United States have not exceeded 2 per cent of actual shipments and shippers are continuing to provide "reasonable supplies," although 1941 arrivals in this country did not match the tax paid withdrawals from customs, Munson G. Shaw, chairman of the executive committee, National Association of Alcoholic Beverage Importers, declared today.

James M. Cox, former Governor of Ohio and Democratic candidate for the Presidency in 1920, was snowed under in the post-war reaction against Woodrow Wilson and the League of Nations. With Franklin D. Roosevelt, his running mate in that campaign, he was one of the worst defeated candidates for the executive office, the first political victim of the great American retreat to isolationism.

PHILADELPHIA, March 31 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered today that the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company be divorced from the holding company system of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation within one year and directed the cancellation of the voting power of Class B preferred stock of Panhandle Eastern.

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 31 -- Charging that members of his own Popular party were guilty of "monstrous criminal conspiracy" against the government and the island people, Luis Munoz Marin, Senate President, insisted on immediate investigation of legislation passed more than a year ago whereby the island treasury was "robbed" of a huge sum.

PATERSON, N.J., March 31 -- The trial in Quarter Sessions Court of four Paterson Aldermen and a former Alderman on conspiracy charges in connection with junk-yard ordinances ended in a disagreement at 11:47 o'clock tonight after the jury had been deliberating more than eleven hours.

Holders of State of San Paulo, Brazil, 7 per cent bonds of the coffee realization loan of 1930 have been notified by the Schroder Trust Company, as special agent, that funds have been received to pay immediately 50 per cent of the face amount of the coupons, due on Oct. 1, 1940, amounting to $17.50 for each $35 coupon and $8.75 for each $17.50 coupon.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The government's charge that the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) retarded the development of synthetic rubber in the United States has "not a shadow of foundation," W.S. Farish, president of the company, told the Truman committee today in answering testimony given last week by Thurman Arnold, Assistant Attorney General in charge of anti-trust enforcement.

The cotton market lost ground yesterday for the first time in a week as active hedging and New Orleans selling induced a reaction after all new-crop months from October forward had advanced to the highest levels in thirteen years. Prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange finished at their lows for the day, 10 to 13 points under the previous close.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Far-reaching and coordinated plans to buttress the Food-For-Freedom program against the movement of an estimated 1,000,000 farm workers into the armed forces and war industries were disclosed to members of Congress today.

Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, announced yesterday several shifts in the executive staff of the bank, immediately effective. Horace L. Sanford, who has been secretary of the bank and manager of the research department, becomes manager of the foreign department.

Generoso Pope, publisher of the Progresso Italo - Americano and Corriere d'America, Italian language newspapers here, is publishing a signed editorial in today's issues saying that employes of the various departments have signed a pledge of absolute loyalty and devotion to the President, the government and the institutions of the United States.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The United States is refusing to sell military and naval materiel to Argentina, but is sending, as far as is practical, equipment and commodities for civilian economic needs, according to authoritative sources today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 31 -- Recruiting of a land army of high school students, members of youth organizations and women to aid in harvesting New Jersey farm produce was suggested by speakers today at a meeting of the State Agricultural Planning Committee.
Prices on the Stock Exchange continued yesterday to drift to lower levels. Sales were 279,690 shares, compared with Monday's total of 229,290.
The activation last week of three new infantry divisions marks the beginning of the expansion of the United States Army into the greatest armed force in our history.

The following table gives the amount of the dealings in the stocks from which the averages are computed, as well as the total dealings in the rails and industrials, and the combined trading in both classes of issues and the number of the latter appearing in the daily and weekly transactions:

Charges that machinery in the shops of the National Youth Administration in New York and Long Island was permitted to remain idle, either in whole or in part, at a time when it could be used to advantage in industry or for training purposes elsewhere were denied yesterday by Miss Helen M. Harris, New York administrator of the NYA.

Representatives of Local 32B of the Building Service Employes Union and of the Realty Advisory Board, representing 3,000 buildings, broke off negotiations for a new agreement yesterday a half hour after assembling in conference at the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 31 (AP) -- It was "profound thinking" which led Lew Ayres into a camp for conscientious objectors, the movie actor said today as he breakfasted on his train en route to a labor camp near Wyeth, Ore.

An experiment in motion-picture entertainment will be put to the test on Saturday when the Broadway Theatre reopens with a program consisting entirely of one-reel and two-reel film shorts. The project is sponsored by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in response to public and critical requests for greater recongition of the short-subjects medium, according to the company.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Dropping from Federal service of business and industrial experts who have come here as dollar-a-year men would mean losing the war for the United States, W.S. Farish, president of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), told the Truman committee today.

A good part of European history is being made outside of Europe at the moment. Some of the more important chapters are written in Washington. The latest illustration of this is the visit to this country of General Sikorski, head of the Polish Government-in-exile, who is obliged to travel between London, Moscow and Washington because it is in these capitals and not in Poland that the future of his country is being decided and shaped.

MEXICO CITY, March 31 -- The Mexican Army expects to get arms soon under the lease-lend agreement and then to be able to do its part in joint defense of its coasts, it was said in authorized military quarters tonight.

Major Gen. Robert Melville Danford, retired, who was named commandant of the City Patrol Corps by Mayor La Guardia on Sunday, said yesterday that he would begin immediately the organization of the corps and would tour the city to familiarize himself with its geography.
CHUNGKING, China, March 31 -- The Chinese are becoming increasingly concerned over the possibility of failure of Sir Stafford Cripps's mission to India.
LONDON, March 31 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique said:

Excellent weather in New York City last week accounted for a general death rate of 10.3 per 1,000 population, an unusually low mark for this season, Dr. John L. Rice, city Health Commissioner, reported yesterday.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., reported net earnings for 1941 of $43,175,902 after all deductions, according to the annual statement of operations issued for publication today. The earnings are equivalent to $1.38 a share on 31,708,452 shares of $5 par capital stock outstanding and compare with $36,409,055, or $1.17 a share earned in 1940.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 31 (AP) -- Louis Farkas of Toledo rolled 1,903 for fifth place in the all-events competition and thus brought about the only change among the leaders in the American Bowling Congress tourney today.
Silver is taking the place of white metal in costume jewelry, it became evident yesterday, as white metal, which is 90 per cent tin, became frozen by government decree.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, March 31 (U.P.) -- A Japanese attempt to establish a secret base for Axis submarines operating against United Nations ships in the South Atlantic was believed frustrated today by Brazilian police who arrested twenty Japanese in the coastal town of Jaquia.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The War Department communique, based on reports received up to 9:30 A.M., follows:

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The American Retail Federation, representing 400,000 retailers, recommended to the Ways and Means Committee today a 5 per cent general retail sales tax, which, it was said, would yield $3,000,000,000 of the $7,600,000,000 in new war revenue sought by the Treasury.

Stanton Griffis, chairman of the special events division of the National Citizens Committee of the Navy Relief Society, announced yesterday that outstanding personalities in the field of sports and entertainment would serve actively in the $5,000,000 fund-raising campaign for the society.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- President Roosevelt held his press conference, visitors including Vice President Wallace with a group of Democratic leaders, the Australian Minister, the new Ambassador from Bolivia, the new Ambassador from Paraguay, Lincoln MacVeagh and Sumner Welles.

MEXICO CITY, March 31 -- Secret service officials here tonight said that, pursuant to an order of President Manuel Avila Camacho, they had started a campaign against a fifth column in the Federal District by arresting thirty suspected Axis agents.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Top-ranking representatives of the United Nations, together with an audience of 4,000, filled Constitution Hall here tonight to hear an all-Russian symphonic program given by the Boston Symphony Orchestra under the direction of Dr. Serge Koussevitzky for the benefit of the Russian War Relief.

RIOM, March 31 -- A sharp controversy developed over France's use of tanks and armored units in the war when specialists in tanks were called to testify in the unpreparedness trial before the Supreme Court here today.

ALBANY, March 31 -- Monday, April 6, was proclaimed as Army Day by Governor Lehman, who "earnestly and solemnly" urged the people of the State today to observe it "not just for the day but for every ensuing day until the forces of hatred and ruthless conquest have perished from the earth."
Detroit, Mich., sold yesterday to a banking group headed by the Bankers Trust Company $16,758,000 of refunding bonds at an interest cost basis to the city of 2.7239 per cent.

As a result of the diversion of numerous industries to war work and a consequent decline in their advertising, agency procedure is beginning to go through a streamlining process with numerous changes in copy, it was pointed out yesterday.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 31 -- Successful United Nations air action against Japanese bases on the approaches to Australia was reported today in Australian communiques that supported yesterday's official announcement that the United Nations forces has won local air superiority in certain areas.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 31 -- The War Cabinet has approved complete reorganization of the High Command of the Australian Army on the recommendation of General Sir Thomas Blamey after consultation with General Douglas MacArthur.

BOSTON, March 31 -- A series of "amphibian" natural substances present in food and vital for the body and acting as both protectors against cancer and cancer stimulators, under different circumstances, were described tonight at the annual meeting of the American Association for Cancer Research.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 31 -- Billy O., a son of Discovery, bred by Alfred Vanderbilt but flying the silks of L. Murray, spotted five other 3-year-olds about eight lengths at the start and still was good enough to score a galloping victory in the Venetian Purse at Tropical Park today.

ALBANY, March 31 -- By a vote of 120 to 21 the Assembly today concurred with the Senate in adopting a resolution continuing for another year the Rapp-Coudert legislative committee which is investigating subversive activities in New York City's schools and municipal colleges and the cost of education generally.

LOS ANGELES, March 31 (U.P.) -- Robert Noble and Ellis O. Jones, isolationists and critics of the nation's war efforts, were taken into custody tonight by Federal agents on sedition charges a few hours after they had been accused by the District Attorney's office of criminally libeling General Douglas MacArthur.

In some restaurants they give you two pieces of sugar with your coffee without asking. In some places they ask whether one piece or two. At the coffee bars they go so far as to ask with sugar or without. But in at least one restaurant the open sugar bowl is still on the table.

In its annual survey of the net profits of 899 commercial and industrial corporations, covering 1941, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in its monthly review issued yesterday estimates that corporate profits, despite increases in wage and material costs and higher Federal taxes, showed a gain of 17 per cent over 1940 and were 18 per cent above the "average" year of 1937.
HOLLYWOOD, March 31 (U.P.) -- Lili Damita, French actress, obtained a divorce today from Errol Flynn, whom she charged with "paying more attention to his yachts than me."

THE history of the modern United States might be told in a tale of two hunchbacks. One was Randolph Bourne. The other was Homer Lea. When I was an undergraduate, back in the cynical era that followed the Versailles treaty, we all read Randolph Bourne.
