John Comparetti, workman in a piano factory in Queens, was arrested last night at his home, 35-16 Ditmars Boulevard, Astoria, after eight sticks of dynamite, each with a detonation cap, had been found in an apartment he formerly occupied at 535 East 138th Street, the Bronx.

Ogden Corporation, now in process of converting itself from a public utility holding company into an investment trust, reported net assets as of Dec. 31 last of $5.49 a share, against $5.69 a year earlier.

The Marine Corps has declared "open season" and unlimited shooting in a special "Japanese hunting license" being issued without charge to potential recruits, it was disclosed yesterday with the receipt here of one of the documents.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- A barter program is being worked out with Sweden, Portugal and other neutral nations under which the United States will ship certain materials these countries need in exchange for critical materials over which they have control.

The near completion of the two large-sized Latin-American guide books that have been in preparation at Duell, Sloan Pearce under the sponsorship of the United States Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs was disclosed yesterday by Earl Parker Hanson, editor of the undertaking.

The cloud of man-made darkness that has hovered over various parts of the metropolitan area during the last few weeks settled last night upon eight square miles of the lower Bronx, where 935,000 persons cooperated in the latest blackout drill.

ALBANY, March 31 -- Acting on an emergency message from Governor Lehman, both houses of the Legislature enacted legislation today to carry out the revision of New York City's finances, involving the transfer of relief revenues and expenditures from the emergency category to the city's regular budget.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Women's and misses' coats and suits led all other departments with increases of 46 per cent during February and 51 per cent for the first two months, compared with the corresponding periods a year ago, according to the Federal Reserve Board's report of department store sales by departments.

James J. Johnston, manager of Abe Simon, who was stopped in the sixth round by Joe Louis last week, appeared before the New York State Athletic Commission yesterday to protest Referee Eddie Joseph's final count, claiming that the official had not given Simon the full toll.

Aqueduct's two most prominent Spring stakes, the Brooklyn Handicap for older horses and the Dwyer for 3-year-olds, have been increased in value, according to an announcement by President Theodore J. Knapp of the Queens County Jockey Club yesterday.

LONDON, March 31 -- The whole question of India seems to have encountered difficulties and it does not appear that the problem will be solved quite as quickly as it was hoped when Sir Stafford Cripps left here with the British War Cabinet's proposals.

NEW DELHI, India, March 31 (AP) -- Strong inferential evidence arose today that Great Britain's final offer of full dominion status to India after the war was about to be rejected because of the un willingness of the more important Indian political leaders to accept the condition that India's defense must meantime remain in British hands.

HATTIESBURG, Miss., March 31 -- Two mighty home runs by smiling Jeff Heath spoiled a gorgeous bit of pitching by the Giants' Dave Koslo today as the New York-Cleveland baseball feud went through its fifth skirmish before about 3,000 soldiers from Camp Shelby.

It might interest F.S. Herman, whose letter was published in your March 30 issue, to know that the initialed plate for automobiles he writes about is made from a material that is not at all vital in our defense effort. It is not metal, and the only reason I use it, and I believe many others do, is to protect the space left when only one license plate is issued.

CHICAGO, March 31 -- Oklahoma and Memphis were named grand prize winners today in the national traffic safety contest, in which all the States and 1,293 cities participated. The contest was conducted by the National Safety Council and covered the calendar year of 1941.

A group of preferred stockholders of the Puget Sound Power and Light Company announced yesterday the formation of a protective committee to oppose the management of the Engineers Public Service Company in handling the affairs of Puget Sound, a direct subsidiary.

Two new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. "My Favorite Blonde," starring Bob Hope and Madeleine Carroll, will be the newcomer at the Paramount. Featured in the comedy are Gale Sondergaard, George Zucco and Lionel Royce. . . . Metro's "Joe Smith, American," will be the new attraction at Loew's Criterion.
MOSCOW, March 31 (AP) -- The Soviet Bureau of Information issued the following communique today:

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- By an almost unanimous voice vote today the Senate rejected motions by Senator O'Daniel of Texas to attach riders to the Smaller War Plants Corporation Bill which would abolish overtime payments for labor, the closed shop, picketing and "force and violence" in labor disputes.

ALBANY, March 31 -- The Assembly by unanimous vote passed today and sent to the Senate the Hollowell bill designed to end alleged discriminations between manufacturers of liquor and retailers and provide for fair trade practices among liquor producers.

Celebrating the liberation of the ancient Hebrews from servitude in Egypt, the Jewish holiday of Passover will be ushered in at sundown today with services in synagogues and temples, followed by Seders or ceremonial feasts at home.

DETROIT, March 31 -- C.E. Wilson, president of the General Motors Corporation, and Walter P. Reuther, director of the General Motors Division of the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., debated for six hours today the merits of Mr. Reuther's plan for converting the automobile industry to war work.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 31 -- A Common Pleas Court jury here brought in a verdict of $1,150 today for Edward W. Earle, a Hillside Junior High School student, and his father against Adolph G. Benitz of Hillside, who wounded young Earle with a blast from a shotgun on June 18, 1941.

The talk of a plan to ration sugar reminds one of the news items of some months ago which told of a big convention of toothpick manufacturers and government officials who were meeting to standardize toothpick sizes to save "millions" by reducing the quantity of wood in each toothpick and the number of styles of toothpicks.

The good work which the Dies committee does intermittently has suffered from another irresponsible act on the part of its chairman. On Sunday of this week Mr. Dies made public a statement accusing thirty-five officials of the Board of Economic Welfare of past affiliation with Communist-front organizations.

Josef Raieff, New York pianist, who made his debut here four years ago, last night gave his third Town Hall recital. Again he showed that he was the possessor of fleet fingers and a fluent technique, and, if there was still no great depth of emotion, there was individuality in both his approach and his choice of program.
Several sales on the lower East Side of Manhattan were reported by brokers yesterday. Another East Side deal involved two small properties in Forty-ninth Street.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 31 -- The world champion Yankees paused here today for a game with Brooklyn's National League champions, only to be reminded for the second time in a fortnight that March was by no means so satisfactory a month as October for them.

Contrary to popular belief concerning increased wartime profits of corporations, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in its monthly review estimates that, on the basis of its summary of 167 leading corporations profits in the final quarter of 1941, after taxes, were smaller than in the fourth quarters of either of the two preceding years.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 31 -- How the Black Dragon Society of Japan, an organization of army officers and Buddhist priests, ran paid advertisements in Japanese language newspapers in this country was revealed today with the arrest in Sacramento of two Japanese described as "big gamblers."

BERLIN, March 31 (From German broadcasts recorded by the United Press in New York) -- Dispatches from Burma said today that Japanese troops had pushed across the Irrawaddy River and were directly threatening Prome.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Arthur B. Newhall, chief of the Rubber and Rubber Products Branch of the War Production Board was named Coordinator for Rubber today by Donald M. Nelson, WPB chairman, with sweeping powers to direct and integrate all current programs dealing with the use, control or production of natural and synthetic rubber.

Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Noyes of London have returned to the Commodore from Palm Beach. They will leave later in the week to visit their daughters, who are in school in Montreal, and their son, who is in Ottawa, Ont.

Because of the terms under which some railroads received land grants, the transport of troops is not always as profitable as it should be, E.J. Engel, president of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway, said in his annual report issued yesterday.

The Air Training Corps of America, organized to provide preflight aviation instruction to youths 16 to 18 years old who later may join the nation's fighting forces, is operating in thirteen schools in the metropolitan area, it was announced yesterday.

ALBANY, March 31 -- The problem as to how to handle the votes this fall of hundreds of thousands of New York State men who are, or will be, in the armed forces by election day, cropped up as a major problem in the Legislature today. It was the subject of a conference between Representatives of the Republicans and the Governor's office.

A United States Navy bomber landed in pitch darkness on a sea so rough that it started a seam of one pontoon of the plane, and rescued four seamen who had been clinging for hours to an improvised raft made of hatchboards after their freighter had been sunk in the Caribbean, it was disclosed yesterday with the arrival here of two of the rescued men.

BRISBANE, Australia, Wednesday, April 1 (AP) -- An American flier whose uncanny marksmanship in attacks on Japanese warships has brought him the Distinguished Flying Cross attributes everything to the accurate sights on his plane and to the practice he got in the Louisiana manoeuvres last year.
The plan of reorganization of the Vertientes-Camaguey Sugar Company was approved at a special meeting of stockholders yesterday in Dover, Del., by a vote of more than 70 per cent of the shares.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- President Roosevelt called the Pacific War Council to meet with him tomorrow to review the progress its members are making in defending themselves' against the powers of darkness. He coupled the Pacific Council's purpose with this Holy Week message to the American people:
SECRET AGENT M-19 (ring twice) arrived back from a tour of the Grapefruit Circuit yesterday and, with regard to the ball clubs and players he had sighted, said in part:
Westchester and Putnam County trout fishermen, supported by many from New York and others from Long Island, are expected to be on the streams in good numbers Saturday, the opening day of the season.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- Moving to meet the East's petroleum supply emergency, Secretary Ickes directed today that oil transportation facilities of the Middle West be made available immediately for eastward oil movements.

LONDON, March 31 -- When Britain's fiscal year ended tonight it was announced that taxpayers had contributed more to the cost of government than ever before in history. The total was 2,074,057,310, an increase of 665,190,213 in ordinary revenue over last year.
Leases for entire floors and for other large units of space were among the business rentals reported yesterday.

Much is being said and written these days about the emergence of the bicycle as a means of individual transportation. Arthur Liebers, in THE TIMES of March 22, had an interesting summary of the present situation. But I am sure that more can and should be said, and soon, about the problems involved.

The plea of Senator Barkley, the majority leader -- the burden of which was that the Senate should sidetrack all labor legislation for the period of the war -- is a remarkable document, whether we examine it from the standpoint of its internal logic or of the broader issues of political policy involved.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- A new peak was reached by loans and deposits of the 13,427 insured commercial banks on Dec. 31, Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, reported today.

FALL RIVER, Mass., March 31 (AP) -- About 3,600 workers in three mills of the Berkshire Fine Spinning Company remained idle today because loom fixers and other key workers stayed out in protest against the employment of one worker who belonged to the C.I.O.

ALBANY, March 31 -- The State Federation of Republican Women's Clubs adopted a resolution at a legislative conference today opposing the Treasury's plan for joint income tax returns. The proposal was attacked as un-American.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 1 -- The Yankees may have had to slip down to the level of Class B baseball to snap their three-game losing streak today. But when the world champions got around to it, they did do a rather thorough job. They belted the Jacksonville Tars into submission by a score of 18 to 1 for their largest scoring spree of the exhibition season to date.

ALEXANDRIA, LA., April 1 -- The Indians' idea of an April Fool gag on Bill McGee today, as the Giants-Cleveland Spring battle swung through its sixth installment, didn't strike favor with the Fiddler.

ALBANY, April 1 -- A minority report on reapportionment, attacking the Republican proposal for a fifty-six-member State Senate as unconstitutional, was submitted to the Legislature today by William J. O'Shea Jr., Democratic assistant counsel to the Reapportionment Committee.

Tire requirements of preferential users came nearer in March to using up the New York City quota than at any time since rationing was instituted, Lee S. Buckingham, Federal Rationing Administrator, said yesterday. The heaviest demands were for new passenger car tires and for recapped and re-treaded tires for trucks.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 1 -- Efforts to settle this city's day-old milk strike were continuing late tonight amid growing demands by public officials for an immediate end of the wage controversy.

Yesterday, for the first time, a special offering on the New York Stock Exchange ran into "regular-way competition." J. W. Seligman Co. made a special offering of 2,780 shares of Revere Copper and Brass Company 5 1/4 per cent preferred at 66, with special commission of 1 1/4.
Leo Reisman, the orchestra leader, has leased an apartment of six rooms and three baths in the building at 136 East Sixty-fourth Street through the Madison Realty Company.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 1 -- Moving with accelerated speed in its Japanese-evacuation program, the Army sent two trainloads of men, women and children today into Owens Valley, set tomorrow for the start of exclusion movements from San Francisco and San Diego and announced the acquisition of six more evacuee assembly centers in Washington, Oregon, California and Arizona.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 1 -- Juan Antonio Rios, who will be inaugurated tomorrow afternoon as President of Chile, pledged full cooperation in the interests of continental solidarity today, but indicated that he would not break off relations with the Axis until the interests of Chile and the "cause to which they are spiritually linked" so required.

Representative Hamilton Fish said yesterday that State Senator Allan A. Ryan Jr., who has announced his candidacy for Representative against Mr. Fish in the Twenty-sixth Congressional District, had failed to answer his question on why at the age of 38 and with a large income he did not volunteer to serve in the nation's armed forces.

Mayor La Guardia discussed yesterday with high officials of the Police Department a whole series of measures designed for the protection of the city against air raids, including "dim-outs" along the ocean front, precautions necessary during the Summer at such crowded places as baseball parks, race tracks and beaches, and special policing on Easter Sunday.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The War Department communique, based on reports received up to 9:30 A.M., follows:

RIOM, France, April 1 -- The prosecution fought incessantly throughout today's debates before the Supreme Court over the question of the numbers of tanks and armored vehicles engaged in the Battle of France by the French and Germans.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Contracts with twenty-five oil, chemical and rubber manufacturing companies, including three Standard Oil concerns, which will bring the annual production of synthetic rubber in the United States up to 700,000 tons a year were announced today by Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce.
BERLIN, April 1 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique said today:

BERNE, Switzerland, April 1 -- "Pierre Laval is particularly active just now, but it is not possible to say whether his many contacts derive from his own initiative or whether they correspond with desires expressed by one or the other party [Vichy and Berlin] or by both."

Twenty-one canvases by Pierre-Auguste Renoir have been assembled at the Durand-Ruel Gallery, 12 East Fifty-seventh Street, to form an exhibition that is being held as a benefit for the Homeless Children's Fund of the Children's Aid Society.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 1 -- Dorothy Comingore today withdrew from RKO's "The Silver Spoon" and was suspended from salary for the third time since her appearance in "Citizen Kane" last year. The new picture, which is based on a story by Clarence Budington Kelland, went before the cameras this morning despite Miss Comingore's withdrawal.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The Senate reached a unanimous consent agreement today that on April 20 it will take up the motion of Senator Connally of Texas to make in order the immediate consideration of his bill to "freeze" existing labor conditions, except wages, in all war industries, and to give the President additional power to seize war plants and facilities where labor or managerial policies are slowing or stopping production for war purposes.

The American Federation of Labor advertisement in THE TIMES of March 30 in a box headed "The Truth About Overtime" presents the idea that time and a half for overtime pays for itself through the reduction in overheads per unit of product.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, April 1 (U.P.) -- General Douglas MacArthur said today that American labor would be the "indestructible backbone" that would determine the outcome of the war, and expressed a firm conviction that workers at home would make a mighty effort to keep their soldiers at the front supplied.

Fordham's nine chalked up its second straight victory of the season yesterday when the Rams defeated Hofstra, 8 -- 2, in a Metropolitan Conference contest on the Rose Hill diamond. The game was the first of the season for the visitors.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The Senate passed and sent to the House today a bill to create a Smaller War Plants Corporation under the supervision of the War Production Board, with a $100,000,000 appropriation to help finance small industries engaging in war production. Approval came by a vote of 81 to 0.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- Several groups of creditors of the Missouri Pacific Railroad voted against a plan of reorganization for that company which had been approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission and the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri, the I.C.C. announced today.
The War Department's communique outlining the military situation as of 4 P.M. said:
WYETH, Ore., April 1 -- Lew Ayres, the motion picture actor who declined to bear arms for his country, registered at the conscientious objectors' camp here today.

Only one of eight New York newspapers, measured by Media Records, registered a gain last month and the group as a whole registered a decline of 6.0 per cent in advertising linage from the corresponding 1941 month, according to a compilation yesterday.
America's dog power is swinging into line to supplement man power in fighting the Axis combine.

All the leading securities and commodity exchanges in the United States and Canada will be closed tomorrow in observance of Good Friday. The principal exceptions will be the livestock markets and the New York Mercantile Exchange. Most of the exchanges closed tomorrow will reopen on Saturday, although one exception to this rule will be the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, which will remain closed until Monday.

HONOLULU, April 1 (AP) -- All twenty-one musicians in the U.S.S. Arizona band were killed in the explosion of that battleship's magazine while they were passing ammunition to the guns above during the Pearl Harbor attack of Dec. 7, naval authorities revealed today.
MOSCOW, April 1 (AP) -- The Soviet Bureau of Information issued the following communique today:

Three more Axis submarines have been blasted by United States fliers, bringing the total number of enemy underwater craft that have been "sunk or presumably sunk" to at least twenty-eight, the Navy Department announced yesterday in Washington.

ALBANY, April 1 -- Legislation affecting the protection of striped bass which was recently introduced in the Legislature calls for the prohibition of netting in the Hudson River, and some of the views of members of the Conservation Department relating to the measure were revealed today.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York has devoted its entire season to celebrating its centennial, but the actual anniversary of the society's founding will be celebrated with this afternoon's concert, for it was on April 2, 1842, that a group of musicians headed by Ureli Corelli Hill voted the society into existence.

Undoubtedly the finest moment of the concert given by the Philharmonic Symphony, the Westminster Chorus, invited soloists, and John Barbirolli, last night in Carnegie Hall, was Barbirolli's arrangement of the noble chorale-prelude of J.S. Bach, "Wenn wir im hoschsten Noethen sind," an arrangement modestly scored, of great and pathetic music.
I read with much concern the article in THE TIMES of March 25 headed, "Raising Rabbits Urged to Cut Family Meat Bill." I think Dr. Gabrielson had no idea what harm that could do.
LONNDON, April 1 -- There is little doubt that the Germans are concentrating small landing craft and supplies in the Black Sea ports of Varna and Constanta, it was said here today.

CHICAGO, April 1 (AP) -- Steers advanced to the highest price since January, 1941, as salable receipts continued moderate. Hogs were steady to strong and sheep, about steady. A top of $16.25 was paid for choice 1,239-pound steers.

The exigencies of what the editors call the present world situation have caused the advance-guard anthology, "Twice a Year," to become a once-a-year publication. A combined edition containing the material that would have been held for Fall is published today by the Twice a Year Press, New York.

The Department of Labor's index number of manufacturing employment in February compares as follows with those of preceding months and with the same month in previous years, based on the average for 1923-1925 as 100 and adjusted to conform with preliminary figures of the Bureau of the Census:

Surrogate James A. Delehanty held yesterday in a construction proceeding in the estate of Colonel Jacob Ruppert that the Metropolitan Museum of Art, as legatee of "tangible personal property" under the will, was not entitled to the proceeds from the sale of the brewer's oceangoing yacht Yankee.

The combined effect of conversions of some manufacturing plants to war industries and the inability of others to get vital materials has released a number of important materials going into protective coatings, with a resultant freer offering of such materials, according to the monthly raw material survey issued yesterday by the National Paint, Varnish and Lacquer Association.

LONDON, April 1 -- Adherents of the "treat them rough" school, who demand the destruction of the German State, listened at luncheon yesterday to the arguments of an exponent of the opposing view that the way to lasting peace in Europe is to "win them over."

The picket line outside the Brass Rail restaurant on Seventh Avenue at Forty-ninth Street, a union experiment in perpetual motion, finally ran down yesterday. The State Labor Relations Board through the Rev. John P. Boland, chairman, announced settlement of the strike at noon. Full terms of the settlement were not announced.

Metro's "The Bugle Sounds," which opens at the Capitol, is this morning's sole film newcomer. Wallace Beery and Marjorie Main head the cast of the topical drama, and Lewis Stone, George Bancroft, William Lundigan, Donna Reed and Chill Wills appear in featured roles.
NEW DELHI, India, April 1 (AP) -- The British communique on the Burma situation said today:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 1 -- An increase of 355 per cent this year in the number of pistol permits issued in Westchester County, caused chiefly by a rush of civilian defense volunteers to carry side arms, caused concern today among defense officials and Supreme Court justices.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 1 -- Each of this colony's newspapers today carried a full-page advertisement telling the public: "Remember Hong Kong and Singapore: Both these colonies fell when water gave out."

Plans for evacuation of children in a war emergency are being evolved in Washington by the Children's Bureau and five other agencies, Dr. Martha M. Eliot, assistant chief of the bureau, which is under the Department of Labor, announced yesterday.
Crown Princess Martha of Norway, accompanied by the Countess Ragni Ostgaard, has come to the Waldorf-Astoria from Pooks Hill, Bethesda, Md.

DETROIT, April 1 -- In the great plants here which are hammering out the tools of war many of the workers' daily tasks are arduous and exacting. The din around them is terrific. The precision required of some, the muscular strain on others, the combination of these requirements -- plus speed -- on still others produce deep weariness at the end of the shift.

Works of European and American artists were sold at auction last night at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., for $27,445. The sale included property of the estates of Rosalie H. Stone of Beverly Hills, Calif.; Wilbur L. Cummings of Greenwich, Conn., and property of Victor Harris of New York, and others.

This week for the first time in many months manufacturers of men's furnishings reported a let-down in new orders. The demand for such items as shirts, neckwear and certain types of hosiery slackened, as stores approached the final week of Easter selling with heavy stocks.

ALBANY, April 1 -- The Senate without debate completed legislative action today on the Todd resolution urging Congress to pass immediately legislation providing for the registration of all women in the country between the ages of 18 and 65 under the Selective Service Act.

PITTSBURGH, April 1 -- The Weirton Steel Company produced 153,823 tons of steel in the first month of operations under the new joint labor-management committee and established a new world's record for production in the industry, it was announced today.

The report of the Engineers Public Service Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Jan. 31, issued yesterday, shows a net income, after all expenses, taxes and other charges, of $4,697,603. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.25 a share on the company's outstanding common stock, and compares with a net of $5,250,861, or $1.55 a common share, in the twelve months to Jan. 31, 1941.

The Parktown Realty Corporation, which recently purchased the thirteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 929 Park Avenue from the Straight Improvement Company, has acquired title to the property. Assessed at $430,000, the building is on a plot 53 by 100 feet and has thirty-nine apartments of three and four rooms each.

PHILADELPHIA, April 1 -- Application for permission to sell $32,500,000 of new securities was made today to the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Southwestern Public Service Company of Dallas, Texas.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The supply and equipment, first by air and later perhaps by sea, of the Serb armies that under General Draja Mikhailovitch are carrying on guerrilla warfare against the Axis in Yugoslavia, and the coordination of General Mikhailovitch's operations with the grand strategy of the United Nations, will be urged by a Yugoslav military mission that has arrived in Washington under the command of Colonel Dragutin Savitch.

A further net drain of 948,000 barrels was made last week on stocks of gasoline and light and heavy fuel oil along the Atlantic Coast, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Gasoline supplies were down 503,000 barrels to 16,470,000 at the close of the week and heavy fuel oil stocks dropped 479,000 to 5,618,000.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) has not disclosed its manufacturing processes for synthetic rubber to the Army and Navy, W.S. Farish, president of the company, conceded under persistent questioning by Senator O'Mahoney of Wyoming, before the Truman committee today.

BOSTON, April 1 -- Studies providing clues to a mechanism by which animals develop a resistance against transplanted cancers, and which may lead to further clues on how to induce immunity against spontaneous cancers, were reported today before the annual meeting of the American Association for Cancer Research by Dr. Anna Goldfeder of the cancer division, Department of Hospitals, New York City, and the department of experimental surgery, New York University College of Medicine.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The so-called trade agreement between Argentina and Spain, referred to in a communique of the Spanish Foreign Office on March 14, does not go very far and is still in vague form, according to information received here.

PALM BEACH, Fla., April 1 -- Mrs. Charles Edward Merrill entertained with a dinner tonight at Merrill's Landing, where Mrs. Camroux Colgate, who had been with Mrs. Jean Vom Berge, and Mrs. Albert F. Jaeckel are guests.

The running battle between Anglo- Russian and German naval forces in the Arctic Ocean probably foretells heavier engagements to come. The logic of the situation, with Allied munitions pouring into Murmansk, compels Hitler to smash this supply line if he can.

While in certain circumstances wartime conditions are expected to make it easier to detect cases in which Germans or Italians obtained United States citizenship through fraud, the process of "denaturalizing" such persons will follow the usual democratic principles of justice and fairness, United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa declared yesterday.

The newly organized Ships Service Committee, headed by Mrs. William H. Vanderbilt, gave a dance last night at the Pierre as the first in a series of entertainments planned to advance its work. The purpose of the new group, in addition to organizing special parties, will be to direct the men of the Navy to welfare agencies providing canteen service, shelter, tickets to theatres, sports events and other attractions.
LONDON, April 1 -- Although he had taken an adamant stand, it was believed that Sir Stafford Cripps had sought word from his government by telephone tonight on how much freedom India might have now.

Wages in twenty-five industries increased almost twice as fast in the first twenty-eight months of this war as they did in the corresponding period of the first World War, according to the findings of a study made public yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board. The rise in the cost of living has been less rapid than a quarter of a century ago, the board also declared.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 1 -- German recruits now moved to the front for the much-heralded Spring offensive received only eight weeks' training, reports the Berlin correspondent of Nya Dagligt Allehanda.

LONDON, April 1 (Reuter) -- A new development in women's war service has been announced by the War Office. The Women's Auxiliary Territorial Service is to man searchlights in the Anti-Aircraft Command. Experiments are about to start to investigate conditions under which they can be employed in full operational roles.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 1 (AP) -- Carding a five-over-men's par 77 to go with her opening-round 79, defending champion Dorothy Kirby of Atlanta pulled away from the titleholders' golf field today with a 36-hole score of 156.

LONDON, April 1 -- The increasing gravity of the situation in Burma is apparent from today's communiques, despite the success of British and Chinese units in fighting their way out of encirclement below Prome and at Toungoo, respectively, and rejoining their main forces on new defense lines.

PHILADELPHIA, April 1 -- John B. Kelly, Director of the National Fitness Program, met reports from Washington today that the appropriation requested would be cut drastically, by declaring that "even if they don't give me a cent, we will cary on this work."

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Major Gen. James H. Burns, an Administration adviser in many phases of the lease-lend program and the subsequent arms-production program as it affects the United Nations, was named today by President Roosevelt as Chief of Army Ordnance.

WITH GENERAL WAINRIGHT'S ARMY in the Philippines, March 31 (Deloyed) (U.P.) -- Corregidor's straight-shooting anti-aircraft gunners knocked a flight of two heavy Japanese bombers into Manila Bay late yesterday in the shortest of the scores of raids on the American fortress during nearly ten days of attacks.

BERLIN, April 1 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Strong Soviet forces have been repelled in attacks in the Donets area and also in the central and northern sectors of the Russian front, the German High Command communique said today.

An underwriting group consisting of Kidder, Peabody Co., G.H. Walker Co. and Harris Hall Co., Inc., will offer today to the public 30,000 shares of 4 1/4 per cent cumulative preferred stock of the Pet Milk Company at $105 a share and accrued dividends.

Maurice E. Rogalin, suspended principal of the William Howard Taft High School, accused of accepting money and other gifts from teachers, entered a general denial of the charges yesterday before a special committee of the Board of Education headed by Ellsworth B. Buck, vice president of the board.

Opposing a court application, the granting of which would open the way to mass police retirements, Mayor La Guardia and Police Commissioner Valentine submitted affidavits to Supreme Court Justice Edward R. Koch yesterday terming the retirement situation "the most difficult and complex administrative problem in the entire history of the Police Department" and warning of "serious consequences of any substantial depletion in the number of men available for police duty."

ATLANTA, April 1 (AP) -- There'll be no war-time suspension of football at the University of Georgia or Georgia Tech unless "further emergency should develop" -- or unless diminishing gate receipts indicate public disapproval.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., April 1 -- Mild Will McKechnie's Reds, meeting the Dodgers for the second time this year, again bowed in defeat today. Leo Durocher's league champions beat them, 3 -- 1, with two rookie right-handers, Les Webber and Eddie Albosta, holding Cincinnati to four singles. Webber hurled the first seven frames and gave the losers only a row of goose eggs on the scoreboard.

Building work is due to start on Monday on Edwin Markham Houses on Staten Island, the New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday after receiving four bids on the general construction contract.

Hailing the nation's change from peacetime production to war production, thus far, as a remarkable achievement in view of the conversion problem, the National City Bank in its monthly review of business and financial conditions says that this could not have been accomplished if waste and inefficiency in the direction and execution of the production program were as great as "uninformed gossip" would have it, or without "skill and devotion" by both management and labor.

MONTREAL, April 1 (AP) -- Free French headquarters here received a cable today saying that Vice Admiral Emile Muselier, naval commander of General Charles de Gaulle's forces, had resigned from the French National Committee in London. The cable said Admiral Muselier had resigned "at his own request and had been replaced by another admiral."

A syndicate of investors represented by Samuel L. Paul, attorney, has purchased from the Chambeau Realty Corporation the apartment house at 3514 Rochambeau Avenue, the Bronx, paying cash above mortgages totaling $112,000. There are accommodations for forty-five families in the building, which is on a plot 109 by 104 feet.

LONDON, April 1 (AP) -- General Charles de Gaulle, showing his resentment at the lack of recognition accorded his Free French movement by the United Nations, declared today that his followers would march "shoulder to shoulder with her allies on the express condition that her allies go forward with her."

Richard Gardiner Casey, first Australian Minister at Washington, said good-bye to Mr. Roosevelt this week. He will soon be leaving us for his post as a member of the British War Cabinet, in the Middle East. He has made himself singularly well liked here, where, indeed, he was far from a stranger.

An exhibition of war paintings by British, French, Chinese, Norwegian, Dutch, Russian and Belgian refugee children, has been assembled by Mrs. Somerset Maugham and Hugh Chrisholm and will open in the lobby of the Imperial Theatre on April 7 at the time of the premiere matinee of the English musical revue, "Gratefully Yours."

Alfred Noyes thinks that when people ask what really happened in France, just one word is enough for an answer. It is "Proust." Three-fourths of the people in the monumental "Remembrance of Things Past," according to Mr. Noyes, show marked signs of perversion.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Broad strategy for the immediate defense of the Southwest Pacific against an anticipated further Japanese push, and, eventually, a United Nations offensive against the Japanese was discussed today at the initial meeting of the Pacific War Council, presided over by President Roosevelt at the White House.

TRENTON, April 1 -- Manufacturers and business men may deduct expenses for blackout precautions from gross income in computing Federal net income taxes, the New Jersey Defense Council announced today on the authority of information received from Norman D. Cann, Acting Commissioner of Internal Revenue.

TUCSON, Ariz., April 1 (AP) -- April Fool or not, the Cubs and the Athletics battled through seventeen innings to a 7-7 tie today and then had to call the game because, said Umpire Ernie Stewart, "we are out of baseballs."
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 1 (AP) -- Wait until the war is over to get married, Dr. Charles F. Marden, assistant professor of sociology at Rutgers University, advises young couples.
MELBOURNE, Australia, April 1 (AP) -- Prime Minister John Curtin issued the following communique today:

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 1 (U.P.) -- General Ivan S. Koneff's Soviet Army has recaptured thirty-four towns and villages in a two-day battle on the Kalinin front that cost the Germans 7,000 killed and possibly cleared the way to Vitebsk, seventy-five miles east of the old Polish border, front reports said tonight.

Senator Vandenberg read into the Congressional Record yesterday a letter in which Chairman Eccles of the Federal Reserve Board endorses earlier recommendations for repeal of the Silver Purchase Act and proposes that the Treasury be authorized to sell to private industry the vast hoard of silver which it has accumulated since 1934 and for which it has no use whatever.

FALL RIVER, Mass., April 1 (AP) -- Work in eleven of Fall River's eighteen cotton textile mills was halted again tonight after new walkouts by members of the Independent American Federation of Textile Operatives who had returned to their jobs Monday after nearly a week's stoppage.
LONDON, April 1 -- Drastic rationing of automobile tires will be effective Saturday. Only vehicles vital for war effort will be permitted to have new tires.
Following is the text of Mayor La Guardia's message transmitting the 1942-43 City budget to the Board of Estimate:
Industrial expansion accounted for a number of the New Jersey realty sales in communities close to the metropolitan district reported yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, April 1 (U.P.) -- Sir Stafford Cripps invited to his residence tonight Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, influential member of the All-India Congress party, and Maulana Abul Kalam Azad, president of the Congress. It was apparent that he was trying to break the deadlock arising from India's demand to be able to name her own Defense Minister.

Every word from India during these fearfully decisive days is like news from a mighty battlefront, in which the fortunes of war go now one way, now the other. Hour by hour, almost, we in America have fluctuated between the fear that this was another lost Battle of France and the hope that it was another victory at the Marne.

The news about the recent anti-trust litigation involving contracts between the Standard Oil Company and the German I.G. Farbenindustrie again brings into the limelight the question of the right, if any, of a United States patentee to prevent the use of his invention for the public good.

The Greyhound Corporation and its subsidiaries, operators of motor bus lines, reported yesterday for 1941 a net profit of $6,529,597, equal, after preference dividend requirements, to $2.28 a share on 2,792,075 common shares, compared with $4,748,309, or $1.70 on 2,693,409 common shares, in 1940.

OTTAWA, April 1 -- Sixty thousand Polish troops recruited from among prisoners and refugees in Russia have crossed the frontier into Iran to strengthen the United Nations defense there, General Wladyslaw Sikorski, Polish Premier and Commander in Chief, said here today when he left Ottawa after a one-day visit.

Washington's explanation of curtailed shipments to Argentina was a principal topic of discussion at the regular monthly meeting of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday, and members agreed that while shipments to other Latin-American countries were moving forward normally, considerable difficulties were now being experienced with regard to exports for that nation.

ELIZABETH CITY, N.C., April 1 -- Speaking at ceremonies commissioning the new naval air station here for lighter-than-air craft this afternoon, Rear Admiral M.H. Simons, commandant of the Fifth Naval District, asserted that "at least" 50 per cent of the merchant vessels which had been lost in the Atlantic since Pearl Harbor would not have become victims of Axis submarines if their masters had obeyed orders.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, April 1 -- Brazilian police during the past two years have amassed dossiers on 8,600 Axis nationals and have kept close watch over those regarded as dangerous, according to Chief of Police Filinto Muller of this city. Two hundred have now been arrested, and round-ups continue in many cities.

Joseph P. Lash, 32-year-old leader of youth organizations and friend of Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt, who supported his unsuccessful attempt to obtain a commission in the Naval Intelligence Service, was ordered to report for induction into the Army as a private on April 13, Selective Service headquarters said yesterday.

Eudice Shapiro, violin, and Irene Jacobi, piano, pooled their talents in a recital given last night in Town Hall. A special feature of the program was a group of works written especially for the occasion by Norman Dello Joio, Frederick Jacobi and Vittorio Rieti, which received their premieres.

Certain shortages in materials may prevent manufacturers of small appliances from reaching the full quota of production permitted by the new War Production Board order for April and May but they will come close to it, distributors said yesterday.

SOMEWHERE IN WEST ENGLAND, April 1 -- Taking a short cut that enables R.A.F. personnel to keep abreast of the steady flow of American aircraft engines, the Air Ministry has established here an important technical training school -- the only one of its kind in Britain -- where ground staffs become as familiar with engines built in the United States as with those made in Britain.

Among downtown properties traded yesterday is the fourteen-and-a-half-story loft building on a plot 50 by 200 feet at 216-18 William Street, running through to 18-20 Rose Street. It was sold by the Bank for Savings to the Belparke Realty Corporation of 570 Seventh Avenue for cash over a purchase money mortgage of $170,000 for ten years.

The first of two post-season performances of Wagner's "Parsifal" was given last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. This only evening presentation of the work during the year was a benefit for the Music School of the Henry Street Settlement.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., April 1 (AP) -- Curious Roman, recently a creditable fourth to the Kentucky Derby candidate, Bright Willie, found no such opposition in the Southland Purse at Tropical Park today and romped to a three-length victory.

The trial of twelve defendants accused of conspiring to extort payment from independent milk dealers and truckers in 1935 continued yesterday in General Sessions, with Judge James G. Wallace taking under advisement the question of punishing one of the defense attorneys for contempt of court.

AUSTIN, Texas, April 1 (AP) -- Production of petroleum in Texas, the biggest producing State in the Union, has been reduced to levels of nearly seven years ago. The Texas Railroad Commission, State oil regulatory agency, has decreed that wells must be shut down eighteen days this month and that the average flow of crude oil must not exceed 1,036,512 barrels daily, compared with 1,450,000 at the start of the year.
LONDON, April 1 -- The stock markets were dull again today. There was no definite trend and where prices were lower it was mainly due to a lack of public interest.

CHICAGO, April 1 -- Movies in which Lew Ayres appears were banned by Balaban Katz today in the 100 theatres which the company operates in metropolitan Chicago. Ayres's pictures also were banned in the down-State theatres operated by the Great States Company, a Balaban Katz subsidiary.

The stock market plodded along yesterday in the familiar pattern of recent weeks, although the list showed a firmer tendency at the close. News was not of a nature to excite trading and, as a result, sales on the Stock Exchange were 281,220 shares, against 279,690 on Tuesday.

Paul Muni, who last acted on the Broadway stage in Maxwell Anderson's "Key Largo" (1939), will return on Tuesday night, April 14, as the star of "Yesterday's Magic," a Theatre Guild offering. The Emlyn Williams play deals with theatrical folk, and in it Mr. Muni will impersonate a once-famous actor who has traveled down the ladder of success because of his fondness for John Barleycorn.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The defenders of Bataan Peninsula today fought off at the bayonet point a major Japanese assault that began last evening, but only after the defenders had retreated from some of the positions in advance of their main lines, the War Department announced tonight.

BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, April 2 -- Judging from reports from the Russian front early this morning from both Soviet and German sources, the operations there are continuing to develop on the lines of a general offensive -- initiated by the Red Army.

LOS ANGELES, April 1 (AP) -- Federal and State Governments cracked down from three directions today on Robert Noble and Ellis O. Jones, arrested last night and accused of criticizing America's war effort and General Douglas MacArthur.

Intensifying its efforts to gain the cooperation of every woman in New York in the drive for waste materials needed for the war, the women's division of the New York City Salvage Committee, headed by Grace Allen Bangs, yesterday urged women to concentrate their salvage efforts on four main items. rubber, metals, rags and paper.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The Soviet Ambassador and Mme. Litvinoff gave a musicale this morning at the Embassy for the debut performance here of the Shostakovich quintet, opus 57, of the distinguished Russian composer, which won for him the Stalin prize of 100,000 rubles sixteen months ago.

PATERSON, N.J., April 1 -- The 6,000 silk and rayon dyers who quit work yesterday in some sixty plants in the Paterson area will return to work tomorrow, it was announced this afternoon by Joseph Knapik, national president of the Federation of Dyers, Finishers, Printers and Bleachers of America, C.I.O., after a meeting of shop chairmen and delegates of Local 1733.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The likelihood of induction into service in May or June of some of the men who registered Feb. 16 was indicated by a new series of orders issued today by the Selective Service System.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Representatives of several railroads asked the Ways and Means Committee today to continue in law a provision permitting them to discharge indebtedness by acquiring securities at less than face value, but eliminating the proviso that to escape taxation in such matters the railroad must certify it is in an unsound financial condition.

Forty-two athletes from six colleges in the metropolitan area were enlisted in the Marine Corps Reserve yesterday afternoon by Lieutenant Valentine E. Diehl of the Eastern Recruiting Division. The ceremony took place in front of a statue of Alexander Hamilton at 116th Street and Amsterdam Avenue on the Columbia University Campus.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 1 -- Mrs. Francis B. Sayre, wife of the High Commissioner to the Philippines, gave an account today of life on the island fortress of Corregidor.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- Senator Bone of Washington introduced today in the Senate a bill to create a Columbia Power Administration, financed by revenue bonds, which would market and control the power generated by the Bonneville and Grand Coulee hydro-electric developments.

CAMDEN, N.J., April 1 -- Nearly 800 employes of the Radio Condenser Company, holder of war contracts estimated to total $5,000,000, went on strike this morning in support of their demand for an increase of 15 per cent in wages.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Pleas of mine operators that the price ceiling on Pennsylvania anthracite, set Monday by the Office of Price Administration, be rescinded, or at least stayed, were rejected by the OPA today following a conference with the mine operators.

Major Gen. Irving J. Phillipson, commander of the Second Corps Area, accepted from Joe Louis and Mike Jacobs a check for $64,980.02 on behalf of the Army Emergency, Relief yesterday at 90 Church Street. The amount was the sum realized from the recent Louis-Abe Simon heavyweight title bout at Madison Square Garden.

NORFOLK, Va., April 1 (U.P.) -- Survivors of the torpedoed American passenger-cargo ship who were landed here said there was a possibility the gun crew of the sunken ship may have exacted retribution. Leroy Tate, a seaman of New York, said that as the lifeboat in which the expectant mother had been placed pulled away from the ship's side, it came within a few feet of destruction.
Business leases for large units of space were reported yesterday in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx.

TRENTON, April 1 -- New Jersey's most extensive test blackout, covering 1,500 square miles and affecting more than half of the State's population, will be held during the week of April 12, the date and hour to be announced later. No indication of the length of the blackout was given.

A departure from the usual form of lease taken for Federal agency space is noted in the contract for quarters of the Public Roads Administration, which moved its offices yesterday to 200 Varick Street, Manhattan. The office for a long time had been maintained in Long Island City.

ALBANY, April 1 -- The Assembly passed and sent today to the Senate the Reoux resolution proposing a constitutional amendment which would curtail the budget-making powers of the Governor. It would prohibit the Governor from decreasing in his proposed budget any amount already fixed in the law as State aid to localities.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., have received the award of an issue of $425,000 of primary road refunding bonds of Sioux City, Iowa, on a bid of 100.1308 for 3/4 of 1 per cent obligations. The bonds, dated May 1, 1942, will mature from May 1, 1943 to 1947.

AT SEA OFF PANAMA, April 1 (AP) -- One of the mightiest forces serving in the joint air, sea and land defense of the Panama Canal is the fleet of patrol torpedo boats, PT boats, which are now operating in the waters off Panama. They have true high-scoring power as proved by the results turned in by the tiny group operating with General MacArthur in the Philippines.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The Physical Fitness Division of the Office of Civilian Defense has been transferred to the Federal Security Agency and is now functioning under the Agency's Office of Defense, Health and Welfare Service, it was stated here today.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The Boston Providence Railroad Corporation today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to reopen the New York, New Haven Hartford reorganization proceedings and to accept an amendment to the reorganization plan which would provide for acquisition of the Boston Providence by the New Haven.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 1 -- In three days of offensive and defensive action, the United Nations air forces have destroyed four Japanese planes, probably destroyed eighteen and damaged eleven, it was announced officially tonight.

Louis Levy, former N.Y.U. champion, qualified yesterday for the United States Chess Federation finals by defeating Jacob Szold in forty-six moves at the Marshall Club. Levy finished his schedule with a score of 5-1. Like Carl Pilnick, City College champion, the other qualifier from Section C, Levy did not lose a game out-right.

From time to time during the past few months, newspaper correspondents and columnists have expressed surprise over the mysterious absence of military parades in this country. Perhaps these comments have inspired the Army Day parade scheduled for next Saturday on Fifth Avenue.

THE only time I was ever in Miami I hired a taxi driver to show me the town. He proved to be a perfunctory, lackadaisical cicerone until he drew up in front of Al Capone's home. Then his eyes danced and his words became eloquent.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey has been given an opportunity to reply to the serious charges made against it by Assistant Attorney General Arnold. It is now possible to form an opinion on the part played by that company in hindering or helping the development of synthetic rubber in this country.

The Jewish holiday of Passover, commemorating the deliverance of the ancient Hebrews from bondage in Egypt, was ushered in at sundown yesterday with religious services in synagogues and temples, followed by Seders or ritual feasts in the home.

LONDON, April 1 -- The government has been exhorting the people to give up their Easter holiday for the sake of the war effort. There is little hope, however, that the pleas will be widely heeded, for the British people will give up almost everything, except a long, free week-end.

LONDON, April 1 -- Convoys carrying war supplies to Russia are to be more heavily guarded, it was learned today. The Germans are making desperate efforts to sever the sea communications between this country and the Soviet's northern ports, and with the days growing longer the convoys will run even greater danger than at present.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- From radios to salad oils, from carpets to coat hangers, the paraphernalia of the American home is falling prey to war demands for the vital metals, fabrics or shipping space represented by these articles. Some have been put under price ceilings, some have been curtailed and some can no longer be manufactured.

Most of the buses that the Third Avenue Railway Company intended to use to replace trolley cars on its Fifty-ninth Street, Tenth Avenue and other lines -- a change that was barred by the Office of Defense Transportation -- will go at once into transportation service for the Navy.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 1 -- German civil courts will be able in the future to carry on their work with an efficiency and dispatch resembled it closely that of the military tribunals, according to a decree signed, by Adolf Hitler March 21 but published in the German press only today.

New York City's four municipal colleges and their 51,000 students have been asked by Ordway Tead, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, to assist the warring United Nations by "taking fuller account of the vast American ignorance of the culture and concerns of China, India and Russia," it was announced yesterday.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, April 1 -- Army Minister Francis M. Forde of Australia went on record today with the promise that General Douglas MacArthur and General Sir Thomas Blamey would have a free hand without political interference in moving army units where they wished in Australia.
BOWIE, Md., April 1 -- Eastern horse racing will get its first test of the war tomorrow, when Bowie opens a nine-day meeting inaugurating Maryland's Spring season.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- The War Production Board hopes that all production workers who do not intend to spend Easter Sunday as a day of religious observance will put in a full day on April 5 at their machines, the office of Chairman Donald M. Nelson said today.

Foreseing the possibility of a Japanese attack on Soviet Russia simultaneously with a resumption or the Nazi offensive against the Red armies, Joseph E. Davies, former American Ambassador to Russia, yesterday urged that the United States send the greatest possible assistance to the Russians to forestall disaster for the anti-Axis cause.

Members of the Religious Society of Friends may serve in the armed forces if they wish, or may become conscientious objectors, without affecting their standing in the society, according to one of the member groups represented yesterday at the opening of the 247th session of the New York Yearly Meeting of the Society.

Mayor La Guardia placed the city departments on a wartime footing yesterday when he submitted his executive budget for 1942-1943 to the Board of Estimate with a tax levy total of $568,881,791, which showed a cut of $4,858,802 from the current tax levy budget of $573,740,594.

With trade sources buying only in a scattered way and mostly on a scale down, the cotton market moved irregularly yesterday in less active trading. On the New York Cotton Exchange, active futures contracts finished 1 point lower to 1 point higher than on Tuesday.

Sam Mele's varsity debut was quit a success yesterday. The husky N.Y.U. sophomore hit a two-run homer in his first time at bat and later slashed out a double with the bases full to give the Violet a 7-3 victory over Columbia at Ohio Field in what was the opening clash of the new Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference for both teams.

Representatives of the loan departments of about twenty New York City banks met yesterday with officials of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in open forum discussion of plans for cooperation between the RFC and the banks in the making of loans to small concerns engaged or desiring to engage in war contracts.

ALBANY, April 1 -- Before the Legislature recessed today for the Easter vacation and the Jewish holy days, to reconvene next Wednesday night two war measures came out of the rules committee in the Assembly, were passed without opposition and now await Senate action. The first is a State "lease-lend" act, which clears away technicalities as to whether property needed in an emergency belongs to the city, the State, or the national government.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- A public offering of about $1,500,000,000 of Treasury certificates of indebtedness at par, to mature in about six months and to bear interest, payable by coupon, at the rate of one-half of 1 per cent, was announced today for April 6 by Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The National War Labor Board was reported split today on the controversial question of union security, with a majority of public and labor members leaning toward a precedent-making ruling which would require a small New Jersey employer to grant a "maintenance of membership" clause.

Short-wave radio channels suffered a sun-spot "blitz" yesterday at 12:35 P.M. It was one the most sudden and complete ever experienced here, according to engineers of the Mackay Radio and Telegraph Company.

NEW DELHI, India, April 1 (AP) -- The Sikhs, warriors of the Punjab, and the Hindu Mahasabha rejected tonight the British plan for Indian post-war independence, and all India awaited tensely the decision of the majority All-India Congress party.

NORFOLK, Va., April 1 -- Attended by a ship's doctor who was in agony because of two broken ribs, a young mother gave birth to a boy in a crowded lifeboat pitched about by fifteen-foot waves after their ship was torpedoed and sunk off the Atlantic Coast Sunday by an Axis submarine.

CHICAGO, April 1 -- Grain markets developed an easier undertone on the Board of Trade today, and while prices held within relatively narrow limits there was a lack of aggressive support in wheat and corn. Corn acted somewhat tired, and with the closing of spreads between corn and wheat, corn finished at losses of 3/8 to 1/2 cent a bushel and wheat lost 1/8 to 1/4 cent.
One thousand rest centers in the city's five boroughs where the Red Cross can feed and shelter bombed-out New Yorkers are available, it was announced yesterday by chairmen of various local chapters.

OTTAWA, April 1 (AP) -- The appointment of Major Gen. Maurice Pope as the representative in Washington of the war committee of the Canadian Cabinet was announced today by the office of Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King, which said General Pope would maintain contact with the combined chiefs of staff committee.

Druggists in New York City began yesterday the enforcement of the War Production Board order requiring buyers of toothpaste and shaving cream in collapsible tubes to turn in an old container. In some places observance was strict, in others the turn-in requirement was waived with a warning.

Filing suit yesterday in Supreme Court for reinstatement, Paul J. Kern, ousted president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, charged Mayor La Guardia with repeatedly attempting to "intimidate and usurp the functions" of the commission, ordering the members of the commission to "perform illegal, improper and unscrupulous acts," and seeking to reduce them to the status of "pliant lackeys."

PHILADELPHIA, April 1 -- Differences between the Society of Friends and other religious bodies do not bar the Society from taking part in the movement toward world-wide Christian unity, the Arch Street Friends' Yearly Meeting agreed today.
ORLANDO, Fla., April 1 (AP) -- The Senators trounced the Orlando Air Base team, 9 -- 2, today in a benefit game played before 1,800 fans -- about 1,000 of them wildly cheering soldiers.

It seems certain from the start that Councilman Isaacs's bill to put a stirrup pump, a pail of sand, a pail of water, and a long-handled shovel at every New York City fireside was impracticable. The materials couldn't be had. OCD Director Landis announced nearly a month ago that "all allocations of protective supplies must and will be made according to plans arrived at in cooperation with the military experts of the War Department."

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The arrests of Robert Noble and Ellis O. Jones makes the fourth in the government drive against seditionists. Last Friday George B. Christians, leader of the Crusader White Shirts, and Rudolph Fahl of Denver were seized on similar charges.

Directors of the Aluminum Company of America yesterday called a special meeting of stockholders to be held in Pittsburgh on June 1 to take action on a proposed increase of $150,000,000 in the company's authorized indebtedness. If the plan is approved the directors will be empowered to issue notes, bonds or debentures up to that amount at their discretion.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 1 (AP) -- A group of stockholders failed today in an attempt to limit the bonuses of George Washington Hill, president, and three vice presidents, at a stormy annual meeting of shareholders of the American Tobacco Company.

The first quarterly statements of condition of the banks were issued yesterday, most of them showing important increases in loans and discounts and the majority moderate increases in holdings of United States Government securities.

WITH THE CHINESE ARMY, on the Toungoo Front, Burma, April 1 (AP) -- Under incessant week-long blasting by Japanese dive-bombers and artillery, a Chinese garrison has slashed its way out of encircled Toungoo, forded the Sittang River and rejoined the main Chinese armies in a bloody withdrawal action personally directed by Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a program of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.
On March 7 you published a letter from me in which I objected to the Desmond-Moffat rent control bill because it was limited in its application to defense areas.

A plea for unity in the insurance field in formulating a plan to cooperate with the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in making $1,000,000,000 of war-damage insurance available to property owners in the United States and its possessions was issued yesterday by the National Association of Insurance Agents.

ALBANY, April 1 -- The State birth rate of 16.3 per 1,000 in February was the highest in eleven years, while the death rate, 11.8, was the lowest for the month in history, the Division of Vital Statistics of the State Health Department stated today.

Diamond rings, which the police said could be traced to three men and a woman arrested after a New York detective became suspicious of them at the Hialeah Race Track in Florida, were recovered yesterday.

At the Belasco Theatre tonight Erwin Piscator will offer the Studio Theatre's production of "Nathan the Wise," Ferdinand Bruckner's adaptation of Gotthold Ephraim Lessing's eighteenth century protest against intolerance and plea for the equality of religions and races. Mr. Piscator will serve as the nominal sponsor.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 2 -- The prospects of disposing of Bermuda's bumper onion crop abroad do not seem bright, according to information issued by the chairman of the Agricultural Board, Sir Stanley Spurling.

The Japanese have injected a note of stark reality into the momentous argument going on in India. By landing in force at Akyab, on the west coast of Burma, they have placed themselves literally and visibly at the gates of India -- within 100 miles of the border and directly across the Bay of Bengal from the seething city of Calcutta.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., April 2--The Dodgers' four-game winning streak was stopped by the Tigers today in the getaway game at City Island Park. Detroit won by 5--2.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., April 2 -- Two former United States open champions and two less well known players provided the Winter golf circuit with its first four-way deadlock at the end of the first round of the Asheville open golf tournament today.

I have read with a sense of real shock the attack on C. Hartley Grattan by Congressman Dies. Nothing could be better calculated to create confusion at home or play into the hands of the common enemy than misrepresentations of this sort, particularly when they are directed against a man whose integrity has never been questioned and who, by Australians, is regarded as one of their best friends in the United States.

BUFFALO, April 2 (AP) -- The C.I.O. United Automobile Workers accused the Curtiss-Wright Corporation airplane division today of violating the National Labor Relations Act by "coming to the assistance" of the American Federation of Labor.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 2 -- Juan Antonio Rios, who led Chile's democratic forces to victory in last February's hard-fought electorol campaign, was inaugurated this afternoon as President for a four-year term.

Deputy Police Inspector Henry Bauer, attached to the Twelfth Division in Brooklyn, filed an application for retirement yesterday. Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen said that his extraordinary grand jury has been "investigating Bauer's official conduct in his supervision of the plainclothes men assigned to gambling cases in the Twelfth Division, and also into his financial affairs."

Mayor La Guardia characterized his appearance yesterday before the Bronx grand jury, which is investigating the paving of a Belgian courtyard on the Lake Mahopac estate of Edward J. Flynn, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, with city material and city employed men, as more of a "conference than an examination."

Despite a substantial increase in deposit liabilities, excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City rose $75,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $955,000,000 the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

The Chase National Bank, as agent, announced yesterday that a cash distribution of 9 cents a share will be paid on American certificates representing rights to receive ordinary shares of the capital stock of General Tin Investments, Ltd. Payment will be made only to those who file a declaration required under the British Trading with the Enemy Act of 1939.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Standard Oil officials believed in 1941 that the British Government was influential in blocking development of synthetic rubber in the United States, although they had no direct evidence to this effect, according to evidence presented to the Truman Committee today.

If the United Nations win this war the principle of the world-wide legal equality of races will have to be recognized. Since this is largely a war of ideas, and since racial equality before the law has become one of the central ideas on the democratic side, we can almost say that this principle, in itself, may be the deciding factor.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Costs of "temporary" structures at the ordnance plant near Minden, La., have advanced to such heights, a House Defense Investigating Committee was told today, that they could be compared with those attending the erection of the marble-fronted edifice that houses the Supreme Court and the new House Office Building.

After the first act of "Me and Harry," which was played at the Studio Theatre last evening, a young gentleman of winning personality said that any one who had paid cash would have his money refunded. This cheering incident had something to do with the theatrical licensing regulations, which had been violated.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 2 -- Declaring national C.I.O. policies "do not contribute to necessary unify within the labor movement or the nation," Ray Edmundson, a close friend and neighbor of John L. Lewis, resigned today as regional director of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- A subcommittee of the Senate National Defense Investigating Committee told the Senate today "there appeared to be no question but that rubber can be produced on a commercially sound basis from guayule."
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 2 -- The Harvard baseball team pounded Navy's pitchers for seventeen hits today to defeat the midshipmen in their season's opener by 15 to 4.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Donald M. Nelson placed before a Senate appropriations subcommittee today a plan to control war contracts profits by empowering government authorities to renegotiate the pacts.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- A suggested $14,800,000,000 tax program based on tapping recent increases in income to individuals and corporations was presented to the Ways and Means Committee today by Professor Joseph E. Shafer of Bowling Green State University, Ohio.
SAVANNAH, Ga., April 2 -- The Yankees continued to find the lower levels of Class B baseball much to their liking today as they polished off the Savannah Indians, 9 to 1, before a gathering of 5,000.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- "Let's Get It Done" will be the main theme at the thirtieth annual meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, to be held in Chicago April 27 to 30, with more than 3,000 delegates from chambers of commerce, trade and industrial associations scheduled to discuss national wartime policies of American business and industry.

CHUNGKING, China, April 2 -- Five thousand sea-borne Japanese troops, heavily escorted by warships, have seized the West Burma port of Akyab, fifty miles from the border of India and 130 miles from the Irrawaddy oil fields, completely outflanking British defenders in the Prome sector, a military spokesman revealed tonight.

Twenty-nine Norwegian sailors whose ship had been torpedoed and shelled by an enemy submarine declared yesterday, after they had been landed at Gloucester, N.J., their eagerness to go back to sea as soon as possible. They were survivors of a medium-sized Norwegian vessel, the loss of which was acknowledged by the Navy in Washington yesterday.

Peter J. McGuinness, Greenpoint Democratic leader, was somewhat surprised yesterday that word had leaked out of the legislative corridors in Albany about the introduction of a bill at the last minute to create the post of deputy commissioner of taxation and finance for the former Kings County Sheriff and Register.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., April 2 -- All-out support for New Zealand in the event of invasion has been pledged by the British High Commissioner, Sir Harry Batterbee, in a speech at Christchurch. This is believed to indicate an improvement of the British position in the war in the Pacific.
LONDON, April 2 -- While there was no official confirmation here of a Japanese landing at Akyab, the report was not denied.

Lashing out against Mayor La Guardia's reduction of $868,358 in the Park Department budget for 1942-43, Park Commissioner Robert Moses said yesterday that the recreational facilities of his department might better be closed than operated under conditions which made increased vandalism possible and diminished public safety in the parks.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- A tanker rate of about 3 cents a gallon between United States Gulf, Caribbean and North Atlantic ports was authorized today by the War Shipping Administration. The pre-war rate was about 1 cent.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- The Federal Housing Administration has exhausted its $300,000,000 authorization for insuring mortgages on defense housing under Title VI, an official said today, but intends to ask Congress soon for additional insurance authority.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Senator Tom Connally of Texas said today that on the basis of information given the Foreign Relations Committee, of which he is chairman, by Vice Admiral Thomas C. Hart during the day he was encouraged to believe that the United Nations forces were sufficiently strong to hold Australia as a base for future offensive action against the Japanese.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 2 (U.P.) -- Germans encountering trouble with their trucks in the Libyan desert are tearing Ford and Chevrolet motors from captured British lorries and installing them in German chassis, it was revealed today.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- President Roosevelt vetoed today a measure which would have provided pay increases for about 160,000 postal employes in the field who have been in the service for more than ten years.

Good Friday will be observed today in all Christian churches with solemn services commemorating the Crucifixion of Jesus Christ on Calvary. Meditations on "The Seven Last Words From the Cross" will be delivered by clergymen in Roman Catholic churches and many Protestant churches at Three Hour services from noon to 3 P.M., the hours Christ hung on the cross.

PORTLAND, Me., April 2 (AP) -- Maine Republicans in the closing minutes of their State convention adopted today without a dissenting voice a 325-word platform promising "whole-hearted support" for President Roosevelt's war program.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 2 -- Expense bills of $6,333,980 for the servicing of mortgages and related securities by the old State Mortgage Commission were approved today by Supreme Court Justice Gerald Nolan in a 14,000- word decision.

RIOM, France, April 2 -- Treason charges were injected into the French unpreparedness trial here today as the Supreme Court recessed over the Easter holidays. There was not the slightest intimation of any intention of discontinuance or prolonged interruptions of proceedings and Presiding Magistrate Pierre Caous announced that the trial would be resumed April 14 at 1 P.M.

The WPB is hard on the heels of the Easter rabbit, but will not over-take him in time to change the contents of this year's baskets. The usual assortment of candy bunnies, chicks and ducks, with a generous sprinkling of gaily colored candy eggs will grace many a doorstep Sunday morning -- with no bow to priorities.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Contracts for the 23,000,000 deadweight tons of merchant vessels which has been set by President Roosevelt as the 1942-1943 wartime goal for American shipyards have now been awarded, the Maritime Commission said today.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 2 -- Five members of the Smithville South Company No. 1 of the North Bellmore Volunteer Fire Department pleaded not guilty here today to indictments charging them with third-degree arson, while three other members of the company pleaded not guilty to indictments charging them with setting brush fires in violation of the Penal Law.

LONDON, April 2 -- As the time for the Spring campaigns approaches the British are more worried about the increasing losses at sea than any other aspect of the war, including the ever-present danger of invasion.

CHUNGKING, China, April 2 (U.P.) -- American air transports, flying over snow-clad mountains, are moving war materials from India to the battlegrounds of China, Kung Hsui-hsi, head of the National Transportation Board, said today.
ALBANY, N.Y., April 2 -- With the State's anglers awaiting the opening of the trout season Saturday there remained one bill on the Governor's desk of interest to the fishermen in Rockland County.

DETROIT, April 2 -- A new speed mark was added to the automobile industry's war production record today when Army ordnance officers authorized an announcement that it had taken the Fisher Body division of General Motors just forty-seven days to complete the first all-welded medium tank ever built for the fighting forces.
