The repeated and persistent attacks against the defenders of Bataan, signalized again yesterday by air raids on Corregidor and sharp skirmishes along the land front, plainly represent an attempt on the part of the enemy to conclude as quickly as possible the campaign of Luzon.

LONDON, April 2 -- Large forces of British bombers fanned out last night and early today over what once were three separate countries that are now all part of Adolf Hitler's swollen military domain. The most important target in the operations was the Matford plant at Poissy, ten miles northwest of Paris, which has been turning out twenty trucks daily for the use of the Nazi generals in transporting soldiers on the Russian front.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 2 (AP) -- The Japanese bombed the northern port of Darwin today for the eleventh time, but their loss of air superiority in this theatre of war led to predictions that their next move might be a sea-borne attack on Port Moresby, key city of New Guinea.

The United Light and Power Company and subsidiaries had a consolidated net income of $4,134,544 in 1941, compared with $5,266,602 in 1940, according to the utility's annual report released yesterday by William G. Woolfolk, president. Gross revenues of the system were $102,990,321, against $97,873,418.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The Treasury's estimate that it would be able to raise about $8,500,000,000 this year from internal revenue taxes on the present tax basis seemed justified by receipts for March, which were officially reported today as totaling $3,082,627,146, an all-time record.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- An Army newspaper, to be known as "Yank" and written by soldiers for soldiers, will begin publication soon, the War Department said today.

In seven countries in the Pacific war area the American Mission to Lepers has for years maintained flourishing leper colonies. Though most of these now are in the shadow of war, we still have eighty-three in Africa and elsewhere in which some of the world's lepers are receiving not only Christian teaching and comfort but also the most skilled modern medical care.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Elimination of Sunday and special deliveries of bakery goods were among seven suggestions offered to the War Production Board today by an advisory committee from the baking industry.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 2 -- United States and British naval officers stood shoulder to shoulder this afternoon as the American Car and Foundry Company launched the J-802 mine sweeper for the British Navy into the Christiana River.
ALBANY, April 2 -- Thousands of New York boys and girls are enrolling for farm jobs to replace workers who have gone into war plants.
All retiring directors of the National Cylinder Gas Company were re-elected at the annual meeting of stockholders in Chicago yesterday when a minority group failed to present an opposition slate.

The number of freight cars loaded in April, May and June is expected to be 14.6 per cent greater than for the same period last year, according to a summary issued by the thirteen Shippers' Advisory Boards yesterday. The estimates usually cover twenty-nine items, but in the latest one the compilation for automobiles, trucks and parts is omitted because of the conversion of industry to production for war uses.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Moving to halt the sale of bicycles to persons who do not need them and to preserve existing stocks for the requirements of war workers, the War Production Board "froze" the sale, shipment, delivery or transfer of all new adult bicycles, effective at 11:59 P.M. tonight.

New York's first all-women parade since the days of the first World War will be held on Saturday, April 11, with ten thousand women in the uniforms of their volunteer defense organizations marching down Fifth Avenue from Eighty-sixth to Sixty-second Street.

Smoked ham -- as traditional a part of Easter as the bunny rabbit himself -- is averaging 34 cents a pound this week-end in representative stores about the city. This price, according to the Consumers Service Bureau of the New York Department of Markets, is 8 cents higher than that which prevailed last Easter, though 2 cents below that of a week ago.
FORT MILLS, Corregidor, March 31 (Delayed) (U.P.)--The defenders of Corregidor buried Lieut. Col. Herbert L. Harries today among the bomb craters of this besieged island fortress.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Bottlenecks in vital aircraft parts so serious that producers of military and naval planes have had to slow down their assembly lines were reported to the Senate today by a special defense investigating committee which blamed the described situation on "a poor job of over-all planning" by the armed forces and the now superseded Office of Production Management.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- James F. Knowlson, Director of Industry Operations, said today that although it is relying on voluntary support by industry of the war production program, the board is prepared to act swiftly and without hesitation whenever necessary to insure compliance. Mr. Knowlson said:

A sailor from a warship and a New York Telephone Company operator, talking over a jukebox microphone shortly before 3 o'clock yesterday morning from the restaurant and tap room at 20 East Ninth Street, in Greenwich Village, brought about the subsequent capture of three ex-convict gunmen six blocks away, who had just held up the bartender and twelve men and women patrons, getting about $300.

Matthew Green, former City College player, gained a place in the United States Chess Federation finals last night when Joseph Hidalgo Jr. of the High School of Commerce was defeated by J.S. Battell at the Marshall Chess Club in a Ruy Lopez lasting fifty-eight moves.

Bank clearings for twenty-three leading cities of the country in the week ended on Wednesday amounted to $6,711,503,000, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The total was $241,134,000, or 3.5 per cent below the previous week and $363,244,000, or 5.1 per cent, below those of a year ago.

A horse-drawn wagon has been substituted for one of the light automobile delivery trucks at the Forest Hills store of the Great Union Company, grocers, 85 Austin Street, Forest Hills. Teddy Siegal, who used to drive one of the trucks, now drives the horse.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, April 2 -- By far the greatest part of the Philippines, both in territory and in population, still is free of the Japanese invader and still is under the American flag. The people are unwavering in their loyalty to the United States, although considerably puzzled over the Allies' continued withdrawals and their failure to take the initiative against Japan.

LONDON, Friday, April 3 (UP) -- Heavy German bombing attacks on the southeast coast of England early today were conducted in such a manner as to cause speculation that the Nazis are worrying about the possibility of a British Spring invasion of occupied Europe.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 2 -- A human fish from Hawaii, Kiyoshi Nakama, stroked a spectacular 1,500-meter race today and sent the three-day National A. A.U. swimming championships off in a foam of records.

I hope I may be allowed to correct the wrong impression which may have been made by Senator Reed's charge about the allegedly large sums which unions received annually from workers on the War Department's construction Jobs.
BERLIN, April 2 (German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique said today:

WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- Joseph Goldstein, a former city magistrate in Brooklyn, presented to the Post Office Department today a petition asking that the weekly magazine Social Justice be barred from the mails. He said the petition was signed by about 5,000 persons, representing many faiths, including a large number of Catholics.

DURHAM, N.C., April 2 (AP) -- Results ran generally true to form today as the best badminton amateurs in the nation played through to the quarter-finals of the men's and women's singles in the United States championships.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 2 -- Bulgarian troops are already on the southern Russian front, reports the Berlin correspondent of the German-inspired S.T.B. News Agency, citing "well informed circles." The correspondent adds that "although German troops are still concentrating on holding the Winter lines, it is hinted in military circles that as far as the southern sector is concerned it is already possible to speak of the beginning of the long-expected offensive."

MEXICO CITY, April 2 -- Newspapers said today that the Department of Interior had arrested eight Germans and Japanese for examination. Unofficially the number of arrests has been put at thirty in Mexico City and a score or more elsewhere.

The raw fur market has again become exceptionally active, as manufacturers have begun to receive substantial orders for made-up furs from jobbers and retailers, according to the market report issued yesterday by the United Fur Brokers.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Donald M. Nelson submitted to a Senate Apropriations subcommittee today a proposal that all war profits above an applied limitation should be recaptured by the government.

The Guaranty Trust Company in its statement of condition as of March 31 reports total deposits of $2,256,851,588, compared with $2,259,895,401 on Dec. 31, 1941, and with $2,520,172,054 on March 31, 1941. Total resources are $2,555,077,767, compared with $2,558,587,698 three months ago and with $2,813,930,185 one year ago.

A scientific approach to the inculcation of temperance in the younger generation was recommended at yesterday's session of the New York yearly meeting of the Religious Society of Friends, held at 221 East Fifteenth Street. Representatives of many groups of the society participated in the day's program.

The 1,650-ton destroyer Farenholt was commissioned here by the Navy yesterday in a colorful "sailor's ceremony" dedicated to the bluejacket, to the apprentice seaman and the petty officer who "year after year have found their sea legs, mastered the skills demanded of them and added to the greatness of a great fighting organization.

ANKARA, Turkey, April 1 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Abdurrahman Sayman, one of four men put on trial today on the charge of trying to kill Franz von Papen, German Am bassador to Turkey, asserted that the conspirators had intended to kill Joachim yon Ribbentrop, German Foreign Minister, too.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Use of tinplate and terne plate as caps for glass bottles was brought under control by the War Production Board today in an order which halted the production of caps for some foods at once, and ordered production for others to stop in a month.

When a woman builds a castle-in-the-air she never sees a Gothic chateau full of armor and tapestries, or an ancient Georgian mansion--her vision, most often, is simply a sunny house in the country somewhere. She furnishes it with well-polished copper, with flowers, with white-painted wood-work and orderly linen closets full of dazzling sheets.
Because of the increasing importance of railways in the transport of oil the Association of American Railroads has added a tank car section to its car service division, it was announced yesterday.

Warning that the United States would have to take the lead in post-war economic readjustment to avert "world chaos," Mayor La Guardia recommended yesterday the immediate appropriation of a Federal fund for national recovery of about $100,000,000 to finance a program of post-war work.

The middle-aged Old Grad who hasn't visited his alma mater for many years is sure to be in for a pleasant session of mental soliloquy when he receives a chance copy of the undergraduate newspaper from the college. The alumni secretary usually sees that he gets this intelligence from the campus, and for good reasons of his own: there is inevitably a financial campaign in the air.

That the forces of democracy and freedom will ultimately triumph over the powers of dictatorship and oppression is the encouraging message that the ancient Jewish holiday of Passover brings to modern America, rabbis declared in sermons here yesterday, the first day of Passover, which commemorates the deliverance of the Hebrews from bondage in Egypt.

Army and Navy units, including West Point cadets and Naval Reserve midshipmen, will take part in the Army Day parade on Fifth Avenue tomorrow afternoon with R.O.T.C. groups from New York colleges, veterans' organizations, other military outfits and civil and patriotic organizations.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Department store sales in the week ended March 28 were 26 per cent above the corresponding periods of last year, the same gain as a week earlier, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. For the four weeks ended March 28 the sales were also up 26 per cent above the corresponding period of 1941.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 2 -- German spies in Sweden are responsible for the sinking of three or four of the eleven Free Norwegian ships that made a dash for Britain from Goeteborg on Tuesday night, it was asserted today by the Nya Dagligt Allehanda and by the new Social Democratic evening newspaper, the Aftontidningen.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- A fourteen-point plan to mobilize men and women for work in war industries, including government power to transfer workers from one factory to another, was laid before the Senate Labor Committee today by Sidney Hillman, labor director of the War Production Board.

BOSTON, April 2 -- Administration of the anti-gray-hair vitamin to thirty gray-haired inmates of a penal institution in eight months has restored the original color of the hair in more than two-thirds of the cases, according to reports made today before the American Institute of Nutrition, which is holding its annual meeting as a component group of the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biolgy.

TORONTO, April 2 (AP) -- Premier Mitchell F. Hepburn announced a surplus of $1,383,552, in delivering his budget message to the Ontario Legislature today, extending an unbroken list of surpluses since his Liberal government came to power eight years ago.

TOKYO, April 2 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- It was officially announced here today that new and improved airfields in Lishui and Chuhsien, to which long-range American bombers had been sent from Java, were destroyed and that "the United Nations' dream of carrying out bombing raids on Japan from China was shattered."

PRINCETON, N.J., April 2 -- Trinity's baseball team turned back Princeton, 7 -- 4, in the Tigers' opening game of the season on University Field today. Frank Steers went the route for the visitors, while Ray Talcott, John Eide and George Palmer shared Princeton's mound duties.

George Whitney, president of J.P. Morgan Co., Inc., has been appointed chairman of the individual contribution division of the New York City Citizens Committee of the Navy Relief Society, Clarence Dillon, chairman of the National Citizens Committee, announced yesterday.

That a feud in the Greek Government-in-Exile that resulted in the dismissal of Aristides Dimitratos as Minister of Labor last February had involved the National Broadcasting Company's international division in a censorship measure was charged yesterday afternoon when the former Cabinet member revealed that a Greek-language broadcast which he was asked to make at 4:30 P.M., Wednesday, had been canceled suddenly.
Clerks and customers in the linen department of R.H. Macy Co. were distracted during yesterday's noon-time rush by the thin wails of an infant abandoned on a supervisor's desk on the sixth floor.

James A. Farley, an honorary chairman of the Greater New York Fund's campaign for 1942, and other speakers made appeals at noon yesterday from the steps of the United States Custom House to 5,000 persons gathered in Bowlhug Green ot contribute to the fund, which seeks to raise $5,000,000 for the support of 400 voluntary welfare and health agencies.

What started out yesterday afternoon to be a publicity stunt, made to order and full of "appeal," ended in a sincere tribute to General Douglas MacArthur by five sergeants of the Royal Australian Air Force.

CAMDEN, N.J., April 2 -- To mark total conversion of the local plant of RCA Manufacturing Company from civilian to war output, William L. Batt, director of the Raw Materials Division of the War Production Board, will be guest of honor at ceremonies here on April 7, when he will receive the last phonograph-radio as it comes off the assembly line.
An appeal for Federal funds to establish nursery schools throughout the city was made yesterday by James Marshall, president of the Board of Education.

PHILADELPHIA, April 2 -- The public utilities division of the Securities and Exchange Commission asked today in a hearing that the Engineers Public Service Company be so restricted as to its operations as to make the retention of the company itself "an economic monstrosity."

Possibility that the War Production Board may issue an order banning the introduction of new products in "nonessential" fields has been receiving attention in both manufacturing and merchandising circles, although trade check-ups thus far do not bear out the likelihood of such an order in the immediate future, reports here yesterday indicated.

On the editorial page of The Times of March 31 is a letter from Maurice P. Davidson of the New York State Power Authority, with its caption "Massena Line Viewed as Need." This letter is answered by your editorial "Massena and Aluminum." I doubt if the correctness of your editorial can be questioned.

CORREGIDOR, P.I., March 31 (delayed) (AP) -- According to Major T.K. McNair of Red Bank, N.J., Corregidor has undergone more than 120 actual air raids since Dec. 29, with the longest raid, of more than six hours duration, this last week.

A collection of 397 books, musical scores and manuscripts autographed by Victor Herbert, William Jennings Bryan, Harry Houdini, Theodore Roosevelt, John Philip Sousa and other famous Americans were donated to Columbia University by the late Isidore Witmark, publisher of popular music, it was announced yesterday at the university.

Invitations are being issued by the American Museum of Natural History for the formal opening and preview of the Hall of North American Mammals on Wednesday. The exhibition will be opened for the public the next day.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra, Serge Koussevitzky, conductor, returned to Carnegie Hall last night and played its very best. This means almost the acme of virtuosity and of tonal luster in performance. It also means that Dr. Koussevitzky was addressing himself with every intuition and artistic energy he possesses to the unfoldment of the music.

A "Handbook of Civilian Protection," prepared by experts acting through the Civilian Defense Council of City College, will be brought out commercially on Monday as virtually an official manual of procedure in such matters as air raids, salvage, fire fighting and first aid.

ALBANY, April 2 -- Governor Lehman in a proclamation today designated the days and hours of registration for all male citizens in this State between the ages of 45 and 65 in compliance with a proclamation issued by President Roosevelt. The days and hours are April 25 and 26 between the hours of 1 P.M. and 6 P.M., and April 27 between the hours of 7 A.M. and 9 P.M., Eastern war time.
RIOM, France, April 2 (AP) -- Former Premier Edouard Daladier, on trial with four other onetime political and military leaders of France, declared today:

Speaking before the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, James G. McDonald, of the Board of Education, complained yesterday that New York City is not getting enough war contracts. It has, he said, the largest potential labor reservoir in the United States and could provide trained labor for much more war work.

Advertising volume in the first quarter of this year dipped from that of last year, but considering the sharp curtailment in consumers' durable goods copy, the decline is less than might have been expected, according to agency executives yesterday.

HONOLULU, April 2 -- The military government of Hawaii froze wages on all island war projects today at the Dec. 1 level, set a forty-eight-hour work week with overtime provisions and issued regulations to hold workers to their present jobs.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The following War Department communique, based on reports received up to 9:30 A.M., was issued today:

HOUSTON, Texas, April 2 -- All other measures having failed to attain a victory, Manager Melvin Ott led his harassed Giants into their first twilight game today, but the experiment, which began in a promising manner, was doomed to failure.

The immense quantities of water that pour over Niagara Falls have worn away the underlying rock into two well-defined channels. Steadily the discharge from the two has been concentrated in one spot to gnaw a notch in the Canadian Horseshoe Falls and detract from their scenic splendor by drawing water away from the entire crest.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- A check for $3,000,000 was delivered today by Dr. Ezequiel Padilla, the Mexican Foreign Minister, who is engaged in official discussions here, to Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, as a payment due from the Mexican Government upon exchange of ratifications of the Claims Convention of Nov. 19, 1941.

The tax laws will prove costly to holders of securities of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway if the plan of reorganization for the company proposed by the Interstate Commerce Commission goes through unchanged, Edward N. Brown, chairman, said in his report for 1941, issued yesterday.
LONDON, April 2 (AP) -- Big-scale fighting in progress on the Leningrad front is growing in intensity "with every hour that passes," the Leningrad radio reported tonight.

BOWIE, Md., April 2 -- G.C. Greer Jr.'s Cape Cod, a Florida campaigner, was a decisive winner today before 12,000 persons who wagered $488,179 on Bowie's eight-race program, which opened the Eastern racing season.

A dinner in honor of Dr. Walter Damrosch will be given Tuesday night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by the Musicians Emergency Fund, which he helped to found, of which he was the first president and of whose board he is now chairman. The dinner will mark the inception of a permanent Walter Damrosch Fund, to be used for the assistance of needy composers and conductors.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- New machinery to better cooperation between the United States and other powers represented in the combined Chiefs of Staff was provided today when the War Department redesignated the War Plans Division of the General Staff as the operations division and made it also a liaison agency.

A regular quarterly dividend of 45 cents a share was voted yesterday by the Commonwealth Edison Company for payment on May 1. This action was taken by the board "in the belief that until the requirements of the new Federal tax laws are known, the dividend policy of the company for the future cannot be determined, and subsequent dividends will have to be reasonably related to the year's earnings," Charles Y. Freeman, chairman, stated.

Two small Laurelton, Queens, boys who decided to spend the first day of their Easter vacation together in Brookville Park, Laurelton, were killed instantly by a Long Island Railroad train three blocks east of the Laurelton station at 9:28 A.M. yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The besieged defenders of Bataan Peninsula today repulsed two onslaughts by the Japanese, in each case after "savage" fighting, the War Department reported tonight.

A drastic step toward the complete reorganization of the American Guild of Variety Artists, which has jurisdiction over 20,000 vaudeville, night club, circus and other performers, was taken yesterday when the international board of Associated Actors and Artistes of America, parent body of all entertainment unions, superseded the national board and officers of the subsidiary A.F. of L. union.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 2 (AP) -- Miss Dorothy Kirby of Atlanta retained her titleholders' golf championship today with a 54-hole total of 239, but was challenged all the way by the bold pitching and putting of 19-year-old Miss Eileen Stulb of Augusta.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 2 -- Exactly a week after their first meeting, Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, Chief of the French State, and Pierre Laval, his former Vice Premier, had another conversation today. Again the scene was Randan, twelve miles from Vichy.

In observance of the Good Friday holiday today all the principal securities and commodity exchanges in the United States and Canada will be closed. Banks in this State will be open today as usual, but those in Connecticut, New Jersey and twelve other States will be closed.

CHICAGO, April 2--Dr. DeLee, founder of the Chicago Lying-In Hospital and the Chicago Maternity Center, became noted also in recent years for the production of motion pictures illustrating approved procedure in obstetrics and gynecology.

FORT DIX, N.J., April 2--Three soldiers were shot and killed tonight and five others suffered gunshot wounds as the result of an argument between Negro and white soldiers over the matter of precedence at a telephone booth just opposite the fort barracks.

WHEN it comes to war, apparently many college athletes prefer to do their fighting in a lofty way. Every day since early December there have been pictures and stories of groups of college athletes -- football players, track and field stars, basketball and baseball captains -- enlisting in the flying forces of the Army and Navy. And thereby hangs a tale.

LONDON, April 2 (AP) -- Note circulation at the Bank of England reached an all-time high of 758,805,000, an increase of 3,738,000 for the week ended yesterday, according to the statement issued today. These figures compare with 614,630,000 at the same date a year ago.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The White House joined Vice President Wallace today in charging that Representative Martin Dies of Texas has served the cause of Axis propaganda. The National Lawyers Guild called for "removal of Martin Dies from public life" and declared that defeat of further appropriations for his Committee on Un-American Activities would be "as important as any military campaign."

LONDON, April 2 (AP) -- Rear Admiral Philippe-Marie Auboyneau has been named commander of Free French naval forces in succession to Admiral Emile Muselier, the Free French press service announced today.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 2 -- For the first time since Federal agents began their post-Pearl Harbor search for "dangerous enemy aliens" on the West Coast, they entered a college campus today to arrest a student.

NEW DELHI, India, April 2 -- With Sir Stafford Cripps's announcement that he has postponed his departure from India, it may now be revealed that there is real hope in influential Indian circles of evolving a compromise on the defense issue that has proved the main stumbling-block in the negotiations.

NORWALK, Conn., April 2 -- Criticizing Federal tire rationing as "inept and needlessly harsh," Elliot E. Simpson, director of several small rubber companies, outlined today a plan to equip all civilian motor vehicles in the United States with retreaded tires for freedom of driving throughout the war.

Universal's "The Ghost of Frankenstein" will be the new arrival today at the Rialto. Lon Charney Jr. appears as the monster in the fourth thriller in the series, with Sir Cedric Hardwicke portraying Dr. Frankenstein. Among the featured players are Bela Lugosi, Ralph Bellamy, Lionel Atwill and Evelyn Ankers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 2 -- Jean Renoir's first directorial assignment at Universal under his new one-picture-a-year contract with the studio will be "Three Smart Girls Join Up," Deanna Durbin's next vehicle, it was learned today.

VALLETTA, Malta, April 2 (AP) -- The Germans, in a persistent dawn-to-dawn attack begun yesterday morning, lost a total of twenty-seven planes destroyed, probably destroyed or damaged, the heaviest losses ever suffered in a twenty-four-hour period over Malta, the British announced in their communique tonight.

BAYONNE, N.J., April 2 -- The locomotive and two baggage cars of a five-car express train of the Reading Company were derailed here at noon today by bricks piled on the tracks by two small boys, who said they did it "just to see what would happen," according to Bayonne police.

The stock market extended yesterday its recovery movement in major fashion and on gains of from 1 to 2 points scored the widest advances in two weeks. The action of the share list on the Stock Exchange was ample reward for those brokers who for the last week had insisted that the market had established a double bottom, from which ascendancy would be easy with even slightly heightened demand.

LONDON, April 2 -- As Sir Stafford Cripps decided to stay in India for a time in the hope of effecting a settlement, there was an air of "cautious optimism" here today. It was believed in official quarters that Sir Stafford's change of plans indicated his belief that there was still a chance of accomplishing his mission.

MILWAUKEE, April 2 (U.P.) -- A War Department official announced today that the Army, Navy and Marines had agreed upon an A flat version of "The Star-Spangled Banner," and urged all, even those who could only "huff and puff," to sing it lustily for the sake of morale.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- President Roosevelt vetoed the bill to raise the pay of more than 150,000 field employes of the postal service, issued an Executive order permitting the importation of jerked beef in Puerto Rico and transacted other official business.

A revaluation of all of the component parts of medical education in this country in the next ten years, followed by a reform of the curriculum, was predicted last night by Dr. Alan Gregg, director for the medical sciences of the Rockefeller Foundation, at the fifty-eighth annual convention dinner of the American Association of Anatomists, in the Hotel Commodore.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- As the first step in an investigation of reported diversions in New York markets of chemicals purchased with priority assistance, WPB announced today that it had ordered the Acme Chemical Company and its subsidiary, the Rona Chemical Company, both of New York, to make no further sales of acetic anhydride or salicylic acid.

War will demand some changes in the normal way of life of civilians. Most of us recognize this and are prepared to accept the changes cheerfully. But in one very important respect a patriotic concern for the national war effort demands, not change, but a determined adherence to normal behavior.

With commendable intent to encourage and dignify the continuance of the development of horizons and capacities for service and satisfaction through one's own initiative after the period of formal instruction has ended, Lyman Bryson, as quoted in your columns on March 25, has essayed a comprehensive definition of education; one that would include "anything that we do for the purpose of taking advantage of the experience of some one else."

PHILADELPHIA, April 2 -- The Public Service Electric and Gas Company of New Jersey, a subsidiary of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey, informed the Securities and Exchange Commission at a hearing today that it had abandoned a plan to sell $15,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage 3 per cent bonds due in 1972 to seven life insurance companies and instead would offer the issue at competitive bidding.
Kansas City, Mo., will enter the market on next Monday with a new issue of $900,000 of airport bonds, it was disclosed yesterday. Details of the proposed offering will be announced at a later date.

Your news dispatches concerning Lew Ayres's, conscientious objector's refusal to aid in the defense of his country in time of world peril recall to my mind the answer that General Douglas MacArthur once gave to these same arguments.

Druggists and manufacturers have requested the War Production Board to ease restrictions on the sale of tooth paste and shaving cream in collapsible tubes, it became known yesterday. They suggest that customers be permitted to make a 2-cent deposit on each tube as an alternative to turning in empty tubes.

CAMDEN, N.J., April 2 -- A back-to-work agreement was reached today between negotiators for the Radio Condenser Company and for Local B-987 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, the affiliate of the American Federation of Labor that called a strike yesterday morning involving 803 employes and tying up $5,000,000 of war contracts, but a decision on a demand for a 15 per cent wage increase was deferred.

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer said yesterday that it would continue in distribution four current films starring Lew Ayres and that it planned to release on schedule two other recently completed films starring the actor, who has been placed in a conscientious objector's camp in Oregon for his refusal to bear arms.

Trade buying and hedging operations were the principal features of trading in cotton futures yesterday and active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange closed at their best levels for the session, with net gains of 7 to 12 points.

Serge Rubinstein, managing director of the Chosen Corporation, described yesterday how assets of that company in this country had been invested in a number of corporations here, with the result that Chosen Corporation lost control of them.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 2 (AP) -- The British Command communique said today:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 2 -- At a conference here this afternoon with officials of the Westchester County Defense Council, Mayor Stanley W. Church of New Rochelle agreed to have that city join in the county blackout to be called next week.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 2 -- Colonel Edward C.O. Thomas, County Director of Civilian Defense, ordered today the immediate dismissal of all enemy aliens engaged in civil defense work in Nassau. He estimated that between 300 and 400 persons would be affected.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Montgomery Ward, the great Chicago merchandising house, is preparing a suit against truckers, the Railway Express and railroads on the Pacific Coast which, it is hoped, will bring squarely before the courts this general question:

CHICAGO, April 2 -- Scattered liquidation and a little hedging pressure disclosed a lack of aggressive support in the wheat market on the Board of Trade today, and while there was a small upturn early in sympathy with cotton, prices dropped later 1 to 1 1/4 cents a bushel to a new low since late last December.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Following moderate advances in prices for agricultural products, the general level of wholesale prices during the week ended March 28 rose to the highest level since the Autumn of 1928, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said today.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- With an increasingly tight situation developing in copper, the armed services as well as power companies and railroads were called upon today by the War Production Board to economize in use of the metal.

MELBOURNE, April 2 -- Lieut. Gen. Henry Gordon Bennett, who commanded the Australian Imperial Force in Malaya, and Lieut. Gens. S.F. Rowell and John Northcott have been appointed corps commanders in the new army organization, it was announced today.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., April 2 -- In what police here described as a duel with pistols, Major William H. Wenstrom, 47 years old, a retired army officer, was killed tonight on the front lawn of his home here.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve banks showed a total bills discounted and the reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date while gold holdings were at the lowest. Holdings of United States Government securities were unchanged.

The nation's investment securities industry slipped into high gear yesterday as it undertook vigorously its first major assignment in assisting the United States Government in financing the war. Having repeatedly volunteered its facilities in this respect, the industry has been called upon by the Treasury to assist in the marketing on next Monday of the $1,500,000,000 of Treasury 0.50 per cent certificates of indebtedness maturing in about six months.

State Senator Allan A. Ryan Jr., who has announced his candidacy against Representative Hamilton Fish in the Twenty-sixth Congressional District, charged here yesterday that Mr. Fish was attempting to use "dictator" methods to prevent having a contest in his home district.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- A Senate Naval Affairs subcommittee established to investigate the possibilities of the Sea Otter as a small, wartime freight carrier, reported its conclusion today that the experimental ship has not had "full and fair consideration" at the hands of the Navy Department and Maritime Commission.
The United States Government will enter the dairy business today for the first time in its history.
ROME, April 2 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command issued the following communique today:

That skiing is playing an important part in promoting Pan-American good-will was shown yesterday at the Hotel New Weston when members of the South American squad reviewed with enthusiasm their eight-week tour of snow centers in the United States.

The Federal Home Loan Banks marketed yesterday, through their fiscal representative here, $42,000,000 of consolidated debentures in two series. Proceeds from the sale of these debentures will be applied to the payment of $52,000,000 of outstanding obligations which mature on April 15.

As far as the arresting police could remember it was the first time that a fifty-passenger bus had been used as a patrol wagon. But in any event there it was, last night, pulling up in front of the West Fifty-fourth Street station -- with one prisoner, a fighting 350-pound Negro woman who, it was charged, had assaulted the bus driver and almost torn the uniform off one of the policemen.

PITTSBURGH, April 2 -- Swept along by high winds, a barrage balloon which snapped its moorings near Akron and raced across Western Pennsylvania late today, trailing a 2,000-foot cable, ripped out power lines and endangered life and property.

The American Sugar Refining Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for 1941 a net profit of $5,417,513 after all charges including taxes. This is equal, after dividend requirements on the 7 per cent preferred stock, to $5.04 a share on 450,000 shares of common stock.
MOSCOW, Friday, April 3 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued the following special communique today on recent activity on the Leningrad front:

LONDON, April 2 -- The stock markets remained quiet today but some prices eased through lack of interest. In the gilt-edge section the 3 per cent war loan declined to 100 1/8. The home rails were dull.

MOSCOW, Friday, April 3 (AP) -- The Russians announced officially today that more than 22,000 Germans had been filled in the Leningrad and Kalinin sectors in a violent Red Army prelude to Adolf Hitler's threatened Spring attempt to smash the Soviet Union.
SEATTLE, April 2 (U.P.) -- Kenji Ito, Seattle-born Japanese attorney, stood before a Federal court jury and pleaded innocent to charges that he failed to register as an agent of Japan.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- During the week ended April 1 member bank reserve balances decreased $31,000,000. Reductions in member bank reserves rose from increases of $131,000,000 in money in circulation and $12,000,000 in Treasury cash and a decrease of $12,000,000 in gold stock, offset, in part, by increases of $13,000,000 in Reserve bank credit and $3,000,000 in Treasury currency and a decrease of $110,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve banks.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Red Cross women volunteers will forego the bellows side pockets with flaps on their uniforms from this date forward, Mrs. Dwight Davis, national director of Volunteer Special Services, said today.

Dr. James S. McLester, Professor of Medicine at the University of Alabama, told the members of the New York Academy of Medicine at the annual Hermann M. Biggs Memorial Lecture last night that "it is a common saying that 'the poorly fed soldier isn't worth a damn,' and within limits the same can be said of poorly fed civilians, for such persons are, as a rule, timid, anxious, nervously unstable and lacking in efficiency."

CHICAGO, April 2 (AP) -- The $14 hog returned today to the livestock market for the first time since October, 1926. One load of choice swine brought $14 a hundred pounds as the general trade was up 15 to 20 cents at $13.75 to $13.90.

It would be easy to minimize the achievements shown in Mayor La Guardia's new budget. Although the Mayor speaks of reductions in the operating appropriations for every department in the city and says that these were "in the great majority of cases reduced by 10 per cent," nevertheless the actual reduction in the tax levy budget from last year amounts to less than 1 per cent.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- President Roosevelt, in a message today congratulating Juan Antonio Rios upon his inauguration as President of Chile, expressed confidence that that country would continue in the vanguard of nations standing for freedom.

NEWARK, N.J., April 2 -- Public Service Coordinated Transport, which operates more than 3,000 buses and trolley cars in this State, has discontinued all sightseeing, excursion and charter trips "not vital to the war effort," officials of the company announced here today.

HONOLULU, April 2 -- In the largest mass decoration ceremony in the history of the United States Army a lieutenant colonel and twelve enlisted men received the Silver Star and 128 officers and enlisted men received the Purple Heart today at Hickam Field for gallantry during the Japanese attack Dec. 7.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The basis on which subscriptions will be received on Monday for $1,500,000,000 of new Treasury certificates of indebtedness was announced today by the Treasury.

While it had been expected that the fabric conservation order of the clothing branch of the War Production Board, eliminating or modifying certain features of women's outer apparel, would be issued toward the end of this week, reports here yesterday indicated that the new regulations would probably not make their appearance until some time next week.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- President Roosevelt accepted today "with deepest regret" the resignation of Alexander W. Weddell as Ambassador to Spain.

CLEVELAND, April 3 (AP) -- To extend the influence of Robert R. Young, chairman of the Alleghany Corporation, over the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) and Pere Marquette Railroads, three bankers and a lawyer, all living in New York, are to be added to the roads' directorates at their annual meetings in May, proxy statements of the railways disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- Terming government printing "the present bottleneck of the war program," Senator Smathers of New Jersey demanded today that small-town newspapers throughout the country receive contracts for printing blanks and forms needed for rationing, licensing and civilian defense.

"Hyacinths? No hyacinths this year. The bulbs came from the Low Countries, and you know what happened there. Lilies? None left. Most of them came from Japan. We did have a few -- and very nice ones, too -- from Florida; but they're all gone. We're even short of cut flowers.
WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- Commander Robert P. McConnell, the rescued commanding officer of the seaplane tender Langley, entered the Navy as an enlisted man in World War I.

In accordance with wartime regulations, no official forecast came yesterday from the Weather Bureau on the all-important question of rain or shine, hot or cold, blustery or calm, for the Easter parade.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- The railroads, called upon to help meet the oil emergency caused by tanker ship sinkings and war diversions, moved a record volume of 506,025 barrels of petroleum daily into the East last week. Petroleum Coordinator Harold L. Ickes reported today.

The hats that file past in the Easter parade will place the emphasis on "prettiness." They will l not be of the freakish variety, the type to inspire derision from conventional souls. They will be dressy and yet demure in treatment.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- The government is developing a long-range weather forecast system for its fighting forces which is expected to match the efficiency of Hitler's secret system, a Weather Bureau staff expert said today.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Secretary Stimson, voicing "the pride which we all share in the Army of the United States," led in a series of official tributes issued today in anticipation of the celebration of Army Day Monday.

Pointing to the self-sacrifice by Christ that led to a "victorious Resurrection," the Right Rev. Henry St. George Tucker, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, in his annual Easter message issued yesterday, called for the principle of complete self-sacrifice in the war days ahead.

DETROIT, April 3 -- Swinging into mass production on war contracts, the automobile industry delivered $580,000,000 worth of guns, tanks, planes and other combat instruments to the Army and Navy in the first three months of this year, George Romney, managing director of the Automotive Council for War Production, reported today.

FORT DIX, N.J., April 3 -- An Army Board of Inquiry began an investigation this afternoon into last night's clash in Pointsville between Military Police and Negro soldiers resulting in the death of one white Military Police and two Negro soldiers and the wounding of five other Negro soldiers.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 3 -- Pre-fabricated dwellings erected on a large parking area outside the Santa Anita race track, and bungalows converted from stables which have sheltered many of America's greatest race horses, were housing 1,000 Japanese evacuees from the San Pedro and Long Beach areas tonight.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -- An increased tax on cigarettes was proposed today before the Ways and Means Committee by Carl B. Robbins, president of the Axton Fisher Tobacco Company of Louisville.

LONDON, Saturday, April 4 -Against the accelerated blows of the Royal Air Force, which included a second night's blasting of the Matford truck works at Poissy in the Paris zone Thursday night, the Nazi Air Fleet bared its teeth over Britain yesterday.

BAYONNE, N.J., April 3 -- Two small boys, who are accused of having caused the derailment of a Reading Company passenger train here yesterday noon, will be arraigned in the Hudson County Juvenile Court on a charge of malicious mischief resulting in damage of about $50,000.

PHILADELPHIA, April 3 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today that in February thirteen registrations aggregating $55,467,000 became effective under the Securities Act of 1933. The total, revealed in an analysis by the commission, compared with $183,098,000 for February, 1941.

LONDON, April 3-The British today from New Delhi categorically denied that any Japanese landing had been made at Akyab, Burmese port northwest of Prome, as reported by a Chungking spokesman. This was the first time in the present war that the British denied anything said by one of their allies.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 3 -- Air Minister Arthur S. Drakeford announced today that the United Nations air forces in Australia would be reinforced by virtually all the men of the Royal Australian Air Force who had served in Malaya as well as by aviation personnel of the Netherlands Indies.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 3 (AP) -- British General Headquarters issued this communique today:

HOLLYWOOD, April 3 (AP) -- Jackie Coogan, "the kid" of silent films who grew to be a soldier, announced today his separation from his wife of less than a year, the former Flower Parry. His disclosure came a month to the day from the birth of their son, John Anthony Coogan.

The annual report of the Canada Life Assurance Company, issued for publication today, shows that the company's life insurance in force at the close of 1941 amounted to $815,470,716, an increase of about $10,000,000 in the year. Assets aggregated $289,058,610.

BABYLON, L.I., April 3 -- After nine hours of running, the judges in the Spring field trial meeting of the Long Island Retriever Field Trial Club were unable to arrive at a decision today on the first three places in the open all-age stake, the principal competition of the week-end, which brought out just two dozen contenders.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., April 3 -- Three types of pursuit planes, heavy and medium bombers, a dive bomber and an observation plane will be on exhibition at the Army Day "open house" here between 1 and 5 o'clock tomorrow afternoon. The planes will be kept ready for instant take-off in case of an air raid alarm.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., April 3 (AP) -- Herman Barron of White Plains, N.Y., the Western open champion, playing in his first tournament in three weeks, today grabbed the half-way lead in the $5,000 Land of the Sky open with his second straight sub-par round for a total of 137.

The Ogden Corporation, a registered public utility holding company, formed in 1940 as the successor to the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, showed net income of $276,979 in 1941, B. H. Brewster reported yesterday in a pamphlet report to stockholders.

Mrs. Eleanor Wilson McAdoo, daughter of the late President Woodrow Wilson, and newly appointed regional adviser of women's activities for the Defense Savings Staff of the Treasury Department on the West Coast, expressed her belief yesterday that American women would play a decisive part in the success of the defense bonds and stamps drive.

An ominous new feature of U-Boat warfare was revealed yesterday when, after the Navy announced the torpedoing of two Allied merchant ships in the Caribbean and the sinking of a tugboat and two barges off the Atlantic Coast, survivors from one of the ships told how a submarine trailed their lifeboat for five days, apparently hoping to pick off any friendly vessel that might come to their rescue.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., April 3 -- Exporters from all parts of the country who have goods held up in warehouses of California ports are swamping assessors in the port cities with inquiries as to how hard they will be hit by California's personal property tax, it was learned here today.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- The Federal Anthracite Commission told President Roosevelt today that the government, in prosecuting the war, had failed to use sufficiently the industrial resources of the Pennsylvania hard coal area.

LONDON, April 3 -- The Easter rush to and from London was under way today despite the government's solemn urging. Thousands of Londoners packed themselves into the scanty trains bound for the country, while residents of the provinces began pouring into London.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 3 -- William Dieterle, RKO unit producer-director for the last eighteen months, has left the company to sign a term contract with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer under which his first picture will be "The Man on America's Conscience," a biography of Andrew Johnson.

DURHAM, N. C., April 3 (AP) -- Dave Freeman of Pasadena, Calif., seeking his fourth straight singles title, will meet Carl Loveday of Montclair, N.J., in the final of the sixth annual United States badminton championships.

LONDON, April 3 -- Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands, in a broadcast to her people in Europe and the Far East today, announced the formation of a special council to act in an advisory capacity in assisting the Netherlands Government as long as it remains outside of the Netherlands.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Dr. Carlton J.H. Hayes, Seth Low Professor of History at Columbia University, was nominated by President Roosevelt today to be Ambassador to Spain. He will fill the vacancy caused by the retirement yesterday for reasons of ill health of Alexander W. Weddell.

New adult-sized bicycles in the hands of dealers and distributors in the New York area were almost gone when the War Production Board order temporarily banning further sales as a prelude to rationing was issued, it developed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- Amid charges and counter-charges of bickering, Mrs. R. Ernest Dupuy, wife of an Army colonel, has resigned with "profound regret" as chairman of the Women's Land Army of the American Voluntary Services.

Market reports here yesterday indicated that the Army call for bids on some 75,O00,O00 yards of wool goods was heavily oversubscribed, with some individual weaves offered in quantities double what the Army was seeking.

A 9-year-old Staten Island school-boy was drowned and four companions, including two of his brothers, were rescued yesterday afternoon after narrowly escaping death when a leaky twenty-five-foot rowboat in which they were paddling on Staten Island Sound sank about fifty yards from the Staten Island shore at Tottenville.

Four midtown theatres will present new attractions this morning. At the Rivoli the newcomer will be the Alexander Korda screen production of Rudyard Kipling's "Jungle Book." Sabu is starred in the Technicolor film, and Joseph Calleia, Rosemary De Camp, Patricia O'Rourke, Frank Puglia and John Qualen have featured roles. . . .

The first service man's post-free letter to be canceled in New York City was a greeting from Corporal Caesar Provenzano of Headquarters Company, First Army, Governors Island, to his mother in the Bronx. She received it yesterday.

LONDON, April 3 (AP) -- The stock market closed generally steady after a dull Good Friday session. British funds were mostly unchanged. Foreign bonds were quiet. Industrials were steady to higher. Rails and Kaffirs were neglected.

The Easter parade will have new interest and new solemnity this year. Flags mingle with the floral sprays that bedeck the avenue, brilliant reminders that all is not well with our world. The best- dressed man will not be wearing the conventional morning coat and topper, but the Navy's stalwart blue or the Army's sturdy khaki.

Nobody outside of Japan knows how many planes that country had when it started the Pacific war. Certainly the number was larger than any one in this country suspected. Indeed, it was enough to give Japan complete air superiority wherever she attacked. All her victories to date, from Pearl Harbor to Java, are in large measure the result of air supremacy.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- College students from eighteen institutions near the national capital will meet here tomorrow under the auspices of the Consumer Division of the Office of Price Administration to discuss wartime consumer problems and the role students can play in the battle against waste.

As a reward for virtue Ferdinand Bruckner's version of Lessing's "Nathan the Wise" has been brought uptown from Twelfth Street to the Belasco, where it had another opening last evening. Since the journey to Broadway gives this department a second opportunity of seeing a celebrated play about religious and racial tolerance, it is again certified in these columns as the first work of real intelligence to appear in our neighborhood for a long time.

Your editorial "End of an Old Service,'' lamenting the passing of the old steamboat lines that plied between New York and New England, bestirs nostalgic memories in this Yorkville New Yorker, who for nearly six decades since young boyhood knew all the steamers that regularly passed up and down the East River.

Basketball in the local area will be concluded for the season with the presentation tonight of a charity double-header at the Bronx Coliseum. With the net proceeds going to several organizations, the Metropolitan All-Stars will oppose Virginia Union University of Richmond and the Renaissance Five will face an all-star professional aggregation in the preliminary.

After commending Mayor La Guardia yesterday for his $4,858,- 803 cut in the next tax levy budget, the Citizens Budget Commission warned that hand-to-mouth financing was rapidly bringing the city to a crisis in which it would not be able to meet mandatory budget charges.

A comprehensive campaign to retrieve several hundred thousand tons of scrap metals from the storerooms of book, magazine and newspaper publishers and printers throughout the country will soon be inaugurated by three divisions of the War Production Board, it was learned here yesterday.

It seems to me that the track writers have overlooked the outstanding achievement of the past indoor season. Everything claimed for Rice, Warmerdam, Dodds, et al, is undoubtedly true. You can't detract anything from their fine performances.

Worshipers of all Christian creeds yesterday observed the nation's first Good Friday at war in twenty-four years by thronging the churches in thousands at the various services held throughout the day to commemorate the most solemn event in Christian annals, the Crucifixion of Jesus Christ on Calvary.

Mrs. Mathilda Harmath yesterday defeated Miss Celia Fawns in a king's knight opening after 42 moves in the women's section of the United States Chess Federation preliminaries at the Marshall Chess Club.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Japanese bombers sank the United States aircraft tender Langley, the destroyer Peary and the Navy tanker Pecos in the raging battles of the Southwest Pacific late in February and early in March, the Navy Department announced tonight.
There will be many Easter Dawn services tomorrow in the New York area. Everywhere prayers will be offered for the men in our armed forces.

VICHY, France, April 3 -- No important announcements were contained in the communique on today's Cabinet meeting, which followed the conclusion of two conversations between Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, French Chief of State, and his one-time designated successor, Pierre Laval. M. Laval visited Paris between the talks.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 3 -- The picture of a United States Navy officer standing coolly at the stern of a half-submerged fleet tanker and peppering machine-gun fire at a Japanese plane that was strafing his men as they swam about in the Indian Ocean was drawn at headquarters of the Twelfth Naval District here today.

A warning against the activities of groups who seek to make political capital of the war and pave the way for the return of prohibition is issued by the New York State Liquor Authority in its annual report that will be submitted today to Governor Lehman and the Legislature.
LONDON, April 3 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

A ROYAL AIR FORCE AIRDROME Somewhere in the Western Desert, April 3 Airmen from Malta, including one American, today told how Royal Air Force fighters and anti-aircraft batteries shot down sixteen Nazi bombers and fighters during German attacks on Malta on Wednesday.

PITTSBURGH, April 3 -- An attempt by John L. Lewis and William L. Hutchinson, president of the A.F. of L. Carpenters Union, to build a third labor movement was charged today by Lester M. Hunt, public relations director of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and spokesman for the president, Daniel J. Tobin.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The Japanese Army on the Bataan Peninsula, which suffered heavy losses yesterday in two strong but futile attempts to breach the defenders' lines, fell back today into the routine of scattered light attacks.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, April 3 -The excellent record made in the Battle of Java by an American pursuit plane squadron headed by Major Charles A. Sprague was revealed today by General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters.

BERLIN, April 3 (From German broadcasts reported by The Associated Press) -- The High Command said today that during February and March the German Navy, operating against the fleets of the United States and Britain, sank one cruiser, eight destroyers, three corvettes, four torpedo boats, twelve motor torpedo boats and motor gunboats, five escort vessels and three submarine chasers.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- President Roosevelt was believed in some Capital diplomatic circles today to be lending his efforts to preventing a rupture in the negotiations in New Delhi on Britain's offer of post-war dominion status for India.

Everybody knows that the retail automobile dealer has been hit hard. There are more than 45,000 such dealers. They find themselves with a stockpile of 1942 models amounting to one-eleventh of the new cars they sold last year, and 25 per cent of this stockpile is "deep frozen" for 1943.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 3 -- An 18-year-old schoolboy sprint sensation from Mercersburg Academy, Alan Ford, thrashed his way to victory tonight in the 220-yard free-style event that highlighted the national A.A.U. swimming championships in the Yale pool.

The New York Housing Authority announced yesterday that it had purchased an additional $107,374 of United States savings bonds, series F, with a maturity value of $145,000. The bonds were bought with funds accumulated as reserves for repairs, maintenance and replacements.
BERLIN, April 3 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique said today:
BOSTON, April 3 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say of the wool market tomorrow:

The President has shown wisdom and tact in appointing Carlton J. Hayes to succeed Alexander W. Weddell as Ambassador to Madrid. From the American point of view Spain is a post of capital importance. Aside from our interest in keeping the westernmost peninsula of Europe out of the war on the Axis side, the cultural and traditional influence of Spain in South America makes its policy of vital concern to the United States.

For the first time in the Second World War New York will see big military parade this afternoon. More than 30,000 men and women will march down Fifth Avenue from Eighty-sixth to Sixty-second Street in the uniforms of the Army and Navy, the American Red Cross, the American Women's Voluntary Services and many other military, civic and patriotic organizations in an Army Day parade.

The New York Botanical Garden in Bronx Park took full cognizance of the Easter season by announcing yesterday that there are on display a bountiful and fragrant group of flowers set against a background of a monastery wall and the front of a cottage.

There's something in Spring air that makes a coiffeur's fingers seem to itch to snip merrily away at the long langorous tresses that we have been carefully cultivating all Winter. This Spring is no exception.

Henry H. Curran, chief magistrate and noted epistolarian, wrote another letter yesterday. It was addressed to the forty-five magistrates under him and dealt ostensibly with summonses for traffic violations. But the learned jurist strayed off into: 1, cocktails; 2, varnishing, and 3, heraldry -- puzzling many of his associates and even getting a little puzzled himself on the last subject.
NEW DELHI, India, April 3 (AP) -- A British General Headquarters communique on the Burma fighting said today:

TEANECK, N.J., April 3 -- Raymond Lufkin, 16 years old, of 134 West Clinton Avenue, Tenafly, was wounded critically tonight when an Army sentry fired on an automobile in which the youth was riding, because the driver did not obey a command to halt after entering the property of the Teaneck Armory, according to Teaneck Township police.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 3 -- Feasting ravenously for the third straight day on a fare of Class B baseball, the Yankees routed the Montgomery Rebels, 14 to 4, today while 2,446 viewed the performance with eminent satisfaction.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The list of German agents traveling to and from Latin America and the cargoes carried on the Italian Lati Air Line, as furnished by the Army and Navy Intelligence services and handed to the Truman Committee today, was as follows:

The Lawyers Trust Company has leased and plans to move its Brooklyn offices early next month into the branch banking quarters formerly occupied by the National City Bank, on the mezzanine floor of the Court-Montague Building, at 16 Court Street, the tallest building in the borough.

The Brooklyn Trust Company reported as of March 31 total deposits of $143,139,698 and total assets of $158,704,230, compared, respectively, with $139,874,550 and $155,506,025 on Dec. 31, 1941. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $51,945,435, against $49,461,430; holdings of United States Government securities, to $56,872,278 against $53,211,270, and loans, bills purchased and bankers acceptances to $30,614,447 against $33,682,646.

This particular detective -- not in life but in a novel -- looked up and a smile illuminated and softened his thin, intelligent face. Literary fashions change not only in respect to contents but even more in respect to labels.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The Navy Department issued the following communique tonight:
Another brook trout season opens in the State today in all but nineteen counties.

Numerous instances in which buyers find it necessary to pay premiums over original contract prices in order to get their goods delivered on time have developed in recent weeks in the fabric and apparel markets, Harry J. Delaney of Meinhard Greeff Co., factors, reported yesterday.

Leigh Willard, president of the Interlake Iron Corporation, in the pamphlet report to stockholders yesterday covering operations of the company and subsidiaries in 1941, states that net profit was $2,406,486, equivalent to $1.20 a share on the common stock.

PHILADELPHIA, April 3 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission gave today its approval to an amended plan submitted by the Great Lakes Utility Company providing for the liquidation and dissolution of the concern in order to effectuate the provisions of Section II of the Holding Company Act.

New issues of municipal bonds scheduled for award next week amount to $24,750,110, representing financing by thirty-seven communities. New issues up for award this week aggregated $28,777,875. The weekly average for the year to date now stands at $23,443,324.

Special "Battle Schools" are now being established in every division of the British Army in Britain under a drastic new training program that puts the soldiers through barrages of real shells and real bullets in test sectors that resemble combat conditions so closely that casualties occur among the troops, it was revealed here yesterday.

ANNAPOLIS, Md. April 3 -- Jack Davis, Navy sophomore, fanned ten batters today as the midshipmen defeated Cornell, 4 to 1, in their second game of the season. Navy rolled up its score in the second and third innings, when Davis and Lefty Lavarkas hit two-baggers.

DALLAS, Texas, April 3 -- On Rebel Field the Giants staged a mild rebellion against the Indians today. A nine-hit attack, coupled with the wildness of Joe Krakauskas, enabled Mel Ott's sorely tried band to end a four-game losing streak with a 5-1 victory.
LONDON, April 3 -- Venders selling dainty Spring flowers from pushcarts at almost every corner of downtown London today lend color to an otherwise grim and drab Easter scene.

The Broadway Theatre will reopen today with a program composed entirely of short subjects. Among the Metro films to be shown are: 'Main Street on the March," "The Tell-Tale Heart," "Optical Poems," 'Wanted, a Master,'' "The Boss Didn't Say Good Morning," "This Is the Bowery," "Quicker' a Wink" and 'Every Sunday."

CLINTON, N.J., April 3 -- Jake's Betsy Ross, a white and orange pointer owned by Frank C. Ash of Fulton, N. Y., and handled by Carl Seattle of Canterbury, N. H., won the junior all-age stake today at the Jockey Hollow Field Trial Club on the New Jersey State Game Preserve.

Several readers have written to ask what "evidence" there is that a penalty wage rate of time-and-a-half for work above forty hours a week has really shortened the average working week and reduced the volume of national production or of war production.

A group of ten new leases has been signed for suites in the building at 161 West Sixteenth Street, Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., agent, reports. The new tenants are Jose Marcal of the Lloyd Brasileiro, Edna Van Zwanenberg of the British Consulate General, S. Herbert Moss, Lucille Gordon, Andrew Adams, Marion Page Armstrong, Thomas McKee, Barrett Roberts, Myrtle Goldenthal and John Bennett.

The shape of each individual and even the proportions of the various parts of his body are determined long before birth, Professor Earl W. Count of the New York Medical College declared at the closing session yesterday of the fiftyeighth convention of the American Association of Anatomists at the Hotel Commodore.

For the last several weeks New York has been girding itself for Easter Sunday and the Spring. There's been a hustle and bustle in the stores on the Avenue. The busiest departments have been those selling suits -- it is one of the greatest suit seasons ever known.

Considerable tightening of credit terms by exporters was reported yesterday by the Export Managers Club following the completion of a survey among its members. Approximately sixty of the 100 members who replied to a questionnaire reported that they were now offering more restricted terms to Latin-American purchasers, in some cases reducing the normal ninety days' credit basis to that of sight drafts.

BOWIE, Md., April 3 -- Cape Cod and Omission, the two big rivals on opening day, will clash here again tomorrow in a field of fourteen named for the $5,000 added Bowie Handicap, which will feature the first Saturday of this Southern Maryland meeting.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on March 28 were 263,208,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines. This represented an increase of 1,484,000 barrels in the week, comprising increases of 1,412,000 and 72,000 barrels in domestic and foreign stocks, respectively.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- C. Hartley Grattan, specialist on Australian affairs for the Board of Economic Warfare and recently accused by Representative Martin Dies as being one of thirty-five board officials with alleged former membership in Communist-front organizations, resigned from the board today in order, he said, to fight another Congressional insinuation that he was a Nazi sympathizer.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- On the night of Feb. 23, with stars shining in a clear sky over the Macassar Strait and scores of Japanese ships plowing through that crucial water, a line of four elderly United States destroyers challenged the Japanese control.

Every caprice of fashion over the last 112 years is vividly reflected in a collection of springtime hats that will open today at the Museum of the City of New York under the theme, "An Easter Bonnet Parade, 1830-1942." More than fifty hats, most of them gifts to the museum, are included.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Office machinery manufacturers were under instructions from the War Production Board today to produce only for government stockpile purposes. When a backlog of machines regarded as sufficient to meet Army, Navy and other essential government as well as Lease-Lend requirements has been accumulated the industry will be required to convert 100 per cent to war work.

For once a real college team that had played a real schedule was invited to the basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden. That team, West Virginia, astonished New York fans by winning. I don't see how they could have avoided doing so.
PHILADELPHIA, April 3 -- Harvard made an auspicious start against Pennsylvania as the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League season opened today, winning, 7-3, on River Field.

Brooklyn society was represented at the Boston Symphony 0rchestra's final concert of the season in the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night. In Box 1 Mrs. Frederick D. MacKay entertained for Mr. and Mrs. Burt Foss Nichols, Mr. and Mrs. William C. Greenwood, Mrs. Edward Fuller, Mrs. Seymour K. Fuller and Mr. and Mrs. George Czarnikow.

Easter will be commemorated tomorrow by churches of all faiths. The tenor of the sermons will be that even with "nation fighting against nation" there shall be no "spiritual blackout." Many of the local Protestant churches will hold additional services, a number of the larger edifices in mid-Manhattan attempting to solve the Easter crowd situation by holding identical late morning services, one following the other, with the same music and the same sermon.
The Municipal Art Society once before has protested in the name of its members at the proposed destruction of the old Aquarium, in Battery Park.

The winning goal in the hockey game that eliminated the New York Rangers from the Stanley Cup playoffs was but a dramatic example of something that has been going on all season long to the apparent discredit of Goalie Jim Henry.
The first move in the war to deprive a person of United States citizenship because of alleged fraud in obtaining it was made yesterday. The person is Paul Huissel, a 40-year-old native of Germany.

For nearly four years the world has followed the schedule of Adolf Hitler. The months and the seasons have been counted according to his timetable. The tempo of aggression has caused us all to move the clock ahead, to turn out the lights, to welcome Winter and dread Spring, to speed up the works of destruction and slow down the works of progress.

The sugar situation has developed into a frightful and expensive mess, and the amazing thing is that the American people still do not realize what has happened to them. Late in 1941 the government bought up the Cuban raw sugar crop. Here is where the Sugar Division of the AAA, which was in existence to police surpluses by establishing quotas, should have folded up and gone out of existence.

Probable effects of retail price control on smaller stores will be discussed at the regional conference to be held Thursday by the smaller stores' bureau of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Possible developments in government price control at the retail level will also be analyzed.

It is impractical and sometimes unfair to compare athletic achievements of the past with those of the present. We can, however, keep the records of the past clear in our minds and correct if we are a bit careful when we refer to past performances.

Wagner's "Parsifal" received its annual Good Friday presentation at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon. A vast audience, which filled every available space in the auditorium, attended, more prospective standees applying for admission than could be accommodated at this closing event in the company's post-season.

BERNE, Switzerland, Saturday, April 4 -- Russian troops maintained the offensive in yesterday's operations, occupying inhabited places in several sectors, according to the midnight Russian communique.
The "Big Show," once the uncontested realm of the horse, rumbled through town yesterday in strict accordance with the order of the day -- mechanized and streamlined.
LONDON, April 3 (AP) -- The reawakened fury of the Western air war left flame and ruin tonight from the Seine to England's stanchly guarded southern coast.

The State Department, Free French representatives and the police in this country and Canada have been trying vainly to locate two youths who left Exeter Academy in January and enlisted in the Free French forces in Montreal.

LONDON, April 3 -- A British concession to the Indian demand for a major voice in the defense of India was reported tonight as a possible outcome of conversations continued in New Delhi between Sir Stafford Cripps, the British representative, and Indian leaders.

Four hundred faculty members of New York City colleges and universities will serve in the future as discussion leaders for the television courses in civilian defense that the Police Department is conducting in association with the National Broadcasting Company, Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine announced yesterday.

SPORT is where you find it. There is no accounting for tastes. This is a true account of a dark pursuit of the Osmerus Mordax, a fish commonly called the smelt and rarely sighted by the ordinary householder except when ushered in, fried, on a hot plate. In the wild state, at this time of year, the Osmerus Mordax leaves the larger bodies of fresh or salt water and runs up rocky streams to spawn.

It is a curious characteristic of this war that today's parade on Fifth Avenue is the first large military parade New York has seen in our first four months of conflict. It is fitting that that parade should be in honor of the new Army of the United States, drawn from farm and factory, town and country -- a cross-section of the men that are America.

As the United States Government began operation of the Netherlands Dairy Company's cheese plant at Syracuse, N.Y., yesterday in its first step in the dairy business, representatives of some dairymen's organizations endorsed the move as necessary to protect farmers and small cooperatives, while others declared that it resulted directly from errors in drafting the recent amendments to the marketing order and from bad government planning in the war.

Pre-Easter trade continued notably active here this week, with estimates putting department store gains over a year ago at around 24 per cent. Main floor items, Easter novelties and candy, millinery and last-minute purchases of men's, women's and children's clothing were outstanding in the business done.

CAMP WHEELER, Ga., April 3 -- More than 10,000 uniformed boys watched the National League champions beat the Camp Wheeler baseball team, 7-5, today and you couldn't convince any of them that the Dodgers weren't lucky the contest didn't turn the other way.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The continued demands upon Congress for legislation to suspend the forty-hour work week and freeze open and closed union-shop conditions for the duration of the war prompted a counter-movement in the Senate today, the introduction of a bill to prohibit some activities by employers and to impose criminal penalties ranging to $10,000 in fines and to imprisonment of six months for violations of labor laws.
Rockefeller Center blossomed yesterday in Easter attire with massed lily plants, while flags of the twenty-six United Nations gave a timely and colorful note to the flower display.

IN his memoirs* George Palmer Putnam, formerly half-owner of the strong old book-publishing house of G.P. Putnam's Sons, gives an account of his stewardship as the inheritor of one of the most enviable backlists in publishing history. The book is easy-moving, anecdotal and frank, and shows quite clearly what goes on in its author's mind and what has been his life.

NEW SHARON, Me., April 3 (AP) -- The body of Mrs. Mary N. Campbell, 58 years old, mother of Florence Buzzell, 20, who was shot to death in June, 1941, was found today in a barn on her farm. There was a bullet wound in her head and at her feet lay a .22-caliber revolver identified as one bought last week at a sporting goods store in Farmington.

The new-issue market this week managed to shake off much of the lethargy that had prevailed for a period of about three weeks and the resumption of corporate financing, coupled with the appearance of several sizable tax-exempt loans, lifted the total of new bond offerings for the week to $35,025,000.

The first of a series of books about Plains Indian tribes prepared by the Montana Writers Project of the WPA has been sent by the State Publishing Company in Helena, Mont.
