"Land of Nakoda" is the story of the Assinboine Indians as it has been told to the writers' project's Indian researchers by old tribal members.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Specific statutory limitations on war profits rather than a general authorization for "reasonable" curbs, as proposed by Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, were approved in principle late today by the Senate Appropiations subcommittee in charge of the $18,300,000,000 supplemental supply bill for Army and Navy.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Reports that the Office of Price Administration had decided upon attacking inflationary price trends by promulgating an order "freezing" wholesale and retail prices for all consumer goods not already under ceilings persisted here today despite official refusals to confirm them.

The new public adress system of the New York Navy Yard in Brooklyn was formally placed in service at noon yesterday when Read Admiral Edward J. Marquart, commandant of the yard and of the Third Naval District, used it to appeal to the 40,000 workers there to work hard and fast and to take every precaution against sabotage.

A study of the effects of the decision of the Canadian Government to train university students so as not to interrupt their studies during the war indicates that the major institutions of higher learning there are maintaining normal operations so far as possible.

CHUNGKING, China, April 3 -In some respects China's famed Flying Tigers may be compared to the equally famed Filipino-American defenders of Bataan, for while each unit has already emblazoned an imperishable record in the pages of history, each is confronted with the same inevitable end unless substantial reinforcements and supplies are quickly forthcoming.

Harald J. Bromley and Day Tuttle will present their production of "The Life of Reilly," the William Roos comedy about a baseball pitcher for the Brooklyn Dodgers, on April 29 at the Broadhurst Theatre. According to the present plans of the producers, the play will open here without benefit of an out-of-town engagement.

I am a capitalist. A capitalist is one who consumes less than he produces. The lowliest laborer is yet a capitalist by this definition if he has but a thin dime. Although we are up to our ears in war, when every second counts, there is an extremely dangerous conflict going on in our midst which, conceivably, may lose the war for us.

On March 9 Governor Edison appointed to the office of Commissioner of Highways Spencer Miller Jr. of South Orange, a registered Republican who voted for Mr. Roosevelt in 1932 and 1936. The President of the Senate admitted the excellence of Mr. Miller's record.

An exhibition of sculpture, entitled "The Animal in Ancient Art," will open on Tuesday at the Sachs Gallery, 63 East Fifty-second Street, and will be on view through April 30. The work to be shown includes an archaic Sumerian horse of 3000 B.C. and a Han rhinoceros of 206 B.C.

Half a dozen sailors provided a Times Square crowd of 2,000 with half an hour's amusement early yesterday morning while they raced monkey-like up and down and in and out of the lattice-work of a one-and-one-half-story electric sign.

An order signed by Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy was filed yesterday decreeing that proceedings for the reorganization of $42,000,000 of real estate securities guaranteed by the old National Surety Company had been completed and discharging Harvey D. Gibson, C. Prevost Boyce and John W. Hannon from "any and all obligation or liability" as reorganization managers.

NEW DELHI, India, April 3 -- Flying Fortresses under the personal command of Major Gen. Lewis H. Brereton, Chief of United States Air Forces in India, have struck their first blow for the relief of the hard-pressed Burma Front by bombing a Japanese cruiser and three troopships of an invasion fleet caught in an Andaman Island harbor in the Bay of Bengal, it was announced tonight.

In an effort to combat misconceptions about the availability of supplies in the printing field, the New York Employing Printers Association, Inc., yesterday issued a four-page folder, detailing the limitation orders on printing supplies and commenting on the supply situation.

Cornell University has sold to J. William and Prudence S. Schmalz the two-story dwelling and one-car garage at 70 Park Avenue, Bronxville, Westchester, valued for taxation at $11,400. The plot measures 73.4 by 102.5 feet. Elliott Bates, Inc., was co-broker in the sale with the Realty Mortgagee Corporation.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Sales of United States savings bonds in March amounted to $557,892,000 or 20.7 per cent less than the $703,300,000 sold in February, the Treasury Department announced today. The drop had been expected, officials said, because of the income tax payments in March.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) would not agree to halt sales of aviation gasoline to the Hitler-controlled Lati and Condor airlines, which carried spies, propaganda and war materials between Europe and Brazil, as well as in South America, until the State Department started action to blacklist the Standard Oil Company of Brazil, a subsidiary, witnesses told the Truman Committee today.

Walter S. Mack Jr., president of the Phoenix Securities Corporation, in his semi-annual report yesterday to stockholders covering the six months ended on Feb. 28, stated that as of that date net asset value of the corporation was $9,053,449 equivalent to $117.11 a share on the $3 dividend convertible preferred stock outstanding, after allowing for the regular dividend payable on the preferred stock on April 1.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., April 3 (AP) -- Mrs. Evelyn Wenstrom, widowed in a gun duel between two retired Army majors, died today of a bullet wound suffered as an innocent bystander.

NEW LONDON, Conn., April - 3 All pleasure craft, regardless of size, have been prohibited from operating in the New London area, according to an announcement this morning at the office of the Captain of the Port of New London.

An investigation by Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson of the feasibility of developing the Rye Lake tract selected as a site for a military airport in Westchester is being sought by Howard S. Cullman, vice chairman of the Port of New York Authority, who is a resident of Westchester.

NEW DELHI, India, April 3 (AP) -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, leader of Free China, was understood today to have appealed to India's leaders to reconsider the formula by which Britain is seeking this subcontinent's full cooperation against the Axis in return for Indian independence after the war.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- President Roosevelt indicated today that the government agencies which are engaged in disseminating information for public consumption will be consolidated under a plan the details of which have not yet been decided upon.

WEST GREENWICH, R.I., April 3 (AP) -- An Army medium bomber crashed into the woodlands here today and exploded, killing all five occupants, two officers and three enlisted men, the First Corps Area announce.

PHILADELPHIA, April 3 -- The Central Power and Light Company of Corpus Christi, Texas, submitted today to the Securities and Exchange Commission a proposal to issue and sell $5,900,000 of its unsecured notes, 2 1/2 per cent, 2 3/4 per cent and 3 per cent, due serially on Aug. 1, 1942, to April 1, 1952, in semi-annual maturities varying from $150,000 to $550,000.
DETROIT, April 3 -- The Catholic Archdiocese of Detroit disavowed today any connection with the magazine Social Justice, founded by the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, Royal Oak radio priest.
Lieut. Comdr. John M. Bermingham, who died in action when the destroyer Peary was sunk, received his final command last January, shortly after he had been preparing to return home on furlough.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (U.P.) -- In the midst of a Senate conflict over proposals to abolish the Civilian Conservation Corps and the National Youth Administration, a statement by President Roosevelt was made public today in which he said, "There is a real place for the CCC during this emergency."

CHICAGO, April 3 -- Further indications of a widening breach between the Congress of Industrial Orangization, headed by Philip Murray, and John L. Lewis's United Mine Workers appeared today when Vernon Ford of Chicago, Middle West regional director of U.M.W. District 50, and Hugh White, State U.M.W. vice president, resigned from the executive board of the Illinois Industrial Council, the C.I.O. controlling body.

LONDON, April 4 -- Sir Stafford Cripps was believed tonight to have moved a step closer to smoothing the way for formulation of what may become a major modification in Great Britain's proposals on Indian independence.

TORONTO, April 4 -- The Detroit Red Wings upset the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight to achieve a 3-2 victory in the first game of their four-out-of-seven final playoffs for the Stanley Cup and the world hockey champion. The contest was played before 14,185 spectators at Maple Leaf Gardens.
CLAREMONT, Calif., April 4 -- Dr. Lillian M. Gilbreth has been selected "woman of the year" by Scripps College.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 4 (AP) -- Army and Navy have moved up five of their Spring sports clashes and scheduled them all for Wednesday, May 27, in order to avoid conflict with the Military Academy's early graduation, May 29, the Army Athletic Association announced today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 4 -- adolf Hitler is not worrying that the German people will abandon him. The outstanding reason why the people still support him is fear -- not fear of the Gestapo, but fear of the consequences of defeat. This state of mind makes the German people rather bear the ills they have than fly to others they know not of -- to paraphrase Hamlet.

It was inevitable that the Government's fiscal authorities from time to time would effect innovations in the usual methods of open-market financing in order to diversify the types of securities outstanding and thus attract all types of idle investment funds.

Sitting beneath an austere-vis-aged portrait of Alexander Hamilton, who founded The New York Post 141 years ago, Dorothy Schiff Backer told yesterday afternoon of her hopes and fears for the city's oldest newspaper, of which she is the new president and publisher.

DURHAM, N.C., April 4 (AP) -- David Guthrie Freeman of Pasadena, Calif., and Pomona College became the men's singles titleholder for the fourth consecutive year tonight when he defeated Carl Loveday of Montclair, N.J., 15 -- 5, 15 -- 10, in the finals of the sixth annual United States badminton championships.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., April 4 -- A novel series of scholarships that will pay all the expenses of a needy student and which may be extended on the same basis for three years of study after graduation, has been announced at Williams College.

Two of New York's best known yachting figures, Charles F. Chapman and Harry A. Jackson, have a distinction unparallelled throughout the country. Each has won twenty-six merit marks during their long years of service in the United States Power Squadrons and each, therefore, when he breaks out his squadron uniform, is entitled to wear twenty-six small gold bars around his left cuff.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 4 -- Two years of German domination have made a new country of Norway. Wilson, Charles Erwin, business executive, president of General Motors since 1940; b. Minerva, Ohio, July 18, 1890; graduate Carnegie Institute of Technology; began career as an electrical engineer with Westinghouse, 1909; with General Motors since 1919; married, six children.

Stocks on the New York Stock Exchange ended yesterday the dullest five-day week in twenty-seven years, or since the week ended on Feb. 27, 1915, which was soon after the Exchange was reopened following its World War shutdown.

One of the most widely discussed literary mysteries of recent years -- the identity of the author of the thrilling anti-Nazi novel "Escape" -- was cleared up yesterday with the disclosure by The Associated Press-Wide World that "Ethel Vance" is Grace Zaring Stone, author of several earlier books, the best known of which is "The Bitter Tea of General Yen."

Taylor of Schenectady, N.Y.

Wainwright's American and Filipino troops, Japanese forces in the Philippines exhibited considerably more caution in the actions reported here down to 9:30 A.M. this morning.

THE Smith College Music Festival to be held April 23-26 at Northampton, Mass., will be devoted to works of the Romantic period. Participants will include the Smith College Orchestra, under Werner Josten; the Smith Glee Club, T.I. Gorokhoff, director, and ensemble groups and soloists also from the school's department of music.

Two of the city's most dissimilar art exhibitions will open to the public simultaneously on Wednesday. One is the twenty-sixth annual exhibition of the Society of Independent Artists at 215 West Fifty-seventh Street. The other is the 116th annual exhibition of the National Academy at its new galleries, 1083 Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Lieut. Gen. William S. Knudsen, Army Production Director, entered the controversy over the forty-hour week today with a statement that while it had caused little delay to the war production program, heavy payments for overtime work had proved a hindrance.

SINCE time immemorial the egg has been a symbol to humanity of life eternal, joy and nourishment. Dietitians recommended it as nature's most digestible food, and economists assure us with mathematical precision that one egg equals one-quarter of a pound of meat in terms of strength and protein value.

BREWSTER, N.Y., April 4 -- The trout fishing season opened in New York State today and many anglers were out at dawn, impatiently awaiting the signal to wade the streams and try their luck against one of the most popular inhabitants of the nation's fresh waters.
TWO top-ranking officers traditionally run the Navy -- the Chief of Naval Operations and the Commander in Chief, United States Fleet. Now Admiral Ernest Joseph King is both of them.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 4 -- The creation of a Council on Undergraduate Affairs to provide integrated administration of problems common to the three undergraduate schools on the Homewood campus has been announced by Dr. Isaiah Bowman, president of Johns Hopkins University.

The representatives of seven nations gathered last Wednesday around the long, polished table of the Cabinet Room in the White House Executive Offices. BENNINGTON, Vt., April 4 -- Opportunity to combine intensive study in a chosen field with regular, supervised farm work will be offered at Bennington College this Summer, it was announced today.

UNIVERSITY, Miss., April 4 -- Mississippians this Spring are feeling more and more the influence of their State university, which, in an effort to expand its scope beyond the classroom, has undertaken to provide service and information to small business, the oil and other mineralogical industries and agriculture, as well as to expand its educational and general cultural facilities.

VICHY, France, April 4 -- General Jean-Marie-Joseph Bergeret, French Secretary of State for Aviation, revealed today that the Vichy government had received "special permission" [which would have to come from Germany] to increase its air force and now had approximately 1,000 modern warplanes, or more than France had in 1939 at the beginning of the war.

SEVASTOPOL, Russia, April 4 (U.P.) -- The Soviet defenders of this Black Sea naval base are hacking steadily into Nazi siege lines with the aid of 75,000 civilians and guerrilla forces that are reported to have killed 600 Germans in a single encounter.

WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, April 4 (AP) -- All Netherland forces in and about Curacao and Aruba, Caribbean Islands, have been placed under the command of Rear Admiral J.B. Oldendorf of the United States Navy, Governor G.J.J. Wouters of Curacao announced in a proclamation today.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The State Department today recognized Free French administrative control over the Cameroons and French Equatorial Africa and announced that a consulate general would be established in Brazzaville, capital of French Equatorial Africa.

FELIX SALMOND, the 'cellist, since the Fall of 1925 associated with the faculty of the Curtis Institute of Music, submitted his resignation to Mrs. Mary Louise Curtis Bok, founder and president, several days ago. It will take effect at the end of the 1942-43 school year, when his contract expires.

AIKEN, S.C., April 4 (AP) -- Lovely Night, carrying the light blue and canary silks of Mrs. F. Ambrose Clark of Old Westbury, L.I., won the fifth running today of the English-modeled Imperial Cup, at two miles over hurdles, in 3:43 3-5.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Sugar rationing will proceed as scheduled in early May, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, and Leon Henderson, head of the Office of Price Administration, declared today in a joint statement made in reply to newspaper and radio reports that the sugar supply situation had improved so materially since January that rationing would be unnecessary.

ORONO, Me., April 4 -- The problem for a university placement bureau nowadays has shifted from finding a job for the senior to finding the man wanted for a job, Philip J. Marking the wind-up of pre-Easter purchasing, retail trade continued notably active here last week. Sales of both department, specialty and chain stores showed heavy gains over a year ago. Department store executive estimated the increase at about 24 per cent over a year ago. The comparison, however, was against a ]ater Easter in 1941 and sales this week are expected to decline because of comparison with rising pre-Easter volume a year ago.

THE conviction must lie deep; it must be burning and passionate, angry and tinged with fear. There is no such conviction today. To most Americans the war is still far away, a drama seen through a glass darkly, a gigantic drama of which the meaning is as yet but little comprehended.

COLUMBIA, S.C., April -- A long-overdue citizens' movement to collect and preserve historical material concerning the State has culminated in the establishment of the South Caroliniana Library on the campus of the University of South Carolina here.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) -- The wartime Easter has brought a protest against the designation "Japanese" for the cherry trees which were a gift from Japan over twoscore years ago.

BOWIE, Md., April 4 -- Cape Cod, winner of the Rowe Memorial on Thursday's opening card, came right back with a victory today in the $6,150 Bowie Handicap as a throng estimated at 15,000 crowded Southern Maryland's mile track. Carrying the colors of G.C. Greer Jr., a Maryland youth of 23 who is in the Army, Cape Cod took the lead at the start and held it the whole mile and seventy yards.

No matter what else changes, one idea remains: Boys and girls aren't made of the stuff we were. At the moment, it is our young men who are considered soft and undisciplined, unable "to take it"; our boys who can't climb trees.

Possibility that development of a "Victory Model" program for consumer articles may mean loss of distinctive trade marks, particularly in the export field, is now being given serious consideration by foreign traders. At a meeting of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau of the National Association of Credit Men last week, the matter was a topic of discussion and although the members were inclined to discount the threat, other traders were somewhat less optimistic.

IT is an old contention which has passed into platitude that Christianity cannot be deemed to be a failure, for the simple reason that it has not been tried. We are offered substitutes in communism and nazism, faiths which have surely conquered kingdoms, the same kingdoms refused by Jesus when He said, "Get thee behind me, Satan."

EVEN before the elections of 1860 the Republican party was split into a right and a left wing, into conservatives and radicals. Because they had a simple program with a definite objective -- emancipation of the slaves and control of the party and country m contrast to the negative and often vacillating program of the conservatives, the radicals (the Jacobins, as John Hay dubbed them) became "the real driving power of the party."
WEST POINT, N.Y., April 4 -- Playing its first baseball game of the season today, Army won from Cornell by 5 -- 1. Tarver and Whitlow held the visitors to five hits.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 4 -- Woebegone and neglected by most former admirers, the League of Nations continues in existence without much animation, but with palpitating hope of eventual rejuvenation.

BATH, Me., April 4 -- Voluntarily absent from daily work are nearly 14 per cent of the employes at the three largest shipyards in Maine, the Todd Bath Iron at South Portland, the South Portland Shipbuilding Corporation and the Bath Iron Works Corporation.

SOMEWHERE IN NORTHERN AUSTRALIA, April 4 (AP) -- Japanese Zero fighters are not any too eager to tackle Flying Fortresses anymore, according to Second Lieutenant Robert Meyer of Birmingham, Ala. He is co-pilot of a Flying Fortress now operating from a North Australian base after fighting in the Philippines and Java.

An exhaustive study of the law and practice of the Federal Trade Commission by Henry Ward Beer, who has served as a trial lawyer on the commission's staff as well as in various other government posts and has also practiced as an attorney representing business concerns, has been published under the title "Federal Trade Law and Practice" by Baker, Voorhis Co., 30 Broad Street.

A NEW coinage started in 1926, when Abdul-Aziz ibn Abdur-Rahman Al-Faisal Al Sa'ud, Sultan of Nejd, was proclaimed King of the Hejaz and united the two dominions into what is known as the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia.

AMONG the things for which one is permitted to be grateful just now is the publication of the second volume of Sean O'Casey's autobiography. The first volume, "I Knock at the Door," appeared three years ago. The second volume is entitled "Pictures in the Hallway," and carries the story of his career through adolescence into the early years of mature life.

When Mr. Morgenthau, Secretary of the Treasury, introduced the subject of taxation of capital gains in his statement before the Ways and Means Committee, he referred to it as another example of special privilege in our tax laws which needs to be remove and as an additional method of avoidance, the removal of which will yield additional revenue.
LONDON, April 4 (Canadian Press) -- Easter week-end football brought out crowds of nearly peacetime size today.
BERLIN, April 4 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

A TOTAL of 3,500 fire towers in the United States furnish the guardians of America's 175,000,000 acres of national forests a place to keep a sharp lookout for that saboteur -- fire -- which last year destroyed enough lumber to house all of Uncle Sam's troops, and more than any of the New England States will produce in the next fifty years.

A piano recital will be given in the clubhouse of the Junior League, 221 East Seventy-first Street, on the night of April 17 by Bruce Simonds as a benefit for the Turtle Bay Music School. Mrs. L. Martin Richmond is chairman of the committee in charge.

IF any one still believes the remark credited to George Harvey that "the traditional American foreign policy is to have no foreign policy" he should read this little book by Professor Nevins. The book is fruitful reading in any case.
LONDON, April 4 (AP) -- Britain and Italy began today the first exchange of sick and wounded prisoners between major belligerents since this war began.

They wanted to cooperate, but the children "just wouldn't take time to eat," so forty mothers told a committee of the Boys Club of New York when a nutrition survey, just completed, was started a year ago. Seems the boys bolted their dinners in order to get out and play; rushed off to school on sketchy nourishment or none, because they weren't up in time for breakfast.

WORD has come from company officials that the big double-decker Fifth Avenue buses are to go. Little by little they are to be withdrawn from service until on Easter morning a year hence the best 10-cent seat in town for the fashion parade will, likely as not, no longer be on sale.

"I DON'T charge anything for this fine show you've seen and all you've still got to see," the Doc of the medicine show told the Florida crowd after his Negro performers had retired from the stage. "The price of admission is your attention."

Both India and Australia are possible objectives against which Japan may direct her main efforts during the coming months. But to regard them as alternatives and suppose that one precludes the other would be an extremely risky proposition.

Ted Allan who can be reached through his agent, Leland Hayward, Inc., 654 Madison Avenue, New York City, is writing a biography of Dr. Norman Bethune, the Canadian surgeon who met his death in China in 1939 while serving with the Chinese forces against the Japanese.

FROM roundabout but reliable sources comes word that, for the first time in its seven-year history, "America's Town Meeting of the Air" will play through the Summer months. To be sure, it will be on the road a good part of that time, returning only occasionally to its home in Forty-third Street, which means that some of the orchestra seat orators will have to restrain themselves.
ON April 17 the Santa Barbara Museum of Natural History will celebrate its twentieth anniversary with a reception for its members and friends at a special exhibition of its achievements.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The Easter season brought delayed Spring weather to this world war capital, and the ancient message that hatred, force and evil can dig no grave deep enough to immure for very long the spirit of celestial grace.

LONDON, April 4 -- Greek guerrilla bands numbering several thousand are constantly harassing the German and Italian invaders throughout many parts of Greece as well as on Crete, according to the latest official reports reaching London.

Orders were so heavy in the better coat and suit market last week that it is anticipated they will hold over even after Easter and postpone the after-Easter clearances, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the McGreevey, Werring Howell Co.

PHILADELPHIA, April 4 -- Making his first hit in three games, Sophomore Art McQuillen drove a home run with two men on the bases to give Pennsylvania's baseball team a 6-5 decision over Harvard in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game on River Field today. This evened the series at 1 -- 1.

The Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company, New York's oldest mutual marine insurance company, will celebrate on next Saturday the 100th anniversary of its founding. Although chartered by an act of the New York Legislature on April 11, 1842, the foundation of the company's business was laid some years earlier when a predecessor company by the name of the Atlantic Insurance Company was organized in 1829.

CLINTON, N.J., April 4 -- Way Yonder, a white and liver pointer owned by Dr. Harold E. Longsdorf of Mount Holly, N. J., and handled by W.D. English of High Point, N.C., won the open all-age stake today, third event of the Jockey Hollow Field Trial Club meeting on the State Game Preserve.

LONDON, April 4 (AP) -- The first of several million Red Army reserves, freshly trained and representing every section of the Soviet Union, were moving into the line from Leningrad to the Black Sea tonight to carry out a plan designed to throttle the German Spring offensive with a total force of 7,000,000 Russians.

Upon his arrival at La Guardia Field by Pan American Airways Clipper yesterday morning after a tour of England, Rabbi Abba Hillel Silver, chairman of the United Palestine Appeal and co-chairman of the United Jewish Appeal, said that the people of England, becoming acquainted with a long series of disasters and impatient with their leaders, want action of an offensive rather than a defensive nature.

CINCINNATI, April 4 -- Each of the ten colleges and schools of the University of Cincinnati has taken steps to gear itself to the war tempo through changes in course subject matter and through accelerated programs, a survey of educational trends on the campus of this municipal institution brought out today.
Much has been written, spoken and rumored about morale of the Army. Certain groups, earnest no doubt, have tried their best to do something about it.

SHREVEPORT, La., April 4 (AP) -- Manager Lou Boudreau today introduced the batting order the Indians expect to use on opening day, but it was barely able to defeat Shreveport of the Texas League, 12 to 10, in eight innings.
"Gardens of Ancient Egypt" is the subject of the free lecture to be given on Saturday at 3:30 at the New York Botanical Garden by H.W. Rickett.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Overriding protests from the War and Navy Departments and the Maritime Commission, the Senate Appropriations Committee today wrote a graduated schedule of rigid, statutory limitations on profits on war contracts into the new $19,062,373,260 sixth supplemental supply bill for the armed forces.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 4 -- Keeping pace with the current trend, students in Princeton University's School of Public and International Affairs will investigate wartime problems of domestic and foreign policy in the United States in two Spring conferences entitled, "Grand Strategy and National Security" and "Domestic Mobilization for War."

The geography, the man power, the material resources of India make it a key theatre of the global conflict that has now spilled from the Pacific to the Indian Ocean basin. The domain of 389,000,000 people, which Mark Twain described as "the country of a hundred tongues, of a thousand religions and two million gods, cradle of the human race," juts deeply into the third largest sea.

DEBT LIMIT: When the Roosevelt Administration began in 1933 the nation's debt was about $22,000,000,000; the legal limit for the debt was $50,000,000,000. Under the pressure of war expenditures the limit was raised to $65,000,000,000; the debt itself has risen to $63,000,000,000.

ERIC KNIGHT, author of "This Above All" and "The Flying Yorkshireman," had just returned after several months in England. He said that he never had been interviewed because "interviewing is no good. We'd have to know each other for twenty years, or get very drunk, before we'd talk truth or be ourselves.

PLANS for strengthening the Civil Aeronautics Authority's Civilian Pilot Training Program at the base by introducing aviation courses into the elementary and secondary schools of the nation are now taking actual shape. By the beginning of the next scholastic year the curricula of the public schools may include subjects that will make fundamental knowledge of flight and airplanes as easily accessible as the multiplication table.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The workman's dinner pail is due to disappear in defense industries. Dr. M.L. Wilson, former assistant secretary of agriculture, who is directing the government's nutrition program, has revealed that a country-wide campaign will be started in the next few weeks to improve specifically the food of labor.

Paul Kilgerrin is a private detective whose motto is: "Shoot first and ask questions afterward." The persons at whom he shoots do not live to answer questions, but their records often speak for them. After Military Intelligence has failed to stop a wave of sabotage that is sweeping the country, the job is turned over to Kilgerrin, and the shooting starts immediately and continues to the end of the story.

With heartfelt pride, admiration and respect, New York paid tribute to the new American Army of freedom and democracy yesterday afternoon as 1,000,000 persons turned out to witness the largest military parade held here since General Pershing's vic torious troops marched up Fifth Avenue after the first World War.
New York's racing season will get under way Thursday at the Jamaica track with most judges agreed that the campaign will be successful.

BABYLON, L.I., April 4 -- Guess of Shagwong, 3-year-old Chesapeake Bay dog, bred and owned by E. Monroe Osborne of East Hampton, L.I., and handled by Mrs. E.L. Morford, today was awarded the chief trophy in the open all-age stake, leading event of the Spring field trial meeting of the Long Island Retriever Field Trial Club.

Four more Allied ships -- United States, Canadian, Norwegian and Latvian -- have been sunk by enemy submarines in Atlantic and Caribbean waters, the Navy Department in Washington announced last night, increasing to twelve the number of sinkings disclosed by the Navy in the last week.

The umbrella plant (some call it "palm") doesn't mind wet feet; indeed, it likes to go wading. So when I wanted a foliage plant for my pebble tray in the north window and also something for the lily pools ("pools" sound better than tubs, which they really are) outside, I bought seeds of Cyperus alternifolius.

GENTRYVILLE, Ind. -- The completion of the museum, shelter and office on Indiana Highway 62 facing the grave of Nancy Hanks Lincoln, mother of the President, will mark the cessation of major construction work at the many Indiana State parks, monuments and historic sites "for the duration."

Social service schools are rapidly adjusting themselves to meet wartime demands for more welfare workers, according to a survey made public yesterday by Miss Anna E. King, chairman of the defense committee of the American Association of Schools of Social Work.

LEWISBURG, Pa., April 4 -- Bucknell University students, attempting to develop an adequate health program in wartime, are not only placing greater emphasis on training for physical fitness but are also providing an immunization plan designed to safeguard the health of the college's 1,300 students.

LIKE robins returning before the snow is well off the ground, the water-colorists begin to flock back to galleries each season as harbingers of Spring. Nearly half of the newly opened shows I saw last week were of work in water-color or gouache, with old friends and new acquaintances, naturalism and surrealism, traditionalism and innovation all represented.

Within the vast area newly conquered by Japan a change in climate is under way which seems bound to affect the course of the war in the Pacific. The rainy season has begun. All the Japanese acquisitions -- islands and coastal territory alike -- are monsoon countries.
LONDON, April 4 (AP) -- The following communique on the operations in Burma was issued here today:

For the second time in the week, new-crop cotton futures advanced yesterday to the highest levels in thirteen years. Active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange gained as much as 13 to 16 points in the short post-holiday session, but by the close of the trading these had been pared to final net increases of 8 to 13 points.

Miss Helena Wheeler, president of the United States Women's Lacrosse Association, announces that the association will cooperate in the Hale America movement by putting on a membership drive in the interest of physical fitness. There is no game for women which requires more speed, stamina and skill than lacrosse.

Urging an all-out national effort for victory, Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum declared last night that the United States soldier, accepting his lot cheerfully, demanded a postponement of internal strife and that bickering between groups, the wranglings of peacetime politics, the fostering of disagreement between capital and labor and the vested interests of selfish groups be "chloroformed" for the duration of the war.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 4 -- The incomparable Adolph Kiefer, the greatest back-stroke swimmer of all time, turned in another of his incredible performances at the national A.A.U. swimming championships in the Yale pool tonight when he smashed his own world record over the 150-yard distance with a stunning 1:30.5 effort.

STRANGE how fiction can sometimes lend its face to fact. When last we saw Laird Cregar he was playing the Gestapo chieftain in "Joan of Paris." Seated behind a large desk, he playfully interviewed unknowing victims, meanwhile delicately peeling a grape with a thin-bladed knife -- a fellow, one knew instinctively, who was affable enough on the surface but thirty below zero inside.

REHOBOTH BEACH, Del., April 4 -- Three specimens of fossil conch shells, believed to be of the Pleistocene age, were picked up this week by Fred Hill, retired Reedy Island lighthouse keeper. They were found among tens of thousands of the gastropod variety which appeared along several miles of shore line at Dewey Beach, just south of this resort.

There was a most interesting news item in your issue of April 1. The Tobacco Federation of Great Britain reported that "the British people smoked 30,000,000 pounds more of tobacco in 1941 than in 1940," and that "the greatest increase came in the quarter from October to December" when the bombings were severest.

Sixteen experts, including seven who qualified in preliminaries at the Manhattan and Marshall Chess Clubs last week, will begin play Friday night in the national championship finals of the United States Chess Federation for the title held by Samuel Reshevsky.

With the increasing need for uninterrupted war production, the trend toward elimination of physical inventory taking which requires plant shutdowns has been greatly accelerated, Dr. R.P. Marple, director of the research and technical service division of the National Association of Cost Accountants, reported yesterday.

A FIDGETY, palefaced, slight young man, who recently received a thunderous tribute from an excited audience of diplomats, Soviet officials and intelligentsia in Kuibyshev's Palace of Rest and Culture as his latest symphony drew to a close, had the satisfaction that at long last he had answered critics whose threatening challenge seven years previously he had boldly taken up.

LEW AYRES'S departure this week for a conscientious objectors' camp in Oregon has left Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer with the choice of abandoning the profitable "Dr. Kildare" series or finding another player for the role Ayres created.

Private enterprise in the United States in 1941 yielded the greatest earnings before Federal taxes in the history of the nation, although employment, payrolls, depreciation charges and general taxes also reached unprecedented heights. Of 758 corporations whose returns are included in this survey 325 reported profits after taxes greater than in 1929, long the symbol of unrestrained prosperity.

Andrew H.G. Evans, who twice refused to accept appointment as chief clerk of the Police Department, retired formally yesterday as acting chief clerk, a post that he took reluctantly a few months ago when war conditions forced a realignment in that branch of the force.

Fronting on the sidewalks of New York are the multiple-dwellings of New York, otherwise known as tenement and apartment houses. They are 130,000 buildings with nearly one and a half million apartments.

MEXICO CITY -- If it's atmosphere and "that native quality" that the visitor is after on his trip to Mexico, he should jot down Las Cazuelas, Columbia 69, Mexico City, as a concentrated specimen of quaintness and color in the restaurant field.

ARTHUR RANSOME'S stories, of which two have come from the press since August, 1939, are one of the alleviations of a wartime world. Beginning with "Swallows and Amazons" some ten years ago, the books by this author now amount to a considerable library of fine stories that combine adventure, genuine characterization and good writing in a way found but rarely in books for boys and girls.

WHILE we watch the stupendous struggle, now raging in the Russian theatre, it has become a matter of course to recall what took place in the same theatre of war 129 years ago. Even in many details, too, there is a striking similarity between the present invasion of Soviet Russia and that of Imperial Russia by Napoleon.

Any attempt to discuss the function of the small college in American education involves certain fundamental assumptions in regard to education itself. These, however, are easy to make. Men have been defining education ever since they began to think, and definitions separated by hundreds of years are so similar in essence as to surprise as well as gratify.

THE Frank M. Hawks Memorial Award, which is presented annually by New York's Air Service Post 501 of the American Legion for "outstanding contributions to aviation" goes to Thomas H. Beck, president of the Crowell-Collier Publishing Company and editorial director of Collier's Weekly, for 1941.

FORT BENNING, Ga., April 4 -- With the familiar yells and Bronx cheers of many former Ebbets Field fans ringing in their ears, the Dodgers ended their "army life" today by beating the Atlanta Crackers, 8 -- 3, on Hank Gowdy Field.

Final arrangements are being completed for the twenty-eighth annual Spring Yorkville Dinner Dance, which will be given April 14 in the main ballroom of the Plaza. The proceeds as in the past will aid the Yorkville Community Association in its maintenance of a neighborhood center at 1639 York Avenue and a Summer camp for u derprivileged children.

Louis Untermeyer, whose "This Singing World" has held its own for many years as one of the most satisfactory poetry collections for boys and girls, and whose "Rainbow in the Sky" is an admirable selection of verse for younger children, has now given us another book of poems chosen for young people.

The United States Barge Office at the Battery was noisy and busy last week as the United States Customs Guards moved out. Numbering 600, in three platoons, they left to take up new quarters at 56 Stone Street, a four-story office building that has a penthouse.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The grand award for the most notable work in fire prevention and protection in the Inter-Chamber Fire Waste Contest during 1941 was won by Cincinnati. Announcement was made by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, sponsor of the contest with the National Fire Waste Council.

IF fame is a roller coaster, no one in the theatre has taken its hairpin curves at more perilous speeds than Katharine Hepburn. No one has plummeted into the abyss of Grade B oblivion and zoomed upward again in quite such breathtaking succession. Certainly few have gambled with talent and a career more flamboyantly or taken the winnings and losses with more persistent recklessness.

Soldiers and sailors overseas, from Ireland to Australia, will soon reap a harvest of phonographs and records, judging from returns reported in the first two weeks of a drive launched by the National Federation of Music Clubs and the American Women's Voluntary Services and from a similar campaign of the Girl Scout Mariners.

RETAILERS were congratulating themselves on the biggest Easter business on record last week when their jubilation was dampened by reports of impending action on an all-out freezing of prices. Some of the Easter figures on sales were amazing, particularly in the men's wear field.

THE old cry, "Steamboat comin' around the bend," will echo again along the Ohio and Mississippi Rivers when the steamer Gordon Greene starts its Spring and Summer tours on May 10. Shore trips to antebellum mansions will be made on those voyages past river country immortalized by "Life on the Mississippi" and "Show Boat."

NOEL COWARD, who has had the script of his naval picture ready for weeks, and his actors fully rehearsed in their roles, stepped on to the big floor at Denham last month the minute that Leslie Howard stepped off.

The alumnae presentees of the Kosciuszko Foundation dances, comprising thirty-four young women representing cities and communities throughout the East who were presented and the Polka Ball in 1941 and 1942, will celebrate their first installation of officers with a supper dance on Friday night at Sherry's.
BERLIN, April 4 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German radio broadcast tonight that mass formations of dive bombers made heavy raids on Malta today.

A HARVEST for collectors of war-censored covers and specialties of France and her colonies is provided by the increasing number of items arriving in this country from the Free French outposts. Along with the many postal issues now listed are the covers, some philatelically prepared, others commercially used and still others which have carried personal correspondence.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, April 4 -- United Nations air forces shot down six Japanese planes in a raid on Kupang, Netherland Timor, yesterday and four more in a Japanese raid on Darwin, it was announced today.

So Topics of The Times, usually forward-looking, concludes that the kitchen of the future is "meaningless and hopeless." On the contrary, it is a picture filled with meaning and hope. A kitchen which is also the dining room and laundry saves the housewife time and motion.

The important role of savings banks in the wartime economy will be the keynote of the economic conference of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks, which will be held on May 6 to 8 in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, it was announced yesterday by Andrew Mills Jr., president of the association, who is president of the Dry Dock Savings Institution.

BARRING entirely unforeseen circumstances, Tom Slater, honorary major in the Forty-fourth Infantry Division, U.S. Army, but better known around Radio Row as the Mutual Broadcasting System's director of special features and sports, will step to the microphone at 2:30 P.M. here today, and during the next thirty minutes a great many people will come to feel that they know a good deal more about their Army.

THE United States today is the world's communication center. Radio has brought it about -- since the beginning of this war. New radio telegraph channels are springing into being almost overnight. No sooner is a new link approved by the Federal Communications Commission and similar authorities in other countries than engineers are on the job with apparatus.

GEORGE COLE'S letter "Concerts for Children" in the March 29 issue of THE TIMES was refreshing and reveals a genuine understanding of children. I have never been able to understand why grown-ups think that children must be tricked into liking music.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 4 -- News comes from Germany today that the Spiritual Church movement launched by the imprisoned Rev. Martin Niemoeller, calling for the unification of the Catholic and Protestant churches throughout Germany "for their mutual protection," is gathering momentum and adherents "to a gratifying degree."

Apparel, main floor, blouse and millinery departments were outstanding in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

The Royal Greek Legation at Washington issued a statement yesterday denying charges made on Thursday by Aristides Dimitratos, former Minister of Labor, that the Greek Government-in-Exile did not represent the Greek people and was not in sympathy with labor.

The schoolhouse of the future will be more than a school. It will be the home of community services. The teacher will be more than an instructor. He will be one of various community workers. The superintendent of schools will also be an administrator of community services.

THE fresh-water angler is threshing about in his waders today, flies in his hat, hope in his heart and, if he is lucky, trout in his creel. For the fishing season got under way in most of New York State yesterday to last on, with one fish or another as the objective, into the Fall.

The eldest male heir to the Milverton estate in Cornwall dies in circumstances which might well be considered suspicious, but the family physician, who is also the coroner, calls it accidental food poisoning, and that is that for the time being.

The Harvard Glee Club, making its yearly visit, and the Sarah Lawrence College Chorus, singing here for the first time, joined forces last night and presented a program at Town Hall which was attended by 1,000 persons.

OTTAWA. ON the highest windswept hill of Ottawa's suburban Britannia Heights stands a small modern brick building surrounded by a maze of red-and-white painted tall poles, where a staff of four engineers picks up for rebroadcasting to many Canadian stations at least twenty-four programs a week originating in Great Britain.

THE source of Hoffmeister's humor in his new book lies -- as does all authentic humor -- somewhere between tragedy and comedy. In his previous books the case for Hoffmeister, the author, was complicated by his striking talent for drawing and caricature.

CAMDEN, N.J., April 4 -- The cruiser Denver, fourth vessel of the Cleveland class to be constructed by the New York Ship Building Corporation, was launched into the Delaware River at 4:59 P.M. today fifteen months and nine days after the laying of the keel.

The importance of intensive use of freight cars will be discussed by the Atlantic States Shippers Advisory Board in the Benjamin Franklin Hotel in Philadelphia on Thursday. C.J. Goodyear, general chairman, will preside.

DETROIT, April 4 -- To guard against spies and saboteurs in plants charged with responsibility for 10 per cent of the national arms program, the General Motors Corporation has doubled its private police force in the period since the Japanese assault on Pearl Harbor.

Firm belief in "the Divine Salvation, the Living Personal Power" of Jesus Christ is needed in the war-torn world today in order to meet the "sorrow and bereavement" that lie ahead, Bishop William T. Manning of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York declared yesterday in his annual Easter message to the people of the diocese. The text follows:

NEW DELHI, India, April 4 (U.P.) -- Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru of the All-India Congress party, asked Americans tonight to reserve opinion on India's refusal to accept Great Britain's proposals for India's post-war independence in their present form.

The furtherance of economic collaboration between Peru and the United States is dependent upon realization by the American people that trade can be maintained only upon a reciprocal basis, David Dasso, Peruvian Minister of Finance, said in an interview at the Savoy-Plaza Hotel last night.
PERHAPS it took a disinterested outsider to give a complete and unbiased report of the history of the Germans in the United States.

A NATIONAL woman's magazine recently commissioned Ylla (Miss Ylla Koffler, of 15 West Fifty-first Street), specialist in "individualized portraits of dogs and cats," to make photographs of fifteen women's shoes. This would have been a very ordinary assignment except for one fact: each shoe was to be posed with a dog.

With the arrival of boating weather, yachtsmen and fishermen were giving considerable attention yesterday to the Coast Guard requirements for persons and crafts that are to travel the "territorial waters of the United States" this Spring and Summer, as well as for landlubbers on isolated shores who intend merely to look at the water.

A spectacular three-alarm fire, punctuated by a series of small gasoline tank explosions, swept the West Side Garage, Inc., a long single-story brick structure at 513-517 West Fifty-fifth Street yesterday morning, destroying one passenger automobile and thirty-five trucks.

Fred Apostoli, former world middleweight champion, advanced a step further along the comeback trail by knocking out Joe Mulli of Bensonhurst in the feature eight-rounder of last night's boxing show at the Ridgewood Grove in Brooklyn before a crowd of 3,000.

The second in the series of post-debutante assemblies for this season will take place next Saturday night in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis instead of at the Pierre, as originally planned. The first of the dances this Spring was given March 21.

UNCLE DUDLEY declares he's had his fill of the milk and honey of L.A., Calif. He wants to go back to Chi. His dutiful nephew, a young man in his teens who, incidentally, tells the story, agrees. But how to get back?

One of the great delights of the early garden is the Star Magnolia. Less familiar than the deep rose-cupped Magnolia soulangeana, this harbinger of the family, Magnolia stellata, blossoms in favorable years as early as late March, delighting the gardener with a profusion of scented loveliness that is equaled by no other plant so early in the season.

FROM the days of Aesop and Aristophanes the bird and animal kingdoms have been drawn on for fables through which human truths might be brought home and social and political satire might find utterance, and Polly Boyden with her tale of the rebellious robin is in good company.

WITHOUT a doubt, the most difficult story in the world to write is the story of Jesus. A God who has come to us in human form to reconcile God and man, and heaven and earth, while offering no problem to the believing theologian, at once creates a dilemma for the novelist who, by the very nature of his art, must needs express himself in concrete images, in tangible realities.

The proceedings which have been brought by Thurman Arnold against the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, and which have resulted in the freeing of the patents to that organization for the manufacture of what is erroneously called "synthetic rubber," draws attention again to our own needs. So it behooves us to go into the subject of making rubber substitutes from petroleum.

HERE is the story of a young Manhattan stenographer, Frances Ella Fitz. who at the turn of the century was lured to Alaska by the excitement and financial possibilities of the great gold strike at Nome. Without sufficient money for her transportation and responsible for her mother's support, she left New York with a party of argonauts directed by a visionary organizer of a cooperatives company -- a man named Rowe.

"WHILE material efficiency has been increasing for two hundred years, the human capacity for working together has in the same period continually diminished." Recognition of this fact is bringing a new skill into practice in business organizations -- skill in dealing with human situations affecting cooperation and morale among workers.

The current revival of interest in home vegetable gardening has been accompanied by renewed concern over the ravages of insect pests. The average home gardener is usually visited by many pests, and some gardeners actually lose most of their production from this cause.

ON a Mexican hill where the Aztecs once worshiped the sun, moon and stars -- at Tonanzintla, Puebla, eighty-one miles from Mexico City -- stands an observatory which American scientists say is more favorably situated for studying the Milky Way than any other since the days of the ancient Egyptian, Arabian, Indian and Mayan astronomers.

Through elimination of the competitive factor in merchandising in many industries, the war may actually have a salutary effect on the packaging field, Henry J. Howlett, secretary of the American Management Association, sponsors of an annual packaging competition, declared in an interview here yesterday.
JERUSALEM, April 4 (AP) -- The worries of the world at war failed to interfere today with the ancient ceremony at the Church of the Holy Sepulchre marking Holy Saturday.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 4 -- All bonds between the United Mine Workers and the C.I.O. in Illinois, except that of technical affiliation, were severed today with the resignation of Oscar E. Carlstrom as attorney for the State Industrial Union Council, a federation of C.I.O. unions.

DURING 1941 the average new car price rose by $140 from $924 in January to $1,061 last December, figures made public by the North American Newspaper Alliance show. The year's average of $942 in turn had gained step by step from $864 in 1938 for a forty-eight-month increase of $200.

To Dr. Walter Damrosch, of American musicians, who celebrated his eightieth birthday Jan. 30, the Musicians Emerge Fund is dedicating its annual dinner and "musical soiree," which will be held Tuesday night in grand ballroom of the Wall Astoria.
AMERICA, land of the motor car, land of the rubber tire, is going off wheels and learning to walk. Of this I sing.

The formation of a Wartime Labor Standards Committee, announced today, unites ten organizations, including women's clubs and labor groups, in a drive to determine that labor standards for women shall not be relaxed unnecessarily during the war.

AT this moment, while the executive part of the organization is busied with the performances of the customary Spring tour in leading American cities, the Metropolitan Opera Association is counting the returns of its New York season of 1941-42, and considering with great care and anxiety its problems for next Winter.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, April 4 -- Remarkably rapid expansion of the New Zealand Army was revealed and continued today when the National Service Ministry announced that all married men of the 29-31 age group were to be called for service with the home army.

Distributors of small electrical appliances, who had feared a sharp let-down in their sales volume for the second quarter, now expect a total well ahead of the like 1941 period as a result of the increased manufacturing allowed for these units during the next two months, they reported yesterday.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, April 4 -- Three Brazilian ships are today in Guanabara Bay to take Axis diplomats to a port in Portugal. Each ship has in large letters on its hull the word "Diplomats."

RALEIGH, N.C. -- A program commemorating the 150th anniversary of the founding of the city of Raleigh as the capital of North Carolina will be held here the week of April 26. A Victory Rally will be a feature of the sesquicentennial observance.

"THERE'S only been one storm that never cleared up -- and that's this one," is the New England saying which has given Granville Hicks the title of his story. "Only One Storm" is the tale of an American who has weathered the storm of intellectual doubts that were deep enough to threaten the roots of his way of life.

THIS outspoken book is a manifesto. In terms that are peremptory and in a tone that is pugnacious, Mr. MacCormac, a vigorous Canadian, demands an end to shilly-shally. Enough of discussion -- in facing the future, get down to realities and adopt a policy.

"TELL IT TO THE LAUGHING STARS" introduces a new writer of great descriptive power and of capacities in other directions still untested and unexplored. It is a first novel of unusual fervor and sincerity, written with self-conscious beauty of style and with what sometimes strikes one as deliberate eccentricity of manner.

A number of new conference groups of business women are being organized throughout the country, according to the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs, especially in the larger cities, where a growing need is felt for their participation in a total war effort.

Some 1,800 manufacturers, of whom 1,500 are subcontractors, have more than $500,000,000 in Army ordnance orders outstanding in the New York Ordnance District, but, while some expansion in the number of factories working for ordnance may be expected, nearly 8,000 concerns have listed their facilities with Army Ordnance and have little prospect of getting orders.

Despite shortages of materials and related problems, United States war production has a record to date "as remarkable as anything in our history," Donald M. Nelson, WPB chairman, declared last night in pledging American fighting men everywhere, "We will not let you down."

With the position that Wendell L. Willkie, former Republican candidate for President, will take in the State and Congressional elections this Fall one of great importance to his party, it was learned definitely yesterday that he will oppose nomination of candidates with an isolationist viewpoint and support those who favor a broad internationalist policy after the war.

APRIL finds the dance breaking into a terrific spurt of activity to close the season with. No less than three ballet companies are prepared for action, two of them of the character known generally as Russe, and one of them entirely American. Besides this Ruth St. Denis is presenting a series of four restrospective recitals and Doris Humphrey is reviving one of her most ambitious group works for three studio performances.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today a series of conferences with representatives of farmers, transportation agencies, storage interests and grain traders to discuss methods of handling this year's grain crops.

LONDON, Sunday, April 5 -- The Royal Air Force struck vigorous blows in German-occupied France during daylight yesterday, after slight offensive action across the Channel Friday night in which British fighters and bombers attacked enemy freight yards and airfields.
BOSTON, April 4 -- A warning that air raids on this country's war plants are "entirely possible" was given today by James M. Landis, Director of the Office of Civilian Defense.

Until the Japanese actually dropped bombs on Pearl Harbor a certain portion of our population, probably much more vocal and articulate than numerous, considered it akin to treason to say that the United States is a success and that our statesmen from Washington, Jefferson and Adams down have, on the whole, given us good service.
Anyhow it seems that there was a siren. That much is definite.

CHICAGO, April 4 -- Scattered liquidation developed today in the wheat market, and the lack of either speculative or commercial support was keenly felt, prices dipping around 1 cent a bushel to the lowest level since early last December and the finish on the Board of Trade being about the bottom.

THE DUDLEYS -- to whom one is introduced in this rather brittle first novel -- are one of those mad, mad families with boundless charm and little sense who crop up so recurrently in fiction. (That they are encountered less often in actuality is, perhaps, a blessing, for one can see that their impetuous little ways might be trying.)
LONDON, April 4 -- Withdrawal of the British covering force from Prome "proceeded satisfactorily" yesterday, according to today's communique on the operations in Burma.

The Police Department was struggling yesterday to cut through a swathe of red tape and obtain revolvers for fifty-seven rookies who have been doing patrol with only a night stick because war priorities have blocked delivery of 250 of 300 weapons ordered and paid for in December.

SOME publishers will blush and some authors will flame with indignation when they read what Harold Nicolson has been saying in The Spectator. In discussing the present difficulties of book production, he takes occasion to remark that, of the many legends which abuse the public mind, one of the most unfair is that which represents publishers as sharks.

ROME, April 4 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The first Italian submarines which have been operating along the United States coast have returned to "an Atlantic base" with eleven small red flags tied to their periscopes, indicating they sank eleven ships, a correspondent of the Giornale d'Italia reported today.

AN airplane production line that will be manned by boys from elementary to high school age and will turn out half a million units in about a year's time is now being set up in this country. The planes thus produced will never take part in actual combat, for they are to be models of real fighting aircraft, and they may have an important bearing on the outcome of battles fought by American air forces.

As might be expected, there are beginning to appear in newspapers and other periodicals statements from many individuals who, with varying degrees of bitterness, are opposed to the Treasury's proposal to require husbands and wives living together to file joint income tax returns.

IN his brief foreword to this book about life in eighteenth-century England Louis Kronenberger says that his chief aim has been to provide a picture of the time. He even italicizes the word "picture" so that the scope of his purpose will not be misunderstood.

A cocktail party, buffet supper and entertainment program will be given next Sunday afternoon and evening at the Columbia University Club, 4 West Forty-third Street, by the Lower East Side Center committee of the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service.

DETROIT, Mich., April 4 -- Federal agents took action today against Koch Laboratories, inc., by arresting Louis Koch, secretary-treasurer, here and Dr. William F. Koch, president at Debray Beach, Fla. The company specializes in a cancer treatment.

AMONG the more cultural by-products of the motion picture industry are the annual reports of President Will Hays to the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America. Mr. Hays regularly melts down the group experiences of the past year and molds them into words of massive texture which have the substance of history.

THE story of the Huguenots, "fighters for God and human freedom," is brought out in English by what is locally a "new" publishing firm, as the famous European house of Fischer initiates its American publications.

In response to a direct appeal by the City Department of Hospitals, Hunter College has planned a Summer program of teacher training courses in nursing education which are designed to turn out enough qualified instructors to alleviate the acute shortage of trained personnel in the city's hospitals, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Philip R.V. Curoe, chairman of the department of education.
LONDON, April 4 -- The British Government's financial accounts for the year ended with March reaffirmed the urgent necessity for reduction of civilian consumption of many commodities.

PHILADELPHIA, April 4 -- The University of Pennsylvania, in extending its services as far as possible during the national emergency, will continue to conduct its regular Summer School this year in addition to a special Summer term to be held in connection with the wartime acceleration of the academic program.

DETROIT -- How many miles do you have left in the tires on your car? Experts say you can measure remaining mileage. A first-line tire is built for about 40,000 miles' wear, 25,000 miles of it contained in the non-skid grooved tread.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 4 -- The American public wants a tough and drastic wartime program for the control of prices and wages.

Shackled by the left-handed hurling of Bill Hogan, the Savage baseball team was easy prey for City College at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday. City collected ten hits and profited on five misplays to run up a 13-to-1 margin. It was the Beaver's initial intercollegiate triumph of the season.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. -- Tribute of high significance will be paid to Thomas Jefferson, author of the Declaration of Independence and founder of the University of Virginia, at the Jefferson Day memorial exercises, which will be held at his Monticello shrine on Monday afternoon, April 13 -- the anniversary of his birth.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) -- A bust of General Douglas MacArthur will be unveiled here Monday and if all goes well the General, from his headquarters in Australia, will participate in the ceremonies by radio.

PHILADELPHIA -- Ivy-clad and spire-topped Gloria Dei Church, in which men were worshiping seventy-six years before the Declaration of Independence was signed in this city, has taken its place by Presidential decree as a national historic site in Philadelphia.

Court delays may force the Reynolds Realization Corporation to default on the terms of its trust indenture, Samuel S. Rodman, president, declared in the annual report, just issued. So far the company, successor to the Reynolds Investing Company, which was caught in the Continental Securities Corporation scandal, has been unable to bring to trial Richard S. Reynolds and Richard S. Reynolds Jr.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Chairman Dies of the House Committee on un-American Activities was asked today to add to his list of ten the names of twenty-five other employes of the Board of Economic Warfare whom he has accused of affiliation with Communist-front groups.

National compulsory registration of women -- a measure which has been considered in a number of versions by the Congress -- is being supported by nine metropolitan business women's organizations in its most inclusive form, to cover all women between the ages of 18 and 64.
In the present campaign for Victory gardens, one simple means of increasing our supply of choice vegetables is still, in some measure, unexploited.

AN airplane production line that will be manned by boys from elementary to high school age and will turn out half a million units in about a year's time is now being set up in this country. The planes thus produced will never take part in actual combat, for they are to be models of real fighting aircraft, and they may have an important bearing on the outcome of battles fought by American air forces.

As might be expected, there are beginning to appear in newspapers and other periodicals statements from many individuals who, with varying degrees of bitterness, are opposed to the Treasury's proposal to require husbands and wives living together to file joint income tax returns.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 4 -- Enjoying a reprieve from their major league opposition for the week-end, the Giants managed to squeeze out a victory over the Memphis Chicks today to the surprise of practically no one, including about 700 observers. The score was 7 to 4 in a game that saw the Polo Grounders outhit, 10 to 7.

Word has come from the American Merchant Marine Library Association that it will omit its annual book drive, usually held at this time of year. Instead, it is issuing an appeal for funds to defray the increasing financial demands placed on the organization by the necessity of replacing library cases lost in the sinking of ships and of providing new articles for the steady flow of new ships putting out to sea.

AT least one important collection of books on the Atlantic seaboard will not be exiled to the provinces for the duration. The completion of the Houghton Library at Harvard insures a reasonably safe and comfortable home for the better part of the rare books and manuscripts belonging to the college.

HERE is a vivid and deeply impressive account of the important battles between the United States Army and various Western tribes during the twenty-five-year period, 1865-1890. It covers combats with the Sioux, Cheyennes (both northern and southern), Apaches, Modocs, Utes, Kiowas, Comanches and even lesser tribes and sub-tribes.
MY GARDEN DAY BY DAY. 1942 -- Calendar. Bedford Village, N.Y.: The Tool Shed.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- William Dudley Pelley, leader of the Silver Shirts and often accused of pro-fascist activities, was arrested today in Darien, Conn., by Department of Justice agents for seditious writings contained in his recently discontinued publication, The Galilean.

MARSEILLE, France, April 4 (AP) -- Max Bonnafous, Provincial Prefect in the Marseille region, called an emergency meeting of all Mayors today to deal with the wheat crisis and announced that France was threatened with six breadless weeks.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 4 (U.P.) -- Lieutenant Gordon E. Bolser of Los Angeles, a 31-year-old naval flier who took his unarmored Sikorsky amphibian aloft as Japanese warplanes were attacking Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7 in order to obtain "information of the enemy," received the Navy Cross for bravery today.

AN "all-out" evening of music and ballet, the entire proceeds of which will be turned over to the Russian War Relief, will be given Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. The participants in this event will be the Ballet Theatre; Jan Peerce, tenor; Mischa Elman, violinist, and Marian Anderson, contralto.

BRIDGE, Idaho, April 4 (AP) -- A four-motored Army bomber on a night flight crashed near this Utah-Idaho border town, killing seven fliers and presumably an eighth whose body had not been found late today.

JIM TULLY has always occupied a curious position in the American literary scene. He is conspicuous by his absence from Dr. Lewisohn's "Expression in America," and Edmund Wilson makes no mention of him in his study of Californian novelists, and yet there have been but a handful of writers since the turn of the century who have explored the American lower depths with sympathy and success.

SOME 75,000,000 words of telegraphic copy having passed over his desk during his eight years as manager of the Washington Bureau of THE NEW YORK TIMES, few can approach Delbert Clark's competence to discuss the reporting of governmental affairs.

SAM SPEWACK, playwright and scenarist, who spent some time in England last year studying the war film subjects made under the supervision of the British Ministry of Information, has outlined for Washington officials a film narrative for a documentary screen record of the events leading up to World War II.

A gala mid-Spring jamboree entitled "Carnival Street" and planned as one of the largest all-night revels ever held at the Waldorf-Astoria will take place in the grand ballroom and adjoining suites there on May 12 as a benefit for the Navy Relief Society.

A metropolitan college all-star basketball team that lived up to its advance billing and potentialities triumphed over Virginia Union University of Richmond, 69 -- 57, in the feature game of the benefit double-header at the Bronx Coliseum last night.
The "progressive student placement" system for German language students at Queens College has produced "excellent" results, a German Department survey indicated yesterday.

C.O.: There were demonstrations in Berlin, in 1930, against the American film "All Quiet on the Western Front," a faithful version of the best-selling novel by Germany's Ehrich Maria Remarque. Brown-shirted Nazis, not yet in power, set off stench bombs and released white mice in theatres showing the movie.

An overwhelming majority of our population is determined to win the war. To accomplish this they will balk at no sacrifice. They are willing to be deprived of tires, gasoline, girdles, sugar, radios and rubber heels. They will contribute without complaint, not only their money, but their sons.

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined $2,389,989,682 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. Average price per share of all listed stocks on March 31 was $22.36. compared with $24.02 at the end of February.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 4 -- Franz von Papen, the German Ambassador, flew to Ankara this morning following his arrival at Istanbul last night by German courier plane from Berlin.

An unscheduled speech at a police banquet is interrupted by a shot and the speaker falls dead. The victim is a private detective named Scanlon, who has been about to make accusations against the Los Angeles Police Department or against certain members of it.

A YACHT, the Golden Plover, is found adrift off the coast of Lower California with not a soul on board and with every indication that she had been abandoned in haste. But this is not another Mary Celeste mystery.

The Ski Union of the Americas, the founding of which is viewed by skiing leaders as a great step forward for the promotion of international competition in the Western Hemisphere, opened its first congress yesterday at the Union Club with delegates from Bolivia, Canada, Chile and the United States attending.
"NOW," said the taxicab driver, "we shall visit some of the squalid suburbs."

Two days before the National Gallery of Art celebrated its first birthday last month the 2,000,000th visitor passed between the classic marble columns that guard its entrance. The monumental building on the Mall, with its long expanse of windowless wall, has proved itself one of the chief points of interest among the countless attractions which Washington offers the visitor and sightseer.

THE Metropolitan Salon of Photography for Junior High Schools, to be held May 18 to 29 at the Metropolitan Vocational High School, will be judged by Dr. Alberto C. Bonaschi, member Board of Education; Wil liam Freese, THE NEW YORK TIMES Studio; and Victor Keppler, illustration and color photographer.

While it is possible to grow many of the dwarf varieties of peas and beans with little or no staking or supports, the taller growing varieties give larger yields of produce. Where this is the desired end, the best method of holding up the vine must be considered.

Expressing the hope that the decision of the Office of Price Administration will not be to establish over-all ceilings on retail prices, Lew Hahn, general manager of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, yesterday voiced his conviction that such an undertaking is not necessary and that, with 1,700,000 retailers in the country, the work of policing and enforcing any over-all price ceilings would be a task "so tremendous that it would be foredoomed to failure."

THE decision to restrict the scope of the current Renoir show at Durand-Ruel's to work done between 1900 and 1919, the year of the great French artist's death, was a fortunate one. The paintings of this period are less widely known and much less generally appreciated at their true worth than are paintings of preceding periods.

Now that Easter's here and people really feel like Spring, no doubt they'll be wanting to do more of their living out-of-doors. It doesn't hurt to look forward to the day when you can have your before dinner cocktail on the terrace or in the back yard.

THE morale and efficiency of the American worker have come to be one of the war's great strategic factors. As we apply more fully the restrictions and controls of total war, the volume, quality and speed of essential production will be limited less and less by the availability of materials or facilities and more and more by the availability and sustained effectiveness of man power.
Five hundred howling, squirming boys yesterday took part in the Gramercy Boys Club Easter egg hunt at 535 East Sixteenth Street.

AMID the current flood of books on the Orient, Mr. Fleisher's attracts attention because of the author's long journalistic experience in Tokyo. He left Japan toward the end of 1940, after a period of more than twenty years of service as editor of the American-owned Japan Advertiser and as correspondent for an American newspaper.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- A "gray" list of importers and foreign traders in Latin-American nations and other parts of the world who have come under suspicion of favoring Axis objectives has grown to considerable proportions over the last three months.

PHILADELPHIA, April 4 -- Bernard J. Rothwell of Worcester (Mass.) Academy set a new junior National A.A.U. record in the fifty-yard high hurdles tonight when he topped the timbers in 6.3 seconds. The old mark was held by Tom Garland, Manhattan College, who did 6.4 seconds in 1940.
John F. Garvey has been admitted to the New York Stock Exchange firm of La Branche Co.

PORTLAND, Me. -- So much is heard these days of steel and alumnium and rubber that one is likely to forget there is such a thing as wood. But lumbering operations are booming at a rate that is governed solely by the number of men that can be obtained.
