LONDON, April 4 (AP) -- The most violent daylight air fighting of the Spring raged over the Continental coast today as group after group of high-flying British battle planes swept over the Channel and returned, with eleven of their number missing, from a bloody encounter with Nazi defenders over France.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- Golf and tennis will be on the sports program for the remainder of this month. The principal golf event is the forty-second annual North and South Invitation Amateur Championship. On the tennis schedule are two tournaments, one professional, one amateur.

IN Treasury Star Parade, newest series of transcribed programs under Treasury Department sponsorship, director William Murray and producer William A. Bacher are offering listeners entertainment by some of the best talent of the country and through it are giving new meaning and urgency to the slogan "Buy a Share in America."

Women in ever-increasing numbers are joining the company of America's "keglers," or bowlers. They have local, regional and even an international association, and right now New York's seventy-seven sanctioned leagues are having a final warming up for their annual tournament which starts on Tuesday.

BOSTON, April 4 -- Two new "magic bullets" of the sulfanilamide family that promise further extension of the field of chemotherapy to bacterial infections were described here today before the closing sessions of the annual meeting of the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology.

A nation that has celebrated the Resurrection of the Prince of Peace for twenty-three years under skies free of war was prepared today to observe Easter in the traditional manner but in a more sober spirit.

THE Commandos bob up in France, wreck a strategic dock or power plant, grab a few prisoners, vanish. They make a dark-night foray on the coast of France or Norway. They harass an Axis outpost in Libya.

The final New York concert of the season by Serge Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall was an unconditional triumph, so far as the reception of the performances by the audience and the performances themselves were concerned.

A striking tableau in red and white portraying the Red Cross war effort will be staged on Wednesday evening at The New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, when members of twenty business women's organizations hold their final rally in the Red Cross War Fund drive.
Magistrate Morris Rothenberg, presiding in Felony Court yesterday, noted that many crimes were being committed by boys and suggested that the police make an investigation.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 5 -- Since San Francisco is in an area designated as "a combat zone," Army and Navy spokesmen here were reluctant today to discuss defenses beyond stating that those in and about the harbor had been "alerted since the first news of Pearl Harbor and will remain alerted to the fullest degree until the enemy has been defeated."
IT was cheering to read a statement delivered by Casey Stengel the other day. Casey said in part:...

Civilian defense agencies and war relief organizations will share in the proceeds from the annual tea dance and cocktail party of the Young Women's Republican Club of New York, Inc., which will be given on Saturday in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis.

During the past week, financial markets hardly moved. Although stock market averages ruled above the lowest of 1942, the difference was only fractional, notwithstanding the moderate recovery of Thursday. They did not reach the low figure of the war or, for that matter, the lowest of any full year since 1933.
HELSINKI, Finland, April 5 (From Finnish broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Finnish High Command issued this communique today:

HARRISON, N.Y., April 5 -- While soldiers with shotguns guarded Kensico Dam in nearby Valhalla, scene of the traditional Easter dawn service, worshipers today attended a 7 A.M. service on the south bank of Silver Lake in Harrison.

It is perhaps just as well for the safety of the nation that WPB has found it necessary to stop the sale of bicycles to non-essential adults. With bicycles being sold at a "terrific rate" prior to the order, it may reasonably be supposed that a great many were going across the counter to people who did not really need them.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The situation of Lieut. Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright's American and Filipino forces on Bataan Peninsula in the Philippines appeared more serious today with the announcement by the War Department that the Japanese had launched another ground attack.
LOS ANGELES, April 5 -- Eight major Pacific Coast manufacturers of the warplanes now fighting on every front announced today the organization of the Aircraft War Production Council, Inc.

Increases of wages and vacations with pay will add $6,250,000 annually to the cost of operating the Norfolk Western Railway, W.J. Jenks, president, said in his report for 1941, issued for publication today. This would compare with an increase of $3,500,000 in revenues which Mr. Jenks estimated would result from the recent increases in freight and passenger rates.

Work of refitting the Gracie Mansion, historic manor house in Carl Schurz Park, as an official residence of the city's mayors is progressing despite priorities on construction materials and lack of adequate appropriations. The house will be ready to receive Mayor La Guardia and his family "well before Summer arrives," it was disclosed yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, April 5 -- Renewed discussions last week of a possible ceiling of 21.47 cents a pound for cotton on farms or 23.04 at mills in the Carolinas and 22.25 for futures slowed down speculative and trade buying in cotton futures after new highs for the last twelve years had been established at the beginning of the period.

LONDON, April 5 -- There was pronounced inactivity last week in the stock markets. To some extent this was an aftermath of London's great effort to achieve in the preceding week its target of 150,000,000 of new money for war loans.

Last week the Irving Fisher Index of wholesale commodity prices rose by 1.0 per cent, the largest weekly gain since last June. This gain was distributed evenly throughout each of the three major groups. Three of the sub-groups embodied most of the important individual price changes.

In their mass attack upon Colombo, the capital of Ceylon, early Sunday morning, the Japanese were evidently trying to duplicate what they did at Pearl Harbor four months before. In this they failed completely. No less than twenty-seven of the attacking planes were definitely destroyed, while a slightly larger number was damaged.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 5 -- The sink-or-swim psychosis of Axis military commanders who are demanding the utmost of mobilization potentialities, extending even to German and Italian nationals abroad, coupled with currency restrictions in several "neutral" countries, combined as the Easter weekend approached to place another scare in the Axis propaganda balance.

Today is the thirty-third anniversary of the discovery of the North Pole by Admiral Robert E. Peary. Penetrating vision matched by an indomitable will made his achievement possible. Through years of hardship he tested the Roof of the World, studying the icy waste with scientific precision.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The first experimental plastic-plywood training plane ordered by the Navy has been delivered and is about to be subjected to performance tests.
JERUSALEM, April 5 (AP) -- Prayers for victory rose in many tongues today as the Holy Land celebrated Easter with its customary centuries-old ceremonies.

TRENTON, N.J., April 5 (AP) -- A three-man investigating committee of the New Jersey Department of the American Legion has found groundless charges of inefficiency made against the United Service Organizations in New Jersey. The committee, headed by Albert E. McCormick of Boonton, reporting to the State executive committee yesterday on charges made by Raymond Pellington Post No. 77 of Paterson, said:

MIAMI, April 5 -- The city has permanently screened out MacArthur Causeway, connecting Miami and Miami Beach. Motorists dim their lights and travel no faster than twenty miles an hour. Experiments are being conducted by the Dade County Defense Council on darkening a larger area.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 5 (AP) -- William Dudley Pelley, leader of the Silver Shirts and publisher of anti-Semitic magazines, was placed in the Marion County jail here tonight on charges of sedition in connection with articles that appeared in his publication, "The Galilean."

Secret plans to protect New York City against sabotage over the Easter week-end were carried out successfully under sealed orders. The Army, Navy, New York Guard, police and civilian defense units took part in what was regarded by the authorities as the city's first successful rehearsal of all defense groups.

Many industrial advertisers are increasing their advertising campaigns this year, chiefly in order to aid the war-production program, according to agency comment. The main copy theme which many have adopted is an explanation of the use of their machinery and equipment to "green" workers who lack adequate supervision in many "boom" plants and of the best methods to use and conserve vital materials.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Large quantities of seventeen commodities and the entire cargo of an Axis ship have been seized for war purposes by government agencies through some sixty separate requisitioning actions, it was revealed today by L.J. Martin, assistant chief of the Bureau of Priorities.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 5 -- Mark Hellinger, who left Warner Brothers in March of 1941 because of disagreement with Hal Wallis, then the production executive at the studio, has rejoined the company under a term contract and will produce "Mississippi Belle" as his first assignment.

The spiritual aims of the United Nations are "aligned with the will of Christ," the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary, declared in his Easter sermon yesterday morning in James Memorial Chapel, 121st Street and Claremont Avenue.

Today thousands of persons throughout the city, including Mayor La Guardia and volunteer workers, will launch a campaign to enroll 10,000 women as volunteer nurses aides. The program has been accelerated by a growing need, backed by a conviction that qualified women best can serve their country by caring for its sick and providing a bulwark against possible periods of disaster.

The Easter message is one of triumph reminding all that, in spite of the evil men do in this world, God's law cannot be overthrown and that evil never can be victorious, Bishop William T. Manning said yesterday in his Easter Day sermon in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

LONDON, April 5 -- After running the gauntlet of German air and naval forces an undisclosed number of Norwegian ships have reached Britain unescorted in a daring voyage from Goeteborg, Sweden, according to an announcement tonight by the Ministry of Information.

According to theatre managers yesterday was one of the biggest Easter Sundays noted along Broadway in many years. Though exact attendance figures were not available last night, practically all houses reported having played to capacity throughout the afternoon and evening, and at some time during the day most houses had street lines.

A gift of $100,000 to the Institute for the Crippled and Disabled, 400 First Avenue, by Jeremiah Milbank, founder and a trustee of that organization, was announced yesterday by Walter E. Hope, president of the institute.

A tour of key cities of the United States by a group of Hollywood's film stars and other entertainers to give benefit performances for the Army Emergency Relief and the Navy Relief Society was announced jointly yesterday by the War and Navy Departments.
The American Women's Voluntary Services announced yesterday a complete plan for the collection of salvaged grease by its 65,000 members in Greater New York.

BERLIN, April 5 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command said today that German planes had bombed "the remnants of the Soviet Baltic Fleet" at the bases of Leningrad and Kronstadt, hitting two battleships and two heavy cruisers with heavy bombs.

Continued buying last week by mill and trade sources lifted cotton prices to the highest level since 1929. The higher prices, however, attracted liquidation and profit taking. At the close of trading on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains of 19 to 30 points.

RIOM, France, April 5 -- With the recess of the French unpreparedness trial, some persons have predicted that it will not be resumed April 14, the appointed date, but those predictions have received no official confirmation.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The Army's No. 1 lady is somewhat of a mystery to Washington. The town that knows everything about everybody admits to a rather complete blank concerning Jean Faircloth MacArthur, the second wife of General Douglas MacArthur.

VICHY, April 5 -- On the eve of the Easter holidays, for which the Lyon Bourse closed for four consecutive days, provoking as a rule a certain amount of selling, it was noticed that, on the contrary this year, the market increased its firmness.

S. Hurok will open his Spring season of ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House tonight with a performance by the Ballet Theatre which will have as its special feature the New York premiere of Michel Fokine's new ballet, "Russian Soldier."

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations and the American Federation of Labor will cooperate in a new nation-wide radio program "to tell how the man in overalls is helping America win the war." The rival labor organizations announced this jointly tonight, through their presidents, William Green of the A.F. of L., and Philip Murray of the C.I.O.

Alice Martindale, 18 years old, of Bexhill-on-Sea, Sussex, England, has arrived here accompanied by her father, Reuben Walter Martindale, a retired petty officer of the Royal Navy, on her way to the British West Indies to assist in the establishment of three naval canteens that will be directed by Mr. Martindale.

The Rev. Dr. Allan Knight Chalmers suggested that "we are on the edge of a new life now" when he delivered his Easter sermon at the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle at Fifty-sixth Street yesterday morning.

SEATTLE, April 5 -- Precautions taken by the Army and Navy to guard Seattle's great war factories are, of course, military secrets. However, it can be reported that the city has spent $400,000 and appropriated $500,000 more for civilian protection and to guard against sabotage.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 5 -- "Sweden's military preparedness is greater than ever before," declared Prime Minister Per Albin Hansson at the Social Democratic Convention at Tidaholm today.

BOSTON, April 5 -- The city's harbor defenses have been strengthened unbelievably since our entrance into the war. Huge coastal defense guns, made only a few miles from City Hall, have been set up and tested. Ninety-millimeter anti-aircraft and even larger types, also built here, form a network, manned by trained crews, which provides a formidable defense against bombers.

Hailing organized labor's proclaimed policy of no strikes and no lockouts for the duration of the war, Senator Elbert D. Thomas of Utah, chairman of the Labor Committee of the Senate, declared last night that "to abolish the forty-hour week at this time of rising prices would mean the return to sweatshop hours and pay."
The Davidson bill, passed in the Assembly on March 31, would practically nullify the Hospital Lien Law.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- A ceiling over wages and profits and an over-all price ceiling, which would involve also a freezing of rents, are receiving close consideration from the Administration, it was learned today.

Brookhattan defeated the New York Americans by 2 -- 1 in the home-and-home final of the Lewis Cup soccer series at Starlight Park, the Bronx, yesterday before a crowd of 4,500. The teams tied a week ago, 2 -- 2.

MIAMI, April 5 (AP) -- William J. Britton Jr., 25, son of the former world's welterweight champion, Jack Britton, and four other persons plunged to death today when two civilian airplanes were in collision 1,000 feet in the air.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 5 (AP) -- A large Easter crowd, attracted to the American Bowling Congress tourney to watch National Champion Ned Day of West Allis, Wis., topple the pins, was thrilled instead by the brilliant performance of his team-mate, Russ Gersonde of Milwaukee, who won a third-place tie in the singles with a 727 series.

There is a deathless hope that man cannot escape, a powerful intuition of immortality rising from major sources, that comes pouring out in times of crises, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick told a congregation of 4,000 persons yesterday at Easter morning services at the Riverside Church.

OSSINING, N.Y., April 5 -- A departure ceremony for three priests assigned to a mission in tropical Bolivia was held in the chapel of Maryknoll Seminary this afternoon with 1,000 persons attending, including Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of New York, Postmaster, General Frank C. Walker and several consular officials of South American counties.
MELBOURNE, Australia, April 5 (AP) -- An Australian communique said today:
Fifth Avenue wasn't the only mecca yesterday for the city's Easter promenaders.

The story of how a medium-sized United States merchant ship outran four submarines, only to be sunk by a fifth, was disclosed here yesterday after the Navy Department in Washington had announced the loss of the vessel. The ship was sent to the bottom off our Atlantic coast on March 20.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, April 5 -- Announcement of the organization and personnel by which General Douglas MacArthur will effect unified command over the United Nations army, navy and air forces in this area is expected shortly.

Mrs. Robert Low Bacon, civic lead of this city and Washington, D.C., yesterday accepted the co-chairmanship of the Greater New York Committee of United China Relief, it was announced by W.R. Herod, president of the organization.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 5 -- A sudden collapse by John Hubbell, younger brother of the redoubtable Carl, imperiled a promised Giant victory over the Memphis Chicks today, to the amazement of about 2,500 onlookers and the consternation of Manager Mel Ott. But a rush call to the bull-pen brought Harry Feldman and a change in Giant fortunes and the New Yorkers eked out the victory, 8 to 7.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 5 -- Members of the congregation of Christ Episcopal Church in this city knelt today where General Douglas MacArthur was christened almost sixty-two years ago, and asked Divine guidance for the Allied commander in the Southwestern Pacific.
Just how long the luck will continue in the East Branch of the Croton River, in the vicinity of Brewster, remains to be seen.
MOSCOW, April 5 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau communique today said:

Expressing regret that the National Youth Administration Symphony Orchestra is being discontinued after an existence of two years, Mayor La Guardia said at the orchestra's final concert last night that even in time of war creative and interpretative art must have continuity.

The Battle of Sunday Closing was fought on Long Island yesterday and at the end the defending forces at two chain filling stations not observing a voluntary Sunday shutdown were weary and battered but still holding out.

PALM BEACH, Fla., April 5 -- Mr. and Mrs. James Taylor Terry gave a dinner at home for their guest, Mrs. Howard C. Dickinson. Other guests were Mr. and Mrs. J. Terry West, Mrs. R. Jay Flick, Mr. and Mrs. Geraud van Nest Foster, Arthur Bradley Campbell and Wellington Wells.

The rejection last week of the Interstate Commerce Commission's plan of reorganization of the Missouri Pacific Railroad by several groups of holders of the road's securities should have no adverse effect upon the consummation of the plan, John W. Stedman, vice president of the Prudential Insurance Company, said in a statement issued for publication today.

Herewith the trade book clinic's monthly pronouncement on the books published in the past weeks that seemed to this unit of the American Institute of Graphic Arts especially well designed: "The Undiscoverables," by Ralph Bates (Random House); "Inside Benchley," by Robert Benchley (Harper) and "Beyond the Solar System," by Bertha Morris Parker (Harper).
The National League, famous for its field altercations, will have less squabbling and faster play this season, President Ford Frick disclosed yesterday, The United Press reported.

The Class I railroads' capital expenditures in 1941 were $543,000,000, the largest since 1930, according to the Association of American Railroads. This was an increase of $113,874,000 above such expenditures in 1940. Gross capital expenditures in 1930 amounted to $872,608,000.

Due entirely to gains in the seamless branch, all previous records for the month were broken by February hosiery shipments, which amounted to 12,758,694 dozen pairs of all types, according to the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., April 5 -- Major Buell Hammett, 44, who was wounded in a gun duel Thursday night with another retired army major, William H. Wenstrom, 45, today faced amputation of his right leg.

CHUNGKING, China, April 5 -- Reports circulating here say that the new Japanese Ambassador to Moscow, Naotaka Sato, has demanded the withdrawal of Soviet troops along the Manchukuo border and the removal of Soviet air bases to points within Siberia from which they could not menace Japan.

In its new financing today the Treasury is adopting several innovations. Instead of the long-term bonds upon which it has chiefly relied recently, it is reverting to a money-market favorite once frequently employed but which has been out of use for eight years -- the Treasury certificate of indebtedness.

Although neither had the regulation quota of fifteen players, the Queens and New York clubs waged a close battle in their Eastern Rugby Union game at Astoria Park yesterday, with the Queens unit triumphing by 6 to 3 on a late rally.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 5 -- In contrast to the blow-outs of several recent Sundays when racing could not be held, the Easter weather was much too lamb like for the dinghy sailors at the Larchmont Yacht Club.
"I don't think about growing old. I only look forward to the work that I have to do."

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- A seven-point "OPA Export Price Policy" designed to hold the balance fairly between domestic and foreign customers of American industry was outlined in a joint memorandum issued today by the Office of Price Administration, which has jurisdiction over export as well as domestic prices, and the Board of Economic Warfare, which deals with applications for export licenses.

Picketing of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey circus at Madison Square Garden by three members of the American Guild of Variety Artists continued yesterday, with no settlement of the dispute over wages yet in view.
WILDWOOD, N.J., April 5 (AP) -- Age triumphed over youth today in the final of the fourteenth annual Eastern States Easter golf tournament.

PHILADELPHIA, April 5 -- Every war plant and every foot of Philadelphia's vital waterfront is under constant patrol by members of the several law enforcement agencies, augmented by members of the Auxiliary Police Corps and of the Pennsylvania Home Defense Corps.

BERNE, Switzerland, Monday, April 6 -- A special announcement received from Moscow this morning said that Soviet troops pressing toward Smolensk had captured positions on the bank of a river after two days of fierce fighting in which the German Thirty-sixth and 331st Infantry Divisions were shattered.

CHICAGO, April 5 -- Prices of wheat were on the down grade last week, dropping to the lowest levels since early last December as tired longs started to liquidate their holdings and found speculative and commercial support lacking. While there were moderate rallies at times, closing sales on the Board of Trade yesterday were at the lowest levels of the week, with losses of 3 to 3 1/8 cents a bushel.

In an era of efficiency, service caps and short coiffures, there is something wistful and a little sad in the whiff of an exotic essence that fleetingly recaptures that now forgotten pre-war mood. But it is here in a new perfume of palest gold -- lavish, extravagant and alluring.

E.J. Zeiner and J.J. VanGonsic tied for the high-over-all scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. Each broke 97 out of 100 targets. There also was a tie in the handicap event between H. Hammer and J. Mercadante, each with 99. The shoot-off went to Hammer.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 5 (U.P.) -- Protestant church groups dedicated to maintenance of Belfast's Sunday blue law last week sent telegrams protesting the holding of Sunday shows for the troops to Prime Minister Churchill and War Secretary Sir James Grigg.

Initial steps taken by the Department of Justice and the War Department have been constructive, but much remains to be done in organizing control of the conduct of alien enemies within the country. Civilian hearing boards should now be established to examine the personal histories and appraise the loyalties of those declared to be alien enemies by the Presidential proclamation of Dec. 8, 1941.

CLINTON, N.J., April 5 -- The white and liver pointer dog Our Congressman, owned and handled by Fred A. Clarkson of New York, gained his first all-age victory today in the amateur stake, final event of the Jockey Hollow Field Trial Club meeting.

America's industrial plant is really beginning to roll, as Donald M. Nelson, War Production Board chairman, said in his Army Day address. An enormous volume of material is being produced, equaling or even exceeding in many cases the high goals set by the President.

The Ski Union of the Americas, now composed of Bolivia, Chile, Canada and the United States, ended a two-day history-making congress yesterday at the home of Roland Palmedo, 1185 Park Avenue. A program as democratic in construction as the principles on which the governing body of Western Hemisphere skiing are built was devised before the delegates departed.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., April 5 -- Belting Ben Hogan, the little man who is the Mr. Big of golf, beat Lawson Little by a stroke to win the Land of the Sky open golf tournament today for the third straight time. His score was 276.

PORTLAND, Ore., April 5 -- Portland is ready to deal with air raids if and when they come. Following a plan originated in 1939 and kept up to date as a result of British experience, this city has coordinated military, State, city and civilian defense efforts under State and local defense councils.
LOS ANGELES, April 5 -- Los Angeles has organized an efficient defense corps, but much remains to be done.

A decisive stage in the Battle of the World opened last week as Germany, Japan, Italy and their satellite nations mobilized their maximum strength for their impending attempt to win the war this year.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 5 -- A German attempt to invade Malta, which most of the island's defenders expect will come, quite possibly will not occur at all, in the opinion of a wing commander of the Royal Air Force who arrived recently in the Middle East from Malta.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 5 -- Five scoreless innings unfolded by Hugh Casey carried the Dodgers to a 4-to-3 victory over Paul Richards's Atlanta Crackers today at Ponce de Leon Field before a gathering of 7,000, some of whom were neighbors of Casey's from near-by Buckhead, Ga., but the game was an incidental development in the ranks of Leo Durocher's players.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt warned last night, in the last of a series of sponsored broadcasts over the Blue Network, that unless soldiers are kept in touch with what is going on at home and feel that their interests are being safeguarded, "we must face the probability that we will have a dangerous pressure group in our midst" after the war.

In their efforts to recover the championship of the Metropolitan Chess League from the Marshall Club in the final round, eighteen members of the Manhattan Club took a lead of 8 -- 5 at the rooms of the former yesterday.

FRANCONIA, N.H., April 5 -- The winner of the sixth annual Edson Memorial giant slalom, held today on the Taft Trail atop Cannon Mountain under the sponsorship of the Amateur Ski Club of New York and the Dartmouth Outing Club, was Robert Meservey of the Dartmouth O.C., whose no fall run of 1 minute 25 seconds was 1.6 seconds faster than that of his team-mate, Jake Nunnemacher.

Australian sailors and airmen conducted a Commando-like raid on an unidentified Netherlands Indies port held by the Japanese recently, spirited away war equipment and destroyed other materiel, the Sydney radio said yesterday in a broadcast recorded here by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

Jean La Cloche, 17 years old, and his brother, Francois, 15, who have been missing since they left Exeter Academy in New Hampshire in January and enlisted in the Free French forces in Montreal, are safe in England, according to a cablegram received last night by their mother, Mrs. Mary La Cloche of 7 Beekman Place, from Anthony Roper, headmaster of the Lady Cross School in London:

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, April 5 (AP) -- John Hay Whitney's Massa scampered to a new track record in winning the $10,000 added Grand Nacional Steeplechase by a nose from his stablemate, Cupid, before 9,000 persons today.

While all statements of condition of commercial banks at the end of the first quarter of this year have not been announced, enough representative reports are at hand to warrant the conclusion that there is little unanimity of experience under wartime conditions, aside from the fact that most banks, large and small, have increased their loans and discounts substantially.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- A War Department communique based on reports received up to 9:30 A.M. said today:

Traditional splendor marked the celebration of the Mass of the Solemnity of Solemnities, the liturgical name for the Feast of Christ's Resurrection, by the Most Rev. Francis J. Spellman, Archbishop of New York, in St. Pattrick's Cathedral yesterday before a congregation of 7,500.
LONDON, April 5 -- Britain today observed her third Easter Sunday of the war by staying at home, or near by.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Adolf Hitler is moving with speed to extend his "system of slave labor throughout subjugated Europe," the Office of Facts and Figures said today.

While total volume in coats and suits tapered off as Easter buying was completed, dress activity continued substantial throughout the week, according to a summary of last week's activities prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buyers.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The Federal Trade Commission announced today that it had issued an amended complaint alleging violation of the Robinson-Patman act in the sale of salt against the International Salt Company of Scranton, Pa., and its subsidiaries, the International Salt Company, Inc., Scranton; the Independent Salt Company, New York, and the Eastern Salt Company of Boston.
DETROIT, April 5 -- The War Production Board is expected to intervene this week in an intra-management controversy that is delaying the placement of unemployed automobile workers in war jobs.

Taxes paid by the Consolidated Edison Company of New York and its subsidiaries in 1941, were equal to $1,842 for each employe, according to the concern's annual report to employes, released yesterday. Taxes on the Consolidated Edison system took $62,966,000 last year, equal to more than 24 cents out of every dollar of revenue.

Spurred on by the sudden renaissance of vaudeville as borne out by the record-breaking business of "Priorities of 1942" at the Forty-sixth Street, Clifford C. Fischer and his partner, Lee Shubert, are pressing their luck with another variety show, headed by the team of William Gaxton and Victor Moore.

In a letter published in another column on this page James G. McDonald draws attention to the need for an improved method of distinguishing between enemy aliens who are really such and loyal "aliens of enemy nationalities." The Department of Justice can deal with "those under suspicion of subversive activities."
Eighty-two fellowships, with grants of funds totaling $196,000, were announced yesterday by the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation, to assist research and creative work.

CHICAGO, April 5 -- A combination of higher temperatures and ample surface and subsoil moisture resulted last week in Winter wheat making rapid growth in many sections of the main producing areas. Aside from a need of rain in parts of Texas and Oklahoma, the outlook for the coming harvest is regarded as unusually favorable.
Plans for expansion moves by industries and stores were revealed in realty transactions reported in New Jersey over the week-end.

More than one hundred governmental and private agencies and commercial concerns throughout the United States are making plans for the post-war period, according to a survey made by the Twentieth Century Fund that is being issued today.

The appointment of Dr. Albert Eide Parr as director of the Ameri can Museum of Natural History was announced yesterday by A. Perry Osborn, acting president of the museum's board of trustees. Dr. Parr, who for four years has directed the Peabody Museum of Yale University, has accepted the appointment and will take office on June 1 as the museum's fifth director.

CHICAGO, April 5 -- Spreading operations between wheat and corn featured trading in the latter grain last week on the Board of Trade here. At the close yesterday May corn was 35 3/4 cents a bushel under the same delivery of wheat, compared with 38 5/8 cents a week before and 41 3/4 cents a month ago.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Labor-management committees have notified Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, that production drives have been organized in plants of 308 companies producing war materials.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Conditions which will govern the offering tomorrow of $1,500,000,000 of 0.5 per cent Treasury certificates of indebtedness were announced today by Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 5 -- With the departure yesterday morning of the last of the Japanese diplomatic corps, accommodated this Winter at the request of the government, the Homestead received guests in the afternoon inaugurating its 176th season.

CHICAGO, April 5 -- Unusually heavy demands for hog meats and lard for lease-lend and other operations are resulting in a shrinkage of supplies in cold storage throughout the country. Packers say there is no indication of a let-up in the demand.
The surface gayety of bright Spring fashions clashed yesterday with the mood of solemnity of the crowds in the city's celebration of the first Easter of this country's Second World War.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 5 -- Engaging in their final tune-up before resuming hostilities with the Dodgers in Charlotte tomorrow, the Yankees buried Nashville under a barrage of eighteen hits today to vanquish Larry Gilbert's Vols for the second successive afternoon. The score was 11 to 6.

The all-Wagner program of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, under John Barbirolli's direction, was composed of music from "Parsifal," previously reviewed in these columns when presented last week, followed by excerpts from "Die Meistersinger" not performed at that previous pair of concerts.

The news of the loss of the U.S.S. Peary, the destroyer which went down in the Far East with guns firing until the sea swamped her, recalls to me the indomitable spirit of the wonderful Peary himself, whom it was my privilege to serve for many years.

Defense preparation is now a day-in-and-day-out activity in the city's public school system, James Marshall, president of the Board of Education, declares in a report released today, listing fourteen additional projects started since February.

Stories of survivors from the Langley, the Pecos and the Peary make grim reading. They tell of helpless ships pounded to wreckage by a ruthless enemy with full command of the air, of our men fighting with hopeless courage until the decks were awash under them.

Diametrically opposite arguments have been broadcast by Axis short-wave radio stations to the people of the United States and to those of Great Britain in an effort to create dissension between the two countries, it was disclosed yesterday by the Anti-Nazi Non-Sectarian League, which released a specimen survey of broadcasts heard between Jan. 15 and March 4.
BALTIMORE, April 5 -- The city's many war plants are under heavy and constant guard and the waterfront area is barred to those persons who have no business there.

PORT MORESBY, New Guinea, April 5 (U.P.) -- The story of the hopeless struggle of the outnumbered Australian garrison of Rabaul, New Britain Island, against Japanese invasion forces Jan. 23, and of the privations the defenders suffered after they evacuated the town was revealed tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Inaugurating radio's "Army Hour" on the eve of Army Day, Secretary Stimson and the chiefs of the continental field forces told Americans tonight of the resolute strength of the nation's soldiers looking to the hour of the offensive that will win the war.

The six-story dwelling containing a self-service elevator and occupying a lot 26.4 by 66.9 feet at 103 Riverside Drive has been sold by the 103 Riverside Drive Corporation, represented by the City Bank Farmers Trust Company. It is assessed at $32,000, of which $27,000 is land value, and was sold for cash over a first mortgage of $14,000.

Greater need for family welfare assistance to alleviate the hardships caused by the war is forecast in the annual report of the Division of Families of New York Catholic Charities, made public yesterday by the Rev. John J. Donovan, director.

Marred by squabbles and enlivened by some accidents -- the soundless siren of the first test and the gun that shelled the Equitable Building -- New York's civilian defense program has gone forward considerably since the Japanese dropped their bombs on Pearl Harbor and brought America into the war.

A plan for shoppers to return all their paper bags to stores once a week to avoid a paper shortage here, with the added incentive of storekeepers paying for the bags with defense stamps, was put forward yesterday by Simon H. Schneider, mail carrier at the Times Square postoffice.

The fusing together of justice and mercy "as basic elements in any ennobling, regenerating new order which may emerge from the present world upheaval," was declared necessary by Mgr. James H. Griffiths, vice chancellor of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, in an Easter sermon yesterday morning at St. James Pro-Cathedral, Jay and Chapel Streets, Brooklyn. Bishop Thomas. E. Molloy pontificated.

ONE OF THE LARGEST ORDNANCE DISTRICTS OF THE UNITED STATES, April 5 -- From the office of this ordnance district, one of the thirteen such districts into which this country is divided, private industry receives its orders for ammunition, pistols, rifles, machine guns, artillery and tanks.

A reduction of more than one-third in the number of unemployed receiving insurance benefits and in the total sum they received for 1941 in this country was reported yesterday in a compilation made public by the American Association for Social Security.

The largest congregation in the history of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, yesterday morning heard the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell deliver his Easter message as "an effective answer to the forces in the modern world that crush and exploit and enslave man, using him as cannon fodder."

Brown Brothers Harriman Co. reported as of March 31, total deposits of $137,462,686 and total assets of $162,019,786, both new high levels. These figures compare, respectively, with $133,722,124 and $157,643,704 on Dec. 31, 1941.

The fragile calm of this tense Easter was broken on two islands the width of the world apart. Ceylon and Ireland are about the same size, but the tropic island on the southern tip of India bears no other resemblance to the misty island at the western edge of Europe. There was no connection between the Japanese raid on the steaming port of Colombo and the private gun battle in Belfast.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- A letter from President Roosevelt to the Fraternal Council of Negro Churches saying that the Committee on Fair Employment Practice was making "vigorous efforts to eliminate discrimination based on race, creed, color or national origin" was made public today by the National Negro Congress.

Mr. and Mrs. Jack Sprat, the prudent pair with the propensity of licking the platter clean, should serve as models of good behavior in these days of wartime economies. Particularly, does Mrs. Sprat, with her habit of not letting one scrap of fat go to waste, stand out as a shining example.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 5 -- The war and the building of the United States defense bases have so changed Bermuda's import situation that during the last year the United States took a commanding lead among the countries supplying the colony.

With the Tammany executive committee scheduled to meet April 14 in an attempt to elect a leader to succeed Christopher D. Sullivan, it appeared yesterday that no candidate had a majority and that there was continued possibility of another deadlock, with Charles H. Hussey, chairman of the executive committee, remaining as acting leader.

LONDON, April 5 -- In what is believed to have been the work of outlawed Irish Republican Army elements commemorating the 1916 Easter uprising, several incendiary bombs, believed to be of German make, exploded early this morning in the big Belfast movie theatre known as the Royal Hippodrome which is used for Sunday evening entertainments for all the troops, both British and American, stationed in Northern Ireland.

LONDON, April 5 -- The next move in the Indian negotiations has been put up to the British War Cabinet, which over the week-end pondered reports from Sir Stafford Cripps, its special representative at New Delhi, and General Sir Archibald P. Wavell, the British Commander in Chief in India.

Air Vice-Marshal William Foster Macneece Foster was among the eleven passengers from Europe who arrived at La Guardia Field at noon yesterday aboard a Pan American Airways clipper. He said he would continue to Washington, where he will head the Royal Air Force delegation.

Consuls General of the Latin-American Republics and their wives will be special guests of the auction committee of the Citizens Committee for the Army and Navy, Inc., today at the third in the series of "All Out" Concerts at Town Hall, and at a luncheon to be given afterward at the Town Hall Club.

Aristides Dimitratos, former Greek Minister of Labor, whose Greek-language broadcast was canceled by the National Broadcasting Company last week, took exception yesterday to a statement by the Greek Legation in Washington, which denied that he was a party leader and asserted that the Greek Government in London followed "policies most favorable to labor."

CHICAGO, April 5 -- Tenants of the American Furniture Mart and Merchandise Mart believe the recent bans on production of a long list of metal toys, electrical appliances and less pretentious household necessities mean a record attendance at the mid-season home-furnishings market which will be held here the week of April 27.
BERLINS April 5 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- A German communique today said:

In the chill of yesterday's gray dawn tens of thousands of New Yorkers -- some on their way to work in war plants -- attended religious services, at most of which the present dark days were compared to the trials of the early Christians.

Aristides Dimitratos, former Greek Minister of Labor, whose Greek-language broadcast was canceled by the National Broadcasting Company last week, took exception yesterday to a statement by the Greek Legation in Washington, which denied that he was a party leader and asserted that the Greek Government in London followed "policies most favorable to labor."

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 5 -- Prime Minister John Curtin announced tonight that United Nations fliers and ground defenses had destroyed at least eighteen Japanese planes yesterday in actions at Kupang, on Timor Island; at Lae, in Northeast New Guinea, and at Darwin.

LONDON, April 5 -- In the first attack on Ceylon, British base off the southern tip of India seventy-five Japanese planes today raided the harbor, airdrome and Ratmalana railway at Colombo and were repulsed with the certain loss of twenty-seven craft shot down.

Consolidated net profit of Aluminium, Ltd., and subsidiaries for 1941, it was announced yesterday, was $16,014,161, equivalent, after preferred dividends and exchange premium thereon, to $20.81 a share on 744,410 common shares, against $12,462,231, or $16.03 a common share, earned in 1940.

The Office of Naval Office Procurement, which was established in February to handle the flood of applications that were being received daily by the Third Naval District for Naval Reserve commissions, has been moved from the Federal Office Building at 90 Church Street to 33 Pine Street, where it will occupy the entire sixteenth floor, beginning today.
Mlle. Josephine Eberli, otherwise known as "Josie" or "the boss," didn't stop her good-natured scolding or "managing" last night, but she had no part in the preparation of a large anniversary dinner.

WASHINGTON, April -- Gen eral MacArthur was hailed today by Foreign Minister Herbert Evatt of Australia as "the symbol of the valorous heart and the dauntless spirit which alone can recapture the Pacific area which the Japanese covet."

Gerald Griffin, executive secretary of the American Guild of Variety Artists, which has jurisdiction over 20,000 vaudeville and kindred entertainers, was removed from his office yesterday afternoon at a meeting of the international board of Associated Actors and Artistes of America, A.F. of L., parent body of all entertainment unions.

LOS ANGELES, April 6 (AP) -- The tennis tour featuring Donald Budge, Bobby Riggs, Frank Kovacs and Fred Perry came to an end today. Business Manager Harry M. Thayer said all future bookings had been canceled.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 6 (AP) -- The defending champion, Miss Dorothy Kirby of Atlanta, was forced to wage a bitter battle against Miss Mary Jane Garman of Sarasota, Fla., today before gaining a 1-up decision to enter the semi-finals of the twelfth annual Forest Hills women's golf tournament.

Mayor La Guardia was taxed yesterday with trying to evade the effort of a Court of Appeals decision that upheld the power of the City Council to subpoena the Mayor and to examine his confidential records.
LONDON, April 6 -- Indications grow stronger daily that the party truce, like Prime Minister Churchill's government, is rapidly losing popular favor.

SYDNEY, Australia, April 6 -- American "hustle" is making itself felt in Australia, a correspondent for The Sydney Sun with the United States forces reported today in describing the transformation of a sheep pasture into a troop camp in twelve hours.

HONOLULU, April 6 (U.P.) -- Gas masks and identification cards have become nearly as essential as food and clothing to the Hawaiian civilian during the first four months of war in the Pacific ending tonight.

WITH THE UNITED STATES ARMY, in Northern Ireland, April 6 -- Major Gen. Russell P. Hurtle, field commander of the United States forces here, suggested tonight in an order of the day commemorating the United States entry into the World War twenty-five years ago that the present conflict be called a "Crusade for Living."

The cooperation of all peoples, especially of all Christendom, is essential if the "ruin of a frustrated and deluded peace" is to be avoided, Mgr. Donald A. MacLean, associate Professor of Social and International Ethics at Catholic University, Washington, declared yesterday afternoon at the sixteenth annual conference of the Catholic Association for International Peace.

Elizabeth Wysor, American contralto who made her New York debut seven years ago, and John Walsh, California baritone, who made his last season, last night joined together and gave a "vocal chamber music recital" at the Concert Theatre. Each sang two solo groups and they sang two duets, "La Ci Darem" from Mozart's "Don Giovanni" and "Ai Caprici della sorte" from Rossini's "L'Italiana in Algeri."

The Appellate Term of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn reserved decision yesterday in a test case involving rates charged by the Queens Borough Gas and Electric Company to large users of electricity and which may affect a considerable sum of money on the basis of a possible refund to consumers.

The people of India -- all of them and not just their political leaders -- have been receiving from Sir Stafford Cripps an outline of what they may expect from a Britain wiser and more generous than the Britain of the past. Yesterday they received two hints of what Japan has to offer them. One came in the form of attacks by Japanese planes on two East Coast towns -- Cocanada and Vizagapatam.

CHUNGKING, China, April 6 -- The Japanese are systematically blasting cities and towns of Burma in the rear of United Nations troops in an effort to create terror and disorder, thus hampering communications and cutting off sources of supplies.
CHARLESTON, S.C., April 6 -- "Song of the Bridge," 1942 winner of the $500 DuBose Heyward Memorial Playwright Award, had its premiere on the stage of the Dock Street Theatre tonight.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 6 -- Just a year after Reichsfuehrer Hitler began his invasion of Yugoslavia the political situation under the new order in the Balkan peninsula remains so uncertain that a political expert of the Tripartite powers has had to be sent to the various capitals, armed with full powers, to insure a proper contribution to the Axis war effort for the forthcoming Spring offensive.

ONE OF THE LARGEST ORDNANCE DISTRICTS OF THE UNITED STATES, April 6 -- The Ordinance Department is succeeding in its struggle to have private industry recognize the need for hair-splitting precision in the manufacture of munitions.
MELBOURNE, Australia, April 6 -- The Royal Australian Air Force returned yesterday to Timor Island to attack Kupang. The raid, on a small scale, was directed at wharves and grounded Japanese planes.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 6 -- An interesting sidelight on German penetration in Alsace comes from a neutral traveler who has just completed a tour of that province and is preparing a report for the International Red Cross on conditions he found there.

LONDON, April 6 -- The mainland of India suffered its first air raids today when Japanese planes from a naval carrier bombed the harbors of Vizagapatam and Cocanada, in the Madras Presidency, causing slight damage and a small number of casualties.
SUMMIT, N.J., April 6 -- This very genteel community atop of a "picturesque ridge called Second Mountain," according to a standard guidebook, ran into garbage-collection trouble today.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Several hundred officials, members of foreign delegations and other guests gathered today at the May-flower Hotel to honor General Douglas MacArthur at the unveiling of a portrait bust of him designed for presentation to the Military Academy at West Point.

On April 9 Norwegians all over the world will remember the second anniversary of the German attack on Norway. Thus, invaded without warning or provocation. Norway has been at war for the last two years. At this time, when Germany is engaged in a vast war on the Russian front, a new and powerful front is established behind her. The occupied countries fight back with an ever-increasing force.
This year the American Doll Show, which opened yesterday at Hearn's Auditorium, Fifth Avenue and Fourteenth Street, has an interest for boys as well as girls.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- Senator Van Nuys, chairman of the Senate's Judiciary Committee, told reporters today that Attorney General Biddle had expressed his approval of the objective of legislation which would permit wartime suspension of the anti-trust laws in certain cases. Mr. Biddle discussed the measure with the committee in a closed session.

"The best opening day in ten years," was the word brought back to town yesterday from Sullivan County by Al Boesel of the Trout and Skeet Club at Livingston Manor. The weather man had a pleasant surprise in store for trout anglers last Saturday though stream temperatures in that vicinity were still low.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Recruitment of "industrial commandos," to bring the little business men and little machine shops into the war effort where they can utilize their resourcefulness, daring and "refusal to take no for an answer" to solve tough armament problems, was urged today by Morris L. Cooke, Philadelphia consulting engineer and former head of the Rural Electrification Administration.
MELBOURNE, Australia, April 6 -- Despite all that has been written about the courageous defenders of Bataan Peninsula, there still are many tales of individual heroism that never have been told.

A musicale and tea in behalf of the Auxiliary of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children will be given tomorrow afternoon at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Chester L. Dane, 720 Park Avenue. The musical program will be presented by Miss Jessica Dragonette, soprano, Miss Frances Blaisdell, flutist; Rudolph Gruen, pianist, and Kenneth Gordon, violinist, all of whom have donated their services for the occasion.

Opening a new program of entertainment as an aid in morale building, the Todd Shipyards Corporation gave forty-five-minute band concerts yesterday at lunch time at its subsidiary yards, the Robins Dry Dock and Repair Company, in Brooklyn, and the Tietjen Lang Dry Dock Company, in Hoboken, N.J.

Fifty-four sons and daughters of British stage performers evacuated to this country early in the war will make their Broadway debuts at the Imperial Theatre this afternoon, when they present "Gratefully Yours," a revue which tells in sketches and songs how the British children have adjusted themselves to American ways.

Jack D. Vickers, 55 years old, an ex-convict from the South, who for three weeks was an air raid warden on the upper West Side, before his fingerprints revealed his past, pleaded guilty yesterday in his three-day Special Sessions trial for petty thefts from a woman air warden.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 6 (AP) -- Russian airmen and ground batteries, scoring one of the biggest bags of the war, destroyed 415 German planes in blazing aerial war during the eight-day period up to and including yesterday, a Soviet communique announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The importance of American solidarity, not only during the war but during the peace that will follow, was stressed by Dr. Ezequiel Padilla, Mexican Foreign Minister, who is on an official visit here, in an address today before the governing board of the Pan American Union.

BERLIN, April 6 (From German broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- The Winter battle in Russia has ended, but large-scale operations are not now possible because of thaw conditions and an "interlude" must precede the German Spring offensive, high military quarters said tonight.

Police Inspector Michael J. Murphy, head of the department's confidential investigating squad for the last eight years, left yesterday for a twenty-six-day vacation in Florida, his first full-time holiday since he took over the job. In the wake of his departure headquarters churned with persistent, but unofficial, reports that his vacation was a prelude to retirement.

Accused of exchanging Nazi salutes with another man in a bar and grill at Twenty-eighth Street and Third Avenue, Brooklyn, and of making pro-German remarks, a man who described himself as William Groth, 39 years old, of Wharton, N.J., was held in $100,000 bail last night in Brooklyn-Queens Night Court, although the specific charge was only disorderly conduct.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., April 6 -- Flanked by an overflow crowd of 7,500 eager-eyed enthusiasts, the Yankees and Dodgers resumed the showing of their 1941 world series repeat performance today and regaled the onlookers with a variety of action.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, April 6 (U.P.) -- Karl Fink, a hardware dealer whose letters to Switzerland about nuts and bolts coincided with Allied ship movements in Rio de Janeiro harbor, was among those arrested today as police continued rounding up suspected Axis agents.
BERLIN, APRIL 6 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

CHICAGO, April 6 -- The Illinois Federation of Retail Associations took steps today to organize some 10,000 retailers of the State for a protest against retail price ceilings and at the same time wired the OPA at Washington its belief that broad price fixing is unjustified.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Mrs. Roosevelt said today that she "rather thought" women would be needed for farm work this year in many parts of the country, and suggested that any one planning to volunteer for service with the Women's Land Army would do well to begin without delay training for physical fitness and the study of farm techniques.

A bomb shelter cocktail party in behalf of the New York Institute for the Education of the Blind was given yesterday afternoon at the Sherry-Netherland. The funds realized will be used for the construction of an air raid shelter for blind children at the school located at 999 Pelham Parkway, the Bronx.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., April 6 -- "A long, hard war, physically, mentally, morally and every other way, before victory is ours" was predicted by Admiral Harold Stark, former chief of naval operations, on a visit to the city of his birth today before he departs for London to assume command of American naval forces in European waters.

TOKYO, April 6 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Premier Hideki Tojo told India's millions today that "great calamities" would be unavoidable "in the course of our subjugation of British forces" in India.
Many of the business leases reported yesterday called for full-floor units of space. A variety of commercial enterprises was represented and the activity was well distributed throughout the city.

TORONTO, April 6 -- The brillient toil of a dozen National Hockey League craftsmen over a full season's play was rewarded tonight with the announcement of their selection for the twelfth annual Canadian Press all-star team.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 6 (AP) -- President Manuel Quezon, dynamic leader of the Philippine people, is working hard with military authorities somewhere in Australia on preparations for eventual reconquest of his island Commonwealth.

GREENVILLE, Miss., April 6 -- Because Manager Mel Ott of the Giants had the misfortune to experiment today with Hugh East as a nine-inning pitcher when Manager Lou Boudreau of the Indians was carrying on an experiment of his own, the New Yorkers lost the benefit of one of their best hitting days of the training campaign.
MELBOURNE, Australia, April 6 (AP) -- Prime Minister John Curtin issued this communique today:

Mayor La Guardia's proposal to pay new policemen at the rate of $1,200 a year for their first six months of service was condemned yesterday before the finance committee of the City Council by Patrick Harnedy, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, who said the reduced salary would drive the rookies into the hands of "loan sharks."

Three co-defendants in the indictment involving Frank A. Miller, former superintendent of the claims department of the Eagle Star Insurance Company, Ltd., in a total of $183,000 in thefts from the concern, joined him yesterday in General Sessions in guilty pleas.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, April 6 -- A group of American nurses arrived unexpectedly tonight at a hotel in this city that is much used by the American military, and the hubbub they caused was a caution. They are the first sizable contingent of American girls to reach the city and, although they stayed at the hotel only for dinner, they walked out with many second lieutenants' hearts, not to mention a major or two.

LONDON, April 6 -- Roaring over Western Europe, more than 300 British bombers through last night pounded several French factories near Paris that were known to be producing war materials for the Germans, bombed the docks at Havre and again raided the Rhineland, where they devoted most of their attention to war-production factories at Cologne.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Severe restriction of varieties and shades of lipsticks, rouges, powders and cleansing creams, and elimination of hand lotions, toilet waters and luxury perfumes, may not be far distant, officials of the War Production Board said today.
The five-story apartment hotel known as the Embassy at 147-53 Sip Avenue, Jersey City, N.J., was sold by the Prudential Insurance Company to the Sip Holding Company, Jacob Paer, president.

With the observance today of the ninth anniversary of the legal sale of beer, the Brewing Industry Foundation declared yesterday that Federal and State taxes from beer during the last nine years amounted to more than $3,250,000,000.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The destroyer Kearny, victim of a German submarine before this country entered the war, has rejoined the Atlantic Fleet after undergoing major repairs in record time, the Navy Department announced today.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 6 -- Seven United States Navy fliers, the crew of a flying boat shot down at sea off North Australia, have contributed a great feat of endurance, it was revealed here today.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The Association of American Railroads announced today that it had refused the request of the Office of Price Administration that the railroads voluntarily forego the increased freight rates on certain commodities granted to them by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- More than $9,600,000 worth of farm products enriched the diets of more than 3,600,000 persons eligible for public assistance as a result of the operation of, the Food Stamp plan in February, the Agriculture Department reported today.

I hope that your readers will not be discouraged by Mrs. Patterson's remarks upon the smelliness of rabbits. In the kindergarten of the school that my little boy attends, rabbits are kept and bred in the classroom without offense to human noses. Smell nearly always yields to cleanliness, and it is questionable if rabbits are, pound for pound, any more offensive in this respect than cats or dogs or human beings.
The battle for Burma is more than a localized struggle and far transcends in importance the relatively small size of the opposing forces.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Canners and packers were advised by WPB today that they can have quota-exempt sugar in whatever amounts necessary for the first processing of fruits and vegetables. The exemption applies only to first processing and is intended to cover the treatment of fruits or vegetables by quick-freezing, cold-packing, canning, preserving or other methods.

Carrying to the Supreme Court their fight to set aside the revocation by John L. Lewis of the charter of the only New York City local of the United Mine Workers, leaders of the Chemical, Drug and Cosmetic Workers Union, Local 12165, obtained from Justice John E. McGeehan yesterday an order requiring Mr. Lewis to show cause on Thursday why the local's charter should not be reinstated and its office property returned.

Miss Anley Loren, who gave her first New York piano recital at the Town Hall last night, was born in New York and is a graduate of New York's exceptional High School of Music and Art. Clearly she is a young pianist, for the High School of Music and Art is itself too youthful to have had many graduating classes.

All new-crop futures advanced yesterday beyond the 20-cents-a-pound level before selling checked the upward movement on the New York Cotton Exchange. Prices of active contracts moved up 20 to 22 points, or $1 to $1.10 a bale, in early trading, but finished at levels 1 point lower to 5 points higher than the previous close.

Six hundred gaily colored Easter eggs sent by Governor Sumner Sewall of Maine were the main attraction at an Easter party presented yesterday afternoon in the parish hall of Christ Methodist Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, by the children of the Sunday School classes.

John Meryett, 26 years old, who, between two loan office hold-ups here last Winter, traveled by airplane to hold up the reception after the wedding of Gloria Vanderbilt and Pasquare di Cicco at Beverly Hills, Calif., was committed yesterday by Judge Jonah V. Goldstein in General Sessions to the Matteawan State Hospital for the Criminal Insane.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended April 1 aggregated $11,707,000,000.

A just completed set of paintings by Thomas Benton -- paintings that refer directly, and savagely, to the present war -- was placed on view last night at the Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue. The pictures may be seen by the public, beginning today. . The widely known American artist took up this task on the eighth of last !December.

PEORIA, Ill., April 6 (AP) -- George P. McNear Jr., president, and two other officials of the now Federally operated Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad went on trial today on criminal charges of violation of the National Railway Labor Act.

THERE it goes again. Excitement in the Dodger camp over the Selective Service status of Pete Reiser and Peewee Reese. It shows one problem that major league managers are going to have "for the duration." And not only major league managers but all coaches and team managers along the front line of sports.

Easter week-end attendance records were shattered at three midtown film theatres, while other houses benefited considerably as a result of the ideal combination of record throngs of paraders and balmy weather over the week-end, a survey of theatres disclosed yesterday.

A Federal grand jury yesterday attributed a little racket to Leo Goldblum, 41-year-old deputy collector of internal revenue. Goldblum was one of the tax experts assigned recently to help people who could not cope with the Federal income tax rules.

Soldiers and war workers, watching metropolitan skies for enemy aircraft, celebrated Army Day here yesterday. At the same time they observed the twenty-fifth anniversary of the entry of the United States into the first World War.

Members of the executive committee for the Red, White and Blue Ball, to be held on April 17 at the Ritz-Carlton for the benefit of the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York, will meet this morning at the home of Mrs. Bruce F.E. Harvey, chairman of the group, at 1111 Park Avenue, to discuss further plans for the benefit.

CHICAGO, April 6 (UP) -- Nine hundred clerks and freight handlers, members of the Brotherhood of Railway Clerks, walked out at two major Chicago carloading terminals today. Delay in vital war shipments was in prospect as a result, according to company spokesmen.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, April 6 (AP) -- Raids described as "among the heaviest yet made by the Allies" were reported to have been carried out today by Australian and American fliers striking at Rabaul and Gasmata, in New Britain, where, it was said, the Japanese are reinforcing their badly battered and overmatched air forces.

DENVER, Col., April 6 (U.P.) -- The spreading revolt of the United Mine Workers against Congress of Industrial Organization leadership continued today with the resignation of six U.M.W. State presidents as regional directors of the C.I.O.

Men's clothing manufacturers will start opening Fall lines officially today with substantial price increases over Spring levels for all-wool goods, reports in the market indicated yesterday. Increases range as high as $3 to $4 a unit, while some makers will use manipulated cloths to hold their goods within certain price brackets.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 6 -- The screen version of "Panama Hattie," which was completed last October but never released, will go before the cameras for complete revision next week with William Lundigan replacing Dan Dailey Jr. as Nick Bullett, Joan Carroll replacing Jackie Horner as Geraldine Bullett, and Roy del Ruth replacing Norman MacLeod as director of the picture, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. announced today that the offering this morning of $1,500,000,000 of 1/2 per cent Treasury certificates of indebtedness of Series A-1942 had been well received and that the subscription books would close tonight. Subscriptions in the mail before midnight tonight, however, will be eligible for allotment, announcement of which probably will be made Friday.

The Hurok "season of ballet" at the Metropolitan Opera House, which is to consist of one week each of performances by the Ballet Theatre and the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, got under way last night with the Ballet Theatre holding the field and three ballets by Michel Fokine constituting the program.

This year's Guggenheim fellowships must obviously leave more than 1,400 aspirants disappointed, for of the 1,500 who applied only eighty-two were successful. Past experience, however, has proved the worth of the sorting-out process. The literary names which the public knows best include John Dos Passos, Gustavus Myers, the English poet, Hugh Auden; Dorothy Baker, author of "Young Man With a Horn," and Carson McCullers, author of "The Heart Is a Lonely Hunter."

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- New maximum freight rates and surcharges for transportation of sugar from Cuba to Atlantic and Gulf ports, effective with vessels tendered for loading in Cuba on and after April 1, were announced today by the Maritime Commission. The agency said the new rates in most categories were lower than those in effect since Dec. 8.

The stock market made considerable headway yesterday in recovering some of the severe losses suffered in March as the list recorded its widest gains in three months. Sales were 335,200 shares, compared with 371,760 shares on last Thursday. After having established a double bottom followed by three sessions of better prices, the market met no obstacles in its recovery effort and the rally reached major proportions in many individual issues.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- The destruction of three more Japanese vessels announced by the United States Navy today raised to a total of fifty-one the number of Japanese ships blasted by far-roving United States submarines -- a total made up of thirty sinkings, ten probable sinkings and the damaging of eleven other ships.

Frauds by which residents of Albany, Newburgh and parts of New Jersey were said to have lost more than $200,000 were charged yesterday to five men in an indictment handed down by a Federal grand jury. The group, according to Jerome H. Doran, assistant United States attorney, sold "royalties" on the basis of false claims that their wells were producing oil.

A banking group composed of John Nuveen Co., Paul H. Davis Co. and Weeden Co., Inc., received yesterday the award of an issue of $900,000 of Kansas City, Mo., airport bonds on a net interest cost basis to the city of 1.53 per cent. The successful offer was 100.046 for $130,000 as 2s and $770,000 as 1 1/2s. The bonds will mature serially from May 1, 1944 to 1954.

Net profit of the Reynolds Metals Company in 1941 was $2,867,674, an increase of 18 per cent over the $2,428,277 earned in 1940, according to the annual report issued yesterday by R.S. Reynolds, president of the company.

The Gnome-Rhone works at Gennevilliers, just outside of Paris, bombed by the British over Sunday night, was the largest French aircraft and motorcycle engine plant before the fall of France. The factory, one of the company's six throughout France was primarily a smelting and forging plant, manufacturing the key materials for the other branches.
MOSCOW, April 6 (From Russian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau broadcast this communique today:

CHICAGO, April 6 (AP) -- Hogs advanced to new sixteen-year peaks today in fairly active trading. Choice swine brought $14.20 a hundred pounds, a new top since October, 1926, while most offerings sold between $13.90 and $14.15. Sows shared the upturn with gains of 25 cents a hundred pounds.

DETROIT, Mich., April 6 --Young men in their thirties who have avoided military service by obtaining soft administrative jobs were sharply criticized today by Lieut. Gen. Ben Lear, commanding officer of the Second Army, in an Army Day speech before the Detroit Economic Club.

Gerald W. Johnson's book, "Roosevelt: Dictator or Democrat," published several months ago by Harper, will be brought out in a German translation by Europa Verlag, Swiss publishing house. Mr. Johnson finds the fact somewhat embarrassing because, he says, the only two languages into which his books have been translated are German and Japanese.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- A War Department communique, based on reports received here up to 9:30 A.M. today, said:
NEW DELHI, India, April 6 (AP) -- Bombs fell among the people of India proper today when Japanese planes, attacking the Indian coast for the first time, raided Vizagapatam and Cocanada.

CHICAGO, April 6 -- Although it he grain markets showed weakness early, wheat breaking 1 1/2 cents a bushel to a new low price for the last four months, prices turned upward late in the session on covering by shorts and in sympathy with soy beans and other commodities.

The annual report of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, issued yesterday by Hermann G. Place, chairman of the executive committee, disclosed for 1941 a consolidated net profit of $4,921,926 after providing a reserve of $550,000 for foreign assets. The profit was in contrast to a net loss of $517,336 reported for 1940.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 6 -- That Reichsfuehrer Hitler can be beaten this year and that victory is conditional on two factors is the view advanced in an editorial today by the Moscow News. The factors are, first, that there must be no inactive armies or unused material in the anti-Hitler camp, and second, every hour and day must be used for the maximum production of planes, munitions and tanks.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 6 -- The committee appointed to consider a national scheme for uniform income taxation has presented a report recommending the retirement of the States from the income taxation field for the duration of the war and one year thereafter, and the substitution of the Commonwealth as the sole income tax authority, it was learned today.

FALL RIVER, Mass., April 6 (AP) -- Members of the American Federation of Textile Operatives voted unanimously tonight to end a two-week strike which had closed seventeen textile mills, many holding government contracts, and had made 18,000 workers idle.

VICHY, France, April 6 -- There is still no official reaction here to the appointment by the United States of a consul at Brazzaville, capital of Equatorial French Africa, which is under Free French control. There has been no mention of the fact in the press, and Easter Monday is a holiday.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Japanese assault troops, fighting with apparent disregard of casualties, today pushed back the defenders of Bataan Peninsula despite "savage" resistance by the heavily outnumbered United States and Filipino soldiers and sailors.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Civilianian employment in the government's executive branch rose by another 32,177 persons in January to a record total of 1,703,009 as compared with 1,153,431 in January, 1941.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The unfamiliar strains of military music -- it was a Sousa march -- gladdened the ears of people in downtown Washington today. But the music was not part of a parade, though this is Army Day. It came from the steps of the Treasury, where a rally was being held to promote the sale of what have been misnamed "Defense Bonds and Stamps."
NEW DELHI, April 6 (U.P.) -- The general himself was at the controls of the Flying Fortress that hit the cruiser.

The German Transocean Agency broadcast a dispatch from Tokyo yesterday reporting that, since the outbreak of war in the Pacific, Japanese Army transports have brought back 320,000 tons of foodstuffs to Japan from the conquered areas.

Robert Lehman, president of the Lehman Corporation, reported yesterday a net asset value of $24.74 a share for 1,988,277 shares of stock on March 31, comparing with $28.77 a share on 2,003,377 shares on July 1, 1941, when the current fiscal year began.

BUFFALO, April 6 -- The possibility of shortening the four-year high school course as a result of war needs, which have already caused curtailment of curricula in some colleges, was discussed today by Dr. James Stuart Plant, director of the Essex County Juvenile Clinic, Newark, N.J., who is attending the golden jubilee convention of the Association for Childhood Education.

Prescott S. Bush, national chairman of the United Service Organizations' campaign for $32,000,000, announced yesterday that thirty-eight State chairmen had been appointed and forty State headquarters established. At the same time he disclosed that the Governors of the forty-eight States had agreed to serve as honorary chairmen.
Belmont Park's Spring stake schedule, released yesterday by the Westchester Racing Association, reveals increases in the value of two fixtures, one of which will be run over a longer distance.

Retail made here last week did not quite measure up to the optimistic forecasts made before the week ended. Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a gain of 10 per cent over the calendar week a year ago, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

A costume supper party entitled "All Out America" will be given on April 24 at Le Coq Rouge for the benefit of the Navy Relief Society. Guests have been requested to attend in costumes representative of one of the forty-eight States or possessions, and awards of defense bonds will be given for best representation.

The bank loans of the Lehigh Valley Railroad were reduced from $56,024,900 to $3,147,500 in 1941, R.W. Brown, president, said yesterday in his annual report. The reduction was made in accordance with agreements with the company's bondholders.

SYRACUSE, April 6 (AP) -- The Work Projects Administration in New York State was placed on a war footing today by an announcement by Clarence W. Post of Albany, assistant State administrator of WPA, during an emergency visit to this city.

ALBANY, April 6 -- Governor Lehman vetoed today, with a memorandum, the Graves bill (S. Intro. 611), which would have permitted persons licensing their cars between April 1 and July 1 to obtain a three-quarter year license.
