The Governor said that the measure would cost the State several millions in revenue, and that in view of the tax cuts made this year the State could not afford further loss at this time.

OTTAWA, April 6 -- The formation of the Canadian forces overseas into the First Canadian Army under General Andrew G.L. McNaughton has been put into motion by the establishment of headquarters in England, it was announced here today.

Four months ago today Japan struck the blow at Pearl Harbor that brought this country into the war. Since then Japan has been moving forward with uninterrupted success over the longest front in the history of modern warfare. With our allies, we have suffered enormous losses in the East. What can we match against those losses, on the credit side of the ledger?

PHILADELPHIA, April 6 -- The Shenango Valley Water Company of Sharon, Pa., filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission today for 7,000 shares of 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock of $100 par value.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 6 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force Middle East Command issued this communique today:

WITH GENERAL WAINWRIGHT'S FORCES in the Philippines, April 5 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- They came with revolvers or automatic pistols slung on their belts. Many of them carried rifles. There wasn't a necktie or a pressed uniform in the lot. But it was a most impressive Easter service.

The Murray and Leonie Guggenheim Dental Clinic, 422-428 East Seventy-second Street, gave free dental care to nearly 16,000 children in New York City last year, according to its annual report for 1941, made public yesterday. The number was the largest in the clinic's twelve-year history.

PHILADELPHIA, April 6 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today the proposed sale of the Hoosier Public Utility Company by the Consolidated Electric and Gas Company the Public Service Company of Indiana for $1,100,000.

The Joint Committee of Teachers Organizations issued yesterday a statement attacking Mayor La Guardia's proposed city budget, which calls for a school appropriation of $3,863,000 less than that of the current fiscal year and would result in the dropping of 399 high school teachers and sixty-five swimming instructors.

The war may actually bring about increased advertising of certain products, which have been established for years but which have never been promoted heavily, agency men pointed out yesterday. Large organizations, in their anxiety to obtain products to replace those banned by material shortages, are beginning to look for smaller companies which they can purchase and whose products they will promote more heavily than the owners did.
LONDON, April 6 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- An immediate 25 per cent curtailment in normal deliveries of fuel oil used for space or central heating and hot water supplies on the Atlantic seaboard and in Oregon and Washington was recommended today by Harold L. Ickes, Petroleum Coordinator.

Mixing good news with bad, the Navy Department revealed yesterday how two American merchant vessels were able to outdistance lurking submarines and make Texas ports safely last month, while a Panamanian ship, surviving a murderous shelling that killed eight of the crew, got into Mobile with forty-two survivors.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- Rear Admiral L. O. Colbert, director of the Coast and Geodetic Survey, announced today that both of his agency's ships in the Philippine Islands were either damaged or missing.

District Attorney William O'Dwyer of Brooklyn has applied to the War Department for a commission in the Army, it was disclosed yesterday. If he passes the physical examination tomorrow there is a possibility that he may be enlisted as a major in Military Intelligence. Mr. O'Dwyer is 52 years old.

A preview of the William H. Coverdale collection of Canadiana was held yesterday afternoon at the Grand Central (Terminal) Galleries, and this large show will open to the public today. It is being held under the auspices of the Maple Leaf Fund, Inc., of which Mr. Coverdale is president.

BOWIE, Md., April 6 -- John L. Sullivan's Transfigure, a horse that couldn't get out of his own way in the Rowe Memorial Handicap last Thursday, won by two and a half lengths today. Beaten by fourteen lengths in the opening day stake. Transfigure captured the $2,000 added General MacArthur Handicap.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended April 1: Decreases of $243,000,000 in holdings of Treasury bills and $377,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and an increase of $102,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic bank.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 6 -- Westchester County faces an expenditure of $2,616,666 in the next twenty years for maintenance and operation of its contemplated airport in the estate area of Purchase, Captain Le Roy L. Odell, an airport consultant, testified today before Supreme Court Justice Lee Parsons Davis.

WHERE is there a really good book on the American labor movement? Where is the book that captures the feelings of men as they superintend the flow of steel through the Mesta machines to the automobile body shops of Detroit? Where is the book that watches a shop steward skillfully settling a grievance on the Chrysler-Kercheval plant floor long before it has a chance to grow into something warranting a strike vote?

Yesterday's almost summerlike weather drew huge crowds to Broadway, but they were a disappointment to the street's showmen. Business was far from up to expectations at the box-offices. Only one offering, "Junior Miss" at the Lyceum, did anywhere near capacity business, with only eleven seats unsold for an afternoon's $1,869 gross, just $20 from capacity.

PITTSBURGH, April 6 -- Delegations of defense workers from Western Pennsylvania, Ohio and West Virginia will assemble here tomorrow night at a rally sponsored by the A.F. of L. and the C.I.O. to pledge labor's efforts anew in America's war production program.

Cornelius Warmerdam, only 15-foot pole vaulter the world has known, was the outstanding performer in the indoor track and field season of 1942. That is the consensus of the Metropolitan Track Writers Association, an opinion that will be shared by many, if not all, followers of the sport.
NEW DELHI, April 6 (U.P) -- The Premier of the Madras Government appealed to the people to keep calm, saying that that would

The Downtown Republican Club, covering the East River waterfront district where former Governor Alfred E. Smith was born and first elected to public office, formally went on record last night as favoring the nomination of Thomas E. Dewey for Governor at the next Republican State convention.

When the Price Control Law was being debated last year Administration spokesmen argued strongly for selective control rather than an over-all ceiling on all prices. But it was clear then that no price regulation could be effective if wages and farm prices were left uncontrolled.

Close on the heels of Easter has come the season's first boatload of local shad. Brought in from his pounds off Port Monmouth, N.J., it was landed at Fulton Fish Market yesterday morning by Captain B. Dennis who counted his catch at 125 boxes, each weighing 250 to 300 pounds.

Ernst Oskar Hopf, whose "International Commercial Agency" adjoining the Nazi consulate at 17 Battery Place was bombed on June 20, 1940, has been indicted by a Federal grand jury here for draft evasion, it was revealed yesterday. The indictment, with others naming six other persons on similar charges, was opened in Federal court yesterday at the request of Howard F. Corcoran, chief aide to United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa.

The export price plan just issued jointly by the OPA and the BEW takes cognizance of "practically all" the problems which have been giving them difficulty, exporters declared yesterday, asserting that it showed a "common-sense" approach to the conditions under which foreign trade is now conducted.

Fifty women in government work met yesterday at the home of Mrs. Elinore Herrick, regional director of the NLRB, at 8 West Thirteenth Street, to plan ways of aiding the current Greater New York Fund Drive. Miss Bess Blood-worth, chairman of the fund's women's council, and former Justice Dorothy Kenyon were co-hostesses.

Readers write to the papers complaining of radio pronunciation. Presumably the protests go in still greater numbers to the radio stations direct, which is much the better way. This is one more advantage which the newspaper writer has over the radio commentator.

SEATTLE, April 6 (AP) -- A leader of the Japanese-American Citizens League released today a letter from Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt, wife of the President, in which she expressed confidence that the government would "provide protection against vigilantes and misguided private citizens."

Fifty women in government work met yesterday at the home of Mrs. Elinore Herrick, regional director of the NLRB, at 8 West Thirteenth Street, to plan ways of aiding the current Greater New York Fund Drive. Miss Bess Blood-worth, chairman of the fund's women's council, and former Justice Dorothy Kenyon were co-hostesses.

Readers write to the papers complaining of radio pronunciation. Presumably the protests go in still greater numbers to the radio stations direct, which is much the better way. This is one more advantage which the newspaper writer has over the radio commentator.

TUCSON, Ariz., April 6 (AP) -- Motors of a big army bomber failed today, one of them burst into flames, and the ship crashed on the desert twenty-two miles southeast of here, trapping and killing five officers and men in the blazing cabin.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The $19,062,373,260 supplemental Army-Navy supply bill, already selected as the vehicle for applying statutory limitations on war contract profits, faced further possible expansion today as moves were made in the Senate to force voting decision on the questions of simultaneous wage and price control and the right of a worker to a defense job without paying an initiation fee to a labor union.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Two new service medals were authorized in orders issued today by the War Department. They are the American Defense Service Medal and the Good Conduct Medal.

Directors of the National Tea Company declared yesterday a dividend of 68 3/4 cents a share on the 5 1/2 per cent $10 par preferred stock to clear up arrears, and the regular quarterly dividend of 13 3/4 cents a share on the issue, both payable on May 1.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The $19,062,373,260 supplemental Army-Navy supply bill, already selected as the vehicle for applying statutory limitations on war contract profits, faced further possible expansion today as moves were made in the Senate to force voting decision on the questions of simultaneous wage and price control and the right of a worker to a defense job without paying an initiation fee to a labor union.

Summer yachting on Long Island Sound will start on May 9 with a two-day regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club for the International Class sloops. That was decided last night at a dinner meeting of the owners in the New York Yacht Club. It will be a week later than first proposed, the later date being decided upon because of the dinghies and other small craft carrying on two weeks beyond their original schedule.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (U.P.) -- The Supreme Court declined today to rule whether the Hatch "clean politics" act applies to primary elections. It remanded a test case for further proceeding in lower courts.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 6 (AP) -- Carrying bedding, eating utensils and some extra clothing, 660 Japanese -- both nationals and American-born-entrained tonight for Southern California in the first compulsory evacuation of Japanese from San Francisco.

The sixth annual scholarship fund dance of the Art Students League of New York will be presented as a United Nations Ball on Friday night at the Hotel Roosevelt. It will be a costume party and, according to a committee announcement, every one named MacArthur will be admitted free, on proper identification.

LONDON, April 6 -- In their drive toward the Burma oilfields Japanese forward troops are near Nyaungbinzeik, which is fifteen miles north of Prome, according to an announcement by the War Office in London today. Defending troops that had been blocking the roads leading to the oilfields have withdrawn to new positions, it was said.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Since posterity would benefit from the war being fought to "preserve the better way of life" for future generations, it should bear a larger proportion of the cost, Representative Treadway of Massachusetts, ranking minority member of the Ways and Means Committee, told the House today.

LOS ANGELES, April 6 -- A field survey of the general securities business in financial centers outside of New York is being made by representatives of the Securities and Exchange Commission, two of whom are in Los Angeles completing interviews.

The WPB cracked down on inventories on two fronts yesterday and made it plain that stocks needed for war production would not be permitted to be held off the market. The board's Inventory and Requisitioning Branch made seizures of copper and aluminum after holders, according to charges, had refused to sell it to the Metals Reserve Corporation.

John Steinbeck's dramatization of his own short novel about life in a Nazi-occupied country, "The Moon Is Down," which became a best seller almost as soon as it was published on March 6, will have its deferred Broadway opening tonight at the Martin Beck Theatre.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- A sitdown strike by seamen aboard a ship is mutiny even if their vessel is moored at a dock in port, the Supreme Court held in a 5-to-4 opinion today. The decision overthrew an order by the National Labor Relations Board.

The Port of New York Authority is in good position to withstand the effect of wartime restrictions on automobile traffic in the opinion of the investment banking firm of R.W. Pressprich Co. expressed yesterday in a booklet reviewing the financial position of the Authority.

HAVANA, April 6 -- Cuba's 1942 sugar crop will amount to 3,950,000 long tons, according to a decree signed today by President Fulgencio Batista. This is an increase of 350,000 tons over the original figure set on Feb. 16 and represents additional sugar which producers now believe can be manufactured.

Mayor La Guardia, on the steps of City Hall yesterday, made an urgent appeal for the voluntary enrollment of 10,000 nurses' aides, as 150 women volunteers formed a colorful V in front of the building.

LONDON, April 6 -- A press conference in New Delhi planned for tomorrow, at which Sir Stafford Cripps, British Cabinet Minister, was expected to announce the fate of the British-Indian negotiations, was canceled today and it may be held on Wednesday.

In number of men engaged and length of front the Battle of Russia is the greatest the world has ever known. Nothing else compares with it, not even the vast and often formless Russian campaigns of the last war. A definite decision in Russia might decide the war as a whole.

The annual report of the California-Oregon Power Company for 1941, issued yesterday by A.S. Cummins, president, shows a net income for the year of $899,934, a decrease of $49,036 from 1940. Gross revenues for the year totaled $5,557,666, a gain of $297,451, or 5.6 per cent above the preceding year.

CHICAGO, April 6 -- A serious situation is developing in the hardwood lumber industry, John W. McClure, secretary-treasurer of the National Hardwood Lumber Association, said today in comment on a 29.4 per cent March increase in inspection totals by comparison with 1941.
CHICAGO, April 6 -- Strikers who left their jobs at the National Carloading Corporation and the Universal Carloading Company today gave an hour's notice before they left.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The Navy announced tonight that Rear Admiral J.W. Wilcox Jr. of Atlanta, Ga., was lost overboard in "heavy weather during normal cruising." No details were given.

Stockholders of the Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation approved yesterday a proposed amendment to the certificate of incorporation to make the sinking fund provisions of the preferred stock more "practicable" in the light of present and probable future rates of income and excess profits taxes.

Mayor La Guardia, on the steps of City Hall yesterday, made an urgent appeal for the voluntary enrollment of 10,000 nurses' aides, as 150 women volunteers formed a colorful V in front of the building.

LONDON, April 6 -- A press conference in New Delhi planned for tomorrow, at which Sir Stafford Cripps, British Cabinet Minister, was expected to announce the fate of the British-Indian negotiations, was canceled today and it may be held on Wednesday.

In number of men engaged and length of front the Battle of Russia is the greatest the world has ever known. Nothing else compares with it, not even the vast and often formless Russian campaigns of the last war. A definite decision in Russia might decide the war as a whole.

The annual report of the California-Oregon Power Company for 1941, issued yesterday by A.S. Cummins, president, shows a net income for the year of $899,934, a decrease of $49,036 from 1940. Gross revenues for the year totaled $5,557,666, a gain of $297,451, or 5.6 per cent above the preceding year.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 6 -- "When hostilities cease America alone will be in a position to feed famished Europe." This phrase began to crop up in discussions and comments some time ago; today it is heard or read almost daily. Its origins and implications are interesting, possibly symptomatic.

PHILADELPHIA, April 6 -- George E. Wanderman of New York, who holds fifty of the 3,393, 821 shares of common stock of the Curtis Publishing Company, brought suit in the Federal District Court today for an injunction which would restrain The Saturday Evening Post from continuing its practice of what he described as "an anti-government, isolationist policy."

DETROIT, April 6 -- The first important test of the readiness of rank-and-file workers to make sacrifices in the interest of the war production program will come tomorrow when representatives of 534,000 members of the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., open a two-day special conference to vote on a recommendation of their leaders for abandonment of double pay for Sunday and holiday work within the basic forty-hour week.

The bill now before Congress to restrict profits of corporations engaged in defense work deserves the closest consideration. We must remember that every Congressman is a politician and few are statesmen. The great public outcry has been against exorbitant wages and farm prices, but unionized labor and organized farmers were too strong politically to be safely attacked, so another sacrifice had to be produced to appease the public wrath.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Charged with diverting 500,000 pounds of secondary aluminum from the requirements of the war program, the Hoover Company of North Canton, Ohio, third largest manufacturer of vacuum cleaners in the country, was prohibited tonight from fabricating or dealing in aluminum for three months.

New York City enjoyed excellent health during the first three months of this year, according to the quarterly report of vital statistics made public yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, city Health Commissioner.

DETROIT, April 7 -- Assured by President Roosevelt that the government would renegotiate war contracts to make certain that the abandonment of double pay for Sunday and holiday work did not mean increased corporation profits, delegates representing the 534,000 members of the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., voted today to give up premium pay within the basic forty-hour work week.

ALBANY, April 7 -- The Legislature will reconvene tomorrow night, following the Easter recess, with April 23 now definitely expected as the adjournment date for the session. Legislative days will be held in the Assembly tomorrow night, Thursday and Friday, while the Senate will try to hold working sessions, according to Joe R. Hanley, majority leader.

Under the proposal made by Senator Pepper all prices, rents, interest, wages and other compensation would be frozen for the duration of the war as of a day to be fixed by Presidential proclamation. The advantage of such a plan is that it would break the wages-farm price cycle which has been so powerful a factor in lifting the general price level.
Merger of several units of the New York City Police Department to form what will, in effect, be a municipal arm of the FBI has been proceeding quietly, it was learned here unofficially yesterday.

The National Music League presented the third of its 5:30 concerts for the benefit of the Citizens Committee for the Army and Navy at The New York Times Hall yesterday afternoon. The artists, who were introduced by Dorothy Gordon, were Jean Bryan, contralto; Walter Robert, piano; Robert Mann, violin, and Martin Noliboff, horn.
BERLIN, April 7 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique said today:

LONDON, April 7 (U.P.) -- A new wave of sabotage, aimed at disrupting Germany's Spring offensive program, is sweeping occupied Europe, Germany and Italy, and many vital factories producing war tools for the Nazis have already gone up in flames, according to intelligence reports reaching United Nations governments here today.
ROME, April 7 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command communique said today:

The Society of Independent Artists, Inc. (no jury, no prizes), opened its twenty-sixth annual exhibition with a preview for the artists and their guests last evening in the galleries of the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 7 (U.P.) -- Army Minister Francis M. Forde asked today for a full report on published statements by soldiers who escaped from New Britain that Japanese invaders shackled Australian troops, stood them in squads and shot or bayoneted them to death.

What may well prove to be the most detailed and comprehensive price schedule yet issued by the Office of Price Administration will be forthcoming in the next few weeks, according to market reports yesterday, when the entire range of finished cotton and rayon fabrics and their mixtures will be placed under ceilings.

New York City's casualties under multiple bombings were estimated at 5,000 to 50,000 persons in a statement by Edward D. Bernecker, Hospital Commissioner, made public yesterday by the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office at City Hall.

William Schumann, who, earlier this season, with his Third Symphony, had given notice of a new and vigorous talent come to town, bowed from the stage of Carnegie Hall last night after Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra had provided an applauding audience with the New York premiere of his Fourth Symphony.

The impression that the Hindu Mahasabha, the pan-Hindu organization, was uncompromising in rejecting Sir Stafford Cripps's scheme is misinformed. The Hindu Mahasabha accepted it partially and welcomed the promised grant of equal co-partnership with Britain, but the scheme made it all conditional on granting freedom to provinces to secede and break up India into a number of independent States with no central Indian Government.

In a new effort to contest the jurisdiction of New York State courts over the suit filed on behalf of the National Bank of Belgium to recover $228,000,000 in gold, the Bank of France applied yesterday to the Supreme Court to vacate the warrant of attachment obtained a year ago on its funds here and to set aside service of the suit, which was made by publication and mailing and not by personal service.
A campaign for $5,000 to carry the National Security Women's Corps through a year of activity was started yesterday at the Town Hall Club.

IT'S a risky thing to set this down in cold print, but these are dangerous days in all directions and everybody has to be brave. The topic was touched upon in this corner a couple of years ago and there was much talk in the sovereign State of Connecticut of launching a flock of civil, criminal and tweed suits against this perfectly innocent bystander.

The recovery movement on the Stock Exchange met profit-taking yesterday, which, while not heavy, was sufficient to discourage any proportionate demand. As a result, the list wavered fractionally except for strength in the air transportation issues and other specialties.

BERLIN, April 7 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Berlin radio told today of Russian breaks into Nazi lines southeast of Lake Ilmen, but the German High Command reported that offensive operations "brought further successes" and that local Soviet attacks had been repulsed.

NORFOLK, Va., April 7 -- Responding to an overpowering urge to show the folks who patronize one of their farm clubs here just how a world champion club performs when it clicks on all cylinders, the Yankees entertained another banner crowd of 7,500 today by giving the Dodgers a thrashing.
Miss Lorna Barber, assistant professor in extension nutrition at Cornell University, has left the calm of campus life to tackle the job of improving the eating habits of some 30,000,000 Americans.
LONDON, April 7 -- The cut-throat competition between Germany and Italy for Europeon markets is being watched by the British today with something akin to astonishment.

The earnings and sales of the American Can Company were satisfactory during the first two months of 1942, Maurice J. Sullivan, president, said at the annual meeting of stockkholders in Jersey City yesterday.

The market for new issues of railway equipment trust certificates ran against the War Production Board's order yesterday freezing the delivery of new locomotives and cars which resulted in the cancellation or deferment of the sales of two new issues aggregating $15,550,000.

The contract for the alteration of the four-story South Brooklyn Savings and Loan Association building at the corner of Willoughby and Jay Streets, Brooklyn, has been awarded to the Morison Allardyce Construction Corporation, according to Andrew S. Roscoe, president of the association.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 7 -- Australian and American bombers and fighters, attacking north of Australia for the third successive day, took the Japanese by surprise at the Lae airdrome, in Northeast New Guinea, early this morning.

A packet of pastry -- a crinkling cellophane bag holding half a dozen irresistible coffee cakes -- is sent over to certain Manhattan shops by a busy baker in Brooklyn. The flaky little pastries, prepared in faithful accordance with Norwegian tradition, are as fresh and fragrant and delicately brown as if they had just emerged from the oven.
CHUNGKING, China, April 7 (U.P.) -- Units of the regular United Continued on Page Three

The submarine menace to shipping between the United States and South America may be expected "to considerably abate and possibly to disappear during the next few months," and the 1,000,000 tons of Axis shipping which have been acquired by Brazil and Argentina "ought to be more than suffficient to take care of any shortage of boats," Daniel A. Del Rio, assistant vice president, Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, declared yesterday.

A group headed by E.H. Rollins Sons, Inc., and including Coffin Burr, Inc., and R.D. White Co., received yesterday the award of an issue of $478,800 of various purpose bonds of the city of Troy, N.Y., on a bid of 100.358 for 2.10s, representing a net interest cost to the city of 2.05 per cent.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Appointment of Milo Perkins, executive director of the Board of Economic Warfare, to coordinate all phases of wartime food administration was reported as probable tonight.

Unless statistical interest in the Federal Reserve Board's weekly figures on bank debits in 274 cities proves to be much greater than is now believed to be the case, the board's plan for reporting bank debits monthly instead of weekly will go into effect next month.

With national advertisers making every effort to eliminate waste in selling and advertising, "self liquidation" premiums appear to be replacing those in which the cost is borne entirely by the advertiser, agency men remarked yesterday.

Manhattan's 1942 football team will face eight college opponents and possibly a service eleven, according to the schedule announced yesterday by Herbert M. Kopf, director of athletics and head coach of football. Two of the four home contests will be played at night at the Polo Grounds.

MONTREAL, April 7 (Canadian Press) -- An experiment that had its birth in necessity -- the transformation of Tommy (Cowboy) Anderson from a forward into a defenseman -- paid a major dividend today when the star guard of the Brooklyn Americans was named winner of the Dr. David A. Hart Trophy awarded annually to the player voted the most valuable to his National Hockey League club.

PHILADELPHIA, April 7 (AP) -- Federal Judge A. Welsh dismissed today a stockholder's suit that sought to have officers and directors of the Pennroad Corporation held liable for losses the stockholder computed at more than $9,000,000 from the purchase by Pennroad of Boston Maine Railroad stock.

Vito Gurino, trigger man for the Brooklyn murder ring, who recently pleaded guilty to three charges of second-degree murder based on underworld killings, received sentences yesterday totaling a minimum term of eighty years' imprisonment, any one of which might be extended to life imprisonment.

Infinite variety of appearance may be easily achieved by ingenious rearrangement of hairdresses -- as is demonstrated by a Fifth Avenue coiffeur who virtually creates personalities with his comb. With a great deal of skillful smoothing and brushing of the same head of hair he has been able to make a single basic tailleur look like a collegiate sport suit, then -- with a change of accessories -- a sophisticate's cocktail costume.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Resumption of shipment of small amounts of food, clothing, lubricants and other essential supplies by the United States to French North Africa was announced today.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The War Department communique based on reports received here up to 9:30 A.M. said:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 7 -- Supreme Court Justice Lee Parsons Davis reserved decision today on the application of members of the Westchester Citizens Committee for an injunction against the construction of a county airport on the Rye Lake site in Purchase.

PITTSBURGH, April 7 -- Starting a joint drive for maximum war production, the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations, representing 10,000,000 organized workers, united here tonight in an impressive demonstration of labor solidarity at a meeting of more than 5,000 members of both organizations and before a nation-wide radio audience.

LONDON, April 7 -- While Indian leaders were taking a long time to say a final and definite no to the British formula for evolutionary independence, such optimism as existed here tonight about the final outcome of Sir Stafford Cripps's mission was of a pale and anemic sort.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 7 -- Robert Ryan, stage actor who was seen last season on Broadway in "Clash By Night" with Tallulah Bankhead, reported to RKO today for the male lead in Pare Lorentz's first picture, "Name, Age and Occupation."

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Production of almost all consumer durable goods will halt within three months, Donald M. Nelson, chief of the War Production Board, warned today. The rapid changeover of industry to full war production, he added, will require the concentration of labor, plants and facilities used on civilian goods in the production of munitions.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- President Roosevelt conferred with Attorney General Biddle and J. Edgar Hoover, F.B.I. Director, on matters which he described as highly confidential, met with the Pacific War Council, held his press conference, conferred with Sumner Welles, and lunched with Governor Lehman.

Warning that the wartime stagger plan for office hours must have the active cooperation of employers and employes throughout Manhattan and Brooklyn "if mandatory regulations are to be avoided," George A. Sloan, head of the city Department of Commerce, said the plan would become effective on Monday, April 20.

Philip S. Newson, in 121 Madison Ave; Donald P. Halsey, in 27 E 30th St; Isabel Gray, in 121 E 31st St; William A. Spelissy, in 211 E 35th St; Clara H. Smith, Mabel Burwell, in 222 E 35th St; Gladys J. Leahy, in 303 E 37th St; Eleanor Knowles, Esther Hartline, in 140 E 46th St; Gilliam McVay, brokers.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- In his testimony today before the Ways and Means Committee, W.P. Hobby, publisher of The Houston Post, said that in the case of his own business income taxes took 15 per cent of net earnings in 1937, 19 per cent in 1938 and 1939, 25 per cent in 1940 and 45 per cent in 1941.

WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, April 7 -- The Netherlands Government is taking all possible military measures in the Netherlands West Indies, in view of the "serious possibility" that these islands might become involved directly in new hostilities, Governor G.J.J. Wouters announced today to the Legislative Council.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, chose today, the third of the preseason heat spell, to urge every home owner who burns coal to purchase next Winter's fuel supply immediately.

NEWARK, N.J., April 7 -- A man who allegedly impersonated an officer of the United States Naval Intelligence Reserve while, as a bogus physician, he was treating scores of patients in Hudson County, N.J., was in the custody of the FBI here today.

VICHY, France, April 7 -- French-American relations, considered in recent days to be improving, were complicated today by an official protest to the State Department and by an outbreak of violent attacks in the Paris press against American influence on the recent negotiations by Pierre Laval for more active collaboration with Germany.

Governors of the New York Curb Exchange accepted yesterday the resignation of George P. Rea, president, effective on June 30. At a special meeting the board adopted a resolution expressing regret over Mr. Rea's retirement.

ALBANY, April 7 -- Governor Lehman today vetoed the Dorn bill, which sought to raise the salaries of lerks to the justices of the Municipal Court in New York City from $1,200 to "not less than" $2,400 annually.
ALBANY, April 7 -- Governor Lehman announced here today that the Federal Government had under consideration plans to facilitate the employment of loyal aliens in war industry jobs.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The types of condensed soups which can still be packed in tin cans after June 30 were listed today by the Division of Industry Operations of the War Production Board in an amendment to an earlier metal conservation order.
CINCINNATI, April 7 (AP) -- Sale of about 150,000 shares of stock in the Park Utah Consolidated Mines Company to a Salt Lake City bank as agent was disclosed today.

Henry T. Kays, vice chancellor, made permanent yesterday in Jersey City an order restraining the American Car and Foundry Company from distributing $599,400 in dividends, or $1 a share, to holders of its common stock, and directed distribution of $773,490 to holders of 7 per cent non-cumulative preferred stock.
The long and bitter trial of the defenders of Bataan drew on toward its eleventh hour yesterday as the enemy continued the most protracted assault since the Philippines were first invaded.

LONDON, April 7 -- The British destroyer Havock, under command of Lieut. Comdr. G.R.G. Watkins, which took part in the attack on six German destroyers in the Narvik Fjord two years ago and also in the Battle of Matapan, has been wrecked off the Tunisian coast and has become a total loss, the Admiralty announced today.

TORONTO, April 7 -- The Detroit Red Wings took a first mortgage on the Stanley Cup at Maple Leaf Gardens tonight when they upset Toronto, 4 -- 2, to take a 2-0 lead in hockey's world series. The teams will play the third and fourth games of the four-out-of-seven series at the Detroit Olympia on Thursday and Sunday.

Out of India yesterday there came one of the saddest messages of the whole war: the forecast that the All-India Congress Party's working committee would reject the Cripps plan. With this news came a ray of hope -- that the Hindu majority was willing to put the case before President Roosevelt.

CHICAGO, April 7 -- In a message read today before the annual conference of the National Catholic Educational Association, President Roosevelt reminded the more than 4,000 priests, nuns and other Catholic teachers that nowhere in the countries "held in slavery by the enemies we are fighting" could such a "free assembly be held."

The Danish people were so completely betrayed and surprised by the invading Germans that they could offer no organized resistance. For their helpless submission Hitler promised them a favored place in his New Order. By painful experience they have tested his favor. Tricked, robbed, exploited, and denied even the elementary right of protest, they are being bled white so that Germany may fight on a fuller stomach.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Fighting on the Bataan Peninsula tonight reached a phase that caused experienced officers here to feel that nothing short of a miracle could enable the battered defenders to withstand much longer the onslaught by the Japanese, which began last Tuesday.

CHUNGKING, China, April 7 (U.P.) -- A military spokesman said today that thirteen Japanese trans-sports, protected by six warships and ten launches, had been seen anchored in Amoy Harbor, on the South China coast above Hong Kong, on March 28.
War service with the Navy is the preference of the largest group in the graduating class of City College, according to the results of a poll by The Microcosm, senior yearbook, made public yesterday.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 7 -For one hundred and fifty days the Red Fleet's main Black Sea base withstood assaults by Nazi Colonel General von Mannstein's Eleventh Army. Sevastopol's de-defenders, including the black-uniformed dare devil Marines, are now said to be ousting the enemy from positions where he spent the Winter.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 7 (AP) -- The first United States plane in its war paint to reach Soviet Russia landed the new United States Ambassador, Admiral William H. Standley, at the airport here today.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., April 7 (AP) -- Long shots dominated the early portion of Tropical Park's program today, but form players managed to whoop a few winners across later in the day.
The text of Lord Halifax's address at Town Hall last night follows:
MOSCOW, April 7 (From Russian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Bureau of Information communique today follows:

With post time for Jamaica's opening tomorrow advanced to 2 o'clock, the earliest hour in the history of the track, there developed yesterday the possibility that Belmont Park might have a 1:30 post time. The Long Island Railroad, faced with heavier wartime travel, has proposed the earlier hour for Belmont, and the management hopes for a 1:45 compromise.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Brig. Gen. Robert Olds, who organized the Army Air Force Ferry Command, has relinquished command and has been succeeded by Colonel Harold L. George.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Navy broke down a historic barrier today by authorizing the enlistment of Negroes for general service in the ranks and as noncommissioned officers.

LONDON, April 7 -- Features were few on the Stock Exchange today and the market is expected to move within narrow limits until after the announcement on the budget. In most sections, however, prices remained firm. There were practically no changes in the gilt-edge and foreign bonds sections.

FORT BELVOIR, Va., April 7 (AP) -- After two months in the Army, Private Warren Pershing, son of General John J. Pershing, the World War A.E.F. commander, was described today by his executive officer as "one of the best soldiers we have in our battalion."
LONDON, April 7 -- Bad weather reduced the scale of the British attacks on Germany during last night and made the results difficult to observe, the Air Ministry announced tonight.

CHICAGO, April 7 -- Although merchants, if anything, discouraged the buying rush, March sales of members of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers ran 80 per cent ahead of 1941, the monthly report of the association showed today.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Plans for greater use of the inland waterway along the Atlantic coast, where shipping would be less exposed to enemy submarine attacks, were disclosed by President Roosevelt at his press conference today.

Thomas H. Beck, president of the Crowell-Collier Publishing Company, last night told 150 members and guests of Air Service Post 501, American Legion, that "this country, as far as our industry is concerned, is going to town." He spoke in the Lotos Club after receiving the Frank M. Hawks Memorial Medal for "outstanding contributions to aviation."

The blockfront improved with a one-story and basement taxpayer on the north side of Roosevelt Avenue, between Eighty-fifth and Eighty-sixth Streets, Jackson Heights, L.I., was sold by the Community Service Society to a client of Hosinger Bode, Inc., brokers.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 7 -- Scoring all its runs in the first five innings. Princeton's varsity baseball team trounced the Manhattan College nine, 13 -- 1, on University Field today.

Leases in the midtown section of the city were reported yesterday with a number of restaurant enterprises. In one group of four arranged by a single broker, three eating places will specialize in foods of as many nationalities.

Martha Hodge, who is the daughter of the late William T. Hodge, one of the best-known American actors and an actress in her own right, has turned producer. On April 28, she announced yesterday, she will place in rehearsal her first production, "The Cat Screams," a mystery melodrama fashioned by Basil Beyea and John Patrick from Todd Downing's book of the same title.

By refusing to follow a courageous and clear-headed policy at the beginning, the Administration has finally got itself into a state of mental confusion concerning the effect of overtime payments. Nothing illustrates this better than the letter which the President has written to R.J. Thomas, the international president of the United Automobile Workers.

James Marshall, president of the Board of Education, and Ellsworth B. Buck, vice president and chairman of the board's finance and budget committee, in statements yesterday predicted the impairment of quality of service and a need for relief later as a result of the cut in school funds proposed in Mayor La Guardia's budget.

MEXICO CITY, April 7 -- Representatives of labor and mine operators here expect an agreement will soon be reached suspending Mexico's drastic labor laws as regards new mines opened to expand production of strategic minerals desired by the United States.

With trade buying confined mostly to a scale down, commission-house and Southern selling brought about an easier tone in the cotton market yesterday and futures suffered their sharpest setback in more than a week. Active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange finished at their lows for the session, with net losses of 9 to l7 points.
Most of the realty sales reported in Manhattan yesterday involved small store and apartment buildings. The buyers generally were investors.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 7 -- The Governors and other high officials of nine Western States, who are reported to be worried over consequences of the Japanese evacuation and resettlement program, were assured today by Federal and Army spokesmen that the re-locations would follow a pattern designed to limit economic disruption in the inland States and to prevent the development of any post-war problems.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, April 7 -- Despite Japan's southward march, major gains in New Zealand security during the past year were reported by Prime Minister Fraser to the annual conference of the Labor Party here. New Zealand now had substantially advanced in naval protection with the taking over of the Anzac area by the United States, Mr. Fraser said.

The trout season opens in New Jersey a week from today and the State's Fish and Game Commission has announced that the job of restocking streams is well advanced. In fact, it is ahead of schedule, with the distribution of some 150,431 brook, rainbow and brown trout during the past month.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 7 (AP) -- Golf's great, arriving for the Masters' golf tournament, got a double helping of cheerful news today.

Supreme Court Justice Benedict D. Dineen yesterday granted an application by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. to strike out substantial parts of the answer to his injunction proceedings against the News Dealers Federal Labor Union, Local 22,371, A.F. of L.

In urging capital-goods manufacturers to maintain their advertising and selling activities during the war, John H. Van Deventer, president and editor of Iron Age, declared yesterday that "today we need production to save America and tomorrow we will need super selling to save production and America." He spoke at the weekly luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- United States production authorities have been notified by the Canadian Government that this country, which is pleading for more aluminum from Canada, must choose between that and a smaller supply of newsprint. The trouble is that there is not enough hydroelectric power for both.

Charlie Chaplin's re-edited sound version of his 1925 comedy classic, "The Gold Rush," will open an engagement at the Globe on April 18. Though the characters of the film are mute, Mr. Chaplin has provided a running commentary on the action which he speaks himself.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today fixed new mail rates for American Airlines, Inc., and, as a result, saved the government some $4,000,000 in payments received by the company during the rate proceeding which was decided today.
" Yes, I believe in a free press, but a free press can only exist if it is a truthful press. I do not think the free press gives any one the right to distort facts," -- Mayor La Guardia.

Visiting buyers reported in the market last week numbered 662, which compared with 607 in the preceding week and 632 in the similar period a year ago, according to the listings in The NEW Y0RK TIMES. Yesterday's registrations totaled 476, as against 192 for last Tuesday.

TRENTON, April 7 -- Any automobile driver in New Jersey who has been twice convicted of exceeding the forty-mile speed limit in the open country and lesser speeds in the congested districts will be notified of the proposed revocation of his license under orders issued today by Arthur W. Magee, Motor Vehicle Commissioner, and Robert W. Johnson, State Rationing Administrator.

PHILADELPHIA, April 7 -- Predicting that complete mobilization of the country's man power is close at hand, William L. Batt Sr., chief of the materials division of the War Production Board, de clared here today that the United States will take the offensive much sooner than Adolf Hitler thinks.

CHICAGO, April 7 -- Although grain prices held within relatively narrow limits today, corn and oats developed independent strength, with rather persistent commission-house buying in evidence on all the dips. The continued strength in hogs, with the rapid widening of the hog-corn price ratio, induced more or less buying of corn, and while the market failed to get into new high ground the finish was unchanged to 1/8 cent a bushel higher.

MELBOURNE, April 7 (U.P.) -The United Nations Supply Council, at a meeting attended by General Douglas MacArthur and American and Australian supply officials, agreed today on a basis for a comprehensive formula to meet all supply needs.

The Reading Company in 1941 bought $108,000 of Delaware River Terminal purchase money 5 per cent bonds, $46,000 Delaware River Terminal extension purchase money 5 per cent bonds, both issues due in 1942; $1,634,000 Reading Company-Jersey Central collateral 4 per cent bonds of 1951 and $1,242,000 Port Reading Railroad first 5 per cent bonds extended to 1956, Edward W. Scheer, president, said in-his annual report issued yesterday.

The twenty-family apartment house at 1026 East Jersey Street, Elizabeth, N.J., was sold by the New Jersey Realty Company to the 1026 East Jersey Street Corporation. Emanuel Finkelstein represented the purchaser. Title was insured by the New Jersey Realty Title Insurance Company.

Voluntary welfare and medical agencies must be prepared to face any eventuality because of the war, and therefore their needs are larger than ever, speakers declared yesterday in appeals for support of the Greater New York Fund, 93 per cent of the proceeds of which go to these agencies.

Since the United States must carry the war to the Seven Seas the American Merchant Marine has become the lifeline of our Army and Navy. Submarine attacks along our coasts show how eagerly the enemy is trying to cut that lifeline. But new dangers and new hardships have not daunted the seamen of the Merchant Marine.

LONDON, April 7 -- The city of Madras had an air raid alarm today, bringing home the imminence of war to one of the most populous areas in India. The siren sounded early in the morning and the all-clear came about an hour and a half later without anything having happened.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 7 -- Three Australian airmen who escaped from New Guinea told an appalling story today of the slaughter of war prisoners by the Japanese invaders. The three were the only survivors of a party of ten officers and fifty men captured at a plantation northeast of Gasmata while escaping through New Britain after the fall of Rabaul.

NEW DELHI, India, April 7 -- A continuing Japanese push northward up the broad, sea-level valley of the Irrawaddy River in Burma was reported today by the British. They announced the defending forces had fallen back more than forty miles north from Prome after destroying oil and cement installations at Thayetmyo and Allanmyo.

CHUNGKING, China, April 7 -- Two hundred Indian civilians daily are being evacuated from Burma by DC-3 transport planes of the China National Aviation Corporation. The planes are piloted by American fliers of the C.N.A.C. who were evacuated from Hong Kong the night of Dec. 8 and 9 in defiance of the Japanese Army, Navy and Air Force.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 7 -- With all appearances of a real air raid alarm except the roar of enemy bombing planes overhead, Westchester County's 574,000 residents experienced tonight their first surprise blackout and discovered there was a vast difference between having advance knowledge of such tests and being caught off guard while motoring, dining, playing bridge, watching prizefights and attending club meetings.

OKLAHOMA CITY, April 7 -- The Giants and Indians, now approaching the end of a ten-State exhibition tour leading to the opening of the major league baseball season, ran into their first disappointment after the longest jump of the trip today.

Hearn Department Stores, Inc., reports net profit of $219,467, after all charges, provision for taxes, depreciation and a contingency reserve of $75,000, for the fiscal year ended Jan. 31. These figures compare with net of $251,125 for the preceding fiscal year.

Production of steel in March set a new high record of 7,392,911 net tons, or more than 150,000 above the previous high of 7,236,068 produced in October, 1941, and more than 260,000 above the output of 7,125,003 in March, 1941, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The United States has today a stock pile of 700,000 tons of natural rubber, or nearly a year's peacetime supply, and should have a synthetic production of 300,000 tons in 1943 and 700,000 tons in 1994, Secretary Jones testified before the Truman committee today.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- At least part of the Treasury's hoard of silver is going to be used in defense production, it was disclosed today by Donald M. Nelson, chief of the War Production Board.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Navy Department today announced a sharp decline in the recent rate of submarine sinkings off the Atlantic Coast. Last week found only one tanker and one small Navy tug subjected to attack by German undersea boats.

Jimmy Hatcher, Lake City, S.C., lightweight, substituting for Eddie Lander of Chicago, who was stricken with appendicitis, scored an upset by defeating Pete Scalzo, former featherweight champion, in the feature eight-round bout at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last night before 4,000.
MELBOURNE, Australia, April 7 -- Many thousands of Australian women in and out of uniform are taking men's places in war work, supplementing the men's war effort.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- President Roosevelt gave newsmen a clue today which indicated that the Administration may be leaning toward a wage and price control system which would discourage general pay advances for the millions of workers in war industries, but would permit wage adjustments to meet the high cost of living.

It was open house at the Imperial yesterday afternoon. On the stage a number of British children, now in residence at the Edwin Gould Foundation, were presenting an enjoyable revue entitled "Gratefully Yours," which was in the nature of a bread-and-butter letter to the people in this country.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- President Roosevelt reported to the Pacific War Council today on the reinforcements of men and materiel, particularly aircraft, that the United States has moved into various points of the Pacific war theatre since Dec. 7, and foreign members of the council said the President's review was "very, very encouraging."

The growing menace of the Axis submarines near our coast lines, as evidenced in the recent sinkings of American and Allied ships in the Atlantic, Pacific and the Caribbean Sea, demands the speedy completion of the Pan-American Highway. The road, when completed, will stretch from Texas on the north to the Magellans at the southerly tip of South America.

There are a great many men, including myself, who had commissions and fought in the last war who are trying desperately to get into active service in the present holocaust and resume our former business of killing Germans. I am speaking of the men between 48 and 52 who are in good physical condition.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Office of Price Administration today brought prices for Lake Superior iron ore, now beginning to move through the Great Lakes to steel-making centers, under a price ceiling through an order which fixed levels approximately at last season's prices.

MADISON, Wis., April 7 -- The preservation of a sound banking system and the bolstering of public confidence in that system is one of the greatest contributions that banks can make to the nation's war effort, according to Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, in a message sent to the 1942 convention of the Wisconsin Banking Conference today.

Having had books by Emil Lengyel recently on Dakar and on Turkey, and having signed Selwyn James to do a book on Central and South Africa and Madagascar, the Random House editors are sitting back smugly and making jokes to the effect that no matter where Hitler jumps this Spring the publishing firm has him covered.

Nick Dean, the Chicago night club operator who is known also as Nick Circella, received a prison sentence of eight years yesterday after United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa had denounced him as a labor racketeer and charged that his recent plea of guilty was just a "gangster manoeuvre."

IN THE BURMA FRONT LINES, April 4 (delayed) -- Weary, battle-stained men with their guns and tanks and lorries are streaming along the only road winding north from Prome. Japanese planes are wheeling over. But the crump of bombs and the staccato bursts of fighters does not hasten the pace of the weary men.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -The War Production Board extended its bicycle-freezing order today to take in all bicycles having frames of more than seventeen inches.

Even if the Broadway theatre had not been moribund for most of the season, it would be easy to like and respect John Steinbeck's "The Moon Is Down," which was acted at the Martin Beck last evening. For Mr. Steinbeck is telling a calm and reasonable story about the immorality of freedom in terms of a tiny village -- probably Norwegian -- that every one can understand.
CAIRO, April 7 (AP) -- The R.A.F. issued the following communique today:

DETROIT, April 7 -- There follows the text of the "Victory Through Equality of Sacrifice" program submitted to the special conference of the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., by the union's international executive board:

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Senate passed by a voice vote this evening the $19,062,373,260 supplemental Army-Navy supply bill, but refused by a 40-21 record vote after an all-day fight to attach to it specific, statutory limitations on war profits.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 7 -- The rift between the Norwegian Church and Premier Vidkun Quisling's State became an accomplished fact when on Easter Sunday virtually every Norwegian minister announced from the pulpit his resignation as a State official.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Three items in the news today served to remind officials once more that transportation remains the fundamental obstacle to the full operation of the war program of the United States and its allies.

Stockholders of General Motors Corporation will be asked to extend the company's contributory retirement pension plan to its employes in foreign countries at their annual meeting in Wilmington, Del., on April 28, according to the proxy statement distributed yesterday.

BOWIE, Md., April 7 -- Apprentice Charlie Wahler carried his brilliant riding into today's feature race, the Charlotte Hall Purse, and booted G.R. Watkins's Gondalina to a "going away" victory, his third of the day and his eleventh of the meeting.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Marriages between American soldiers and Australian girls have the approval of Mrs. Herbert V. Evatt, wife of the Australian Minister for External Affairs, now in the United States on a war mission. At a press conference this morning Mrs. Evatt said she saw "no reason why they shouldn't get married," adding that she herself was American-born, and, "after all, my husband married me."

Reporting to stockholders on 1941 operations, E.H. Little, president of the Colgate-Palmolive-Peet Company said that sales of $105,405,550 were the highest in the history of the company, surpassing the previous record of $101,935,438 reached in 1939, when all the company's subsidiaries and branches, except those in Germany, Italy and Poland, were included in the consolidation.

I noticed this morning that a letter appeared in your paper written by John H. Hayes concerning an amendment to the Hospital Lien Law which was introduced by me and which recently passed the New York State Assembly. I should like to clarify this situation somewhat.

There can be no other motive than terrorism for the Japanese destruction by fire bombs of two-thirds of Mandalay, the last capital but one of Burma. It was largely a city of monasteries and pagodas. Of the latter there were some 450, not the least interesting of which, perhaps, is the one, Sir Herbert Thirkell White tells us, "built by Shimbone, a famous beauty, who married five kings in succession.

The National Academy of Design opened its 116th annual exhibition of contemporary American painting and sculpture yesterday afternoon with a reception at its galleries, 1083 Fifth Avenue. This is the first annual exhibition of the academy to be held in the academy's new home, to which is moved early this year.

Purchases of ordinary life insurance in Great Britain in 1941 were 19 per cent higher than in 1940, according to a survey by the Institute of Life Insurance, but remained 38 per cent below 1938, the last year of peace.

Herbs and their uses in perfumery, cosmetics and cooking were discussed yesterday at the opening session of the two-day Herb Conference being given as a public service at the New York Botanical Garden Museum Building.

PHILADELPHIA, April 7 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today the adoption of a simplified registration procedure for securities of certain companies which are entitled to use Form A-2.

CHICAGO, April 7 -- The customary seasonal lag in business borrowing and the effects of Federal restrictions on finance company loans and certain other types of credit were reflected today in the quarterly bank-call figures, which showed a decline in Chicago bank loans and discounts.

If the Indian leaders reject the British proposal for the settlement of the Indian problem the British Government will do its duty in its own way for the defense of India against Nazi and Japanese aggression, Viscount Halifax, British Ambassador to the United States, declared last night in an address at Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The rift between the adherents of John L. Lewis and Philip Murray, president of the C.L.O., widened today when members of the United Mine Workers of America demanded that, as chief of the C.I.O., Mr. Murray take action to repudiate "disloyalty" attacks made on Mr. Lewis, national chief of the miners' organization.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Permission for service stations and other retailers of gasoline in New York and sixteen other States in the Eastern Seaboard region where sales have been curtailed by Federal edict, to charge 3 cents a gallon above cost, was granted today by the Office of Price Administration.

Tribute to Dr. Walter Damrosch, who on Jan. 30 celebrated his eightieth birthday, was paid last night by 600 persons at the annual dinner of the Musicians Emergency Fund in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. Dr. Damrosch, who is chairman of the fund's board, was one of the organization's founders and its first president.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 7 (U.P.) -- The Red Army has broken through the German siege lines and reopened railroad traffic to beleaguered Leningrad, Soviet dispatches implied tonight in reporting the arrival of a trainload of goods in the old Czarist capital.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- President Roosevelt re-emphasized his opposition today to a Federal sales tax, even though he conceded that the burden on income tax payers was bad enough now without their trying to borrow trouble by computing their 1942 taxes on the basis of Treasury Department proposals for raising new war revenue.

After a study of the measures now pending before the Legislature, the committee on housing of the Community Service Society has recommended passage either of the Desmond or the Wachtel rent-control bills.

A contract was signed yesterday for the sale of properties in South Carolina of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation to the South Carolina Public Service Authority for a consideration of about $40,000,000, it was announced by Denis J. Driscoll and Willard L. Thorn, trustees of the corporation.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- A series of arrangements for facilitating the production effort of Mexico in collaboration with the United States for war purposes was announced in a joint statement tonight by Dr. Ezequiel Padilla, the Mexican Foreign Minister, and Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, upon the conclusion of their official conversations of recent days.

William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, announced yesterday that he expected to complete his investigation of alleged "irregularities" in the office of Borough President James J. Lyons andd the Department of Highways and Sewers of the Bronx within a week, and then would present a summarized transcript of all his evidence to District Attorney Samuel J. Foley.

ALBANY, April 8 -- Only 940 new stock companies were formed in the State in March, compared with 1,348 in March, 1941, Secretary of State Michael F. Walsh announced today. Of this number 819 gave New York City as the principal office, the remaining 121 being distributed among twenty-seven up-State counties.

Reguisite in a well-regulated household of bygone years was a small square room in the cool cellar that was called "the preserve closet." It was a pleasant place, if you recall, the shelves lined with deep crimson jellies, with mason jars filled with brandied peaches and with quart bottles containing mustard pickle.

The Theatre Guild officially announced yesterday that "Without Love," in which Katharine Hepburn is appearing on the road, will not arrive on Broadway this season, but will come to the Shubert Theatre in September. The local premiere already had been set back several times.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 8 -- Humphrey Bogart will play the lead opposite Michele Morgan in Warners' "Casablanca," replacing Ronald Reagan, who will be called for Army service on April 19, the studio announced today. Ann Sheridan and Dennis Morgan also have been named for roles in the film, which is being adapted from an unproduced play by Murray Burnett and Joan Alison about American war, refugees in French Morocco.

The consecration of the Very Rev. James Pernette De Wolfe as Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island will take place in the Cathedral of the Incarnation, Garden City, L.I., Friday, May 1, at 10:30 A.M., according to the official order issued yesterday by Presiding Bishop Henry St. George Tucker.

At the continuation yesterday of the General Sessions trial of twelve men in the alleged $157,000 milk extortion racket, the prosecution called the head of one of the largest independent retail milk concerns in the country. The witness, Sam Miller of 30-01 148th Street, Flushing, Queens, is the president of Queensboro Farm Products, Inc., at 35-13 Forty-first Street, Long Island City, which, he told the jurors, did an annual business of $7,000,000.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The defenders of Bataan Peninsula tonight fought back sturdily at wave after wave of fresh Japanese troops who hammered at new positions to which the defending forces retreated last night.

An exhibition of new paintings and drawings by Paul Meltsner, sponsored by Gertrude Lawrence, will be held at the Ferargil Galleries from April 20 through April 25. Proceeds will be donated to the American Theatre Wing War Service, Inc., which operates the Stage Door Canteen for service men.

ALBANY, April 8 -- The Senate, reconvening here tonight after the Easter recess, passed and sent to the Assembly the Desmond bill for a simplified State income-tax return for persons earning less than $5,000 a year and similar to that new used by the Federal Government.

The N.Y.U. baseball team recorded its second victory in the newly formed Metropolitan Collegiate Conference yesterday at Lewisohn Stadium, turning back City College, 9 -- 6. Although the Violets were outhit, twelve to nine, Coach Bill McCarthy's men led all the way, getting off to a 4-run start in the opening frame.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 8 -- Several moves to add safety and efficiency to air raid tests were advocated today by Colonel Frederick L. Devereux, chairman of the Westchester County Defense Council, in analyzing the results of last night's surprise blackout and people's army mobilization in the county.

Reserve stocks of gasoline on the eastern seaboard have been reduced from a thirty to a sixteen-days' supply within the past month and a half despite rationing of deliveries to dealers, it was learned yesterday as the pinch of existing sales restrictions began to make itself felt.

A decision of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals absolving the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad Company from liability for income taxes incurred by three railroads it has leased for many years was on file yesterday. The court directed the United States, plaintiff in the action, to take steps to collect the back taxes of $197,241 out of rentals due the leased lines.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, April 8 (U.P.) -- Judge Julio C. de Gregorio, Uruguayan Government investigator, alleged tonight that oil had been smuggled through Southern Brazil to German warships in the Atlantic and that a map showing plans for German conquest of South American territory had been confiscated in the same area.
ROME, April 8 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

Two hundred writers, journalists, physicians, radio commentators, lawyers, playwrights, college presidents, clergymen, educators, editors, artists, publishers and government officials sent a cable message yesterday to Leon Blum, former leader of the French Popular Front, who has spent nearly two years in prison as one of the accused in the "war-guilt" trial at Riom.

CHICAGO, April 8 (AP) -- Prices of hogs hit new sixteen-year peaks early today for the third consecutive session, but lost virtually all their initial gains of 15 to 20 cents a hundredweight as packers and shippers resisted the upturn. Choice hogs brought $14.55, the highest price since mid-September, 1926, but later sales were made at $14 or less.

"If the world wants a true measure of Hitler's New Order, not as a blueprint or as an ideology but in naked, deadly practice, it might turn to Norway under Nazi domination," Wilhelm Morgenstierne, Norwegian Minister to Washington, said yesterday in a statement on the second anniversary of the invasion of Norway by the Germans.

MOSCOW, Thursday, April 9 (AP) -- A dispatch from the Northwestern Front today to the army newspaper Red Star quoted a captured German lieutenant as saying 139 German troop-carrying aircraft were destroyed in the three-day period from April 3 to 5 -- 123 of them on the ground.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- Prior to the present Japanese attack on Bataan Peninsula the defending troops had established their main lines slightly north of the road that traverses the peninsula between Pilar and Bagae. This may have been the "previously prepared defensive position" to which Lieut Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright withdrew his forces.

DETROIT, April 8 -- The agreement of organized labor to give up its right to strike for the duration of the war is being imperiled by delays in the handling of National War Labor Board cases and by the board's refusal to accept disputes growing out of the dismissal of workers for union activities, the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., warned in a resolution adopted this afternoon by unanimous vote of delegates representing its 534,000 members.

Two new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. "The Courtship of Andy Hardy," twelfth release in the popular series sponsored by Metro, will be the newcomer at the Capitol. Heading the cast of the comedy are Mickey Rooney, who again portrays the title character; Lewis Stone, Cecilia Parker, Fay Holden, Ann Rutherford, Sara Haden and Donna Reed.

NEWARK, N.J., April 8 -- Sale of cemetery lots in the George Washington Memorial Park at Paramus, N.J., was permanently enjoined today by Federal Judge William F. Smith here on the application of the Security Exchange Commission, which held that the certificates for the lots were actually securities and these had not been registered with the commission under the Securities Act of 1933.

Two hundred picked women students gave demonstrations of physical education for defense yesterday at the thirty-second annual inter-school meet of the department of physical education for women at Pratt Institute, 215 Ryerson Street, Brooklyn.

PITTSBURGH, April 8 -- Leaders of the American Federation of Labor and of the Congress of Industrial Organizations were completing plans here today to implement labor's campaign for "unity and victory" to the country.

LONDON, April 8 (U.P.) -- The Nazi-sponsored Quisling regime in Norway has authorized untrained laymen to fill the pulpits vacated by the mass resignations of 1,100 Protestant clergymen, and churchgoers are preparing to fight on with their clergy against German oppression, "even from the catacombs," the Norwegian Government in exile reported tonight.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The President's proclamation on "I Am an American Day" read as follows:
DETROIT, April 8 AP) -- The automobile industry's vision of armament production in "staggering" volume is taking form.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 8 (U.P.) -- Germany lost 137,000 men killed and more than 400,000 wounded on the Russian front in February and March, the army newspaper Red Star said tonight as other reports told of the Red Army's smashing across the old White Russian border, 250 miles west of Moscow.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Approval of a bill authorizing the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to purchase or make loans on the security, of any article whose sale has been rationed by government authority was urged upon the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today by representatives of the National Automobile Dealers' Association and Senator Murray, chairman of the Senate's Small Business Committee.

The 1,166 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $60,578,981,933 par value as of March 31, had a total market value of $58,140,382,211, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday. As of Feb. 28 there were 1,165 issues, aggregating $60,532,171,333 par value, which had a total market value of $57,584,410,504.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- Increased April sugar supplies were approved by the War Production Board today for more than forty defense areas where population has increased l0 per cent or more in the last year.

Two years ago today Adolf Hitler took Norway under his protection. He protected her by invading her territories, bombing her cities, killing her soldiers and civilians, and driving out her chosen Government. She resisted his protection, under arms, for sixty-two days.

A.N. Williams, president of the Western Union Telegraph Company, told stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday that the company's net income this year probably will be less than in 1941. Last year's net was $7,366,000, compared with $3,745,000 in 1940.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The National Youth Administration, now regarded as on trial for its life, is contributing to war production about 30,000 skilled and semi-skilled workers every month and proposes, if allowed, to train during the coming year 600,000 of the country's youth for participation in the war effort.
Regardless of your own individual methods, there still may be reasons why you are not lucky when you fish.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (UP) -- The Silas Mason Company of New York raised the salaries of eighty-four administrative employes an average of 37 per cent as soon as it received a Louisiana ordnance plant contract, a Congressional committee was told today.
NEWARK, N.J., April 8 -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation office here announced today that it had arrested the second man in as many days on a charge of impersonating a naval officer.

MEXICO CITY, April 8 -- The agreements announced in Washington yesterday are generally welcomed here as going a long way toward solving for the present all outstanding questions between the United States and Mexico except the oil issue, which is expected to be settled by the end of this month.

VICHY, France, April 8 -- Free French claims of a 98 per cent vote for General Charles de Gaulle in the plebiscite on St. Pierre and Miquelon were denied here today by former Governor General Baron de Bournat in an interview following his reception by Marshal Petain.

The Wilbur Wright High School of Aviation Trades, started at the request of the government as a training center vital to the war program, will not be built, it was disclosed yesterday at the Board of Education. Construction has been halted because of Federal priorities on building materials and equipment.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The Children's Bureau of the Department of Labor is trying to figure how to tell Latin-American delegates to a conference early in May to bring "black tie" without runnning afoul of cable censors, the knowledge of social slang of the delegates or the Controller General.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The government called a halt today to non-essential building through an order requiring governmental sanction for construction projects whether publicly or privately financed. The order put in jeopardy construction projects which are partly completed, by specifying that such building might be stopped if materials to be used in such projects could be put to more effective use in the war program.

We think every American who has read the accounts of the Riom trial would be glad to sign the cablegram which some 200 American writers, artists, professional men and women and public officials sent to Leon Blum in honor of his seventieth birthday today. We think all lovers of freedom everywhere would like to have Mr. Blum know that they deeply admire his "courageous stand in the cause of freedom and democracy."

LONDON, April 8 (AP) -- Athenians showed the Axis that they remembered April 6, the date the Germans attacked Greece a year ago, with demonstrations in which a number of Italians were killed, according to reports reaching London tonight.
WEST POINT, N.Y., April 8 -- Army defeated the University of Vermont at baseball today, 8 -- 2.

Garment manufacturers will begin today production of Fall garments of wool under detailed restrictions ordered by the War Production Board. Similar restrictions on garments of other fabrics will go into effect on June 19. In general, the restrictions, while comprehensive, were as liberal as manufacturers had expected and they anticipated that there would be little disruption of the market.

Mexico and Central America were the inspirations behind the Brigance collection of beach and play fashions presented by Lord Taylor yesterday afternoon. In his styling, the young designer borrowed from the bathing suit worn by the natives of Acapulco and from the shawl-wrapped bodices favored by the women of Guatamala.

The possibility that Colby M. Chester may retire as chairman of the General Foods Corporation before the annual meeting of stockholders in 1943 was mentioned by Mr. Chester at the annual meeting for 1942, held yesterday in the Hotel Barclay. Mr. Chester will be 65 this year, and eligible for retirement.

Deeper cuts into Monday's recovery of prices on the New York Stock Exchange were made yesterday as the market drifted irregularly lower and the volume of business dropped under the 300,000 share mark. Trading was confined chiefly to low-priced issues, and the list sank more from its inactivity than from pressure of selling.

Further curtailment of operations in the oil industry last week brought activity in all branches well below that of a year ago. Reflecting largely the closing of wells in Texas for two days weekly, the country's output of crude oil was almost 100,000 barrels a day less than a year ago.
