Lord Halifax reviewed the history of British rule in India in his Town Hall speech night before last. He said two factors have immeasurably strengthened the sense of unity among the peoples of Hindustan, and along with it the British influence. These are English law and English education.

Pig iron production in March, according, to The Iron Age, was 5,113,187 net tons, a new high record, against 4,458,273 tons in February. The daily average last month was 164,941 net tons, against 159,188 in the preceding month.

Stocks of gasoline and light and heavy fuel oil along the East coast showed a net decline of only 17,000 barrels last week, the smallest since the first of the year, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Gasoline supplies rose 849,000 barrels to 17,319,000 and heavy fuel oil stocks gained 98,000 to 5,716,000.

LONDON, April 8 -- Squadrons of R.A.F. fighters crossed over the Channel in springlike weather early this morning and swept the sky over Northern France, but found little trace of the Luftwaffe. Messerschmitt Fockewulfs shirked combat and the sole casualty to the British was a plane that became detached from the main squadron and now is reported missing.

Jamaica will throw open its gates today for the beginning of New York's 180-day racing season, with war clouds lowering, with pickets at the gates in a labor dispute and with the barns full of horses. The expectation is for a crowd of 25,000 to welcome the thoroughbred back after an absence since last Fall, and post time is 2 P.M.

Despite the possibility that Canada will be forced to divert electric power from the manufacture of newsprint to that of aluminum newsprint interests and publishers here declared yesterday that the situation will probably not become serious before the Fall.

Secretary Knox's announcement that Negroes are henceforth to be enlisted in naval and marine combat units, and that they may expect to be promoted according to merit to noncommissioned ranks is good as far as it goes. The unhappy undertone in this new policy is its admission that the Navy has heretofore made racial distinctions, for which no warrant can be found in the Constitution, the statutes or the democratic traditions of the United States.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 8 -- Lieut. Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright, fighting the Japanese on Bataan, received a broadcast "letter from home" today which included a message from his wife and a bark from his dog.

PHILADELPHIA, April 8 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today the proposed sale of $8,000,000 of 4 per cent notes by Ohio River Power, Inc., to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to obtain funds to construct an electric-generating plans and a transmission line linking Ohio River Power with the Ohio Public Service Company.

Net sales of Russeks Fifth Avenue, Inc., for the twelve months ended with February, rose to a new high of $6,724,799, according to the annual report issued to stockholders yesterday by Max Weinstein, president. The total represents a gain of $1,552,229, or 30 per cent, over the preceding fiscal year.

It will be at least two years before the average citizen may hope for relief from the present tire restrictions, according to Robert P. Russell, executive vice president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, an authority on the synthetic rubber that is that far away.

As we avidly turn the dial or the page to compare or contrast the prophecies and interpretations of a host of war commentators and columnists of diverse merit, let us take heed lest some future Isaiah (Chapter 47, Verse 13) be obliged to tell us:

Fordham timed its hits in eminently judicious fashion at Baker Field yesterday and pieced together a 4-2 victory over Columbia in a Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference game. It was the third triumph in a row for the Maroon and the third defeat in succession for the Blue.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 8 -- The committee on social and moral welfare of the Presbyterian Church in the United States in a report released here today, asserted that a great majority of Christians believe this country is engaged "in a necessary war" and urged church members to perform their duty to the nation in a most faithful manner.
BEELIN, April 8 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- A special German High Command communique said today:

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Administration quarters are giving consideration to a major increase in the $7,610,000,000 new tax bill as part of the drive to prevent serious inflation while the nation is at war.
LONDON, April 8 -- Reports from scattered European centers tonight gave a picture of turmoil in Nazi-occupied countries suggesting growing rebellion.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The War Department communique based of reports received here up to 9:30 A.M. said:

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Ambassador Gaston Henry-Haye protested under instructions of his government today to Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, on the ground that the State Department did not consult Vichy before announcing that it would establish a consulate general at Brazzaville, in Free French Equatorial Africa.

Entries for the United States Chess Federation championship finals, scheduled to start at the Hotel Astor at 7 o'clock tomorrow evening, closed last night at the federation headquarters in Brooklyn, when drawings were made by the players for numbers on which to base the pairings for fifteen rounds.
Local covering operations and some price-fixing orders induced a late recovery in the cotton market yesterday after futures prices had eased sharply from early gains.

LONDON, April 8 (U.P.) -- Axis armored forces rolled into action on a sixty-mile front in North Africa today and there were reports of German troop movements in Greece, indicating that Adolf Hitler's drive for the Suez Canal and the Middle East was about to begin.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 8 (AP) -- The British communique said today:

The city of Chicago will be in the market on April 15 with an issue of $2,300,000 of judgment funding bonds, for which bidders are asked to name the rate of interest. The bonds, dated May 1, 1942, will mature from Jan. 1, 1945 to 1947.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 8 -- Some Japanese evacuees who left the West Coast military area No. 1 voluntarily to seek new homes in Rocky Mountain States before the recent "freezing" order went into effect are trying to get back to their former residential districts so that they may be moved out under Army supervision, it was learned today.

The distinguishing characteristic of the American standard of living, the quality that made it truly the envy of the world, was the astonishing wealth of mechanical comforts and conveniences turned out by American industrial mass production. Far beyond any other home in the world the American home has been supplied with bath tubs, radios, vacuum cleaners, washing machines and a long list of other contrivances which make living easier and more enjoyable.

BALTIMORE, April 8 -- The world series contestants of 1941 knocked each other about in royal fashion today for the edification of 7,500 onlookers and, although the Yanks sent four of their shots soaring out of the arena for home runs, the Dodgers won the game, 13 to 9.

Mozart's "Don Giovanni" was presented by the opera department of the Juilliard School of Music last night at the Juilliard Concert Hall in an English version by Edward J. Dent. The department had given the four other operas by the composer that are most frequently performed, but this was the first time "Don Giovanni" was staged under its auspices.
VALLETTA, Malta April 8 (AP) -- The British Command issued the following communique tonight covering raids of yesterday and today:

Decisions of the highest importance are in the making in Washington and London. Great events are unfolding behind the rising curtain of the Spring. In the Libyan desert, on the Russian front, in the clearing skies above the English Channel, the first moves of the long-heralded offensive begin to take shape and motion.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 8 -- The view that conflicts within Europe, on which National Socialist foreign policy has thrived, may now have turned against Reichsfuehrer Hitler is advanced here on the bases of reports from the Danubian Balkan States.

LONDON, April 8 -- A special communique received from Cairo tonight indicated that Field Marshal Erwin Rommel might have started his Spring offensive in the Libyan desert. The bulletin reported an eastward movement by two or three German columns. The enemy columns were said to have moved forward from the Mekili area and to have encountered British forces, who apparently retired some distance to positions where they had prepared to meet a German attack.

KINGS POINT, L.I., April 8 -- The death early this morning of George Keller Burbridge, whose body was found in his automobile in the garage of his home at 1 Birchwood Lane, here, was attributed tonight to carbon monoxide poisoning by Dr. Abraham Freireich, Nassau County Medical Examiner, who performed an autopsy this evening in Meadow-brook Hospital Morgue, East Hempstead.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 8 -- Paul Lacy's bat and Jack Davis's two-hit pitching enabled the Naval Academy to gain a 6-to-0 triumph over Rutgers today.

Increased use of public transportation facilities because of tire rationing has brought about a substantial gain in ear card billings in some areas, reports yesterday indicated. As a result of the sharp rise in car card circulation, amounting, for example, to 63 per cent in St. Louis in one year, advertising rates for the medium are beginning to go higher also.

BUFFALO, April 8 (AP) -- Paul R. Hanna, National Resources Planning Board consultant, recommended tonight in an address prepared for the Association for Childhood Education golden jubilee coordinated effort in providing services necessary in rearing physically sound and mentally alert young Americans.

It was the girls' night out last night and the collective ears of Manhattan's top flight executives would have buzzed if they had been at the dinner party of Seraphic Secretaries Association of America, Inc., in the Hotel New Weston, Madison Avenue at Fiftieth Street.

Many dinners were given last night before the performance of John Steinbeck's new play, "The Moon Is Down," at the Martin Beck Theatre, to assist the Kips Bay Boys Club. The proceeds will further the philanthropic projects of the beneficiary, which provides recreational and educational programs for more than 2,000 boys from the middle East Side
BERLIN, April 8 (From German broadcasts recorded by The United Press in London) -- Today's German communique said that British forces had been thrown back southeast of Mekili, Libya.
VICHY, France, April 8 -- Admiral Francois Darlan, the Vice Premier, in a speech to peasants at Valence, today urged them to intensify production to their utmost.

Mrs. Edward J. Flynn, wife of the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, will be among the dozen witnesses appearing tomorrow before the Bronx grand jury that is hearing evidence on the paving of a courtyard on the Flynn estate at Lake Mahopac, it was announced yesterday by District Attorney Samuel J. Foley.

Last week, in an editorial entitled "This Forty-Hour Week War," you denounced, as being "irresponsible and silly," a statement of mine to the effect that the Nazi propagandists know the technique of dividing a people and that it was not beyond either their morals or their brains for them to play employer against employe in this country.

The eighteenth annual pet show of the Kips Bay Boys Club was held yesterday afternoon with considerable confusion and noise. Ninety animals of various types and more varied ancestry and 400 cheering boys and their parents mingled in the club auditorium at 301 East Fifty-second Street.

Americans must reject distrust among races, creeds and political, social and economic groups, because such distrust aids the enemy, Pearl S. Buck, novelist, told 3,000 persons last night at a rally of the Council on African Affairs in Manhattan Center, Thirty-fourth Street and Eighth Avenue.

WICHITA, Kan., April 8 -- The Giants today encountered their second successive postponement in the annual Spring series with the Indians, who now cannot be beaten by the New Yorkers. Mel Ott's band will be unable even to square the series, granting the Polo Grounders win all the remaining games.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Linking the fashion industries and the women of the nation in a comprehensive program of simplification -- but not regimentation -- of styles for next Fall, the War Production Board today issued an order embodying garment regulations designed to yield a minimum saving of 100,000,000 yards of fabric, thus adding at least 15 per cent to the available number of garments.

An audience of 2,100 bought $5,776 worth of War Savings Stamps last night in order to attend the concert given at Carnegie Hall by the New York Youth Orchestra under Max Goberman, with Joseph Szigeti, violinist, as the soloist.

Sigmund Bostrup, 42 years old, a former lieutenant in the Danish Royal Palace Guards, was sentenced to five to ten years in State prison yesterday in General Sessions on his guilty plea to the theft of a $1,000 wrist watch from the suite of a woman guest at the Hotel Alrae in East Sixty-fourth Street, where he was the engineer.

Opposition to any program requiring mandatory blending of fibers in order to conserve wool was voted yesterday by the National Association of Wool Manufacturers at its seventy-seventh annual convention at the Hotel Commodore.
LOS ANGELES, April 8 -- Babe Ruth was fighting for his life in the Hollywood Hospital tonight.

PORT MORESBY, New Guinea, April 8 -- The reported Japanese landing at Lorengau follows the landing made a few days ago at Bougainville in the Solomon Islands, east of New Britain and the Admiralty group. This latest Japanese move appears to be of little strategic value unless they are planning to establish a chain of warning stations to meet the increasing threat of an offensive by the United Nations in the South Pacific.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The President's proclamation naming May 10 as Mother's Day was as follows:

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 8 -- The Japanese have occupied Lorengau, administrative centre of the Admiralty Islands on Manus Island, 380 miles northwest of Rabaul, New Britain, it was announced today. Before the landing the Australians there withdrew after they had destroyed the airdrome and other military installations.

Fifteen prizes and medals were awarded yesterday at the 116th annual exhibition of painting and sculpture at the National Academy of Design, 1083 Fifth Avenue, as the show, including the work of 336 painters and sculptors, was opened to the public.
LOS ANGELES, April 8 (AP) -- Dr. D.A. Davis said today that the Japanese Government has agreed to permit the Young Men's Christian Association to investigate needs of Americans interned by Japan.

LONDON, April 8 (AP) -- British forces in Burma occupied tactically improved positions north of Thayetmo today. Their latest withdrawal was to a point in the narrowing rrawaddy Valley that offered prospects of a continuous front for the first time since the Japanese started their up-river drive.

Returning yesterday to La Guardia Field after having attended a two-day meeting of the Permanent Joint Board of the Defense of Canada and the United States at Montreal, Mayor La Guardia paid high tribute to Canada's contribution to the war.
MOSCOW, April 8 (From Russian broadcast recorded by The associated Press) -- A soviet Information Bureau communique today said:

LONDON, April 8 -- The Russian armies of the center were reported tonight to have forced the heavily fortified upper Dnieper River in a major flanking movement designed to cut off and destroy the German Rzhev-Gzhatsk-Vyazma salient before Moscow, the last enemy line of consequence standing east of Smolensk.

SYDNEY, Australia, April 8 (AP) -- An Australian war correspondent reported today from Port Moresby that, "excluding Allied air operations north of Australia yesterday and today, we have destroyed or seriously damaged at least 157 Japanese aircraft in the past month in a brilliantly executed air offensive over a front extending from Timor to Rabaul."

The report of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation for 1941, issued yesterday by Sosthenes Behn, president, shows a consolidated net loss for the year of $193,218, compared with a net income of $27,219 in 1940.

The joint campaign to sell War Savings Bonds undertaken three months ago by a group of twenty two commercial banks and trust companies in this city has resulted in total sales of $190,000,000, maturity value, it was announced yesterday by Nevil Ford, State administrator of the savings bond staff.

BOWIE, Md., April 8 (AP) -- Hygrohour, a Texas-owned, Texas-bred colt that the bettors overlooked, dashed to a convincing victory today in the sixteenth running of the Kindergarten Stakes before a crowd of 8,000.

BERLIN, April 8 -- (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- German bombers, striking 150 miles beyond the Russian battlefront, raided an airplane engine works at Voronezh Monday night, causing heavy destruction, the German radio reported today.

PHILADELPHIA, April 8 -- Art McQuillen's home run with the bases full in the eighth gave Pennsylvania a loosely played 11-9 victory over Villanova today. It was the Red and Blue's first triumph against the Wildcats in nine years.

Although a critical shortage is apparent in some necessary drugs because the normal foreign supply has been cut off, good possibilities exist in the Western Hemisphere for the cultivation of these drugs, it was declared yesterday at the closing meeting of the two-day Herb Conference at the New York Botanical Garden.

New Yorkers should for get "the skyscraper concept" of the city "with all its foolish crowding," Ralph Walker, architect and former president of the Municipal Art Society, said last night at a dinner held by the organization in celebration of its fiftieth anniversary.
LONDON, April 8 -- The uncertainties in the India situation checked business on the stock markets today, but prices continued firm. Gilt-edged issues were unchanged and home rafts steady.

Supreme Court Justice Peter Schmuck reserved decision yesterday on a motion by the Bank of France to vacate the attachment obtained last year on behalf of the National Bank of Belgium upon funds of the Bank of France on deposit with the Federal Reserve Bank here.
LOS ANGELES, April 8 (AP) -- Robert Noble and Ellis O. Jones, organizers of "Friends of Progress," were indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of sedition.

A group of twenty-seven underwriters, headed by Van Grant Co., Detroit, will formally offer today to the public 166,667 shares of common stock of Ampco Metal, Inc. The stock will be priced at $7.50 a share, representing a market value of approximately $1,250,000.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Shoes of many colors and many styles, although perhaps not as extravagant in the use of "broccoli," will be available indefinitely to spruce up the limited dress wardrobes envisaged in today's War Production Board apparel order.

Since Pearl Harbor, inventions of new weapons have been reaching Washington at a rate said to be in excess of 700 a day. Nothing else so well illustrates the earnest desire of plain people everywhere to put their brains as well as their shoulders behind the wheel.

The challenge of the current world upheaval is whether the ultimate level of world living shall be one of "freedom, cooperation and good-will, which exalt the soul of man, or of violence, exploitation and tyranny, which debase it," thirty Unitarian ministers declared in a statement drawn up at a three-day convocation that ended yesterday.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 8 (U.P.) -- Admiral William H. Standley, new United States Ambassador to Soviet Russia, said today that by the end of April the flow of American supplies to Russia would fulfill the United States commitments to the Soviet Government as outlined in official statements drawn up at Moscow.

Seven baby boys born to New Yorkers recently have been named Douglas MacArthur. In addition, the Health Department has birth certificates for five babies named Douglas Arthur, which, Commissioner John L. Rice said yesterday, "possibly", were named for the United Nations commander in the Pacific.

In the immense and fateful drama now being written on the plains of India it is increasingly clear that the greatest obstacle to an agreement has not been a difference of opinion about the control of Indian defenses for the duration of the war. That question, certainly, has offered difficulties.

HONOLULU, April 8 -- Lieut. Comdr. Edward S. Hutchinson told here today the story of his long tour at sea -- or rather under it -- on offensive submarine patrol in Japanese waters, during which his command sank two fast Japanese tankers that carried more than 6,000,000 gallons of vital fuel.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 8 -- Many new types of engines of war probably will go into action during the Spring fighting on the Russian front. According to Russian reports received tonight, some of this materiel -- heavy tanks that are described as "offering good targets for artillery" -- already has been brought up by the Germans.
The upper four-fifths of the Bronx, which so far has had no occasion to put its lights out en masse, will get the chance tonight at 9 o'clock in the latest of the city's series of blackout drills.

The Federal Communications Commission's charges of monopoly in network broadcasting are criticized by William S. Paley, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, in his annual report distributed yesterday.

The Jewish holiday of Passover reminds us that struggle is the price of Rabbi Israel freedom, Goldstein said in a sermon in Temple B'nai Jeshurun, Eighty-eighth Street, near Broadway, yesterday, the seventh day of Passover. The holiday, commemorating the deliverance of the ancient Hebrews from bondage in Egypt, is observed for seven days by Reform Jews and for eight days by the Orthodox.

Retail store executives thought they saw some indications yesterday that the wide publicity given to the winding up of the durable goods industries at the end of May was starting another buying wave. Sales of small electrical appliances picked up but it was difficult to say yet whether there would be another consumer rush.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- When Mrs. America cleans house this Spring, the War Production Board asks that instead of stowing broken lamps and extra hot water bottles in some attic corner she will turn them over to the government for salvage.

The narcotic racket, which has been reduced greatly through the difficulties of smuggling in wartime, was attacked suddenly in concerted moves yesterday by Federal authorities here and in Arizona. As the East and West Coasts virtually have been closed to the traffic, such supplies as can be obtained have been brought in across the Mexican border.
Two more United States ships have been sunk by enemy submarines off our Atlantic coast, it was officially disclosed by the Navy yesterday.

Dr. Ezequiel Padilla, Mexican Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, expressed the belief yesterday that the United States was the center of the world's hopes for victory and that "all America has a new destiny" of fighting together to give the ideals of brotherhood, justice, real democracy and higher standards to the world.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- President Roosevelt and Attorney General Francis Biddle have approved a Treasury-War Production Board plan for the "loan" of about 40,000 tons of silver to war plants which Donald M. Nelson, WPB chief, disclosed yesterday in his press conference had been arranged to conserve scarce supplies of copper.

BALTIMORE, April 8 (AP) -- The commanding general of the Third Corps Area proposed today that the National Amateur Athletic Union adopt wartime rules permitting United States service teams to play all comers without affecting the standing the soldier athletes held before being called to military duty.

The report of the Atlantic, Gulf and West Indies Steamship Lines and its subsidiaries announced yesterday shows a gross profit of $4,103,658 for the first two months of this year, against one of $4,785,851 in the similar period of 1941.

At last the feminine minds of the country can be set at rest regarding the government's regulation of styles. No longer need they have the jitters. Yesterday morning the War Production Board made public its announcement concerning the regulation of styles for the duration.

LONDON, April 8 -- Reports from New Delhi tonight took on a sudden spurt of optimism, based on a belief that, through his special envoy there, Colonel Louis Johnson, President Roosevelt had offered a new formula for solution of the Indian problem.

Two new books on the ill-fated half-brig Mary Celeste are being published this month. George S. Bryan's "Mystery Ship: The Mary Celeste in Fancy and Fact," a corralling of the legends, facts and tenable theories about how the ship was abandoned in 1872, has just been published by Lippincott.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- Government counsel told the United States Court of Claims today that Postmaster General Farley "had a clear duty" to cancel the domestic air mail contracts in 1934 "when the evidence before him showed a combination to defeat competitive bidding at its inception."

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Formation of an emergency warehouse association in which the facilities of New York City storage warehouses would be pooled to permit more efficient use of facilities and simplify dealings between warehousing companies and government procurement agencies, is being sponsored by the Office of Defense Transportation, it was announced today.
LONDON, April 8 (U.P.) -- An Anglo-Japanese naval battle may be imminent in the Bay of Bengal, it was believed tonight on the basis of Calcutta press dispatches and Axis broadcasts.

The Board of Education is one hundred years old today. It began its work in file days when Dickens was our guest and Washington Irving our new Ambassador to Spain. Even in those days we were not a provincial people, and our sailing ships made their landialls in the lar East, whose Indian history is still and increasingly a matter for our concern.

A four-point program to minimize the danger of Japanese interference with the war procedure of the United States was outlined yesterday by Kilsoo K. Haan, secretary of the Sino-Korean People's League, in an interview in the Hotel Algonquin.

In an atmosphere reminiscent of the American town meeting, officials of the Board of Economic Warfare promulgated yesterday a new administrative law on export licensing after presenting it in tentative form here to fifty leading exporters, trade publishers and newspaper men.

President Elie Lescot of Haiti declared yesterday at an interview in the Roosevelt Hotel that the people of Haiti "would rather be destroyed than submit to the enemies of the United Nations." He added that his country was cooperating with the United States in economic and naval problems and pointed to the extensive cultivation of rubber plantations as one example of hemisphere solidarity.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- When the WPB orders limiting construction and the use of iron aria steel in durable consumers goods begin to take effect they will hurt, and hurt hard. They will strike at the livelihood of tradesmen in every city street and at every cross-roads, and they will in time harshen and make scarce the household equipment of every citizen.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 8 (AP) -- R.J. Wysor, president of the Republic Steel Corporation, told the stockholders today that the company was setting production records in materials vital for defense, but faced a slump in ingot manufacture unless more scrap metal was obtained.

A reorganization of the service division of WPA, employing 20,711 persons, to key its activities and projects directly with the war and civilian defense programs was announced yesterday by Irving V.A. Huie, WPA Administrator for New York City.

Assistant District Attorney Lawrence J. McKenna, in appearing in downtown Traffic Court yesterday to ask the dismissal of two warrants issued for motorists who allegedly parked their cars illegally, indicated that a new racket may be spreading in Manhattan, by which motorists who leave their automobiles in private parking places may be victimized by unscrupulous employes.

The ominous roar of flying squadrons in the skies of Europe and Asia heralded the commence merit of the Spring offensives yesterday as air power -- weapon of destiny -- started 1942's decisive struggle for the domination, of the world.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Women who make dresses at home for their own rise or their children's use are not required to conform to the clothing order issued today by the War Production Board.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, April 9 (U.P.) -- The Melbourne Sun reported today of the Lorengau occupation that the Japanese landing was made from a destroyer and a transport after the Australian garrison had withdrawn.

TOLEDO, Ohio, April 8 (AP) -- Net profits of the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company for the quarter ended March 31 were announced today as $534,186, or 21 cents a share, including $204,680 of nonrecurring income. In the corresponding period of 1941, when the company had the highest first quarter shipments in its history, earnings were $3,400,917.37, or $1.35 a share.

The city's organized business and professional women presented a check for $7,000 to the Red Cross War Fund last night at a ceremony made colorful by a tableau in The New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (UP) -- Senators from silver- producing States, members of a special silver committee, announced today that a series of hearings will be held beginning April 21 on the possibility of obtaining priorities on mining equipment.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The railroad industry was advised by the War Production Board today that materials will be allocated for the rest of this year for construction of an additional 18,000 freight cars and 300 locomotives for domestic use, in an effort to assure adequate transportation of war supplies.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- Price Administrator Leon Henderson, seeing President Roosevelt today for the first time since his return from a trip to Brazil and Puerto Rico, said that he had discussed the general price question and presented "general observations on what I would call the enthusiastic, cooperative attitude of the Brazilians toward us."

CHICAGO, April 8 -- Live stock dealers said today that lease-lend buying of pork so far has defeated Federal efforts to stop inflationary tendencies in meat prices. The result, small meat packers heard, is that 13 per cent of their number may be wiped out before the end of the year by rising live hog costs and ceilings over wholesale pork prices.

LONDON, April 8 -- General George C. Marshall, United States Army Chief of Staff, and Harry L. Hopkins, close aide of President Roosevelt, arrived here today on their first visit since American entry into the war and immediately went into conference with Prime Minister Winston Churchill and other high government officials on unannounced subjects.

Doubt was cast upon the fiscal soundness of the Ives Bill and Governor Lehman's plan, both proposals to liberalize State unemployment insurance benefits now pending before the Legislature at Albany, in a report sent yesterday to the Governor and the Legislature by a two-thirds majority of the Unemployment Insurance Advisory Council of 342 Madison Avenue.

CHICAGO, April 8 -- The grain markets, with the exception of oats, showed a heavy undertone on the Board of Trade today. Liquidation by holders of May contracts were largely responsible for the decline, although there was some selling of wheat on a Weather Bureau weekly summary indicating that the Winter grain crop was in good to excellent condition except for local damage in parts of Texas and Oklahoma.

It was a great night at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, for the Ballet Theatre put on a program of unusual distinction with the world premiere of Antony Tudor's magnificent new work, "Pillar of Fire," as its particular feature.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 8 -- Byron Nelson has found his range -- and maybe that's a preview of the 1942 Augusta Masters' golf tournament which opens tomorrow.

A $100,000,000 city-wide gambling racket said to provide members of the Police Department's plainclothes divisions in Brooklyn with an annual graft of $1,000,000 for protection was bared yesterday in six presentments handed up by Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen's two extraordinary grand juries.

Fifteen hundred members of the American Museum of Natural History attended yesterday the dual ceremonies of the official opening of the Hail of North American Mammals and the unveiling of a bronze bust of the late Professor Henry Fairfield Osborn, president of the museum many years and one of the world's leading palaeontologists.

" REMEMBER always that all of us are descended from immigrants," said Franklin D. Roosevelt on a certain stern occasion. "The Amazing Roosevelt Family: 1613-1942,"* by Karl Schriftgiesser of THE NEW YORK TIMES staff, is written with the President's words in mind. This is genealogical excavation without snob appeal, family history without unction, a study of ancestors that lacks any trace of stultifying ancestor worship.

NEW DELHI, India, April 9 -- Great Britain and India are in general agreement on a self-government plan that will establish the first all-Indian national government in two centuries and provide for an executive council of fifteen members, all but one of them to come from the various political parties, it was learned tonight.

Last night saw a gala performance of music and ballet for the benefit of Russian War Relief at the Metropolitan Opera House, with a capacity audience, row upon row of standees and a gross intake at the box office of more than $10,000.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Burma, April 5 (delayed) (AP) -- A guerrilla army of anti-British Burmese armed by the Japanese now is raiding the west side of the Irrawaddy River as far as sixty miles above Prome.

The achievements of the free Chinese under Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in resisting the armies of Japan four and a half years and shattering the myth of Japanese invincibility were acclaimed here last night at a dinner at the University Club attended by more than three hundred leaders of American government, business and labor, in the interest of United China Relief.

A suit accusing the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers of misusing its control of "practically 100 per cent of all of the copyrighted musical compositions which have found public favor" and demanding triple damages of $606,784 was filed in Federal court here yesterday by 157 operators of 235 motion-picture theatres.

LONDON, April 9 -- The outstanding feature on the Stock Exchange today was a sharp rise in gilt-edge securities. This was attributable to talk of still cheaper borrowing when the coming budget is introduced. The conversion 3 1/2 per cent loan rose 3 points to 106 7-16 and the 3 1/2 per cent war loan 1/8 to 106.
LONDON, April 9 -- The British Government struck out boldly today in a campaign to make the "liberty cut" -- which really is just a short haircut the national coiffure for women.

A voluntary cooperative campaign to bring about more normal conditions in the sale of men's clothing was adopted yesterday by about fifty representatives of chain, department, specialty and small stores, at a luncheon meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Mrs. Halstead G. Freeman gave a luncheon yesterday at the Stork Club for Mrs. William D. Chambers, national commandant of the Women's Voluntary Service Corps of the Canadian Red Cross, who came from Montreal to attend the tea and reception held later at the British War Relief Society's Shop, 6 East Fifty-seventh Street, to mark the opening of an exhibition of uniforms for women attached to the fighting forces of Great Britain.

The Mid-Continent Petroleum Corporation and its subsidiaries had last year a consolidated net profit of $4,866,037 after all charges and reserves, according to the annual statement of Jacob France, president, issued for publication today.

James A. Farley accepted yesterday the chairmanship of the national corporations committee of the war fund campaign of the United Service Organizations, to begin on May 11 and continue through July 4.

CHUNGKING, China, April 9 -- Reinforced American Volunteer Group fliers have roared back into the Battle of Burma, destroying ten planes and damaging two others in a mass dogfight with twenty Japanese Zero fighters in which one American plane was lost but its pilot saved, an A.V.G. communique announced tonight.

In an unexpected move that may present a test case of far-reaching effect in the Police Department, Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen's two extraordinary grand juries returned supplemental presentments yesterday against two high-ranking police officers who had sought retirement while under investigation in connection with alleged police protection of a $100,000,000 city-wide gambling racket.

Two items in adjoining columns a little to the left on this page yesterday insist on merging into a single idea. In connection with the centenary of this imperial city's Board of Education it was stated that in 1842 New York had a school enrollment of 47,900 children.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- President Roosevelt conferred with Secretary Stimson, John G. Winant, Ambassador to Great Britain; David Dasso, the Peruvian Minister of Finance, and Gaston Henry-Haye, the Ambassador of France.

THE snow was whipping past the windows of the National League office in Radio City yesterday when an intruder arrived to ask some questions about baseball prospects. President Ford Christopher Frick of the National League, flanked by the stout Mr. Bill Brandt of the National League Service Bureau, was floored by the first question thrown in his direction.

As the thoughts of American housewives turn to Spring housecleaning, government and private agencies issued instructive reminders yesterday for the preservation of vacuum cleaners, rugs, draperies, woolen and rayon fabrics. The aim of the instructions is to make all household articles last longer in the face of rationing.

LONDON, April 9 -- Formation of a national government in which each Indian group will have representation in accordance with its strength and influence emerged tonight on the basis of what it is strongly hoped will be a settlement of the problem.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The War Production Board issued today an order further curtailing gasoline deliveries to filling stations and bulk consumers in seventeen Eastern States, the District of Columbia and Oregon and Washington.

The British cruiser Dorsetshire, sunk with the Cornwall in the Bay of Bengal, was the ship that delivered the coup de grace to the Bismarck in the spectacular sea fight in the North Sea last Summer. Colored as this fact is with tragic irony, it is overshadowed by another aspect of the disaster.

The road that had no turning and that led from its beginning straight over the hills of hardship to death and defeat was approaching its end in the Philippines yesterday while the Japanese commenced the campaign of India.

LONDON, April 9 -- Danes in London today observed the second anniversary of the German invasion of their country by giving 38,300 for airplanes. Prime Minister Churchill, accepting the gift, promised the liberation of Denmark, "perhaps sooner than it would be prudent or sensible to hope."

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Bills providing for the construction and operation of plants for the manufacture of synthetic rubber to a total capacity of 400,000 tons annually, and the creation of a special government authority to have charge of production and sales, were introduced in the Senate and House today.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce, and Eugene Meyer, editor and publisher of The Washington Post, were participants in a fistic encounter at the annual dinner of the Alfalfa Club at the Hotel Willard tonight.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Secretary Morgenthau said today that the United States Government would not let Great Britain "run out of dollars in any way that would interfere with the war effort."

CHICAGO, April 9 -- Scattered liquidation by holders of May wheat contracts was in evidence on all of the minor upturns on the Board of Trade today and prices at one time were 1 cent a bushel below yesterday's finish. Part of the loss was recovered later on covering by shorts, with the close at losses of 3/8 cent.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Its authority to reform public utility accounting having been confirmed by a court decision a few days ago after it had been questioned at intervals in the last twenty years, the Federal Power Commission dissolved today its previously granted stay of an order in connection with the Alabama Power Company's Jordan Dam project.

The report of the Standard Oil Company of California for 1941, released for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $32,955,333 after all charges, taxes and reserves, equal to $2.53 each on the 13,003,953 capital shares outstanding.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Voluntary consolidation of domestic telegraph companies and separate mergers of international concerns, long under Congressional study and controversy, would be permitted under legislation presented today to the Senate to carry out recommendations made last October by a special subcommittee which had been assigned to work out the problem.
NEW DELHI, India, April 9 (Reuter) -- Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru said today, in part:

The Union for Democratic Action made public a letter yesterday, addressed to its chairman, Dr. Reinhold Niebuhr, by Acting Secretary of State Sumner Welles, declaring that the State Department has not extended "any form of recognition, formal or informal" to the Independent Hungary Committee headed by Dr. Tibor Eckhardt, or to any other "free movements."

Yesterday's weekly statement of the twelve Reserve banks showed reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date. Holdings of United States Government securities decreased $1,000,000.

Sales of electric ranges in February by manufacturers totaled 39,945 units, a decline of 22.9 per cent from the 51,790 moved in the like 1941 month, according to a report yesterday by the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Admiral R. Stark, recently relieved as Chief of Naval Operations to become Commander of American Naval Forces in European waters, was presented with the Navy Gold Star today in a surprise ceremony arranged by President Roosevelt.

The Marine Corps yesterday enlisted a recruit who was sworn into the service by the commanding officer of Marine Corps recruiting for this district. He was Victor I. Morrison Jr., 17 years old, son of Lieut. Col. Victor I. Morrison.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The general level of wholesale prices rose to a new thirteen-year peak last week following widespread advances in commodity markets, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average, was 97.9 for the week ended April 4, compared with 97.4 on March 28, 97.2 on March 21, 96.9 on March 7 and 82.2 on April 5, 1941.
A day's pay instead of an hour's pay as municipal employes' annual contribution to the Greater New York Fund was urged yesterday by Newbold Morris, president of the City Council.

Capitalizing on feminine fancies induced by Spring, an old French firm has produced a new American color that comes in an almost indelible lipstick, a rouge and a nail enamel -- as bold and bright as the stripe on a Marine's trousers and just as effective.

In your issue of April 8, Assemblyman Irwin D. Davidson attempts to defend his amendment to the Hospital Lien Law. There are many serious errors in his statements, which I hope you will enable me publicly to correct.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 9 -- Armored columns of Marshal Rommel's Afrika Korps felt their way into the Cyrenaican No Man's Land again yesterday, but the riddle remained unsolved whether he meant only to take a few positions or to attempt a full-scale advance.

The fall of Bataan to the Japanese invaders struck the stock market heavily yesterday and values were reduced as much as 2 points in the leading motors and steels. The decline, however, was general and the aggregate loss was the most severe in about a month.
Lieut. Gen. Lear's indictment of "desk fighters" (TIMES, April 7) is commendable, but as with all generalities there are exceptions.

DETROIT, April 9 -- The amazing Detroit Red Wings spotted the Toronto Maple Leafs two first-period goals tonight and then came on to seize their third victory in three games, 5 to 2, before 13,354 spectators at the Olympia in the four-out-of-seven Stanley Cup finals.
Florists' window displays reflected yesterday the fact that roses from near-by greenhouses are arriving in more generous shipments than for many months.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 9 -- The Norwegian people spent today, the second anniversary of the German invasion, in a grim silence that the sound of Vidkun Qusling's marching storm troopers and German soldiers, who had the streets of Oslo to themselves, could hardly penetrate, according to word received here.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 9 (AP) -- The text of a communique issued here today follows:

Could a service man who boasts of New York City as his home town say a few words about what may perhaps sound trivial to those still living normal civilian lives? When I arrived in Detroit I was amazed but very pleased when a bus driver said to me: "Men in uniform don't pay carfare in this city."
MOSCOW, April 9 (AP) -- The Soviet Bureau of Information communique today followss

LONDON, April 9 -- The Japanese have struck a heavy blow against the British Navy in the struggle for mastery of the Bay of Bengal, which is the key to the Indian Ocean, in sinking by air attack the heavy cruisers Dorsetshire and Cornwall.

Building projects submitted yesterday by architects included plans for thirty-three small homes in various communities in Queens County designated as defense areas. The two largest developments will be in Queens Village and Glendale, where groups of fourteen and seven dwellings, respectively, will be erected.

The former Marshall Field Building at 309-15 Thirty-fourth Street, Union City, N.J., has been leased by The Vimalert Company, Ltd., to the General Motors Corporation's Argonaut Realty Division for a storage and distribution depot. This is a two-story brick and steel structure containing about 18,000 square feet of floor space, with a sprinkler system, on a wire-fenced tract of about one acre.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Representatives of mutual fire, casualty and automobile insurance companies opposed before the Ways and Means Committee the Treasury requests that they no longer be taxed less than stock companies.

Alexander Gretchaninoff, whose Fourth symphony was performed for the first time by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall last night, is a gallant gentleman. He wears his seventy-seven years lightly. He walked out for his curtain calls with the springy step of a man who is young in spirit, and he bowed neatly and crisply, with the grace of the old school.

Five of seven divisions of the food marketing industry in the city have completed plans for alternate locations and other means to assure an uninterrupted flow of foodstuffs in the event of enemy bombing, Daniel P. Wolley, Commissioner of Markets, reported yesterday.

Unpaid salary accruals from the pay of city employes who have gone into the armed services already have reached $271,592, it was disclosed yesterday when the Board of Estimate made a routine budget transfer involving the sum.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 9 -Whirlaway, 1941 turf champion, failed today in his first test as a 4-year-old, finishing second behind Devil Diver, a rising Kentucky Derby prospect, in the $2,500-added Phoenix Handicap on Keeneland Park's opening program.
LONDON, April 9 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique today follows:

LONDON, April 9 (U.P.) -- Japanese air missiles, probably torpedoes, have sunk the British heavy cruisers Dorsetshire and Cornwall in the Indian Ocean, and British and Japanese fleets are massing in the Bay of Bengal for a far bigger battle to help decide the mastery of Ceylon and India, British sources said tonight.

Interest of newspaper readers in advertising exceeds, in the case of women, that shown in society news or pictures, while among men it equals their interest in sports news or pictures. This is the conclusion reached by the Advertising Research Foundation, Inc., following a summary of forty-two examinations of the Continuing Study of Newspaper Reading released this week by the Advertising Research Institute.

TRENTON, April 9 -- In preparation for civilian registration under the sugar rationing program from May 4 to May 7 and the distribution of Rationing Book 1, the Federal Government has issued a booklet containing answers to typical questions the public is likely to ask in getting acquainted with the procedure.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- The colorful Thirty-first Infantry Regiment, "America's Foreign Legion," shared in the glory of the three-month defense of Bataan. Only this unit was identified by Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson today.

The Intercontinental Rubber Company reported yesterday for 1941 a consolidated net income of $370,233 after all charges, taxes and reserves, equal to 62 cents each on the 596,004 capital common shares outstanding, compared vith $323,614 or 54 cents a share in 1940.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- An overwhelming Japanese Army, aided by the allies of hunger, fatigue and disease, today crushed the small mixed force that had held Bataan Peninsula since December.

SULPHUR SPRINGS, Texas, April 9 -- The United States is already making more than 3,300 planes a month, Speaker Rayburn revealed at a Texas Unity Rally here today. He said that Administration leaders have every confidence that the President's schedule of 60,000 planes in 1942, including 45,000 combat planes, would not only be met but exceeded.

CHUNGKING, China, April 9 -- Clad in the sacred saffron robes of the Poongee -- literally meaning "great glory" -- the fifth column in Burma is taking advantage of the historic sanctuary provided by Burmese Buddhism. In the past the Poongees have included, besides the genuinely devout, many thieves, bandits and general malcontents, and they have always been a major problem for British administration.

Mayor La Guardia and the city administration won a victory in the Supreme Court yesterday in their fight to prevent mass retirements from the Police Department of men who, while they have served more than twenty years, are under 55 years of age and have served less than twenty-five years on the police force.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Leo T. Crowley, alien property custodian, said he had taken over the holdings of foreign nationals in the Magnesium Development Corporation, of New York, and the Luscombe Airplane Corporation of West Trenton, N.J.

There will be no May Day parade of radicals, laborites and Communists this year, it was announced yesterday by the United May Day Committee, 80 East Eleventh Street. Instead, those who in years past have responded to the committee's parade call were asked to remain at work and concentrate on the task of war production.

Mayor La Guardia, Park Commissioner Robert Moses and Councilman Joseph E. Kinsley engaged yesterday in a sharp three-cornered row over Mr. Kinsley's charge that an architect's fee of $591,000 on the new Idlewild Airport in Queens was "the most outrageous grab" he had ever seen.

Household hints on how to conserve foodstuffs as well as the containers in which edibles are packed were outlined yesterday afternoon by Mayor La Guardia to 150 women at a meeting in the Brooklyn Civilian Defense Volunteer headquarters, 131 Livingston Street.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- Use of rubber covers or rubber sealing rings in containers for packaging more than forty groups of products, including coffee, tea, tobacco, candy, spices and various sauces, was prohibited today by the War Production Board, effective May 9.

ALBANY, April 9 -- The Senate passed today by a vote of 37 to 1 the Moffat bill empowering New York City to change the site of the free foreign trade port from Staten Island to Manhattan for at least the duration of the war. The measure now goes to the Governor.

The use of motion-picture cameras to sustain charges of police corruption is novel. In other respects the story which Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen unearthed in Brooklyn and presented to two special grand juries is distressingly old. Mr. Amen and his staff did a remarkable job of investigation.

TOKYO, April 9 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in San Francisco) -- An Imperial Headquarters communique declared today that two British cruisers had been sunk and sixty British planes shot down during a naval engagement in the Bay of Bengal and the Indian Ocean.

A familiar name returned to the New York Stock Exchange yesterday when that institution announced that Donald G. Geddes of Clark, Dodge Co. had bought the seat of Daniel R. Collins for $18,000. The price was $1,000 above that in the previous transaction.

The vital importance of a United Nations victory with a proper and complete "winning of the peace" after the war, and the contribution lectures and forums can make to these ends were discussed by six writers and educators and one representative of the United States armed forces yesterday at a luncheon conference on "The American Platform in America at War."

The 1942 Ringling Brothers and Barnum and Bailey Circus, a show of extraordinary beauty, opened last night in Madison Square Garden. Money taken in at this performance will go to the Navy Relief Fund, the Army Emergency Fund and to the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

New York City's failure to dim its shorefront lights on Long Island is frustrating the effort to protect coastwise shipping against the submarine menace, according to a protest sent to Mayor La Guardia yesterday by Colonel Edward C.O. Thomas, Director of Civilian Defense for Nassau County, who said his own community had complied with Army orders.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Per capita circulation of money in the United States at the end of March was $86.26, the Treasury reported today. This compared with $85.67 at the end of February and indicated that the steady increase ila the amount of money in circulation noted for more than a year still continues.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 9 -Spring sowing has been in progress for several weeks in the Tadzhik and Uzbek Republics of the Northern Caucasus. A big drive is under way, in which President Mikhail Kalinin is taking keen personal interest, to advance and increase the season's sowing to compensate for the temporary loss of the Ukrainian granary.

The Harry Payne Whitney residence at 871 Fifth Avenue, above Sixty-eighth Street, one of the most palatial private houses in the city, is to be razed and its costly furnishings and works of art sold at auction.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- At a time when European dispatches suggested a new strain on relations between Vichy and the German Government over conduct of the government of Unoccupied France Gaston Henry-Haye, French Ambassador, went to the White House today to present to President Roosevelt a personal message from Marshal Henri Philippe Petain written by the marshal in a bound volume of the speeches he has made since France fell in June, 1940.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 9 -Republic today signed Joe E. Brown to co-star with Judy Canova in "Lazybones," Harriet Parsons's first production for the studio, which Joseph Santley will direct, starting on April 27. Jack Townley, Robert Harari and Eve Greene have written the scenario from a story idea by Miss Parsons.

PHILADELPHIA, April 9 (AP) -- The public utilities division of the Securities and Exchange Commission opposed today at a hearing by the SEC a proposal for the Engineers Public Service Company to buy 35,000 shares of its own preferred stock for $2,150,000.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (U.P.) -Congress today received news of the fall of Bataan with a stirring tribute to its valiant defenders and a renewed pledge that the war will not end until the Japanese had been driven back "to their little island and cut entirely to pieces."

" Lamb is the best buy today," is, the advice that comes this weekend from the Consumers Service Bureau of the New York Department of Markets. Breast of lamb ranges between 10 and 18 cents a pound, averages 14 and costs about 2 cents less than it did last Friday.

New York took its racing yesterday with dashes of war, large doses of snow, and a good nature clearly indicating that the racegoer will endure almost anything with a grin in order to see the thoroughbreds run and get a whack at the mutuel machines.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Further limitations were placed upon the production of electrical appliances today by the War Production Board, which reduced the production permitted to 20 per cent of a company's factory sales value in 1941, exclusive of A-10 and higher orders.

The cotton market made moderate gains again yesterday as covering operations by local operators brought about an upward trend near the close of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange. Active futures advanced as much as 10 to 13 points early in the session, but final quotations were only 5 to 9 points higher than the previous close.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Friday, April 10 (AP) -- General Douglas MacArthur was informed late last night of the fall of Bataan, whose defense he directed on the scene until his transfer to Australia in March.

Virtually every women's organization in the city will send representatives for the parade of 15,000 women down Fifth Avenue tomorrow afternoon to spur the environment of 10,000 volunteer nurses' aides, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the campaign.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 9 (U.P.) -- The reinforced Red Army has absorbed successfully the first impact of Germany's Spring offensive, repulsing mechanized attacks along the entire front, including an assault by 100 tanks in the Crimea, the strongest since the battle for Moscow, Russia reported tonight.

The women's coat and suit industry began its adjustments yesterday to the new WPB regulations for simplification of women's styles. This branch of the apparel trade was the first to be directly affected as the new rules covering woolen merchandise went into effect immediately.

ALBANY, April 9 -- Retail merchants, including spokesmen of many of the large department stores throughout the State, clashed with representatives of industrial sellers and organized labor here today at the public hearing on the Feinberg-Delany Trade-Practice Bill, held in the Assembly chamber before the Senate Judiciary Committee.

Secretary Knox cannot say whether a decline in shipping losses during the past week is due to the increasing effectiveness of the American patrol or to a temporary withdrawal of enemy craft for rest and replacement. But in any case it is certain that our counter-measures have been considerably improved.

A fictionally treated biography of the daughter of Maria Monk has just been published by Macmillan under the title "And Down the Days." The author is the Rev. John Louis Bonn and the volume is the April selection of the Catholic Book Club.

Contributions to the special gifts committee of the 1942 appeal of the New York Catholic Charities are substantially ahead of last year, John A. Coleman, executive chairman, announced yesterday at the third report meeting of the committee in the Empire State Club, 350 Fifth Avenue.

Their concluding road game canceled in Wilmington, Del., yesterday, the Yankees and Dodgers arrived last night prepared to fight out the final three games of their exhibition series in the more familiar confines of their home fields.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The story told by Secretary Stimson today of our inability to supply in considerable quantities by sea the heroic troops on Bataan, whom we could not reinforce at all, proves the wisdom of the large construction program of air freighters and transports now under way.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- As the result of an exchange of notes between Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, and Leighton McCarthy, the Canadian Minister, Canadian nationals registered under the United States Selective Service Act who have not declared intentions of becoming citizens of this country may elect to serve in Canada's armed forces.

" Dangerously They Live," which opens at the Strand, is the sole film newcomer this morning. The cast of the action drama is headed by John Garfield, Nancy Coleman and Raymond Massey. Moroni Olsen, Lee Patrick, Esther Dale and Frank Reicher are among the featured players.

To the weary men who have at last been overpowered by superior force on the Bataan Peninsula the praise of their countrymen will bring cold comfort. They would have preferred a chance to fight the Japanese on something like even terms. This chance was denied them.

Although bank transactions in this city declined for the third straight week, the margin of improvement reported by leading cities outside New York brought the total bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday 5.7 per cent ahead of the corresponding figure a year ago.

A nation-wide banking group headed by Blyth Co., Inc., and including the First Boston Corporation, Otis Co., Inc., and Stranahan, Harris Co., Inc., received yesterday the award of a new issue of $17,500,000 city of Cleveland. Ohio, transportation system revenue bonds on an interest cost basis to the city of 3.7459 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, April 9 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, holding the present capitalization of the Commonwealth Southern Corporation to be "repugnant" to the Public Utility Holding Company Act, directed today that the $1,173,984,806 concern recapitalize on a common-stock basis within one year.

Arrangements have been made by 322 clubs and associations to conduct 1,800 Hale America tournaments this year for the benefit of the American Red Cross, according to a report issued yesterday by the United States Golf Association.

Caution in increasing retail inventories at this time was urged yesterday at the regional conference of the bureau of smaller stores of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

NEW ORLEANS, April 9 (AP) -- An Army-A.A.U. controversy was settled today when Lawrence Di Benedetto, president of the Amateur Athletic Union, accepted Army proposals to clarify the status of amateur athletes in the armed services.

NEWARK, N.J., April 9 -- The dismissal of four former members of the German-American Bund from key positions in the Harrison (N.J.) gas works of the Public Service Gas and Electric Company was disclosed here today. The plant, one of the largest of its kind in this country, is encircled by war-production-plants.

CHICAGO, April 9 (AP) -- Leland Olds, chairman of the Federal Power Commission, told the Midwest Power Conference today that private power interests had underestimated the kilowatt needs of a war economy and that "development of additional hydroelectric power is an essential part of any adequate plan for war power supply."
The war and its relation to problems of conservation were among the topics discussed yesterday at the North American Wildlife Conference in session in Toronto.

The customary pre-season odds on the major league pennant races issued by Jack Doyle were announced by the "official" betting commissioner yesterday and showed one drastic departure, the Browns in the American League first division, but clung steadfastly to the practice of recent years of making the Yankees favorites to win the flag.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- On both sides of the Capitol the Congressional gatherings were tense today, and members for the most part were sparing in voicing their reactions to the disaster on Bataan Peninsula.

Courage and determined endeavor on the military and production fronts will be needed in 1942 to insure a final victory for the democracies, Jan Masaryk, Foreign Minister of the Czechoslovakian Government-in-exile, warned yesterday at service flag presentation exercises at City College, Convent Avenue and 139th Street.
HOLLYWOOD, April 9 (U.P.) -- Babe Ruth was fighting off an attack of pneumonia tonight with such fortitude that he may be out of danger in a few days if his resistance to the ailment does not lessen.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The value of department store sales during March showed less than the usual seasonal rise from the unusually high levels prevailing in January and February and the adjusted index of the Federal Reserve Board, based on the 1923-25 average, declined to 122, compared with 126 in February, 138 in January and 103 in March, 1941.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -The Agricultural Marketing Administration confirmed today reports that it had asked packers operating under Federal inspection to offer for sale to the government at least two-fifths of their production of pork cuts and canned pork and two-thirds of their production of lard and hog casings to meet lease-lend requirements of Great Britain and Russia during the late Spring and early Summer.

With nature cooperating 100 per cent by providing a moonless, slushy, dismal night for the occasion, the vast upper four-fifths of the Bronx, home of 885,000 residents, took its turn last night at joining New York City's parade of community blackouts.

The report of "he United Corporation, utility holding company, for the first three months of this year, issued yesterday, shows a net income after taxes and charges of $1,185,528. This compares with a net of $2,013,198 in the March quarter of 1941.

The Victory Committee of German American Trade Unionists, consisting of representatives of A.F. of L, and C.I.O. organizations in the New York area, announced yesterday that it would launch a drive for a bombing plane to be presented to the government "to symbolize the desire of German Americans to see the United States take the offensive and crush Hitler and the Axis."

Under the Silver Purchase Act of 1934 the Treasury has piled up a stock of over 3,300,000,000 ounces of silver. Although it has ceased lately to buy up foreign silver, the Treasury is compelled to continue to add to its stocks by buying the domestic production at 71 cents an ounce, against a market price of 35 cents an ounce.
Sixteen experts will start play tonight at the Hotel Astor in the first round of the biennial tournament for the national championship under auspices of the United States Chess Federation.

In contrast to the substantial gains in the excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System as a whole, the excess funds of New York City member banks in the week ended on Wednesday showed a decline of $85,000,000, it was revealed yesterday.

In the first three days of this week the German rulers of occupied France engaged in what seems a queer business. They raided the Institute of France, arrested ten of its members and went through their private papers. The charge against them was possession of anti-Axis propaganda.

Friday night, April 24, has been reserved for the debult of the new variety offering, "Keep 'Em Laughing," at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre. Headed by William Gaxton, Victor Moore, Argentinita, Joe Smith, Charles Dale and a few more of stellar rank, the show will undergo trial performances (April 21-22) in Bridgeport.

Problems of the New York Curb Exchange were brought into the spotlight this week by George P. Rea's resignation as president, which emphasized the need for greater revenue for the average member as opposed to a better balance between revenue and out-go for the Exchange as an institution.
BERLIN, April 9 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique said today:

Gerald Griffin, who was relieved on Monday from his post as national executive secretary of the American Guild of Variety Artists when the Associated Actors and Artistes of America superseded all officers of the subsidiary A.F. of L. entertainment union, yesterday was exonerated by the latter body of charges of anti-semitism which were brought against him.

The two-family dwelling at 1679 Eastburn Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the Title Guarantee Trust Company, as trustee, to Henry and Ethel Bass for occupancy in a deal arranged by Edward A. Kelly, Inc., broker. The house is said to have been held at $10,500.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- A new battle between the Administration and Congress over the character and the amount of new war taxes appeared imminent tonight.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, April 10 (U.P.) -- United Nations planes, most of them manned by American crews, were believed to have destroyed eight heavy Japanese bombers and one fighter plane and damaged a troop transport in a heavy raid yesterday on Rabaul, main Japanese base in New Britain, it was announced today.

A group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and including Estabrook Co., Paul H. Davis Co. and Daniel F. Rice Co., was the successful bidder yesterday for a total of $2,989,500 City of Minneapolis, Minn., refunding, relief and school bonds.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Government circles are reported to be discussing the possibility of stabilizing the unprecedented wage costs which will enter into the estimated $11,000,000,000 defense construction program for the next year.
Military, safety and moral reasons indicate the urgent need of a classification of aliens of enemy nationality as proposed by James G. McDonald in his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES of April 6.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Rules have been adopted by Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, War Shipping Administrator, to discourage seamen on United Nations ships from floating from ships of one flag to those of another, a practice which delays prompt turn-arounds of vessels engaged in the war effort, according to a report today of the Special Inter-departmental Commitee on Maritime Labor.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 9 -- For the first time since the masters' tournament was inaugurated nine years ago to perpetuate the memory of his achievements in the world of golf, Bobby Jones, 40-year-old Atlantan who scored the only grand slam ever made, today gave his followers something to cheer about.

The Eastman Kodak Company will produce this year a far greater amount of non-photographic military products, measured in dollars, than the largest output of the civilian goods normally produced in the same plants in any peacetime year, according to the pamphlet report mailed yesterday to stockholders.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., April 9 -The Giants-Indians Spring series, the ninth renewal of which is nearing completion, will be mapped on a different basis next year if the pilots of the rival squads can influence arrangements.

Probably no order of the War Production Board to conserve steel, copper or other scarce and strategic materials received more prayerful consideration than the board's new order to conserve fabrics which will influence the future course of women's clothing styles. The board, which is entirely composed of men, must have faced a difficult problem.
LONDON, April 9 -- The British Royal Air Force and the Nazis' Air Fleet exchanged minor blows last night and today.
LONDON, April 9 -- A 10,000-ton eight-inch-gun Italian cruiser has been sunk in the Central Mediterranean by torpedoes from a British submarine, the Admiralty announced today.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 9 (AP) -- Lew Ayres, who was sent to a conscientious objectors' camp because he refused to bear arms, has applied for reclassification for noncombatant service in the Army, the State Selective Headquarters said today.

LONDON, April 9 (AP) -- The Bank of England's note circulation advanced 5,121,000 this week to a high record of 763,926,000, the bank's statement disclosed today. This compared with 618,718,000 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- The final battle of Bataan appeared likely today to be recorded as numerically the heaviest reversal ever suffered by an American force in a single engagement with a foreign foe.

ALBANY, April 9 -- The legislative leaders moved swiftly today to settle the remaining problems of the session, as the Senate formally voted for adjournment on April 23, a move in which the Assembly will concur at its next session Monday night.
LOS ANGELES, April 9 (AP) -- Seven persons died of heart attacks and an air raid warden fell off a two-story building when the Los Angeles area blacked out an hour and fifty-one minutes last night.

BERLIN, April 9 (From German broadcast recorded by the United Press in New York) -- The High Command said today that a Qboat -- a heavily armed ship disguised as an unarmed vessel -- was among thirteen vessels sunk off the American Atlantic coast and that it was sent to the bottom by a submarine only after a "bitter battle."

PHILADELPHIA, April 9 -- THE NEW YORK TIMES has won for the fourth time the F. Wayland Ayer Cup, highest recognition, in the twelfth annual exhibition of newspaper typography conducted by N.W. Ayer Son, Inc., of this city, it was announced today.

March engineering construction awards totaled $729,485,000 for the second highest monthly volume ever reported, according to the Engineering News-Record. It represented a rise of 61 per cent above the figure for the same month of 1941, and lifted the aggregate for the first quarter of 1942 to $1,993,088,000, the highest on record for the period.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The manufacture of golf clubs was ordered curtailed today by the War Production Board and stopped completely by May 31. WPB hastened to reassure the golfers, however, that supplies of new clubs added to the numbers to be manufactured by the shut-off date would be ample to meet normal needs for this season.

Spyros P. Skouras, president of the National Theatres, was elected president of Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, and Wendell L. Willkie was elected chairman of the board at a directors' meeting held yesterday in the company's offices, 444 West Fifty-sixth Street.

The Brooklyn Dodgers did it before, but they can't do it again, in the opinion of the baseball experts, who by a 2-to-1 margin have picked the St. Louis Cardinals to take the 1942 National League pennant.

Attorney General John J. Bennett joined yesterday the investigation of William Johann Adams, German securities dealer charged with defrauding German-Americans and German aliens here by threats of instigating expropriation of property and other harm to their relatives in Germany.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Senator Bunker, Democrat, of Nevada, today attacked the Defense Plant Corporation, an RFC subsidiary, charging that the terms of its contract with Basic Magnesium, Inc., for a plant at Las Vegas, Nev., meant "unconscionable profits."

The Congressional Library in Washington houses on its top floor a cafeteria, frequented by staff and students alike. The Public Library at Forty-second Street has no such facility available for its employes and readers.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The Justice Department's anti-trust division filed today an application with the Interstate Commerce Commission for reconsideration of its recent action in authorizing a merger of eight large Atlantic seaboard trucking companies, alleging it has discovered new evidence of a collusive arrangement with an American Federation of Labor union which would tend to make this new company a monopoly.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 10 (AP) -The properties of the Minneapolis St. Louis Railroad are to be sold on May 15 upnder terms of a consolidated final decree signed today by Judge Gunnar H. Nordbye in Federal court. Attorneys for the receiver said, however, that a thirty-day delay may be sought to perfect arrangements.

Although some observers were prepared for an unusually high percentage in the allotment of the new issue, of $1,500,000,000 of Treasury one-half of 1 per cent certificates of indebtedness due on Nov. 1, next, the announcement yesterday that the allotment will be 48 per cent on subscriptions of more than $25,000 proved to be somewhat larger than the market and banking officials had anticipated.

The Ballet Theatre provided another top-notch evening at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, with Alicia Markova in the first "Giselle" of the Spring season and Agnes de Mille as guest artist in her own "Three Virgins and a Devil" as the novelties of the occasion, and Irina Baronova in a repetition of spectacular "Princess Aurora'' for more than good measure.

Frank W. Phelan, president of the All-America Corporation and the Commercial Mackay Corporation, announced yesterday results of operations of the two corporations for 1941. Consolidated net earnings of All-America available for interest on its income debentures amounted to $1,224,362 and full 4 per cent interest on the debentures will be paid on May 1, Mr. Phelan announced.

Dedicating the new Information Center for Civilian Defense in Pershing Square yesterday, Mayor La Guardia appealed to the public for patience, fortitude, morale, extra work and the sacrifice of luxuries and comforts in "the most difficult, long and hard war" ahead.

In response to the recently begun Archbishop Spellman Roll-Call of Catholic Men, 100,000 members, many of them recent recruits, of the New York Archdiocesan Union of Holy Name Societies, are scheduled to receive holy communion tomorrow morning in their respective parish churches and "to pray for the spiritual and physical welfare of the men and women in the armed forces of the United States."

WASHINGTON April 10 (AP) -Production of sugar cane for sugar and seed in 1941 was reported today by the Department of Agriculture to have totaled 5,462,000 short tons, of which Louisiana produced 4,488,000 and Florida 974,000, compared with 4,218,000 short tons in 1940, of which Louisiana produced 3,258,000 and Florida 960,000.
Investors were active yesterday in the Manhattan trading with purchases of a tall loft building and several residential parcels along the West Side.

UTICA, N.Y., April 10 (AP) -Fifteen New York dairy cooperatives were asked by the Dairy Farmers Union today to meet here Monday to unite for a concerted blow against what the union described as a conspiracy to deprive farmers in cooperatives of the right to sell their milk.
No matter what the weather is, 15,000 women will march down Fifth Avenue this afternoon in the first parade of its kind since the days of the first World War.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- A relatively large force of sailors and Marines found refuge on the fortified island of Corregidor before the fall of Bataan Peninsula yesterday, the Navy Department announced here today. An official spokesman said that, lacking definite reports, it could be stated only that "most of an estimated 3,500 men" so escaped.
