SOMEWHERE IN ENGLAND, April 10 -- The fastest bombing plane thus far flown by the Royal Air Force has given a superb account of itself in recent daylight attacks on the Germans. It is the American-built DB-7B which the British have named the Boston No. 3, it was revealed today.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- A more effective utilization of the joint agricultural resources of Canada and the United States for the production of several farm products needed in the war effort was announced today with the approval by President Roosevelt and Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King of two joint arrangements recommended by the Joint Economic Committees of the two countries.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 10 (U.P.) -- Russian air, tank and infantry forces have captured scores of localities and wiped out a German infantry regiment in a battle of annihilation on the central front, the Red Army reported tonight.

First effort to relate the market pattern of magazines to the official marketing data developed by the Bureau of Census has been started by the Magazine Marketing Service. The first of a series of reports, relating the physical inventory of magazines in the home and the readership of magazines to the basic market pattern of all classifications of advertised products, was released to member publishers yesterday.
The problem of wartime censorship is a difficult one at best. In regard to American military production, a good case can be made out for concealment, as well as one for publicity.

The New York Stock Exchange firm of Schoellkopf, Hilbert Co. will dissolve on Thursday next, when Webb Hilbert, William T. Emmet, John P. Cronin and R.T. von Palmenberg, the last a limited partner, will form Hilbert Co., it was announced yesterday by the Stock Exchange.
KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 10 -It is amazing how rapidly and how completely the Russian people have adapted themselves to war conditions.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Conservation of electric power may be necessary in Canada this Fall to feed war industries which are being established, William L. Batt, chairman of the United States-Canada Materials Coordinating Committee, said today.

LONDON, April 10 -- According to reports just received here by the Yugoslav Government, the Germans have demanded the surrender of Yugoslav guerrillas under threat against their relatives, it was announced here today.

I read your editorial of April 2 "More Niagara Power" with great interest. It is evident that THE TIMES did not know of or had forgotten the work done in the Twenties to demonstrate both how additional water could be drawn from the Falls for power with no interference with scenic qualities, and also, what to me seems even more important, how the gradual degradation of the Falls could be permanently avoided.

Department of Labor people in Washington are trying to find an answer to a difficult query from Latin America. Delegates from the southern republics are coming here for a labor meeting next month. They inquired by cable whether they must bring along tails and white tie, or "smoking," or what?

CHICAGO, April 10 -- While the bedding industry as a whole is anxiously awaiting the details of a forthcoming "M" order fixing definitely the status of some of the products which it uses, consumers are buying innerspring mattresses heavily and retailers are considering promotions for cotton mattresses, a check of the industry showed today.

LONDON, April 10 -- Theodore Schulze, twenty-two-year-old son of Mrs. Anthony J. Drexel Biddle Jr. by her first marriage, is serving with General Charles de Gaulle's forces, Mrs. Biddle disclosed today when, as chairman of the Allied-British War Relief Society of America, she handed over medical equipment to the Free French sanatorium established in Great Britain.

Today's events -- Victory concert, New York Public Library, 5 P.M.; Jazz concert, Town Hall, 5:30; "The Bat," Pythian Theatre, 135 West Seventieth Street, 8:30; Belgian Piano String Quartet, Washington Irving High School, evening; Columbia University Band, McMillin Academic Theatre, Columbia University, 8:30; Hans Basserman, violin, and chamber orchestra, Hunter College Auditorium, 8:30.

AT A UNITED NATIONS AIR BASE, in the Southwest Pacific, April 10 -- There are no farewells when American fliers take off on a business mission. The men who man our bombers are too intent on their job to bother about anything else and fliers are not the sentimental sort.

Thirty thousand trained workers are needed immediately in subcontracting plants working on parts for naval vessels, it was disclosed yesterday by Rear Admiral H.L. Brinser, chief of the Office of Inspector of Navy Material. All the plants are in the metropolitan area.

With the new billion and a half dollar financing successfully concluded, the United States Treasury Department might, with profit, turn its attention to the fertile field of general public participation in government loans, and reconsider past decisions in this regard -- particularly in view of the reports from Washington that Secretary Morgenthau is not satisfied with the sale of war bonds.

"China Sunday" will be observed tomorrow in the churches. Pastors will urge their parishioners to contribute to the United China Relief drive for $7,000,000 opening tomorrow. At the request of the special committee, clergymen will commend the cause "spiritually" to the people in general.

The three apartment and store buildings at 1431-33-35 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, assessed at $18,000, have been sold by Henry Muller of West Orange, N.J., to Rebecca Price for investment. The broker was H.E. Esterbrook.

Because of the war the outlook for the title insurance business in the near future, like that of most branches of the realty field, is not too bright, several speakers declared yesterday at the nineteenth annual convention of the New York State Title Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

MILWAUKEE, April 10 (AP) -Boy Scouts, Girl Scouts and amateur junkmen in general have done such a grand job of gathering waste paper to help in the war that Middle Western mills and dealers are swamped. And now, at Spring housecleaning, the stuff coming out of basements and attics is amazing.

Possibility of a break in the deadlock that has existed in the Tammany executive committee appeared yesterday when Representative Joseph A. Gavagan, leader of the Twenty-second Assembly District, withdrew as a candidate for the leadership of Tammany Hall made vacant by the ousting of Christopher D. Sullivan.

NEWARK, N.J., April 10 -- Concern for the health of the large number of persons being drawn into wartime industries, particularly that of women leaving sheltered home environments for jobs requiring arduous physical labor, was expressed today by Dr. Emil Frankel, director of statistics and research in the State Department of Institutions and Agencies.

E.R. Jessen made a very hollow argument in his effort to belittle the national invitation basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden. If he watched games here regularly he would realize that only the best teams in the country are brought in to face the local fives.

Following an interval of seventeen years, Morris Weinberg has returned as president and publisher of The Jewish Day, New York Jewish language newspaper, Louis Lipsky, former president of the Zionist Organization of America and trustee of the Day Foundation, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Mrs. Chase Going Woodhouse, Secretary of State of Connecticut, has accepted an appointment as consultant in charge of listing and placing scientifically trained women in war jobs under the National Roster of Scientific and Specialized Personnel.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- A novel maintenance-of-union-membership clause, which compels delinquent members to rejoin the union and also, for the first time, provides against union coercion of employes, was contained in a decision made public today by the National War Labor Board.

Provision of $3,166,335 for Federal income and excess profits taxes based on recent Treasury Department proposals, reduced the net profit of the Underwood-Elliott-Fisher Company for the first quarter of this year to $393,582, according to a statement of earnings announced yesterday.
MELBOURNE, Australia, April 10 (AP) -- A communique announced by Prime Minister John Curtin today follows:

FOLSOM STATE PRISON, Calif., April 10 -- Five hundred inmates of this penitentiary, picked from a group of 1,100 volunteers, are going through the regular Army drill (without guns) forty-five minutes every day as the wish to participate in the war effort spreads through California's penal system.
Commissioner Harry M. Armstrong reports that streams are expected to be high for the opening of the trout season in New Jersey on Wednesday.

CHUNGKING, China, April 10 (U.P.) -- Three Japanese columns are storming Chinese defense lines above Toungoo, on the highway to Mandalay, while to the west below the Burma oil fields a new threat to the British flank was developing from Japanese creeping up the Irrawaddy River in small boats at night, dispatches from the front said tonight.

BERLIN, April 10 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- German forces defending their ground on the Kerch peninsula in the Crimea have beaten back strong Russian attacks supported by tanks and planes and have destroyed or put out of action eighty-two tanks, the German High Command reported today.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The United States is pressing through diplomatic channels for the release of two United States Army officers and three soldiers held captive by the Japanese after making land on a perilous journey from the Philippines to Indo-China.

Mrs. Edward J. Flynn, wife of the chairman of the National Democratic Committee, testified for thirty-five minutes yesterday before the Bronx County grand jury that is hearing evidence of city materials and labor being used in the paving of a Belgian courtyard on the Flynn's Lake Mahopac estate.
VALLETTA, Malta, April 10 (AP) -- A British communique issued here tonight said:

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- Six government agencies were designated by President Roosevelt today to inspect plants and to audit books and records of firms with war contracts "to prevent the accumulation of unreasonable profits," avoid waste of government money and to implement measures taken to forestall price rises and inflation.

Fifty commanders and Special Services officers from Army camps, posts and stations in New York, New Jersey and Delaware attended a conference on Governors Island yesterday at 2 P.M. to complete a plan whereby dependents of soldiers in the Army win be immediately assisted financially whenever they require money for emergencies.

PHILADELPHIA, April 10 -- Maxim M. Litvinoff, Russian Ambassador to the United States, called tonight for "definite united efforts now" by Great Britain and the Soviet Union, "with some supplementary aid from the United States," in order to smash Hitler into "complete destruction and final defeat" on the Russian Front.

Sales of leading mall-order and chain store companies showed an average increase of 23.9 per cent during March, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The increase, reflecting a heavy volume of preEaster trade, was somewhat larger than that noted for February, when a percentage rise of 22.3 per cent over last year was reported.

Thursday's 2-inch snowfall which, mixed with considerable rain, melted down to a total precipitation of 1.36 inches, or half of April's normal quota, was of substantial benefit to the city's water reserves. Water Supply Commissioner Patrick Quilty urged consumers to continue to conserve water, however.

The stock markets recovered somewhat yesterday from the shock of the fall of Bataan and prices held their ground, with an attempt at recovery appearing in some issues. The list generally held firm throughout most of the session except among the utilities.

Cancellation or deferment of the sales of several issues of railway equipment trust certificates and at least one other corporate loan left the market for new bond issues exclusively to the tax-exempt field this week. The appearance of several sizable loans, including one of the largest flotations in that group this year, lifted the total new offerings to $22,068,300.

The cotton market advanced yesterday to within 1 to 6 points of the thirteen-year high levels it touched on last Monday, but continued liquidation in the near months and selling by local operators near the close of trading induced an easier tone.

This year for the first time the yearbook of the New York Stock Exchange contains a list of the stocks that have had the longest records of consecutive dividend payments. These 129 issues that have paid for twenty-five to ninety-four years are headed by the Pennsylvania Railroad, which made its first distribution in 1848.

Vincent J. Vince, 30 years old, an insurance counselor of 35 Riverside Drive, when he appeared yesterday in the Criminal Courts Building, proved that he had run up something of a record as a continuous law violator. In the preceding three years he twice escaped with suspended sentences on criminal indictments in General Sessions, but in the interim he had ignored twenty-two traffic summonses.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 10 (AP) -- The British Middle East General Headquarters communique said today:

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The Federal Reserve Board today announced adoption of a regulation designed to carry out President Roosevelt's executive order of March 26, which was planned to facilitate the financing of war production, particularly by small industry.

At a tax lien sale held in the Vesey Street rooms yesterday the City of New York bought fifteen parcels of realty in scattered sections of Manhattan for $28,000. In this suit, George A. Ewald and others were defendants and the auctioneer was H. Louis Hollander.
MELBOURNE, Australia, April 10 -- General Douglas MacArthur, Supreme Commander of the United Nations forces in the Southwest Pacific, made the following statement today:
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The Federal Public Housing Authority announced today that it would sell soon to private bidders $94,793,000 of temporary loan notes of thirty local housing authorities.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 10 -- The Red Army will liquidate the German Army in Russia in 1942, S.A. Lozovsky, Soviet Vice Commissar for Foreign Affairs, said at his press conference today, adding that United States supplies are reaching the Russian forces and being "used to make Nazi corpses,"

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 10 -- Yale will defer action on naming a new head football coach for a while longer. Ogden Miller, athletic director, tonight disclosed that the board of athletic control would submit no recommendations to tomorrow's meeting of the university corporation.
BERLIN, April 10 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press ) -- The German High Command communique said today:

THE manufacture of golf balls in this country ceased, by government order, on April 1, and there was no April fooling about it. The manufacturing of golf clubs, by a more recent government order, will cease on May 31 and the ban probably Will hold "for the duration." But that doesn't mean the end of golf by a long shot. There should be no panic on the links.
MOSCOW, April 10 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau communique broadcast today follows:

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The main mission in London of General George C. Marshall, United States Chief of Staff, and Harry L. Hopkins, special representative of President Roosevelt, is to ascertain whether the British Government is justified in the stand it has taken against invading Europe this Summer, it is learned in diplomatic quarters here.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 10 -- Under indescribably difficult conditions, more and more dominated by mud and slush, the Red Army has kept up its attrition tactics, and today figures came from the Soviet capital that, if added up, give a total of 12,000 Germans killed on various parts of the front in the last few days.
CHICAGO, April 10 (AP) -- Mello Bettina, heavyweight championship aspirant, decisively outpointed Booker Beckwith, Gary, Ind., Negro, in their ten-round battle at the Chicago Stadium tonight.

A new college rowing season will get under way this afternoon on the shallow waters of Carnegie Lake in Princeton where the Tigers and Rutgers will meet in the first of the regattas which will provide active week-ends for rowing colleges through this month and May.

PHILADELPHIA, April 10 -- The American Tobacco Company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement proposing the sale of $100,000,000 of twenty-year 3 per cent debentures due on April 15, 1962, the proceeds from which would be used with other funds to pay $104,477,000 of indebtedness.

Rudolph M. Andolschek, former chief inspector in New York State for the Federal Alcohol Tax Unit, was named yesterday in an indictment that accused him and twenty-one other Federal agents of accepting bribes amounting to more than $500,000. The money, the indictment charges, was taken from the manufacturers of perfumes and hair tonics to overlook large withdrawals of denatured alcohol that found its way into bootleg channels.

TOKYO, April 10 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press in New York) -Japanese dispatches said tonight her forces had occupied Cabcaben, on the southeast shore of Bataan Peninsula, and were advancing toward the last uncaptured town, Mariveles, on the south coast.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 10 -- Although their putters were on a sit-down strike, two golfers, Byron Nelson, 30-year-old Texan now serving as pro at the Inverness Club in Toledo, and Sam Byrd, former Yankee outfielder, who is located at the Merion Club in Philadelphia, today were in the limelight in the masters' tournament at the Augusta National course.

All of New York City's problems were solved in such a short time by a substitute City Council yesterday at City Hall that a member of the regular Council moved that his legislative body adjourn and turn all legislation over to members of fifty-six Hi-Y chapters in Brooklyn and Queens.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Sailors and marines played an important part in the gallant defense of Bataan Peninsula, but most of their accomplishments have been secret up to now because of the lack of facilities to communicate their story to the Navy Department.

MEXICO CITY, April 10 -- Mexican railway workers, like the miners, have agreed to cooperate in carrying out the economic defense agreements announced by the United States and Mexico on Tuesday, officials of the National Railway Administration said last night.

Rear Admiral Randall Jacobs, Chief of the Bureau of Navigation, presented diplomas to 233 naval officers who were graduated yesterday from the Naval Training School for Indoctrination at Fort Schuyler in the Bronx, and commended them for their offer of service to their country.

ALBANY, April 10 -- Governor Lehman vetoed today the Young bill, which would have exempted the secretary of the Presiding Justice of the New York City Domestic Relations Court from civil service requirements. The Governor acted at the suggestion of Mayor La Guardia, who termed the proposal a "special private" measure.

LONDON, April 10 -- Britain's negotiations with India, which have seemed several times on the verge of complete breakdown, only to have hopes revived on the basis of what was reported to be a new formula, now are reported to be a failure.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 10 (AP) -- Hudson Manhattan Railroad employes lost today their attempt to win two seats on the carrier's board of directors at a meeting of stockholders.
A painting which thousands of visitors saw at the Masterpieces of Art Exhibition at the New York World's Fair in 1939 was sold at auction last night for $19,000 at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 10 -- Norway's spiritual leader, Bishop Eivand Berggrav, and three other churchmen were arrested yesterday by Premier Vidkun Quisling's order and will be sent to Dachau or some other concentration camp in Germany on charges of having "incited the Norwegian clergy to rebellion," it was reported from Oslo today.

Apache, William Woodward's Kentucky Derby hope and the 3-year-old many expect to be the main Eastern hope for the Churchill Downs test, will get his first 1942 race today in the $5,000 added Experimental Handicap, feature on the first Saturday of Jamaica's race meeting.
PHILADELPHIA, April 10 -The text of the address of Maxim M. Litvinoff, Russian Ambassador to the United States, before the American Academy of Political and Social Science tonight was as follows:

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Three additional galleries containing art from the Chester Dale collection will be opened at the National Gallery of Art tomorrow afternoon. There are now five large galleries devoted to nineteenth-century French paintings sent here by Mr. Dale on indefinite loan. Work in the first two galleries has already been commented upon.

The Appellate Division, unanimously reversing a ruling of Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin, dismissed yesterday a suit brought by Max M. Hirson, as receiver of the New York assets of the Tobacco Products Corporation of Delaware, against the United Stores Corporation and directors of the latter company.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., April 10 (AP) -- The front-running Sir Marlboro, next to the longest shot in a field of eight, brought a smashing finale to the Florida racing season today with victory in the $10,000 Tropical Handicap before 8,857 fans at Tropical Park.
LONDON, April 10 -- Another attack on an enemy convoy by a British submarine was reported today.

Andrew H. Brown, in 530 Park Ave; Haughton Fitz Randolph, in 10 Mitchell PI; Samuel Roberts, in 174 E 71st St; Priscilla Fleitman and Barbara Symmes, in 175 E 62d St; Angelo J. Smith Jr, in 156 E 37th St; Mrs. Vivian D. Bradshaw, in 44 E 92d St; Dr. John P. Caffey, through Bing Bing, Inc, in 435 E 57th St; Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc, brokers.

The last Long Island Railroad train to run on the street surface in the Rockaways left the Far Rockaway station at 11:26 A.M. yesterday, and thus marked completion of a grade-crossing elimination project which cost $11,650,000 and took two and a half years to build.

CHICAGO, April 10 -- War production by Marshall Field Co.'s manufacturing units will equal their civilian output by the end of this year, Frederick D. Corley, president, told stockholders today at the annual meeting in the Merchandise Mart.

"To the weary men who have at last been overpowered by a superior force on the Bataan Peninsula the praise of their countrymen will bring cold comfort. They would have preferred a chance to fight the Japanese on something like even terms.

A rally to urge complete and immediate independence for India, rather than any compromise offered by the British Government, was attended by 2,500 persons last night at Town Hall under the auspices of the Post War World Council.

By consent of both sides, Supreme Court Justice Peter Schmuck yesterday ordered the transfer to the Appellate Division of the reinstatement suit brought against Mayor La Guardia by Paul J. Kern, ousted president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, and Wallace S. Sayre, who was removed by the Mayor at the same time as Civil Service Commissioner.

The merchant seamen of the United Nations have come in for a full measure of well-earned public praise. That is as it should be. This is a war of transportation, and the final outcome may well rest with those who man the cargo ships and sail the seven seas.

DETROIT, April 10 -- A protest because the Ford company retained Charles A. Lindbergh was made in a resolution today by the production foundry workers unit of the United Automobile Workers (C.I.O.) in the Rouge plant.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture reported today that the Winter wheat crop, which got an excellent start last Fall, still shows good prospects, with production indicated at 624,983,000 bushels on the basis of conditions prevailing on April 1.

William J. Fraser has purchased for cash above a purchase money mortgage of $5,100 from Morton Bros. Housing Corporation, Barney L. Morton, president, the two-story dwelling for one family at 141-24A Seventieth Road, Flushing, Queens. The plot is 17 by 100 feet.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 10 -- Sweden's five-year defense plan, costing some $900,000,000, was today laid before the Riksdag. The plan will make 100 per cent use of the power of defense of the Swedish people, the preamble states.

The scourge of malaria, with its annual toll of 10,00,000 lives, now constitutes a greater menace than ever, since Java, which supplied 95 per cent of the world's quinine has fallen to the enemy, it was stated last night by Professor Marston Taylor Bogert, noted organic chemist of Columbia University.
LONDON, April 10 -- Efforts to coordinate the war propaganda of Britain and the United States will be augmented soon, it is stated here.

There are few scenes more pleasing to contemplate than one that can be tritely labeled "a quiet evening at home." To be in keeping with such a peaceful occasion the evening meal must be simple and satisfying. One, for example, that might include the following good, though unelaborate, dish:

Bishop William T. Manning, in a pastoral letter mailed yesterday to the 500 Protestant Episcopal clergy in the New York Diocese, called upon his ministers to give the utmost spiritual support to our war program and to help in such material ways as conserving gasoline and food and sparing the tires on their cars.

Mrs. Finley J. Shepard, the former Helen Gould, left an estate of $3,272,918 net, after giving away more than $2,300,000 in the two decades before her death, the filing of the estate tax appraisal showed yesterday. The gross estate of Mrs. Shepard, daughter of the late Jay Gould, railroad financier, was appraised at $3,706,978 before deduction of debts and expenses.

AN AUSTRALIAN PORT, April 10 (U.P.) -- A battle-scarred American submarine has arrived safely at this port after sinking one Japanese light cruiser and torpedoing three more during a long cruise on which, always flirting with disaster, it survived sixty-nine depth charges in two days.

CORREGIDOR, April 9 (Delayed) -- All night long last night nurses dazed with fatigue and war-weary fighters braved Japanese bombers and shark-infested waters to escape stricken Bataan for the comparative safety of this fortress in Manila Bay. Across the narrow channel that separates Bataan Peninsula from Corregidor came civilians as well, all who could or dared make the trip to the fortress.

NEWPORT, R.I., April 10 -- A torpedo ran wild last evening for a distance of almost six miles in Narragansett Bay, struck and damaged the Navy cargo vessel Capelia and injured eight of her crew, some seriously, the Navy disclosed today.

"HOW JAPAN PLANS TO WIN"* is a catchy title. But the book has very little connection with its title. It is primarily a pep talk for Japanese home consumption. Written in 1940, it is an argument designed to shame, scare and encourage the Japanese people into going to war against us.

Acting upon the academic principle that demands "full investigation of the facts before reaching a conclusion," three young Townsend Harris High School seniors embarked yesterday on a search of vacant city buildings to disprove Mayor La Guardia's recent statement that the institution should be abolished because the floor space it occupies at present is needed by the City College School of Business.

The visit of General Marshall and his party to London is a prologue to action. Amid all the speculations regarding the object of the mission, it can be taken for granted that it represents the growing feeling of Washington that it is better to take the initiative with the forces now available than to wait until the preparations for a major offensive are complete.

Enemy submarines operating off the Atlantic coast have struck at four more American merchantmen, sinking one, damaging two and taking possibly a toll of forty-seven lives, the Navy Department announced last night.

"Four Flights to Love," reportedly one of the last films produced in France before the German invasion, will have its local premiere today at the Little Carnegie Playhouse. Fernand Gravet is starred in the romantic drama, and Elvire Popesco, Alerme and Micheline Presle are among the featured players.

Continued heavy shipments of United States currency to Cuba, with a preponderance of denominations of $20 and larger, evidently to supply a hoarding demand, were reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in its monthly survey of shipments and receipts.

The return of local housing authorities to the new-issue field with offerings amounting to $76,839,000 will increase to $85,260,953 the amount of new municipal issues scheduled to be sold next week. This compares with $26,739,085 this week and with a weekly average of $23,696,374 for the year to date.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on April 4 were 261,768,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines. This represented a decrease of 1,440,000 barrels in the week, comprising decreases of 1,124,000 and 316,000 barrels in domestic and foreign stocks, respectively.

GLOUCESTER, N.J., April 10 -Two hundred delegates from locals of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C.I.O., adopted by an overwhelming vote today a resolution expressing their willingness to forego premium wages for Saturday, Sunday and holiday work, except where such labor was in excess of a forty-hour week.

Strengthening of the nation's social security system as a weapon essential to the winning of the war as well as of the peace was the principal theme of discussion at the fifteenth national conference of the American Association for Social Security at the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday.

BELMAR, N.J., April 10 -- A large mine believed to have broken loose from some place in the harbor defenses of New York was hauled on the beach here this afternoon by members of the Shark River Coast Guard Station.

Just as captured Singapore has become the hub for Japan's westward expansion into Burma and India, so captured Rabaul, 3,000 miles to the southeast in New Britain, is the hub of enemy operations against Australia and our Pacific supply route. Rabaul is only a small town on a half-explored volcanic island, but it is of supreme strategic importance in the coming struggle for the Western Pacific.

Disease always follows in the train of war. Overcrowding, a lowered standard of living, a shortage of physicians are only a few of the reasons. Particularly to be feared is the spread of tuberculosis, against which a campaign has been waged successfully for many years by public health associations.

TOKYO, April 10 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- Captain Hideo Hiraide, Japanese naval spokesman, said today that Britain "is certain to lose India" and that Japanese naval operations now being carried out over a 10,000-mile area "will not be terminated until the enemy strength is wiped out."

Trading in chemicals, especially solvents, has quieted appreciably in the last week or more and traders yesterday attributed the slower market to several influences. They admitted that the WPB crackdown upon an alleged "black market" transaction last week had shut off a number of offers, but they added that the various restrictions upon inventories and upon production of non-essential civilian goods have reduced demand.

Sales of equipment trust certificates, which were postponed because of an order of the War Production Board on last Saturday, which halted the construction of railway locomotives and cars, are expected to be resumed as a result of conferences between the board and the transport industry committee.

TRENTON, April 10 -- Declaring that a serious breakdown in motor vehicular transportation in New Jersey might occur even before the Legislature meets again next Monday, the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners urged today the enactment of legislation giving it authority to press into service every available bus to meet the impending crisis.

Charles Evans Hughes is 80 today. It would be impertinent to give formal compliment to one whose intellectual and moral gifts are written as clearly as his career is upon the minds of his countrymen. Is there a more enviable American? The smoke of partisanship has long died away from about him.

Members of the City Council voted unanimously yesterday to change the name of East River Drive to MacArthur Drive in honor of the hero of the Philippines who is now Commander in Chief of the United Nations forces in the Southwestern Pacific area.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 10 (AP) -- Although the Grand Circuit schedule has been reduced by the government taking over the grounds of three State Fairs, there will be at least ten tracks in operation this year, Secretary Will Gahagan said today.

Only minor differences were shown in recommendations for color fastness labelling rules submitted to the Federal Trade Commission yesterday on behalf of several groups. The commission held a hearing on color-fastness standards at the Hotel Pennsylvania, attended by nearly 200 representatives of manufacturing, distributing and consumer groups.

Commas, apostrophes and the word whom bother Janet Aiken. Dr. Aiken teaches Shakespeare, writing and the English language at Brooklyn College and Columbia University; she is the co-author of a book called "Psychology of English," and she is the author of a book on ethics, "Surely Goodness," published yesterday.
UPPERVILLE, Va., April 10 (AP) -- Sixty-four show horses were sold at the Whitney-Allen dispersal sale today at Mrs. Mary Elizabeth Whitney's Llangollen Estate, the sales amounting to $23,837.
MELBOURNE, Australia, April 10 -- The fate of Luzon and Bataan was sealed just before 1 P.M. on Dec. 8, some ten hours after the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- President Roosevelt confirmed reports today that Administration officials were drafting a new anti-inflation campaign, which is reported to include still higher taxes, wage controls, profit restrictions, additional credit controls and a more general exercise of price-fixing powers.

Heinz von Lepel, a dealer in the diathermy machines which are credited by some experts with an ability to send code messages by short-wave radio, has been seized by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents and taken to Ellis Island as an enemy alien, it was learned yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 10--''Scorched Earth," a screen story by Leo Mittler, Victor Trivas and Guy Endore about the Russian defense against the German invasion, was bought today by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer as a vehicle for Robert Young.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Voluntary registration of women between the ages of 18 and 65 is being seriously considered in connection with the total mobilization of the country's man power, President Roosevelt revealed today at his press conference.

Sixteen of the nation's outstanding chess players, including Samuel Reshevsky of Boston, the national champion, last night began play in the fourth biennial tournament of the United States Chess Federation at the Hotel Astor.

TRENTON, April 10 -- State Controller Homer C. Zink disapproved after a hearing today payment of a $5,533 "grocery" bill for the Governor's Summer cottage at Sea Girt last August after Augustus Giunco, co-owner of a Sea Girt market had testified liquor and beer delivered during the month had been billed as crates of oranges and West Virginia hams at the request of George Milligan, the executive's butler.

On April 11, 1842, Samuel Bangs, soldier and printer, after hard labor at the hand press produced "in a one-room shack" the first number of the four-page Galveston News. In ten days the Battle of San Jacinto effectually remembered the Alamo. Though Galveston had to wait some time for her glory as "the Oleander City," she was full of delicacy.

John W. Hanes, former Under-Secretary of the Treasury and this year's chairman of the Greater New York Fund, announced yesterday that contributions of $1,581,149 had been received in the campaign for $5,000,000 that began three weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- The Ways and Means Committee heard new protests today against a sales tax along with objections to any changes in the present tax exemption features of pension trust funds.

This is a lot different from running a busy boxing office and booking boxers for bouts all over the country. But the Army has the best set-up in the world for getting men in shape for the big fight and boxing trainers can take a lesson from drill lieutenants who know how to condition raw recruits.
Leighton McCarthy, the Canadian Minister, and Mrs. McCarthy have arrived from Washington and are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Emphasizing the importance of the full development of this hemisphere's resources as a guarantee of its security, Dr. Ezequiel Padilla, Mexican Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, invited American business yesterday to make "just investments" in Mexico and aid in its development.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Further investigations into contracts and agreements between the Defense Plant Corporation and Basic Magnesium, Inc., were predicted today as the controversy grew between Jesse H. Jones, Secretary of Commerce and chairman of the Federal agency, and Senator Bunker over the company's $63,000,000 war project in Nevada.
Every baseball fan entering the Polo Ground this season on a complimentary ticket or pass will be obliged to purchase a 25-cent war stamp.
LONDON, April 10 -- The principal change in the stock market today was a setback in the oil shares. Burmah and Iranians lost 7 1/2d, Shell 103d and Ultramars 1s 6d.

On unmistakable evidence that a goodly number of service men like to read, the American Library Association, the American Red Cross and the USO last January undertook a Victory Book campaign. Greater New York was asked to give 2,000,000 books for men in the armed services.
LONDON, April 10 (AP) -- The Admiralty issued the following communique today:

SAN FRANCISCO, April 10 -As Japanese truck farmers abandoned or prepared to give up much fertile farm land in California to go to assembly centres for evacuees, the agricultural division of the Wartime Civil Control Administration reported today that aliens of non-enemy countries, including Mexico, were eligible to receive special farm loans if they wanted to take over the tracts.

After James V. Forrestal, Under-Secretary of the Navy, had declared here last night that what had been yielded in Bataan "shall be retaken," Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board asserted that even Washington officials had begun to get thrills over the figures of war materials rolling from assembly lines.

GALVESTON, April 10 -- The Galveston News will mark its 100th anniversary tomorrow with a special centenary edition. The oldest news chronicler in the Lone Star State will join a company of 146 other newspapers with a century or more of uninterrupted publication.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 10 -- Another unit of Marshal Erwin Rommel's Afrika Korps advanced into Cyrenaica's No Man's Land yesterday to take up positions around Tengeder and complete the new and fairly unified German line consisting of strong points stretching south from a point about midway between Tmimi and Gazala.

The brass hats of the Amateur Athletic Union provide such shining targets that few can resist a temptation to take a shot at them. Yet, to give the devil his due, the blasts fired at the A.A.U. in the case of the Maryland selectee, Marty Passaglia, were entirely misdirected.

In his letter of last Saturday, E.R. Jessen appeared to be misinformed and not up to par in his knowledge of basketball when he tried to belittle the national invitation basketball tournament in New York and the local quintets.

State and Federal income tax inquiries loomed yesterday into the allegedly "swollen bank and brokerage accounts" of the policemen accused by Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen's two extraordinary grand juries of participating in an annual graft of $1,000,000 to protect a city-wide $100,000,000 gambling racket.

The Manhattan Life Insurance Company, in its ninety-first annual report to policyholders released for publication today by J.P. Fordyce, president, announced a new high in new paid-for insurance. In 1941 new life insurance written totaled $20,155,381, an increase of 13.92 per cent over the previous year.

A Spring Dance, devised especially to pay tribute to young men in the armed forces stationed at Mitchel Field, Floyd Bennett Field Governors Island and other nearby camps, as well as to several visiting British service men, was !given last night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton.

GALVESTON, April 10 -- The Galveston News will mark its 100th anniversary tomorrow with a special centenary edition. The oldest news chronicler in the Lone Star State will join a company of 146 other newspapers with a century or more of uninterrupted publication.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 10 -- The air forces of both the United Nations and the Japanese are steadily mounting in the Australian area, according to statements today by Lieut. Gen. George H. Brett, Chief of the United Nations Air Forces, and Australian Air Minister A.S. Drakeford.

In his letter of last Saturday, E.R. Jessen appeared to be misinformed and not up to par in his knowledge of basketball when he tried to belittle the national invitation basketball tournament in New York and the local quintets.

State and Federal income tax inquiries loomed yesterday into the allegedly "swollen bank and brokerage accounts" of the policemen accused by Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen's two extraordinary grand juries of participating in an annual graft of $1,000,000 to protect a city-wide $100,000,000 gambling racket.

The Manhattan Life Insurance Company, in its ninety-first annual report to policyholders released for publication today by J.P. Fordyce, president, announced a new high in new paid-for insurance. In 1941 new life insurance written totaled $20,155,381, an increase of 13.92 per cent over the previous year.

A Spring Dance, devised especially to pay tribute to young men in the armed forces stationed at Mitchel Field, Floyd Bennett Field Governors Island and other nearby camps, as well as to several visiting British service men, was !given last night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton.

The Citizens Budget Commission has called attention to a bill now before Governor Lehman which would compel New York City and every other municipality in the State to appoint only uniformed members of the police force to positions in the operation of police communications systems.

Around 2 o'clock yesterday morning Mrs. Alfred Kraft turned restlessly in bed in her East Flatbush home at 534 East Fifty-first Street in Brooklyn. Hail picked at the panes and wind thrust viciously at the eaves.

Women fearful of the future of manufactured beauty aids will be glad to learn that domestic sources of essential perfume oils are rapidly being developed on a large scale. According to Percy Magnus, president of the importing firm of Magnus, Mabee Reynard, thousands of acres are yielding satisfactory replacements for previously imported oils.

Led by Miss Grace Uhthoff, the Hunter College team triumphed by 9 to 0 over both St. Elizabeth College and Brooklyn College as the fourteenth annual women's intercollegiate fencing championships got under way last night on the Hunter strips.

Marking the first decline for any week thus far this year, retail trade here this week dipped well under the 1941 figures. Department store executives estimated the drop for their type of establishment at about 10 per cent, with a larger decrease indicated for apparel specialty shops.

The tenth division of the American Women's Voluntary Services is sponsoring a large cocktail party and entertainment to be given this afternoon at El Morocco. Several hundred tickets have been sold for the fete, proceeds from which will aid the organization in its wartime work.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- A War Department communique based on reports up to 10 A.M. today said:
The importance of the plane in modern war was again emphasized by yesterday's news that another proud ship bearing the White Ensign was sunk by Japanese carrier based planes in the Indian Ocean.
If you're watching a major league baseball game when an air raid comes, don't go away. You probably will be sitting in the best bomb shelter in the neighborhood, and you might miss part of the game.

Councilman Joseph E. Kinsley, chairman of the Council Finance Committee, introduced a resolution at yesterday's Council meeting calling for an investigation by five Councilmen of the contract between the Dock Department and Jay Downer, architect, whose fee on the new Idlewild Airport in Queens was the subject of a dispute between Mr. Kinsley and Mayor La Guardia on Thursday.
Like most Brooklynites, I usually will defend to the death any actions taken by the Dodgers. However, for once I protest.

The audience roared its final approval and the last harmonies of "Auld Lang Syne" faded into the Madison Square Garden rafters as James Reynolds -- "Jimmy to my pals" -- finally sank deep into the only soft chair in his office, and spoke about the Big Show's air raid service.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 10 -- Thirty-eight more stockholders of the defunct Westchester Title and Trust Company of this city settled today the claims filed against them by creditors of the company. The settlements added $211,242 to the $368,900 previously given by other defendants.

CHICAGO, April 10 -- Prices of wheat held within a range of about 1 cent a bushel today, fluctuating in an erratic manner. An early break carried the market down, but when short covering developed offerings were light and a strong rally followed, with the close at gains of 1/8 to 3/8 cent.

ALBANY, April 10 -- Three junior bank examiners have been appointed to begin their duties on April 16, the State Banking Department announced today. The compensation is $10 a day. The appointees are Edward V. Riekert, 93-03 104th Street, and John F. Sullivan, 91-14 111th Street, Richmond Hill, Queens, and Alexander R. Billington, 93-34 225th Street, Queens Village.

On the same day that she was chosen as the country's No. 1 contract bridge player for 1941, Mrs. Alexander M. Sobel of New York took top place last night among thirty-six invited masters playing in the masters' individual championship tournament at the Park Central Hotel.

NORFOLK, Va., April 11 -- Mrs. Desanka Mohorovicic, wife of an attache of the Yugoslav Consulate in New York, named her eight-pound baby son, born in a tossing lifeboat off the Atlantic Coast on March 29, after their rescue ship, the destroyer Jesse Roper.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C. -- The resort section of the North Carolina Sandhills is now a mass of blossoms and the dogwood and wistaria are in full bloom. At the Southern Pines Country Club two tournaments are slated for the next two weeks.

IF you saw four non-newsreel-looking cameras and crew discreetly ensconced at the Yankee Stadium during the world series last year, those were the first harbingers of what will soon be Samuel Goldwyn's picture on Lou Gehrig, titled "The Pride of the Yankees."

Three of the figures in the department store show window are dummies; the fourth is a corpse. Lark St. Dennis, who is window shopping with the young man who wants to marry her, is the first to make the discovery. Lark's Uncle Dan is the chief of police, and he is easily persuaded to let his niece play detective by pretending to be an employe of the store.

TAKE Mr. Steinbeck on his own terms. In "The Moon Is Down," which finally turned up at the Martin Beck last week, he is making a confession of faith in a style of practicable reality. Using a small mining town as his laboratory, he has written the story of a brilliantly organized military invasion that gradually breaks down in the face of elusive resistance by free men who are ingenious and angry.

Registration of applicants under sugar rationing regulations will be held from 3 to 6 P.M. on April 28 and 29 in high and junior high schools throughout the city, Lee S. Buckingham, acting Federal rationing administrator, announced yesterday.

Lieutenant Charles O. Dannhauser of the Twelfth Division, Brooklyn, the highest ranking officer of thirty-two members of the Police Department accused last week of participation in a $100,000,000 city-wide gambling ring, applied for retirement from the force on Thursday, twenty-four hours after his name had been coupled with the ring in presentments handed up by two Brooklyn grand juries, Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen disclosed yesterday.

The skills and the experience possessed by an estimated 100,000 college alumnae in the metropolitan area are soon to be card catalogued in an endeavor to bring a greater proportion of them into civilian defense posts. The work of collecting information on this large section of potential volunteers has been undertaken by the College and University Women's Center, in which 100 college clubs and alumnae groups are represented.

ATLANTA, April 11 (AP) -- Stripped of their rifles by a War Department order, Georgia State Guardsmen will spring up to repel any attack with "baseball bats, shotguns, rocks or anything else," Commander Lindley W. Camp said tonight.

North Carolina will celebrate the 150th anniversary of the founding of its State capital from April 26 through 29. Although one of the original thirteen colonies, North Carolina had no permanent capital until 1792, when the settlement named for Sir Walter Raleigh was chosen as the seat of government.

HONOLULU, April 11 (U.P.) -- The defenders of Bataan built three airdromes for the American planes they thought would arrive to aid them, Jeff J. McNamee, a Navy administrative assistant, revealed today.

STAND at a grocery counter for a few minutes as the customers cluster around giving their orders and you are likely to hear a dozen interpretations of the recent WPB order which is causing so much concern over that typically American convenience -- canned food.

The 71-year-old gentleman, resplendent in his long red coat, unblemished white vest and shiny black topper, would have never known that yesterday was a special occasion for him until Roland Butler, the Big Show's imaginative press agent, handed him a bottle of wine and remarked: "Happy anniversary, Fred."
CHICAGO, April 11 -- Baseball awaits the opening next Tuesday of the most momentous and what may be the most interesting campaign in its history.

The Treasury's revival of its recommendation for the adoption of the mandatory joint income tax return of married couples has evoked, on the part of both sides, some criticism which does not help to clarify the issue. The proposal affects the wife because her income is superimposed on the income of the husband in a single return.

C.V.R. THOMPSON, author of "I Lost My English Accent" and "Trousers Will Be Worn," is at work on a book which he hopes will remove some of our misconceptions about the English and some of the Englishman's misconceptions about us, and he is anxious to receive letters from various parts of the United States answering certain questions.

TO a symposium on "The Bases of Artistic Creation," published by Rutgers University Press, Maxwell Anderson contributes an essay on "The Basis of Artistic Creation in Literature." As a playwright Mr. Anderson confines his discussion, which first appeared, in slightly different form, in the Sunday pages of THE TIMES, to the theatre.

THIS is a snug and cozy story of a plump kindly little woman whose delight was to lavish comfort and cheer on the people about her. Her tidy little home "like a tea caddy" was five miles from an English village, and it brimmed over with such homely, happy comforts as open fires, garden flowers, hot teas, chicken pies and simmering stews.

The World War last week needed four oceans, all the continents and a number of islands in which to stretch its terrible limbs. From Murmansk to Darwin, from Malta to the Philippines and Ceylon, from the Mediterranean to the Bay of Bengal, there was fighting. As usual, there were battles along the great Russian line, or which we know so little and for which we hope so much.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Eventual organization of the Board of Economic Warfare into three major divisions -- export, import and economic warfare -- was forecast here today following announcement Thursday that the board has established an Office of Export in which is grouped all functions and responsibility for the control of goods leaving the United States.

TRENTON, N.J., April 11 -- The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, one of a dozen light bulb manufacturers named defendant by the anti-trust division of the Department of Justice in a monopoly suit, accepted wide restraints sought by the government in the litigation in a consent decree filed today in the United States District Court here.

Delivering last year the first $1,000,000,000 of war orders of close to $15,000,000,000, the automobile industry and its suppliers had record sales and earnings before taxes in 1941, and for the tire companies even the profits of 1929 were surpassed after a record tax.

Racing officials from all parts of the country will meet here this week in an effort to arrive at some concrete plan for raising money to be turned over to war charities, it was disclosed last night by Herbert Bayard Swope, chairman of the Turf Committee of America.

ALBANY, April 11 -- Governor Lehman vetoed today the Mitchell bill appropriating $250,000 to aid up-State milk farmers who are suffering from shortage of hay due to the 1941 drought. The measure would have permitted the State Commissioner of Agriculture to allow up to $10 a bale for the purchase of hay to farmers needing it.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- Basing its expectations on the size of the Easter holiday crowds, Atlantic City is looking forward to a busy Spring and Summer season.

CLEVELAND, April 11 -- The Giants headed for home tonight, their annual Spring series with the Indians at an end. Mel Ott's squad and the Clevelanders again were prevented from playing today and the final contest, scheduled for tomorrow, also was called off.

May I call to your attention a very serious problem that we face on the Pacific Coast. Perhaps you in the East are fully aware of the situation of the Japanese here, although I have not seen any comment in the Eastern papers.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The War Production Board ordered a stop today of all production of medium and heavy trucks for civilian use after existing quotas have been completed. This will turn over another large segment of the automotive industry to war work.

Nearly 350 Catholic high school teachers, representing fifty-five secondary schools on the Eastern seaboard, attended the first annual conference for commercial teachers conducted yesterday by the Fordham University School of Education to promote and coordinate the teaching of commercial subjects in Catholic high schools.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 11 -- The Bulgarian Cabinet resigned today after the refusal of a majority to approve Reichsfuehrer Hitler's program for the Balkan nation -- believed by diplomatic quarters here to call for active war participation against Russia or Turkey, or both.

OF late there have been interesting charts exposed in the public prints -- some the work of single scientists, others a group production by registered experts -- under the rather misleading heading of "How the Teams Will Finish." It would be closer to the truth if such charts were exposed to view under the more modest heading "How the Teams Will Not Finish."

NEW ORLEANS, April 11 (AP) -- The Crescent Club of Tulsa, Okla., with some of the finest grapplers of Oklahoma A. and M. competing for it, won four of ten titles and took two runners-up places for 28 points and the National A.A.U. team wrestling championship tonight. The New Orleans Athletic Club was second.

ONLY one new play has been brought to London in the last fortnight. It is Samson Raphaelson's "Skylark," which seems to be going to have a success at the Duchess Theatre with Constance Cummings in the leading role.

THIS Easter-tide London had three performances of Bach's St. Matthew Passion. First in the field was the choir of Southwark Cathedral; then came a performance by the Bach Choir in the Albert Hall and finally the oratorio was given by the St. Michael Singers in the church of St. Michael, Cornhill.

An editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES of March 22, in commenting on plans for hospitalization payments, repeats some errors which are being widely circulated concerning the position of the Social Security Board, and the conclusions reached rest upon some misapprehensions.

Stocks closed fractionally easier yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange in the second dullest session of this year. Volume was only 142,560 shares, and only 456 issues were traded. Of these, 205 fell, 101 rose and 150 were unchanged.

An article was published in the April 10 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES, under the title "United States Recognition Denied." Since that article may give rise to misunderstandings, I feel it my duty to call your attention to the following:

THE McNeills are at it again, and that should be enough to cause any detective story fan to sit up and take notice. As you probably remember, Jeffrey McNeill is an assistant professor of surgery in a university, and Anne is his wife.

When Police Lieutenant Charles E. Field of the Police Academy saw two men fighting in the Borough Hall station of the I.R.T. in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon he placed both under arrest on a charge of disorderly conduct. But it developed later that one was a pickpocket and the other his intended victim.

Panama has recently revised its system of university credits to facilitate the transfer of students to North American universities without the formality of a special examination, according to Dr. Catalino Arrocha Graell, dean of the University of Panama.

Leave it to deer to keep part of the State's research staff busy these days. Damage done to farmers' crops and orchards in past years has furnished the impetus in studies now being made in New York to control the feeding habits of deer.

Advertising and marketing students at the New York University School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance are bringing their term reports to life in a unique educational experiment devised by Professor Dale Houghton, in which various aspects of marketing are presented through playlets.

WE are only at the beginning of a new wave of war books about that special kind of revolutionary warfare which floes on underground in occupied countries against the Nazi invaders. Judging from William Woods's and similar novels, it almost looks as if the little starved, enslaved people of Norway, Poland, France and Czechoslovakia would win the war for us, a thought in which there is a good deal of comfort and consequently danger.

The third of four panel discussions on "The Child in Wartime," sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES, will take place at 8:15 P.M. Wednesday in THE NEW YORK TIMES Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street. Dr. Frank J. O'Brien, Associate Superintendent of Schools, will be the chairman.

OF our many war problems one of the most acute is the need for graduate trained nurses. There are nurses now with American troops in Ireland, in Iceland and in Bataan, with fox holes dug beside their sleeping cots; there were four on Wake Island when the Japs got there.

A group of debutantes has just been organized for active war-relief effort to assist in a special Spring campaign to be conducted for United China Relief. With Miss Charlotte Van Vechten as chairman, the debutante committee will sponsor a series of teas, beginning the last week of the month and continuing through May.

The airplane crash in which Gillian Moore dies is called an accident, but there are those who know that it was deliberately planned. Moore was the owner of Dromore Sanitarium in Vermont, close to the Canadian border.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, April 11 -- In a special decree signed by Acting President Ramon S Castillo, the government today ordered the expulsion from Argentine territory or internment of fifty-nine persons as alleged "Communist agitators."

IN reference to Mr. Ehrmann's recent letter: I saw his play ("Under This Roof") opening night in Boston. I was a part of that audience, which, according to Mr. Ehrmann, found so much merit in his play.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 11 -- In its struggle against the Quisling authorities, the Norwegian clergy has won the first round, a report from Oslo said tonight. Major Vidkun Quisling, Nazi-supported Premier, did not dare press his ultimatum to the clergy, which expired at 2 P.M. today, and it would seem that "he is stalling for time," according to the Oslo report.

The 1942 appeal of New York Catholic Charities for funds to meet the increased demands that the war is expected to make on its 200 health and welfare agencies will be opened formally today with a pontifical high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral at 11 A.M. Archbishop Francis J. Spellman will preside and will preach the sermon.

A Spring entertainment will be given at the Cosmopolitan Club on the afternoon of April 22 for the benefit of the Art Workers Club for Women. Mrs. Reginald B. Lanier will sing and there will be Spanish dances by Lolita and Chatita Tovar.

A mutiny by twelve Chinese seamen, quelled only after their captain had shot and killed one of them aboard a United Nations freighter at a Brooklyn pier, and a similar but less violent outbreak later by Chinese at Stapleton, S.I., resulted yesterday from a conflict between the immigration laws and the desire of the sailors to come ashore.
ITHACA, April 11 -- Cornell University will initiate an emergency program this Summer in an effort to meet the heavy demand for men with special training in physics for war purposes.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Price ceilings imposed by the Office of Price Administration on radios, phonographs, washing and ironing machines and domestic cooking and heating stoves and ranges apply to the prices charged by individual dealers for the same models of each appliance on March 19, when the ceiling became effective, the OPA announced in telegrams to about 500 manufacturers and trade associations who have been asked to disseminate the information.

THE Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo tomorrow opens the second week of the Hurok "Season of Ballet" at the Metropolitan Opera House. As originally planned, this was also to have been the final week of the season, but public response has apparently been so satisfactory that a third week is to be added, beginning Monday, April 20.

PITTSBURGH, April 11 -- Just as it did a quarter of a century ago, the Salvation Army is accompanying the new A.E.F. to Europe to serve the troops, to death, if necessary, Miss Evangeline Booth, former head of the organization, said today.

It is very satisfying to make the rounds to see some of the unpainted furniture in stores about town. You'll see great quantities of inexpensive, well-designed furniture that, used with a little imagination, makes for immensely attractive small apartments and homes.

CHICAGO, April 11 (AP) -- Scoring two runs on a passed ball and two walks with the bases loaded in the seventh inning, the Cubs evened the Spring city series with the White Sox in the first game played locally today.

Vacations by motor car will be close to home this year, the American Automobile Association predicts. Aimless driving and extra miles will be cut entirely out of the traveler's itinerary, it is contended, though travel of real recreational value is encouraged as essential by Federal spokesmen. So instead of "seeing America first" during war years, car owners planning vacation trips may well accent seeing their States first.

BROADCASTS from the homes of famous American authors of the past have been the special feature of Ted Malone's radio book talks during the past two years. "American Pilgrimage" collects sixteen of these localized and personalized lectures and expands them with additional material belonging to the "pilgrimage" idea.

LANCASTER, Pa. -- The pious Amish, whose customs have been maintained unchanged for centuries, have suddenly become models for the nation's consumers. Their self-denial and avoidance of "luxury goods" fits in the new national pattern amazingly well.

LONDON, April 11 -- Besides the pending budget of the Chancellor of the Exchequer, from which the major limitations of Britain's civilian consumption of commodities is expected to come, the increased Japanese activity by air and sea in the Indian Ocean is attracting great attention in the British commodity trade.

No people on earth have felt the torture of war more terribly than the Chinese; none have fought more bravely against odds as heavy; none are in direr need of tangible evidence of American friendship. China has fought without truce for more than four and a half years.
NEW DELHI, India, April 11 (AP) -- The text of a press statement by Sir Stafford Cripps on Indian negotiations:
NEW DELHI, India, April 11 (AP) -- The text of the All-India Congress party's rejection of the British proposals carried by Sir Stafford Cripps follows:

GALESBURG, Ill., April 11 -- Blanket graduation requirements are a thing of the past at Knox College, where the faculty has just adopted a system of all-out individualization in which each student's course of study will be tailor-made to fit his own professional aims and aptitudes.

With the privilege of free franking recently granted men in the service, a new field opens to the collector of war mail. There will no doubt be countless varieties of stampless covers -- soldier's sailor's and marine's mail -- from local camps, far-away bases, foreign ports and ships.

The Kentucky Derby candidate, Apache, owned by the Jockey Club's chairman, William Woodward, and trained by the veteran Jim Fitzsimmons, made his return to competition yesterday at Jamaica and impressed 26,845 spectators with a winning race.

CORREGIDOR, April 7 (Delayed) -- More bombs have been falling on Corregidor than any other place in the world, in proportion to area. Side roads of this small island fortress are a picture of No-Man's Land. Trees, stripped by explosions, seem to outline a cold Winter sky. Shell craters are everywhere.

The twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the National Jewish Welfare Board, parent organization of the 328 Jewish Centers and Young Men's Hebrew Associations and a member agency of the USO, will be marked by a three-day conference at the Hotel Commodore beginning Saturday.

LONDON, April 11 -- Various speakers at a large meeting today organized by the National Council for Civil Liberties in Support of Freedom of the Press criticized the "antic" of Home Secretary Herbert Morris in invoking Defense Regula tion 2-D, whereby without a court trial the government can suppress any newspaper or other publication that it deems obstructive to the country's war effort.

In wise garden planning, vines can no more be grouped into a class than can trees. As with trees, there are giants and dwarfs among them; rampant and delicate growers, each of value but only when knowingly placed. Too often the inexperienced gardener will plant a wisteria because he likes wisteria, not because there exists a suitable location for it.

Yachting, instead of being regarded as a frivolous pastime of millionaires, is hailed this season as a patriotic gesture. A new slogan might well be "Go Boating and Help Win the War." There is ample authority on all sides for this attitude.

MR. SMITH, the air raid warden, found he had twined his legs into a tight knot underneath the hard school-room desk. He was chewing his pencil and staring at two words that leaped from the printed examination form.

IN a shipload of Gold Star mothers. Europe-bound a decade ago to visit the graves of their sons in the peaceful French countryside, the Army Quartermaster General found forty-five who could not speak English. For them he provided German interpreters, for they were German-born residents who had lost sons fighting in the American Expeditionary Forces against the "Fatherland."
MELBOURNE, Australia, April 11 -- President Manuel L. Quezon of the Philippine Commonwealth said in a statement today, issued at United Nations Headquarters:

In the greatest "realignment" of the Police Department's high command since Mayor La Guardia assumed office more than eight years ago, Police Commissioner Valentine announced the transfer last night of ten of the sixteen inspectors commanding the uniformed forces in the five boroughs.

PEOPLE go right on falling in love in wartime, and Spring remains the nuptial season. But planning a wartime wedding is a nerveracking, uncertain business. Dates are set and changed as leaves are postponed or advanced. Young men arrive in town from camp or convoy duty and announce blithely that they'd like to be married tomorrow but will compromise on the day after.

In connection with the paragraph accompanying the picture material for "Women With Wings" in the Magazine Section of March 29, may we suggest that THE TIMES note for the record that the Civil Air Patrol of the Office of Civilian Defense is not in any sense a women's organization.

Some of the discouraging news of last week came not from Bataan, where the United States suffered one of the worst physical reverses in its military history, not from the Bay of Bengal, where the Japanese, by new victories, were clearing the sea road to India, but from London.

Norway will never give up the fight against the Nazis until victory is won for herself and the United Nations, Crown Prince Olaf promised 2,700 of his countrymen last night at a victory rally that taxed the capacity of Carnegie Hall.

Wartime demands upon college students and recent graduates which have precipitated them into positions of responsibility in industry and the armed forces have necessitated a revision of teaching methods along the lines of developing qualities of personal leadership and the "ability to get things done and to get along with people," in addition to academic training, according to Dr. Herman Feldman, dean of the City College School of Business and Civic Administration.
Theatre parties continue as a popular means of augmenting the maintenance funds of various philanthropic organizations. Several have been arranged for the near future.

NONE of us on the long line outside the big munitions factory spoke of the war. There were seventy-five women. We talked to each other about the possibility of getting hired that day and making decent money. That was the important thing.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The decision of the War Labor Board in the dispute between the Walker-Turner Company of Plainfield, N.J., and its C.I.O. union employes enlarged the Wagner act, diminished the guarantees of the Bill of Rights, avoided the formulation of a fundamental war labor-industry policy and left the board free to reverse this ruling on the same basic issue in future cases if it finds a different set of facts.

University evening colleges, with their largest all-time total enrollments, are making a great contribution to America's victory effort by gearing their educational programs to meet the exigencies of all-out war.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Inclusion in the impending $7,600,000,000 tax bill of a voluntary savings program for individuals and corporations, to curb present inflationary spirals and at the same time build up backlogs and cushions post-war readjustments, was urged today by Senator George of Georgia, chairman of the Senate Committee on Finance.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, April 11 -- More than two months have passed since all South American countries, except Argentina and Chile, broke all relations with the Axis. Little or nothing has happened in that time to incline Argentina to recede from the position assumed at the Rio de Janeiro conference.

Unseasonable weather last week, plus the fact that many stores delayed after-Easter clearances until later in the month, were responsible for a decrease in apparel orders, according to the weekly report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. Nevertheless, there was a continuation of Fall and Winter purchasing wherever desirable opportunities arose.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 11 -- More than a hundred students from twenty-five Eastern colleges will gather in Princeton April 24 for a two-day conference on "New Strategies for the Post-War World," sponsored jointly by the American Whig-Cliosophic Society, undergraduate debating organization, and the International Student Service of New York City.

Passengers on United Air Lines planes operating between San Francisco and Los Angeles look at the names of the captain and the first officer posted on the door opening into the cockpit and usually concluded the craft is being handled by brothers.

When the gardener desires to obtain a few additional plants of some shrub, rose or perennial he can often employ to advantage the ancient practice of layering. Layering is a simple and satisfactory means of increasing the stock of favorite plants.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- A story of increasing difficulty in caring for Bataan's wounded before the fall of the peninsula has been released here by the American Red Cross through the publication of excerpts from two reports sent to headquarters by Catherine L. Nau, Red Cross Field Director attached to Field Hospital No. 2 on Bataan.

The general shutdown of manufacturing in a wide list of consumers' durable goods by the end of May, combined with the War Production Board restriction of inventories in distributing and dealer channels to sixty days, will force many distributors out of business before the end of the year, according to opinions expressed here last week by executives in the field.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Constitution Hall, headquarters for the Daughters of the American Revolution, boasts an air raid shelter large enough to care comfortably for the ninety-six building employes or, in case of an emergency, more than 500 people.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Comdr. Harold P. Smith, former skipper of the destroyer Stewart which was demolished in a Java drydock to prevent its falling into Japanese hands, received today the award of the Navy Cross for meritorious conduct in the Battle of Bali.
BERLIN April 11 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 11 -- The University of Pennsylvania baseball team defeated Navy, 11 to 8, today in a game marked by a ninth-inning home run for Art McQuillen, seventeen bases on balls, a balk and two hit batsmen.

PARE LORENTZ, the former chief of the United States Film Service, who produced "The River," "The Plow that Broke the Plains" and "The Fight for Life," has begun work on his first commercial entertainment feature, "Name, Age and Occupation," for RKO.

Despite rumors and alarms, camera equipment is still available, according to evidence contained in a special fifty-two page buying guide of cameras and supplies listed in the May Directory issue of Popular Photography, the magazine's fifth anniversary number.

The new little pepper plants had at last grown tall enough to be transplanted into the garden. Then one morning I discovered a great many of them snipped off short just above the ground. I remembered that the same thing had happened a year ago and practically ruined my crop.

SCIENTIST: Eight years ago, in London, the Congress of Anthropological and Ethnological Sciences heard a distinguished British authority dispute the racial theories of Nazi Germany. The speaker was J.B.S. Haldane, Professor of Genetics at the University of London and versatile author of numerous popular books on scientific subjects.

Robert Kaplan, Abraham Lincoln High co-captain, last night annexed top honors in the Amateur Fencers League of America's fifth interscholastic individual foil tournament conducted on the strips of Washington Irving High School. The A.F.L.A. staged the competition in cooperation with the P.S.A.L.

War has always brought to the forefront woman's capacity to work. Millions of women were employed in industry in the last war; many more will be needed in this war. But does the fact that we are now considering voluntary registration of women up to 65 years, as revealed by the President last week, indicate that we are letting down the age barriers?

ON April 24 and 25 in Cincinnati, Eugene Goossens and the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra will give the first performance of a concerto for voice and orchestra by John W. Haussermann Jr. This score was composed in the year from March, 1941, to this March.

Drastic revision of the present system of general licenses for exports may be expected as a result of the new policy on requirements for individual licenses just announced by the Board of Economic Warfare, exporters asserted last week.

Of the many entertainments arranged this season in the interests of the men serving in the armed forces, one that has received wide popular support in its advance preparations is the Red, White and Blue Ball to be given Friday night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton.

THE disappearance of illustrations from the English novel is deplored by V.S. Pritchett in the course of a New Statesman article on Smollett. He regrets this especially as involving a loss to literary criticism. For one of the obligations of the critic is to possess himself of the eyes with which a novelist's contemporaries read him, and this the good illustrator helped him to do.

Well-informed retailers prepared last week to accept an over-all price ceiling as a practical certainty in the near future. All doubt that such a ceiling was imminent disappeared and attention turned to possible steps to soften as much as possible the impact of this development upon retail distribution.

BERLIN, April 11 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command announced today that the Russians had lost seventy-two tanks and that twenty-nine others had been put out of action in the recent Red Army attack on the Kerch Peninsula in the Crimea.

The Victory Garden Council of Queens and Nassau Counties has planned a Victory garden course for the residents of Flushing, Bayside, Douglaston and Little Neck. It will be given at St. George's Parish House, Main Street and Thirty-eighth Avenue, Flushing.

Efforts of women's groups to improve their understanding of the good-neighbor policy lend greater significance to their programs for Pan-American Day, which will be observed on Tuesday. While study courses and lectures on South American affairs have multiplied in recent years, their number is likely to increase still further as a result of the formation of the All-America Friendship League.
