OBERLIN, Ohio, April 11 -- The department of mathematics of the University of Toronto won the first prize of $400 in the fifth annual William Lowell Putnam mathematical competition held on March 7, according to an announcement by Professor W.D. Cairns, secretary-treasurer of the Mathematical Association of America and formerly head of Oberlin College's' department of mathematics.

IF you look at Alfred Hitchcock obliquely, which is the way he likes to look at things, he appears absolutely the same from any angle -- as nearly spheroid as a man can be. Push him gently and he might rock on his axis like a humpty-dumpty.
LONDON, April 11 -- Lord Davies added his voice today to those that are demanding that Great Britain create a second front in Western Europe, urging that it be done this year.

There has been belatedly brought to my attention a statement in THE NEW YORK TIMES of March 8, made by Father Thorning, based upon a complete misconception of the activity carried on by the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs in the matter of the exchange of students between the United States and the Latin-American republics.

The goal of the Americas in the present war is social security for all as the foundation stone of an enduring peace, Nelson A. Rockefeller, Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs, told the national conference of the American Association for Social Security at its concluding session yesterday at the Hotel Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- President Roosevelt, participating in a program to raise a $7,000,000 relief fund for China, said tonight that "China has paid in blood, tears and treasure as high a price as a people can possibly pay for the freedom in which it believes."

The thirtieth annual congress of the national Society of Daughters of the Union, 1861-65, opens tomorrow at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Mrs. Louise Ward Watkins of Pasadena, Calif., whose three-year term of office as president-general closes with the meeting, will preside.

A letter published on your editorial page of March 8 contains certain misleading and erroneous statements about the Blackfeet Tribe and economic conditions on the Blackfeet Indian Reservation today. The letter is signed by Lincoln Billedeaux.

DETROIT, April 11 (U.P.) -- All favorites advanced tonight in the third round of the national table tennis tournament, with Lou Pagliaro of New York protecting his two-year record of victories by trouncing Bill Ablin, Chicago, 19 -- 21, 21 -- 14, 21 -- 18, 21 -- 8.

Major league baseball, having managed to advance this far in its efforts to carry on in pretty much the same fashion that it has in other years, embarks this week upon a championship campaign fraught with uncertainty, but not lacking in any of the essentials needed to assure a colorful and spectacular season.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- The Homestead Hotel at Virginia Hot Springs has opened to the public for the 176th season. At the request of the government, the hotel played "host" to the Japanese diplomatic corps during the Winter months, but within two hours of their departure last week guests started to show up.

In the history of America's two major labor organizations the city of Pittsburgh has figured prominently. In the Smoky City sixty-one years ago eight national trade unions came together in the Federation of Organized Trades and Labor Unions of the United States and Canada, later known as the American Federation of Labor.
Service men on furlough in New York will find a new entertainment center opening for them on Wednesday evening at the Junior League clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street.

The problem of the physically handicapped is one which is not often treated in books for young people with more than a sidelong half-evasive glance, yet there must be many young people walled up in their own pride and loneliness who would welcome a book which combines understanding with a frank acknowledgment of the difficulties which must be faced.
LONDON, April 11 -- Britain spent more than 384,162,000 on its Royal Navy and merchant marine during 1940, according to figures published for the first time today.

Now that the outboard brigade has announced its plans for the customary Hudson River marathon down from Albany on May 17, the daredevils of the American Inboard Association will meet Thursday night at the Hotel Lexington to discuss their part in the 140- mile grind.

Manifestations which resemble the pranks of a poltergeist accompany the murder with which this story deals. That is why Dr. Basil Willing, psychiatrist-detective, is the proper person to solve the mystery, for psychiatrists have what appears to be a reasonable explanation of poltergeist phenomena.

IN the book reviewing trade "brilliant" is an overworked and possibly rather meaningless adjective. Yet there is no other which half so well fits this novel by Christine Weston, and it has here precise descriptive force. "The Devil's Foot" is a brilliant novel in the dictionary definition of the term, "sparkling or glowing with luster or light: very bright."

DAY-BY-DAY REPORTS of our Bomber Command already add up to a magnificent epic of heroism and courage, and the tale is not half told as yet. Reading these brief accounts, one realizes that Homer had no monopoly on the hero tale; that this, too, is a heroic age.

A transcontinental United Air Lines transport, landing at La Guardia Field at 5:37 A.M. yesterday from Chicago wheeled off the runway and plunged into Flushing Bay, severely injuring the stewardess and the co-pilot, and slightly injuring the third member of the crew.

Lieut. Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright, commander of the hard-fighting army in the Philippines, foresaw as early as last November that he would face the over-whelming Japanese attack that now has taken place, his son revealed Friday night.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Having broken the resistance of the exhausted American and Filipino forces on Bataan Peninsula, the Japanese struck swiftly yesterday at many points on the east and west coasts of the island of Cebu, established beachheads and increased their number today, according to two communiques issued here by the War Department today.

With the Tammany executive committee meeting Tuesday to elect a leader to succeed Christopher D. Sullivan, United States Senator Robert F. Wagner announced last night that he hoped for the election of Representative Michael J. Kennedy of the Fifth Assembly District.

Despite the Nazi conquest of Europe, some paintings by old masters have been brought to this country from the Continent by devious ways. Seven such paintings are to be shown here this week in the exhibition of Flemish Primitives at the galleries of M. Knoedler Co. for the benefit of Belgian sailors with Allied fleets.

BERKELEY, Calif., April 11 -Performing true to form, the University of Southern California's Trojans launched their 1942 bid for sectional and national track and field honors today by swamping the University of California, 81 2-3 to 49 1-3, in their annual dual meet before 8,000 fans.

POTTSTOWN, Pa., April 11 -- With over 90 per cent of the sixth form entering college in June or July and with a number of significant wartime changes in curriculum, the high school presents a picture of how a boys' school mobilizes in the national interest.

GUAYULE -- Rapid progress in the guayule rubber production project is reported by the Department of Agriculture's Forest Service. Plowing and disking of the nursery beds and soil surveys and maps have been completed. Five hundred acres will be sown progressively as irrigation systems are installed in the nursery at Salinas, Calif.

A proposal to change the basis of their membership in the General Federation of Women's Clubs is being warmly debated among members of the New Jersey Federation. The resolution, asking withdrawal from universal membership, is the result of a formal request of two member clubs made to the board of trustees.

Out of the morning skies over England last Wednesday droned an American bombing plane. It circled an airport, dropped to a landing and taxied to the hangars. From it stepped General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff of the United States Army, and Harry L. Hopkins, close adviser to President Roosevelt.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: Roses that have been "on order" are now being shipped. Success with dormant plants depends largely on getting them planted immediately on receipt -- cold weather will not hurt them. Hilling up the plants will protect lower eyes from drying out until the plants get a start. . . .

The wartime expansions of loans, reflecting the financing of vital industries, an increase in holdings of United States Government securities and the consequent further reduction in top-heavy cash positions, are revealed in the first-quarter statements of condition of the leading Wall Street banks.

The cotton market experienced yesterday its sharpest set-back in recent weeks. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange lost 18 to 25 points, or 90 cents to $1.20 a bale, in late trading, but within the closing period prices recovered about 5 points and finished with final net decreases of 17 to 21 points, or 85 cents to $1.05 a bale.

BOWIE, Md., April 11 -- W.L. Brann's Pictor survived a claim of foul to score his first victory of 1942 in the $5,000 added Southern Maryland Handicap, closing-day feature at Bowie today. The stable-mate of Challedon and one-time Kentucky Derby hope, finished three parts of a length in advance of Phil Bieber's Maechance and an additional three lengths ahead of Gustave Ring's Cis Marion.

To Steppin, brown, eager and limber, tap-dancing was the only art in the world, but Harlem boys don't have much money for dancing lessons; and fame seemed very far away as he sat forlornly under the Wishing Tree.

CHUNGKING, China, April 11 (AP) -- Severe fighting and fresh Japanese advances on the Chinese front in Burma were reported here today, and it was said 2,000 Japanese had been killed or wounded and many prisoners taken in a three-day battle.

THE fact that there is already a fair-sized repertoire of American operas is shown by Alfred Wallenstein's announcement that he will conduct an i American opera festival from May 7 to June 18 over station WOR. Quinto Maganini's "Tennessee's Partner," an opera with an all-male cast based on a Bret Harte story, is the only new work.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Wartime demands have made the task of writing a tax bill a major political and economic nightmare to the members of Congress assigned to that duty.

SOME, slackening in trade after the Easter rush was expected and it followed that schedule last week. Due to the earlier holiday, retail volume may have shown its first decline of the year when figures were compared with the 1941 total of the pre-Easter week.

NEWARK, N.J., April 11 -- A combined garden forum for the sixth, seventh and eighth districts of the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs will be held Thursday at the Woman's Club of Upper Montclair. Beecher S. Bowdish of the New Jersey Audubon Society will speak on "What Our Birds Mean in Defense."

One of the most popular meetings of the year in the Eastern section is that sponsored each Spring by the Orange County Field Trial Club. Its success is not founded on huge purses, the attendance of famous professional handlers and the competition of the champion pointers and setters.

MONTHS ago we were watching a rehearsal of "Best Foot Forward," for which Gene Kelly staged the dances and Hans Spialek and your correspondent provided the orchestrations. Near the end of a long dance routine following a song called "Three Men on a Date," nine boys lined up across the stage.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Continuing its account of submarine operations in distant seas, the Navy Department announced this afternoon that one of our underwater craft, just returned from an extended patrol in Far Eastern waters, had reported the sinking of a 7,000-ton enemy merchant vessel and a small Japanese submarine chaser.

HAMILTON, N.Y., April 11 -- To help villagers as well as students understand day-to-day problems resulting from America's war efforts, Colgate University will present a course in "Current War Problems" three evenings a week during the Summer term beginning May 19 and ending Aug. 18.

BOSTON, April 11 -- Leading educators from many nations of the Western Hemisphere will discuss basic problems of the Americas with Latin American and North American students from fifty New England colleges and universities at an Inter-American Student Conference for New England to be held at Simmons College April 24 and 25 under the joint auspices of the college and the Pan-American Society of Massachusetts.

VICTORIA, B.C., April 11 -- Lieut. Comdr. T.P. Ryan of the Royal Canadian Naval Volunteer Reserve, here on leave after two years of service with Atlantic convoys, said in an interview today a German submarine captured by a Canadian destroyer several months ago, "is now operating on our side in the Atlantic."

Main floor departments were steadily active in the three major retail test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Sportswear was active and coats and suits fairly good.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 11 -- The Swallow, a sprightly filly sporting the colors of John Hay (Jock) Whitney, today served warning on other 3-year-old thoroughbred misses that she will be a dangerous contender for divisional honors this year when she flashed to an impressive victory at Keeneland in the featured Ashland Stakes, formerly the Ashland Oaks.

DURHAM, N.H., April 11 -- Originally set up as an agency of service to State and local government officials, the Bureau of Government Research at the University of New Hampshire is being utilized as an effective instructional device by the Department of Government.

LONDON, April 11 -- Richard Austen Butler, president of the Board of Education, gave the National Union of Teachers this week an outline of the post-war reforms in Great Britain's educational system that have been provisionally worked out.

ADD to the late Spring's possibilities -- it may even be better than that -- a play called "The Rich Get Richer." The work of Mary Hall, actress financial consultant and (with this, her first item) playwright, the play is scheduled to go into rehearsal in ten days or so under the direction of Arthur Hopkins.

This season, when vegetable seeds must be conserved in every possible way, the benefits of pre-planting seed treatment -- a type of "gardener's insurance" -- are even more important than normally. Right methods will kill disease-producing fungi or bacteria carried on or in the seed and will protect young seedlings from the damping-off organisms present in the soil.

The Rev. Dr. William Ewart Dudley, pastor for thirteen years of the Flatbush Congregational Church, Dorchester Road and East Eighteenth Street, Brooklyn, will announce his resignation at the morning service today, effective Sept. 15, to accept a post as pastor of the First Congregational Church, Toledo, Ohio.

MEDFORD, N.J., April 11 -- The open puppy stake, third event of the English Setter Club of America's Spring trials, was won today by Wahoo's Pirate, a white and liver pointer dog owned by Jake Flowers, coach of the Pittsburgh Pirates, and handled by George Crangle of Waynesboro, Ga.

The masters' individual tournament will come to a close after the two final sessions are played this afternoon and tonight at the Park Central Hotel, and the Vanderbil Cup tournament for the national team-of-four championship will begin tomorrow night at the Hotel Pierre.

EDDIE FORD was a division butt in 1918. He was loose-hipped and effeminate and his speech matched top note on a pitch pipe. If you touched his back he squealed and leaped like a mettlesome filly. He had the female lead in the division variety show because no other soldier bid for it.

ALFRED NOYES, whose home is on the Isle of Wight, where, as he puts it, he "awaits the call of the Muse," each morning in his study, is in this country on an extensive lecture tour, the profits of which, he said, are going to British refugee children.

Coins of German New Guinea recall the founding of the colony by the German New Guinea Society, a private company chartered by the German Government. Today the German missionaries guiding the invading Japanese through the jungles of the island may be descendants of the early German settlers.

WILL HAYS, who didn't get a chance to testify last Fall at the Senate subcommittee hearings into alleged war mongering by the film producers, is going to have his say on the matter after all. The Hays statement, which is in the nature of a historical survey of the whole question of freedom of speech and its application to the screen, will shortly be published in book form, according to reports.
Education in the liberal arts is fully as important in time of war as in time of peace, Dean Herbert E. Hawkes of Columbia College said yesterday.

School teachers have been caught in the rush toward highly paid jobs in war industry and, in the face of an increasing shortage of instructors, the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs is setting out to collect a debt of discrimination, long outstanding, from school boards throughout the country.

MIDDLEBURG, Va., April 11 (AP) -- Hold Forth, owned, by Mrs. Frank M. Gould of New York and ridden by W. Leonard, won the Louie Leith Cup, feature four-mile timber race of the twenty-second Spring race meet of the Middleburg Hunt Race Association at the Glenwood course today. The time was 8:14.4.

WERE an inquiry in order concerning the present state of music in America, the celebration which takes place at 12:30 today of the 500th concert of "Music Hall on the Air" in Radio City would have significance.

LONDON, April 11 -- Despite the fact that men are still being called up by the thousands and the end of the war is not in sight, Labor Minister Ernest Bevin disclosed yesterday that he was already considering problems of demobilization after the war.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (U.P.) -- The submarine Perch normally carried a complement of fifty officers and men. Her overall length was 300 feet and her displacement was 1,330 tons.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Shotguns will be issued to State Guard units and Army military police to replace rifles, which will be recalled for "troops of the United Nations," the War Department announced tonight.

Motorists intending to conserve rubber and gasoline this year by foregoing week-end jaunts and vacation trips to resorts distant from New York will find in Westchester County, almost at their doorstep, lush views, rugged hills, wooded glens, bridle paths, bicycle trails, sandy beaches, golf courses and camping grounds such as were hitherto sought at remote seashore and mountain retreats.

The seventh annual horse show of the Wall Street Riding Club was held in the ring of the Riding and Polo Club yesterday, with more than 300 horses competing in the various events. The vanning situation and other causes connected with the war effort combined to bring the entry below that of last year.

ALMOST every time one looks at the sports page in the morning paper, it seems, Miss Gloria Callen has broken another half dozen swimming records. The half dozen is used literally: Only last month she broke six records and tied another in one evening.

Captain James H. Tomb, superintendent of the New York State Merchant Marine Academy at Fort Schuyler, the Bronx, is to be named commandant of the new United States Merchant Marine Academy on the old Chrysler estate near Great Neck, L.I., it was announced here last week.

AT A UNITED NATIONS AIR BASE, Southwest Pacific, April 11 -- An American bomber group composed of youths averaging 22 years old, most of whom have been in the Army no more than a year, has completed its first mission -- the most thorough raid on Rabaul, Japanese stronghold in New Britain, that it has so far received.

A professional movie show right in your own home, varied over a great range of special appeal from pure slapstick to the grim seriousness of contemporary warfare, is available to every amateur who owns or can rent a movie projector and a screen.

The crews of British freighters in this port have raised such a disturbance at the consulate, 25 Broadway, and at steamship offices because they have received only $2.50 in United States currency for their English pound note that Godfrey Haggard, the British Consul General has arranged that the officers and men will receive a certain amount of money for spending here in cash at the rate of $4 to the pound sterling.

The perennial border, though of a permanent nature, requires certain care if it is to retain its full beauty and usefulness. Chief among its requirements is the division of old plants. Perennials left undivided for several years tend to produce dry dead centers in the crowns, resulting in weaker stemmed flowers and indifferent growth.

HAVERFORD, Pa., April 11 -- Construction of the latest addition to the Haverford College library, a treasure room to house and display its collections of Quakeriana, has been completed and the room will be dedicated on May 4.

Enemy submarine activity along the Atlantic seaboard has curtailed sharply the movement of coal to the New York and New England regions, with the result that serious consideration is being given to alternate methods of transportation.

BUENOS AIRES, according to Betty de Sherbinin, is a city which on the surface seems modern, sophisticated. thoroughly Europeanized, but which actually clings steadfastly to immemorial ways. Except for an insignificant segment of Argentine society, the pattern of its life is dominated, as always, by the family and the church -- with results that tend to be stultifying.

OTTAWA, April 11 -- Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King started off the plebiscite campaign on Tuesday last in one of the most forthright war speeches he has ever made to the country and it is estimated that in all the Provinces except Quebec a majority is assured for the release of the government from any past pledges regarding the methods to be employed for raising men for the army overseas.

TORONTO, April 11 (Canadian Press) -- A net profit of $3,279,604, equal to $1.97 a share, was realized in 1941 by the Ford Motor Company of Canada, Ltd., compared with $2,571,030 or $1.55 a share in 1940, it was announced today. The operating profit was $4,459,030, against $4,070,300.

BUFFALO, April 11 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. H.H. Arnold, deputy chief of staff for air, advised the Curtiss-Wright Corporation airplane division today that German pilots were finding Curtiss P-40 pursuit planes hard to match in battle.

BY reason of his stature or his location in the chronology, or both, Thomas Hardy has been taken as a sort of official landmark in English literature. Anthologies have a way of running from Shakespeare to Hardy or from Beowulf to Hardy.

LOST AT SEA: Winter in the North Atlantic is never a pleasant season. Winds, mountainous seas, cold that turns salt spray quickly to ice, such is the monotonous round that sends even the stoutest vessels limping to port. The Winter just past has been no exception to the rule; in fact, according to some accounts, it has gone the rule one better.

A decision directing eight present or former executives of the General Motors Corporation to reimburse the concern for $4,348,044, plus interest charges estimated at another $2,000,000, was handed down yesterday by Judge Vincent L. Leibell in United States District Court.

Several women identified with society and sports here and in England will act as sponsors for a collection of sports costumes in British wool by noted British designers, which will be displayed under the auspices of Bundles for Britain on April 28 during the luncheon period at the Hotel Pierre.
CLINTON, N.J., April 11 -- Boots of Arlington, owned by Albert Jones of Arlington, Va., won the open all-age event held by the Irish Setter Club of America today.

CHICAGO, April 11 (AP) -- Livestock prices held about steady today after a week of rising tendencies. The major factor in the advance of hogs, livestock men said, was the prospect of continued heavy government purchase of pork and lard.

Miss Ruth Mary Hardwick and Mrs. Dorothy Round Little, the two foremost British women tennis players of recent years, left for Hartford yesterday to open a tour to raise funds for the British and American Ambulance Corps.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- An increase in the retail price of sugar, but not to exceed one cent on each five pounds was approved today by the Office of Price Administration in five New England States, and Delaware to Cover additional transportation costs involved in efforts to relieve an acute sugar shortage in the regions affected by the order.

LONDON, April 11 -- With the stepped-up attacks by fighters and bombers of the Royal Air Force against the Germans during the last few days, the Air Ministry announced today that yesterday's fighter sweep across the Channel was one of the largest this year and last night the Bomber Command raided Western Germany for the fourth time in the week.

LONDON, April 11 (AP) -- four-motored Stifling bombers, capable of carrying eight tons of bombs, were being added today to the British squadrons whose continuing offensive against industrial targets in Germany and German-occupied territory brought fresh destruction to the Ruhr last night.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (U.P.) -- Officials of the War Production Board said today that about 350 concerns hold 85 per cent of the $100,000,000,000 in war contracts, which have been awarded thus far.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 11 -- Although German and Italian columns continued to move about in the Cyrenaican No Man's Land yesterday, no heavy fighting developed.

Testifying before the House Ways and Means Committee, W.P. Hobby, former Governor of Texas and publisher of The Houston Post, urged the inclusion in the new tax bill of some provision that would permit businesses and individuals to maintain payments on their honest debts.

Frankie Rubino of Brooklyn came back after being knocked down three times to win the decision from Curley St. Angelo, Bronx lightweight, in the feature bout of eight rounds at the Ridgewood Grove, Brooklyn, last night.

THE timely, the picturesque, and the historically interesting are ingredients excellently served forth in the new book by the author of "The Caribbean." It would be too much to describe "The French in the West Indies" as a piece de resistance in a menu of present-day reading, but it is certainly to be recommended as a savory; and that not because it is sensational or romanticized, but, basically, because it is not.

The New York Wellesley Club has drawn up plans for its fifth annual Bicycle Breakfast, which will take place on the morning and afternoon of April 26 at the Stork Club. The event will be held "rain or shine" and its net proceeds will augment a fund for the purchase of comfort kits for men in the United States fighting forces.

In a letter published elsewhere in this issue A.J. Altmeyer ably defends the Social Security Board's proposed payroll tax of 1 per cent to provide cash benefits for low-income workers who need hospital care. This is an extension of old-age, unemployment and disability insurance to health -- a fundamental error in the opinion of many experts.

Swinging into full stride at last, college baseball faces its busiest week of the season to date. There are seven Metropolitan Conference games scheduled and the Eastern League, which lists five contests, will have its full roster of members in action for the first time.

Members of New York Typographical Union No. 6, popularly known as "Big 6," by a vote of two and one-half or three to one, have ratified a new two-year contract providing for a weekly wage increase of $3 for printers on New York City newspapers, with practically no change in working conditions, it was disclosed yesterday.

THE Japanese attack upon Pearl Harbor and the German declaration of war solidified American opinion. Overnight the isolationists and the interventionists discovered that the issue which gave rise to their perennial debate had disappeared. We were in the war. There could no longer be any division of opinion as to the purpose of the United States policy.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- Long-trip travel by passenger automobiles in the United States already has dropped by almost 40 per cent, due to nation-wide tire rationing and gasoline restrictions in the East and Pacific Northwest, the American Automobile Association reported today.

BEFORE Sherwood Anderson sailed on his last voyage he had written what may be called his last will and testament. This is it. It is not an easy thing for a reviewer to take hold of, for a whole man is in it, and the man was full of contradictions.

Taking up a tradition cut short by the German domination of Paris, French students from New York's municipal colleges are collaborating in the production of two medieval plays, "Le Miracle de Theophile" and "Le Farce de Maitre Pathelin," next Saturday at Hunter College, 695 Park Avenue. Proceeds will be used to buy a military plane for the government.

Johann Strauss's masterly operetta, "Die Fledermaus," received a performance last night at the Pythian Theatre, under the sponsorship or the Committee for the Preservation of Austrian Art and Culture in the U.S.A. The original version of the score was employed in a presentation in German by a cast largely composed of Austrian singers who had appeared in the work in Vienna and other Central European cities.

Modern weapons of war are so closely interdependent that they are next to useless except to the extent that their production is balanced and synchronized. Accordingly, it follows that we can do the maximum damage to the enemy, not by hitting his "war production" at random, but by trying to unbalance and unsynchronize that war production.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 11 -- A fellow-Texan, Ben Hogan, pro at the Hershey Club in Pennsylvania, today challenged Byron Nelson for honors in the ninth annual masters' golf tournament.

The British radio, heard in New York yesterday by the Columbia Broadcasting System, reported that four Poles had been sentenced to death for attacks on German military transports at the border of Poland and East Prussia.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- The Senators returned to their home grounds today and suffered an 8-0 beating by the Phils.

There is a section in Brooklyn known as Brownsville, where rows of battered red brick flats line the streets. On the avenues and tucked away in side streets are cigar stores, dark and dingy, soda fountains, sweet shops. Brownsville was once the scene of pitched battles between two rival gangs -- the Bloody Hollowers and the Bone Fiddlers.

While the loss of two more medium-sized United States merchant ships off the Atlantic Coast was revealed yesterday, the Navy Department, in a special statement, cited evidence to prove that not all vessels traveling in submarine-infested waters are proving easy prey for the Axis U-boats.

NEW DELHI, India, April 11 -- The mission of Sir Stafford Cripps came to naught in an atmosphere of gloom today with rejection by the All-India Congress party and the Moslem League of the British proposals for Indian dominion. "With the enemy at the gates," Sir Stafford announced, his proposals had run afoul of a "spate of criticism" and a "critical and unconstructive attitude."

SUPPOSE, to get rid of the exposition in a hurry, you produce plays for a living -- Heaven forbid! Twenty-three are running on Broadway, half of them are making money, but none of them is yours. In such a situation, granted you were too stagestruck to get into another line of business, what would you do ?

Here is a mystery-adventure thriller that begins in London at about the time of Germany's invasion of Poland and ends at Gibraltar just after England's entry into the war. Those two events have an important bearing on what happens to Carol Shaw, American night-club dancer, to Harry Rosario, Gibraltar "rock scorpion," and to several other persons who play prominent roles in this story.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 11 -- It is time the German people woke up to the fact that there is a war going on, complains the Berlin weekly, Schwarze Korps. According to this periodical, the Germans are not yet spiritually armed for the demands of war when it is only grudgingly and with sense of heavy sacrifice they consent to do without things that are unnecessary.
TULSA, Okla., April 11 (AP) -- "Mining" for oil will soon have a commercial test in Pennsylvania as a means of reviving production.

With the permission of the British postal authorities the Czech Army forces stationed "somewhere in England" have been permitted to set up their own "Ceskoslovenska Polni Posta" (Czechoslovakia Field Post) and to place cachets on mail handled there.

LONDON, April 12 -- A charter setting forth basic, minimum rights for all children "above considerations of sex, race, nationality, creed or social position," was adopted by the New Education Fellowship Conference here today.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The Federal Trade Commission today ordered the Wool Trading Company, Inc., which sometimes trades under the name Peter Pan Yarn Company, 361 Grand Street; Samuel and Peter Gottlieb, trading as Gottlieb Brothers and as Jack Frost Yarn Company, 207 Avenue C, and Philip Jablon, trading as Bell Yarn Company, 371 Grand Street, all New York City, to cease alleged misrepresentation in the sale of their products.

The "streamlining" of the city's air warden service, appointment of Deputy Police Commissioner John H. Morris as full-time commander of the service and the creation of a defense aide and coordinator to the Mayor, were announced by Mayor La Guardia yesterday in his "talk to the people" over station WNYC.

CHICAGO, April 12 -- Lynn U. Stambaugh, National Commander of the American Legion, has issued the warning that the Legion's annual convention, scheduled to be held in New Orleans Sept. 21 to 24 inclusive, may be limited solely to Legion business and that the usual frivolity will be prohibited, William Mundt, Illinois adjutant, announced at a State executive committee meeting today.

PARADISE VALLEY, Mount Rainier, April 12 (AP) -- Matt Broze, 30-year-old Seattle fireman, won the eighth annual running of the Silver Skis today, speeding down the 3.16-mile course on Mount Rainier's icy slopes in 4 minutes 57 seconds, only 3 seconds over the record set by Pete Radacher of Austria in 1938.

VICHY, April 12 -- The statement of the condition of the Bank of France for March 12 shows a decline in the sums furnished the market, for only advances on bonds increased by 112 millions while decreases are noted of 270 millions in bills discounted, 640 millions in bills purchased in open market dealings and 50 millions in advances on securities.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 12 -Political circles in Rome consider the new Bulgarian Government a manifestation of King Boris's ascending power in his increasingly pro-neutral Parliament. It is added that after his trip to Berlin, during which he saw Adolf Hitler, King Boris had intended "in any case" to request the collective resignation of the Cabinet "in order that his hand might be free to renew in part at least the directing personnel of the country."
A demand for apartments in buildings on the East Side was indicated by lists of new Spring rentals issued over the week-end by brokers and renting agents.

Thirty independent gasoline dealers from Queens, carrying American flags and many placards, picketed the main offices or Sobol Brothers at 110th Street and Fifth Avenue yesterday in protest against Sunday sales. The demonstration continued for nearly three hours from 11:30 A.M.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 12 (UP) -General Erwin Rommel has mysteriously withdrawn the Axis column operating on his southern flank in Libya where British Headquarters has been expecting a renewed German offensive toward Egypt for the last two weeks, a communique said today.

LONDON, April 12 -- Japanese troops in Central Burma tonight continued advancing northward along the Irrawaddy River south of Magwe, key center 100 miles north of Prome, and gateway to the oil fields, while their planes carried out heavy attacks over the whole front, bombing and machine-gunning British advanced units.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 12 -- Still not quite over that "back-from-the-dead" feeling, British prisoners who have arrived here from Italy in the first contingent under the new exchange plan sat on hospital cots today and told how it felt to be day after day in a prisoners-of-war camp, often completely out of touch with relatives and friends, with no hope of anything different in the near future.
The old master will be on the firing line tomorrow at the Polo Grounds, when the Giants square off against the Dodgers in the opening of the National League championship campaign.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- All units of American expeditionary forces are being provided with a new type of athletic kit before embarking for overseas, the War Department said today.

The report of the Cities Service Power and Light Company and subsidiaries for 1941, issued yesterday by R.E. Burger president, shows a consolidated net income, after expenses and charges, of $4,222,857, a decrease of $1,749,813 from 1940.

CINCINNATI, April 12 (AP) -- The Reds ended their exhibition schedule today with a 6-to-5 victory over the Tigers. Four walks issued by Harold White, rookie Detroit right-hander, in the first two innings contributed to the Cincinnati scoring.
LONDON, April 12 -- The well-known saying that the "early bird catches the worm" is particularly applicable to conditions all over Britain today.
National Wildlife Restoration Week is now being celebrated throughout the country, and its primary purpose is to make the nation conservation-conscious.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- About sixty editors of Congress of Industrial Organizations national and local labor publications and publicity directors of C.I.O. unions pledged themselves at a week-end conference here to 100 per cent cooperation with the American Federation of Labor, the railroad brotherhoods, with industry and with government in publicity to promote war production.

CHICAGO, April 12 -- Corn gained about 1 cent a bushel on wheat at one time last week on the Board of Trade here, but a rush yesterday to close spreads between those grains disclosed no aggressive support for either one and the difference widened again to about the same basis that prevailed at the end of the preceding week.

If the problem of India can still be solved, the solution can rest only on a candid recognition of the factors that have led to the present impasse. The responsibility for the breakdown of negotiations is many-sided. Long ago the British people should have recognized the urgency of the Indian problem.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (U.P.) -- Charles Pack, head of the Doehler Die Casting Company, one of the country's largest producers of die castings, denounced tonight proposed ceilings over war wages and profits as "undemocratic and un-American."

Mrs. Yetta Weisbrod, 107 years and 6 days young, blew out seven candles with as many lusty puffs yesterday afternoon and turned to the guests at her birthday party. Casting her keen eyes over six children, fourteen grandchildren and twenty great-grandchildren, she exclaimed:

CHUNGKING, China, April 12 -- Generalissimo and Mme. Chiang Kaishek returned by air from Burma today after a week's inspection and important conferences with United Nations commanders in an attempt to knit together the Allied forces in Burma.

ALBANY, April 12 -- Governor Lehman declined to comment today on the story published in this morning's issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES that President Roosevelt was planning to call him to Washington soon to assume a high position in the nation's war effort.

WILMINGTON, N.C., April 12 -- John P. Broome, regional director of the Federal Public Housing Administration, has arrived here to direct the planning of 800 additional demountable homes and 220 additional trailers which are to be built here by the government to meet a shortage of housing for war workers in the yards of the North Carolina Shipbuilding Company.

Maria Safonoff, pianist, and Julia Mery Gilli, soprano, who left their native Russia together in 1921 and who have given previous recitals together, were heard late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall in a program devoted to Tchaikovsky and his favorite composer, Mozart.

NEWARK, N.J., April 12 -- The New Jersey State Industrial Council's special war production convention here called today on the Federal Government to place a representative on the board of directors of every war plant in the United States.
DETROIT, April 12 (AP) -- Louis Pagliaro of New York and Miss Sally Green of Indianapolis still are the king and queen of table tennis.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 12 (AP) -- The Bulgarian Premier, Bogdan Philoff, said in a Sofia broadcast tonight that his newly formed Cabinet would hew to the previous government's policy of "cooperating closely with the Axis."

PRINCETON, N.J., April 12 -- The Princeton Tiger, one of the oldest campus humor magazines in the United States, will suspend publication for the duration of the war with the sixtieth anniversary issue on May 2.

Wartime problems of packaging, packing and shipping will be discussed at a three-day conference under the auspices of the American Management Association, which opens Tuesday at the Hotel Astor. An important feature will be the Thursday morning session, at which the entire staff of the Containers Branch of the War Production Board will answer manufacturers' questions regarding critical packaging materials.

A large Washington Heights property changed hands with the sale by the Weyland Realty Corporation of Roxbury Terrace, a six-story apartment building at 105 Pinehurst Avenue, near West 181st Street. Occupying a plot 150 by 105 by 135 feet and containing fifty-eight suites, the building was sold for cash over a first mortgage of $230,000.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Ten industrial concerns holding millions of dollars in war contracts were ordered today by the President's Committee on Fair Employment Practice to cease discriminating against available workers because of their race or religion.

CHUNGKING, China, April 12 (U.P.) -- Japanese fifth columnists and secret agents have intensified their activity and intrigues in Afghanistan as part of the Axis program of expansion in the Near and Middle East, Chinese Foreign Office sources disclosed today.

Praising the "heroic people of China" for their struggle against Japanese aggression, Bishop William T. Manning yesterday urged support of the drive of United China Relief for funds. He spoke following confirmation rites in St. Agnes's Protestant Episcopal Chapel, Trinity Parish, in Ninety-second Street, west of Columbus Avenue.

Mahler's Eighth symphony, which had not been heard in this city in twenty-six years, was performed yesterday noon under Erno Rapee's direction, at the Center Theatre, before a concert audience. The presentation of the neglected masterpiece marked the 500th program of the Radio City Music Hall of the Air, and was the first radio hearing of the work, being broadcast over WJZ on affiliated Blue Network stations and via shortwave throughout Latin America.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The American-Filipino defenders of Corregidor Island at the entrance to Manila Bay were standing up under almost continuous Japanese air bombardment and artillery fire today, the War Department reported.

Religion will play an important part in the "new order" to be established by the victors in the present conflict, said J. Hutton Hynd, leader of the St. Louis Ethical Society, in an address yesterday at the Meeting House of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, Central Park West and Sixty-fourth Street.

A modern gift of beauty comes disguised in the form of a diminutive, pink-and-white hand mirror with a bow of chartreuse tulle tied saucily about its handle. This little baroque looking-glass represents a "gift certificate" that can be exchanged for a series of custom-made cosmetics to be "fitted" to the recipient in a pretty, pink-and-white bandbox of a shop.

Urged on by 20,086 hardy preseason enthusiasts, the Yankees and Dodgers belted each other around in a most exhilarating manner at the Stadium yesterday to conclude their Spring exhibition campaign. But, as might be suspected, it was the Yanks who were just a trifle more effective in the belting and to the Bronx Bombers went the battle, 8 to 7.

Declaring that Townsend Harris High School had proved to be "educationally sound and practically necessary," Dr. Carmyn Lombardo, member of the Board of Higher Education, wrote to the State Legislature yesterday asking that it adopt the Young-Davidson bill, compelling the Board of Higher Education to continue the school.

WEST CHESTERFIELD, Mass., April 12 -- Gregory Carhart, 29-year-old recluse who threatens to turn his shotgun on any one who attempts to force him into the army, probably will have "visitors" at his hilltop cabin near here tomorrow. They will be government agents and their call will not be social.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Corregidor, the island bastion and last stronghold of defense of Lieut. Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright and his combined American and Filipino force, is twenty-seven miles across water from the enemy-held city of Manila.

PHILADELPHIA, April 12 (U.P.) -- The Fourth Naval District announced tonight that the 3-year-old girl and the body of her young mother, who died just six hours before rescue, had been brought ashore at Lewes, Del., after a Navy vessel discovered them drifting in a lifeboat with ten other survivors of a torpedoed medium-sized American cargo-passenger ship.

JERUSALEM, April 12 -- After discharging a cargo of 7,000 tons of wheat at Piraeus for the starving population of Greece, the Swedish ship Ramdanso has returned from her mission of mercy and has proceeded to an Egyptian port.

The Anaconda Copper Mining Company reported yesterday for 1941 a consolidated net income of $43,433,659 after charges, taxes and a reserve of $5,000,000 for contingencies, but before depletion of metal mines. This was equal to $5.01 each on the 8,674,338 shares of capital stock outstanding.

The Galimir Quartet, composed of Felix Galimir, first violin; Adrienne Galimir, second violin; Lotte Hammerschlag, viola, and Arthur Winograd, 'cello, was heard in its first New York concert last night in Town Hall. Mr. Galimir, who arrived in America a few years ago, founded a quartet in Vienna of the same name, which he also headed.

John A. Brown, president of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, has accepted the chairmanship of the industry section of the Greater New York USO campaign, it was announced yesterday at the headquarters, 57 William Street. The drive is for $32,000,000.

The first lecture in a real estate brokerage course to be given by the New York Chapter Knights of Columbus Business School will be held on Wednesday night in the school at 316 West Fifty-seventh Street. The course will run for nine weeks on Wednesday and Friday nights.

DETROIT, April 12 -- The gallant Toronto Maple Leafs, on the brink of elimination from the Stanley Cup hockey finals, came from behind twice tonight to defeat the Detroit Red Wings, 4 to 3, before a record crowd of 13,695 at the Olympia.

BALTIMORE, April 12 -- Crown Princess Martha of Norway today christened the St. Olaf, a liberty ship, at the Bethlehem-Fairfield shipyards. This was the first public launching ceremony held here since the United States entered the war.

VICHY, April 12 -- The central fund for deposits and transfers of securities now has been organized fully and is functioning. Its aim is to centralize securities placed on deposit with exchange agents and banks with official authorizations.

Crown, Prince Olav and Crown Princess Martha of Norway, accompanied by Count Nikolai Ostgaard, aide-de-camp, and Countess Ragni Ostgaard, have come from Pook's Hill, Bethesda, Md. and are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

"YES, life has its terrors. But given the wings of faith, one can be stronger than anything life can show." This affirmation of faith, faith in the joy of living, in human goodness and in the ultimate goodness of God, comes on the last page of Nina Fedorova's novel "The Children."*

The report for 1941 of the Consolidated Oil Corporation, released for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $18,972,493 after all charges, taxes and reserves, but before deduction of a special provision for contingencies of $2,500,000.

The New York City Board of Education begins today a week's celebration of its one hundredth anniversary. The commercial, industrial and financial world is cooperating in the celebration. Exhibitions of school work, old and new, will appear in nearly 100 department stores, shops, banks, restaurants and other business establishments throughout the five boroughs.

EAST HARTFORD, Conn., April 12 -- One of the many trailer colonies now dotting the nation from West Coast war plants to Atlantic ammunition factories, "Trailer Village'' has been built on an old tobacco field here.
BERLIN, April 12 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The text of the German communique today said:

CHICAGO, April 12 -- Scattered liquidation developed last week in the wheat market on the Board of Trade here and prices dropped to the lowest marks in four months. They held within a range of about 2 cents a bushel, however. The pressure increased on all minor upturns and bearish sentiment pre- dominated as the result of the unfavorable news from the Far Eastern war front and the outlook for a liberal Winter wheat crop.

The Navy Department announced yesterday the loss of a medium-sized Norwegian vessel off our Atlantic Coast. She was torpedoed early last Tuesday morning by an enemy submarine and went to the bottom within an hour after the attack.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The War Shipping Administration announced today a revised schedule of war risk insurance rates covering cargoes on American merchant ships, effective tomorrow, but subject to change without notice.

The Foundation Company, internationally known in the engineering and construction business, settled its claims with the Peruvian Government for the equivalent of $207,692, John W. Doty, president, said in his report for 1941.
The influence of air power upon war was again demonstrated last week over Western Europe, in the Southwest Pacific, in the Indian Ocean and in Burma.
CARDIFF, Wales, April 12 -- One of the most interesting political campaigns that has been fought out in this country since the war began came to a close today.

NEWARK, N.J., April 12 -- Edward McKenna, 52 years old, a retired seaman, was found dead yesterday morning in a rooming house at 20 Court Street. An autopsy showed that his death resulted from exhaustion of oxygen by a gas heater.

WASHINGTON, April 12 - Currency in circulation in the United States has increased in the last year from $8,800,000,000 to $11,500,000,000, an advance of 30 per cent, the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System reported today.

MOSCOW, April 12 (AP) -- Control of the Italian Navy by the Germans, who intend to send it into action in the Eastern Mediterranean and at the same time use the French Fleet in the Western end of the sea, "is a matter of the near future," Tass news agency reported today from Geneva, Switzerland.

Fire Chief and Commissioner Patrick Walsh appealed yesterday to the members of his "hard-pressed" department to "think seriously'' before submitting their retirement applications and thus avoid committing a public disservice in exchange for a "few paltry dollars or a life of ease."

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 12 -- United Nations airmen continued to hammer Japanese positions in the area north of Australia over the week-end, attacking Lae, in Northeast New Guinea; Rabaul, in New Britain, and Faisi, in the Solomon Islands.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 12 (U.P.) -- Russian artillerymen have shattered twelve successive German tank attacks on the southern front -- on the road to the oil-rich Caucasus -- destroying "dozens" of tanks and killing 1,000 enemy troops, the Soviet press reported tonight.

What is believed to be the first public performance of a play in sign language will be given Sunday night, May 10, at the Fulton Theatre when the dramatic club of Gallaudet College, Washington, D.C., will present "Arsenic and Old Lace."

TOLEDO, Ohio, April 12 -- The special for the best in show at the twentieth annual all-breed fixture of the Toledo Kennel Club tonight went to Champion Maro of Maridor, English setter, owned by Wilfred S. Kennedy of Walled Lake, Mich. James W. Trullinger of Pittsburgh judged.

Menu makers in these sober war days can find a way of contributing to victory in the list of food available to those whose limited budgets are supplemented by purchases under the stamp plan. For the list, carefully adjusted to the national food-for-freedom program, enumerates the supplies that are especially plentiful and on which we are all asked to concentrate.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (U.P.) -- General Milo Djukanovic of Yugoslavia was a beloved hero of many wars and campaigns in his mountainous homeland district of Montenegro, the Yugoslav legation said tonight. He was on his way from Capetown to the United States, where he hoped to rally Yugoslav-Americans into a Yugoslavian military unit to fight with Allied forces against the Axis in the Near East.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose from 104.8 to 105.4, a gain of 0.6 per cent on top of the previous week's rise of 1.0 per cent. The sharpest gain among the sub-groups was that of the hide and leather index, which rose by 2.8 per cent as a result of a rise in the price of shearlings.

NEW ORLEANS, April 12 -- Denials by officials of the Commodity Credit Corporation that a cotton pool will be formed now and announcement of a cessation of monthly offerings of government-owned stocks by the corporation with the sale in June bolstered sentiment last week in the cotton futures market here, as did also a flood of unfavorable crop reports.

Clara I. Austin of East Orange, N.J., chairman of the military recreation committee of the Dancing Masters of America, Inc., was elected president of the New York Society of Teachers of Dancing, Inc., at its meeting yesterday in the Hotel Astor.

ALBANY, April 12 -- Governor Lehman today announced his veto of the Hampton-Pillion bill, which would carry out the Republican plan to grant salary increases to all State employes receiving less than $2,000 a year to help them meet the rising costs of living, beginning in June, 1943.

Five new films are scheduled to open at Broadway theatres this week. The first to arrive is "Guerrilla Brigade," a Soviet drama dealing with guerrilla fighters in the Ukraine in the first World War, opening today at the Stanley Theatre.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The most emphatic recovery in land values since the low levels of the depression in 1933 was noted by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics today in a review of farm real estate in the twelve months to March 1.

Books on the war -- on its background, strategy, economics, geography, its long-term effects on a world eventually at peace -- come from the publishers in an ever-mounting tide. In addition to Stuart Chase's book published today and Joseph Newman's, next Friday will bring four new ones.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- L. Metcalfe Walling, Wage and Hour Administrator of the Department of Labor, announced today that a new study will be made of economic conditions within the railroad industry with a view to the recommending of new minimum wage scales, not however, to exceed 40 cents an hour.

JERUSALEM, April 12 -- Another step toward minimizing wartime profiteering was initiated by the Palestine Government today with the gazetting of new defense regulations applying control measures more strictly than hitherto.

SYDNEY, Australia, April 12 -- Our freighter was attacked 290 miles east of Honolulu early last December, a few days after America entered the war. A Jap submarine fired two torpedoes, both of which missed, then it came to the surface and attacked us with its guns.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 12 (AP) -- Richard T. Frankensteen, national director of aviation for the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., said tonight that aviation workers "are not betraying the defenders of Bataan" by seeking wage increases.

The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo will open a nine-day engagement tonight as part of S. Hurok's "Season of Ballet" at the Metropolitan Opera House. The program for the premiere will consist of three ballets by Leonide Massine, two of which were presented for the first time in the company's local season last Fall.

Possibly the most serious worry of the German General Staff at this time is the transport problem. The Nazis built up a marvelous network of motor highways, which are now practically deserted because of the shortage of gasoline. On the other hand, the Nazis never took proper care of the replacement of railroad equipment.

BOSTON, April 12 (U.P.) -- Fulfilling a boyhood desire to fly, 25-year-old George M. Orner, son of a Congregational missionary in British East Africa, enlisted in the Naval Air Corps yesterday after a 10,000-mile ocean trip broken by a ship torpedoing and two days adrift in a lifeboat.

Unfavorable weather hampered volume in coats, suits and dresses last week, although buyers continued to place orders for Summer merchandise and for wool styles suitable for early Fall selling, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buyers.
CAIRO, April 12 (AP) -- British Headquarters issued this communique today:

TOKYO, April 12 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Japanese heavy guns rolled up to position on Bataan Peninsula commanding a full view of Corregidor fortress today and poured a "withering" fire on the American stronghold in Manila Bay, as Japanese bombers roared overhead and added to the fury with tons of destructive missiles, Domei reported.

UNION CITY, N.J., April 12 -- The Rev. Conrad C. Eiben, producer and co-author of the passion play "Veronica's Veil," celebrated today his final mass as pastor of St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church here.
CANBERRA, April 12 (AP) -- An Australia communique issued today said:

Fierce resistance against Japanese landing forces on Cebu, and the gallant defense of Corregidor under plunging shell and bombs, cannot conceal the fact that the end of our fight to hold the Philippines is approaching. As yet, the enemy holds no more than half the great archipelago, but the attack on Cebu indicates that he is now ready to conquer the rest piecemeal.
SYDNEY, Australia, April 12 (AP) -- An Australian communique issued today follows:

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 12 -- The defense of parts of Northern Iran, Syria and Palestine soon will be largely entrusted to Polish forces now moving in from Russia, an informed United Nations source said today.

AT A UNITED NATIONS AIR BASE, Southwestern Pacific, April 12 -- Jerry Crosson, former New York policeman, who had his first go at the Japanese in a raid on Rabaul, New Britain, the other day, would very much enjoy a dinner at the Rainbow Room in Radio City.

The fight for the Philippines has come to mean much to the American people, and a depressed feeling swept the nation on the receipt of news of the fall of Bataan. While the capitulation of the small but stout Army of American and Philipino defenders was not unexpected, it brought home to the people of the United States the cost in human blood and wealth necessary in fighting a powerful enemy at such a distance.

It is not mere coincidence that on the day Sir Stafford Cripps departed from India, his mission a failure, the Germans launched their first air raid on the coasts of the Caucasus. The raid was only incidental to the fighting on the Kerch peninsula, the narrow neck of land stretching from the Crimea toward the Caucasian bridge.

An innovation in campaigns designed to tell the public of industry's participation in the war effort will be started in May issues of weekly and monthly magazines by Philco. Instead of the customary illustrations of war implements, copy will feature a series of noncommercial inspirational cartoons by leading editorial cartoonists relating to America's war efforts, including Rollin Kirby, Herbert Johnson, Rube Goldberg, C.E. Sykes, Arthur Szyk and Carl Rose.

Brookhattan gained the final of the Lewis Cup soccer competition by defeating the Philadelphia Americans, two corner kicks to one, in a thrilling overtime struggle at Starlight Park, the Bronx, yesterday, before a crowd of 5,000.

A special drive within a drive will begin throughout the five boroughs this morning, aimed at filling within a week New York's quota of 2,000,000 books toward the national total of 10,000,000 sought by the Victory Book Campaign.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- An Army officer just returned from Corregidor reported today that living on the Philippine fortress island was "like living on a bull's eye."
LONDON, April 12 (Reuter) -- A communique relating to the Chinese forces in Burma received in London today states:
ST. LOUIS, April 12 (AP) -- The Browns today nipped the Cardinals, 5 to 4, to square their annual two-game series. The victors counted all their runs in the first four innings.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- President Roosevelt tonight commended the United Service Organizations and expressed the hope that the nation would intensify its support of the program of "offering open-handed and open-hearted hospitality to members of the armed forces and war industrial workers."

VICHY, April 12 -- The foremost place in the preoccupations of the government has devolved upon the question of food supplies. Results of the last wheat crop had been satisfactory to the extent that the amount raised should have been sufficient to feed the population up to the time when the new crop could be harvested.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 12 -- A prominent German banker, whose name it is not permitted to divulge, has been visiting Stockholm since Tuesday. A report current in diplomatic circles today is to the effect that he has approached British officials here with offers scarcely distinguishable from those taken to Britain by Adolf Hitler's deputy, Rudolf Hess, eleven months ago.

KUIBYSHEV, April 12 -- Soviet forces have flooded the Germans out of a bitterly defended and strongly fortified village by changing the course of a stream swollen by thawing snows, frontline dispatches reported tonight.

Charity tempered by "justice and the merciful defense of the helpless millions in enslaved nations,'' should be the American motivation for war, Archbishop Francis J. Spellman declared yesterday in a sermon at solemn pontifical mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral, initiating the twenty-third annual appeal for Catholic Charities.

LONDON, April 12 (U.P.) -- Labor Minister Ernest Bevin said today, in the midst of a hurried series of American-British war strategy conferences, that the United Nations would take the offensive soon, backed by an overwhelming superiority in the air.

With the contest for the leadership of Tammany seemingly narrowed down to three candidates, Representative Michael J. Kennedy, former Representative James H. Fay and Dennis J. Mahon, supporters of each were active yesterday without any indication that there had been a break that would result in any one of them getting a majority at the Tammany executive committee meeting tomorrow.

Gimbel Brothers, Inc., had in the year ended on Jan. 31 net profits of $3,174,336, or $2.08 a common share, against $2,348,054 or $1.21 a share in the previous year, according to the annual report released today by Bernard F. Gimbel, president.

The War Labor Board has just made a very extraordinary decision. It has compelled the Walker-Turner Company of Plainfield, N.J., to accept a far-reaching maintenance-of-union-membership clause in its labor contract. In some respects this order of the board goes beyond anything it has previously done.

Representatives of four industries and a labor union will hold meetings today in an effort to intensify their work for the Greater New York Fund's campaign in behalf of its 400 voluntary welfare and health agencies.

AHWAZ, Iran, April 12 -- A British Tommy who a few weeks ago stood at the throttle of a locomotive plunging through home fogs and who is now operating a train in this distant land, today pointed out to the writer that several coaches as well as other railroad equipment were from French railways.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- Usually well-informed sources reported today that President Roosevelt would have an omnibus program for curbing inflation and dealing with other wartime economic problems ready for Congress by next week-end.

ALBANY, April 12 -- The three labor representatives on the State Unemployment Insurance Advisory Council renewed in a statement today their objection to the proposal of the six other council members, representing industry and the public that employes covered by the State's unemployment insurance law contribute 1 per cent of their wages to the fund.

Trial by disorganization is different from the trial by fire that our boys are experiencing -- and will experience -- yet it is just as devastating and, from the national viewpoint, still more serious. Lack of organization cuts at the very root of all defense effort. Without it the job to be done is infinitely more difficult.

To insist on certainty before beginning to live as a follower of Christ is to deny the nature of the Christian way of life, the Rev. Dr. Allan Knight Chalmers, pastor of the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, at Fifty-sixth Street, declared in a sermon yesterday.

Declaring that the forty-nine policemen named in the grand jury presentments revealing a $100,000,000 city-wide gambling racket had brought "shame" to him and his administration, Mayor La Guardia in his weekly broadcast yesterday sought to place part of the responsibility for police failure to enforce the gambling law on some magistrates and justices of special sessions.

Conditions governing the three automotive rations -- new cars, tires and gasoline -- appear still to be in an amorphous state. Beyond the undeniable shortages in automobile manufacturing space, rubber and tank ships, which gave rise to the controls on consumption, there are the infinite variables of interpretation and administration.

A decline of 1.9 per cent in 1941 passenger traffic in and out of New York City on railroads and ferries was shown in the annual report of the Transit Commission made public yesterday. The downward trend continued a decline of 5 per cent in the 1940 traffic compared with 1939.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 12 -- While, according to early information, Norwegian ministers were able to conduct religious services today without interference from Vidkun Quisling, it was reported later that the former dean of Oslo University, Professor Aarup Seip, together with fifty other prominent Norwegians in concentration camps at Grini, near Oslo, had been deported to Germany.

CARACAS, Venezuela, April 9 -- Development of a new sesame plant, bearing large quantities of oil, has been announced by the Venezuelan Ministry of Agriculture following several years of experimentation by Dr. Derald G. Langham of Vinton, Ohio, geneticist of the department.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 12 -- Hardly conceded much more than a fighting chance for second place at the start of today's final round, little Ben Hogan of Hershey, Pa., finished with a birdie 3 on the eighteenth hole of the Augusta National course to tie for first money with his former Texas buddy, Byron Nelson of Toledo, in the Masters' golf tournament.
LIVERMORE, Calif., April 12 -- Two huge Navy amphibian patrol bombers crashed in quick succession today in the cattle-grazing country south of Livermore, killing fourteen men and injuring one.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 12 (AP) -- The standings, virtually unmolested for a week, were shaken up at the American Bowling Congress tournament today as first place in three events passed into new hands and a half a dozen lesser changes were recorded.

Four new works were presented yesterday afternoon in Room 213 of the New York Public Library at the fourth young composers concert of the season sponsored by the League of Composers. All were serious and although Paul Schwartz's songs were not very interesting the other works had decided merit.

Angered by Police Commissioner Valentine's suspension of Inspector Camille C. Pierne and Lieutenant Terence J. Harvey after they had applied for retirement, the five organizations of members of the department were reported yesterday to have broken with the city administration.

LONDON, April 12 -- The stock markets here ended last week in a somewhat gloomy mood which was hardly surprising in view of the serious British naval losses in the Indian Ocean and the imminence of the breakdown of Sir Stafford Cripps's negotiations in India.

TRENTON, N.J., April 12 -- Planned moves to force immediate action on controversial proposals promised to enliven tomorrow's Assembly business, but Senate leaders said they planed a quiet routine session.

PITTSBURGH, April 12 -- Even though many steel companies must depend on a day-to-day supply of scrap and pig iron for maximum steel output, and even though problems in steel distribution were continuing to be more difficult, the steel industry last week was again shattering records previously made in steel production and finishing.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 12 --Again Berlin sources announced today that France is at the crossroads and that once and for all she must determine her attitude toward Germany. This time there are signs that the issue may be forced.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -The Senators pushed over two runs in the eighth to defeat the Phils, 4 to 2, today. Washington pounded three hurlers for nine blows, one of them a home run by Jimmy Vernon in the sixth.

Harry J. Fishbein of New York won the contract bridge masters' individual championship at the Park Central Hotel last night in a strong finish that permitted him to overcome the early lead that had been piled up by the country's leading women players, Mrs. R.C. Young of Philadelphia and Mrs. A.M. Sobel of New York.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 12 -- Arthur Knapp, with his Class B boat Prissy, and George Isdale, with the Class X craft Queen Mary, took the titles in the cold weather dinghy sailing regattas at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

CHUNGKING, China, April 12 (U.P.) -- The influential newspaper Ta Kung Pao, reflecting keen Chinese disappointment at the failure of Sir Stafford Cripps's mission in India, urged today that the United States and China participate in a "collective settlement" of the Indian problem7.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- The Federal Government is studying the problem of putting restrictions on the foreign-language press in the United States, it was learned today. The program has been under quiet discussion in the Justice and War Departments for several weeks, although no final decisions have been arrived at.

Graduating into the ranks of Broadway producers tonight is Max Liebman with "Autumn Hill," opening at the Booth. Having served an apprenticeship (mostly as a writer) in various theatrical enterprises which increased his knowledge of show business, Mr. Liebman is not exactly a newcomer to Broadway.

Playing a purely defensive game against a correct development of pieces by Matthew Green of the Marshall Chess Club in a Ruy Lopes, Samuel Reshevsky of Boston, defending champion, drew his match in the third round of the championship tournament of the United States Chess Federation at the Hotel Astor yesterday.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 12 -- Lieut. Gen. H. Gordon Bennett, now commanding an army corps in Australia, said today in discussing the fall of Singapore that Lieut. Gen. Arthur E. Percival, who surrendered the base, had been unjustly maligned.

Many young women headed by Miss Macy Ann Reilly have assisted in the sale of tickets for the performance of the circus at Madison Square Garden today for the benefit of the Carroll Club of New York. Mrs. Basil Harris, president of the club, heads the executive committee for the benefit.

Bullets whistled near Tenth Avenue yesterday morning, churchgoers screamed, and children playing in the street ducked into doorways. Finally Patrolman Michael Higgins collared his man, a prisoner who had escaped by jumping out of a hospital window, and the prisoner, James Larosees, plaintively murmured:

Brody From sold to the 2506 Davidson Avenue Realty Corporation the six-story apartment house for forty-two families at 2506 Davidson Avenue, near 190th Street, in the Bronx, through Quinto Herbst and William M. Jeremias, brokers.

BOSTON, April 12 (Wide World) -- A plan to establish a post-war "world equilibrium" designed to eliminate all future wars has been reported to the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, oldest organization of its kind in the country.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 12 -- Administrative preparations for war in a progressive New England town are emphasized in the fifth annual supplement to the annual report being mailed to every taxpayer of this community.

LONDON, April 12 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, was 110.3 on March 31, compared with 1l0.3 a fortnight and a month before, 104.3 a year ago and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

A defendant in a bootleg ring, more terrified of the law than of surgery, was resting comfortably yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital after, it was charged, he had "high-pressured" doctors into arranging an immediate operation that revealed "nothing of an emergency nature" but forced a halt to his trial.

Many young persons of the parish of St. James Episcopal Church will take part in the entertainment which will be one of the features of the church's annual Spring Festival to be held on the afternoon of April 24 in the main ballroom suite of the Plaza for the benefit of the children of the United Nations.
MOSCOW, April 12 (From Russian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Bureau of Information communique today follows:

A survey conducted at Bellevue Hospital in the campaign to enlist and train 10,000 women to serve as volunteer nurses' aides has disclosed that women between the ages of 30 and 50 are best equipped to fill the posts, it was announced yesterday at the end of the first week of the drive.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Manufacturing, mining and railroad companies harvested substantially higher profits in 1941 than in 1940, even after paying all costs, charges and taxes, and they retained a substantial portion of them as dividend payments increased less than net income, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 12 -- Conquest is not synonymous with riches, says the Osservatore Romano, the Vatican newspaper, in the issue received here today, in another of its series of articles on principles for the erection of a "real new order" in the world.
CHICAGO, April 12 (AP) -- The White Sox defeated the Cubs, 4 to 3, today to conclude the crosscountry city series with an edge of six victories to five.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 12 -The Hungarian Chief of Staff, Lieutenant Field Marshal Franz Szombathelyi, is expected in Rome late tonight on an official visit to his Italian opposite number, General Ugo Cavallero, reportedly for discussions in view of getting the Italian Government's mediation in Berlin for a lightening of the German demands on Hungary and a modification of the German attitude in the present Hungarian-Rumanian conflict.
The annual report of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., and its subsidiary companies, issued for publication today by Jack I. Straus, president, shows the highest sales in the history of the corporation.

BERLIN, April 12 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Four ships were damaged yesterday in a German dive-bomber attack on a strongly protected United Nations convoy in Arctic waters, the Germans reported today.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The War Production Board today issued an interpretation of its order restricting production of phonographs and weighing and amusement machines.

America wants no return to "normalcy" as a result of the war, but needs today as never before dreamers who will stand witness to the American dream and think far beyond ways of smashing the Callahan, the new pastor, declared yesterday in a sermon at the Methodist Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.

BOSTON, April 12 (AP) -- Rookie Johnny Pesky, the youngster Manager Joe Cronin of the Red Sox brought up to take his place at shortstop, made four errors today as the Braves took the only game in the Spring city series, 7 to 5, at Fenway Park.

Although there is no satisfactory explanation for it, no fashioner of handiwork in the home is so little appreciated as the writer. We have recently witnessed an illustration of this in the comments made by Mrs. Ellen Proctor, 31-year-old wife of a Minneapolis shoe-store manager, when she came to New York to receive a check for $10,000 as winner of the 1942 Redbook Magazine-Dodd, Mead novel contest.

Councilman Stanley M. Isaacs announced yesterday that, on the basis of a letter he had received from James M. Landis, National Director of Civilian Defense, he would ask the Council's committee on defense to act favorably at its meeting Wednesday on his air raid fire equipment bill in its amended form.

Dismissing fears that the war may cause revolutionary changes in our social and economic structure, Professor Wesley C. Mitchell, director of research of the National Bureau of Economic Research, ventured a forecast yesterday of the economic problems of the post-war era.

CHUNGKING, China, April 12 -- More than a million Chinese refugees, approximately one-eighth of the total Chinese population in Southern Asia and the Southwestern Pacific, are trekking back to China from areas invaded or threatened by the Japanese.
The Navy released its own "food column" yesterday with some mouth-watering statistics about menu items transported to the fighting men overseas.

Outstanding obligations of local housing authorities are not included in the Treasury Department's recommendation that interest on outstanding State and local obligations should be subjected to Federal income taxes, the Treasury Department stated in a recent letter to Lehman Brothers.

On March 20 THE TIMES carried a story by Nona Baldwin on the nationwide campaign to collect fats from American kitchens to be sent to processing plants in order to increase our supply of glycerine needed for war purposes.

Columbia and Cornell played their inaugural Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League game yesterday at Baker Field, with Andy Coakley's Lions recording a mild upset in the form of a 3-2 victory over the Ithacans.

Thomas J.
