Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation, has asked the company's directors to modify his employment contract so that his profit-sharing compensation is reduced to 2 1/2 per cent from 5 per cent, retroactive to 1941, and to exclude therefrom any profit from manufacture of munitions.
With the deadline tomorrow, 10,000 State income tax returns were filed yesterday at the State Income Tax Bureau, 80 Centre Street.

LONDON, April 13 -- Lord Louis Mountbatten, second cousin of King George, has been appointed chief of combined operations of the British Army, Navy and Royal Air Force, Prime Minister Churchill announced in the House of Commons today.

The Modern Industrial Bank soon will move its Graham Avenue, Brooklyn, branch banking office into the former quarters of the World Exchange Bank, at 815 Broadway, on the corner of Ellery Street, in that borough. The new office will occupy the entire banking floor and basement, which originally was constructed for use by the latter institution.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 13 -In a strongly worded note to the Vichy government last Friday the Germans are today reported to have set as a deadline Thursday of ti.q week for a "comprehensive answer," clarifying that government's attitude toward complete cooperation -- immediately and unequivocally.

THE TIMES editorial of April 4 on the attitude of New Jersey legislators toward Governor Edison's nomination of Spencer Miller Jr. to be Commissioner of Highways brings out a point of grave significance. It is the danger to the nation's war effort from sabotage by politicians "intent upon pie."

The annual report of Southeastern-Greyhound Lines and its subsidiaries, issued yesterday by Guy A. Huguelet, president, showed for 1941 a consolidated net income of $797,938, equal, after preferred dividend payments, to $3.76 each on 199,840 common shares outstanding prior to the acquisition on Dec. 31 of the union Bus Company and Dixie Coaches, Inc.

In an all-cash deal negotiated by H. Stanley Hillyer, Inc., and Murray Klein, the six-story elevator apartment house at 421 West Twenty-first Street has been sold by the Straight Improvement Company for investment to the Landscape Realty Company, Julius Heiman, president.

The waterfront estate on Center Island, Oyster Bay, L.I., formerly owned by P. Russell Brown, has been sold to William T. Moore of the Moore-McCormack Lines, Inc. The property includes an eight-room house and a guest cottage with three acres of land fronting on Oyster Bay.

Charlie (Lulu) Costantino, 128 1/2, East Side, remained unbeaten in fifty-five professional boxing starts by outpointing Harry Jeffra, 127, Baltimore, former world featherweight titleholder, in a fierce eight-round main bout last night at the St. Nicholas Palace.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 13 -- The prepared text of the address by Emil Schram, president of the New York stock Exchange, before the Nashville Chamber of Commerce here tonight was as follows:

The Mayor's appointment of Deputy Police Commissioner John H. Morris to be full-time director of the Air Raid Warden service, and of Assistant Chief Inspector Arthur W. Wallander to be civilian defense aide and coordinator, ties at least two knots in our loosely woven defense system, Mr. Morris will have the aid of a full-time police officer in each precinct.

The entire question of police pensions, a departmental sore spot since the start of the war, moved closer to the explosive point yesterday when it was learned that the 17,500 members of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association had voted almost unanimously to reject the recent request of Mayor La Guardia for a stagger system of retirements that would limit them to forty a month.

In line with plans of the Treasury to obtain a pledge from every regularly employed person in the United States to purchase war savings bonds regularly, the New York Defense Savings Staff soon will announce a one-week campaign seeking to reach every regular receiver of income in the State.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Relocation and extension of pipe lines to provide for a greatly increased overland movement of oil to the Eastern States, where shortages have developed because of diversion and loss at sea of tankers, will be undertaken at once under an emergency program announced today by Secretary Ickes, Petroleum Coordinator.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The American flag will appear in colors on the covers of more magazines published between June 25 and July 4 than in any comparable period in history, the United States Flag Association said today. Virtually every leading magazine and scores are the lesser ones will use the flag as their cover design in issues appearing during that period.

It is essential to maintain in good shape as much as possible of the 3,000,000 miles of highway in the United States. Movement of military vehicles, vital commercial traffic, trucking to defense plants and constant travel of passenger cars on essential errands all require a road system at its peak of effecient condition.

Representative Michael J. Kennedy took a commanding lead last night in the contest for the leadership of Tammany Hall when former Representative James H. Fay withdrew from the race in his favor. The coalition, negotiated at a conference lasting almost four hours, apparently assured Mr. Kennedy of more than a majority of the votes in the Tammany executive committee.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Two freighters of the Army Transport Service have been lost in Far Eastern waters as a result of enemy action, the War Department announced today. They were the Liberty and the Meigs.
TOKYO, April 13 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Imperial Head quarters, reviewing Japanese operations in the Indian Ocean, said today:

NEWARK, April 13 -- Operating difficulties that threatened to halt vital war output have been overcome in several local shops by the recently inaugurated free technical advisory service for war plants in Northern New Jersey, sponsored by the New Jersey Chapter of the American Society for Metals, according to John F. Wyzalek of the Hyatt Bearings Division, General Motors Corporation, Harrison, N.J., chairman of the advisory service.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 13 (U.P.) -- Russian shock troops have driven a spearhead twenty-one miles through the German lines southwest of Moscow and weathered fierce counter-attacks that "failed to remove the Soviet threat to a large city stronghold," the Army newspaper Red Star reported tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- President Roosevelt's visitors included Secretary Perkins, Juan Trippe and William H. Davis. He nominated Harry T. Foley of Yonkers for reappointment as surveyor of customs in New York.

Wanted! Two hundred college and high school girls who are not afraid of getting up at 5 in the morning. They are required for work on New York farms whose owners have suddenly been faced with the alternative of hiring feminine labor and under-draft-age boys or leaving the fruit to rot on trees and bushes.

Discussing the war emergency bill, now in the Assembly, Lieut. Gov. Charles Poletti, at a luncheon yesterday in the Empire State Club, declared that the office of local director of civilian protection under the State War Council should be filled by civilians on a full-time basis and not by the Mayors of the communities.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Senator Wagner has had a long illness, but there was a pleasant note of restored health in his quip at the White House the other day. Asked for his views on inflation, he answered "I'm against it." If the Senator had intended this as a satirical comment on the administration's anti-inflation record, which of course he did not, he couldn't have made a more penetrating comment.

Two-thirds of Brooklyn -- about fifty-four square miles with a population of more than two millions -- will be blacked out from 9 to 9:20 o'clock tonight in the widest test of the kind to date in the city.

Scoring his third victory in succession in his adjourned game from the second round with I.A. Horowitz at the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday, Isaac I. Kashdan took the lead in the championship tournament of the United States Chess Federation.
BERLIN, April 13 (Recorded by The Associated Press from German broadcasts) -- The German High Command communique said today:

ALBANY, April 13 -- The Assembly passed tonight, 140 to 1, the main State defense bill, creating a State war council, as the introduction of a supplemental defense bill revealed that the State is counting on the Federal Government to pay for the care and feeding of the distressed in and from bombed areas.
MELBOURNE, Australia, April 13 (AP) -- Prime Minister John Curtin issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The right of local governments, in this instance New York City, to prohibit the commercial advertising through the distribution of handbills on city streets, was upheld by the Supreme Court today in a unanimous opinion written by Justice Roberts.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Ten army officers and six enlisted men have received decorations from the War Department for "extraordinary achievement while participating in an aerial flight" from Washington to a town in Great Britain in July, 1941, the War Department said today.

CHICAGO, April 13 -- Machine tool builders must do what seems impossible, get and hold 168-hour operation, George H. Johnson, president, declared at the annual convention of the National Machine Tool Builders Association which opened here today at the Edgewater Beach Hotel.

Today is Pan-American Day. It occurs under circumstances too astounding to have been foreseen at any of the previous celebrations. A year ago President Roosevelt addressed words of defiance to the Axis Powers and accompanied them with an appeal for closer cooperation among the republics of the Western Hemisphere.

Contradicting reports of a razor blade shortage, more than 140 newspapers in selected areas will be used in a twenty-six-week campaign by Treet Safety Razor Corporation to advertise Treet single-edge blades. Humorous cartoons will illustrate copy in which the central theme, "Maybe You're Missing Something," will be highlighted.

UTICA, N.Y., April 13 -- Every bottle of milk coming into New York City will bear a union label if the Dairy Farmers Union gets the strength it expects from its affiliation with John L. Lewis's United Mine Workers of America.

TOKYO, April 13 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Imperial Headquarters said today in a review of last week's air and naval operations that 120 British planes had been destroyed or set afire and more than sixty ships sunk or damaged in the Bay of Bengal from April 5 to 9.

LONDON, April 13 -- A Japanese fleet of at least three battleships -- one of them of the modernized Nagato type, which has 16-inch guns -- five aircraft carriers, a number of heavy and light cruisers and destroyer flotillas has been operating in the Bay of Bengal since April 4, Prime Minister Winston Churchill told the House of Commons today.

Japan's apparent concentration on the invasion of India by land and sea has persuaded some observers that she intends to ignore Australia. A month ago, after the enemy had overrun Java, an invasion of Australia seemed imminent. At this moment it seems less likely.

The city of Norfolk, Va., will be in the market on April 21 with an issue of $3,500,000 of water and general improvement bonds for which bidders are asked to specify a rate of interest not exceeding 3 per cent. The bonds, dated May 1, 1942, will mature serially from 1943 to 1967.

AT A UNITED NATIONS AIR BASE, Southwestern Pacific, April 13 -- Australian and American planes bombed Lae, Northeast New Guinea, again this morning in a continuation of their heavy air attacks in this area. United Nations fighters escorted the attacking bombers, and all the planes returned safely.

BERLIN, April 13 (from German broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- The official D.N.B. news agency said today in a Rome dispatch that Egyptian Nationalists killed five persons, including three British soldiers, and wounded the Egyptian Foreign Minister, in four simultaneous attacks throughout Cairo on Saturday.

I do not think the civilian population fully realizes what is being done for the men of the armed services by the United Service Organization and its ascsociated agencies. My own civilian friends are surprised when I tell them of the kindnesses and attention given us by these fine groups and of how much we appreciate what is done for us.
LONDON, April 13 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique tonight:

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- The Navy announced tonight that Rear Admiral Claude C. Bloch, commandant of the Fourteenth Naval District at Honolulu, had been ordered to duty of an unannounced nature in the office of Secretary Knox here.
ROME, April 13 (From Italian broadcast recorded by The United Press in New York) -- Today's High Command communique said that a submarine chaser had sunk a British submarine in the Mediterranean.

Two authoritative voices have reassured Americans about the future of their historic institutions; provided, of course, we win the war. In the field of economic theory, very few scholars command greater respect than Wesley C. Mitchell of Columbia University and the National Bureau of Economic Research.

New dispatches from Washington which indicated plainly that the government was ready to institute a program for inflation control supplied another problem for the stock market and as a result activity was limited yesterday to a bare minimum and prices drifted narrowly.

Serious consideration must be given to the advisability of concentrating civilian goods production in a few plants of an industry and converting the balance entirely to war work, David Ginsburg, general counsel to the Office of Price Administration, declared yesterday at the afternoon session of a one-day "war conference" of the Controllers Institute of America.

The President is said to be considering new and more drastic methods of solving the problem of inflation. That problem cannot be solved until we remove the basic causes of inflation. This should be axiomatic. Yet the whole secret of the Administration's failure thus far to solve the problem is that it has refused to face squarely the causes of inflation and has tried to cure mainly the mere symptoms of inflation.
The estate known as The Lindens, comprising a twenty-three-room dwelling with five acres of land on Rumson Road and Buena Vista Avenue, Rumson, N.J., has been sold to Victor H. Lindlahr.

The Horace Mann High School for Girls, now at 120th Street and Broadway, will be transferred from its present building to the Lincoln School Building on 123d Street near Amsterdam Avenue in time for the next school year.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended April 8: Increases of $365,000,000 in holding of Treasury bills, $602,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and $98,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and decreases of $102,000,000 in balances with domestic banks and $149,000,000 in United States Government deposits.

ABOARD AN AMERICAN TRANSPORT, in the Pacific, April -- (Reuter) -- British ships are playing an important part in helping America to deliver men and materiel in convoys to war points in the Pacific. From the decks of this crowded American transport it is good to see a British ship riding along in close company -- a convincing illustration of Anglo-American teamwork.
CHUNGKING, China, April 13 -- The situation in Burma is critical, with the Japanese desperately striving to drive a wedge between the British and Chinese sectors.

AT A UNITED NATIONS AIR BASE, Southwestern Pacific, April 13 -- William J. Westland, a Brooklyn boy who, in his own words, is "going on 20" and who is a graduate of Public School 238, told today how he had shot down a Japanese Zero fighter over Rabaul, New Britain, while on his first real war mission.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Warned that the burlap situation had reached a point where further allocations of the material for use in floor coverings is improbable, rug and carpet manufacturers have been advised by the War Production Board to investigate the possibility of using their stocks of carpet wool into the production of blankets and of apparel.

PRINCETOH, N.J., April 13 -- Princeton's varsity baseball team suffered its second setback of the season today as the Newark Bears of the International League combined eleven hits with five Tiger errors to give the collegians a 12-0 drubbing in an exhibition game on University Field.

Pledged to carry on in the traditional manner, professional baseball today will launch another major league championship campaign -- the sixty-seventh without interruption for the National circuit; the forty-second for the American.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Although the Japanese continue to pound relentlessly from air and land the last strongholds of Lieut. Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright's depleted American and Filipino forces in the Philippines, the War Department announced in two communiques issued here today, they continue not only to hold out but also to inflict serious damage on the Japanese.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- A plan of reorganization of the bankrupt Florida East Coast Railway Company that would reduce its capitalization from $95,616,000 to $37,000,000 was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
I am very much aroused about the proposed closing of the Townsend Harris High School this coming August.

Twenty-seven contract bridge teams of four began their annual contest for the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup at the Hotel Pierre last night. The tournament, which is for the national team-of-four championship, will continue through Saturday.

LONDON, April 13 -- Asserting he had not lost hope that the people of India would one day come to an agreement with Britain on the terms of their freedom, Sir Stafford Cripps told newspaper interviewers at Karachi, India, today he accepted all blame for the failure of the India talks himself.
WEST POINT, N.Y., April 13 -- Idle since last Tuesday, the Giants today sharpened their batting eyes while prolonging their baseball mastery over the Military Academy cadets.
The difficulties of waging war with allies have been emphasized by recent reports from Britain and Australia.

TOKYO, April 13 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York and San Francisco) -- Three American planes have attempted unsuccessfully to bomb Manila suburbs, the Domei agency asserted today as Imperial Headquarters announced the appointment of Lieut. Gen. Masaharu Homma as Commander in Chief of all Japanese expeditionary forces in the Philippines.

The Tide Water Associated Oil Company yesterday reported for 1941 a consolidated net income of $12,817,613 after all charges, taxes, reserves for depreciation and depletion and net charges of $2,746,780 for appropriations for post-war adjustments, losses in the Philippines and other items.

Six more ships of the United Nations have been sunk by enemy submarines operating on the western side of the Atlantic, it became known yesterday. This was the largest toll that has yet been revealed in a single day since the submarine warfare began three months ago, although the actual sinkings were spaced over a period of about a week.

EVERYTHING is set for the baseball openings. Except the weather. It is hoped that the Weather Man will cooperate. He was courteous last year. Only one game was rained out. That was in St. Louis, where the Browns had to wait one more day to get at Bobo Newsom, who had been picked to wheel the ball down the alley for the Tigers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 13 -- Universal today signed Ilona Massey and Jon Hall to play the leading roles in "The Invisible Spy," the last Frank Lloyd-Jack Skirball production for the studio, which will go before the cameras April 27 with Edwin L. Marin directing.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 13 -- Playing golf that at times was almost cruel in its perfection, Byron Nelson, 30-year-old Texan, today annexed top honors in the Masters' tournament for the second time.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended April 8 aggregated $9,507,000,000.

The Theatre Guild will present "Yesterday's Magic," a new play by Emlyn Williams author of "Night Must Fall" and "The Corn Is Green," at the Guild Theatre tonight. Paul Muni, last seen on Broadway in "Key Largo" in 1940 and best remembered for his performance in "Counsellor-at-Law" in 1931, will have the leading role of Maddoc Thomas, a battered and boozy actor who has seen definitely better days.

WASHINGTON, April 13 --Representative O'Connor of Montana, telling the House today that the nation's capital was a city "overflowing with pleasure seekers," urged that it be declared a war zone and barred to those not directly connected with the war effort, the government or essential business.
DOVER, N.J., April 13 -- As dismissal bell signaled "school's out" at the high school here today, 900 pupils filed outdoors, most of them headed not for fun or further study but for work.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 13 -- Better understanding of the school as an institution in the community will help in the solution of postwar problems, Dr. Edmund Des Brunner, Professor of Education in Teachers College, Columbia University, said today in addressing the opening session of the annual institute for parent teacher leaders at Cornell University.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 13 (AP) -- The puppet Premier of Norway, Vidkun Quisling, has taken over personal direction of churches in that country after failing to force the rebellious clergy to resume the pulpits from which they resigned in mass a week ago, reports reaching here said today.

Essential oils for the drug and cosmetic trades, which were formerly imported, are now being successfully replaced by home-produced oils in many instances, Percy C. Magnus, president of the New York Board of Trade and head of Magnus, Mabee Reynard, said yesterday at the annual convention of the Affiliated Drug Stores at the Hotel Biltmore.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md. April 13 (AP) -- Alsab flashed a sign of his old championship form today as he finished a bang-up second to R. Sterling Clark's Colchis in the Chesapeake Trial on opening day here before a crowd of 12,000.

Fordham's baseball nine took the lead in the Metropolitan Baseball Conference race yesterday with an easy 5-0 victory over City College on the Rose Hill diamond. It was the undefeated Maroon team's third straight conference triumph and its fourth of the season.

Robert L. Stott, chairman of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange, has been renominated to that office for a further term of one year, according to a slate for the annual election on May 11 made public yesterday.

Union of the Presbyterian and Protestant Episcopal churches received impetus yesterday, when the New York Presbytery approved unanimously a proposal for joint ordination. The action was taken at the annual meeting, held at the Fifth Avenue Church Parish House, 7 West Fifty-fifth Street.

Arranged as a benefit for Belgian sailors with the Allied fleets, the Flemish Primitives exhibition opened with a private view yesterday afternoon at the Knoedler Galleries, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street. It opens to the public today. Admission at the preview was $2.20 and to the public it will be 55 cents.

Consecrating a new permanent altar in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning, Archbishop Francis J. Spellman named the white marble statue of the Blessed Virgin that surmounts the altar "Our Lady of New York."

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Highway officials and representatives of automobile and trucking groups urged the Ways and Means Committee today to refrain from increasing the Federal motor fuel tax and leave that field of revenue open to the States.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 13 -- Miss Martha Lord Miller, who made her first transcontinental journeys by stagecoach and became an aviation enthusiast at the age of 98, celebrated her 106th birthday today at her home here by reading Longfellow poems to a group of twenty-five friends and cutting a cake that bore one giant candle and six of smaller size.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 13 -- The national debt may eventually reach $200,000,000,000, but "the American system is quite equal to any burden which it may have to carry," Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, said here tonight.

Ten industrial concerns, working on Government contracts for materials to be used in this war for democracy, have been ordered by the President's Committee on Fair Employment to "revoke all discriminatory orders submitted to employment agencies and desist from submitting any further discriminatory specifications to any employment agency."

Asserting that property owners here are confronted with a loss in rentals estimated at more than $50,000,000 per year from retail stores because of WPB restrictions on the production of durable goods, Thomas H. Doyle, president of the Midtown Real Estate Association, urged yesterday a cut of at least $20,000,000 in the city's 1942-43 budget.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 13 (AP) -- Babe Ruth got out of his hospital bed long enough today to receive a few visitors and voice two predictions about the major league baseball campaign -- one of them a surprise.

In an effort to learn what proportion of loans by banks is going to war industries and the nature of the borrowing according to industries and size of the borrowing concerns, Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, has asked every bank in the Second Federal Reserve District to make available detailed information on its commercial loans, it was learned yesterday.

The lowly office boy, whom tradition has pictured as a specialist in either remembering the batting averages of the Dodgers or taking his time in returning to the office, is coming into his own, thanks to a shortage of boy power.

TRENTON, N.J., April 13 -- Efforts of Assemblyman John Warhol Jr. of Bergen to create a three-member State Highway Commission in place of a single commissioner received a setback today when the Republican majority in the House of Assembly rejected in caucus his bill setting up the bipartisan body.

Immediate opening of a Western front to relieve Spring pressure on Russia was urged last night by Dr. Hewlett Johnson, dean of Canterbury, speaking from England by transatlantic telephone to a victory meeting and Te Deum at Carnegie Hall, arranged as a celebration of the successes of the Soviet Army.

LONDON, April 13 -- The war news from Burma with the breakdown of negotiations with India and the nearness of the budget kept the stock markets quiet today. Gilt edge issues where changed at all were fractionally better. Home rails showed little change.

Declaring that the radio seemed to be his only medium of announcing important events to the people of New York City, Mayor La Guardia went on the air three times yesterday with defense announcements, but made sure that every newspaper received a verbatim text of his afternoon talk for publication in the press.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- An over-all anti-inflationary program, which will comprise higher taxes, a broader price ceiling, possibly reinforced by rationing, limitation of profits and probably stabilization of wage levels, will be presented to Congress by President Roosevelt within the next two weeks.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Supreme Court decided today that the greater part of trusts of many million dollars set up for the benefit of the late Zachary Smith Reynolds, tobacco fortune heir, could not be included in his estate for taxation purposes, but left unsettled the fate of other millions which he had willed from the trusts to his brother and sisters.

An appeal to the public as well as to theatre operators to resist the proposed modified form of block booking and blind selling of films advocated by the United Motion Picture Industry was issued yesterday in Hollywood by a powerful group of independent producers, including Charles Chaplin, Samuel Goldwyn, David O. Selznick, Walt Disney, Alexander Korda, Mary Pickford, Orson Welles and Walter Wanger.

Mrs. Johanna M. Lindlof, only woman member of the Board of Education, was the official hostess yesterday at a reception in the hall of the board, 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn, formally opening a week-long program to mark the 100th anniversary of the founding of the board.

Some of the disastrous effects of an effort to bring the benefits of science to the narcotics racket here were revealed in Federal court yesterday when Dr. John E. Jackson admitted that he had served as research expert in the affair.

A new peak in net proceeds of national infantile paralysis campaigns connected with President Roosevelt's birthdays was set this year by the diamond jubilee birthday celebration, it was announced yesterday by Keith Morgan, national chairman of the Committee for the Celebration of the President's Birthday for the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

ALBANY, April 13 -- Both Houses of the Legislature worked late tonight on their calendars, as they entered what is scheduled to be their next to last week, and also what is to be a full working week. They passed a number of measures of the "must" variety.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Farm leaders will begin an offensive against John L. Lewis's campaign to organize dairy farmers next Friday when they will appear before a House Judiciary committee.

Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen, who has spent eleven months with two grand juries investigating alleged police protection of a $100,000,000 gambling syndicate, declared yesterday that lenient court sentences in gambling cases encourage policemen to regard bribes in such cases as matters of little consequence.

As officials of the Victory Book campaign repeated yesterday the purposes and goals of the drive, reminding civilians of the great demand for good reading in all branches of the nation's armed services, evidence was received that the three-month-old drive was being pressed with renewed activity toward its goal of 10,000,000 books.
PAWHUSKA, Okla., April 13 (AP) -- Miss Lorene Squire, 32, one of America's foremost photographers of wild life, suffered fatal injuries yesterday in a motor-car accident. Her home was at Harper, Kan.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- The Supreme Court upheld today a lower court decision declaring that under New York State law a false accusation of racial intolerance against a public official was libelous per se.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., April 13 -- Colonel Eddie Rickenbacker, World War ace, declared here today that the United States needed at least 300,000 pilots to achieve victory and that the war would last five years and possibly ten. He spoke to several hundred members of combat air units in a discussion of aerial combat psychology in the post gymnasium.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- A War Department communique based on reports received here up to 9:30 A.M. said:

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- James M. Landis, Director of the Office of Civilian Defense, asserted tonight that his agency had been so speedy in attempting to supply items for civilian defense that it actually had ordered $20,000,000 of gas masks before a "clearance order" had been received from the Bureau of the Budget, "because we did not know any better."

The Macbeth Gallery, 11 East Fifty-seventh Street, opened yesterday an exhibition celebrating its fiftieth anniversary. This establishment was founded in 1892 by William Macbeth, the first address being 237 Fifth Avenue. William Macbeth died in the Summer of 1917 and the management of the gallery was taken over by his son.

SINCE every generation must establish its own working relationships with the past, it is idle to suppose that "definitive" biographies can ever be written about truly great men. Certainly no single book could ever contain the whole truth about such a protean character as Thomas Jefferson, frontiersman, lawyer, architect, agriculturist, classicist, revolutionary pamphleteer, diplomat, statesman, backroom politician, father, philosopher, democrat, inventor, and, yes, smuggler.

In yesterday's paper a dwarf dispatch from London must have given a pleasant fillip to the memory of every A.E.F. lad that read it. It said that next Saturday The Stars and Stripes, "founded by the first A.E.F. in France," will resume publication. Its first number appeared in France Friday, Feb. 8, 1918.
KUISBYSHEV, Russia, April 13 -- The text of the warning to Japan published today in the official Communist newspaper Pravda follows:
Until Pearl Harbor there wasn't a topic that could arouse salt-water fishermen to action as quickly as an argument concerning striped bass legislation.

In the third of a series of panel discussions on the general theme, "The Child in Wartime," Dr. Frank J. O'Brien, Associate Superintendent of Schools, will lead and direct the participants tomorrow evening at The New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, where the topic, "The Child at School," is scheduled for presentation.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Mills Novelty Company of Chicago, producers of "Panorams," coin-operated machines which show motion pictures accompanied by music, today was penalized by the War Production Board for alleged violation of wartime priority orders.

A Kentucky Derby eligible and a veteran jockey shared the limelight at Jamaica yesterday as New York's racing season swung into its first full week. The first sunshine of the session brought out a crowd of 16,834 that saw Don Meade boot Louis Lee Haggin 2d's Derby prospect Air Current home handsomely in the Boniface Purse and then round out his second triple of the meeting in the last two races.

A Canadian company has come to the rescue of those Americans who argue that breakfast is hardly breakfast without English marmalade to spread on their toast. This concern is now shipping sturdy glass jars filled with a special sort or orange marmalade, comparable in many ways to the British variety that is becoming increasingly hard to find in these parts.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Production of cargo ships, now admittedly the biggest of the war bottlenecks, must be stepped up 13 per cent more, with steel being supplied accordingly, if the 8,000,000-ton goal set by the President in January for this year is to be reached, Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the Maritime Commission, told the House Naval Affairs Committee today.

The National Sugar Refining Company has been awarded a tax refund of $1,500,000 from the Treasury Department in settlement against an original sugar processing tax, declared unconstitutional by the United States Supreme Court, it was announced at the annual meeting in Edgewater, N.J., yesterday.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 13 -- Mighty Russia, with hundreds of deadly bombers and submarines 680 miles from Tokyo, sternly warned Japan today to observe strictly their year-old neutrality pact despite the "prattle" of Japanese military leaders about a war in Soviet Siberia.

Seeking to clear up "misrepresentation" about the city's air raid signals, Mayor La Guardia warbled his own versions of what the alarm and the all-clear sounded like during an interview over WEAF with H.V. Kaltenborn at 6:15 last evening.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week showed a decline of 15 per cent under the calendar week a year ago, which, however, included the wind-up of Easter trade in 1941, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

While the bright lights of Times Square and adjacent midtown amusement areas are proving the mecca for thousands of new visitors, mostly service men of the United Nations and their families and friends, who have poured in increasing numbers into New York during the last month, the more scenic and educational landmarks of the city by no means have been neglected, a survey disclosed yesterday.

HONOLULU, April 13 -- Four officers and five enlisted men of the Hawaiian Air Force received the Distinguished Flying Cross at Hickam Field this morning for performing a hazardous photographic mission over Japanese territory.

LEXINGTON, Ky.; April 13 -- Counsel for Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation declined today to agree to a government request that testimony taken in the Federal Court trial of the New York utilities-holding company on civil anti-trust charges be made a part of the record in the anti-trust case pending against Columbia in Delaware.

The financial community is prepared for the secondary distribution of one of the largest blocks of common stocks of an industrial corporation in many months. A large underwriting group headed by Clark, Dodge Co. and the Lee Higginson Corporation is hopeful that the offering of not to exceed 225,000 shares of International Harvester Company common may be made after the close of the market today.

CHUNGKING, April 13 (U.P.) -- American Volunteer Group fliers have shot down or damaged at least thirty-five Japanese planes since roaring back into the thick of the battle for Burma last Wednesday, after having been kept out of action because of a shortage of ammunition and other supplies, it was disclosed tonight.

A further sharp decline in the volume of bankers' acceptances outstanding in the United States occurred in March, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday in its monthly survey of the trade acceptance market. The decline in March was $7,335,000, reducing the total of these bills outstanding to $182,675,000, reflecting declines in the nation's import trade financed through the banks as well as a further decline in export business.

Frederique Petrides's Orchestrette of New York completed its ninth season last night at Carnegie Chamber Music Hall with its third New York concert. As in the past, the program was divided between classic works and modern novelties, and the small hall was filled.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 13 (AP) -- The two American airmen had never taken up a Flying Fortress before. But they patched this one up from the parts of three damaged ones -- then had to do the job over because the Japanese attacked the airport and sent bullets through the carburetor and magneto.

Ending the confusion that had existed about the draft status of Pete Reiser, the Dodgers' center fielder and National League batting champion, New York Selective Service officials said yesterday through The Associated Press that he had been reclassified but that his parents had appealed.

LONDON, April 13 -- The British Government has decided that luxurious meals in night clubs and at bottle parties must come to an end, and is bringing in an order banning the serving of meals after 11 P.M. except to hotel residents and at places catering to night workers.

The second chapter of S. Hurok's "Season of Ballet" at the Metropolitan Opera House opened last night with the first of eleven performances by the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo. On the program were two ballets which had their premieres earlier this season -- "Saratoga" and "Labyrinth" -- and the ever faithful "Gaiete Parisienne," which, though far from new, still retains much of its original pep.
MOSCOW, April 13 (From Russian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

Captain Hilton Rowe, master of a British freighter moored at Columbia Street in Brooklyn, was held in $1,000 bail for grand jury action yesterday after waiving examination in Brooklyn Felony Court on a manslaughter charge resulting from the slaying of one of twelve Chinese seamen who mutinied aboard his ship on Saturday.
CARDIFF, Wales, April 13 -- Deep in the valleys that spread out from Cardiff like the fingers of a hand lies the buried fuel for Britain's war industries.

The enterprising Adolf Hitler is revealed as an extremely successful publisher, one unbothered by competition, excess profits levies, the difficulties of getting authors who will sell, or any of the other nuisances of an uncertain business. According to the Times Literary Supplement, London, Hitler's known interest in the large German publishing combine Zentral Verlag is actually sole ownership.

CHICAGO, April 13 -- Springlike weather prevailed in the Grain Belt over the week-end and with reports of wheat making good growth and seeding well under way in many sections, wheat and other grains turned downward today on the Board of Trade, with the close near the bottom.

Eight midtown theatres are scheduled to hold over their current attractions. "Gone With the Wind" today starts its third week at the Astor. Tomorrow "To the Shores of Tripoli" will enter its fourth and last week at the Roxy; "My Favorite Blonde" opens its third week at the Paramount and "Joe Smith, American," starts a third week at Loew's Criterion.

Expectation of a Presidential message to Congress soon urging enactment of anti-inflationary measures was reflected yesterday in one of the quietest cotton markets in recent weeks. Final prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were 1 point lower to 3 points higher than on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Agreement on several measures for strengthening the military, naval and economic position of Haiti were announced today following the recent conferences with United States officials or Elie Lescot, president of the Caribbean republic.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Senate Patents Committee opened hearings today on a bill to "draft patents" for all-out war production with the approval of President Roosevelt and Attorney General Biddle. Mr. Biddle charged that existing patent privileges in this country have been used by enemy interests to restrict and cripple such production.

Twelve jurors and two alternates were accepted yesterday in General Sessions for the trial of two men in the alleged theft of $795,000 in about five years from the Tide Water Associated Oil Company, Inc., through alleged bogus printing bills.

LONDON, April 13 -- The drive on the Burma oil fields is proceeding according to Japanese plan and in London it is acknowledged that the situation is serious. One commentary here tonight characterized the campaign in Burma now as little more than a stubbornly contested rear-guard action designed to give India time to prepare for invasion.

William G. Woolfolk, president of the American Light and Traction Company, announced yesterday that the company, one of the oldest holding concerns in the business, would be liquidated in compliance with the integration and simplification provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

LONDON, April 13 (Reuter) -- Fourteen soldiers, officers and members of the Home Guard, including a brigadier general, were killed when British planes, taking part in combined exercises in Southern England today, dive-bombed and machine-gunned spectators by mistake.
LONDON, Tuesday, April 14 -- Northern Italy was bombed by the Royal Air Force early yesterday morning in the first raid by home-based British planes on that country since last September.
Because of his answers while applying as an enemy alien for a travel permit, Fritz Witte, a German, may find himself traveling to an internment camp, it was disclosed yesterday.

An uncommonly stimulating program of chamber music was presented by Louis Krasner, violinist, and Jacques de Menasce, pianist, at The New York Times Hall last night. It consisted of three sonatas by living composers. The first was by Mr. de Manasce; the second, in E, by Paul Hindemith, and the third by Bela Bartok.

From Washington The Associated Press reports that the Government is studying the question of putting restrictions on foreign-language newspapers and periodicals published in this country. There are said to be some 1,600 such publications, of which 400 appear in the three enemy languages, German, Japanese and Italian.

Although Norma Mitchell and John Harris live in Old Lyme, Conn., they probably get down to Broadway occasionally. Their "Autumn Hill," which was acted at the Booth last evening, looks like the nightmare of a pair of playgoers who have seen a lot of mystery shows and pooled their memories, throwing in a dash of Yankee village life as their personal contribution.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The intention of the United States Government to continue to deal with the Free French forces wherever they are in effective control was announced by Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, in a note today to Gaston Henry-Haye, the French Ambassador.

PHILADELPHIA, April 13 -- The International Harvester Company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment to its registration statement, listing fifty-two underwriters for 225,000 shares of common stock, already outstanding and to be offered for the account of two trust estates.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 13 -- Dr. Maurice F. Neufeld, State Director of Rationing, met this afternoon at the County Center with 200 persons who will handle sugar rationing in Westchester, Rockland, Orange, Dutchess and Putnam Counties.

BOSTON, April 13 (AP) -- Rangy Jimmy Mulligan, Lowell, Mass., schoolboy and the National A.A.U. boxing tournament's only defending champion, pounded Warren Outlaw, Hammond, Ind., Negro, to qualify for the middleweight class quarter-finals during tonight's opening bouts at the Boston Garden.

An exhibition of paintings by American abstract artists is being arranged by A.E. Gallatin for the benefit of the Navy League of the United States, to be held at the league's headquarters, 746 Madison Avenue, beginning next Tuesday.

The President recently sent to the Senate the name Of Earl G. Harrison for the important post of Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization. It would be reasonable to expect the Senate to confirm promptly so excellent a choice if Senator Guffey had not indicated he would oppose the nomination as a matter of "Senatorial courtesy."
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Pierre Laval's record is such that henceforth, on the part of Vichy, a very different policy must be taken as a practical certainty.

Work hours in United States war industries are well above forty a week, according to a survey by the National Industrial Conference Board, the findings of which were announced yesterday. The survey covered shift schedules in a representative group of plants.

DOVER, England, April 14 (AP) -- The Germans have put thousands of laborers to work building new gun emplacements and strengthening already formidable defenses along the French coast as an added precaution against an invasion. The laborers were seen plainly today, through field glasses, some twenty miles across the Channel.

LONDON, April 14 -- Britain's wage earners and producers escaped heavier income taxes today for the first time since the war began when Sir Kingsley Wood, Chancellor of the Exchequer, presented a budget calling for revenues this year of 4,500,000,000 and expenditures of 5,286,000,000, in addition to United States lease-lend aid, now running at the rate of about 100,000,000 monthly.

VICHY, France, Wednesday, April 15 (U.P.) -- Pierre Laval, the collaborationist, has been named Premier, with full control of the French Government, including the right to pick his own Cabinet, in an attempt to prevent Adolf Hitler from setting up a French "gauleiter" in Paris, it was reported today.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 14 -- Signs are multiplying that the Roosevelt Administration will ask Congress for a law freezing all prices and wages to head off inflation. If a national plebiscite were held to get the views of the common man on such a law, it would be found that the people are far ahead of their government.

Yesterday the clock was turned back 100 years for New York City's 1,000,000 school children. Throughout the day they sat primly, curtsied when addressing the teacher, and went through their three Rs in sing-song rote.

In preparation for its limitation order on the production of robes, the Clothing Section of the War Production Board is giving "very careful" consideration to the recommendations on the use of wool in men's robes made recently by Leo C. Safir, president of the Rabhor Company.

BOSTON, April 14 -- The end of the war will usher in an era of "socialized capitalism" in which business, labor and government will all participate, Paul T. Babson said today, adding that "this may not prove to be such a bad thing if the transition can be kept gradual."

LONDON, April 14 -- The government has again refused to lift its ban on the publication of The Daily Worker. After a debate in the House of Lords today Viscount Simon said the ban would be continued because the government found that there was not sufficient ground for a reversal of its decision.

MEXICO CITY, April 14 -- It is expected here that joint or separate reports of the American and Mexican appraisers of expropriated oil properties will be made by the end of this week. It is widely believed that it will be a joint report providing a basis for liquidation of the debt arising from nationalization of American-owned properties.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- President Roosevelt reiterated today that General Douglas MacArthur was in supreme command of all land, air and naval forces in the Southwest Pacific theatre of war.

The rush to pay State income taxes continued yesterday with only slight abatement. Almost 10,000 persons filed their returns in person at the office of the State Income Tax Bureau here at 80 Centre Street. The congestion at noon was not quite so great as on Monday, when the peak of 10,000 was reached, but at other times yesterday from 9 A.M. to 9 P.M. the crowds were as large.

BERLIN, April 14 (From German broadcast recorded by The United Press in New York) -- Pierre Laval will become chief of the French Government and Marshal Henri Philippe Petain will renounce his chairmanship of the Council of Ministers, according to a Vichy announcement reported here late today.

The shortage of skilled labor on the New York Central Railroad is becoming increasingly serious, L.W. Horning, manager of personnel, said yesterday. He disclosed that the company was considering holding employes in service after they reach 65, an age when retirements should begin under the Railway Pension Law.

PHILADELPHIA, April 14 -The Securities and Exchange Commission in its seventh annual report, made public tonight, gave a plain warning that public utility holding companies could expect no breathing spell in enforcement of the "death sentence" clause of the Holding Company Act because of the war.
LONDON, April 14 -- War Secretary Sir James Grigg was elected to Parliament by the voters of Cardiff East yesterday, it was announced today, following completion of the count.

A group headed by Shields Co. received yesterday the award of $1,000,000 State of West Virginia road bonds on an interest cost basis to the State of 1,538 per cent. The successful bid was 100.021 for $110,000 as 4s and $890,000 as 1 1/2s. Dated April 1, 1942, the bonds were reoffered at prices to yield 0.40 to 1.60 per cent for maturities ranging from April 1, 1943 to 1967.

Commercial and industrial failures in the United States for the week ended April 9 decreased in all industry groups as compared with the like week last year, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. Decreases in the week ranged from around 40 per cent in construction and commercial service to 4 per cent in retail trade.

Mayor La Guardia added yesterday $43,816,970 in relief expenses to the executive budget total of $568,881,791 that he announced on April 1, making the city's tax levy total for the 1942-43 fiscal year $612,698,761.

With streams reported in excellent condition, New Jersey's trout season will open today under favorable circumstances. Feeder brooks are high, but the main streams are regarded as ideal, and from reports received it is evident that the fly fisherman will have an opportunity to display his skill.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Slowdowns in "eight very vital war plants" last week cut their production from 25 to 90 per cent, according to a report from the Assistant Secretary of the Navy to Senator Byrd, who made it public.

The report on a "final" peace offer by Hitler as telephoned by your Stockholm correspondent in today's issue is, to say the least, disturbing, for it covers a clever double-propaganda move on the part of Goebbels.

The annual report for 1941 of the International Paper Company, made yesterday by Richard J. Cullen, president, disclosed after taxes and all other deductions a net porfit of $16,253,761, compared with $15,696,577 net reported the year before.

CHICAGO, April 14 (AP) -- Bob Muncrief sent the Browns off to a fast start in the 1942 American League season today by setting the White Sox down with only three singles and beating them, 3 -- 0. A crowd of 9,879 saw the contest and colorful military ceremonies which preceded it in Comiskey Park.
A total of 190,775 persons paid their way to hail the opening of the major league baseball season yesterday. The National League clashes brought out 100,728 spectators and the American League 90,047.

Chu Hsueh-fan, president of the Chinese Association of Labor, charged yesterday that "tens of thousands" of Chinese seamen employed on ships carrying munitions and war supplies to the United Nations were being "grossly underpaid and compelled to work under conditions which would be utterly unacceptable to British and American seamen."

Prices on the Stock Exchange suffered yesterday the widest break in more than a month as holders of securities plainly revealed their concern over the return of Pierre Laval to power in the Vichy regime. The obvious strain on the relationship between the French Government and Washington was reflected in the steady stream of selling throughout the session.
MOSCOW, April 14 (From Russian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

The three five-story buildings at 72 and 74 Warren Street and 88 West Broadway, which form an L around the northwest corner of the intersection, have been sold by Gerry Estate, Inc., to an investing client of Adams Co., Inc., broker.

Adam Conrad Maurer, 70 years old, artist and lithographer, was found dead on Monday in the three-room apartment he occupied alone at 172 Waverly Place, in Greenwich Village. He was discovered, clad in pajamas and a robe, lying on the floor of the living room, where, according to Dr. Raymond B. Miles, assistant medical examiner, he had collapsed about a week earlier.
PHILADELPHIA, April 14 (AP) -- Sixty-year-old Hans Lobert, making his debut as a full-fledged major league manager, saw his Phils drop the season opener, 2-1, to the Braves before 10,150 fans today.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Women who seek to replace drafted men as farm workers, or to help relieve local rural labor shortages soon will be told when and where they can register for such work, Federal Security Administrator Paul V. McNutt announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, April 14 -- The market value of securities sold on all registered exchanges in February amounted to $385,857,078, a sharp decrease from the preceding month and from February, 1941, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.
LONDON, April 14 -- Hard fighting continues along the whole Burma front with the Japanese edging closer to the Yenangyaung oil fields.

LONDON, April 14 -- For nine and a half hours today Spitfires of the Fighter Command carried out offensive sweeps over the English Channel and the coasts of France for the loss of four planes. Four German fighters were shot down and many others probably destroyed or damaged in this longest daylight raid of the year by the Royal Air Force, the Air Ministry said.

They raised the barrier on the National League's 1942 championship campaign at the Polo Grounds yesterday amid the boisterous acclaim of some 50,000 onlookers, but for an interminable period it looked as though the Giants would never leave the post.

LONDON, April 14 -- Unusually little criticism of Chancellor of the Exchequer Sir Kingsley Wood's budget was voiced here today, perhaps largely because it contained no new direct taxation and made certain concessions in allowances.

Three hundred men of the United States, Canadian and British armed services crowded the Defense Recreation Service Men's Center at 99 Park Avenue last night for the opening broadcast of a series of programs over WNYC to be given there every Tuesday evening at 8 o'clock.
ROME, April 14 (From Italian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command communique said today:

WASHINGTON, April 14 Hundreds of thousands of retailers in all lines of trade face certain bankruptcy if a general "price freeze" is imposed, the National Association of Retail Grocers warned Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, in a telegram today.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 14 -- With the Germans occupying a series of positions forming a screening front from the coastal region between Tmimi and Gazala to El Teleim, twenty-seven miles inland, the Cyrenaican fighting zone again began to be stabilized yesterday after nearly a week of fluid patrol fighting.
CANBERRA, Australia, April 14 (AP) -- Primer Minister John Curtin issued this communique today:
The downtown and midtown business districts held the center of interest for commercial leasing contracts yesterday. Brokers reported a number of stores and offices taken in these two sections.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., April 14 -- With throat-splitting cheers, martial music and waving banners, 3,000 residents of this city jammed the New Haven Railroad station here today to bid godspeed to 178 trainees leaving for Army camps. During the tumult five women fainted and several persons were bruised, but the trainees departed with vivid memories that the home town was backing them to the limit.

The investment banking community is being forced to mark time pending the clearance of several large security offerings from the SEC. Dealers were prepared yesterday for the secondary distribution of 225,000 shares of International Harvester common stock, but, at the last minute, the company found it necessary to clear up a few details.

UTICA, N.Y., April 14 -- Fred Van Schaick dug one foot into the red loam of the Cortland County farm he has operated for twenty-two years. The other rested on a fender of the truck he uses to deliver his milk to a Sheffield receiving station.

PHILADELPHIA, April 14 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, acting under the "death-sentence" clause of the Public Utility Holding Company Act, issued today an order stripping the North American Company of all but fragments of the system of eighty subsidiaries.

It may yet come about in this terribly complicated world that John L. Lewis will end up as the book dictator of the American people. Gifts of books for the armed forces are now being collected in New York by the milk drivers.

More than $1,000,000 is expected to be made available for the construction of defense-housing projects on Staten Island under the terms of a cooperative participation plan being developed by members of the Staten Island Savings and Loan League, according to Claude B. Gandy, president of the league.

H.M. Tillinghast, president of R. Hoe Co., said at the annual meeting here yesterday that unfilled orders now are double those a year ago. The company is operating on a two-shift six-day week, but expects to increase this rate substantially.

NO matter what comes along, Mr. John A. Topping of Bronxville, N.Y., has some idea of what to do about it. It's the blackout that has intrigued Mr. Topping of late. Spring is here. Summer is coming. Fall is our finest season. Come the blackouts, Mr. Topping thinks it would be dreadfully boring to have to sit indoors and cower until the "All Clear" is sounded.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Robert R. Guthrie, former War Production Board executive, renewed his charges today that dollar-a-year men working in the WPB had been favoring their own industries at the expense of the war effort and contended that recent orders by Donald Nelson, severely curtailing production for civilian use, had vindicated his stand.

CHICAGO, April 14 -- Liquidation developed today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade, with wheat futures dropping more than 2 cents a bushel to a new low mark since Dec. 1, while corn was off 1 1/2 cents and went into new low ground since early in February.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Calling this "the Survival War," President Roosevelt declared today that it would take two or three years to make certain that our type of civilization would be saved. He added:

LONDON, April 14 -- Restrictions on luxury living in hotels, effective next week, are designed primarily to keep up public morale rather than to save supplies, according to Lord Woolton, the Food Minister.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 14 (AP) -British Headquarters issued this communique today:

After "The Corn Is Green" comes "Yesterday's Magic" in Emlyn Williams's library of plays. Although it is theatrically attractive a good part of the time and also amusing in odd bits, it comes a long way after Mr. Williams's autobiographic story of life in Wales.

A few weeks ago 12-year-old Frank Mannino of 469 Second Avenue joined a cooking class at the Madison Square Boys Club, 301 East Twenty-ninth Street. Yesterday he defeated five other boys, in the opinion of Oscar of the Waldorf, and won the tenth annual cooking championship of the club.

WITH INDIAN FORCES, in Iraq, April 14 -- Having been with various units of the Indian Army in Iraq over a seventeen-day period during Sir Stafford Cripps's negotiations in India, this correspondent feels in a position to express the opinion that the outcome, while admittedly disappointing, was far from being a crushing blow destined to impair the effort and efficiency of India's army as at present constituted.

Although nothing could dim Brooklyn's spirits last night after the Dodgers' opening game victory over the Giants, another in the city's series of blackout drills was able to cast a pall over fifty-four square miles of the borough from 9 to 9:20 P.M.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The War Department communique based on reports received here up to 10 A.M. said:

HARDING TOWNSHIP, N.J., April 14 -- The press of war, it developed here today, has forced six rural school teachers, the full complement of the township school, to turn in their resignations to take effect at the end of the term.

Supreme Court Justice Charles E. McLaughlin has approved a plan for leasing the two-story and basement garage building at 401 Pearl Street, corner of Vandewater Street, for five years at an average rental of about $10,000 to Ross M. Wall through John J. Cray as trustee for certificate holders under Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Company issue No. 211,734.

Leading creators of millinery should do more to establish definite trends in this merchandise and coordinate hat styles with other womens apparel items, according to views expressed yesterday at a meeting of the Millinery Merchandising Executives Association at the St. Regis Hotel.

Should France, as a result of the new changes in the Vichy Government, now yield her long-disputed fleet to Germany, the Axis thereby would gain a formidable force of five battleships, a dozen light and heavy cruisers and perhaps as many as fifty destroyers and an equal number of submarines.
In his last stage appearance Alfred Lunt shouldered a gun and went out to wreak vengeance on the Nazis. Yesterday he seized a kitchen knife, but the object of his assault had changed to a grapefruit.

How the rumble of the subway, the clatter of dishes, the patter of rain and the sound of the radio inspired youthful composers to creative work was described yesterday by a score of students at the High School of Music and Art. Tomorrow the school will present its fourth annual concert of original compositions.

Purchases of fuel, materials and supplies by the Class I railroads in 1941 were larger than in any year since 1929, J.J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads, announced yesterday.

Buyer registrations in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,045 as against 662 in the preceding week and 822 in the like period of 1941, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Visiting buyers reported yesterday numbered 413, which compared with 476 for last Tuesday.

TOKYO, April 14 (From Japanese broadcast recorded by The United Press in New York) -- Imperial Headquarters asserted today that from the beginning of the general offensive against American-Filipino forces on the Bataan Peninsula to Sunday, the Japanese captured 40,000 prisoners, including 15 generals and 6,700 Americans.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- President Roosevelt said at his press conference today that he was working on a program to curb inflation, but said he had not yet decided whether to send a message about it to Congress or whether to ask for still higher taxes as part of it.

Today Dr. Hawkes has been Dean of Columbia College twenty-five years and he has made a remarkably good job of it. He is a Professor of Mathematics. That requires imagination. He has a sort of imaginative sympathy with his undergraduates. He tries to understand them.

Some rationing of power to non-defense consumers may be necessary throughout the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation system, Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the utility, declared yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders. He added that war industries would receive first call on all power facilities throughout the system.

Karl Kucker, 36 years old, a registered alien who came to this country from Germany in 1925, was sentenced by Judge John A. Mullen in General Sessions yesterday to serve eighteen months to three years in Sing Sing for embezzling $54,838 in five years from James M. McCunn Co., wholesale liquor dealers, at 314 West Fourteenth Street.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 14 -- The American-Filipino defenders of Cebu apparently have fought stiffly against the Japanese landing on the island, but they were never regarded as having had a chance to make more than a few days' stand.
A soldier pays his respect to the men of Bataan in your column with "'Suckers' of Bataan, we, the truly blind, salute you!" I should like to pay the respectful tribute of an appreciative civilian.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- President Roosevelt asked today the cooperation of all citizens, newspapers and radio stations to make a success of Victory Book Day, which has been set for Friday, to spur the national drive that has sought to raise 10,000,000 books for the nation's armed services.

UNION, N.J., April 14 -- Although the Board of Education split sharply on the issue, a request of Samuel E. Swauger, industrial arts supervisor of the Union public schools, for a leave of absence for the duration of the war to permit his acceptance of a post of civilian instructor of drafting at Fort Monmouth, was rejected by a majority of the board members at a meeting held last night.

Wings over the sea have modified Mahan's traditional concept of sea power. Sea power is now a three-dimensional element; it is idle to talk of control of the sea unless one also controls the air above it and the depths beneath the surface.

VICHY, France, April 14 -- Without waiting for the new Cabinet to be formed, the Vichy Government tonight ordered rejection of the United States note explaining the appointment of an American consul at Free-French Brazzaville in Equatorial Africa.
LONDON, April 14 (AP) -- A joint communique of the Air and Home Security Ministries said today:

To cooperate with the Government in plans for the production of women's uniforms, and to insure greatest efficiency in volume output, the proposal has been made in the women's coat and suit industry that the Army and the WPB adopt a design which will permit "commercial" production in lieu of the specifications now used for most uniforms, it was learned here yesterday.
Announcement of the formation of D'Assern Co., at 49 Wall Street, was made yesterday. Partners of the Stock Exchange firm are Joseph M. D'Assern, J.J. Farrell, John Belck and H. Walter Mewing.
BERLIN, April 14 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- A special German High Command communique said today:

The main ballroom of the Plaza was the setting last night for the Spring dinner dance in the aeries of dances which' have been given for many years to aid the work of rite Yorkville Community Association. The proceeds will assist the sponsoring organization's projects at its neighborhood center, 1639 York Avenue, and its Summer camp for underprivileged boys and girls.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- With rationing of sugar scheduled to begin May 5 because of depleted supplies, President Roosevelt signed a proclamation today suspending all import and marketing quotas on both raw and refined sugar.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Admiral William D. Leahy may be recalled as United States Ambassador to France as a result of the return of Pierre Laval to the French Cabinet.

ALBANY, April 14 -- Two separate liquor control bills, announced as intended to end disastrous liquor wars, were sent to the Governor today by the Legislature. The first measure was the Hollowell Bill, on which legislative action was completed by the Senate, and the second was the Condon Bill, on which legislative action was completed by the Assembly.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 14 -- One of the most dramatic stories of the war, a story of a desperate fight for life by 2,000 British Empire prisoners of war trapped in a ship that was torpedoed while en route to Italy, was told to me today by a group of survivors.

More than thirty examples of monopolistic control by industry, labor and agriculture that are held to retard United States war production are cited by Thurman W. Arnold, assistant attorney general, in a book just released by the University of Oklahoma Press.

DETROIT, April 14 (AP) -- The Indians presented 24-year-old Lou Boudreau, youngest manager ever to start a major league baseball season, with a 5-to-2 victory over the Tigers today before 39,267 spectators in the American League opener here.

Running one of the best races in his long career, Speed to Spare yesterday captured the St. James Handicap at six furlongs before 15,465 at Jamaica despite his nine years and the fact that he was facing as formidable a thoroughbred as Arnold Hanger's Dit.
LONDON, April 14 (AP) -- A Norwegian spokesman estimated today that the German-controlled Quisling regime had imprisioned 2,000 teachers and Lutheran ministers in Norway in the last six weeks.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Ora E. Gasaway, president of District 50 of the United Mine Workers, said tonight the drive to unionize 3,500,000 dairy farmers would be carried into the forty-eight States "without use of strikes, coercion or violence."

Katharine Cornell will present Bernard Shaw's "Candida" under the auspices of the American Theatre Wing War Service at four special matinees on April 27, 28 and 30, and May 1, at a theatre to be named later. All the proceeds will be turned over to the Army and Navy Relief organizations, it was announced.

With only two classifications showing fractional increases, newspaper advertising linage for March in fifty-five cities measured by Media Records registered a decline of 6.5 per cent from the corresponding month of last year. This drop brought the loss for the first quarter of the year to 5.7 per cent.

Mayor La Guardia was roundly criticized yesterday by fifty-two members of the National Society of Daughters of the Union, 1861-1865, when they arrived at City Hall to dedicate a plaque in honor of President Lincoln and found that the city administration had refused their gift without notifying them of the action.

The favored contract bridge team-of-four was eliminated from the tournament for the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup last night at the Hotel Pierre in one of the biggest upsets in tournament bridge since 1933. Howard Schenken, Edward Hymes Jr., B. Jay Becker and Theodore A. Lightner of New York and John Crawford of Philadelphia scored only 5 1/2 out of 12 possible points, while 6 points were needed to qualify.

Pierre Laval always wears a white tie. In those feverish days in the mid-Thirties, when the walls of Jericho were crumbling and European statesmen dashed from capital to capital peddling paper pacts to stuff into the cracks, the white four-in-hand became a kind of badge or trade-mark of Laval as he perambulated between Berlin and London, Rome and Moscow.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Before a crowd of 31,000 that jammed Griffith Stadium almost to capacity, Joe McCarthy's world champion Yankees opened the 1942 season as Red Ruffing pitched a shutout triumph over Bucky Harris's Senators today.

Mayor La Guardia's demand for a stagger system of retirements from the Police Department, with a limit of forty retirements a month, was hotly rejected yesterday at a monthly meeting of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association in the Hotel Commodore, according to unofficial report.

PHILADELPHIA, April 14 -Individuals' savings in all forms in the fourth quarter of 1941 amounted to $6,810,000,000, according to a new compilation made public tonight by the Securities and Exchange Commission "in response to a growing demand as a result of the war program for detailed data on the volume and composition of saving by individuals in the United States."

WASHINGTON, April l4 -- Representatives of the oil and gasoline producing States were urged today by Secretary Ickes, Petroleum Coordinator, to ignore State lines and all considerations other than their responsibility, jointly and severally, to provide the supplies required by the nation's war effort.

ALBANY, April 14 -- Spurred on by definite promise of adjournment at the end of next week, much progress was made in the Legislature today in clearing the calendars. At the start of work both houses passed in final form a resolution for adjournment on April 24, a day later than was proposed in the original adjournment resolution.
The text of the majority decision of the National War Labor Board in the Walker-Turner case contains some amazing expressions of opinion on particular points. Take this, for example:

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Constantin Fotitch, the Yugoslav Minister, today submitted to Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, the names of the Yugoslav army officers whom the Germans have demanded be surrendered on penalty of reprisals against their families, relatives and friends. He appealed to the humanitarian instincts of the world against such measures.

Mayor La Guardia called attention yesterday to the needs of the Navy Relief Society as he joined former District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey in an appeal for support of the organization's drive for $1,000,000.

Japan has more airplane carriers than any nation in the world. She has had more success with them than any nation. Except for the Battle of Java all her naval victories have been won by plane carriers. The crippling attack on Pearl Harbor which immobilized our Pacific Fleet was made from carriers.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Although the Japanese continue to bomb and shell Corregidor and its three near-by forts from which the American flag still flies over Manila Bay, communication has been re-established with Cebu, where our forces are offering stiff resistance to the enemy advance, the War Department announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Production of phonograph records and of radio transcriptions was hit severely today by a War Production Board order lowering by 70 per cent the amount of shellac to be made available to manufacturers.

Archibald MacLeish, director of the Office of Facts and Figures and librarian of the Library of Congress, warned a Russian War Relief luncheon rally here yesterday that there were groups, including a minority of the press in this country, that would rather lose this war than win it with the aid of peoples they dislike.

TOLEDO, Ohio, April 14 (AP) -- Three directors of the Air-Way Electric Appliance Corporation have resigned, contending the stockholders' meeting of March 24 was irregular, Joseph H. Nuffer, president, announced today. The resigning directors, all stockholders, were George Coury and J.M. Doroshaw, both of Chicago, and M.J. Zivian of Detroit.

General health conditions in New York City continued favorable last week, John L. Rice, health commissioner, reported yesterday. The death rate was 10.2 for 1,000 population, a figure not generally achieved until May. The birth rate jumped to 17 for 1,000 population.

In celebration of Pan-American Day 1,000 persons attended the performance of "A Night in the Americas" held last night at the Starlight Roof of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria under the joint sponsorship of the Pan-American Society and Inter-America House.
NEWMARKET, England, March 14 (Canadian Press) -- Great Britain's restricted flat racing season opened today with one of the smallest attendances in years.

AT A UNITED NATIONS AIR BASE, Southwestern Pacific, April 14 -- Lieutenant David Nelson, 27 years old, an Air Corps navigator from Altadena, Calif., has the reputation of being a cool, methodical fellow. He added to that reputation the other day on his first bombing mission.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Current American shortages of tungsten carbide, vitally needed for machine-tool production for the war effort, are due to a monopoly-seeking patent-pooling arrangement of the General Electric Company with the Krupp armament works in Germany, a Senate committee was told today.

Probably the most nonplussed man in Manhattan last night was an unknown cab driver who left Park Avenue and East Eightieth Street about 7 o'clock with three women who wanted to go to 429 East Twenty-third Street.

The arrest of a stubby, grim-looking butcher's helper who has sent many hundreds of Nazi propaganda booklets to officers and soldiers in the Army was revealed yesterday by P.E. Foxworth, assistant director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, April 15 -- A military spokesman in Moscow announced on the radio this morning that Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's forces northwest of Kharkov had smashed "a gaping hole more than twelve miles wide" in key German defenses in the Donets Basin.

Samuel Reshevsky, the defending titleholder, defeated Benjamin Altman after twenty-seven moves in the fourth round of the United States Chess Federation championship tournament at the Hotel Astor last night. It was Reshevsky's third victory in the competition.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Proclaiming "National Emergency Week" for the week of May 3, President Roosevelt called on employers today to give special attention to the hiring of veterans of the first World War and other men and women over 40 years of age because there was a place for them "in the gigantic war production program in which we are engaged."

Weary, confused, and for the most part in no mood to give a detailed account of their adventures, the 290 passengers and crew members who formed the entire ship's company of a British liner torpedoed off the Southeast coast on Saturday arrived just before midnight last night at Pennsylvania Station.

"Bottled stockings" are the answer to the modern maiden's prayer -- cool, comfortable and, above all, economical.
