Now that Summer is near, and those precious pairs of sheer silk are being trotted out on only the rarest occasions, the synthetic stockings that come in jars, tubes or bottles seem particularly appealing.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 14 -West Coast Japanese, numbering 105,000, who have waited to be moved from military area No. 1 under Army supervision, are to be settled in communities of 5,000 or more population on lands now owned or to be purchased by the Federal Government, under a policy announced today by Milton S. Eisenhower, director of the War Relocation Authority.

The two factory buildings at 208-12 Dupont Street and 231-35 Eagle Street, Brooklyn, have been sold by the Green Point Savings Bank to the Ramlo Realty Corporation through Frank R. Fischer, broker. The buildings are on a plot 75 by 100 feet.

ST. LOUIS, April 14 (AP) -- Lacing Mort Cooper for three singles and a double to score three runs in the sixth inning, the Cubs beat the Cardinals, 5 to 4, before a crowd of 13,821 paid and 1,000 soldiers today.
ALBANY, April 14 -- The Senate rejected today an attempt by Mayor La Guardia to put himself on the State War Council.

The consolidated net income for 1941 of the Creole Petroleum Corporation, as reported for publication today, amounted to $12,297,275 after deducting $1,800,942 as an adjustment for prior royalties paid to the Venezuelan Government.

RIO DE JANIERO, Brazil, April 14 -- The "Battle for Rio de Janeiro" begins at dawn tomorrow, when motorized divisions of the "Red Army," encamped on the city's outskirts, assault the "Blue Army" defending the caital in what will be the Brazilian Army's largest manoeuvres.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., April 14 -- Dr. Frederick E. Vaughan of 50 Croton Avenue, this village, chief of the Surgical Division of the Northern Westchester Hospital here, died as the result of a cerebal hemorrhage today in an operating room of the hospital after completing a major operation on a patient. His age was 57.

Though its name is ponderous, the Belgian Piano-String Quartet of Colorado College plays with point and perception. In a concert at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon this ensembl of musicians, who come from Europe and who are maintained as a unit at an American school, gave performances that bespoke maturity of musicianship and experience as public performers.

Representative Michael J. Kennedy was elected yesterday as leader of Tammany Hall, defeating former Sheriff Daniel E. Finn Jr. by a vote of 14 2/3 to 9 7/12 at a meeting of the New York County Democratic Executive Committee. He replaces Charles H. Hussey, who had been serving as leader temporarily since the ouster two months ago of former Representative Christopher D. Sullivan.

Miss Alice Marble, former tennis champion, announced yesterday that she had resigned from the Office of Civilian Defense, where she has been serving as a dollar-a-year woman on the staff of John B. Kelly, assistant director of civilian defense in charge of national physical fitness.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, April 14 -- Foreign Minister Alberto Guani will open the first sitting of the Emergency Advisory Committee for Political Defense tomorrow evening, it was announced today.

LONDON, April 14 (U.P.) -- The Royal Air Force, in its longest and most devastating daylight raid of the year, hurled squadron after squadron of planes over Northern France today, blowing up a Power works and other objectives in Normandy and destroying or damaging six German planes.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Social Justice, the magazine founded and long edited by Father Charles E. Coughlin, was barred from the mails, pending further inquiry, under an order issued tonight by Postmaster General Walker.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York made known yesterday that it was now ready to receive applications from banks and war materials manufacturers for aid in financing holders of contracts and subcontracts of the Army, Navy and Maritime Commission.
When the Dodgers and the Giants are involved, strange happenings are inevitable, but yesterday's wartime opening of the National League season at the Polo Grounds produced a phenomenon.

The will of Dr. John Lovejoy Elliott, senior leader of the Society for Ethical Culture, whose funeral services will be held today, leaves to Austin H. MacCormick, head of the Osborne Association, Inc., the task of freeing from Sing Sing a young man whose name is given in the will but withheld from publication at present.
NEW DELHI, India, April 14 (AP) -- British Headquarters issued this communique today on the Burma situation:

New York consumers were assured yesterday by N.J. Cladakis, administrator of the metropolitan milk marketing area, that the outcome of the controversy over the campaign to organize dairy farmers would not affect prices.

Organization of a central bureau for the entire packaging industry with representatives from each branch was suggested yesterday by Irwin D. Wolf, vice president of Kaufmann Department Stores, Inc., Pittsburgh, at the luncheon presentation of the award sponsored by him for the best package of the year, at the Hotel Astor.

Because of the Federal and State tax situation, the directors of the Erie Railroad have not considered the payment of common dividends, Robert E. Woodruff, president, said at the annual meeting here yesterday.

"Moontide," Twentieth Century-Fox's screen version of the Willard Robertson novel, starring Jean Gabin and Ida Lupino, will have its world premiere at the Rivoli Theatre on Wednesday, April 29, the company announced yesterday. "Moontide" is the first American film to be made by Gabin, who heretofore has starred in French films such as "Pepe Le Moko," "Grand Illusion" and "Port of Shadows."

Spruille Braden, newly appointed Ambassador to Cuba, was elected honorary chairman of the Inter-American Commercial Arbitration Commission at the annual meeting of the group yesterday. Twenty-six members of the commission, in addition to Ambassador Braden, attended the meeting at the offices of the chairman, Thomas J. Watson, 590 Madison Avenue.

Mary Boland, stage and screen actress, was exonerated yesterday by Actors Equity Association of charges of "contract-jumping" brought against her by the Theatre Guild, producers of "The Rivals," in which she was co-starred until her sudden departure from the show's cast in Chicago last month.

Randolph Paul, tax adviser and assistant to Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau, told the mid-year dinner of the National Association of Insurance Agents at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night that a sales tax not only would be unfair to low income groups but also would be bad economics.

In the sports world the first ball was "tossed out" yesterday; in the field of fashion Mary Lewis put the first cotton showing of the Summer season over the plate. She did it at the luncheon hour in the Hotel Ritz Oval Room. Her score was high, with calicos and denims taking the lead.
It was a lazy Spring day in Washington Square yesterday and residents were buzzing with talk of new neighbors that were moving in.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Control of the government's "stockpile" program and effort to acquire essential and critical materials abroad was shifted today from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, of which Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce, is the head, to the Board of Economic Warfare. headed by Vice President Wallace.

CHICAGO, April 14 -- Senator C. Wayland Brooks, one of the nation's most outspoken isolationists before America's entry into the war, was renominated today in the Illinois Republican primary, scoring a landslide victory over State Treasurer Warren E. Wright, a supporter of President Roosevelt's foreign policy.

Although the championship schedule of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound was adopted last month, it was decided yesterday to summon the delegates of the clubs in the association to meet in the New York Yacht Club at 5 P.M. on April 30, to consider holding the regattas on Sundays instead of Saturdays.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Two governmental developments relating to the tax situation were noted today as the Chamber of Commerce of the United States proposed to the Ways and Means Committee a tax program designed to raise upwards of $10,000,000,000.

Women can best help the war program in the home by buying foods in season and by buying "intelligently," Mrs. Frances F. Gannon, director of the Bureau of Consumer Service of the Department of Markets, declared yesterday afternoon at the second lecture of a series of ten in a course, "The Consumer and the War," at the Long Island Historical Society, 60 Clinton Street, Brooklyn.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 14 -- The board of trustees of Rutgers University has raised the department of journalism to the status of a school of journalism, it was announced here today by Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of the university.

College students today, compared with those of 1917, are more "objective" regarding the war and less "emotional," Dr. Herbert E. Hawkes, dean of Columbia College, said in an interview yesterday. Present students of the institution, he added, also are "more determined and informed about the war than their predecessors, although no more sincere or patriotic."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 14 -- Supreme Court Justice Lee Parsons Davis denied today the application by Truman S. Mesereau, as chairman of the Westchester Citizens Committee, for an injunction restraining Westchester County from developing an airport on the 503-acre tract that adjoins Rye Lake in the estate area of Purchase.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 14 -- Sol A. Herzog, counsel for the Eastern States Gasoline Dealers Council, today told a conference of 100 representatives of the trade that indications from the Office of Petroleum Coordinator are that dealer rationing is effective in reducing consumption and that customer or card rationing will not be necessary.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 14 -- A judgment of $1,000,000 against stockholders of the defunct Westchester Title and Trust Company of this city was granted today by Charles B. Sears, Supreme Court referee, at the close of a trial which began March 17.

CANBERRA, Australia, April 14 -- Prime Minister John Curtin was sworn in as Minister of Defense today by the Governor General, Lord Gowrie. Mr. Curtin had been Minister of Defense Coordination. The primary object of the change is to facilitate discussions with General Douglas MacArthur.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, April 15 -- The prodigal heir apparent Pierre Laval, on returning to power yesterday -- effective Friday morning -- declared his restoration "need not affect adversely" Vichy's relations with the United States, the Paris radio reported this morning.

BOSTON, April 14 (AP) -- Jimmy Mulligan, Lowell, Mass., schoolboy and the National A.A.U. boxing tourney's only defending champion, was eliminated by a close margin by Ursal Snapp, rugged Pocatello, Idaho, middleweight, in a bruising quarter-final bout tonight at the Boston Garden.

Dismissal of Dr. David Hart, former chairman of the Brooklyn College Chemistry Department, and Dr. Frederick L. Weber, Professor of Chemistry at City College, was recommended yesterday by a trial committee of the Board of Higher Education.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 14 -- Plans for studio production of twenty-six short information films to stimulate the war drive took shape today with the disclosure that Clark Gable will be one of a number of stars to appear in the pictures.

Stroll eastward along a certain quiet city street until you can look up at a patch of crimson awning that flutters like a gay beacon in the Spring sunshine. Pause on the pavement in the small square of shade and glance in at a pastry shop that is hardly larger than a butler's pantry.

Active liquidation by New Orleans operators combined yesterday with commission house selling to send the cotton market to new lows for the current movement, as active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed at losses of 11 to 16 points.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 14 -- As America's most popular sport got under way in baseball parks all over the country today, the American public was strongly united in its desire to keep professional sports going for the duration of the war.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Secretary Knox advocated today a freezing of open and closed union shop conditions in industry for the duration of the war.

CINCINNATI, April 14 (AP) -- The Pirates opened the 1942 baseball season on their own terms today as Big Max Butcher kept Cincinnati's Reds well under control for a 4-2 victory before 34,104 fans who expected an improved home team.

The General Foods Corporation has borrowed an additional $3,000,000 from banks under its revolving credit arrangement with three banks, of which $2,883,018 has been used to pay Federal income taxes and the balance has been applied to current bills.

While hundreds of residents of a small East Coast community watched in horror, an enemy submarine torpedoed and shelled a medium-sized American merchant ship within sight of our own shores last Friday, killing nineteen members of her crew of forty-eight and sending the ship to the bottom.

WESTFIELD, N.J., April 14 -- The banking building occupied by the First Federal Savings and Loan Association at Prospect and Broad Streets here has been purchased by the association from the Morgan Securities Corporation, of which Colonel Leigh M. Pearsall is president.

LONDON, April 14 -- The British are perturbed by the news of Pierre Laval's return to the government in Vichy. The move is interpreted here as giving a man the British thoroughly distrust almost complete power as active head of the Cabinet, responsible only to the Chief of State.

After yielding four hits and three runs in the first two innings, Tom Courtney settled down to pitch Manhattan to a 6-4 victory over Lehigh on the Jasper field yesterday. The Green tied the count in the third without a hit and got three more tallies on four safeties in the sixth.

TORONTO, April 14 -- Toronto remained in the thick of the hunt for the Stanley Cup tonight by swamping the Detroit Red Wings, 9 -- 3, before 15,076 spectators in the fifth game of the four-out-of-seven final series. It was the second straight victory for the Maple Leafs after three successive drubbings.

ALBANY, April 14 -- A legislative investigation of the State Tax Commission's methods of supervision and equalization of real estate assessments, and abandonment for the current year of the plan for State-wide boards of assessment and review was recommended today in the report of the Joint Legislative Committee on Assessing and Reviewing.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 14 -- Japanese Minister Hikotaro Ichikawa and his staff of six were ordered today to leave Iran within a week following a diplomatic break which authoritative sources said resulted from subversive activities by the Japanese Legation here.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 14 -- "The Divine Young Lady," a new adaptation of the previously announced "They Lived Alone," will be Deanna Durbin's next picture at Universal, replacing "Three Smart Girls Join Up" on her schedule for the time being.

LONDON, April 14 -- The stock markets were quiet today, with the Chancellor of the Exchequer introducing the budget. Gilt edge issues were better, with the 3 1/2 per cent war loan at the year's highest price of 106 1/4, the 3 per cent at 100 1/4 and the 3 1/2 per cent conversion at 106 5/8.

Colonel John Paul Ratay, United States military attache at Bucharest, Rumania, for the last three years, arrived here on a Pan-American Airways transatlantic clipper last night, the first American official to be exchanged with the Axis powers since the outbreak of the war.

BOSTON, April 14 (AP) -- Lanky Ted Williams picked up today where he left off last season against the Athletics by banging out three hits -- including a three-run first-inning homer -- to drive in five tallies and spark the Red Sox to an 8-3 triumph in the opening day engagement before 11,101 fans, 9,901 of whom paid, and 1,200 service men.

PHILADELPHIA, April 14 -- New issues of securities offered for cash in February amounted to $2,335,000,000, the largest amount raised through such sales since the subscriptions to Liberty Loan bonds in 1918, according to a statistical summary made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The Court of Appeals having decided that the Board of Higher Education is not legally authorized to continue Townsend Harris High School, Irwin D. Davidson has introduced in the Assembly a bill to amend the law so that institutions created by the State Legislature may not be destroyed by local decree.

The four-story apartment house on a plot 63 by 100 feet at 11-15 Gardner Avenue, Jersey City, has been sold by the Fidelity Union Trust Company, trustee, to the Gardner Holding Company, Hyman Hoberman, president. The price was $45,000, the seller taking back a purchase money mortgage for $33,500.

Yesterday was payment day on the part of subscribers to the Treasury's recent issue of certificates of indebtedness, and it was estimated that the New York City banks turned over $310,000,000 in cash to the Treasury on behalf of themselves and their customers.
Mrs. Elgin R.L. Gould has arrived from San Antonio, Texas, and is at the Westbury.

Mayor La Guardia, delivering an indictment against the "mechanization of treatment" of juvenile delinquents, heaped ridicule yesterday upon psychologists and psychiatrists, whom he accused of sticking fingers into children's eyes and "banging them on the knees" to study their reactions and asking them embarrassing questions about their family life.
BERLIN, April 15 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique today said:
CAIRO, April 15 (AP) -- A British communique said today:

Perhaps the most interesting aspect of Sir Kingsley Wood's report on the new budget is his indication that the British income tax may have reached or passed the point of maximum returns, and has certainly done so in the upper brackets. "If we were to take away every penny of income above 2,000 from those whose incomes exceed 2,000," he declares, "the gain to the Exchequer would be only about 30,000,000."

Nine out of ten of those Americans who are familiar with the doctrines preached in the Coughlin magazine, Social Justice, would feel that the air was purer if this publication were to disappear. We think that no one, of whatever faith, can have any difficulty in distinguishing between Father Coughlin's functions as an ordained priest of the Catholic Church and his self-appointed undertakings as an agitator.

ALBANY, April 15 -- Governor Lehman said today that the 17,000 officers and enlisted men of the New York State Guard would have their rifles, which are needed by the Army and are being recalled by the War Department under a recent order, replaced by riot guns and that the outfit would continue to remain "an effective and powerful auxiliary arm of the service."

The 1942 "Little Green Book," official directory of municipal, State and Federal officialdom in the city, was out yesterday and, like the Social Register, was scanned for names dropped and names added.

WILLIAM WOODS is an unlucky man. His "The Edge of Darkness,"* a first novel, to a powerful, if sometimes unconvincingly melodramatic, story of revolt in an occupied Norwegian town. But it has the misfortune to come out at a time when John Steinbeck's somewhat similar story, "The Moon Is Down," is rocketing to the top of the best-seller lists and provoking acrimonious controversy in the columns of the weekly magazines.

Hitler defeated France once, but it was not enough. He conceived the diabolic device of dividing the country in half, cutting all the arteries of communication and trade that made it a whole organism, creating in effect two small, abnormal and dependent states that were placed under different regimes and set against each other.

CHICAGO, April 15 (AP) -- Federal Judge Michael L. Igoe approved today fees totaling $1,012,521 for attorneys, accountants, protective committees and others involved during the past several years in reorganization proceedings of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad.

Reporting on the contributors' drive now in progress for the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York, Mrs. G. Franklin Ludington, chairman of the drive in Manhattan, declared yesterday that $60,000 was needed to complete Greater New York's quota of $125,000.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Manufacture of oil burners and coal stokers for residential use was ordered halted on May 31, by the War Production Board today. Another order froze all stocks of heating and plumbing equipment and all sales of such material except those of $5 or less at retail and such sales as are necessary to fill orders bearing a preference rating of A-10 or higher.

At a reception given last night in the members' clubrooms of the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, by the United Women of the Americas, emblems of the organization were presented to wives of Latin-American consular representatives and members of clubs and organizations in the United States in recognition of conspicuous services rendered to Pan Americanism.

JERUSALEM, April 15 -- Two recent events have brought Palestine's industrial war effort into the foreground. First is the recent announcement by the Palestine Administration's Controller of Supplies that Army orders being placed here for the coming year will amount to 8,000,000 as compared with 4,000,000 last year and 1,000,000 in 1940.

The cut in the funds of the Board of Education should be restored to the city budget. The New York City school system, owing to the paucity of appointments of younger teachers in recent years, is already heavily overweighted with teachers of 60 and over. The sharp reduction in the educational budget will force out about four hundred high school teachers, those most recently appointed of course -- that is to say, the youngest ones.

Two more United States ships, one small and the other medium-sized, have been torpedoed and sunk off the Atlantic Coast, the Navy revealed yesterday, but sixty-three of the sixty-six men in the two crews have been saved. Both ships were sent to the bottom last Thursday.

Instead of being allowed to develop a concrete plan of expansion, the dehydrated food industry is still being treated by the government as a group of manufacturers out "for business at a profit and as such to be viewed at arm's length," L.K. Harper, vice president of the Sardik Food Products Corporation, charged yesterday in an address at the packaging conference sponsored by the American Management Association at the Hotel Astor.

A slight error and one or two omissions in your obituary of John Lovejoy Elliott inspire the writing of this note by one who had had the privilege of friendship with Dr. Elliott since he first came to New York almost fifty years ago.

The American Society of Newspaper Editors will open its twentieth annual three-day meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel this morning. Editors from all parts of the country will attend. Two hundred and fifty are expected.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The Federal Trade Commission may be expected in about a month to set up labeling standards for the dyes used in all cotton woven goods, according to the Consumer Division of the Office of Price Administration.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- After two months' investigation into the fire that swept and sank the liner Normandie at her New York pier last February, a House Naval Affairs subcommittee reported formally today that it, like other investigating bodies, had been unable to uncover even a trace of sabotage.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- An assertion that restriction of American use of tungstem carbide in machine tool manufacture alleged to be due to American monopoly prices amazed German manufacturers of the product after 1936, when the Nazi rearmament program already was in high gear, was made before the Senate Patents Committee today.

Richmond, the Head Play colt that raced for A.J. Sackett, made his 1942 debut with a head victory in the Polydor Handicap before 16,079 spectators at Jamaica yesterday. Jockey Jimmy Stout had to put all his power into the finish, for one of the Pacific Coast racers was right alongside.

Stressing the emergency aspect of his present-day activities, Mayor La Guardia came to City Hall yesterday in a small coupe painted to resemble a police radio car, but distinguished from the average police car by numerous appurtenances the Mayor has introduced as exclusively his own.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 15 -- After fifteen days of editorial inveighing against France in columns of print, the Italian press throughout today generally buried the dispatch announcing the change of the Vichy Government in a five-line item.

The New York Guard, which has a current total strength of around 17,000 officers and men, responded in astonishingly quick time yesterday to a surprise mobilization order, the first of its kind, issued by Major Gen. William Ottman, Guard commander.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The communique based on reports received up to 5 P.M. said:

"We are meeting the schedules," was the laconic description of current war output given last night by Sidney Weinberg, assistant to Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, at the semi-annual dinner of the Packaging Institute, Inc., at the Hotel Astor.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Some pork dealers who are alleged to have manipulated prices to establish artificially high levels for themselves immediately before the Office of Price Administration issued its temporary price ceilings on pork learned today that they must restore quotations to more normal levels by April 20.

IN 1941 Mr. J.A. Robert Quinn's Braves opened the season by losing a ball game to the Phils in Philadelphia. This season the Braves opened by winning a ball game from the Phils in Philadelphia. Over the span that was a fair distribution of honors, but this baffled bystander was puzzled over one little item. Why did the Phils -- of all clubs! -- open at home two years in succession?

One hundred and twenty-five employes of the Beachcombers Club at 1634 Broadway walked out at the dinner hour last night, leaving eighty patrons to find their evening's entertainment elsewhere. The strikers included waiters, bartenders, kitchen help, electricians and the members of the seven acts and two bands who perform in the night club.

Walter S. Gifford, president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, declared yesterday that the Bell System will seek increases in telephone rates if the Treasury tax proposals for 1942 become law.
Baseball, eager to do its share in the nation's war effort, yesterday came through with two announcements of plans that are certain to win the support of fans everywhere.

LONDON, Thursday, April 16 -- Explosions in the Calais area of the English Channel coast were audible on the English shore last night after big formations of the Royal Air Force had been heard in flight toward France.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The House Naval Affairs Committee unanimously approved today the Maas bill to create a Women's Auxiliary Reserve in the Navy, after Rear Admiral Randall Jacobs, Chief of the Bureau of Navigation, told the committee that more than 1,000 men had already been relieved of shore duty, apparently in expectation of early Congressional authorization for women to fill their jobs.

IN THE PITTBURGH MANUFACTURING AREA, April 15 -- The ancient method by which man first "spun" and thereby shaped crude pottery works forms the basis for the newest method of mass production in bombs and shells.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- America's factories have been forced to change over from peacetime to war production as quickly as it was possible to convert them to new products, Philip D. Reed, chief of the Bureau of Industry Branches of the War Production Board, told the Truman defense investigation committee today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, April 16 -- An early report from Moscow this morning said that Russian troops thrusting westward toward Bryansk had occupied four strategic points after smashing the Germans' first and second lines of defense around the city itself.

LONDON, April 15 -- Prices on the Stock Exchange today were hardly affected by the new taxes. The budget was described as "reasonable" although the increase in beer, spirits and tobacco duties were much higher than was expected. Shares of the companies most affected were marked down at the start, but there were few sellers and some of the stocks recovered before the close.

BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, April 16 -- It was learned here early this morning that the Petain government of "unoccupied France" has until 11 o'clock -- noon, Berlin time -- to submit the new Cabinet list for German approval or take the consequences.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, April 15 (AP) -- In the most spectacular aerial thrust of the Pacific war, thirteen United States Army bombers crossed the vast stretches from Australia and heavily assaulted Japanese bases on three Philippine Islands to redeem before the world the first installment of General Douglas MacArthur's pledge that the invader would yet be cast out of his lodgements there.

The report of the Johns-Manville Corporation and its subsidiary companies for the first quarter of this year, issued yesterday by Lewis H. Brown, president, reveals an increase of 31 per cent in net sales to $21,883,773 from $16,713,047 in the corresponding three months of last year.

DETROIT, April 15 (AP) -- The Tigers squared their series with the Indians by gaining a 6-to-2 decision today behind the seven-hit pitching of Paul (Dizzy) Trout. Rudy York's two-run homer in the fifth inning featured an 11-hit Detroit attack against three pitchers.
MOSCOW, April 15 (Russian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Bureau of Information communique today said:

Arnold S. Denker, former State champion, by defeating Herman Hahlbohm of Chicago in forty-five moves in the fifth round at the Hotel Astor last night moved into the lead in the championship of the United States Chess Federation leaving Samuel Reshevsky of Boston, the titleholder, in second place.

BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, April 16 (AP) -- Pierre Laval, vigorous pro-German leader, will serve as "civil supervisor of all France" in a new Cabinet to be announced today in Vichy, according to reliable diplomatic sources here.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The Office of Price Administration today fixed maximum prices at which various grades of domestic and foreign wood pulp may be sold in the United States or for export.

UNITED STATES ARMY HEADQUARTERS, in Australia, Thursday, April 16 (AP) -- General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters announced today the names of twenty-five service men and civilians who were brought to Australia yesterday by the American bomber squadron returning from the attack on Japanese bases in the Philippine Islands.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 15 -- With a pair of homers by Lefterus Lavrakas accounting for five runs, the Naval Academy baseball team today defeated the University of Michigan, 7 to 5. Jack Davis weakened in the late innings and Phil Hurt pitched the ninth for the Tars.

The Brooklyn Museum is opening today a timely exhibition of prints portraying circus scenes by nineteenth century and contemporary artists. It has been installed in the Print Gallery on the second floor and will be current through May 31. In addition to the prints, an original model of the circus, designed by R.H. Rey, will be shown.

District Attorney Samuel J. Foley of the Bronx contended yesterday that alterations in official records of the Department of Highways and Sewers were not made to conceal the use of city laborers at the Lake Mahopac state of Edward J. Flynn, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, as charged by Paul J. Kern, deposed president of the Civil Service Commission.

CHICAGO, April 15 -- Grain futures made a weak start and a firm finish today. Scattered liquidation was in evidence at the opening and for a short time thereafter, but it quickly ran its course and buying induced by the belief that the market was entitled to a natural recovery advanced wheat around 1 cent a bushel and corn 1/2 cent from the early low levels with the finish well toward the top.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15 (AP) -- The Braves made it two straight over the Phils today, gaining a 6- to-2 victory behind Jim Tobin. Except for the second, when Ben Warren tripled and scored on Bobby Bragan's single, and the ninth, when Danny Litwhiler hit a homer, Tobin held the Phils in check.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, new resident of Washington Square, twice yesterday expressed her annoyance at the interest the press has shown in her moving. On Tuesday she had supervised the transfer of furniture and household goods from the Roosevelt house on East Sixty-fifth Street to the new residence at 29 Washington Square West.

Mayor La Guardia joined yesterday the hundreds of Mayors and other public officials throughout the nation who have pledged their efforts to make Victory Book Day tomorrow a success, agreeing to serve as New York City chairman of the national one-day "push" for books for the armed services.

Steady trade demand throughout the session yesterday turned the cotton futures market upward again after new lows for the current movement had been reached. On the New York Cotton Exchange, final prices showed net gains of 4 to 8 points and they were near the best levels of the day.

A jury that deliberated less than an hour returned a conviction of murder in the first degree yesterday in General Sessions against Joseph Sonsky, 32-year-old convict on trial for slaying Detective James Garvey eight years ago at Seventy-fourth Street and Broadway.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 15 -- Boris Morros and S.P. Eagle, Twentieth Century Fox producers, announced today that they had obtained film rights to the music of Nicolai Rimsky-Korsakoff through negotiations with the Russian Government and that they will make a picture based on an incident in his career as a Russian marine in the last century.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (U.P.) -- Brig. Gen. Ralph Royce, who led American bombers from Australia in their raid on Japanese bases in the Philippines, is a 52-year-old native of Marquette, Mich., and was graduated from West Point in 1914.

When "It Happens on Ice" finishes its 650th performance Saturday night, April 25, the ice show at the Center Theatre will go out of existence. A new ice show, how ever, will be ready for presentation in the same spot late in June or early July.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 15 -- Both the British forces and the civilian population of Malta appear no worse despite the heaviest bombing in history. This is the report of Sir Walter Monckton, Acting Minister of State, who, with Air Marshal Arthur William Tedder, has just returned from a visit to the island.

The entire field of magnesium production and fabrication was thrown open yesterday to all industrialists in this country by the filing of a Federal court decree with the consent of a group of corporations and individuals who had been accused of restricting and curtailing the market in magnesium.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 15 -- Army defeated Georgetown at baseball today, 7 -- 3. The cadets shelled Dieckelman, the Hoyas' starting pitcher, in the early innings and piled up enough runs to win. Tom Tarver hurled the route for Army and never was in danger.

LONDON, April 15 -- Japan's armies in Burma, racing against the time when the rainy season will halt all campaigning, pushed ahead today on the two existing fronts and seriously threatened to open up a third.

JERSEY CITY, April 15 (AP) -- Arthur A. Pollan, executive vice president, said today at the annual meeting of the United Fruit Company that "maintenance of a healthy economic condition in the Caribbean countries is essential to the war effort."
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- To the officers and crews of two Army transport planes that carried the Harriman Mission to Moscow in September were awarded today the Distinguished Flying Cross.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

Formation of the Council on Books in Wartime, a group representing educational, library publishing and authors' organizations that will further the concept of "books as weapons in the war of ideas," was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The split between followers of John L. Lewis and Philip Murray within the United Mine Workers of America widened tonight when Mr. Murray expressed the hope that the U.M.W. rank and file would "clean house" to end "the conflict that is raging among the elected and appointed officers of our union."

Two hundred tubercular patients have been evacuated from Kings County Hospital and removal of some chronic patients from Bellevue Hospital also is planned, to provide room for victims of any disaster here growing out of the war, Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, Commissioner of Hospitals, disclosed yesterday.

Carolyn Wells, author, who died on March 26, bequeathed her Walt Whitman collection to the Library of Congress, and named her faithful companion and maid of many years, Miss Bridget Mary O'Connell, 130 West Sixty-seventh Street, principal legatee in her will. The will was offered for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday.
In THE TIMES of April 12 Thomas Hamilton, your correspondent in Santiago, Chile, made certain statements about Chile's position in the present international situation which need interpretation.

A number of contracts with relatively small companies not normally supplying department stores were reported to have been placed this week by some of the big stores here on various types of merchandise. Banking on an over-all ceiling, the stores were said to be more concerned over getting the goods on order, since an over-all ceiling would put all outstanding contracts and all later sales on an equal basis.

BEAUMONT Texas, April 15 (AP) -- Representative Dies said today that he would begin soon at his ranch near Jasper, Texas, a series of hearings which would "expose once and for all the entire Nazi espionage ring in this nation."
A recommendation that the Long Island Railroad install bicycle racks for commuters at its stations was made yesterday by Magistrate Jenkin R. Hockert of Queens in a letter to the railroad.
The Junior League Camera Club will open its third national photographic exhibition at a preview today in the Junior League clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street.

WASHINGTON, April I5 -- A directive informing General Douglas MacArthur of the area of his United Nations command and his authority over the forces of other nations in the Southwestern Pacific has been transmitted to the American commander.
MELBOURNE, Australia, April 15 -- The American Air Force on Bataan usually consisted of one or two combat planes in flyable condition, on good days, that is. Usually there was none.

A warning against the possible development of "wild-cat schemes" in connection with the National Nutrition Program was sounded yesterday by the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America in a special letter to its members and at a meeting of magazine publishers' representatives at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Like the old soldier he was, he stuck to his post. His last piece was in the same issue with his obituary. Active in many ways, he was a good officer, a strong administrator, a good business man when he beat his sword into a Moline plow. But it was first as an orator, hammerer, demonstrator, lambaster, that he stirred up his countrymen.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15 -- The stockholders of the Curtis Publishing Company rejected today a proposal that the board of directors serve in the future as a censor of all material accepted for publication in the Saturday Evening Post.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -- A $900,000,000 submarine building program to underline anew the Navy's announced determination to gain supremacy "above, beneath and on the seas" was approved today by the House Naval Committee less than a day after introduction of the measure.

MEXICO CITY, April 15 -- Official circles said tonight that the chiefs of the Falange Espanola were among the anti-democratic agents arrested here and that incriminating evidence might send about ten of them to Mexico's Tres Marias Penal Islands.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, April 15 -- Foreign Minister Alberto Guani of Uruguay formally inaugurated this evening the Emergency Advisory Committee for Political Defense, established in accordance with a resolution of the Rio de Janeiro conference to coordinate and promote measures by all American republics to curb foreign activities likely to endanger their security.

The Association of American Railroads has imposed a control embargo on commercial freight movements destined from inland points to transshipping points on all American coasts, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Recommendations that the operation of all merchant ships of the United States -- the American Merchant Marine -- be placed under the jurisdiction of the Secretary of the Navy and that such vessels, together with their personnel, function as an auxiliary to the Navy, were made to the Congress today by the House Naval Affairs subcommittee which investigated the fire that put the liner Normandie out of commission.

As the bitter and unending struggle for control of the oceans -- the struggle that may decide this war -- continued during the week, there was slowly emerging from the crucible of conflict some faint outline of the new sea power.

CHICAGO, April 15 (AP) -- A good wholesale demand for dressed beef, with prices higher than last week, lifted steers and yearlings today on the livestock market. A top of $17 a hundred pounds was reached by choice steers weighing 1,313 pounds, the highest mark since late 1937, when choice steers were above $19 a hundred pounds.

Echoing President Roosevelt's forecast as to the probable duration of the war, the senior class of the School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance of New York University feels that the war will last from two to three years, according to a poll taken by the senior year book, The Violet, the results of which were announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- By way of celebrating the return of the prodigal, Joe DiMaggio and the Yankees hammered Bobo Newsom at Griffith Stadium today as the world champions galloped to their second straight victory over the Senators before 7,500 fans, 2,500 of them service men.
UNITED STATES ARMY HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, April 15 (AP) -- The following communique was issued tonight:

LONDON, April 15 -- Members of the House of Commons generally seemed disposed today to accept Sir Kingsley Wood's conception of the budget as an economic weapon as well as a revenue raising instrument, although doubt was expressed in some quarters that it alone would achieve the economy in spending and consumption that he anticipated.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The largest building program in the nation's history will be carried out by the construction industry this year, the War Production Board predicted today. Total construction for the year will reach $14,750,000,000, compared with $11,500,000,000 last year, the highest total for any year up to that time.

Boy Scout membership in New York City reached a record of 42,368 Boy Scouts, Sea Scouts and Cubs enrolled in 1,339 Scouting units, it was reported yesterday by William H. Pouch, president of the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York. A membership goal of 44,500 boys in 1,372 units has been set for 1942.

TOKYO, April 15 (From Japanese Broadcast Recorded by The United Press in San Francisco and New York) -- Japanese naval planes bombed on Monday three airfields on Mindanao, big southern island of the Philippines, and Japanese Army planes bombed and machine. gunned troops fleeing to the mountains from Cebu City, on the island of Cebu, north of Mindanao, press dispatches said today.

BERRYVILLE, Va., April 15 -- To extract the useful material from a pile of unread books and papers relating to the war -- an accumulation of many months in Washington -- this correspondent has put the Blue Ridge and the Shenandoah River between the capital and himself for a few days.

CANBERRA, Australia, April 15 -- In an Australia-wide broadcast tonight Prime Minister John Curtin launched the sale of the new 10 [Australian] national savings bonds, which carry 3 per cent interest. Through a quota system for towns and districts, based on an average subscription of 6 yearly, it is hoped to raise at least 40, 000,000 yearly toward war costs, which now exceed 1,000,000 daily.

School authorities and other city officials are considering a plan to lengthen the school day -- perhaps to have all-day sessions, in which war work, recreation and other community activities would be added to the school program if New York is subjected to air raids -- Dr. Frank J. O'Brien, associate superintendent of schools, revealed last night.

Three new films will open in Broadway theatres this morning. "A Gentleman After Dark," will be the newcomer at Loew's State. Brian Donlevy, Miriam Hopkins and Preston Foster head the cast of the feature, which was produced by Edward Small and is released through United Artists.

CINCINNATI, April 15 (AP) -- Elmer was no Riddle today to the Pirates, who, knocking last year's leading National League hurler from the Box with a five-run out-burst in the first inning made it two straight over Cincinnati, 6 to 2.

Selma Mednikov, pianist from Kansas City, now an associate instructor of piano at the Juilliard Graduate School, last night gave her first New York recital at Carnegie Chamber Music Hall. She proved to be a thoughtful and musicianly performer with a well-grounded technique.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 15 (AP) -- Admiral William H. Standley, new United States Ambassador to Russia, presented his credentials to President Mikhail Kalinin in Moscow last night in the midst of a diplomatic whirl and a Spring breeze of rumors that is keeping the Kuibyshev foreign colony in a dither.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, April 16 -- Lieut. Col. John Hubert Davies, who led one group of the United States Army bombers that attacked Japanese bases in the Philippines Monday and Tuesday, said today: "We smacked hell out of them and gained at least a little revenge for members of our squadron who fought in the front trenches in Bataan."

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 15 -- The first United States war decoration awarded in Bermuda was pinned on the chest of Lieutenant Joseph Abraham Jaap of the United States Navy this afternoon by Rear Admiral Jules James, commandant of the naval operating base.

Adolf Busch and his Chamber Music Players gave the third and final concert of their Town Hall series last night. This time only half, instead of the entire program, was given over to works by Bach, the rest of the list consisting of offerings by Mozart and Beethoven.

PITTSBURGH, April 15 -- The Pittsburgh Steel Company was restrained from making further purchases of iron and steel scrap at above "ceiling" prices in a temporary order issued today in the Federal District Court here. Price Administrator Henderson requested the action, which is the first civil suit of its kind by the Office of Price Administration.

The history of New York City's Fire Department is illustrated in an extensive exhibit to be opened today with an invitation preview at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street. Beginning tomororw the show will be open to the public until Sept. 30.

One of the things about New York which greatly depressed M. Jules Romains in a city which for the most part he loves and admires were the remnants of the vanishing "L." He takes a newly arrived countryman for a stroll down Ninth Avenue and tells him that only a little while ago this spacious and airy thoroughfare was traversed by an elevated railroad.

The City Patrol Corps, under the direction of Major Gen. Robert Melville Danford, retired, will be functioning in a few weeks and within two months its "full benefit" will be felt by the Police Department, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15 -- The Franklin Medal, the highest honor conferred by the Franklin Institute, was awarded today to Dr. Jerome C. Hunsaker, general coordinator of Navy research and chairman of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics, and Dr. Paul Dyer Merica, vice president of the International Nickel Company, who achieved recognition for his work in the hardening of alloys.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Plans to resume shipment from the United States of food, clothing and essential supplies to North Africa and milk and clothing in a Red Cross vessel for the children of France are being held in abeyance pending clarification of the Vichy Cabinet crisis, Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State announced today.

One of the most extensive blackouts the nation has known covered 1,300 square miles of Northern New Jersey last night. It was hailed as generally successful by official observers at vantage points, most of whom agreed, however, that the problem of blackout facilities for industrial plants working on defense production was serious.

It would contribute materially to an improved state of mind, as between the Administration with its multitudinous agencies on the one hand and the public on the other hand, if there were a clearer official perception of the difference between unity and conformity.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15 -- Behind the four-hit pitching of Sophomore Ken Jamieson, Pennsylvania easily defeated Yale today in the latter's opening Eastern Intercollegiate League game, 16 to 2. It was the second straight league conquest and fourth in a row for the Red and Blue.

Eighteen thousand more women will be placed in jobs for war industry within the next six months in New York State, according to a joint survey by the Federal Employment Service and the State Labor Department, made public yesterday. During the same period, employers expect to add 72,000 more men to their payrolls.
Erling Riis has been nominated as a director of the International Paper Company for election at the annual meeting here on May 13, succeeding Calvin A. Agar.

FORT DIX, N.J., April 15 -- The Fort Dix pay reservation campaign for the purchase of war bonds and stamps by military personnel will begin at one minute after midnight tonight when Colonel Cassius M. Dowell, post commander, will sign a voucher authorizing the finance department to set aside a part of his pay each month for the purchase of bonds.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, April 15 -- Thirteen United States Army bombers, in a devastating sweep across the Philippines, have sunk or damaged eight Japanese ships, shot down five airplanes and damaged many more, and returned with some evacuees from the beleaguered islands, it was announced here tonight.

The possibility of critical developments in the relations between Vichy France and the United States and Britain threatens the entire trans-African air transport and supply route that has now been built up by the United Nations military services in cooperation with Pan American Airways and the British Overseas Airways Corporation.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- President Roosevelt met with the Pacific War Council; his callers included Secretary Morgenthau, Rear Admiral Land, Representative Robert L. Doughton, Joseph P. Kennedy and Summer Welles, Acting Secretary of State. Another visitor was J.H. Marsman, a Philippine citizen of Dutch descent, who told of his escape from the Japanese at Hong Kong.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Few city families make a habit of eating all the protective foods necessary for health and strength, the Office of Defense Health and Welfare Services reported today, on the basis of a nutrition survey recently conducted in South Bend, Ind.

For seven months Detective Fletcher Varrelman visited hundreds of hospitals, health centers, dispensaries and drug stores searching for the source of a baby's food formula that had been left with a child abandoned in a chapel pew.

As a result of the failure of people entitled to new cars to buy them, several companies have again started advertising campaigns to push sales of present stocks. Within the last week Oldsmobile and Buick released newspaper copy pointing out that many people may be entitled to buy a new car without knowing it and that new cars are more economical on gas and rubber than old ones.

Today a new American destroyer named for Rear Admiral Fullam is scheduled to slide down the ways at Boston. It will join the fleet as part of the "three-plane navy" which he was among the first to urge and fight for. It was his contention that surface warships of the future would be useless without submarines to defend them from the depths and planes to protect them in the air.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 15 (AP) -- Warren Wright's Kentucky Derby hopeful, Sun Again, blacked out his more famous stable-mate, Whirlaway, and Colonel E.R. Bradley's lone Derby candidate, Bless Me, at Keeneland Park today.

Apparently the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo and its particular public are partial to the old favorites, for last night the program at the Metropolitan Opera House boasted the largest audience and the best performance of the company's season to date.

CHICAGO, April 15 (AP) -- The Browns, held in check for eight innings by Johnny Humphries today, cut loose for five runs in the ninth to defeat the White Sox, 6 -- 5. It was the Browns' second straight victory.
ALBANY, April 15 -- The Legislature moved today in the interest of the national war effort to restore part of the legal existence of a man who is already "civilly dead."

John W. Hanes, chairman of the fifth annual campaign of the Greater New York Fund, warned yesterday that some of the 400 voluntary health and welfare agencies benefiting by the drive might have to close their doors unless greater support were forthcoming.

ALBANY, April 25 -- Manoeuvvring over proposed investigations held legislative attention today as the Republicans delayed action on a bill to create a committee with powers to go into any State department to ascertain possible economies.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Representative Doughton, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, stated today after a conference with President Roosevelt that he did not expect the administration at this time to set a tax revenue goal higher than the $7,610,000,000 recommendation presented to the committee by the Treasury early last month.

The deadline for filing the 1941 State income tax passed last midnight. At the main office of the State Income Tax Bureau in this city, 80 Centre Street, yesterday's mail brought a record volume of returns, 40,000, according to the estimate of Wesley M. Dawson, district supervisor.
NEW DELHI, India, April 15 (AP) -- A British communique on the Burma front situation said today:

BERNE, Switzerland, April 15 -- What is Pierre Laval bringing to the French to justify his return to office with wider powers than before? What has he pledged himself to give to the Germans in return for their support?

A number of "compliance commissioners" will shortly be assigned to the Priorities Field Office here to speed handling of violations of priority and limitation orders, it was learned yesterday. The move has the twofold objective of preventing economic loss through delays to concerns wrongly suspected of violations and to speed the transfer of vital materials to war work when the suspect is guilty.

Members of a subcommittee to coordinate planning for post-war transportation were named yesterday by Clarence L. Riegel, executive manager of the New York Credit Men's Association and secretary of the transportation committee of the National Association of Credit Men.

Judge John J. Sullivan in General Sessions yesterday refused to accept intoxication as an excuse for the wartime theft of $12,000 in sugar on a motor truck and trailer as he sentenced John Pantuliano, 35 years old, of 32 Grand Street, to a Sing Sing term of eighteen months to three years.

Fordham hit too well, fielded too adroitly and was given too keen a pitching performance at the Ram field yesterday for Brooklyn College to do anything but become the Maroon's fifth straight victim in an unbeaten string. With Dick Fitzgerald twirling a three-hitter the Rams scored their fourth consecutive Metropolitan Collegiate Conference victory, 5 -- 1.
Art property of the late Mrs. Christian R. Holmes brought $45,000 yesterday afternoon at the first of four auction sessions at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc.

Thirteen local public housing authorities, consisting of ten cities and three counties, sold yesterday a total of $54,629,000 of temporary-loan notes, all dated April 29, 1942. A banking group headed by the Chemical Bank and Trust Company received the award of $51,080,000 of the total, while the remaining $3,549,000 of notes was sold separately to four other concerns.

VICHY, France, April 15 -- Pierre Laval's return to office has been accepted in France without perceptible reaction. It arouses no comment in the press of either zone. In both regions the communique announcing the decision to form a new Cabinet is printed without comment.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 15 (AP) -- Howard S. Palmer, president of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, asserted today that unless it received delivery of locomotives now on order there was a "possibility" of freight embargoes "or the rationing of transportation during the latter part of this year or early next year."

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The 50,000,000 recipients of income in the United States will be asked within a few weeks to sign a "pledge of freedom," calling for regular investment by all working citizens in United States war bonds and stamps.

LONDON, Thursday, April 16 -- Bretons at St. Nazaire, France, took up sporadic street fighting against the Germans with British firearms after the spectacular British raid on the German-held French port on March 28, The Daily Mail reported today.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Declaring that the present formula for working out parity prices for farmers is unfair, Representative Fulmer, chairman of the Agriculture Committee, said today that he would call that body together to work out a new proposal.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Major prime contractors handling war contracts were urged today by Donald M. Nelson, War Production Board chairman, to subcontract more of their work among other companies whenever deliveries can be hastened by doing so.

Michael J. Kennedy, the new leader of Tammany Hall, is a West Side product, having been born within a block of his present home, on West Fifty-first Street. He has been active in politics in that neighborhood, once ruled over by "The" McManus, since he came of voting age.

The selling of stocks that was prompted on Tuesday by the return of Pierre Laval to power in unoccupied France subsided yesterday and prices made an attempt at recovery, with spotty success. As volume dwindled the market reverted to its familiar narrow range, and, although the war news in the Pacific was better, it was hardly broad enough to encourage any buying.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 15 (AP) -- Fighting in the slush of a more definite mass battle line, the Red Army was reported tonight to have achieved a break-through in the first lines of the important Bryansk sector of the central front.

LONDON, April 15 -- General George C. Marshall, United States Army Chief of Staff, and Harry Hopkins, chairman of the United States Munitions Assignment Board, had luncheon with King George today at Buckingham Palace. Afterward General Marshall went to have a talk with General Wladyslaw Sikorski, Polish Premier.

Only one of the favored teams lost its match in the national contract bridge tournament for the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup as the original field of twenty-seven teams was reduced to eight teams at the Hotel Pierre last night.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15 -- The Washington Gas Light Company of Washington, D.C., filed today a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a proposed offering of 40,000 shares of $5 cumulative preferred stock of no par value.

The General Foods Corporation declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of 40 cents a common share, payable to holders on May 15. This represented a reduction of 10 cents from the previous quarterly rate.

An appeal for all possible assistance in recruiting 10,000 volunteer nurses' aides to work in New York's hospitals was made to the New York City Visiting Committee of the State Charities Aid Association yesterday by Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, recently appointed Commissioner of Hospitals.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 15 -- Several of the world's ablest intelligent services are concentrating their efforts on attempts to discover how the German High Command is disposing or preparing to dispose its troops and impedimenta in preparation for further offensive operations on the Russian front.

Because of the illness of Eddie Cantor, who underwent a minor operation on Monday, the engagement of "Banjo Eyes," the musical comedy starring Mr. Cantor at the Hollywood Theatre, was terminated yesterday afternoon. The starts a patient in Sydenham Hospital, which he entered Tuesday afternoon upon the advice of his physician, Dr. Joseph S. Diamond.

Many stores, particularly those in the so-called target areas, are resorting to duplication of all their more important records and are storing them at remote points presumed to be safe from air raids, Harry L. Margules of Gimbel Brothers, said last night at the dinner meeting of the Metropolitan Controllers Association at the Hotel Martinique.

LONDON, April 15 (U.P.) -- Pierre Laval's return to power in France reduces that country to the level of "a five-cent Balkan State" in the Nazi new order, but Admiral Francois Darlan still stands between Germany and the French fleet, British sources said tonight.
LONDON, April 15 -- The work of the Department of Political Warfare, which is under the direction of Bruce Lockhart, was defended but not explained by Brendan Bracken in the House of Commons today.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The National Conference of Petroleum Regulatory Authorities urged today, at the final session of its first meeting, that the public domain be opened to greater oil development.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -- Governor Phillips of Oklahoma condemned the Civilian Conservation Corps and National Youth Administration today as "poison to our boys," and declared that "a great majority" of first-term prisoners he had interviewed in his State's reformatory were former CCC enrollees.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Draft deferment for employes of railroads will not solve permanently the problem of manning and maintaining the nation's railroads in the face of increasing labor shortages, representatives of American railroads were told at a meeting called by the Office of Defense Transportation.
For the first time the Metropolitan Museum of Art has honored the country's advertising artists by holding in its galleries the twenty-first annual exhibition of the Art Directors Club.

It was logical that the Young Timers Fashion showing by Bendel's at the Waldorf yesterday should end with a bride. The clothes were all for the young, both in heart and figure. The bride and her single attendant were in heavenly blue organdie.

In line with his transfer last Saturday of ten of the sixteen inspectors commanding the uniformed forces in the five boroughs, Police Commissioner Valentine yesterday assigned 112 plainclothes men to uniformed duty and replaced them with young patrolmen who have never before served in plain clothes.

Mel Ott, the late John McGraw's "boy," who this year took the job held for years by the man Ott respected most, yesterday managed his Giants into a 6-4 triumph over the Dodgers before a Polo Grounds crowd of 12,440.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The National War Labor Board ordered the International Harvester Company today to sign a maintenance c. union membership provision in its union contract if a majority of union members in each of eight plants favored such a provision at a secret referendum ordered by the board.

Heavy buying featured the three-day convention of the Affiliated Drug Stores which closed yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore. Gains ranging from 25 to more than 50 per cent over a year ago were noted on many "sundry" merchandise items as more than 500 member stores placed orders for goods for Summer, Fall and Christmas selling, it was reported yesterday by Joseph Rosenwald of the buying office.

The War Production Board order reducing by 70 per cent the amount of shellac that will be available to phonograph record manufacturers has caught the industry relatively unprepared, the presidents of the three leading companies said yesterday.

BOSTON, April 15 (AP) -- Joe Dobson, who ended the 1941 season with seven consecutive triumphs, started in impressive fashion today by hurling the Red Sox to a 3-1 triumph over the Athletics with a six-hit performance.

The Borden Company is hopeful of continuing the current rate of dividends on the common stock if future taxes are not too drastic, Theodore C. Montague, president of the company, said yesterday at the annual meeting in Jersey City. In recent years the company has paid three interim dividends of 30 cents each, and a final dividend of 50 cents, or $1.40 annually.

Anthony Barracota, who persuaded two physicians that he needed an abdominal operation last Friday, when he should have been at his trial in Federal court for bootlegging, died yesterday. Death was caused by a pulmonary embolism.

A further net drop of 858,000 barrels in supplies of gasoline and light and heavy fuel oil along the Atlantic Coast occurred last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Gasoline stocks declined 284,000 barrels to 17,035,000 at the close of the week and light fuel oil supplies dropped 754,000 to 6,261,000.

Thirteen American bombers have paid the first installment on the promise of General MacArthur that we shall return to the Philippines. They left a wake of destruction over almost the entire length of the archipelago, from Manila in Luzon to Davao in Mindanao. Transports were sunk and damaged; enemy planes shot down; a supply ship bombed; hangars and runways wrecked.
LONDON, April 15 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:
BLAIRSTOWN, N.J., April 15 -- New Jersey's fresh-water fishermen turned out today in large numbers as the State's trout season officially opened at daylight.

"By offensives alone can we win" is not a fair statement of fact. It is not the lesson taught by the present war. The victorious offensives have succeeded only against nations having inadequate defenses. Hitler, chief advocate and beneficiary of offensive strategy, has not neglected to fortify Germany before pressing his campaigns abroad.
ST. LOUIS, April 15 (AP) -- The Cardinals may not have the sluggers they used to have, but as long as their hitting is as timely as it was today they'll be near the top.
WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -- The Division of Physical Fitness, formerly part of the Office of Civilian Defense, was abolished today by Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator.

Ezequiel Padilla, Foreign Minister of Mexico, exponent of Latin-American solidarity against the Axis, has signed a contract with Alliance to write a book entitled "Free Man of America." The thesis of Senor Padilla's work will be that since Europe is being drained, its culture going into a permanent decline, the leadership of the world will inevitably shift to the Americas and the free men will become the arbiters of culture.
The U.S.S. Duncan, a new destroyer, was commissioned at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn yesterday less than two months after launching and five months ahead of schedule.

BOSTON, April 16 (AP) -- Every Red Sox player scored at least once and all except one hit safely today while gaining their third straight victory over the Athletics, 19 -- 4, behind the seven-hit pitching of Charley Wagner.

LONDON, April 16 (AP) -- Bloody, weary, but still on their feet and fighting, a battalion of the King's Own Yorkshire Light Infantry, a regiment with 186 years of glorious history, held the Minhla sector of the Western Burma front today in obedience to the regimental motto, "Yield to none."

CHUNGKING, China, April 16 -- The Japanese were pouring fresh divisions that may total upward of 80,000 men into the Burma campaign tonight. They were expending ammunition on a vast scale in a massive attempt to complete the conquest of the country and shut off China from the other United Nations before the May monsoon gives the nearly exhausted defenders relief.

NEWARK, N.J., April 16 -- Out-hit, but more fortunate in other respects, Buffalo bagged a ten-inning decision over the pennant-defending Bears today in their International League baseball opener before 7,762 fans at Ruppert Stadium. The score was 5 to 4.

PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad, April 16 -- Ten United States training planes were forced down Sunday by adverse weather in the jungles of Eastern Venezuela at Baja, the United States command disclosed tonight along with the announcement that all twenty airmen involved had been rescued by the close cooperative efforts of the Army and Navy and civilian fliers.

One hundred men and women were routed from their apartment homes last night by fire sweeping through the Progressive Lumber Yard at 1170 Southern Boulevard, the Bronx, at the corner of Home Street. Four alarms were sounded for the fire, which was discovered at about 11 P.M. and was not under control until after 12:30 A.M.

BERLIN, April 16 (From German broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- German troops on the Russian front are carrying out offensive operations "in bottomless mud and ice-water," the German Transocean agency said today.

A United States Coast Guard amphibian plane on a routine flight from the Brooklyn Coast Guard station crashed into the sea off Gay Head, Martha's Vineyard, early yesterday with the loss of the three crew members.
Twenty-nine critics of the country named their choices yesterday for the annual Pulitzer Prize awards. The results were noteworthy for the absence of unanimity.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- With strong sentiment evidenced in Congress for new labor legislation, the Senate Labor Committee abandoned its months' long opposition today and at its direction a subcommittee drafted legislation aiming to restrict the extension of closed-shop agreements and increases in wages and salaries.

Justice Herbert A. O'Brien of the Domestic Relations Court, Queens, charged last night that Mayor La Guardia's criticism of the Children's Court at the opening of the Bureau of Prevention of Juvenile Delinquency in Harlem on Wednesday indicated that the Mayor was "utterly incapable of understanding the work of the court."

LONDON, April 16 -- The stock markets were quiet and firm again today. Gilt-edge issues were unchanged. Leaders in the industrial section improved with the outstanding feature a rise of four points in Cunard 6 per cent preference to 127s, the 5 per cent preference higher at 96 1/2s and the ordinary up at 15 7/8s.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- An allowance of half a pound of sugar a week a person has been set for American consumers for the first eight weeks of the sugar-rationing program. In disclosing plans for "the greatest short-time registration history" officials of the Federal Price Administration said that registrations of about 130,000,000 consumers would start May 4 and continue through May 7.

Dedicating the new Benjamin Franklin High School yesterday, Mayor La Guardia told the student body, composed entirely of boys, that they must prepare not only to go to war if it continues but afterward to assume responsibility when they "face another war -- a dislocated world."

Henry Goelet, operator, who recently bought the six five-story apartment houses comprising the block bounded by West 189th and 190th Streets and Amsterdam and Audubon Avenues, has resold the last of the buildings to a client of Benjamin Miller, attorney.

One of the largest distributions of common stock undertaken in recent years took place late yesterday afternoon with the public offering of 225,000 shares of common stock of International Harvester Company by a group of fifty-two underwriters, headed by Clark, Dodge Co. and Lee Higginson Corporation.

Alexander Smith Sons and C.H. Masland Sons announced yesterday that, effective immediately, all lines of carpets and rugs were being withdrawn, but that goods in stock will be offered subject to prior sale. Production will continue at a restricted rate under the limitation orders on wool and jute, and as goods become available they will be added to the stock lists, against which new orders will be taken on a pro rata basis.

Although the people of Korea and India never heard of the WPB, the designs evolved by their fashion dictators might well be adapted to today's wartime restrictions. To prove this the Museum of Costume Art at Rockefeller Center has assembled an exhibit of fifty traditional garments, which it showed yesterday morning at a press preview.

Charles Walzer, operator, has purchased for cash above a first mortgage of $119,500 in a deal negotiated by Edgar P. Goodwin, broker, the four-story walk-up apartment house at 32.05 Eighty-first Street, on the southeast corner of Thirty-second Avenue, in Jackson Heights, Queens.

Only New York teams were left in the running last night after the quarter-final round in the contest for the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup and the national contract bridge team-of-four championship, at the Hotel Pierre.

Mrs. Robert Low Bacon, co-chairman of the New York campaign committee for United China Relief, entertained at a typical Chinese luncheon yesterday in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, to observe women's day in the current China Week, being promoted by the organization's fund-raising drive.

A feature of "collaborative" measures already in effect in unoccupied France is an artificially stimulated anti-Semitism, according to refugee passengers who arrived here yesterday on the Portuguese vessel Guine. The Guine docked at Staten Island with 210 passengers after a long voyage from Lisbon, Casablanca and Havana.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- An amendment to the automobile rationing order, intended to liberalize its terms, is in the course of preparation, Rolf Nugent, chief of the Automobile Rationing Section of the Office of Price Administration, said tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- A ban against the use of any materials to build or change radio broadcasting stations was urged today by the Defense Communications Board upon the War Production Board and Federal Communications Commission.

CHICAGO, April 16 (AP) -- A change in the base period for computing ceilings which traders said lowered the level at which sales to the retail trade could be made had a strongly depressing influence on dealings in hogs today. The top price declined 40 cents to $14.25 a hundred pounds.

Bruno Walter had three "seconds" in his corner at Carnegie Hall last night. Since this is the report of a concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, the news is about the seconds and what happened to them. They were, in the order of their appearance, Dvorak's Second Symphony, Samuel Barber's Second Essay and Brahm's Second Symphony.

DETROIT, April 16 -- The rebounding Maple Leafs squared the Stanley Cup hockey series at three games each by crushing the Red Wings, 3 to 0, before 13,153 fans tonight for their third successive victory. The deciding game will be played Saturday in Toronto.

Victory Book Day will be celebrated today, ending the three-month drive sponsored by the American Red Cross, the USO and the American Library Association for 10,000,000 books for the nation's armed services.

Mayor La Guardia's war budget, aggregating $612,698,761, was the target of attack yesterday by speakers battling to regain lost ground in the fields of education, public health and social services, while Park Commissioner Robert Moses headed a drive to regain the park and playground areas put out of action by the Mayor's budget cuts.

Bank clearings of the twenty-four principal cities of the nation were 6.1 per cent above the total of the preceding week and 12.3 per cent above the comparable week a year ago, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

LONDON, April 16 -- More than 400 Spitfires and other squadrons of bomb-carrying Hurricanes and two-motored bombers -- the greatest number of planes yet reported used in a daylight offensive on the Western Front -- delivered heavy blows against the Germans in Northern France today.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, April 16 (AP) -- It was disclosed here today that the American bombers that spread "destruction and dismay" among the Japanese in the Philippines early this week used a secret fighter-guarded base deep in those islands and provisioned it in expectation of returning again and again.

Henry M. Williams of New Dorp, S.I., city fireman who joined the United States Marine Corps, acted in a "most commendable spirit of patriotic devotion" but he "misunderstood the law," Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag said yesterday in denying a petition by his father, Harry M. Williams, to compel the city to pay the fireman-marine the difference between his pay as a fireman and as a marine.

Police Commissioner Valentine's ban on cruising taxicabs in the midtown district, which becomes effective on Monday for an experimental period of thirty days, also prohibits empty cabs from making U-turns or left turns from avenues into streets, it was disclosed yesterday when the new regulations were made public.

TRENTON, April 16 -- State Milk Director Arthur F. Foran filed with the Secretary of State today orders reducing milk prices throughout New Jersey, effective May 1. In Northern Jersey, reductions of one cent a quart were ordered, provided consumers accept delivery of two quarts every other day.

LONDON, April 16 -- In view of travel restrictions, the government has asked every Borough Council in Greater London to do everything possible to make the city more attractive as a holiday center. The Ministry of Labor wants every one to remain at home this Summer.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Lefty Gomez today launched his thirteenth straight year as a Yankee hurler, and though he gave Manager Joe McCarthy the jitters, the world champions eventually beat the Senators, 8 to 5, at Griffith Stadium.

PHILADELPHIA, April 16 (AP) -- Ernie Lombardi spoiled a great pitching performance by Tommy Hughes today to give the Braves a 2-1 verdict over the Phils in ten innings and a clean sweep of the three-game series.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The general level of wholesale prices in the week ended April 11, although comparatively steady, showed a slight rise and reached the highest level since September, 1928, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
