WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- Donald Nelson, War Production Chief, declared today that the government officially favored vacations for war workers, but he asked that industry "show its ingenuity in securing the vacation benefits without paying a counterbalancing cost in productive hours lost."

ALBANY, April 16 -- The Janes bill calling for further tapering off of the mortgage moratorium, through the payment of a sliding scale of amortization charges based on interest rates, was killed in the Senate today by its sponsor, Rodney B. Janes, Rochester Republican and chairman of the Senate Committee on Mortgages and Real Estate.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The functions of the Office of Civilian Defense were redefined by executive order today in such a way as to integrate the activities of OCD "more closely with those of other war agencies and to gear its program to the war effort."

HAVANA, April 13 -- The enemy submarine campaign against shipping in Cuban waters has focused attention here on Cuba's inadequate radio communication in coastal areas and the need for better control of radio in the island.

A "War Savings Festival," under the auspices of the Social Agencies Division of the New York Defense Savings Staff, will be held tomorrow at 10:30 A.M. in the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street. Children of ten New York social agencies will attend the festival, which is designed to dramatize their efforts on behalf of the United States War Savings program.

With the approval of the War Department the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, has prepared an extensive program to utilize art and Ameri can artists for the benefit of the country's armed forces.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 16 -- A screen adaptation of Leon Gordon's stage play, "White Cargo," reportedly has been scheduled at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer as a vehicle for Hedy Lamarr with Victor Saville as producer. An English film version of the play was made in 1930 by British International Pictures with Maurice Evans.
ST. LOUIS, April 16 (AP) -- The Cardinals concluded their first series of the season with a two-to-one edge over the Cubs, taking a wild hitting and fielding game today, 11 to 6.
LONDON, April 16 -- Now that "austerity" has been adopted as a shibboleth by the government most British politicians and the people are demanding greater equality of sacrifice.

BUFFALO, April 16 (AP) -- Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt can make "her contribution to our national welfare by keeping quiet for the duration on subjects of which she knows but little, if anything," said Jacob Ark of Rochester, New York State Commander of the American Legion, at a dinner last night.

Apache, William Woodward's Kentucky Derby hope, had a workout at Jamaica yesterday before 15,335 racegoers who saw the brown son of Alcazar capture the High Quest Purse, a three-horse race at a mile and a sixteenth. The winner, clocked in the moderate time of 1:44 2/5 under 117 pounds, scored by a length and a half, going very easily. He paid $2.80.

Sixteen men -- thirteen lieutenants, two acting lieutenants and one sergeant -- previously engaged in supervising plainclothes operatives engaged in getting evidence of vice in New York City were transferred to routine police station duty in yesterday's developments in the department shake-up.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 16 -- It has been reliably learned in Stockholm that Bishop Eivand Berggrav was released from prison yesterday and that the three other Lutheran churchmen who had been arrested at the same time as he were freed today by Premier Vidkun Quisling's authority.

Double the number of parents and citizens are needed as "school aides" in the Civilian Defense that is being directed by the United Parents Associations of this city, it was revealed yesterday at a meeting of this organization in the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

The Office of Price Administration has found a method of over-coming the principal weakness of the temporary freeze order system, according to trade comment yesterday. The policy was instituted with respect to pork prices and trade observers in other fields said they expected it to spread.

BERRYVILLE, Va., April 16 -- So completely have political considerations been established in the field of American military strategy that the dispatch of Harry L. Hopkins with General Marshall to London seems to have been accepted as a matter of course, though the mission was primarily a military one. Mr. Hopkins is certainly no war strategist.

With their ship lurching beneath them from a gaping hole blasted by an enemy torpedo, sailors on a medium-sized ship of United States registry opened fire with a machine gun on the submarine that had attacked them, it was disclosed yesterday with the permission of the Navy.
BERLIN, April 16 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued the following communique today:

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- A long-standing patent-pooling arrangement between Krupp and a General Electric subsidiary not only prevented Germany from shutting off our supplies of tungsten carbide but made possible development of more economical ways of using this important alloy in speeding America's war effort, Zay Jeffries, chairman of the board of the Carboloy Company, Inc., of Detroit, told the Senate Patents Committee today.

There were several reminders yesterday of the increasing pace of Treasury disbursements. First, although the Treasury received payment for its new issue of certificates of indebtedness in the week ended on Wednesday, the weekly Federal Reserve figures showed a net gain of only $100,000,000 in Treasury cash and deposits with the Reserve Banks.

HAVANA, April 15 -- The Cuban Government will continue control of sugar production despite the suspension of the quota system in the United States, according to an official note issued by the Secretary to the President, Morales del Castillo, last night.
Once a year the budding Beethovens, Bachs and Brahms at the High School of Music and Art get the golden opportunity of giving their creations a public hearing. What is more, they perform themselves.

The Giants waited long and patiently for their "big inning" at the Polo Grounds yesterday. But the big round which the Gotham fans in the two previous days of the new season had come to regard as a regular part of the show never came, and the Dodgers literally walked off with the ball game, 4 to 2.
DETROIT, April 16 (AP) -- Don Ross and Rudy York hit home runs today to give the Tigers a 5-4 victory over the Indians.

NEWARK, N.J., April 16 -- Archie Otom, 47-year-old Negro, was sentenced today to serve one year in the Essex County Penitentiary after his conviction by Police Judge William F. Untermann on a charge of disorderly conduct during last night's blackout test.

LONDON, April 16 -- The Ministry of Economic Warfare, comparing Sir Kingsley Wood's tax provisions with those in effect in Germany as reported through its secret sources, says that powerful German industrialists have recently succeeded in forcing Adolf Hitler to grant them important concessions.

ALBANY, April 16 -- By a vote of 90 to 16, the Assembly passed today the Graves bill establishing a State-wide speed limit of 40 miles an hour. The measure, which now goes to the Governor, carries out President Roosevelt's recent recommendation that such a limit be set to help conserve automobiles and tires.

Strangely enough, a spectacular occurrence in the Western Pacific makes civilian defense in this neighborhood seem of more immediate importance. If American bombers can make a round trip of 4,000 miles, even with an un identified intermediate stop "much nearer the targets," un-American bombers might do the same thing.

In what is believed to be the first campaign addressed to the public on the science of electronics, General Electric Company will run a series of color ads in national magazines, predicting that the country is "standing on the threshold of one of the most fascinating periods in the history of science -- the Electronic Era."
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- A War Department communique, based on reports received up to 10 A.M., said today:

ALBANY, April 16 -- Governor Lehman signed today the Defense Bill creating a State War Council of twenty members, and local war councils as well, to take the place of the present defense councils. In doing so the Governor appealed to the Mayors to turn over the task of Director of Civilian Protection in their communities to full-time, paid directors and not to try to assume the job themselves.

DETROIT, April 16 -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin will assume full responsibility for the editorial matter of the magazine Social Justice, if any one connected with the publication is charged with sedition, in the opinion of the magazine's attorney, Prewitt Semmes.
A gift to this country from Korea, which formally fell victim to Japanese aggression as early as 1910, was presented yesterday to former Governor Alfred E. Smith in the Empire State Tower.

Wholesale grocers, unable to obtain many of their usual items and with their profits limited because of wartime restrictions, are turning to such unrelated items of merchandise as workshirts, flower bulbs and household appliances in an effort to maintain business volume, according to initial findings of an informal survey released yesterday by the National American Wholesale Grocers Association.
WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- The War Department announced today the names of thirty officers and twenty-seven enlisted men who were killed in action or died of wounds in the Southwest Pacific.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 16 -- Vice Admiral William A. Glassford 2d, commander of the United States naval forces in the Southwest Pacific, brought personal word to America today that air power had been the greatest need in that theatre of war since Dec. 7, that it was still the greatest need, and that it was likely to continue to be the greatest need until victory was achieved.

PHILADELPHIA, April 16 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a proposal by the Associated Electric Company that it be permitted to sell the securities and other indebtedness of the Union Gas and Electric Company to the Union Utilities Company for $800,O00 in cash.
LONDON, April 16 -- The Japanese continued to press forward on all fronts in Burma, according to reports reaching London today.
LONDON, April 16 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Japanese forces enlarged their operations in the Philippines today by landing on the island of Panay, large and wealthy sugar-producing area, where they met resistance of a degree not yet made clear in dispatches reaching the War Department here.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 16 -- High-explosive and incendiary bombs were showered on the airport at Japanese-held Kupang, in Netherland Timor, before dawn today by planes of the Royal Australian Air Force, it was announced.
CHICAGO, April 16 (AP) -- The Browns made it three in a row over the White Sox today by getting fourteen hits for twenty-five bases and a 13-3 victory.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- President Roosevelt's combined War Labor Board "jointly and unanimously" told the President today that its members were opposed to the stabilization or freezing of wages.

The number on the New York Stock Exchange service flag, which hangs above the trading floor, has been changed from 160 to 900. The first number covered members and employes of the Exchange proper who were in the armed services.
The New York Drama Critics Circle decided yesterday to make no award for the best American play of the season and chose Noel Coward's "Blithe Spirit" as the best foreign play.

With price changes magnified in only a handful of issues, the stock market plodded along yesterday in a session painful because of its lack of activity. Business on the Stock Exchange slumped to 262,720 shares, third smallest volume since last June, against 347,630 shares sold on Wednesday.

The War Production Board is believed to have abandoned its original plans to shut down entirely on production of innerspring mattresses and certain types of living room furniture in the immediate future, manufacturers said yesterday.

The cotton futures market advanced yesterday to net gains of 15 to 18 points over Wednesday's closing levels on the strength of continued trade buying. Offerings of active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange became relatively scarce near the end of trading and the highs for the session were registered at the close.

Andre Maurois gave an advance reading from his memoirs yesterday afternoon at the French Institute, 22 East Sixtieth Street, under the sponsorship of the Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- Estimated operating revenues of eighty-eight Class 1 railroads, representing 82.7 per cent of total operating revenues, increased 27.4 per cent in March compared with March, 1941, the Association of American Railroads reported today.

Reflecting the large-scale Treasury operations in the week ended on Wednesday, excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City dropped $150,000,000 to $720,000,000, lowest level since April 13, 1938, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

TRENTON, April 16 -- That much-investigated epicurean "grocery" bill for Governor Charles Edison's Summer cottage in Sea Girt last August, a $5,533 item described by Mr. Edison as "preposterous" when he refused in February to approve payment by the State, was submitted to another inquiry today, this time by a State Senate committee.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- During the week ended April 15 member bank reserve balances decreased $213,000,000. Reductions in member bank reserves arose from increases of $14,000,000 in money in circulation, $111,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks, and $135,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts, offset in part by increases of $31,000,000 in Reserve Bank credit and $3,000,000 in gold stock, and a decrease of $11,000,000 in Treasury cash.

An auction sale was held yesterday afternoon at the Plaza Art Galleries, Inc., for the benefit of the Citizens Committee for the Army and Navy, Inc. A wide variety of objects had been donated for the sale, as well as cash contributions.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Department store sales last week, reflecting the fact that Easter came a week earlier this year than last, were 12 per cent below the sales in the corresponding week of 1941, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. In the preceding week a gain of 22 per cent was reported.

ALBANY, April 16 -- Factory employment in New York State in March rose slightly over the February figure, Frieda S. Miller, Industrial Commissioner, reported today. The net gain was 1 per cent and came principally from companies in the metals and machinery groups, although slight gains were noted in the apparel industries and in miscellaneous manufacturing and leather goods industries.

JERSEY CITY, April 16 -- The ever-flamboyant opening of Jersey City's baseball season again jammed Roosevelt Stadium today and, for a change, ended on a happy note as the Little Giants tied Montreal in the ninth inning and won in the tenth, 3 to 2.
LONDON, April 16 (AP) -- Note circulation of the Bank of England continued its uninterrupted rise for the eighth consecutive week, increasing 3,184,000 to the high record of 767,110,000.
LONDON, April 16 -- For the first time in history a medal -- the George Cross -- has been conferred on a part of the British Commonwealth: Malta.

VICHY, France, April 16 (U.P.) -- While Pierre Laval, the French-German collaborationist, mapped out a new government today, with himself as Premier, the police guarded him from a huge crowd in the streets and a fresh wave of violence, including a German troop train derailment that killed thirty-five to forty persons, swept through occupied France.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- An appeal to all to cooperate with restrictions on gasoline sales which went into effect today was issued tonight by Secretary Ickes as Petroleum Coordinator; Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board and Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator.

NEW DELHI, India, April 16 (U.P.) -- Japanese forces tonight were almost at the gates of the British-defended Burma oil fields. To the east they held the Chinese on the Mandalay road in a partial pincer.

In an expansion move made necessary by the war, the Air Reduction Company, Inc., manufacturers of acetylene and oxygen welding and cutting apparatus, and producers of the gases, has leased an additional entire floor consisting of about 8,000 square feet in the building at 295 Madison Avenue.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., April 16 -- Stimulation of United States New Zealand trade by the war was revealed today by a number of United States inquiries here for key raw materials. Talc, of which New Zealand is reported to possess promising deposits, and magnesite, of which there are millions of tons of high-grade quality in one region alone, were sought.

Lieut. Gen. Brehon B. Somervell, commanding the Services of Supply of the War Department, flew here yesterday from Washington for a one-day tour of three important war plants in the metropolitan area, to give management and labor, as he said, "the truth as I see it."

ALBANY, April 16 -- School administrators face a tremendous task in planning for the evacuation of 3,000,000 school children if cities of the State are bombed, Dr. Edwin R. Van Kleeck, Assistant Commissioner of Education, warned at an area conference here today on "Safeguarding the Elementary School Child."

VICHY, France, April 16 -- The foundations of the new French Cabinet are rising slowly. Pierre Laval, returning from consultations in Paris, saw Marshal Henri Philippe Petain shortly after noon today and later in the afternoon the Marshal, Admiral Francois Darlan and M: Laval held their scheduled conference.

Plans calling for full cooperation between organized baseball and the fighting forces will be formulated today at a meeting at the Hotel Roosevelt, called by Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis. The meeting followed a brief one yesterday at which no specific action was taken on baseball's further moves toward raising money for the war effort.

The Lehman Engel Singers made their New York debut last night in Town Hall in a concert presented by the American Music Foundation for the benefit of Russian War Relief. Lehman Engel, the composer, who founded the group of young American vocalists a year ago, conducted, sitting with them at a table after the fashion introduced hereabouts by the English Singers.

For the second consecutive day, offerings of short-term notes of local housing authorities accounted yesterday for the bulk of sales in the tax-exempt field. Two local housing authorities sold a total of $22,210,000 of notes, following the $54,629,000 sold on Wednesday by thirteen local authorities.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 16 -- That relations with the United States play no small part in the present political crisis in France is emphasized by the controversy that has developed over a statement of policy alleged to have been made yesterday by Pierre Laval.

Heavy rains have failed to halt the battle raging on the Russian front. The Germans call the downpour worse than any experienced last Fall. They say it has turned the land into a quagmire in which tractors are lost in the mud and even horses are of little use. But the Russians minimize what to them is a normal Spring.
O'Connor, O'Connor, O'Connor and O'Toole will be "fighting Irish" before long.
Ships of all kinds, from tankers and cargo vessels to patrol craft and carriers, are at the moment the most important single factor in the war.

ALBANY, April 16 -- Agreement on greatly increased unemployment insurance benefits, as well as a new system of benefits for the partly unemployed, headed the list of legislative accomplishments today, as both Houses drove toward adjournment by the end of next week.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- Panay is the fourth island of the Philippine Archipelago, with an area of 4,448 square miles. Its capital, Iloilo, had a population before the war of more than 88,000, making it the fifth city of the Philippines and one of the seven ports of entry for the Commonwealth.

Flowers for a woman's lapel -- gardenias, orchids and sweet peas -- are the stars of the stalls this week-end, according to the State Department of Agriculture. During a post-Easter slump, when no one seems to be corsage-conscious and the demand is slight, these three are especially plentiful and inexpensive.

Johnny and Jimmy, the Woods twins, who were subjects of an experiment in infantile behavior conducted by the Normal Child Development Clinic of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, will be 10 years old tomorrow.
MOSCOW, April 16 (From Russian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau broadcast this communique today:

MIDDLETOWN, Ohio, April 16 -- The first heat of steel made in the new Texas plant of the Sheffield Steel Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of the American Rolling Mill Company, will be tapped next week, and all departments of the new plant are expected to be in operation by late June, Charles R. Hook, president of American Rolling Mill, told stockholders at their annual meeting today.

PHILADELPHIA, April 16 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had taken action to enable national securities exchanges to experiment with a system of special offerings on a broader basis than has been possible in the past.

Displaying effectiveness with men on the bases, Ossie Day pitched Rutgers to a 7-to-2 triumph over New York University at Ohio Field yesterday. Day parted with ten safeties, but he held the Violets scoreless after yielding single tallies in the first two innings.

One central, immensely important point stands out in the report of the House subcommittee which has been investigating the disaster of the Normandie. There was no clearly established and clearly recognized responsibility for the safe-keeping of this great ship.

Today at the Museum of the City of New York begins an exhibition of objects illustrating fire defense in New York from 1724. Print and painting and document and newspapers make us contemporary with our famous fires and the apparatus and costume of the firemen.

As a result of the settlement of damage suits brought by Robert R. Young and his associates against the George and Frances Ball Foundation and George A. Ball of Muncie, Ind., 998,012 shares of the Alleghany Corporation's common stock will be turned over to the Young group for an undisclosed consideration, according to a proxy statement for the annual meeting of the Alleghany Corporation, to be held on May 9 in Baltimore, Md.

The central meal of the weekend, whether it be served on Saturday at 7 or on Sunday at noon, can be very successful if it is preceded by a bit of planning. For studying retail prices invariably results in prudent purchases -- and delicious dinners.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Secretary Morgenthau expressed confidence today that the people would voluntarily buy enough war bonds without compulsory saving. He presented to the Ways and Means Committee details of the plan used successfully by management and workers of the General Motors Corporation in encouraging buying.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 16 -- The government's emergency bill before Congress for special powers in economic matters for a period of six months to face the consequences of the war may be withdrawn, it was learned in political circles this evening, although the report was not confirmed officially.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- A third legislative program designed to curb war profits and meet issues raised in controversies over labor's part in the production effort was placed today before the House Naval Affairs Committee as it prepared to make decisions on all the proposals before it.

A program devoted to American works was presented by the Mozart String Sinfonietta conducted by Wesley Sontag at Carnegie Chamber Music Hall last night under the auspices of the National Association for American Composers and Conductors.

TOKYO, April 16 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York and San Francisco) -- Cebu, capital of Cebu Island in the Philippines, fell to 15,000 Japanese troops April 9 after a violent all-day battle in which the American-Filipino defenders fired from behind sugar-bag barricades, Domei, the official news agency, reported today from a base in Cebu.

As the first step in its program of surveying the retailer's stake in post-war economic developments, the post-war economy committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association is now engaged in making a study of housing, with a preliminary report due by the end of this month, it was learned here yesterday.

A complaint accusing the Curtiss-Wright Corporation of fostering a company union and discouraging membership in an A.F. of L. organization at its two big New Jersey propeller plants was issued yesterday by Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board.

A large apartment in the building at 876 Park Avenue has been leased to Mrs. Howard C. Taylor, in one of several residential rentals reported by Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc. Other new tenancies arranged by the Elliman concern were with J. Russell Doak in 243 East Forty-sixth Street; Dr. F. Levering Neely, in 301 East Twenty-first Street, and Colin R. Greenlees, in 1365 York Avenue.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (U.P.) -- Ralph A. Bard, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, said today that Navy reports on production "slowdowns," recently quoted by Senator Byrd, did not represent the conclusive views of the Navy Department. Mr. Bard issued a statement, saying:

In discussions of how to prevent inflation, not enough attention has been given to the fact that high wages are a chief cause of increases in price, which in turn are a cause of inflation. When labor demands higher wages to correspond to the increased cost of living, it ignores the fact that it thereby increases the cost of living still further, so that there is no end to the vicious circle.

A total of 4,413 non-farm mortgages amounting to $15,888,000 was recorded in cities and towns of New York State during February, the Federal Home Loan Bank Administration announced yesterday. Last year during the same month non-farm mortgage recordings aggregated $16,200,000 while in January of this year they totaled $20,008,000.

DAMASCUS, Syria, April 16 -- The placing of Pierre Laval at the head of the Vichy Government may prove to be a disguised blessing, according to an opinion widely held by the Free French here, who claim to be in touch with political trends in both occupied and unoccupied France from a variety of sources.

William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, indicated yesterday that his investigation of eight alleged instances of irregularities in the office of Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx had uncovered other irregularities in Mr. Lyons's office.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The War Production Board today put sharp limitations upon the use of natural resins which have been substituted in civilian use for the synthetic resins needed for war purposes. The action was taken because the natural resins, which are imported chiefly from the Far East and Africa, are now in short supply.

In an all-cash deal, Irving Posnasky has purchased from George M. Mayer the two-family house, on a plot 28.6 by 140 feet, at 2076 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn. The assessed valuation is $10,500. Morris Felder was attorney for the buyer. There are thirteen rooms and two baths in the house and on the plot is a two-car garage.

Samuel Reshevsky, defending champion; Isaac I. Kashdan and Arnold S. Denker were tied for first place in the United States Chess Federation tournament at the Marshall Chess Club at the end of last night's play.

Paper is the packaging material most available in supply and is followed by fiberboard, lumber and glass and cooperage, in that order, Charles L. Sheldon, deputy chief of the Containers Branch of the War Production Board, declared yesterday at a round-table discussion on "What's Washington Thinking on Packaging," which was a feature of the final day's session of the packaging convention sponsored by the American Management Association at the Hotel Astor.

Yesterday's weekly statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total bills discounted and reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date. Holdings of United States Government securities increased $10,545,000.

A goal of $2,000,000 for war relief was set by the executive committee of the Turf Committee of America at a meeting at Chairman Herbert Bayard Swope's office here yesterday, the money to be raised from race tracks, owners, breeders and others connected with the sport.

Operations of Alpha Portland Cement Company thus far in 1942 are at about 70 per cent of capacity and better than a year ago, F.G. McKelvy, president, said at the annual meeting in Jersey City yesterday. The months covered are normally a period when the use of cement is comparatively limited, he said.

Byron Price, Director of Censorship, warned the twentieth annual convention of the American Society of Newspaper Editors at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday that freedom of the press is now on trial and that whether the present system of voluntary censorship shall continue or shall be replaced by compulsory censorship depends entirely on the manner in which newspaper editors and publishers live up to their responsibilities.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Canada's women are the guardians of their country's price control law, reporting to authorities through their club organizations any infractions of retail price ceilings, according to Byrne Hope Sanders, Director of the Consumer Reporting Branch of the Wartime Prices and Trade Board of Canada.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- President Roosevelt issued an executive order integrating the Office of Civilian Defense into the war effort more directly. He conferred with Harold Smith, Budget Director; five officials of the C.I.O.'s United Automobile Workers Union; met with his A.F. of L.-C.I.O.

Revivals of the Soviet film version of Dostoyevsky's "Petersburg Nights," and the French film, "The Living Corpse," will begin a week's engagement today at the Irving Place Theatre. . . . The French picture, "Nine Bachelors," together with a revival of "The Scoundrel," is being shown today and tomorrow at the Thalia Theatre.

IT'S impolite to look a gift horse in the mouth. But it's all right to stand off and estimate its height at the withers, isn't it? Or to glance at its fetlocks and lead it around a bit to see how it moves? If so, off with the blanket and give everybody concerned a look.

Soldiers, sailors and marines are hungry for books. This statement may jar people who were brought up on Richard Harding Davis or whose conception of marines was formed on "What Price Glory?" None the less, it is accurate. Service men have minds, literary tastes and a little spare time.
New Jersey's policy of heavily stocking the trout streams closest to population centers seems to assure an active year for the anglers in the Garden State.

Albert F. Coyle, 49 years old, a Stanford graduate, holder of a Yale divinity degree and once a relief worker in Europe under Herbert Hoover, was held in $10,000 bail yesterday by Judge Jonah J. Goldstein in General Sessions on an eleven-count grand larceny indictment.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- In view of the Congressional hearings to define the control of patents in m wartime, the fact that the government has present power over United States patents had been lost sight of, experts said today. Legislation granting this power has been on the statute books for many years, but is considered by no means adequate to meet the situation.

CINCINNATI, April 16 (AP) -- The Reds finally bagged their first victory today, but had to go twelve innings to get it on a run forced in by a two-pitcher walk with the bases full that halted the Pirates, 8 -- 7.
Out of the dusky interior of an old apothecary shop, with its spicy smells and rows of gilt-labelled bottles, came inspiration for a new collection of petal-fresh sachets, scents and soaps.

R.G.A. van der Woude, president of the Shell Union Oil Corporation, told stockholders at the annual meeting held here yesterday that the results of the company's operations in the first three months of this year were satisfactory.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce, published today a telegram which he sent this morning to Clarence Stanley, president of the Union Trust Company of Pittsburgh offering on behalf of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to take all or any part of the unsubscribed portion of a $50,000,000 loan which the company is negotiating on behalf of Standard Steel Spring Company of Coraopolis, Pa.

The vital role of youth in the war was the theme of the annual Metropolitan Boys Club Workers Association luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday at which the annual Exposition medal was awarded posthumously to Charles Hayden, noted philanthropist who died in 1937.

"A Kiss For Cinderella," the Sir James M. Barrie fantasy which marked Luise Rainer's debut on the New York stage, will terminate its Broadway career after tomorrow night's performance, it was announced yesterday by Cheryl Crawford and Richard Krakeur, the producers.

Predictions that police applications for retirement on pension may go to the unprecedented number of 300 before this month's deadline tonight were made freely yesterday at Police Headquarters. The number of retirement applications at the end of the day stood at 275, which is unprecedented.

CHICAGO, April 18 -- Retail stores in the Chicago area were selling eggs and butter at midwinter prices today as wholesale markets recorded new advances. Wholesale egg prices advanced 1/4 to 1 cent a dozen to the highest levels since February.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The House approved promptly and unanimously today the construction of 200,000 more tons of submarines, more than 100 craft, as fast as ways can be cleared to lay new keels.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 16 (U.P.) -- Guard units of the Red Army have repulsed thirty powerful German counter-attacks on the central front and are advancing over melting snowfields strewn with the dead toward a river guarding a vital enemy stronghold, Russian military sources reported tonight.

"The Magic Swan" and "Rouge et Noir" had their first presentations in the Spring season of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, along with a repetition of "Gaite Parisienne."

Newell J. Nessen, president of the Quaker City Federal Savings and Loan Association of Philadelphia, presented yesterday a "possible solution" of the investment problem facing life insurance companies before the Executive Association of Philadelphia in the Wellington Hotel there.

The Owens-Illinois Glass Company and its wholly-owned subsidiaries earned $9,513,648 in the twelve months ended on March 31, after deducting all charges, including $12,824,538 provision for Federal income and excess profits taxes.

The new paid-for life insurance last month was 1 per cent higher than in March a year ago, while the total for the first quarter this year was 25 per cent correspondingly greater than in 1941, according to the Association of Life Insurance Presidents in a report to the United States Department of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- A bill to authorize forming a women's auxiliary reserve in the Navy was adopted unanimously today by the House of Representatives after it was brought to the floor this morning with only about twenty members present.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- After the Senate Labor Committee had instructed a subcommittee today to revise the Ball bill, Senator Hill, whose subcommittee will handle the revised measure, stated that the labor committee had previously rejected a proposal to substitute the Ball measure for a drastic bill introduced by Representative Howard Smith of Virginia, which passed the House several months ago.

Today the two top teams of the major leagues in 1941 will strut before thousands of fans in their home inaugurals -- the world champion Yankees against the Red Sox at the Yankee Stadium and the National League champion Dodgers against the Phils at Ebbets Field.

The grimmest sequel to the defeat and occupation of France has been long in developing, but as the change in the Vichy regime is measured in terms of its possible effects on the world struggle, it is increasingly clear that it marks one of the great turning points of the war.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The United States is expected to announce withdrawal of Ambassador William D. Leahy from Vichy tomorrow when the formation of a government dominated by Pierre Laval, puppet of Germany, is scheduled to be formally disclosed.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- Colonel Claire L. Chennault, commander of the American Volunteer Group of fliers fighting the Japanese advance in Burma, was called to active duty in the United States Army today and nominated to be a brigadier general.

Dean Herbert E. Hawkes of Columbia College was honored last night for twenty-five years' service in that post, at a dinner in Columbia University's John Jay Hall attended by 500 students, alumni and members of the faculty.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 16 (AP) -- Ogden D. Miller, Yale athletic director, discussing the university's wartime "athletics for all" program, said today that Ed Leader, veteran crew coach, had received the title "supervisory coach of crew" and would oversee the entire rowing program throughout the year.

A further break-up of the huge Associated Gas and Electric System was disclosed yesterday with the announcement by the trustees in reorganization that initial agreements had been reached for the sale of the Kentucky-Tennessee Light and Power Company, one of the largest southern properties in [the Associated system, for a base price of $7,000,000.

Despite the heavy draft made by the Army and Navy upon physicians in private practice, despite the findings of the National Committee for Resettlement of Physicians, a bill has been introduced in both houses of Congress, and passed without debate by the Senate, to perpetuate in the District of Columbia a medical situation that cries for reform.

LONDON, April 17 (AP) -- The Red Army was driving ahead against fierce German resistance tonight and capturing "one great fortress after another" in the area of Demidov, forty miles northwest of Smolensk, the Moscow radio reported.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The American Army is "getting pretty near to the stage of being ready for an offensive," and will take that offensive "at the earliest practicable moment," Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson said at a press conference today.

James T. Buckley, president of the Philco Corporation, said at the annual meeting in Philadelphia yesterday that while no definite statements can be made because of tax uncertainties, it is reasonable to assume that first-quarter earnings will cover the dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock paid on March 12.

CHICAGO, April 17 -- Participants in the regional credit clinic of the American Bankers Association here were warned today by C.B. Upham, Deputy Controller of the Currency, to tighten their control over installment paper and other forms of consumer credit as a curb on inflation and as an escape from possible losses on paper made uncertain by war conditions.

Bernard De Voto, the Mark Twain specialist, calls his next book "Mark Twain at Work." It is scheduled for publication by Harvard University Press some time this month. The three essays gathered in the volume will deal with Twain's habits of writing, the material he used, his methods of working and how he overcame the difficulties he encountered.

VICHY, France, April 17 -- Under a decree published today, the Council of the State Advisory Body on Legislation is empowered to issue legal status to religious congregations outlawed under the laws of 1901. By the same procedure religious orders may be dissolved.

For shouting "Heil Hitler!" on the upper Bowery Monday night and giving the Nazi salute, Ernest Kuske, 52 years old, who came to this country from Germany thirty years ago, was sentenced yesterday in the Probation Court in the Criminal Courts Building to a thirty-day workhouse term.

LONDON, April 17 (U.P.) -- The United States could be relied upon to make any further Japanese conquests increasingly difficult, Richard G. Casey, who resigned as Australian Minister to Washington last month to enter the British War Cabinet as Minister for the Middle East, said today.

The President has called Senator Bone's attention to the relation of patents to war production and suggested the formulation of "a wise patent policy to guide us toward that victory which we all so devoutly wish." There can be little doubt that the admonition is prompted by the patent contracts in which American and German corporations have been involved.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- While beleaguered Corregidor continued today to nick the edges of sustained Japanese aerial attacks, the War Department announced that approximately 35,000 United States and Filipino "combatant troops" on Bataan Peninsula were presumably in the hands of the enemy.

Mrs. Susan Springer, 31 years old, the woman "Raffles" who was captured on Feb. 1 after she had robbed three upper East Side homes of about $3,500 in jewelry, furs and other garments, was freed yesterday by Judge John J. Sullivan in General Sessions on a suspended sentence to make restitution to her victims.

Two ten-family apartment houses, known as 30-13 and 30-17 Forty-third Street, Long Island City, Queens, have been sold by the Swethem Realty Corporation to Carl Hertel, to whom the Lawyers Title Corporation issued the title policy. The properties are assessed for a total of $32,000.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 17 -- Violent Russian attacks on the Svir River and near the Stalin Canal were reported from Helsinki today. The Red Army appears to be trying to establish bridgeheads and occupy favorable points on the northern bank of the Svir before the thaw transforms it into a formidable obstacle.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, April 17 -- After watching America's planes going and coming on secret fields during our initial offensive blow at the Japanese deep in the Philippines I was permitted to make the long hop to Australia in the plane that carried Brig. Gen. Ralph Royce, the commander of the flight.

In a manner thoroughly in keeping with the atmosphere of the occasion the Yankees opened their twentieth season at the Stadium yesterday before a gathering of 30,308, of whom 1,243 were service men, guests of President Ed Barrow.

The far-flung foreign staff of The Associated Press was praised yesterday by Kent Cooper, general manager, who said in his annual report that it "continued to acquit itself brilliantly, often in the face of great personal danger, and always in the midst of serious obstacles."

LONDON, April 17 -- Destruction of the oil fields at Yenangyaung -- most important of Burmese producing centers with an output of 1,000,000 gallons daily -- was reported here today as the British fell back to north of Magwe, twenty miles south of Yenangyaung.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 17 (AP) -- Alsab and Requested, two for the Kentucky Derby's big "name" horses, and twelve other 3-year-olds were entered today in tomorrow's Chesapeake Stakes, traditional trial for the blue grass classic.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- An American Olympics, pitting athletes of each of the forty-eight States against one another, was proposed for 1943 today by the Federal Security Administrator, Paul V. McNutt.

With the opening of the trout season in Connecticut today freshwater fishing in the metropolitan area reaches an early season peak. The lifting of the barrier in the Nutmeg State gives New Yorkers their widest fishing radius of the year, for not only can they try their own State waters but they now have the additional option of traveling to New Jersey or Connecticut.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

There are today probably more natives of the United States in Australia than there are natives of Australia in the United States. Out of approximately eleven and a half million white people born abroad who were recorded by the Federal census two years ago the natives of Down Under were a little group of 11,000 men and women.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Plans for organization of a new Army unit, the Tank Destroyer Command, designed to carry the offense against armored forces of the enemy, were made public today.

As Victory Book Day was observed yesterday throughout the country, with donors being urged to give up books for the use of the nation's armed services, the Victory Book Campaign entered its last stages.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- A return to wooden cargo ships, and even sailing vessels, to cope with submarine activity, conserve steel for the armed forces and keep open the Allied nations' supply lines was urged today by Representative Martin F. Smith, Washington Democrat.

Former Police Inspector John Reddan, named as one of seventeen policemen who had retired while under investigation by Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen's two extraordinary grand juries in connection with a $100,000,000 gambling syndicate that allegedly paid $1,000,000 a year for police protection, demanded yesterday that he be called before one of Mr. Amen's grand juries and "either indicted or vindicated."
ASBURY PARK, N.J., April 17 (AP) -- New Jersey fuel oil dealers were told today that American homes may not be as cozy next Winter as they were last season.

The Juvenile Aid Bureau, for twelve years the Police Department's principal crime-deterrent agency among the youth of the city, will pass out of existence, at least for the duration of the war, on July 1, it was learned yesterday.

The National Academy of Design elected twenty-five associate members at a meeting yesterday afternoon at its galleries, 1083 Fifth Avenue. Twelve architects were elected, the largest number of associates added to this class of membership since the academy was founded 116 years ago.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The Federal Public Housing Authority today awarded to George Siegler, Jersey City, N.J., a $1,357,350 contract for construction of Edward Markham Houses on Staten Island, N.Y.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 17 (AP) -- Walter Ward, 46, of Cleveland, said back into second place in the American Bowling Congress ten-year ratings today, and Ned Day of West Allis, Wis., moved out front again.

Department stores sales here this week returned to more normal comparisons with a year ago as the shift in the respective dates of Easter were eliminated and gains of 8 to 10 per cent over 1941 were estimated by store executives here. However, there was considerable variation between stores inasmuch as some establishments staged sales in the corresponding week of 1941 that were canceled this year.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- A program to prevent inflation and maintain workers' efficiency at maximum levels for war production has been devised by Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, who made it public today.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The Ways and Means Committee completed hearings today on the greatest tax proposal in history, with indications that it is agreed on the Treasury's aim of $7,610,000,000 in new war revenues, although seemingly disagreeing on some of the methods.

TRENTON, April 17 (AP) -- The Hudson County Tax Board told Governor Charles Edison today that if charges of improper conduct made against it by the City Affairs Committee of Jersey City "can be supported by facts," they should be submitted to the State Supreme Court.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 17 (AP) -- Prison terms and fines were imposed today on two officials of a Boonville automobile sales firm in the government's first prosecution under the Federal tire rationing regulations, but one sentence later was suspended.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., April 17 -- The 400 employes of the Edison Cement Corporation of New Village in Warren County were notified today that the firm was going out of business because its operations had been unprofitable for years.

DETROIT, April 17 (AP) -- Ray (Sugar) Robinson of New York, widely regarded as king of boxing's welterweight division, achieved his thirtieth professional victory tonight by scoring a technical knockout over Harvey Dubs of Windsor, Ont., in the sixth round of a scheduled ten-round bout.

VICHY, France, April 17 -- After resignation of the Darlan Cabinet here today, the French Government was informed officially that Admiral William D. Leahy, the United States Ambassador, had been called to Washington to report on the situation here and the future prospects for France.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., April 17 (AP) -- A "liturgical panic" in Protestantism to recover Catholic forms of worship was reported by a theological authority today to the Troy Conference of the Methodist Church.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 17 -- Army came from behind to defeat Harvard today, 12 to 9. The Crimson had a 6 -- 1 lead when Army came to bat in its half of the fourth and tallied four times. During the next two frames the cadets continued their attack and made seven more runs.

Mayor La Guardia intervened yesterday in the threatened strike of some 30,000 elevator operators and other building service employes. In an effort to induce employes and employers to resume negotiations for a new contract to take the place of the agreement expiring on Monday, the Mayor has called a conference in his offices at City Hall at 10:30 A.M. Monday.

LONDON, April 17 -- The election of the Most Rev. William Temple as Archibshop of Canterbury took place in the Nelson Chamber of St. Paul's Cathedral today before the Royal Commissioners -- the Bishops of London, Winchester, Salisbury, Worcester and Rochester.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 17 -- The American people are ready in wartime to give up many of the things which they supported most enthusiastically in peacetime. One of the things which they feel they can do without at present is government spending for a number of non-war purposes.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 17 -- Most of the wool yarn from national manufacturers being sold in stores here is 3 per cent to 25 per cent below the advertised weight stamped on the skeins, Dudley W. Goldsmith, New Rochelle sealer of weights and measures, charged today after a two-week investigation.
In your issue of April 10, James U. Norris denies that any racket exists in New York hospitals and that it is difficult to believe any hospital has ever knowingly charged for services not rendered.

Commending the action of Attorney General Francis Biddle and Postmaster General Walker in banning the newspaper Social Justice from the mails, members of the American Labor party in the City Council introduced a local law yesterday prohibiting the sale and distribution of any publication that incites religious hatred or interferes with the country's war aims.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., April 17 -- The Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation announced today that it established 157 new production records last year and was geared to even greater efforts to help win the war.

Plans were filed yesterday by architects for twenty-seven dwellings in various communities in Queens. Architects also filed for a home, a restaurant building and for alterations to a hospital in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Opportunities for highly technical work by women are opening up rapidly in the Army, Navy and other agencies, but women are not being trained to use them, according to a first survey made by a special committee of the National Roster of Scientific and Specialized Personnel.

Naval shipbuilding facilities in the New York area were augmented yesterday with the completion, in the record time of forty-three days, of a 700-foot service pier in the shipbuilding yards of the Bethlehem Steel Company at Mariners Harbor, Staten Island.

To meet wartime emergency needs Boy Scout Service Troops are now being organized as units of the American Red Cross Disaster Relief Service, it was announced yesterday by Kenneth Collins, chairman of the executive board of the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York.

ALBANY, April 17 -- Former Lieut. Gov. M. William Bray of Utica was appointed by the Governor today to a vacancy on the Public Service Commission, and the nomination was immediately confirmed by the Senate with Senator after Senator rising to pay tribute to the former presiding officer.

Behind all of our preparation to win this war there is confusion of thought. We are staggering under the impact of the unexpected, and are frustrated over the sudden plunge we have taken in a universal war.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- David M. Conn of 1265 Broadway, New York, has stipulated with the Federal Trade Commission that he will cease using in the advertising of his "Dr. McKenzie's Sanitary Health Sox" the word "doctor" to imply that a physician is connected with their manufacture or the word "health" to imply special health features.

TRENTON, April 17 -- Seeking to dispel an impression created by his personal butler that "open house" was maintained much of the time at the "little White House" at Sea Girt, Governor Charles Edison declared today that the place had been in reality a workshop.

WASHINGTON, Saturday, April 18 -- The War Department and the Navy Department said early today that they had no confirmation of reports that United Nations airplanes had bombed Tokyo. The reports, however, created no surprise in official circles, and there was no denial of the possibility that American planes might have participated in an attack upon the Japanese capital.

With the return to power of Pierre Laval and indications that the pendulum-like policy of Vichy is once again swinging toward even closer collaboration with Germany, the strength and disposition of the French Fleet again becomes of importance.

The possible transfer of this year's edition of the Poughkeepsie regatta from the Hudson to another site was discussed as several stewards of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association met last night at the Hotel Biltmore.

Many apartment rentals were reported along the West Side yesterday. The new tenancies covered quarters in buildings from Greenwich Village to the Dyckman area in Manhattan and to Riverdale in the Bronx. On the East Side most of the leasing was in the midtown section.

The Class I railroads had 930 locomotives on order or under construction on April 1, the Association of American Railroads announced yesterday. This total comprised 426 steam and 504 electric and Diesel types. On March 1 they had 651 new locomotives on order, which included 300 steam and 351 electric and Diesel.

Some of the one-design classes that will be racing on Long Island Sound this season will have to get along without spinnakers because so many of the husky young spinnaker men have turned their nautical talents to the nation's maritime forces.

It becomes clearer each day that we are only at the beginning of the French crisis. The war is obviously making its own pattern, foreseen by none of the combatants in the beginning, foreseen least of all by Adolf Hitler, as "Mein Kampf," reread in the light of today, rather startlingly reveals.
MELBOURNE, Australia, April 17 -- In the last desperate showdown, the Battle of Bataan ended because the quinine pills ran out saw the last scenes of the drama and this is the story.
The New York Stock Exchange firm of S.B. Blumenthal Co. is to be formed on May 1 by Simon B. Blumenthal and Maurice B. Blumenthal Jr. The latter will retire from Faroll Brothers on April 30.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 17 -- The Nazi-accented theory that interbreeding of different races results in inferior offspring was described as "a myth" today by Dr. M.P. Ashley-Montague, a Philadelphia anthropologist, who said that half-castes, taken as a whole, were for the most part superior biologically to their parents.

A great deal has been said and written about the "Golden Era" of sports in the late Twenties and early Thirties. While I admit that such praise is justified by the great figures of those days -- Tilden, Ruth, Jones, Didrickson, Wills, Grange et. al. -- I think we should not sell short our athletic crop of the past decade.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 17 -- Katharine Hepburn will play the lead opposite Spencer Tracy In Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's "Keeper of the Flames," which will go before the cameras next month, the studio announced today. Miss Hepburn's Broadway engagement in "Without Love," by Philip Barry, has been postponed until next season, and she will come to the Coast May 1 for the film.

Johnny Allen, veteran of many a baseball battle in the National and American Leagues, emerged as the latest hero of Flatbush yesterday when he pitched and batted the Dodgers to a 7-1 triumph over the Phils in the Ebbets Field opener.
MOSCOW, April 17 (From Russian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

Members of the tandem committee for the Fifth Annual Bicycle Breakfast, which will take place under the auspices of the New York Wellesley Club, April 26, at the Stork Club, were guests at a reception given yesterday at the Wellesley Club headquarters at the Barclay by Mr. and Mrs. Luellen Stearns.

"The resistance of the Bishops of Norway to Quisling is to me the best news which has come out of Europe since the war began," Bishop Francis J. McConnell of the New York Methodist Area declared yesterday.

ALBANY, April 17 -- Governor Lehman today transmitted to the Senate for confirmation the name of Ashley T. Cole Sr. of New York City as member of the State Racing Commission. Cole was nominated by the Governor to succeed John Sloan, whose term is about to expire.

So far as any of the nations now at war with Japan are concerned, the closest probable base for a raid on Tokyo would be in some of the areas of Southeastern Free China. The closest distance of any base in this region would be from 1,200 to 1,300 airline miles from Tokyo -- which Flying Fortresses could cover with not-too-large bomb loads and return.

NEVER mind the baseball races for a moment. The teams are just getting warmed up. The pennants aren't being decided today. With the kind indulgence of the subscribers, this observer will revert to an old argument in this corner and present the following communication:

Regulations to control the occasional employment of school children as replacements for farm labor drawn into the armed services and war industry were promulgated yesterday by the State Board of Regents. The board met at the State Office Building, 80 Centre Street.

New bond financing this week again was restricted to the State and municipal field, where only four loans were placed on the market for a total of $4,040,000. This compares with $22,068,300 in new bonds marketed last week and with a total of $16,842,614 offered in this week last year.

LONDON, April 17 -- This week on the Stock Exchange has been one of the quietest on record. Gilt-edge issues opened quietly today but came into demand this afternoon. Some foreign rails were steady, apart from the Argentines, which fell a further 10s on decreases in traffic.

Former State Senator A. Spencer Feld, who served in the Senate from 1927 to 1940, was disbarred yesterday by the Appellate Division in a series of rulings which disbarred also four other attorneys and censured two more. Another of those disbarred was William Lurie, a witness in the bribery trial that resulted in the acquittal of former Kings County Judge George W. Martin.

Teams representing the Cavendish Club and the New York Bridge Whist Club won their way to the final round of the national contract bridge team-of-four tournament for the Harold Vanderbilt Cup at the Hotel Pierre here last night.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Congressional attention to proposals for suspension of the forty-hour week, freezing of open and closed shop conditions and related war labor issues were turned sharply today to the unionization of the farmer, a fast-spreading movement that brought leaders of agricultural organizations before a House Judiciary subcommittee in mass protest.

CHUNGKING, China, April 17 -- While the Japanese are sending more troops from Rangoon and Thailand to the Burma front in a race to attain high, dry ground before rains start, sizable Chinese reinforcements are likewise streaming down the Burma Road against the foe.

NEW ORLEANS, April 17 (AP) -- A lifeboat pushing off from a torpedoed South American ship in the Atlantic Ocean on March 7 was blown to pieces by one of two torpedo explosions and its ten occupants were killed, six survivors of the sunken ship declared on their arrival here from the West Indies.
ST. LOUIS, April 17 (AP) -- The "dark horse" Browns stretched their winning streak to four straight today as they downed the Tigers, 7-6, to stay in a first-place tie with the Yankees.

The best handicap field of the metropolitan season is to compete today at Jamaica, where Market Wise, the Cinderella horse, will face eleven others, including Pictor, Olympus, Sir Marlboro and Dit. The test is the mile and a sixteenth of the $10,000 added Excelsior Handicap, with Market Wise back on his home heath.

BOSTON, April 17 (U.P.) -- Leroy Jackson of Cleveland carried off the ll2-pound crown in the national amateur boxing championships tonight when he defeated Ralph McNeil, Newark, N.J., in the final round before 7,500 fans at the Boston Garden.

Suggestions that the Republican party, through the National Committee or its Representatives in Congress, formulate a definite foreign policy were made last night by Supreme Court Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter and City Councilmal Stanley M. Isaacs in speeches at the annual meeting of the Fifteenth Assembly District Republican Club, 122 East Eighty-third Street.

The recall of Ambassador Leahy from Vichy is an action not merely justified but required by the course of events in France. As long as the aged and tiring Petain was able to play for time, in his devious and patient diplomatic game with Hitler, a good case could be made for keeping an American Ambassador in France.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 17 -- The French situation is being watched most attentively here, where it is believed that the French people's attitude has a direct bearing on the future strategy of the war.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The production of several strategic war materials has been lessened by the existence of international patent pools and similar agreements, Thurman Arnold, assistant attorney general in charge of antitrust law prosecutions, told the Senate Patents Committee today.

District Attorney Samuel J. Foley of the Bronx announced yesterday that he expects to have presented to the Bronx County grand jury by the end of next week all the testimony in the case of the paving of a courtyard on the Lake Mahopac estate of Edward J. Flynn, chairman of the Democratic National Committee.

Maybe the third hold-up suspect didn't want to use up too much gasoline, but anyway he failed to keep the motor running in the get-away car at Richardson and Humboldt Streets, Greenpoint, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon. He was altogether too slow in starting for John Santoro, 23 years old, of 406 Union Street, and Joseph Machin, 34, of 32-15 Thirtieth Street, Astoria, so police averred.
MELBOURNE, Australia, April 17 (AP) -- An Australian communique said today:

PITTSBURGH, April 17 (AP) -- The revamped Pirates showed 18,824 supporters snappy fielding, hitting and pitching as they defeated the Cardinals today, 3 to 2, at the opening of the Forbes Field season.

MEXICO CITY, April 17 -- An interview given by Ezequiel Padilla, Mexican Foreign Minister, before he left New York was published on the first page of the newspaper Excelsior here today under an eight-column headline reading: "United States Exacted Nothing From Mexico in Return for Her Cooperation.
NEW DELHI, India, April 17 (AP) -- British Headquarters issued this communique today:
Brooklyn College broke into the winning column yesterday with a well-earned victory over the Manhattan College nine on the Brooklyn field, 5 to 2.

American fashion leaders can be more effective than the government in making it "fashionable" to save, Mrs. Henry Morgenthau Jr. declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Fashion Group in the Murray Hill Hotel. Admitting the hardships facing the luxury trade, the wife of the Secretary of the Treasury urged 350 members of the group's sales promotion division to "turn their talents loose" on the idea that "it is smart to be thrifty."

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Admiral William D. Leahy, the United States Ambassador to France, was directed by President Roosevelt today to return to this country in view of the return to power of Pierre Laval.

With the last-minute decisions of the producers of "Nathan the Wise" and "Autumn Hill" to close the runs of their attractions after tonight's performance, the number of week-end departures from Broadway rose to three. Earlier the management of "A Kiss for Cinderella" had announced the termination of its engagement this evening.

LONDON, April 17 -- The British were still cautious over the situation in Vichy tonight and officials were skeptical of the truth of reports being ballooned in the London press to the effect that Pierre Laval was about to take Vichy into war with the United States and Britain.

In an advertisement published a few days ago General Motors Corporation gave the public an interim report on its war work. The dollar value of first-quarter deliveries this year was nearly five times that of a year ago. This is good news at a time when every clock-tick counts.

The Chelsea area yesterday jumped into the limelight, boasting the first neighborhood defense organization officially connected with the Manhattan Civilian Defense Volunteer Office as the plan for decentralization of the Office of Civilian Defense got under way.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 17 -- The German Government protested to Brazil today through D.N.B., the official news agency, against Brazil's treatment of Axis nationals and threatened that country with economic strangulation after a final Axis victory unless Brazilian policy was changed.

CLEVELAND, April 17 (AP) -- Bob Pastor of New York got up from the floor twice in the first round tonight and, wearing his man down with jolting blows, carved out a firm ten-round decision over Jimmy Bivins. The victor scaled 183, the Clevelander 176 1/4.

Today's events: Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Young People's concert, Carnegie Hall, 11 A.M.; Frank Kneisel, violin, assisted by Ray Lev, piano, Institute of Musical Art of the Juilliard School of Music, 3 P.M.; Victory concert, New York Public Library, 5; "In Time of Battle," concert presented by the School of Democracy, Town Hall, 8:30; Carol d'Arcy, mezzo-soprano, Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, 8:30.

While about 10,000 persons watched breathlessly, four persons dazed by smoke from a fire in a six-story building at 200 West Fiftieth Street were helped to safety down extension ladders yesterday by firemen and auxiliary fire corps volunteers.

OTTAWA, April 17 -- Canada can readily provide in the air-training schools operating under the Commonwealth plan accommodation for large numbers of additional students from others of the United Nations, Air Vice Marshal L.S. Breadner, chief of the air staff, said today in commenting on the Roosevelt-King announcement.

LONDON, April 17 (AP) -- A usually reliable source said today that unconfirmed reports asserted that thirty highly placed Italians had Been disciplined or rebuked by Premier Mussolini recently for attempting a movement for a separate Italian peace with Britain.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 17 (U.P.) -- It was announced here today by Raden Loekman Djajadiningrat, head of the Netherlands Indies Government Commission for Australia and New Zealand, that large quantities of American bombers, fighters, tanks, machine guns and other war materials that had been ordered for the defense of Java were now reaching Australia.

The fast approaching crisis in the relations between Washington and Vichy stifled yesterday even the modest buying of previous sessions in the securities markets and under a mild wave of liquidation stock prices were set back to the lowest levels since 1933.

In the category of vital-facts-to-know are the contents of a bulletin recently issued by the United States Department of Labor. This little leaflet, with its interesting set of statistics, informs the nation's householders that grocery bills increased again from mid-February to mid-March.

CHICAGO, April 17 -- Liquidation was on in wheat today and with pressure from professional traders prices of futures dropped around 1 1/2 cents a bushel on the Board of Trade to a new low since late last November. The May sold at $1.18 7/8 at one time, or within 3 7/8 cents of the government loan basis on the 1941 crop.

OLD BEDFORD VILLAGE, N.Y., April 17 -- Continuing a brilliant record established as a puppy, the white and liver pointer dog List Wind Boy today was awarded the first trophy in the junior all-age stake, leading event of the first day of the fifteenth annual Spring trials of the Southern New York Field Trial Club.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- C. Hartley Grattan, expert on Australian affairs, who resigned recently from the Board of Economic Warfare after Representative Voorhis of California, a Dies Committee member, had identified him to the House as the author of the foreword to the German White Paper on Poland, circulated in this country in 1940, has received a clean bill, but with reservations, from the House member.

The American National Red Cross in Washington has announced that braille service for the blind will be abolished as a Red Cross activity not later than Dec. 31. This is not an order for the duration of the war but for all time. Several reasons have been given for this decision, but not one of them is a really good or sufficient reason.

The United Nations air training conference, announced yesterday by President Roosevelt and Prime Minister King to meet next month at Ottawa, another move toward a necessary pooling of resources. Canada has more training fields and equipment than her own candidate fliers can use.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 17 -- The Tokyo radio announced tonight that "enemy bombers" had attacked Tokyo, the Columbia Broadcasting System's listening station reported. The Tokyo broadcast said:
LONDON, April 17 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

The New York State Bar Association declares that it is not often that such a "masterly report" is prepared by any Commissioner as has now been submitted to the Governor by Robert M. Benjamin. Mr. Benjamin was appointed by the Governor in 1939 to study the exercise of quasi-judicial functions by the boards and commissions of New York State.

NEWARK, April 17 (AP) -- Behind the steady pitching of Tommy Byrne, the Newark Bears today conquered the Bisons, 5 to 1. Gene Corbett led the attack with two doubles and a single in four trips and scored twice.

Charlie Chaplin's "The Gold Rush" will open an extended engagement this morning at the Globe Theatre. The characters of the re-edited sound version of the 1925 silent comedy do not speak, but Mr. Chaplin has provided a musical score and has written and narrates the film's commentary.

MOBILE, Ala., April 17 -- Easing of Walsh-Healey Act restrictions in cotton textile mills working on government contracts, to permit employment of workers between 16 and 18 years of age, was strongly urged by Dr. C.T. Murchison, president Cotton-Textile Institute, New York, in an address before the Alabama Cotton Manufacturers Association here today.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- The government could save money and time by buying war materials held by the large number of companies which go out of business each week, Senator William H. Smathers of New Jersey suggests.

Some 400 boys and girls of the Riverdale Country Schools of Riverdale-on-Hudson, this city, were heard in a choral concert given last night in Town Hall to aid the American Red Cross War Fund. Arthur Christmann and Eleanor Stanley conducted.

ALBANY, April 17 -- William G. Griffin of Buffalo was appointed today a junior bank examiner in the State Banking Department, it was announced in the department's weekly bulletin. His salary is to be $10 a day. The appointment will become effective on May 1.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt took up today the suggestion of Jacob Ark, New York commander of the American Legion, that she contribute to the national welfare by "keeping quiet for the duration on subjects of which she knows little if anything."

BOSTON, April 17 -- The Giants strove desperately to overcome a number of serious obstacles today, not the least of these being the wrath of an outraged umpire, but despite homers by Manager Mel Ott and Johnny Mize, found the combined opposition too much for them.
Patrolman Oscar C. Hettler, the "cop with the golden smile," is retiring from the Police Department. He filed notice of that intention yesterday at Police Headquarters.
CHICAGO, April 17 (AP) -- Cincinnati's Johnny Vander Meer pitched five-hit ball today, but the Cubs took advantage of his wildness and two Red errors to win their home opener, 3 to 2.

NEWARK, N.J., April 17 -- Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation swarmed into a tavern in Long Branch, N.J., last night and arrested Ralph Greco, 35 years old, of Hoboken, who was described by Federal authorities as the "No. 1 bank robber fugitive" of the nation.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on April 11 were 258,442,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines, Department of the Interior. This represented a decrease of 3,326,000 barrels in the week, comprising decreases of 3,286,000 and 40,000 barrels in domestic and foreign stocks, respectively.

President Roosevelt was asked yesterday by a group of automobile dealers associations to relieve the financial distress of new car dealers by having the government buy and take over at the retail prices established by the Office of Price Administration, plus carrying charges to date, all new automobiles now in dealers hands.

Any large piece of new financing in which most of the important investment firms participate is always spiritually, as well as financially, uplifting to the investment banking community, and, with the appearance of sizable new issues, so few and far between these days, the forthcoming offering of $100,000,000 of debentures of the American Tobacco Company looms "sweeter than ever before."

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week by forty municipalities and local public housing agencies aggregates $32,345,624, compared with $86,010,453 this week, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $27,591,004.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 17 -- Preliminary foreclosure proceedings are under way against Chelsea Village, model apartment house development completed here eighteen months ago for some 300 families. The South Jersey Title and Finance Company of Atlantic City is making a title search on behalf of the Irving Trust Company of New York, holders of an $875,000 first mortgage, as a forerunner to actual filing of the foreclosure suit in New Jersey Chancery Court.

The United States is "over the hump" on war production, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, declared at the annual dinner last night of the American Society of Newspaper Editors in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- An efficiency checkup on executives of the War Production Board is in progress under the direction of Paul A. Mertz, former director of company training for the Sears, Roebuck Co. and for sixteen months an official of the WPB.

LONDON, April 17 -- The first issue of the revived Stars and Stripes, the United States Army newspaper, was published here today. In eight-page tabloid form, with a page and a half devoted to sports, it carries on from where the paper of the A.E.F. in France in World War I left off at Paris twenty-three years ago.

LONDON, April 17 (AP) -- The Ministry of Information explained today, in answer to questions in Parliament, why it imposed censorship upon any news story that tended to foment ill will between allies or between allies and neutral nations by releasing samples of recent dispatches to South Africa, Australia and New Zealand.

"The Good Shepherd" will be the theme of many of the sermons tomorrow. According to the ritualistic calendar, the gospel for the second Sunday after Easter is St. John x, verses 11-16, in which it is recorded that Jesus said: "I am the good shepherd; the good shepherd giveth his life for his sheep."

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, April 17 -- Tomorrow night the American colony in Brazil will celebrate the fifty-ninth birthday of Brazil's President, Getulio Vargas, which falls on the following day. Harry Grainstein, president of the American Society of Rio de Janeiro, conceived the idea of originating a President's Day.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The War Production Board issued today a question-and-answer explanation of the new rigid control of what it has defined as non-essential construction. Following are examples:

Archibald MacLeish, Director of the Office of Facts and Figures, denounced a minority of the American press yesterday as engaging in defeatist propaganda, and appealed to the rest of the newspapers to live up to their responsibilities by taking a definite stand against the defeatists.

Some boys went away from a few stations in Westchester with bands and banners the other day. They were to be inducted into the Army. There was much emotion, and mothers and brothers and sisters and sweethearts hovered over them and gave them presents.

A festival concert in connection with the celebration of the centenary of the Board of Education of this city was given by the All City High School Chorus and Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall, under the general direction of George H. Gartlan, director of music in the city's schools.

Qualifying rounds for the Hale America National open golf tourney are scheduled at eighty courses throughout the country, according to an announcement made yesterday by Francis Ouimet, chairman of the committee. With two exceptions in the Far West, these thirty-six-hole tests will be held on Monday, May 25.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 17 -- A much calmer view of the situation in France is being taken here tonight in foreign circles with access to private information. For one thing, rumors of a German ultimatum expiring yesterday obviously were without foundation and the impression is growing that things are not as cut and dried as had been represented.
