Association of the National Investors Corporation with the Tri-Continental group of investment trusts will cut its total management and corporate expenses from $138,389 in 1941 to about $75,000 in 1942, F.F. Randolph, chairman of the board of the Tri-Continental Corporation, declared in releasing the quarterly reports for the group yesterday.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 17 -- To balance the diet of the Australian and American fighting men vegetable production throughout Australia will be increased many thousands of tons by substituting garden-plot production by large-scale farming of thousands of acres, as in the United States and Russia.

The millinery industry opened its campaign to sell its quota of $1,000,000 of war-savings bonds and stamps at an open-air rally yesterday noon in Thirty-ninth Street, which was roped off between Fifth and Sixth Avenues. Carol Bruce, film actress, was the the "Minute Man" speaker of the day, making her address from a Treasury float.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Strict limits on the weight and size of parcels to be sent outside continental United States were imposed by the Postoffice Department today in order to give more ocean and air transportation space to war materials and to relieve congestion at ports.

The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, as plaintiff in foreclosure proceedings against the Chadoz Realty Corporation and others, bid in at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street rooms for $325,000 the fifteen-story apartment house at 9-11 East Ninety-sixth Street, on a plot 72.6 by 100.11 feet.

ALBANY, April 17 -- Both Legislative and Congressional reapportionment legislation met defeat in the Senate today, thus ending for some time plans for a more even distribution, according to population, of representation in the Legislature and in Congress.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 17 -- The first gun, an anti-aircraft weapon, turned out by the Hudson Motor Car Company's new naval ordnance plant at Centerline Mich., was presented today to the destroyer Shaw, which is rapidly being made ready at a West Coast Navy yard for return to the fleet after being damaged at Pearl Harbor.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- A War Department communique based on reports received up to 10:30 A.M. today said:

CAPE CHARLES, Va., Saturday, April 18 (AP) -- Bernard O. Hamilton, 32, of Norfolk, a professional diver, was rescued at 1:05 A.M. today after spending nine hours trapped under mud and fallen piling in the Pennsylvania Railway Terminal Harbor here.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 17 -- Raul Morales, Minister of the Interior, emphatically denied today that the government intended to push an "emergency law" through Congress regardless of whether or not the bill to grant extraordinary powers to the Executive to deal with the financial situation was deemed constitutional.
PHILADELPHIA, April 17 (AP) -- Home runs by Bob Johnson and Bill Knickerbocker in the ninth and tenth innings gave the Athletics a 5-4 victory over the Senators in their home opener today.

BOSTON, April 17 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The wool market, which was quiet up to midweek, has been more active, as mills which have been given government contracts have been taking up options which they had taken against these contracts, especially scoured wools for blankets and shirtings.

A triduum of thanksgiving commemorating the fiftieth anniversary of its establishment in Bedford Park, the Bronx, was opened yesterday morning by the Academy of Mount St. Ursula with a solemn mass at which Archbishop Francis J. Spellman presided.
LONDON, April 17 (U.P.) -- A British submarine has torpedoed and sunk a large Italian transport in the Mediterranean, the Admiralty announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Brig. Gen. Hugh S. Johnson, soldier, lawyer, industrialist, columnist and publicist, and alike in war and in peace a "first-class fight man," was buried today with full military honors in the National Cemetery at Arlington, Va. He died here on Wednesday at the age of 59.

Organized baseball was mobilized in support of the service charities yesterday with the announcement by Commissioner Kenesaw Mountain Landis of his recommendation that each major league club donate the entire receipts of one regularly scheduled game to Army and Navy relief.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Vacationists were urged today to start their holiday trips in the middle of the week to avoid traffic congestion. In a statement issued by Joseph B. Eastman, director of the Office of Defense Transportation, he added that vacations should be staggered throughout the year so that vacation travel would not be concentrated in July and August.

OTTAWA, April 17 -- Control of Canada's entire production of beef may become necessary, Donald Gordon, chairman of the Dominion Wartime Prices and Trade Board, said today. For several weeks there has been a shortage of beef in different parts of the country, and Mr. Gordon described the marketing situation as chaotic.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 17 (U.P.) -- Russia, calling on her varied peoples for a vast upsurge in food production, today decreed the mobilization for farm work of every available man and woman and sharply raised the minimum number of days they must work in a year.

American Export Lines, Inc., reported yesterday for the year ended with December a net profit of $13,699,498 after depreciation, interest and $300,000 provision for Federal income taxes, but exclusive of $986,462 profit on the sale of capital assets which was credited to the earned surplus account.
CLEVELAND, April 17 (AP) -- Chicago's "Sunday pitcher," Ted Lyons, appeared on the scene two days early to pitch the White Sox to a 1-0 triumph over Cleveland today in the Indians' home opener.

CINCINNATI, April 17 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury today indicted the Kroger Grocery and Baking Company,five Cincinnati dairies and the Mutual Bottle Exchange Company, Inc., and ten individuals for conspiracy to fix the price of milk and milk products in the Cincinnati area.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, April 17 -- One of the group's participating in last week-end's audacious American raid on the Japanese in the Philippines was led by Lieut. Col. John H. Davies of San Francisco. There were ten medium bombers in the Davies group.

Stepped-up war production due to an expected early Fall military crisis, plus a more rigid interpretation of the draft laws, will cause an unprecedented demand for women workers in war industries, Dr. Lewis Wilson, deputy commissioner of education of the New York State Education Department, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Broad plans for increasing the United Nations' air crew training facilities on the North American continent, which already are turning out priors, bombardiers, navigators, and aerial gunners at a rate approaching 50,000 annually, were disclosed today by President Roosevelt and Prime Minister W.L. MacKenzie King of Canada.

More than 400 graduates of Notre Dame University and their friends attended the annual dinner of the Notre Dame Club of New York last night in the Hotel Woodstock. The dinner was held in conjunction with alumni dinners throughout the country celebrating the university's one hundredth anniversary this year.

After trying since August to acquire the extra half inch of height he needed for entrance into the Fire Department, Gino Franceschini finally made the grade and yesterday was marked qualified on the records of the Municipal Civil Service Commission.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- Plans for decentralization of Federal housing operations to speed construction for war workers were announced today by John B. Blandford Jr., National Housing Administrator.

A 71-year-old proprietor of a second-hand store at 3303 Third Avenue, the Bronx, whose license to operate his business was revoked by License Commissioner Paul Moss, during a hearing on the matter in Bronx Supreme Court yesterday created a furor by waving his walking stick angrily at Justice Louis A. Valente and shouting, "I want to be heard.

Ranch mink prices eased yesterday at the sale conducted here by Lampson, Fraser Huth, Inc. Mink of the American National Fur Breeders Association brought a top of $17.75, with about 70 per cent of the offering of 65,000 skins changing hands.

UTICA, April 17 (AP) -- The Federal Government left it to dairy leaders today to evolve a plan to alleviate a critical surplus milk condition in the New York milk-shed, a situation which the dairy-men blamed on recent amendments to the Federal marketing order regulating the nation's largest shed.

The widening breach in relations between the United States and France and the anticipation of hedging on Commodity Credit Corporation cotton brought heavy liquidation into the cotton market yesterday at the opening, depressing prices 13 to 20 points.

A proposed resolution, aimed against any government subsidy of the press which "might gravely endanger the news and editorial integrity of the newspapers," stirred up such an unexpected controversy at yesterday afternoon's session of the twentieth annual convention of the American Society of Newspaper Editors, at the Waldorf-Astoria, that it crowded off the agenda a scheduled general discussion of how far newspapers should go in wartime in criticizing the government.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- Plans for decentralization of Federal housing operations to speed construction for war workers were announced today by John B. Blandford Jr., National Housing Administrator.

A 71-year-old proprietor of a second-hand store at 3303 Third Avenue, the Bronx, whose license to operate his business was revoked by License Commissioner Paul Moss, during a hearing on the matter in Bronx Supreme Court yesterday created a furor by waving his walking stick angrily at Justice Louis A. Valente and shouting, "I want to be heard.

Ranch mink prices eased yesterday at the sale conducted here by Lampson, Fraser Huth, Inc. Mink of the American National Fur Breeders Association brought a top of $17.75, with about 70 per cent of the offering of 65,000 skins changing hands.

UTICA, April 17 (AP) -- The Federal Government left it to dairy leaders today to evolve a plan to alleviate a critical surplus milk condition in the New York milk-shed, a situation which the dairy-men blamed on recent amendments to the Federal marketing order regulating the nation's largest shed.

The widening breach in relations between the United States and France and the anticipation of hedging on Commodity Credit Corporation cotton brought heavy liquidation into the cotton market yesterday at the opening, depressing prices 13 to 20 points.

A proposed resolution, aimed against any government subsidy of the press which "might gravely endanger the news and editorial integrity of the newspapers," stirred up such an unexpected controversy at yesterday afternoon's session of the twentieth annual convention of the American Society of Newspaper Editors, at the Waldorf-Astoria, that it crowded off the agenda a scheduled general discussion of how far newspapers should go in wartime in criticizing the government.
Isaac I. Kashdan and Samuel Reshevsky won their games in the sixth round of the United States Chess Federation tournament at the Hotel Astor last night and remained tied for first place.

Yale Towne Manufacturing Company, Philadelphia division, has scheduled a series of large insertions in leading magazines in which the copy will be devoted entirely to promotion of the war effort, with the name of the company appearing only in the slug.

Kenneth H. Campbell, director of the foreign department and manager of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau of the National Association of Credit Men, has been appointed chief of the exporters service section of the Office of Exports, Board of Economic Warfare, at Washington, it was announced yesterday.

Ken Feldman, a sophomore right-hander, outpitched three Violet hurlers and was given slightly better support by his mates as Brooklyn College upset the N.Y.U. baseball team, 11 -- 8, at Ohio Field yesterday. It was the first setback for the Violets in the Metropolitan Collegiate Conference.

ATHOUGH Harry Homer, unlike little Jack, is much too modest to cry "What a bright boy am I!" he is no dunce. If anything, it is his very precocity that from time to time entangles him. At the still tender age of 31 he has been at odd times mechanical engineer, an architect, industrial designer, interior decorator, actor, assistant director and scenic artist.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 18 -- The rational dinghy championships, which started today at the Larchmont Yacht Club, were marred by a high wind that upset five craft, swept the masts and sails out of two others and snapped steel-wire rigging as if it were string.

NORFOLK, Va., April 18 (AP) -- A school for chaplains, the first of its kind in naval history, has been started here to teach ministers and priests, newly commissioned in the Naval Reserve, the ways of the Navy as a working and fighting organization.

ALBANY, April 18 (AP) -- Moving to alleviate a possible shortage of water in New York City, Governor Lehman today signed a bill permitting the city's Board of Water Supply to buy equipment necessary for completion of the Delaware Aqueduct without the public letting of contracts.

OSCAR LEWIS says here that James Horton, the California millionaire whose unconventional biography he presents in "I Remember Christine," is a fictitious person. So he may be. At least, it is no part of a reviewer's business to dispute the point with him.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 18 -- The board of directors of the Finnish Chamber of Films resigned today when a majority voted for the continued showing of American films in Finland, thereby differing from a recent decision of the Axis-dominated so-called International Film Chamber Convention banning United States films in Europe as from Jan. 1, 1943.

Pierre Laval's reappearance as head of the Vichy government means this: Hitler and his advisers are aware that France's home territory and overseas empire will be soon in the thick of the fight. They need the assistance of a French ruler as sincerely devoted as themselves to the "new world order."

In THE TIMES Magazine of March 29 there appeared a picture of our house at 24 Washington Square North labeled "One Flight Up." This is an entirely false statement, as our house is a private house and not an apartment house.

A MALIGNANT form of dry rot has settled in the system of the New York theatre and unless something turns up pretty quickly to put new life in it, days of a ghostly drabness are ahead -- you hear that said on every hand these days.

LONDON, April 18 (Canadian Press) -- Scotland beat England by 5 -- 4 today in an upset avenging two Wembley defeats in wartime international soccer matches. A crowd of 75,000, the maximum allowed, watched the spirited battle at Glasgow.

A radio dramatization of the work of the Jewish Welfare Board and a broadcast message from Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. last night marked the opening of the board's twenty-fifth anniversary conference at the Hotel Commodore.

The pleasant accomplishment of setting a pretty table is one that is not likely to be handicapped by the battles of the Atlantic and the Pacific. Nearly all the stuff shown in these pictures is American made, and at that only a small sampling of the variety of linens, china, glass and silverware now manufactured in this country.

APPROPRIATELY enough, the exhibition of Flemish Primitives at Knoedler's is being held as a benefit for Belgian sailors with the Allied fleets. Belgium is no longer Flanders, and yet the relationship between modern Belgium and the less geographically determinate Flanders of the late Middle Ages is very real.

THE story of a rabbi's daughter who, born in sedate and leisurely Baltimore, has become at the age of 80 the "grand old lady" of Zionist Palestine will rank with the dozen or more first-rate books which have been written about American women.

HOW soon and how decisively we win the war will depend on how soon and how completely we face the fact that today air power must be the backbone of any successful strategy. This revolution in national thinking is essential before we can proceed to mobilize the men, the ideas and the weapons for victory.

LONDON, April 18 -- As Spring comes and day after day passes without any sign of the big offensive which Hitler always seems to start in April, the British are beginning to wonder just what has gone wrong with the German plans and why they have not yet heard of jack-booted German armies on the move.

CHICAGO, April 18 (AP) -- Prices of livestock were steady today after a week of renewed strength in the cattle and sheep departments but a downward reaction in hogs was caused by the revision of government-imposed ceilings on most pork products. The report of the United States Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -- Men expecting to be inducted into the Army can now expect furloughs soon after being sworn in, to wind up their personal affairs.

Whether he chooses the present or the past as the setting, Stephen Meader always tells a good story and brings his characters to life against an authentic background. In his latest book Mr. Meader describes the experiences of two farm boys living in the Pocono Mountains, Buck Evans and his friend, Joe Sullivan, who undertake to have their own blueberry farm.

As one who has had lifelong experience with foreign-language publications, may I speak up in commendation of your eminently fair and timely editorial "Foreign-Language Papers." Long before Pearl Harbor and since then the majority of those publications have been among President Roosevelt's stanchest followers.

LONDON, April 18 -- Docks and harbor installations at Rangoon, Burma, were heavily bombed by large aircraft operated by United States Army Air Force fliers, it was announced in New Delhi, India, today. They struck Thursday.

AKRON, Ohio, April 18 (AP) -- "Only time and further tests can determine" whether rubberless tires will provide emergency aid to American motorists, Chairman John W. Thomas of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company asserted today.

Elimination of commencement exercises and extended vacations, substitution of an "all-out physical fitness program" for varsity athletics, and an accelerated course for day engineering students are among the changes adopted by the trustees of Cooper Union to contribute to the nation's war effort, Dr. Edwin S. Burdell, director, announced.

Young Manhattan joined in war songs, tap dancing, tumbling, calisthenics, singing and dramatic acts yesterday morning in a two-hour "war savings festival" that "brought the house down." The event took place in THE NEW YORK TIMES Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, under the auspices of the Social Agencies Division of the New York Defense Savings Staff.

Dams, bridges, airports, factories, highways, public buildings -- in little more than a decade steel, concrete and plastics have transformed the American landscape. The transformation has been accelerated by the nation's all-out war effort, which demands factories and power plants on a tremendous scale. For generations the edifices reared by Americans were small islands in a vast sea of mountains and plains.

GENERAL MACARTHUR'S HEADQUARTERS, in Australia, April 18 (U.P.) -- Complete agreement of all United Nations on General Douglas MacArthur's Southwest Pacific command has set the stage for an intensified phase of the promised Allied counter offensive from new Australian bases.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Isolationists won the first heat in the 1942 Congressional sweepstakes this week, but the significance of the victory was minimized considerably by the locale of the contest -- Illinois -- and the caliber of the opposition which faced Senator C. Wayland Brooks, seeking renomination in the Republican party.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- Following a meeting of the officers of the Foxhowe Association of Buck Hill Falls, Pa., it was announced by Dr. Alexander C. Purdy, director, who is also Professor of New Testament at the Hartford (Conn.) Theological Seminary, that the theme for the Sunday evening lecture programs for this season will be "Foundations for an Enduring World."

Few amateur gardeners realize the importance of soil as a factor in the culture of plants. The soil is the foundation of success or failure with flowers, vegetables, fruits or trees. Men and women who loved to grow plants realized this centuries before science began delving into the hows, why and wherefores of soil composition and its effect upon plant growth.

At the seventieth anniversary service of the dedication of Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, yesterday, Rabbi Jonah B. Wise said the members must consecrate themselves by greater sacrifice and service to America.
A demand for opening a second European war front was sent to President Roosevelt yesterday by 4,112 delegates representing 253 C.I.O. unions in this city.
Waller, extreme outsider at more than 25 to 1 in a field of nine, captured the $12,275 Excelsior Handicap at Jamaica yesterday as betting records of all kinds were shattered by a crowd of 36,496.

If there was supposed to be a marked distinction between "Scientific" Johnny Woods, and his twin brother, "Just Plain" Jimmy, there was no way of knowing it last night at the circus. They gaped with mouths at the same angle, beamed simultaneously, laughed together and roared joint approval.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, April 18 -- The Spanish ship Cabo de Buena Esperanza, with 3,000 tons of fuel oil, has been here four days trying to get 700 more tons so as to be able to make the round trip to Cadiz, Spain, it was learned today.

COMMANDO CHIEF: At the start of the last World War a native of Austria who had become a naturalized British citizen was serving as First Sea Lord of the Admiralty. He had been Prince Louis of Battenberg -- a name he changed to Mountbatten.

New impetus has been given by the war production drive to the WPB's Training Within Industry program and the local office, which already has trained some 1,632 job instructors in the New York City area, has scheduled training sessions for 3,400 more instructors, D.J. Hoose, chief of the office here, said last week.

The world is discovering that wisdom of a practical sort may come "out of the mouths of babes," and that children's criticisms have money value. The child's classic remark, "This book told me more about penguins than I wanted to know," once regarded as a mere whimsicality to be smiled at and dismissed, would today be taken seriously and put to use.

EVERY week-end in New York thousands of boys in United States and Allied forces, in town on leave, are going to dances given by groups of warmhearted citizenry. Cherub-faced R.A.F. boys in dark green-gray, Yorkshiremen with dialects as thick as cream cheese, shy farm boys from Texas, bolder boys from the big cities, expertly whirl about girls from department stores and almost any large office in town where girls work.

The annual masters' individual tournament, concluded here last Sunday night, always provides an opportunity of observing the bidding habits and preferences of expert players from all parts of the country and to measure bidding trends which have arisen during the past twelve months.

The way to plant a garden is on your knees. You have to bow to the earth. You must get your fingers in the soil -- bare fingers that can feel the inner warmth of Spring. Now and then you will pause and sit back on your heels and listen to the cardinal whistling in the maples that stand in opening bud against the April sky.

Smiling broadly, swarthy Pierre Laval walked last Tuesday morning from the entrance of Vichy's Hotel du Parc. Buds were burgeoning on the trees and shrubs in the square facing the hotel and in the parks along the shallow Allier near by. A pleasant sun shone on the scene in France's most famous spa, where her defeated government has made its capital since the Summer of 1940.

The question is whether Charles Mountain murdered his wife, Margaret. The police and the District Attorney hold that he did and they have evidence to support their contention. Mountain's friends are convinced of his innocence, but they have little to offer in confu tation of the evidence.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, April 17 (Delayed) -- Before Bataan fell an American airman stationed in Australia tried singlehanded to get food to the hungry American soldiers on that peninsula. He failed, but his valiant efforts deserve a chapter in the annals of our air force.

SHAD are in the Hudson, and back in the woodlands the shadbush is in bloom. That means Spring beyond doubt or cavil. The shadbush gets its old-fashioned name because its blossoms come while the shad are spawning in the rivers.

TWO more abstractionists, both American, have entered the Spring gallery schedule. Arthur Dove is making his annual appearance at An American Place and the Buchholz is showing work (it dates from 1938 to the present year) by Karl Knaths of Provincetown.
LONDON, April 18 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

Their ship sunk by three torpedoes just a week ago off the Atlantic Coast, twenty British children bound for home from Australia and the Far East flew Chinese kites yesterday at a picnic for Allied youngsters given by United China Relief in Central Park.

Tomorrow at the Hotel New Yorker, persons flirting with the idea of a dude-ranch vacation this Summer will get some valuable pointers when the United States Travel Bureau opens a round-up of information in the hotel's north ballroom.

Not all of the errors show in the box score. Yale made two of omission in the third inning of its Eastern Intercollegiate League baseball game with Columbia at Baker Field yesterday and then went completely downhill the rest of the way to suffer a lop-sided 12-to-2 defeat.

Joseph J. Flynn, recently appointed Port Security Coordinator, yesterday reported steady progress in the protection of this port against fire hazards, sabotage and other subversive activities. He added that conditions today are good, and that steady improvement may be expected.

An illustration of the practical aid that may be contributed to the war effort by art museums will be given by the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, with the public opening on Wednesday of an exhibition of wartime housing, arranged in collaboration with the National Committee on the Housing Emergency.

Settled this week in new and larger quarters, the New York City and State Leagues of Women Voters are launching their part of an energized national program to supply democracy with the fire of analytical and constructive citizen participation which it needs to sear the Axis.

Although travel restrictions imposed by air raid precautions have curtailed the number of elementary school children who will compete in the seventh annual Catholic School Music Contest Festival, there, nevertheless, will be 1,300 young persons among the contestants, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -- The Bituminous Coal Division has revoked the registrations of fifteen coal distributors in New York State for failure to show they were engaged actively as distributors.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The new Presidential order which assigned to Vice President Wallace, as chairman of the Board of Economic Warfare, authority over acquisition of war stock piles that has been exercised by Secretary of Commerce Jones has been seized by the Secretary's critics as the heaviest ammunition in their long barrage against him.

At one time the only garden I could have was a garden of annuals. Rented ground and temporary residence of uncertain duration made it seem foolish to plant perennials, shrubs or hedge. So, early in the Spring I planted a tripple row of Jerusalem artichokes all around the boundary of my garden.

AFTER recording its first decline since March of last year, owing to the earlier Easter, retail merchandise trade last week snapped back fairly well but not to the previous level of increase. The food business reports continued high volume as sugar-rationing instructions go out to the school teachers of the nation.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Ninety-seven thousand fewer workers were employed on farms in the United States on April 1 this year than last, according to the Department of Agriculture. As a result of this actual scarcity and of a greater prospective shortage, the index of farm wage rates has increased 28 per cent during the year.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- In the four months since the United States entered the war, 7,000 registered nurses from every part of the country have volunteered for war duty through the Red Cross, according to Mary Beard, National Director of the Red Cross Nursing Service.

THIS reviewer last saw Alexander Werth with a group of British correspondents awaiting evacuation in the lobby of the Hotel Splendide in Bordeaux, on the eve of the French capitulation. It was perhaps the lowest ebb of Allied fortune during the entire war.

Samuel Reshevsky of Boston, national champion, and Isaac I. Kashdan of the Manhattan Chess Club, were still tied for first place in the title tournament of the United States Chess Federation after the seventh round was played at the Hotel Astor last night.
NORWALK, Conn., April 18 -- Fly fishermen were more in evidence today as the trout season opened in Connecticut than they had been on the earlier inaugurals in either New York or New Jersey.

MALTA'S CROSS: Malta, the "unsinkable aircraft carrier," the Mediterranean bastion which recently sustained its 2,000th air raid, was singled out last week for special honor. To the island fortress King George VI awarded the George Cross "to bear witness to a heroism and devotion that will long be famous in history."

The bombers that carried the war for the first time to the heart of Japan yesterday, according to the Japanese Imperial Command, attacked the seaport of Kobe and the industrial city of Nagoya, seat of the principal Japanese aircraft plants, as well as making raids, previously reported by Japan, on Tokyo and Yokohama.
