WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Correspondence showing that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had cleared the records of nine employes of the Board of Economic Warfare who had been accused by Representative Dies, chairman of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, of having had subversive connections was released today by Representative Eliot of Massachusetts, a leader of the fight against continuance of the investigating body.

Thousands of owners and operators of small craft officially catalogued as "pleasure" vessels by the United States Navy and the Coast Guard learned to their sorrow last week that the happy days of untrammeled seafaring were over, at least "for the duration."

I read the sprightly magazine article "The Joy of Walking" by Donald Culross Peattie and rejoiced in its freshness and in its paradoxical appearance among many grim and somber essays on war deeds. In the afternoon, in strict accordance with his advice, I trod the soft earth in the country and saved the tread on my car's tires.

AT the time when he was writing his "Singermann" saga -- and his other related stories of life in the mining West -- it seemed that Myron Brinig had the equipment of a really major novelist and that he might very possibly become one.

An elaborate musical program entitled "In Time of Battle" was presented last night at Town Hall, under the auspices of the School for Democracy. As Louis Lerman explained in his prefatory narrative, read by Mordecai Baumann, the concert was intended to emphasize the importance of music as a weapon in the present world crisis.

War and priorities apparently have had little effect on the ever-colorful Penn Relay Carnival which will be staged for the forty-eighth time at Franklin Field on Friday and Saturday. The statistics never vary from year to year -- 3,000 athletes from 500 schools and colleges.

A BOOK with a thesis courts criticism, but no one can quarrel lightly with Professor Spykman. His work is free of the starry mists of Atlantic Unions and Parliaments of Man; no musty dust of the cloister clouds his polished pages; and there is in his book none of the lush, rococo journalism of "inside" this or that, or of thunder over Ruritania.

BUFFALO, April 18 -- The shipping season has reopened on the Great Lakes, and 10,000 ships' officers and men are ready to top the record season that ended in December with 165,000,000 net tons of cargo handled in bulk freighters.
NEWARK, N.J., April 18 (AP) -- The Bears shelled two Buffalo pitchers for fourteen hits today to romp to their second decision in the three-game series, 10 to 3.

It may be a grimy job to bend the knees, unscrew a valve cap and check the inflation of your automobile tires, but that is a job that pays today. It may be a little rough on the crease of the trousers, the spotless hands or the woman driver's afternoon bridge ensemble, but there are gloves, old clothes and other times than the last minute to do the job.

Efficiency promotes further efficiency. Within indefinite top limits, the more people do the greater becomes their capacity of accomplishment. This is happening in the motor-vehicle world, which already is busier in the war effort than at any time in its history.

AN ADVANCED ALLIED BASE in the Southwest Pacific, April 17 (Delayed) -- The Allied air force in this area is getting six Japanese planes in combat to every one Allied plane the Japanese get, Lieut. Gen. George H. Brett, supreme Allied air commander, said in an interview tonight. He emphasized that the picture here was much brighter than it was a few months ago, when the Japanese were still pushing southward.

The Amerada Corporation, a leading independent petroleum producer with 1,000,000 acres in the Mid-Continent and California oil fields, and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the year ended Dec. 31 last a net profit of 82,569,560 after depreciation, depletion, drilling costs, abandoned leases, Federal income taxes and other charges.

WITHOUT the crowds the circus would lose character. For the crowd are quivering with excitement even in the streets out-side Madison Square Garden. When we whirled up for an afternoon performance the taxicab could not find an empty space near the curb and proceeded to debouch us in the middle of the street.

St. John's University's baseball team handed C.C.N.Y. a 10-5 defeat in a Metropolitan Collegiate Conference game in Lewisohn Stadium yesterday as five Beaver hurlers paraded to the mound in a futile effort to find the plate.

A CHILD couldn't want a gayer tambourine than one made from an old pie plate, its pierced edge hung around with flattened bottle tops, and the whole thing bright with red and yellow paint. Using odds and ends for play materials (making dolls from paper bags, puppets from peanuts) is only one of many ways in which the Play Schools Association is keeping step with new demands.

Many experts consider that among yellow, orange and copper hued annual flowering plants calliopsis is easily the most satisfactory. Seed sown in Autumn or on the snow in March or later in Spring will provide a constant display of gorgeous bloom from early Summer until the plant is cut down by hard frosts.
IN 1932 a study of development in young children was started with infant twin boys, and continued until the twins were aged 2.

Two of the veteran Cunard White Star commanders who have been known to thousands of American transatlantic travelers, Commodore Robert B. Irving and Captain J.C. Townley, have retired and are now back in England, it was disclosed yesterday.

HERSHEY, Pa., April 18 (AP) -- Harold G. Hoffman, executive director of the New Jersey Unemployment Compensation Commission, said tonight that if industry adopted a basic forty-eight-hour week, government should go along on the longer war work schedule.

IF James T. Farrell's collection of sketches which bear the title of "$1,000 a Week and Other Stories," were called a note-book, it might have greater significance for the reader. For, primarily, the individual contributions are more concerned with liming a character against his background than telling a story.

Fables and animal folk tales with their talking birds and beasts, their humor, their directness and lively action, make a strong appeal to boys and girls from their earliest years on. This is as it should be, for animal folk tales hold the beginnings of local literature.

After an intensive police hunt lasting thirteen months, Carlo Malone, 32 years old, of 177 Rock-away Avenue, Brooklyn, a brother of Harry (Happy) Malone, was arrested yesterday morning by Detective John McDonough of the Liberty Avenue precinct as he stepped from a taxicab at That-ford and Pitkin Avenues, Brooklyn.
MR. DOWNES'S illuminating article on the Eighth symphony of Gustav Mahler and the splendid rendition of the symphony by Mr. Rapee recalled the world premiere of this great work to my mind.

TOKYO, April 18 (From Japanese Broadcasts) -- Domei, the Japanese news agency, today quoted Mamoru Shigemitsu of the Foreign Office as advising the Japanese people not to lose their composure as the result of air raids.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 18 -- To emphasize the importance of the civilian consumer in the war effort Vassar College student organizations have started a campaign to make every girl in the college realize that how she spends her money and her time, how she takes care of her own belongings and of college property, are her answer to the question, "Are you impeding or speeding our victory?" adopted as the keynote of the campaign.

The recently founded American War Heroes Foundation will be aided by the proceeds from the new War Heroes game, which will be demonstrated by a group of younger members of society on May 1 during the cocktail hour at the One, Two, Three Club in East Fifty-fourth Street and the dinner hour in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 18 -- Appointment of a committee to select a successor to Chancellor William P. Graham of Syracuse University was announced today by Hurlbut W. Smith, president of the board of trustees. The action was taken, Mr. Smith said, at the request of Dr. Graham, who will continue in office until his successor is appointed.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Suggestions for economical operation of trucks were issued today by the Office of Defense Transportation.

Because of offsetting tax-loss sales and dividends, which are considered as returns of capital, twenty-three closed-end investment trusts last year paid dividends which were partly or wholly non-taxable, according to the 1942 edition of "Investment Companies and Their Securities" by Arthur Wiesenberger, which has just appeared.

With United States aircraft production nearing the pace set by President Roosevelt in his request for 180,000 planes within two years, it has become necessary to create an aviation reservoir of the nation's youth to man and service these planes.

The shad are running again in the Hudson. To epicures and the more adventurous housewives, that spells something different on the table. To the shad fishermen up and down the great river off New York it means the reward of weeks of preparation, the climax of an annual gamble with weather and tide and the spawning season.

LONDON, April 18 -- Strong sweeps of Royal Air Force fighters and bombers went on over the Channel today to give no respite to the Nazis' defense and war-base forces in Western Europe. The sweeps, made through misty weather, followed extensive British night bombings that included what the Air Ministry called "a heavy attack" on Hamburg.

The 1"qev York Botanical Garden Iwill sponsor a three-day short course in practical gardening April 27, 28 and 29. The work will be entirely practical. Students will be provided {vith individual plots of ground, suitable tools and supplies, and under expert supervision will prepare ground, sow seed, stake and prune, and generally carry out the fundamental gardening operations.

No decision was reached yesterday by the Intercollegiate Rowing Association as to the possible shifting of the Poughkeepsie Regatta from the Hudson River to another locale, it was announced by Asa S. Bushnell, executive director of the Central Office for Eastern Intercollegiate Athletics.

New York drama critics have found no American play of this season good enough for their annual award. But with sufficient imagination and a certain amount of courage they might have made one choice that was sure to evoke a great deal of popular approval.
PHILADELPHIA, April 18 (AP) -- The Washington Senators won their first game of the season today by turning back the Philadelphia Athletics, 10 -- 6.
KUIBYSHEV, April 18 (U.P.) -- Soviet successes reported in war dispatches today included:

All active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday with 6-point increases. The session's second spurt of trade buying at the end counteracted a late morning appearance of hedging that had caused the market to recede to the opening lows, 1 point higher to 1 point lower than the previous day's final prices.
WOODBRIDGE, Va., April 18 (AP) -- Sixteen passengers were injured today when a southbound bus from Washington, D.C., crashed into the rear of a truck three miles south of this community.

From Winter playground to Air Force training center is the war-time story of Miami Beach. To the bright blue of the ocean and the gleaming white of the beach has been added the khaki of soldiers who soon will total 30,000, housed in great waterfront hotels. Thirty-one of them, or 30 percent of the housing capacity of the resort, have been taken over for military use.

JOSEPH MEDILL PATTERSON, the president of The Daily News and a former playwright -- quiescent in this latter art, however, since 1911 -- is at work on a drama called "Day Before Yesterday." His collaborator is Harriet Ford, with whom he wrote "The Fourth Estate" and "A Little Brother of the Rich," both in 1909.
WORCESTER, Mass., April 18 -- Scoring all its runs in the ninth, Fordham rallied to defeat Holy Cross at baseball today, 3 to 1.

A NEW addition to the long line of fictionized biographies is this account of the strange life of Elizabeth St. John Eckel by John Louis Bonn, S.J. Elizabeth was the daughter of a notorious woman named Maria Monk.

TORONTO, April 18 -- Staging a brilliant third-period rally, Toronto won the Stanley Cup, which had evaded the team for ten years, by defeating the Detroit Red Wings, 3 -- 1, at Maple Leaf Gardens tonight.
WITH the publication some weeks ago of the volume on Oklahoma, the Writers' Program of the WPA brought to conclusion the series of State guides upon which it had been engaged since 1935.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Cebu City, on the island of Cebu in the Philippines, apparently is in Japanese hands, the War Department disclosed today. The city, which is the principal port of the second most important Philippine Province, is, however, burning, the War Department added.

There are other good furniture woods, it seems, besides mahogany, walnut and maple. The American colonists knew this and often used woods which grew near at hand -- elm, hickory, cherry and apple -- in making their chairs, tables and beds. American ash, too, has a beautiful grain which shows up well either in its natural cream color or a stained finish.

Patriotism was the keynote of the season's sixth and final Young People's Concert of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra yesterday morning at Carnegie Hall. It opened with the National Anthem, the "everybody sing" number was "America" and it was brought to a close with John Philip Sousa's "Stars and Stripes Forever."

WASHINGTON, April 18 (U.P.) -- An American ex-soldier, barred from the armed service because of desertion nineteen years ago, has sent a $100 check to Secretary Stimson to "purchase bullets or bayonets to avenge Bataan."

DETROIT, Mich., April 18 -- Federal and local authorities moved this week to relieve a situation in connection with housing and transportation which, officials of the Ford Motor Company warned, unless quickly solved would seriously hamper full efficiency in the operations of the company's $80,000,000 bomber plant at Willow Run.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 18 -- The newspapers, radio and movies were taken to task today by Dr. John R. Steelman, Director of the United States Conciliation Service, for their "careless recital of the dramatic side of strikes."

SINCE China was opened to the world relations between East and West may he divided into three stages. In the first the weapon of the West toward China was always force. By the pointing of a gun at her the West made her suffer humiliation after humiliation. All her port cities were opened, in an actual as well as a metaphorical sense, at the point of the bayonet.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- To provide effective distribution not only of the manpower but also of the woman power of the United States for the war on both the battle and home fronts, President Roosevelt established a War Manpower Commission of nine members today, with Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator, as its chairman.
The United States Coast Guard has issued an urgent appeal for small power craft and for men with special qualifications needed for boat operation, it was disclosed yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., April 18 -- Several district conferences, a little theatre tournament and a victory garden forum combine to make a busy week for affiliates of the New Jersey Federation of Women's Clubs.

In a broad formula designed to solve the city's parking and traffic problems, the Regional Plan Association, Inc., proposed yesterday construction of extensive new facilities to absorb congestion in midtown Manhattan and other crowded business districts.
PHILADELPHIA, April 18 -- Princeton's well-balanced track team, by taking first place in five events and sharing honors in two others, won the second annual Quadrangular track and field meet today.

The government's fiscal authorities, with the blessing of the Administration, are determined to keep the sale of war savings bonds on a strictly voluntary basis as long as possible. From the very beginning they have carefully avoided any pretense of "high-pressure salesmanship" or any form of a compulsory savings program.

The military note sounds today on almost every college campus. Some colleges have become almost exclusively training schools for officers of the Army and Navy; in others the ROTC has been expanded, and from them flows a widening stream of junior officers. Almost universally, commencement has been advanced a month or more in the war speed-up.

Still trying to satisfy the demand from civilians who want to learn yacht navigation and eventually offer their services to the Navy and Coast Guard, the Stamford Power Squadron started a class Thursday night in elementary piloting and small-boat handling.

Fire struck again last night at the former French luxury liner Normandie and burned inside her for more than three and a half hours before it was considered under control. Black smoke billowed for hours from the stricken craft, lying on her port side at the West Forty-eighth Street pier since the disastrous blaze of Feb. 9.

THOSE who pride themselves on seeing everything that goes on in the dance world would do well to engage at once a nice quiet suite of cells in a sanatorium to recuperate in, for the current week is definitely going to do things to them.

Referring to a photograph of Prime Minister Winston Churchill where he is seen accepting a gift from Austrians living in Great Britain you state: "Churchill takes gift from enemy aliens.'" Austrians are not considered enemy aliens in Great Britain; they are also "neutrals" in this country.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., April 18 -- Enrollment of nearly 8,000 women in Pennsylvania State College's new engineering defense training program is largely responsible for raising the technical job training registration to nearly 30,000 students, it was announced today by E.L. Keller, in charge of Penn State's tuition-free defense training work.

Many types of deer and antelope are to be found in North America. It is not always necessary to go to a zoo to see them, for not infrequently one may catch a glimpse of these appealing, graceful creatures from roads bordered by woodland, and indeed their curiosity sometimes leads them close to human habitations.

FORT BENNING, Ga., April 18 (AP) -- When the Rev. Raymond S. Hall of Lowell, Mass., was assigned to parachute troops here he felt that a champlain should share the same dangers as his men -- so he became "a jumping chaplain."
AMONG the achievements of that multiple-career man Ben Franklin, one of the most important and enduring is the Library Company of Philadelphia, which he and his friends of the Junto founded in 1731.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- With Social Justice, founded by Father Charles E. Coughlin, as the first point of attack, Federal officials have undertaken a vigorous campaign to rid this warring nation of publications suspected of subversive or seditious motives.

Possibility that the apparent deadlock over the appointment of a single wartime Food Administrator with wide powers will be resolved by the establishment of a three-man commission is now being seriously discussed in the food industry, it was learned last week.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Carrying direct to the Senate Committee on Labor the fight of the Congress of Industrial Organizations against legislation to restrict wartime extensions of closed-shop agreements and increases in wages and salaries, Philip Murray, C.I.O. president, declared today that enactment of such measures would "completely destroy" the voluntary no-strike agreement made with management under White House sponsorship.

Retail trade here was fairly active last week. Sales comparisons with a year ago, freed from the distortion occasioned by the later Easter in 1941, resumed their upward trend. Department store volume was estimated as 8 to 10 per cent higher, with a larger increase seen for specialty shops.

NOGALES, Ariz. -- The State of Arizona, United States of America, and the State of Sonora, Mexico, claim a municipality in common. It is this border city, and though bisected by the international boundary line the city is anything but divided against itself.

ANKARA, Turkey, April 18 -- The specter of revolt in the Balkans and Central Europe that has haunted the Reich's leaders and the puppet rulers of Germany's southeastern satellite countries since the first snows of last November, with the attendant slowing down of the Nazis' offensive and the onset of one of the bitterest Winter's in European history, is now emerging in the Spring as a possible reality.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 18 -- That the Reich looks upon all that happened in Vichy today as a mere formality is made evident by dispatches from Berlin received here. The Wilhelmstrasse minces no words. It says simply: "M. Laval fully realizes that he must begin from zero."

More than 600 newspaper publishers, editors and business managers of the United States and Canada are arriving in New York City today for the annual meetings of The Associated Press and the American Newspaper Publishers Association this week at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

LEESBURG, N.J., April 18 (AP) -- Two wooden submarine chasers for the Navy, the PC648 and 649, went down the ways today in the Delaware Bay Shipbuilding Company's last launching of the war open to the public.

Members of the Westchester County Federation of Women, holding their twenty-first annual meeting on Friday, will attend a full day's program at the Contemporary Club of White Plains. In the business sessions and the sectional round tables to follow in the afternoon, the influence of war on federation interests will be emphasized.

Xavier High School's first team returned a total of 1,067 points to pace a field of seven squads in the metropolitan sectional shoot of the National Rifle Association interscholastic championship tournament on Far Rockaway High's range yesterday.

ROUNDING out fifty years of faithful service to American art, the Macbeth Gallery pauses to celebrate with a modest anniversary exhibition. It is a show thronged with reminiscence. All of the canvases and water-colors are by American artists who were leaders, or whose work was deemed full of promise, during the early days of the gallery's career.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 18 (AP) -- F.W. Lucas of this city, president of the Southern Cotton Shippers Association, advocated today release of government cotton stocks as the best substitute for a ceiling on cotton prices. In an address at the association's twenty-seventh annual meeting he said:
CLEVELAND, April 18 -- Two were out in the ninth and there were two strikes on Pinch-Hitter Fabian Gaffke when he singled today to give the Indians a 1-to-0 triumph over the White Sox.
NEW DELHI, India, April 18 (AP) -- A British Burma headquarters communique said today:

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., April 18 -- Recreational facilities here bid fair to be more in demand than in many years, since few families are anticipating leaving later for Summer resorts as has been the custom in former seasons. Already the golf course and the tennis courts are being prepared, and the dates of the annual Tuxedo Horse Show in behalf of the local hospital have been announced for June 5 and 6.

ABERDEEN, Md., April 18 (U.P.) -- Vice President Wallace today told ninety-five newly commissioned second lieutenants, including his son Robert, that in the latter part of 1942 the United States would be producing more war material than any nation "or combination of nations" in the world's history.

Bobby Ruffin, Long Island City lightweight, captured the decision over Carmelo Fenoy of Spain in the star bout of eight rounds at the Ridgewood Grove Sporting Club, Brooklyn, last. A crowd of 3,000 fans saw Ruffin win on his long-range boxing superiority.

C.R. Smith, who played a major part in making American Airlines one of the world's outstanding airlines, has taken on a new air transport job. Last week he was commissioned a colonel in the Army Air Forces and attached to the Ferrying Command. Basically transport is transport, whether it be for wartime military or peacetime commercial ends, and Mr. Smith knows the air transport business.

THE author of textbooks for use in schools is unlikely to attain thereby a literary reputation, but he may sometimes reap very substantial financial profits from his work. Charles Pendlebury, whose death was reported recently, wrote no popular novels, but he must nevertheless be numbered among best sellers.

DETROIT, April 18 (AP) -- Adolph Kiefer of Chicago tonight clipped two full seconds off his own world record for the 100-meter back stroke by swimming the event in 1 minute 2.8 seconds in a match race at the Detroit Athletic Club.

Captain Granville Conway, director in New York of the United States Maritime Commission, has been named Atlantic Coast director of the War Shipping Administration, with supervision of the agency's activities on the entire coast from Savannah, Ga., to Portland, Me., it was disclosed here yesterday.

Of the making of anthologies there is no end; that is as it should be, for every compiler's taste and experience in poetry are different and each new collection is likely to introduce us to something unknown before or to remind us of old favorites temporarily forgotten.

SOMEWHERE IN NORTHERN IRELAND, April 18 -- Early air bombing support by American planes and pilots was today promised Britain's embattled Royal Air Force by General George C. Marshall, United States Army Chief of Staff, at a press conference following a review of American troops at a command post in Northern Ireland.
The metropolitan tennis season will open June 2, when the Manursing Island Club at Rye will launch its annual invitation tournament for women in singles and doubles.

With a consumer information center now open at the Uptown Y.W.C.A. and stocked with all manner of information from market lists to blackout instructions, Bronx households are preparing to go on an efficient wartime basis. One of the first complete centers to be opened in the metropolitan district, the new project is the achievement of the war service committee of the branch at 301 East Kingsbridge Road.

Anticipating a large enrollment of incoming students in the field of social work as a result of the war, Hunter College has created a Department of Sociology and Anthropology, Professor Agnes M.H. Byrnes, newly elected chairman, announced yesterday.

The gavels will be pounding this week to sound the open season on annual conventions of women's organizations, whose delegates are being summoned in a more serious mood than ever before. This first Springtime of the war, many of them are discovering that they must orient themselves to new locales, as priorities in hotel accommodations have crowded them out of the national capital, favorite of convention cities.

The President has told us that victory lies in production of ships, planes, tanks and guns. We must have the equipment in huge quantities to wage successful war in every part of the world, against foes who are resourceful and fully equipped, and desperately resolved to stamp out everything for which we stand.

THIS delightful book is a love letter for Maryland, from a man who found his home there thirty years ago. And that the tribute may lack no possible expressiveness it is richlyand beautifully illustrated by a gifted artist, in twenty-seven full-page drawings, two panoramic endpaper pictures and thirty-one headpieces.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- With the blessing of President Roosevelt and President Manuel Avila Camacho of Mexico, the American and Mexican experts selected by the two governments today fixed $23,995,991 as the value of American-owned oil properties expropriated by Mexico on March 18, 1938.
VICHY, France, April 18 (AP) -- The French Government of Pierre Laval, as announced today:

PRINCETON, N.J., April 18 -- Bucking a strong headwind that piled up whitecaps on the usually calm surface of Lake Carnegie, an inexperienced Navy varsity crew got away to an early lead and slowly pulled away from Princeton to finish a length ahead in a mile-and-three-quarters race today. Navy's time was 10:43.6, Princeton's 10:47.4.
PITTSBURGH, April 18 (AP) -- The Pirates moved into a tie for the National League lead today as Lefty Ken Heintzelman, making his 1942 debut, blanked the Cardinals, 3 -- 0. He allowed only five hits.

MacARTHUR, W.Va. -- A letter to General Douglas MacArthur, hero of Bataan and Supreme Allied Commander in the Southwest Pacific, was given No. 1 cancellation at the official opening on April 15 of the new postoffice bearing his name, according to The Associated Press.
Villanova defeated Manhattan yesterday on Manhattan Field, 13 to 12, in a loosely played eleven-inning ball game. This was the Wildcats' third victory of the season and the Jaspers' third loss.

Although retail sales last year rose 19.9 per cent to a new high record, net profits increased only 5.4 per cent over 1940, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES based on the annual reports of sixty-one leading mail-order, chain store, department store and specialty shop organizations.

WITH THE A.V.G., in Southwestern China, April 17 (U.P.) -- A spokesman for the American Volunteer Group said today that the Japanese had lost seventeen Zero planes in recent engagements with A.V.G. planes on the Burma front. Consequently, he said, the Japanese have abandoned, at least temporarily, attempts to knock out A.V.G. bases in the area.

WALDO FRANK, novelist, historian and critic, returned time and again to the matter of his status as a writer in other countries. "When I first visited Argentina it was front page news -- not only the first day, day after day I was played up in interviews, pictures.

The New York Bridge Whist Club team won the national contract bridge team championship and the Harold S. Vanderbilt Trophy last; night by the narrow margin of 250 points from the Cavendish Club team. They were the survivors of twenty-seven teams that started the tournament Monday night.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 18 -- Twenty girls in the Cooking Club of the Grover Cleveland Junior High School were convinced today that discretion had a good deal to do with valor when it came to sending cookies and cakes to the Army camps.

Although sprays and dusts for the home garden are not yet rationed, and most of the proprietary mixtures sold in the past are still available in stores, a threatened shortage of raw materials makes it imperative that all chemicals be used wisely.

TOKYO, April 18 (Japanese broadcast recorded by the United Press at San Francisco) -- Radio Tokyo broadcast messages today from six American aviators imprisoned in Japan after they "were forced down in an attempted raid on Japanese positions."

In the small hours before the dawn of April 19, 1775, "a shape in the moonlight, a bulk in the dark" rode headlong from Charlestown to Lexington. On pounding hoofs, Revere, the Massachusetts silversmith, was bringing to hamlet and sleeping farm the call to battle that was to fashion a free people.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The War Shipping Administration has requisitioned possession and use of all essential oceangoing tankers and dry cargo vessels owned by American citizens.
WEST POINT, N.Y., April 18 -- Williams hammered four pitchers and buried Army under an avalanche of twenty-one nits today to score a surprising 23-2 rout on the diamond.
BERLIN, April 18 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:
Mr. and Mrs. William McMaster Mills have arrived from Palm Beach and are at the Pierre until late next month, when they will go to Newport.

Miss Frederica de Peyster Lawrence heads a group of young women of society aiding in plans for a Springtime dinner dance to be held on May 7 in the Gardens of the Ambassador for the benefit of the Canteen Division of the New York Women's Council of the Navy League.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- A wide range of convention groups will meet in Atlantic City during the next two months, thus augmenting a host of Spring visitors.

Citing the switchover of the automobile industry from peace to war as showing the way in typical American style, I.A. Hirschmann, vice president of Bloomingdale's, yesterday urged that business get quickly to work on "the heavy tanks of the promotion business."

OBSERVING in the public prints that the new Blue Theatre Players are calling themselves a radio stock company, a veteran of the days when stock was stock -- or, for that matter, even a Summer theatre actor -- could be forgiven a slightly condescending smile.

Junior auxiliaries of the American Women's Voluntary Services in the city will unfurl their own division flag at their first rally this afternoon at Town Hail. The banner, which was designed by James P. Weir, who also designed the Navy Relief Society flag, and by Mrs. Morton Spring, co-chairman of arts and decorations of the A.W.V.S., carries the organization emblem on a center panel of royal blue, bordered in red.

More than four months after Japan struck against Pearl Harbor, the "inevitable war" between Russia and Japan is still deferred. But large Japanese and Russian armies eye each other across the Amur, and both nations stand to arms against the day of hostilities that is surely coming.

MEXICO CITY, April 18 -- The joint report of the American and Mexican appraisers, published tonight, was regarded here as finally settling the four-year-old oil controversy by payment to the expropriated American companies of about seventeen cents on the dollar, on the basis of their own valuations.
With the hearty cooperation of the traveling public, the nation's rail lines are doing their job in the vast struggle for victory efficiently and with very little ballyhoo.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sunday, April 19 -- Well-filled hunter classes produced a majority of the highlights during the fifteenth annual Spring horse show concluded early today at the Round Hill Club stables.

BOSTON, April 18 -- The Giants simply refused to take defeat for an answer today and, with the help of an imposing three-run circuit clout by Hank Leiber in the ninth inning, sank Professor Casey Stengel's Braves, 8 to 5.

Accepting the new police regulations against taxicabs cruising in mid-Manhattan, the city's operators have agreed to "cooperate fully in giving the new plan a fair trial," Julie Becker, editor of Taxi Age, declared yesterday.

In the magazine Science Dr. Peter L. Kapitza, a physicist whose name is identified with brilliant efforts to reach absolute zero, reviews the work done by Russian scientists to improve weapons and to find substitutes for much needed importations. His story parallels that which has been told by American and British scientists.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18 -- Dartmouth rallied with eight runs in the eighth inning today behind the record strikeout pitching of Will Gray to defeat Pennsylvania in the Indians' opening Eastern Intercollegiate League game, 11 -- 3.

DID Nettie Carrington die a natural death as she lay in her mud pack in Emily Bokart's beauty parlor? Janet Barron thinks not, and Janet is a detective, as is also her husband, Peter. Just how Mrs. Carrington was killed is another question and not an easy one to answer.

Estranged from his former associates in the Congress of Industrial Organizations, John L. Lewis is gambling his whole future on his ability to convince the nation's 3,000,000 dairy farmers that their salvation lies in enrollment under the banner of the United Mine Workers of America.

The Magazine Section of THE TIMES of March 15 has an article about "The Basques in Exile," which says that the Gascons, in France, are the cousins of the Spanish Basques and adds that these Gascons "speak Basque." That would be almost enough to make a real Gascon unsheathe his sword and challenge the author of the article to a duel.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 18 -- Princeton's varsity baseball team trounced Harvard, 8 -- 4, behind Roy Talcott's seven-hit pitching on University Field today to open the defense of its Eastern Intercollegiate League crown. Talcott, unbeaten in E.I.L. competition last Spring, chalked up his ninth straight league triumph.

FRAGILE little glass disks are crossing the Atlantic in the air these days. They are bringing first-hand information to American workmen about the performance of the new implements of air warfare now being sent eastward in greater quantities to do battle over the Channel, France and Germany.

In "On Safari," that very human and thoroughly interesting account of how a young explorer started on his chosen career; in "The White Panther," a tale of the South American jungle, and now in "Lions on the Hunt," a story of the South African veldt., Theodore Waldeck, explorer, hunter and writer, opens up for his readers an amazing outdoor world full of breath-taking adventure and rare beauty.

LAWRENCE, Kan., April 18 (AP) -- The Kansas Relays, holding prominence in the country's track and field activity for nineteen years, felt the shake-up created by the war at their twentieth running today.

To discover practices and policies that are used by the best schools in this country, a cooperative study of twenty-eight public school systems is now under way. It is hoped that general patterns will emerge that may be applied to American education everywhere.

CHICAGO, Ill., April 18 -- As part of the exercises commemorating the 1,000th anniversary of the medieval scholar Saadia Gaon, the Jewish Theological Seminary of New York will confer honorary degrees on three modern educators Monday evening at the University of Chicago.

THE League of Composers is about to celebrate its twentieth anniversary. True to its policy of forwarding the cause of contemporary music and keeping its audiences thoroughly abreast of its developments, the league has secured from leading composers of Europe and America the promise of "birthday" pieces to honor the occasion.

The exigencies of war have caught up with the publishers of the Standard Postage Stamp Catalogue. Priorities and increased costs of metal, paper, glue, thread and other items have compelled Scott Publications, Inc., to plan the 1943 edition in two volumes instead of one.

OLD BEDFORD VILLAGE, N.Y., April 18 -- Tancanhoosen Brook, a white and liver pointer dog, today was awarded the highest honors in the open all-age stake, leading event on the card of the three-day meeting of the Southern New York Field Trial Club.

Greatly increased activity in women's Fall and Winter cloth coats featured wholesale trade last week, with many buyers visiting the local market to place early orders, according to the weekly report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.
MOSCOW, April 18 (From Russion broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau communique today said:

ALBANY, April 18 -- Governor Lehman appealed today to all coal users of the State to buy their coal now for next Winter's needs. He also directed that "every ton that can be stored" be ordered by the State for immediate delivery.

Chile has released two additions to the current air-mail series. Inscribed "Linea Aerea Nacional" (National Air Line), a 50-centavos bright orange pictures a United States Stinson monoplane flying over the Andes and an 80c bright blue shows a twin-engined Douglas transport above Chile's coast line.

Corner cards, cachets and slogans have been used on mail for many years and to serve many purposes, chiefly advertising and other propaganda, both national and institutional. Not the least interesting of these are the "patriotics" -- serious messages used in time of national distress to inspire new faith in a country.

HONOLULU, April 18 -- Congressional medals were presented at Pearl Harbor today to Captain Cassin Young and Warrant Officer Donald K. Ross for extraordinary heroism last Dec. 7. At the same ceremony aboard a ship of the Pacific Fleet the Navy Cross was conferred on Lionel S. Baker, pharmacist's mate.

THIS distinguished novel about China at war, written by a Chinese and beautifully translated by an American scholar whose name is withheld because he is at present interned in a city occupied by the Japanese, should not only help us to understand the great people who are courageously resisting the invader but also engender in us an affection for them.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The War Production Board today added commercial laundry and dry cleaning equipment to the list of durable goods on which civilian production will be ended for the duration of the war.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 18 (UP) -- Montreal salvaged one game out of its three-game series with the Jersey City Giants today, winning by a score of 5 to 3.

ALBANY, April 18 -- The first move in opposition to continued control of the Republican party in the State by the forces supporting Thomas E. Dewey for Governor was taken today. It came from within the New York State Association of Young Republican Clubs, where a group regarded as belonging to the Wendell L. Willkie camp announced today an opposition ticket, on an anti-isolationist basis, for the coming elections in the Young Republican organization.

WYCKOFF, N.J., April 18 -- Within ten minutes of a local disaster, Mrs. Edward Mowerson, chairman of the welfare department of the Junior Woman's Club of Wyckoff, could, with the aid of her fellow club members, she reported yesterday, have at Fire Hall, which has been set aside for use in emergency, equipment ranging from a wheelchair to bandages to augment supplies of the Red Cross and Defense Council.

THE Eastman School of Music of the University of Rochester will open its twelfth annual Festival of American Music, April 27, in Rochester, N.Y. Compositions written by faculty members and graduates of the school in celebration of its twentieth anniversary will form the six programs to be presented.

Sergio Bernstein, a slim, studious boy whose family had fled from Italy and come to this country by way of France three years ago, was known to neighbors in the large apartment house at 875 West End Avenue for his extreme politeness and for his devotion to the study of chemistry.

CHUNGKING, China, April 18 -- China's wartime capital, victim of 107 Japanese air raids in which 20,136 persons have been killed, jubilantly declared a holiday today upon the reports that Allied planes had blasted Tokyo, Yokohama, Kobe and Nagoya in Japan.

The destruction last week by the British of the Burma oil wells has complicated further the problem of supplies of petroleum for the United Nations in their war with Japan. With the exception of the production in British India, which probably is not much more than 5,000 barrels daily, all the oil fields of the Far East have passed to the Japanese or their producing wells have been destroyed.

LOUISVILLE, Ky. -- Despite a war which might have made General Sherman a bit more emphatic had he been planning a celebration, Kentucky is beginning her long-planned, far-flung series of sesquicentennial programs. There will be events from now until Dec. 19 between the Big Sandy and the Mississippi and between Covington and Cumberland Gap.

BURLINGTON, Vt., April 18 -- Breaking a tradition of 138 years the University of Vermont, beginning next year, will no longer require Greek and Latin for its A.B. degree. The change is only one facet in a movement that is liberalizing arts and sciences curricula in this century-and-a-half-old New England institution.
Stocks turned moderately upward yesterday and gave a firm closing to a week which had seen prices at the lowest levels in nearly a decade, or since 1933.

THE "Mangrove Coast" is the west coast of Florida; and this is a book which has cried out to be written and which is to be welcomed with a warm delight. Its author has no truck with resort reporters. That virtually universal query to Northerners returning from Florida -- "How was the weather?" -- would never enter his head.

EVER since a certain sad day in 1932, when the dusty, faded curtain of the Palace was rung down for the last time, a refrain has gone across the land from the fabled corner of Forty-seventh Street and Broadway: "Vaudeville is dead."

War relief work for the British and Canadian forces will be carried on through the Summer months by the Canadian Women's Club of New York, unaffected by the closing of the club season, according to an announcement yesterday by Mrs. Anthony Bassler, president of this group.

OTTAWA, April 18 -- Parliament will resume its session on Monday after a three-week Easter recess in an atmosphere of some uncertainty regarding the outcome of the national plebiscite which is to be held on the following Monday, April 27.
Thoughtful Americans see grave consequences in excluding religious education from our public schools.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Every person holding a war ration book can get a special allotment of a maximum of five pounds of sugar a year for home canning or preserving fresh fruits and vegetables for home consumption, the Office of Price Administration announced today.

WHETHER you like it or not, Summer is practically at hand, and so the talk is of replacements for headliners who will presently be vacationing. In Eddie Cantor's Wednesday night place will be "Those We Love," beginning July 1 and carrying on for thirteen weeks.

DONALD CULROSS PEATTIE'S forthcoming book, "Forward the Nation," which G.P. Putnam's Sons will publish on May 15, is the story of Meriwether Lewis and William Clark, leaders of the Lewis and Clark Expedition of 1805 up the Missouri, across the Rockies, to the Pacific Ocean.

Mayor La Guardia and his eight-man "war Cabinet" held their first formal meeting yesterday afternoon in the Mayor's office at City Hall, The session, which began at 2:30 P.M. and ended at 4:15 P.M., was interrupted to permit the Mayor and his associates to pose for photographers in the City Council chamber on the second floor of the building.

The insignia of the National Order of Honor and Merit of the Republic of Haiti has been conferred upon Albert Greenfield, amateur photographer and traveler, for distinguished services based on his published camera work and articles on Haiti.

TUCSON, Ariz., April 18 -- Basic research to discover new cellulose compounds of wood and new sources of mucilage from plants and their seeds of the American desert has put the shoulders of University of Arizona senior and graduate chemistry students firmly behind the wheel in the nation's war effort.

The sophomore class of Barnard College won the laurels yesterday at the fortieth annual Greek Games in its gymnasium. The sophomores received 55 out of a possible 100 points in contests with the freshmen in dancing, music, lyrics, athletics and costumes.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 18 -- A memorial to Newton Diehl Baker, Secretary of War under Woodrow Wilson, was announced in Cleveland this week by President Winfred G. Leutner of Western Reserve University. The memorial will be the home of the downtown division of the university, Cleveland College, which was Mr. Baker's major outside interest during the reconstruction after World War I.

CHICAGO, April 18 -- Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., chairman of the Republican National Committee, arriving in Chicago today for the committee's session Monday, said the party was "100 per cent behind the prosecution of the war," and added:

Your "Trapping the U-Boat" (issue of April 5) seems to illustrate the trouble with United States thinking on the U-Boat problem. Our Navy heads seem to be waiting for destroyers when they should have all the fishing boats, yachts, motor boats, everything that will float, to keep the subs down or report them when they come up.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., April 18 (AP) -- Trenton High School runners captured two of four State championship relay events today at the tenth annual Long Branch relay carnival with victories in the 880-yard and mile races. It was the first time in the history of the carnival that one school had annexed more than a single State title.
Peppery Hans Lobert lost an argument with Umpire Larry Goetz at Ebbets Field yesterday, but his lowly Phils won the ball game from the champion Dodgers by a 2-1 margin.

Plans are being advanced rapidly for the Spring Tea Dance in behalf of the Child Placing and Adoption Committee to be held on May 26 at the Stork Club. Mrs. Henry J. Taylor and Mrs. Daniel M.S. Hegarty are in charge of arrangements for the event.

ALBANY, April 18 -- A gradual siphoning of New York State's farm man power by the armed forces and by industrial defense plants has created a shortage of farm labor that is expected to reach the critical stage by Summer.
SEATTLE, April 18 (AP) -- The University of Washington crews set three new course records today in making a clean sweep of their thirty-ninth annual regatta with the University of California.

WHEN cables had to be laid under a new landing field in Australia, American soldiers rolled out their Jeeps, hitched on a plow, a cable reel, a roller, and did a two-day pick-and-shovel job in two hours. Australians marveled; A.E.F. men didn't, for they knew their Jeeps.

THERE have been few musicians of our generation who have not been troubled at one time or another by the problems of our world. Should they remain aloof on the concert stage or should they take an active part in trying to remedy the world's evils? Each artist has faced the question in his own way.

IN the national capital there are New Dealers who, like others in the country, believe that the war has not been pushed with sufficient vigor. Their solution has been generally expressed in four words: "Send for Bill Douglas."

A FRESH treatment of a hackneyed subject is the booklet bearing the modest title, "Recipes to Match Your Sugar Ration." This unpretentious pamphlet is prepared by the Bureau of Home Economies and is distributed free for the asking by the Office of Price Administration.

When Ann Fenton arrives at the Connecticut estate of Mrs. Hale she finds that her hostess is ill and seriously upset about something that has happened to her. That same evening, before she has told Ann much about what has frightened her, Mrs. Hale is found dead in her garden.

RUBBER THREAD -- The first synthetic rubber thread ever developed in this country made from the "Ameripol," a Goodrich product, has been introduced, but only for military use. The thread will go into harnesses, parachutes, gas masks and respirators, and other equipment.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The War Department communique based on reports received until 9:30 A.M. said:

IN recent years parents have been experiencing a mild boom as literary subjects. Nothing as lush as the vogue for doctors, but definitely an upswing. For years the traditional attitude toward parents was one of respect.

THE return of warm weather means wonderful week-ends in the country, but also that accompanying Friday trial -- packing. Packing a suitcase so that your clothes emerge later fresh and unmussed is a difficult trick. Among other things, it means lots of tissue paper, but not as used by professional ladies' maids.

GROUP and one-man shows in formidable numbers were added to the Spring freshet of exhibitions last week. Among the newcomers to the local galleries is Borislav Bogdanovich of Yugoslavia, whose bright-hued and well-spaced compositions at Lilienfeld's seem to be eclectic modern French rather than Southern European, with Lautrec, Degas, Matisse and Bonnard as possible influences.

LONDON, April 18 -- Great Britain, which in great measure has been more or less forced to let the Axis powers take the lead in determining war tactics, as well as the dates on which they would be executed, has served notice on her European enemies, particularly Germany, that she is determined to take and maintain the lead in offensive aerial warfare.

Members of six women's organizations are joining today in honoring Dr. Alice Salomon, noted German sociologist, now exiled in this country. The occasion, her seventieth birthday, will be marked with a tea at the Hotel Biltmore, at which she will make one of the few public speeches she has given since she arrived here five years ago, following her expulsion by the Nazis.

JUST recently, at one of our air bases in Australia, Brig. Gen. Royce was tagged with the Distinguished Service Cross for his brilliant leadership of a 4,000-mile bombing flight, the best part of which was the unloading of a shower of high explosives and hot metal for the Japs who had muscled into the Philippines.

Cash awards of $4,000 and a ouryear university scholarship valued at $6,000 are being offered Dy the Inter-American Student Forum of the Pan American Union, Waslington, D. C., for "the most meritorious written discussions" of not i more than 700 words on the subject "What Inter-American Col operation Means to My Country."

In his statement of March 3, announcing the Treasury's proposals on corporation taxes, Secretary Morgenthau suggested an excess profits tax of 75 per cent and then a corporate normal and surtax of 55 per cent.

Clothing manufacturers will be able to turn out a larger quantity of goods than the low cloth allocations reported by some mills for Fall last week would appear to allow, manufacturers said yesterday. Some mills still refuse even to estimate what quantity of worsteds, manipulated worsteds and woolens they will be able to allot to their customers, but several gave indication of what they might do for the next three months.

Miss Hildegarde Balmain of the Junior Skating Club of New York gave an exceptional free-skating performance to win the honors in the women's senior division of the twenty-first Middle Atlantic figure-skating championship tournament at Iceland Rink in the Madison Square Garden building yesterday.

In today's Magazine Mme. Chiang Kai-shek returns to the task, which she has almost made her own, of explaining and reconciling the East and the West. She has become to Americans no vague and distant, however illustrious, a figure. She has endeared herself. She is present.

The Yankees lost yesterday at the Stadium. What is more, it was only by the slimmest of margins that they averted the added humiliation of their first whitewashing of the new season before a gathering of 24,021 fans, 977 of them service men who looked on from the right-field lower stand.

Paintings and other art objects, including several large tapestries of the Gothic and Renaissance periods, were among articles sold at the closing session yesterday of the auction of the art collection of the late Mrs. Christian R. Holmes of this city and Sands Point, L.I.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The United States is now exceeding the Axis in production of tanks, Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, announced tonight as he participated in the first broadcast of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. joint radio program, "Labor for Victory."

The courage of a young woman who grabbed a hold-up man and the gallantry of a buck private of the Army -- the latter so modest that he refused afterward to take credit or even to give his name -- led just before 10 o'clock last night to the frustration of a robbery in a Western Union office at 5911 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn.

TO win the war we shall have to get our teeth into the enemy. Once we do that to the Nazis, more than a hundred million people in Europe will help bite them to death. For we have a great army of allies on the Continent.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 18 -- With the nation faced by an acute shortage of public health workers, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, a pioneer in public health education, today announced plans of meeting this condition by inaugurating special intensive and accelerated programs of graduate study to equip men and women with the needed training for the various public health services.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., April 18 -- Adoption of a plan permitting associate membership in the Honors College at Wesleyan University for high-standing freshmen and sophomores was announced today by Professor Thomas W. Bussom, head of the Honors College.

CHICAGO, April 18 -- The jittery feeling that prevailed yesterday in the grain markets on the Board of Trade disappeared overnight, and with securities and cotton showing firmness today, grains started higher, with wheat running up around 1 cent a bushel from the previous close before profit-taxing checked the advance.

While retail trade was slow during the early part of last week, volume picked up toward the end of the week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

More than 800 members of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association, who have been anxiously awaiting the new season's schedule, will be glad to know that their executive board has arranged a complete list of tournaments.

IF you haven't heard of B. Reeves Eason, blame that on Hollywood. Mr. Eason, familiarly known as Breezy, is a motion picture director with more than 200 productions to his credit. He has been shooting epics since 1913, when John Ford, Victor Fleming and Gregory LaCava were tyros and when Frank Capra, Ernst Lubitsch and William Wyler had not yet seen the inside of a studio.

BOSTON, April 18 -- Predicting the mobilization of 3,000,000 women within a year not so much in war production as in jobs releasing men for it, Secretary Perkins questioned today the willingness of women to forego snappy uniforms and take over unglamorous work such as in grocery and drug stores, bakeries and laundries and on bus lines.

Constantine was having a little difficulty getting a male ballet dancer to understand the kind of pose he wanted. After repeated attempts, Constantine put down his camera and said, "Here, let me show you." And with a dexterity and grace indicative of the trained dancer he danced the routine until his subject finally got the idea.

Because of pressure of other business, Mayor La Guardia was not at City Hall at 12:30 P.M. yesterday to keep an appointment with representatives of the Jewish Teachers Community Chest, from whom he was scheduled to accept a $3,500 check, to be used to buy an ambulance for the city's civilian defense equipment.

The problem of the France of tomorrow is of interest first of all to Frenchmen; but it affects the entire world both because France must be one of the pillars of the new order and because France must take on again her role of leader in the development of civilization.

One hundred and fifty editors and publishers, ending a three-day annual convention of the American Society of Newspaper Editors, spent a "day with the Army" yesterday in a nine-hour session that was heartily -- and in the case of many veterans, nostalgically -- enjoyed by the group from the Fourth Estate.

Old-fashioned Tiger Lilies with the fragrance of the auratums and the color blendings of the regales and speciosums -- that is the dream of F.L. Skinner, Canadian hybridist whose successful experiments in breeding hardier plants and shrubs, conducted at his nurseries in Northern Manitoba, have earned him a international reputation.

Re-zoning of Tokyo, accomplished with United States help in the ten years following the disastrous earthquake-fire of 1923, has made the center of that metropolis safer from bombing damage than any other city in Japan. Reinforced concrete buildings have been erected to border wide streets and form fire-breaks to keep a blaze from sweeping from end to end of the capital.
As a telephone engineer I wish to attempt to clarify the seemingly existing confusion over the decibel and its application to air raid sirens.

FORTUNE GALLO'S San Carlo Opera Company will give an eleven-day season, beginning May 7, at the Center Theatre. Works scheduled for performance are "Carmen," "Rigoletto," "Aida," "The Secret of Suzanne," "Martha," "La Boheme," "La Traviata," "Cavalleria Rusticana," "Pagliacci," "Faust," "The Tales of Hoffmann" and "Il Trovatore."

Columbia's varsity crew moved into the winner's circle its first time out when it triumphed yesterday over a good Rutgers crew that came to the Harlem River with the scalp of Princeton, taken a week earlier in the season's first race.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The Office of Defense Transportation issued today a twelve-point statement of government policy for conserving equipment in the field of local passenger transportation.

HONOLULU, April 17 -- The health of the soldiers in the Hawaiian Department is "at an all-time high," Lieut. Gen. Delos Emmons, Commanding General of the department, declared in a "victory jamboree" radio program here.
VICHY, France, April 18 -- Pierre Laval completed today his Cabinet in which he assumes, in addition to the Ministries of Foreign Affairs, Interior and Information, the title of Chief of Government.

THERE are occasional blasts from official quarters about complacency in the general public. There is an almost pathetic eagerness to put first things first.

Various plans for the curbing of profits on government contracts for the supply of war materials have been under consideration. While such limitations have been sought there has been expressed within the same circle a strong feeling against the suggestion that wages, rents and commodity prices be simultaneously frozen.

GRINNELL, Iowa, April 18 -- Keeping stride with the national emergency, Grinnell College has revamped its educational program to supply its students a training designed to increase their usefulness in the war effort as well as prepare them for living in times of peace.

Tokyo, Yokohama, Nagoya and Kobe, that the Japanese say were bombed yesterday (Tokyo time) by American airplanes, are four of the five major centers of Japanese war effort. Osaka, near Kobe, is the other -- and the greatest single industrial center of Japan.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Japan's air fleet is about 10 per cent smaller than it was Dec. 7 and the imperial forces are now losing three to five planes for every American aircraft destroyed, it was stated in official circles today as Tokyo's announcement that American bombs had fallen on the Japanese capital and other key cities caused jubilation in Washington.

Warm weather is creeping up fast, and it's high time to get the Spring chores over with. Putting woolens away and getting out the slip covers and Summer rugs is easier on the nerves if you do it now, instead of waiting for a real dog day.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 18 -- Steel Heels won the $2,500 added Ben Ali Handicap at Keeneland Park today after Whirlaway and The Rhymer had been withdrawn. Junius W. Bell's entry, with Jimmy George in the saddle, covered the mile and a sixteenth in 1:46 2-5 and was the 11-to-10 favorite.

AT long last -- after four months of stalling, each waiting for the other to move -- the government's film coordinator and the motion-picture industry have gotten together on a program of "who shorts" to be made in Hollywood.

FORTY-ONE more nineteenth century French paintings from the great Chester Dale collection have been placed on permanent loan in the National Gallery of Art in Washington. It seems to me that no pharmacists are needed in the armed forces of the United States. This is the opinion formed after looking over the Selective Service occupational questionnaire. In the list of "professional and scientific workers" the pharmacist is missing.

Fifteen months before Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen's extraordinary grand juries began studying police corruption in Brooklyn Commissioner Valentine ordered his commanding officers to investigate confidential reports that "handbook operators throughout the city are being choked for protection money by plainclothes men."

LONDON, April 18 -- The giant submarine Surcouf, the largest in the world "is considerably overdue and must be considered lost," Free French headquarters announced today. There was no indication of where the vessel went down, when it happened, or whether it was the result of enemy action or an accident.

ONE of the busiest in the entertainment world today is Kay Kyser, band leader extraordinary and "professor demeritus" of the College of Musical Knowledge. One of the busiest, and one of the most successful.

A YOUNG man well within today's draft limit "sat at a little improvised desk in a stuffy parlor" in a three-story brick house on Market Street, Philadelphia, composing a committee report. He worked at it for seventeen days, writing "fine, clear, meticulous script, revealing the neat precision of a scientific and poetic mind, aware that each word counted."

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 18 -- A better understanding of Chinese life and the importance of China as America's ally is the objective of a conference on "The Far Eastern Front" to be held Wednesday and Thursday by students of the University of Rochester.

A move to initiate neighborhood planning for residents of East Harlem is being sponsored by the Women's City Club, which has called a meeting of welfare and educational leaders from that area. Views will be exchanged on the community's needs and how they can be met.

PEORIA, l., April 18 (AP) -- George P. McNear, presi ent of the government-operated Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad, informed the War Labor Board today that he was too busy on a Federal Court case to give adequate attention to the board's request that he participate in the arbitration of a labor dispute on the line.

Four girls in a South American city are killed and horribly mangled apparently by a black leopard which has escaped from the custody of a night-club singer who has adopted the animal as a pet. RICHMOND, Va., April 18 -- The use of air to speed the reclamation of rubber from old tires, shoes, hose and other articles is described in a patent (No. 2,279,047) granted to Walter G. Kirby and Leo E. Steinle of Naugatuck, Conn., and assigned to the United States Rubber Company of New York.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., April 18 -- An Institute of Foreign Affairs and Trade, to train students for foreign administrative posts in the post-war world, is being organized at the University of Maryland, under direction of Dr. H.C. Byrd, president.

LONDON, April 18 (AP) - A new weapon, developed apparently by the Royal Air Force, has made its appearance on the aerial battlefields of Europe: Incendiary charges floated to their targets by small, hydrogen-filled balloons. The Swiss radio broadcast today an army warning to civilians against the contraptions, some of which apparently have been drifting on to Swiss territory.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 18 (AP) -- For the first time in history, the American Bowling Congress will limit, at Buffalo, N.Y., in 1943, the length of its national tournament and the number of competing teams.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., April 18 -- "The Good Neighbor" means more than empty words in the American Southwest, especially in New Mexico, where Spanish is the household language of 40 per cent of the population, and the southern border is shared with old Mexico.

The War Shipping Administration has authorized an increased freight rate surcharge on all cargoes moving from the United States Atlantic and Gulf ports to ports in Persia, it was announced last week. Another increase has been authorized on shipments between Pacific ports of the United States and East Coast ports of South America.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 18 (AP) -- Allied bombers attacked the Japanese-held port of Rabaul, on New Britain Island, today and damaged a Japanese transport with two near misses and set a smaller vessel afire, United Nations Headquarters announced tonight.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 18 -- Breaking stubborn Finnish-German resistance, the Red Army has launched a vigorous offensive on an important sector of the Finnish front on the Karelian Isthmus, piercing the enemy's first defense lines and advancing several miles, according to today's reports.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- Golf, tennis, matinee races and trapshooting are on the calendar for the remainder of this month, which will be one of the busiest periods of the season. Shooting will be resumed, after an absence of several seasons, with the North and South clay target shoot and the North Carolina State championships at Pinehurst Gun Club from April 23 through 25.

THE motion picture industry's war effort took a spurt this week with the formation of a program for commercial production of twenty-six government-inspired "information" films, and the adoption by the Producers Association of measures to insure the continued output of pictures in case of war damage to Hollywood.

CHICAGO, April 18 -- The war today canceled United States participation in the first Pan-American games at Buenos Aires, Argentina's big 1942 sports show arranged to take the place of the suspended Olympics.

WASHINGTON, April 18 - Lease-lend aid to the Soviet Union was 150 per cent greater in March than in February, and all lease-lend assistance, including goods awaiting delivery, reached a record figure of nearly $600,000,000, Thomas B. McCabe, acting lease-lend administrator, reported to President Roosevelt today.

FIELDING BURKE with her subtle, Southern highland stories brings to her readers her Carolina country of soft, magical beauty and the people with the pungent, picturesque language of their slow-dying frontier.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt visited the exhibition of Flemish primitives yesterday as a co-sponsor with Count van der Straten-Ponthoz, the Belgian Ambassador. These masterpieces of fifteenth and sixteenth century art were placed on display at the Knoedler Galleries, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street earlier in the week for the benefit of Belgian seamen attached to ships of the United Nations.

FIELDING BURKE with her subtle, Southern highland stories brings to her readers her Carolina country of soft, magical beauty and the people with the pungent, picturesque language of their slow-dying frontier.

By unanimous agreement reached more than two weeks ago, the Senate is scheduled to take up today the motion to consider immediately Senator Connally's labor bill. Several substitute measures will also come up for consideration. Putting aside any discussion of the merits or faults of these particular measures, let us ask ourselves instead what the broad requirements now are of a labor program for the period of the war.

Although, for reasons which are obvious, the city's traffic problem has been simplified in recent weeks, the need remains for thoughtful planning to meet the situation that will be back with us again when the war is over. The Regional Plan Association has given much thought to this question, and has just made public final recommendations based upon an eighteen-month study.

VICHY, April 19 -- It is shown clearly in the last statement of the Bank of France what an important role is being played in the monetary situation in France by the payments of costs of the German armies of occupation, which, it has been announced, amount to 300,000,000 francs a day.

The use of clubs, social and eating establishments and large athletic institutions throughout the city as first-aid receiving stations in an emergency was suggested yesterday by Howard S. Cullman, president of Beekman Hospital, in a letter to Dr. Edward D. Bernecker, Hospital Commissioner and New York City's Emergency Medical Director.

In the belief that "this is a time when every able-bodied person should be employed and every potentially employable person should be made ready for a job in war production," the Welfare Department is conducting a survey of the work capacity of all persons receiving home relief or veterans' relief in this city, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- General George C. Marshall, United States Army chief of Staff, returned to the nation's capital by plane from New York this afternoon after his ten-day mission in England. It is said that General Marshall was accompanied by three British naval officers and a British civilian of high rank.
CHICAGO, April 19 -- Seeding of Spring grains made rapid progress
TORONTO, April 19 (AP) -- "By Jiminy!"

It is not necessary to await detailed reports of the bombing raids on Tokyo, Yokohama, Nagoya and Kobe to assess some of the results. Official Japanese broadcasts offer ample evidence that they were widespread and destructive. It may be some time before we learn the actual extent of the physical damage inflicted.
CHICAGO, April 19 -- Following are the texts of the resolutions proposed by Wendell L. Willkie and Senator Taft for adoption by the Republican National Committee, which meets here tomorrow:
MELBOURNE, Australia, April 19 -- Privates in many instances took precedence over generals in the evacuation of United States and Filipino troops from Bataan Peninsula to Corregidor.

Many automobile dealers in New York and New Jersey have successfully converted their shops and showrooms to war production, according to Thomas T. Lloyd, chief of the automobile and truck section of the regional office, Office of Price Administration.

Attacking under cover of darkness, an Axis submarine shelled oil installations of the Royal Dutch Petroleum Company at Bullen Bay on the island of Curacao yesterday, but she was driven off by the return fire of a coastal battery before she had done an damage, according to despatches from Willemstad to The Associated Press and The United Press.

NEWARK, N.J., April 19 (AP) -- The Montreal Royals, capitalizing on lack of control by Newark pitchers, registered a double victory today over the International League champions before a crowd of 7,000. They won the opener after ten innings, 8 -- 7, and took the seven-inning nightcap, 13 to 0, with Joe Hatten giving six scattered hits.

Edwin A. Archer of the Consumers Durable Goods Section, Regional Office, OPA, announced yesterday that with the beginning of new and used typewriter rationing this morning, eligible buyers could procure application Form R-401 from local rationing boards handling automobiles and tires.

Amateur fliers in well-knit task forces are taking part in America's "Battle of the Atlantic," the First Air Force at Mitchel Field disclosed yesterday. Directed by the Army and Navy, their work is to spot and report enemy submarines.
NEW BEDFORD, Mass., April 19 (AP) -- Some young sailor is going to draw a second-hand uniform. But it will be better than new.

Marking the ninetieth anniversary of the founding of the parish of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Incarnation, Madison Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street, the Very Rev. George A. Robertshaw, dean of the Cathedral of the Incarnation, Garden City, L.I., yesterday congratulated the congregation on an announcement that the Rev. John Atherton Bell, now of St. James Church, would become the new curate on Sept. 1.

LONDON, April 19 -- Chinese troops are said to have joined the British forces on the Irrawaddy front in Burma. Chungking announced today that the Chinese had taken over from the British authorities the management of all communications in Burma, including railways, highways, telephones and telegraph.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Under a new system for coordinating official broadcasts the American public will hear fewer government appeals and more basic war information, according to an announcement today by the Office of Facts and Figures.

BERLIN, April 19 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command, reporting its first large-scale victory in weeks on the Russian front, said in a special communique tonight that four Red Army divisions -- some 60,000 men -- had been encircled and destroyed in a six-day battle in a sea of mud and slush.

First apparent confirmation from a non-Axis source of the Japanese-reported raids of Saturday on four cities of Japan was contained in Swiss Telegraphic Agency reports from its Tokyo bureau; received from Berne by THE NEW YORK TIMES last night.

CHUNGKING, China, April 19 (U.P.) -- About 350 Americans interned in Hong Kong have completed an effective organization and are functioning under a committee headed by William Hunt, former Shanghai shipping man, a reliable informant told The United Press today.

BOSTON, April 19 -- Paced by the heavy bludgeon of Johnny Mize, the Giants flashed just enough power today to bowl over the Braves for the second successive afternoon and win the deciding encounter of a three-game series, 5 to 2. The victory, which sorely depressed a gathering of 13,694, sent Mel Ott's Polo Grounds cast back to the 500 mark with a decidedly more cheerful outlook.

LONDON, April 19 -- Having tried a law forbidding strikes that failed because jailed workers produce nothing, Britain has turned with increasing emphasis to the cooperative plan of joint works councils in the hope of stepping up war production and cutting down labor difficulties, which have caused an average loss of 2,122 workdays every day since the war began.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 19 -- After visiting more than 160 factories in his inspection swing across the country, Lieut. Gen. William S. Knudsen, production chief of the War Department, said last night that he was "not satisfied" but was "encouraged."
SAN FRANCISCO, April 19 -- San Francisco had its longest alert period of the war early today.

The Polish armed forces now number more than 200,000 seasoned fighting men, the Polish Information Center at 151 East Sixty-seventh Street announced yesterday on the basis of official cables from the Polish Government in London.

Installation of air raid sirens throughout the city will be completed within two weeks, probably by Saturday, after which there will be alert tests more comprehensive than the blackout drills held so far, Police Commissioner Valentine said yesterday.

LONDON, April 19 -- Outlying parts of the empire that have been pounded by or lost to the enemy will be aided by the Empire Air Raid Distress Fund, it was announced tonight by Sir John Dawson Laurie, Lord Mayor of London.

TOKYO, April 19 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The occupation of several islands southwest of Sumatra and east of Java in the Netherlands Indies was reported by war correspondents today.

HOLLYWOOD BEACH, Fla., April 19 -- The Right Rev. Mgr. Michael J. Ready, general secretary of the National Catholic Welfare Conference, declared today that the country's religious forces lacked aggressive unity in promoting as well as in protecting the position which private voluntary and religious institutions have enjoyed since the inception of the American Republic.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Secretary Morgenthau will open May 1 a campaign for the voluntary use by the public of at least 10 per cent of income for the purchase of war savings bonds.

LONDON, April 19 -- In this top-sy-turvy world one sees women casually doing jobs that only a few years ago would be considered improper for them. At railroad stations uniformed women porters stagger under heavy loads of baggage while male travelers, carrying morning newspapers and canes, blithely follow in their wake.

BOSTON, April 19 -- Dartmouth's green burgee waved high on the Charles River basin today as Emil Mosbacher, Long Island Sound ace, led the Indians to the Eastern Intercollegiate Y.R.A. championship and the Prof. George Owen Trophy.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 19 -- An exchange of actresses has been arranged whereby Ingrid Bergman, who is under contract to David O.
