Selznick, will go to Warner Brothers to star in "Casablanca" and Olivia de Havilland, Warner player, will appear in Selznick's "She Walks in Beauty" as Miss Bergman's co-star after "Casablanca" is completed.
HARTFORD, Conn., April 19 -- The Hartford Courant said today that submarine attacks on American shipping had cost insurance companies, writing marine lines, a loss of $17,000,000 since Jan. 1.

A comprehensive series of lectures, demonstrations and dramatic programs designed to acquaint the women of New York with the essential points of home defense will be given this week at Gimbel Brothers, Broadway and Thirty-third Street, it was announced yesterday.

Bruno Walter's superlative attainments as conductor were never more fully in evidence than in his interpretations of the works on yesterday afternoon's program of the Philharmonic-Symphany Orchestra in Carnegie Hall. Under his magisterial direction this final subscription concert of the organization's centennial season, still to be followed by the non-subscription Beethoven series led by Arturo Toscanini, proved a memorable event that brought on an exceptionally fervid and prolonged ovation at its close.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 19 -- Bread mold has been inducted into service in the war effort.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The work of the Rio de Janeiro conference has already laid the foundation for a regional association that may ultimately develop the attributes of "a great international confederacy of the Americas," a survey entitled The Rio de Janeiro Conference of 1942, to be published tomorrow by the Foreign Policy Association, declares.

LONDON, April 19 -- Squadrons of Royal Air Force fighters and Hurricane bombers were across the Channel again today to keep up Britain's aerial offensive as Prime Minister Winston Churchill publicly commended the Bomber Command for its daylight raid on Augsburg, Southern Germany, on Friday.

ELMSFORD, N.Y., April 19 -- Selected members from every unit of the town of Greenburgh's 2,000 civilian defense workers staged a spectacular demonstration this afternoon before 5,000 persons at the Greenburgh High School Athletic Field on Stadium Road near here.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Civilian employment in the entire service of the executive branch of the United States Government reached a total of 1,670,922 in December, 1941, as compared with 1,487,924 for the previous September, an increase of 12.3 per cent.

The universality of the gospel of Christ, with its over-all power to change human life, was hailed as the saving factor of a chaotic world by the Rev. Dr. Samuel M. Zwemer, former Near East missionary, who was the guest preacher yesterday morning at the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue, between Eleventh and Twelfth Streets.

CANBERRA, Australia, April 19 -- Sir Owen Dixon, who has been appointed Minister to the United States in succession to Richard G. Casey, will receive special leave from the High Court bench, of which he is a member, it was announced today.
BERNE, Switzerland, April 19 -- Italian official comment on events in Vichy continued today to follow the example of the Germans and Italian editorial comment continued absent.

Columbia University Press's biweekly bulletin The Pleasures of Publishing, never at a loss for a new idea, has opened a literary liquidation contest. The idea is to name the five living American authors who would be the first citizens of the lit'ry world to be taken care of by Hitler -- if he could -- also the five deceased authors whose work would first be banned.

MEDFORD, N.J., April 19 -- After eleven hours of competition, Way Yonder, a pointer owned by Dr. Harold E. Longsdorf of Mount Holly, won the all-age stake today in the South Jersey Field Trial Club's annual Spring meet on the grounds of the English Setter Club of America.

Three hundred men and women to whom Dr. Alice Salomon, noted German sociologist, has been an inspiration, gave a tea for her yesterday on her seventieth birthday. The celebration took place in the Hotel Biltmore, under the auspices of six women's organizations.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Dr. Maurice Parmelee said today that his dismissal by the Board of Economic Warfare might give the public the impression that the board was "the accomplice of Dies." His statement was made in a letter to Milo Perkins, executive director of the board, protesting the board's action.

ST. LOUIS, April 19 (AP) -- The Browns and Tigers split a brace of pitchers' battles today, with home runs deciding the issue both times. The Tigers won, 1 to 0, after the Browns had taken the opener, 2 to 1.

A four-point program intended to put "all of labor's forces and resources" behind the war program was announced yesterday by Matthew Woll, second vice president of the American Federation of Labor, in his capacity as president of the Labor League for Human Rights.

Before the biggest crowd of the baseball season to date, Marv Breuer made a costly error yesterday at the Stadium, where the Yankees concluded their first home series of the campaign with the Red Sox. Catcher Bill Dickey made another and Phil Rizzuto came along with a third misplay that only added to the dismay. And the Yankees lost the game, 5 to 2.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., April 19 -- Two real fires, a false alarm and fifty pre-arranged incidents gave 2,000 air wardens, police, auxiliary firemen, regular firemen and first aid workers a major test of air raid precautions here this afternoon.

MEXICO CITY, April 19 -- The Mexican press today gives precedence over the war news to the report for settlement of the oil issue, emphasizing that the companies get from one-eighth to one-sixth of what they asked and that the award is final.

Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, a Republican, appealed yesterday for an end to political capitalization on the mistakes that the Roosevelt Administration may make in the conduct of the war. He spoke at the second annual communion breakfast of the St. George Association of the Treasury Department at the Waldorf-Astoria.

DAMASCUS, Syria, April 19 -- Vichy's resentment of the establishment of a United States Consulate-General in Brazzaville is taken here as one of the many indications that Pierre Laval's government may launch a military campaign to win back the Free French areas.

Mgr. Bryan J. McEntegart, national secretary of the Catholic Near East Welfare Association, appealed yesterday at a solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral for donations to Catholic charities in emulation of Christ, Who said: "I am the Good Shepherd.
LOS ANGELES, April 19 -- Directors of the Pacific Finance Corporation have announced that an offer to acquire the common stock of the corporation has been received from the Transamerica Corporation.

L. Metcalfe Walling, Federal Wage-Hour Administrator, ruled yesterday that utility employes were covered by the Wage-Hour Act if the electric power, steam or water produced by them was used by manufacturers engaged in interstate commerce, radio stations, telephone exchanges or railway terminals. This ruling will apply even though the power is produced entirely for consumption within the State.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- WPA-operated cooking units which provide hot luncheons for school children are to be made available for feeding adults in a war emergency.
Lieutenant T. Suffern Tailer, in 888 Park Ave; Clara M. Kjose, in 40 E 62d St; John A. Stewart, in 243 E 46th St; Mrs. Lillian Kitty, in 301 E 21st St; Douglas L. Elliman Co, brokers.

The railroad managements in the last few weeks have found it increasingly difficult to understand some of Washington's policies. They believe they are contributing as much as or more than any other industry toward winning the war, but they find themselves increasingly handicapped in their effort by the decrees of government bureaus.
PHILADELPHIA, April 19 -- The Philadelphia Americans defeated the Kearny Scots-Americans, 3 -- 2, in the replay of the National Challenge Cup Eastern semi-final today.

PITTSBURGH, April 19 (AP) -- Rookie John Beazley allowed four hits today as the Cardinals shaded the Pirates, 3 -- 2, but his fine effort almost became a masterpiece of futility in the ninth, when the Buccos scored their runs without a hit.

ST. THOMAS, Virgin Islands, April 19 -- A realistic air raid drill which warned 12,000 residents here of the "approach" of enemy aircraft and sent many of them scurrying to raid shelters was described tonight as "entirely satisfactory." It was the first such drill on the islands.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices increased to 105.6, a change of 0.2 per cent over the previous week. In two of the major commodity indexes, semi-manufactured and finished goods, there were but few individual changes, and increases were balanced by decreases.

The Queens R.C. defeated the Boston R.C., 16 to 0, in an Eastern Rugby Union contest at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday. Queens fielded fourteen men and Boston only twelve, including two players borrowed from the New York R.C. and one from Queens.

As fire-fighters finished their work yesterday and salvage crews went back to an increasingly complicated job, naval and police officials were silent concerning the latest fire on the former French liner Normandie off West Forty-eighth Street.
NEW DELHI, India, April 19 (AP) -- A British communique on Burma follows:
Sales of loft buildings featured realty trading reported in Manhattan over the week-end.

The four-story apartment building at 210 Westchester Avenue, Port Chester, in Westchester County, was sold by Thomas V. Kennedy, William H. Bassett and Simon H. Scheuer, as successor trustees in the Lawyers Westchester Mortgage and Title Company Issue 4-5812, to investing clients of Wolf Kohn, attorneys.

READING, Pa., April 19 (AP) -- Joe Chitwood, Indian driver from Reading, dominated Promoter Ralph Hankinson's 1942 automobile speed inaugural today before more than 26,000 fans when he established a new half-mile track record, finished first in a match race and then won the feature 10- mile event.

The massed colors of the United Nations standing out in bold relief as their symbol, 8,000 persons marched up Sixth Avenue early yesterday afternoon in a picturesque demonstration calling attention to the United China Relief drive.

LONDON, April 19 -- Financial London's reaction last week to the biggest British budget on record was the smallest on record. It accepted it with the philosophy and fortitude which the markets learned long ago to display. The public expected a budget and it certainly got one.

Speaking on the twenty-fifth anniversary of his pastorate, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman declared in his sermon yesterday in Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, that "the church today is more independent in its judgment and more conscious of its power than it was when I began my ministry twenty-five years ago."

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 19 (AP) Alsab, the bargain colt owned by Albert Sabath, is a 3-to-2 choice among the nation's sports writers and radio sportscasters to win the sixty-eighth Kentucky Derby here May 2.
PHILADELPHIA, April 19 (U.P.) -- Athletes from the armed forces may steal part of the spotlight from the college track stars at the forty-eighth annual Penn relay carnival Friday and Saturday.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., April 19 -- J.L. Perry, president of Carnegie Illinois Steel Corporation, denied tonight that the company had violated priority regulations. Both he and H.E. Lewis, president of the Jones Laughton Steel Corporation, expressed surprise at charges made by the War Production Board.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The War Production Board accused today the Carnegie-Illinois and Jones Laughlin steel corporations, two of the largest in the country, of "repeated, deliberate violations of priority regulations" from May 31, 1941, to the present time.

Victors in exceptionally well played games, Samuel Reshevsky of Boston, the defending champion, and Isaac I. Kashdan of the Manhattan Chess Club, were still tied for first place at the close of the afternoon session in the eighth round of the championship tournament of the United States Chess Federation at the Hotel Astor, yesterday.

Quiet strength in the Canadian dollar was the only incident of an otherwise dull week in the foreign exchanges. At the closing price of 87.31 cents, Dominion remittance was up 7/1 cent over the previous week, and a recovery of all the ground lost in the last month.

Just how a family will budget its sugar rations undoubtedly will be as highly individual a matter as its monetary budgeting. To many, sugar in coffee is a definite "must." Others, who prefer to savor its pristine flavor, will have precious extra ounces to sweeten the grapefruit, which, in its natural state, seems to them quite inedible.

OLD BEDFORD VILLAGE, N.Y., April 19 -- In the presence of a fair-sized gallery, the final awards were made late today in the annual meeting of the Southern New York Field Trial Club, bringing to a close the three-day meeting.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 15 -- Nearly doubling her trade figures of 1940, the United States maintained last year a commanding position as Bermuda's leading supply source with total imports here from American markets 1,154,064.

ALBANY, April 19 -- The legislative session enters its fifteenth and final week tomorrow, with virtually all major problems well under control. This is fortunate for procedure, since the adjournment resolution adopted ten days ago is irrevocable. While the clock can be stopped to give the leaders leeway, no new legislative day can be started after 4 P.M. on Friday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19 (AP) -- With Buck Newsom unhittable in the pinches, the Senators rallied to defeat the Athletics, 5 -- 4, and earn a split in a double-header today. Philadelphia took the first contest, 5 -- 1.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The War Department communique based on reports received until 1 P.M. said:

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Although vastly outnumbered and facing an enemy who has large quantities of modern war implements, including arplanes, at his disposal, General Jonathan M. Wainwright's scattered forces of American and Filipino soldiers continue not only to offer stubborn resistance to the Japanese invasion of the islands of Cebu and Panay but also in daring forays to inflict telling blows on the foe in the hills of Northern Luzon.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 19 -- The Southwest Pacific Command of the United Nations came into final being today with General Douglas MacArthur in the position of Commander in Chief operating from headquarters in Australia.

Civic workers and resort men whose interests lie in the profitable operation of the many beaches in the metropolitan area should take heart from the reassurances of public officials in the past few days that as far as can be foreseen now this Summer should not witness basic curtailment of waterfront pleasure and amusement.

Rereading yesterday your issue of April 13, I came across Aida Campbell's communication urging prayers for the armed forces. Miss Campbell's letter fairly warmed my heart. Quite properly, in its all-out war effort our nation is mobilizing on a tremendous scale its material resources; I have seen almost no mention made of the part that our spiritual strength must play in the conflict we face if we are to come out the victors.

Favorable weather stimulated retail demand last week in most kinds of seasonal apparel and accessories for immediate delivery, as buyers held back additional purchases of Fall and Winter staples to await the anticipated "freezing" of all prices, according to a summary prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident offices.

Women artists are being hauled out of their ivory towers for the duration, but they do not have to give up their painting to help in the war. Instead of joining factory assembly lines, they can help to disguise those factories so that enemy bombers, in the split second of confusion caused by the sight of an unfamiliar object, will miss their mark.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 19 -- Exemptions of Japanese wives of Filipinos from the Army's evacuation order requiring all persons of Japanese descent to leave the Far West's military area No. 1 will be sought by the American Civil Liberties Union at the request of a Filipino organization.

Oral instructions given last night to the police emergency division ordered Emergency Squad 2 to report at 9 A.M. today at Fourth Street and the East River, where a civilian diver, hired by the Police Department, will make a descent to locate an automobile and possibly a body.

Unfortunately, there is plenty of evidence to indicate that American motorists still fail to understand the reality and the implications of the rubber shortage. The State Legislature of New York has just approved a bill which adopts the President's request that maximum speeds be limited to forty miles an hour.

Challenging Philip Murray's statement to the Senate Committee on Labor on the need for union security as a war production policy, the National Association of Manufacturers in a statement issued yesterday charged that any provision to that end as a condition of employment "is dictatorship."

PITTSBURGH April 19 -- While collections of scrap metal were still conducive last week to an easier flow, compared with a month ago, some shortages of that material, in addition to necessary repairs to furnaces, reduced the steel-ingot operating rate one point to 98 per cent of theoretical capacity, the first important decline in several weeks.

BOSTON, April 19 -- After being urged to compete by his wife, ailing Joe Smith, 27-year-old Medford milkman who feared he was too weak to attempt such a punishing task, today surprised even himself by winning the Boston A.A. marathon in the course record-smashing time of 2 hours 26 minutes 51 1/5 seconds.

The United States will win the war and outlast any government based on oppression and tyranny, Lieutenant Governor Charles Poletti declared yesterday afternoon before a conference of the Division of Fraternal and Benevolent Organizations of the Jewish Education Committee of New York at the Hotel Astor.

An account of an entire hospital staff remaining on duty twenty-four hours a day for ten days, of operating teams working in ceaseless relays for several days, of convalescent patients rising from their sick beds to nurse emergency cases and of the way sulfanilamide therapy is revolutionizing the treatment of wounds was given here yesterday by Captain Reynolds Hayden of the Navy's Medical Corps.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 19 (AP) -- Bill Flesch of Mount Prospect, Ill., turned in an 1,884 series at the American Bowling Congress tournament today to take over second place in the two-year average list.

Cotton prices fluctuated irregularly last week and net changes were small. On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures contracts closed the week with net gains of 3 to 6 points, in contrast to net losses of 8 to 16 points in the previous week.

Customarily we think of silver in terms of currency. In this period of war production it is more important to think of silver in terms of current -- electric current. For silver, in addition to its other qualities, happens to have a very low resistance to electric current.

Mayor La Guardia is expected to attend the showdown session of the Police Pension Fund at police headquarters today rather than send a deputy to press his determined stand to limit retirements from the department to the prewar average of forty a month, it was reported last night.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The War Production Board has designated 500 plants in thirty-two States as full-fledged participants in the nation-wide campaign to accelerate the production of armaments.

French children in the parish of l'Eglise du St. Esprit, many of whom have arrived in the country since the beginning of the war, will be aided by a tea to be held on Friday at l'Ecole Francaise du St. Esprit, 109 East Sixtieth Street. Countess de la Mare de Boutteville 'heads the committee in charge of plans for the benefit.

Caterina Jarboro, Negro soprano, who made her recital debut here three months ago, last night gave her second Town Hall recital of the season. It was under the auspices of the New York branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
JERSEY CITY, April 19 (AP) -- Jersey City took both ends of a double-header from Toronto today, 6 to 2 and 1 to 0.

DETROIT, April 19 (AP) -- Despite the difficulties of conversion to war production, the automobile industry, after automobile output had been halted, turned out military equipment in February equaling 27 per cent of its entire 1941 production of the kind, Ernest Kanzler, chief of the automotive branch of the War Production Board, said today.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- The American Federation of Labor asserted today that war workers were facing "economic disaster" because of "failure of the Office of Price Administration to enforce, effectively and vigorously, price ceilings on consumer goods, and to institute fair and democratic rationing."
Only four new films will arrive on Broadway this week. The schedule is as follows:

LONDON, Monday, April 20 -- Early establishment of joint Anglo- American air headquarters in Britain, resulting from conferences here of General George C. Marshall, was predicted today by competent military observers.

I noted with pleasure the article in THE TIMES regarding the number of periodicals whose cover designs will "flaunt the national emblem" around July 4. That article says, "No printed word may be impressed upon the flag."

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., April 19 -- New furniture designs and stylings, plainly testifying that wartime freezing of materials is taxing the ingenuity of designers and manufacturers alike, confronted a record week-end attendance of buyers at the annual Spring exposition of the Jamestown Furniture Market Association that opened here yesterday.

Stray dogs and cats, whose dimensions and colorings for the most part violated all accepted standards, had their day -- and then some -- at the Ellin Prince Speyer Hospital's annual pet show yesterday in the Hotel Roosevelt. Not only was the off-key purr and bark tolerated willingly but the mixed participants were linked formally to the war.
WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- Selection of twenty-three naval officers for advancement to the next higher grade upon retirement was announced today by the Navy.

" What Big Ears!" co-featuring Taylor Holmes and Ruth Weston, is tonight's premiere at the Windsor. The new entry marks the debut of L. Daniel Blank and David Silberman as producers and of Arthur Pierson, actor, as a Broadway director.

Last week the King of England conferred the George Cross on the island fortress of Malta, "to honor her brave people" and "bear witness to heroism and devotion that will be long famous in history." Awarding a medal of valor to a place is without precedent, but so is the endurance of this island citadel.

SEATTLE, April 19 (U.P.) -- The Japanese-American Citizens League of Seattle met last night for what was probably its final session before members are evacuated by order of the Western Defense Command. Delegates, nevertheless, pledged full cooperation with the government in all evacuation steps.

Chief Judge Irving Lehman of the Court of Appeals, who is honorary president of the National Jewish Welfare Board, paid tribute to the organization's services in war and peace during a quarter of a century at a founders dinner at the Hotel Commodore last night.

Speaking in behalf of the Presbyterian United World Emergency Fund in his sermon yesterday in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell dwelt on the heroism and sacrifices of the Chinese in their struggle against Japanese aggression for the last five years, and the debt that Americans and all free peoples fighting against totalitarian domination owe to China.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 19 -- It is officially announced in Helsinki, Finland, that on May 1 monthly rations of meat will be further reduced. Other reports reaching here indicate that on the eve of the offensive in which Adolf Hitler expects Finland to take an important part the food situation has further deteriorated.
McALESTER, Okla., April 19 -Fighters, Incarcerated, an organization of life-term convicts, appealed to President Roosevelt today for a chance to perform suicide missions in the war.

Just as centuries before Christ men cried out to God in their trouble, so today they are crying out in the distress of their souls for a faith upon which they can pin their lives, the Rev. Laurance I. Neale declared in his sermon yesterday in the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The War Department reported today that "our flag on Corregidor was a casualty for a few minutes yesterday."

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- Specialists of the Bureau of Dairy Industry are starting a campaign to eliminate under-grade cheese and improve the quality of 900,000,000 pounds of American cheddar cheese expected under the 1942 production goals.

Hitler is not primarily the cause of our difficulty but the manifestation of a condition, for this pagan never could have arisen in a world that was trusting in God and living as our Heavenly Father would have his children live, the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer declared yesterday in his sermon in Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street.

The German-controlled Amsterdam radio yesterday quoted a correspondent of the Japanese newspaper Yomiuri as bemoaning the thorough scorched earth tactics of the Chinese defenders in Burma, who leave nothing of value behind. The broadcast was recorded at the Columbia Broadcasting System short wave listening station. Here is the text:

PHILADELPHIA, April 19 -- John D.M. Hamilton, former Republican National Chairman, asked the House members of his party, in an open letter today, to take a united stand on the war. He warned against conducting the Fall campaign "primarily as partisans, capitalizing on irritations against the national Administration."

Philip Krumholz, Inc., has purchased from the City of Bayonne a parcel of fifty lots located on Broadway, Kelly Parkway and East First Street, Bayonne. The price was $19,000. The buyer will erect fifty two-story brick and frame dwellings on the site to accommodate 100 families.

All is well in Flatbush again. The Dodgers may have been handcuffed by Rube Melton on Saturday, but they proved yesterday that there was nothing wrong with the club that a few timely base hits would not cure. With Dixie Walker supplying most of the power, the Brooks routed the Phils, 6 -- 2, to take the series, two games to one.

The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the Metropolitan Opera House last night restored to its season's repertory the "Afternoon of a Faun" and "Capriccio Espagnol." In the former Lubov Rostova, who has been absent from the company for several seasons, returned to her old role of the nymph, while George Zoritch was the faun.

In past seasons thousands of salt water fishermen, living within or close to the metropolitan district, have used the Long Island Railroad's Fishermen's Special to Montauk and other points as a means of reaching the fine salt water fishing which Long Island offers.

Democracy must develop an "offensive of a great idea," rooted in the principles of international justice and morality and at least equal to the "dynamic" attempt of the Axis nations to create a new world order, if it is to triumph in the war, Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen, Professor of Philosophy at the Catholic University of America, declared yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles Lane Poor of 35 East Sixty-ninth Street and Dering Harbor, Shelter Island, L.I., celebrated the fiftieth anniversary of their marriage last night at a small dinner in their home here for members of their family and the original wedding party.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 19 -- Foreign observers here foresee three causes for difficulties for France in the near future -- first, an awakening of public opinion to the facts attending the change of policy; second, the ambiguous position of Admiral Francois Darlan, and, third, industrial and agricultural production.

NEW ORLEANS, April 19 -- Unfavorable war news and apprehension over possible repercussions from the President's over-all anti-inflation drive accounted early last week for declines of as much as a dollar a bale in the prices of cotton here.

OTTAWA, April 19 (U.P.) -- Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King returned to Ottawa from Washington today and it is expected that he will have a statement to make to Parliament when it reconvenes tomorrow concerning Vichy's relations with Canada and the United States, the forthcoming United Nations air conference in Ottawa, and the matter of Canadian aid to Australia.

CHICAGO, April 19 -- A new factor developed last week as a price-making influence in wheat. This was the strained political relations between this country and France. It started a liquidating movement on the Board of Trade here by holders of futures which was not checked until the market had declined to the lowest level since late last November.

In spite of all that can be said of the economy and eventual necessity of refilling old lipstick cases with fresh sticks of paste, the most talented of women seem to balk at the idea. They vision crimson streaks on fingers or on furniture.

By the novel means of organizing its war savings bonds sales committees to represent old community subdivisions, many of which have existed since colonial days, the Bronx war bonds and stamps organization has begun a borough-wide sales campaign, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Joseph Coughlan, vice chairman of the Bronx organization and chairman of women's activities.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 19 (AP) -- Still grieved by the apparent death of his parents and bewildered by his own escape from Japanese, 13-year-old Robert Lacomble, son of a Netherland naval commander, has arrived in San Francisco in a group of several score Pacific war refugees that includes wives and children of wealthy commercial leaders and officials of the Netherlands Indies and Malaya as well as a number of wounded service men.
LONDON, April 19 -- The British Board of Trade's index of wholesale commodity prices in March is 158.8, compared with 158.5 for February and with 150.8 for March, 1941.

CHICAGO, April 19 (AP) -- The Reds made eight errors, were held hitless by Claude Passeau for seven and one-third innings but won today from the Cubs, 2 -- 1, in the fourteenth inning. None of the Redlegs' misplays figured in Chicago's run, scored in the sixth inning.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- The Treasury, in announcing today a war-bond quota campaign, said that the May quotas for States and counties would be released soon and would be "revised and stepped up in succeeding months." By July, it added, it was expected the campaign would bring war-bond purchases to more than twice the previous monthly totals.

" Dead soldiers can't use the things that are delivered too late," declared Lieut. Gen. Brehon B. Somervell in a tour of war plants, urging production speed and pointing out that "within the next 200 days we must win or lose the battle for a free world."

THAT'S the trouble with baseball in the American League. There are no more feuds in it. The fire has gone out. This was mentioned to Joe Cronin only yesterday, apropos of a recent picture showing Manager J.J. Dykes with an arm draped over the shoulder of a naval officer, the same being Lieutenant G.S. Cochrane of the Great Lakes Naval Training Station.

Voluntary subscription of $170,062 to a fund for the suggested purchase of an Army bomber by employes of the New York Central System "indicates an attitude of mind and a willingness to act that well might be emulated by all our people," James A. Farley, former Postmaster General, declared yesterday when a check for that amount was given to the Army at a ceremony in Grand Central Terminal.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 19 -- Their advance retarded in some sectors by densely laid enemy mine fields, the Russians nevertheless reported today that their offensive against the Finns was continuing satisfactorily. The fighting increased in intensity yesterday as the Finns hurled heavy reserves, including tanks, into the battle to try to stem the Russian advance, which was reported to have pierced the first defense line in one important sector.

LONDON, April 19 -- Percy E. Bates, chairman of the Cunard Steamship Company, in a statement published today preparatory to the board's annual meeting in Liverpool on April 29, pointed out the post-war possibilities of serious competition between air lines and transoceanic steamships for passengers. He described the war development of ocean flying as a barometer of the future.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Not only is there sufficient soap in this country to meet all needs, says the consumer division of the Office of Price Administration, but the heavy wartime demand for glycerin, a major by-product of commercially manufactured soap, makes home soap-making almost an unpatriotic conservation move.
BERLIN, April 19 (From German broadcast recorded by Reuter) -- A communique issued by the High Command today follows:

LONDON, April 18 -- Britain's problems of commodity prices remain largely unsolved. This is the conclusion drawn from last week's budget statement of the Chancellor of the Exchequer, inasmuch as it did not introduce adequate measures to remove the public's surplus purchasing power.

" Dead soldiers can't use the things that are delivered too late," declared Lieut. Gen. Brehon B. Somervell in a tour of war plants, urging production speed and pointing out that "within the next 200 days we must win or lose the battle for a free world."
H. Galka, auctioneer, leased the five-story warehouse at 234-36 East Forty-sixth Street through Huberth Huberth and Butler Baldwin, brokers.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 19 (AP) -- Lieut Gen. Akira Muto has been removed as chief of the Japanese Bureau of Military Affairs, the Tokyo radio said in a Japanese-language broadcast heard tonight by the Columbia Broadcasting System's listening station.

LONDON, April 19 -- Leaving shortly for his post in the Middle East, Richard G. Casey, former Australian Minister to Washington, tonight told Britain over the British Broadcasting Corporation network in a widely heard Sunday postscript following the "Nine O'Clock News" that the future of the world must be regarded with real alarm unless "the British Commonwealth of Nations and the United States maintain close, sympathetic contact and unity of policy."

Miguel de Capriles of Salle Santelli won the metropolitan open individual electric epee championship on the Salle Santelli strips yesterday. He won ten of his thirteen one-touch bouts. Eduardo Guirola, a clubmate, the victor last year, did not defend.

SELDEN, L.I., April 19 -- An estimated 2,000 acres of brush and scrub pine were destroyed in Suffolk County today by fire, and one of the fifteen fires reported threatened for a time this afternoon to reach a colony of Summer bungalows at Mastic. All the fires were out tonight.

CHICAGO, April 19 -- Establishment last week of new ceiling prices on many lines of cured pork products by the Office of Price Administration had relatively little effect on the market, but the tight situation reported in lard for the last two weeks appeared to be becoming more acute.

The war, which is deciding many small issues as well as large, has reached into many a family domain to stop an old argument. Now, with a few exceptions, no one can build anything larger than a chicken coop; so the new house that has been energetically and sometimes acrimoniously discussed hours without end can be gently laid aside for the duration.

CHICAGO, April 19 -- There was scattered liquidation in corn futures at times last week on the Board of Trade here, but the market showed considerable resistance to selling and closed yesterday at losses of 1 1/4 to l 7/8 cents a bushel for the week, with May at 85 7/8 cents, July at 88 5/8 to 88 1/2 and September at 90 3/4 to 90 5/8.

A large subscription has been reported for the performance of "Blithe Spirit" tomorrow night at the Morosco Theatre for the benefit of the House of St. Giles the Cripple, which gives care and treatment to crippled children. The benefit is sponsored by the Tiny Tim Society, the ladies' auxiliary of the institution, of which Mrs. Frank H. Traendly is president.

Major department and specialty stores agreed at the April meeting of the Retail Men's Wear Council to open the straw hat season in the period from May 18 to 21, depending on the individual store policies with respect to window changes. It was voted to devote windows exclusively to straws and omit felt hats from windows until June 8.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The War Production Board has undertaken a complete survey of the use of metal in the United States during the first quarter of this year and of anticipated requirements for the quarter beginning on July 1, it was announced today.

CHICAGO, April 19 -- The question whether the Republican party will adopt a broad international policy or avoid any declaration of what this policy should be when the present war is over will be fought out at a meeting of the Republican National Committee here tomorrow in action on resolutions, drafted by Wendell L. Willkie and Senator Taft of Ohio, who were rivals for the Presidential nomination in 1940.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 19 -- New titleholders were crowned in the national dinghy championships, which ended today at the Larchmont Yacht Club. Howard McMichael is the Class B leader, succeeding the four-year champion, Frank Campbell.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 18 (Delayed) -- The virtual wiping out on the Eastern Front of the entire air personnel with which the German air force entered the war is claimed by Major General of Aviation D. Grendahl in Red Star, the army newspaper.

Continuing his policy of using WNYC, the municipal radio station, as his primary means of telling the public about his officials activities, Mayor La Guardia devoted a substantial part of his weekly "Talk to the People" yesterday to criticism of the press, singling out THE NEW YORK TIMES and mentioning The Daily Mirror, accusing them of inaccuracies in editorials, headlines and news stories dealing with civilian defense matters and the controversy over police retirements.

American industry lost 1,500,000,000 man days as a result of accidents to its employes in 1941, the productive equivalent of forty-five battleships or 35,000 combat planes, William J. Simon, assistant to the executive vice president of the Greater New York Safety Council, asserted yesterday at a regional conference of the National Association of Chiropodists in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Determination of the American people to fight until victorious without complaining of the cost was voiced by newspaper publishers from every section of the country arriving here yesterday for the annual meetings of The Associated Press and the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

VICHY, France, April 19 -- Comparing France's present situation to that of June, 1940, Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, Chief of State, called the nation in a broadcast tonight to rally behind the government of Pierre Laval as it undertakes its task in national and European organization.

BUENOS AIRES, April 19 (AP) -- A spokesman for the Argentine Olympic Committee said today the Pan-American games would be held here this year despite the decision of the United States not to participate because of the war.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., April 19 -- Seton Hall opened its collegiate baseball season today by overwhelming Brooklyn College in a seven-inning game at Setonia Field, 16 -- 0.

A nation-wide campaign to increase sales of war savings stamps and bonds will be launched May 30 in 15,000 motion-picture theatres and continued for the duration of the war, the motion-picture industry's war activities committee announced yesterday.

A nation-wide campaign to increase sales of war savings stamps and bonds will be launched May 30 in 15,000 motion-picture theatres and continued for the duration of the war, the motion-picture industry's war activities committee announced yesterday.
The text of that part of Mayor La Guardia's broadcast referring to THE NEW YORK TIMES, as recording by THE TIMES, follows:

Determination of the American people to fight until victorious without complaining of the cost was voiced by newspaper publishers from every section of the country arriving here yesterday for the annual meetings of The Associated Press and the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

VICHY, France, April 19 -- Comparing France's present situation to that of June, 1940, Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, Chief of State, called the nation in a broadcast tonight to rally behind the government of Pierre Laval as it undertakes its task in national and European organization.

NEWARK, N.J., April 20 -- The Newark plant of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation was taken over today by Captain Samuel J. Zeigler of the Navy's Bureau of Aeronautics, on behalf of Captain George C. Westervelt. Captain Zeigler presented his orders to G.A. Luburg, plant manager, and immediately called a meeting of department heads.

Captain George C. Westervelt, Construction Corps, United States Navy retired, and Captain Wadleigh Capehart, U.S.N., arrived at the Long Island City headquarters of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation shortly after 4:30 P.M. yesterday and immediately went to the executive offices of the plant.

The New York State Bankers Association is notifying its membership that the Controller of the Currency has ruled that the restrictions on national banks preventing them from making a business loan of more than 10 per cent of their capital funds, do not apply in instances where the loans are guaranteed by the Army, Navy or the Maritime Commission.

The section of Brooklyn unaffected by last week's blackout drill will have its chance tonight from 9 to 9:20 o'clock. Barely onequarter of the borough's seventyone square miles will be affected, but the population included is estimated by the police at more than 968,000.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- President Roosevelt today commandeered and directed the Navy to operate four plants of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation, with-headquarters at Long Island City, because its existing management "has not proved adequate under the circumstances confronting it effectively to operate the corporation's plants" to assure delivery of combat aircraft needed for the war effort.
MOSCOW, April 20 (From Russian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau communique today said:

The second act of Mozart's "Don Giovanni" was presented in a concert version last night at the Concert Theatre. It was conducted by Laszlo Halasz, director of the St. Louis Grand Opera Association, who also conducted the Concert Orchestra, a new group of thirty musicians, in Rossini's Overture to "The Silken Ladder" and Wagner's "Siegfried Idyll."

Cotton prices yielded moderately in quiet trading yesterday. Apprehension over the French political situation and the reluctance of traders to make commitments until the effect of hedging, resulting from the recent sale of spot cotton by the Commodity Credit Corporation can be gauged better, were held responsible for the easiness in the market.
VICHY, April 20 -- Concurrently with his own return to power, Pierre Laval declared to the French people tonight that reconciliation with Germany is the only means of saving France.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Intimation that little space soon will be left on commercial airlines for ordinary civilian usage marked the announcement today by the War Department of the progress of negotiations for converting one-fourth of the commercial airline facilities to direct military operations.

Representative Michael J. Kennedy held yesterday his first levee as leader of Tammany Hall, receiving all but a few of the district leaders in the traditional leader's chambers on the second floor of the Tammany Building at Seventeenth Street and Union Square.
I was interested in your editorial "Rejected" and note that the third paragraph commences with the very natural question "Is it necessary?"

Pierre Laval's first appeal for French support of his new Government is precisely the appeal that one would expect to come from a renegade Frenchman whose very life now hangs on a German victory. He adopts complaisantly the whole Nazi theory of the origin and issue of this conflict.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Facing an imperative need for fliers, the Army Air Forces set out today to enroll students in every college for future training.

GLEN COVE, L.I., April 20 -Kuo Ching Li, president of the Wah Chang Trading Corporation of New York and of the Chinese Chamber of Commerce and a leading authority on antimony and tungsten, has purchased a six-acre waterfront business plot from Herbert L. Underhill, president of E.M. Underhill Son, North Shore contractors, and will establish a chemical plant there at once.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 20 -- Many lawyers working as salaried employes of title companies in the metropolitan area are becoming members of Local 96 of the Bank and Brokerage Employes Union, a C.I.O. affiliate, it was learned here tonight when union organizers announced plans to seek contracts with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company and the Security Title and Guaranty Company, both of New York and White Plains.

ALBANY, April 20 -- The Republican-controlled Legislature paved the way tonight for a legislative investigation of the State civil service. Legislators included an appropriation for $25,000 in the supplemental budget, made public by the Republican fiscal chairman, and reported out of the Assembly Rules Committee the Hollowell resolution calling for the investigation.
CLEVELAND, April 20 (AP) -Ken Keltner and Rookie Oris Hockett led the Indians' ten-hit attack today to give Veteran Al Smith a 4-to-3 victory in his first start of the season, against the Browns.

Back in January the campaign to collect 2,000,000 books for the men of the armed forces began. The mark has not been reached. The campaign is still going on this week. The small space to which most flat dwellers are confined makes their libraries diminutive. They have room for few books.

Resuming the uptrend in dollar volume, sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 12 per cent last week over the corresponding period of 1941, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Leon Henderson, Price Control Administrator, predicted last night a gap of at least $15,000,000,000 by the end of this year between national income and the amount of consumer goods that will be available, a situation which he described as "explosive" because of its inflationary potentialities from increased prices.

The latest in a series of recent realty transactions in the Chelsea area of Manhattan was reported yesterday when the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank sold to the Kenrob Corporation for cash above a purchase money mortgage of $262,000 the twelve-story loft building with a one-story extension at 245-51 Seventh Avenue, on the northeast corner of Twenty-fourth Street.

In his latest Sunday afternoon radio talk Mayor La Guardia charged that THE TIMES had been inaccurate: first, in an editorial, dealing with the recent "streamlining" of the city's civilian defense organization; second, in three news stories and headlines dealing with the controversy over police-retirement applications.

Last year's batting and pitching leaders in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League are picking up where they left off, according to the first official statistics released yesterday. George Hain of Pennsylvania, who won the Blair Bat in 1941, is well on his way toward repeating with an average of .529, and LeRoy Talcott of Princeton, undefeated in eight pitching starts as a sophomore, scored in his first junior outing.

Defeating the same outfit they beat the day they clinched the pennant last September, the Dodgers catapulted into sole possession of first place in the National League yesterday. They routed the Braves, 9 -- 2, before a gathering of 4,374 at Ebbets Field.

After testifying for an hour yesterday before the Bronx County grand jury that is hearing evidence in the paving of a courtyard on the Lake Mahopac estate of Edward J. Flynn, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, with city materials and labor, Borough President James J. Lyons was "entirely cleared of having any knowledge of the matter" by District Attorney Samuel J. Foley.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 20 -- Two Yale University engineers, Frederick E. Brooks and Herbert L. Krauss, have designed a remote-control apparatus for an automatic blackout of anything from a street light to a whole city.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., April 20 -- Murmuring of "mercy killing" as consciousness returned after swallowing twelve sleeping tablets, admittedly taken with suicidal intent, Daniel W. Cahill, 78, former State Superintendent of Buildings, confessed to District Attorney Carl J. Hynes in a hospital today that he strangled his wife, Mrs. Catherine Storer Cahill, 71, with the cord from his bathrobe as she slept at their home at noon yesterday.

AT high noon yesterday the Braves were tied for the lead in the National League and Manager Casey Stengel was in an expansive mood. His chest was out and his thumbs were hooked into the armpits of his weskit. As he talked, he swayed backward and forward rhythmically and blissfully. Every now and then he would take a hitch in his swing to emphasize a point.

HOLLYWOOD,, Calif., April 20 -- The first of a group of government-inspired films designed to further the war effort will be made by Warner Brothers as a feature picture and will treat of the exploits of the American Merchant Marine, it was learned today.

New York City welfare authorities, in cooperation with the local Work Projects Administration, are prepared at a moment's notice to utilize the facilities of WPA-operated cooking units in feeding the city's population in the event of a war emergency such as an air raid, it was learned yesterday.

Denying the charge by Mayor La Guardia that he was "dishonest" in the public statement that caused his removal, Paul J. Kern, ousted president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, declared in a new affidavit filed in Supreme Court yesterday that this "vilification" by the Mayor resembled "the conduct of a mentality bent with an almost psychopathic urge to impugn the integrity of all who refuse to bow abjectly to its indomitable whim."

Fashion has invaded the great entrance hall of the Metropolitan Museum. There, under the shadow of the austere sphinxes, to whom this must offer a new riddle to solve, stand three golden pavilions. Their slender columns harbor twenty-eight manikins of attenuated stature and exotic beauty.

The four-story apartment house on a plot 75 by 100 feet at 17-21 Fifty-first Street, Weehawken, N.J., has been sold by the Hudson County National Bank, trustee, to the Burland Realty Corporation. Sale of the structure, which is assessed for $66,000, was for a stated consideration of $47,500.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Tuesday, April 21 (U.P.) -- General Douglas MacArthur today named two American generals who accompanied him from the Philippines to head his staff for supreme command over the United Nations forces in the Southwest Pacific.

With sales on the Stock Exchange yesterday only 240,000 shares the market idled along on a fairly even keel. Price swings of any proportion were confined to a few issues. The volume was the third smallest in almost a year, and compared with 418,395 shares on Friday.

Anthony (Duke) Maffetore and Abraham (Pretty) Levine, both minor members of the Brooklyn murder ring, were freed of all criminal charges against them in Brooklyn yesterday when Kings County Judge Louis Goldstein suspended penitentiary sentences on the basis of their pleas of guilty to petit larceny in the theft of an automobile used in an underworld killing.
BOSTON, April 20 (AP) -- Jack Wilson, recent Red Sex castoff, held his former tam-mates to five hits today while hurling the Senators to a 10-4 victory.

PHILADELPHIA, April 20 -- The Virginia Public Service Company submitted today to the Securities and Exchange Commission a voluntary plan for simplification of its corporate structure in accordance with Section 11 of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

Following a three-hour executive session in City Hall yesterday at which Mayor La Guardia explained his executive budget of $612,698,761, the Board of Estimate decided to accept the Mayor's figures without changing a single dollar.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The successful torpedoing of a Japanese submarine by a United States submarine became known today coincident with the award of Navy Crosses to four commanders of United States submarines.

William B. Given Jr., president of the American Brake Shoe and Foundry Company, in the March quarter report to stockholders, announced yesterday that net sales increased to $15,300,000 from $10,500,000 the year before.

CHICAGO, April 20 -- Reports of further beneficial rains in the Southwest and advices from Washington that Senator Taft of Ohio had come out in favor of ceiling prices on all raw materials, including agricultural products, started general selling of wheat futures in the early trading here today.

With 600 newspaper editors and publishers present from all parts of the country, the annual meeting of The Associated Press at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria voted amendments yesterday to its forty-year-old by-laws to liberalize the election of new members to meet today's new and changing conditions.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 20 (AP) -Dean G. Darrow, an American sailor, who carried a Japanese bullet in his heart for four months without knowing it, was reported to be recovering today at a West Coast naval hospital.

Soon after the opening yesterday of the sixth week of the General Sessions trial of twelve men accused of an extortion racket in the retail milk industry, Judge Wallace, on the motion of Assistant District Attorney Aaron Benenson, discharged three of the defendants named in the forty-five count indictment.
LONDON, April 20 -- New evidence reached London today that the United Nations own version of the war of nerves is having its effect on Nazi-dominated Europe.
BOSTON, April 20 -- The undefeated Fordham baseball team scored its seventh straight victory today, beating Boston College, 1 -- 0, in the Eagles' opening game, which was cut to five innings.

RICHMOND, Va., April 20 (AP) -The Federal Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals took under advisement after five hours' argument today the appeal of six States and State court receivers in West Virginia from a decision of the Federal District Court of Southern West Virginia assuming jurisdiction over the reorganization or liquidation of the $25,000,000 Fidelity Assurance Association of Wheeling, W. Va.
NEW DELHI, April 20 (AP) -British Headquarters issued the following communique today:

The Body and Mind Foundation, Inc., of which Dr. Edward Spencer Cowles, well known psychiatrist, is director, is accused in an information filed by the New York County Grand Jury of having violated the State laws governing the practice of medicine.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -President Roosevelt conferred with Congressional leaders, and with Secretary Hull, General Marshall, Ambassador Winant and Harry Hopkins, who were his luncheon guests. He nominated J. Webb Benton of Pennsylvania and John W. Dye of Minnesota to be consuls general, and withdrew the nomination of Murray Elman to the post-mastership at Milburn, N.J.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- New Japanese batteries using 240-mm. guns, which fire shells nearly 9 1/2 inches in diameter, blasted away today at Corregidor and Forts Hughes and Drum, at the entrance to Manila Bay, causing some casualties and damage, the War Department reported tonight.

AN AMERICAN AIR BASE, India, April 20 (U.P.) -- Major Gen. Lewis H. Brereton arrived today and decorated the crews of two Flying Fortresses that he led on damaging attacks against Japanese warships in the Andaman Islands.

Addressing the closing session of the National Jewish Welfare Board's twenty-fifth anniversary conference in the Hotel Commodore yesterday, Major Gen. Irving J. Phillipson, commanding officer of the Second Corps Area, praised the work of the board and other United Service Organizations as "invaluable in terms of Army morale."
CHICAGO, April 20 -- Following is the text of the resolution adopted today by the Republican National Committee:

Winners of the United China Relief poster contest, conducted among public school children last week at the organization's headquarters, 1790 Broadway, were announced yesterday by Frederick H. Wood, Greater New York committee chairman.

ALBANY, April 20 -- The policy of the State Association of Young Republican Clubs has been anti-isolationist for the past two years, Ralph Becker, retiring president declared today. His statement was designed to answer the move by supporters of Wendell L. Willkie to elect a ticket of their own at the convention of the association to be held in Hamilton, N.Y., on May 16.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Secretary Hull returned to his desk today after an absence of more than two months and expressed satisfaction over the progress of this country's war effort, "particularly in the production of war supplies for the figthing fronts."

From the early season reports at hand from game protectors the Conservation Department states that thousands in New York State "have enjoyed the best early season in many years" from the standpoint of both the size of the trout and the number taken.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Secretary Morgenthau said today that State quotas for the Treasury's campaign for the voluntary purchase of war savings bonds would be announced Thursday evening.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Pending House measures intended to place labor unions under the regulation of anti-trust statutes and bring them within the provisions of the anti-racketeering law of 1934 were condemned by spokesmen for organized labor today before the subcommittee of the House Judiciary Committee.

Should German and Japanese bombing planes span the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans and rain tons of bombs on American cities it is unlikely that they could do more to impair our war production than the citizens of the United States do each year through carelessness, Joseph B. Eastman, Director of the Office of Defense Transportation, declared last night at the tenth annual award dinner of the National Traffic Safety contest.

LONDON, April 20 -- One of the lesser known aspects of American-British grand strategy relates to an agreement in principle between Washington and London that an increase in production of all types of food products on British farms to save shipping space is a cardinal point in Allied war plans.

LOS ANGELES, April 20 -Heedless of the fact that the offer of the Transamerica Corporation to acquire common stock of the Pacific Finance Corporation was made to holders of record of last Friday, stock market traders pushed the stock up to $15 a share today, although it later gave up a portion of the advance.

JERSEY CITY, April 20 (AP) -Toronto registered its first victory of the International League season today, defeating Jersey City, 2 to 1, behind the effective three-hit pitching of Southpaw Joe Sullivan.

LONDON, April 20 -- A combined counter-assault by British and Chinese forces on the Burma oil town of Yenangyaung has resulted in its recapture from the Japanese, it was reported today from Chungking. Despite this success, it was said here that there was no great change in the general situation.

Hickey-Freeman Company yesterday officially opened its Fall clothing lines with retail advances averaging about $3 over the present Spring level and about $5 over the Fall, 1941, basis. The line starts at $68 and goes as high as $110.
Lady Thornton has arrived from Mechanicsburg, Pa., and is at the Madison.

Addressing 1,400 persons at the centenary dinner of the Board of Education at the Waldorf-Astoria last night, James Marshall, president of the board, predicted that education in the next hundred years "will get its greatest stimulus from psychology and psyciatry."

In the Fulton Fish Market the dealers still discuss the events of May Day, 1940. For it was on that date -- an event in local piscatory history -- that 276,000 pounds of silvery, spotted shad arrived from the waters of the Hudson. The haul, held by some to be the largest in twenty-five years and by others the greatest in half a century, has yet to be rivaled.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 20 -- United Nations bombers that raided Rabaul yesterday for the second successive day directly hit one Japanese ship, straddled others with near misses and severely damaged shore installations and buildings.

Mr. Burlingham here and there in the course of writing his note to the Mayor must have smiled at the thought of Mr. La Guardia in the role of Hamlet. This is the letter in which Mr. Burlingham gently urged the Mayor to treat the New York reporters with the same generosity which Prince Hamlet ordered Polonius to bestow on the strolling Players.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Proposals in New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania to set clocks ahead an additional hour, either on State-wide or scattered community basis, were criticized today by Joseph B. Eastman, Director of Defense Transportation, as an action that would be "wasteful of necessary public transportation facilities."

BERNE, Switzerland, April 20 --As Pierre Laval appealed for French unity in support of his policy of "collaboration" with Germany, reports of renewed tension came tonight from the French zone occupied by the Germans.

Thomas Walsh, 73 years old, a civilian diver, walked the bed of the East River from the foot of Fourth Street to the foot of Sixth Street yesterday on the first lap of a hunt for the body of Patrick Walsh, a police sergeant who vannished on Sept. 9, 1939.

" Of V We Sing," the topical revue, will come to the end of its course at the Concert Theatre, 202 West Fifty-eighth Street, on Saturday night, at which time the show will have had seventy-four performances there. Originally presented off Broadway by the American Youth Theatre, an ambitious group of torchbearers, the musical found shelter at the Concert on Feb. 11 under the combined auspices of the A.Y.T. and Alexander H. Cohen.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- President Roosevelt decided today to send a message to Congress and make a "fireside chat" to the nation next week, probably Monday, outlining Administration policy for combating inflation and holding down the cost of living during the war.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The House passed today and sent back to the Senate a bill authorizing expenditure of $800,000,000 on the Navy's shore facilities. As passed by the Senate the measure originally authorized expenditure of $1,000,000,000 without specifying any of the projects, and it was amended by the House Naval Affairs Committee to give a general indication of the facilities to be constructed.

United States Steel Corporation reports foreign holdings of its common stock numbering 493,500 shares, or 5.7 per cent of the issue, on March 31, comparing with 491,875 shares, or 5.6 per cent, held by foreigners on Dec. 31. Preferred shares held abroad were 56,017, or 1.5 per cent, against 56,992, also 1.5 per cent, three months before.

The Members Art Show of the New York Junior League will open Thursday at the clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street, with a luncheon, at which the judges of the show will be guests of honor. They are Hobart Nichols, Roy Brown, Herbert Adams, Paul Manship, Miss Isabel Bishop, Wayman Adams, Albert Sterner, Miss Georgia O'Keefe and Miss Marguerite Kirmse.

Gertrude Lawrence, the versatile and volant star of "Lady in the Dark", is sponsoring a one-man exhibition of portraits of stage celebrities by Paul Meltsner. It is being held at the Ferargil Gallery, 63 East Fifty-seventh Street, and will be throughout the week.

LONDON, April 20 -- Three German fighter bombers -- ME-109s -came over a South Coast town early this morning, attacked a train with cannon and machine-gun fire and then dropped bombs that caused a small number of casualties, three of which were fatal.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 20 (AP) -- Two of Emerson F. Woodward's Valdina Farms' Kentucky Derby entries, Valdina Orphan and Hollywood, not only pleased Trainer Frank Catrone but set railbirds talking at the Churchill Downs workouts today.

In New York 1,700 women no longer need to telephone garages if their automobiles come to an unexpected halt. Graduates of motor mechanics courses, they are capable of lifting up the hood and diagnosing the trouble.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 20 -- Brig. Gen. Elmer Adler, who is leaving his post here as chief of the air section of the United States North African military mission for an assignment in another war theatre, said today that "my experience in his part of the world has convinced me more than ever before of the important part the air forces play, will play and must play on the whole team."

Pointing out that "the efforts of every citizen and every institution must be directed toward an American victory," the tenth year report of the New York Hospital-Cornell University Medical College Center made public yesterday emphasized the part the institution was playing in the war.

Several younger members of society are aiding in the sale of tickets for two performances of "Angel Street" at the Golden Theatre in behalf of philanthropy, that tonight for the benefit of the Catholic Center for the Blind, and on the night of April 30 in aid of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies.

Completion of the previously mentioned deal whereby Hunt Stromberg would become associated with United Artists as an independent producer was announced yesterday afternoon at a reception marking the signing of the contracts in the executive offices of U.A. at 729 Seventh Avenue.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 20 (AP) -- Sylvester W. Labrot's Sunset Boy dealt a hard blow to form players by defeating Mrs. Walter M. Jeffords's Seamanlike in the Jarrettsville Purse today. Sunset Boy, gelded last Winter, came to the outside and wore down the heavy choice to win by a length and a half in a field of eight, with John L. Sullivan's Cold Crack third.

The typical New York boy raid messenger and the typical New York girl war work volunteer were officially designated yesterday by Frank L. Andrews, president of the Hotel New Yorker and chairman of the Greater New York Boys and Girls Week.

Japanese military spokesmen still appeared confused last night in their attempts to account for bombing raids that they said struck four of the principal Japanese cities on Saturday, and they seemed to be indulging in a guessing contest, possibly in the hope of eliciting definite information from this side of the Pacific.

Oh, oh, oh! Nobody knows the trouble you get in by going to see plays on opening nights. Take, for instance, "What Big Ears!", which opened at the Windsor last evening. Jo Eisinger and Judson O'Donnell wrote it under the impression, perhaps, that "Charley's Aunt" is a brisk farce worth imitating.

Without abandoning hopes of staging the classic elsewhere, the board of stewards of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association announced yesterday that the organization's forty-fifth regatta definitely would not be held at Poughkeepsie this year

LONDON, April 20 -- The stock markets were firm again today. Gilt-edge issues advanced fractionally. In the industrials the breweries were a feature, with rises of 3d to 6d. Marks Spencer improved, but the rayons and textiles were easier. Courtauld lost 3d.

Commercial bank depositaries in the New York Federal Reserve District were notified yesterday by the Treasury that it will withdraw from its balances with these banks $47,306,000 on Thursday and a like amount on Friday. The calls for the entire country will amount to $73,583,000 on each day.

In its ninth report, which covers the period from July, 1940, to February, 1942, the League Loans Committee (London), of which the Earl of Bessborough is chairman, asserts that as a result of the extension of the war in Europe the service of the greater part or the whole of the bonds of each of the League Loans is in default.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the new War Manpower Commission, said today that the machinery for making certain that all available manpower was utilized for war production would include a labor priorities system as well as provision to discourage the "pirating" of labor by competing employers.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The movement for returning American and European Axis diplomats will begin on or about ay 5 when the Swedish liner Drottningholm, which has been chartered for the purpose, will sail from New York for Lisbon with Axis representatives, the State Department announced today.

Johnny Longden and Billy Thompson repeated their performances of Saturday at Jamaica yesterday when Longden had another triple and Thompson rode the winners of the first two races for the daily double. For Don Meade, who had piled up eighteen victors and most of the meeting's cheers, there was the experience of hearing jeers instead.

Thousands of tons of scrap metal and other strategic materials are lying unused on railroad sidings, piers and in private corporation yards, Arthur E. Corbin and Frank S. Williams of the Special Projects Section of the Bureau of Industrial Conservation, a division of the War Production Board, reported yesterday.

Among those reported yesterday as having signed leases for new residential quarters was Gustoaf Miesegaes, president of Transfilm, Inc., who leased the nine-room apartment at 450 East Fifty-second Street through the Harold C. Samuels Company, broker.
Leases with a variety of businesses centering in the midtown section were reported yesterday by brokers and agents.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The traditon that "the show must go on" was laid down tonight as the primary rule of safety for theatres and their patrons in the event of air raids. This injunction was stressed in a pamphlet issued by the Office of Civilian Defense entitled "Suggested Regulations for Theatres for Blackouts -- Air Raids."

THE NEW YORK TIMES of April 8, 1942, carried a dispatch from India outlining the policy of an "All India Moslem Conference," quite in contrast to the stand taken by the All India Moslem League. The following day in your editorial, "Indian Unity," you referred to this organization.

A veiled hat occasionally veered into view. A soft tone thrilled through the hum of masculine conversation Thus, yesterday, in the bustle of the annual conventions of The Associated Press and the American Newspaper Publishers Association at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, did the women publishers point up their presence, although far, far outnumbered.

OTTAWA, April 20 -- The question of the continued presence in Ottawa of a Minister representing the Vichy government, with consular agents in Montreal and Quebec, was raised in the House of Commons this afternoon by Opposition Leader R.B. Hanson.

Abe Simon, giant Richmond Hill fighter, who twice met Joe Louis, has retired from the ring, it was announced yesterday by his manager, Jimmy Johnston. This action was taken upon the advice of Simon's physician and the insistence of his wife, when it was revealed that if Simon continued in competition he might seriously impair his health.

DETROIT, April 20 -- In a press statement issued today at the Shrine of the Little Flower at Royal Oak the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin accepted full responsibility for the editorial policy of the weekly magazine Social Justice which he founded in 1936 and which last week was banned from the mails.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Floor and committee consideration of legislation to apply controls to labor and wages was suspended for a week today in response to a "personal and official" request by President Roosevelt that action, if any, await the delivery next week of an anti-inflation message to Congress and an address to the nation.

Louis Clay, Harvard's captain, took Columbia on a personally conducted tour from first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League down into third place yesterday at Baker Field, the Cantabs winning impressively, 5 to 2. It was the Lions' first defeat in three circuit starts and left Princeton and Dartmouth tied for the lead.
VICHY, France, April 20 -- Following is the text of Pierre Laval's broadcast to the French people today:

ST. PAUL, April 20 (AP) -- A new mechanical ear, called the symballophone, which traces the movement of sounds from place to place inside the human body, was shown at the American College of Physicians meeting here today.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The Office of Petroleum Coordinator announced today that deposits would be required to insure return of drums and other metal containers used in marketing petroleum products.

Two thousand women attended the four lectures in the fundamentals of home nursing, nutrition, air raid precaution and salvage that formed the program yesterday of Gimbel Brothers "Women's Spring Offensive." The all-day meetings are to continue through Saturday.

The reported bombing of Japan continued yesterday to be a minor mystery of the war, as enemy "explanations" contradicted and modified previous statements and the planes that participated disappeared beyond some "lost horizon" of the Orient.

TRENTON, N.J., April 20 -- Governor Charles Edison fired another shot today in his continuing battle with Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City when he appointed Senator Crawford Jamieson of Trenton to the Public Utility Commission. The nomination was confirmed immediately by the Senate.

A conflict between capital and labor was resolved yesterday in favor of the armed forces of the United States, at least as far as the price of shaves and haircuts are concerned in the barber shop of J.J. Albano at 628 Third Avenue.

A first mortgage bondholders' committee has been organized under the chairmanship of George H. Brown Jr., vice president of the Girard Trust Company of Philadelphia, for the Broadway-Exchange Corporation, owner of the thirty-three-story office building at 61 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The fire on the liner Normandie which resulted in its capsizing at its dock in New York while it was being converted into a transport was blamed today by a naval court of inquiry on "gross carelessness and utter violation of rules and common sense" by workmen employed by the Robins Dry Dock and Repair Company, Inc.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 20 -Pierre Laval's address to the French nation, broadcast from Vichy this evening, was heard with interest by foreign circles here, but before even venturing to comment on it, observers put this question: Is France yet aware of the statements issued in Berlin by the Wilhelmstrasse and the German official news agency?

Sixty-two applications of policemen for retirement were approved yesterday at the regular monthly meeting of the board of trustees of the Police Pension Fund, out of a record total of 295 applications. The cases not approved, which numbered 233 went over to the next meeting on May 18.

A plea for a more generous response to the Greater New York Fund this year than in 1941 was made yesterday by Lieut. Gov. Charles Poletti at a meeting of State department heads to organize for the current drive.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended April 15 aggregated $10,875,000,000.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The United States has sent a strongly worded protest to Vichy concerning reports reaching the State Department that several merchant vessels of the French fleet had been placed in Japanese hands in Indo-China waters, it was learned tonight.
BERLIN, April 20 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique said today:

PHILADELPHIA, April 20 -- The Rohm Haas Company, Inc., declared today that "there is not now, and never has been, any shortage of this company's transparent methyl methacrylate plastic sheet (plexiglas) for war purposes," adding:
The text of the address by Archibald MacLeish, director of Office of Facts and Figures, at The Associated Press annual luncheon yesterday follows:

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -Office of Price Administration officials said today that while the announced sugar allotment of five pounds a year per person for home canning purposes was "subject to change," no assurance could be given of an upward revision later in the Summer.

MONTREAL, April 20 -- Charles Vining, president of the Newsprint Association of Canada, said today that there was a sufficient supply of newsprint for North American consumers to tide them through 1942.

If, instead of canceling or curtailing appropriations, advertisers put their advertising to the service of their country, they would be helping to make it possible to earn profits tomorrow in a free and self-initiating economy, Walter J. Weir, copy director of Lord and Thomas, declared yesterday in a luncheon address before the National Newspaper Promotion Association at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The Western extension of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad, construction of which put the company into bankruptcy, pays under the stimulus of war, the annual report of the company disclosed yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, April 20 (AP) -The Cubs loosed a spectacular drumfire of base hits in the eighth inning today for six runs which gained them an 8 -- 2 decision over the Pirates.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 20 -- At a meeting devoted almost entirely to war problems, the Westchester County Board of Supervisors voted today to demand reimbursement from the State for the cost of sheltering evacuees, to hasten the construction of the county airport in Purchase and to seek development of a unified county bus system.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Tuesday, April 21 (AP) -- Russian front dispatches said today that Red Army units on the Leningrad front had captured seventeen strongholds in administering a shattering defeat to the 217th German Division.

LONDON, April 1 -- In the midst of a wartorn world and in a Britain that is slowly settling down to total war, the two Royal Princesses, Elizabeth and Margaret Rose, are growing up in as normal a way as is possible.

Plans were filed yesterday with the Department of Buildings for a defense housing project of 190 two-family dwellings in Great Neck, Queens, close to the Nassau County line. The buildings are estimated to cost a total of $950,000, or 5,000 each.

ALBANY, April 20 -- State Rationing Director Maurice F. Neufeld today urged retailers, wholesalers and institutional and industrial users of sugar to fill out their registration forms in advance of the trade registration dates.
