BERLIN, April 20 (From German broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York and London) -- Reichsfuehrer Hitler celebrated his fifty-third birthday today with a luncheon party at headquarters on the Eastern Front, but, at his own request, none of the guests brought him presents, the Transocean News Agency reported.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Today's radio address of Pierre Laval outlining his position followed expectations and was regarded as raising no new questions for action by the United States.

Net profit of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation in 1941 amounted to $25,717,512, a new high record and a gain of nearly two-thirds over the previous high of $15,746,874 recorded in 1940, according to the annual report issued yesterday by Guy W. Vaughan, president.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Continued priority violations by the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation and the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation would react to the "detriment of maximum efficiency in the prosecution of the war," the government asserted as it filed suits today against the two companies in Wilmington, Del., and Pittsburgh.

The Chinese recapture of Yenangyaung in the Irrawaddy oil fields is the first encouraging news to come from Burma since the British began their long retreat from Rangoon. It indicates that a continuous Allied front is now bridging the gap between the Irrawaddy and Sittang Rivers, as the Chinese move in for a stouter defense than General Alexander's exhausted British are able to maintain.

UNITED STATES ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Canal Zone, April 20 (AP) -- The largest field manoeuvres conducted in Panama since the start of the war have just ended with the theoretical repulse of an invading "yellow" army employing tactics used by the Japanese in the Pacific.

ALBANY, April 20 -- The use of a strengthened State Guard to repel possible raids by the enemy along the Long Island coasts was agreed on here tonight, after the proposal had been advanced by Assemblyman Moffat, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee.

The city of Albuquerque, N.M., will enter the market on May 19 with an issue of $505,000 of various-purpose bonds, for which bidders are asked to name the interest rate. The bonds, dated July 1, 1942, will mature serially on July 1, 1945 to 1962.

LONDON, April 20 -- An 18-year-old girl who formerly worked in a silk factory had her name inscribed on the War Office Roll of Honor today as the first member of the Auxiliary Territorial Service -- the women's branch of the British Army -- to be killed by enemy action while on duty at an anti-aircraft gunpost.

Thomas N. McCarter, chairman of the board of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey, informed shareholders yesterday at their annual meeting in Newark that the impact of taxes in the first quarter of this year had cut the utility's net income in half, compared with the same period last year.
HOLLYWOOD BEACH, Fla., April 20 -- The Most Rev. John F. Noll, Bishop of Fort Wayne, called today for a world crusade among Catholics for the regeneration of society through God.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The "real" pooling of United Nations shipping is essential to win the war, Harry L. Hopkins said today, as diplomatic quarters reported that means of combating shipping losses off the Eastern Coast of the United States was to be one of the subjects of Anglo-American conferences in Washington.

CHICAGO, April 20 -- Wendell L. Willkie succeeded today in removing the brand of isolationism from the Republican party when the national committee unanimously adopted a resolution declaring its realization that the United States had "an obligation" for world cooperation.

CHICAGO, April 20 (AP) -- Rookie Harry Sketchley's double that drove in two first-inning runs gave Johnny Rigney and the White Sox a 3-to-1 decision over Paul Trout of the Tigers in a pitchers' duel today.

Witold Malcuzynski came to his American debut at Carnegie Hall last night with nearly everything in his favor. The young Polish pianist won top prizes in his native Warsaw. He was one of the rare pupils Paderewski took on. He had a harrowing time escaping from the Nazis and from Europe, which entitled him to sympathy here.

Warning that the Axis is about to launch a new "peace" offensive this Summer, Archibald MacLeish, director of the Office of Facts and Figures, urged at the forty-second annual luncheon of The Associated Press at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday that the newspapers of the nation help bring about a united strategy of defense.

A curtailment of production in any one field by a stated percentage does not mean that advertising will be reduced by a similar amount, because in many industries non-advertised or private brands are feeling the pinch first, an agency executive pointed out yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (U.P.) -How does it feel to go into air battle against a flock of Japanese bombers? was the question put today to Lieutenant Edward H. (Butcher) O'Hare, the Navy's No. 1 air ace, who shot down six planes in a single encounter.

Grace Zaring Stone, who was revealed a few days ago as the author of "Escape," thereby clearing up the two-and-one-half-year-old guessing game about the identity of the Ethel Vance whose name was signed to the best seller, is completing a new book.

LONDON, April 20 -- The Russian army of the center was reported tonight to have drawn its big guns up to within range of Smolensk, base of German military power about 230 miles west of Moscow, while the Northern Russian forces were violently assaulting the main German and Finnish lines about Leningrad.

The Common Council for American Unity wishes to endorse your editorial protesting plans, reported from Washington, to suppress or license that part of the American press published in foreign languages.

Mayor La Guardia conferred yesterday at City Hall with the Building Service Employes International Union and members of the Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations on a new contract between the two groups to replace the one which expired yesterday.

Irving Chernev of Brooklyn and Louis Levy, former N.Y.U. representative, played to a draw last night at the Manhattan C.C. in an adjourned sixth round game in the United States Chess Federation championship. Sixty-two moves were recorded.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The War Department's communique based on reports received here up to 9:30 A.M. said:

The staggering of working hours for 120,000 municipal and private office employes started smoothly yesterday as a wartime measure to relieve rush-hour congestion on the subways and other transit facilities of the city. As a number of large business houses started the new system several weeks ago, it is estimated that 300 concerns with 150,000 employes are now cooperating.

The Phils made their 1942 debut at the Polo Grounds yesterday and they did not seem to have changed much from a year ago, except that they won the ball game. They downed the Giants, 6 to 3, by the simple process of doubling their home-run output of the new campaign.

The New York City WPA has marshaled its forces to funnel as many women as possible into war industries. On an average sixty women a day file into the offices at 70 Columbus Avenue to have their abilities and training reevaluated.

Combed Cotton yarn holdings of various knitters and weavers whose inventories are in excess of normal are about to be taken over by the War Production Board, according to reports yesterday, but actual "requisitioning" will be put off until after efforts to bring about "horse trading" by peaceful means have failed.

Women's slips and housecoats and furniture covers are listed among the articles that no longer will be equipped with zippers, according to an announcement yesterday by the consumer division of the Office of Price Administration.

LONDON, April 20 -- The United States now has about 6,000,000 persons engaged in war production and will need 10,000,000 more for the work to carry out President Roosevelt's program, R.J. Watt of the American Federation of Labor told a meeting here today of the governing committee of the International Labor Office.
The City College nine scored six runs in the first to rout Queens College, 10 -- 3, yesterday at Queens Field in the game postponed from April 11.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The Department of Agriculture today declared unequivocally that persimmons are "good eating." The same claim was made for pawpaws, Juneberries, buffalo berries, the high-bush cranberry of the Great Plains, the Western sand cherry and elderberries.

The board of directors of the Young Women's Christian Association of New York City re-elected Mrs. Cleveland E. Dodge first vice president at their annual meeting yesterday afternoon at the Studio Club of the Y.W.C.A., 210 East Seventy-seventh Street.

Harold I. Crow of Radburn, N.J., executive vice president of Air Associates, Inc., of Bendix, N.J., was elected last night president of the company to succeed Frederick G. Coburn, who became president last November after the United States Army took charge of the plant during labor difficulties.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -Walter R. Hutchinson, special assistant to the Attorney General, accused two American firms today of participating with German and English firms in an international cartel which had resulted in rigid restrictions on production of a plastic glass widely used in military aircraft.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Heeding the danger of threatened serious price advances by producers, Price Administrator Leon Henderson fixed temporary maximum prices at which manufacturers can sell oil, paints and varnishes at levels which prevailed on April 12, 1942, effective April 22.

FORT SNELLING, Minn., April 20 -- The Bulletin, publication of this Army camp, added today a department to provide "absolutely authentic" information for spies and all nosy people." Authored by Goofy Glotz, the first story included this information:

BERNE, Switzerland, April 20 -Reichsfuehrer Hitler observed his fifty-third birthday today at his field headquarters on the Eastern Front and beyond the congratulations of his immediate staff the day ran its course like any other day on the front.
PHILADELPHIA, April 20 (AP) -A hall of fame for college gridiron stars, patterned after baseball's hall in Cooperstown, N.Y., will be established in Franklin Institute, Philadelphia, this Fall.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, April 20 -- Nowhere in Australia do American soldiers receive a heartier welcome than in the north, where the arrival of the Americans coincided with the complete change in the aspect of the war in that area.

LONDON, April 20 -- The Duke of Norfolk, parliamentary secretary to the Ministry of Food, warned the public today that the government could not guarantee that the meat ration would continue at the present allowance of 1 shilling and 2 pence worth weekly per person and called on every one in Britain to grow his own vegetables either in his own garden or on the arable land assigned to him.

KEARNY, N.J., April 20 -- Mrs. Hazel Davis and her mother, Mrs. Anna Ellison, 71 years old, were fatally burned early today by a fire that destroyed the interior of their home at 25 Rutland Avenue, Arlington. Mrs. Ellison's husband, William, 76, and the Davis children, Lee, 16, and Howard, 11, are in West Hudson Hospital with severe burns.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 21 -- W. Arnold Hanger's Harvard Square won Keeneland Park's Calumet Handicap today and in doing so wrote a couple of question marks beside the name of Sun Again, the Calumet Farm's chief reliance for a Kentucky Derby victory. Sun Again finished second in the sixfurlong feature.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 19 (Delayed) -- Polish troops are now "somewhere in Iran." They will proceed to unspecified destinations. When this correspondent made a tour of one of their camps with their commander, a major general, he was told that they would be dispatched as soon as possible to areas where they were needed.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 21 -- Four top-ranking scholarships, carrying distinction because of demand for high scholarship, capacity for leadership, service and athletic achievement, were announced today by Yale University.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 21 -- Marcel Weinum, a youth of 18, has been shot at Strasbourg by order of the German authority immediately after a special court had found him guilty of "acts of sabotage and terrorism" extending over eighteen months.

Air raid alarms sounded again yesterday afternoon over Central and Western Japan, according to Axis radio broadcasts recorded here by The Associated Press and the United Press, while Japanese spokesmen continued to minimize the damage of Saturday's attacks on Tokyo, Yokohama, Kobe and Nagoya, still unconfirmed by the United Nations high commands.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The Federal Power Commission disallowed today $574,860 of the claimed cost of the Pennsylvania Power and Light Company's hydroelectric project in Pike and Wayne Counties, Pa., as "unwarranted company profits" and determined the actual, legitimate cost to be $8,573,895.
ST. LOUIS, April 21 (AP) -- The Cardinals shut out the Reds, 8 to 0, today as Mort Cooper turned in a masterful three-hit pitching performance. His younger brother, Walker, did the catching.

ALBANY, April 21 -- The Senate, by a vote of 27 to 19, passed and sent to the Assembly today the Wicks bill increasing the State's take on pari-mutuel race-track pools from 5 to 6 per cent and increasing the State's share of the "breakage" from 50 to 60 per cent. The measure, effective Jan. 1, would not affect racing this season.

LONDON, April 21 -- Heavy bombers of the United States Army Air Corps, the first of the all-American striking units that will soon fly wing-to-wing with the Royal Air Force against the Nazi continent, are being ferried to British operational bases, it was reported reliably tonight.

The pamphlet report for 1941 of the Great Northern Railway Company, issued yesterday, showed after charges and taxes a net income of $16,785,159, equal to $6.72 each on the 2,498,923 capital shares, compared with $10,208,194, or $4.09 a share, in 1940. F.J. Gavin, president, said the road's net income last year was less than in any of the years in the 1923-30 period, partly because of increased taxes.

Two speeches of outstanding importance were published in full in yesterday's TIMES. One was the address of Archibald MacLeish at the annual luncheon of The Associated Press. The other was the broadcast from Vichy in which Pierre Laval announced to the French people and to the world his program of "entente and reconciliation" with Hitler's Germany.
U.S. ARMY HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, April 21 (AP) -The first communique issued from General MacArthur's new Southwest Pacific Command said today:

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, April 21 -- There will be no deputy Commander in Chief in the Southwest Pacific but a spokesman explained unofficially today that because of his rank and seniority as the first ranking officer after General Douglas MacArthur this post falls virtually to General Sir Thomas Blamey of Australia, commander of the Allied land forces.

The by-laws of Sears, Roebuck Co. have been amended by the directors to eliminate all references to the powers and duties of the executive vice president, according to a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission made public at the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

Headdresses as well as hats were featured in the Summer millinery collection of Lilly Dache, shown yesterday in a press preview at her shop, 78 East Fifty-sixth Street. The collection emphasized materials unaffected by priorities, eliminations and shortages, using such unorthodox hat fabrics as papier-mache, cotton and paper string, scrim, organdie and cotton lace.

A proposal that P.S.A.L. athletes be permitted to engage in non-scholastic competition without penalty during regular seasons was rejected on a close vote by the high school games committee of the league at a meeting in the Hotel Astor yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Legislation empowering the War Production Board to draft executives into government service from private industry may soon be necessary as a result of the unjust criticism leveled by Congress, the public and others at business men in the war effort, Donald M. Nelson, production board chief, today told the Senate's Truman Committee, which is investigating progress of the war effort.
If Professor Casey Stengel picks the Dodgers to win another pennant hands down, nobody in the ladies' day crowd of 11,202 at Ebbets Field yesterday will be surprised.

LOS ANGELES, April 21 -- Directors of the Security First National Bank voted today to retire the remaining $6,000,000 of the bank's preferred stock, thus completing ahead of schedule a program which had been proceeding at the rate of $1,000,000 a year.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Broad strategy of the United Nations in the Spring military campaigns and production of sufficient military materiel to equip the fighting men were discussed at the White House today by President Roosevelt in a series of conferences with the diplomatic representatives of Soviet Russia, China Australia, New Zealand, the United Kingdom, Canada and the Netherlands.

A recent order from the commandant of the Third Naval District states that "Passengers and guests on vessels within the Third Naval District are not ordinarily required to have a Coast Guard identification card, but owners and operators will be held responsible that no act is committed inimical to the interests of the government."

Two girls, each about 12 years old, snatched a handbag from a Bronx housewife yesterday as she was going up the steps of a building at 540 Fox Street, the Bronx, and then one of the girls pulled the woman's coat, causing her to fall down a flight of stairs and break her right leg.

Possessed of neither a war contract nor priority rating, troubled by no wages and hours disputes (even on Sundays), one of the most efficient assembly lines of the city was observed yesterday as it worked on its war order, sending with utmost dispatch its material to the nation's armed services.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Wednesday, April 22 (U.P.) -- The Australian destroyer Vampire has been sunk in recent operations in the Bay of Bengal during which she and a British destroyer, attacking a superior Japanese force, sank one Japanese destroyer and damaged another, Prime Minister John Curtin announced today.

A sharp increase in infant mortality was noticed in New York City last week, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, reported yesterday. The death rate rose to 41 per 1,000 live births, contrasted with 33.3 the preceding week and 31.6 for this year so far.

A subcommittee of the House Judiciary Committee is conducting hearings on several bills intended to place labor unions under the regulation of anti-trust statutes and to bring them within the provisions of the anti-racketeering law of 1934. These bills are drawn with unusual care and restraint.

ANYTHING can happen on the big league diamonds in April. At the crack of the bat the Braves and Browns rushed off and posted themselves at the top of their respective leagues. It just goes to show. "April, April, laugh thy girlish laughter!"

After four years the troublesome Mexican oil controversy has reached the stage of final settlement. It has been a difficult problem that could easily have blocked the cause of hemisphere solidarity. There could be no question of Mexico's right as a sovereign nation to expropriate foreign-owned natural resources.

The New York County grand jury yesterday handed up to Judge Saul S. Streit in General Sessions indictments charging three men, two of them with previous police records, with a holdup and criminally bringing stolen property into the State.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21 -- The Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation applied today to the Securities and Exchange Commission for permission to retire $9,477,000 of twenty-five-year 5 per cent debentures due on May 1, 1952, and twenty-three-year 5 per cent debentures due on April 15, 1952.

The National Biscuit Company had a net profit in the first quarter this year of $2,431,289 after taxes and all charges, according to official figures announced yesterday. This is equal, after allowing for dividend requirements on the preferred stock, to 32 cents a share on 6,289,448 common shares.
BERLIN, April 21 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique said today:
PHILADELPHIA, April 21 -- The Yankees celebrated the fifty-fifth birthday of their manager, Joseph Vincent McCarthy, at Shibe Park today by battering the hapless Athletics into subjection, 10 to 4.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- In a joint statement issued today, Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, charged that the National Association of Manufacturers is "trying to slip over a fast one by having Congress freeze the injustices of the open shop by law."

MEXICO CITY, April 21 -- Authorized quarters here expressed the view today that the oil agreement went far toward disposing of long-pending obstacles to a rapprochement with the United States and that collaboration could now proceed unhampered.

The Engineers Public Service Company system spent $18,108,000 for the construction of new facilities last year, compared with $11,726,000 in 1940, D.C. Barnes, president, said yesterday in his annual report to stockholders. The major part of last year's expenditures was for electric transmission and distribution facilities and extensions to serve new customers.

Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow has accepted the chairmanship of the women's division of the USO's second campaign, which starts on May 11, Henry C. Brunie, general chairman of the Greater New York USO War Fund, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Doubt was expressed by Secretary of State Cordell Hull at his press conference today as to whether the French people would accept a policy of complete collaboration with Germany and the Axis under Pierre Laval.

LONDON, April 21 -- The threat of a great threefold attack in Burma looms as the British and Chinese defenders hasten to consolidate recent successes just south of Yenangyaung in the oil fields. Today's Allied communiques describing tactical reverses suffered by the Japanese also reflect the gravity of the picture as a whole, however.
CHICAGO, April 21 (AP) -- Lynwood (Schoolboy) Rowe kept the White Sox from passing second base until the ninth inning today, and the Tigers converted his six-hit pitching into a 4-to-2 triumph.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- The Army today modified physical standards for voluntary enlistment or induction of Selective Service recruits.
ALBANY, April 21 -- The Assembly today overwhelmingly defeated the Rapp bill providing for the retirement of all New York City teachers at the age of 65 instead of at 70.

John Raleigh, Columbia Broadcasting System correspondent, said in a broadcast from Australia yesterday that the United States destroyer Peary, acknowledged by the United States to have been sunk Feb. 19 at Darwin when the Japanese scored five direct bomb hits, previously had been bombed by the Australians by mistake.

Monday's meeting of trustees of the Police Pension Fund retired only thirty-nine able-bodied policemen of the 200-odd who had applied for retirement, Commissioner Valentine disclosed yesterday. Twenty-two others were retired for physical disability or prolonged illness.

To demonstrate the dependence of war production on adequate housing, the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, opened an exhibition of wartime housing last night with a preview and a nation-wide broadcast. The exhibition has been arranged in collaboration with the National Committee on the Housing Emergency.

LONDON, April 21 (AP) -- Great Britain already has a joint general staff working so closely together that its members share the same building and eat together, Prime Minister Winston Churchill said in a White Paper tonight.

With Mayor La Guardia turning in three mock alarms during the twenty-minute drill period, the northern quarter of Brooklyn was blacked out last night in another successful demonstration of the city's ability to turn off its lights under threat of attack.

NEWARK, N.J., April 21 -- Uninvited and unwelcome, FBI agents and local police went to Hitler birthday parties all over the State last night, arresting eleven enemy aliens, questioning 100 other head of the FBI, said sixty-two persons and confiscating contraband.

LONDON, April 21 -- Posthumous award of the Victoria Cross to Second Lieutenant George Ward Gunn, M.C., of the Royal Horse Artillery, and to Rifleman John Beeley of the King's Royal Rifle Corps for gallantry in battle at Rezegh, Libya, last November was announced today.

F.B. Davis Jr., president of the United States Rubber Company, and John L. Collyer, president of the B.F. Goodrich Company, emphasized at their respective annual meetings yesterday that it was the paramount duty of all to conserve rubber products. The Goodrich meeting was held here, while that of United States Rubber was held in Jersey City.

The fate of the burned and capsized liner Normandie, despite unofficial optimistic reports in shipping and naval circles since the disaster of Feb. 9, is far from settled and the ship may yet be scrapped, it was disclosed here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Lieutenant Edward H. O'Hare, the naval flier who single-handed shot down five Japanese bombers and damaged another in combat action off the Gilbert Islands on Feb. 20, was presented with the Congressional Medal of Honor today by President Roosevelt.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 21 -- Paul Henreid will play the male lead opposite Michele Morgan in RKO's "Challenge to the Night," repeating the starring combination of "Joan of Paris," the first American picture made by the two players, it was learned today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, April 22 -- Just over six months after they were driven from that key point of the "Stalin Line," Russian forces yesterday morning stormed the last line of German fortifications defending the eastern approaches to Smolensk, west of the Dnieper bend.

RICHMOND, Va., April 21 (AP) -- Robert R. Young, New York financier and chairman of the Alleghany Corporation, returned to control of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway today with the stockholders' election of five new directors to replace board members he once classed as allies of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York.

In planning a pleasant, leisurely luncheon for a sunny springtime day, a canny kitchen executive makes a wise choice in asparagus. She can build a memorable menu around the tender green stalks if they are served with a smooth cheese sauce rather than the traditional melted butter.

Eight thousand members of Local 32-B of the Building Service Employes Union filled the large auditorium and two additional halls at Manhattan Center, Thirty-fourth Street near Eighth Avenue, last night, at a rally called to hear the report of the union's officers on the negotiations for a new agreement now in progress with the Realty Advisory Board.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 21 -- Discovery of a new precursor of vitamin A, and its conversion into the vitamin, a feat never before accomplished in the laboratory, was announced here today at the annual Spring meeting of the American Chemical Society. The report was presented by Dr. Norris D. Embree and Edgar M. Shantz, of the Laboratories of Distillation Products, Rochester, N.Y.

A Federal retail sales tax has many advocates at this time because of certain obvious advantages. It is easier to administer than personal income taxes. It taps the spending power of those who account for the bulk of the wartime increase in income payments. It taxes consumption rather than saving.

BUENOS AIRES, April 21 -- Reports received here from Montevideo last night that the Argentine tanker Victoria had been torpedoed in the Caribbean were partly confirmed today when the Ministry of the Navy received a cable from the Argentine Embassy in Washington informing it that the Victoria was damaged but making way under her own steam to New York, where she was expected today.

ALBANY, April 21 -- Demolition of another of Manhattan's elevated structures in the very near future was indicated here tonight as the Assembly Rules Committee reported out the Jarema bill, authorizing the demolition of the Second Avenue "El" from Chatham Square to Fifty-ninth Street.
Andre Breton may as well -- certainly as well as any one else -- lead off this footnote on a Spring afternoon in Fifty-seventh Street.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -Secretary Stimson asked Congress today for legislation to increase the strength of the Cadet Corps at the United States Military Academy by about 25 per cent.

All war entertainments involving the use of professional talent will be routed through a new parent committee, known temporarily as the Actors War Activities Committee, which was organized yesterday afternoon at a meeting held in the New Studio Building of the Columbia Broadcasting Company, 49 East Fifty-second Street.

VICHY, France, April 21 -- Admiral Francois Darlan, on assuming his duties as Commander in Chief of the land, sea and air armies today, affirmed, in an order of the day broadcast to the forces, that he is to serve under the direct orders of Marshal Henri Philippe Petain.

LONDON, April 21 -- General Wladyslaw Anders, the commander of Polish forces in Russia, and General Kopanski, the commander of the Carpathian Brigade, which won fame at Tobruk and in the British Empire's Libyan offensive, arrived in London this afternoon to report on progress of organization of the Polish Army of the East.

The special offering of Snider Packing Company stock at 14 on the New York Stock Exchange, with special commission of 1/2 point, will continue this morning for the fifth consecutive business day. The stock was first offered at 10:43 o'clock on Friday morning by Auchincloss, Parker Redpath.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- High school and college students will be recruited for farm work during the Summer by the United States Employment Service, Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the new War Man Power Commission, stated today.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Following a telegraphic survey of steel plate consumers, the War Production Board announced today that users with excessive inventories will receive no allocations in May. A constant check is being made of plate inventories because demand continues at least 50 per cent in excess of supply, even though this is rising and is expected to exceed 900,000 tons next month.
In one of the tightest pitching duels of the local college season, St. John's defeated the Brooklyn College nine, 2 to 1, at Dexter Park in Queens yesterday, to remain unbeaten in four starts.

Major William J. Walsh, assistant selective service director for New York City, estimated that at lease 900,000 men would be enrolled in the five boroughs in the fourth draft registration on Saturday, Sunday and Monday.

Resignation of the entire faculty lunchroom committee of City College was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of the college, following a report by an alumni investigating committee that found the lunchroom had not been managed in an "efficient and businesslike manner."

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 21 (U.P.) -- The Red Army, bent on saving its initiative and paralyzing any German offensive before it starts, was reported tonight to be moving vast masses of fresh troops and equipment up to the entire front.

Into a book that will carry on its jacket a picture of a modern speed highway system and superimposed upon that a large sardine can with cover rolled back revealing a group of exceedingly crowded-in people, Jose Luis Sert will put some of the findings of the Congres Internationeaux d'Architecture Moderne on the subject of city planning.

Air raid wardens will be required to complete a six-week training course before being assigned to permanent active duty and receiving government equipment, it was specified yesterday in police orders issued by Commissioner Valentine.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The House passed by a voice vote today a Senate bill which would strengthen the law requiring registration of lobbyists, press agents and other representatives in the United States of foreign governments.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- An American Legion-sponsored bill which would authorize the President to fix prices of "any article, service or thing," license business and industry and require any person in the United States to do whatever war service was required of him was introduced today by Representative May, chairman of the House Military Affairs Committee.

TOKYO, April 21 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Tokyo radio broadcast, today a Domei dispatch quoting Toyohiko Kagawa, most famous of Japanese Christian leaders, as asserting that among Japanese Christians "prayers are being said daily for an early conclusion of the war and the restoration of peace throughout the world."

Eugene Loring brought his newly organized Dance Players to the National Theatre last night for their New York bow and thus put officially into the field a project that has been in the making for some time with a wealth of interest accumulated about it.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 21 -- Leaving my hotel room in Manila on Dec. 31, I was plunged into war on two hours' notice. Just as suddenly I was snatched out of the war and set down in a hotel room in Australia. For 106 days and nights I lived in jungle bivouacs on Bataan and on other Philippine islands, skipping almost at will between Japanese forces by water and by air.

ADVANCED ALLIED AIR BASE, Southwest Pacific, April 21 -- Lieut. Gen. George H. Brett completed his inspection of the Port Moresby area of New Guinea today, taking off for the south just previous to a Japanese air raid.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- New Zealand will be included in a new South Pacific command under an American naval officer who will receive his orders from Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander-in-Chief of the United States Pacific Fleet, it was disclosed by a responsible source today.

William Masselos, New York pianist, who made his debut here three years ago, showed again yesterday afternoon that he is a young man of extraordinary gifts. He appeared in the fifth concert of the series sponsored at The New York Times Hall by the National Music League and the Citizens Committee for the Army and Navy.

CHICAGO, April 21 (AP) -- An advance of 10 to 20 cents a hundredweight in prices of hogs today wiped out all the loss of yesterday and carried the top back to $14.30, highest since the Office of Price Administration revised wholesale pork ceilings last week. The dressed wholesale pork market was steady to a shade higher, with top grade light loins up 1/2 cent a pound.

Arbitration hearings on the demands of the cloak joint board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union for a 15 per cent wage increase for 35,000 cloakmakers were ended yesterday before former Mayor James J. Walker, impartial chairman of the garment industry, after employers had argued that probably early freezing of garment prices would make it difficult for them to raise wages.

A group headed by Lehman Brothers received yesterday the award of $3,550,000 of water and improvement bonds of Norfolk, Va., on an interest cost basis to the city of 2.3397 per cent. The syndicate bid 100.10 for $2,500,000 of water bonds to mature on Dec. 1, 1943 to 1967, as 2.40s and $1,050,000 of general improvement bonds due on May 1, 1953 to 1967, as 2 1/4s.

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., April 21 -- Members of the executive board of the Glen Ridge Junior Auxiliary will hold a tea for provisionals tomorrow at the home of the president, Mrs. Herman Lazarus Jr. Mrs. Robert Daly, hospitality chairman, is in charge of arrangements.

Because Hunter College is the largest college for women in the world, it should be able to fill half the quota of 2,000 nurses' aides pledged to the city by colleges in the metropolitan area, Diane Gilman, head of Hunter defense headquarters, told 1,700 students at a nurses' aide rally held there yesterday.

ALBANY, April 21 -- Congressional reapportionment was revived in the Legislature today on word of an alleged threat from Washington that if the Legislature did not reapportion the New York seats in the House of Representatives, unchanged since 1911, Congress itself would do so.

TRENTON, April 21 -- The orders of State Milk Director Arthur F. Foran reducing milk prices throughout New Jersey, effective May 1, were stayed today due to an attack on the so-called "skip-day" plan by representatives of labor, milk processors, dealers and subdealers.
There are probably several thousand women in New York City today who, at 6 or 7 o'clock, will look up from their desks, sigh and say, gratefully:

Production of war materials by the General Electric Company will approximate $1,000,000,000 in 1942, Charles E. Wilson, president, disclosed yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders in Schenectady. That such a goal will be reached is indicated by the fact that last month's output was at the annual rate of $860,000,000, Mr. Wilson added.
The Burma campaign continued to have very critical aspects yesterday as Japanese troops drove to within 150 miles of Mandalay, key point of Central Burma.

Kentucky Derby horses again were in the spotlight yesterday at Jamaica, where Air Current captured the Pompey Purse before 15,270 persons for his second victory of the meeting. At the end of the mile and a sixteenth, the Louis Lee Haggin 2d color-bearer just got up under a hustling ride by Alfred Robertson to nose out another Derby eligible, J.H. Miles's K. Dorko.

LONDON, April 21 -- Quiet conditions prevailed again on the Stock Exchange today, but the markets on the whole were firm. The weakest feature was Mexican Eagle Oil, which dropped 7 1/2d yesterday to 12s 6d and opened today at 12s 1 1/2d. Heavy selling developed later and the close was 11s 7 1/2d. Burmans and Ultramar remained stationary.

HOLLYWOOD BEACH, Fla., April 21 -- This country must supply Latin America with machinery, equipment and manufactured goods even if we deprive ourselves to do it, Walter T. Prendergast, assistant director of the Science and Education Division of the Office of Inter-American Affairs, declared tonight.

Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, and Emile Rieve, vice president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, have been elected to the board of directors of the American Arbitration Association, it was announced yesterday by Lucius R. Eastman, chairman of the board of the association.

Ten grants of $1,000 each will be made jointly by the American Academy of Arts and Letters and the National Institute of Arts and Letters next month to nonmembers doing creative work in art, literature and music.

The members of The Associated Press at the second day's session of their forty-second annual meeting in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria voted yesterday to reject application by Marshall Field for a "night report" membership in that non-profit, cooperative news-gathering organization for his new morning newspaper, The Chicago Sun.

A movement to start neighborhood planning in East Harlem was set in motion yesterday by the Women's City Club when welfare, health and educational leaders from that section met in the club lounge, 55 West Forty-fourth Street, to discuss community needs.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 21 -- Motorists who tempt automobile thieves in this city by leaving ignition keys in parked automobiles will face penalties of six months in jail and $50 in fines under the terms of a local ordinance passed last night by the City Council and scheduled to become operative May 20.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 21 -- Summarizing for the first time the thorny question of new or impending diplomatic relations between the Holy See and different belligerent states, the semi-official Catholic organ, Italia, outlines the position as follows:...
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The War Department communique, based on reports received here up to 9:30 A.M., said:

CAIRO, Egypt, April 21 (U.P.) Malta's defenders shot down five German planes during three raids today, running their total since Sunday to at least seventeen, dispatches from there tonight said. Four other planes were probably destroyed and eight were damaged during raids shortly after dawn.

VICHY, France, April 21 -- German occupation authorities executed twenty French hostages at St. Nazaire today and announced that, in addition to the thirty killed at Rouen yesterday, eighty more would be shot and 1,000 deported if the saboteurs of a German troop train were not captured by Thursday.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Plans for unionization of this country's 3,000,000 dairy farmers were discussed at a meeting today of the thirty-three regional directors of District 50, United Mine Workers of America.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Representative Dickstein, chairman of the Immigration and Naturalization Committee, lost the first round of his fight today against a drastic "concentration camp" bill which would authorize the indefinite detention of aliens against whom deportation warrants have been issued hut who cannot leave the United States because of present conditions.

The nine defendants declined to take the witness stand yesterday at the opening of their defense in General Sessions on an indictment accusing them of numerous extortions in the last five years from independent dealers and truckers in the retail milk industry in this State.

To take care of the steadily expanding requirements of the Office of Emergency Management under the war program, the Federal agency has leased large space in the Empire State Building for occupancy by the New York regional office of the Office of Price Administration, Sylvan Joseph, regional director of OPA, announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission was asked today by its public utilities division to order the New England Gas and Electric Association to simplify its corporate structure on an all-common stock basis.

Matthew Green, in the men's championship, and Mrs. Nanny Roos, in the women's division, were the early victors in the title tournaments of the United States Chess Federation at the Hotel Astor last night.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The Labor Department classified today 13,0.00,000 women as "employables" from which workers in war plants may be drawn.

The National Association of Manufacturers, through its president, William P. Witherow, denied here last night that it had agreed to arbitration of the "closed-shop" issue at President Roosevelt's labor-management peace conference in December.

A promotion campaign to increase the purchase of war bonds in New York State, using newspaper advertising, radio announcements, direct mail literature, posters, movies and voluntary payroll deduction schemes, was outlined last night to members of the Savings Banks Officers Forum of Group IV at their monthly dinner in the Astor.

LONDON, April 21 -- Further evidence of German nervousness over the possibility of invasion of her 2,000-mile coast line was contained in news reaching Norwegian circles in London today to the effect that several well-equipped new divisions, including armored units, had crossed into Norway.

Maxie Shapiro, East Side lightweight, scored a technical knockout over Frankie Martin of Pasadena, Calif., in last night's feature bout at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn. With 40 seconds left in the seventh round the referee, Pete Hartley, stopped the action to save Martin, also called Chief Crazy Horse, from further punishment.

EASTVIEW, N.Y., April 21 -- Stephen J. Stilwell, former State Senator from the Bronx, died here last night in Grasslands Hospital, where he had been receiving medical treatment as a prisoner of the near-by county jail. Incarcerated since April of last year, he pleaded guilty Feb. 9 to a charge of attempted bribery, and at his death was awaiting sentence.

Further indications of an increasing coolness between Wendell L. Willkie, the 1940 Republican Presidential candidate, and Thomas E. Dewey, the likeliest Republican candidate for Governor of New York this Fall, developed yesterday on the heels of the Republican National Committee meeting in Chicago, where a resolution declaring that the United States has an obligation for world cooperation was adopted.

Under "Salute Punctilious" you give credit to Lieut. Gen. Drum for reinstating the salute off duty as well as on the post. Let me quote Section II, War Department Circular No. 50, dated Feb. 20, 1942:

SYDNEY, Australia, April 21 -- In the last weeks before the fall of Bataan four battered planes, called "The Bamboo Fleet," dodged Japanese fighter and reconnaissance aircraft night after night to bring quinine and other drugs to the besieged garrison from a secret Philippine base.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- A short debate interspersed with "boos" from both sides occurred in the House today over the Republican National Committee's declaration at Chicago yesterday in favor of relentless prosecution of the war and cooperative efforts for peace after the war.
ALBANY, April 21 -- The Assembly by a vote of 122 to 18 passed and sent to the Senate today the Ives bill liberalizing the State's unemployment insurance law.

Miss Dorothy L. McFadden, president of Junior Programs, Inc., will lead a forum discussion on "The Child and His Amusements," to be held today at The New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street. This analysis of recreational programs for children in times of emergency will complete a series of four panels on "The Child in Wartime."

"Fingers at the Window," last Lew Ayres film to be released by Metro since the actor left the studio for a conscientious objectors camp, will open this morning at Loew's Criterion. Laraine Day and Basil Rathbone are co-featured in the film, the supporting cast of which includes Walter Kingsford, Miles Mander, Charles D. Brown and Russell Gleason.

The strangeness of this war-convulsed world is illustrated by an announcement from Washington that a certain ship left a certain European port this week on its way to New York. Three years ago such sailings were listed with the shipping news, and none save those directly concerned thought much about them.

Six of the seven major war contracts undertaken by the Chrysler Corporation before Pearl Harbor already are in volume production, and shipments on the seventh will begin within thirty days, K.T. Keller, president of the company, said at the annual meeting of stockholders in Detroit yesterday.

BUFFALO, April 21 -- More than $1,000,000 in gold was smuggled from Canada into the United States from 1938 until late in 1941, a Federal Court jury was told today at the trial of Bernard Kushner of Brooklyn, on charges of conspiracy to smuggle gold.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The Pacific War Council at its meeting here today adopted the agenda of the Walrus in "Alice" to the extent of talking about ships. But even if the Walrus had not prescribed these as one of the "many things" it is time to talk about, the Pacific War Council would have discussed ships anyhow, for the shipping shortage remains the fundamental brake on the war program, although its grip is decreasing.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 21 (AP) -- Assistant Attorney General Arnold in charge of Anti-Trust Act prosecutions, was criticized today by Benjamin T. Brooks, a New York chemist.

MADRID, April 21 (U.P.) -- Spain would add 1,000,000 men to the 15,000 Spaniards now fighting on the Russian front if the German armies needed help to crush the Russians, Foreign Minister Ramon Serrano Suner said yesterday.

The Navy took over the plants of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation in Long Island City, Newark and Johnsville, Pa., because "no finished planes were being produced," it was announced yesterday by Captain George C. Westervelt, U.S.N., retired, who has been designated by the Navy Department to operate the seized factories.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Organized labor's no-strike policy was hailed today as "an astounding success" by William H. Davis, chairman of the National War Labor Board, who said that strike idleness in relation to war production, with its increased employment during the first quarter of 1942, was one-fifteenth of the corresponding period of 1941.

Pearl L. Bergoff, formerly operator of a strike-breaking agency, charged in General Sessions Court yesterday that Attorney General John J. Bennett was prosecuting him as part of a "general plan of unions to emasculate industry." The Attorney General charged Bergoff, his son, daughter, brother and three more associates with a misdemeanor last December in operating a private detective agency without a license and of violating the State anti-strike-breaking law.

MAX EASTMAN is a man of strong enthusiasms, violent prejudices, controversial opinions. For more than thirty years he has been airing them in print, from the days when he edited the radical socialist Masses before our entry into the First World War. In more recent years he has been Leon Trotsky's most stalwart literary champion in the intramural left-wing fracas against the orthodox or Stalinist party-liners.

ALBANY, April 21 -- Governor Lehman today named Mrs. Richard J. Bernhard of New York City, his niece, to membership on the nonsalaried State Board of Social Welfare. Mrs. Bernhard succeeds the late Dr. Solomon Lowenstein.

Marjorie Tollman, soprano soloist of St. James Presbyterian Church in Harlem, made her New York concert debut last night at Town Hall. She revealed herself as the possessor of a naturally lovely voice.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, April 21 (U.P.) -- Allied fliers, rounding out three days of heavy attacks on Japanese invasion bases north of Australia, have damaged hangars and headquarters buildings and blown up a fuel dump at Salamaua, New Guinea, General Douglas MacArthur reported today in his first communique as supreme commander in the Southwest Pacific.

LONDON, April 21 -- The government has decided to ration fuel, including coal, coke, gas, electricity and paraffin, starting in June, Hugh Dalton, the President of the Board of Trade, told the House of Commons today.

Thomas Walsh, diver, covered another two blocks of the East River bed yesterday, the second day of his search for the body of Police Sergeant Patrick Walsh, who vanished Sept. 9, 1939. Monday's search from Fourth to Sixth Streets and yesterday's from Sixth to Eighth have been fruitless.

Completing his first buying trip in the United States in twenty-one years, Hector B. Deque, Uruguayan wholesaler, was guest honor yesterday at a luncheon held by the Block International Corporation at the Advertising Club. F.J. Emmerich, vice president of the corporation, presided at the luncheon, which was designed to foster inter-American trade.

James Marshall, president of the Board of Education, will not be a candidate for re-election when his term expires next month, it became known at board headquarters yesterday. He is to remain as a member of the board, however.

Anzac Day, the national festival of Australia and New Zealand, commemorating the landing of the Anzacs at Gallipoli in 1915, will be marked Friday by the Anzac Division of the British War Relief Society with a dinner at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, a feature of which is expected to be a broadcast message from General Douglas MacArthur in Australia.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The Ways and Means Committee reported today by a divided vote a revised bill to exempt from State and local sales and use taxes property bought by contractors for war orders.
A Federal court jury, which deliberated almost five hours, convicted last night twelve persons and two corporations of conspiracy to violate the Harrison Narcotics Act.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- S.C. Kelton, secretary of Rohm Haas Company, Inc., Philadelphia, manufacturers of a plastic glass substitute used in bombers and military aircraft, told the Senate Patents Committee today that the story of Plexiglas (the trade name of his company's product) was a "story of one-way flow of information."
PITTSBURGH, April 21 (AP) -- Manager Frankie Frisch gave the Pirates a thorough shaking up today, and the movement paid a 5-2 dividend victory over the Cubs.

In the first of a series of orders intended to dictate the uses to which the looms of America's 815 cotton mills can be put, the War Production Board yesterday ordered conversion to bag fabric production of specified percentages of looms now producing a wide variety of cotton fabrics commonly used in clothing and in the home.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- Arnold Hanger, vice president and treasurer of the Silas Mason Company of New York City, general contractor for a government shell-loading plant near Minden, La., told a House Military Affairs subcommittee today that the company would realize a profit of only 1.6 per cent on the job.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Home owners are warned to clean their furnaces, heating stoves and boilers this Spring to prevent deterioration from rust and corrosion while they are idle during the Summer. The consumer division of the Office of Price Administration suggests also that delay until Fall may mean that parts are not available.

Increased buying by the trade and New Orleans interests near the close of trading halted a steady downward movement in the cotton market yesterday and left active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange with net losses of 5 to 8 points.

The modest improvement in the stock market was continued yesterday, but with volume again so small that the pattern of the share list was not clarified. In spotted sections there were price changes of a point or more, but the general run of alterations again was held to fractions. Business on the Stock Exchange was 270,250 shares, against 240,000 on Monday.

Two assistants of Dr. Edward S. Cowles, psychiatrist, in operating the Body and Mind Foundation Clinic at 139 East Sixty-ninth Street were arraigned in Special Sessions Court yesterday and pleaded not guilty to charges of practicing medicine without licenses.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 21 -- With only a third of American families at present paying Federal income taxes, one of the most controversial issues of the next few weeks will be whether to lower the exemptions in such a way as to make the middle third pay as well as the top third.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- President Roosevelt announced today that he had directed Leo T. Crowley, Alien Property Custodian, to seize all patents controlled by the enemy, even if they were ostensibly owned by citizens of allied or neutral nations or of the United States.

Mayor La Guardia, by his recent criticism of the Office of Civilian Defense, has reopened for public discussion the degree of preparedness of the Air Warden Service in this city. May I suggest that, quite irrespective of New York City's difficulties in obtaining proper fire-fighting equipment, there are urgent needs for improving the internal organization and for forming a policy on many matters, of which the following are most important:

Industry should start preparing now for the new Production Requirements Plan, which will definitely go into effect after July, Major H.R. Battley, district public relations officer of the Air Corps, declared yesterday at a forum discussion on the form PD-3A.
CLEVELAND, April 21 (AP) -- The Indians bunched four of their seven hits in the fifth inning today to tally three runs, which led to a 4-to-2 triumph over the Browns.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Four Navy enlisted men won promotion today for gallantry in action in the Pacific Ocean.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 21 -- Eight thousand hysterical high school children and elementary school pupils, apparently overwrought by the presence of Carol Bruce, stage and screen star, broke up a program intended to promote sale of war stamps and war bonds here today.

CHICAGO, April 21 -- Expressing the hope that Republican adoption of the resolution recognizing the international obligations of the United States has removed "isolationism" as an issue in the November elections, the executive committee of the party's national committee prepared today to make an active campaign for the election of Representatives and United States Senators.

U.S. and Foreign Securities Net assets of the United States and Foreign Securities Corporation at the end of March were about $23,370,305, approximately $135 a share on the first preferred stock, on which dividends are $59.50 in arrears. This compared with $155 at the end of 1941.

The resolution adopted by the Republican National Committee at its Chicago meeting cuts cleanly away from those influences within the party which still counsel a "defensive" war, a war of limited liability, a war in which we "keep our weapons for ourselves," a war in which we concentrate our attack against Japan and give only second thought to Nazi Germany.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 20 -- That Italy is facing many difficulties is made clear by a survey of the situation there appearing in Suedost-Echo, published in Vienna, today. It is dated from Rome and credited to "an occasional contributor."

It is pleasant to know that Secretary Hull, who has been away from the State Department for several months on account of his health, has returned to his post. His labors have been long and exhausting. His countrymen hope that he comes back strong and hearty. In his absence Under-Secretary Welles has shown his wonted knowledge, skill and judgment.

The Riom trial that never reached a verdict but came to an abrupt end with Pierre Laval's return to the Vichy government, was condemned by prominent French refugees at a mass meeting at the Cosmopolitan Opera House, 135 West Fifty-fifth Street, held last night under the auspices of France Forever, the Free French organization in America.

Visiting buyers in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 869, which compared with 1,045 in the preceding week and 1,152 in the similar period a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's registrations totaled 400, as against 413 for last Tuesday.

SUMMIT, N.J., April 21 -- A funeral service for Lewis W. Gillilan, traffic service superintendent of the New York Telephone Company, was held here today at his home, 106 Maple Street, by the Rev. Dr. Leonard V. Buschman, pastor of the Central Presbyterian Church.

The sinking of a small United States ship and a medium-sized Norwegian vessel by enemy submarines off our east coast and the damaging of a medium-sized ship of Panamanian registry, which managed to reach port with a big torpedo hole in her side, were announced yesterday by the Navy.

NEW DELHI India, April 21 -Sir Archibald P. Wavell, Commander in Chief in India, broadcast an assurance to the people of India tonight that the defenses of India were growing stronger every day and that the time was not far distant when the United Nations would have the sea power to drive the Japanese from the Indian Ocean.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., April 21 -- The capitals of the United Nations are thoroughly alive to the Pacific situation, Prime Minister Peter Fraser said today at a public reception for Brig. Gen. Patrick J. Hurley, the new United States Minister to New Zealand.

"Wasteful and silly publicity" from countless government bureaus, including those of the Army and Navy, was condemned at the fifty-sixth annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association yesterday by publishers who pledged themselves to "share uncomplainingly the sacrifices of war."

DETROIT, April 21 -- Officials of the Department of Street Railways went to Washington today to discuss with Federal authorities the possibility of this city's obtaining abandoned coaches, formerly used on New York's elevated system, to carry workmen to the Ford Motor Company's Willow Run bomber plant.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Pressing the long-pending $19,151,597,000 Army-Navy supplemental supply bill toward final Congressional action, the House cast overboard today its previously adopted program for curbing war profits by fixing statutory percentage limitations and accepted a Senate plan which seeks to recapture excessive industrial gains through renegotiations with contractors.
LONDON, April 21 -- Sir Stafford Cripps returned to London today and almost immediately saw Prime Minister Churchill.

A suit to test the power of the State Industrial Commissioner to compel production of books of employment agencies in an investigation of charges of racial and religious discrimination in war industry jobs was argued yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Peter Schmuck.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The aerial bombardment and cannonading of Corregidor Island and Forts Hughes and Drum, in the entrance to Manila Bay, slackened somewhat today, the War Department reported, and resulted in small damage despite the use of 240-mm. guns.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The American planes which bombed Tokyo came from a new secret base in Shangri-la, the fictional land of "Lost Horizon."

Tobacco Debentures at Par The $100,000,000 of American Tobacco Company 3 per cent twenty-year debentures will be priced at 100 when placed on the market later this week. Formal offering to the public is expected on Friday morning by an underwriting syndicate of 146 members, headed by Morgan Stanley Co. The underwriting contract was signed yesterday.

The Junior League clubhouse at 221 East Seventy-first Street will be the setting May 5 for a "Flower Morning Benefit" to raise funds for the Winifred Wheeler Day Nursery, of which Mrs. Walter S. Fischer Jr. is chairman and Mrs. Flagler Matthews, treasurer.

In order to further the development of general advertising for newspapers and to resist unfair and unjustified attacks on legitimate advertising, committees from the New York and Chicago Newspaper Representatives Association have formed a national association to be known as the American Association of Newspaper Representatives, it was announced yesterday.

LONDON, April 21 -- Princess Elizabeth, heir presumptive to the British throne, made her first public appearance at an official ceremony today, her sixteenth birthday, when she reviewed the Grenadier Guards, of which she is cologne, in chief.

Herbert Agar, president of Freedom House, speaking at a meeting of the American Theatre Wing War Service yesterday, asserted that many Americans were unaware of the real meaning of the war and that a clear explanation of its cause and effect was needed to build a united nation.

HOLLYWOOD BEACH, Fla., April 22 -- Addressing the National Council of Catholic Women at its closing meeting tonight, Dr. Max Jordan, former European representative of the National Broadcasting Company, deplored rebellion against divine rule, which he said has brought about the present crisis.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- A Federal grand jury will make an immediate investigation into reported seditious activities of individuals and organizations in the Chicago area, Attorney General Biddle said today.

NEWARK, N.J., April 22 -- An indictment accusing a Polish engineer of the theft of a blueprint for a seaplane ramp being used by the United States Navy was quashed today by Common Pleas Judge Walter D. Van Riper after Leon Kapp, assistant prosecutor of Essex County, had declared the defendant was the victim of "an apparently vindictive employer."

An investigation of irregularities in the Marriage License Bureau has disclosed indications that physicians are violating the law requiring a pre-marital examination by giving the couples blood tests only and not making physical examinations, William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, announced yesterday.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, an organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

Mrs. Coster Morris has leased through Douglas Gibbons Co., Inc., brokers, from Mrs. Dwight F. Davis, an apartment of twelve rooms and five baths in the building at 1 Sutton Place. The Gibbons concern also rented quarters in the new building at 33 East End Avenue to Llewellyn L. Calloway Jr., John Hanan DeMuth, Alice G. Hansen and Mrs. Louis La Brasche.

While his father's mosquito torpedo boats were again making the headlines, John Duncan Bulkeley Jr. yesterday slept through his first press conference. Even the continuous flashing of bulbs from the cameras of half a dozen photographers failed to wake Commander Bulkeley's new son in the arms of Mrs. Bulkeley.

The War Production Board's limitation order L-99 allocating specific percentage of certain cotton goods looms to the manufacture of bag fabrics will result in sweeping changes in promotion plans on a wide range of work clothing, sports wear, children's wear, domestics, and upholstery and drapery cloths, according to trade comment yesterday.
Olsen and Johnson nearly caused another riot yesterday afternoon, but this time they were not buffooning behind footlights.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- President Roosevelt's visitors included Senator Glass, Governor Charles Harwood of the Virgin Islands, Attorney General Biddle, Basil O'Connor and the directors of the Tennessee Valley Authority.

NEWARK, N.J., April 22 -- David Brown, an organizer for District 50 of the United Mine Workers, charged today that he had been dropped from the union's payroll because he refused to sign a "pledge of blind loyalty" to the policies of John L. Lewis. Mr. Brown said his refusal was based on a belief that allegiance to the Lewis attitude toward the war meant opposition to "everything that is progressive in American life."

Governors of the New York Stock Exchange voted yesterday a temporary suspension from dealings of the common stock of the Pacific Finance Corporation of California. The move was due to violation of the company's listing agreement with the Exchange in connection with an exchange offer made public on Monday and the resulting confusion on the floor of the Exchange.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 22 -- News of a new British Commando action at Boulogne-sur-Mer supports the growing opinion in foreign military circles that the war is about to enter what is styled its "American phase."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 22 -- "I'd Rather See a Ghost," a screen story by Jack Jungmeyer Jr. and Maurice Rapf, was purchased today by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer as a vehicle for Keenan Wynn, son of Ed Wynn, whom the studio recently signed to a term contract.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Melvyn Douglas, director of the Arts Council of the Office of Civilian Defense, has returned from Hollywood to resume his duties here. The film actor is consultant for the program to coordinate in the war drive the volunteer talent of the several fields of the arts.

WHEN my 4-year-old daughter Elizabeth talks of a creature known as the "Wickun," which is her own Lewis Carroll jabberwocky word for wicked one, or witch, she is repeating a creative process that is as old as language. If I ever felt like correcting her, Dr. Margaret Scklauch's "The Gift of Tongues"* has forever disabused me of the idea.

MEMPHIS, April 22 -A discovery that animals and human beings, as well as plants, need carbon dioxide in the nourishment of their cells and tissues was reported today before the Spring meeting of the American Chemical Society.

Former Police Inspector John Reddan, one of the forty-nine policemen named recently by Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen's two extraordinary grand juries in their inquiry into alleged police protection of a $100,000,000 gambling syndicate, disclosed yesterday that he had sent another letter to Mr. Amen demanding that he be afforded an opportunity to "defend his good name."

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 22 -- Unofficial accounts of Monday's raid on Salamaua, New Guinea, say that the Japanese were taken completely by surprise. Unopposed, United Nations bombers hammered the airdrome heavily. On their way home the crews could see columns of smoke from burning fuel dumps when they were twenty miles away.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 22 -- Opening its home season today, Yale bowed to Brown, 9 -- 1, for its third straight defeat.

CLEVELAND, April 22 (AP) -- Vernon Kennedy's five-hit pitching against his old team-mates gave Cleveland a 3-to-2 triumph over the Browns today and a sweep of the three-game series. St. Louis filled the bases with none out in the ninth, but was unable to score.
BERLIN, April 22 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique said today:

Directors of the Liggett Myers Tobacco Company authorized yesterday a quarterly dividend of 75 cents a share, payable on June 1, on the common and common B stock. The declaration represented a reduction of 25 cents from the previous quarterly rate of $1 maintained since 1928.

Dr. Edward S. Cowles, operator of the psychiatric clinic known as the Body and Mind Foundation, was planning a national chain of such dispensaries then Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. upset matters by initiating prosecution last Monday, it was declared yesterday at the Attorney General's office.

Six bars of gold valued at $18,900 and a safety deposit box containing money, jewelry and bonds worth at least $18,600 became the subject of police and Federal investigations yesterday when the possessor of this wealth failed to offer adequate explanation of how he acquired it.

ALBANY, April 22 -- Despite the fact that Russia and the United States are allies, communism is a continuing menace to the American system, the Legislature was told today in the report of the Rapp-Coudert committee winding up the "subversive-elements" investigation by that group into the New York City school system.

Eighty-four entries were selectled from .thousands of drawings submitted in the preliminary showing held this week at the WaldorfAstoria in the American Psychiatric Association's contest for' an emblem. The drawings chosen have been sent to the Rhode Island Art Museum, Providence, to remain on exhibition until May 2.

ALBANY, April 22 -- Two major measures, the liberalization of the Unemployment Insurance Law and payment of income tax returns in quarterly installments, starting with 1943, were sent to Governor Lehman today as legislative action on them was finished.

Louise Richardson, soprano, was presented by the American Music Foundation, Inc., in a recital given last night at Town Hall for the benefit of the Artists Victory Pianos Trust Fund. Miss Richardson originated and founded the fund, the purpose of which is to donate pianos to military encampments, air field and naval stations of this country for the exclusive use of visiting artists.

Three proposals that will be submitted to stockholders at the annual meeting of the F.W. Woolworth Company to be held in Watertown, N.Y., on May 20 will be opposed by the management, it is disclosed in the proxy statement, and the officers recommend that all stockholders vote against the proposals.

ABOARD A BRITISH NAVAL LIGHT CRAFT, April 22 -- "Halten!" This was the only word spoken by a torch-swinging German forming a one-man patrol that was the first to challenge British Commandos during their two-hour reconnaissance excursion near Boulogne early today.

ALBANY, April 22 -- The Senate completed action today on a Republican-sponsored resolution calling for a legislative investigation of the State Civil Service Commission. The resolution, introduced by Assemblyman Hollowell, creates an eight-man committee and appropriates $25,000 for its work.

The first men's straw hat ever made of material grown in the United States has been presented to Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, by the Hat Style Council. This hat is the result of efforts by Miami, Fla., to develop a local industry, as previously all braid has been imported from such places as the Philippines, Dutch East Indies, Nassau, the Bahamas and a few South American countries.

LONDON, April 22 -- Increasing agitation for a unified command under one chief for air, land and sea warfare was shown in the House of Lords today when Lord Strabolgi argued for the creation of an Allied grand general staff.

Jack Rubin, 42-years old, notorious jewelry fence who admittedly spent $20,000 in a legal battle in which the Court of Appeals last year reversed his seven-and-one-half-year sentence to State prison as the criminal receiver in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel jewelry shop holdup in 1939, only to plead guilty recently at the start of his new trial, got off with a sentence of three and one-half to seven years yesterday in General Sessions.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The number of new automobiles available for rationing this year is about 60,000 larger than the 340,000 originally indicated by manufacturers' reports, according to an official count of the Office of Price Administration, that agency announced today.

Newspapers should make every proper effort to convince the government of the value of paid advertising in selling war bonds, Walter M. Dear, general manager of The Jersey Journal of Jersey City, declared yesterday in his presidential address to the fifty-sixth annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, meeting in executive session at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

LONDON, April 22 -- How an English woman and her 5-year-old son, who had been drugged for four days and nights to prevent him from betraying them by speaking English, escaped from a German prison camp in France was told in London today.
Sales of residential properties by institutional owners featured the Westchester activity reported yesterday.

Several thousand employes in the financial district gathered in front of the Sub-Treasury at Broad and Wall Streets at noon yesterday to witness the presentation of a check from the employes of the New York Stock Exchange to the campaign of the Greater New York Fund for $5,000,000.

BUENOS AIRES, April 22 -- A more serious view of the incident of the Argentine tanker Victoria was being taken by Argentine authorities today, since all reports from the United States agreed that the Victoria was almost certainly torpedoed, not damaged by floating mines.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 22 -- Just as everything appeared patched up -- on the surface, at least -- between Hungary and Rumania in readiness for the Axis Spring military offensive, the Hungarian press this evening launched another blast at the "treacherous methods" of the Bucharest Government.

LONDON, Thursday, April 23 (U.P.) -- British heavy guns on Dover Strait blazed away for a half hour early today, lighting a wide stretch of the shore with ragged sheets of flame, after German planes had bombed a town in Southwest England.
Mayor La Guardia predicted last night that "it won't be long now before the people of Italy take things into their own hands, toss Mussolini and his gang overboard and declare 'Viva Italia!'"

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- United States air services throughout the Americas will be increased at once to speed the war effort and defense activities in accordance with plans worked out in cooperation with government departments, it was announced today by Pan American Airways.

Twelve organizations interested in the preservation of Castle Clinton -- the Aquarium -- threatened with removal as part of the Battery Park conversion, appealed yesterday to the Board of Estimate for a full hearing before final action on the matter is taken.

The industrial property at the northwest corner of Fifty-sixth and Jackson Streets, West New York, N.J., has been sold by the Union National Radio Company of Delaware, a subsidiary of the Philco Radio Company, to the Arrow Embroidery Works, through J.B. Wolfe, Inc., broker.

BUENOS AIRES, April 22 (U.P.) -- To prevent abandonment of the Pan-American Games at Buenos Aires in November, the United States Sports Federation was urged today to send a small delegation of athletes despite last week's official withdrawal.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22 -- Master Melvin Ott and mighty Jawn Mize laid a couple of doubles end to end today and that was about all that the Giants needed to flatten the Phils in the opening clash of a two-game series, 3 to 0.

Hard on the heels of the War Production Board's sharp charges against the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation and the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation -- charges that these companies have violated priority regulations to the detriment of the war effort -- comes announcement that the Navy has bestowed honors upon these same two companies for exceptional contributions to the war effort.

Bishop William T. Manning, president of the New York Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society, 38 Bleecker Street, announced yesterday at a meeting of the society's board of managers that the Rev. Dr. Louis W. Pitt of Grace Church, Tenth Street and Broadway, and the Rev. Dr. John H. Johnson of St. Martin's Church, 230 Lenox Avenue, had accepted membership on the board.
Walter R. Moyer has become associated with Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane, in charge of the municipal bond department in Philadelphia.

Doubt Not, an old horse of 6, and Askmenow, a youngster of 2, triumphed at Jamaica yesterday where 16,472 persons wagered $903,414 on seven races. Mrs. Tilyou Christopher's gray son of Burgoo King was something of a surprise in a field of six that had to be 4 years or older, for he was the easiest sort of winner at the substantial enough price of 7 to 2 in the Red River Handicap.

The writer is the owner of a weekly newspaper and a 300-acre farm in the hills of Southeastern Ohio. We have been reading with considerable amusement, not altogether unmingled with disgust, the distorted ideas which city folks seem to have about the bonanza which the farmer is enjoying since the war has elevated the prices of his products.

AN ADVANCED UNITED NATIONS AIR BASE, Southwest Pacific, April 22 -- Gene R. Dreasher, a bombardier of one of the planes that have been making life unpleasant for the Japanese in Rabaul, Lae and Salamaua, has come to the conclusion he will never use a parachute.

CHICAGO, April 22 -- The better demand for cash wheat which developed yesterday was again in evidence on the Board of Trade today, with buying by milling interests sufficient to tighten up the market in the early trading. At no time was there any material pressure to sell and the close was about the top, with gains of 1/2 to 5/8 cent a bushel.
American planes and pilots were being prepared yesterday, according to reports from England, to join the British air offensive against Germany in Western Europe.

ALBANY, April 22 -- Another step was taken today toward establishment of a semi-public health research institution in New York City, with the passage by the Assembly of the Moffat bill, allowing cities to enter into contracts with such agencies. The measure is scheduled for a vote tomorrow in the Senate.

Reporting yesterday on operations of the Gulf Oil Corporation and its subsidiaries, excluding those in Europe, W.L. Mellon, chairman, and J.F. Drake, president, informed stockholders that the 1941 net profit amounted to $33,568,624 after $8,740,175 provision for Federal, State and foreign income taxes and $2,000,000 provision for contingencies.
