WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Vallejo and Napa, Calif., with a rise of 66 per cent in department store sales in March, still led all other cities in percentage increases, as compared with March of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The organizing committee of District 50, United Mine Workers of America, headed by John L. Lewis, intimated today to Philip Murray, president of the C.I.O., that an attempt may be made to oust him as a vice president of the miners' union at its convention in October.

The Girl Scout Council of Greater New York announced yesterday that it would undertake to provide periods of physical and mental refreshment for Girl Scouts and girls who are not Scouts, who cannot attend organized Summer camps in the rural areas.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- Fighting bitterly against overwhelming numbers, American-Filipino troops on the island of Panay were forced to withdraw from their positions at Lambunao in the interior of the island, the War Department announced today.

ALBANY, April 22 -- Forty miles an hour became today the maximum speed permissible for automobiles and motor cycles on the State highways as Governor Lehman signed the Graves bill, adopted by the Legislature as a war measure.

LONDON, April 22 -- Commando troops landed on the French coast near Boulogne early this morning and battled the German defenders for two hours, then withdrew without losing any ships and suffering only light casualties, according to a British communique.

The report of the Detroit Edison Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on March 31, made public yesterday, shows a net income after all expenses, taxes and other charges of $11,615,964. This was equal to $1.83 a share on the company's 6,361,300 shares of capital stock outstanding, and compares with a net of $11,037,022, or $1.73 a share in the twelve months to March 31, 1941.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Five members of the French Embassy staff resigned today because of the return to power of Pierre Laval. They said their decision was precipitated especially by his assertion that it was a crime for the French Government to have taken the country into war.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 22 -- At both ends of the Finnish front, on snow still crisply fresh, the Red Army has established the initiative in its recently launched offensive. From desolate mountain positions within the Arctic Circle, the Russians have broken through German positions in force and held their gains despite furious Nazi counter-attacks.
A two-story brick Brooklyn house was wrecked early yesterday morning when a trolley car skipped its tracks and plowed into the century-old structure.

LONDON, April 22 -- The stock markets were quiet again today. Interest was centered in the oils. Burmah rose 7 1/2d to 30s 7 1/2d and Iranians 1s 10 1/2d to 38s 1 1/2d and Shells 71/2d to 40s. The Mexican Eagles failed to recover yesterday's fall and closed at 11s 3d.

The Blackfriars Guild will present "Savonarola" by Urban Nagle tonight at the Blackfriars Theatre, 320 West Fifty-seventh Street, under the direction of Dennis Gurney. The play is about Fra Girolamo Savonarola, who drove the Medici from Florence, established his own republic and finally was put to death by citizens of his self-established State.
PITTSBURGH, April 22 (AP) -- The Pirates backed up Luke Hamlin's seven-hit pitching with an extra-base bombardment on Paul Erickson today and downed the Cubs, 9 -- 1.

Social and welfare workers who met yesterday at the Russell Sage Foundation, 130 East Twenty-second Street, to protest the failure of Mayor La Guardia and the Board of Estimate to provide in the 1942-1943 budget for retention of the skilled staff of the juvenile aid bureau of the Police Department, were told that an effort would be made on Monday to get the Board of Estimate to remedy this situation.
Time stood still yesterday in Manhattan Probation Court, and waited to see what the sentence would be. But all Magistrate Aurelio could do was exclaim:

It is not easy to furnish appropriate commentary upon the concert given last night in Carnegie Hall, where Arturo Toscanini led the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, the Westminster Choir and a quartet of soloists in the performance of Beethoven's "Missa Solemnis."

In spite of facts which could be read between the lines of the dispatches and communiques released for publication about the fighting on the Bataan Peninsula the American people probably suffered from illusions, down to the moment of the surrender, as to what was actually taking place there.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The general price control plan which President Roosevelt is expected to set up will freeze the cost of 70 per cent of the nation's foodstuffs, according to some sources of information. Fresh fruits and vegetables are among the products expected to be exempt.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, April 22 (U.P.) -- Merged United States-Australian air forces left the Japanese base at Rabaul, New Britain, aflame after a blistering raid yesterday, while an enemy attack on Port Moresby, New Guinea, was beaten off with four enemy planes shot down, United Nations headquarters announced today.

The "enemies of democracy" in this country, and to a lesser degree in Canada, have united in an "anti-Soviet front," which is the "ally of Hitler within our gates," the Rev. Dr. Harry F. Ward told an audience of 500 at the Town Hall Club last night.

BOSTON, April 22 -- Nine innings of shut-out pitching by Whitlow Wyatt and three more of the same by Hugh Casey finally were rewarded today when the league-leading Dodgers exploded a twelfth-inning rally against Jim Tobin to beat the Braves, 4 -- 0, for their fourth straight triumph.
MOSCOW, April 22 (From Russian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau communique today said:

Although children can "take it" when it comes to viewing scenes of cruelty in the movies or listening to war broadcasts on the radio, parents do not want them to be subjected to realism in their amusements, it was agreed yesterday at the fourth and final meeting on "The Child In Wartime" held at The New York Times Hall under the sponsorship of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Twenty-four briefs approving or attacking a new joint report on the recently reopened reorganization of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad were filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Liberal quantities of recognized brands of processed and packaged food in the hands of merchants throughout the country constitute the best safeguard of public health and of the food supply under the threat of bombardment, H.J. Heinz 2d, president of the H.J. Heinz Company, of "57 varieties" fame, declared yesterday.

Down deep in the heart of Texas and over the border in Mexico, the culinary art is practiced in a fashion that seems strange indeed to conservative Northerners. At first, the enchiladas and the tamales and the chile con came taste as if they had been seasoned with an extravagant, rather than expert, hand.

Denouncing the "carnival mood" prevailing in America "because our good old Uncle Sam is spending a lot of money and we are in on the take," Dr. Frank Kingdon, chairman of the Emergency Rescue Committee, declared yesterday that "America is losing the war" and will continue to do so until the Americans realize that this is their war and give it greater individual support.

Gentlemen's clothing, traditionally the wifely domain of search for loose change, may be tapped by tailors and cleaners for funds to further the war. Phil Cooper, New York cleaner and dyer, proposed yesterday that all cash found in clothing sent to tailors, cleaners, dyers and laundries be forfeit hereafter to the USO, Navy and Army Relief and the Red Cross while the war lasts.

The National Association of Manufacturers and a number of columnists and editorial writers have denounced the War Labor Board's decision in the Walker-Turner case, in which the board granted to the union a maintenance of membership order. In every case those denouncing the board's decision have failed to give the facts in full.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The National War Labor Board and the presidents of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations issued statements today contradicting the assertions of William P. Witherow, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, who denied last night that the employers had ever agreed to arbitrate the "closed shop" issue at the President's labor-industry conference in December.

Samuel (the Dove) Turtletaub, 32 years old, was convicted of second-degree murder by a General Sessions jury late yesterday afternoon in the accidental shooting of Manny (Birdie). Burdy, a confederate, on April 24, 1933, when they and other Lepke-Gurrah thugs invaded the headquarters of the Needle Trades Workers Industrial Union at 131 West Twenty-eighth Street.

LONDON, Thursday, April 23 (AP) -- Madagascar, the strategic French island lying athwart the Allies' vital Cape route to the Indian Ocean ports and the Middle East, was reported today to be undergoing a reign of terror in the enforcement of new Vichy orders to imprison Free French sympathizers.

Owing to the heavy tax burden and lower profit margins, earnings of the Colgate-Palmolive-Peet Company in 1942 will not equal those of 1941, E.H. Little, president, said at the annual meeting of stockholders in Jersey City yesterday.

The experiment now under way for a thirty-day period, under which taxi-cabs are forbidden to cruise, to make U turns, or to make left turns from avenues into streets, will be watched with interest by pedestrian and motorist alike. Already the bedeviled pedestrian in the midtown area heaves a sigh of relief.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Industrial activity continued at a high rate in March and the first half of April, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The volume of consumption was large and commodity prices advanced further.

ROCHESTER, April 22 -- It will be necessary for the United States, Great Britain and the powers of Western Europe to subsidize the Asiatic nations after the war, Dr. Kurt Bloch told the opening session today at the University of Rochester of a conference on the Far East.

Japanese leaders yesterday warned their people to prepare for more attacks from the United States, similar to the bombing raids last Saturday in which, according to the Imperial High Command, Tokyo, Yokohama, Kobe and industrial Nagoya were hit.

CHICAGO, April 22 (AP) -- Don effective ninth-inning relief pitching by Buck Ross, gave the White Sox the odd contest of their three-game series with Detroit today, 3 to 1. Ross, coming to Bill Dietrich's rescue after Barney McCosky and Rudy York had opened the ninth with singles, retired the next three Tigers.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 22 -- Whether the Commonwealth wins its fight to abrogate the States' income-taxing rights during the war depends on the support of Parliament and the influence State Labor party executives can exert in support of the States' resistance.

Colonel Robert R. McCormick, publisher of The Chicago Tribune, said yesterday that he hoped the "overwhelming" vote of the members of The Associated Press on Tuesday refusing Associated Press membership to Marshall Field for The Chicago Sun "means that the Gestapo is out of American newspaper offices forever."

PRINCETON, N.J., April 22 -- Behind the seven-hit pitching of Roy Talcott, Princeton's defending champions routed Columbia, 13 -- 2, today to move into first place in the current Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League race with two victories in two circuit games.

Because he had stolen $8.50 worth of cigarettes while he was hungry and homeless to pay a debt he owed a luncheonette for coffee and cakes, 19-year-old Joseph Prinzivelli walked out of Kings County Court yesterday with $32.67 that had been collected in seven minutes by passing the prosecutor's hat about the crowded courtroom.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- A Navy spokesman said here today that without doubt the Argentine vessel Victoria had been torpedoed by an Axis ship. This statement followed Axis reports from South America declaring that the Victoria had been damaged by striking United States mines.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 22 -- Travelers just returned from France say that a painful impression has been created by news of the shooting of more hostages by the German occupying authority even though Pierre Laval is now chief of the government.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- All authority and responsibility of the Department of Justice in connection with alien property, together with the personnel and records of its Alien Property Division, were transferred by President Roosevelt today to Leo Crowley, Alien Property Custodian.

A woman 85 years old received yesterday the first "crusader pin" of the Women's Field Army of the New York City Cancer Committee. She was Mrs. Louis A. Dreyfus of Grimes Hill, S.I., a cured cancer patient who has devoted "her time, her energy and her money" to the cause of cancer cure and education.
A recent article in THE NEW YORK TIMES mentioned the proposed elimination of the Juvenile Aid Bureau of the Police Department, already foreshadowed in the Mayor's budget message.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- Most of the executives of the labor division of the War Production Board offered a blanket resignation to Donald M. Nelson, who refused it.

NEWARK, N.J., April 22 (AP) -- A two-base wallop by George Stirnweiss which scored Pitcher Larry Guay in the eighth inning enabled Newark to register an 8-to-7 victory today over Montreal. The Bears were forced to come from behind thrice, Hank Majeski driving a 400-foot homer with two aboard in the seventh.

General MacArthur's first communique as Commander in Chief of the forces of the United Nations in the Southwest Pacific marks the change that has taken place on the Australian front since his arrival there, five weeks ago. Then the Allies were clinging precariously to the northern fringe of the continent, expecting invasion at any moment.

LONDON, April 22 -- Heavy fighting continues on all fronts in Burma. Since the Chinese are now participating in every action, most information reaching here comes from Chungking, or from Chinese headquarters at the front.

Twenty thousand police circulars put out here yesterday call for public aid in apprehension of "Colonel Hale Heatherington Halquire," master swindler for two generations. He is wanted this time for larceny of $15,000 in cash from two New York City furriers to whom he held out promise of lush, but mythical, war contracts.
In THE TIMES of April 19 there is a story from Washington stating that the farmers are short 97,000 workers, yet are going to raise more food than ever.

Two stone masons from the Department of Public Works spent all day yesterday trying to repair breaks in the marble steps of City Hall that were caused by four Army jeeps that climbed the steps on Monday for a picture with Mayor La Guardia to popularize the current campaign of the United Service Organizations.

Declaring that the response to the Catholic Charities 1942 Appeal has been generous, Mrs. Paul T. Kammerer Jr., chairman of the women's special gifts committee, reported yesterday that $44,493 had been collected by her group to date. The meeting was held at their campaign headquarters in the Park Lane Hotel.
LOS ANGELES, April 22 (U.P.) -- This city faced a bit of a crisis today because women municipal employes want to work in slacks.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Some seventy-five representatives of the food trade met here tonight with officials of the Office of Price Administration to discuss the part this industry will play in the war effort on the home front. The meeting was regarded in some quarters as a means of OPA'S sending up of "trial balloons" on the over-all price freezing order expected from the Administration shortly.

CHUNGKING, China, April 22 -- Indicative of the emancipation of women, which is one of the most significant features of China's regenerated nationalistic spirit as a result of the Japanese aggression, is the Chinese women's part in the war.

Competition in a war industry was put aside for a day when officials of Alexander Smith Sons yesterday took production men of eighteen other carpet mills on a tour of its Yonkers mills which have been converted to the manufacture of duck. At a forum following the tour the visitors asked questions on technical details and also volunteered suggestions based on their own experiences in war conversion.

KUIBYSPIEV, Russia, April 22 -- Successful development of Russian tactics against German tanks is indicated today in the Army newspaper Red Star, which stresses the importance of nipping off advancing tanks from their supporting units of infantry and artillery.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22 -- The Boise Water Corporation, a subsidiary of the General Water Gas and Electric Company applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission today for permission to acquire as a subsidiary the Kellogg Power and Water Company, at present also owned by General Water Gas and Electric.

A squeeze play in the eighth inning, with Captain Mike Rudko on the bunting end, brought C.C.N.Y. an 8-7 victory over Manhattan at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday. It was the first triumph in five Metropolitan Collegiate Conference starts for the Beavers.

In observance of the ninetieth anniversary of the birth of Edwin Markham, the Staten Island committee of the Markham Memorial Association will hold an open-house party today at the Markham House, 92 Waters Avenue, Westerleigh, S.I., from 2 to 5 P.M. and from 8 to 9:30 P.M.
Officials of fifteen local housing agencies sold yesterday a total of $17,954,000 of temporary-loan notes, all dated May 6, 1942, and maturing variously from Sept. 30, 1942, to May 11, 1943.

ALBANY, April 22 -- Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan, State Director of Civilian Defense, resigned today as the result of criticism in official and legislative quarters over the way he has handled defense activities. Lieut. Gen. Stanley H. Ford, his principal assistant, also resigned, leaving to Governor Lehman the task of filling both places by May 1, when the new State War Council comes into being.

Declaring that this country needs China as much as China needs us in the conflict with Japan, Paul G. Hoffman, national chairman of United China Relief, made a plea yesterday for "investment in Chinese morale" as a vital move in helping "to win this war and to win it quickly."

With feet and legs coming into general use again, and not as yet frozen, the noble art of pedestrianism may be revived. Bear Mountain Park officials, it is reported, are "convinced that walking is the thing these days." More visitors are tramping the park's 300 miles of trails than in any Spring season in its thirty-two-year history.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Ways and Means Committee began today the task of writing the largest tax bill in history, but not without misgivings that President Roosevelt's coming recommendations for inflation control might alter the measure materially.

ALBANY, April 22 -- Party lines were split today when the Assembly, by a vote of 101 to 40, adopted the resolution by Assemblyman Caffery, Buffalo Democrat, putting the State on record against the proposed St. Lawrence Seaway. Many New York City Democrats voted for the resolution after Assemblyman Torsney, Queens Democrat, warned that the seaway would ruin the Port of New York.

Samuel Reshevsky of Boston took an undisputed lead in the biennial championship of the United States Chess Federation at the Hotel Astor last night by defeating Harry Baker in thirty moves. Thereby the famous internationalist left Isaac I. Kashdan behind.

"No record exists of any worker refusing to work as long as necessary to turn out war materials," State Industrial Commissioner Freida S. Miller declared yesterday in a special report on the operations of war industry in New York State under emergency dispensations lifting some of the State restrictions on working hours.

STOCKHOLME, Sweden, April 22 -- The German food problem is steadily growing more difficult, according to Dr. Max Klauss, writing in the Nationale Sozialistische Landpost. The Reich today has 8,000,000 more to feed than at the outbreak of war, he said, and the occupied countries are now a burden instead of an asset as at the beginning.

Other things being reasonably fortunate, to be 16 ought to be happiness enough. To be 16 and a Princess would be the top of good fortune, according to the old reckoning of court poets. Tuesday the Princess Elizabeth was 16. The birthday marked her coming of age and her beginning of the duties to which she was born.
NEW YORK { Judge and Nfrs. 1. Delano Put-{ nam have come from Boston to the { Biltmore.

LONDON, April 22 -- Announcement that American troops are in India and that more will be coming was made by Colonel Louis Johnson, President Roosevelt's special envoy to India, in a press interview at New Delhi today.

Sale of the six-story apartment building at 172 Fifth Avenue, corner of Twenty-second Street, by the Never-Fail Realty Corporation to the Random Realty Corporation was announced yesterday by Dwight, Voorhis Helmsley, brokers, who also sold the twelve-story loft building at 598 Broadway for, the Fifty Central Park West Corporation to Margaret M. White.

Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands, piloting a twin-engined plane lent to him by the Canadian Government, flew into New York from Ottawa yesterday to join his wife, the Crown Princess Juliana, in a brief visit to the United States that will take them to the White House today as guests of President and Mrs. Roosevelt.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 22 (U.P.) -- Russian forces, waging an offensive on the 2,000-mile front from the Black Sea to the Arctic, destroyed 126 German tanks in a three-day battle around a strategic railway station on the southern front, military dispatches reported tonight.

FRENCH LICK SPRINGS, Ind., April 22 -- If the United States is to avoid "damaging inflation" the greatest part of the money to finance the war should be obtained from the current income of the people, the economic policy commission of the American Bankers Association reported here today at the annual Spring meeting of the association's executive council.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 22 -- All departments in the Westchester County government were ordered today by County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach to reduce their expenditures 5 per cent below the allowances granted in the 1942 county budget.

Wartime rationing orders from Washington acted as a counterbalance yesterday on the stock market, and as a result the price range was narrow with stocks drifting in another dull section. Volume on the Stock Exchange just managed to climb over the quarter million share mark as the day set the fourth lightest five-hour session in almost a year.
WEST POINT, N.Y., April 22 -- Army and Syracuse battled eleven innings to a 12-all tie today in a long-drawn-out and loosely played game that was called on account of darkness.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Sugar rationing in the United States was definitely set today for May 5 by the Office of Price Administration, which fixed the normal allowance to each person at a trifle more than half a pound a week.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The armed forces are great places for career women but not for playgirls, according to Mrs. Julia Flikke, the highest-ranking woman officer in the Army.
Pelham St. George Bissell, President Justice of the Municipal Court, was installed as Exalted Ruler of the Mother Lodge of Elkdom No. 1 last night at the Elk Clubhouse, 799 Seventh Avenue.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 22 (UP) -- The status of New Zealand in the United Nations set-up was partly cleared up today when it was learned that Vice Admiral Robert L. Ghormley of the United States Navy had been ordered to Auckland to organize a joint American-New Zealand naval command.

BETHPAGE, L.I., April 22 -- Thousands of workers at the Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation's plant, here, gave an enthusiastic greeting today to Lieut. Comdr. Edward H. O'Hare, who flew in just before noon from Washington after having received the Congressional Medal of Honor yesterday from President Roosevelt in recognition of his feat in shooting down five Japanese bombers and damaging another.

VALLETTA, Malta, April 22 (AP) -- At least thirty-seven Axis planes were destroyed or damaged in heavy enemy thrusts at airdromes and the harbor area on this British island base yesterday and today, it was reported tonight.

THE relation of the termite to athletics, now under academic discussion in scientific circles, was taken up with this department's highly unpaid scientific consultant, Mr. William L. Laurence, who is a Harvard alumnus with redeeming qualities.

Working to the rhythm of a grandfather's clock, sixty women with "analytical minds" have taken over a large laboratory in Wall Street as inspectors for the gauge division of the Inspection Board of the United Kingdom and Canada.
The Louis Goodman Company, electrical contractors, has leased the three-story factory building at 729 Metropolitan Avenue, Brooklyn, containing about 10,000 square feet.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Approval was given by the House today to a bill increasing from $300,000,000 to $800,000,000 the government's mortgage insurance authority for the housing of war workers.

Before the present war interrupted all such efforts the United States was making fair progress with housing reform, backed by public subsidies, credit, mortgage insurance and tax exemptions. Last year housing reform changed into defense housing. This year it has become war housing, justified only as it promotes larger production in the war industries.

ST. LOUIS, April 22 (AP) -- A double and single with two out in the ninth spoiled a five-hit shutout for Harry Gumbert today as the Cardinals plastered Cincinnati, 6 to 1. The tally, scored on the one-two punch of Chuck Aleno and Ray Lamanno, served only as a face saver for the Reds, who had been blanked yesterday.

Commuters to New York City who are 45 to 64 years old, inclusive, must register for selective service in their home communities and not in any of the 280 registration places in the five boroughs, on Saturday, Sunday or Monday, it was reiterated yesterday by Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, draft director here.
For the first time since 1930, a new player heads the rankings of the National Squash Tennis Association.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 22 -- Under the slogan "Sell More to Chile, Buy More From Chile," Argentina commenced effective work today on a survey of Chilean markets, linking up of the industries of the two countries and withdrawal of all barriers for intensification of economic and commercial relations.

The nation's gasoline inventories at the close of last week amounted to 103,502,000 barrels, a decline of 1,078,000 from the 104,580,000 reported a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A year ago these stocks amounted to 97,377,000 barrels.

Warned by a passenger plane flying overhead that a submarine was trailing her, a medium-sized United States ship zigzagged for hours in a futile attempt to shake off the underwater craft, and when this failed tried to ram the submarine, it was revealed yesterday by survivors on their arrival in New Orleans.

NEW DELHI, India, April 22 (AP) -- The Japanese are throwing into the battle for Burma all the powerful forces that overran Malaya, including tanks and heavy guns, British quarters said tonight. Bitter British-Chinese resistance, however, is held to be spoiling the time-table of conquest and giving the Allies a chance to mass sea and air power for the salvation of India.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- "Roughly 50 per cent of the expansion in consumer income during recent months has been saved," a Department of Commerce report said today.
"Pop," said 15-year-old George, "what's hay?" Pop looked up from his paper and grinned. "Hay? Well, now, you take a thousand bucks. That's not hay."
WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- The Red Sox buried the Senators under a seventeen-hit barrage today to win, 13 to 4, and keep step with the Yankees.

Throughout the nation, in the parks, plazas and other open spaces, there are thousands of monuments which have long outlived their original significance and which never did offer any great artistic appeal to the eye. Would it not be a good thing to follow the example of early patriots and melt these superfluities into armament, thus combining permanent esthetic benefit with an important contribution to the war effort?

The New York Music Critics Circle announced yesterday the five orchestral works and the seven chamber music compositions from which it will choose its award winner in each category as the best new American work of the season.

VICHY, France, April 22 (AP) -- The Germans freed today the one French hero of the Battle of France, General Rene Jacques Adolphe Prioux, whose sacrificial stand enabled the British to escape at Dunquerque. It was announced that the 63-year-old general had returned to France "for reasons of health."

What prompted the Office of Petroleum Coordinator to request the American Petroleum Institute to refrain from publishing weekly refinery activity and oil-product inventories along the Atlantic Coast is not clear to many persons in the industry. Since early this year, when submarine activity started off the Atlantic Coast, the inventory position on the East Coast has been steadily deteriorating.

In releasing new wholesale prices prices for Fall on its Worsted-tex line of clothing, Cohen, Goldman Co. yesterday announced that under present circumstances it would not make any recommendations on suggested retail prices. At the same time, because of the limited amount of goods which will be available for Fall, the company asked its accounts to purchase on the basis of a certain percentage of the advance orders placed a year ago.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- A bill to authorize the Reconstruction Finance Corporation or a subsidiary to buy or advance money on the 600,000 new ears which are "frozen" in the showrooms of dealers was approved today by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Evidence showing that former Governor James M. Curley of Massachusetts, and Donald W. Smith, one-time member of the National Labor Relations Board, served as officers of Engineers Group, Inc., a lobbying organization accused of swindling four firms of contractors of $21,000 they had paid as "deposits" for defense housing contracts, was presented today to the Truman senatorial investigating committee.

Praise and awards were bestowed at Police Headquarters yesterday upon twenty-four policemen who had performed humane deeds for animals. The awards were given by the Humane Society as a feature of "Be Kind to Animals Week."

JERSEY CITY, April 22 (AP) -- Jersey City made it three out of four in its series with Toronto today by winning, 2 to 1, when Sid Gordon's long fly to left scored Hugh Poland from third base in the tenth.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- A blanket freezing of virtually all prices at last month's levels probably will be proclaimed next Tuesday as part of the administration's drastic anti-inflation program, authoritative sources said today.

CHICAGO, April 22 (AP) -- Apparently anxious to get about all the swine the country had to offer, buyers pushed hogs up 10 to 20 cents a hundred pounds today for the second consecutive session. Trading was at an active pace. Divergent trends featured cattle trading. Wooled lambs were steady and shorn offerings steady to unevenly higher. Department of Agriculture figures:

Non-exploitation of the State's wild life resources and adoption of a rule that Federal grants be used to supplement State conservation appropriations are among the recommendations made by Conservation Commissioner Osborne in his annual report to the Governor and the Legislature.

The work of the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association is helping to take the minds of national advertisers off the question of rates and fasten their attention on newspaper values, according to the bureau's twenty-ninth annual report issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Gasoline rationing in seventeen Eastern States and the District of Columbia, with the general motorist restricted to 2 1/2 to 5 gallons a week, will begin on May 15, except for commercial vehicle operators and some off-the-road users.
HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 22 (AP) -- True North, owned and bred by the Howe Stable, scored a handy victory in the thirtieth Aberdeen Stakes today.
LONDON, April 22 -- A combined Operations Headquarters communique follows:

The two-family dwelling at 32-39 Thirty-fifth Street, Long Island City, Queens, has been sold by Auguste Karlman to Paul and Mildred Villare in a deal arranged by William Krahe Son, Inc., broker. There are eleven rooms and two baths in the structure, which is on a lot 25 by 98 feet.

LIMA, Peru, April 22 (U.P.) -- President Manuel Prado today announced postponement of a visit to the United States, a day before the Peruvian Congress was scheduled to meet to decide whether he should be authorized to make a "visit of state."

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday, after a conference at City Hall with John H. Delaney, chairman of the Board of Transportation, that plans for early demolition of the Second Avenue elevated line between Sixtieth Street and Chatham Square would soon be presented to the Board of Estimate for approval. With the plans will be submitted a request for authority to discontinue service on the line, as a preliminary to the demolition job.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 22 -- In the first lawsuit brought by a prospective Japanese evacuee attacking the constitutionality of the evacuation orders of Lieut. Gen. John L. De Witt, the Federal District Court at Seattle has expressed the view that movements of civilians may be restricted, regardless of their loyalty or lack of it, "in critical military areas desperately essential for national defense."

Buying by mills in the late trading, under the impetus of the government's placement of heavy orders for cotton products, advanced the cotton market as much as 14 points yesterday. On the strength of hedging at the close, however, active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange backed away to final net gains of 5 to 11 points over Tuesday's closing levels.

LONDON, April 22 -- Ivan M. Maisky, the Soviet Ambassador, expressed the belief today that as a result of efforts by the United Nations "a decisive turn will take place in the war's course this year and the first light of day will appear before struggling humanity."
LONDON, April 22 -- Lord Portsea in the House of Lords today made a dramatic plea for food for the children of Jersey and Guernsey, two of the largest of the Channel Isles under German occupation.

AN ADVANCED UNITED NATIONS AIR BASE, Southwest Pacific, Thursday, April 23 -- A flight of United States bombers on one of the most recent raids on Rabaul, New Britain, was pounced on by fifteen Japanese Zero fighters, but all the United States planes returned safely.

VICHY, France, April 22 -- German occupation authorities executed more than fifteen additional French hostages in Paris today, bringing to more than 100 the number killed in the past week in reprisal for continued sabotage and attacks on German soldiers. The announcement that fifteen were executed was followed by the disclosure that another group of an unspecified number had been put to death.

Eleven millinery colors have been selected for the 1942 Fall season, it was announced here yesterday by the Textile Color Card Association. They were chosen, it was said, to conform not only to dyestuff restrictions but for their adaptability to medium and dark fur felt stocks, especially the latter, which now constitute practically the only available stocks for civilian use.

The Yankees gave it to the Athletics yesterday with every barrel and blasted their way to an 11-to-5 victory at the Stadium. In flattening the well-flattened Philadelphians they enjoyed their biggest hitting and run-gathering day of the new campaign as they made thirteen safeties for twenty-three bases.
CHUNGKING, China, April 22 (Reuter) -- This Chinese communique was issued today:

DETROIT, April 23 (AP) -- Rookie Hal White of the Tigers pitched his second successive American League shutout today by limiting the White Sox to five scattered hits for a 9-0 triumph. The 23-year-old right-hander, up from Buffalo of the International League, permitted no Chicagoan to reach third base.
BERLIN, April 23 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:
The address of Lord Beaverbrook before the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association last night follows:

NEW DELHI, India, April 23 (U.P.) -- The American and Indian people are "natural comrades and allies" and even though the United States is helping the expansion of India's war industries it has no post-war economic ambitions here, Colonel Louis Johnson, President Roosevelt's special envoy, said tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Doubt that the motoring public would be cut so low as 2 1/2 to 5 gallons a week when gasoline rationing begins in the East was expressed today by Secretary Ickes, Petroleum Coordinator, and Leon Henderson, chief of the Office of Price Administration.

The first Woodhaven Music Festival, presented under the auspices of the Woodhaven Festival Committee, headed by C. Edward Mills, opened last night with a choral program by the Woodhaven Methodist Church Choir, under the baton of Dr. Harold A. Strickland, the festival's musical director.

CANTERBURY, England, April 23 -- A blaze of medieval pageantry, made more inspiring by the grim overtones of modern warfare, marked the enthronement today of the ninety-sixth Primate of All England in the cathedral here.

The City College Reserve Officers Training Corps, largest voluntary collegiate unit in the nation, held its twenty-fourth annual President's Day review and decoration ceremonties yesterday in Lewisohn Stadium, 138th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

ALBANY, April 23 -- After extended debate and with no votes to spare, the Assembly today passed and sent to the Governor the Halpern bill which allows local boards of education to make their own rules for the conduct of "varsity" athletic programs.

Establishment of a clear-cut national program for the orderly recruitment, training and placement of the country's total labor force was foreshadowed at the employment and vocational guidance conference, held last night under the auspices of the Welfare Council of New York at Hotel Pennsylvania, as a major stop in the war program.
NEWARK, N.J., April 23 (AP) -With Bud Metheny and George Stirnweiss rapping three blows apiece in a nine-hit attack, the Bears today vanquished the Red Wings, 6 to 4.
POUGHKEEPSIE, April 23 -- Mrs. Sara-Delano Roosevelt, mother of the President, left a net estate estimated at $1,089,872, a New York State transfer tax appraisal showed today.
A German Transocean wireless dispatch, datelined Brussels, Belgium, and recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES last night, said in part:

The advantages of directing an Arctic attack upon the Nazi occupants of Norway to preserve the lease-lend supply lines to Russia were put forward last night by Johan Nygaardsvold, Prime Minister of the Norwegian Government-in-Exile, who arrived here yesterday on a Pan American Airways clipper.

A banking group headed by Smith, Barney Co., submitted yesterday the highest bid for an issue of $6,000,000 City of Indianapolis, Ind., gas utility revenue bonds, naming a price of 100.8599 for 3 1/8s. Official award of the issue is expected to be made today.

Lee Savold, Des Moines heavyweight, will have his chance to reestablish himself as a first-flight performer as the result of a match made yesterday by Mike Jacobs, president of the Twentieth Century Sports Club. Savold was signed by Jacobs as a replacement for Abe Simon against Lou Nova in a ten-round bout on the Navy Relief card scheduled for Washington on May 21.

Bronx Zoo officials have been on constant edge since 4 P.M. Tuesday, when the male baby giant panda climbed to the top of a forty-foot hickory tree and refused to come down. After doing a "sitting-on-a-flagpole" act for forty-one hours, he was coaxed down yesterday morning with a bowl of mush.

Mrs. Catherine J. Gregg pleaded guilty yesterday before Judge Jonah J. Goldstein in General Sessions to the theft of $15,000 from Mrs. Elizabeth Clark Tyler Miller of 277 Park Avenue, whose trusted financial agent she had been. The plea came as the jury was being selected to try her on the charge, which caused her extradition from Cleveland early this year.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Strict control was put by the War Production Board tonight on all new installations of telephones and extensions.

MEXICO CITY, April 23 -- Vicente Lombardo Toledano, Mexican labor leader, has told the Federation of Mexican Workers that when he was recently in Washington, Vice President Henry A. Wallace told him President Roosevelt was disposed to urge Latin-American governments to give every facility for organization by Senor Lombardo Toledano of a Latin-American labor federation.

BUENOS AIRES, April 23 -- Demand for firm action by the Argentine Government on the torpedoing of the tanker Victoria was made by the newspaper El Mundo this morning. It is the first of the major dailies to take up the matter editorially. The impression caused by El Mundo's remarks is heightened by the fact that they were made in violation of the State siege regulations which forbid any public discussion of international questions.
The Tokyo radio, obviously fishing for information, indirectly asked the United State Army and Navy yesterday to tell what they knew about Saturday's air raids on Japan.

PRINCTON, N.J., April 23 -- Seniors at Princeton University have chosen Laurence B. Holland of Glencoe, Ill., as the "most likely to succeed" and the one who has "done most for the class," while Dewey F. Bartlett of Marietta, Ohio, is considered the "best all-around man" and the "most respected."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 23 (U.P.) -- Two waves of bombers flew high over Copenhagen last night, but dropepd no bombs, and Swedish observers reported today they believed the planes sowed magnetic mines in waters east and south of the German-occupied Danish capital that now are largely ice-free.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 23 -- About 1,100 Norwegian teachers who refused to join the Quisling Teachers Union have been sent to northern labor camps, over protests of townspeople and clergy, it was reported here today.

LONDON, April 23 -- Opposition to the plan outlined by Dr. Hugh Dalton for fuel, gas and electricity rationing is now so strong that the government announced today it was giving the House of Commons an opportunity to discuss the Beveridge report before any order based on it was issued.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, April 23 -- The New Zealand command, separate from that of the Southwest Pacific, will include Fiji and other islands in this area, it was revealed today by Prime Minister Peter Fraser.

Members of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, at their annual meeting at the Hotel Waldorf - Astoria yesterday, the final business session of their annual convention, unanimously adopted a resolution pledging "unswerving support" to President Roosevelt "in this hour of national crisis."

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed reserve note circulation and holdings of United States Government securities to be at the highest of the year to date, the latter showing increase of $41,743,000 for the week.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 23 (U.P.) -- A powerful hormone that has increased production in some crops as much as 100 per cent was described before the American Chemical Society today. The compound, levulinic acid, has produced remarkable increases in yields of cotton, corn, oats, alfalfa, soy beans, cowpeas, beats and grasses, according to W.W. Moyer of the A.E. Staley Manufacturing Company of Decatur, Ill.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (U.P.) -- Secretary Stimson said today that the Army was installing along the nation's coastlines new "electric eye" detection devices capable of reducing the surprise element of enemy raids by locating planes or ships more than a hundred miles away.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- A consolidated net profit of $4,229,821 was realized by the Baldwin Locomotive Works after provision of $4,498,000 for taxes in the twelve months ended on March 31, it was reported today by Charles E. Brinley, president.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Senate completed Congressional action today on war profits control legislation and sent it, attached to the $19,151,597,000 Army-Navy Supplemental Appropriation Bill, to President Roosevelt.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 23 -- All German school children down to 10 years of age as well as women not already engaged in war work are being mobilized to help farmers with Spring sowing and later with the harvest, according to a decree just published in Berlin.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- War bond quotas for the country for May, June and July, and May quotas for the States were announced tonight as the Treasury called upon the people to voluntarily put 10 per cent of the national income into the securities.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 23 (AP) -- Colonel E.R. Bradley's Bless Me faded out of the Kentucky Derby picture today by losing a three-and-a-half-length decision to Mrs. Payne Whitney's Shut Out in the $10,000 added Bluegrass Stakes at Keeneland's Spring meeting finale.

BOSTON, April 23 -- With good fortune, a few timely base hits and the dependable right arm of Fireman Hugh Casey, the Dodgers ran their winning streak to five straight today. They beat the Braves by 9 to 5.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Department store sales in the week ended April 18 were 15 per cent above the corresponding week a year ago, the Federal Reserve m Board anno.dnc'ed today. Last week l a decrease of 12 per cent was reported.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Announcement by Secretary Morgenthau today that the Treasury would embark on new financing in May led to speculation whether the new issue would see a change in the. Treasury's borrowing policy. The expected change would be from open-market flotations to registered issues and from very short and very long term issues to securities varying between two and ten years.
ALBANY, April 23 -- Moving to clear their calendars in the drive for adjournment tomorrow, both houses of the Legislature acted on a series of defense measures today.

The War Production Drive provides management with the greatest opportunity it has ever enjoyed to cross the "present no-man's land between it and labor," but so far few plants have taken advantage of it, Clyde M. Vandeburg, liaison officer between the Army, Navy and Maritime Commission and the War Production Board, declared yesterday in a luncheon at a one-day forum of the House Magazine Institute at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

During the flurry yesterday regarding the discussion of gasoline rationing and its effect upon trips to fishing centers this Summer it was a coincidence that an envelope postmarked "Quebec" should arrive. It proved to contain an information bulletin from the Quebec Tourist Bureau, with provisions governing gasoline rationing for visitors to Canada.

BOSTON, April 23 -- Sharp decreases in orders received by Massachusetts mills and factories are shown in the monthly index of orders released today by the Associated Industries of Massachusetts. As compared with February of this year, March orders for textiles showed a decrease of 27 per cent; those for paper dropped 14.4 per cent; the metal trades component was off 7.7 per cent, and the combined group slumped 6.8 per cent.

CHUNGKING, China, April 23 (U.P.) -- Japanese forces with numerical superiority as high as ten to one have swept to within 140 miles of Mandalay on the central Burma front, captured Loikaw in the east and may have outflanked the Chinese at Yenangyaung in the Continued From Page One west, a Chinese communique announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- An agreement whereby the United States will help in the development of the rubber resources of Peru and other strategic materials was concluded today by the exchange of notes between Secretary Hull and David Dasso, Minister of Finance Commerce of Peru.
ST. LOUIS, April 23 (AP) -- The Indians smashed through the Browns' defense in the eighth and ninth innings today for a 9-to-2 victory.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 23 -Addressing the German Chamber of Commerce the Amsterdam, the Netherlands, yesterday, Reich Finance Minister Count Lutz Schwerin von Krosigk declared that the study of post-war financial problems had taught the German people how to avoid inflation and economic dependence on the outside world.

The controversy over whether the employer representatives at President Roosevelt's industry-labor conference last December had agreed to let the War Labor Board arbitrate cases involving the closed shop was renewed last night when nine of the twelve employer representatives joined in a statement denying that they had ever agreed to arbitration of the closed shop issue.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Home deliveries by retailers will be curtailed beginning May 15, when local carriers, including stores, dairymen, laundries and others, will be forbidden to make any special deliveries, or "call backs," and will be limited both as to number of deliveries and mileage.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -The Senators routed the Red Sex today, 10 to 5, and dropped Boston out of a first-place tie with the Yankees.

The pending over-all freeze of prices which is expected to be announced next week will not bring abandonment of the piece-meal ceiling system, according to market reports here yesterday, and it was indicated that the Office of Price Administration will continue to issue ceiling orders affecting various commodities.

GENERAL JOSEPH ORVILLE SHELBY of Missouri was bowlegged, heavily bearded and tough. He was one of the great Confederate cavalry leaders of the Civil War. He wore a plume in his hat and a cloak with a red silk lining. His skill and daring in Arkansas and Missouri, plus the intense personal devotion he inspired in his troops, make him one of the most attractively dashing and surprisingly little publicized of all the Confederate cavaliers.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- James H. Doolittle, Army flier in the last war and a speed flier in the Twenties, became a brigadier general in the Army today.
CHICAGO, April 23 (AP) -Lou Novikoff, the celebrated "Mad Russian," opened the Cubs' sixth inning with a homer today to give Chicago a 2-1 decision over the Cardinals.

LONDON, April 23 (AP) -- Note circulation of the Bank of England increased 36,000 in the week ended yesterday, reaching 767,146,000, a high record, the condition statement disclosed today. It was the ninth consecutive weekly increase but was smaller than usual.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -Charges of malfeasance made against officials of the Defense Plant Corporation by Senator Bunker of Nevada on the ground that they had negotiated with Basic Magnesium, Inc., a contract for the production of magnesium at a new plant in Las Vegas which would give the corporation enormous profits were denied today by Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce.

The more important issues of outstanding revenue bonds felt the impact yesterday of rather severe selling pressure as investors generally viewed with increasing alarm the prospect of drastic curtailment of passenger vehicular traffic as a result of the rationing of gasoline.

The President plans to send to Congress next week a new and more comprehensive program for guarding against inflation. This is a matter of vital importance for the nation and every one in it. Failure to control inflation could readily bring on social and economic dislocations sufficient to imperil the success of our country in the war and the survival of our traditional political economy after the war.

Lord Beaverbrook pleaded last night in his speech before the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association for the immediate opening of a second front in Europe. He is convinced that it can be done: "How admirably Britain is now equipped in weapons of war for directing such an attack on Germany I well know."

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The general level of wholesale prices continued last week to climb slowly toward the 1926 average, according to the index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average, was 98.3 for the week ended on April 18, compared with 98.1 on April 11, 97.9 on April 4, 97.2 on March 21 and 83 on April 19, 1941.

The response to the Hickey-Freeman plan to achieve a 25 per cent cut in the price of Army officers' uniforms has been so prompt and widespread that the company will extend the scheme to cover officers' clothing for the Air Corps and the Navy, J.G. Hickey, president of the company, said yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 23 -The United States' refusal to recognize the Balkan countries' declarations of war. "in solidarity with the Tripartite pact members" and Sumner Welles's declaration early this month that if Hungary, Rumania and Bulgaria continued to extend active support to Hitler's war machine, the Washington government would move to declare war on them, has aroused the Budapest press to explanations.

Declaring that "nothing really matters except victory and a lasting peace," Mrs. William Henry Hays, re-elected president of the Women's National Republican Club, urged members at an annual meeting yesterday to strive for unity in the war program of "bringing freedom to the world."

Officials of Boston, Mass., announced yesterday plans for the sale next week of a total of $8,776,000 of new securities. On Monday the city will offer $5,000,000 of temporary loan notes, dated April 30 and maturing on Nov. 5. On Tuesday officials will entertain bids on $3,776,000 of funding and relief bonds, for which bidders are asked to specify the rate of interest.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -Thurman Arnold, assistant Attorney General, told Senators today that "when Hitler broke the cartel system" in Germany there was a boom within six months.
The ever-colorful Penn Relay Carnival, the forty-eighth in the series, will be staged at Franklin Field in Philadelphia today and tomorrow.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, April 23 (AP) -- The United States Army Air Force fought to the end on Bataan Peninsula and, with the Japanese only a few miles away, sent its last flyable plane into the air to attack and attempt to check the enemy's final advance.

Under the sponsorship of the National Safety Council, the War Production Fund to Conserve Manpower has been launched by a group of the nation's leading industrial executives to extend the safety drive on all fronts. Leaving out of account the terrible cost in human misery which is the result of our national carelessness, the bare statistics of the national accident loss are alarming.

Mayor La Guardia informed the City Council yesterday that he disapproved the proposal to provide free transportation on the city transit system for men in the armed services. The Mayor said it would be costly to the city and the taxpayers and pointed out that no railroad in the country had granted the privilege of free rides.

ALBANY, April 23 -- The Legislature passed and sent to the Governor today the bill advancing the date of the primary election, and all political dates hinging on the primary, by five weeks, to permit, at least theoretically, the casting of votes by New York State soldiers on foreign soil in the November election.

A nation-wide underwriting syndicate of 146 members, headed by Morgan Stanley Co., will offer today to the public a new issue of $100,000,000 of American Tobacco Company twenty-year 3 per cent debentures, due on April 15, 1962. The debentures will be priced at 100.

LONDON, April 23 -- There are villages in the British Isles as remote as the most isolated backwoods community in the Kentucky hills. One of them, consisting of a cluster of homes and a small chapel high in the Berwyn Mountains of Wales, has been until recently a stronghold of isolationism.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- President Roosevelt impressed upon members of the Board of Economic Warfare today the necessity for the utmost speed in acquiring the maximum amounts of war materials from foreign countries, both to accelerate the war production program and to prevent the Axis powers from obtaining supplies.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Internal revenue receipts for the nine months ended March 31 last were $9,255,717,021, which was $3,952,821,214, or 70 per cent more than for the corresponding period a year earlier, the Treasury reported today. For the month of March alone they were $3,457,140,116, as compared with $1,472,294,600, or nearly two and a half times as great.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 23 (U.P.) -- Russian shock troops have broken through the German first line of defense in the vital Bryansk sector 210 miles southwest of Moscow and are fighting furiously inside the belt of enemy fortifications, it was reported today.

Mayor La Guardia was criticized in the City Council yesterday for remaining away from Board of Estimate hearings on the budget, as Councilman Louis Cohen introduced an amendment to the City Charter to require the Mayor's attendance at Board meetings.
TRENTON, April 23 (AP) -- The State Defense Council, which has been at work since a few days after war broke out in Europe in 1939, sang its swan song today in almost perfect harmony.

PITTSBURGH, April 23 (AP) -Breaking loose with their biggest rally of the season, a five-run surge in the seventh, the Cincinnati Reds today set back Pittsburgh, 5 to 3, and gave Johnny Vander Meer his first victory of the year.

The three-story garden apartment house covering the south blockfront on Forty-second Avenue between 20th and 205th Streets, in the Bayside-Flushing section of Queens, has been sold by a client of Herbert Charles Co., brokers, to Frederick Brown for cash above a new 4 per cent ten-year mortgage of $97,500.

Another event in the novel series known as "All-Out" Town Hall concerts, under the auspices of the auction committee of the Citizens Committee for the Army and Navy, Inc., will be held at noon on Monday. At each of the events, to which the public is admitted without charge, debutantes of the season collect voluntary contributions.

LONDON, April 23 -- The stock markets were helped today by encouraging news from India and maintained a firm appearance. Gilt-edge issues showed little change. There was little response to the announcement of a new series of 3 per cent savings bonds.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 23 -- With Pierre Laval directing propaganda and censorship in Vichy in addition to running the Ministries of Interior and of Foreign Affairs, French public opinion is more than ever kept in the dark regarding foreign reaction.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Joseph B. Eastman, chairman of the Transportation Board, told the Truman Senatorial investigating committee today that he saw "nothing ahead now" to compel the government to take over the railroads as it did in the First World War.
PRETORIA, Union of South Africa, April 28 (U.P.) -- The Union of South Africa broke relations with Vichy France today.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Serious doubt that Japan would attempt an all-out attack on Australia was expressed in a press conference here today by Dr. Hubertus van Mook, Lieutenant Governor General of the Japanese-occupied Netherlands Indies.

There is a perfectly clear distinction between the activities of Communists on the Russian front and Communist activities in the New York public schools. We should be ungrateful fools not to aid and endorse the first. We are not called upon to accept the second, any more than Stalin is called upon to permit anti-Communist propaganda in the schools of Moscow.

WITH THE A.V.G. in Burma, April 10 (Delayed) (AP) -- Driven out of Mingaladon and then Magwe, the fighting Yanks of the American Volunteer Group, with the colors of China and Great Britain on their plane wings, now are braced against the inevitable heavy Japanese assaults on their new base defending Northern Burma.

" Keep 'Em Laughing," Clifford C. Fischer's second effort to revive vaudeville, will open tonight at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre. Victor Moore, William Gaxton, Hildegarde and Paul and Grace Hartman will present the headline acts.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 23 -- The United States Employment Service for Connecticut has filed the first registration card received in the State-wide mobilization of women with the notation "applicant placed," according to announcement made here yesterday by Leonard J. Maloney, State director of the service.

Eugene Loring's new Dance Players company gave its first change of bill last night at the National Theatre, introducing Mr. Loring's ballet, "Prairie," with music by Norman Dello Joio. If the company should not have another thing up its sleeve for its entire fortnight, this would more than justify its existence, for it is a poignant and lovely little work.

Lamb, traditional in the sunny Springtime, is an appealing and appropriate choice for the principal meal of the forthcoming week-end. And although the neck slices are unknown to many good housekeepers, they are nevertheless extraordinarily economical.

Rear Admiral Philippe Auboyneau, commander of the Free French naval forces, declared at an interview yesterday at the Free French Delegation offices, 626 Fifth Avenue, that he doubted if the Vichy-controlled fleet would be put at the disposal of the Nazis.

VICHY, France, April 23 (U.P.) -- German authorities in Paris tonight reprieved thirty-five Frenchmen from death and cut short a fifty-four-hour ban on amusements as reward for the arrest by French police of two groups of "terrorists" accused of attacking German soldiers, it was announced here.

The General Aniline and Film Corporation, stock control which of was taken over recently by the United States Treasury because of the predominant German interest in the company, will dispose today of its holdings of 153,053 shares of common stock of Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), it was disclosed yesterday.

Acting on their belief that the message of Major A.P. de Seversky's "Victory Through Air Power," published Monday, will revolutionize public thinking about the war, the judges of the Book-of-the-Month Club at a special meeting have decided to distribute the book with the previously selected book for June, a novel.

TRENTON, April 23 -- New Jersey, the State where motion-picture theatre bingo is believed to have been born about twelve years ago, turned thumbs down today on the modernized version of the game, "bank night."

The stock market took yesterday its worst plunge in more than a month, prices dropping to the lowest levels since early 1933 as the problems or taxes, rationing, price-fixing and control of inflation became more tangled than ever.

Spurred by messages from President Roosevelt and Donald M. Nelson, executives of twelve of the nation's largest corporations set in motion yesterday a campaign to cut down the toll of industrial accidents, which last year cost as many man-days of production as would be required to build sixty-six battleships or 180,000 fighter planes.

A very interesting feature of Laval's broadcast published in THE TIMES of April 20 is the fact that he makes no mention of the United States. Is it because he can find no slander against this country, even in his own fertile imagination and when his master is poking him in the ribs?

OTTAWA, April 23 (Canadian Press) -- Dominion Government deposits increased $5,347,000 to $98,936,000 in the week ended yesterday, the Bank of Canada reported today in its weekly bank statement. Notes in circulation decreased $1,598,000 to $513,838,000.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Women of the Congress of Industrial Organizations have told President Roosevelt that they want price control, rationing, fair taxation and wage increases to meet rising living costs, and have offered their services to help in enforcing retail price ceilings.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Should Social Justice, the magazine founded by Father Coughlin, be barred from the mails as a seditious publication, its circulation through virtually every other medium could be prevented under a ruling issued today by Attorney General Biddle.

A further reduction in gasoline deliveries to garages and service stations has been recommended to Petroleum Coordinator Ickes by the industry, to take effect May 1, it was disclosed yesterday as motorists took hope from Washington developments that their rations this Summer would enable them to keep their cars in operation.

JERUSALEM, April 23 -- Yugoslav sources here reported today that, according to information just received, Croatia is beginning to show signs of swinging over to the United Nations. They announce the creation of a "Green Army," made up mostly of deserters from the units of Ante Pavelitch, President of the new Croat State.

After another quiet session, active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday at the day's low levels and at net losses of 8 to 12 points. Near-month liquidation and appreciably diminished trade support near the close were responsible mainly for the decline.

A drive to raise $50,000 for the Spence School, 22 East Ninetyfirst Street, was announced last night at a dinner at the school attended by 500 graduates and former students in celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the school.

For the first time in many years the weekly statement of the sixteen regularly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City, as of Wednesday, reveals borrowing of "Federal funds" to bolster reduced reserve positions.

LONDON, Friday, April 24 (U.P.) -- Big British bombers hammered Germany for the second consecutive night of the Royal Air Force's reusmed offensive last night and early today, and a German broadcast said that Berlin itself was among the objectives

OTTAWA, April 23 -- Donald Gordon, chairman of the Canadian Wartime Prices and Trade Board, today welcomed the impending establishment by the United States of an over-all price ceiling as likely to aid the Dominion immeasurably in its own price control program.

The discovery at the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, of an electrical test for detecting cancer of the stomach in its early and still curable stages, that may open the way for the eventual elimination of this deadly type of cancer that accounts for nearly two-thirds of the cancer victims in the United States, came to light yesterday.
Thanks to the amazing ineptness of the aimless Athletics the Yankees this morning are undisputed owners of first place in the American League standing for the first time this year.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The eight executive officers of the Congress of Industrial Organizations made public today a series of communications dissenting from John L. Lewis's request that the C.I.O. credit the miners' union with two months per capita taxes because of a "debt" of $1,665,000 owed by the parent body to the miners' union.

Irving K. Hessberg, president of the Van Raalte Company, Inc., said at the annual meeting of stockholders here yesterday that operations in the company's regular lines of hosiery, gloves and underwear probably would be at a minimum of 50 to 60 per cent of capacity this year.

LONDON, Friday, April 24 (U.P.) -- Today's Soviet radio announcement of the internment of a United States war plane and its crew was the first confirmation from an Allied source that United States fliers had carried the war to Japan.

PEORIA, Ill., April 23 (AP) -George P. McNear Jr., president, and two other officials of the Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad were acquitted by a Federal court jury today of charges of violating the National Railway Labor Act by coercing union employes.

Commercial bank depositaries of the United States Government in the Second Federal Reserve District were notified yesterday by the Treasury that $28,147,000 will be withdrawn on Monday from these accounts and a like amount on the following day.

PITTSBURGH, April 23 -- Girls in Pittsburgh public schools may wear slacks to classes, if they choose, providing the fad does not create distraction, acting superintendent Gerald D. Whitney ruled today.

Shakespeare, whose 378th birthday occurred yesterday, brought 3,000 persons of all ages and nationalities together during the afternoon in Central Park. Children laughed as the famous clown scene from "A Midsummer Night's Dream" was enacted for their special beenfit and listened intently while sonnet were heard once more in such a setting as might have inspired them.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- A 70-year-old theory that three separate prehistoric cultures, one of them dating from the glacial or pre-glacial age, existed in what is now New Jersey has been disproved as the result of extensive excavations requiring five years to complete, it was stated today in a paper read before the American Philosophical Society by Dr. Dorothy Cross of the department of sociology and anthropology at Hunter College.

MONTREAL, April 24 (U.P.) -Feeling in this French-Canadian city against conscription of men for military service outside of Canada erupted late last night and early today in unauthorized street demonstrations, which were broken up by large detachments of policemen.

LONDON, April 23 -- Today's reports from Burma show the Japanese pressing forward in their Mandalay drive, which now appears to be developing as a three-pronged attack. Two columns seem to be trying to envelop the resisting Chinese in Salween and Sittang valleys.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission announced today an investigation into complaints by railroads operating in New York State that the New York Public Service Commission and the Transit Commission had refused to permit them to establish for intrastate transportation of passengers increased commutation rates and fares corresponding to the 10 per cent increase in interstate fares recently authorized by the commission.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 23 (AP) -- America was declared today to have the world's greatest secret weapon, the inventive genius.

In the years of adolescence, perhaps life's most poignant affliction is that to which the British refer as "spots." At 16 a "spot" assumes the significance of a blight, and it is fortunate, psychologically speaking, that something can be done.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The War Production Board ordered a reduction today in the amount of elastic fabric permitted in corsets, girdles, combinations, brassieres and similar women's apparel, in a move to double the number of garments which could be manufactured from present stocks.

Warners' "Larceny, Inc.," starring Edward G. Robinson, will be the new attraction opening this morning at the Strand. The comedy, based on the Laura and S.J. Perelman play "The Night Before Christmas," includes in the cast Jane Wyman, Broderick Crawford, Edward Brophy, Jack Carson, Harry Davenport and Barbara Jo Allen. Featured in the Strand's stage show will be Jackie Cooper, the film actor.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 23 -- Nine-tenths of the whole German Army is on the Russian front and Reichsfuehrer Hitler has called up 1,900,000 reserves, but the Red _Army is moving'up enough men to meet this immense threat, the official Soviet spokesman declared today.
Through the night and up to 11 A.M. yesterday Bellevue's "shutins" ran a temperature, but doctors were not alarmed.

Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of Christ Church, was the guest of honor last night at a dinner in celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of his pastorate. About 500 members of the church attended the testimonial dinner, which was held in the parish hall of the church, at Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

One thousand insurance workers gave up part of their lunch hour yesterday to participate in a patriotic rally on behalf of Friends of Beekman, Inc., which was sponsore by Insurance Post 1081 of the American Legion at Maiden Lane and William Street.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Practically all products of the cotton textile industry will be under price-ceiling control of the Office of Price Administration after May 4, when all types of carded gray and finished cotton goods not previously covered by schedules come under ceilings, under terms of an order issued today.

Supreme Court Justice Peter Schmuck denied yesterday an application by the Bank of France to vacate the order of attachment on funds of the bank held in the Federal Reserve Bank here, which was obtained a year ago in connection with the suit by the National Bank of Belgium for recovery of $228,000,000 in gold.

Maria Maximovitch, Russian-American soprano, who gave a series of five song programs earlier in the year, was heard in her final recital of the season last night in Town Hall. According to her custom, Miss Maximovitch had arranged a list containing numerous worthy compositions infrequently presented.

United China Relief is prepared to bring some Chinese relief to housewives of the United States who are fighting the battle of vitamins on the home front. Vitamins are an old story in China -- not by name, but included in the fundamentals of skilled cookery to preserve nutritious elements in food.

A medium-sized United States cargo ship was torpedoed off the Atlantic Coast on April 18 but despite a gaping hole in its starboard side was able to make an East Coast port, it was disclosed yesterday by the Navy. The master, Captain John D. Baldwin of Brooklyn, and one member of the crew, were slightly injured by the explosion.

CHICAGO, April 23 -- A change in sentiment occurred in the wheat market overnight as the result of the constant repetition of reports that drastic price-control measures would be announced by the Office of Price Administration early next week, in addition to a statement by the same government agency that there would be no change in the ceiling on fats and oils.

Eighty per cent of the Johns-Manville Corporation's production is essential to the prosecution of the war, Lewis H. Brown, president, told a large number of stockholders at an informal meeting in the Roosevelt Hotel here yesterday afternoon.

The Goodyear Aircraft Corporation has invoked nearly every form of advertising and promotion activity to step up its production rate under the direction of a joint labor-management production committee. Tying in with the WPB program of one plane every eight minutes this year, the company used the numeral 8 as its symbol in a campaign in newspapers, radio, billboards, house organs, car cards and direct mail.

Renwick Hall, the home of Major and Mrs. Donald C. Strachan in Westport, Conn., will be the setting tonight for a Commando Ball to be given as a tribute to the men of Britain and Norway who compose the Commando units raiding the coast of Nazi-occupied Europe.

LONDON, April 23 -- Britain's latest foray by Commando troops across the English Channel near Boulogne seems to have added considerably to the jumpiness of Nazi commanders along that long 2,000-mile coast line from Norway's frontiers to Spain which they have to guard.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 23 -Fredric March was signed today by Warner Brothers to play the title role in "The Adventures of Mark Twain," Jesse Lasky's next production, which will go before the cameras June 15. Irving Rapper, who directed March in Warners' "One Foot in Heaven," has been named to direct "Mark Twain," replacing Howard Hawks, and Olivia de Havilland is expected to appear as Olivia Langdon, wife of the humorist.
BERMUDA, April 23 -- Thirty-three survivors of a torpedoed Swedish ship were landed here last night. Six men, including the captain, were reported missing.

ALBANY, April 23 -- Governor Lehman filled two important State posts today. He appointed Carroll E. Mealey, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, to the presidency of the tax commission, succeeding Mark Graves, who recently resigned because of ill health.

Declaring that a stirrup pump used against incendiary bombs was "nothing more than a glorified bicycle pump with an extra length of rubber," the City Council Defense Committee announced yesterday that no householder would be compelled to buy such a pump if its cost was more than $5.

In Edward Alden Jewell's article on the exhibition of Flemish primitives at Knoedler's the mistake was made of stating that French is the official tongue of Belgium, while Flemish, or a dialect based upon it, still is spoken.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Following is the joint appeal to automobile owners issued by Harold L. Ickes, Petroleum Coordinator; Donald Nelson, War Production Board chairman; the Price Administrator, Leon Henderson; J.B. Eastman, Defense Transportation Director, and the War Shipping Administrator, Emory S. Land:

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 23 -- Anti-Soviet tendencies in certain Polish newspapers published in London are exposed in the Russian newspapers Pravda and Izvestia by publication of a Tass news agency dispatch from London citing criticisms of the policies of the Polish publications in the Mlade Ceskoslovenske, the organ of the Left-Wing group of Czechoslovaks in London.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The gaudy lures with which fishermen tantalize trout and other fish fell a casualty to war production today. Intent upon saving the metals, plastics and cork which go into equipment upon which fishermen spent $15,000,000 last year, the War Production Board ruled today that after May 31 the industry must stop using such materials for fishing tackle.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Secretary Morgenthau said today that the Treasury Department was preparing to recommend legislation which would make newly mined domestic silver available to industrial users at the world market price just as imported silver is now.

George D. Widener, master of Erdenheim Farm and a figure in international racing for a generation, was elected president of Belmont Park yesterday at a meeting of the board of directors of the Westchester Racing Association. The election followed the resignation of A.G. Vanderbilt, who has applied for a commission in the Navy.

Two air raid wardens of Zone 1, in the Washington Heights section, were dismissed yesterday for the unauthorized collection of funds with which to buy equipment for their post, and four other wardens of the same zone resigned in protest over the alleged failure of the police to back them up in disciplinary action taken against a woman warden.

In fighting to defeat totalitarianism, England never will go totalitarian herself, but, through a "people's victory," will emerge as an even stronger democracy in which "there will be no room either for selfish privilege or idleness," Lord Halifax, British Ambassador to the United States, declared here last night.

In maintaining national unity the country is faced with the problem of keeping alive the patriotism of aliens, "a great majority of whom are loyal and just as interested in winning the war as any one," it was said yesterday at a conference on "The Christian's Responsibility Toward the Alien."
