WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Army offered today the special inducement of choice of service to any youth of the pro-draft ages of 18 and 19 who enlists.

ALBANY, April 23 (U.P.) -- The Court of Appeals upheld today the right of a bettor to recover gambling losses in court by reversing a lower court order favorable to Frank Erickson, who has been called "a tin horn gambler" by Mayor La Guardia.
CHUNGKING, China, April 23 (Reuter) -- Today's Chinese communique follows:

In London, about a year before the outbreak of the present war, my wife and I were hastening in a taxi upon urgent business through pressure of traffic when the taxi-driver suddenly drew up to the edge of the sidewalk, stopped and shut off his engine. "Why are you stopping?" I asked him. "

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- A plan' for excess profits taxes on corporations higher than had been recommended by the Treasury was presented to the Ways and Means Committee today by experts of the Joint Committee on Internal Revenue Taxation.

In order to keep abreast of the heavy demands for power arising out of the war, the American Gas and Electric Company system will spend approximately $42,000,000 for new construction in 1942, George N. Tidd, president, said yesterday in his annual report to stockholders.

Bank clearings of twenty-four major cities of the country for the week ended on Wednesday increased 9.2 per cent above the preceding week and 3.9 per cent over the comparable week a year ago, according to figures announced yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- Hal Schumacher, having served his five-day suspension, returned to the wars today, and without so much as casting a glance in the direction of his arch tormentor, Umpire Ziggy Sears, hurled the Giants to a 5-to-2 victory over the Phils.
VALLETTA, Malta, April 23 (Reuter) -- The British Command here issued this communique tonight:
Members of the Board of Estimate engaged in three disputes yesterday, livening up an otherwise dull session at City Hall.
JERSEY CITY, April 23 (AP) -Buffalo, helped considerably by Jersey City's pitchers, who issued thirteen bases on balls, defeated the Little Giants, 13 to 10, today.
Despite larger taxes, earnings of the National Distillers Products Corporation in the first three months of this year increased over those of the corresponding period a year ago.

Team-work is needed between the American press and government if we are to win the political and propaganda warfare that the Axis is waging against us, along with its military operations, Mrs. Anne O'Hare McCormick of the editorial staff of THE NEW YORK TIMES told the annual dinner of the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association in the Waldorf-Astoria last night.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Only by the loose and misleading use of plain words an distortion of the facts can it be argued -- as the National War Labor Board and union leaders lurray and Green are arguing -- that the employer members of the President's industrylabor peaee' conference here last December "agreed" that the closed shop issue should be arbitrable during the war.

ALBANY, April 23 -- A written promise by Mayor La Guardia that free transfers and an escalator would be provided for Queens passengers about to be deprived of the use of the Second Avenue elevated line was demanded today by Queens members of the Legislature, with the result that action again was delayed on the Jarema bill, which would speed the demolition of the Second Avenue elevated line from Queens to Chatham Square.

A 32-year-old Norwegian seaman, second officer on a torpedoed tanker sunk by an Italian submarine on April 6, told an unusual story here yesterday of a nine-day voyage that he and his men made after the sinking and which ended after they had covered 400 sea miles and come back to the place of torpedoing to be rescued.
The New York Junior League opened its annual Members Art Show yesterday in the clubhouse at 221 East Seventy-first Street. A luncheon preceded the judging of the work selected.
Spring has come to the Russian southern front and the ground is dry around the dark waters of the Black Sea.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, April 23 (AP) -- A quickening of the tempo of United Nations air raids on the Japanese-held base of Rabaul, New Britain Island, was announced today at General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters, along with word that Netherland and Australian forces still were battling the Japanese invaders of the island of Timor.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 23 (AP) -- The venerable State Board of Medical Examiners, which now has only $41 to its good name, went hat-in-hand to the Medical Society of New Jersey for financial help today -- and got the brush-off.

William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, charged yesterday that the Bronx Borough President's office had supplied Edward J. Flynn, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, with city-owned passenger cars for his private use and with city-owned station wagons for trucking purposes.

Less than two weeks ago India was on the front page of every free newspaper in the world because it was still hoped that she would reach an agreement with Great Britain in the matter of self-government. Now, because the British and Chinese Armies are trying to hold back the Japanese advance in Burma, the spotlight rests on the other side of the Bay of Bengal.

ROCHESTER, April 23 -- Fighting side by side with the Filipinos on Bataan, and facing the Japanese enemy against which China has protected us for five years, Americans know now "the real equality between races" and know "that in that idea of equality lies the only sure hope of the future," Wendell L. Willkie declared here tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- President Roosevelt conferred with the Board of Economic Warfare, Secretary Jones and Secretary Hull. He sent to the Senate the nomination of James Pope to be a director of the Tennessee Valley Authority.

A petition to the United States and British Governments, signed by more than 400 Protestants and asking for a declaration of war on the Vichy and Franco governments, was made public yesterday by Kenneth Leslie, editor of The Protestant, sponsor for the petition.

In your April 9 issue you published a letter from W. Houston Kenyon Jr. wherein he outlined the difficulties encountered by inventors who have both "paper" and tested inventions turned down by those in charge of our military services.

The house-to-house solicitation in 376 parishes of the New York Archdiocese in behalf of the 1942 Catholic Charities Appeal ended with 785,000 in hand or in sight, on the basis of incomplete returns, it was announced yesterday by Mgr. Robert F. Keegan, the Archbishop's secretary for charities.

Of the "several thousand" commodities normally imported into the United States, only 213 items are now receiving priorities which will facilitate their entry, and of that number probably only about 100 are arriving in the quantities desired, Harvey Klemmer, shipping consultant of the War Production Board, declared yesterday at the annual membership luncheon of the National Council of American Importers, at the Hotel Astor.

Although the cause is worthy, the play is weak. The cause is the development of Catholic dramatic literature for use in church drama clubs all over America. The play is Urban Nagle's "Savonarola," put on last evening at the Blackfriars Guild.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The text of the war profits control bill as passed by Congress is as follows:

Bishop Cuthbert O'Gara, C.P., Vicar Apostolic of Yuanling, China, the only North American member of the Passionist Order who is a prelate in the Roman Catholic hierachy, has been a prisoner of the Japanese in Hong Kong since that British crown colony was captured last December, it was learned yesterday.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 23 -- In a meeting arranged by Prime Minister John Curtin of Australia the Premiers of the States of Australia heard today a comprehensive review of the war situation. At its conclusion Mr. Curtin said that General Douglas MacArthur had presented a long and detailed exposition of the situation in the Pacific theatre generally and of that in the Southwestern Pacific particularly.
ROME, April 23 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:
MOSCOW, April 23 (From Russian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau's communique said today:

SAN FRANCISCO, April 23 -- Not since 1938, record year of the great dust bowl migration, have job-seeking Okies and Arkies been pouring into California and Arizona at the rate they are maintaining this year, according to border statistics made public today.

One particular case of personal hardship threatened by gasoline rationing involves a school teacher living in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. His school is in Coney Island. It must be a distance of all of five miles. Now that he can no longer drive to work he will have to use the subway, which involves three changes and a long walk.

Forty thousand workers engaged in the manufacture of women's coats and suits in this city received a 10 per cent wage increase yesterday under the terms of a decision handed down by former Mayor James J. Walker, impartial chairman of the industry.
ALBANY, April 23 -- Police Commissioner Valentine's action in excluding interstate buses from New York City's midtown section was nullified by the Court of Appeals today in a unanimous decision.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- A Marine Corps sergeant today won the Navy Cross for gallantry at Pearl Harbor Dec. 7.

Winning a long game, adjourned from the ninth round, that lasted seventy-seven moves, Isaac I. Kashdan gained upon Samuel Reshevsky, the titleholder, in the United States Chess Federation championship at the Marshall Chess Club last night.

Obstacles in the form of "red tape" that prevented Dr. Louis Zaretzki, 39-year-old radiologist of Mount Sinai Hospital, from serving in the United States Army Medical Corps were broken through yesterday when Dr. Zaretski informed Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan that he had obtained a "certificate of derivative citizenship" from the Bureau of Naturalization and Immigration in the record period of thirty days.

The arrest of a 30-year-old man whom the police described as "the worst sex criminal in Brooklyn in years" was announced yesterday after a police raid on his home in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn. The prisoner admitted attacking at least eighty-eight women in the last four months, the police said.

THE policy of appeasement having failed as miserably in this corner as it did in Europe, this observer is now at war with Connecticut. It started on a golf course, which is quarrelsome ground by tradition. Upon retreating from a reconnaissance expedition into Connecticut yesterday, a pause was made at the border to "cry 'Havoc' and let slip the dogs of war."
This is the season for costume blossoms, according to the New York State Department of Agriculture, which recommends a long list of inexpensive blooms to be found in the flower stalls of Manhattan.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 24 -- Victor Mature will play the lead opposite Linda Darnell in Twentieth Century-Fox's "Sioux City," replacing Randolph Scott, the Studio announced today. Fritz Lang will direct the film from a scenario by Stuart Anthony, Marcus Goodrich and Sam Hellman.

TOKYO, April 24 (From Japanese Broadcasts Recorded by The Associated Press) -- Tomokazu Hori, Japanese Information Bureau spokesman, said today in a press conference the United States Government had not yet issued a communique on last Saturday's air raids on Japan because "it has no way of communicating with the American war planes which attacked Japan."
ALBANY, April 24 -- Major accomplishments of the legislative session included the following:

Emil Schram's recent statement that our government could assume up to $200,000,000,000 of indebtedness indicates a robust trend of thought that is gaining headway among the more enlightened of our leaders in finance.

IN his "Studs Lonigan" series James T. Farrell made himself practically synonymous with literature about the furtive, hard-pressed life that goes on in the cheaper warrens of Chicago, but Jim Farrell's specialty has been the South Chicago Irish, and, as every Kelly-Nash doorbell ringer and ward hack knows, the brogue isn't the only key to the hearts -- and votes -- of the multitudes who live jam-packed between Loop and suburb.

OTTAWA, April 24 -- The women of Canada are being made an integral part of the Dominion's price-control effort and through regional and local committees are now functioning actively in the intensive drive against inflation, Miss Byrne Hope Sanders, director of the consumer branch of the Wartime Prices and Trade Board, said here today.

Hermann Hahlbohm of Chicago played sterling chess last night against Samuel Reshevsky of Boston, the defending titleholder, in the eleventh round of the United States Chess Federation championship at the Hotel Astor. After forty-five moves Hahlbohm claimed a draw by repetition of position.

Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook approved yesterday a $1,375,000 settlement offer made by defendants in an accounting suit brought by the General Investment Corporation and some of its stockholders against former directors of the corporation and others.

Traffic on the Boston Maine Railroad is running 40 per cent ahead of last year's levels, E.S. French, president, said in Washington yesterday. Coal and oil is moving in large volume by rail into New England, he added.

Police Commissioner Valentine, the Court of Appeals rules, had no authority under the City Charter to promulgate a rule excluding interstate buses from certain areas of Manhattan, or to deny to those vehicles the right to use terminals within those areas. That regulation has never been put into effect. An adverse decision by a Supreme Court judge stayed it and the proposed construction of a terminal on Ninth Avenue.

It's an escapist's holiday to browse about the Bronx Zoo and learn of things that go on behind the scenes. A trek taken yesterday to the animal kingdom turned up an interesting item. Its significance might well be kept for posterity.

VERBANK, N.Y., April 24 -- A junior all-age stake that developed fair competition and a puppy stake that will rank as one of the greatest in the long history of the Orange County Field Trial Club, made up the program for the first day of the thirty-first anniversary meeting of that organization.

VICHY, France, April 24 -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's eighty-sixth birthday was celebrated in privacy in Vichy today. He did not vary his routine, receiving numerous callers, among them representatives of peasants and artisans.

Thanks to the appeals made by the press, thousands of Americans offered up their blood for Great Britain soon after Hitler embroiled Europe in war -- blood needed for emergency transfusions and stored in "banks." Such was the response that by February, 1941, it was no longer necessary to send blood to make good that which had been lost in the bombing raids on English cities.

YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N.Y., April 24 -- After developing a $20,000 animal shelter on Hunterbrook Road here the Westchester County Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals has been refused a certificate of occupancy because neighbors foresee a bedlam of noises from the dogs, cats, goats, monkeys and other animals that would inhabit the place, town officials of Yorktown said today.

Dealers in securities who betray the confidence of their clients were denounced yesterday by Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind as he fixed the sentences of a group recently found guilty of mail fraud. The court suspended sentence on eight defendants who had pleaded guilty as well as one who was convicted by a jury.

Tom Main, Canadian manager of Ducks Unlimited, who says he was raised among ducks and never saw a crow until he was 12 years old, left town yesterday after paying his annual visit. He has made some sixty-six talks since Jan. 1 for the organization which has expended more than half a million dollars on duck restoration and one of them was to a gathering of duck hunters Thursday evening at the Yale Club:

A regional conference for members of the Third Order of St. Dominic will be held at 4 P.M. tomorrow at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer, Lexington Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street. The Rev. Edward Urban Nagle, national director of the Blackfriar's Guild, will preach.

What is believed to be one of the first instances in which a company will gauge an advertising campaign on the amount of support the trade gives to the idea was announced yesterday by Easy Washing Machine Corporation. The company's annual home laundry clinic has been replaced by a wartime clinic, which has three major aims.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The first scientific proof that a dehydrated vegetable retains most of the vitamin content inherent in the fresh vegetable was contained in a report just received from Department of Agriculture laboratories in California.

Dr. Eugene A. Colligan, former president of Hunter College, called yesterday for a full investigation "before a public and responsible tribunal" of charges made by the Rapp-Coudert Legislative Committee that a group in the Board of Higher Education had obtained his resignation in 1939 by the use of undemocratic methods.

After Malaya, Burma. While the United Nations' strategists were speculating as to Japan's next significant move, she was making it. During the past two or three weeks she seems to have greatly strengthened the relatively small forces which have been operating in Southern Burma since early this year.

THE eminent J.J. Dykes, manager of the White Sox, is rushing the season. He is sputtering already about the work of his ballplayers. This pitcher and that hitter will have to do better in a hurry or they will not be getting cakes and coffee at the expense of the White Sox management very long. And the season not two weeks old!

After trying unsuccessfully to ram the Axis submarine that had shelled his vessel, the last act of Captain Samuel L. Cobb of Staten Island was to destroy his papers to keep them out of the enemy's hands, the Navy revealed last night in announcing the recent loss of another United States merchant ship.

Willard Marshall, the strong, silent young outfielder who marched into the Polo Grounds this Spring with perhaps less fuss and fanfare than ever was accorded a Giant rookie of his talents, exploded another home run yesterday.

BOGOTA, Colombia, April 24 -- The Ministry of Foreign Relations announced today that a convention has just been signed by the Colombian Ambassador and the Vatican in Rome making modifications and additions in the conventions of 1887 and 1892.

Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, Australian Minister for External Affairs, in an address here last night warned the United Nations that "there must be no more argument about strategy." Speaking before several thousand guests at the Anzac Day ceremonial dinner held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by Australians and New Zealanders living in New York, Dr. Evatt declared that the directive recently issued to General Douglas MacArthur had determined the strategy.

ALBANY, April 24 -- The Assembly, in the closing hours of its final session, passed tonight and sent to the Governor the Feinberg-Delany Trade Practice Act, designed to eliminate the "wholesale racket" and protect consumers from misrepresentation of commodities by unscrupulous merchants. The bill was passed by a vote of 89 to 44.

CHICAGO, April 24 -- After showing weakness in the early trading on the Board of Trade today the grain markets suddenly reversed their action and wheat rallied over 2 cents a bushel from the bottom when shorts started to cover and found little for sale.

Not the least tribute to the art of Toscanini is the fact that the sepulchral gloom with which Carnegie Hall is customarily darkened for its afternoon concerts was not able yesterday, while he was directing the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, to dim the radiance and the brilliancy of his interpretations of the First and Second Symphonies and two of the overtures of Beethoven.

Unmindful of the hundreds of persons passing through the shopping district at 149th Street and Third Avenue, hub of the Bronx, and of the number of policemen on duty in the area, an armed thug held up, at 11:15 A.M. yesterday, two employes of Alexander's Department Store, 153d Street and Third Avenue, and seized $8,000 in currency and $400 in checks.

Colonel V. Britton, the British radio's "Voice of Doom" to Nazi occupation, yesterday ordered the "V for Victory" army behind the German lines to get ready for large-scale wrecking of German communications when the "greatest battle in the history of the world" opens.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- From Independence Square on beams directed toward Australia and New Zealand the American Philosophical Society started this afternoon a series of weekly broadcasts designed to carry around the world a message to those places where "there is still interest in the progress of learning and faith in that form of government which had its origin in this very place."

City College scored its second victory in the newly formed Metropolitan Intercollegiate Baseball Conference by overpowering Brooklyn College, 14 -- 3, before 1,000 rooters on the Kingmen's field yesterday.

Bids were opened yesterday by the Park Department on contracts totaling $150,000 for development of the area of Flushing Meadow Park north and east of the amphitheatre on the shore of Meadow Lake and on both sides of Horace Harding Boulevard near the Grand Central Parkway Extension crossing.

In the last war Americans learned to admire the steadiness, imperturbable valor and gayety of heart shown by the fighting forces of Australia and New Zealand. This city had the pleasure of knowing a lot of them personally. Their sons are like them. Distance doesn't count.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 24 -- The rationing of gasoline, which is becoming a permanent measure of national economy, is reducing the number of automobiles on the streets here, while bus transportation between Chilean cities is suffering.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- Byron Price, director of censorship, said tonight that "the heart of the whole censorship system" was the splendid voluntary cooperation of press and radio in withholding information of value to the enemy.
ALBANY, April 24 -- Following is the effect of Congressional reapportionment, as voted by the Legislature today:
In a recent article William H. Stoneman stated that British social workers had reported a rise of 50 per cent in juvenile delinquency in Great Britain.

CHICAGO, April 24 -- A rush of customers to buy durable household goods such as refrigerators, washing machines and radios in the last few months as the result of war curtailment decrees was a dominant factor in the rise of sales of Montgomery Ward Co., the company's stockholders were told today.

Sixteen have been named for the Wood Memorial, Jamaica's feature today, and if all go to the post it will be a record field for this $30,000 test, which is the East's biggest prep for the Kentucky Derby. Eleven of the horses, including Apache and Requested, are Derby eligibles, but Colchis, two-time conqueror of Alsab, is not.

The flotation yesterday of $100,000,000 of American Tobacco Company twenty-year 3 per cent debentures lifted the total of new bonds formally placed on the market this week to $105,550,000. This is the largest volume to be offered since the period ended on Jan. 23 last, when $152,835,000 in new bonds was floated, including the $80,000,000 of Alabama Power Company 3 1/2s and $50,000,000 of New York City bonds.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- The Athletics backed up Phil Marchildon's fine hurling performance with a twelve-hit attack to gain a 7-2 victory over the Senators today.
The little island of Malta, which has lived with death daily these last two years and endured one of the epic sieges of history, was bombed again yesterday for about the 2,200th time.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- Wheeling into the home stretch like a team of horses, Campbell Kane of Indiana, Leslie MacMitchell of N.Y.U. and Don Burnham of Dartmouth staged a titanic battle for the distance medley relay championship that featured the opening session of the forty-eighth annual Penn Relay Carnival on sun-baked Franklin Field this afternoon.

DETROIT, April 24 (U.P.) -- James F. Dewey, Federal conciliator, reported tonight a deadlock between representatives of the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers (C.I.O.) seeking renewal of a labor contract covering about 150,000 hourly paid workers in eighty-two plants over the country.

Mayor La Guardia's executive budget contains a $3,500 salary for Michael Carey, brother of Sanitation Commissioner William F. Carey, who will serve as second deputy commissioner in the department after failing in a civil service test for the subordinate post of superintendent of landfills, it was learned yesterday.

TORONTO, April 24 -- The sole restriction which the Canadian Wartime Prices and Trade Board is considering placing on retail advertising is a regulation banning the use of comparative prices, Edgar G. Burton, retail trade administrator of the board and general manager of the Robert Simpson Company, Ltd., said in an interview here today.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- President Roosevelt gave to spokesmen for organized labor today the general outline of his plans for price and wage stabilization and they left the White House firmly maintaining their opposition to any attempt to freeze wages.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- The end of civilization and even the human race, itself, may be in sight unless education can put itself successfully to the dual task of doing all in its power to help win the war while at the same time intensifying its research for a formula for preventing further military strife, Dr. James R. Angell, president emeritus of Yale University, said tonight in an address before the American Philosophical Society.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The Mayors of America were asked today to take the initiative in local drives to make Spring housecleaning a means of increasing the flow of rags, metals and rubber to the country's war machine.

LONDON, April 24 -- Lord Beaverbrook's speech in New York yesterday advocating the opening of a second front in Europe now or as soon as possible, set many persons here to talking today, and there is no question that it evoked sympathetic feelings in most British hearts, including those in the army.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The Army and Navy Munitions Board today classified twenty-eight strategic materials, including fifteen metals, among critical materials which may not be used hereafter in construction for the armed forces except by specific exemption on a showing that no substitute can be applied.
A building superintendent who decried our war program in a bar-room talk with a Navy seaman was sentenced to thirty days in the workhouse yesterday by Magistrate Morris Rothenberg in Yorkville Court.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that stocks of wheat in interior mills, elevators and warehouses and on farms totaled 441,554,000 bushels on April 1. This is the largest amount on record, and is more than twice the 1931-1939 average.

As a baseball fan who enjoys an occasional game for recreation and feels a certain amount of satisfaction when the Dodgers win, I want to protest against the regimentation now invoked at the games played in New York and Brooklyn.
I read with the greatest interest your telegram from Kuibyshev titled "Czech Guerrillas Ambush Hungarians," in your issue of April 18.

LONDON, April 24 -- A Japanese advance of about eighty miles in Eastern Burma was indicated in somewhat confused dispatches from New Delhi and Chungking today, but Chinese forces appeared to be counter-attacking mechanized Japanese vanguards in the vicinity of Taunggyi, 100 miles southeast of Mandalay.

JERSEY CITY, April 24 (AP) -- Buffalo staged a five-run rally in the ninth today to defeat Jersey City, 7 to 5. Jimmy Outlaw's single, which scored Boken and Heller, accounted for the tying and winning runs.

Edward J. Flynn, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, testified for forty minutes yesterday before the Bronx County grand jury that has been hearing evidence of the paving of a courtyard on his Lake Mahopac estate with city materials and labor.
ROME, April 24 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Assoelated Press) -- The Italian High Command communique said today:

PRINCETON, N.J., April 24 -- The independent vote in American politics -- that group of voters who do not claim allegiance to any particular party -- is smaller today than at any time in the last five years, but it will hold the balance of power in this year's election.

For the first time since it initiated the service, more than half a century ago, the Central Railroad of New Jersey, "because of present war conditions," will abandon for the current Summer its ship schedules between Atlantic Highlands, N.J., and Manhattan, which have proved popular with thousands of commuters and sightseers.

LONDON, April 24 -- The belief of Sir Stafford Cripps that his mission to India might bear unexpected fruit began to be fulfilled, tonight when it was reported that the Madras section of the Congress party, of which C.R. Rajagopalachari is the leader, had broken all Congress precedents by acknowledging the Moslem claim for separation.

Forty-two registration booths were set up yesterday in Manhattan to carry the drive for volunteer Red Cross nurse's aides to the women of this city. Twenty of the booths were staffed by volunteer workers of the New York Red Cross Chapter, while the others were in charge of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, which is directing the drive.

The Budapest press is annoyed because Under-Secretary of State Sumner Welles recently hinted that the United States would have to declare war on Hungary, Bulgaria and Rumania if their Governments did not stop being so helpful to the Axis. The annoyance is a product of hurt pride. Five helpless minor Governments declared war on us after the attack on Pearl Harbor: Rumania, Slovakia, Hungary and Bulgaria on Dec. 13, Albania on Dec. 18.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Spokesmen for Pennsylvania farmers' cooperative groups told a House subcommittee today that their truck drivers entering markets of Philadelphia, Scranton, New York and Newark were forced to pay "racketeers" for unloading.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

D.R. Collins Co. retired on April 23 as a member firm of the New York Stock Exchange, it was announced yesterday by the Stock Exchange. Proposed dissolutions of member firms on April 30 include Hughes Bull, O.A. McFall Co., Reynolds, Fish Co., and C.E. Welles Co.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- President Roosevelt approves the principle of a merger of the Postal and Western Union telegraph systems, Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce, said today in an appearance before the Senate's subcommittee on Interstate Commerce, which is considering a bill which would make the merger possible.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 24 -- A sensational half-mile by William Lyda, one of the nation's top-ranking runners, enabled the University of Oklahoma sprint medley team to establish an American collegiate record in the opening program of the thirty-third annual Drake Relays today.

County officials of Westchester are apprehensive because the State Legislature has empowered cities, as well as counties embracing cities, to maintain independent War Councils and Directors of Civilian Protection under the law that becomes operative May 1. Our great urban communities need this power.

The Park Department's plans for the immediate partial development of Marine Park in Brooklyn offer a valuable wartime benefit -- facilitation of the movement of vehicular traffic between Avenue U and the Marine Parkway Bridge. Our park officials rightly believe that the expansion of Floyd Bennett Field to meet the needs of the United States Navy is imperative to relieve traffic congestion in the area.
ALBANY, April 24 -- The 1942 session of the Legislature came to an end this evening with adoption of Congressional reapportionment as the major achievement of the final day.

In its total war program the nation will have to recruit "at least 5,500,000 new workers, most of them women," by the end of next year, A.F. Hinrichs, Acting Commissioner of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor, said yesterday before the employment and vocational guidance conference of the Welfare Council, held at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Obviously, there can be no quarreling with Lord Beaverbrook's demand for a second front in Europe so that the war may be won this year. Germany has always tried to avoid wars on two fronts, including Hitler's Germany.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- President Roosevelt hinted today that the already gigantic goals of the war production program may be increased, so well is the program going.
The creation of a "reservoir of democracy" is the challenge facing youth leaders today, seventy-five delegates to the annual meeting of District II of the Camp Fire Girls were told yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, April 24 (AP) -- Frank McCormick and Ival Goodman landed a one-two punch which resulted in a 9-5 victory today for the Reds over the Pirates and a sweep of the two-game series.

Although now with the Army in Panama, I'm still a rabid follower of baseball. So I read with interest John Kieran's recent survey of the major league pennant races and the list he gave of players whose services have been requisitioned by Uncle Sam.

It seems there were four Irishmen, six doughnuts, a bottle of milk, two phantom Japanese, a benign judge and Brooklyn's first all-woman jury, consisting of thirteen members, and may the saints bless them!

Mayor La Guardia was asked yesterday to reconsider his slash of $868,359 in the Park Department budget for next year by Mrs. Arthur Hays Sulzberger, president of the Park Association. She said restrictions on automobile operation this year would send many persons to the parks for recreation.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- President Roosevelt gave a measure of official confirmation today to Tokyo reports that United States planes had bombed Japan.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt asserted last night that some "awfully clever people" were spreading anti-labor propaganda among the armed forces, as well as among the civilian population, and called upon labor and the American people in general to combat any such propaganda as a menace to united support of the war.

The first of the four tryout performances of "Mexican Mural," Ramon Naya's play, will be given tonight at the Chanin Auditorium, 122 East Forty-second Street, under the auspices of Robert Lewis. The critics have been asked to wait until tomorrow evening before examining it. The action of the play takes place in Vera Cruz, and is divided into "four panels" instead of formal acts.
CHICAGO, April 24 (AP) -- Jack (Chappie) Blackburn, guiding genius behind Champion Joe Louis's sensational ring career, died today.
Harrison Cady, the artist, has leased a studio apartment of eight rooms and two baths in the building at 27 West Sixty-seventh Street through Albert B. Ashforth, Inc.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 24 -- No surprise has been caused in United States diplomatic circles here by the news that five United States fliers, one a captain, have been interned as a result of a forced landing in the Soviet Far East after raiding Japan last Saturday.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee made a $12,314,513 move for a "practical economy" today, reaching into government bureaus and agencies (two of them White House adjuncts) and striking primarily at alleged swollen projects, payrolls, running expenses, public relations, information and educational services and travel accounts.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, April 24 -- Condor do Brazil, an airline now operating in a restricted area and under an alleged new management, will find it difficult to continue as it will not be able to obtain fuel, it became known today. After having been placed on the American black list Condor ceased operating last December but resumed service this month.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The American Automobile Association said tonight it had urged the government to allow the "most liberal gallonage basis possible," contending that the 10,000,000 cars affected by the rationing "represent transportation of 82,000,000,000 passenger miles in an average year and that of this total 55 per cent is for necessity driving."

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The Bank of France urged the Supreme Court of the United States today to reverse a ruling of the New York Supreme Court whereby assignees of the National Bank of Belgium won a $228,294,283 judgment to compensate for gold which the Belgian bank had on deposit with the French institution when the Germans took Paris.

"Reasonable assurance" has been received that the Louisville Nashville Railroad will obtain twenty-two locomotives which it ordered but delivery of which was delayed by a decree of the War Production Board, J.B. Hill, president of the company, said yesterday in Washington.

CHICAGO, April 24 (AP) -- Orders from National Selective Service headquarters creating a new dependency classification which gives preference to men engaged in war jobs or supporting activities and ignoring any dependency status acquired since Dec. 8, were announced tonight by Colonel Paul G. Armstrong, Illinois draft director.
BERNE, Switzerland, Saturday, April 25 -- Prince Josias of Waldeck and Pyrmont, 46-year-old commander of an Elite Guard corps, has been appointed new High Commissioner of Police in occupied France.

A marathon -- more momentous than it might seem at first -- is now being staged in the barnyards of the nation. American hens, down to the very last biddy, are the participants. The goal, as announced by the Department of Agriculture, is an egg production that will total 4,200,000,000 dozen at the end of the year.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- The Commonwealth Utilities Corporation filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a declaration proposing to use the net proceeds, $3,238,169, from the sale of the common stock of its former subsidiary, the St. Louis County Water Company, to purchase for retirement 2,345 shares of its Class A common stock and 200,675 shares of its Class B common stock at $15.95 a share, the book value as of March 31.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, April 24 (U.P.) -- American-Australian fliers swept down on Rabaul for the fourth time in five days yesterday, dumping high explosive and incendiary bombs among shipping, warehouses and barracks and strafing Japanese troops, it was announced today.
LOS ANGELES, April 24 (AP) -- The common head cold, a puzzle to doctors as long as the medical profession has existed, may join the list of conquered diseases, and through the agency of the carrot.

Department stores, milk companies and other merchants making home deliveries were puzzled yesterday by the new order of the Office of Defense Transportation requiring them to reduce their truck mileage by at least 25 per cent below the corresponding month of 1941 to conserve rubber.

BERNE, Switzerland, Saturday, April 25 -- Further Red Army successes were reported from Moscow this morning on the Leningrad, Kalinin and Crimean fronts, where fighting, despite slush and torrents, has favored the continuance of the Russian initiative.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- The market value of all sales on registered securities exchanges for March was $478,232,603, an increase of 23.9 per cent compared with February and a decrease of 4.8 per cent from March, 1941, it was disclosed today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
OTTAWA, April 24 -- Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King made an earnest final appeal to the people of Canada tonight to vote "yes" in Monday's manpower plebescite.
BERLIN, April 24 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique said today:

Net sales of E.I. duPont de Nemours Co. for the first quarter of 1942 were reported yesterday as $122,023,170, and total operating revenues as $123,359,050, compared with $103,983,376 and $109,145,959, respectively, in the same period in 1941.

With apparel carrying the best part of the weight, department store sales here this week probably ran 10 to 12 per cent ahead of a year ago, according to estimates of leading retailers. Home furnishings continued to lose ground. Store traffic was described as heavy, and apparel and accessories were stimulated by war weather.

The report on Treasury war borrowing and the banks which has been prepared by the Economic Policy Commission of the American Bankers Association, under the chairmanship of W. Randolph Burgess, is an excellent study. Its value is not in any novelty in the ideas it presents but rather in the sensible fashion in which it discusses a formidable problem.

An exhibition of fifty-two original drawings by Hendrik Willem van Loon for the new edition of "In Praise of Folly," by Erasmus, will be held at Holland House, from next Wednesday to May 20. The drawings, presented by Walter J. Black, publisher of The Classics Club, will be autographed by Mr. van Loon and sold for the benefit of refugees from the Netherlands East Indies.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- The War Labor Board reported today complete cooperation from C.I.O. and A.F.L. international union officers in urging strikers to return to their posts at the Cornell Dubilier Condenser Corporation, South Plainfield, N.J. About 2,200 employes are involved.

Dance Players at the National Theatre presented another distinguished new work last night in Lew Christensen's "Jinx." That the same Lew Christensen who created the amusing but superficial "Filling Station" and "Charade" for the Ballet Caravan should also have created this curiously powerful and inturned bit of drama is almost incredible.

Morgan Stanley Co. sold yesterday through a group of dealers and brokers, after the close of the market, a block of 153,000 shares of Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) common stock. Priced at 30 5/8, the closing price on the Stock Exchange, the shares met a brisk demand which permitted the distributors to close the subscription books at 4:17 o'clock.

NEWARK, N.J., April 24 -- Squads of policemen under Police Commissioner George Kaas made three simultaneous raids in Newark's Chinatown tonight and arrested eighty-six Orientals on charges of gambling with dominoes. It was the third raid in four months and the largest haul of prisoners in Commissioner Kaas's campaign to throttle games of chance in the Chinese quarter. Fifty-one of the men seized were said to be residents of New York City.

The cherry trees in bloom in Central Park as pictured in THE TIMES announce the actual arrival of Spring, and more and more New Yorkers are making pilgrimages along the park pathways, averting, where possible, the gloom of war and developing a new interest in some of the memorials which they pass and near which they pause to rest and relax.

HONOLULU, April 24 -- How he torpedoed a large Japanese submarine in its own waters after first polishing off a 5,000-ton enemy freighter near a major Japanese naval base, was related here today by Lieut. Comdr. Elton W. Grenfell, one of four Pacific fleet submarine commanders who received the Navy Cross last week for operations off Japan.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 (AP) -- William H. Speer, general attorney for the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey, told the United States Third Circuit Court of Appeals today that "arbitrary" actions by the Securities and Exchange Commission "threaten the destruction of American corporations."
CHUNGKING, China, April 24 (AP) -- TI C]ineso Comzond i$steg ] tls foZZowig comleniqlg toiglt:

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- There's nothing admirable about a winning streak that has been shattered. The league-leading Dodgers found that out today when the cellar-dwelling Phils set them back on their heels to snap the Brooklyn skein at five games.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Conclusion of an agreement with Peru for the purchase of a maximum of 200,000 bales of Peruvian cotton annually during the war was announced today by Secretary Wickard.

NEWARK, April 24 (AP) -- Frank Kelleher's third home run of the campaign with one aboard in the sixth inning proved the winning margin as the Bears defeated the Red Wings for the second straight time today, 6 to 4.
BOSTON, April 24 -- The Yankees put on their heaviest artillery display of the young campaign to shatter the pretensions of the Red Sox before a ladies' day gathering of 21,356 in Fenway Park today.

Continued liquidation in the near months, induced principally by the proximity of the first notice day on May contracts, depressed the cotton market again yesterday. Active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed near the lows of the session at net losses of 3 to 8 points from Thursday's final prices.

The Amateur Athletic Union seems to be having difficulty in finding a sponsor for the national track and field championships this year. Why not hold the meet at some Army camp or training base -- at the Great Lakes Naval Training Station, for instance?

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- May quotas will make available fewer certificates for new tires but more for recapping than in April, the Office of Price Administration said today. The increase in recapped tires was described as following a seasonal pattern of expansion as warm weather permits a stepping-up of industrial and construction activities.

The comment in Topics of The Times regarding the excess volume of radio appeals is most timely. To say that the public is "irritated" is putting it mildly. It appears that many sponsors, under-rating the intellect of their audience, and determined to offer something in the nature of a patriotic gesture, are deluging the public with a barrage of twaddle which is an affront to the listener.
LONDON, April 24 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

VICHY, France, April 24 (U.P.) -- Adolf Hitler has ordered merciless repression of terrorism in occupied France, entrusting it to Prince Josias of Waldeck and Pyrmont, old-line Nazi, as the wave of incidents started by Pierre Laval's return to power spread to the unoccupied zone with two bomb explosions at Montpellier.

Paul King, baritone from Hattiesburg, Miss., gave his first New York recital last night in Town Hall. With Charles Albert Baker at the piano, he was heard in a comprehensive program composed of early classics by Cesti, Rontani and Handel; German Lieder by Wolf, Brahms and Kaun; French lyrics by Franck, Pierne, Widor and Massenet, and songs in English by Carpenter, Warlock Malotte and Giovanni Camajani.

The two-story eight-family garden type apartment house, with a seven-car garage, at 149-01 Hawthorne Avenue, Flushing, Queens, on the southeast corner of 149th Street, an L-shaped building consisting of six units, has been sold by Kopelman Realty, Inc., for cash above a first mortgage of $23,500 to A. Salzman, a Chicago investor.

LONDON, April 24 -- Following up its heavy night attack on Rostock, the R.A.F. carried out today what was described as the greatest single daylight aerial offensive of the war in its raid against Flushing.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week, twenty-six issues, aggregates only $11,058,343, compared with $34,145,624 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $27,976,570.

Holders of stocks continued yesterday to take a pessimistic view of values and only light liquidation was necessary to force prices lower on the Stock Exchange. Losses ran to 2 points. War news once more was relegated to the background as a trading factor and interest centered almost entirely on the possible injury to corporate earnings as a result of the new economic war controls and the projected tax program.

The Times Literary Supplement, London, of March 28, which has just reached here is a Grand Alliance Number and is given over largely to reviews of American books, books about, and from, Russia and China, and to special articles.

No city in Britain, not even Coventry, suffered so much in a single bombing attack as did the Baltic port of Luebeck in the raid by the Royal Air Force on the night of March 28, according to a statement issued in New York last night by the British Press Service.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 24 -- Without underestimating the privations that the Soviet people have accepted in their war effort, it may be said that it is in their finer habits of mind rather than of body that those not serving in the army have been most profoundly affected.
ST. LOUIS, April 24 (AP) -- The Browns went down to their sixth straight defeat today as they bowed to the Indians, 2 to 0, before the four-hit pitching of Mel Harder.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- A bill to provide government financial relief for automobile dealers unable to sell their cars because of rationing restrictions was approved unanimously today by the House Banking and Currency Committee.

DETROIT, April 24 (AP) -- With two out in the ninth inning, Bob Patrick, rookie outfielder, belted a home run today to give the Tigers a 2-to-1 victory over the White Sox and a sweep of the two-game series.

LONDON, April 24 (U.P.) -- Heinrich Koppenberg, manager of Germany's Junkers Aircraft Works, has been imprisoned by Reichsfuehuer Hitler, who is "purging" the chiefs of Germany's war industries for failing to meet the rising output of American factories, highly informed sources said tonight.

The appointment of John T. Madden, administrative vice president of the Manufacturers Trust Company, as chairman of the Greater New York War Bond Pledge Campaign, was announced yesterday at the local headquarters of the Treasury war savings staff.

A slight woman wearing a gray felt hat with a tassel on the crown, a gray trench coat and powder blue silk dress paused yesterday in the main hall of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. She looked curiously at an elaborate Germaine Monteil red-beaded evening dress with draped skirt, part of the museum's feature exhibition "Renaissance in Fashion."

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Plans for a 1,500-mile pipe line, which has been urged for months as a solution for the gasoline shortage in the East, are being drastically revised in an effort to eliminate every pound of steel that is not absolutely necessary, aides of Secretary Ickes, Petroleum Administrator, disclosed tonight.
Nine hundred thousand New York men between the ages of 45 and 64 inclusive will register today, tomorrow and Monday in the fourth selective service registration.

CHICAGO, April 24 (AP) -- Prices of hogs slumped late today 15 to 25 cents a hundredweight as producers, encouraged by recent advances, shipped a comparatively large supply to market. A top of $14.50 was paid at the opening, but $14.35 was the best price later.

A raid by Michael J. Quill and 250 members of the Transport Workers' Union on the New York headquarters of John L. Lewis's United Mine Workers precipitated a new showdown yesterday in the relations between Mr. Lewis and Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.
CHICAGO, April 24 (AP) -- The Cubs made only five hits off four Cardinal pitchers today, but eked out a 4-to-3 victory to win a series for the first time this season.

The Harvan Realty Corporation, an investing client of George J. Broido, purchased yesterday from the Harlem Savings Bank the Gabay Building, a seven-story store and office structure at 30-32 East Twentieth Street, between Broadway and Fourth Avenue. John S. Woodward 2d was the broker.

ALBANY, April 24 -- Acting on the basis of a formal pledge from Mayor La Guardia that Queens passengers on the Second Avenue elevated system will get free transfers to other lines in Manhattan, the State Legislature today adopted the Jarema bill speeding demolition of the elevated line.

The appointment of Mgr. Charles E. Fitzgerald, pastor of the Holy Family Church, New Rochelle, as vice president of the College of Mount St. Vincent, Riverdale, to succeed the late Mgr. John F. Brady, was made public yesterday.

Combined sales of $82,624,650 were reported for 1941 by the sixteen member associations of National Cooperatives, Inc., a gain of $23,804,543, or 40.5 per cent over 1940, according to a report issued yesterday by Howard A. Cowden, secretary.

BERMUDA, April 24 -- Twenty-six survivors of a United States merchantman were landed here this afternoon -- the third group of survivors brought here in the last two days. The latest group spent eight days in a lifeboat. Three were hospitalized and two were placed in the infirmary in the Sailors' Home.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- The Army Air Forces asked today for 2,000 civilian pilots to begin serving as flight instructors in expanding Army flying schools within the next sixty days.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- As a result of a remarkable acceleration of the pace of armament, this country will spend for war in the fiscal year 1942-43 not the originally estimated $56,000,000,000 but the unprecedented amounts of $70,000,000,000, according to Harold D. Smith, Budget Director.

LONDON, April 24 (U.P.) -- General K.A. Meretskoff's Red Army of the North, striking unexpectedly through forty-five miles of forests and bogs, pulverized a section of the German front line below Leningrad and drove one to two miles deep into the enemy fortifications, a Kuibyshev dispatch said tonight.

LONDON, Saturday, April 25 -- Royal Air Force bombers delivered a pre-dawn assault today on the German Baltic port of Rostock and the Heinkel aircraft factories near that city in which the Air Ministry said the massed British planes loosed "the greatest weight of bombs" for a single raid in the R.A.F.'s history.

J.F. Hartlieb, president of the Continental Can Company, Inc., reported yesterday for the twelve months ended with March net earnings of $7,551,555 after deducting $8,564,657 for depreciation, depletion and estimated income and excess profits taxes.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, April 24 (AP) -- A communique issued here today said:

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 24 -- Present conditions do not indicate any paper shortage, and even if there is a curtailment of production "it may be assumed with reasonable safety that there will still remain sufficient paper and board with which to produce all the necessary printed products," the annual conference of the Graphic Arts Industries was told today by E.W. Palmer, assistant chief of the Printing and Publishing Branch, War Production Board.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Consent decrees accepted by the Justice Department's anti-trust division in lieu of prosecutions of patent cases involving international cartels, which are alleged to have impaired America's production for war, were criticized today by members of the Senate Committee on Patents.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The government employs more than twice as many civilians as at the peak reached in the First World War, the Civil Service Commission indicated today in reporting a total executive branch payroll of 1,805,186 on Feb. 28.

LONDON, April 24 -- The home rails were the outstanding feature today in a quiet market. Week-end influences caused the usual Friday tendency to dullness but the more cheerful war news kept most prices firm. Gilt-edge issues were 1/16 to 1/8 point easier.

TOKYO, April 24 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Japanese Cabinet approved today a "material resources mobilization plan" designed chiefly to strengthen armaments and taking into account, according to an official broadcast, "the vast material resources made accessible to Japan by her sweeping victories in the present war."

Paul J. Kern, former president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, will be the principal speaker at a meeting of the Bronx Borough Taxpayers League, Inc., next Tuesday night at the Hotel Concourse Plaza, 161st Street and the Grand Concourse, the Bronx.

A new wartime shortage was revealed yesterday when the Jewish Board of Guardians, an agency of the Federation of Jewish Charities, announced the successful substitution of "Big Sisters" for Big Brothers who have been drawn into the armed forces.

SOUTH PLAINFIELD, N.J., April 24 (AP) -- A strike of nearly all the 2,200 employes of the Cornell-Dubilier Corporation, largest work stoppage in industrial New Jersey since Pearl Harbor, virtually closed down today the plant making communications equipment for the armed forces.

As was expected, the offering yesterday by a nation-wide underwriting group of $100,000,000 of twenty-year 3 per cent debentures of the American Tobacco Company, met an unusually broad investment demand. Morgan Stanley Co., as managers of the syndicate, announced that subscriptions had been received substantially in excess of the offering and that for all practical purposes the subscription books had been closed at an early hour.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 24 -- A railway has been completed from Khorramshahr to the Transiranian Railroad junction at Ahwaz, providing a second Persian Gulf port of entry for Anglo-American supplies bound for Russia, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King in his expected statement to Parliament next week on Canadian policy toward the Vichy Government of Pierre Laval will cause no surprise here if he announces a break in diplomatic relations.

"Live at home and like it" is a wartime motto which many decorators are taking as a guide this season, with the result that interiors are becoming gayer and more comfortable. Hobbies are given due consideration: the flower lover, the print collector and the armchair military strategist come into their own.

The 136th annual meeting of the Medical Society of the State of New York, the largest State medical organization in the United States, with a membership of more than 18,000 physicians and surgeons, will open here tomorrow for a four-day session at the Waldorf- Astoria.

Solution of one of the most important problems ever faced by the New York City Board of Education, that of out-of-license teaching, appeared imminent with the passage by the Legislature of three Coudert-Olliffe bills which now await the Governor's signature, Theodroe Fred Kuper, law secretary of the board, asserted yesterday.

The chief threat to ultimate victory in the war lies within America rather than abroad, Rabbi Hymen J. Schachtel declared yesterday in the West End Synagogue, 160 West Eighty - second Street. He asserted that the United States must reduce the danger of fifth and sixth columnists to a minimum.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- In its first move against a violator of the wool conservation program, the War Production Board suspended the Susquehanna Woolen Company of New Cumberland, Pa., which will be prohibited from putting into process any wool, yarn or cloth for non-military orders for three months.

"Total war" was still a theory to most Americans not many months ago. The concept had been devised by the totalitarian powers. It had been graphically expressed by such spokesmen as Colonel Hermann Foertsch of the German General Staff. On the eve of World War II, this officer, who has been called a twentieth-century Clausewitz, wrote a treatise, "The Art of War Today and Tomorrow."

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- With war industries planning staggered vacation schedules, starting earlier and ending later than usual, Atlantic City is considering a plan to open its beach two weeks ahead this year.
The first blows of the Summer offensives fell on Western Europe last week as British planes roared over the Continent.

This is a reporter's dream come true. What newspaper man has not burned at times with the desire to tell the publisher, not to speak of the managing editor and the business manager, exactly what he thinks? This goes especially for the newspaper woman. Since we crashed the gate of the Fourth Estate, you may not have noticed it, but our behavior has been circumspect in the extreme.

VERBANK, N.Y., April 25 -- Dr. Sam's Jonnie, a white and orange pointer dog owned and handled by Dr. S.O. Black of Spartanburg, S.C., today captured the amateur open all-age stake, the leading event of the three-day meeting of the Orange County Field Trial Club held over the preserves of the Verbank Hunting and Fishing Club.

A large exhibition of anti-Axis posters will be opened tonight at the Salmagundi Club, 47 Fifth Avenue. For many weeks this organization of artists has been preparing the collection as a part of its war work. The Army, Navy and Marine Corps have sent men in the services to pose for the artists several times a week and supply background data.

Educational movies aiding the war effort are being produced in a wide variety of interests. Chiefly designed to supplement the teaching of trades and crafts, they serve the double purpose of cutting down the training time and clarifying instruction through visual representation.

Because the men in service put sports items first on their list of preferred home-town news, the Recreation Rookies of the Bronxville Women's Club are setting to work to supply regular accounts of sports events. A new committee formed for this purpose has organized two groups of members to work at the clubhouse, clipping items and pasting them into lightweight scrapbooks suitable for shipment to posts overseas.

Just how drastic the gasoline rationing, scheduled to go into effect on May 15 along the Atlantic seaboard and in the Pacific Northwest, should be, is a question on which there is a divergence of opinion both in government circles and among oil executives.

Street crowds at West Eighty-first Street and Columbus Avenue experienced a flurry of excitement yesterday morning when a 49-year-old gardener ran amuck with a claw hammer and injured three women with the weapon before he was overpowered by several taxicab drivers.

Largely increased plantings of home orchards may be looked for during the war period, and after. In small plots a high yield is important, since cost of production must include a considerable outlay in spray materials and labor if good crops are to be harvested.
"How will I be able to get there?"

BERLIN, April 25 (From German broadcasts recorded by the Associated Press) -- The German High Command reported today that Nazi bombers last night loosed heavy explosives on the Devonshire town of Exeter, England, in "reprisal" for repeated R.A.F. attacks on German cities.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- The value of New Caledonia as an air base was recognized here even before the southward surge of the Japanese focused attention on the islands off Australia, it was said today. Pan American Airways choose Noumea, the capital, as a port of call for its San Francisco-Auckland, New Zealand, route.

TROY, N.Y., April 25 -- In a report to President Hotchkiss regarding a course that Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute has designed to broaden the education of the engineer, the Department of English this week directed attention to the "picture" of the freshman class which the course revealed.

A dramatic closing of the year's activities has been planned for the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs. At its annual meeting and convention on Friday at the Hotel Astor, Mayor La Guardia will dedicate the ambulance which member clubs together have given to the city for war service.

WAR'S ON.: When Great ]3ritain went to war, the inhabitants of a remote town in Wales pronounced it a "foreign" conflict declared by the English in London. Recently a bomb knocked the roof off the town's chapel. Last week the inhabitants renounced neutrality, agreed to fight Hitler.

In his message to the second annual meeting of USO representatives President Roosevelt reminded us that the task of providing "spiritual and social values" for men in the armed services rests upon "the individual citizen, the community and the nation as a whole." The individual citizen especially needs to take this admonition to heart.

The annual cocktail and bundle party in aid of the Lafayette Guild of the Maternity Center Association will be held on Tuesday at the home of Mrs. Henry Alan Johnston, 40 East Eighty-eighth Street. As part of the admission fee guests have been requested to bring packages of useful articles suitable for resale later at Everybody's Thrift Shop for the benefit of the organization.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 25 -- Whirlaway achieved his first 1942 triumph today by nosing out Miss Helen Hickman's Aonbarr before 15,000 racegoers in the $2,500 added Clark Handicap, feature race on the opening day of the nineteen-day Spring meeting at Churchill Downs.

In W.J. Ghent's review of Fairfax Downey's book, "Indian-Fighting Army," in THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Review of April 5 a grave injustice is done the name of Wovoka, the Paiute Indian Messiah and founder of the famous Ghost Dance cult of the Western Indians at the close of the last century.

THE Mary Celeste still trails her wake of unanswered question through a public interest that is ever at full tide. How could such interest ebb, indeed, when the ship's mystery is insoluble? George S. Bryan has done a fine job in telling the story of the brigantine that was found moving along all shipshape in midocean, without a human being -- living or dead - aboard.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 25 (AP) -- Harry J. Rockafeller, back in harness as Rutgers' head football coach, said today there would be no "de-emphasis" of the sport, but that the program would conform with the university plan for "toughening" students for war service.

The Teachers Union of the City of New York, charged by the Rapp-Coudert committee last Wednesday with being Communist-controlled, struck back yesterday with assertions that the State legislative investigation of subversive teaching in the schools was Fascist-dominated.

Much publicity was given last week to a visit at the State Department of the French Ambassador, M. Henry-Haye, who had made the visit to protest against the appointment of an American Consul General at Brazzaville, French Equatorial Africa, a French colonly now under control of General de Gaulle, Commander in Chief of the Free French forces.

LONDON, April 25 -- From France, Belgium and Yugoslavia reports of increasingly violent unrest flooded London today. They are replete with stories of sabotage, including one instance in which Belgian workers in a munition factory failed to fill 1,500,000 cartridges with powder as well as storic, of the execution of hostages as a lesson that few seem to be learning.

COFFEE FILTER -- Dr. Peter Schlumbohm, known as the inventor of a propane system of refrigeration, has patented a one-piece pyrex-glass filter which solves the problem of making perfect coffee. Percolators are now made in two pieces -- an upper filter and a lower flask.

Interest in Pan-American affairs as a significant factor in hemispheric defense should be stepped up noticeably as a result of the annual convention this week of the General Federation of Women's Clubs. For a full week this theme will be brought constantly before the delegates assembling at Fort Worth, Texas, and its various aspects discussed by invited speakers.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 25 -- Phil Hurt pitched four-hit ball today as the Naval Academy nine defeated the University of North Carolina, 6 to 2.

TRENTON, April 25 -- Creation of a special ship production division to "smash the bottleneck that is preventing materials from reaching our fighting forces" was urged today by Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., chairman of the Republican National Committee, at a luncheon of the Women's State Republican Club of New Jersey at the Trenton Country Club.

Dr. Joseph F. Thorning, author, educator and lecturer, has been chosen, by Pi Alpha Sigma, Pan-American fraternity of St. John's College, as the recipient of the first gold medal to be awarded by that organization to the person who, in its judgment, has done most to promote good-will and a greater understanding of the Latin Americas under the Good-Will policy.

GERALD SAVORY could hardly have chosen a more difficult and challenging _ .subject for his first novel. He had to interpret the behavior of a 29-year-old human creature who had been tossed into life hopelessly marred in body and so deficient mentally that even to those who

VICHY, France, April 25 (U.P.) -- The Germans have completed fortifying the entire occupied European coast and are ready to meet any invasion attempt, Premier Pierre Laval's newspaper reported today. The Moniteur of Clermont Ferrand printed a German-origin dispatch saying that General Field Marshal.

Prominent women of society are among the patronesses of the orchid and diamond fashion show to be held on May 7 at the Pierre for the benefit of the Nearly New Shop and its eight auxiliary philanthropies. The latest costumes designed by New York and Hollywood designers will provide a background for rare orchids from the Thomas Young Nurseries and diamonds from Fifth Avenue jewelers.
ALBANY, April 25 -- Governor Lehman today proclaimed "National Music Week" for the week of May 3, to be observed in the State. He said:

Axis submarines operating off the Atlantic Coast have increased their toll by damaging one Norwegian vessel and sinking two United States ships, but not without cost to themselves, for at least one of the underwater raiders is believed to have been sunk and another was reported almost certainly damaged.

MARKING the newest in radio, from the, modernistic in architecture to the latest in the field of transmission equipment, the National Broadcasting Company will inaugurate its new ten-studio broadcasting facilities in San Francisco during the week beginning today.

City College's baseball team won its fourth straight game and brought its season average to .500 by trouncing Queens College, 20 -- 3, in a seven-inning game in Lewisohn Stadium yesterday. While Bill Hogan, Al Golub and Bill Simms limited Queens to three singles, the Beaver batsmen pounded the offerings of Morris Leen, Joe Pargone and Charles O'Neill for twelve blows, including four doubles.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- Young Sid Hudson allowed ten scattered hits as the Senators scored a 10-7 victory over the Athletics today.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 25 -- A letter received by a Red Army artilleryman at the front -- typical of many forwarded daily to the Moscow newspaper offices -- reached this correspondent today from one of those Moscow offices.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (U.P.) -- The Army will be forced by next Fall to begin induction of men with financial dependents, including parents, brothers and sisters, Colonel Carlton S. Dargusch, deputy Selective Service director, declared tonight.

"Eat Soy Beans for Freedom" is the slogan and theme of a current campaign sponsored by the New York League of Women Voters. The organization is distributing a leaflet of soy bean recipes to non-members as well as members.

FORTY paintings by twenty members of the Modern Artists of New Jersey are being shown at the Newark Museum through May 24. Among those represented are Eva Lapovsky, Jean Morrison, Wes Lee, Charles Goeller, Helen Dumsian, Edward John Stevens, Charles Wright, Frances Hagemann, Mildred Browne Muse, Raymond O'Neill, Helen McAuslan, M.P. Williams, Eleanor Karl, Muriel Mason, Hazel Fredericks, Jill Johnson, Morton Tobias, Angel Velez, Ruth Velez and Lloyd Ney.

On the wide lowlands of Northern Mecklenburg, where the Warnow River winds down to the Baltic Sea, lies the ancient German port of Rostock. The tower of St. Peter's Church, built in the fourteenth century when the town entered the Hanseatic League, has served as a landmark for ships making for the harbor.

The United States has been forced into the belief that during the war it is responsible for the well-being of the United Nations and that after the war it must assume responsibility for the world at large.

AFTER several hectic months of organizational effort and a recent major revamping of its original policy, the motion-picture division of the Office of the Coordinator of Inter-Ameriican Affairs has reached the stage where it is ready to put into actual operation an impressive program of short films Aimed primarily at bolstering hemispheric solidarity among the nations of the West.

It is well that plans are now being formulated for application when the present war is terminated and is succeeded by world peace. The one important test which must be applied to every measure is that it must be free from injustice to any one. The democratic proviso of equal rights for all and special privileges to none must be the rule.

IN engaging Sir Thomas Beecham for next season the Brooklyn Symphony Orchestra is obviously making a bid for a position as one of the country's major orchestras. Sir Thomas will conduct it in four concerts, the final one of which will consist of a presentation of one of the great oratorios.

The State Department has rejected an offer of the Nazi government to provide for American citizens, living in the United States, who were the wives or children of German nationals interned here as enemy aliens, it was disclosed yesterday afternoon by Miss Jane Hoey, director of the public assistance division of the Social Security Board in Washington.

The Bronx Zoo yesterday proudly called attention to the fact that the baby giant pandas who arrived from China last January have been finally named. The male henceforth will be called Pan-Dee and the female Pan-Dah.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., April 25 -- A group of officers of the armed forces of the United Nations will be guests of honor next week-end, May 2-3, at a series of fetes to be given at the Mount Kisco Country Club. The guests will be met by a committee headed by H. Edward Martin when they arrive at noon next Saturday and luncheon will be served in the grill immediately afterward.

THERE is a captivating charm about sheer black that is hard to resist. Nowadays, with dates beginning at cocktail time and dinner starting before dark, street-length dresses in sheer black are in high favor after 5 o'clock.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 25 -- Faculty, trustees and alumni of Princeton University have cooperated to formulate a system of advisory councils "to criticize, encourage and stimulate the educational, scientific and scholarly work" of the various departments and divisions of the college, it was announced today by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university.
CONSIDER Antony Tudor. After "Pillar of Fire," it is impossible not to consider him, and seriously, for here is no glib talent but something very like a new force in the evolution of the dance.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 25 (AP) -- A Royal Australian Air Force officer said today that the Japanese treacherously struck at the R.A.A.F. on the Malayan-Thai border and that 15,000 Japanese were killed by the Australian airmen five hours before it was officially known that Japan had declared war.
BERNE, Switzerland, April 25 -- The "abrupt" termination of the opera season in New York provoked comment in the German press today.

THE old adage that children should be seen but not heard is neatly reversed several times each week when children take over the microphones to present their own shows for 'teenage listeners. And adults, to judge from the letters they write to the studios, don't mind this iconoclasm one bit.

Wholly without malice, and because the picture may even be good for morale, we find ourselves thinking of a dear old lady in Washington. She drops in at the Library of Congress and asks to see Mr. MacLeish.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- President Roosevelt will register in the Cabinet room of the White House Monday morning in the nationwide counting of men between 45 and 65 to ascertain the availability of manpower for non-military war duty.

IT is doubtful if the pages of "The Animal Book" will long retain their pristine fairness once it is introduced into the family, for children will inevitably have to share it with any of their elders who have not forgotten the furry charms of the zoo.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 25 -- A long supply train for Japanese troops on Luzon Island moved slowly over a mountain road between the towns of Ayangen and Bagabag one night before the battle of Bataan reached its climax.

THIS book's true record is a love story from China at war. Just so, it becomes a revelation of continuity through contrast, as well as a narrative which blends romance with adventure and personal devotion with patriotic fervor.

A forest fire which for a time threatened the naval air base at Lakehurst, N.J., was brought under control late yesterday, after destroying about 1,000 acres of pine woods between Lakehurst and Toms River.

OTTAWA, April 25 -- The decision of the Canadian Government to hold a nation-wide plebiscite on Monday, asking release from the last restraints on the organization of the country on a total-war footing, is not, as it may seem, an admission of failure of the voluntary system to which until now Canada has largely adhered. It is just the opposite.
TEN-CENT-STORE glass goblets, intended for table use, make charming little flower vases when gilded all over with ordinary gold paint. Nice for two or three big roses or a bunch of Spring violets.

A group of young women under the leadership of Miss Tracy Haight has been organized as a manikins committee for the British wool fashion show to be presented Tuesday during the luncheon hour at the Pierre as a benefit for Bundles for Britain.

Edward L. Shea, president of the North American Company, indicated yesterday that he would oppose any attempt by the Securities and Exchange Commission to break up the $1,000,000,000 utility system at present depressed market values.

Tank ship losses to submarines and to transfer for work other than supplying American civilians have been high. The ships average 80,000 gallons in capacity. In a year each ship can carry enough crude oil or refined products to supply about 100,590 cars.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Silver, that rival and handmaiden of gold both as adornment and monetary base, is to be put to work in a big way. It will be war work. Almost a billion ounces of free foreign silver has already been lent by the Treasury through the Defense Plant Corporation to American industry to replace copper in those electrical conductors known as "bus bars."

A gala entertainment program based on the procedure of a modern radio show, including audience participation and impromptu performances, is being devised by Miss Elsa Maxwell for the benefit evening party to be given May 5 on the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis as an invitation opening of that rendezvous for the late Spring and Summer season.

LONDON, April 25 (U.P.) -- Free French circles in London say the return to power of Pierre Laval has caused fresh outbreaks against the Germans in occupied and unoccupied France and that Paris remains one of the chief centers of resistance.

LANCASTER, Pa., April 25 -- Set up as a policy-forming body at the suggestion of Theodore A.
