Distler, the new president of Franklin and Marshall College, a planning committee has been formed to think through current educational problems and present its solutions to the faculty and board of trustees for final consideration.

Like covers from all other men in the service, those from sailors reveal little or no important information. Their origin -- the location of ships -- is a mystery. Their cancellations tell almost nothing. This situation, a radical change from earlier days, took place as quickly as routine could be regulated, after Dec. 7, 1941.

THEY were on their way to Alaska. But only forty-five minutes from their home hangar at Lock Haven, Pa., they milled around in the rain, 3,000 feet above the "Hell Stretch" of the Alleghenies, lost. They had, to be sure, a radio, "if only Margie or I had known how to use it."

BERNE, Switzerland, April 25 -- With a price of 100,000 marks on his head, General Henri Honore Giraud, high up on the list of ranking officers of the French Army, has escaped from captivity in Germany, thus repeating his adventure in World War I.

The United States Maritime Commission and the War Shipping Administration announced last week the establishment of an Atlantic Coast District and a Gulf Coast District, and the names of directors in each area. The appointment of Captain Granville Conway as director of the Atlantic Coast District had been reported a week ago.

Three reasons dictate the War Production Board's policy of permitting apparently non-essential industries to continue the use of important materials for an additional two or three months at a time when the war production drive demands practically all the major commodities, representatives of such industries said here last week.

Batting strongly while Right-Hander William Parmer hurled efficiently, Dartmouth routed Columbia, 11 to 2, in the nightcap contest of their Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League double-header at Baker Field yesterday, and thus obtained an even break for the afternoon.

Doris Humphrey's "With My Red Fires" is one of the great dance works of our time. If there has ever been any doubt about it, the revival which is now current at the Studio Theatre of Miss Humphrey and Charles Weidman at 108 West Sixteenth Street should settle the point for all time.

The annual Narcissus Show of the Horticultural Society of New York will be held in the society's headquarters, 598 Madison Avenue, from 2 to 10 P.M. tomorrow and from 10 A.M. to 10 P.M. on Tuesday. The exhibit will be open to the public.

CHICAGO, April 25 -- With Rookie Los Fleming's four singles leading the attack, the Indians marched into a tie with the Yankees for the American League lead by beating the White Sox, 5 to 4, in the ninth inning today.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, April 25 (U.P.) -- American and Australian planes have blasted anew at the Japanese airdrome of Lae, on the Huon Gulf of New Guinea, and enemy troops, in their first foray in weeks, have sacked and burned the near-by native village of Kaniucun, General Douglas MacArthur's General Headquarters communique said today.

A streamlined urban counterpart of the time-honored hunt breakfast will take place today as several score members of the New York Wellesley Club and their friends participate in their annual bicycle breakfast with its attendant features which will take them on wheels over several miles of city streets and Central Park roadways.

Private industry has already earmarked at least $75,000,000 for this year's promotion of the government's National Nutrition Program, according to the first results of a survey now being conducted by the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The National War Labor Board split 8 to 4 today in directing the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, a subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, to grant the C.I.O.'s Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America a "maintenance of membership" clause covering 11,500 employes at the company's shipyard at Kearny, N.J.

SOME time ago the head football coach at the University of Oregon, Gerald (Tex) Oliver, resigned that job to become a lieutenant commander in the Navy. Vaughn Corley, Oliver's assistant at the University of Oregon, took over the football reins on the campus. But he didn't hold them long. Just recently he resigned, too. He's a lieutenant in the Navy now.

Although one often hears complaints in some quarters about short-season cut flowers, there is much to be said in their favor. They usually come into blossom quickly, spending all their energies in a glorious, though short, season of color.

A MOMENT or two before the Army Hour made its debut three Sundays ago over WEAF, listeners tuned to that and other stations of the Red network must have been mildly surprised to hear a little advice from H.V. Kaltenborn, who, as it happened, was concluding one of his programs of comment.

NEWARK, N.J., April 25 -- An application of subcontracting to the educational field was disclosed here today in an announcement that Newark College of Engineering and Upsala College had entered into a cooperative agreement designed to meet the growing need for engineers in war industries.

"The Nightingale and the Rose," a one-hour radio opera by George Lessner with text by Nicholas Bela, based on Oscar Wilde's prose poem of the same name, received its world premiere yesterday afternoon at Radio City in a nationwide broadcast over the NBC Red network.

HERBERT WILCOX of the screen is getting together a series of entertainments which during the Summer are to tour Canada for the benefit of the Canadian Air Cadet League. The idea is that each unit -- consisting of short plays, vaudeville, etc. -- will cross Canada from Montreal to Vancouver, the first setting out about May 24 from Ottawa.
Familiarization flights from Moncton, N.B., to St. John's, Nfld., are being made by Trans-Canada Air Lines in preparation for the beginning of scheduled commercial service to Newfoundland on May 1.

INTERLARDING Beethoven's sonatas with your own improvisation on "Yankee Doodle" may seem to a no place on the formal concert platform of today, yet the art of improvisation was regarded as highly important by the masters Mozart, Beethoven, Bach, Liszt.

NEW ORLEANS, April 25 (AP) -- To Lieutenant James W. Robb Jr., daring Navy pilot who disregarded all safety measures and went gunning for Japanese bombers at Pearl Harbor Dec. 7 in an amphibian plane armed only with a rifle, was awarded the Navy Cross in ceremonies today at Eighth District Navy Headquarters.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- The April 27 issue of Social Justice, weekly magazine founded by the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, was ruled non-mailable today although Postmaster General Frank C. Walker said the "tone of the paper" had changed since the April 20 issue was banned from the mails.
THEY are the loneliest women in America. Their husbands serve in the Army and Navy for the duration while they bayonet each hour with two queries, "Is he alive? Will he come back?"

THIS Napoleon demanded of the Directory 145 years ago. The great military leader, fed up with senile generals of 60, sent for young officers to lead his men in the kind of war that wins, the "war of movements."

THE author of this timely volume has attempted the hard and fascinating task of bridging the gap between a young man named Claes and nicknamed Kleytjen (the "Little One"), who came to America in 1613, and Franklin Delano Roosevelt, thirty-second President of the United States.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., April 25 -- The Rev. Dr. Judson Leeman, resident physician at St. Luke's Hospital in New York for a year, will become acting rector of St. Peter's Episcopal Church here in July. Able in both callings, he hopes to become a medical missionary in the Orient after a year at St. Peter's.

LONDON, April 25 -- Indian Congress leaders were today reported in turmoil over the unexpected defection of the Madras section of the Congress party, which yesterday by resolution recognized the claim of the Moslems for a separate State.

IT is refreshing to come across a book about tomorrow which makes practically no effort to say what tomorrow will look like. The case is unusual. On every hand the blueprinters are hard at work on their new world patterns amid the flying wreckage of so many earlier programs and prophecies.

SHEPHERDSTOWN, W. Va. -- Spring is the smiling season -- and there is no broader smiling anywhere than in the Shenandoah Valley with the green creeping over it. The caissons roll but the apple and peach trees bloom just the same; and, anyhow, war is old stuff to the most warred-over piece of territory in America.

Mrs. Richardson Pratt will be hostess at a tea to be given at her home Tuesday for the members of the women's committee sponsoring the benefit performance of "Angel Street" for the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies on Thursday at the Golden Theatre.
WEST POINT, N.Y., April 25 -- Army defeated the Swarthmore nine today by 5 to 1.

ALWAYS audacious, H.L. Mencken is no man to be deterred from entering what might seem to others a pre-empted field. Few men but he would have ventured to add another to the existing dictionaries of quotations. There was Bartlett, there was Hoyt, there was the immense "Home Book of Quotations" compiled by Burton Stevenson.

DETROIT, April 25 (AP) -- The Tigers received continued good performances from rookies today when Pitcher Charley Fuchs and Shortstop Billy Hitchcock collaborated to defeat the Browns, 4 to 2. The setback extended the St. Louis losing streak to seven games.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, April 25 -- Warning symptoms of the grave political crisis that is likely to break out with considerable violence when Congress is formally reopened next month became visible today when the Concordancia coalition, the whole sector that supports Acting President Ramon S. Castillo's policy, boycotted a preparatory meeting of the Chamber of Deputies held today for the purpose of electing its president and two vice presidents.

A start has been made under the new system of commercial bank loans to war industries which are guaranteed by the central banks of the Federal Reserve System that may take up the slack that is now increasing as the result of wartime contraction of consumer credit lines.

As the Navy continues to intensify its unprecedented officer-training program throughout the country, New York will soon assume a major role as a "second Annapolis," with 1,400 midshipmen -- a number almost equal to 60 per cent of normal registration at the Naval Academy -- scheduled to attend special ensign-training schools here this Summer, it was disclosed yesterday.

IN this his first novel Mr. Lucien Hubbard has done what some one was bound to do sooner or later: he has fictionized the historical trip of the first steamboat down the Ohio and Mississippi Rivers. That steamboat was the New Orleans.

The announcement of the President last week that he had directed the Alien Property Custodian, Leo T. Crowley, to seize enemy-alien-owned patents brought into the spotlight one of the powers already possessed by the government in dealing with the problem of patents in wartimes.

DARWIN TEILHET'S new novel, primarily a historical piece, is a good many different kinds of story rolled into one. The variegated plot centers round a mystery with a boy doing the detective work on "Who stole old Mrs. Westfield's emerald pendant on the night of the Binghams' Christmas ball?"

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The Army Air Forces will begin an intensive drive tomorrow to enlist 100,000 men from the New York metropolitan area and eventually a sufficient number from the entire country to bring the total strength in personnel to 2,000,000.

Nearly one-third of New York's 900,000 men 45 to 64 years old inclusive registered between 1 and 6 o'clock yesterday afternoon in the fourth selective service registration. The total was announced last night as 269,102 -- 89,840 in Brooklyn, 77,546 in Manhattan, 49,720 in the Bronx, 46,732 in Queens and 5,264 in Richmond.

It is not surprising that Hitler's decision to replace Petain with Laval should coincide with a fresh outbreak of official German murder in France. Both events spring from the same cause. Hitler is worried about a second front. Conquered France must not again become a battleground while Russia still remains unconquered.

IN his first novel, which is uneven in style but lively, Mr. Phillips is concerned with a boy who is drawn to the race track despite an intuition that the life isn't fit for man or beast. Through the story people who believe in sport are aligned against people who believe only in money, -- and the sports lose out.

When Lonnie and his elder brother Bruce floated down the Tennessee River to New London in 1838 they put on their ruffled shirts and broadcloth coats to make a good impression in the town where they were going to set up a business, but only bears and rattlers greeted them.

It is beyond dispute that criticism is a legitimate activity of the citizen in a democracy. If offered in a constructive spirit, it is a healthful and stimulating purgative. There must, however, be some self-imposed discipline that will render verbal attack and counter-attack unable to impair national unity.

A defense training program for aliens, begun by the New York section of the National Council of Jewish Women last January, is undergoing a complete change, due to a new ruling of the American Red Cross, which bars enemy aliens from participation in any branch of its war effort.

A VETERAN novelist of the Victorian tradition here revives again the roll of Drake's Drum which stirred the imperialist soul of Henry Newbolt. "Where the old trade's plyin' an' the old flag flyin'," we meet the most dreaded of Queen Elizabeth's unleashed seadogs, "ware and wakin' as they found him long ago."
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Paul V. McNutt this week pitched into the job of obtaining the most efficient use of the nation's basic stuff of war, human hands and skills, a task of giant proportions.

LONDON, Sunday, April 26 -- Adolf Hitler, returning unexpectedly to Berlin from the Eastern Front, will address a special session of the Reichstag at 3 P.M. today (10 A.M., Eastern War Time), according to a German broadcast heard here today by The United Press.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25 -- Lippy Leo Durocher put Pete Reiser and Dixie Walker back in his Dodger line-up today against right-handed pitching and Dixie celebrated by whacking a two-bagger to right to empty the filled bases and give Johnny Allen more runs than he needed for his second triumph of the campaign.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 25 -- William Brann's Challedon won the Philadelphia Handicap today, nosing out Charles S. Howard's Mioland in a photo finish after a rousing duel. Grover C. Greer Jr.'s Cape Cod was third.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Because the country's stock of new passenger automobiles is taxing available space and they are deteriorating in storage, Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, announced today that practically any one performing essential civilian services or war work who really needs a new car for transportation purposes may now buy one.

Women from thirty-two States will meet in Chicago this week to determine how best they can spread intelligent understanding of national issues to an increasing percentage of the citizenry. Delegates to the biennial convention of the National League of Women Voters, they are expected to adopt a program with conspicuous changes of method from those used in the past largely within its own circle of members.
LONDON, April 25 -- Chinese forces on the Burma front were reported tonight to be fighting desperate battles less than seventy-five miles from Mandalay.

HAMILTON, N.Y., April 25 -- To assure the preservation of about $75,000 worth of rare books, newspapers, magazines, maps, manuscripts and other items of intrinsic value, Colgate University has built a rare book room in James B. Colgate Memorial Library.

A new development in sleeping-car design called a duplex roomette car has been completed by the Pullman Company and is already in experimental operation. It is the result of the tests begun several years ago to develop a car with increased individual room accommodations which could be offered at lower cost than the larger standard type rooms.

LONDON, April 25 (Canadian Press) -- Big crowds watched soccer cup matches throughout Britain today with one of the features at Stamford Bridge, where Portsmouth beat Charlton, 1 -- 0, to advance to the final of the London Cup. A crowd of 20,000 saw Tom Black, Scottish international, score the only goal.

BOULDER, Col., April 25 -- Having reached the highest peaks of scholastic attainment in previous years, the University of Colorado's Department of Mountain Recreation will offer thirteen "courses" this Summer. Mountaineering courses are a very serious part of the Summer curriculum.

Many thousands of railroad cars are tied up on sidings and at docksides storing materials ordered by foreign nations and held up by the shipping embargo, according to Colonel John S. Coneybear, field representative of the Inventory and Requisitioning Branch of the War Production Board.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 25 (AP) -- Fighting off a last-quarter Princeton challenge, Pennsylvania's 150-pound varsity crew set a new course record today in defeating the Tigers by a length in the Wood Hammond Trophy race on Lake Carnegie.

Unlike many other mystery writers, Mr. Oppenheim does not use the present war as a background for his plot. As a matter of fact, the war is not mentioned and one may fairly assume that the events recorded take place in England at peace.

JAPAN has been bombed. Her people's morbid fear of attack from the air, which already had reached the proportions of a national psychosis, is beginning to be realized. That fear has accounted for many of the island empire's war moves.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission approved today new wholesale rates of the Natural Gas Pipeline Company of America, cutting about $3,770,000 from annual bills of ten utility customers. It also ordered refunds totaling $6,283,149 to fourteen companies as excess charges from Sept. 1, 1940, to March, 1942.

SYDNEY, Australia, April 25 -- Opinion in Australia still strongly favors a major offensive role for the United Nations forces in the Southwest Pacific, and there are hopes that decisions coincident with the organization of General Douglas MacArthur's Southwest Pacific command will be followed by allotment of sufficient men, planes and ships for an early counter-attack in this theatre of war.

LONDON, Sunday, April 26 (AP) -- The conservative and influential Sunday Times today belittled the New York speech of Lord Beaverbrook, in which the British supply emissary urged a second front in Western Europe, and said the suggestion was "hardly in the category of a service."

BETHLEHEM, Pa., April 25 -- The year 1742 will greet 1942 during the next week-end when Moravian Seminary and College for Women celebrates 200 years of uninterrupted service in the education of women.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The job of the railroads in wartime is to keep man power moving to battlefronts and factories and to move from factory or farm to consumption points all the goods soldiers and sailors need to fight with and civilians need to sustain them for their part in the war effort.

THE new book by one of the sponsors of basic English bears a descriptive subtitle: "A Course in Effective Reading with an Introduction to 100 Great Words." But a review must introduce the book itself with the statement that the course is by no means easy.

STORIES out of the Northwest, and probably they can be duplicated from other parts of the country, tell of city folks, some with big names, who are buying farm land. It is not the feeling of Spring that is driving them to the soil. It is not the urge latent in most humans to own a plot of ground that can be labeled "This Is Mine."

Bolivia, in line with most of the republics of South America, is almost completely in sympathy with the war program of the United Nations, but is prevented from doing its full share because of price control in the United States and lack of proper shipping facilities, it was asserted yesterday by Rene Ballivian, the new commercial counselor to the Bolivian Embassy in Washington.

Following the conflict between the Merrimac and onitor in 1862, Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt offered his ship Vanderbilt to President Lincoln to be used against the Nierrimac if and when the "ironclad" was repaired and ready for battle again.

WHEN the Rev. Howard L. Brooks, sent on a mission to France by the Unitarian Service Committee, saw for the first time the concentration camp at Rive-saltes, with 4,000 children "cruelly and senselessly robbed of their freedom, children who had to grow up in filth and hunger and misery." he felt "the whole inhumanity, the appalling eruslty" of the situation. "

LONDON, April 1. SOME student of wartime sociology somewhere, we hope, is taking note of an anniversary Londoners celebrate this week -- the second birthday of "Gone With the Wind." Just two years ago, on a nipping Spring afternoon when Narvik seemed the hub of the world, the Mitchell-Selznick work moved into Leicester Square.

H.L. DAVIS is a poet-novelist and neither is separated from the other. His Pulitzer Prize novel, "Honey in the Horn," had overtones of poetry. His poetry has a strong strain of prose. It is mainly regional: the landscape, nature, characters, experience of the Far West, from Oregon to Mexico.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 25 (AP) -- Red Army cavalry units have taken a number of German-occupied villages and have reached an important highway feeding the German front, dispatches to Izvestia said today.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Recent conferences and activities here and in London have given rise to some hope that the shipping situation -- an extraordinarily important factor in fighting the war this year -- may approach a temporary solution by a pooling method.

A report in your news columns concerning the terms of settlement arrived at between the governments of Mexico and the United States surmises that the latter has conceded the right of the sovereign to subsoil rights, for which the interested oil companies have long contended, if not the American Department of State.
VICHY, France, April 25 (U.P.) -- The German radio, reporting the escape, said that any one found guilty of aiding General Giraud "will be punished by death."
VICHY, France, April 25 -- Reduction of the French bread ration, which had generally been forecast for May 1, was postponed again by the new Laval government today.
I should very much like to make a few comments on the letter titled "Apothecary Regrets Plight of an Ancient Profession" which appeared in the April 17 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

THE death of Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney has taken from the art world one of art's most loyal and loving supporters. Aside from her on achievement as a sculptor, realization of which occupied much of her time for many years, Mrs. Whitney gave us the museum that bears her name.

The drastic retreat of prices of stocks in the last three days was checked yesterday, and except for continued weakness in a few key issues the market managed to remain on an even keel. In both over-all interest and activity in individual stocks, however, the session was insignificant, for transfers on the Stock Exchange were only 156,400 shares, against 184,660 on the preceding Saturday.

IN the Spring and Summer of 1868 Mark Twain made a trip to California and back by way of Aspinwall, formerly Colon. The purpose of the jaunt was to regain the copyright of the Quaker City Letters from the San Francisco Alta California, to incorporate them in the forthcoming "Innocents Abroad."

Long before the recent WPB ruling on styles, New York designers began to anticipate it. Rumors circulating freely through the garment world were sufficient to set them on their way to creating clothes that would meet the war-time standards. They have begun to show how smartly stylish they can make dresses with a limited amount of material.

AT its annual meeting, snuggled down in the Algonquin as usual, the Drama Critics Circle voted not to give a prize for an American play this year. Of the seventeen members voting, eleven concluded that there was no new American play of prize rank this season.

LONDON, April 25 (AP) -- A fire in the Grunewald Forest in Berlin caused "considerable damage to valuable timber stocks" and was controlled only after hours of tedious work by fire brigades, the Berlin radio said tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The Office of Price Administration fixed an overall price ceiling today on commodities and products sold for export to all foreign countries and the territories and possessions of the United States.
I should like to reply to the article written by Fannie Hurst which recently appeared in the IViagazine, entitled "Glamour as Usual ?"

The next tournament opportunity for local players will be the Eastern mixed team-of-four championship, to be played in two sessions on Sunday, May 17. The American Contract Bridge League has established the custom of holding this contest separately from the other Eastern championship events, and of donating its proceeds to a charitable cause.
VALETTA, Malta, April 25 (AP) -- The British issued this communique tonight:

Many an Eastern motorist is today revising his vacation plans in the light of the gasoline rationing to take effect next month. Carefree days on the open roads with service stations ready at every milestone to replenish the tank are virtually things of the past.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- President Roosevelt will not have a formal bodyguard in the future, but Charles W. Frederick, member of the Secret Service since 1913, will take over most of the duties relinquished today by Thomas J. Qualters, who will report Friday as a captain of air intelligence at Bolling Field.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 25 -- Unique in Southern education is Vanderbilt University's creation of the Institute of Research and Training in the Social Sciences.
Putting on a strong, punishing rally in the second period after being held scoreless in the first, Yale defeated the New York Rugby Club, 15 -- 3, yesterday on Randalls Island field.

THE day after reported American air raids on Tokyo, the aerial wires of the Mikado's radio were in a state of flux. During one five-minute news summary there were three breaks in the program. Each time the beam went dead, one hoped it would stay that way; but Nippon's radio men finally managed to patch up the broken wires.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 25 -The program for removing and resettling outside the combat zone the 113,000 Japanese of the Far West's Military Area No. 1 has been an evolutionary development, with experience dictating an important change here and there.

THE position of the young American conductor and his problems in gaining a job make the burden of a letter from a correspondent who suggests that all American orchestras invite at least one native son each season to conduct some guest performances. In this way native talent may be identified and brought to public notice.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 25 -- Roy Cochran, who mastered running at Indiana University, carried the colors of the Great Lakes, Ill., Naval Training Station to a world record in the final program of the thirty-third annual Drake Relays today.

THE children had poor appetites, or sucked their thumbs, or stuttered, or showed fidgety behavior; the parents said, variously, "It runs in the family," or "It's just laziness," or, "Oh, doctor, do you think it can be St. Vitus's dance?"

Standing off three challenges, the most formidable in the last hundred yards, Requested yesterday captured the $31,400 Wood Memorial before 36,785 persons who wagered $1,822,832, a record for Jamaica. Just a nose behind at the finish of the mile and a sixteenth, after having come from the rearguard, was Bleu d'Or, who easily took second by three lengths from the tired Apache.

Practicing photography on the side is earning extra cash for men in the camps. After a day of drilling and other activities that make up a workday in Uncle Sam's Army, enterprising soldier photographers are operating little businesses that net them a fair income.

NO State in the Union has a more colorful history than Texas, and to very many, perhaps to most Americans, the phrase, "Remember the Alamo!" is only a little less familiar than today's "Remember Pearl Harbor."

ST. LOUIS, April 25 -- Lieut. Comdr. Edward H. O'Hare visited his home town as a conquering hero today. The 28-year-old pilot, who shot down five Japanese bombers and damaged a sixth, rode through gaily decorated downtown streets in a parade watched by an estimated 60,000 persons.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- A retrenchment in operations of the Civilian Conservation Corps, reducing the number of camps to 350 and the personnel to about 70,000, was announced today by Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator.

The Erie Railroad Company announced yesterday that it has offered the holders of the New York Greenwood Lake Railway Company prior lien 5 per cent bonds, with May 1, 1938, and subsequent coupons attached, the opportunity of exchanging them into Erie securities.

Men and women prominent in society, military, artistic and civic circles are cooperating in final plans for "Carnival Street," the elaborate all-night entertainment to be presented May 12 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria as a benefit for the Navy Relief Society.
GLADYS SCHMITT, winner of the Dial Press Award for 1942, is an ardent student, it seems, of the works of Proust and Thomas Mann, and has actually been heralded by Whit Burnett as the American Proust.

The story of the last hours of the passenger-cargo ship sunk off the Atlantic Coast in an attack by three submarines Tuesday night was related last night by Lawrence W. Earle, 18-year-old son of George H. Earle, former Governor of Pennsylvania, at his home in Haverford, Pa.
CINCINNATI, April 25 -- The veteran right-hander, Claude Pas seau of the Cubs, outlasted big Paul Derringer today to annex an eleven-inning, 5-4 victory from the Reds.

While Samuel Reshevsky of Boston, the defending titleholder, was engaged with Carl Pilnick, City College champion, in the twelfth round of the United States Chess Federation tournament at the Hotel Astor yesterday, Miss N. May Karff of Boston, the women's champion, successfully defended that honor by defeating Mrs. Nanny Roos, former Belgian champion, her nearest rival, after twenty-eight moves.

THREE albums devoted to Brahms are April's gift to admirers of the composer. They bring us the mature Brahms, mellow in spirit and masterful in craftsmanship. They are a new version of the Second Symphony (Columbia M-493, five 12-inch records); the Trio No. 1, in B, Op. 8 (Victor M-883, four 12-inch records) and Two Songs for Alto, with viola obbligato and piano, Op. 91 (Victor M-882, two 12-inch records).

THE Book-of-the-Month Club is asking its members to contribute a million books to the Victory Book Campaign. Since the club has more than 500,000 members, the sacrifice asked of each individual is not a great one.

The report of the International Business Machines Corporation and its subsidiary companies for the three months ended on March 31, issued yesterday, shows a net profit of $2,806,897 after providing for estimated United States Federal and Canadian income and excess profits taxes, including $1,507,100 of United States excess profits tax as levied under the Revenue Act of 1941.

Many a gardening or homecraft job is put off "for another day" because of the time and trouble involved in locating and getting out the tools to do it. Tools have a way of getting mislaid, or becoming rusted and dulled if no proper place is provided for them.

LONDON, April 25 -- British economists are confident they have drawn the sting out of inflation. The man in the street is quite willing to trust them, although for both inflation is the dreaded bogy that arose in the German debacle following the first World War.

BY this time it should be hardly news that Herbert Asbury when he sits down to write does best when he has rascals and rascality as a subject. He has produced a small shelf of books in the years since he shocked some Bostonians half to death with his American Mercury story of "Hatrack," the girl who was no better than she should have been.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25 -- Colgate handled the baton in flawless style in the mile relay that supplied the grand finale to the forty-eighth annual Penn Relay Carnival before 35,000 spectators on sun-flooded Franklin Field today. Favored Georgetown, however, handled the stick as though it were a hot potato.

PONTIAC, Mich. -- A month after inauguration here on March 16 of the "Michigan Plan" for war conservation of automobiles and tires through efficient use, results accomplished among the city's 60,000 residents are:

AT least for the present, according to gossip around Radio Row, James C. Petrillo of the American Federation of Musicians has withdrawn his demand that the Red and Blue networks set up separate units of sixty-five musicians instead of maintaining a group of about 130 who would be available to either chain.

LONDON, April 25 -- At a small Ministry of Labor exchange in the country today a fair-haired 16-year-old girl presented her identity card, borrowed a pen from the clerk on duty and signed the national register for war work thus: "Elizabeth Alexandra Mary Windsor."

CAIRO, Egypt, April 25 -- British bombers attacked the Axis airdrome at Comiso, Sicily, early yesterday, causing heavy fires and explosions, and, in another foray, probably hit an Axis merchantman in the Central Mediterranean.

BOSTON, April 25 -- It was established to the satisfaction of Tom Yawkey, Eddie Collins, Joe Cronin, et al., at Fenway Park today that lightning does not strike twice in the same place. Some 21,955 fans viewed the demonstration as the Red Sox snapped a four-game winning streak of the world champion Yankees by annexing a tense struggle, 4 to 2.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 25 -- Harvard's smooth-rowing varsity crew came from behind during the last 200 yards to defeat Cornell's powerful eight by four-fifths of a second in the Rowe Memorial Regatta's five-cornered feature race today on the Charles River's Henley course.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- A story of how a supply shortage of one small patented screw is holding up production of fighting planes for the Army and the Navy was told today by Thurman Arnold, Assistant Attorney General in charge of anti-trust law prosecutions, as "a perfect example of a patent on a gadget operating to block entire assembly lines."

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 25 -- The Navy varsity and plebe crews carried the Blue and Gold of the midshipmen to victory over Columbia on the Severn River today, but the Lion jayvees nosed out the Navy junior varsity by one-eighth of a length.

WHEN Ellery Queen arrives at the little town of Wrightsville he does not know a soul there. When he leaves he has become the intimate friend of some of the town's leading citizens and has been one of the central figures in the only murder mystery that Wrightsville has ever known.

ALBANY, April 25 -- The end of the legislative session left much soreness within the State's Republican party, always a fertile field for subsurface dissension. The manner in which reapportionment legislation was handled was the chief cause of renewed friction, it was agreed today.

LONDON, April 25 -- The Royal Air Force attack in double depth, with the biggest bombers crossing over hundreds of miles of enemy territory to drop their loads on a selected target -- Rostock on the Baltic for the second night in a row -- while fighters and medium bombers blasted the near-by Nazi-held coast of Europe, went on last night and today on a scale unequalled by other British offensive efforts.

The only reason the Metropolitan Intercollegiate Baseball Conference game between St. John's and Manhattan at Manhattan Field yesterday didn't end in a tie as their earlier meeting had was because the Redmen managed to get a run across in the thirteenth inning.
BERLIN, April 15 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command said today in a communique:

NAVAL CHIEF: Aa General 3KacArthur and his staff last week were mapping plans for an eventual offensive against Japan, the man in charge of Allied sea forces wss Vice Admiral Herbert F. Leary, U. S. 1.

Inaugurating the outdoor season for dog shows in the metropolitan area, the Orange Kennel Club will give its ninth annual exhibition Saturday, May 9, on the grounds of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club, Ridgewood Road, South Orange, N.J. Like many other events this year, the show will have the Navy Relief Society as its beneficiary.

BETWEEN the jacket cover and the title the prospective reader gets a very fair idea of the book. The cover shows a background of Boston Harbor in the days of sail, against whichare posed a dandy and two damsels in the dress of Revolutionary times.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The texts of the majority and minority opinions of the War Labor Board in the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company case follow:

VICHY, France, April 25 (U.P.) -German occupation authorities in Northern France have arrested and sent to a Compiegne concentration camp the entire entourage of Grand Duke Vladimir Kyrillvitch, 25-year-old pretender to the Czarist throne of Russia, it was revealed today.

JOSEPH ZUPPAN GILMAN, who inherited the farms and industrial enterprises in the district surrounding Zuppanville, Mich., acquired by his thrifty Dutch grandsire, emerges as the central figure in this family saga of many characters, with its twin theme of the perennial conflict of parental and filial ideas and the already historic opposition of isolationists and interventionists.

COLONEL BLIMP was born old, one might say almost senile. Recently Sir Stafford Cripps announced his death in the House of Commons, declaring it was time he was buried. But it takes more than an obituary notice to get rid of some one who never really existed and therefore cannot be laid away like an ordinary mortal.

IT has been fairly estimated that a good 80 per cent of the folk who like motion pictures have a bias toward one or more stars. President Roosevelt is rumored to admire the work of Gary Cooper very much. Winston Churchill has seen a certain film starring Vivien Leigh at least six times. And Sally Jones, who lives around the corner, is just cr-razy about Errol Flynn.

Thirty-five members of the Old Guard of the City of New York, resplendant in their brilliant uniforms -- white coats with gold buttons and gold epaulets, blue trousers with gold stripes, great gold chains and braid, silver sabers and giant bearskin shakos -- observed their 116th anniversary here yesterday in joint parade with members of the Army.
PHILADELPHIA, April 25 (AP) -- The Rutgers University varsity crew defeated the University of Pennsylvania eight by a little more than a length in their fifth annual regatta today.

FOLLOWING the example of John Steinbeck in the filming of "The Forgotten Village," Orson Welles, according to reports received from his movie expedition to Rio de Janeiro, is employing people of the country to re-enact dramatic events in their own lives in his new film, "It's All True."

WITHIN a few days distribution interests of the country will have particulars on the most important development in their business history. The price ceiling program will be announced on Tuesday following the outline which is expected in the President's message to Congress tomorrow.

YOU may have blown out the candies on a good many birthday cakes, but that fact alone does not indicate that you need a special diet, nutritionists at the New York State College of Home Economies report. The need for vitamins and minerals in particular does not decrease with age -- on the contrary, meals rich in these little nutritional wonder-workers can add years to one's life.

NOW that we have presumably outlived the silly idea, widely prevalent before Pearl Harbor, that a Japanese attack on the United States and Great Britain would be a deliberate act of national suicide, now that we recognize that Japan began war with every intention of winning, it is useful to learn how our enemies propose to achieve their objective.

At least once annually, if not oftener, most householders succumb to the fascination of paint, and the dream of applying bright clean color to their walls and windows themselves. And it usually happens about this time of year, along with other Spring offensives.

ALBANY, April 25 -- Motor fuel revenue in the State fell off during the first two months of this year, while beverage and cigarette tax receipts increased in March, the Department of Taxation and Finance reported today.

THIS is a good time to get to know the constellations. The stars shine serenely in their appointed positions regardless of any state of war or peace on earth. And that very fact is important to our fight for victory. It means that charts of the heavens, laboriously and patiently compiled by obscure astronomers in leisurely days of peace, can now be applied to the navigation of fast-flying, far-ranging bombers.

GLYNDON, Md., April 25 -- Asking for and receiving his head about halfway between the fifteenth and sixteenth fences, Stuart S. Janney Jr.'s bay gelding Winton went to the front in the forty-ninth running of the country's greatest hunt race, the Maryland Hunt Cup, and finished a length and a half ahead of the Rokeby Stable's Rustic Romance, with John Bosley up, today.

THIS is a rather late day to be firing bouquets at Charlie Chaplin, especially for a film which he made seventeen years ago. But such are the anomalies of motion pictures (and the immutability of celluloid) that suddenly Mr. Chaplin's "The Gold Rush," which was first shown in 1925, emerges as just about the most perceptive and "enjoyable" film on Broadway today.

Educators in this and other free countries must emphasize the importance of teaching loyalty to the democratic ideals, rather than a continued insistence on personal freedom and "equality of opportunity," Dr. I.L. Kandel, authority in the field of comparative education, asserts in the Education Yearbook of the International Institute of Teachers College, issued last week.

PUBLIC reaction to Lew Ayres's declaration of his scruples as a conscientious objector to war remains a puzzling question. William F. Rodgers, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer sales manager, said this week that theatres which had canceled the Ayres film, "Dr. Kildare's Victory," in the first flurry of excitement are now rebooking the picture.

The President is expected tomorrow to present to Congress the Administration's program for coping with the grave problem of inflation. That program, if it is to have any chance of success, must recognize that inflation can be curbed only by dealing with its basic causes and not merely with its surface symptoms.

The tap-root of democracy is free access to unbiased information, and to all biased information as well. A dictatorship gives access to only bias, and therefore tolerates no institution worthy to be called a college or university. The first war necessity, voiced over and over by Army and Navy spokesmen, is for officer material with a broad and thorough college education.

JOSEPHINE was a cat in prewar Paris, and she came from a life of manifest though undefined tribulation to sanctuary in Kathleen Coyle's apartment near the Luxembourg Gardens. She was a wild and sorrowful refugee, but from the first she was a dominating individual; and as grief and rebellion yielded to health and happiness, she not only lived her own life but exercised full measure of control over the lives of her human family.

NEW shows in the galleries range from American genre of the middle nineteenth century to present day abstraction a la mode, and from religious sculpture to highly personal expressionism, with South American landscapes and some quite remarkable work by children thrown in for good measure.

Production of cotton duck at prices acceptable to the government, yet on a profitable or at least a break-even basis, is one of the major concerns of carpet manufacturers, who are rapidly converting to war work, they said yesterday.

TORONTO, April 25 -- Successful thus far in halting a devastating rise in the cost of living, Canada's over-all price ceiling will depend for its future effectiveness upon two major factors which must be called increasingly into play, according to observers of the price control program in the Dominion.

It begins to appear that the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference is just what the doctor -- or Jack Coffey -- ordered. For yesterday at Ohio Field the Coffey-coached Rams triumphed over N.Y.U., 9 -- 4, for their fifth straight victory in the league and their eighth in a row for the campaign.

With commodity prices in the East definitely higher, industrial purchasing agents in this area are of the opinion that "the war against inflation is being lost," according to the monthly report issued yesterday by the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.

Four boys marooned on a crumbling island in a raging flood, faced with the choice of safety for themselves or of helping other victims, will react in various ways, but their decisive action will be the result of the strongest one's character.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., April 25 -- Pioneer among State universities in the field of coeducation, Indiana University is celebrating with a comprehensive program the seventy-fifth anniversary of admission of women on an equality with men to its classrooms.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 25 -- Lou Bufalino's double, scoring Sam Hunter, with one out in the ninth broke a tie and gave Cornell a 6-5 victory over Princeton, defending Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League champion, before a Spring Day crowd of 3,000 today.

Tomorrow the voters of Canada will decide this question: "Are you in favor of releasing the Government from any obligation arising out of any past commitments restricting the methods of raising men for military service?" Under the War Measures Act the Government has the right to draft manpower.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 25 (U.P.) -- Red Army forces have broken through German defenses on the Leningrad, central and southern fronts in heavy fighting that shattered enemy battalions equipped with flame-throwers, tanks and armored cars, it was reported tonight.

With the exception of immediate deliver goods, purchasing of staples came to a near standstill as merchants awaited the terms of the Presidential price-freezing announcement, according to the weekly report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.
BUCKINGHAM PALACE, April 21 Today is the anniversary of the birthday of the Princess Elizabeth.

All gardens, and especially Victory gardens, where every inch of space has to produce the maximum yield, may well contain a few clumps of chives. It is not an important crop, to be sure, and need not take up much room in the garden, while two or three clumps in the window garden should provide seasoning material for salads throughout the Winter.

EVER since George Gershwin gave Porgy songs to sing, Todd Duncan has sung them. Big, broad-faced and smiling, it was he whom Gershwin chose for the original production of "Porgy and Bess" some seven seasons ago and now, after singing the role in a West Coast revival several years ago, he is back on Broadway again in Cheryl Crawford's current version of the American opera.

Jersey City and this town for four hours yesterday afternoon didn't have the services of their Chief Executives. There was a justifiable reason. The Mayors and their families were among the 20,000 who packed Madison Square Garden for the circus matinee.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 25 -- Frederick Lewisohn of New York City, now has a building at the University of Tennessee which bears his name, an honor bestowed upon him on the fortieth anniversary of the annual Lewisohn Scholarship Award to the outstanding junior of the School of Home Economics.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The War Department announced officially this afternoon that American troops have "arrived" at the island of New Caledonia, a French possession in the Southwest Pacific, controlled by General Charles de Gaulle's Free French forces.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, recommended yesterday that the Free Italian movement receive the same recognition as is extended to the Free French and other similar causes.
TOPEKA, Kan., April 25 -- The convention of the National Federation of Press Women closed today with the award of citations of merit for long outstanding service.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., April 25 -- The strike halting war production of communications equipment at the Cornell-Dubilier Corporation plant here continued today. Alexander Smalley, who came this morning as a representative of the labor division of the War Production Board, said after a conference with union and plant officials that if work were not resumed by Monday the Army would take over and operate the factory.

On behalf of the "National Charity Fund," "Secours National" (National Aid) has been overprinted on four values each of French stamps of Dahomey, French Guinea, French Sudan, Ivory Coast, Mauritania, Niger, Senegal, Togo.

Dr. Meryl Rose of Amherst finds that frogs whose forearms and wrist bones have been cut off will grow new ones in about four months. After studying the literature on the regeneration of tissue in lower animals he formulated the hypothesis that if the wound was kept open, so that oxygen could enter where development was to occur, waste products would pass out more easily and the aggravated region would draw an increased blood supply.

Business was generally good last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Demand for coats, suits, dresses and sportswear was good.

Midspring again will bring to city dwellers the opportunity to visit several notable backyard gardens and landscaped penthouse terraces on the annual pilgrimage of the City Gardens Club, which will be conducted on the afternoons of May 6 and 13.

NATURAL brown rice passes all tests for a food of simplicity and nutrition, and might well be drafted for national defense. Rice has usually come to our tables in refined and polished form -- white rice. Brown rice, although lacking the elegance of the white, far surpasses it as a source of body energy.

BOBBS MERRILLL has issued a sturdily bound, jumbo edition of Richard Halliburton's two books of travel that they have called "Complete Book of Marvels" ($3). The incredible young author wrote them to palliate his never-relenting yen for travel in strange places, and in an introductory letter offers the accounts of his adventures to the boy and girl readers who take the place of the dream children he never had.

Western civilization is faced with the greatest menace to its survival since the Moslem invasion of Europe in the seventh century, the "thoroughly pagan totalitarianism'' of the dictatorships, Professor Carlton J.H. Hayes, newly appointed United States Ambassador to Spain, declared yesterday.

The next best thing to an ocean voyage this year will be a Great Lakes cruise, where one hankering for vistas of sky and water will find them. On Lake Superior ships are out of sight of land, but the passenger also lazes at the rail to watch the steamer unload freight and pass through the locks at Sault Ste. Marie.

President Roosevelt had as guests at a two-and-a-half hour luncheon in the White House last week two men just back from England, after a sudden trip that had aroused world-wide speculation. One was General George C. Marshall, Army Chief of Staff. The other was Harry L. Hopkins, lease-lend aide and Presidential confidant.
LONDON, April 25 (Reuter) -- Results of football games in Great Britain today follow:...

DRAFT REGISTRATIONS this week-end will put virtually all our man power on record and subject to call. All told, about 40,000,000 men should be on the draft rolls. The list, of course, includes draft board members themselves, who have to register the same as any other citizen.

The way of Felicity, the great-aunt who had willed to the Mere dith family her Vermont farmhouse and its famous herb garden, was certainly an unpredictable one. When Dale gave up her first year of college and moved her family there so that her mother might have a year's rest she hoped to finance the family by carrying on with her aunt's profitable Felicity Balm.

PAUL I. WELLMAN, who has given us before now some admirable accounts, both fictional and non-fictional, of warfare in the plains and deserts of the Southwest, has found for his latest novel a theme of surpassing color and excitement.

VICHY, France, April 25 (U.P.) -Allied planes, it was revealed today, flew over the western edge of the French unoccupied zone at 3 A. M. Friday, drpping leaflets containing translations of United .States Under-Secretary of State Snmuer Welles's pledge to respect the integrity of all parts of the French Empire.

THE annual Stadium Concert Series of the Essex County Symphony Society will open June 2 in Newark, N.J., with a performance of Rossini's "The Barber of Seville," conducted by Sir Thomas Beecham and featuring Metropolitan artists. The cast will include Josephine Antoine, Edwina Eustis, Robert Weede, Salvatore Baccaloni, Nicola Moscona and Carmine Gagliardi.
THIS phrase from Kipling's "Ballad of the Clampherdown" in the graphic language of which the poet was master might well have described so many of the great naval actions of this war.

PIERRE LAVAL has just taken up the reins of command at Vichy. In choosing his colleagues he has been somewhat groping; but in his program he shows neither hesitancy nor doubt. Laval's political exile lasted sixteen months. The better part of this time he spent in Paris, under German protection, in endless conversations with Otto Abetz, representative of the Reich in occupied France, and Abetz's masters.

CHICAGO, April 25 -- Buying by mills rescued the wheat market today following an early dip on the Board of Trade and caused an upturn of around three-quarters cent a bushel from the bottom figures. However, the aggregate trade was not large.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- Attorney General Biddle said today that he would ask postponement for the duration of the war of an anti-trust action pending in the Federal District Court of New York against the General Electric Company and others.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, April 24 -- Japanese cooperatives in Sao Paulo, which have monopolized truck gardening and fisheries and controlled a large percentage of the cotton crop, with yearly trade totaling around $20,000,000, are to be taken over by non-official agencies soon.

Members of the Defense Recreation Committee will be guests instead of hosts tomorrow night. Instead of giving free tickets to soldiers and sailors, they will receive tickets to a show given by soldiers and sailors at the Metropolitan Opera House.

Although she has milder relatives in real life, you will not find Elizabite in any handbook of the vegetable or animal kingdom. She is, fortunately, a unique creation from the unpredictable and always amusing brush of H.A. Rey, who has given us "Curious George" and other original picture books.

English and French furniture, Georgian silverware, china, tapestries and rugs from the collections of the late Mrs. Helen Gould Shepard and F.W. Woolworth were sold at auction yesterday in the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

It's now the open season for Spring cleaning, one of those things that just has to be faced and got over with. There seem to be two schools of opinion about it -- either you do the whole job in one terrible siege, turning the place upside down and having dinner out for the duration, or you do it piecemeal with a minimum amount of upset.

H. Gerrish Smith, president of the National Council of American Shipbuilders, declared last week at the organization's annual election meeting that if labor would cooperate and the allied industries continue to furnish materials the shipyards of the nation would produce the tonnage called for by the government.

WITH a view to meeting the shortage of paper it has been suggested that there should be set up a committee of five judges to examine all books intended for publication, weed out the rubbish, and allocate among the survivors such paper as might be available.

The attempt of John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, to organize the milk producers preliminary to an effort to unionize all farmers and control the food supply of the country in wartime was attacked last night by Thomas E. Dewey, former District Attorney and prospective Republican nominee for Governor.

"I CAN tell you an andecdote about 'War and Peace,'" said Countess Alexandra Tolstoy, the youngest daughter of the author of that novel. "On one day during my childhood all the family except my father had gathered in the dining room, a very large room that we used as a sitting room also, a comfortable gathering place, and we were reading 'War and Peace.'

CHICAGO, April 25 -- In his first major clash with party leaders since his defeat in the 1940 election, Wendell L. Willkie furnished the leadership on what the Republican National Committee came to realize was an issue of importance to the future of the party, and he won a victory.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- Within the next few days all the golf courses of the leading resorts of the region will open for the 1942 season. The twenty-seven-hole Buck Hill Golf Course opened yesterday and the courses at Pocono Manor and the Skytop Club are to open on Friday.

NEW BERN, N.C. -- Noted for its colonial architecture, New Bern will open its old homes to the public on Saturday in honor of the Army, Navy and Marine officers and their wives now in this area. There will be no admission charge, but a voluntary offering may be made for war relief work.

TWENTY-NINE short stories and sketches, written during the course of as many years, make an offering which no admirer of the work of Sho lem Asch can afford to overlook. It would be interesting to know the specific order in which these stories were written, but this is not revealed to us.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 25 -- The twenty-seventh anniversary of the Anzac landing at Gallipoli, which was one of the major British disasters in World War I, was the most somber on record, owing to the government's policy of discouraging the massing of persons in cities.

Even the dictionary recognizes Spring fever for approximately what it is. Only approximately, however. To call it "a lazy, listless feeling" is to under-rate it at the same time that one completely ignores its deeper manifestations. And to say that it simply comes "with the first warm days of Spring" is to pay only the slightest attention to its real causes.

Elisha M. Friedman makes an interesting case against the corporation surtax on the grounds that it is regressive. Nevertheless, among the "alternatives suggested" he recommends the notoriously regressive sales tax in THE NEW YORK TIMES of April 19.

While a group of 5 and 6 year olds in a schoolroom at St. Etienne in unoccupied France thought they were merely saying thank you to the various relief agencies in this country who have been shipping vitamins to hungry French children by describing an imaginary voyage of "Little Drop of Vitamin" from America, they were also, as a matter of fact, making a very charming little book.

OTTAWA, April 25 -- More than 4,000,000 of Canada's 11,500,000 population are expected to vote in Monday's plebiscite in which the government is asking release from past commitments about the manner in which men can be raised for the army.

Thousands of pets and their owners paraded hopefully before judges yesterday as sixteen pet shows were held simultaneously in as many city playgrounds. The events were sponsored by the Department of Parks as a finale to "Be Kind to Animals Week."

Jim Steele is nothing if not cooperative. Disposing of an inconvenient corpse is all in the day's work for him. Anything to oblige a friend who is in a jam. Larry Maxwell does not know at the time just how much of a jam he is in, but he soon finds out, and Steele, who is not a detective by profession, has his work cut out for him.

NEW DELHI, India, April 25 (AP) -- The hard-pressed Chinese defending the United Nations eastern flank in Burma counter-attacked tonight in an effort to halt a Japanese drive six miles west of Taunggyi.
RICHMOND, Va., April 25 -- Henry Ford is revealed as the inventor of a new liner for the cylinders of auto engines which will not develop "hot spots" in a patent (No. 2,279,671) just granted to him.

CHICAGO, April 25 (AP) -- Prices of livestock were steady today after a week of irregular gains for many grades and classes led by fat lambs. The report of the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 25 -- The Russians say that one swallow does not bring good weather. There is always some doubt about the demarcation of Spring and Summer in this land where at a long Winter's end you see children sunning themselves and playing hopscotch on a dusty pavement on one side of a street while on the other side people are still skidding and slipping in the snow.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 25 -- The volatile Italian public was treated this week to an intensification of the editorial invective against France that has been under way since the beginning of this month.

WASHINGTON, April 25 - With the exception of expansion of facilities already planned for the production of such vital materials as steel, aluminum, magnesium and synthetic rubber the construction of new war plants will be discontinued, under a new policy to be adopted by the War Production Board.

The first private showing of the United China Relief documentary film, "The Western Front," will take place tomorrow afternoon at the home of Mrs. Henry Martyn Alexander, 4 Sutton Place North. Mrs. Alexander will act as hostess for the occasion and will be assisted by Lady Ashburton, Mrs. Franklin Hoyt and Mrs. Philip K. Rhinelander. After the showing Sanford Clark will speak on China and her needs.

IN "Salsette Discovers America," the author of the many-volumed, wide-focused "Men of Good-Will" takes the happiest holiday. As the exiled French university professor who is its protagonist looks about him -- to the streets of New York, the parkways and suburbs, the New England countryside -- Jules Romains's writing excursion makes its way in sublety, wit and charm.

Reports from the draft boards throughout the metropolitan area yesterday indicated that the latest group to register, those between 45 and 64, were of the "early bird" variety and appeared eager to contribute as soon as possible to the war.

It is Christmas at Upper Cutting and there will be murder all around, although Gordon and Liz Parrott do not know that when they accept Aunt Hester's invitation. Hester is Gordon's aunt and this is the first time she has expressed any desire to meet Gordon's wife.

CHICAGO, April 25 -- Chicago, the city which sold the nation the most successful World's Fair in its history while the country was in the depths of its worst depression, has decided to sell the Second World War to the Middle West.

Pruning roses is a common Spring task, for it's a rare garden that hasn't a few rose bushes. The bush plants -- which in most gardens are Hybrid Teas -- are those scheduled for Spring pruning. Floribundas need little if any annual pruning.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25 -- England stands ready to turn her back on many things of the past in favor of some new order born of "united thinking by men of good will," Professor Charles K. Webster, director of the British Information Service in New York City, asserted tonight in an address at the annual dinner of the American Philosophical Society.

With every emphasis on community service and none on purely social affairs, the Association of Junior Leagues of America this week holds its twenty-second annual conference. Advance programs of the sessions at Kansas City, Mo., and instructions to delegates gathering from 154 cities of the United States, in Mexico and Canada, forecast a four-day meeting without frills.

RECIPROCAL needs were filled in the annual Spring tour of the Metropolitan company, which closed last night in Richmond, Va. The country at large enjoyed the opportunity to visualize in the flesh the performances and performers hitherto familiar to radio listeners only by ear.

NEWARK, N.J., April 25 (AP) -- Al Gerheauser, big left-hander who toiled for Kansas City last year, held the Red Wings to five hits, all singles, today and breezed to his first victory as Newark supported him with a 14-blow barrage off three Rochester pitchers for a 12-2 verdict.
Another Air Ministry communique today said:
One of the strong points of Master Melvin Ott's newly constructed Giants this Spring is that if it isn't one fellow belting a ball out of the arena it is quite certain to be somebody else.

Postmaster General Walker's announcement that the sesquicentennial of Kentucky's Statehood will be commemorated with a three-cent stamp on June 1, and that release of postal paper in connection with the war effort is being considered, has been welcomed by collectors.

RADIO is ridding itself of an overwhelming and cumbersome variety of vacuum tubes -- with considerable advantage, if not actual profit, to both industry and consumer. A few days ago the War Production Board ordered the country's radio tube makers to discontinue making 349 types of bulbs now on the market.

TIM SULLIVAN, good-luck batboy of the New York Yankees, is wearing a new kind of uniform this Spring. He's in the Coast Guard learning that for the time being national defense is more important than the national pastime, and going about his new job with the same spirit that led the Yanks last year to vote him a $1,500 share of their world series money.

Safety regulations and maritime precautions designed to reduce casualties at sea during the war have been issued by Vice Admiral Russell R. Waesche, commandant of the United States Coast Guard, through the Guard's division of inspection and navigation.

EVANSTON, Ill., April 25 -- At a time when the world is more aware of the importance of technology than ever before, Northwestern University is preparing to dedicate its new $6,735,000 Technological Institute June 15 and 16.

Although this problem has not received as much publicity as has the transport of oil, the railroads that serve the Northern Atlantic seaboard are giving considerable thought to the movement of coal from the Pocahontas fields to New York and New England.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 25 -After four defeats Yale scored its first victory of the baseball season today, overcoming Penn by 4 -- 1 in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game.

The growing trend toward participation of established organizations in the victory drive is acknowledged in the spacious Pershing Square headquarters of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office. Here Mrs. John W. Castles Jr., recently appointed director of group activities, is working to assist clubs in setting up their war programs and to fit them as units into the larger metropolitan pattern.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 25 -- A full program of victory courses, designed to serve the needs of workers employed in industrial plants of near-by areas, has been drawn up by the Board of Educational Directors of the Fairleigh Dickinson Junior College here.

AMHERST, Mass., April 25 -- Backed by the entire student body, Massachusetts State College will present its fourth annual music week from Tuesday through May 3, as a demonstration of the value of good music in everyday living.

Organized philately's effort to support wartime charity will take the form of a "Buddy Bazaar" to be held in New York on June 19 and 20, it was announced last week by Emil Bruechig, president of the American Stamp Dealers Association. Net proceeds will be turned over to the U.S.O., which will use the money to provide entertainment for the armed forces.

The Treasury's revival of the mandatory joint income-tax return of husband and wife is prompted, of course, by the present great need for revenue. While the emergency justifies the adoption of any equitable form of taxation, it does not seem to warrant the introduction of a measure which would disrupt fundamental personal rights established by the States and guaranteed by the Federal Constitution.

The Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity has turned off 12,000 street lights in the city, and has partly blacked out, with paint, 15,000 lights in shorefront areas in an effort to change the lighting pattern of the city so that it may be unrecognizable from above, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Any "price freeze" which fails to take into consideration existing differences between current shelf prices and replacement costs will put 100,000 to 150,000 retail grocers out of business within six months, Herbert H. Sack, president of the National Association of Retail Grocers, asserted here tonight.

During the last three years Professor Harold Rugg of Teachers College has been the victim of the most unfair attacks on his school textbooks ever vented on an author in modern times. In these attacks, be they malicious, inadvertent or innocent, Dr. Rugg is merely a symbol, although, unfortunately, a very conspicuous symbol, of public injustice.
On April 16 THE NEW YORK TIMES published an account of the formal opening of the Juvenile Welfare Council.

CHICAGO, April 26 -- A continued brisk demand for lard for lease-lend purposes has prevented any accumulation in supplies of that commodity at leading packing points in the West, local packers report.

NORWALK, Conn., April 26 -- Roton Point Park, on Long Island Sound, comprising over thirty acres, which has been an excursion resort and amusement park for New Yorkers for nearly three-quarters of a century, will not open this year, and will be placed on the market for sale, it was disclosed today by Neville Bayley, operating owner for the past twenty-eight years.

An immunization campaign against smallpox and diphtheria, to guard New Yorkers against these infection hazards resulting from war conditions, was announced yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner.

LONDON, April 26 (AP) -- General Charles de Gaulle, the Free French leader, has sent a welcome to the commander of United States Army forces that Washington announced yesterday had arrived at New Caledonia, French island of the Southwest Pacific.

One formula frequently put forward for "stabilizing" wages reveals that a large number of people still do not recognize the real effect of war on civilian consumption. This formula proposes that wages be not allowed to rise further except for such advances "as may be necessary to keep pace with the increased cost of living."

BOSTON, April 26 -- The largest crowd in the history of Fenway Park since the Boston club banned overflow patronage on the field today saw the Yankees give the Red Sox their worst trimming of the campaign.

The report for 1941 of the Union Pacific Railroad Company, released for publication today, discloses that last year the carrier's investments in other companies decreased $17,937,091 to $106,082,475. The securities sold included 100,000 shares of New York Central Railroad Company capital stock, reducing holdings in that road to 160,000 shares.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 26 (U.P.) -- The German Air Force, renewing mass attacks on Leningrad, sent 165 bombers and fighters against the city Friday night and Saturday at a cost of thirty-five planes shot down and three damaged, the Red Army reported tonight.

PITTSBURGH, April 26 -- With all efforts directed toward maximum production of steel in the war effort, the industry last week was able to increase its output half a point from the week before to 98 1/2 per cent of rated capacity. Indications are that the nation's output this week will be equal to or greater than last week's volume.

LONDON, April 26 -- Because anything to do with food is important to an island nation at war, the announcement that the monthly egg ration is to be increased by one egg per person can be said to be the major event on Britain's home front this week.

Although the bill introduced in the last session of the State Legislature to prohibit the netting of striped bass in the Hudson River met defeat, many of the sportsmen's groups that supported it plan to continue to work for some means of protecting the bass.

A NORTH ATLANTIC PORT, April 23 (Delayed) -- Twenty-one survivors of a torpedoed United Nations freighter told today of a violent four-day running battle with German dive-bombers and submarines that attacked a convoy returning to the United States after unloading supplies for Russia at Murmansk.

Ernest Bloch has been selected as the first composer to receive the gold medal of the American Academy of Arts and Letters, it was announced yesterday by Walter Damrosch, president of the academy. The medal is the academy's highest award and it only has been presented on five previous occasions, the last one being in 1930.

All Hitler's recent speeches have been attempts to justify himself for going to war. Yesterday he went back to the collapse of the Roman Empire in an endeavor to prove that this conflict was inevitable, one of those "elemental conflicts which shake the world once in a thousand years and usher in a new millennium."
MOSCOW, April 26 (From Russian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

Twelve hundred additional volunteer telephonists and switchboard operators are needed at once to fill quotas for the emergency warning centers being established by the Fire Department in the five boroughs, Mrs. Eliot Johnson, director of the A.W.V.S. switchboard service, said yesterday.

Ten winners have been selected by the American Academy in Rome in its regional competition in painting and sculpture in the eastern district, comprising New England and the Middle and South Atlantic States. These winners will compete with winners in the three other districts of the country for two $1,000 prizes in painting and sculpture, and second, third and fourth prizes in each subject of $100, $50 and $25.

CHICAGO, April 26 -- Announcement last week that there would be no change in the ceiling price of soy bean oil, further weakness in prices for bean meal and the possibility of a liberal carry-over of old beans into the new crop season brought in general selling of futures at times and prices dropped to the lowest level in several months before short covering on the strength in wheat caused a strong rally.

The church lives and will continue to live because no other agency makes worship its primary function and because the church through the power of great faith creates faith in the power of God, the Rev. Dr. Frederic W. Perkins declared yesterday.

The American Women's Volunteer Services supper party, "Meet the Celebrities," tonight at the Savoy-Plaza will feature an auction conducted by Victor Moore. The supper will follow a theatre party for the organization at "Keep 'Em Laughing" at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Monday, April 27 -- Two persons were killed and 233 others injured, seventy of whom remained at hospitals, when a six-car train of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad was wrecked in the tube seventy-five feet below Exchange Place, Jersey City, at 11:20 o'clock last night.

Gasoline rationing will have a momentous effect on American habits of living. It is important that a good start be made. Near disaster occurred when card rationing, to begin May 15 in the East, was announced last week in Washington, with an "unfortunate" prediction putting the ration too low.

Four thousand persons, including representatives of the United Nations, attended the annual St. George Day service yesterday afternoon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, where Bishop William T. Manning described the war as "a crusade against the powers of evil."
VICHY, France, April 26 (U.P.) -- American motion pictures are being shown in "bootleg" theatres in German-occupied Paris, where life would be impossible without the "black markets."
JERSEY CITY, April 26 (AP) -- Jersey City and Rochester divided a double-header today, the Little Giants taking the nightcap, 4 to 3, after dropping the opener, 3 to 0.

Cotton textile selling agents, beset with a number of problems as to how to work out ceiling prices on various fabrics affected by the latest ceiling order, took time out yesterday to ponder on a question to which there seemed to be no immediate answer.

CALCUTTA, India, April 26 (AP) -- In a press conference here today Pandit Nehru refuted the recent statement of Sir Stafford Cripps in London that his mission to India had made the situation here "more encouraging."

If Hitler's speech yesterday can be taken at its face value, it is a very encouraging one for the United Nations. Hitler found it necessary to repeat once more all his old alibis for his failure to destroy Russian resistance. Winter came four weeks too early, and where Napoleon had to combat temperatures of only 25 degrees below zero, Hitler's men and their equipment encountered temperatures 53 degrees below.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26 -- With Dolph Camilli, Augie Galen and Arky Vaughan all on the hospital list and Billy Herman playing first base for the first time in his life, the dauntless Dodgers today swept both ends of their double-header-with the Phils, 3 -- 1 and 10 to 2, before a crowd of 21,766.

DETROIT, April 26 -- Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Commissioner and head of the new War Man Power Commission, told 2,000 delegates to the first American Slav Congress today that "American unity is something that dictators cannot understand; it is the blind spot in their plan for world conquest."

The vital need for exporters to maintain their export advertising during the war period, even though they are for the moment unable to fill any export orders, is stressed in a report of the foreign trade committee of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc.
BERNE, Switzerland, April 26 -- Adolf Hitler told the German Reichstag today that the "Bolshevist colossus will be hit until it is destroyed," but for the first time failed to say when.

CHICAGO, April 26 -- Although there was no material change last week in the general situation as to supplies of corn, liquidation developed in that grain on the Board of Trade and the market showed less disposition to rally than was the case in other commodities.

The police and air wardens will have their most grueling test Thursday when mid-Manhattan, including the Times Square area, is to be blacked out, Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday in orders detailing plans for the four final sectional blackouts before borough-wide drills are ordered.
