Although Ramon Naya's "Mexican Mural" has acquired two respectable prizes and has also achieved at least one production in a distant part of the country, it has been a long time waiting for a stage in New York. Last evening Robert Lewis squeezed it into the miniature theatre on top of the Chanin Building.

Warning that many of Mayor La Guardia's supporters had lost faith in him because of his "parsimonious treatment of the schools, the parks and public health," the New York Federation of College Teachers called upon the Mayor yesterday to recommend restoration of proposed cuts in budgetary funds for education and social services.

MEXICO CITY, April 26 -- Settlement of the four-year-old oil controversy, coupled with the financial agreements announced in Washington April 7, is expected to remove the last major obstacle to that economic cooperation that will be Mexico's chief contribution to the democratic cause.

Some refreshing contrasts furnished by a sunny morning in April seemed worth recording. After study of the day's tragic headlines and news reports from the war's many scenes, the beginning of my excursion through the fields of early Spring was still burdened by the world-wide strife and suffering.

ST. LOUIS, April 26 -- Frankie Frisch's hustling Pirates blanked the Cardinals by 2 to 0 in the first game of a double-header today and then battled to a 4-4 deadlock in the nightcap, which was called at the end of eleven innings because of darkness.

The Very Rev. James P. De Wolfe, dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, who will be consecrated as Bishop of Long Island at Garden City on Friday, received his episcopal ring at a special service last night in the Church of the Holy Nativity, 204th Street and Bainbridge Avenue, the Bronx.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices went up from 105.6 to 106.3. The farm products index rose 1.1 per cent because increases in the prices of oranges, eggs, potatoes, steers and lambs exceeded declines in hogs and grains.

At what age does the city-bred male find the idea of farm life most attractive? There is a tide in these matters, and while war is not a respecter of wishes, it will do the government no harm to try where possible to put people to work where they will be reasonably happy.

The Rev. Dr. Robert W. Searle, general secretary of the Greater New York Federation of Churches, asserted in a sermon yesterday morning that the church's mission was focused clearly and that the time had come "to take the reins out of the hands of the so-called practical men" who had forgotten Jesus Christ and dismissed Him.

Washington's announcement that American troops have "arrived" at New Caledonia may be accepted as notice to the Laval Government that the United States has assumed military control of French possessions in the South Pacific for the duration. It affirms a working arrangement with the Free French acknowledged on March 2, but coming at this time it has a broader significance.

HALETHORPE, Md., April 26 (AP) -- Three persons were killed and twenty-nine injured, seven seriously, when two buses crashed head-on near here today on the crowded dual-lane Baltimore-Washington Boulevard.

LONDON, April 26 (AP) -- The textile trades noticeably are moving toward the government's goal of 100 per cent "utility" production, with reports of more stringent style cuts in the offing. Expected to be banned are long, full sleeves, with pockets limited in all garments, even functional buttons reduced, and frilly party frocks discontinued.

Some have promulgated a theory, based apparently on grounds of racial tradition, that, since Mr. Toscanini is an Italian, he cannot play Beethoven. The old story of Lincoln and Grant came to mind last night as this consummate musician interpreted the "Coriolanus" overture and the Fourth and Third symphonies, in the order designated, in Carnegie Hall.

Calling anew upon members of the department not to apply for retirement during the war, Police Commissioner Valentine said yesterday that men with more than twenty years' police service were being classified by draft boards as 1-A for induction as "ordinary soldiers."

The unbending attitude toward Vichy of Under-Secretary of State Summer Welles was hailed by the Rev. Dr. John A.F. Maynard, rector of the French Episcopal Church of the Holy Spirit, 109 East Sixtieth Street, in her sermon yesterday morning. Dr. Maynard had this to say:

VICHY, France, April 26 (AP) -- Delayed dispatches reported today the execution by a German firing squad of six Belgians in the Northern France-Belgium zone of military occupation but there was no word on the fate of more than 100 Frenchmen facing death before Nazi rifles.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 26 -- Adolf Hitler's Reichstag speech is full of menace to the home front, of excuses for the Winter's lack of success, as much a heartfelt sigh of relief that the Winter is over as a gloomy foreboding of what Russia is preparing for Germany. It sounded here as encouraging for Russia as it was discouraging for Germany.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- A War Labor Board official charged last night that an A.F.L. textile union in New Bedford failed in "its duty to its country" by permitting a walkout in the Naushon and Wansutta Mills.

America's greatest war need is for men of strong soul, the Very Rev. Francis X. Shea, vicar for religious orders of the Archdiocese of New York, declared yesterday in a sermon in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 26 -- Four companies of the New York Guard fought each other across the rolling hills of the 365-acre Warburg estate here today -- but with blank, cartridges and empty beer cans as weapons.

At least 192 square feet of the main lobby of City Hall will be partitioned off to provide an office for Deputy Chief Inspector Arthur W. Wallander of the Police Department, most recently described by Mayor La Guardia as "chief of staff of defense activities," it was disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- The Athletics won a double-header from Washington, 6 to 1 and 6 to 3, before 25,000 spectators today.

Lord Beaverbrook's demand last week for the establishment of a second front in Europe, which reinforces pleas previously made by the Russians, obviously has met in Washington and in London a mixed reception of anger, approval and impatience.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 26 (AP) -- A two-motored bomber carrying five men crashed and burned today a few minutes after it took off from the Fairfax Airport, in Kansas City, Kan.
BERLIN, April 26 (From a Ger man broadcast) -- Excerpts from today's address by Adolf Hitler follow:

Trade indications that 1942 greeting card sales for Mother's Day will far exceed those of any previous year have been noted by the Greeting Card Industry, national organization of card publishers, according to Stephen Q. Shannon, director.

Samuel Reshevsky of Boston, defending champion in the United States Chess Federation tourney at the Hotel Astor, yesterday defeated Irving Chernev of Brooklyn in thirty moves in a thirteenth-round game. He now leads with a score of 11 -- 1.

The percentage of outstanding foreign dollar bond obligations in default on at least some phase of their contractual service continued to increase during 1940, according to the annual report of the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, Inc., for that year, which is released for publication today.

An economic conference "devoted to victory by saving" will be opened in the Waldorf-Astoria on May 6 and continue through May 8, when members of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks meet to discuss savings under war conditions.

OTTAWA, April 26 (AP) -- The Board of Transport Commissioners has authorized the New York Central Railroad to make changes in the service on its line from Malone, N.Y., to Montreal, Canada, effective May 11.
VICHY, France, April 26 -- Instructions to protest the landing of American forces in New Caledonia were sent today by the government here to Ambassador Gaston Henry-Haye at Washington.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- To General Douglas MacArthur and Mme. Chiang Kai-shek were awarded tonight national honor keys by Pi Gamma Mu, national social science honor society.

As the second in its Makers of Modern Literature series, New Directions of Norfolk, Conn., will bring out in June a volume on Virginia Woolf by David Daiches. Mr. Daiches is a professor of English at the University of Chicago.

The part the 1,200 women physicians of New York State can play in the war program took precedence over scientific discussions yesterday as the twenty-sixth annual meeting of the Women's Medical Society of New York State opened at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. It will continue through today.

PITTSBURGH, April 26 -- The Inland Steel Company in an analysis of testimony given at the "Little Steel" wage hearing in Washington warned today that if the War Labor Board granted the Steel Workers Organizing Committee its demands for a wage increase of 12 1/2 cents an hour, a spiral of uncontrollable inflation would be started in America.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The War Shipping Administration will announce tomorrow that it is prepared to underwrite war-risk insurance policies covering commercial fishermen against loss of life or injury arising from war action.

Urging that "no hasty judgment" be made in favor of the plans for reconstruction of Battery Park proposed by Park Commissioner Robert Moses, the Citizens Union yesterday asked the Board of Estimate to "invite criticisms and counter-suggestions" from competent groups and to hold a public hearing.

Mayor La Guardia took the Office of Civilian Defense to task again yesterday for failure to provide the city with such equipment as fire pumps and gas masks. He declared that Citizens, lacking gas masks, would have to "do the best they can" should an enemy air raid occur.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Beginning tomorow at midnight, the nation will feel the first effects of the sugar rationing program. From that time until rationing begins on May 5 retail sugar sales will be prohibited.

FORT DEVENS, Mass., April 26 -- The 101st Cavalry Regiment, whose colorful history can be traced through four of the nation's wars, has finally become a mechanized unit of the armed forces. The horses are gone and in their place are the rumbling tanks and armored cars of modern warfare.

Economy measures will offer to women ample opportunity to express their good taste and ingenuity. It soon will become a game for clever ones to see how many changes they can ring on a single dress. It's no sleight-of-hand performance but a matter of having a selective eye in picking out the correct accessories to go with a basic dress.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday appointment of Professor Edmond Borgia Butler of the Fordham Law School as a member of the New York City Housing Authority and said he would be recommended for chairman of that body.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, April 26 (U.P.) -- American fighter pilots down all eleven of the planes that the Japanese lost yesterday in their first raid in three weeks on Darwin.
BERLIN, April 26 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

NEWARK, N.J., April 26 (AP) -- Newark strengthened its International League lead today by defeating Toronto, 3 -- 2 and 9 -- 3, before a crowd of 7,343. The Bears boosted their winning streak to six games.

Toward the close of the week the stock market resumed its decline, reaching the lowest average, not only of 1942, but since April of 1933. Bond averages held up fairly well; wheat and cotton moved uncertainly. The stock market's weakness did not occur because of unfavorable war news, but rather because of uncertainty as to earnings and as to duration of the war.

Sidor Belarsky, basso cantate, who appeared in an all-Jewish recital earlier in the season, last night sang an all-Russian program at Town Hall. There was an enthusiastic audience of 1,300 which insisted on four repetitions and six encores, including requests shouted from the floor.

LONDON, April 25 -- Great Britain's coal problem is beginning to stir up political troubles and the fervor of the opposition is shown by debates in Parliament on the coal question as a result of the unsuccessful coal policy of the government since the outbreak of the war.

LONDON, April 26 -- Taunggyi, eastern railway terminus in the Shah States, has been recaptured by Chinese forces who literally pushed into the city by weight of numbers and savage fighting despite Japanese superiority in artillery and tanks and supremacy in the sky, it was announced today from Chungking.

ALBANY, April 26 -- Creation of a student-nurse reserve and assignment of special representatives in each of the nine Army Corps areas as further stimulants to the enrollment of nurses were announced today by Miss Ruth Hall, president of the New York State Nurses Association.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The commanders of two of the most heavily bombed United Nations fortresses, the United States' Corregidor and Great Britain's Malta, have exchanged radio greetings.

Creation of a special government bureau to investigate subversive activities in this country was suggested last night as a "preliminary to winning the peace" by Carl Sherman, former Attorney General of New York State and chairman of the administrative committee of the American Jewish Congress, whose twenty-fifth anniversary dinner he addressed at the Hotel Astor.

Dropping all pretense of amity in relations with John L. Lewis, the Greater New York Industrial Union Council of the C.I.O. gave the signal yesterday for all-out warfare against him and his representatives in this city.

CALCUTTA, India, April 25 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, leader of the All-India Congress party, today praised Colonel Louis Johnson, President Roosevelt's personal envoy in India, for his recent statements on the lack of post-war commercial purposes of the United States technical mission sent here to spur war production.

CHICAGO, April 26 -- Prices of oats and rye followed those of other grains on the Board of Trade here last week, breaking early but rallying later. A good demand prevailed for cash oats, with choice quality grain bringing a premium over the May future.

BOSTON, April 26 -- The entire length of New England's coastline was darkness tonight "until further notice," in compliance with a military command designed to protect American shipping from enemy submarines.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- (U.P.) -- The time spent by workers in shelters during a blackout or air raid alarm is not to be counted as hours worked if the employe does nothing for the employer during that period, the wage-hour administration stated tonight.
THIS is no longer food for serious thought, but it's a topic that might be tossed about the dinner table just for the fun of it. There is a slight mystery attached to it and it has to do with food.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 26 (AP) -- German planes, in "three deliberate daylight heavy bombing attacks" on Red Cross-protected hospital areas on Malta, killed at least eleven persons and injured an undetermined number of others, a special British communique said today.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- As President Roosevelt prepared tonight to send to Congress tomorrow his over-all program for preventing ruinous inflation, Treasury officials expected there would be little about increasing taxes in the special message.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- That New Zealand was anxious to make its ties with the United States in peace and war as strong, close and fruitful as those it already had with Britain was asserted by Walter Nash, Minister to Washington, in a broadcast today over the Mutual Network heard throughout the British Commonwealth.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The Man Power Commission was completed today when President Roosevelt named the eight members who will serve with Paul V. McNutt, chairman, under instruction "to bring about the most effective mobilization and the maximum use of the nation's man power for the prosecution of the war."

The Lighthouse Players, a group of young blind women sponsored by the New York Association for the Blind, will present their sixteenth annual production on Wednesday and Thursday nights at the Lighthouse Little Theatre, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The State Department announced today that Mrs. Lea Burdett, wife of Winston Burdett, American radio man and a correspondent for the New York newspaper PM, was shot and killed Friday by a band of Kurds in a remote region of Northern Iran.

The Committee on the Domestic Relations Court of New York City, in describing attacks on the Domestic Relations Court and its judges as "unfair and founded upon incorrect allegations of fact," yesterday admitted the existence of "defects," and attributed them to i "the insufficiency of personnel in the court."

NEW ORLEANS, April 26 -- Reflecting nervousness over the President's impending talk on anti-inflationary measures, cotton futures quietly retreated last week in the face of several bullish developments. Selling on the Cotton Exchange here never was heavy and at various times support arrived from more favorable interpretations of the war news, continued unfavorable crop reports, particularly from drenched areas of East Texas, and a market Improvement in the turnover of spots.

How rapidly war pressures are opening up opportunities for technical work by women in the Army, the Navy and other agencies is indicated in a preliminary survey made by a new committee operating under the auspices of the National Roster of Scientific and Specialized Personnel. Unfortunately, women are not being trained to use these opportunities.

CHICAGO, April 26 -- Held to one hit for seven innings, the Indians cut loose in the eighth today for all their runs to defeat the White Sox, 3 to 2. It was the Tribe's eighth straight victory and enabled Cleveland to remain tied with the Yankees for first place.
Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday the names of twenty-three members of the department who, by deeds of bravery last year, earned medals, five of them at the cost of their lives.

A new office of de Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company at Rockefeller Plaza and Fiftieth Street in the RCA Building will be opened today. It replaces the bank's branch at 2 West Forty-ninth Street.

CHICAGO, April 26 -- A suggestion that Congress should enact a national labor policy clearly guaranteeing the right of all to work without regard to membership or non-membership in a labor union was voiced today by Albert W. Hawkes, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States and an employer member of the National War Labor Board.

The average American places so much emphasis on speed, according to the Rev. Dr. Otto H. Bostrom, pastor of the Gustavus Adolphus Lutheran Church, 151 East Twenty-second Street, that he is more interested in the horsepower of a motor than in the steering gear and brakes.

VICHY, April 26 -- Before resigning, the Cabinet, headed by Admiral Francois Darlan, ordered measures in favor of certain categories of workers who had not benefited by former increases in wages. Included under the new ruling are domestic servants and bank employes under 18 years of age who will benefit by a minimum scale. The change of government, it is declared, will cause no alteration in the social policies.

LONDON, April 26 -- The British were intensely interested in the incident staged by Adolf Hitler and Reich Marshall Hermann Goering in the Kroll Opera House of Berlin this afternoon when Herr Hitler received the mandate he demanded of the Reichstag to supplant the German courts of justice with his own judgment, as he last Fall substituted his "intuition" for the science of his generals on the field of battle.

PITTSBURGH, April 26 (AP) -- A twenty-foot wooden bridge girder, made by two Carnegie Institute of Technology senior engineering students from layers of plywood, was demonstrated yesterday before industrialists and lumbermen. The span was described by C.W. Muhlenbruch, civil engineering instructor, as "safe as steel."

His clown uniform was a blaze of colors and his face a dripping mixture of paint and perspiration, but 3-foot 8-inch Howard K. Marco was taking no chance of missing the country's fourth selective service registration yesterday afternoon.

The president of the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce, Colonel Jouett, reports that the aircraft industry is keeping up to schedules laid down by the Government. Already it has performed something on the order of an industrial miracle. Aircraft and engine builders tripled in 1941 their production of 1940 and added a fifth for good measure.

Dazzled, perhaps, by the totally unexpected spectacle of a crowd of 49,834, with nothing more than the lowly Braves for an attraction at the Polo Grounds yesterday, the Giants did quite the unexpected, and in a most astounding fashion. They tripped twice over the Stengeleers and practically wrecked themselves right at the take-off for their first flight into the West.

PEORIA, Ill., April 26 (AP) -- George P. McNear Jr., whose refusal to arbitrate a wage dispute resulted in government seizure of the Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad, called upon the National War Labor Board last night to revoke its "unlawful order" for compulsory arbitration.

LONDON, April 26 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, was 110.3 on April 14, compared with 110.3 a fortnight and a month before, 104.3 a year before and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

CHICAGO, April 26 -- Weather conditions for crops and seeding operations were unusually favorable last week and the few complaints about the outlook for the harvest were confined largely to small areas. The most serious complaints received were from parts of the Southwest and Southwestern Nebraska, where excessive rains have fallen recently, and to a few dry spots in Nebraska.

Morgan D. Wheelock, vice president of Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., leased a duplex apartment of eight rooms and four baths in 8 East Ninety-sixth Street through the concern of which he is vice president and Edgar A. Levy, broker.

The New York Department of Camps and Auxiliaries, Sons of Union Veterans of the Civil War, held its annual exercises yesterday in front of Grant's Tomb on Riverside Drive, commemorating the 120th anniversary of the birth of General Ulysses S. Grant.

CHICAGO, April 26 -- Injection of new influences into the grain markets in the way of anti-inflation and price-ceiling measures resulted last week in most erratic fluctuations of prices on the Board of Trade. Wheat dropped to the lowest marks since last November, and corn to the lowest levels since early in January, under the weight of scattered liquidation and some local selling pressure.

VERBANK, N.Y., April 26 -- With the running of the Orange County Stake for high-class shooting dogs suitable for the Verbank pheasant covers, the thirty-first annual meeting of the Orange County Field Trial Club came to a close today.

Exceptional activity in dress lines for immediate and Summer selling, as well as advance Fall buying of coats and suits, were features reported in a summary of last week's business prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

Submarine attacks on commerce of the Western Hemisphere have underlined the need for inter-American solidarity, according to The Guaranty Survey, monthly publication of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York. The possibilities of this solidarity, says the magazine, "are supremely inviting because it holds promise not merely of indispensable strength for the present emergency, but also of fitting preparation for the future progress of these nations in a world at peace."

For eight years our national laws have compelled the Treasury, against its judgment, to accumulate endlessly a vast store of silver for which it had no use and for which it was required to pay artificially high prices. The foolish claims originally made for this program have all proved delusions.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 26 -- Eight races were sailed at the Larchmont Yacht Club today for a fleet of Class B dinghies engaging in their first session of the post-season series.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 26 -- A strict military blackout, imposed under new Army orders with such suddenness that it surprised thousands of week-end travelers, darkened the entire coastline of Connecticut tonight.

Establishment at an early date of an Eastern Military Area along the entire Eastern seaboard, with the Army taking immediate control over dimming of shore lights and regulation of enemy aliens, was announced here yesterday by Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commanding general of the Eastern Defense Command and First Army.

The fifth annual bicycle parade of the New York Wellesley Club, losing most of the masquerade touches of previous years, bore witness yesterday morning to the growing dependency of men and women on the dependable old two-wheelers.

For the first time in five years theatre-goers this afternoon will he able to see Katharine Cornell in "Candida," when Miss Cornell, Raymond Massey, Burgess Meredith, Midred Natwick, Dudley Digges and Stanley Bell will appear in a revival of the famous play by George Bernard Shaw.

The text of the statement by Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commanding general of the Eastern Defense Command and First Army, with headquarters at Governors Island, announcing preliminary plans for the establishment, at an early date, of an Eastern Military Area along the Atlantic coast follows:

With at least one of the soldier models in the audience, the war posters exhibition of the Salmagundi Club, dedicated to realism in the portrayal of our fighting men, was opened formally last night at 47 Fifth Avenue.

Formal opening to the public will be made today by a banking group headed by Smith, Barney Co., of $6,000,000 of City of Indianapolis, Inc., 3 1/8 per cent gas utility revenue bonds. The issue was awarded to the group in a competitive sale held last week.

LONDON, April 26 (AP) -- Oliver Lyttelton, British Production Minister, told Great Britain in a broadcast tonight that more "socialism" and more "government planning" would be necessary to make a bet- the post-war world. [Mr. Lyttelton added, according to the British official wireless: "The essence of democracy should be a balance between the organizing power of the State and the driving force of the free individual. We must foster both."]

While topping results in 1929 for the most part in 1941 net profits of the chemical industry last year made only slight headway over 1940 because of the increased burden of taxes and other charges. Supplying a wide variety of all-purpose chemical products, most of which find application in the war effort as they did in peacetime pursuits, forty companies in this field had combined profits of $197,418,345 in 1941, against $184,402,604 in 1940.

CARACAS, Venezuela, April 26 -- President Isaias Medina Angarita addressed his annual message to Congress yesterday, outlining an impressive record of Venezuelan accomplishment and issuing a financial statement believed unique in the world at this time.

Irma D. Kluger bought from the Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company the one-family home on a plot 75 by 192 feet at 19 Easton Avenue, White Plains, in Westchester County. The property is assessed at $17,900 and has been occupied by the buyer for the last two years.

Two loft buildings in the garment area were purchased by a syndicate of investors when the State Department of Insurance, as liquidator of the properties of the New York Title and Mortgage Company, sold the twenty-story and penthouse structure at 307 to 317 West Thirty-eighth Street and the four-story building at 308 West Thirty-ninth Street to a group represented by Irving Brodsky, attorney.

OTTAWA, April 26 -- Owing to a misunderstanding of a radio speech which he made on Friday evening regarding tomorrow's plebiscite, Primes Minister W.L. Mackenzie King felt obliged last evening to issue a statement making it clear that an affirmative vote would not be regarded as an expression of confidence in the government, but merely to release the regime for past commitments on the method of raising troops for overseas.

Any question about how women in industry will readjust themselves to meet the problems created by the return of men from the armed forces after the war should not be permitted to slow up the absorption of women into factories and other war production jobs now, Miss Thelma McKelvey, chief of the women's labor supply service of the War Production Board, said yesterday.

Gregor Piatigorsky, the eminent Russian 'cellist, gave his second and last recital of the season yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, this time for the benefit of the American-Russian Committee for Medical Aid to the U.S.S.R., Inc. As usual, the artist was in the peak of form, and under his skilled fingers and bow the 'cello became an instrument capable of rivaling the violin in variety of effects.

Up in the Far North country there is an old and soundly-established woolen mill where, year after year, fleecy flannels come rolling off the looms, every bolt imprinted with a famous name. Suddenly, not long ago, that same signature began to appear in tiny, lavender letters about the top of a snowy bottle of hand lotion -- and the answer to the mystery was lanolin.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 26 (AP) -- A special British communique follows:

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Twelve men spent three days last week stuffing themselves with custard and cake and scrambled eggs, all for the sake of the war effort. The men were being trained as egg testers.

"Awarding a medal of valor to a place is without precedent, but so is the endurance of this island citadel." This is Mrs. Anne O'Hare McCormick's comment on the awarding of the George Cross to the island of Malta.

Plans for the annual Junior League theatre benefit to be held on May 26 have been announced by the president of the league, Mrs. Garret J. Garretson 2d. The performance will be a preview of Dwight Deere Wiman's new production, "All's Fair," starring Ray Bolger, at the Shubert Theatre.
Athletes at the Penn Relays over the week-end exceeded the efforts of trackmen at the Drake carnival in eleven of the eighteen events common to both meets, according to The Associated Press.

Enrolling at a rate of more than 1,000 a minute throughout the long, sunshiny afternoon, 319,650 New Yorkers between the ages of 45 and 64 inclusive cheerfully answered the nation's call between 1 and 6 P.M. yesterday, the second day of the fourth selective service registration.
LONDON, April 26 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:
LONDON, April 26 -- Social, commercial and political organizations have been asked by the government not to hold conferences in the coming months unless they are essential.

Eight midtown theatres will present new film attractions this week. The first arrival is "The Man Who Wouldn't Die," featuring Lloyd Nolan and Helene Reynolds, which opens this morning at the Rialto. The schedule for the remainder of the week is as follows:

Clarification of the problems of boys and girls from fourteen to eighteen years, who are wondering "what they can do" during the Summer to aid in the war program, is the objective of a symposium arranged by the Child Study Association of America, to be held at the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, at 3 P.M. on Wednesday.

The Cadet Chapel Choir of the United States Military Academy took part in the service yesterday morning at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University. The 150-voice choir filled half the loft and the first ten rows in the chapel. It sang "The Light, the Truth, and the Way," by Koschat-Holden, and "The Corps," by W. Franke Harling, arranged by Frederick C. Mayer, conductor.

VICHY, April 10 -- Only on returning to France after a trip abroad does one realize many of the changes brought about by restrictions and regulations consequent upon the war. The contrast with Switzerland, for instance, is striking.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 26 -- Charles R. Rogers, United Artists producer, has bought an option on "What a Lucky Guy," an unproduced play by Charles Sherman, and has sent the manuscript to Cary Grant with the hope of engaging him for the leading role.

PORTLAND, Me., April 26 (AP) -- Thirty-five shells and a single torpedo fired by a German submarine sent a medium-sized American freighter to the bottom of the North Atlantic the night of April 20, the Navy disclosed today after the vessel's entire crew of thirty-five arrived here uninjured.
CINCINNATI, April 26 (AP) -- With a revised line-up the Reds entertained their first Sunday home crowd of 12,858 fans today by beating the Cubs, 9 -- 5.

SOMEWHERE IN ENGLAND, April 26 -- Although the question of whether or not the United Nations can open a European front is still a secret, the British Army in England is training itself, nevertheless, for the terrific hardships it will have to face if such a front is opened.

LONDON, April 26 -- The Stock Exchange here has undergone a decided change to a bullish feeling in keeping with the growing offensive spirit displayed by the United Nations. There also has been an increase in tension, produced by a belief that one of the greatest battles of the war is about to begin.
DETROIT, April 26 (AP) -- Before a crowd of 42,698 the Tigers today defeated the Browns in both ends of a double-header and climbed to third place in the American League, half a game out of the lead.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 26 -- Details of the departure of the "death cargo" of 500 Norwegian teachers, who by Premier Vidkum Quisling's orders were sent from Trondheim to labor camps in Northern Norway despite protests from the Premier's own party men on the spot and of local German authorities, reached Stockholm today.

Two hundred and forty-eight senior, vocational and junior high schools throughout the city will remain open from 1 to 4 P.M. today for the distribution of registration forms to expedite the registration of the sugar trade tomorrow and Wednesday.

Earnings of 150 leading manufacturing companies after making allowances for taxes were less in the first quarter of this year than those a year ago in the majority of cases, according to a tabulation announced yesterday by the National City Bank of New York.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 26 -- Max Singer, National Commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, declared here this afternoon that among the thousands of persons mobilized by the government to administer detail work in the war, "we must naturally expect to find the usual percentage of cheap politicians, dishonest persons and incompetents."

Cooperating with the United States Employment Service and the agricultural extension service of Cornell University, the Board of Education has mapped a program for high school students who desire to work on farms in this State during the Summer vacation, thus helping to offset the present shortage of farm labor.

The one-story garage for 150 cars on a plot 193 by 86 feet at 1201-1209 Clinton Street, northeast corner of Twelfth Street, Hoboken, N.J., has been purchased by John J. Casale, Inc., of 510 West Twenty-first Street, Manhattan, from Edward E. Mattson, of Garden City, L.I. It is assessed for $25,800 and was sold for $35,000, the seller taking back a purchase money mortgage for $20,000.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The President's proposals for the limitation of excess profits and of all incomes to $25,000 will be discussed tomorrow before the Ways and Means Committee by Treasury representativesb40 who admitted they had no specific plan to implement them but were prepared to draft one.

Members of the United States Atlantic Tuna Tournament committee assembled at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday and talked of many things besides tuna. An impression gained by any one attending the gathering was that here was a group of sportsmen, most of whom had registered for the draft in the last two days, who would like to do something about volunteering their services.

Members of the Republican Committee of One Hundred are sponsoring a Spring candlelight dinner dance for the benefit of the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York which will be held on May 8 in the Roof Garden of the Pierre. The club provides shelter and recreation for all enlisted men in the United States armed forces and service men of allied and friendly countries.

NEWARK, N.J., April 27 (AP) -A home run by Nick Gregory, first up in the eighth inning, against Walter Stewart, who had just entered the game, gave Toronto sufficient margin to defeat the Bears today, 8 to 6, and end a six-game winning streak for the International League leaders.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- As a part of the program of the Office of Price Administration to bring the entire textile industry under price control, Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, today issued a maximum price regulation covering the processing of piece goods made of cotton, rayon and their mixtures as they are converted from the unfinished "gray goods" state into finished piece goods.

LONDON, April 27 (AP) -- British bombers and fighters smashed violently at German air bases across the Channel today and encountered their heaviest opposition of the Spring, indicating the R.A.F. was beginning to achieve one of its main objectives by forcing Adolf Hitler to divert his aerial strength from the Eastern Front.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, April 27 (U.P.) -- United States fighter planes based in New Caledonia have gone into action against the Japanese, shooting down or driving off enemy seaplanes, which have tried several times to scout the Free French island 800 miles east of Australia, United States Army officers revealed tonight.

FORT WORTH, Texas, April 27 -- Undaunted by war-time hardships or Texas floods, the general Federation of Women's Clubs opened its first convention of the second world war here tonight in the Will Rogers Memorial Auditorium.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Policing and enforcing of the overall price control order, issuance of which is expected within the next 24 hours, will first be in the hands of pricing experts, probably from the Bureau of Labor Statistics, and later will be assigned to local price administration boards.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Reichsfuehrer Hitler's Reichstag speech yesterday is regarded here as gloomy and, by some, as possibly indicating a breach between him and the German High Command. In the latter event it might be the forerunner of a purge.

The academic careers of more than 2,200 municipal college students will be jeopardized if National Youth Administration funds are cut by Congress, the Board of Higher Education asserted yesterday after a survey on the campuses of City, Brooklyn, Hunter and Queens Colleges.

TRENTON, N.J., April 27 -- The Republican-controlled Senate took no action today on Governor Charles Edison's nomination of Spencer Miller Jr. of South Orange as successor to State Highway Commissioner E. Donald Sterner of Belmar, whose resignation is effective on Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The War Department communique based on reports received until 1 P.M., eastern war time, said:
PRYOR, Okla., April 27 -- A brief, violent tornado reportedly killed at least 100 persons and injured 250 late today in this war boom town and left the main business district in ruins.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- President Roosevelt presented in a message to Congress today a sweeping anti-inflation program.

Steps that consumers may take to counterbalance the lowering of living standards as industrial effort and increasing sums of money must be devoted to war were outlined yesterday by Miss Rachel Lynn Palmer of the National Consumer-Retailer Council.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The War Department announced today that the United States troops cooperating with Free French forces in the defense of the Pacific island of New Caledonia are under the command of Major Gen. Alexander McM. Patch Jr.

The one millionth free ticket for a Broadway show to be given away by the Defense Recreation Committee here was handed by Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt to Corporal William Raney, 23 years old, of Seattle, now stationed at Fort Hamilton. Brooklyn, in a ceremony yesterday afternoon at 99 Park Avenue.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 27 (AP) -- Rochester gained a 2-1 edge in its four-game series with the Jersey City Giants today by winning, 7 to 3.

For an understanding of the damage that British fliers are now inflicting upon German cities like Luebeck and Rostock it is necessary to turn back to the bombing of Coventry in 1940. The Nazi described that assault as "the greatest in aerial history," and at the time it was feared that such raids might paralyze the industrial capacity of England.

SOUTH PLAINFIELD, N.J., April 27 -- Pleas of Federal and union representatives failed to persuade all the employes of Cornell-Dubilier Corporation to return to work today. Even a warning that unless they did so the Army would take over the plant had little effect.
The regulations prescribed by Major Gen. Irving J. Phillipson for the dimming of lights in the Second Corps Area follow:

Effective tonight, strict regulations for dimming out lights along the New York, New Jersey and Delaware coast will be enforced by the Army, Major Gen. Irving J. Phillipson announced last night. Coastal resorts will be virtually darkened and every light in New York City higher than fifteen stories must be shaded or turned out.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -The War Department announced in a communique today that Major Gen. Charles H. Bonesteel, commander of the American troops in Iceland, had taken over the command of all forces of the United Nations there. Major Gen. Henry Osborne Curtis of the British Army had been in command, but there was no indication in the announcement whether British troops were being withdrawn from Iceland.

NORFOLK, Va., April 27 -- An Army plane and a blimp dropped provisions into their overcrowded lifeboat, survivors of a torpedoed Panamanian cargo ship related on their arrival at Norfolk after sailing an estimated 400 miles during the seven days they were in the boat.

With new wage contracts in domestic newsprint mills going into effect on May 1, manufacturers are anxiously awaiting action by the Office of Price Administration on the prices to be put into effect on June 1. April and May prices were frozen by OPA action at their prevailing levels of $50 a ton and mills are hopeful that the OPA decision will be forthcoming by the middle of next month.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. announced today that the Treasury would borrow $4,000,000,000 in May and June, $2,000,000,000 in each month, the largest borrowing in a two-month period on record.

The house of delegates of the Medical Society of the State of New York, which opened its 136th annual meeting here yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria, officially approved, and voted to "sponsor and support in every manner possible," three corporations in the State offering medical insurance to subscribers.

LONDON, April 27 (U.P.) -- Members of the Royal Air Force who flew "house-top high" across France and 400 miles into Germany in daylight on April 17 to bomb the main Diesel engine manufacturing plant at Augsburg, received medals today.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The beleaguered fortress of Corregidor in the Philippines, headquarters of Lieut. Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright, has experienced its 250th air raid alarm but is still flying the American flag over the entrance to Manila Bay, a War Department communique released here this afternoon reported.

A plan to comply with a Federal order for a cut of 25 per cent in delivery route mileage and still retain daily milk deliveries was presented yesterday by Gus McDonough, president of the teamsters' union unit at the Borden Company. Major milk distributors here have suggested reducing deliveries to one every other day to meet the requirement.

JERUSALEM, April 27 -- A Yugoslav official spokesman revealed today that General Draja Mikhailovitch, leader of the guerrilla army fighting Axis forces in Yugoslavia, has made a deal with the Italians for fuel to operate his military vehicles in exchange for certain Italian prisoners.

TRENTON, N.J., April 27 (AP) -A fourth dividend payment of $1,198,242 to general creditors of the New Jersey Title Guarantee and Trust Company of Jersey City was recommended today to Henry T. Kays, Vice Chancellor, by Eugene E. Agger, State Commissioner of Banking and Insurance.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (UP) -Virtually all new radio station construction was stopped for the duration of the war by the Federal Communications Commission today.
BERNE, Switzerland, April 27 -- The Italian reaction to Reichsfuehrer Hitler's Reichstag speech was characterized semi-officially from Home tonight as one of "stupefaction."
TOKYO, April 27 (From Japanese broadcasts) -- Premier General Hideki Tojo said today that despite successive Japanese victories "the war still has to be fought."

CALGARY, April 27 (Canadian Press) -- The scrambling, fore-checking type of hockey which has characterized National League play in recent years has driven into retirement one of the smoothest left wingers of the last decade -Dave (Sweeney) Schriner.

District Attorney William O'Dwyer, who won nation-wide attention by breaking up the Brooklyn murder ring, announced yesterday that he had received word from the War Department that he had been commissioned a major in the Army.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -Spokesmen for organized labor were confused and puzzled as to the meaning of President Roosevelt's reference in his message to Congress to the need for stabilizing "the remuneration received by individuals for their work."

Although Bernard Shaw's "Candida" has been put on the stage many times, no one ever saw it until yesterday afternoon when it was really acted at the Shubert Theatre. For the Katharine Cornell revival for the Army Emergency Fund and the Navy Relief Fund is flooded with new light and is the foremost event of the theatre season.

A bit back, License Commissioner Paul Moss was casting a baleful eye on the Gaiety and Eltinge Theatres, haunts of the weird sisters of Burlesque. Like all tender plants caught by the Moss eye, the theatres withered and died, amid statements, petitions and hearings.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 27 -Albert Sabath's Alsab, one of the favorites for the Kentucky Derby, cut his right hind leg near the ankle bone on a nail today, but Trainer Sarge Swenke said he would not know until tomorrow morning whether the injury would keep the colt from running in the Derby Trial Stakes at Churchill Downs tomorrow.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 27 -Delegates representing 154 Junior Leagues, including the organization at Honolulu, will assemble here tomorrow for the twenty-second annual conference of the Association of Junior Leagues of America, representing a total membership of 36,000 young women.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., April 27 -- Commissioner Ernest I. Pugmire, territorial commander of the Salvation Army in eleven Eastern States, told Salvationist leaders of the United Service Organizations at a conference in the Hotel Gramatan here today that the reputation and the future of the Salvation Army would not be impaired by the present union with five other groups in operating the USO.

CHICAGO, April 27 -- Participants in the World Trade Conferences here today were told by Eugene P. Thomas, president, National Foreign Trade Council, that "it is not too early to plan for an economic conference in London of the United Nations" as a further expression of the economic aims of the Anglo-American agreement last February.

LONDON, April 27 -- British bombers struck once again at Rostock last night, pounding that German Baltic port, a base for the North Russian front and site of Heinkel plane factories, for the fourth straight night.

Recent months have brought a widespread public acceptance of vitamin enriched bread and a considerable increase in its sales, members of the Quality Bakers of America agreed yesterday at their thirty-third general conference at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
Representatives of the graphic arts industry held a round-table discussion at the Hotel Astor yesterday to plan their part in the current drive of the Greater New York Fund.

The New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra will continue for a second season with no regular conductor, it was announced yesterday by Marshall Field, president and chairman of the board of directors. Instead there will be six or seven guest conductors, including Arturo Toscanini.

Therese Bonney returned from Europe a few months ago, and brought with her ten water-colors of flowers by Raoul Dufy, which were placed on view yesterday at the Bignou Gallery, 32 East Fifty-seventh Street. They may be seen there until May 16.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., April 27 (AP) -- The general chairman of the United Dairy Farmers and other officers of the organization committee of the former Dairy Farmers Union will be asked to resign for "unauthorized actions," the Jefferson County D.F.U. chairman said today.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The nation had 13,300,000 men and women available for full-time or half-time employment in addition to the 3,600,000 who were reported last month to be in the labor market for full-time jobs, F.H. Dryden, acting WPA Commissioner, said today.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- The first official list of Americans held as prisoners of war by the Japanese, containing 120 names, was published today by the War Department.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended April 22 aggregated $10,995,000,000.

The Board of Estimate revised the city's method of stating its yearly budgetary expenses yesterday when it approved, a new-type budget aggregating $777,911,106 that is designed to give an adequate picture of municipal expense in the 1942-43 fiscal year.

CHUNGKING, China, Tuesday, April 28 -- Japanese mechanized forces, in a swift sweep around the eastern end of the United Nations line in Burma, have penetrated within sixty-seven miles of the Burma Road terminus at Lashio and have by-passed Mandalay, a Chinese communique announced today.

Two hundred and fifty salvage workrooms and collection depots in forty-six States are already converting unused material and clothing into practical garments for war emergency needs in what has become "the major national project" of Bundles for America, Inc., 475 Fifth Avenue, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Wales Latham, president of the organization.

LONDON, April 27 (AP) -- Russia's immediate hope of knocking Finland out of the war, thus uncovering the northern flank of the main German armies, rested tonight on a developing counter-offensive on the still frozen terrain of Lapland and Karelia in the eerie light of an almost continuous Arctic day.

Four thousand persons visited the Children's Zoo of the New York Zoological Park in the Bronx last Sunday to pay their respects to a sheep known as Slaughter House Ma on becoming a grandmother, statisticians at the zoo computed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Formation of a women's army auxiliary corps, which the Army High Command has asked Congress to authorize so as to release possibly 150,000 soldiers for combatant service, met an unexpected reverse today when the Senate ordered the entire project recommitted to its Military Affairs Committee for further study.

In response to complaints from American foreign traders asserting that British publications were advertising scarce materials in export markets, the British Secretary of the Department of Overseas Trade some months ago prepared an official notice to be carried in all export publications as follows:

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The effect of Executive Order 9128, putting the Board of Economic Warfare (the BEW) in charge of all import procurement except weapons and munitions of war, has been generally analyzed as superseding the RFC's previous authority in that sector of the war program.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Overruling a ten-year-old decision, the Supreme Court held today that a State where a company is incorporated may tax a transfer of the corporation's stock when a non-resident stockholder dies.

HAMMONTON, N.J., April 27 -A severe forest fire swept over the southeastern portion of this town this afternoon and was not brought under control for six hours. It veered to the west after burning for a half-mile in a southeasterly direction from Weymouth Road to the Mullican Township line, finally shifting toward Hammonton.

LONDON, April 27 (U.P.) -- Russian sailors, striking behind the German lines in Commando-like raids at both ends of the Eastern Front, have wrecked two Axis coastal bases, one west of Murmansk in the far north and the other on the shore of the Black Sea, Soviet reports said tonight.

A luncheon celebrating the seventieth anniversary of the founding of the State Charities Aid Association will be given May 4 at the Hotel Commodore. This was announced yesterday by Homer Folks, its secretary, who said it also would celebrate the thirty-fifth anniversary of its State Committee on Tuberculosis and Public Health.

A group composed of the First National Bank of Boston, the Chemical Bank and Trust Company and the First Boston Corpo-l ration received yesterday the award of $5,000,000 city of }oston, IVfass., temporary-loan notes at 0.57 per cent, plus a premium of $57.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Congressional reaction to President Roosevelt's anti-inflation program indicated today that it would bring a severe test of his wartime leadership, particularly on the farm price issue.

H.M. McCormack, previously in charge of paper milk container sales in the Atlantic division of American Can Company, has been promoted to the general sales department where he will have supervision for the entire country over paper milk containers and the transition from metal to fiber containers for all general line products.
Retailers and manufacturers here eagerly awaited specific provisions of the over-all price-ceiling order, following Roosevelt's presentation yesterday of his seven-point anti-flation program.

LONDON, April 27 (U.P.) -- Adolf Hitler "is perhaps planning another purge" because there are forces arising in Germany not subservient to his will, Viscount Simon, the Lord Chancellor, said tonight in the first government comment on Herr Hitler's speech of yesterday.

It is a pleasure to commend you on the editorial appearing in THE TIMES of April 24, entitled "The Coudert Report." The editorial represents an intelligent and a balanced view of the problems presented by the report. As you say, there is, of course, a perfectly clear distinction between the activities of Communists on the Russian front and Communists in New York City schools.

CHICAGO, April 27 -- Albert W. Hawkes, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, said today that his "first reaction" to President Roosevelt's proposal that no persons should be permitted to retain more than $25,000 of income annually after taxes was that "it would cause dislocations that would be most unfortunate."

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 27 (AP) -- The Soviet Government in a new list of atrocity charges declared tonight that the Germans had demanded that "several million of the choicest Russian workers" in occupied territory be delivered immediately to Germany for forced labor.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- At least 50,000 persons, including President Roosevelt himself, have net incomes exceeding $25,000 a year -- the figure which the Chief Executive said ought to be an individual's maximum after payment of taxes.

VICHY, France, April 27 (U.P.) -Pierre Laval went to United States Ambassador Admiral William D. Leahy today for their first meeting since M. Laval's rise to power as head of a collaborationist government and their last before Admiral Leahy leaves for home to report to President Roosevelt.

The national executive committee of the Girl Scouts has adopted a resolution urging that school buildings and playgrounds throughout the United States be kept open all Summer to provide play space for children, Mrs. Paul Rittenhouse, national director, announced yesterday.

The Queens County Savings Bank of Flushing and Corona, L.I., closed twenty-seven sales of realty in the first three months this year, exceeding any similar period to date, Le Roy T. Stratton, vice president of the bank, announced yesterday.

Airtight pitching by Tim Fiori, converted outfielder and product of New Utrecht High, yesterday gave St. John's another victory in the Metropolitan Baseball Conference. Fiori yielded only two hits to City College at Dexter Park as the Redmen blanked the Beavers, 5 to 0.

VICHY, France, April 27 -- United States Ambasador William D. Leahy, who has been called to Washington to report on the situation in France since the formation of the Laval Cabinet, today took leave of Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, Chief of State.

VICHY, France, April 27 -- Although the Riom trial has been suspended, the Propaganda Ministry has edited and published the complete text of the prosecution's charges against former Premiers Edouard Daladier and Leon Blum, General Maurice Gustave Gamelin, former Controller General Pierre Jacomet and former Air Ministers Guy La Chambre and Pierre Cot.

ALBANY, April 27 -- Governor Lehman today signed the bill amending the law on the allocation of $60,000,000 or the grade crossing bond issue so that the money can be used only for the construction of highways and parkways which have been certified by the Governor as necessary for national defense.
ALBANY, April 27 -- Governor Lehman called attention of young women today to "the great need" for an increased enrollment in nursing classes to help offset the loss of those aiding in war work.
MOSCOW, April 27 (From Russian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- A communique broadcast today by the Soviet Information Bureau said:

Radical changes in procurement methods within the very near future were predicted here last night by Lieut. Col. A.G. Stevens of the New York Quartermaster Corps, War Department, as the result of a survey which will be conducted in this city and vicinity this week by officials of the WPB and the War Department.

Remarkable stamina was shown yesterday by the stock market in the face of the President's seven-point program to curb inflation, although several investment type issues were hard hit. The real weakness occasioned by Mr. Roosevelt's message to Congress appeared in the commodities, where wheat tumbled almost 3 cents a bushel in a session featured by erratic fluctuations.

NEW DELHI, India, April 27 -Mohandas K. Gandhi, in today's issue of his newspaper Harijan, published at Ahmedabad, attacked the policy that has resulted in the arrival of United States troops in India.

The report of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on March 31, made public yesterday by Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the board, shows a net income after all expenses and charges of $32,693,453.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 27 -The Eastman School Junior Symphony Orchestra and the Eastman School Choir tonight gave the first performance of the annual festival of American music in which the American composers concerts project of the school each year reaches its climax.

KUIBYSHEV, April 27 (U.P.) -- Foreign Commissar Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff dispatched a note to all friendly foreign governments tonight, charging that Germany had ordered her army in Russia to carry out systematic atrocities on a wholesale scale.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Congressional reaction today to the President's anti-inflation message was sharp and varied.

NEW CITY, N.Y., April 27 -State troopers arrested Sheriff Edward C. Dormann of Rockland County today at his Spring Valley home on a charge of "contriving and assisting in a lottery" on March 30. He was arraigned before County Judge John A. McKenna here and held in $50,000 bail for a hearing on May 4.

Sales of sugar in retail stores in the metropolitan area spurted sharply yesterday as housewives stocked up to carry them through the rationing registration period in which all sales to consumers will be banned. Registration will begin today for trade and institutional users and the ban on retail sales here will not be lifted until May 6 or 7.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 27 -- "Stand By to Die," the story of a famous aviatrix who was lost in the South Pacific, has been purchased by RKO from Horace McCoy for $35,000 as a vehicle for Rosalind Russell and Joel McCrea. Of the purchase price, $7,000 will go to George Palmer Putnam, husband of the late Amelia Earhart, to obtain a waiver protecting ment allegations, according to Mr. McCoy.
The annual report of Reo Motors, Inc., issued yesterday, shows net profit for 1941 of $1,089,760, in contrast to a net loss of $1,292,365 for 1940.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -George Holden Tinkham, bachelor, big game hunter, world traveler and Republican isolationist, announced tonight his intention to retire from public life at the end of his present term as Representative of the Tenth Massachusetts District.

The American Academy of Arts and Letters and the National Institute of Arts and Letters will open the first comprehensive exhibition of work by nearly all of their 250 members on May 8. The exhibition will be housed in the Academy's gallery and museum at 633 West 155th Street and will include painting, sculpture, architecture, literature and music.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 27 -- Louis Austin Vierbuchen, motorman of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad train that was wrecked in the tube under Exchange Place in Jersey City at 10:48 last night, was held without bail in Jersey City today pending grand jury action on charges of manslaughter and of operating a locomotive while under the influence of liquor.

The alleged negligence of the officers of a United States destroyer operating off the Florida coast three months ago was made the basis of a lawsuit filed in Federal court yesterday against the government. The Ford Motor Company, plaintiff in the action, asked $7,500 for damages suffered by its motor vessel, Green Island, which was rammed by the destroyer.

If there is a great variety of ways, thoughts and worldly status among American men between the ages of 21 and 44 inclusive, there is even more among those between the ages of 45 and 64 inclusive. In thousands of registration places all over the United States yesterday, or on Sunday or Saturday, this must have been apparent.

In a finish that had 17,039 racegoers standing on their chairs, Don Meade just managed to bring home Tom Heard's favored Boysy at Jamaica yesterday. By a margin of a nose, gained in the stretch duel, Boysy flashed across the wire in front of Louis B. Mayer's Sir Jeffrey, with the Greentree Stable's The Rhymer eight lengths back in third place.

With the General Motors Corporation now 90 per cent engaged on war work, the effects of a sharp transition from civilian to arms production in the first quarter of 1942 were revealed in the report made public yesterday by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman.

CIVILIANS, as Raymond Daniell of this newspaper has phrased it, must fight. But they must also cultivate a sense of proportion about a war whose truly heroic campaigns are being waged on the Russian and Chinese fronts. With our understandable hunger for victories of our own, we spent a Winter lapping up banner headlines about MacArthur's magnificent defensive stand on Bataan.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended April 22: A decrease of $74,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans, an increase of $420,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and decreases of $394,000,000 in government deposits and $238,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.

ST. LOUIS, April 27 -- Showing surprising good cheer although his club had suffered two disastrous setbacks over the week-end at the Polo Grounds, Manager Melvin Ott said tonight he would start his ace left-hander, Cliff Melton, in the hope of getting his Giants off on the right foot when they open their western invasion against the Cardinals tomorrow.
Rentals by jewelry concerns and allied enterprises in the uptown jewelry center on West Forty-sixth and Forty-seventh Streets featured the business leasing reported yesterday.
LONDON, April 27 -- The shortage of a kinds of cosmetics and beauty accessories here since the fall of France has been one of the minor worries of British women.

Officials of the Cities Service Company have entered into an agreement with the Mexican Government for settlement of claims against Mexico arising out of the expropriation of oil properties owned by the Cities Service Oil Company in 1938, it was disclosed yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 27 -- American business men were warned today that war production in this country must exceed the $72,000,000,000 annual rate in order to insure complete victory over the Axis, because "there is no possibility of a compromise peace that will not mean defeat for the democracies."
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The Sperry Corporation has readjusted its present and scheduled war contracts, with a saving to the government of $100,000,000, Secretary Knox announced today.

Let me congratulate you on your timely editorial on the problem of rejected selectees. Only this week I underwent that most embarrassing experience of having a farewell party and accepting gifts from friends before leaving for the Army, only to return that same evening after being rejected by the Army doctors.

MONTREAL, Tuesday, April 28 -- Canada as a whole has voted "yes" in response to the government's request for release from past pledges regarding the manner of raising men for the armed forces, but the Province of Quebec has voted emphatically "no," according to incomplete though conclusive figures early today.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- In the absence from Washington of Chairman William H. Davis and most of the members of the War Labor Board, a staff conference was held this evening regarding the refusal of some employes of the Cornell-Dubilier Corporation to return to work.

RICHMOND, Va., April 27 (AP) -Secretary Perkins said tonight that the reconstruction of labor standards would be a major task of the post-war world and a Roman Catholic spokesman, on the same platform, envisioned an occupational labor-group system somewhat along the lines of that established by the American railroads -management and workers -- as the machinery for a sound social order.

The country is at war and is necessarily spending money at an unprecedented rate. In order to pay partially for the cost of the war it is essential that all shall contribute to the limit of their ability. To stave off inflation it is urged that excess income be siphoned off. Many proposals are heard for accomplishing these ends, such as compulsory savings, sales taxes, etc.

The food industry is too important to the war effort to be dealt with as an "orphan" and a coordinated food administration should be established immediately to handle its problems, Paul S. Willis, president Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, declared yesterday at the opening session of the National Delicatessen Show at the Hotel Commodore.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Joseph B. Eastman, Director of the Office of Defense Transportation, called upon the entire nation tonight to organize a war transportation program. This call was issued simultaneously to the Governors of every State and to the Mayors and other chief executives of every town and city with a population of 10,000 or more.

The often-repeated advice that flowers best express admiration took on new meaning yesterday as the annual narcissus show of the Horticultural Society of New York opened a two-day run with 20,000 blooms on display at the society's headquarters, 598 Madison Avenue.

Because of the necessity of using in their products substitute materials which cannot be claimed to be as good as the original, manufacturers of some nationally advertised goods are pondering the advisability of using their name or trade-marks on such merchandise.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., April 27 -- Danny Williams and Jim O'Connor, a home club team, won the opening pro-amateur best ball tournament of the New Jersey P.G.A. today, beating par by seven strokes with a score of 33, 32 -- 65 over the Crestmont links.

TRENTON, N.J., April 27 (AP) -New Jersey's fourth test blackout tomorrow night, covering 4,460 square miles and affecting a population of 728,000, probably will be the last staged with advance warning.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 27 (AP) -- Hartford, which knew Katharine Hepburn as a red-headed tomboy, finally saw her as a star tonight, for the first time in her years of stardom as one of the nation's leading stage personalities.

CHICAGO, April 27 -- First place in the tenth annual conspicuous achievement award contest conducted by the American Trade Association Executives went today to the Farm Equipment Institute of Chicago, it was announced at the meeting of the group.

Federal Judge Grover M. Moscowitz sentenced eighteen men and two corporations yesterday for taking part in a narcotics conspiracy. He characterized the case as "especially reprehensible" because some of the defendants were registered pharmacists and men in whom the public places its trust.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 27 -It was reported from Prague today that the death penalty has been decreed in the Protectorate of Bohemia-Moravia for farmers and peasants who fail to report their entire crop or to offer them for sale.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Highlights of President Roosevelt's message to Congress today were as follows:

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The 1,190-ton United States destroyer Sturtevant was sunk off the coast of Florida by an underwater explosion in the last twenty-four hours, the Navy Department revealed today. Most members of the crew reached port safely, the Navy said, and loss of life was "small."

LONDON, April 27 (U.P.) -- General Mikhailovitch's guerrillas are raiding Axis garrisons only 130 miles southeast of Belgrade, and negotiations are going on in Washington to provide lease-lend supplies for his front, Yugoslav sources reported tonight as they denied Axis radio reports of his capture.

Under the heading "Mr. Steinbeck's Unbridled Fantasy," the Belgian Information Center in New York has issued a bill of complaints against that part of "The Moon is Down" in which the Nazi commander relates his experiences in Belgium in the first World War.

Every thought and instinct of President Roosevelt should impel him to seek an effective program for guarding against wartime inflation. An uncontrolled upward spiral of prices and the cost of living could not only handicap our winning of the war but would bring in its aftermath economic injustices and social dislocations destructive of everything for which Mr. Roosevelt has stood.

BALTIMORE, April 27 (AP) -- Battle Jack, 13-to-5 second choice sporting the sky-blue colors of J.W.Y. Martin, raced to his second record-smashing victory in the Baltimore Spring Handicap today as Pimlico's meeting opened before 10,000 fans.

The Rev. Dr. Joseph F. Thorning, author, lecturer, Professor of Sociology and chairman of the department of social science at Mount St. Mary's College, Emmitsburg, Md., received the first gold medal to be awarded by Pi Alpha Sigma, Pan-American fraternity at St. John's University, Brooklyn, at a dinner last night at the Hotel St. Moritz.

As inevitable material shortages develop in a nation at war, one of the important national problems becomes that of salvage. A program to speed this necessary work has just been initiated by Bundles for America with the approval of the War Production Board. It will be a program both of collecting waste material and of restoring it to useful service through remodeling and reprocessing.

Carl Pilnick, City College champion, surprised Samuel Reshevsky last night by playing to a draw in ninety-two moves with the national titleholder at the United States Chess Federation tournament at the Manhattan C.C. Their match had been adjourned from the thirteenth round.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 27 -The immediate conversion of the nation to total war demands a conversion of men and their ideas, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, declares in the current issue of the Harvard Alumni Bulletin.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 27 -- Diplomats here were asking several questions today in regard to Reichsfuehrer Hitler's speech to the Reichstag yesterday, and they were inclined to answer them all in the affirmative.

PHILADELPHIA, April 27 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, translating into action its frequent warnings that there would be no slackening of "death-sentence" proceedings against holding companies because of the war, denied today a motion by the Central Illinois Public Service Company that its case be suspended until after peace.

As a wartime measure, the Pullman Company will not give refunds for tickets unless they are returned in advance of train time, George A. Kelly, vice president, said yesterday. The ruling is to insure maximum use of Pullman accommodations.
LONDON, April 27 (AP) -- The Air Ministry said in a communique today:

CHICAGO, April 27 -- Grain markets fluctuated in a most erratic manner today. Liquidation was in evidence early, wheat breaking around 1 1/4 cents a bushel, but short covering lifted the market about 2 cents later on the President's message.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 27 -- The war's influence on Soviet architecture was the subject of discussion at the tenth plenary session of the Architects Union just concluded in Moscow. Experiments with local material and a study of American and British small house construction are envisaged.

PHILADELPHIA, April 27 -- A plan for the dissolution and liquidation of Associated Utilities Corporation, a subsidiary holding company of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation, was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

One of the most extensive non-official blackout drills ever held in the East was conducted last night from 9 to 9:40 P.M. at the 130-acre Parkchester development in the Bronx. The participants included 30,500 persons who live in the fifty-one apartment buildings bounded by East Tremont, Castle Hill, White Plains and McGraw Avenues.

Supreme Court Justice Peter Schmuck signed an order yesterday, on the petition of former Magistrate Joseph Goldstein, directing Park Commissioner Robert Moses to show cause tomorrow why he should not be compelled to forbid the sale of the magazine Social Justice on all newsstands on property under the jurisdiction of the Park Department.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -The Supreme Court ruled today that the Federal Circuit Court at Philadelphia had acted incorrectly in setting aside findings of the Board of Tax Appeals against the government's contention that disputed sales of stocks in 1934 and 1935 by the late Mrs. Alice du Pont Artiz of Wilmington, Del., should result in a deficiency income tax assessment. Justice Douglas delivered the unanimous opinion.

The first Fall collection to come to town since the passing of the WPB regulations was offered for review yesterday afternoon. It was that of Howard Greer, well-known Hollywood designer. The clothes were not for immediate wear. They are models for wholesalers to view and to use as inspiration for their Fall collections.

One important asset that Level's return to Vichy gives the United Nations concerns the million or more French soldiers still prisoners in Germany. If Laval does not bring about their prompt release as proof of Nazi reciprocity, how ridiculous it would be to expect the French to show less disgust for the New Order than they have in the past!

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The dispute between the Defense Plant Corporation and the War Production Board which held up the delivery of free Treasury silver for use in war industry was settled Saturday, it was learned at the Treasury today.

NOW the big push in baseball is starting, the swing movement that, in time, will tell all. On the big league diamonds one-half will soon find out how the other half lives. In one league the East is invading the West and in the other the West is invading the East. It's a war of movement and the fans soon will see "reprisal with pursuit" and other such striking tactics.

While the Yankees marked time yesterday, awaiting today's invasion of the Stadium by the Browns, first of the Western teams to come to town, and the Giants and Dodgers were en route to St. Louis and Cincinnati, respectively, a one-time Yankee, probably the greatest of all, returned to this city.

The American Arbitration Association has awarded $3,925 to Miss Le Verne Busher, prominent ice skater, who uses the stage name of Le Verne, it was announced yesterday by Jonas Silverstone, national counsel of the American Guild of Variety Artists, of which union Le Verne is a member.

Natives in conquered Poland who work for Germany are obliged to wear a yellow patch with a purple letter "P" on their right breasts to mark their nationality and their inferior status. This follows the precedent of the Star of David by which Jews are compelled to identify themselves in Germany and Poland.
BERLIN, April 27 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique said today:

The registration of more than 13,000,000 Americans between the ages of 45 and 64, among them President Roosevelt, was completed yesterday by 6,500 local draft boards scattered throughout the United States. In New York City alone 322,878 men in this age group enrolled yesterday, bringing the city's three-day total to 911,630.

Opening an intensive program of religious education designed to reach the non-church members in the metropolitan area and southeastern New York State, Lieut. Gov. Charles Poletti said yesterday that it had never been contrary to Christian principles to fight for a cause.

VALLETTA, Malta, April 27 (Reuter) -- Many of Malta's most famous and historic buildings, including the palace of the Grand Masters, Auberges, or the Inn of Knights, and the Grand Building of Knights where Napoleon stayed after his capture of the island from the Knights of St. John in 1798, have been either destroyed or badly damaged in the Germans' non-stop air raids against the island.

Nineteen inspectors, investigators and former attaches of the United States Alcohol Unit went on trial yesterday before Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo in Brooklyn Federal Court. They were indicted on charges of conspiring to defraud the Federal Government by aiding in the alleged fraudulent withdrawal of denatured alcohol.
CINCINNATI, April 27 (AP) -- An eleventh-inning error by Shortstop Eddie Joost today helped the Cubs to their second overtime victory in the series of three games, as they defeated the Reds, 4 to 3.

Because of anticipated higher Federal taxes and in anticipation of larger freight and passenger revenues, the Pennsylvania Railroad in March revised its basis for tax accruals for 1942, making the revision retroactive to Jan. 1. The company reported tax accruals of $6,478,000, against $4,376,000 in February and $4,306,000 in January.
