WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The State of Georgia is a "person" under the Sherman Anti-Trust Act, and as such may sue for treble damages when allegedly injured by monopolistic practices, the Supreme Court held today in an 8-to-1 division.
CHUNGKING, China, April 27 (AP) -- The Chinese Government issued this communique today:

President Roosevelt's message to Congress raised yesterday's cotton market to midday gains of 22 to 31 points, or $1.10 to $1.55 a bale. Subsequent heavy liquidation in the near months soon neutralized the advances and sent active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange to final net losses of 6 to 11 points, or 30 to 55 cents a bale, from Saturday's closing prices.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The text of President Roosevelt's message to Congress on price controls follows:

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia ruled today that officers and directors of a corporation were not prohibited from buying its stock while a plan of reorganization was under consideration by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 5 per cent last week over the corresponding week of last year, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. In the preceding week the gain over 1941 was 12 per cent.

John L. Lewis and other officials of the United Mine Workers Union won yesterday on technical grounds a dismissal of a Supreme Court suit by the Chemical, Drug and Cosmetic Workers Union, Local 12,165, the only local of the union in this city, to set aside revocation of the local's charter by Mr. Lewis.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The manufacture of hairpins and bobbie pins was ordered cut in hail during the next ninety days in an order issued today by the War Production Board. At the same time, the decree placed restrictions on the length and thickness of hairpins and bobbie pins, so that the manufacture of heavy wire hairpins will be stopped altogether, and bobbie pins will have to be made of lighter wire.

CHICAGO, April 27 -- While the first-day registrations of buyers set a new mid-season market record at both the American Furniture Mart and the Merchandise Mart, a series of informal conferences between furniture manufacturers and government representatives set the stage for a more rapid conversion of the furniture industry to war work.

LONDON, April 27 -- Prices in most sections were firm today on the stock markets as dealers interpreted Herr Hitler's speech favorably. In the gilt-edge section the 3 1/2 per cent war loan opened at 104 5/8 ex the half-year interest and hardened later to 104 11/16.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- "A good start" has been made in making enemy-controlled industrial processes available to American manufacturers of vital war products, Leo T. Crowley, Alien Property Custodian, told the Senate Committee on Patents today.
I was interested in Josephine W. Frank's letter, "Plea for Braille Service," which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES of April 18.

Spices that are freshly ground, with heady aromatic scents and full piquant flavors preserved in closely covered glass jars, are making their first appearance this week in a city store. And they have met a ready response from shoppers.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The State Department is investigating reports of mistreatment of American nationals in Japanese-occupied territory, as at Manila and Hong Kong, Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today.

CINCINNATI, April 27 -- The Dodgers will open their first Western invasion of the year with Dolph Camilli back at first base, Arky Vaughan back at third and Whitlow Wyatt on the mound when the league leaders tackle the Reds tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -President Roosevelt sent a message to Congress outlining steps to combat inflation; nominated Rear Admiral Robert L. Ghormley to be a vice admiral, Cornelius Van H. Engert to be United States Minister to Afghanistan, and Maynard B. Barnes to be a consul general; registered under the Selective Service Act, and met with legislative leaders from the Capitol.

Because the imagination rejects catastrophes which it has not yet experienced, few of us will accept the reality of the air raid danger on this coast until it actually materializes. This is one of the difficulties civilian defense has had to face. But the submarine danger is already here.

LONDON, April 27 (U.P.) -- Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru has appealed to the United Nations to "acknowledge the independence of India" as a means of ending the bitterness that developed after the failure of Sir Stafford Cripps's British mission, it was revealed today.

A Pan American Airways Clipper, commanded by Captain Howard Maurice Cone, arrived at La Guardia Field yesterday afternoon carrying fifty-three passengers, 4,688 pounds of mail and twenty pounds of air express.

May 30 will mark the end of Gertrude Lawrence's longest engagement on Broadway. On that date her starring vehicle, "Lady in the Dark," the Moss Hart-Kurt Weill-Ira Gershwin musical, will terminate an honorable career at the Alvin after a run of 460 performances (not consecutive), which first began on Jan. 23 of last year.

Although there is every indication that Congress will refuse to enact, at this session at least, any legislation which will subject the income from State and municipal bonds to Federal income taxes, the market for those obligations continues sensitive, if not jittery, to each new mention of the Administration's stand for a removal of all tax immunity.

Forty-three faculty promotions at Columbia University were announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president. Five men were raised to the rank of professor: fourteen were made associate professors; twenty-three, asistant professors, and one was named visiting professor.

The four-story apartment house at 93-95 Van Wagenen Avenue, Jersey City, have been sold by the McKinley Square Realty Corporation of Manhattan to Frances D. Block. The structure contains twenty apartments and is on a plot 64 by 100 feet.

General Robert E. Wood, chairman of Sears, Roebuck Co., told stockholders at their annual meeting here yesterday that six principal lines of the company's business have been wiped out by war restrictions, resulting in a loss of $100,000,000 in prospective annual sales.

Thomas E. Dewey got a running start for the Republican nomination for Governor yesterday when the Queens Republican Executive Committee formally pledged its support to him at a meeting in the Richmond Hill Republican Club.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York announced yesterday admission of J.P. Morgan Co., Inc., to membership in the Federal Reserve System, effective immediately. The Morgan bank, with deposits of $637,020,357 and total assets of $693,491,887 on March 31, ranks as the eleventh largest bank in Wall Street.

The March of Time is preparing a two-part film report on India which is to be released nationally to theatres on May 8. The two subjects are "India in Crisis" and "India at War," each of which is a separate and complete story. "India in Crisis" is concerned with the political and social background of the Indian question.

Available newspaper comment on President Roosevelt's message to Congress yesterday indicates general support as far as it goes toward checking a rise in the cost of living, but some newspapers questioned its adequacy, expressing the view that a ceiling over wages also should be provided.

Expressing the belief that Governor Lehman would sign the "whole stream of bills" passed by the Legislature providing punishment for employment discrimination against racial or religious minorities in this State, Rabbi J.X. Cohen, chairman of the economic discrimination committee of the American Jewish Congress, declared yesterday that the work of those who have fought discrimination "is beginning to bear fruit."

An inspector, two lieutenants, a sergeant and thirty patrolmen appeared in the trial room at Brooklyn Police Headquarters yesterday on departmental charges growing out of the recent disclosures by John Harlan Amen.
The following are comments, as gathered by The Associated Press, on President Roosevelt's assertion that no American citizen now ought to have a net income, after taxes, of more than $25,000 a year:
The crystal chandeliers in the ballroom of the Harry Payne Whitney house at Fifth Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street shone yesterday on a scene different from any other they had ever illuminated.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The use in court of information obtained through listening devices was greatly broadened today by two 5-to-3 Supreme Court rulings each regarded by officials as strengthening the government in its fight against saboteurs, spies and other subversive elements.

TULSA, Okla., April 9-7 (U.P.) -Many were killed and injured at Pryor today when a shuttle train which carries war workers to the ordnance plant nearing completion near by was blown off the track by the tornado.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 753, as against 869 in the preceding week and 794 in the like period of last year, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Visiting buyers recorded yesterday numbered 273, which compared with 400 for last Tuesday.

The Jones Beach State Park, the Jacob Riis Park in Queens and the Wolfes Pond Park in Staten Island will be closed at 9 P.M. throughout the Summer to conserve electricity and comply with blackout and dim-out regulations, it was announced yesterday by Robert Moses, New York City Park Commissioner and chairman of the Long Island State Park Commission.

CHICAGO, April 28 -- While merchandising interest in the one-week furniture market today centered on the details of the price ceiling program, it did not prevent new attendance records being rolled up at both the American Furniture Mart and the Merchandise Mart, accompanied by a surprisingly heavy volume of orders.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 28 -- It would seem that the occupation authorities in Yugoslavia were too optimistic when they announced recently that "communism" had been wiped out, meaning the insurgents still resisting in mountains and forests.

VICHY, France, April 28 (AP) -- For the wounding of one Nazi soldier at Rouen the Germans ordered the execution today of five French hostages and served notice that fifteen more would be shot and 500 deported to Eastern Europe if those responsible were not handed over by May 5.

Chinese reinforcements are pouring into Northeast Burma in an eleventh-hour effort to meet a situation which has turned from critical to desperate. If they fail to stem the latest Japanese drive northward through the Shan States toward Lashio, all Burma may be lost.

The book printer's art as it has been practiced for almost a quarter of a century by the Grabhorn Press in San Francisco will become an American Institute of Graphic Arts exhibition, opening Monday evening at the galleries at 115 East Fortieth Street.

Wall Street's reaction to President Roosevelt's message has been, in the language of the brokers, "largely academic." The market showed no direct effects. Volume remained low. There was no sign of stocks being dumped.

After five separate trials that extended over eight years, probably setting a record in this State for continued prosecution on the same indictment, two men were convicted in Kings County Court yesterday on a charge of first-degree arson.

Five thousand soldiers from the twelve metropolitan regiments of the New York Guard were mobilized at their armories last night and transported in a fleet of fifty buses and 200 taxicabs to 100 strategic points throughout the city in an emergency test of their readiness to deal with concerted citywide sabotage by enemy agents and fifth columnists.

With a 1909 Buick waiting in Vanderbilt Avenue, William C. Durant, founder of the General Motors Corporation in 1908, told ninety members of Automobile Old Timers, Inc., in the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday that the banking firm of J.P. Morgan Co. had sought in the same year to form the first automobile combine.

LONDON, April 28 -- More than 5,000 Japanese have knifed through the northern Shan States in the direction of the Lashio terminus of the Burma Road. The invaders are reported to have re-entered Taunggyi, some 110 miles southeast of Mandalay, which was captured by the Chinese under United States Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell with heavy losses four days ago.

BOSTON, April 28 (AP) -- Hal White, rookie Detroit right-hander, who registered shut-out victories in his first two starts, was knocked out of the box today as the Red Sox beat the Tigers, 6 to 1, in their series opener.
LONDON, April 28 -- Norwich, with its vestiges of Roman and Norman culture, was selected last night by the Germans for their retaliation for British raids on German cities.
CINCINNATI, April 28 -- Leo Durocher's Dodgers won their fourth straight game today by beating the Reds, 7 -- 3, but lost the services of their ace pitcher, Whit Wyatt, for an indefinite period.

Although the OPA order freezing rents for two-thirds of the nation's families will not bring about many downward adjustments in the prices of living quarters here, it will have the happy effect of removing from the minds of tenants the fear that they might become the victims of the upward spiral of rents that had disturbed conditions in many parts of the country.

In 1852 a few public-spirited citizens of New York established a hospital amid the cabbage-patches of Twenty-eighth Street in a small four-story building. That hospital now occupies eighteen buildings and cares for about 46,000 patients in all departments. Its name is Mount Sinai, and it is now celebrating its ninetieth birthday.

FORT WORTH, Texas, April 28 -- Responsibility for the success of the price control plan of the government was put directly on the shoulders of the women of America by Dan A. West, director of the consumer division of the Office of Price Administration, speaking tonight before the annual convention of the General Federation of Women's Clubs.

BERLIN, April 28 (From German broadcasts recorded by the United Press in New York) -- Reichsfuehrer Hitler has empowered his Nazi party district leaders to mobilize every man, woman and child in Germany and occupied territory for German war and food production, giving them unlimited authority to organize and carry out a vastly expanded labor program as they see fit, the official D.N.B. news agency revealed tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Maximum sale prices for bituminous coal at the mines or preparation points were established today by Leon Henderson, Price Controller, at figures based on those of the Oct. 1-15 period, plus some of the increased production costs which the industry has incurred since then.

CHUNGKING, China, April 28 -- A little group of sixty-nine Britons attached to the Chinese convoy of the Friends Ambulance Unit [Quakers] in Burma is rendering yeoman service in front-line activities, it was revealed today.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Suggestions to housekeepers to help them preserve irreplaceable metal articles was issued today by the Bureau of Home Economics of the Department of Agriculture. Drawn up by Lenore Slater, chief of the Household Equipment Section for the bureau, they are:

A banking group headed by Lehman Brothers was the successful bidder yesterday for an issue of $3,776,000 city of Boston funding and relief bonds, receiving the award on a bid of 100.289 for the bonds as 1 3/4s. Dated May 15, 1942, and maturing serially from May 15, 1943 to 1952, the bonds were immediately reoffered to the public at prices to yield from 0.50 to 1.75 per cent, according to maturity.
ST. LOUIS, April 28 -- Mel Ott and his Giants had the eminent satisfaction today of putting their former colleague, Harry Gumbert, to rout. But It didn't quite win them the ball game.

Your editorial "Uncontrolled Buses," in THE TIMES of April 25, emphasizes that they need not be uncontrollable buses. The Court of Appeals has ruled that the Police Commissioner is without power to exclude interstate buses from certain areas of Manhattan.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- In announcing the General Maximum Price Regulation to the American people today, Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, made the following statement:

British designers presented an advance showing of Fall fashions at the Hotel Pierre yesterday. Features included generous flaps on double patch pockets of warm wool, sports jackets of extra fullness and a bounty of plaited skirts. The bureau of fashion trends, which offered this presentation for the benefit of Bundles for Britain, explained, however, that these clothes had been shipped from England before the WPB yardage restrictions went into effect.
The recent American air raid against Japan probably was the first of many bombings to which metropolitan Japan will be subjected before this war is ended.

With many uniformed soldier-relatives in the crowded galleries, cadets of the Knickerbocker Greys held their annual Spring drill yesterday afternoon in the drill shed of the Seventh Regiment Armory, at Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Rationing of gasoline for passenger-car owners in the Eastern States after May 15 will be according to occupation and distance traveled to and from work, according to a description of the ration cards released today by the Office of Price Administration.

Rocco Buscetto, a young New London grocer, married there Saturday and in New York on his wedding trip, was found dead yesterday morning in a grease pit in a gasoline station at the northeast corner of Fifty-seventh Street and Eleventh Avenue.

Pressed by public opinion to reduce teaching staffs to conform with a fall in pupil registration which has been in progress for more than ten years, the Board of Education has resorted to various stratagems to avoid actual dismissal of experienced teachers.

The controversy over ceiling prices for farm products resulted yesterday in the cotton market selling at new low levels for the movement. On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures contracts closed at net losses of 5 to 16 points.

Shipments of the United Aircraft Corporation in the first quarter of 1942 were in excess of $110,000,000, or better than double the same period of 1941, Eugene E. Wilson, president, said at the annual meeting at East Hartford, Conn., yesterday.

Since Emil Schram first mentioned it the proposal to create a better market for seats on the New York Stock Exchange has undergone some changes. The original idea was to allow a member to own more than one seat and to permit corporations which were planning to become firms to buy seats in anticipation of that move.
The Victory Book Campaign to gather books for our men in service is drawing to a close. Many people have given generously, but still more books are needed.

Lieut. Col. Sam F. Seeley, Executive Officer of the Medical Division of the Procurement and Assignment Service in Washington, told the 136th meeting of the Medical Society of the State of New York at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday that because of an urgent need for 16,000 more physicians by the Army before the end of this year, the age limit for active service by physicians had just been raised from 45 to 55 years.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 28 -- Peter B. Putnam of Hartford, Conn., blind Princeton University junior, has been elected president of the Triangle Club, 53-year-old campus dramatic group, it was announced today by Mark Lawrence, class of '42, of Washington, D.C., retiring head. G. Schofield Shapleigh, '43, of St. Louis, will be vice president and George N. Hazlehurst, '44, of Spotswood, N.J., secretary, the first sophomore ever elected to that post.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Areas housing more than 76,000,000 persons were designated by the Office of Price Administration today as defense rental areas where rents must be stabilized in accordance with Federal recommendations.

Of the very few middle-aged men who refused to sign up in the selective service registration last week-end, only one was under arrest here yesterday, but all were under investigation. The one man taken into custody was Julius Eichel, an opponent of war and "regimentation," who obtained citizenship many years ago through naturalization of his father.

The retirement of nineteen members of the Columbia University staff, including James C. Egbert, Director of University Extension; Daniel Gregory Mason, MacDowell Professor of Music; W. Benjamin Fite, Davies Professor of Mathematics, and Robert S. Woodworth, Professor of Psychology, was announced yesterday by the trustees of the university.

After a temporary decline, the incidence of whooping cough among New York children has resumed its upward movement, noticed generally for the year so far, it was reported yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner. There were 270 new cases of the disease last week, compared with 225 the week before.

THAT'S how important the Dodgers have become; there's a play written around them now. It is scheduled to hit Broadway tonight. In the "Advance Theatrical Guide," edited by the esteemed Mr. Samuel Zolotow, there was notice to the effect that it "deals with a pitcher for the Brooklyn Dodgers and a female fortune-teller in whom he has implicit trust."

NEWARK, N.J., April 28 -- Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, aided by the local police, raided tonight the homes of forty-five Japanese aliens in points throughout the State and took into custody an unrevealed number of persons.

James T. Soby of New York and Farmington, Conn., has been elected a trustee of the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, it was announced yesterday by Stephen C. Clark, chairman of the board of trustees of the museum.

Our fancy, from the time when we were first permitted to come to the table and partake of grownup meals, has vacillated between two favorite flavors -- chocolate and coffee. One morning earlier this week, however, we reached what seemed -- at the moment -- to be a final choice in this momentous matter.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 28 -- President Roosevelt will likely have a hard time trying to get the United States to accept a new name for this war. By and large most of the country is apparently satisfied to go on calling it the "Second World War," or "World War II."

The two-family house on a plot 40 by 100 feet at 1624 Fifty-third Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Title Guarantee Trust Company, as substituted trustee, to Bernard Freundlich. Title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.
The Shell Union Oil Corporation and the Phillips Petroleum Company reported yesterday for the first quarter of this year earnings in excess of the same period last year.

All subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation shipped 5,136,418 net tons of finished steel products in the first quarter, a record for the period, with more than 97 per cent of March shipments under A-10 ratings or better, Irving S. Olds, chairman of the corporation, said yesterday after the directors' quarterly dividend meeting.

Assistance given to the Army Air Corps in effecting negotiated contracts for parachute textiles, such as canopy cloths, shroud lines, tape and thread, both of silk and nylon, was an outstanding feature of the work of the National Federation of Textiles in the year just closed, Irene Blunt, secretary, reported at the federation's sixty-ninth annual meeting at federation headquarters, 15 West Thirty-seventh Street, yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Sharp protests against the Office of Price Administration's action in making March the governing period in fixing both retail and wholesale prices under today's universal price ceiling order will be registered this week by independent retail grocers, spokesmen indicated tonight.

In his address last night the President expressed for the first time publicly his concern lest the new Government of France "seek to force the brave French people to submission to Nazi despotism." We may be sure that ways will be found to bring his words to the ears of the French people, and that the warning he has given will not make it easier for Pierre Laval to betray the interests of his country.
Harry Jeffra halted the rise of Frankie Rubino, Brooklyn featherweight, with a clear-cut eight-round decision in the feature bout last night at the Broadway Arena.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Prices of every major item affecting living costs were ordered frozen today by the Office of Price Administration.

PHILADELPHIA, April 28 (AP) -- The Indians notched their ninth consecutive victory today and gained undisputed possession of first place in the American League with a 6-to-4 victory over the Athletics.
A quarterly dividend of 40 cents a common share was voted by the Jewel Tea Company, Inc., or 20 cents less than the previous quarterly rate.

Blyth Co., Inc., as head of a nation-wide banking group which earlier this month offered $17,500,000 city of Cleveland, Ohio, Transportation System revenue bonds, announced that they had made payment yesterday to the city of the proceeds of the loan and received delivery of the bonds.

A bemedaled youth in uniform, who in a USO broadcast over WNYC last week boasted of his prowess at Pearl Harbor and the Philippines, told of his friendship for General MacArthur and of a thrilling escape from Bataan to New Zealand, was revealed last night as an Army private from Brooklyn who deserted from a camp in the South on Feb. 12.

MEXICO CITY, April 28 -- It is expected that about ten of Mexico's leading Germans, probably with their families, will be sent to the United States in time to return to Germany with the Nazi diplomats held at White Sulphur Springs, Va., aboard the Swedish liner Drottningholm, leaving New York about May 5.

Indications that frugal American housewives intend to turn to their sewing baskets to dress up their homes for the duration were evidenced when 300 women appeared yesterday for a home decoration clinic to master the art of making slip covers.

The stock market, after its initial show of calm over the President's anti-inflation program, was thrown off balance yesterday by selling which cropped out in some of the key issues. Prices were returned to new lows since early in 1933, and although the general losses were not of major proportions, some of the trading favorites suffered severe inroads.

As her contribution to national morale and the fund-raising campaign of the United Service Organizations, Kate Smith yesterday signed a one-dollar contract with Columbia Pictures to make a series of musical shorts under the general title "America Sings With Kate Smith."

At 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon a reception was held in the ground-floor galleries of Holland House, 10 Rockefeller Plaza, to mark the opening of an exhibition of drawings by Hendrik Willem van Loon. The drawings were made for a new edition of "The Praise of Folly," by Desiderius Erasmus, published for the Classics Club by Walter J. Black of New York.

Newsprint manufacturers, who had been seeking higher prices to compensate for increased operating costs, were shocked yesterday when the Office of Price Administration issued an order fixing newsprint prices at the level of Oct. 1-15, 1941, which was the same price as prevailed on April 1, 1938, or $50 a ton for the majority of producers.

A 43-yea-olt mother, Mrs. Bess '-Kuttner, was elected to menberol ship in Phi Beta Kappa, national' honmay schblasfiC sdciey, alongi with thirty-three other sel0rs of1 the New York University Wash- ington Square College of Arts and! Sciences, Dean Charles nxwelli fcConn announced yesterday.
What does the order -- the shutting down on the manufacture of fishing tackle after May 31 -- mean?

WASHINGTON, April 28 (U.P.) -- The Office of Price Administration fixed maximum prices tonight for gasoline and other motor fuels sold at service stations amid indications that the gasoline curtailment, now confined principally to the East Coast, soon may affect other areas.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Senators dealt the White Sox their fifth straight defeat today, 4 -- 3, as Buck Newsom registered his second victory of the season, permitting nine hits.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Claude R. Wickard, Secretary of Agriculture, predicted today that the farmers of the country would give President Roosevelt's anti-inflation program, including that part which would lower their price allowances from 110 per cent to 100 per cent of parity, their full support.

New York City's neon aurora and skyscraper diadem were dimmed for the war's duration after sundown yesterday. Along with the rest of the Eastern seaboard the City of Light's nocturnal display was reduced by Army order to dispel sky glow that has brought our ships far at sea into sharp silhouette in Axis gunsights.

By the Dominion-wide plebiscite held on Monday Canada, like the United States, is now free to draft her able-bodied male citizens for military service anywhere in the world. Legally the government of Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King has had this power whenever it wished to use it.

Retailers, manufacturers and wholesalers began preparations yesterday to write a new page in American business history in the controlled economy to be established by the nation's first over-all price ceiling covering millions of merchandise items.
LONDON, April 28 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued the following communique today:

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 28 -- In another heavy raid on the Darwin airdrome at noon yesterday, the second raid in three days and the fifteenth since Feb. 19, the Japanese lost three bombers and four fighters, the United Nations Headquarters said today.

Criticism of the British Government's policy in Palestine for its "appeasement" of the Arabs and refusal to permit creation of a Jewish army, and belief that victory by the United Nations would mean a "new day" for Jews throughout the world, were voiced yesterday by speakers at the annual donor luncheon of the women's division of the American Jewish Congress.
The east side of the midtown section figured in the bulk of the apartment rentals reported yesterday by brokers. A number of the leases called for space in buildings in Park and Fifth Avenues.

OTTAWA, April 28 -- Pierre Dupuy, Canadian Minister to France, has been called home for consultation. Pending his report, no decision has been reached regarding the continued presence in Canada of a French Minister with his staff and consular officers at Montreal and Quebec representing the Vichy government, Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King informed the House of Commons this afternoon.

LONDON, April 28 (AP) -- The Berlin radio broadcast tonight that a heavy Russian attack, supported by armored trains and tanks, had broken the German lines at one point northeast of Orel, some 200 miles south of Moscow. The announcer added that the "situation later was restored."

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Office of Price Administration will wage its extended battle for a stabilized cost of living through a new set-up headed by the Retail Trade and Services Division, working through an estimated 10,000 or more local Wartime Price and Rationing Boards, Leon Henderson told his press conference this morning.

Dr. Carl Comstock, 28 years old, house physician at Bellevue Hospital, was taken into custody by the State Police late yesterday at the request of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan in connection with an alleged assault upon Dr. Morris Miller, 26-year-old junior interne at Bellevue, who is reported in critical condition at the hospital, suffering from cerebral hemorrhages.

Operating within the framework of the patent laws, our major industries have built up a monopolistic system that is effectively throttling the pioneer manufacturer. The success of this system has been greatly accelerated by the Securities and Exchange Commission, acting under the Securities Act, which casts a shadow of doubt and even a presumption of fraud upon new and speculative enterprise.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 28 (U.P.) -- Reports of heavy German losses and removal of Nazi Gen eral Engelbrecht from command of the Svir River sector were believed by neural observers today to indicate important decisions by Adolf Hitler in connection with the Finnish front.
JOHNSTOWN, Pa., April 28 -- A strike of 700 C.I.O. workers in the coke oven department tonight threatened curtailment of war production at the Cambria plant of the Bethlehem Steel Company.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 28 -- General Henri Honore Giraud, hero of two wars and twice escaped from captivity, has been in France for some days. It is understood that he has been in Vichy, has seen Marshal Henri Philippe Petain and has told him things -- as one soldier to another.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 28 -- One person was killed and at least ten others were injured when an explosion in a small chemical plant rocked a mile-square area near the business district here late this afternoon. The blast occurred at 5:35 P.M. in the store-front premises of a two-story brick building occupied by the Beacon Chemical Company at 192 French Street.
MOSCOW, April 28 (From Russian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau communique said today:

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 28 -- A chemical analysis of a blood specimen supported today earlier charges that Louis A. Vierbuchen, veteran Hudson Manhattan Railroad motorman, was under the influence of liquor when operating the six-car New York-bound tube train that was derailed and wrecked Sunday night at the Exchange Place station here, causing the death of five passengers and the injury of 222 others.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, April 29 -- Russian forces on the southern front from Kharkov to Bryansk appear to have begun the first stages of their Spring offensive, according to reports from Moscow received here this morning.

In the opinion of Joseph P. Lash, 32-year-old leader of youth movements and friend of Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt, his induction into the Army yesterday definitely put an end to the activities that brought him considerable publicity in the past and, on one occasion, questioning by the Dies committee because of his left-wing sympathies.

JERSEY CITY, April 28 (AP) -- The Jersey City Giants and the Rochester Red Wings battled to a 3-3 deadlock in the final contest of a four-game series today when the tussle was called at the end of nine innings to allow both teams to catch a train.

LONDON, April 28 -- British submarines have inflicted further losses on enemy supply ships operating in the Mediterranean by sinking a large, heavily laden supply ship as well as a large schooner and an enemy minesweeper, the Admiralty announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- President Roosevelt made a radio address to the nation, personally awarded the Distinguished Service Medal to Vice Admiral Wilson Brown for service in leading a naval task force in the Pacific, held a press conference and conferred with Ambassador Winant.

Thomas J. Curran, Republican leader of New York County, declared last night that "constructive and unrelenting criticism" of inefficiency and favoritism was responsible for the most important gains to date in the organization of the United States for war and he called upon the Republican party to continue this policy.

No professional writer for the newspapers can expect to go on earning his bread day after day without falling, every now and then, into conduct which is a disgrace to American journalism, which marks the writer as grossly ignorant, and which constitutes an unwarranted and vicious attack on a respectable and hard-working body of citizens or public servants.
WITH BRITISH ARMY IN BURMA, April 19 (Delayed) -- The British Imperial Army in Burma is in retreat, but it is a glorious retreat, marked by almost superhuman courage and endurance.

A three-act comedy by William Roos about a screwball pitcher for the Brooklyn Dodgers, entitled "The Life of Reilly," will open tonight at the Broadhurst Theatre, with Glenda Farrell in the leading role. Others in the cast include Peter Hobbs, Charita Bauer, Loring Smith, Polly Walters, Len Hollister, John Shellie, George Mathews, John Call, Norman Tokar and Howard Smith.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Department of Commerce today estimated that the total value of new construction this year may reach $12,000,000,000 or nearly $500,000,000 more than last year.

Still undefeated after fourteen rounds, Samuel Reshevsky of Boston, the defending champion, will enter the final round of the United States Chess Federation championship tournament tonight half a point ahead of Isaac I. Kashdan, with whom he drew last night at the Hotel Astor after thirty-two moves.
MADISON, N.J., April 28 -- Plans for a practice blackout tonight in this Morris County community of 8,000 were so complete that even the President's radio speech was blacked out from 10 to 10:15 P.M.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- President Roosevelt gave a pledge tonight of offensive action by the United States in Europe and the Far East and called upon the American public to help win the war by sacrifices on the home front as its fighting men are beginning to turn the tide in battle.

The Public Health Relations Committee of the New York Academy of Medicine, commending both the diagnostic and the treatment clinic for psychiatric cases of the children's division of the Domestic Relations Court as "important and necessary," recommended in a report made public yesterday that the treatment clinic be financed out of city funds and that it have a larger staff, including more and better qualified probation officers.
CHICAGO, April 28 (AP) -- The Braves ganged up on Big Bill Lee for four runs in the fourth inning today to defeat the Cubs, 6 to 3, on a total of 12 hits against two of three pitchers.

A system of comprehensive food rationing is "as inevitable as tomorrow," Edwin P. Geauque, executive director, National Grocers Institute, asserted at the second day's session of the National Delicatessen Show at the Hotel Commodore yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- When the American housewife walks into her corner grocery to do her marketing on May 18 she will find about three-quarters of the food items on her shopping list will be sold to her under a sign reading "Ceiling Price $ --- ."

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Relations between the United Mine Workers and the Congress of Industrial Organizations moved swiftly toward a crisis today when it became known that Ora Gasaway, president of District 50 of the miners' union, had asked President John L. Lewis for an emergency meeting of the union's executive board.
A Pan American Airways clipper arrived yesterday at La Guardia Field carrying thirty-five survivors of two recent Atlantic torpedoings. The flying boat was commanded by Captain Marius Lodeesen.

About one-quarter of racing's planned contribution of $2,000,000 to the war effort was in sight yesterday, following an announcement at Jamaica by representatives of the five New York State racing associations that each would give the first $100,000 of its profits this year before paying any dividends.

The Browns, strangely enough, found the Yankees just what the doctor ordered yesterday for curing their lingering nine-game losing streak. The St. Louis combination, opening the Western clubs' first invasion of the Stadium this season, jolted the Bombers, 3 to 1, and nudged them into second place, a game behind the Indians, with whom the world champions had been tied for the lead.

Consolidated net income of the Cities Service Company system for the first quarter of this year totaled $3,888,252, W. Alton Jones, president, told shareholders at their annual meeting yesterday in Dover, Del. This compares with a net of $3,231,602 in the March quarter of 1941.

CHICAGO, April 28 -- Describing the National League of Women Voters as "an indispensable sentry post," Bernard DeVoto, author and editor, told delegates to the organization's convention here tonight that "Main Street is in your keeping," that the home town "is where you must wage your war."

At every appearance of a manikin at the Ritz Carlton Oval Room fashion show yesterday noon one was reminded of the iridescence of fresh soap suds. It was a cotton showing that Franklin Simon put on and every dress could be put into a tub.

LONDON, Wednesday, April 29 (AP) -- President Roosevelt's disclosure that United States warships and troops now were in the Middle East area attracted the attention of Britons here today, but there was no immediate official comment.

LONDON, April 28 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, Lord Privy Seal, reported to the House of Commons today on his recent mission to India. Without making any revelations he impressed the House sufficiently to eliminate almost entirely criticism of the government as well as of himself.
The Manhattan realty trading reported yesterday was mixed, with loft buildings, apartments and private dwellings passing into new hands.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- William H. Davis, chairman of the National War Labor Board, informed the International Longshoremen's Association and the American Sugar Refining Company today that the board would not consider the merits of their dispute unless striking employes returned to work at once in accordance with an agreement to arbitrate.

Presiding Bishop Henry St. George Tucker told the National Council of the Episcopal Church at the opening session of the quarterly meeting yesterday at 281 Fourth Avenue that the church's gift of $300,000 to the Church of England had served as a stimulus to the British church effort.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- This is "The General Maximum Price Regulation" as issued by the Office of Price Administration.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 28 -- Censorship for all dispatches of foreign correspondents working in the Reich will be introduced forthwith, according to reports from Berlin tonight. It is thought that censorship will go into effect before the end of this week.

The advertising agency of Weiss Geller New York, Inc., plans soon to transfer its headquarters to the building at 400 Madison Avenue, where a suite of eleven offices has been leased through Pease Elliman, Inc., brokers, and Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton, Inc.

TRENTON, April 28 -- Quartermaster General Stephen H. Barlow had his "day in court" today in the New Jersey Senate's investigation of food costs at the State-owned Sea Girt cottage occupied last Summer by Governor Charles Edison.

Grace Castagnetta, young New York pianist, who has successively revealed her talents as a prodigy, a serious pianist, a composer and a co-author of books with Hendrik van Loon, last night at her recital i rat Town Hall revealed still another talent -- that of an improviser.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Industrial statistics compiled by the Department of Labor, at the request of Senator Harry F. Byrd, reveal that at the end of February, 1942, the average of weekly hours devoted to production of materiel was not anywhere near the level of a total war requirement, and that the average of hours spent in non-materiel production was even less impressive.

Three leading creative milliners, Lilly Dacha, Sally Victor and John Frederics, have agreed to cooperate in launching style trends for the Fall season, it was announced here yesterday by the Millinery Stabilization Commission, Inc. These three milliners, under the name of Millinery Fashion Authority, Inc., will present a trade showing beginning June 15 which will be made available to a limited number of manufacturers, who will be given copying rights.

LAS CRUCES, N.M., April 28 -- A friendly alkaline microbe discovered in beer, which kills nearly all other kinds of germs in the human body, was reported today to the Southwestern Division of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 28 -- A long-legged galloper out of Texas captured the Derby Trial Stakes at Churchill Downs today, but a little matter of seven pounds had every one up in the air about what the race proved for Saturday's Kentucky Derby.

LONDON, April 28 -- The stock markets today were dull with most prices, were changed, lower. Home rails were quieter on profit-taking. In the industrial section the stores were dull, United Molasses easier at 28 3/4 and and Cunard 3d lower. The brewery shares were in demand.

This is the story of two Irishmen and an antique chair. The two Irishmen were arraigned last night in Brooklyn-Queens Night Court, charged with having attempted to use high-pressure salesmanship to sell the "antique" chair to William Nicolay, 68-year-old proprietor of an antique shop at 204 Flatbush Avenue.

LONDON, April 28 -- The British aircraft carrier Illustrious has now arrived back in a Northern British port after having undergone repairs at the United States Navy Yard at Norfolk. The Illustrious was damaged in a terrific dive-bombing attack by German and Italian planes in the Mediterranean.
BERLIN, April 28 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique said today:

MELBOURNE, April 28 (U.P.) -- American and Australian fighter planes shot down seven of twenty-six Japanese aircraft raiding Darwin yesterday in the longest and most spectacular air battle ever fought over the Australian port and sent the rest fleeing in beaten, ragged squadrons, it was announced officially today.

VICHY, April 28 (UP) -- Reports from Paris tonight said that Andre Bloch, 46, president of the Society of French Poets and prominent in theatrical circles, had been arrested for nonobservance of the anti-Jewish laws.
Hitler's latest speech makes it evident that there is a great deal of criticism going on in Nazi Germany. Also that the judges apparently do not always convict the accused.

PHILADELPHIA, April 28 -- Sharply reflecting the listlessness which has pervaded the whole financial field since the outbreak of war, the Securities and Exchange Commission made public today a recapitulation showing securities amounting to $366,854,000 were effectively registered in the first quarter of 1942, compared with a quarterly average of $696,788,000 for 1941.

The President's "anti-inflation program" as announced to Congress, the official explanation of the price ceilings that the Government has fixed, and the President's radio address last night to explain his plan, combine to form an outlook that is profoundly disheartening.

The estimated earnings of the Texas Company, excluding European subsidiaries, in the first quarter of this year were $7,900,000 after charges, depreciation, depletion, amortization, provision for Federal income and excess profits taxes at the 1941 rate and a charge of $5,000,000, for a reserve against possible additional taxes and other contingencies because of the war, W.S.S. Rodgers, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.

GLEN COVE, L.I., April 28 -- Plans for the sale of part of the 2,000-acre Charles Pratt estate, located in one of the most exclusive residential districts on the North Shore of Long Island, to a manufacturing company engaged in the production of boxes and crates for war use were revealed here tonight at a meeting of the Glen Cove City Council.

Combined net earnings of the Commercial Investment Trust Corporation for the quarter ended on March 31, according to unaudited figures disclosed to stockholders yesterday by Arthur O. Dietz, president, amounted to $3,590,880, compared with $4,241,641 for the first three months last year.

Your editorial "Rejected," in THE TIMES of April 18, certainly touches one of the sore spots in our efforts to raise an army for the "War of Survival." THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine on the Sunday fallowing mentioned that over 50 per cent of the men called for induction are rejected.

Speaking immediately after her husband had been heard on the radio, Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt avoided comment on his address last night but came out strongly for compulsory registration of women for war work.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Deliveries of newspapers will be restricted to one edition a day at any one point beginning May 15, an Office of Defense Transportation official said today in an informal explanation of the ODT's April 20 order to eliminate special trips and reduce local trucking mileage.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- To Vice Admiral Wilson Broom, commander of the Scouting Force in the Pacific, President Roosevelt today personally presented the Distinguished Service Medal.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, April 28 -- A dispatch to THE NEW YORK TIMES from Berne under yesterday's date, indicating the possibility of an early change in the Italian attitude toward the war as a result of King Victor Emmanuel's personal intervention, was prominently featured by the press here to-day and it awoke more interest and speculation than had been caused by any single news story for a long time.

PRYOR, Okla., April 28 -- Relief agencies reached out to help this tornado-wracked town back on its feet tonight. Nearly 100 dead and 150 to 300 wounded were left by yesterday's storm. Damage was estimated by Mayor Thomas J. Harrison at $1,000,000.

With May just around the corner, thoughts are likely to take a horticultural turn -- whether one's efforts extend to lily ponds and herbaceous border or simply to a modest window box. The art of grubbing is both pleasant and productive, but it presents a problem in cleanliness and beauty.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The necessity of buying war bonds and stamps out of current income rather than from cash reserves was urged on the American people today by President Roosevelt at his press conference, while Secretary Morgenthau stated in a letter to business men that workers must buy three times as many bonds as they are doing.

DOVER, Del., April 28 (AP) -- Formal protest against nonpayment of dividends on Cities Service Company preferred stock was registered at a stockholders' meeting today. James D. Cleland, a securities dealer in New York and a holder of all classes of Cities Service stock, declared there was a "mounting wave of dissatisfaction" among preferred shareholders because they have received no dividends -- except for a $3 payment last Aug. 1 -- since 1932.
Following is the text of President Roosevelt's broadcast last night as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 28 -- Warner Brothers today announced that Paul Lukas has been signed to repeat his stage role as Kurt Mueller in the screen version of Lillian Hellman's "Watch on the Rhine," which will go before the cameras June 1.

CHICAG0, April 28 -- Captain Edward V. Rickenbacker of New York, flying ace of the First World War and president of Eastern Air Lines, Inc., predicted before the Chamber of Commerce of the United States tonight that the United Nations' war against the Axis will last a minimum of five, and possibly ten, years, and cannot be won unless the nation gives up its "gimmie" complex.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Ways and Means committee will take a vote tomorrow on the excess profits rates in the new corporation tax bill, Representative Doughton, the chairman, announced tonight.

BATH, England, April 28 -- This perfect old Georgian city -- hitherto so far from the war and any war production activities that it was made a reception area for evacuees -- is struggling back to life again after two fierce blitzes Saturday and Sunday night.

A record price of $300,000 has been paid by Twentieth Century-Fox for the screen rights to the John Steinbeck drama "The Moon Is Down." This is the highest outright sale price on record, though the final purchase costs of other plays, which involved a percentage of the film's receipts, have bettered this mark.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Consideration of labor legislation was shunted aside for an indefinite period today by the Senate in response to the suggestion, in effect, in President Roosevelt's anti-inflation message that none be enacted.

LONDON, April 28 - One-armed Squadron Leader J.P.D. Maclachlan, who wears the Distinguished Flying Cross and who is fitted with a specially made arm and hand -- that can work the throttle and many other gadgets -- has got his first German since rejoining the Royal. Air Force.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture issued today its final report of the 1941 cotton crop, placing production at 10,744,000 bales of 500 pounds gross weight, compared with 12,566,000 bales in 1940.

The old Larchmont National Bank and Trust Company building, on the northeast corner of Larchmont Avenue and the Boston Post Road in Larchmont, Westchester, has been purchased by the Chelsea Fireproof Storage Warehouses, Inc., from the Director of the Currency of the United States in an all-cash transaction.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 28 -- Second-day Italian comment on Reichsfuehrer Hitler's speech is even more agitated than yesterday's. Despite "corrections" in the text published in the press in Italy, his pessimism appears to have hit home.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 28 -- Behind the six-hit pitching of Bob Anderson, Fordham's undefeated baseball team downed Princeton, 9 -- 4, extending its winning streak to nine games, on University Field today. It was the Tigers' fourth defeat in eight starts.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Disregarding assertions that the methods of the Dies Committee, are not only obstructing a unified war effort by the nation, but also interfering with the Justice Department's drive against Fifth Columnists, the House voted an additional $110,000 today to enable it to continue its investigation of "un-American" activities.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Office of Price Administration, in connection with its general price freezing order, issued today a separate list of ceilings on products requiring special price treatment. For the most part the maximum levels set are of an earlier date than March. The list, with those to whom it applies, the basic price level date and effective date, follows:

Dance Players opened its second week at the National Theatre last night with another novelty, its first presentation of Eugene Loring's "City Portrait" with music by Henry Brant and settings and costumes after Reginald Marsh.

James G. Blaine, chairman of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, joined Mayor La Guardia yesterday in announcing a new plan expected to add 150,000 volunteer defense workers to the 110,000 already recruited. Mr. Blaine said every large business house in the city as well as churches and labor unions would be asked to designate a recruiting officer for volunteers.

Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag signed yesterday an order directing Max Schott, president of the Climax Molybdenum Company, to deposit in a special account with the Guaranty Trust Company all money received by him since Dec. 31, 1938, from sales of Climax stock.

Maurice E. Rogalin, suspended former principal of New Utrecht High School in Brooklyn, was balked yesterday in his attempt to retire on pension when he failed to get a majority of the votes required in the teachers' retirement board.

LONDON, April 28 -- The government was defeated by one vote in the House of Lords today over those funny-looking gas bags that are beginning to be seen on top of automobiles and trucks, which are part of a rather cumbersome apparatus for running cars without gasoline.

Golden trumpet narcissi in colorful basket and suow-white blooms in elegant vases, in picturesque arrangements to add new beauties to the home, drew the attention of several thousand visitors yesterday at the second and final day showing of the nual narcissus show of the Horticultural Society 0f New Yorl
VICHY, France, April 28 -- French colonial administrators have gathered in Vichy again for one of their periodical conferences on colonial matters.
One passage in Hitler's speech on Sunday to the Reichstag has an interesting background. In it he said:

PITTSBURGH, April 28 (AP) -- Earl Naylor, a made-over outfielder, was assigned the thankless task of pitching for the Phils today, but his team-mates helped make his first-mound start a wry one as the Pirates romped to a 7-1 victory.

The Sandhogs Union, Local 147, won from Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook yesterday a ruling granting its plea for an injunction forbidding interference with the local and its members by Joseph V. Moreschi and the International Hod Carriers.

" SOLDIERS of different nations fight each other with a passion not their own; but when a people engage in civil war it is because some despise what the others hold sacred." And the struggle is cruel, merciless and terrible because men will fight with far more desperate fury over an idea than for territorial claims or national honor.
PHILADELPHIA, April 28 (AP) -- The Curtis Publishing Company announced today a dividend of 25 cents a share on the prior preferred stock, payable on July 1 to stockholders of record of June 5.

The Office of Facts and Figures issued yesterday a radio war guide containing suggestions to assist advertisers in reaching a proper understanding of the relative programming of factual war information and general program ideas. Serving as the coordinating agency, the office has met with information departments of the Government and set up a five-group ranking system for war information subjects, assigning priority rankings to specific topics.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 28 -- Federal agents, with the cooperation of police and sheriff's deputies, renewed their raids today on Japanese colonies throughout Northern California.

Although the announcement late on Monday by Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau that the Treasury would sell in the open market $4,000,000,000 in new securities during May and June, $2,000,000,000 each month, came as no great shock to the financial community generally, the rather abrupt realization of the extent to which the tempo of governmental expenditure has been stepped up brought about considerable selling and general weakness yesterday in the market for outstanding government securities.

Machinery for the rationing of sugar was set in motion yesterday as dealers, both wholesale and retail, industrial users and institutions began registering at 248 designated schools in New York City and receiving certificates entitling them to replenish their stock.

Seton Hall swamped the Brooklyn College nine, 24 -- 0, on the loser's diamond yesterday, achieving its fourth straight shutout in college competition as Southpaw Steve Nagy limited the Kingsmen to two hits, while fanning sixteen.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 28 -- The surest sign that Spring has arrived on the central front is the appearance of trucks laden with felt boots traveling eastward from the battle zones. These "valenky" deserve an honorable place in the gallery of war heroes and the United Nations owe a great debt to those who managed to provide the Red Amy's fighting men with them.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Responding to pleas that the nation's automobile dealers are in need of immediate relief, the House today passed and sent to the White House a bill which would authorize the RFC to buy or lend money on frozen stocks of all rationed articles.

Two exhibitions will open tomorrow at Wildenstein's, both installed in the large galleries on the fifth floor. These bring to public notice bronze portrait heads and small figures in bronze and terra cotta by the French sculptor, Guitou Knoop, and twenty-eight canvases by Johannes Schieffer, who came to this country some months ago as a refugee from France.

Plans for a surprise total blackout of the entire State of New Jersey some time in the near future were announced last night by Leonard Dreyfuss, State Civilian Defense Director, after a test blackout from 9:58 to 10:17 o'clock, in the western and southern counties of the State.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- This official explanation of the price ceilings order, presented in question and answer form, was issued tonight:
BOSTON, April 29 (AP) -- With only one batter to get by for a shut-out victory, Yank Terry passed two Tigers today to set the stage for a four-run rally and a 4-2 defeat for the Red Sox.

CINCINNATI, April 29 -- Bill McKechnie's Reds had a ball game almost wrapped up with a 2-1 lead and two out in the ninth inning today. At that point the Dodgers' recent invalid, Dolph Camilli, looked at one outside pitch from the veteran Ray Starr and then rifled the next one into the right center-field corner of the bleachers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 29 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has assigned Walter Pidgeon to the role of Witzel in the screen version of "White Cargo," which will go before the cameras next week with Hedy Lamarr as Tondeleyo. Leon Gordon, author of the play, has written a screen adaptation for producer Victor Saville.

LONDON, April 29 (UP) -- Russian dispatches said tonight that the Red Army, preparing to storm Kursk in an attempt to lay open the northern flank of the Axis, armies in the Ukraine, had reached the Sosna River above the city and was fighting to cross the Seim River to the south.

The rapidly expanding armed forces of the nation place a duty upon every civilian to give "generously, and now" to the United Service Organizations, which will be providing recreation for 4,000,000 men by the end of this year, speakers declared yesterday at the first birthday luncheon of the USO in the Hotel Biltmore.

LONDON, April 29 (UP) -- An army of 5,000 Greek guerrillas, roaming along the Bulgarian border, has opened a new Balkan front against Axis occupation troops, killing several hundred Germans in its first foray, the Greek Government in Exile disclosed tonight.

LONDON, April 29 -- The vanguard of the Japanese troops slicing through Northern Burma this morning reached New Lashio, a suburb of Lashio, occupying the town of Nanmang, Chungking reported in tonight's communique. [Nanmang does not appear on available maps; the place referred to possibly is Nanlan, about twenty-five miles southeast of Hsipaw.]

Facilities for handling thousands of questions from manufacturers wholesalers and retailers who shortly must begin to operate under frozen prices were being set up here yesterday by the Office of Price Administration. Although 1,500 telephone calls and several hundred in-person inquiries were handled yesterday, officials said they expected a much heavier deluge today.

A last-minute postponement has set back the premiere of "Harlem Cavalcade" from tonight until tomorrow evening at the Ritz Theatre. This marks the second time the opening of Ed Sullivan's all-Negro show, backed by the Shuberts, has been deferred.

Dim-out regulations threatened yesterday to halt night baseball and other outdoor nocturnal sports. Police Commissioner Valentine bluntly interpreted dim-out orders as putting an end to these pastimes. Army authorities, on the other hand, seemed uncertain.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The War Production Board received greater authority over electric power today under an agreement approved by President Roosevelt determining the extent of the influence of the WPB and the Federal Power Commission over the field during the war.
CAIRO, April 29 (AP) -- The British General Headquarters' communique on the Libyan fighting said today:

Reflecting in part the increased passenger and cargo traffic stimulated by the accelerated war effort, American Airlines, Inc., reported yesterday a profit of $349,392 for the three months ended with March. The result, which is after providing for depreciation and obsolescence, interest and Federal taxes, compares with a profit of $71,059 shown in the corresponding quarter a year ago.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Reports broadcast by the Rome radio today of orders by Premier Mussolini for Fascist district leaders to be more severe in enforcing laws because of a deterioration on the home front are being scrutinized here to determine whether they have a tactical significance.

General Henri Honore Giraud, commander of the French Ninth Army, had been eating soup and cabbage in Saxony for two years, come May 15. He had been suddenly called upon to supersede General Corap and rally his army. He was making his way to the front in a light tank when the Germans got him.

Percy S. Straus and Jack I. Straus, with the officers of Macy's Twenty-Five Year Club, were hosts to thirty-eight new club members installed yesterday at a luncheon held in the store's executive offices. Seven members who have celebrated fifty years of service with the store were guests of honor.

ALLAHABAD, India, April 29 (UP) -- Mohandas K. Gandhi has started a battle royal in the Congress party working committee over a draft resolution by which he would commit the party to nonviolence against Japan and close the door to further negotiations with Great Britain.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 29 -- After two days completely free of ice following the break-up of the ice, the section of Europe's longest river, the Volga, that flows past the terrace of Kuibyshev is now chock full of jostling lumps of ice. But it is hoped that the first ship will leave here about May 7.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 29 -- Two trends are observable in Italy today regarding relations with France -- that of the Italian Foreign Office and that of the Vatican. Dispatches received here make the distinction clear.

CHICAGO, April 29 (AP) -- The Braves, aided by a homer, a double and two singles by Froilan Fernandez, rookie third baseman, overwhelmed the Cubs, 8 to 3, today to make it four in a row. Fernandez had four hits yesterday and extended his streak to eight.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., April 29 -- Professor George C. Smith, retired dean of New York Law School, was killed today by a freight train near his home here. He was 78 years old.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- A suggestion that President Roosevelt voluntarily reduce his salary to $25,000 a year and that Mrs. Roosevelt limit her net income to that figure was made today by Representative Springer, Republican, of Indiana.

Word has been received by the headquarters of the Maryknoll Fathers in Ossining, N.Y., that forty-five Maryknoll priests, brothers and nuns in Korea were safe. The message, which said that missionaries had been interned and were understood to reside on mission property, was obtained through the Holy See, whose delegate in Tokyo, Archbishop Paul Marella, made direct inquiry of the Japanese Government.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 (AP) -- The Indians stretched their winning streak to ten in a row today by coming from behind to beat the Athletics, 11 -- 6. The victory gave the first place Indians a one and a half game lead over the Tigers, who moved into second ahead of the Yankees.

STORLIEN, on the Swedish-Norwegian Border, April 29 Travelers from Trondheim, Norway, who crossed the border today, said that last night seventy-five heavy British bombers attacked the harbor around midnight and continued hammering the Nyhavna submarine base for several hours.

Although shipments by the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company in the first quarter of this year were $31,000,000 more than in the similar period last year, earnings after provision for Federal taxes were about $1,500,000 less than in the 1941 quarter.

After the force of near-month liquidation, prevalent in the market for more than a week, had been spent in the early morning, the cotton market turned upward yesterday on the strength of trade buying and covering by New Orleans interests.

TORONTO, April 29 (AP) -- The last-place Maple Leafs uncorked a spirited six-run ninth-inning rally to overcome a 9-to-4 deficit and gain a 10-to-9 victory over Jersey City today in the local opening of the International Baseball League campaign.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan, who appeared unexpectedly yesterday before Judge Saul S. Streit in General Sessions to demand that no bail be fixed for a refugee physician, accused of being the head of an "abortion ring" at 116 East Sixty-third Street, asserted that Supreme Court Justice Thomas C. Kadien Jr., a resident of Queens, had violated the code of criminal procedure the night before by accepting $5,000 bail for the physician.
The German Transocean Agency carried the following communique of the Finnish High, Command:

As the full impact of the new price ceiling orders hit yesterday, manufacturers were flooded with requests from retailers as to their interpretations and possible future action and the manufactures in turn descended on suppliers of raw materials to find out what they were going to do.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- President Roosevelt's seventh point in his anti-inflationary program to the effect that, besides discouraging credit and installment buying, the government should encourage the payment of debts, mortgages and other obligations, has caused some puzzlement in Administration and Congressional circles.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- Secretary of Commerce Jessie Jones announced tonight that Metals Reserve Company and the State Department had completed arrangements with the Mexican Government "which should result in a very substantial increase" in the production in Mexico of strategic and critical metals and minerals necessary to hemisphere defense.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 -- The Evening Bulletin said yesterday that while the Federal Government was preparing to ration gasoline in the Eastern States, it had been learned that in the Bradford-Oil City petroleum district of Western Pennsylvania refineries had filled every available tank, tub and vat to overflowing with motor fuel that could not be distributed.

When the Germans moved their pocket battleships from Brest and hid a large part of their fleet in Trondheim fjord they hoped to escape the constant bombing to which the French port was exposed. It was a vain hope. The British are now bombing Trondheim with heavier concentrations than they ever sent over Brest.

Independent food retailers, aroused over what they consider will be the disastrous effects of the price control order on their industry, are planning a series of protest meetings through their trade associations, it was learned yesterday.

A report on relief and rescue activities, conducted with the support of American Jews in Europe, Palestine and the Western Hemisphere for victims of nazism, was heard yesterday at a meeting in the Hotel Biltmore of the executive committee of the United Jewish Appeal, the single fund-raising organization for the Joint Distribution Committee, United Palestine Appeal and National Refugee Service.

LONDON, April 29 (AP) -- The Independent French News Agency, A.F.I., reported today without qualification that Germany had made three peace proposals to Britain within the last six weeks. The agency said the proposals were similar and that the first was made through Turkey, the second through Switzerland and the third through Sweden.

Midtown Manhattan, including the Times Square area, will have its first blackout from 9:30 to 9:50 o'clock tonight. The police estimated yesterday that 1,000,000 persons or more, including vast numbers of amusement seekers in the theatrical area, would probably experience the blackout, although the residents of the district number only 836,750.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 29 -- Dominick La Rose solved a predicament occasioned by the fourth selective service registration by surrendering yesterday as a man wanted in Cleveland, Ohio, for the fatal shooting of a business partner on Nov. 30, 1919.

The small manufacturer who can convert his plant to the manufacture of vital materials for the armed services and the Maritime Commission, as part of a vast "bits-and-pieces" program, is assured of financial accommodation in adequate amounts and at comparatively low interest rates, it was revealed yesterday in banking circles.

LONDON, Thursday, April 30 (AP) -- The arrival of United States fighter planes on Malta was the reason given in Berlin for the recent more deadly defense of that British base in the central Mediterranean, London morning newspapers reported from Stockholm early today.

Miss Marie Eichelberger of the State Department of Social Welfare, speaking yesterday afternoon at the opening of a three-day Lutheran welfare conference for the Atlantic region, emphasized a need to train children for the event of aid raids.

DETROIT, April 29 -- While 800 Michigan troops stood guard, the first tenants today were moved into the $1,000,000 Sojourner Truth Homes, the Federal housing project for Negroes which has been the subject of a five-month controversy.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Because time, machinery and transportation go into the making and marketing of wooden furniture, the Consumer Division of the Office of Price Administration today admonished housewives to care for their wooden chairs, beds and tables as though they were made of irreplaceable aluminum.

CHICAGO, April 29 -- While business leaders were reporting to the Chamber of Commerce of the United States today that President Roosevelt's war production goals were being achieved, fiscal experts were telling members at another chamber session that parts of the President's anti-inflation program might impede defense output.
The sale of an apartment property comprising twin buildings in Hackensack was among the main New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

BALBOA, C.Z., April 29 -- Funeral services today brought tributes to Mrs. Esther Witkin, wife of Rabbi Nathan Witkin, for her services here to enlisted men of the Army and Navy and to refugees and the public generally. Mrs. Witkin, killed yesterday when an airplane crashed into the building of the Jewish Welfare Board, was engaged in social service work in New York City before coming to Panama in 1937 with her husband.

Lillian Stephens, soprano from Texas, who gave her first Town Hall recital last night, made known a pure, velvety voice of unusual beauty. But its fine possibilities were only partly realized because of a type of production resulting in unsupported, breathy tones, incapable of acquiring much variety in coloring.

The Yankees and the Browns apparently have reversed their usual roles, with the St. Louis clan the sprightly, hard-hitting team and the Bombers the bedraggled doormats. For the second successive day the Brownies bowled over the world champions at the Stadium yesterday, winning by 11 to 6 and pushing Joe McCarthy's operatives still another notch lower in the standings to third place behind the Indians and the Tigers.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Mayor La Guardia, appearing before the Federal Communications Commission today as special counsel for WNYC, attacked the Columbia Broadcasting System for opposing night hours for New York's municipal radio station.

Retail sales of sugar to consumers in New York City will be resume next Wednesday to all persons holding ration books, Lee S. Buckingham, acting Federal Rationing Administrator for the city, announced yesterday. In most other communities sales to ration book holders will be resumed on Tuesday.

Despite the arguments set forth in the OPA's statement of considerations involved in issuance of the general price freeze, the time lag between advances in goods at wholesale and at retail was still a major problem in many lines yesterday.

The millions of young persons throughout the country who will be freed from school this Summer can help in the war by working on farms or in factories, salvaging waste materials, or taking Summer courses that will increase their skill for important tasks to come later, it was brought out in a symposium sponsored by the Child Study Association of America yesterday afternoon at The New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Virtually all types of cotton goods and cotton yarns, which are now controlled by sliding scales attached to raw cotton prices, were frozen at the basis of the highest March price by the Office of Price Administration today.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 -- The Kentucky-Tennessee Light and Power Company petitioned the Securities and Exchange Commission today for permission to sell all of its physical properties and other assets in Frankfort, Ky., in accordance with an agreement between the company and John Kirtley and Louis Cox, residents of Kentucky.

Questions regarding the price status of new styles introduced since March and as to what procedure should be adopted by mills which did not offer any goods for sale during that month, were among those most frequently asked yesterday by knit goods sellers following initial reading of the price freezing order.

A considerable increase over last year's contributions is indicated in this year's campaign of the Greater New York Fund, John W. Hanes, former Under-Secretary of the Treasury, who is chairman of the drive, said yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the millinery division in the Hotel Biltmore.

CHICAGO, April 29 (AP) -- The livestock market was unsettled today by the price ceiling order issued overnight and prices sagged in all departments except sheep. Livestock men said the ceiling order apparently affected retail and wholesale charges for all types of meat, except mutton and lamb.

All civilian defense workers in the protective services, such as air raid wardens and auxiliary firemen, must meet Federal standards of training before they can wear the official OCD insignia or receive protective equipment from the recent $100,000,000 appropriation by Congress, it was disclosed yesterday.

Eight well-known Republicans living in the Twenty-sixth Congressional District sent a letter to members of the Republican County Committees of Orange, Dutchess land Putnam Counties yesterday declaring that Hamilton Fish Jr. should not be renominated in the Congressional primaries and that "even if he should run independently, he cannot be elected in November."

ST. LOUIS, April 29 -- Although the Cardinals put Carl Hubbell to rout in the ninth inning today with a three-run blast that tied the score, the feat accomplished little beyond spoiling what would have been a fine comeback for the old screwball maestro and lifting a ladies' day crowd of 4,000 to a high pitch of excitement.

Directors of the American Tobacco Company declared yesterday a dividend of 75 cents a share on the common and common B shares, payable on June 1. George W. Hill, president, said in a letter to stockholders that the amounts for the third and final quarters would depend upon earnings for the year, which would be contingent principally on the tax rate.

The joys of learning about poultices, plaster casts, vitamins and hospital bed-making while taking care of a family of five were recounted last night by Mrs. Evelyn McGarry, a West Side housewife with a merry Hibernian twinkle in her eye, as she prepared to receive two diplomas at the Children's Aid Society's West Side Center, 419 West Thirty-eighth Street.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- A War Department communique, based on reports received up to 9:30 A.M. today, said:
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 29 -- Yale today beat the Wesleyan nine by 6 -- 2 on Jack Neville's effective pitching and well-bunched hits off Stan Kay.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 29 -- Axis bombers raided Alexandria last night and early this morning, killing fifty-eight persons, injuring 111 and causing some property damage, but at least three of the raiders never got back.

Directors of the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company approved yesterday a plan whereby the company's outstanding class B preferred stock would be purchased outright from the Columbia Oil and Gasoline Corporation.
