This issue, outstanding in the principal amount of $1,000,000, elects two directors to the Panhandle board who are nominees of Columbia Oil.

The United States Supreme Court has consented to review the case of Gene McCann, former financial operator who recently obtained release from a jail, to which he had been sent on conviction of mail fraud. This was reported yesterday by McCann, who said his attorney would be Frank J. Walsh of 501 East 161st Street, the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- A medium-size armed vessel operated by the Japanese in Manila Bay was sunk by the guns of our island fortresses commanding the entrances to the bay, a War Department communique announced today.
Senora de Michels, wife of the Chilean Ambassador, and her daughter. Senorita Cristina Michels, have arrived from Washington and are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Because he was suspected of having "tattled" that the senior woman interne in his division at Bellevue Hospital had left her post to go to a party last Saturday night on Long Island, Dr. Morris Miller, 26 years old, a junior interne, was struck in the face in the hospital last Monday, Assistant District Attorney Paul Reilly charged yesterday.

The two-family dwelling at 23-90 Thirty-second Street, Astoria, Queens, has been sold by Liberan Homes, Inc., Michele Azzarone, president, to John and Albina Baducci for cash above a first mortgage of $2,000. The tax valuation of the parcel is $11,000, of which $1,800 represents the value of the 19 by 65 foot plot. The title policy was issued by the City Title Insurance Company.

Plans for stressing accident prevention in factories, communities and homes of war workers and their families, and the organization of industry committees to cover every field contributing to war production and regional committees to coordinate the work according to the needs of various geographical areas, were outlined yesterday at an organization meeting of the executive committee of the War Production Fund to Conserve Man Power of the National Safety Council.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 29 -- Italian press comment today on President Roosevelt's radio address is still limited. The hour at which he spoke prevented Italian papers from giving the text until considerably later in the morning. Most party organs stress the President's "admission" that American battle fleets are operating in the Mediterranean and reason that "the British Fleet was not enough."

TOKYO, April 29 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- Japanese armies in occupied lands in the south joined with the nation at home in observing Emperor Hirohito's forty-first birthday today.

The Harry Payne Whitney residence at Fifth Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street became a temporary auction house yesterday as some of its luxurious furnishings were sold for $220,379 to bidders who overflowed the carved and gilded oak ballroom.

Bond's Clothing Stores yesterday set a base price of $24 for their one-trouser suits, which brings them below the prevailing prices of other leading chains such as Howard and Crawford. The former charges $26.75 and the latter $24.95. Bond's also introduced coat and trouser combinations at $22 to $32.

Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy granted yesterday summary judgment in favor of the Koninklijke Lederfabriek Oisterwijk N.V., a Netherlands concern now located in Curacao, Dutch West Indies, for the recovery from three New York banks of $450,000 as the value of securities deposited with the banks before the German invasion of the Netherlands.

MADISON, N.J., April 29 -- That all-out blackout here last night, a pitch-dark affair if there ever was one, won't be repeated. Alexander Milne, deputy director of the State Defense Council in charge of the Morristown region, announced that he had received instructions from the State Council to "see that it won't happen again" in Madison.

It is becoming increasingly clear that the Treasury must have the market for new investments pretty much for its own exclusive use in order to finance the war to the extent that now appears necessary through purely open market operations. This obviously is having a cumulative effect upon the market for new issues of corporate securities.
BERLIN, April 29 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High, Command communique said today:

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Every agency of the government that may be affected by a wage order of the National War Labor Board will be consulted prior to the wage determination so that President Roosevelt's wage-stabilization policy may be administered effectively.

Jim Perkins, Rutgers ace, hurled a no-hit, no-run game yesterday in turning back Manhattan, 2 -- 0, on Manhattan Field. In addition to his brilliant mound feat, Perkins got two of the seven safeties made by the Scarlet and tallied once.
The news of defeats in Burma came to Chungking on Tuesday night (or, by Chinese time, Wednesday morning) along with this statement in President Roosevelt's radio talk:

Under a hard stretch drive by Warren Mehrtens, John A. Bell Jr.'s chestnut filly Hurriette got up in the last stride at Jamaica yesterday to take the $7,725 Rosedale Stakes by a nose from the Wheatley Stable's Optimism. A crowd of 14,877 saw the filly, in trouble during the early running, courageously come around the field to win.

Leopold Stokowski will conduct the New York City WPA Symphony Orchestra in the first two in a series of five "war stamp" symphony concerts at the Cosmopolitan Opera House, it was announced yesterday. Like the recent concert at Carnegie Hall, only those who buy war stamps at the box office will be admitted.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- The White Sox sustained their sixth straight defeat today as Washington mauled Bill Dietrich and Buck Ross for fifteen hits to win, 10 to 4.
LONDON, April 29 -- German bomber pilots continued their "Baedeker" raids on England last night by attacking another famous cathedral town, York.

LONDON, April 29 -- Royal Air Force bombers dealt smashing blows at the German naval bases of Kiel and Trondheim early today, rounding out a week's offensive that saw the German port of Rostock all but obliterated and a trail of devastation spread from the French coast through the Ruhr Valley to the Skoda munitions works in Czechoslovakia.

AT ADVANCED UNITED NATIONS BASE, Southwestern Pacific, April 29 (North American Newspaper Alliance) -- Even while the United Nations and Japanese are trading bombs and machinegun slugs over these islands, the Australian Government is working out a political and geographical merger to combine Papua with Northeast New Guinea and the surrounding islands now used by the Japanese for their bases.

Borough President Edgar J. Nathan Jr. of Manhattan relinquished his office yesterday afternoon to James F. White, a 17-year-old High School of Commerce honor student, who assumed the Borough President's duties for the day in connection with Boys and Girls Week.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The major means of preserving beauty and glamour during the war is up to the women of America themselves, the War Production Board pointed out today in a plea to women to save all their lipstick containers, compacts and the multitude of jars and cans in which their favorite cosmetic and toilet preparations are packed.

ALBANY, April 29 -- Governor Lehman today accepted, with the thanks of the State, the $38,000 fund offered to it by the United Spanish War Veterans, which the State was authorized to receive under the Kirnan bill enacted by the Legislature.

Fordham's unbeaten baseball team made it ten in a row, six in the Metropolitan Collegiate Conference, by downing the hitherto undefeated St. John's nine, 7 -- 5, at Fordham Field yesterday. St. John's went into the game with a record of five victories, four in the league, and a tie.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 29 (AP) -- Information gathered in Bucharest diplomatic circles by a neutral diplomat indicated today that the Axis plans to hurl about 280 divisions -- perhaps 5,000,000 men -- against the Russians when Reichsfuehrer Hitler's now offensive begins.

The Bank of the Manhattan Company has sold in an all-cash deal to Dan Seymour, the tenant, the colonial-type residence with eight rooms and three baths and a three-car garage at 7 Fairway Drive, Gedney Gardens, White Plains, Westchester. The plot is 75 by 152 feet and the assessed valuation is $16,100.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- A 100 per cent parity ceiling on farm products, as recommended by President Roosevelt in his message to Congress Monday, would require a reduction in the prices of several important commodities. Under the present Price Control Act ceilings on farm products may not be set at less than 110 per cent of parity and in some cases the ceiling must be higher.

Mrs. Lou Gehrig, widow of the Yankee baseball star, unveiled two bronze memorial plaques marking off Lou Gehrig Plaza yesterday afternoon Before 300 persons, including the former baseball star's parents, many of his former teammates and President James J. Lyons of the Bronx, who presided.

Last October a consignment of food packages arrived at a German prison camp and was divided among a group of French war prisoners. Inside the packages the prisoners found postcards on which they were to acknowledge receipt of the food.

The German Government claims to have made a discovery of "historic" importance in the President's radio address. It has discovered proof of "American war guilt." The passage in the President's address which furnishes Dr. Goebbels with this evidence is Mr. Roosevelt's statement: "Although the treacherous attack on Pearl Harbor was the immediate cause of our entry into the war, that event found the American people spiritually prepared for war on a world-wide scale."

The Real Estate Board of New York yesterday issued a statement expressing its willingness to cooperate with the Federal Government and the OPA in the matter of rent ceilings "whenever conditions here make local application of any of its rulings essential," but said the date of March 1, 1942, selected as the maximum rent date for stabilization of prices of apartments, might in many cases work "grave injustice."

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- An Anglo-American Coordinating Committee charged with the over-all integration of the war efforts of the two countries and especially with breaking the serious shipping bottleneck will be established soon, a responsible government official said today.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 29 -After a two-day hearing, a Territorial Court (military tribunal) in Zurich condemned former Major Ernst Leonhardt and the writer Franz Burri in absentia to five years in the penitentiary, and the former to degradation and expulsion from the Army and both to ten years' loss of civic rights on charges of founding the "Swiss National Socialist Movement."

CHICAGO, April 29 (AP) -- Jack Blackburn, ring-cagey Negro who developed Joe Louis from an awkward amateur into the world heavyweight champion in less than three years, was buried today in a $5,000 casket under fifteen auto loads of flowers.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 29 -- The Beat-the-Big-Hoss Society for the improvement of Derby long-shot stabbers held a meeting today and decided that if some fancy-figured racer is going to knock off Devil Diver at Churchill Downs on Saturday, it could very well be his former stablemate, Sweep Swinger, who is expected to like the mile-and-a-quarter route.

CANBERRA, Australia, April 29 -- Arrival of more United States reinforcements in Australia was announced here today, and at the same time it was revealed that the Japanese were steadily reinforcing the areas they occupy in New Guinea and the near-by islands despite United Nations air attacks.

A group composed of the Union Securities Corporation, the Central Republic Company and Bramhall Stein received yesterday the award of an issue of $350,000 of refunding bonds of the city of Portland, Ore., on a bid of 100,049 for 1 3/8s.
According to the newspapers, during the last few days the sale of war stamps and bonds has fallen off and the Treasury Department is planning to start a new sales campaign.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- William Green today urged all members of the American Federation of Labor to comply promptly with the government's program for voluntary 10 per cent payroll deductions for the purchase of war bonds. He said he opposed compulsory action on payroll deductions.

How a Navy gun crew scored a direct hit on an enemy submarine with the deck gun of a merchant ship that had picked them up after their own, medium-sized United States cargo vessel was torpedoed and sunk was disclosed here yesterday after Washington had released the news of the sinking.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- Luke McNamee, president of the Mackay Radio and Telegraph Companies, suggested today that the bill permitting merger of telegraph and radio systems be amended to protect his system's international and domestic operations "in the event of a merger in which Mackay Radio is not proposed to be included."
MOSCOW, April 29 (From Russian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

IT'S well to start off on a patriotic note these days. For that reason attention is called to the fact that among the sturdy citizens who refused to reel under the shock of President Roosevelt's suggestion that personal incomes, after deduction for taxes, should not exceed $25,000 per year were the ballplayers wearing the uniform of the Phils.

Paul Huissel, a naturalized American citizen who has consistently refused to aid his adopted country's war effort, had his day in court yesterday and after a brief but scrupulously fair trial, a jury required only four minutes to find him guilty of draft evasion.

The National Distillers Products Corporation filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering a proposed offering of $15,000,000 of seven-year debentures, due on March 1, 1949. Other details of the offering, including the interest rate, will be filed by amendment at a later date.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Proposed legislation providing for definite benefit allotments to families of service men and for supplemental Federal grants where necessary was endorsed by Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator, in a statement read today before a Senate Subcommittee on Military Affairs.

Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the board of the Standard Gas and Electric Company, announced yesterday his opposition to the breakup of the $1,000,000,000 utility system under present war market conditions.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 29 -- Mrs. Henry Ford, wife of the automobile manufacturer, made an appeal to the women of America today to dry and preserve all the fruit possible.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- President Roosevelt's anti-inflation program as outlined in his message to Congress Monday and his radio address last night seemed headed for at least one sharp fight but probable eventual acceptance, legislative and executive circles indicated today.

Mayor La Guardia said yesterday that it was impossible to foresee the future of voluntary hospitals because of rising costs of maintenance and declining sources of income and suggested that the situation could be helped if the Federal government would allow a greater exemption from taxation for contributions to "useful institutions."

VICHY, France, April 29 (UP) -- Jacques Doriot, supporter of the government of Pierre Laval, demanded in a speech at Bayonne today that former Premiers Leon Blum and Paul Reynaud and Georges Mandel, former Minister of Interior, be shot without trial.

The issuance of railway equipment trust certificates with a short-term redemption clause has become a possibility as a result of recent promulgations of the War Production Board, it was disclosed in railroad management circles yesterday. The possibility has arisen as a result of WPB decrees which threaten the delivery of cars ordered or to be ordered by various railroads.

Dodd, Mead announced yesterday that it was offering a $1,000 advance against royalties as a prize for the best war novel submitted by Oct. 15. Although any aspect of the war may furnish the background or plot, the publishers made it plain that they particularly wished to obtain a manuscript dealing with American action in the war.

The nation's gasoline stocks at the close of last week were 102,897,000 barrels, a decline of 605,000 from the 103,502,000 at the end of the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A year ago these stocks amounted to 96,172,000 barrels.

TRENTON, April 29 -- By a vote of 19 to 1, with one member absent, the State Senate confirmed tonight Governor Charles Edison's nomination of Spencer Miller Jr. of South Orange as State Highway Commissioner.

CHICAGO, April 29 -- Uncertainly about the government's price-ceiling program was dissipated partly yesterday, and operators, after a study of the plan, concluded today that it was not bearish. This brought in a fair amount of short covering and also a little commission house support and closing sales of wheat futures on the Board of Trade were at gains of 1/2 to 7/8 cent a bushel.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- A procedure for settling union jurisdictional cases that may come before the National War Labor Board has been set up by joint agreement between William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, and Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, William H. Davis, chairman of the board, stated today.

Four midtown theatres will offer new film attractions this morning. The Roxy will present the world premiere of Twentieth Century-Fox's "My Gal Sal," starring Rita Hayworth and Victor Mature. Other players in the cast of the Technicolor musical are Carole Landis, James Gleason, Mona Maris and Walter Catlett. . . .

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Approval of universal price ceilings established yesterday was expressed today by Dr. Esther Cole Franklin, speaking for the American Association of University Women, and Mrs. Edna Van Horn, for the American Home Economics Association.

MEXICO CITY, April 29 -- Reorganization of Mexican defense, involving an increase of 50 per cent in the number of troops on the West Coast and strengthening of the forces guarding the oil fields near the gulf of Mexico, was explained here today by an authorized military source.

The ghosts of American colonists will be paraded tomorrow before Justice Louis A. Valente in Bronx Supreme Court by four of their descendants who are asking the court to make an attorney, who assumed their name legally for business reasons but without any intent of infringing on their heritage, to take unto himself another name.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The transformation of the taxicab into the jitney, in part at least, was indicated as a war necessity today by Joseph B. Eastman, director of the Office of Defense Transportation.

Major Gen. Irving J. Phillipson, commanding the Second Corps Area, received orders yesterday transferring him to Washington, where he will succeed Major Gen. William N. Haskell as executive director of Army Emergency Relief.

Labor unions in this city showed yesterday no disposition to abandon pending demands for wage increases or to surrender increases about to be put into effect, although their leaders expressed general approval of the principles laid down by President Roosevelt in his victory program.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 29 -- Diplomatic observers here tonight linked yesterday's meeting of the ninety-eight Italian Prefects in Rome under the presidency of Premier Mussolini with Adolf Hitler's Reichstag speech Sunday as indications of the gravity of the internal situation of the two Axis countries.
FORT WORTH, April 29 -- Concern over the possible draft of women into war industry was shown today at the convention of the General Federation of Women's Clubs.

No units of the State Guard were "lost" and none were caught in the Queens practice blackout while on manoeuvres Tuesday night, as had been previously reported, Brig. Gen. George A. Herbst, chief of staff of the guard, explained yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Ralph K. Davies, deputy oil coordinator, announced today abandonment of plans to cut east coast gasoline deliveries to 50 per cent of normal before retail rationing is started on May 15. Meanwhile Representative Rivers moved for a Congressional investigation of the eastern seaboard "shortage."

After a session of four and a half hours in the fifteenth and final round of the biennial championship tournament of the United States Chess Federation at the Hotel Astor last night, Samuel Reshevsky, the defending champion, and I.A. Horowitz adjourned their game.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Ever since the State Department and the Federal Loan Agencies realized what Executive Order 9128 did to them, if the President allows the Board of Economic Warfare to administer it in anything like full degree, they have conceded that Milo Randolph Perkins has become a dominant government figure.

The rehabilitation program for refugees from the war zones, conducted on this continent by the American ORT Federation along along the lines on which it was founded in Europe sixty-two years ago, is an important contribution to "the present fight for democracy," Edgar J. Nathan Jr., Borough President of Manhattan, declared yesterday as the campaign for funds opened.

DURING World War I strategists split into eastern and western schools. The easterners quarreled over ways of supporting Russia; Lord (Jackie) Fisher, for example, wanted to force the Baltic, while Winston Churchill held out for the seizure of the Dardanelles. But such quarrels were tea-fights compared to the intellectual slugging that is going on among the strategists of World War II.

Workers at the vast steel plant of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation at Bethlehem, Pa., whose purchases of war bonds are being encouraged by the means of giant posters, at the present time are 96.3 per cent buyers of war bonds by means of payroll deductions, it was announced yesterday by Eugene G. Grace, president of the company.

It is no gilding of the fact to say that the miracle of Mr. Toscanini's Beethoven grows as he continues with the concerts devoted to the music of that master, of which the fourth was given last night with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Lieut. Gen. Brehon B. Somervell, commander of the recently created Army's Services of Supply, said today that plans are being laid to eliminate the "bottleneck" in shipping.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- A fifth judgeship for the New Jersey Federal District Court was created today when President Roosevelt signed a bill sponsored by Senator William H. Smathers focussing attention on four Smathers candidates for the post.

CHICAGO, April 29 -- The freezing of rents in defense areas is a requisite for the winning of the war and the landlords of the nation are expected to cooperate fully was the message brought today by government officials to the National Conference on Rent Control in the Drake Hotel.

There was a bright, racy fashion show at Saks Fifth Avenue yesterday and another at W. Sloane, where the "colors of the Andes" were launched in furniture and frocks, the latter displayed by Bonwit Teller.

There was only one touch of the World of Tomorrow on Edward Ungelter's desk at 45 Beaver Street. It was a lacquered log that could only have come from the fantastic naked tree that grew near the bridge over which No. 10 buses rumbled toward the British Pavilion.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 29 -- Adolf Hitler made his unexpected Sunday speech because the surveys that the Gestapo conducts from time to time by steaming open of a certain percentage of domestic mail revealed that defeatism and gloom had lately reached alarming proportions -- that is the explanation given by travelers regarded as extremely well-informed on German matters, who left Berlin as recently as two days after the Reichsfuehrer's speech.
Tomorrow is Child Health Day. And parents throughout the country, especially mothers, are urged to reconsider the eating habits of their offspring.

With adequate support assured from manufacturers and wholesalers, the Home Furnishings Industry Committee yesterday voted in Chicago to seek a bigger enrollment of retailers for the industry's national promotional campaign. It will be waged under the slogan of "Keep Up the Homes We're Fighting For."

CHICAGO, April 29 (AP) -- Flour business has had in the last few days a few bright spots, according to the weekly survey today of The Northwestern Miller, with some improvement in new bookings but no indication yet of general revival.

War history was written in shadow on the Gay White Way last night. On the second evening of the dimming of city light to prevent sky glow that silhouettes off-shore ships all the great electric and neon signs went dead.

A promise, that housewives in New York City may soon narrow to a single office their search for answers to problems in wartime home management was contained in the announcement made yesterday by James G. Blaine, chairman of the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, that all services and information for consumers are to be correlated and made available through a central consumer information bureau.
LONDON, April 29 -- The stock markets today were steady, with the exception of the gilt-edge section, which had further fractional losses.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- President Roosevelt instructed all Federal agencies to take immediate steps to insure a sizable reduction in the number of private automobiles carrying government employes to work; proclaimed May 22 as National Maritime Day, and signed several bills including the $19,000,000,000 Supplemental War Appropriation Bill and the War Department Civil Functions Appropriation Bill; he conferred with the Pacific War Council, and with Lieut. Gen. William S. Knudsen.

Details of the intensive campaign for smallpox vaccination and diphtheria immunization to be held in New York City in May were announced yesterday before the 136th annual meeting of the Medical Society of the State of New York at the Waldorf-Astoria, in a paper by Dr. John L. Rice, New York City Health Commissioner.

With a clearer definition of the part that the domestic economic front is to play in the total war effort, investors long on the sidelines threw off some of their timid-ness yesterday, and the stock market rallied along a broad front to end with gains of 1 to 2 points.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- President Roosevelt has instructed all Federal agencies to take steps immediately to "substantially reduce" the number of private automobiles taking government employes to work. He said that because of the rubber and gasoline shortage the transportation problem for laborers was becoming "critical" in many places.

After more than twenty years of Youth Movements of various kinds, it has come about that the grandfathers of the nation have registered for war work. Who is responsible for a war that finds it necessary to take into account the services of men of 64?

As if the Dodgers had not already complicated modern times sufficiently, they are now offered as heroes of "The Life of Reilly," which was acted at the Broadhurst last evening. "Heroes" is stretching the point a little. For Mr. Roos, the author, is suggesting that Reilly, the southpaw, and his two pals are below average intelligence.

A plan to insure adequate distribution of newspapers to readers, in harmony with the government's order of April 20 for a sharp curtailment in the use of trucks, tires and gasoline, is under consideration by committees representing the Publishers Association of New York in the morning and evening newspaper fields.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 29 -- A three-run drive in the eighth inning gave City College a 7-4 triumph over the Hofstra nine today in a Metropolitan Baseball Conference contest. Weak fielding aided in Hofstra's defeat, the Flying Dutchmen committing six miscues.

Stockholders of the Wolverine Tube Company at their annual meeting in Detroit yesterday approved a proposal to accept the Calumet and Hecla Consolidated Copper Company's offer to purchase their company's assets for $2,690,361.

When I called at the Red Cross blood donor headquarters this week I was fascinated. Persons from every walk of life were cheerfully registering for their contributions. Business and professional men and women, shopkeepers, stenographers, taxi drivers, society women and a barber all seemed eager to be of service to help our all-out war program.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, an organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

PITTSBURGH, April 29 (AP) -- Rookie Johnny Barrett from Hollywood just about clinched a major league berth today by smacking out singles in the ninth and tenth innings, the second one driving in the run which gave Pittsburgh a 7-to-6 victory over the Phils.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Spokesmen of farmers throughout the country were summoned to Washington today by the Senate Agriculture Committee to seek to dispute a statement by Secretary Wickard that they would support the lowering of ceilings on commodity prices, as proposed by President Roosevelt in his anti-inflation message.

It has been and remains the view of this newspaper that no general freezing of all prices would have been either necessary or desirable had the Government shown the courage and foresight to come to grips with the basic forces making for a rising spiral of living costs.

CHICAGO, April 29 -- Dr. Hu Shih, the Chinese Ambassador, told the National League of Women Voters at its convention tonight that the issue at stake in the war was "despotism versus democracy, freedom versus oppression and peace versus the lust for conquest by brute force."
WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- Registration of all rented dwellings will be required in cities and towns brought under Federal rent control, Price Administrator Leon Henderson announced today.

Charles Underhill Powell, since 1915 chief engineer of the Queens Topographical Bureau, who planned 75,000 acres and 2,500 miles of streets in that borough, has applied for retirement after forty-three years of service to the city, it was announced yesterday by Borough President James A. Burke.

In my home paper, The Hanover (N.H.) Gazette, there was an editorial by Earl Hewitt, the editor, in which he stated that Assistant United States Treasurer John L. Sullivan has recently appointed two men, at salaries of $4,600 and $3,800 respectively, for "promoting a savings bond sales drive in New Hampshire."

The metropolitan area's first "dim-out" revealed -- in the glare of electric signs, blazihg lights in tall buildings, automobile headlights and unnecessarily illuminated highways -- that a considerable number of people still don't realize how close the war has come to this coast.

CHUNGKING, China, April 29 (U.P.) -- Spokesmen here believed the Japanese columns in Burma reached the peak of their striking power Saturday, when they raced over from Thailand to positions north of the main battle line running through Taunggyi and Loilem.

The Bowery Savings Bank has sold for cash above a purchase money first mortgage of $260,000 the six-story elevator apartment house at 203 West Ninetieth Street, northwest corner of Amsterdam Avenue, to a client of Abraham Leichter, attorney.

Retailers are hopeful of relief in enforcement of the general maximum price regulation by the Office of Price Administration, particularly with respect to the time lag between wholesale and retail price increases, Lew Hahn, general manager of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, said in a statement yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, April 29 -- The Commercial Discount Company has submitted to holders of its Series A 8 per cent preferred and Series B 7 per cent preferred stocks a plan for exchanging their shares for a new issue of debentures, authorized in the principal amount of $1,000,000.

A large exhibition arranged for the benefit of Russian War Relief, Inc., has been installed at the Andre Seligmann Gallery, 15 East Fifty-seventh Street. It opens there with a reception and private view this evening at 8 o'clock, and will continue through May 9.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- President Roosevelt signed bills today appropriating more than $20,000,000,000 for war purposes, discussed Far Eastern developments with the Pacific War Council and received a personal report from Lieut. Gen. W.S. Knudsen that conditions were "very fair" on the home production front but that "we have a long way to go."
LONDON, April 29 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

LONDON, April 29 -- To facilitate the closest cooperation between the Army and Air Force officers are being exchanged between the two commands, Sir Archibald Sinclair, Air Minister, said in the House of Commons today. Amplifying his statement Sir Archibald told a questioner that Royal Air Force squadrons cooperated with the Army in reconnaissance and other tasks agreed upon by the commanders in the field.

The Northern Pacific Railway moved a "tremendous" amount of raw materials and finished products and sustained a heavy movement of troops and military equipment in a satisfactory manner after the outbreak of the war, C.E. Denney, president, said in his annual report issued yesterday.
LINDENHURST, L.I., April 29 -- Fishing for flounders may not require the skill attributed to a fresh water angler but it serves as the means of recreation for thousands each year.

SAGINAW, Mich., April 29 -- Rioting between C.I.O. and A.F.L. United Automobile Workers broke out today at the Wilcox-Rich division of the Eaton Manufacturing Company. A dozen men received minor injuries.
Your paper has a dispatch from Fort Devens, Mass., that the last mounted squadron of the 101st Cavalry was paraded and dismissed as horse cavalry.

Bonds called before maturity for payment in April totaled $179,888,000, the largest amount for any month since July of last year. Last month's prepayments compared with $131,349,000 in March and with $392,273,000 in April, 1941.

In anticipation of a ruling by the Federal Trade Commission that a commission resident buyer may not represent a retailer and receive his commission from the seller, the 155 commission resident buyers who are members of the National Association of Commission Representatives, Inc., are modifying the form of their business to conform to the expected order, it was learned in market sources yesterday.

War or no war, British inventors may still file applications for patents in Germany under the Trading With the Enemy Act of 1939 and still pay the fees required to maintain their rights. Canada and Germany likewise permit patent transactions with the enemy. In all these warring countries the national interest determines whether or not a license to deal with the enemy will be granted, so that patents are by no means inviolate.

FORT WORTH, April 30 -- After passing two wartime emergency resolutions, the General Federation of Women's Clubs devoted most of its business session today to a discussion of oleomargarine. Twenty resolutions lived; one died, the latter advocating the repeal of the Federal tax on margarine.
Sales of small residential properties accounted for most of the New Jersey realty activity reported yesterday.

Consolidated earnings of Paramount Pictures, Inc., and subsidiaries in the year ended on Jan. 3, amounted to $9,206,242. Including $1,045,000 of undistributed earnings of partially owned companies applicable to Paramount the net amounted to $3.41 a share for 2,744,923 common shares, it was announced in the annual report issued yesterday by Barney Balaban, president.

The plant of the York Ice Machinery Corporation between Forty-first and Forty-second Streets on Second Avenue in Brooklyn has been taken under purchase contract by the United States Coast Guard for warehouse and storage purposes.
Girl Scout Grace Myslik went to Central Park yesterday afternoon to say her piece and, notwithstanding Commissioner Moses's discomfort, she was going to say it.

Richard J. Blum, vice president of Saks Co. and managing director of Saks-34th Street, and Elliott Beilen of the law firm of Chadbourne, Wallace, Parke Whiteside, were elected to the board of directors of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., at the annual stockholders' meeting held here yesterday.

A verdict of guilty was handed up early this morning by a blue ribbon jury in General Sessions in the case of nine men accused of participating in an extortion conspiracy to victimize independent milk dealers and truckers in New York State.

Several hundred delegates attending the fourth annual convention of the New York State Association for Nursery Education at the Hotel Pennsylvania heard last night that nursery education should become part of wartime planning for better family living.

Not only the products but the containers in which they arrive are becoming more interesting in America these days. An ordinary oval box of exceptionally fine face powder, for example, appears with what seems to be a spool of crimson sewing silk perched jauntily on its top.

Professor Carlton J.H. Hayes of Columbia University, newly appointed Ambassador to Spain, yesterday was the guest of honor at a reception by the National Conference of Christians and Jews at the Hotel Roosevelt. Professor Hayes, who has been Catholic co-chairman of the conference since 1928, leaves within a few days for Madrid.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Posthumous award of the Distinguished Service Medal to Brig. Gen. Harold H. George, 48 years old, air officer on the staff of General Douglas MacArthur, was announced this morning by Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Charged with sedition, the Philadelphia Herold, a weekly printed partly in English but chiefly in German, was temporarily barred from the mails today by Postmaster General Walker on advice of Attorney General Biddle.

Until recently all tabulations of corporation earnings have shown a substantial year-to-year rise. For example, a calculation by the National City Bank covering 2,540 corporations showed a rise in combined net income for 1941 of 20 per cent over 1940 and a smaller sample by the Federal Reserve Board showed an equal rise.
Your editorials are strongly against putting a ceiling on prices. You say that this is the wrong way to prevent inflation.

WITH THE UNITED STATES ARMY IN NORTHERN IRELAND, April 30 (AP) -- Sergeant William V. Clitsham, 23, of Narbeth, Pa., went on trial before a military court today on a manslaughter charge in the death of an Irish bus driver by machine-gun fire April 17.

LONDON, April 30 -- Speculation about the attitude of C.R. Rajagopalachari, a former Premier of Madras, if the All-India Congress party rejected the Madras resolution urging recognition of the Moslem League's separatist claim was set at rest today by news from India that he had resigned from the Congress party working committee.

CHUNGKING, China, April 30 -- The spectacular drive of the Japanese mechanized spearhead to Lashio was designed not only to cut the main artery for United Nations' supplies and reinforcements but also to lay the groundwork for encircling the Chinese troops in Burma's eastern bulge.

Trusts totaling $33,214,891 in the estates of Henry O. Havemeyer, late president and one of the founders of the American Sugar Refining Company, and that of his widow, Mrs. Louisine W. Havemeyer, were accounted for yesterday in Surrogate's Court, where their children filed statements in the estates of their parents.

Lamp manufacturers learned yesterday that the War Production Board was planning to extend until May 31 the period in which they may use up their inventories of finished metal other than copper and brass. According to earlier instructions, these inventories could not be consumed after April 23.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Conversations that might lead ultimately to United States recognition of the Free French National Committee if the Laval-dominated Vichy government should supply military aid to Germany were begun today between ranking State Department officials and Free French representatives.

CHICAGO, April 30 (AP) -- Prices of livestock resumed their slump today as the market continued to reflect uncertainty in the trade regarding the effect of ceilings on all types of meat except lamb and mutton. Prices have been substantially above parity for some time and no steps have been taken to restrict them, although wholesale pork has been subjected to ceilings for several weeks.

While the newly organized machinery for enforcing the over-all price ceilings will not threaten business men with a "big stick" there is no question but that a number of concerns eventually will be put out of business for violating the regulation, it was indicated by a spokesman for the Office of Price Administration here yesterday.

New York University crushed Brooklyn College, 22 -- 6, in a Metropolitan Collegiate Conference baseball game on the Brooklyn College Field yesterday. The uneven contest was called at the end of the seventh.

General Roberto Fierro, commander of the Mexican Air Forces, said yesterday in an interview at the Hotel Roosevelt that his nation will fight if threatened by Japan. He witnessed Japan's "brutal and reckless" destruction in Shanghai in 1936 as military attache to the Mexican Embassy at Tokyo.

LONDON, April 30 -- Ambassador John G. Winant and Admiral Harold R. Stark, former Chief of Naval Operations in Washington, arrived from the United States today in a British plane. Mr. Winant is returning to his post after nine weeks absence and Admiral Stark is taking over command of United States naval forces in European waters.

With the distribution yesterday of the 120th annual Official Catholic Directory, it was announced that Catholics in the United States, Alaskan and the Hawaiian Islands number 22,556,242, an increase of 263,141 over last year.

LONDON, April 30 -- J.A. Scott Watson, formerly Professor of Rural Economy at Oxford, will go to Washington and Ottawa shortly as a coordinator of post-war agricultural policies of Britain, the United States and Canada, it was announced today.

ST. LOUIS, April 30 -- The Giants had one of their big innings today, but the round did not arrive until the ninth, and by that time the Polo Grounders had crowded so much bad baseball into the afternoon it scarcely made any difference.
BUFFALO, N.Y., April 30 (AP) -- Rattling off five home runs, the league-leading Bears ruined the home-coming of the Bisons today as they rolled upa 15-5 triumph before 14,991 fans.

BRING on the blackouts. Much may be saved and probably little worth bothering about will be lost. With the whole country on war time, there is enough daylight to go around the wide field of sports. For years the golfers have been whacking their devious ways around the links "in the calm twilight of Platonic shades." Twilight tennis long has been an established custom in many communities.

The Whitney Museum of American Art will open on Tuesday an exhibition of drawings by Hugh Ferriss, entitled "The Power of America in Building," which is the record of a journey of 18,000 miles covering forty States.

A yellow moon was the only source of light in Times Square and in all Manhattan from Greenwich Village to 124th Street the full width of the island from river to river, in the area's first complete blackout from 9:30 to 9:50 o'clock last night.

LONDON, April 30 -- In two by-elections yesterday caused by the elevation of Captain David Margesson and Lieut. Col. John T.C. Moore-Brabazon to the peerage, government-supported candidates were defeated, it became known today.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 30 -- Today's communique from United Nations Headquarters reported a successful air raid yesterday on the airdrome at Lae, in Northeast New Guinea. Twenty grounded Japanese planes were destroyed or seriously damaged.

Unions engaged in printing and delivering newspapers protested yesterday against the order of the Office of Defense Transportation under which newspaper deliveries would be limited to one edition daily.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (U.P.) -- Senator Ellison D. Smith of South Carolina, chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, introduced today a bill to require a one-year extension of loans on 1941 cotton, wheat and corn stocks held by the Commodity Credit Corporation.

Itabo and Blue Pennant, the former by a nose in a photo finish and the latter with a good stretch run, won interesting races at Jamaica yesterday, but the thrill for the 15,862 spectators came when the longest priced winner of the meeting, Brown Gal, came down in front in the fourth to pay $180.20 for $2.

Activity among investment bankers was stepped up yesterday by the belief that at least three fair-sized issues of new securities are shaping up for public offering this month. The Public Service Electric and Gas Company has indicated to underwriters that it probably will consider bids about May 25 on its issue of $15,000,000 of bonds.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The Office of Price Administration said today that there is no reason to fear that the cotton textile industry cannot absorb a further limited increase in cotton cost without earning less than reasonable profits.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Long pending legislation to expand the basic work week from forty to forty-eight hours, to freeze open and closed union shop conditions and to apply curbs to controverted practices of organized labor for the war's duration was cast into the discard today by a 13-to-12 vote of the House Committee on Naval Affairs.

A well-known building occupying a blockfront in the downtown insurance district passed to new control yesterday when the William-Platt Corporation, James A. Beha, president, sold 100 William Street to the Aetna Insurance Company of Hartford, Conn.

PITTSBURGH, April 30 (AP) -- George E. Little, Rutgers University athletic director, proposed today a three-point program of economy in athletics whereby colleges may meet enrollment and budget shortages brought on by the war.

PITTSBURGH, April 30 (AP) -- The Phils won their fourth game of the season today, exploding four home runs against the Pirates to snatch a 6-to-3 victory. The triumph snapped a five-game losing streak for the Quakers.

CHICAGO, April 30 -- The International Harvester Company yielded tonight to a War Labor Board decision that it should enter union membership maintenance contracts with A.F.L. and C.I.O. groups in eight of its plants. The company accepted the order with reluctance, stating that it was moved by a desire to avoid hampering its war efforts.

Ted Genock, Paramount Newsreel photographer, who hasn't slept more than two nights in the same bed in the last two years of his war coverage, said yesterday upon his return to New York that he had come back from Java and Australia because the time was not yet ripe in that sector for pictures of "Jerry and the Jap getting kicked in the pants."
An apartment of ten rooms and three baths in the building at 993 Park Avenue has been leased by Herbert E. Meyer through Bing Bing, Inc., and the Madison Realty Company.

Commercial loans of the sixteen regularly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City fell $109,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the widest decline for any week in several years, the Federal Reserve Bank reported yesterday in its weekly summary.
MOSCOW, Friday, May 1 -- Following is the text of Premier Joseph Stalin's order of the day for May Day:

Flotations of new securities, exclusive of United States Government obligations, aggregated in April $265,752,000, composed of $261,352,000 in twenty-six bond issues and $4,400,000 in two stock emissions. These figures compare with financing aggregating $109,749,000 in March, composed of $99,394,000 in twenty-six bond issues and $10,355,000 by four stock offerings.

A few in overalls and most of them in dusty school clothes, 450 eager youthful farmers, all city bred, gave pledges to give up their Summer vacations and farm for victory at the Board of Education's experimental farm, on Kissena Boulevard, Flushing, Queens, yesterday afternoon.

The appointment of F.R. Gerard, general manager of the Lehigh Valley Railroad, to vice president and general manager was announced yesterday by R.W. Brown, president. Mr. Brown also announced the appointment of D.J. Mullane as assistant to the president.

Beginning at 12:01 A.M. today only the 35,000 employes of the city's unified transit lines will be entitled to free passes and about 20,000 passes that have been honored for many years, including the two years since transit unification, will be canceled.

Things that should be done during the merry month of May include tending a garden, or taking a walk along a rural road, or spending a Saturday afternoon in the warm sunshine. Now it is that housekeepers, agreeing there is little time to waste in their kitchens, plan streamlined meals.
HANOVER, N.H., April 30 -- Princeton took two long strides toward the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League championship by winning both games of a double-header with Dartmouth today.

Bonwit Teller has hopped aboard the cotton bandwagon. This most recent endorsement of the American staple took place yesterday in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre Hotel at the luncheon hour. The editing in this instance was perfect.

Mayor La Guardia delivered a one-hour oration in City Hall yesterday to 350 members of the speakers' bureau of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office in which he cautioned them against oratory in their dealings with the public and stressed the advantages of plain conversational speaking.

BERLIN, April 30 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command said today that Soviet troops had "succeeded in breaking through our positions" at the outskirts of a large locality, but had been thrown back by a counter-attack.
MOSCOW, April 30 (From Russian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

A banking group headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. received yesterday the award of an issue of $1,936,000 of Series A refunding bonds of the Charleston (W. Va.) Housing Authority on a net interest cost to the authority of 2.175 per cent.

While the main section of the list of shares on the New York Stock Exchange increased yesterday by almost a point its recovery of Wednesday, American Telephone and Telegraph made almost a phenomenal gain. With the list so oversold as to respond to even feeble support after having been hammered down to nine-year low marks, the market effected a steady although moderate rise through most of the session.

MEXICO CITY, April 29 -- The agreement for expansion of mining of strategic metals announced yesterday in Washington is welcome here as bringing additional capital and employment. It was for this reason that the miners' union agreed to forego for the duration of the war some of its statutory rights, including three months' dismissal pay.

CHICAGO, April 30 -- The Government's rent freezing program for defense areas struck a snag today when 700 realtors from all over the country, meeting in the Drake Hotel, adopted a resolution withholding approval unless ceilings were also placed on operational costs, wages and property taxes.

Your remarks on the subject of inflation in THE TIMES of April 24, 28 and this morning impressed me most favorably. However, you touch on one subject concerning which you apparently lack correct and full information. For this I can scarcely blame you, since misconceptions are apparently widespread.

Although for months he lay near death in Bellevue Hospital from a bullet wound in the abdomen, 70-year-old Benedetto Garafolo's clemency plea to Judge Jonah J. Goldstein in General Sessions yesterday brought 73-year-old Tony Guarari, who shot him, a suspended sentence.

TRENTON, April 30 -- While an all-Republican State Senate committee continued today to investigate last Summer's food costs at the "Little White House" in Sea Girt during occupancy of the State-owned cottage by Governor Charles Edison, Democrat, the Legislature was asked by Assemblyman Peter P. Artaserse of Hudson County to close the dwelling "in the interests of public economy and to prevent scandal and the improper and extravagant use of public funds."

Action putting prices immediately at the March ceiling levels established by the OPA price control order was taken yesterday in the retail, manufacturing and wholesale fields. The move anticipates by ten and seventeen days, respectively, the effective ceiling date of May 11 for manufacturers and wholesalers and of May 18 for retailers.

Bank clearings of the major cities of the nation for the week ended Wednesday amounted to $6,796,330,000, a decline of $209,457,000, or 3.1 per cent from the preceding week's total, but 11.5 per cent better than the $6,093,011,000 recorded in the corresponding week last year, according to the report of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
MELBOURNE, Australia, April 30 -- Today's communique from General MacArthur's headquarters announcing the death of General George and Mr. Jacoby gave no details of the accident.

Standing on the steps of the Sub-Treasury Building, at the base of George Washington's statue, several speakers yesterday compared the nation's present difficulties with the problems confronted on April 30, 1789, when the country inaugurated its first President and proceeded to overcome obstacles much greater than those growing out of today's war.

The report of Marshall Field Co. issued to stockholders yesterday by F.D. Corley, president, shows that profit before Federal taxes in the first three months of 1942 increased to $2,840,605 from $1,319,836 in the corresponding period a year ago.

LONDON, April 30 -- Meals that now cost about 16s in the better London hotels and eating places will soon cost 5s -- on paper. Actually, they will come to 18 1/2s, under the schedule of charges on which Lord Woolton, Food Minister, and hotel representatives agreed today.

LOUISVILLE, April 30 -- The man who has seen all the Kentucky Derbies and who built the race into an international spectacle predicted today that at least fifteen would face the starter Saturday in the $75,000 added renewal of the mile-and-a-quarter gallop which has been run sixty-seven times.

Lieut. Comdr. Griffith Baily Coale, as one of a group of artists doing special work for the Navy, goes to sea with a drawing board. His assignment is to do illustrations and paintings of ship-board life, of bases and whatever action he encounters.

President Roosevelt's recommendation for a ceiling on individual incomes of $25,000 for the duration of the war is bringing somewhat anguished objections from reactionaries both in and out of Congress. Curiously, many of those who dislike this idea are the very ones who were trying to reduce the wages of war workers by abolishing the forty-hour week, with its provision for time and a half for overtime.

On the ground that "the general registration of 39,000,000 adult women to meet the possible need for an additional 2,000,000 new women workers in 1942 seems unwise," four of the five authorities consulted by the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs oppose national registration of women at this time.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 30 -- In their all-out war effort Russia's workers have sacrificed the most popular of their two annual festivals. In the rear as at the front the "Great Patriotic War" continues without respite. May Day, 1942, will be a workday for the first time since 1918.

LONDON, Friday, May 1 -- Britain's bomber forces switched their offensive Wednesday night and early yesterday from the Nazis' Baltic bases and navy to the industry of occupied France that is working for Reich Marshal Hermann Goering's Air Fleet, which is now retaliating by raids on England's lightly defended cathedral cities.

Current statistics indicate a trend toward recrudescence of tuberculosis in the present war, and the times call now for a new health campaign to eradicate the disease, it was declared yesterday at the closing sessions of the 136th annual meeting of the Medical Society of the State of New York at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel.

Your editorial "The President's Program" correctly states that any program to combat inflation must deal with its cause rather than its symptoms. You evidently consider excess purchasing power in the hands of the people as a cause. In my opinion it is but a symptom resulting from a misconception on the part of business at the beginning of the rearmament program.

CHICAGO, April 30 -- Delegates to the biennial convention of the National League of Women Voters voted today their approval of eight points of a ten-point war-time program, following a special caucus, at which Miss Marguerite Wells, president and nominee for re-election, received a unanimous vote of confidence.

Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow, in her first interview as chairman of the women's division of the Greater New York-USO-Joint War Appeal, made it clear yesterday that there should be no encroachment upon the needs of other war service organizations in the forthcoming USO campaign.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 30 -- Crowding each other in the rapidity of their development, events in the Axis camp are reported to be approaching a crisis, which is expected within the next forty-eight hours when an announcement from Berlin or Rome is due to reveal the subjects discussed by Reichsfuehrer Hitler and Premier Mussolini in a meeting they are scheduled to hold before Saturday morning.

CHUNGKING, China, April 30 -- Five years of Japanese aggression in China, with all its slaughter, looting and wholesale destruction of industrial enterprise and cultural institutions, has resulted in mass migration of a large section of the population, affecting fifty million persons, comparable to the entire population of France or the British Isles.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The State Department announced today that President Manuel Prado of Peru would arrive in Miami May 5 for a two-week official visit at the invitation of President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The Senate overruled protests of administration leaders today and cut more than $12,000,000 from the $2,125,985,890 independent offices appropriation bill. The legislation is expected to be passed tomorrow after consideration of the appropriation for the Tennessee Valley Authority which has been increased by $42,251,528 in the Senate Appropriations Committee.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The Treasury issued today individual war savings bond quotas for all the 3,070 counties in the United States while Secretary Morgenthau pleaded for a fair chance for the voluntary bond-selling campaign and for President Roosevelt's whole "equality of privilege" program.

IF any competent war correspondent doesn't have a book manuscript in his luggage these days it isn't because publishers have not cabled him attractive offers. The fame and fortune of the Sheeans, Gunthers and Shirers shine like a beacon before their eyes, as persuasive an inspiration as the fabulous success story of Miss Margaret Mitchell has been to droves of historical novelists.

Billings of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation in the first quarter of 1942 reached a new three-month high mark of $306,000,000, and new bookings for the period were nearly $305,000,000, it was disclosed yesterday by Eugene G. Grace, president, following the meeting of directors.

CHICAGO, April 30 -- Immediate legislation to return the "open shop" throughout the United States, suspend the forty-hour week and give the Office of Price Administration statutory authority to control wages and salaries during wartime were urged today by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- The cellar-shackled White Sox suffered their seventh straight defeat today as young Early Wynn of the Senators beat 41-year-old Ted Lyons, 1 to 0.

" This Above All," Twentieth Century-Fox's screen transcription of the Eric Knight novel, will have its world premiere at the Astor on Tuesday, May 12. Produced by Darryl F. Zanuck and directed by Anatole Litvak, the topical story deals with the romance of a veteran of the Dunkerque evacuation and a member of the British women auxiliary forces.

The great island of Madagascar, with its naval base at Diego Suarez, one of the finest natural harbors in the world, has assumed in the past week a new significance in the complicated strategy of the Indian Ocean.
BERLIN, April 30 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press ) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

Apparently there is nothing wrong with the Yankees that good pitching can't cure. That was proved at the Stadium yesterday when Tiny Bonham spun a gorgeous, four-hit shut-out and the Bronx belters turned on their tormentors, the Browns, for a 3-0 victory which lifted them back over the Tigers into second place.

Did the poets force the English to make so much of the First of May? The English temperature of the month is somewhere in the early fifties. There must have been much "sharpness of the golden dawn" when the earlier English used to go out hunting garlands and Maypoles.

Early gains of 12 to 18 points in yesterday's cotton market were lost when New Orleans selling and near-month liquidation entered the market near the end of trading. Under this pressure, active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 1 to 4 points lower than the final prices of the preceding day.

The totality of last night's blackout wiped out sectional differences that characterize the Manhattan night skyline and merged the soaring buildings of midtown into a depth of darkness that stretched from Harlem down through Greenwich Village.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, April 30 -- Signs that Japan is augmenting her forces in the Southwest Pacific and intensifying air activity are being watched with natural concern by New Zealand. While New Zealanders are reluctant to believe their sturdy little pastoral State will ever be invaded, they realize that one of the possible next Japanese moves in the Pacific would be attacks on Fiji, New Caledonia and finally New Zealand.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, April 30 -- At a press conference after his re turn from Moscow today, United States Ambassador William H. Standley described an hour-and-a-half interview he had with Premier Joseph Stalin in the office of Foreign Commissar Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff in the Kremlin.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The Home Owners Loan Corporation called today for payment on July 1 $875,000,000 of its Series G 2 1/4 per cent bonds. The bonds have a maturity date of July 1, 1944, but are subject to call on July 1.

Dr. Herman Rauschning, once one of the leading citizens of Danzig, where he was President of the Senate, yesterday took out his first United States citizenship papers and declared that for him it was a "very decisive and favorable moment."

MOSCOW, Friday, May 1 -- Premier Joseph Stalin, in a May Day order of the day, pledged that Russia has no territorial ambitions in foreign countries and declared that the Soviet's sole aim is to liberate its lands from "the German Fascist blackguards."

The four former showgirls to whom William Guggenheim, industrialist and amateur poet, willed his entire estate will have to content themselves with half of a meager $10,458, it was disclosed yesterday when the estate tax appraisal was filed here.

Declaring that the government has not abrogated its right to control restraint of trade because of the war, Dr. Benjamin Wein, marketing lecturer at New York University, declared yesterday that this is not the time for organized insistence on maintenance of fair trade contracts and loss leader laws.

The feasibility of night baseball under the dim-out regulations remained in doubt yesterday. Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine denied that he had said that nocturnal play would be banned and even "hoped it would not be necessary to discontinue night baseball."

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Department store sales during the week ended April 25 again showed an increase over the corresponding week a year ago, rising 13 per cent, compared with an increase of 15 per cent for the week previous, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

LONDON, April 30 -- The fall of Lashio to the Japanese was announced by Chungking today. The city, where large stocks of materials had been built up to feed China's war machine via the Burma Road, was reported ablaze. Lease-lend goods that could not be removed in time were said to have been set afire to prevent their capture.

Samuel Goldstein, former assistant district attorney under William F.X. Geoghan of Brooklyn and close political associate of Frank V. Kelly, Democratic leader of Kings County, was cited for disbarment yesterday by Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen's extraordinary grand jury in a presentment alleging fraud, deceit, crime and unprofessional conduct.

VICHY, France, April 30 (U.P.) -- The nationalist weekly Gringoire of Marseille said today that the "French Fleet is now ready to play its part in the war" and that Dakar was the springboard from which "loyalist forces can leave to reconquer dissident colonies in Africa."

Notwithstanding heroic efforts by I.A. Horowitz to defeat Samuel Reshevsky of Boston, national champion, in their adjourned game from the fifteenth and final round of the United States Chess Federation tournament at the Manhattan Chess Club, the result was recorded as a draw in seventy-two moves after another three-hour session yesterday.

E.H. Burgess, general solicitor of the Lehigh Valley Railroad, has been elected chairman of the Traffic Executive Association for Eastern Territory and of the Trunk Line Association, to succeed D.T. Lawrence, who will retire after fifty-two years' railroad service. N.W. Hawkes, chairman of the freight traffic managers' committee of the Trunk Line Association, has been appointed vice chairman to succeed Harry Wilson, who retired after fifty-eight years' railroad service.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 30 -- Members of Princeton University's eighteen upper-class eating clubs will entertain more than 700 young women here this week-end at the annual Spring house parties.

CHUNGKING, China, April 30 (AP) -- The Japanese Army has launched a vigorous offensive in Southern Honan Province, thrusting several columns west and northwest from Sinyang, important railway town 150 miles north of Hankow, a Chinese military spokesman said today.
DETROIT, April 30 (AP) -- The American League pitching career of Lynwood (Schoolboy) Rowe came to an end today when the Tigers sold the 30-year-old right-hander to the Dodgers.

The automobile insurance industry has entered into a voluntary agreement to construe policies now in force, and hereafter written, as covering the emergency use of automobiles in war work at no additional cost to the car owner and without endorsement of policies, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- A total of $162,416,000,000 in war funds has been made available by Congress or the Reconstruction Finance Corporation since June, 1940, the WPB announced today.

A budget for 1943 for missions, education, social relations and work among youth, totaling $2,500,000, was adopted yesterday morning by the National Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church at the closing session of a three-day meeting at its headquarters at 281 Fourth Avenue.

CHICAGO, April 30 (AP) -- Home runs by Buddy Gremp and Ernie Lombardi enabled the Braves to beat the Cubs, 3 -- 2, behind the five-hit pitching of Jim Tobin today. Gremp also drove in Sisti with the Braves' third run in the ninth with a double.

More than a month of study by collegiate and charities executives of a Treasury proposal to the Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives has convinced them that their first impression of it was correct -- the first blow the Federal Government ever has launched at such institutions, delivered in a time of their greatest trouble.

In a strongly worded rebuke to the crowds who thronged the Times Square district in New Year's Eve fashion to gape at the blackout, Mayor La Guardia decreed last night that henceforth all persons must get off the streets during blackouts and alert drills.

The volume of business on the New York Stock Exchange last month not only slumped to the smallest for any month since July, 1940, but sales of 7,589,297 shares for April were the dullest for any corresponding month since 1918, when they amounted to 7,436,714 shares.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The corporation excess profits tax, one of the principal methods upon which President Roosevelt is relying to reduce war profits, was tentatively fixed at a flat 90 per cent today at a conference between Treasury officials and experts of the Ways and Means Committee.
Stream fishing in Connecticut has been halted as part of the regulation to close wooded areas because of the existing fire hazard.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Continuing studies of war contracts with a view to keeping costs and profits on such agreements under constant review are being carried forward by the War and Navy Departments and the Maritime Commission in collaboration with the War Production Board, Donald M. Nelson, board chairman, said today.

On motion of Representative Michael J. Kennedy, new leader of the Tammany political organization, General Douglas MacArthur was unanimously elected an honorary member of the Society of Tammany, or Columbian Order, at its annual meeting last night in Tammany Hall.

Although Dr. Emory Klein, accused of being the head of an alleged "abortion mill" at 116 East Sixty-third Street that was raided by the police on March 30, was released last Tuesday night by Supreme Court Justice Thomas C. Kadien Jr. in Queens in $5,000 bail on an indictment charging an attempt to tamper with a witness, Justice Peter Schmuck refused in New York County Supreme Court yesterday to fix bail for him.

The Disabled American Veterans of the World War held a "Wake Up America" meeting last night at the Town Hall, at which resolutions were adopted calling for a pooling of the efforts of industry and labor, of patents and monopolies, of all races and creeds.

TORONTO, April 30 (AP) -- Without hitting a ball past the infield, Jersey City scored four runs in the third inning today to beat Toronto, 6 to 3. Buster Maynard's second-inning homer off Dick Conger started the scoring and Harry Shuman was called to the mound in the third when three infield singles, two walks and a costly error accounted for four more runs.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 30 -- Eighteen Norwegians were executed today in Oslo by a German firing squad in reprisal for the assassination of two Gestapo men. This is the first time that the Germans have applied in Norway the method of mass execution in reprisal that they use in France.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30 (AP) -- The Indians, behind Vernon Kennedy, scored their eleventh straight victory today, beating the Athletics, 6 -- 1, although Manager Lou Boudreau disregarded a baseball tradition not to break up a winning combination.

Formation of a special committee to serve as a clearing house for information on American ship and cargo insurance was announced yesterday by the American Institute of Marine Underwriters. Henry H. Reed of the Insurance Company of North America has been named chairman.

Enough survives of the New York World's Fair of 1939 and 1940 to give employment to a staff of three men with desk room and a telephone listing. Our memories of that brave attempt to stage a preview of the world of tomorrow on Flushing Meadows are not cheerful.

Election of R. Emerson Swart as president of Huyler's was announced yesterday by Winston Paul, chairman of the board. Mr. Swart, one of a group which recently acquired the Schulte interest in Huyler's, succeeds Charles J. Gregory, president of the Southeastern Gas and Water Company and a voting trustee of Huyler's, who had been acting president pending the election of a successor.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- A War Department communique, based on reports received here up to 9:20 A.M. today, said:

When the President said: "I do not think that any American citizen should have a net income in excess of $25,000 per year after payment of taxes," I wonder whether he had given adequate consideration to what this would do to religious, educational and philanthropic institutions.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- New methods of financing, including an experimental 2 1/2 per cent tap issue registered for institutional investors, a $1,250,000,000 2 per cent medium term bond designed for purchase by banks and the stepping up of the weekly amount of Treasury bills to be issued to the unprecedented total of $250,000,000, were announced tonight by the Treasury for next Monday.

CHICAGO, April 30 -- Liquidation was on in the grain markets in volume today on the Board of Trade as a result of liberal tenders of cash grain on May contracts. Soy beans led the decline and broke around 4 1/2 cents a bushel at one time.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Voluntary reductions in mass production prices of aircraft parts and accessories which will save the Government an estimated $73,354,000 on outstanding contracts have been made in recent weeks by the Bendix Aviation Corporation, its president, Ernest R. Breech, told, the House Naval Affairs Investigating Committee today.

A strike of 20,000 elevator operators and other classes of service workers in Manhattan office, loft and apartment buildings was threatened for Monday after negotiations for a new collective agreement between the Realty Advisory Board and Local 32-B of the Building Service Employee International Union, A.F. of L. had collapsed yesterday at a City Hall conference.
BOSTON, April 30 (AP) -- The Red Sox bombarded three Tiger pitchers for thirteen hits and a total of twenty-one bases today to give Dick Newsome his third straight pitching victory, 8 to 3.

Mrs. M. Harris Hamersley gave a reception yesterday afternoon in her apartment at the Devon for Mr. and Mrs. Francis Rogers. Spring flowers were used in the decorations. At the tea table were Mrs. Robert S. Peabody, Mrs. Francis Oakey, Mrs. Joseph West Dixon and Mrs. Charles F. Moulton.
LONDON, April 30 (AP) -- The statement of condition of the Bank of England issued today reported a new record for note circulation which stood at 771,154,000, an increase of 4,008,000 in the week.

The sinking of a medium-sized United States merchant ship and a small Swedish freighter, with the probable loss of twenty lives, was announced yesterday by the Navy which, however, counter-balanced this bad news with an account of how gunners on a small American freighter scored a direct hit at long range on an enemy submarine encountered in the Atlantic.

John Golden's headquarters in the St. James Theatre Building once more is assuming the unrestrained enthusiasm of a theatrical producer's office involved in a new project. Spurred on by Philip Dunning, Mr. Golden has signed James Barton for the leading role -- a North Carolina sheriff -- in the George O'Neal play, "Not on Friday."

CINCINNATI, April 30 -- The National League's most valuable player in 1941 definitely was the Dodgers' most valuable player today as Leo Durocher's pace setters won a seesaw battle with the Reds, 11 -- 8, to sweep the series and run their string to six consecutive victories.

In reply to a letter sent by eight well-known Hudson Valley Republicans to Republican county committee members in the Congressional district represented by Representative Hamilton Fish Jr., urging them to oppose the renomination of Mr. Fish, the latter declared yesterday that since Pearl Harbor he has supported every war measure and has urged an all-out war to final victory.

Manhattan's candle, snuffed almost out for a little while last night, will burn more dimly from now on until we win this war. It took the big fist of Mars a long time to reach across the ocean and do this thing to us, but now it has happened. The Great White Way -- or, as it has been in recent years, the Great Colored Way -- has ceased to be.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Effective control of lighting along the Atlantic seacoast on a voluntary basis has failed and in the future, and apparently for the duration of the war, the military authorities will have to enforce dim-out regulations along the entire Eastern seaboard for the protection of our vital coastal shipping, Secretary Stimson told a press conference this morning.

LONDON, April 30 (AP) -- The Russian Army has hurled German troops back from an unspecified sector of the central front after many hours of hand-to-hand fighting, the Moscow radio announced tonight. The Red Army scored a "major victory" in this engagement, the broadcast said.

Championship competition of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound will be held on Sundays the coming Summer instead of on Saturdays. That was decided yesterday afternoon at a special meeting of the club delegates, held in the New York Yacht Club.

Hinting at a possible curtailment of the use of city-owned automobiles, Councilman Joseph E. Kinsley, chairman of the Council finance committee, sent questionnaires to all department heads yesterday asking specific information on the number of city cars and the uses to which they are put.

Twenty-four little boys and girls, all fine physical specimens, undressed to their underclothes in the Jones Center of the Children's Aid Society, 405 East Seventy-third Street, yesterday morning and lined up before a physician and a nurse. As part of the program of National Child Health Day, they were final contestants for the society's crowns for Health Day King and Health Day Queen.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The General Motors Corporation, one of the largest automobile manufacturing companies in the country, was cited today by the War Production Board for violation of the war agency's priority regulations.

President William Green of the A.F. of L. and President Philip Murray of the C.I.O. have done a wise and patriotic thing in agreeing to a procedure which, it is hoped, will do away with jurisdictional labor disputes for the duration of the war. Such disputes may arise between different unions in the same big national organization or between an A.F. of L. union and a C.I.O. union.

The pale star of the Eternal Light in Madison Square Park, memorial to the soldier dead of the first World War, faded at 9:30 o'clock last night in the blackout drill, apparently extinguished for the first time in the eighteen years it has shone from its 125-foot height.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The Consumer Division of the Office of Price Administration made known today what was expected of the consuming public and what changes in buying habits might be looked for as a result of the freezing of prices.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 30 -- Mary Martin will play the feminine lead in Columbia's "The Gang's All Here," formerly "Winter Garden," which Laura and S.J. Perlman have written, if current negotiations to borrow the actress from Paramount are successful, Columbia disclosed today.
