One of the weirdest Aprils on record ended yesterday with a maximum temperature of 86.9 degrees, a record for April 30, reached at 3:35 P.M.

A petition for the nullification of the naturalization of Mario Lauro, 50-year-old correspondent for the Telegrafo, the newspaper owned by Benito Mussolini's son-in-law, Foreign Minister Count Galeazzo Ciano, was filed in Federal court yesterday by United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa.
A "tough guy" -- all of 8 years old, perhaps -- down at Greenwich House, neighborhood settlement at 27 Barrow Street, looked disgustedly yesterday afternoon at a little girl and asked:

No doubt about vaudeville's coming back. On Forty-fourth Street you can see Victor Moore; on Forty-sixth Street, Willie Howard. On Forty-second Street and up a bit on Broadway itself, two former burlesque houses have yielded to the blandishments of License Commissioner Moss and have installed variety to preserve the smooth state of the nation.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, May 1 (AP) -- The guns, bombs and bayonets of the Red Army have punctured beyond repair Adolf Hitler's vaunted Spring offensive plans, the Russians declared on this May Day in announcing an imposing list of Soviet victories by land and sea to bear them out.

The University Women's Chorus, under the direction of Morris Watkins, gave its annual Spring concert last night in Carnegie Chamber Music Hall. Lura Stover, soprano, and Betty Paret, harp, were the assisting artists, and Luis Harold Sanford presided at the piano.

Budgetary problems still beset most menu-makers, in spite of price ceilings present and to come. And one of the shewdest ways of solving them, long known to canny housekeepers, is to buy a large piece of meat and make it do for two or three meals.
BERLIN, May 1 (From German broadmasts recorded by The Associated Press ) -- German communique said today:

BERNE, Switzerland, May 1 -- At least 250 Belgian workers were killed in an explosion at a chemical works at Tessenderloo in Belgian Limburg, according to today's reports from Berlin. The only news of the disaster came through the German official news agency D.N.B.

To make it possible for the public to be admitted free at the concerts of the Music Critics Circle of New York, Tuesday afternoon, May 12, in Town Hall, and Wednesday night, May 13, in Carnegie Hall, the composers and publishers of the seven chamber works to be presented at the former event, and of the five symphonic works to be presented at the latter, have waived performance fees.
ST. LOUIS, May 1 (AP) -- Lashing out with home runs, the Cardinals caught the Braves in the ninth inning today and beat them in the tenth, 8 to 7. Thirty-three players participated in the wild game.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, May 1 (AP) -- Gross business increased but higher taxes and other costs cut the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company's first-quarter net profit to $2,576,579, which was equal, after preferred dividends, to $1.41 a common share, the company's consolidated income account showed today.

GARDEN CITY, L.I, May 1 -The 1942 golf season opened on Long Island today when members of the Metropolitan P.G.A., including the Westchester and Long Island sections, competed for places in the national P.G.A. championship to be held at Atlantic City May 25-31.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 1 -- I was in Noumea, principal city of New Caledonia, last Saturday, the day the War Department at Washington announced that United States forces had arrived there, and I saw reassuring evidence that the islands on the strategically vital northeastern flank of Australia had been fortified strongly.

The Office of Price Administration wants the shoe industry to maintain its quality while simplifying lines and conserving raw material, according to Burton E. Oppenheim, price executive in the textiles, leather and apparel section of OPA.

VICHY, France, May 1 (AP) -- The German-dominated Paris press made a somewhat restrained effort today to depict United States Ambassador William D. Leahy as expressing approval of Pierre Laval's appointment as leader of the French Government, but American Embassy circles here promptly denied any such implication as "pure invention."

IT may be that Schoolboy Rowe will do all right for the Dodgers. He came from Detroit. Billy Sullivan was a Tiger man before he put on that Dodger drapery and Billy the Barrister has been doing all right for the Flatbush Flock. For that matter, Dixie Walker was another who doffed the Detroit uniform to join the Brooklyn boys. And Dixie has been a Flatbush hero ever since.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 1 -- In a resplendent two-hour ritual at the Cathedral of the Incarnation here today, the Right Rev. James Pernette De Wolfe, former dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York, was consecrated as Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island.

Here is a little problem for the mathematicians. Suppose the President of the United States in a radio speech wants to cite two outstanding cases of personal heroism and devotion to duty in the Pacific fighting.

Philip Le Boutillier, president and general manager of Best Co., Fifth Avenue store, sent a telegram to Leon Henderson at the Office of Price Administration in Washington yesterday pledging full support of the OPA price ceilings as the "first big attempt" to end the "inflation spiral."

Total sales of war savings bonds in the Second Federal Reserve District, through agencies other than post offices, amounted to $102,200,000 in April, compared with $104,000,000 in March, according to official tabulations completed yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which acts as wholesaler to the non-post office agencies in this district.

An item in THE TIMES of April 21, dated from Bahia Blanca, Argentina, reported that a new world record in 18.1 balkline billiards had been made by Pedro Leopoldo Careras, who had compiled a grand average of 3.824 points per inning for six hours of play.
The Pan American Airways Corporation announced yesterday the election of Charles Francis Adams of Boston and John W. Hanes of New York to its board of directors.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 1 -- Fire-fighters operating under martial law appeared late tonight to have conquered the worst outbreak of forest fires in Rhode Island's recent history, Governor J. Howard McGrath announced.

A 16-year-old blind girl who submitted an essay in Braille on "What Obligations Must I Assume for the Priceless Heritage for Freedom?" received the first prize awarded by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York yesterday for the best contribution from any 8A grade contestant in the public elementary schools of Manhattan.

VICHY, France, May 1 -- A large crowd of government officials, diplomats and personal friends came to the railroad station here tonight to bid farewell to Admiral William D. Leahy, the American Ambassador, who had been called to Washington to report on the situation in France.
CHICAGO, Saturday, May 2 -- The passenger list of the UnitedI airliner that crashed near Salt Lake City, as issued by the line's

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Summer use for war services of the nation's schools is recommended in a report of the wartime commission of the United States Office of Education. The program has been approved by J.M. Studebaker, Commissioner, and Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator.

The City Council's Defense Committee introduced a new and less rigorous bill in the Council yesterday establishing the fire-protection equipment required for the city's 810,000 buildings, which will serve as a substitute for the original Isaacs bill that drew much criticism.

For the seventh year the New York Public Library yesterday opened its outdoor reading room in Bryant Park, just behind the central library building, and, as usual, the public welcomed this foretaste of Summer.

Representing Indians in a "Sitting Bull session" to consider whether they should buy back Manhattan Island, the Hunter College class of '42 won top honors and a silver baton yesterday in the twenty-sixth annual inter-class song competition.
LONDON, May 1 (Reuter) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique tonight:
Dr. Gustav Stolper will address the Society of Security Analysis at a luncheon on Thursday noon at the Block Hall Lunch Club. His subject will be "Is Private Enterprise Dying?"

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, presented to President Roosevelt today an autographed copy of the new thirty-page "Maximum Price Regulations," fixing ceilings on prices. Later he told reporters that the presentation was made to spike reports that the regulations governing the new price controls had grown to the thickness of a mail-order catalogue.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The use of jute in the manufacture of rugs, carpets and linoleum for civilian use is prohibited by an amendment to the jute conservation order issued today by the War Production Board.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, May 1 -- President Getulio Vargas suffered minor injuries today in an automobile accident while on his way to deliver a May Day address to 30,000 Brazilian workers in the Vasco Da Gama Stadium. He was taken to Guanabara Palace and Labor Minister Alexandre Marcondes Filho read his speech.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 1 -Ray Milland will play the lead opposite Ginger Rogers in the screen version of Moss Hart's "Lady in the Dark," Paramount announced today. He will be seen in the role of Charlie Johnson, played on Broadway by Macdonald Carey, who is now under contract to Paramount, but who will not appear in the film.

CANBERRA, Australia, May 1 -- The Opposition resolution calling for militia service outside Australia was defeated today, 31 to 27, with the aid of two Independents, on whose votes the government relies.

I have read with interest the discussion regarding the return by fans of foul balls so they may be turned over to the armed forces. One reader says that these 'lost' balls "rightfully belong to the fans."

A high-ranking French general, spokesman for the fighting forces of Free French, appealed yesterday for an early United Nations invasion of his own homeland and an American expedition to wrest the strategic island of Madagascar from the Nazi-dominated Vichy regime.
PANAMA, May 1 -- Workers in Panama and the Canal Zone celebrated May Day here in the greatest demonstration in a number of years, with support for the United Nations war effort the theme of speakers.
CINCINNATI, May 1 (AP) -- The Reds turned back a ninth-inning threat today to defeat Philadelphia, 6 to 5, for their first victory in five starts.

THIERS, France, May 1 -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain inaugurated the French labor festival today with a message to the nation. It was delivered from this little town thirty miles from Vichy, a center of the cutlery industry that has flourished through generations of artisans.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, May 1 (U.P.) -- The story of how the strategic island of New Caledonia broke away from Vichy rule and placed itself under the Free French banner of General Charles de Gaulle may be told today for the first time -- almost two years later.

Demonstrating a gun game called "Russian Roulette," in which all cartridges save one are taken from a six-chambered revolver and the player risks his life on the chance of the firing pin striking an empty chamber, Francis J. O'Neil Jr., 20 years old, a sophomore at Fordham University, killed himself yesterday afternoon in his home.

Dr. Harry Gilbert of 120 West Seventieth Street yesterday became the first physician in New York State to lose his license to practice medicine because of neglect to report treatment of a gunshot wound, a violation of the penal law.

In the old days Hitler and Mussolini used to meet at the halfway point at the Brenner Pass. It is not to be wondered that the erstwhile Duce now crosses the line and travels a hundred miles into German territory to keep a date. His Italy is as much a prisoner of Hitler's Reich as is defeated France or conquered Poland.

The volume of new bonds reaching the market this week took a sharp drop from that of the preceding period, amounting to $10,286,000, all in the tax-exempt field, compared with $105,550,000 last week, when the $100,000,000 American Tobacco debenture issue accounted for most of that total.

Seven firemen, including a captain and a lieutenant, were overcome by smoke early this morning while fighting a fire in a five-story apartment house at 2489 Tiebout Avenue, near Fordham Road, the Bronx. Twenty five families, aroused from sleep at 12:30 o'clock by the shouts of firemen and volunteers, ran to the street in their night clothing.

With many of the best sprinters in training among the fifteen named, the $5,000 added Jamaica Handicap features this afternoon's card at Jamaica. The race has an estimated value of $7,425, and as those named include eight winners at the current meeting, the eleventh running of this six-furlong sprint for three-year-olds and upward has the promise of real action.

Letters in THE TIMES have brought up the question as to who is to receive credit for the baseballs donated to the services. All these arguments are nothing compared to the howl which is emitting from the fans about who should receive credit for the half-price hot dogs, drinks, etc. which the service men can buy at the special canteens established for them by the concessionnaires.

The largest newspaper and magazine advertising campaign in its ninety-five-year history has been launched this year by Pond's, and by the end of 1942 will reach a total circulation of more than 1,000,000,000, C. IVf. Baker, president, announced yesterday.

One of the most dangerous delusions spread by certain Americans, including at least a few refugee Germans, is that there is a considerable and growing group of "better Germans" in the Reich today. I am not sure even that such a powerful anti-Nazi play as "Watch on the Rhine" and the melodramatic movie "Underground" do not encourage, among unthinking Americans, this same belief in "better Germans."

A retrospective loan exhibition of paintings by Yasuo Kuniyoshi will be held at the Downtown Gallery from May 5 through May 29 to assist United China Relief. The works to be shown have all been borrowed from museums and private collections and were painted between 1921 and 1941.

The management of the Brill Corporation and its underlying companies is working on a plan of recapitalization for presentation to stockholders, it was disclosed at the annual meetings of the corporation and the American Car and Foundry Motors Company here yesterday by Charles J. Hardy, president.

Members of the Christian church in America are tending toward the role of "spectator rather than participant" in this time of crisis, the Rev. Dr. E. Stanley Jones, a Methodist missionary, said yesterday in an address at a session of the New York Annual Conference of the Methodist Church.

CHICAGO, May 1 -- Throwing caution to the winds, the Giants and Cubs exchanged heavy blows today as they opened a two-game series before a ladies' day crowd of 8,620. Somewhere in the exchanges the Giants were slightly short-changed, with the result that Jimmy Wilson's Chicagoans, presenting a vastly revamped line-up, finished on top, 13 to 9.
A revival of Paramount's screen adaptation of the Ernest Hemingway novel, "A Farewell to Arms," will begin an indefinite engagement today at the Little Carnegie Playhouse.

The theme of wartime service predominated at the 118th convention of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs, held yesterday at the Hotel Astor at which a fully equipped ambulance was presented to Mayor La Guardia. Delegates from the 212 clubs heard how they could help the salvage and rationing programs and otherwise increase civilian participation in the war.
Cotton prices moved erratically yesterday in quiet trading. However, on persistent buying by the trade, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange closed at net gains of 7 to 10 points.
THE NEW YORK TIMES and the Newspaper Guild of New York yesterday signed a one-year agreement covering news and editorial department employes, effective until May 1, 1943.

Forms and other material necessary for the registration of sugar consumers and the issuance of ration books were delivered yesterday to the 1,000 public, private and parochial schools that will serve as registration centers next week. Registration of consumers begins Monday morning at 9 o'clock.
With an intimate knowledge of France which extends over a period of nearly half a century and personal experience of conditions from the outbreak of war until a few months ago, I am wondering:

UNION, N.J., May 1 -- The season's opening tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association brought out a record field of seventy players today, with Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches posting the winning gross score of 38, 37 -- 75 for the well-groomed Suburban Club course.
Fifty-one per cent of American women are eager to aid in the war effort, according to the Gallup poll. But no agency yet exists that can help free patriotic mothers from their home responsibilities.

Leading producers of better grade dresses and sportswear will stage their openings of Fall lines on June 1, according to announcements made yesterday. A number of the members of the Fashion Originators Guild of America, Inc., will exhibit diversified collections beginning on that date and the Sportswear Guild houses will also show their Fall offerings then.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -war in the Pacific apparently is approaching a period of intense naval and land action among the islands southwest of Hawaii, well-qualified authorities said today, with the security of the United Nations' supply route to Australia as the prize at stake.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Acting on the contention that if the disputants were left to their own devices the case would be interminably prolonged and an agreement would perhaps never be reached, the National War Labor Board, using such procedure for the first time, submitted a complete collective bargaining contract today and directed the union and the employer to sign it.

As the din of carpenters' hammers resounded through the main corridor of City Hall yesterday Mayor La Guardia was asked by Councilman Joseph E. Kinsley to stop chopping the 130-year-old building up into a series of cubbyholes for defense offices, and to restore it to the condition he found it in when he took office in 1934.

CHICAGO, May 1 -- A national stabilization agreement on wages and working conditions in the shipbuilding industry was reported approaching the final stages of negotiation tonight after five days of conferences between labor, management and government.
BOSTON, May 1 (AP) -- The Browns mauled three of four Red Sox pitchers today for a 10-6 victory in the first contest of their two-game series.
PHILADELPHIA, May 1 (AP) -- The White Sox broke a seven-game losing streak today. Behind the six-hit pitching of Johnny Rigney they defeated the Athletics, 5 -- 2.

BERLIN, May 1 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press in New York) -- The following communique, dated from Salzburg and relating to the meeting between Adolf Hitler and Benito Mussolini, was issued here at noon today:

Ceilings which become effective May 18 for retailers by the provisions of the over-all price order are intended to be permanent, whereas those of manufacturers and wholesalers, in many cases, may be only temporary and subject to "pushing back" in order that "squeezes" may be absorbed equitably.

Termination of automobile production and conversion of virtually all facilities to war work brought a decline in the net sales of the Chrysler Corporation in the first quarter of 1942 to $136,299,759 from $252,768,166 in the period in 1941 and a decline in net profit to $4,899,233, or $1.13 a share, from $9,561,982, or $2.20 a share. The declines were 46 per cent and 48 per cent respectively.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

CHICAGO, May 1 -- Wholesale prices of medium and lower grades butter advanced 1/4 to 1/2 cent a pound here today. Best butter sold at 38 3/4 to 39 3/4 cents a pound. Trading in butter futures on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange was the largest in eight weeks with the November contract at a new twelve-year peak of 40.15 cents a pound.

In a recent column John Kieran quoted a Navy officer: "It is disheartening to note the large number of universities and small colleges that seem to have a misguided conception of patriotism and show same by discontinuing all competitive athletics."

The corporate tax situation came nearer yesterday to clarification with a recommendation for a levy of 94 per cent approved by the House Ways and Means Committee, but the stock market elected to look on the brighter side of the ledger. As a result, the long-neglected public utilities took the spotlight in both volume and price enhancement on the Stock Exchange, with American Telephone and Telegraph again the spearhead for the entire share list.

The Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company reported yesterday for the first quarter of 1942, net income of $1,201,096 after provision of $4,504,000 for Federal income and excess profits taxes. Provision for Federal taxes includes an estimate for increased taxes.

Lessons from the blackout of mid-Manhattan, including the Times Square area with its otherwise teaming night activity, Thursday night, will be drawn by pastors in their sermons tomorrow and prayers will be offered that there will be no spiritual blackout in his country owing to the war.

CHICAGO, May 1 -- A serious shortage of teachers faces this country, which may result in the closing of 50 per cent of the rural elementary schools as well as many public schools in large cities, prominent educators warned at the opening of the twenty-fifth annual conference of the American Council on Education.

LONDON, May 1 -- While one Japanese force moved slowly northward along the railroad toward Mandalay, another moved through captured Lashio in a northeasterly direction to the vicinity of the village of Hsenwi, where heavy fighting is reported now under way. Hsenwi is about thirty miles from Lashio and fifty miles from China's Yunnan border.

Hugh Grant Straus, vice president and treasurer of the Abraham Straus department store, Brooklyn, at a meeting of executives and company chairmen yesterday, urged support of the Greater New York Fund which is making its fifth appeal for the benefit of 400 voluntary health and welfare agencies.

DETROIT, May 1 -- C.E. Wilson, General Motors president, tonight announced that the corporation would suspend the manufacture of automotive service parts of all kinds indefinitely until a punitive order against G.M. by the War Production Board "can be properly clarified."
Yankee pitching took its worst shellacking of the year yesterday at the Stadium as the Detroit Tigers clubbed the world champions back into third place before a Ladies' Day gathering of 10,568.

ALBANY, May 1 -- Governor Lehman asked every citizen of the State today to put his home on a wartime basis and not only meet but exceed the government's quota of 10 per cent of income in the purchase of war bonds.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull assured Adrien Tixier, chief Free French delegate in the United States, at a long conference today of the continued cooperation of this government, but he did not go to the extent of promising diplomatic recognition of the Free French national committee in London as the national government of France.

The brilliantly painted Drottningholm, one of the few neutral passenger liners left in the world, came into port yesterday afternoon at the end of a special "safe conduct" voyage from Gothenburg with 154 passengers, most of whom had been stranded in North Europe since the war began in 1939.

Newly aroused interest in the care and ecucation of young children in the United Nations was reported last night at the dinner meeting of the annual conference of the New York State Association for Nursery Education at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Thurman Arnold, head of the Justice Department's anti-trust division, has been prevented by Attorney General Biddle from testifying before a House committee on a bill aimed at alleged coercion by labor unions, it was disclosed today.

BURLINGTON, N.J., May 1 -Burlington Township authorities this afternoon advised the Farm Security Administration of the revocation of a permit the Township Committee issued on April 24 for the erection of a migrant labor camp on State Highway No. 25, one mile from the city of Burlington.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- President Roosevelt today cut short the attempt of the Board of Economic Warfare, of which Milo Perkins is executive director and Vice President Wallace the chairman, to take over part of the foreign relations work of the State Department.

In its wartime financing the Treasury faces a dilemma. It must finance as large a part as possible of the deficit outside the commercial banks so as to minimize the inflation of bank credit. At the same time it will have to finance a very large part of its deficit with the commercial banks, because other sources cannot supply all the needed funds.

"Jason," the George Abbott production of Samson Raphaelson's comedy concerning the troubles of a drama critic, will end its Broadway engagement on May 9, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Raphaelson's play will have been seen at the Hudson Theatre for a total of 125 performances.

LOUISVILLE, May 1 -- Seventeen have been entered for the sixty-eighth Kentucky Derby, to be run here tomorrow, and the post-time blare of the bugle will have a double significance for the third time since the race was inaugurated in 1875.

The Public Service Commission yesterday authorized the Long Island Lighting Company to issue and sell $10,000,000 of 3 3/4 per cent sinking fund debentures and $883,000 of unsecured notes for the purpose of refunding $5,178,000 of higher interest bonds and to pay off bank and other loans of $5,890,000.

The Office of Price Administration moved yesterday into the prosecution stage of price-ceiling enforcement here and won a temporary injunction restraining a hosiery wholesaler from selling nylon hosiery above the wholesale price ceiling established by OPA in February.

Representative Hamilton Fish Jr., who has been under attack as an "isolationist," formally announced yesterday that he would be a candidate for re-election from the Twenty-sixth District, which he has represented in Congress for twenty-two years.

Complaint of the shortage of caddies leads Frank Smalley to ironical sympathy with golfers who think it a burden to carry their own bags. "Real golfers like those one finds at the public links, think nothing of playing 36 or 54 holes at a clip and then attending a dance," says he.

Scoring three runs in the eighth inning, Manhattan overhauled Brooklyn College, 7 to 5, on the Jaspers' field yesterday in a Metropolitan Collegiate Conference engagement. Relief Pitcher Dick Bachman was the hero of the fray, since he set the Kingsmen down with one hit in the last four innings after Left-Hander Charlie Gatz had given up ten blows in the first five.

"Cartoons of the Day" is the title of an exhibition that opens this morning at the Metropolitan Museum, to remain current through June. Installed in Gallery A 22, it is not a large show, but manages to cover considerable ground, with respect both to subject and to technical procedure.

ALBANY, May 1 -- New York State went on a full wartime basis today. A tighter grip is given to the State on defense and protection activities machinery is set up to meet disaster caused by enemy action and penalties become effective for blackout violations.

PITTSBURGH, May 1 -- The first of May saw the last of the Dodgers' six-game winning streak. Frankie Frisch's second-place Pirates today beat the National League leaders, 7 -- 6, in the ninth when Arky Vaughan let a hard-hit grounder by Vince DiMaggio go through for an error.

In two new decisions the Supreme Court has shed some light on the rather dark ground of interception of communications under the Federal Communication Act of 1934. In one case the Court held that testimony obtained by means of wire-tapping could be used in court against a defendant who had no hand in the interception of the message.

The first pin bearing newly designed insignia for the United Nations was presented to Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt yesterday afternoon at Freedom House, 32 East Fifty-first Street, before diplomatic representatives of seventeen of the twenty-six Allied countries.

Events this year and particularly dislocations caused by the war have changed radically the outlook for the company from an earnings standpoint in 1942, W.S. Farish, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, said yesterday following a meeting of directors at which dividends on the company's capital stock were declared.

BERLIN, May 1 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press in New York) -- Adolf Hitler and Premier Mussolini have reached a new accord on all military and political aspects of the war, it was announced in a communique today. It was their first meeting since their countries went to war with the United States last December.
Elizabeth, Lady Cheylesmore, left the Savoy-Plaza yesterday to visit her sister-in-law, Mrs. Amos Tuck French, in Chester, N.H., until June 1, when she will go to Newport for the season.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Germany is trying to meet her inflation problem by the freezing ofi prices, not only of civilian but of] war goods, the fixation of profits and even the partial abolition of the practice of setting aside re-! serves for plant depreciation, ac-! cording to a report made public by! the Commerce Department today.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that its basic loan rate on 1942-grown wheat would be $1.14 a bushel at the farm. The corresponding rate for 1941 wheat was 98 cents.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., May 1 -- Shading John D. Rowland of New Brunswick, N.J., in a shoot-off, Joseph Hiestand of Hillsboro, Ohio, won the doubles title for the fourth time as the thirty-seventh annual national amateur championships at clay targets opened today at the New York A.C. traps on Travers Island.

Women workers at the Northam Warren plant at Stamford, Conn., who once spent their days standing guard over a brew of nail polish or fashioning a bottle cap to preserve the polish in suitable elegance, are setting about new tasks today -- they will help make bombers.

Adolf Hitler in his recent speech asserted that this year's cold in Russia was much more terrible than in Napoleon's year of destiny, 1812 -- 52 degrees below zero (Fahrenheit) this Winter against 25 degrees in 1812.

By piecing together scraps of information that reach these shores, Drs. Gustav Egloff and P.M. Van Arsdale, two well-known oil chemists, managed to present to the American Chemical Society a picture of Europe's oil problems which is as good as we can expect. From Spitzbergen to Naples, from Moscow to Paris, there is a dearth of motor fuel.

Bankers Trust Company, as successor trustee, has designated for redemption on June 1 at 102 and accrued interest out of moneys in the sinking fund $199,000 of Portland General Electric Company first-mortgage 5 per cent bonds, due July 1, 1950.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for sale next week by twenty-two municipalities and one housing authority amounts to $14,682,561, compared with $13,836,343 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $27,191,002.

TRENTON, May 1 -- Confronted by the conflicting opinions of State and Federal authorities, the Legislature recessed tonight until May 18 without acting on a proposed reorganization of civilian defense. In so doing it took the risk that Leonard Dreyfuss would carry out a threat to resign as New Jersey Civilian Defense Director and take with him Thomas S. Digman, his chief of staff.

LONDON, May 1 (U.P.) -- Wing Commander Max Aitken, 32, Canadian-born elder son and heir of Lord Beaverbrook, led into action a squadron of Beaufighters that downed four of five German raiders near Northeast England last night, the Air Ministry announced today.

Frank Ciaffone allowed only two hits as unbeaten Abraham Lincoln High gained its eighth baseball victory yesterday by blanking Manual Training, 6 to 0, in a Brooklyn P.S.A.L. contest on the latter's diamond. It was the fourth loop success for Lincoln, which went into a first-place tie with idle Madison.
The United States Steel Corporation has made a contribution of $75,000 to Russian War Relief, Inc., it was announced yesterday by Edward C. Carter, president of Russian War Relief.

A strike of 8,000 elevator operators and other service workers in 800 apartment buildings on the West Side of Manhattan ended at 7 P.M. yesterday after the National War Labor Board had called on the striking American Federation of Labor union to send its members back to work.

Retail trade here was only fairly active this week. Department store executives estimated the gain over last year at around 5 to 6 per cent, or about the same percentage of increase noted last week. 1VIerchants noted some deferring of buying by consumers in anticipation of lower prices when the price ceiling goes into effect at retail on May 18.

In times such as our country faces it is necessary that each citizen take stock of his activities and see if he is really doing his part to serve best his nation. I have just completed my basic training in the Army and grow prouder every day that I am a member of that organization.

As a special tribute to General Douglas MacArthur, under whom the "Fighting Sixty-ninth" served in the first World War, the "Fifty-nine Battle Rings" will be displayed at a regimental communion breakfast of the Sixty-ninth Regiment of the New York Guard tomorrow at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

An ensemble performance of an uncommon character, introducing a work which perhaps not a hundred in the audience had heard, was a feature of the fifth concert of Toscanini's Beethoven series with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (U.P.) -The weekly newspaper X-Ray, published and edited by Court Asher at Muncie, Ind., was barred from the mails tonight by Postmaster General Frank C. Walker.

Eve Curie will do a book on her five-months' trip to the battlefronts of the war. Mlle. Curie visited Libya, the Middle East, Russia, Burma, India and China. Doubleday, Doran says the book is under way and will be ready for Fall.
SALT LAKE CITY, Saturday, May 2 -- Eighteen persons were killed when a United Air Lines passenger plane crashed into Ensign Peak, one mile north of the Utah capital, late last night and burned.

BERNE, Switzerland, Saturday, May 2 -- Accompanied by an imposing array of totalitarian talent, including their Foreign Ministers and Chiefs of Staff, Reichsfuehrer Hitler and Premier Mussolini met on Wednesday and Thursday in Castle Fueschi on the lake near Salzburg, about twenty miles from Herr Hitler's Berghof.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 1 -- For the second successive day the United Nations Air Force yesterday bombed and machine-gunned the Japanese base at Lae and scored many hits on a line of thirty planes. The official communique said it was a brilliant and heavy attack that started many large fires in the target area.
The financing of the war effort will be attacked with fresh impetus on several fronts over the week-end, with the new program scheduled to be in full swing on Monday.
LONDON, May 1 -- Hundreds of British planes swung across the Channel at twilight today in what coast observers called one of the war's greatest single thrusts against the Nazi-held Continental coast.

Advocating "equal pay for equal performance by women in industry," William P. Witherow, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, said yesterday that industrialists attending conferences on women in industry in ten cities throughout the country had expressed their complete agreement with this policy and that progress was being made in this direction through programs of scientific job analysis.
